original: Namo tassa bhagavato arahato sammāsambuddhassa
analyzed: namaḥ tassa bhagavataḥ arahataḥ sammāsambuddhassa
translated: Homage to that Blessed One, perfected one, fully enlightened one

original: Visuddhimagga-mahāṭīkā
translated: The Great Commentary on the Path of Purification🔽(The First Part)

original: (Paṭhamo bhāgo)🔽Ganthārambhakathā
analyzed: paṭhamaḥ bhāgaḥ  gantha ārambha kathā
translated: The Introduction

original: Saddhammaraṃsimālī yo, vineyyakamalākare;
translated: He who is a garland of the true Dhamma, a maker of the lotus garden of disciples,

original: Vibodhesi mahāmoha-tamaṃ hantvāna sabbaso.
analyzed: vibodhesi mahā mohatamam hantvāna sabbaso
translated: Having completely destroyed the darkness of great delusion, he illuminates.

original: Ñāṇātisayabimbaṃ taṃ, visuddhakaruṇāruṇaṃ;
analyzed: ñāṇa atisaya bimbam tam visuddha karuṇā aruṇam
translated: That image of the excellence of knowledge, red with pure compassion,

original: Vanditvā nirupaklesaṃ, buddhādiccaṃ mahodayaṃ.
analyzed: vanditvā nirupaklesam buddha ādiccam mahodayam
translated: Having paid homage to the one without affliction, the great rising of the sun of the Buddha,

original: Lokālokakaraṃ dhammaṃ, guṇarasmisamujjalaṃ;🔽Ariyasaṅghañca samphullaṃ, visuddhakamalākaraṃ.
analyzed: lokāloka karam dhammam guṇa rasmi samujjalam  ariya saṅgham ca samphullam visuddha kamala ākaram
translated: The Dhamma, which illuminates the world, shining with the radiance of its qualities,🔽And the noble Sangha, in full bloom, a pure lotus garden,

original: Vandanājanitaṃ puññaṃ, iti yaṃ ratanattaye;
analyzed: vandanā janitam puññam iti yam rata nattaye
translated: The merit produced by paying homage, thus to the Three Jewels,

original: Hatantarāyo sabbattha, hutvāhaṃ tassa tejasā.
analyzed: hata antarāyaḥ sabbattha hutvā aham tassa tejasā
translated: Having become free from all obstacles everywhere, by the power of that,

original: Sampannasīlācārena, dhīmatā sucivuttinā;
analyzed: sampanna sīla ācārena dhīmatā suci vuttinā
translated: With perfect virtue and conduct, wise, of pure livelihood,

original: Ajjhesito dāṭhānāgattherena thiracetasā.
analyzed: ajjhesitaḥ dāṭhā nāgattherena thira cetasā
translated: Requested by the elder Dāṭhā, who had come from Anāgata, with a firm mind,

original: Visuddhacarito nātho, yaṃ visuddhimanuttaraṃ;
analyzed: visuddha caritaḥ nāthaḥ yam visuddhim anuttaram
translated: The protector of pure conduct, having attained the unsurpassed purity,

original: Patvā desesi karuṇāsamussāhitamānaso.
analyzed: patvā desesi karuṇā samussāhita mānasaḥ
translated: Which he taught with a mind uplifted by compassion,

original: Tassā adhigamūpāyo, visuddhanayamaṇḍito;
analyzed: tassāḥ adhigama upāyaḥ visuddha naya maṇḍito
translated: The means of attaining it, adorned with the system of purification,

original: Visuddhimaggo yo vutto, suvisuddhapadakkamo.
analyzed: visuddhi maggaḥ yaḥ vuttaḥ su visuddha padakkamaḥ
translated: The Path of Purification, which is well purified,🔽The method of its composition is well purified,

original: Suvisuddhaṃ asaṃkiṇṇaṃ, nipuṇatthavinicchayaṃ;
analyzed: su visuddham asaṃkiṇṇam nipuṇa attha vinicchayam
translated: Well purified, unmixed, with subtle meaning analyzed,

original: Mahāvihāravāsīnaṃ, samayaṃ avilomayaṃ.
analyzed: mahā vihāra vāsīnam samayam
translated: The rule of those who dwell at the Great Monastery,

original: Tassa nissāya porāṇaṃ, kathāmaggaṃ anākulaṃ;🔽Tantinayānugaṃ suddhaṃ, karissāmatthavaṇṇanaṃ.
analyzed: tassa nissāya porāṇam kathā maggaṃ an ākulam  tanti naya anugam suddham karissāma ttha vaṇṇanam
translated: Which is uncorrupted, I will make a commentary

original: Iti ākaṅkhamānassa, saddhammassa ciraṭṭhitiṃ;
analyzed: iti ākaṅkhamānassa saddhammassa ciraṭṭhitim
translated: On that, depending on the ancient method, which is unconfused,🔽Following the thread of the argument, pure,

original: Vibhajantassa tassatthaṃ, nisāmayatha sādhavoti.
analyzed: vibhajantassa tassa attham nisāmayatha sādhavaḥ ti
translated: So may the good examine it.

original: Nidānādikathāvaṇṇanā
analyzed: nidāna ādi kathā vaṇṇanā
translated: The commentary on the introduction, etc.

original: 1. Svāyaṃ visuddhimaggo yaṃ suttapadaṃ nissāya paṭṭhapīyati, taṃ tāva nikkhipitvā
analyzed: su ayam visuddhi maggaḥ yam sutta padam nissāya paṭṭhapīyati tam tāva nikkhipitvā
translated: Now, this Path of Purification which is expounded depending on the text of the Dhamma, the Dispensation, should first be placed.🔽Then, in order to comment on its meaning in various ways by way of the definition of its introduction, etc.,

original: tassa nidānādiniddhāraṇamukhena nānappakārato atthaṃ saṃvaṇṇetuṃ “sīle patiṭṭhāyā”tiādi
analyzed: tassa nidāna ādi niddhāraṇa mukhena nānā pakārataḥ attham saṃvaṇṇetum sīle patiṭṭhāya atiādi
translated: “Having established virtue” is begun.

original: āraddhaṃ. Dhammaṃ saṃvaṇṇentena hi ādito tassa nidānaṃ vattabbaṃ, tato payojanaṃ
analyzed: āraddham dhammam saṃvaṇṇentena hi āditas tassa nidānam vattabbam tatas payojanam
translated: For when a Dhamma is being commented on, its introduction should be stated at the very beginning, then its purpose,

original: piṇḍattho padattho sambandho adhippāyo codanā sodhanaṃ vattabbaṃ. Tathā ceva ācariyena
analyzed: piṇḍatthaḥ padatthaḥ sambandhaḥ adhippāyo codanā sodhanam vattabbam tathā ca iva ācariyena
translated: its summary meaning, its word meaning, its connection, its purport, its exhortation, and its demonstration should be stated. And that is how the teacher

original: paṭipannaṃ. Ettha hi bhagavantaṃ kirātiādi desanāya nidānapayojananiddhāraṇaṃ, visuddhimaggaṃ
analyzed: paṭipannam ettha hi bhagavantam kirāti ādi desanāya nidāna payojana niddhāraṇam visuddhi maggam
translated: Herein, the words “The Blessed One was once staying at Benares in the Deer Park at Isipatana” and so on are the statement of the occasion for the purpose of establishing the nidāna.

original: bhāsissantiādi piṇḍatthaniddhāraṇaṃ, sīle ṭhatvātiādi padatthasambandhādhippāyavibhāvanā,
analyzed: bhāsissanti ādi piṇḍattha niddhāraṇam sīle padattha sambandha adhippāya vibhāvanā
translated: The words “I will teach you, bhikkhus, a method of exposition by which one who has had practice in it for only so long as it takes to walk back and forth (a few times) might, if he so wished, say thus: ‘Destroyed is birth, the holy life has been lived, what had to be done has been done, there is no more for this state of being’” are the statement of the general subject-matter.🔽The words “Bhikkhus, what do you think? What is the root of all things?” and so on are the statement of the question.

original: kiṃ sīlantiādi codanā, tato paraṃ sodhanaṃ, samādhipaññākathāsupi eseva nayo. Kasmā🔽panettha vissajjanagāthā ādimhi nikkhittā, na pucchāgāthā. Pucchāpubbikā hi vissajjanāti?
analyzed: kim codanā tato param sodhanam samādhi paññā kathāsu pi esā iva nayo kasmā  pana ittha vissajjana gāthā ādimhi nikkhittā na pucchāgāthā pucchā pubbikā hi vissajjanā ati
translated: The words “Bhikkhus, virtue is the only way” and so on are the statement of the answer.

original: Vuccate – tadatthassa maṅgalabhāvato, sāsanassa ādikalyāṇādibhāvavibhāvanato, bhayādiupaddavanivāraṇena🔽antarāyavidhamanato, upari saṃvaṇṇetabbadhammasaṅgahato cāti veditabbaṃ.
analyzed: vuccate tad atthassa maṅgala bhāvataḥ sāsanassa ādi kalyāṇa ādi bhāva vibhāvanataḥ bhaya ādi upaddava nivāraṇena  antarāya vidhamanataḥ upari saṃvaṇṇetabba dhamma saṅgahataḥ ca ati veditabbam
translated: The words “Bhikkhus, virtue is the only way” and so on are the statement of the answer.🔽The words “Bhikkhus, what do you think? What is the root of all things?” and so on are the statement of the question.🔽The words “Bhikkhus, virtue is the only way” and so on are the statement of the answer.

original: Etthāha – kasmā panāyaṃ visuddhimaggakathā vatthupubbikā āraddhā, na satthuthomanāpubbikāti?
analyzed: ettha āha kasmā pana ayam visuddhi magga kathā vatthu pubbikā āraddhā na satthu thomanā pubbikā ati
translated: The words “Bhikkhus, virtue is the only way” and so on are the statement of the answer.🔽The words “Bhikkhus, virtue is the only way” and so on are the statement of the answer.🔽The words “Bhikkhus, virtue is the only way” and so on are the statement of the answer.🔽The words “Bhikkhus, virtue is the only way” and so on are the statement of the answer.🔽The words “Bhikkhus, virtue is the only way” and so on are the statement of the answer.🔽The words “Bhikkhus, virtue is the only way” and so on are the statement of the answer.🔽The words “Bhikkhus, virtue is the only way” and so on are the statement of the answer.🔽The words “Bhikkhus, virtue is the only way” and so on are the statement of the answer.🔽The words “Bhikkhus, virtue is the only way” and so on are the statement of the answer.🔽The words “Bhikkhus, virtue is the

original: Vuccate – visuṃ asaṃvaṇṇanādibhāvato. Sumaṅgalavilāsinīādayo viya hi dīghanikāyādīnaṃ
analyzed: vuccate visum a saṃvaṇṇanā ādi bhāvataḥ sumaṅgalavilāsinī ādayaḥ hi dīgha nikāya ādīnam
translated: Reply: Because it is not a separate commentary, etc.,

original: nāyaṃ visuṃ saṃvaṇṇanā, na pakaraṇantaraṃ vā abhidhammāvatārasumatāvatārādi viya.
analyzed: nāyam visum saṃvaṇṇanā na pakaraṇa antaram vā abhidhammāvatāra sumatāvatāra ādi viya
translated: For this is not a separate commentary on the Dīgha Nikāya, etc., like the Sumangalavilāsinī, nor is it a separate treatise like the Abhidhammavatāra and the Sumatāvatāra.🔽But it is a special commentary on the Sumangalavilāsinī, etc.,

original: Tāsaṃyeva pana sumaṅgalavilāsinīādīnaṃ visesabhūtā. Tenevāha “majjhe visuddhimaggo”tiādi.
analyzed: tāsam yeva pana sumaṅgala vilāsinī ādīnam visesa bhūtā tena iva āha majjhe visuddhi maggaḥ tiādi
translated: Therefore it is said: “In the middle, the Path of Purification,” etc.

original: Atha vā thomanāpubbikāpi cāyaṃ kathā na vatthupubbikāvāti daṭṭhabbaṃ. Sāsane hi vatthukittanaṃ
analyzed: atha vā thomanā pubbikā api ca ayam kathā na vatthu pubbikā avā ati daṭṭhabbam sāsane hi vatthu kittanam
translated: Or else, this talk should be regarded as not preceded by a subject of conversation, but by praise. For in the Dispensation

original: na loke viya kevalaṃ hoti, sāsanasampattikittanattā pana satthu aviparītadhammadesanābhāvavibhāvanena🔽satthuguṇasaṃkittanaṃ ulliṅgantameva pavattati. Tathā hi vakkhati “ettāvatā tisso
analyzed: na loke viya kevalam hoti sāsana sampatti kittana ttā pana satthu aviparīta dhamma desanā bhāva vibhāvanena  satthu guṇa saṃkittanam ulliṅgantam eva pavattati tathā hi vakkhati ettāvatā tissaḥ
translated: the glorification of the subject is not merely like that in the world, but it proceeds by implication to the glorification of the Master’s special qualities by showing the undeludedness of the Master’s teaching of the True Idea.🔽Thus he says: “In this way the three trainings,” etc.

original: sikkhā”tiādi. Sotāpannādibhāvassa ca kāraṇanti ettha hi ādi-saddena sabbasakadāgāmianāgāmino
analyzed: sikkhā ati ādi sotāpanna ādi bhāvassa ca kāraṇanti ettha hi ādi saddena sabba sakadāgāmi anāgāmino
translated: And the reason for the states of Stream-Entry, etc., Here the word “etc.” includes all the Once-Returners, Non-Returners, and Arahants.

original: viya sabbepi arahanto saṅgayhanti vibhāgassa anuddhaṭattā. Tena tiṇṇampi bodhisattānaṃ
analyzed: viya sabbe pi arahantaḥ saṅgayhanti vibhāgassa an uddhaṭa ttā tena tiṇṇam pi bodhisattānam
translated: and all Arahants are included, since no distinction is made.

original: nibbedhabhāgiyā sīlādayo idha “sīle patiṭṭhāyā”tiādivacanena saṅgahitāti daṭṭhabbaṃ.
analyzed: nibbedha bhāgiyā sīla ādayaḥ idha sīle patiṭṭhāya ati ādi vacanena saṅgahitā iti daṭṭhabbaṃ
translated: So it should be understood that the virtues, etc., of the three Bodhisattvas that are conducive to penetration are included here by the words “having established virtue” .

original: Tiṇṇampi hi nesaṃ carimabhave visesato saṃsārabhayikkhaṇaṃ, yathāsakaṃ sīle patiṭṭhāya🔽samathavipassanaṃ ussukkāpetvā taṇhājaṭāvijaṭanapaṭipatti ca samānāti. Atha vā “so
analyzed: tiṇṇam pi hi na esam carima bhave visesataḥ saṃsāra bhayi kkhaṇam yathāsakam sīle patiṭṭhāya  samatha vipassanam ussukkāpetvā taṇhā jaṭā vijaṭana paṭipatti ca samānāti atha vā so
translated: For all three of them, in their last existence, the fear of the round of rebirths was special, and they all established themselves in virtue,🔽and they all developed serenity and insight, and they all practised the way that disentangles the tangle of craving.

original: imaṃ vijaṭaye jaṭa”nti sādhāraṇavacanena sātisayaṃ, niratisayañca taṇhājaṭāvijaṭanaṃ
analyzed: imam vijaṭaye jaṭanti sādhāraṇa vacanena sa atisayam niratisayam ca taṇhā jaṭā vijaṭanam
translated: Or alternatively, the disentanglement of the tangle of craving is included by the words “he will disentangle this tangle” , which are stated in a way that is both special and not special.

original: gahitaṃ. Tattha yaṃ niratisayaṃ savāsanappahānatāya. Tena satthu pahānasampadā kittitā
analyzed: gahitam tattha yam niratisayam sa vāsanā pahāna tāya tena satthu pahāna sampadā kittitā
translated: Herein, the not-special is that of the Master, which is accompanied by the abandoning of the defilements together with their inherent tendencies.🔽So the Master’s perfection of abandoning and the perfection of knowledge that has that as its root are proclaimed,

original: hoti, tannimittā ñāṇasampadā ca. Tadubhayena nānantarikatāya ānubhāvasampadādayopīti.
analyzed: tad nimittā ñāṇa sampadā ca tad ubhayena na ānantarika tāyai ānubhāva sampad ādayaḥ api iti
translated: and also the perfection of psychic power, etc., because they have no sequel.

original: Evampi thomanāpubbikāyaṃ kathāti veditabbaṃ. Atha vā thomanāpubbikā evāyaṃ kathāti
analyzed: evam pi thomanā pubbikā ayam kathā iti veditabbam atha vā thomanā pubbikā eva ayam kathā iti
translated: So this story should be understood as told by way of the not-special. Or alternatively, this story is told by way of the special.

original: daṭṭhabbaṃ, “sabbadhammesu appaṭihatañāṇacāro”tiādinā satthu thomanaṃ purakkhatvā🔽saṃvaṇṇanāya āraddhattā. Sā panāyaṃ yasmā pucchantassa ajjhāsayānurūpaṃ byākaraṇasamatthatāya
analyzed: daṭṭhabbam sabba dhammesu appaṭihata ñāṇa cāro ti ādinā satthu thomanam purakkhatvā  saṃvaṇṇanāya āraddhattā sā pana ayam yasmā pucchantassa ajjhāsayā anurūpam byākaraṇa samattha tāya
translated: “He should be seen as one whose knowledge and insight are unobstructed in all things” .🔽The commentary is begun with the eulogy of the Master because it is a commentary that proceeds by way of elucidation,

original: vibhāvanavasena pavattitā, āciṇṇañcetaṃ ācariyassa yadidaṃ saṃvaṇṇetabbadhammānukūlaṃ
analyzed: vibhāvana vasena pavatti tā āciṇṇam ca itam ācariyassa yat idam saṃvaṇṇetabba dhamma anukūlam
translated: since it is capable of answering in accordance with the inquirer’s intention. And it is the teacher’s wont to begin a commentary with a eulogy of the subject of the commentary.

original: saṃvaṇṇanārambhe satthu abhitthavanaṃ. Tasmā iminā kāraṇena evamettha thomanā pavattitāti.🔽Thomanākārassa vuccamānassa kāraṇaṃ uddharantena paṭhamaṃ vissajjanagāthaṃ nikkhipitvā🔽tassā nidānacodanāmukhena pucchāgāthaṃ sarūpato ca atthato ca dassetvā tassā pucchāya
analyzed: saṃvaṇṇanā ārambhe satthu abhitthavanam tasmai iminā kāraṇena evam ettha thomanā pavatti tā ati  thomana ākārassa vuccamānassa kāraṇam uddharantena paṭhamam vissajjana gātham nikkhipitvā  tassāḥ nidāna codanā mukhena pucchāgātham sarūpato ca atthato ca dassetvā tassāḥ pucchāya
translated: Therefore the eulogy occurs here for this reason.🔽When the reason for the eulogy is being stated, the first answer verse is placed first,🔽and then the question verse is shown in its wording and meaning by way of the explanation of its nidāna.

original: aviparītabyākaraṇasamatthabhāvāvajotanaṃ bhagavato thomanaṃ purakkhatvā yathādhippetadhammasaṃvaṇṇanā
analyzed: aviparīta byākaraṇa samattha bhāva avajotanam bhagavataḥ thomanam purakkhatvā yathā adhippeta dhamma saṃvaṇṇanā
translated: After that, the commentary on the subject as it has been determined is begun with the eulogy of the Blessed One, which shows his ability to answer the question without error.

original: katā. Tenāha “sīle patiṭṭhāyā”tiādi. Tattha gāthāya attho parato āvi bhavissati.
analyzed: katā tena āha sīle patiṭṭhāya atiādi tattha gāthāya attho paratas bhavissati
translated: and so he said “Having established himself in virtue” . Herein, the meaning of the verse will appear later.

original: Itītiādīsu itīti ayaṃ iti-saddo hetu parisamāpanādipadatthavipariyāyapakārāvadhāraṇanidassanādianekatthappabhedo.
analyzed: iti iti ādīsu iti iti ayam iti saddaḥ hetu parisamāpana ādi padattha vipariyāya pakāra avadhāraṇa nidassana ādi aneka attha ppabhedaḥ
translated: In the words it is thus, etc., the word thus has many different meanings, such as cause, completion, and so on.

original: Tathā hesa “ruppatīti kho, bhikkhave, tasmā ‘rūpa’nti vuccatī”tiādīsu hetumhi āgato.🔽“Tasmātiha me, bhikkhave, dhammadāyādā bhavatha, mā āmisadāyādā. Atthi me tumhesu
analyzed: tathā ha esa ruppati iti kho bhikkhave tasmā rūpanti vuccati itiādīsu hetumhi āgataḥ  tasmā ati ha me bhikkhave dhamma dāyādāḥ bhavatha mā āmisa dāyādāḥ atthi me tumhesu
translated: For it is found in the sense of cause in such passages as “It is because he is cooled that he is called ‘a visible rūpa’ , bhikkhus” .

original: anukampā ‘kinti me sāvakā dhammadāyādā bhaveyyuṃ, no āmisadāyādā”tiādīsu parisamāpane.
analyzed: anukampā kinti me sāvakāḥ dhamma dāyādāḥ bhaveyyuṃ no āmisa dāyādā ati ādīsu parisamāpane
translated: In the sense of completion in such passages as “Therefore, bhikkhus, be my heirs in Dhamma, not my heirs in material things. I have compassion for you, bhikkhus, thinking ‘How can my disciples become my heirs in Dhamma and not my heirs in material things?’” .

original: “Iti vā iti evarūpā naccagītavāditavisūkadassanā paṭivirato”tiādīsu ādiatthe. “Māgaṇḍiyoti
analyzed: iti vā iti evarūpā nacca gīta vādita visūka dassanā paṭiviratā iti ādīsu ādi atthe māgaṇḍiyā ti
translated: In the sense of beginning in such passages as “Thus he abstains from shows of dancing, singing, and music, and from going to see such shows” .

original: tassa brāhmaṇassa saṅkhā samaññā paññatti vohāro nāmaṃ nāmakammaṃ nāmadheyyaṃ nirutti
analyzed: tassa brāhmaṇassa saṅkhā samaññā paññatti vohāraḥ nāmam nāma kammam nāmadheyyam nirutti
translated: In the sense of a name in such passages as “The brahmin Māgaṇḍiya’s name was Māgaṇḍiya” .

original: byañjanaṃ abhilāpo”tiādīsu padatthavipariyāye. “Iti kho, bhikkhave, sappaṭibhayo
analyzed: byañjanam abhilāpa uti ādīsu padattha vipariyāye iti kho bhikkhave sa paṭibhayaḥ
translated: In the passage, “So, bhikkhus, the fool is with fear,

original: bālo, appaṭibhayo paṇḍito. Saupaddavo bālo, anupaddavo paṇḍito. Saupasaggo bālo,
analyzed: bālaḥ appaṭibhayo paṇḍito sa upaddavaḥ bālaḥ anupaddavaḥ paṇḍito sa upasaggaḥ bālo
translated: the wise man is without fear. The fool is with sorrow, the wise man is without sorrow. The fool is with danger, the wise man is without danger” , it is in the sense of a class.

original: anupasaggo paṇḍito”tiādīsu pakāre. “Atthi idappaccayā jarāmaraṇanti iti puṭṭhena🔽satā, ānanda, atthītissa vacanīyaṃ, kiṃpaccayā jarāmaraṇanti iti ce vadeyya, jātipaccayā
analyzed: anupasaggaḥ paṇḍito ti ādīsu pakāre atthi idappaccayā jarā maraṇanti iti puṭṭhena  satā ānanda atthi itissa vacanīyam kiṃpaccayā jarā maraṇanti iti ce vadeyya jāti paccayā
translated: In the passage, “When asked, ‘Is there a specific condition for ageing-and-death? ‘🔽if one says, ‘There is,’ one should say, ‘What is its condition? ‘ and it should be said, ‘Its condition is birth’ ” , it is in the sense of a definition, the meaning being a determination.

original: jarāmaraṇanti iccassa vacanīya”ntiādīsu avadhāraṇe, sanniṭṭhāneti attho. “Atthīti🔽kho, kaccāna, ayameko anto, natthīti kho, kaccāna, ayaṃ dutiyo anto”tiādīsu nidassane.🔽Idhāpi nidassane daṭṭhabbo, pakāretipi vattuṃ vaṭṭateva. Paṭhamo pana iti-saddo parisamāpane
analyzed: jarā maraṇanti iccassa vacanīya nti ādīsu avadhāraṇe sanniṭṭhāna iti atthaḥ atthi iti  kho kaccāna ayam ekaḥ antaḥ natthi iti kho kaccāna ayam dutiyaḥ antaḥ ti ādīsu nidassane  idha api nidassane daṭṭhabbaḥ pakāra iti pi vattum vaṭṭatā iva paṭhamaḥ pana iti saddaḥ parisamāpane
translated: In the passage, “‘Is there, Kaccana, any one condition dependent on which ageing-and-death occurs?’ ‘There is, Kaccana’ ‘And what is that condition, Kaccana?’ ‘Ageing-and-death occurs dependent on birth as its one condition’ ” , it is in the sense of a definition, the meaning being a determination.🔽In the passage, “‘Is there, Kaccāna, any one condition dependent on which ageing-and-death occurs?’ ‘There is, Kaccāna’ ‘And what is that condition, Kaccāna?’ ‘Ageing-and-death occurs dependent on birth as its one condition’ ” , it is in the sense of a definition, the meaning being a determination.🔽In the passage, “‘Is there, Kaccāna, any one condition dependent on which ageing-and-death occurs?’ ‘There is, Kaccāna’ ‘And what is that condition, Kaccāna?’ ‘Ageing-and-death occurs dependent on birth as its one condition’ ” , it is in the sense of a definition, the meaning being a determination.

original: daṭṭhabbo. Hīti avadhāraṇe. Idanti āsannapaccakkhavacanaṃ yathādhigatassa suttapadassa abhimukhīkaraṇato.
analyzed: daṭṭhabbaḥ hi iti avadhāraṇe idam ti āsanna paccakkha vacanam yathā adhigatassa sutta padassa abhimukhīkaraṇato
translated: In the passage, “‘Is there, Kaccāna, any one condition dependent on which ageing-and-death occurs?’ ‘There is, Kaccāna’ ‘And what is that condition, Kaccāna?’ ‘Ageing-and-death occurs dependent on birth as its one condition’ ” , it is in the sense of a definition, the meaning being a determination.🔽In the passage, “‘Is there, Kaccāna, any one condition dependent on which ageing-and-death occurs?’ ‘There is, Kaccāna

original: Vuttanti ayaṃ vutta-saddo saupasaggo, anupasaggo ca vappanavāpasamīkaraṇakesohāraṇajīvitavuttipamuttabhāvapāvacanapavattitaajjhesanakathanādīsu dissati. Tathā hi ayaṃ –
analyzed: vuttam ti ayam vutta saddo sa upasaggaḥ anupasaggaḥ ca vappana vāpa samīkaraṇa kesa uhāraṇa jīvita vutti pamutta bhāva pāvacana pavattita ajjhesana kathana ādīsu dissati tathā hi ayam
translated: The word said is found with and without prefix in the sense of sowing, of making equal, of shaving, of livelihood, of release, of the state of being released, of being proclaimed, of being invited, of speaking, and so on. For it is said:🔽Cows are born for him,

original: “Gāvo tassa pajāyanti, khette vuttaṃ virūhati;
analyzed: gāvaḥ tassa pajāyanti khette vuttam virūhati
translated: what is sown grows in his field,🔽he eats the fruit of what is said,

original: Vuttānaṃ phalamasnāti, yo mittānaṃ na dubbhatī”ti. –🔽Ādīsu vappane āgato. “No ca kho paṭivutta”ntiādīsu aṭṭhadantakādīhi vāpasamīkaraṇe.🔽“Kāpaṭiko māṇavo daharo vuttasiro”tiādīsu kesohāraṇe. “Pannalomo paradattavutto migabhūtena
analyzed: vuttānam phalam asnāti yaḥ mittānam na dubbhati iti  ādīsu vappane āgataḥ no ca kho paṭivutta nti ādīsu aṭṭhadantaka ādīhi vā apasamīkaraṇe  kāpaṭikaḥ māṇavaḥ daharaḥ kesa hāraṇe pannalomo para datta vuttaḥ miga bhūtena
translated: who does not deceive his friends.

original: cetasā viharatī”tiādīsu jīvitavuttiyaṃ. “Seyyathāpi nāma paṇḍupalāso bandhanā pavutto🔽abhabbo haritatthāyā”tiādīsu bandhanato pamuttabhāve. “Yesamidaṃ etarahi porāṇaṃ
analyzed: cetasā viharati iti ādīsu jīvita vuttiyam seyyathā api nāma paṇḍu palāsaḥ bandhanā pavutto  abhabbaḥ harita tthāya ati ādīsu bandhanataḥ pamutta bhāve yesam idam etarahi porāṇam
translated: Herein, it is found in the sense of sowing. In the passage beginning, “But he did not say ‘Yes’ ” , it is found in the sense of making equal by means of the eight tusk-like teeth, and so on. In the passage, “The young brahman Māṇava, his head anointed” , it is found in the sense of shaving. In the passage, “He lives with hair and beard grown long, clothed in rags picked up from the dust-heap, his livelihood being announced” , it is found in the sense of livelihood. In the passage, “Just as a withered leaf tossed by the wind goes down, down to the ground,🔽so too this man, his life gone, goes down, down to death” , it is found in the sense of the state of being released from bondage. In the passage, “Whatever ancient verses there are in the world, composed by the seers,

original: mantapadaṃ gītaṃ pavuttaṃ samihita”ntiādīsu pāvacanabhāvena pavattite. Loke pana
analyzed: manta padam gītam pavuttam samihitam ti ādīsu pā vacana bhāvena pavattite loke pana
translated: that have been uttered and are honoured” , it is found in the sense of being proclaimed. In the world it is found in the sense of being invited.

original: “vutto guṇo vutto pārāyano”tiādīsu ajjhesane. “Vuttaṃ kho panetaṃ bhagavatā ‘dhammadāyādā
analyzed: vuttaḥ guṇaḥ vutto pārāyanaḥ ti ādīsu ajjhesane vuttam kho pana itam bhagavatā dhamma dāyādā
translated: “The quality has been stated, the consummation has been stated” , in the sense of invitation. “But this has been said by the Blessed One: ‘The disciples inherit Dhamma,

original: me, bhikkhave, bhavatha, mā āmisadāyādā’ti”ādīsu kathane. Idhāpi kathane eva daṭṭhabbo.
analyzed: me bhikkhave bhavatha mā āmisa dāyādāti ādīsu kathane idha api kathane eva daṭṭhabbo
translated: In such passages as “The virtue has been spoken of, the surcease of bondage has been spoken of” , it is in the sense of invitation. In such passages as “But this has been said by the Blessed One: ‘Make yourselves the heirs of the Dhamma, bhikkhus, not the heirs of material things’ ” , it is in the sense of speaking. Here it should be understood in the sense of speaking.

original: Tasmā “iti hi evameva idaṃ suttaṃ desita”nti yathānikkhittaṃ gāthaṃ desitabhāvena
analyzed: tasmai iti hi evam eva idam suttam desitanti yathā nikkhittam gātham desita bhāvena
translated: So he shows the verse as taught in the way in which it was taught, saying “Thus this sutta is taught” .

original: nidasseti. Tassā vā desitākāraṃ avadhāreti.
analyzed: nidasseti tassāḥ vā desita ākāram avadhāreti
translated: Or he adverts to the way in which it was taught.

original: Kasmāti hetumhi nissakkaṃ. Panāti vacanālaṅkāramattaṃ. Ubhayenāpi kāraṇaṃ pucchati.🔽Etanti yathāvuttaṃ suttapadaṃ paccāmasati. Vuttanti pucchānimittaṃ. Tadatthassa attano🔽buddhiyaṃ viparivattamānataṃ upādāya “ida”nti vatvā puna bhagavatā bhāsitākāraṃ sandhāya
analyzed: kasmā iti hetumhi nissakkam pana ati vacana alaṅkāra mattam ubhayena api kāraṇam pucchati  etat ti yathāvuttam sutta padam paccāmasati vuttan ti pucchā nimittam tad atthassa attano  upādāya idam ti vatvā puna bhagavatā bhāsita ākāram sandhāya
translated: Why? In the sense of cause. But is merely a particle of speech. By both he asks the reason.🔽This is the sutta passage as already stated.🔽The word “said” is the reason for the question. Having said “this” with reference to the turning about of his own understanding of the meaning of that,

original: “eta”nti vuttaṃ. Sakalena panānena vacanena desanāya nidānaṃ jotitaṃ hoti. Parato
analyzed: etat ti vuttam sakalena pana anena vacanena desanāya nidānam jotitam hoti paratas
translated: he said “that” with reference to the way in which it was spoken by the Blessed One. But by the whole of this statement the source of the teaching is made known.

original: tassā desakadesakālapaṭiggāhake vibhāvetuṃ “bhagavantaṃ kirā”tiādi vuttaṃ. Tattha
analyzed: tassāḥ desaka desa kāla paṭiggāhake vibhāvetum bhagavantam kirāti ādi vuttam tattha
translated: In order to show the place, the time, and the recipient of the teaching, the following words were spoken: “It is said that the Blessed One … ” Herein

original: kirāti anussavanatthe nipāto. Tena vuccamānassatthassa anu anu suyyamānataṃ dīpeti.
analyzed: kirāti anussavana atthe nipātaḥ tena vuccamānassa atthassa anu anu suyyamāna tam dīpeti
translated: “It is said” is a particle in the sense of hearsay. It shows that the meaning being stated is heard by him again and again.

original: Rattibhāgeti rattiyā ekasmiṃ koṭṭhāse, majjhimayāmeti adhippāyo. Vessavaṇādayo viya
analyzed: ratti bhāge iti rattiyāḥ ekasmin koṭṭhāse majjhima yāmā iti adhippāyaḥ vessavaṇa ādayaḥ viya
translated: “In the middle watch of the night” means in one part of the night; the intention is the middle part of the night. Like Vessavaṇa, etc.,

original: apākaṭanāmadheyyattā aññataro. Devo eva devaputto. Saṃsayasamugghāṭatthanti vicikicchāsallasamuddharaṇatthaṃ
analyzed: apākaṭa nāmadheyya ttā aññataraḥ devaḥ eva deva putto saṃsaya samugghāṭa ttham ti vicikicchā salla samuddharaṇa ttham
translated: he is “a certain” because his name is not well known. He is a “son of a god” because he is a god. “In order to remove his doubt” means in order to remove the dart of doubt.

original: pucchīti yojanā. “Saṃsayasamugghāṭattha”nti ca iminā pañcasu pucchāsu ayaṃ vimaticchedanāpucchāti
analyzed: pucchī iti yojanā ca iminā pañcasu pucchāsu ayam vimati chedanā pucchā ati
translated: The construction is: he asked. “In order to remove his doubt” shows that this is a question asking for a decision in order to cut off doubt among the five kinds of questions.

original: dasseti. Yena atthena taṇhā “jaṭā”ti vuttā, tameva atthaṃ dassetuṃ “jāliniyā”tiādi
analyzed: dasseti yena atthena taṇhā jaṭā ati vuttā tam eva attham dassetum jāliniyā ātiādi
translated: In order to show the meaning for which craving is called “a tangle,” it is said: “With its net of craving, etc.”

original: vuttaṃ. Sā hi aṭṭhasatataṇhāvicaritappabhedo attano avayavabhūto eva jālo etissā🔽atthīti “jālinī”ti vuccati.
analyzed: vuttam sā hi aṭṭhasata taṇhā vicarita ppabhedaḥ attanaḥ avayava bhūtaḥ eva jālaḥ etissā 🔽atthi iti jālinī iti vuccati
translated: For it is a net in the sense of being spread out in the form of the eighty-eight types of craving. Since it has a net that is itself, it is called “having a net.”

original: Idānissā jaṭākārena pavattiṃ dassetuṃ “sā hī”tiādi vuttaṃ. Tattha rūpādīsu ārammaṇesūti
analyzed: idānissā jaṭā ākārena pavattim dassetum sā hi itiādi vuttam tattha rūpa ādīsu ārammaṇesu
translated: Now, in order to show its occurrence by means of the tangle of hair, the root-cause, etc., it is said: “That craving, etc.” Herein, in regard to objects such as visible forms, etc.

original: tassā pavattiṭṭhānamāha, rūpādichaḷārammaṇavinimuttassa taṇhāvisayassa abhāvato.
analyzed: tassā pavatti ṭṭhānam āha rūpa ādi chaṭṭa ārammaṇa vinimuttassa taṇhā visayassa abhāvataḥ
translated: He shows the place of its occurrence. For there is no object of craving apart from the six objects such as visible forms, etc.

original: Heṭṭhupariyavasenāti kadāci rūpārammaṇe kadāci yāva dhammārammaṇe kadāci dhammārammaṇe
analyzed: heṭṭhu pariya vasena ati kadāci rūpa ārammaṇe kadāci yāva dhamma ārammaṇe kadāci dhamma ārammaṇe
translated: By way of the lower and the upper: sometimes in regard to the object of visible forms, sometimes up to the object of mental phenomena; sometimes in regard to the object of mental phenomena,

original: kadāci yāva rūpārammaṇeti evaṃ heṭṭhā, upari ca pavattivasena. Desanākkamena cettha🔽heṭṭhupariyatā daṭṭhabbā. Kadāci kāmabhave kadāci rūpabhave kadāci arūpabhave kadāci
analyzed: kadāci yāva rūpa ārammaṇā iti evam heṭṭhā upari ca pavatti vasena desanā kkamena ca ittha  heṭṭhu pariyatā daṭṭhabbā kadāci kāma bhave kadāci rūpa bhave kadāci arūpa bhave kadāci
translated: sometimes up to the object of visible forms. Thus it occurs by way of the lower and the upper. But here the lower and the upper should be understood by way of the order of teaching.

original: vā arūpabhave…pe… kadāci kāmabhaveti evamettha heṭṭhupariyavasena pavatti veditabbā.🔽Sabbasaṅkhārānaṃ khaṇe khaṇe bhijjanasabhāvattā aparāparuppatti ettha saṃsibbananti
analyzed: vā kadāci kāma bhave iti evam ettha heṭṭhu pariya vasena pavatti veditabbā  sabba saṅkhārānam khaṇe khaṇe bhijjana sabhāva ttā apara apara uppatti ettha saṃsibbanam ti
translated: Sometimes in the sense-desire realm, sometimes in the form realm, sometimes in the formless realm, sometimes in the formless realm, … sometimes in the sense-desire realm. Thus its occurrence should be understood by way of the lower and the upper.🔽Because all formations have the nature of breaking up moment after moment, their arising again and again is called “entanglement” here.

original: āha “punappunaṃ uppajjanato”ti. “Saṃsibbanaṭṭhenā”ti idaṃ yena sambandhena jaṭā viyāti
analyzed: āha punappunam uppajjanato ti saṃsibbana ṭṭhena ati idam yena sambandhena jaṭā viyāti
translated: Therefore it is said: “because of arising again and again.” As to the meaning of entanglement: since it is like a tangle, it is called “entanglement” .

original: jaṭāti jaṭātaṇhānaṃ upamūpameyyatā, taṃdassanaṃ. Ayaṃ hettha attho – yathā jālino🔽veḷugumbassa sākhā, kosasañcayādayo ca attanā attano avayavehi saṃsibbitā vinaddhā🔽“jaṭā”ti vuccanti, evaṃ taṇhāpi saṃsibbanasabhāvenāti, “saṃsibbitaṭṭhenā”ti vā pāṭho,🔽attanāva attano saṃsibbitabhāvenāti attho. Ayaṃ hi taṇhā kosakārakimi viya attanāva🔽attānampi saṃsibbantī pavattati. Tenāha bhagavā “rūpataṇhā loke piyarūpaṃ sātarūpaṃ,
analyzed: jaṭāti jaṭātaṇhānam taṃ dassanam ayam ha ittha atthaḥ yathā jālinaḥ  veḷu gumbassa sākhā kosa sañcaya ādayo ca attanā attanaḥ avayavehi saṃsibbitāḥ vinaddhā  jaṭā ati vuccanti evam taṇhā api saṃsibbana sabhāvena ati saṃsibbita ṭṭhena ati vā pāṭhaḥ  attanāva attano saṃsibbita bhāvena ati atthaḥ ayam hi taṇhā viya attanāva  attānam pi saṃsibbantī pavattati tena āha bhagavā rūpataṇhā loke piya rūpam sāta rūpam
translated: “Tangles” : the similes for craving are the tangles, and the seeing of them is the seeing of the tangles. The meaning here is this. Just as the branches of a bamboo thicket, and the bundles of reeds, etc., are called “tangles” because they are intertwined and bound together by themselves with their own parts,🔽so too craving is of the nature of intertwining. Or alternatively, the reading may be “by the characteristic of intertwining” ,🔽the meaning being that it is intertwined by itself. For this craving occurs intertwining itself, as it were, with itself, like a spider spinning thread. Hence the Blessed One said: “Craving for sensual pleasures in the world is a form of relishing, a form of attraction,🔽

original: etthesā taṇhā uppajjamānā uppajjati, ettha nivisamānā nivisatī”tiādi. Ime sattā “mama🔽ida”nti pariggahitaṃ vatthuṃ attanibbisesaṃ maññamānā abbhantarimaṃ karonti. Abbhantarattho🔽ca antosaddoti sakaparikkhāre uppajjamānāpi taṇhā “antojaṭā”ti vuttā. Pabbajitassa
analyzed: ettha īsā taṇhā uppajjamānā uppajjati ettha nivisamānā nivisati itiādi ime sattāḥ mama 🔽idam ti pariggahitam vatthum atta nibbisesam maññamānāḥ abbhantarimam karonti abbhantara tthaḥ 🔽ca antosaddo ti saka parikkhāre uppajjamānā api taṇhā antojaṭā ti vuttā pabbajitassa
translated: The tangle is a simile for craving. The meaning here is this. Just as the branches of a bamboo clump, and the bundles of reeds, etc., are called a “tangle” because they are intertwined and bound together by themselves with their own parts, so too craving is a tangle because it is of the nature of intertwining. Or alternatively, the reading is “by the state of being intertwined,” and the meaning is that it is a tangle because it is intertwined by itself with itself. For this craving occurs as if it were a spider spinning out thread and binding with it the very self that produced it. Hence the Blessed One said: “In the world, bhikkhus, craving is a thing that has arisen. Herein craving arises, herein it ceases” , and so on. These beings, thinking “This is mine, this I am, this is my self,” make their own self a distinction in the things they have taken as “I” and “mine.” And the word “inside” has the meaning of “within.” So craving, though it arises in regard to one’s own requisites, is called “the tangle within.”

original: pattādi, gahaṭṭhassa hatthiādi sakaparikkhāro.
analyzed: patta ādi gahaṭṭhassa hatthi ādi saka parikkhāro
translated: The bowl, etc., are the requisites of the householder. The elephant, etc., are the requisites of the king.

original: “Attā”ti bhavati ettha abhimānoti attabhāvo, upādānakkhandhapañcakaṃ. Sarīranti keci.
analyzed: attā ati bhavati ettha abhimāno ti atta bhāvaḥ upādānakkhandha pañcakam sarīranti keci
translated: “Self” is the selfhood that is the five aggregates subject to clinging, which is the basis for the conceit “I am.” Some say that “self” is the body.

original: Mama attabhāvo sundaro, asukassa viya mama attabhāvo bhaveyyāti vā ādinā sakaattabhāvādīsu
analyzed: mama attabhāvaḥ sundaraḥ asukassa viya mama attabhāvaḥ bhaveyya iti vā ādinā saka attabhāva ādīsu
translated: The mode of appearance of craving is to be understood as follows: “My selfhood is beautiful,” or “May my selfhood be like so-and-so’s.”

original: taṇhāya uppajjamānākāro veditabbo. Attano cakkhādīni ajjhattikāyatanāni. Attano,🔽paresañca rūpādīni bāhirāyatanāni. Paresaṃ sabbāni vā, saparasantatipariyāpannāni🔽vā cakkhādīni ajjhattikāyatanāni. Tathā rūpādīni bāhirāyatanāni. Parittamahaggatabhavesu
analyzed: taṇhāyaḥ uppajjamāna ākāraḥ veditabbo attanaḥ cakkha ādīni ajjhattika āyatanāni attanaḥ  paresam ca rūpa ādīni bāhira āyatanāni paresam sabbāni vā sa para santati pariyāpannāni  vā cakkha ādīni ajjhattika āyatanāni tathā rūpa ādīni bāhira āyatanāni paritta mahaggata bhavesu
translated: One’s own eye, etc., are the internal sense bases.🔽One’s own form, etc., and the external sense bases of others, or all of them, or the eye, etc., included in one’s own and another’s continuum,

original: pavattiyāpi taṇhāya antojaṭābahijaṭābhāvo veditabbo. Kāmabhavo hi kassacipi kilesassa
analyzed: pavattiyā api taṇhāya antojaṭā bahijaṭā bhāvaḥ veditabbaḥ kāma bhavaḥ hi kassaci pi kilesassa
translated: are the internal sense bases. Likewise, form, etc., are the external sense bases. The internal and external sense bases should be understood as the internal and external tangles of craving, respectively, in the case of craving that occurs in the limited and exalted realms.

original: avikkhambhitattā kathañcipi avimutto ajjhattaggahaṇassa visesapaccayoti “ajjhattaṃ,
analyzed: a vikkhambhita ttā kathañci pi a vimuttaḥ ajjhatta gahaṇassa visesa paccayaḥ ti ajjhattam
translated: For in the sensual realm, because of the non-suppression of defilements, one is not liberated in any way, and the internal grasping is a special condition for the external grasping.

original: anto”ti ca vuccati. Tabbipariyāyato rūpārūpabhavo “bahiddhā, bahī”ti ca. Tenāha bhagavā
analyzed: antar iti ca vuccati tad bipariyāyataḥ rūpa arūpa bhavaḥ bahiddhā bahi iti ca tena āha bhagavā
translated: and it is called “inside.” The opposite of that is the plane of existence consisting of the form and formless worlds, which is called “outside” and “external.” Hence the Blessed One said:

original: “ajjhattasaṃyojano puggalo, bahiddhāsaṃyojano puggalo”ti. Visayabhedena, pavattiākārabhedena🔽ca anekabhedabhinnampi taṇhaṃ jaṭābhāvasāmaññena ekanti gahetvā “tāya evaṃ uppajjamānāya🔽jaṭāyā”ti vuttaṃ. Sā pana “pajā”ti vuttasattasantānapariyāpannā eva hutvā punappunaṃ
analyzed: ajjhatta saṃyojanaḥ puggalaḥ bahiddhā saṃyojanaḥ puggalaḥ ti visaya bhedena pavatti ākāra bhedena  ca aneka bheda bhinnam pi taṇham jaṭā bhāva sāmaññena ekam ti gahetvā tāya evam uppajjamānāya  jaṭāya iti vuttam sā pana pajā iti vutta satta santāna pariyāpannā eva hutvā punappunam
translated: “The person fettered internally, the person fettered externally” .🔽Craving, though divided into many classes according to the diversity of its objects and modes of activity, is taken as one by the common character of being a tangle. Therefore it is said: “By that same craving when it arises as a tangle” .

original: taṃ jaṭentī vinandhantī pavattatīti āha “jaṭāya jaṭitā pajā”ti. Tathā hi paramatthato
analyzed: tam jaṭentī vinandhantī pavattati iti āha jaṭāya jaṭitā pajāti tathā hi paramatthato
translated: But that craving occurs again and again, entangling and binding the continuity of beings, which is called “the generation” . Therefore it is said: “The generation entangled in a tangle by craving” .🔽For in the ultimate sense

original: yadipi avayavabyatirekena samudāyo natthi, ekadeso pana samudāyo nāma na hotīti avayavato
analyzed: yadi pi avayava byatirekena samudāyaḥ natthi ekadeso pana samudāyaḥ nāma na hoti iti avayavato
translated: though there is no assemblage apart from the parts, and though a part is not called an assemblage,

original: samudāyaṃ bhinnaṃ katvā upamūpameyyaṃ dassento “yathā nāma veḷujaṭādīhi…pe… saṃsibbitā”ti
analyzed: samudāyam bhinnam katvā upamūpameyyam dassentaḥ yathā nāma veḷu jaṭā dīhipe saṃsibbitā ati
translated: nevertheless, in order to show the simile and the thing symbolized by taking the assemblage apart from the parts, it is said: “Just as when a tangle of bamboos … is bound together” .

original: āha. Imaṃ jaṭanti sambandho. Tīsu dhātūsu ekampi asesetvā saṃsibbanena tedhātukaṃ🔽jaṭetvā ṭhitaṃ. Tenassā mahāvisayataṃ, vijaṭanassa ca sudukkarabhāvamāha. “Vijaṭetuṃ
analyzed: āha imam sambandhaḥ tīsu dhātūsu ekam pi a sesetvā saṃsibbanena tedhātukam  ṭhitam tena assā mahā visaya tam vijaṭanassa ca su dukkara bhāvam āha vijaṭetum
translated: He said: This tangle, etc. The construction is: In the three planes of becoming there is not even one thing that is not entangled in the tangle of craving, and so it is a tangle of three planes.🔽By this he shows that it has a vast scope and that it is hard to disentangle.

original: ko samattho”ti iminā “vijaṭaye”ti padaṃ sattiatthaṃ, na vidhiādiatthanti dasseti.
analyzed: kaḥ samatthaḥ iti iminā vijaṭayā iti padam satti attham na vidhi ādi atthan ti dasseti
translated: By “Who is able to disentangle it?” he shows that the word “entangle” has the meaning of “entangled,” not the meaning of “to entangle,” etc.

original: Evaṃ “antojaṭā”tiādinā puṭṭho pana assa devaputtassa imaṃ gāthamāhāti sambandho.
analyzed: evam antojaṭā ti ādinā puṭṭhaḥ pana assa deva puttassa imam gātham āha iti sambandho
translated: When asked thus, “What is the tangle within?” etc., the deva replied with this stanza.

original: “Edisova imaṃ pañhaṃ vissajjeyyā”ti satthāraṃ guṇato dassento “sabbadhammesu appaṭihatañāṇacāro”tiādimāha.
analyzed: ediso va imam pañham vissajjeyya ti satthāram guṇataḥ dassentaḥ sabba dhammesu appaṭihata ñāṇa cāro ti ādim āha
translated: “Only one such as he could answer this question,” said the Elder, showing the Teacher’s excellence.

original: Tattha sabbadhammesūti atītādibhedabhinnesu sabbesu ñeyyadhammesu. Appaṭihatañāṇacāroti🔽anavasesañeyyāvaraṇappahānena nissaṅgacārattā navihatañāṇapavattiko. Etena tīsu kālesu
analyzed: tattha sabba dhammesu iti atīta ādi bheda bhinnesu sabbesu ñeyya dhammesu appaṭihata ñāṇa cāro ti  anavasesa ñeyya āvaraṇa pahānena nissaṅga cāra ttā na vihata ñāṇa pavattiko etena tīsu kālesu
translated: Herein, in all ideas means in all ideas to be known, classed as past, future, etc.🔽His knowledge has free course means that his knowledge occurs unobstructed.🔽By this he shows that his knowledge is unobstructed in the three times.

original: appaṭihatañāṇatāvibhāvanena ādito tiṇṇaṃ āveṇikadhammānaṃ gahaṇeneva tadekalakkhaṇatāya
analyzed: a paṭihata ñāṇa tā vibhāvanena āditas tiṇṇam āveṇika dhammānam gahaṇena iva tad eka lakkhaṇa tāya
translated: By the words “From the beginning he has taken up the three special knowledges,” he shows that the three special knowledges are the characteristic of the knowledge of the three times.

original: tadavinābhāvato ca bhagavato sesāveṇikadhammānampi gahitabhāvo veditabbo. Dibbanti
analyzed: tad avinābhāvato ca bhagavato sesa āveṇika dhammānam pi gahita bhāvaḥ veditabbaḥ dibbanti
translated: And because they are inseparable from him, it should be understood that the rest of the Master’s special qualities are included as well.

original: kāmaguṇādīhi kīḷanti laḷanti, tesu vā viharanti, vijayasamatthatāyogena paccatthike
analyzed: kāma guṇa ādīhi kīḷanti laḷanti tesu vā viharanti vijaya samattha tā yogena paccatthike
translated: They play, enjoy themselves, and amuse themselves with the five strands of sense pleasure. Or they live in them, and by the power of their victory they long to conquer their enemies.

original: vijetuṃ icchanti, issariyadhanādisakkāradānaggahaṇaṃ, taṃtaṃatthānusāsanañca karontā🔽voharanti, puññātisayayogānubhāvappattāya jutiyā jotanti, yathādhippetañca visayaṃ
analyzed: vijetum icchanti issariya dhana ādi sakkāra dāna ggahaṇam taṃ taṃ attha anusāsanam ca karontā  voharanti puñña atisaya yoga anubhāva ppattāya jutiyā jotanti yathā adhippetam ca visayam
translated: They deal with the giving of gifts, the bestowal of honours, and the offering of advice.🔽They shine with the radiance that they have attained through the power of their abundant merit. And they go to their desired objective without hindrance. And they are able to create whatever they wish.

original: appaṭighātena gacchanti, yathicchitanipphādane ca sakkontīti devā. Atha vā devanīyā
analyzed: appaṭighātena gacchanti yathā icchita nipphādane ca sakkonti iti devāḥ atha vā devanīyā
translated: Or alternatively, they are worthy of being worshipped by gods,

original: taṃtaṃbyasananittharaṇatthikehi saraṇaṃ parāyaṇanti gamanīyā, abhitthavanīyā vā,
analyzed: saraṇam gamanīyāḥ abhitthavanīyāḥ vā
translated: worthy of being gone to and relied upon by those who are in trouble and seek to be rescued from it,

original: sobhāvisesayogena kamanīyāti vā devā. Te tividhā – sammutidevā upapattidevā visuddhidevāti.
analyzed: sobhā visesa yogena kamanīyā ati vā devā te tividhā sammuti devā upapatti devā visuddhi devā ati
translated: or they are worthy of being admired because they possess a special beauty. They are of three kinds: gods by convention, gods by rebirth, and gods by purification.

original: Bhagavā pana niratisayāya abhiññākīḷāya uttamehi dibbabrahmaariyavihārehi saparasantānagatapañcavidhamāravijayicchānipphattiyā
analyzed: bhagavā pana niratisayāya abhiññā kīḷāya uttamehi dibba brahma ariya vihārehi sa para santāna gata pañcavidha māra vijayi chā nipphattiyā
translated: The Blessed One, however, is endowed with the highest form of speech, which consists in the supreme manifestation of his knowledge-body, and which is characterized by the following: the victory over the five aggregates of clinging together with their underlying tendencies, by means of the unsurpassed play of direct knowledge, the supreme divine and noble abodes, and the fulfillment of the wish to conquer Mara;

original: cittissariyasattadhanādisammāpaṭipatti aveccapasādasakkāradānaggahaṇasaṅkhātena,
analyzed: citti ssariya satta dhana ādi sammā paṭipatti avecca pasāda sakkāra dāna ggahaṇa saṅkhātena
translated: the correct practice of the seven treasures of the mind, such as confidence, etc.; the acceptance of the offerings of faith made by others;🔽and the teaching of the Dhamma in accordance with the inclinations of beings, who are of various natures and dispositions.

original: dhammasabhāvapuggalajjhāsayānurūpānusāsanīsaṅkhātena ca vohārātisayena paramāya paññāsarīrappabhāsaṅkhātāya
analyzed: dhamma sabhāva puggala jjhāsaya anurūpa anusāsanī saṅkhātena ca vohāra atisayena paramāya paññā sarīra ppabhā saṅkhātāya
translated: The Blessed One is also endowed with the highest form of radiance, which is called the light of wisdom;

original: jutiyā, anaññasādhāraṇāya ñāṇasarīragatiyā, māravijayasabbasabbaññuguṇaparahitanipphādanesu🔽appaṭihatāya sattiyā ca samannāgatattā sadevakena lokena “saraṇa”nti gamanīyato,🔽abhitthavanīyato, bhattivasena kamanīyato ca sabbe te deve tehi guṇehi abhibhuyya
analyzed: jutiyā anañña sādhāraṇāya ñāṇa sarīra gatiyā māra vijaya sabba sabbaññu guṇa para hita nipphādanesu  a paṭihatāya sattiyā ca samannāgata ttā sa devakena lokena gamanīyataḥ  abhitthavanīyataḥ bhatti vasena kamanīyataḥ ca sabbe te deve tehi guṇehi abhibhuyya
translated: with the highest form of power, which is not shared by others, and which is unobstructed in the conquest of Mara, in the attainment of all the qualities of omniscience, and in the production of benefit for others;🔽and with the highest form of speech, which is worthy of being gone to, relied upon, and listened to, by the world with its gods, because he is the foremost, the best of all gods, by virtue of his qualities of conquering Mara, of being worthy of offerings, and of being the supreme field of merit.

original: ṭhitattā tesaṃ devānaṃ seṭṭho uttamo devoti devadevo. Sabbadevehi pūjanīyataro devoti
analyzed: ṭhita ttā tesam devānam seṭṭhaḥ uttamaḥ devo ti devadevo sabba devehi pūjanīyataraḥ devo ti
translated: The Blessed One is called “the god of gods” because he is the foremost, the best of all gods, by virtue of his qualities of conquering Mara, of being worthy of offerings, and of being the supreme field of merit.

original: vā, visuddhidevabhāvassa vā sabbaññuguṇālaṅkārassa vā adhigatattā aññesaṃ devānaṃ
analyzed: vā visuddhi deva bhāvassa vā sabbaññu guṇa alaṅkārassa vā adhigata ttā aññesam devānam
translated: or of the purity of the divine state, or of the attainment of the qualities of omniscience and the adornment of virtue,

original: atisayena devoti devadevo.🔽Aparimāṇāsu lokadhātūsu aparimāṇānaṃ sakkānaṃ, mahābrahmānañca guṇābhibhavanato adhiko
analyzed: atisayena deva uti devadevaḥ  aparimāṇāsu lokadhātūsu aparimāṇānam sakkānam mahābrahmānam ca guṇa abhibhavanataḥ
translated: or because he has attained the purity of the divine state, or the adornment of the special qualities of omniscience, he is the god of gods.🔽He is the overlord of Sakka and of Great Brahmā, because he surpasses the special qualities of the innumerable Sakkas and Great Brahmās in the innumerable world systems.

original: atisayo atirekataro vā sakko brahmā cāti sakkānaṃ atisakko brahmānaṃ atibrahmā. Ñāṇappahānadesanāvisesesu
analyzed: atisayaḥ atirekataraḥ vā sakkaḥ brahmā ca ati sakkānam atisakkaḥ brahmānam atibrahmā ñāṇa pahāna desanā visesesu
translated: He is the overlord of Sakka and the overlord of Great Brahmā.

original: sadevake loke kenaci avikkhambhanīyaṭṭhānatāya kutocipi utrastābhāvato catūhi vesārajjehi
analyzed: sa devake loke kenaci a vikkhambhanīya ṭṭhāna tāya kutocipi catūhi vesārajjehi
translated: He is confident because he is not to be overcome by anyone in the world together with its gods, because he is not frightened by anything, and because he possesses the four confidences.

original: visāradoti catuvesārajjavisārado. Yaṃ sandhāya vuttaṃ “sammāsambuddhassa te paṭijānato
analyzed: visāradaḥ ti catu vesārajja visāradaḥ yam sandhāya vuttam sammāsambuddhassa te paṭijānataḥ
translated: This is the reason why it is said: “When you claim to be fully enlightened,🔽there are these things that are not fully understood by you. Here, then, is a recluse or a brahmin…

original: ime dhammā anabhisambuddhāti tatra vata maṃ samaṇo vā…pe… vesārajjappatto viharāmī”ti.
analyzed: ime dhammāḥ an abhisambuddhā ati tatra vata mamam samaṇaḥ vāpe vesārajja ppattaḥ viharāmi iti
translated: I abide having reached these four confidences.”

original: Ṭhānāṭhānañāṇādīhi dasahi ñāṇabalehi samannāgatattā dasabaladharo. Yaṃ sandhāya vuttaṃ
analyzed: ṭhāna aṭhāna ñāṇa ādīhi dasahi ñāṇa balehi samannāgata ttā dasa bala dharaḥ yam sandhāya vuttam
translated: He is the bearer of the ten powers because he possesses the ten powers of knowledge, such as the knowledge of what is possible and impossible, etc. This is the reason why it is said:

original: “idha tathāgato ṭhānañca ṭhānato, aṭṭhānañca aṭṭhānato yathābhūtaṃ pajānātī”tiādi.
analyzed: tathāgataḥ ṭhānam ca ṭhānataḥ aṭṭhānam ca aṭṭhānataḥ yathābhūtam pajānāti itiādi
translated: “Herein, the Tathagata understands as it really is what is possible as possible and what is impossible as impossible” .

original: Yaṃ kiñci ñeyyaṃ nāma, tattha sabbattheva anāvaṭañāṇatāya anāvaraṇañāṇo. Tañca sabbaṃ
analyzed: yam kiñci ñeyyam nāma tattha sabbattha iva an āvaṭa ñāṇa tāya an āvaraṇa ñāṇo tat ca sabbam
translated: He is the one who has knowledge without obstruction in regard to anything that can be known, because of his knowledge that is not obstructed in any object whatsoever.

original: samantato sabbākārato hatthatale āmalakaṃ viya paccakkhato dassanasamatthena ñāṇacakkhunā🔽samannāgatattā samantacakkhu, sabbaññūti attho. Imehi pana dvīhi padehi pacchimāni🔽dve asādhāraṇañāṇāni gahitāni. Bhāgyavantatādīhi kāraṇehi bhagavā. Yaṃ panettha vattabbaṃ,🔽taṃ parato buddhānussatiniddese vitthārato āgamissati.
analyzed: samantataḥ sabba ākārataḥ hattha tale āmalakam viya paccakkhataḥ dassana samatthena ñāṇa cakkhunā  samannāgata ttā samanta cakkhu sabbaññū ti attho imehi pana dvīhi padehi pacchimāni  dve asādhāraṇa ñāṇāni gahitāni bhāgyavanta tā ādīhi kāraṇehi bhagavā yam pana ittha vattabbam  tam paratas buddhānussati niddese vitthārataḥ āgamissati
translated: He is the one who has the eye of knowledge that is able to see all things in all aspects and in every way, as if he had it in the palm of his hand,🔽because he is endowed with the eye of knowledge that is able to see all things in all aspects and in every way, as if he had them in the palm of his hand. The meaning is: he is the one who knows all. But by these two terms the two kinds of knowledge that are not shared by anyone else are included.

original: Ettha ca “sabbadhammesu appaṭihatañāṇacāro”ti iminā tiyaddhāruḷhānaṃ pucchānaṃ bhagavato
analyzed: ettha ca sabba dhammesu appaṭihata ñāṇa cāro ti iminā tiyaddhā āruḷhānam pucchānam bhagavataḥ
translated: The Blessed One is so called because of his possession of the qualities of greatness, and what is to be said about that will be said in the Description of the Recollection of the Buddha .

original: byākaraṇasamatthatāya dassitāya kiṃ devatānampi pucchaṃ byākātuṃ samattho bhagavāti
analyzed: byākaraṇa samattha tāya dassitāya kim devatānam pi puccham byākātum samatthaḥ bhagavā iti
translated: And here, by showing that the Blessed One is able to answer the questions of the three divine messengers, he shows that the Blessed One is able to answer the questions of the deities as well.

original: āsaṅkāya tannivattanatthaṃ “devadevo”ti vuttaṃ. Devānaṃ atidevo sakko devānamindo
analyzed: āsaṅkāya tad nivattana attham devadevaḥ iti vuttam devānam atidevaḥ sakkaḥ devānam indo
translated: “God of gods” is said for the purpose of warding off the doubt that might arise thus: “Since he is a god, he is Sakka, the king of the gods,

original: devatānaṃ pañhaṃ vissajjeti, “tato imassa ko viseso”ti cintentānaṃ tannivattanatthaṃ🔽“sakkānaṃ atisakko”ti vuttaṃ. Sakkenapi pucchitamatthaṃ sanaṅkumārādayo brahmāno
analyzed: devatānam pañham vissajjeti tatas imassa kaḥ visesaḥ ti cintentānam tad nivattana attham  sakkānam atisakko ti vuttam sakkena api pucchitam attham sanaṅkumāra ādayaḥ brahmānaḥ
translated: who answers the deities’ questions. What is the difference between him and Sakka?”🔽“Surpassing Sakka” is said for the purpose of warding off the doubt that might arise thus: “Since he is Sakka, he is Sanaṅkumāra, etc., the Brahmās,

original: vissajjenti, “tato imassa ko atisayo”ti cintentānaṃ tannivattanatthaṃ “brahmānaṃ
analyzed: vissajjenti tatas imassa kaḥ atisayaḥ ti cintentānam tad nivattana attham brahmānam
translated: who answer the questions of Sakka. What is the difference between him and the Brahmās?”

original: atibrahmā”ti vuttaṃ. Ayaṃ cassa viseso catuvesārajjadasabalañāṇehi pākaṭo jātoti🔽dassanatthaṃ “catu…pe… dharo”ti vuttaṃ. Imāni ca ñāṇāni imassa ñāṇadvayassa adhigamena🔽saheva siddhānīti dassanatthaṃ “anāvaraṇañāṇo samantacakkhū”ti vuttaṃ. Tayidaṃ ñāṇadvayaṃ
analyzed: atibrahmā ati vuttam ayam ca ssa viseso catu vesārajja dasa bala ñāṇehi pākaṭaḥ jātaḥ ti  dassana attham catupe dharo ti vuttam imāni ca ñāṇāni imassa ñāṇa dvayassa adhigamena  saha iva siddhāni iti dassana attham anāvaraṇa ñāṇo samanta cakkhu iti vuttam tayā idam ñāṇa dvayam
translated: This difference of his has become evident through the four kinds of intrepidity and the ten powers of knowledge.🔽“Bearer of the ten universal characteristics” is said for the purpose of showing that. And since these kinds of knowledge are established together with the acquisition of these two kinds of knowledge,

original: puññañāṇasambhārūpacayasiddhāya bhaggadosatāya siddhanti dassento “bhagavā”ti avocāti.
analyzed: puñña ñāṇa sambhāra upacaya siddhāya bhagga dosa tāya siddhanti dassentaḥ bhagavā ati avoca iti
translated: “Omniscient, all-seeing” is said for the purpose of showing that. And since these two kinds of knowledge are established in one who has accumulated the requisites of merit and knowledge and has thus removed the defects,🔽he is called “Blessed” .

original: Evametesaṃ padānaṃ gahaṇe payojanaṃ, anupubbi ca veditabbā. Yaṃ panetaṃ pacchimaṃ🔽anāvaraṇañāṇaṃ sabbaññutaññāṇanti ñāṇadvayaṃ, taṃ atthato abhinnaṃ. Ekameva hi taṃ
analyzed: evam etesam padānam gahaṇe payojanam anupubbi ca veditabbā yam pana itam pacchimam  anāvaraṇa ñāṇam sabbaññu taññāṇanti ñāṇa dvayam tam atthataḥ abhinnam ekam eva hi tam
translated: This is the purpose of the terms, and this is the order in which they should be understood.🔽The last two terms, however, namely, “knowledge of omniscience” and “knowledge of the termination of the outflows,” are identical in meaning.

original: ñāṇaṃ visayapavattimukhena aññehi asādhāraṇabhāvadassanatthaṃ dvidhā katvā vuttaṃ.
analyzed: ñāṇam visaya pavatti mukhena aññehi asādhāraṇa bhāva dassana attham dvidhā katvā vuttam
translated: For they are one and the same knowledge, which is stated in two ways in order to show that it is unique in being the object of the entire knowable and in being unobstructed.

original: Anavasesasaṅkhatāsaṅkhatasammutidhammārammaṇatāya sabbaññutaññāṇaṃ, tatthāvaraṇābhāvato🔽nissaṅgacāramupādāya “anāvaraṇañāṇa”ntipi vuttaṃ. Yaṃ panettha vattabbaṃ, taṃ parato
analyzed: anavasesa saṅkhata asaṅkhata sammuti dhamma ārammaṇa tāya sabbaññu ta ññāṇam tattha āvaraṇa abhāvato  nissaṅga cāram upādāya anāvaraṇa ñāṇam ti pi vuttam yat pana ittha vattabbam tat paratas
translated: The knowledge of omniscience is so called because it has as its object all the dhammas of the three times and the conventional dhammas without exception.🔽The knowledge of the termination of the outflows is so called because it is unobstructed in regard to them.

original: buddhānussatiniddese vakkhāma.
analyzed: buddha anussati niddese vakkhāma
translated: What should be said about this has been said in the Buddha-Recollection .🔽The Great Sage is the Blessed One, who has sought out and found the great aggregates of virtue, concentration, wisdom, etc.

original: 2. Mahante sīlakkhandhādike esī gavesīti mahesi, bhagavā. Tena mahesinā. Vaṇṇayantoti
analyzed: mahante sīlakkhandha ādike esī gavesī iti mahesi bhagavā tena mahesinā vaṇṇayanto ti
translated: By him, the Great Sage,🔽I shall expound🔽in accordance with the truth

original: vivaranto vitthārento. Yathābhūtanti aviparītaṃ. Sīlādibhedananti sīlasamādhipaññādivibhāgaṃ.
analyzed: aviparītam sīla ādi bhedananti sīla samādhi paññā ādi vibhāgam
translated: the analysis of virtue, etc.

original: Sudullabhanti aṭṭhakkhaṇavajjitena navamena khaṇena laddhabbattā suṭṭhu dullabhaṃ.
analyzed: su dullabhanti aṭṭhakkhaṇa vajjitena navamena khaṇena laddhabba ttā suṭṭhu dullabham
translated: Hard to find : it is very hard to find, since it is to be found only in the ninth of the eight opportunities .

original: Sīlādisaṅgahanti sīlādikkhandhattayasaṅgahaṃ. Ariyamaggo hi tīhi khandhehi saṅgahito
analyzed: sīla ādi saṅgaham ti sīla ādi kkhandha ttaya saṅgaham ariya maggaḥ hi tīhi khandhehi saṅgahitaḥ
translated: Comprising virtue, etc., : comprising the three aggregates beginning with virtue. For the noble path is comprised by the three aggregates beginning with virtue,

original: sappadesattā nagaraṃ viya rajjena, na tayo khandhā ariyamaggena nippadesattā. Vuttañhetaṃ
analyzed: sa padesa ttā nagaram viya rajjena na tayo khandhāḥ ariya maggena nippadesa ttā vuttam ha etam
translated: just as a city is comprised by its moat, etc., because they are similar to it. But the three aggregates beginning with virtue are not comprised by the noble path because they have no similarity to it. For this is said:

original: “na kho, āvuso visākha, ariyena aṭṭhaṅgikena maggena tayo khandhā saṅgahitā; tīhi
analyzed: na kho āvuso visākha ariyena aṭṭhaṅgikena maggena tayaḥ khandhā saṅgahitā tīhi
translated: “Friend Visākha, the three aggregates are not comprised by the noble eightfold path;

original: ca kho, āvuso visākha, khandhehi ariyo aṭṭhaṅgiko maggo saṅgahito”ti. Kilesacorehi
analyzed: ca kho āvuso visākha khandhehi ariyaḥ aṭṭhaṅgikaḥ maggo saṅgahito ti kilesa corehi
translated: but the noble eightfold path is comprised by the three aggregates” .🔽Safe : because it cannot be plundered by the thieves of defilements.

original: aparipanthanīyatāya khemaṃ. Antadvayaparivajjanato, māyādikāyavaṅkādippahānato ca🔽ujuṃ. Sabbesaṃ saṃkilesadhammānaṃ māraṇavasena gamanato pavattanato, nibbānassa magganato,
analyzed: a paripanthanīya tāyai anta dvaya parivajjanataḥ māyā ādi kāya vaṅka ādi ppahānataḥ ca  ujum sabbesam saṃkilesa dhammānam māraṇa vasena gamanataḥ pavattanataḥ nibbānassa magganataḥ
translated: Straight : because it avoids the two extremes and because it abandons the crookedness of the body, etc., beginning with deceit.🔽Path : because it goes by way of the destruction of all defiling phenomena, because it is the way to go, and because those who seek Nibbāna must go by it.

original: nibbānatthikehi maggitabbato ca maggaṃ. Visuddhiyāti nibbānāya, visuddhibhāvāya vā, arahattāyāti attho.
analyzed: nibbāna atthikehi maggitabbataḥ ca maggam visuddhiyā ti nibbānāya visuddhi bhāvāya vā arahattāya ati attho
translated: Purification : for the sake of Nibbāna, or for the sake of the purified state of Arahantship.

original: Yathābhūtaṃ ajānantāti evaṃ sīlavisuddhiādivisuddhiparamparāya adhigantabbo evarūpo
analyzed: yathābhūtam evam sīla visuddhi ādi visuddhi paramparāya adhigantabbaḥ evarūpaḥ
translated: Not knowing things as they really are: such a person cannot attain the kind of virtue, etc.,

original: evaṃkiccako evamatthoti yāthāvato anavabujjhantā. Sakalasaṃkilesato, saṃsārato ca🔽suddhiṃ vimuttiṃ kāmenti patthentīti suddhikāmā. Api-saddo sambhāvane. Tena na kevalaṃ
analyzed: evaṃkiccakaḥ evamattho ti yāthāvataḥ anavabujjhantā sakala saṃkilesataḥ saṃsārataḥ ca  suddhim vimuttim kāmenti patthenti iti suddhi kāmāḥ api saddo sambhāvane tena na kevalam
translated: Not knowing the truth: not understanding the truth of the matter as it really is, namely, that such and such is the function and such and such the benefit of the purification of virtue, etc., which must be reached by means of the successive stages of purification beginning with the purification of virtue.

original: sīlamattena parituṭṭhā, atha kho visuddhikāmāpi samānāti dasseti. Idhāti imasmiṃ🔽sāsane. Bhāvanāya yuttapayuttatāya yogino vāyamantāpi visuddhiṃ uddissa payogaṃ parakkamaṃ
analyzed: sīla mattena parituṭṭhā atha kho visuddhi kāmā api samānā ati dasseti idha ati imasmin  sāsane bhāvanāya yutta payutta tāya yoginaḥ vā āyamanta api visuddhim uddissa payogam parakkamam
translated: They are “longing for purification” because they long for, i.e., desire, purification and deliverance from the whole of the defilements and from the round of rebirths. The word “also” shows that they are not satisfied merely with virtue but also long for purification.🔽Here in this Dispensation, the meditators, i.e., the yogis, who are occupied with development, who are engaged in the practice of development, and who are striving, i.e., who are making effort, with the aim of purification, do not reach purification because they have not discovered the means. This is the construction.

original: karontāpi upāyassa anadhigatattā visuddhiṃ nādhigacchantīti yojanā. Tesanti yogīnaṃ.
analyzed: karontā api upāyassa anadhigata ttā visuddhim na adhigacchanti iti yojanā tesanti yogīnam
translated: Theirs: of the yogis.

original: Kāmañcāyaṃ visuddhimaggo samantabhaddakattā savanadhāraṇaparicayādipasutānaṃ sabbesampi
analyzed: kāmam ca ayam visuddhi maggo samanta bhaddaka ttā savana dhāraṇa paricaya ādi pasutānam sabbesam pi
translated: And although this path of purification is entirely auspicious, still,

original: pāmojjakaro, yogīnaṃ pana sātisayaṃ pamodahetūti āha “tesaṃ pāmojjakaraṇa”nti. Bāhirakanikāyantaraladdhīhi🔽asammissatāya suṭṭhu visuddhavinicchayattā suvisuddhavinicchayaṃ. Mahāvihāravāsīnanti
analyzed: pāmojja karaḥ yogīnam pana sa atisayam pamoda hetu iti āha tesam bāhiraka nikāya antara laddhīhi  a sammissa tāya suṭṭhu visuddha vinicchaya ttā su visuddha vinicchayam mahā vihāra vāsīnam ti
translated: It is the cause of gladness for yogis, since it is the cause of their special gladness. It is well purified in its decisions, since its decisions are well purified by the absence of admixture with the doctrines of the outsiders and with the doctrines of the other schools of Buddhism. The residents of the Great Monastery:🔽🔽

original: attano apassayabhūtaṃ nikāyaṃ dasseti. Desanānayanissitanti dhammasaṃvaṇṇanānayasannissitaṃ.🔽Ettha ca “tesaṃ pāmojjakaraṇa”ntiādinā sabbasaṃkilesamalavisuddhatāya visuddhiṃ nibbānaṃ
analyzed: attanaḥ a passaya bhūtam nikāyam dasseti desanā naya nissitam ti dhamma saṃvaṇṇanā naya sannissitam  ettha ca tesam pāmojja karaṇa nti ādinā sabba saṃkilesa mala visuddha tāya visuddhim nibbānam
translated: It is a source of gladness for those who are meditators, since it is a cause of their special gladness. It is well purified in its decisive-support since it is not mixed up with the views of other sects, and it is well purified in its investigation since it is well purified in its decisive-support. The dwellers in the Great Monastery: he shows that his own sect is the standard. It is based on the method of teaching: it is based on the method of expounding the Dhamma.

original: patthentānaṃ yogīnaṃ ekaṃsena tadāvahattā pāmojjakaro ñāṇuttarehi sammāpaṭipannehi🔽adhiṭṭhitattā suṭṭhu sammā visuddhavinicchayo mahāvihāravāsīnaṃ kathāmaggoti dasseti.
analyzed: patthentānam yogīnam eka aṃsena tad āvahattā pāmojja karaḥ ñāṇa uttarehi sammā paṭipannehi  adhiṭṭhita ttā suṭṭhu sammā visuddha vinicchayaḥ mahāvihāra vāsīnam kathā maggo ti dasseti
translated: And here he shows that the Path of Purification, which is the Nibbāna that is purified by the complete purification of all the stains of defilement, is a source of gladness for meditators who are intent on that Nibbāna, since it is the means to it, and that it is well purified in its investigation since it is well purified in its decisive-support, because it is undertaken by those who are rightly practising by means of the knowledge that comes at the end of the purification of virtue, and it is the path of talk for the dwellers in the Great Monastery.

original: Sakkaccaṃ me bhāsato sakkaccaṃ nisāmayathāti yojetabbaṃ.
analyzed: sakkaccam me bhāsataḥ sakkaccam nisāmayatha iti yojetabbam
translated: The words “Listen, good sirs, to my talk” should be construed as “Listen, good sirs, to my talk that is well purified in its decisive-support and well purified in its investigation, which is a source of gladness for those who are rightly practising by means of the knowledge that comes at the end of the purification of virtue, and which is the path of talk for the dwellers in the Great Monastery.”

original: Ettha ca “imissā dāni gāthāyā”ti iminā visuddhimaggabhāsanassa nissayaṃ, “kathitāya
analyzed: ettha ca imissā dāni gāthāya ati iminā visuddhi magga bhāsanassa nissayam kathitāya
translated: And here, by the words “Now, in this stanza” he shows the support for the teaching of the Path of Purification,

original: mahesinā”ti iminā tassa pamāṇabhāvaṃ, “yathābhūtaṃ atthaṃ sīlādibhedana”nti iminā
analyzed: mahesinā ati iminā tassa pamāṇa bhāvam yathābhūtam attham sīla ādi bhedanam ti iminā
translated: by “the true meaning of virtue and so on,”🔽the unperverted general meaning,

original: aviparītapiṇḍatthaṃ, “sudullabhaṃ…pe… yogino”ti iminā nimittaṃ, “tesaṃ pāmojjakaraṇa”nti🔽iminā payojanaṃ, “vaṇṇayanto atthaṃ, suvisuddhavinicchayaṃ mahāvihāravāsīnaṃ desanānayanissitaṃ,
analyzed: aviparīta piṇḍa ttham yogino ti iminā nimittam tesam pāmojja karaṇam ti  iminā payojanam vaṇṇayantaḥ attham su visuddha vinicchayam mahā vihāra vāsīnam desanā naya nissitam
translated: by “so hard to find … for meditators,”🔽the cause, and by “to give them joy,”

original: sakkacca”nti ca iminā karaṇappakāraṃ dassetvā “visuddhikāmā sabbepi, nisāmayatha
analyzed: ca iminā karaṇa ppakāram dassetvā visuddhi kāmā sabbe api nisāmayatha
translated: the purpose. Having shown the method of composition by “expounding the meaning, the very pure discernment of the residents of the Great Monastery, based on the method of teaching,🔽with respect,”🔽he exhorts the good people to listen with respect by “Therefore all who long for purity,

original: sādhavo”ti iminā tattha sakkaccasavane sādhujane niyojeti. Sādhukaṃ savanapaṭibaddhā hi sāsanasampatti.
analyzed: sādhavaḥ ti iminā tattha sakkacca savane sādhu jane sādhukam savana paṭibaddhā hi sāsana sampatti
translated: good people, listen attentively.” For the success of the Dispensation depends on listening attentively.

original: 3. Vacanatthavibhāvanena paveditavisuddhimaggasāmaññatthassa visuddhimaggakathā vuccamānā
analyzed: vacana attha vibhāvanena pavedita visuddhi magga sāmañña tthassa visuddhi magga kathā vuccamānā
translated: The explanation of the path of purity, which has been shown by the analysis of the meaning of the words,🔽arouses confidence in the meaning of the path of purity in common with the Path of Purity.

original: abhiruciṃ uppādetīti padatthato visuddhimaggaṃ vibhāvetuṃ “tattha visuddhī”tiādi
analyzed: abhirucim uppādeti iti padatthataḥ visuddhi maggam vibhāvetum tattha visuddhi itiādi
translated: To analyze the Path of Purity according to the word-meaning, he says “Herein, purity” and so on.

original: āraddhaṃ. Tattha tatthāti yadidaṃ “visuddhimaggaṃ bhāsissa”nti ettha visuddhimaggapadaṃ
analyzed: āraddham tattha tattha ati yat idam visuddhi maggam bhāsissanti ettha visuddhi magga padam
translated: Herein, “there” refers to the words “I shall expound the path of purification” .

original: vuttaṃ, tattha. Sabbamalavirahitanti sabbehi rāgādimalehi, sabbehi saṃkilesamalehi🔽ca virahitaṃ vivittaṃ. Tato eva accantaparisuddhaṃ, sabbadā sabbathā ca visuddhanti
analyzed: vuttam tattha sabba mala virahitan ti sabbehi rāga ādi malehi sabbehi saṃkilesa malehi  ca virahitam vivittam tatas eva accanta parisuddham sabbadā sabbathā ca visuddham ti
translated: Free from all stains: free from all stains of lust, etc., and from all stains of defilement.🔽And because of that, utterly pure. The meaning is that it is purified in every way at all times.

original: attho. Yathāvuttaṃ visuddhiṃ maggati gavesati adhigacchati etenāti visuddhimaggo.🔽Tenāha “maggoti adhigamūpāyo vuccatī”ti. Visuddhimaggoti ca nippariyāyena lokuttaramaggo
analyzed: atthaḥ yathāvuttam visuddhim maggati gavesati adhigacchati etena ati visuddhi maggaḥ  tena āha maggo ti adhigama upāyaḥ vuccati iti visuddhi maggo ti ca nippariyāyena lokuttara maggo
translated: It is the path of purification in that it seeks out, finds, and reaches the purification described in the way stated.🔽Hence it is said: “The word ‘path’ signifies the means to reach .”

original: veditabbo, tadupāyattā pana pubbabhāgamaggo, tannissayo kathāpabandho ca tathā vuccati.
analyzed: veditabbaḥ tad upāya ttā pana pubbabhāga maggaḥ tad nissayo kathā apabandho ca tathā vuccati
translated: The supramundane path itself should be understood as the path of purification in the ultimate sense. But the path of preliminary concentration, which is a means to that , and the connected discourse are so called by extension.

original: Svāyaṃ visuddhimaggo satthārā desanāvilāsato, veneyyajjhāsayato ca nānānayehi desito,
analyzed: su ayam visuddhi maggo satthārā desanā vilāsataḥ ca nānā nayehi desitaḥ
translated: This path of purification has been taught by the Master in various methods out of his skill in the teaching and his desire to benefit his disciples.

original: tesu ayameko nayo gahitoti dassetuṃ “so panāya”ntiādi āraddhaṃ. Tattha katthacīti
analyzed: tesu ayam ekaḥ nayaḥ gahitaḥ iti dassetum saḥ pana ayanti ādi āraddham tattha katthaci iti
translated: Herein, one method has been taken up and explained.

original: kismiñci sutte. Vipassanāmattavasenevāti avadhāraṇena samathaṃ nivatteti. So hi tassā
analyzed: kismiñci sutte vipassanā matta vasena iva ati avadhāraṇena samatham nivatteti saḥ hi tassā
translated: In some sutta. By the word “only” he excludes serenity,

original: paṭiyogī, na sīlādi. Matta-saddena ca visesanivattiatthena savisesaṃ samādhiṃ nivatteti.🔽So upacārappanābhedo vipassanāyānikassa desanāti katvā na samādhimattaṃ. Na hi khaṇikasamādhiṃ
analyzed: paṭiyogī na sīla ādi matta saddena ca visesa nivatti atthena sa visesam samādhim nivatteti  saḥ upacāra ppanā bhedaḥ vipassanāyānikassa desanā ti katvā na samādhimattam na hi khaṇika samādhim
translated: for that is the opposite of insight, not virtue, etc. And by the word “only” he excludes concentration with its special qualities, for it has the meaning of exclusion of what is different.🔽For that is taught for one whose vehicle is insight, which is of two kinds, access and absorption. It is not concentration only,

original: vinā vipassanā sambhavati. Vipassanāti ca tividhāpi anupassanā veditabbā, na aniccānupassanāva.🔽Na hi aniccadassanamattena saccābhisamayo sambhavati. Yaṃ pana gāthāyaṃ aniccalakkhaṇasseva
analyzed: vinā vipassanā sambhavati vipassanā ati ca tividhā api anupassanā veditabbā na anicca anupassanā eva  na hi anicca dassana mattena sacca abhisamayaḥ sambhavati yam pana gāthāyam anicca lakkhaṇassa iva
translated: for insight does not occur without momentary concentration. And by “insight” should be understood the three kinds of contemplation, not only contemplation of impermanence,

original: gahaṇaṃ kataṃ, taṃ yassa tadeva suṭṭhutaraṃ pākaṭaṃ hutvā upaṭṭhāti, tādisassa vasena.
analyzed: gahaṇam katam tam yassa tat eva suṭṭhutaram pākaṭam hutvā upaṭṭhāti tādisassa vasena
translated: for it is not possible to penetrate to the truths merely by seeing impermanence. But the reason why only the characteristic of impermanence is mentioned in the verse is that it appears more obvious and clearer to some people in that way.

original: Sopi hi itaraṃ lakkhaṇadvayaṃ vibhūtataraṃ katvā sammasitvā visesaṃ adhigacchati,
analyzed: saḥ api hi itaram lakkhaṇa dvayam vibhūtataram katvā sammasitvā visesam adhigacchati
translated: For he too, by comprehending the other two characteristics in a more refined way, reaches distinction.

original: na aniccalakkhaṇameva.
analyzed: na anicca lakkhaṇam eva
translated: He does not reach it by the characteristic of impermanence alone.

original: Sabbe saṅkhārāti sabbe tebhūmakasaṅkhārā, te hi sammasanīyā. Aniccāti na niccā addhuvā
analyzed: sabbe saṅkhārā ati sabbe tebhūmaka saṅkhārā te hi sammasanīyā aniccā ati na niccāḥ addhuvā
translated: All formations: all formations in the three planes, for they are to be summed up. Are impermanent: they are not permanent, not lasting,

original: ittarā khaṇabhaṅgurāti. Paññāyāti vipassanāpaññāya. Passati sammasati. Atha pacchā🔽udayabbayañāṇādīnaṃ uppattiyā uttarakālaṃ. Nibbindati dukkheti tasmiṃyeva aniccākārato
analyzed: ittarā khaṇa bhaṅgurā ti paññāya ati vipassanā paññāya passati sammasati atha pacchā  udaya bbaya ñāṇa ādīnam uppattiyāḥ uttara kālam nibbindati dukkha iti tasmin yeva anicca ākārato
translated: but are perishable by nature. He sees: he sees with insight knowledge. He comprehends: he comprehends with conformity knowledge. Then afterwards: after the arising of the knowledge of rise and fall, etc.,

original: diṭṭhe “sabbe saṅkhārā”ti vutte tebhūmake khandhapañcakasaṅkhāte dukkhe nibbindati🔽nibbidāñāṇaṃ paṭilabhati. Esa maggo visuddhiyāti esa nibbidānupassanāsaṅkhāto virāgādīnaṃ
analyzed: diṭṭhe sabbe saṅkhārā ti vutte tebhūmake khandha pañcaka saṅkhāte dukkhe nibbindati  nibbidā ñāṇam paṭilabhati esa maggo visuddhiyā ti esa nibbidā anupassanā saṅkhāto virāga ādīnam
translated: He becomes dispassionate towards suffering: in that same sign of impermanence he becomes dispassionate towards suffering consisting of the five aggregates in the three planes of existence, which are summed up as “all formations.”

original: kāraṇabhūto nibbānassa adhigamūpāyo.
analyzed: kāraṇa bhūtaḥ nibbānassa adhigama upāyaḥ
translated: He obtains the knowledge of dispassion. This is the path to purification: this path to purification, consisting of the contemplation of dispassion, is the means to attain Nibbāna, which is the cause of fading away of greed, etc.

original: Jhānapaññāvasenāti samathavipassanāvasena. Jhānanti cettha vipassanāya pādakabhūtaṃ
analyzed: jhāna paññā vasena āti samatha vipassanā vasena jhānanti ca ittha vipassanāya pādaka bhūtam
translated: By means of jhāna and insight: by means of serenity and insight. Herein, jhāna is intended as the jhāna that is the basis for insight.

original: jhānaṃ adhippetaṃ. Yamhīti yasmiṃ puggale. Jhānañca paññā cāti etthāyamattho – yo
analyzed: jhānam adhippetam yamhi iti yasmin puggale jhānam ca paññā ca ati ettha ayam atthaḥ yaḥ
translated: In whom: in which person. Both jhāna and insight: the meaning is that in whom both jhāna and insight are present.

original: puggalo jhānaṃ pādakaṃ katvā vipassanaṃ paṭṭhapetvā taṃ ussukkāpeti. Sa ve nibbānasantiketi
analyzed: puggalaḥ jhānam pādakam katvā vipassanam paṭṭhapetvā tam ussukkāpeti sa ve nibbāna santikā iti
translated: A person, having made jhāna the basis, sets up insight and develops it. He is said to be “near to Nibbāna.”

original: so byattaṃ nibbānassa samīpe ekantato nibbānaṃ adhigacchatīti.
analyzed: so byattam nibbānassa samīpe ekantataḥ nibbānam adhigacchati iti
translated: He is able to attain Nibbāna completely.

original: Kammanti maggacetanā. Sā hi apacayagāmitāya sattānaṃ suddhiṃ āvahati. Vijjāti sammādiṭṭhi.
analyzed: kammanti magga cetanā sā hi apacaya gāmi tāya sattānam suddhim āvahati vijjāti sammādiṭṭhi
translated: “Kamma” is the volition of the path. It brings about purification of beings because it leads to diminution . “Knowledge” is right view.

original: Sīlanti sammāvācākammantā. Jīvitamuttamanti sammāājīvo. Dhammoti avasesā cattāro
analyzed: sīlanti sammā vācā kammantā jīvitam uttamanti sammāājīvaḥ dhammo ti avasesā cattāro
translated: “Virtue” is right speech, action, and livelihood. “The supreme life” is right livelihood. “Dhamma” is the remaining four path factors.

original: ariyamaggadhammā. Atha vā kammanti sammākammantassa gahaṇaṃ. “Yā cāvuso visākha,🔽sammādiṭṭhi, yo ca sammāsaṅkappo, ime dhammā paññākkhandhe saṅgahitā”ti vacanato.🔽Vijjāti sammādiṭṭhisammāsaṅkappānaṃ gahaṇaṃ. Dhammoti samādhi “evaṃdhammā te bhagavanto
analyzed: ariya magga dhammā atha vā kammanti sammākammantassa gahaṇam yā ca āvuso visākha  sammādiṭṭhi yaḥ ca sammāsaṅkappo ime dhammā paññā kkhandhe saṅgahitā ati vacanato  vijjā ti sammādiṭṭhi sammāsaṅkappānam gahaṇam dhammo ti samādhi evaṃdhammā te bhagavanto
translated: Or alternatively, “kamma” is the inclusion of right action,🔽because of the statement: “Now, friend Visākha, right view and right intention are included in the wisdom aggregate” .🔽“Knowledge” is the inclusion of right view and right intention. “Dhamma” is concentration,

original: ahesu”ntiādīsu viya. Taggahaṇeneva “yo cāvuso visākha, sammāvāyāmo, yā ca sammāsati,
analyzed: ahesunti ādīsu viya tad gahaṇena iva yā ca āvuso visākha sammā vāyāmaḥ yā ca
