translated: as in the passages: “Those Blessed Ones were of such virtues” , etc. By the inclusion of that, “Now, friend Visākha, right effort and right mindfulness are included in the concentration aggregate” .

original: yo ca sammāsamādhi, ime dhammā samādhikkhandhe saṅgahitā”ti vacanato sammāvāyāmasatīnampi
analyzed: yaḥ ca sammāsamādhi ime dhammā samādhi kkhandhe saṅgahitā ati vacanato sammā vāyāma satīnam pi
translated: “Right concentration” — these things are included in the concentration aggregate.”

original: gahaṇaṃ daṭṭhabbaṃ. Sīlanti sammāvācājīvānaṃ. Jīvitamuttamanti evarūpassa ariyapuggalassa
analyzed: gahaṇam daṭṭhabbam sīlanti sammā vācā jīvānam jīvitam uttamanti evarūpassa ariya puggalassa
translated: So the right effort and right mindfulness should be seen as included in the concentration aggregate. “ Virtue” is right speech and right action. “ Life” is the life of a noble person.

original: jīvitaṃ uttamaṃ jīvitanti evamettha aṭṭhaṅgiko ariyamaggo vuttoti veditabbo.
analyzed: jīvitam uttamam jīvitanti evam ettha aṭṭhaṅgikaḥ ariya maggaḥ vuttaḥ ti veditabbaḥ
translated: “ Supreme” is the supreme life. Thus the eightfold noble path should be understood as stated here.

original: Sīlādivasenāti sīlasamādhipaññāvīriyavasena. Sabbadāti samādānato pabhuti sabbakālaṃ.
analyzed: sīla ādi vasena āti sīla samādhi paññā vīriya vasena sabbadā ti samādānataḥ sabbakālam
translated: “ By virtue and so on” means by virtue, concentration, wisdom, and energy. “ All” means all the time, from the time of undertaking.

original: Sīlasampannoti catupārisuddhisīlasampadāya sampanno samannāgato. Paññavāti lokiyalokuttarāya🔽paññāya samannāgato. Susamāhitoti taṃsampayuttena samādhinā suṭṭhu samāhito. Āraddhavīriyoti
analyzed: sīla sampannaḥ ti catu pārisuddhi sīla sampadāya sampanno samannāgato paññavā ati lokiya lokuttarāya  paññāya samannāgato su samāhito ti tad sampayuttena samādhinā suṭṭhu samāhitaḥ āraddha vīriyaḥ ti
translated: “ Endowed with virtue” means endowed with, possessing, the accomplishment of virtue consisting in the fourfold purity. “ Wisdom” means endowed with mundane and supramundane wisdom.

original: akusalānaṃ dhammānaṃ pahānāya, kusalānaṃ dhammānaṃ upasampadāya paggahitavīriyo.
analyzed: akusalānam dhammānam pahānāya kusalānam dhammānam upasampadāya paggahita vīriyaḥ
translated: “ Well concentrated” means well concentrated by means of the concentration associated with it. “ One who has aroused energy” means one who has undertaken energy for the abandoning of unwholesome states and for the acquisition of wholesome states.

original: Pahitattoti nibbānaṃ patipesitattatāya kāye ca jīvite ca nirapekkhacitto. Oghanti
analyzed: pahitatto ti nibbānam patipesitattatāya kāye ca jīvite ca nirapekkha cittaḥ
translated: “ One who has attained calm” means one who has attained the calm of the mind by means of the concentration associated with it. “ One who is intent” means one who is intent on nibbana, one whose mind is indifferent to the body and life. “ One who has crossed the flood” means one who has crossed the four floods of sensuality, existence, views, and ignorance.

original: kāmoghādicatubbidhampi oghaṃ, saṃsāramahoghameva vā.🔽Ekāyanoti ekamaggo. Maggapariyāyo hi idha ayana-saddo, tasmā ekapathabhūto ayaṃ,
analyzed: kāma ogha ādi catur bidham pi ogham saṃsāra mahā ogham eva vā  eka ayanaḥ ti eka maggaḥ magga pariyāyaḥ hi idha ayana saddo tasmai eka patha bhūtaḥ ayam
translated: Or else, the flood is of four kinds, namely, the flood of sense desire, and so on, or else the great flood of the round of rebirths.

original: bhikkhave, maggo, na dvedhāpathabhūtoti attho. Ekaṃ vā nibbānaṃ ayati gacchatīti
analyzed: bhikkhave maggaḥ na dvedhāpatha bhūtaḥ ti attho ekam vā nibbānam ayati gacchati iti
translated: The one-way path: the one path, the one way. For the word ayana here is a synonym for path. So this path, bhikkhus, is a one-way path, not a two-way path, is the meaning. Or it is a one-way path in that it goes to the one Nibbāna,

original: ekāyano, ekena vā gaṇasaṅgaṇikaṃ pahāya vivekaṭṭhena ayitabbo paṭipajjitabboti ekāyano,
analyzed: ekāyanaḥ ekena vā gaṇa saṅgaṇikam pahāya viveka ṭṭhena ayitabbo paṭipajjitabbo iti ekāyanaḥ
translated: Or it is a one-way path in that it should be entered upon by one who has gone alone, abandoning the society of many, in the sense of seclusion.

original: ayanti tenāti vā ayano, ekassa seṭṭhassa bhagavato ayanoti ekāyano, tena uppāditattā,
analyzed: tena ati vā ayanaḥ ekassa seṭṭhassa bhagavataḥ ayanaḥ ti ekāyanaḥ tena uppādita ttā
translated: Or it is a one-way path in that it is the way of the one best person, the Blessed One.

original: ekasmiṃ vā imasmiṃyeva dhammavinaye ayanoti ekāyano. Sattānaṃ visuddhiyāti rāgādimalehi,🔽abhijjhāvisamalobhādiupakkilesehi ca sattānaṃ visuddhatthāya visujjhanatthāya. Yadidanti
analyzed: ekasmin vā imasmiṃ yeva dhamma vinaye ayanoti eka ayano sattānam visuddhiyā ati rāga ādi malehi  abhijjhā visama lobha ādi upakkilesehi ca sattānam visuddha tthāya visujjhan atthāya yat idam ti
translated: Or it is a one-way path in that it is the way in this Dhamma and Discipline, which is the one .🔽For the purification of beings: for the purification of beings from the defilements of lust, hate, and delusion, and from the stains of avarice, malevolence, etc.,

original: nipāto, ye imeti attho. Pubbe saraṇalakkhaṇena maggaṭṭhena ca maggoti vuttasseva
analyzed: nipātaḥ ye ime iti atthaḥ pubbe saraṇa lakkhaṇena magga ṭṭhena ca maggo ti vuttassa iva
translated: For the overcoming of sorrow and lamentation: for the overcoming of the sorrow and lamentation that arise owing to the fact of change, etc.,🔽The words “and so on” include the rest of the terms in the list of the thirty-two aspects of the Four Noble Truths, namely, “for the spiritual faring on in comfort” and so on.

original: kāyādivisayabhedena catubbidhattā “cattāro satipaṭṭhānā”ti vuttaṃ. Sammappadhānādīsūti
analyzed: kāya ādi visaya bhedena catubbidha ttā cattāro sati paṭṭhānā iti vuttam sammappadhāna ādīsu iti
translated: The four foundations of mindfulness are so called because they are fourfold by the division of the body, etc., as object.🔽The “other path” is the path of purification taught in such suttas as the Appamādaratā sutta, the Appamādavagga sutta, and the Appamādavagga sutta of the Anguttara Nikāya.

original: ettha ādi-saddena appamādābhiratiādīnaṃ saṅgaho veditabbo. Appamādābhiratiādivasenāpi
analyzed: ettha ādi saddena appamāda abhirati ādīnam saṅgahaḥ veditabbaḥ appamāda abhirati ādi vasena api
translated: The word “etc.” in the words “the other path, etc.” should be understood to include the Appamādaratā sutta, the Appamādavagga sutta, and the Appamādavagga sutta of the Anguttara Nikāya.🔽For the path of purification is taught in these suttas too, according to the method of delight in diligence, etc.

original: hi katthaci visuddhimaggo desito. Yathāha –
analyzed: hi katthaci visuddhi maggaḥ desitaḥ yathā āha
translated: As it is said:

original: “Appamādarato bhikkhu, pamāde bhayadassi vā;
analyzed: a pamāda rataḥ bhikkhu pamāde bhaya dassi vā
translated: “The bhikkhu who delights in diligence, Who sees fear in negligence,

original: Abhabbo parihānāya, nibbānasseva santike”ti. ;
analyzed: abhabbaḥ parihānāya nibbānassa iva santike
translated: Is incapable of decline, And is close to nibbāna.”

original: 4. Tatrāti tassaṃ gāthāyaṃ. Upari vuccamānā gāthāya vitthārasaṃvaṇṇanā niddesapaṭiniddesaṭṭhāniyā,
analyzed: tatra ati tassam gāthāyam upari vuccamānā gāthāya vitthāra saṃvaṇṇanā niddesa paṭiniddesa ṭṭhāniyā
translated: Herein, in this stanza, the detailed explanation of the verse that is being taught is the place of the demonstration and the counter-demonstration,

original: tato saṃkhittatarā atthavaṇṇanā uddesaṭṭhāniyāti āha “ayaṃ saṅkhepavaṇṇanā”ti. Yathāuddiṭṭhassa🔽hi atthassa niddesapaṭiniddesā sukarā, subodhā ca hontīti. Sīle patiṭṭhāyāti ettha
analyzed: tatas saṃkhittatarā attha vaṇṇanā uddesa ṭṭhāniyā ti āha ayam saṅkhepa vaṇṇanā ti yathā uddiṭṭhassa  hi atthassa niddesa paṭiniddesā sukarā su bodhā ca honti iti sīle patiṭṭhāya ati ettha
translated: while the explanation of the meaning in brief is the place of the summary. Therefore it is said: “This is the brief explanation.”🔽For the demonstration and the counter-demonstration of the meaning as taught are easy to understand and easy to grasp.🔽“Having established virtue” : here virtue is the wholesome virtue.

original: sīleti kusalasīle. Yadipi “katame ca, thapati, akusalā sīlā”tiādīsu akusalā dhammāpi
analyzed: sīla iti kusala sīle yadi api katame ca akusalā sīlā ati ādīsu akusalā dhammā api
translated: Although in such passages as “What are unwholesome virtues, dear sir?” unwholesome dhammas are also called “virtue” ,

original: sīlanti āgatā. Vuccamānāya pana cittapaññābhāvanāya adhiṭṭhānāyogyatāya kiriyasīlānampi
analyzed: sīlam ti āgatāḥ vuccamānāya pana citta paññā bhāvanāya adhiṭṭhāna ayogyatāya kiriya sīlānam pi
translated: “Virtue” is what has come . But when the development of understanding is being spoken of, the keeping of virtue is not possible even in the case of the kinds of virtue called “keeping in being” and “guarding” ,🔽to say nothing of the other kinds. So only profitable virtue is intended here.

original: asambhavo, kuto itaresanti kusalasīlamevettha adhippetaṃ. Sīlaṃ paripūrayamānotiādīsu
analyzed: asambhavaḥ kutas itaresanti kusala sīlam eva itthā adhippetam sīlam paripūrayamānaḥ iti ādīsu
translated: In the passage beginning, “One who is fulfilling virtue” ,

original: paripūrayamānoti paripālento, parivaḍḍhento vā, sabbabhāgehi saṃvaranto, avītikkamanto
analyzed: paripūrayamāno ti paripālentaḥ parivaḍḍhentaḥ vā sabba bhāgehi saṃvarantaḥ a vītikkamantaḥ
translated: “fulfilling” is nourishing or increasing or guarding or not transgressing.

original: cāti attho. Tathābhūto hi taṃ avijahanto tattha patiṭṭhito nāma hoti. “Sīle”ti hi
analyzed: ca ati tathābhūtaḥ hi tam a vijahantaḥ tattha patiṭṭhitaḥ nāma hoti sīla iti hi
translated: The meaning is that he does not abandon it and he is “established in it” in this way. For “in virtue” is🔽an indeclinable locative.

original: idaṃ ādhāre bhummaṃ. Patiṭṭhāyāti duvidhā patiṭṭhā nissayūpanissayabhedato. Tattha
analyzed: idam ādhāre bhummam patiṭṭhāya ati duvidhā patiṭṭhā nissaya upanissaya bhedato tattha
translated: “Having established” : there are two kinds of establishment, namely, support and decisive support .

original: upanissayapatiṭṭhā lokiyā, itarā lokuttarā abhinditvā gahaṇe. Bhinditvā pana gahaṇe
analyzed: upanissaya patiṭṭhāḥ lokiyāḥ itarāḥ lokuttarāḥ a bhinditvā gahaṇe bhinditvā pana gahaṇe
translated: Herein, the support is mundane, while the other is supramundane.

original: yathā lokiyacittuppādesu sahajātānaṃ, purimapacchimānañca vasena nissayūpanissayapatiṭṭhā
analyzed: yathā lokiya cittuppādesu sahajātānam purima pacchimānam ca vasena nissaya upanissaya patiṭṭhā
translated: In the case of the mundane, it is as the conascent and the immediately antecedent conditions in the case of the kinds of consciousness classed as mundane.

original: sambhavati, evaṃ lokuttaresu heṭṭhimamaggaphalasīlavasena upanissayapatiṭṭhāpi sambhavati.
analyzed: sambhavati evam lokuttaresu heṭṭhima magga phala sīla vasena upanissaya patiṭṭhā api sambhavati
translated: But in the case of the supramundane, it is the decisive support in the form of the virtue of the lower path and fruit.

original: “Patiṭṭhāyā”ti ca padassa yadā upanissayapatiṭṭhā adhippetā, tadā “saddhaṃ upanissāyā”tiādīsu🔽viya purimakālakiriyāvasena attho veditabbo. Tenāha “pubbeva kho panassa kāyakammaṃ🔽vacīkammaṃ ājīvo suparisuddho hotī”ti. Yadā pana nissayapatiṭṭhā adhippetā, tadā
analyzed: patiṭṭhāya iti ca padassa yadā upanissaya patiṭṭhā adhippetā tadā saddham upanissāya ati ādīsu  viya purima kāla kiriyā vasena attho veditabbo tena āha pubbā iva kho panassa kāya kammam  vacī kammam ājīvo su parisuddho hoti iti yadā pana nissaya patiṭṭhā adhippetā tadā
translated: “Established” : when the meaning intended is support as decisive support, then the meaning should be understood as the action of the prior state, as in the case of “having faith as support” .

original: “cakkhuñca paṭiccā”tiādīsu viya samānakālakiriyāvasena attho veditabbo. Sammāvācādayo
analyzed: cakkhuñca paṭicca ati ādīsu viya samāna kāla kiriyā vasena attho veditabbo sammā vācā ādayaḥ
translated: Therefore it is said: “But his bodily action, his verbal action, and his livelihood have already been purified earlier” . But when the meaning intended is support as reliance, then the meaning should be understood as the action of the same state, as in the case of “with the eye as condition” .

original: hi attanā sampayuttānaṃ sammādiṭṭhiādīnaṃ sahajātavaseneva nissayapaccayā hontīti.🔽Narati netīti naro, puriso. Yathā hi paṭhamapakatibhūto satto, itarāya pakatiyā seṭṭhaṭṭhena
analyzed: hi attanā sampayuttānam sammādiṭṭhi ādīnam sahajāta vasena iva nissaya paccayāḥ honti iti  narati neti iti naraḥ purisaḥ yathā hi paṭhama pakati bhūtaḥ satto itarāya pakatiyā seṭṭha ṭṭhena
translated: For right speech, etc., are a condition by way of conascence only for right view, etc., with which they are associated.🔽“Man” : a man is one who “leads” , who “goes” . For just as a being who is of the first nature is called “man” in the sense of best, since he is “lying down” in the highest place, the other nature,

original: puri ucce ṭhāne seti pavattatīti “puriso”ti vuccati, evaṃ nayanaṭṭhena “naro”ti vuccati.
analyzed: puri ucce ṭhāne sa iti pavattati iti puriso ti vuccati evam nayana ṭṭhena naro ti vuccati
translated: so he is called “man” in the sense of leading.

original: Puttabhātubhūtopi hi puggalo mātujeṭṭhabhaginīnaṃ netuṭṭhāne tiṭṭhati, pageva itaro
analyzed: putta bhātu bhūtaḥ api hi puggalaḥ mātu jeṭṭha bhaginīnam netu ṭṭhāne tiṭṭhati pagā iva itaraḥ
translated: For even a person who is a son or a brother stands in the place of a leader to his mother or to his elder sister, much more so to others.

original: itarāsaṃ. Narena yogato, narassa ayanti vā nārī, itthī. Sāpi cettha kāmaṃ taṇhājaṭāvijaṭanasamatthatā
analyzed: itarāsam narena yogataḥ narassa ayanti vā nārī itthī sā api ca ittha kāmam taṇhā jaṭā vijaṭana samattha tā
translated: and the other women.🔽A woman is a man’s “woman” because she goes to him .

original: atthi, padhānameva pana sattaṃ dassento “naro”ti āha yathā “satthā devamanussāna”nti.
analyzed: atthi padhānam eva pana sattam dassentaḥ naro ti āha yathā satthā deva manussānam ti
translated: But although she is capable of being entangled in the tangle of craving, nevertheless, in order to show the principal one, he said “man” as in the passage beginning, “The Master, the Teacher of gods and men” .

original: Aṭṭhakathāyaṃ pana avibhāgena puggalapariyāyo ayanti dassetuṃ “naroti satto”ti vuttaṃ.
analyzed: aṭṭhakathā ayam pana avibhāgena puggala pariyāyaḥ ayanti dassetum naro ti satto ti vuttam
translated: But in the commentary the word “man” is said to mean “being” in order to show the meaning of “person” without distinction.

original: Sapaññoti vipākabhūtāya saha paññāya pavattatīti sapañño. Tāya hi ādito paṭṭhāya
analyzed: sa paññaḥ iti vipāka bhūtāya saha paññāya pavattati iti sa paññaḥ tāya hi āditas paṭṭhāya
translated: Possessing wisdom: he occurs together with wisdom, which is a ripening.

original: santānavasena bahulaṃ pavattamānāya ayaṃ satto savisesaṃ “sapañño”ti vattabbataṃ
analyzed: santāna vasena bahulam pavattamānāya ayam satto sa visesam sa pañño ti vattabba tam
translated: For it is because of that which occurs in a series from the beginning that this being is worthy to be called “possessing wisdom” with distinction.

original: arahati. Vipākapaññāpi hi santānavisesanena bhāvanāpaññuppattiyā upanissayo hoti
analyzed: arahati vipāka paññā api hi santāna visesanena bhāvanā paññā uppattiyāḥ upanissayaḥ hoti
translated: For ripening wisdom is a decisive support for the arising of development wisdom by means of a special quality in the series.

original: ahetukadvihetukānaṃ tadabhāvato. Sampajaññasaṅkhātāya ca taṃtaṃkiccakārikāya paññāya
analyzed: ahetuka dvi hetukānam tad abhāvataḥ sampajañña saṅkhātāya ca taṃ taṃ kicca kārikāya paññāya
translated: And it is because of the absence of that in the case of those without root-cause and of those with double root-cause .🔽And it is proper to speak of him as “possessing wisdom” by means of the wisdom called “understanding” that is concerned with this or that function.

original: vasena “sapañño”ti vattuṃ vaṭṭati. Aṭṭhakathāyaṃ pana nipaka-saddena pārihārikapaññā
analyzed: vasena sa paññaḥ ti vattum vaṭṭati aṭṭhakathāyam pana nipaka saddena pārihārika paññā
translated: But in the commentary the word “skilful” is said to mean “possessing ripening wisdom” and “possessing understanding wisdom.”

original: gayhatīti vipākapaññāvasenevettha attho vutto. Kammajatihetukapaṭisandhipaññāyāti
analyzed: gayhati iti vipāka paññā vasena iva ittha atthaḥ vuttaḥ kamma jati hetuka paṭisandhi paññāya ati
translated: The meaning here is stated in terms of resultant understanding.🔽🔽Understanding of rebirth-linking due to kamma-process and to destiny

original: kammajāya tihetukapaṭisandhiyaṃ paññāyāti evaṃ tihetuka-saddo paṭisandhi-saddena🔽sambandhitabbo, na paññā-saddena. Na hi paññā tihetukā atthi. Paṭisandhito pabhuti
analyzed: kamma jāya ti hetuka paṭisandhiyam paññāyāti evam ti hetuka saddo paṭisandhi saddena  sambandhitabbaḥ na paññā saddena na hi paññā ti hetukā atthi paṭisandhito pabhuti
translated: The meaning here is stated in terms of resultant understanding. In the rebirth-linking of kamma-born triple-rootedness:

original: pavattamānā paññā “paṭisandhiyaṃ paññā”ti vuttā taṃmūlakattā, na paṭisandhikkhaṇe pavattā eva.
analyzed: pavattamānā paññā paṭisandhiyam paññā iti vuttā tad mūlaka ttā na paṭisandhi kkhaṇe pavattā eva
translated: the word “triple-rootedness” should be construed with the word “rebirth-linking” and not with the word “understanding,” for there is no triple-rootedness that is understanding. The understanding that occurs from the time of rebirth-linking onward is called “understanding in rebirth-linking” because it has that as its root, not because it occurs at the moment of rebirth-linking.

original: Cinteti ārammaṇaṃ upanijjhāyatīti cittaṃ, samādhi. So hi sātisayaṃ upanijjhānakicco.
analyzed: cintā iti ārammaṇam upanijjhāyati iti cittam samādhi saḥ hi sa atisayam upanijjhāna kicco
translated: The mind is that which thinks , that which considers , its object, which is concentration. For that has the function of considering its object with special intensity.

original: Na hi vitakkādayo vinā samādhinā tamatthaṃ sādhenti, samādhi pana tehi vināpi sādhetīti.🔽Paguṇabalavabhāvāpādanena paccayehi citaṃ, tathā santānaṃ cinotītipi cittaṃ, samādhi.
analyzed: na hi vitakka ādayaḥ vinā samādhinā tam attham sādhenti samādhi pana tehi vinā api sādheti iti  paguṇa balava bhāva āpādanena paccayehi citam tathā santānam cinoti iti pi cittam samādhi
translated: For applied thought, etc., do not establish that object without concentration, but concentration does so even without them.🔽The mind is that which is caused to be by conditions that bring about its being made to be in a profitable way, and it is that which causes a continuity to be in that way, which is concentration.

original: Paṭhamajjhānādivasena cittavicittatāya, iddhividhādicittakaraṇena ca samādhi cittanti
analyzed: paṭhamajjhāna ādi vasena citta vicitta tāyai iddhividha ādi citta karaṇena ca
translated: And concentration is the mind because it is the various kinds of consciousness classed as the first jhāna, etc., and because it is the maker of the various kinds of consciousness classed as the kinds of supernormal power, etc.

original: vināpi paropadesenassa cittapariyāyo labbhateva. Aṭṭhakathāyaṃ pana citta-saddo viññāṇe
analyzed: vinā api para upadesena assa citta pariyāyaḥ labbhateva aṭṭhakathā ayam pana citta saddo viññāṇe
translated: and he can do so without being taught by another. But in the commentary the word citta is used in the sense of consciousness,

original: niruḷhoti katvā vuttaṃ “cittasīsena hettha samādhi niddiṭṭho”ti. Yathāsabhāvaṃ pakārehi
analyzed: niruḷhaḥ iti katvā vuttam citta sīsena ha ittha samādhi niddiṭṭhaḥ ti yathāsabhāvam pakārehi
translated: and so it is said: “Here concentration is indicated under the heading of consciousness.”

original: jānātīti paññā. Sā yadipi kusalādibhedato bahuvidhā. “Bhāvaya”nti pana vacanato bhāvetabbā
analyzed: jānāti iti paññā sā yadi pi kusala ādi bhedataḥ bahuvidhā bhāvayanti pana vacanataḥ bhāvetabbā
translated: Understanding is the discerning of the specific characteristics of states by means of the faculties of understanding. Although it is of many kinds as classed as profitable, etc.,🔽it is nevertheless intended here as subject for development in the sense of “understanding” in the phrase “understanding that is development” .

original: idhādhippetāti taṃ dassetuṃ “vipassana”nti vuttaṃ. “Bhāvaya”nti ca idaṃ paccekaṃ
analyzed: idha adhippetā ti tam dassetum vipassanam ti vuttam bhāvayanti ca idam paccekam
translated: And that is shown by the word “insight.” And the word “develop” should be construed with each of the terms, as follows: “He develops consciousness,” “he develops understanding.”

original: yojetabbaṃ “cittañca bhāvayaṃ, paññañca bhāvaya”nti. Tayidaṃ dvayaṃ kiṃ lokiyaṃ,🔽udāhu lokuttaranti? Lokuttaranti daṭṭhabbaṃ ukkaṭṭhaniddesato. Taṃ hi bhāvayamāno🔽ariyamaggakkhaṇe taṇhājaṭaṃ samucchedavasena vijaṭetīti vuccati, na lokiyaṃ. Nānantariyabhāvena
analyzed: yojetabbam cittam ca bhāvayan paññam ca bhāvayanti tayā idam dvayam kim lokiyam  udāhu lokuttaram ti lokuttaram ti daṭṭhabbam ukkaṭṭha niddesato tam hi bhāvayamāno  ariya magga kkhaṇe taṇhā jaṭam samuccheda vasena vijaṭā iti iti vuccati na lokiyam na ānantariya bhāvena
translated: Now, is this pair of things, that is to say, consciousness and understanding, mundane or supramundane?🔽They should be regarded as supramundane, since the extreme of the exposition is intended here. For it is said that one who develops it severs the tangle of craving, and that is why it is called “supramundane.”🔽But the mundane is included here too by the word “also,”

original: panettha lokiyāpi gahitāva honti lokiyasamathavipassanāya vinā tadabhāvato. Samathayānikassa
analyzed: pana ittha lokiyā api gahitā ava honti lokiya samatha vipassanāya vinā tad abhāvato samatha yānikassa
translated: and the mundane is included by the word “also” because there is no development of the supramundane without the mundane.

original: hi upacārappanāppabhedaṃ samādhiṃ itarassa khaṇikasamādhiṃ, ubhayesampi vimokkhamukhattayaṃ
analyzed: hi samādhim itarassa khaṇika samādhim ubhayesam pi vimokkha mukha ttayam
translated: for without the concentration classed as access and absorption and the other’s momentary concentration, and without the triple gate to deliverance in both cases,

original: vinā na kadācipi lokuttarādhigamo sambhavati. Tenāha “samādhiñceva vipassanañca bhāvayamāno”ti.
analyzed: vinā na lokuttara adhigamo sambhavati tena āha samādhiñca iva vipassanañca bhāvayamāno ti
translated: there is no possibility of the attainment of the supramundane. That is why he said “developing concentration and insight.”

original: Tattha yadā lokiyā samathavipassanā adhippetā, tadā “bhāvaya”nti idaṃ bhāvanākiriyāya
analyzed: tattha yadā lokiyā samatha vipassanā adhippetā tadā bhāvayanti idam bhāvanā kiriyāya
translated: Herein, when mundane serenity and insight are intended, then this “developing” is said to be the cause of the act of developing;

original: hetubhāvakathanaṃ, bhāvanāhetūti attho. Taṃbhāvanāhetukā hi vijaṭanakiriyāti. Yadā🔽pana lokuttarā adhippetā, tadā kevalaṃ vattamānabhāvaniddeso. Tadubhayabhāvanāsamakālameva
analyzed: hetu bhāva kathanam taṃ bhāvanā hetukā hi vijaṭana kiriyā ati yadā  pana lokuttarā adhippetā tadā kevalam tad ubhaya bhāvanā sama kālam eva
translated: the meaning is that it is the cause of the act of developing. For disentanglement is due to that act of developing which has that as its cause.🔽But when the supramundane are intended, then it is simply a statement of the present state of development.

original: hi taṇhājaṭāvijaṭanaṃ.
analyzed: hi taṇhā jaṭā vijaṭanam
translated: For the disentanglement of the tangle of craving occurs at the same time as the development of both.

original: “Ātāpī nipako”ti idaṃ yathāvuttabhāvanāya upakārakadhammakittanaṃ. Kammaṭṭhānaṃ anuyuñjantassa
analyzed: ātāpī nipako ti idam yathāvutta bhāvanāya upakāraka dhamma kittanam kammaṭṭhānam anuyuñjantassa
translated: “Ardent, clearly comprehending” : this is a commendation of the states that are helpful to the development stated as above.🔽For when he is devoted to the meditation subject,

original: hi vīriyaṃ sati sampajaññanti ime tayo dhammā bahūpakārā. Vīriyūpatthaddhañhi kammaṭṭhānaṃ
analyzed: hi vīriyam sati sampajaññanti ime tayo dhammā bahu upakārāḥ vīriya upatthaddham hi kammaṭṭhānam
translated: three things are very helpful to him: energy, mindfulness, and full awareness.

original: satisampajaññānupālitaṃ na paripatati, upari ca visesaṃ āvahati. Patiṭṭhāsiddhiyā🔽cettha saddhāsiddhi, saddhūpanissayattā sīlassa, vīriyādisiddhiyā ca. Na hi saddheyyavatthuṃ
analyzed: sati sampajaññā anupālitam na paripatati upari ca visesam āvahati patiṭṭhā siddhiyā  ca ittha saddhā siddhi saddhu upanissaya ttā sīlassa vīriya ādi siddhiyā ca na hi saddheyya vatthum
translated: and it does not fail to reach distinction above.

original: asaddahantassa yathāvuttavīriyādayo sambhavanti, tathā samādhipi. Yathā hi hetubhāvato
analyzed: asat dahantassa yathā vutta vīriya ādayaḥ sambhavanti tathā yathā hi hetu bhāvataḥ
translated: Herein, faith is established by the establishment of virtue, and energy, etc., are established by the establishment of concentration. For the energy, etc., mentioned above do not exist in one who does not have faith in the objects of faith. So too with concentration.

original: vīriyādīhi saddhāsiddhi, evaṃ phalabhāvato tehi samādhisiddhi. Vīriyādīsu hi sampajjamānesu
analyzed: vīriya ādīhi saddhā siddhi evam phala bhāvataḥ tehi samādhi siddhi vīriya ādīsu hi sampajjamānesu
translated: For just as faith is established by energy, etc., as their cause, so concentration is established by them as its fruit. For when energy, etc., are active,

original: samādhi sampannova hoti asamāhitassa tadabhāvato. Kathaṃ panettha satisiddhi? Nipakaggahaṇato.🔽Tikkhavisadabhāvappattā hi sati “nepakka”nti vuccati. Yathāha “paramena satinepakkena
analyzed: samādhi sampannaḥ uva hoti asamāhitassa tad abhāvato katham pana ittha sati siddhi nipaka gahaṇato  tikkha visada bhāva pattā hi sati nepakkanti vuccati yathā āha paramena satinepakkena
translated: concentration is perfected, since it is absent in one who is not concentrated. But how is mindfulness established here? By the act of apprehending.🔽For mindfulness that has reached the state of keenness and lucidity is called “apprehending,” as it is said: “He is supremely endowed with mindfulness that is not held in common” . But in the commentary the meaning is given as follows: “Apprehending is understanding” .

original: samannāgato”ti. Aṭṭhakathāyaṃ pana “nepakkaṃ paññā”ti ayamattho dassito. Taggahaṇeneva
analyzed: samannāgato ti aṭṭhakathā ayam pana nepakkam paññā iti ayam attho dassito tad gahaṇena iva
translated: By the word “apprehending”

original: satipi gahitāva hoti. Na hi sativirahitā paññā atthīti. Apare pana “sapañño”ti imināva
analyzed: satī pi gahitā ava hoti na hi sati virahitā paññā atthi iti apare pana sa paññā iti iminā ava
translated: and it is only when there is understanding that there is mindfulness, not otherwise.

original: pārihārikapaññāpi gayhatīti “nipako”ti padassa “sato”ti atthaṃ vadanti. Yadipi kilesānaṃ
analyzed: pārihārika paññā api gayhati iti nipakā iti padassa satoti attham vadanti yadi api kilesānam
translated: But others say that the word “attentive” is used to exclude the kind of understanding that is merely superficial.

original: pahānaṃ ātāpanaṃ, taṃ sammādiṭṭhiādīnampi attheva. Ātappasaddo viya pana ātāpasaddo🔽vīriyeyeva niruḷhoti āha “ātāpīti vīriyavā”ti. Atha vā paṭipakkhappahāne sampayuttadhammānaṃ🔽abbhussahanavasena pavattamānassa vīriyassa sātisayaṃ tadātāpananti vīriyameva tathā
analyzed: pahānam ātāpanam tam sammādiṭṭhi ādīnam pi atthā iva ātappa saddo viya pana ātāpa saddo  vīriyeya iva niruḷhaḥ ti āha ātāpī iti vīriya vā ati atha vā paṭipakkha ppahāne sampayutta dhammānam  abbhussahana vasena pavattamānassa vīriyassa sa atisayam vīriyam eva tathā
translated: Though the abandoning of defilements is a burning up, still burning up is a term applicable to right view, etc., too. But the word “burning up” is used only of energy, as the word “glow” is used only of fire.🔽That is why it is said, “He is ardent: he possesses energy,”🔽Or alternatively, since energy occurs in the act of bearing up the associated states in the abandoning of the opposites, it is the energy that is called “burning up” in the sense of its being the chief cause of that burning up, not the others.

original: vuccati, na aññe dhammā. Ātāpīti cāyamīkāro pasaṃsāya, atisayassa vā dīpako. Vīriyavāti🔽vā-saddopi tadattho eva daṭṭhabbo. Tena sammappadhānasamaṅgitā vuttā hoti. Tenāha
analyzed: vuccati na aññe dhammā ātāpī iti ca ayamīkāraḥ pasaṃsāya atisayassa vā dīpakaḥ vīriya vā ati  vā saddaḥ api tad atthaḥ eva daṭṭhabbaḥ tena sammappadhāna samaṅgi tā vuttā hoti tena āha
translated: And the letter -a- in the word ātāpī is a particle of praise or of superlative sense.🔽The word vā also should be regarded as having the same meaning.🔽So it is said, “In the sense of burning up defilements and scorching opposing states.”

original: “kilesānaṃ ātāpanaparitāpanaṭṭhenā”ti. Ātāpanaggahaṇena cettha ārambha dhātumāha
analyzed: kilesānam ātāpana paritāpana ṭṭhena ati ātāpana ggahaṇena ca ittha ārambha dhātum āha
translated: And here the word “burning up” signifies the element of initial effort.

original: ādito vīriyārambhoti katvā, paritāpanaggahaṇena nikkamaparakkamadhātuyo sabbaso paṭipakkhato
analyzed: āditas vīriya ārambhaḥ ti katvā paritāpana ggahaṇena nikkama parakkama dhātuyo sabbaso paṭipakkhato
translated: and the beginning of the effort is called “the arousing of energy.”🔽The words “he is called” are supplied in order to show that the words “he is called wise” and so on are in apposition to the words “he is called one who has aroused energy” and so on.🔽The words “he is called one who has aroused energy” are supplied in order to show that the words “he is called one who has aroused energy” and so on are in apposition to the words “he is called wise” and so on.

original: nikkhantataṃ, uparūpari visesappattiñca upādāya. Nipayati visoseti paṭipakkhaṃ, tato🔽vā attānaṃ nipāti rakkhatīti nipako, sampajāno. Kammaṭṭhānassa pariharaṇe niyuttāti pārihārikā.
analyzed: upari upari visesa ppattiñca upādāya nipayati visoseti paṭipakkham tatas  vā attānam nipāti rakkhati iti nipakaḥ sampajānaḥ kammaṭṭhānassa pariharaṇe niyuttā ati pārihārikā
translated: The words “he is called one who has aroused energy” are supplied in order to show that the words “he is called one who has aroused energy” and so on are in apposition to the words “he is called one who has aroused energy” and so on.

original: Abhikkamādīni sabbakiccāni sātthakasampajaññādivasena paricchijja netīti sabbakiccapariṇāyikā.🔽Kammaṭṭhānassa vā uggaho paripucchā bhāvanārambho manasikāravidhi, tattha ca sakkaccakāritā
analyzed: abhikkama ādīni sabba kiccāni sātthaka sampajaññā ādi vasena paricchijja neti iti sabba kicca pariṇāyikā  kammaṭṭhānassa vā uggahaḥ paripucchā bhāvanā ārambho manasikāra vidhi tattha ca sakkacca kāri tā
translated: The words “he is called one who has aroused energy” are supplied in order to show that the words “he is called one who has aroused energy” and so on are in apposition to the words “he is called one who has aroused energy” and so on.🔽The words “he is called one who has aroused energy” are supplied in order to show that the words “he is called one who has aroused energy” and so on are in apposition to the words “he is called one who has aroused energy” and so on.🔽The words “he is called one who has aroused energy” are supplied in order to show that the words “he is called one who has aroused energy” and so on are in apposition to the words “he is called one who has aroused energy” and so on.

original: sātaccakāritā sappāyakāritā nimittakusalatā pahitattatā antarāasaṅkoco indriyasamattapaṭipādanā
analyzed: sā atacca kāri tā sappāya kāri tā nimitta kusala tā pahitatta tā antarā asaṅkocaḥ indriya samatta paṭipādanā
translated: The words “he is called one who has aroused energy” are supplied in order to show that the words “he is called one who has aroused energy” and so on are in apposition to the words “he is called one who has aroused energy” and so on.🔽The words “he is called one who has aroused energy” are supplied in order to show that the words “he is called one who has aroused energy” and so on are in apposition to the words “he is called one who has aroused energy” and so on.

original: vīriyasamatāpādanaṃ vīriyasamatāyojananti evamādīnaṃ sabbesaṃ kiccānaṃ pariṇāyikā
analyzed: vīriya samatā āpādanam vīriya samatā yojanan ti evamādīnam sabbesam kiccānam pariṇāyikā
translated: The words “he is called one who has aroused energy” are supplied in order to show that the words “he is called one who has aroused energy” and so on are in apposition to the words “he is called one who has aroused energy” and so on.🔽The words “he

original: sabbakiccapariṇāyikā. Bhayaṃ ikkhatīti bhikkhūti sādhāraṇato bhikkhulakkhaṇakathanena
analyzed: sabba kicca pariṇāyikā bhayam ikkhati iti bhikkhū ti sādhāraṇataḥ bhikkhu lakkhaṇa kathanena
translated: Bhikkhu: he sees fear in what is fearful. By this phrase the bhikkhu is defined by his general characteristics.

original: paṭipattiyāva bhikkhubhāvo, na bhikkhakabhinnapaṭadharādibhāvenāti dasseti. Evaṃ
analyzed: paṭipattiyā ava bhikkhu bhāvaḥ na bhikkhaka bhinna paṭadhara ādi bhāvena ati dasseti evam
translated: He is a bhikkhu by virtue of his practice, not by virtue of his being a beggar, a wearer of the patched cloak, and so on.

original: hi katakiccānaṃ sāmaṇerādīnaṃ, paṭipannānañca apabbajitānampi saṅgaho kato hoti.
analyzed: hi kata kiccānam sāmaṇera ādīnam paṭipannānam ca a pabbajitānam pi saṅgahaḥ kataḥ hoti
translated: For in this way he includes the novices and others who have done their duties, and also those who are practicing the way but are not gone forth into homelessness.🔽But here the meaning should be understood as referring to one who has gone forth.

original: Idha pana paṭipajjanakavasena attho veditabbo. Bhindati pāpake akusale dhammeti vā
analyzed: idha pana paṭipajjanaka vasena atthaḥ veditabbaḥ bhindati pāpake akusale dhamme iti vā
translated: Or alternatively, he is a bhikkhu because he is one who begs for the sake of destroying evil, unwholesome states.🔽The person who is wise, who, having established himself in virtue,

original: bhikkhu. So imaṃ vijaṭayeti yo naro sappañño sīle patiṭṭhāya ātāpī nipako cittaṃ🔽paññañca bhāvayanti vutto, so bhikkhu imaṃ taṇhājaṭaṃ vijaṭayeti sambandho. Idāni🔽tampi vijaṭanaṃ veḷugumbavijaṭanena upametvā dassetuṃ gāthāya yathāvutte sīlādidhamme
analyzed: bhikkhu saḥ imam vijaṭayeti yaḥ naraḥ sappaññaḥ sīle patiṭṭhāya ātāpī nipakaḥ cittam  paññam ca bhāvayanti vuttaḥ saḥ bhikkhu imam taṇhā jaṭam vijaṭayā iti sambandhaḥ idāni  tam pi vijaṭanam veḷugumba vijaṭanena upametvā dassetum gāthāya yathā vutte sīla ādi dhamme
translated: and who develops understanding and mindfulness, can disentangle this tangle.🔽The meaning is that he can disentangle this tangle of craving. Now, in order to illustrate that disentanglement by means of the simile of the creeper tangle, the verse restates the states beginning with virtue as stated in the verse,

original: “iminā ca sīlenā”tiādinā paccāmasati. Tattha yasmā yogāvacarasantānagatā nānākkhaṇikā
analyzed: iminā ca sīlena ati ādinā tattha yasmā yogāvacara santāna gatā nānā kkhaṇikā
translated: and then concludes with the words “By this virtue” and so on. Herein, since the various states of consciousness and consciousness-concomitants that occur in the continuum of a meditator,

original: missakā sīlādidhammā gāthāya gahitā, tasmā te ekaccaṃ gaṇhanto “chahi dhammehi samannāgato”ti
analyzed: missakā sīla ādi dhammā gāthāya gahitā tasmā te ekaccam gaṇhantaḥ chahi dhammehi samannāgataḥ ti
translated: The virtues, etc., are included in the verse, “Endowed with six things,” etc.,🔽

original: āha. Na hi te cha dhammā ekasmiṃ santāne ekasmiṃ khaṇe labbhanti. Yasmā ca puggalādhiṭṭhānena
analyzed: āha na hi te cha dhammā ekasmin santāne ekasmin khaṇe labbhanti yasmā ca puggala adhiṭṭhānena
translated: The virtues, etc., are included in the verse under the heading of “mixed states.” Therefore, in order to include them, the Exalted One says, “Endowed with six things.” For these six things cannot be found in a single continuum or in a single moment.

original: gāthā bhāsitā, tasmā puggalādhiṭṭhānameva upamaṃ dassento “seyyathāpi nāma puriso”tiādimāha.🔽Tattha sunisitanti suṭṭhu nisitaṃ, ativiya tikhiṇanti attho. Satthassa nisānasilāyaṃ
analyzed: gāthā bhāsitā tasmai puggala adhiṭṭhānam eva upamam dassentaḥ seyyathā api nāma purisaḥ iti ādim āha  tattha su nisitam ti suṭṭhu nisitam ativiya tikhiṇanti attho satthassa nisāna silāyam
translated: And since the verse was spoken with reference to a person, the Exalted One, in order to illustrate the simile with reference to a person, says, “Just as if a man were to take a sword,” etc.

original: nisitatarabhāvakaraṇaṃ, bāhubalena cassa ukkhipananti ubhayampetaṃ atthāpannaṃ katvā🔽upamā vuttāti tadubhayaṃ upameyye dassento “samādhisilāyaṃ sunisitaṃ…pe… paññāhatthena
analyzed: nisitatara bhāva karaṇam bāhu balena ca ssa ukkhipananti ubhayam petam attha āpannam katvā  upamā vuttā iti tat ubhayam upameyye dassento paññā hatthena
translated: Here, “well-sharpened” means very sharp. The meaning is: “extremely sharp.” The sword is placed on the whetstone in order to make it sharper. And it is lifted up with the strength of the arm. Both of these are mentioned in the simile.

original: ukkhipitvā”ti āha. Samādhiguṇena hi paññāya tikkhabhāvo. Tenāha bhagavā “samāhito
analyzed: ukkhipitvā iti āha samādhi guṇena hi paññāya tikkha bhāvaḥ tena āha bhagavā samāhitaḥ
translated: Therefore, in order to show both of these in the example, the Exalted One says, “The sword is well-sharpened on a whetstone,” etc. The meaning is: “having lifted it up with the hand of wisdom.” For wisdom becomes sharp through the quality of concentration. Therefore the Exalted One says, “One who is concentrated,” etc.

original: yathābhūtaṃ pajānātī”ti. Vīriyañcassā upatthambhakaṃ paggaṇhanato. Vijaṭeyyāti vijaṭetuṃ🔽sakkuṇeyya. Vuṭṭhānagāminivipassanāya hi vattamānāya yogāvacaro taṇhājaṭaṃ vijaṭetuṃ
analyzed: yathābhūtam pajānāti iti vīriyam ca assāḥ upatthambhakam paggaṇhanataḥ vijaṭeyya ati vijaṭetum  sakkuṇeyya vuṭṭhāna gāmini vipassanāya hi vattamānāya yogāvacaraḥ taṇhā jaṭam vijaṭetum
translated: He understands as it really is.” And his energy is a support for him, since it is the instigator.🔽He would disentangle: he would be able to disentangle.🔽For when insight leading to emergence is occurring, the meditator is said to be able to disentangle the tangle of craving.

original: samattho nāma. Vijaṭanaṃ cettha samucchedavasena pahānanti āha “sañchindeyya sampadāleyyā”ti.🔽Dakkhiṇaṃ arahatīti dakkhiṇeyyo, aggo ca so dakkhiṇeyyo cāti aggadakkhiṇeyyo, aggā
analyzed: samatthaḥ nāma vijaṭanam ca ittha samuccheda vasena pahānam iti āha sañchindeyya sampadā āleyya iti  dakkhiṇam arahati iti dakkhiṇeyyaḥ aggaḥ ca saḥ dakkhiṇeyyaḥ ca ati aggadakkhiṇeyyaḥ aggā
translated: And here disentanglement is abandonment by cutting off. That is why it is said: “He would cut, sever, and demolish.”🔽Worthy of offerings: worthy of the offerings of gods and men.🔽The best: the foremost.

original: vā dakkhiṇā aggadakkhiṇā, taṃ arahatīti aggadakkhiṇeyyo.
analyzed: vā dakkhiṇā agga dakkhiṇā tam arahati iti aggadakkhiṇeyyaḥ
translated: Or the best offering is the foremost offering. He is worthy of that, thus he is worthy of the foremost offering.🔽Therein: in that verse.

original: 5. Tatrāti tassaṃ gāthāyaṃ. Ayanti “naro”ti ca “bhikkhū”ti ca vutto yogāvacaro. Puna
analyzed: tatra ati gāthāyam ayanti narā iti ca bhikkhū iti ca vuttaḥ yogāvacaraḥ puna
translated: He: the meditator referred to by the words “man” and “monk.”🔽Again, therein: in that understanding.

original: tatrāti tassaṃ paññāyaṃ. Assāti bhikkhuno. Kattari cetaṃ sāmivacanaṃ, anenāti attho.🔽Karaṇīyaṃ natthi visesādhānassa tihetukapaṭisandhipaññāya abhāvato. Tenāha “purimakammānubhāveneva
analyzed: tatra ati assa ati bhikkhuno kattari ca itam sāmi vacanam anena ati atthaḥ 🔽karaṇīyam natthi visesa ādhānassa ti hetuka paṭisandhi paññāya abhāvato tena āha purima kamma anubhāvena iva
translated: He: a monk. This is a possessive form of the instrumental case. The meaning is: by him.

original: hissa sā siddhā”ti. Tenāti yoginā. Bhāvanāyaṃ satatapavattitavīriyatāya sātaccakārinā.
analyzed: hi ssa sā siddhā ati tena ati yoginā bhāvanā ayam satata pavattita vīriya tāya sātacca kārinā
translated: Tenā ti yoginā: by the yogin, by one who is constantly energetic in the practice of meditation, by one who is persevering.🔽Paññāvasenā ti by means of the wisdom called “the investigation of the way” .

original: Paññāvasenāti yathāvuttanepakkasaṅkhātapaññāvasena. Yaṃ kiñci kattabbaṃ, tassa sabbassa
analyzed: paññā vasena ati yathā vutta nepakka saṅkhāta paññā vasena yam kiñci kattabbam tassa sabbassa
translated: Yaṃ kiñci kattabbaṃ, tassa sabbassa

original: sampajānavaseneva karaṇasīlo, tattha vā sampajānakāro etassa atthi, sampajānassa
analyzed: sampajāna vasena iva karaṇa sīlo tattha vā sampajāna kāro etassa atthi sampajānassa
translated: sampajānavaseneva karaṇasīlo, tattha vā sampajānakāro etassa atthi, sampajānassa

original: vā asammohassa kārako uppādakoti sampajānakārī, tena sampajānakārinā. Atrāti assaṃ
analyzed: vā asammohassa kārako uppādako ti sampajāna kārī tena sampajāna kārinā atra ati assam
translated: vā asammohassa kārako uppādakoti sampajānakārī, tena sampajānakārinā. Atrāti assaṃ

original: gāthāyaṃ. Sīlādisampādane vīriyassa tesaṃ aṅgabhāvato taṃ visuṃ aggahetvā “sīlasamādhipaññāmukhenā”ti vuttaṃ.
analyzed: gāthāyam sīla ādi sampādane vīriyassa tesam aṅga bhāvato tam visum aggahetvā sīla samādhi paññā mukhena iti vuttam
translated: gāthāyaṃ. Sīlādisampādane vīriyassa tesaṃ aṅgabhāvato taṃ visuṃ aggahetvā “sīlasamādhipaññāmukhenā”ti vuttaṃ.

original: “Visuddhimaggaṃ dassetī”ti avibhāgato desanāya piṇḍatthaṃ vatvā puna taṃ vibhāgato
analyzed: visuddhi maggam dasseti iti avibhāgataḥ desanāya piṇḍa attham vatvā puna tam vibhāgataḥ
translated: “Visuddhimaggaṃ dassetī”ti avibhāgato desanāya piṇḍatthaṃ vatvā puna taṃ vibhāgato

original: dassetuṃ “ettāvatā”tiādi vuttaṃ. Tattha ettāvatāti ettakāya desanāya. Sikkhāti sikkhitabbaṭṭhena
analyzed: dassetum ettāvatā iti ādi vuttam tattha ettāvatā iti ettakāya desanāya sikkhā āti sikkhitabba ṭṭhena
translated: dassetuṃ “ettāvatā”tiādi vuttaṃ. Tattha ettāvatāti ettakāya desanāya. Sikkhāti sikkhitabbaṭṭhena

original: sikkhā. Sikkhanaṃ cettha āsevanaṃ daṭṭhabbaṃ. Sīlādidhammehi saṃvaraṇādivasena āsevanto
analyzed: sikkhā sikkhanam ca ittha āsevanam daṭṭhabbam sīla ādi dhammehi saṃvaraṇa ādi vasena āsevantaḥ
translated: Training is to be regarded as repetition here. One who repeats the states of virtue, etc., by means of the states of virtue, etc.,

original: te sikkhatīti vuccati. Sāsananti paṭipattisāsanaṃ. Upanissayo balavakāraṇaṃ. Vajjanaṃ🔽anupagamanaṃ. Sevanā bhāvanā. Paṭipakkhoti pahāyakapaṭipakkho. Yadipi gāthāyaṃ “sīle”ti🔽sāmaññato vuttaṃ, na “adhisīle”ti. Taṃ pana taṇhājaṭāvijaṭanassa patiṭṭhābhūtaṃ adhippetanti
analyzed: te sikkhati iti vuccati sāsananti paṭipatti sāsanam upanissayaḥ balava kāraṇam vajjanam  anupagamanam sevanā bhāvanā paṭipakkhaḥ ti pahāyaka paṭipakkhaḥ yadi pi gāthā ayam sīla iti  sāmaññataḥ vuttam na adhisīle ti tam pana taṇhā jaṭā vijaṭanassa patiṭṭhā bhūtam adhippetanti
translated: is said to “train” in them. The Dispensation is the Dispensation of the way. A condition is a powerful cause. Non-going is non-approach.🔽Cultivation is development. Opposite is the opposite that abandons. Although in the verse “in virtue” is said in a general way, not as “in higher virtue,”

original: āha “sīlena adhisīlasikkhā pakāsitā”ti. Bhavagāmi hi sīlaṃ sīlameva, vibhavagāmi
analyzed: āha sīlena adhi sīla sikkhā pakāsitā ati bhava gāmi hi sīlam sīlam eva vibhava gāmi
translated: nevertheless it is higher virtue that is intended as the basis for disentangling the tangle of craving. Hence he said: “The training in higher virtue is revealed by virtue.” For virtue that leads to becoming is simply virtue,

original: sīlaṃ adhisīlasikkhā. Sāmaññajotanā hi visese avatiṭṭhatīti. Esa nayo sesasikkhāsupi.
analyzed: sīlam adhisīla sikkhā sāmañña jotanā hi visese avatiṭṭhati iti esa nayo sesa sikkhāsu pi
translated: but virtue that leads to the destruction of becoming is the training in higher virtue. For the illumination of the general rule is established in the particular.🔽So too with the other trainings.

original: Sīlenāti adhisīlasikkhābhūtena sīlena. Taṃ hi anaññasādhāraṇatāya sāsanassa ādikalyāṇataṃ
analyzed: sīlena ati adhi sīla sikkhā bhūtena sīlena tam hi anañña sādhāraṇa tāya sāsanassa ādi kalyāṇa tam
translated: By virtue: by virtue as the training in higher virtue. For that is the Dispensation’s goodness at the beginning since it is not shared by others,

original: pakāseti, na yamaniyamādimattaṃ. Tena vuttaṃ “sīlañca suvisuddhaṃ, sabbapāpassa akaraṇa”nti
analyzed: pakāseti na yama niyama ādi mattam tena vuttam sīlam ca su visuddham sabba pāpassa akaraṇam ti
translated: He does not reveal the mere restraint of the rules of training. Hence it was said above: “And virtue is well purified, And all evil is not done.”🔽“Of the profitable”: of the profitable path. Or “profitable” can mean “blameless.” Thus

original: ca. Kusalānanti maggakusalānaṃ. Kusalānanti vā anavajjānaṃ. Tena ariyaphaladhammānampi
analyzed: ca kusalānam ti magga kusalānam kusalānam ti vā anavajjānam tena ariya phala dhammānam pi
translated: there is included also the noble fruition states.

original: saṅgaho siddho hoti. Sabbapāpassa akaraṇanti sabbassāpi sāvajjassa akiriyā anajjhāpajjanaṃ.
analyzed: saṅgahaḥ siddhaḥ hoti sabba pāpassa a karaṇam ti sabbassa api sāvajjassa a kiriyā an ajjhāpajjanam
translated: “All evil is not done”: all that is blameworthy is not done, is not experienced.

original: Etena cārittavārittabhedassa sabbassa sīlassa gahaṇaṃ kataṃ hoti. Kattabbākaraṇampi🔽hi sāvajjamevāti. Ādivacanatoti gāthāyaṃ vuttasamādhipaññānaṃ ādimhi vacanato. Ādibhāvo
analyzed: etena cāritta vāritta bhedassa sabbassa sīlassa gahaṇam katam hoti kattabba akaraṇam pi  hi sāvajjam evā ti ādi vacanato ti gāthāyam vutta samādhi paññānam ādimhi vacanataḥ ādi bhāvo
translated: And by this the inclusion of all virtue classed as virtue of restraint and virtue of undertaking is made. For the non-doing of what should be done is also blameworthy.🔽“By the word ‘etc.’”: because of the word “etc.” in the verse. For the word “etc.” includes concentration and understanding, which are the beginning of the verse. And the beginning is the root of the supramundane states.

original: cassa tammūlakattā uttarimanussadhammānaṃ. Ādīnaṃ vā vacanaṃ ādivacanaṃ. Ādisaddena
analyzed: cassa uttari manussa dhammānam ādīnam vā vacanam ādi vacanam ādi saddena
translated: Or the word “etc.” is the word “beginning.”🔽Herein, the inclusion of the following passages should be understood: “Virtue, concentration, understanding,

original: cettha “sīlaṃ samādhi paññā ca, vimutti ca anuttarā”ti evamādīnaṃ saṅgaho daṭṭhabbo.
analyzed: ca ittha sīlam samādhi paññā ca vimutti ca anuttarā ati evamādīnam saṅgahaḥ daṭṭhabbo
translated: And the unsurpassed freedom” ,

original: Sīlassa visuddhattā vippaṭisārādihetūnaṃ dūrīkaraṇato avippaṭisārādiguṇāvahaṃ. “Avippaṭisārādiguṇāvahattā”ti
analyzed: sīlassa visuddha ttā vippaṭisāra ādi hetūnam dūrīkaraṇataḥ a vippaṭisāra ādi guṇa āvaham a vippaṭisāra ādi guṇa āvaha ttā ati
translated: It is the source of the qualities of non-remorse, etc., because it is the cause of the removal of the conditions for remorse, etc., by the purification of virtue.

original: etena na kevalaṃ sīlassa kalyāṇatāva vibhāvitā, atha kho ādibhāvopīti daṭṭhabbaṃ.
analyzed: etena na kevalam vibhāvitā atha kho ādi bhāvaḥ api iti daṭṭhabbam
translated: By this phrase, “the source of the qualities of non-remorse, etc.,” it should be understood that not only is the excellence of virtue demonstrated, but also the excellence of the beginning.

original: Tathā hissa sutte avippaṭisārādīnaṃ vimuttiñāṇapariyosānānaṃ paramparapaccayatā vuttā.
analyzed: tathā hissa sutte a vippaṭisāra ādīnam vimutti ñāṇa pariyosānānam parampara paccaya tā vuttā
translated: For in the sutta the successive conditionship of non-remorse, etc., up to the knowledge of the destruction of the cankers is stated.

original: Samādhināti adhicittasikkhābhūtena samādhinā. Sakalaṃ sāsanaṃ saṅgahetvā pavattāya
analyzed: samādhinā ati adhi citta sikkhā bhūtena samādhinā sakalam sāsanam saṅgahetvā pavattāya
translated: “By concentration”: by the concentration that is the training in the higher mind.

original: gāthāya ādipadena ādimhi paṭipajjitabbassa sīlassa, tatiyapadena pariyosāne paṭipajjitabbāya
analyzed: gāthāya ādi padena ādimhi paṭipajjitabbassa sīlassa tatiya padena pariyosāne paṭipajjitabbāya
translated: Since virtue, which should be practiced at the beginning, is included by the first line of the verse, and wisdom, which should be practiced at the end, is included by the third line of the verse,

original: paññāya gahitattā majjhe paṭipajjitabbo samādhi pārisesato dutiyapadena gayhatīti
analyzed: paññāya gahita ttā majjhe paṭipajjitabbaḥ samādhi pārisesataḥ dutiya padena gayhati iti
translated: the concentration that should be practiced in the middle is included by the second line of the verse, which is stated in the middle.

original: “kusalassa upasampadātiādivacanato hi samādhi sāsanassa majjhe”ti vuttaṃ, na kusalasaddassa
analyzed: kusalassa upasampadā ati ādi vacanataḥ hi samādhi sāsanassa majjhe ti vuttam na kusala saddassa
translated: For it is said: “The concentration is in the middle of the Dispensation because of the words, ‘The undertaking of what is skillful’ , etc.” The word “skillful” does not

original: samādhipariyāyattā. Pubbūpanissayavato hi samāhitatādiaṭṭhaṅgasamannāgamena abhinīhārakkhamatā
analyzed: samādhi pariyāyattā pubba upanissayavataḥ hi samāhita tā ādi aṭṭhaṅga samannāgamena abhinīhāra kkhama tā
translated: for it is dependent on concentration. For one who has previously made the support is endowed with the eight factors of the path beginning with right concentration.🔽The excellence of the Buddha’s dispensation is the excellence of the path. The excellence of the path is the excellence of the fruit. The excellence of the fruit is the excellence of the person. The excellence of the person is the excellence of the dispensation.

original: samādhissa iddhividhādiguṇāvahattaṃ, aggamaggapaññāya adhigatāya yadatthaṃ pabbajati,
analyzed: samādhissa iddhividha ādi guṇa āvahattam agga magga paññāya adhigatāya yadattham pabbajati
translated: The excellence of the dispensation is the excellence of the path, etc., because the path, etc., are respectively the cause, the condition, the support, and the object of the excellence of the dispensation.

original: taṃ pariyositanti paññā sāsanassa pariyosānaṃ. Tenāha bhagavā “sikkhānisaṃsamidaṃ,🔽bhikkhave, brahmacariyaṃ vussati saddhādhipateyyaṃ paññuttaraṃ vimuttisāra”nti. Sakaṃ🔽cittaṃ sacittaṃ, sacittassa sabbaso kilesānaṃ samucchindanena visodhanaṃ sacittapariyodāpanaṃ.
analyzed: tam pariyositanti paññā sāsanassa pariyosānam tena āha bhagavā sikkhā nisaṃsam idam  bhikkhave brahmacariyam vussati saddhā ādhipateyyam paññuttaram vimutti sāranti sakam  cittam sa cittam sa cittassa sabbasas kilesānam samucchindanena visodhanam sa citta pariyodāpanam
translated: The excellence of the path is the excellence of the fruit because the fruit is the result of the path.🔽The excellence of the fruit is the excellence of the person because the person is the possessor of the fruit.🔽The excellence of the person is the excellence of the dispensation because the person is the support of the dispensation.🔽The excellence of the dispensation is the excellence of the path, etc., because the dispensation is the cause, the condition, the support, and the object of the path, etc.🔽The excellence of the path, etc., is the excellence of the dispensation because the path, etc., are respectively the cause, the condition, the support, and the object of the excellence of the dispensation.

original: Evaṃ pana paññākicce matthakappatte uttari karaṇīyābhāvato sāsanassa paññuttaratā
analyzed: evam pana paññā kicce matthaka ppatte uttari karaṇīya abhāvato sāsanassa paññuttara tā
translated: The excellence of the dispensation is the excellence of the path, etc., because the dispensation is the cause, the condition, the support, and the object of the path, etc.🔽The excellence of the path, etc., is the excellence of the dispensation because the path, etc., are respectively the cause, the condition, the support, and the object of the excellence of the dispensation.🔽The excellence of the dispensation is the excellence of the path, etc., because the dispensation is the cause, the condition, the support, and the object of the path, etc.🔽The excellence of the path, etc., is the excellence of the dispensation because the path, etc., are respectively the cause, the condition, the support, and the object of the excellence of the dispensation.🔽The excellence of the dispensation is the excellence of the path, etc., because the dispensation is the cause, the condition, the support, and the object of the path, etc.

original: veditabbā. Tādibhāvāvahanatoti yādiso iṭṭhesu, lābhādīsu ca anunayābhāvato, tādiso🔽aniṭṭhesu, alābhādīsu ca paṭighābhāvato. Tato eva vā yādiso anāpāthagatesu iṭṭhāniṭṭhesu,
analyzed: veditabbā ta ādi bhāva avahanato ti yādisaḥ iṭṭhesu lābha ādīsu ca anunaya abhāvato tādisaḥ 🔽aniṭṭhesu alābha ādīsu ca paṭigha abhāvato tatas eva vā yādisaḥ anāpātha gatesu iṭṭha aniṭṭhesu
translated: The excellence of the path, etc., is the excellence of the dispensation because the path, etc., are respectively the cause, the condition, the support, and the object of the excellence of the dispensation.🔽The excellence of the dispensation is

original: tādiso āpāthagatesupīti tādī. Tassa bhāvo tādibhāvo, tassa āvahanato. Vātenāti vātahetu.
analyzed: tādisaḥ āpātha gatesu pi iti tādī tassa bhāvo tādi bhāvo tassa āvahanataḥ vātena ati vāta hetu
translated: Because of the wind: because of the cause of the wind.

original: Na samīratīti na calati. Na samiñjantīti na phandanti, kuto calananti adhippāyo.
analyzed: na samīrati iti na calati na samiñjanti iti na phandanti kuto adhippāyo
translated: It does not stir: it does not move. It does not shake: it does not tremble. The intention is: how can it move?🔽Just as virtue, etc., are the illuminators of the higher training in virtue, etc.,

original: Tathāti yathā sīlādayo adhisīlasikkhādīnaṃ pakāsakā, tathā tevijjatādīnaṃ upanissayassāti🔽tesaṃ pakāsanākārūpasaṃhārattho tathā-saddo. Yasmā sīlaṃ visujjhamānaṃ satisampajaññabalena,
analyzed: tathā ti yathā sīla ādayaḥ adhi sīla sikkhā ādīnam pakāsakā tathā tevijja tā ādīnam upanissayassa ati  tesam pakāsanā kāru upasaṃhāra atthaḥ tathā saddaḥ yasmā sīlam visujjhamānam sati sampajañña balena
translated: so too are the three kinds of knowledge, etc., the supports for the three kinds of clear-vision.🔽The word “too” is for the purpose of including the mode of explanation.

original: kammassakatañāṇabalena ca saṃkilesamalato visujjhati pāripūriñca gacchati, tasmā🔽sīlasampadā sijjhamānā upanissayasampattibhāvena satibalaṃ, ñāṇabalañca paccupaṭṭhapetīti
analyzed: kammassakata ñāṇa balena ca saṃkilesa malataḥ visujjhati pāripūrim ca gacchati tasmā  sīla sampadā sijjhamānā upanissaya sampatti bhāvena sati balam ñāṇa balañca paccupaṭṭhapeti iti
translated: Because virtue, when being purified, is purified and reaches fulfilment by means of the power of mindfulness and full awareness and by means of the power of knowledge of the ownership of kamma,🔽therefore🔽when the perfection of virtue is being perfected, it actualizes the power of mindfulness and the power of knowledge as the perfection of the support.

original: tassā vijjattayūpanissayatā veditabbā sabhāgahetusampādanato. Satinepakkena hi pubbenivāsavijjāsiddhi,
analyzed: tassāḥ vijjatta yūpa nissaya tā veditabbā sa bhāga hetu sampādanato sati nepakkena hi pubbenivāsa vijjā siddhi
translated: Thus its state of being the support for the three kinds of knowledge should be understood as the bringing about of the associated cause. For the success of the knowledge of recollection of past lives is due to mindfulness and full awareness,

original: sampajaññena sabbakiccesu sudiṭṭhakāritāparicayena cutūpapātañāṇānubandhāya dutiyavijjāsiddhi,🔽vītikkamābhāvena saṃkilesappahānasabbhāvato vivaṭṭūpanissayatāvasena ajjhāsayasuddhiyā🔽tatiyavijjāsiddhi. Puretaraṃ siddhānaṃ samādhipaññānaṃ pāripūriṃ vinā sīlassa āsavakkhayañāṇūpanissayatā
analyzed: sampajaññena sabba kiccesu su diṭṭha kāri tā paricayena cutūpapāta ñāṇa anubandhāya dutiya vijjā siddhi  vītikkama abhāvena saṃkilesa ppahāna sabbhāvataḥ vivaṭṭu upanissaya tā vasena ajjhāsaya suddhiyā  puretaram siddhānam samādhi paññānam pāripūrim vinā sīlassa āsava kkhaya ñāṇa upanissaya tā
translated: The second knowledge is successful by the purification of view, which is the condition for the knowledge of passing away and reappearance, by the practice of right view in all activities through the means of clear comprehension.🔽The third knowledge is successful by the purification of intention, which is the condition for the abandoning of defilements by the way of non-transgression, by the purity of intention in the sense of being the proximate cause for the turning away from the defilements.🔽The conditionality of virtue for the knowledge of the destruction of the cankers should be demonstrated by the dry insight worker and the canker-free person, without the fulfilment of concentration and wisdom which have already been successful.

original: sukkhavipassakakhīṇāsavehi dīpetabbā. Samādhipaññā viya abhiññāpaṭisambhidānaṃ sīlaṃ🔽na sabhāgahetūti katvā vuttaṃ “na tato para”nti. “Samāhito yathābhūtaṃ pajānātī”ti🔽vacanato samādhisampadā chaḷabhiññatāya upanissayo. Paññā viya paṭisambhidānaṃ samādhi
analyzed: sukkha vipassaka khīṇāsavehi dīpetabbā samādhi paññā viya abhiññā paṭisambhidānam sīlam  na sa bhāga hetū iti katvā vuttam na tatas param ti samāhitaḥ yathābhūtam pajānāti iti  vacanataḥ samādhi sampadā chaḷabhiñña tāya upanissayo paññā viya paṭisambhidānam samādhi
translated: It is said that “there is no further” because virtue is not a homogeneous cause for the direct knowledges and the analytical insights, as it is for concentration and wisdom.🔽It is said that “there is no further” because concentration is not a homogeneous cause for the analytical insights, as it is for the six kinds of direct knowledge, according to the passage: “One who is concentrated knows and sees correctly” .

original: na sabhāgahetūti vuttaṃ “na tato para”nti. “Yogā ve jāyate bhūrī”ti vacanato pubbayogena,
analyzed: na sa bhāga hetū ti vuttam na tatas paranti yogā ve jāyate bhūri iti vacanato pubba yogena
translated: It is said that “there is no further” because wisdom is not a homogeneous cause for the direct knowledges, as it is for the analytical insights, according to the passage: “When there is much practice, much development, much repetition of the kinds of direct knowledge, the analytical insights arise” .

original: garuvāsadesabhāsākaosallauggahaparipucchādīhi ca paribhāvitā paññāsampatti paṭisambhidāpabhedassa🔽upanissayo paccekabodhisammāsambodhiyopi paññāsampattisannissayāti paññāya anadhigantabbassa
analyzed: garu vāsa desa bhāsā kaosalla oggaha paripuccha ādīhi ca paribhāvitā paññā sampatti paṭisambhidā apabhedassa  upanissayo pacceka bodhi sammāsambodhiyo pi paññā sampatti sannissayā ati paññāya an adhigantabbassa
translated: And the perfection of understanding, which is developed by the study of the scriptures, by the vernacular language, by the questions and answers in the monastery, etc., is the decisive support for the kinds of understanding classed as the kinds of knowledge of the scriptures, etc.,🔽and for the kinds of understanding classed as the kinds of direct knowledge, and for the kinds of understanding classed as the kinds of analytical knowledge, and for the kinds of understanding classed as the enlightenment of a disciple, the enlightenment of a paccekabuddha, and the supreme enlightenment.

original: visesassa abhāvato, tassā ca paṭisambhidāpabhedassa ekantikakāraṇato heṭṭhā viya
analyzed: visesassa abhāvato tassā ca paṭisambhidā apabhedassa ekantika kāraṇato heṭṭhā viya
translated: So, because there is no distinction that cannot be reached by understanding, and because the kinds of analytical knowledge, etc., have understanding as their sole cause,

original: “na tato para”nti avatvā “na aññena kāraṇenā”ti vuttaṃ.🔽Ettha ca “sīlasampattiñhi nissāyā”ti vuttattā yassa samādhivijambhanabhūtā anavasesā
analyzed: na tatas param ti avatvā na aññena kāraṇena ati vuttam  ettha ca sīla sampattiñhi nissāya ati vutta ttā yassa samādhi vijambhana bhūtā anavasesā
translated: unlike the passage below , the words “not by any other means” are not repeated here.

original: cha abhiññā na ijjhanti, tassa ukkaṭṭhaparicchedavasena na samādhisampadā atthīti.
analyzed: cha abhiññāḥ na ijjhanti tassa ukkaṭṭha pariccheda vasena na samādhi sampadā atthi iti
translated: And since it is said “with the perfection of virtue as condition,” it follows that one who has not attained the six kinds of direct knowledge without remainder, which are the opposite of concentration, has no perfection of concentration in the sense of the highest limit.

original: Satipi vijjānaṃ abhiññekadesabhāve sīlasampattisamudāgatā eva tisso vijjā gahitā.
analyzed: sati api vijjānam abhiññeka desa bhāve sīla sampatti samudāgatāḥ eva tissaḥ vijjā gahitā
translated: And although the kinds of direct knowledge are a part of the kinds of knowledge, only the three kinds of knowledge that arise with the perfection of virtue as their support are included here.

original: Yathā hi paññāsampattisamudāgatā catasso paṭisambhidā upanissayasampannassa maggeneva
analyzed: yathā hi paññā sampatti samudāgatā catasso paṭisambhidā upanissaya sampannassa maggena iva
translated: For just as the four analytical knowledges that arise with the perfection of understanding as their support are included in the kinds of analytical knowledge,

original: ijjhanti, maggakkhaṇe eva tāsaṃ paṭilabhitabbato, evaṃ sīlasampattisamudāgatā tisso
analyzed: ijjhanti magga kkhaṇe eva tāsam paṭilabhitabbataḥ evam sīla sampatti samudāgatā tisso
translated: They succeed through the path, because they are to be acquired only at the moment of the path. So the three knowledges succeed through the fulfilment of virtue and the six kinds of direct knowledge through the fulfilment of concentration.

original: vijjā samādhisampattisamudāgatā ca cha abhiññā upanissayasampannassa maggeneva ijjhantīti🔽maggādhigameneva tāsaṃ adhigamo veditabbo. Paccekabuddhānaṃ, sammāsambuddhānañca
analyzed: vijjā samādhi sampatti samudāgatā ca cha abhiññāḥ upanissaya sampannassa maggena iva ijjhanti iti  magga adhigamena iva tāsam adhigamaḥ veditabbaḥ paccekabuddhānam sammāsambuddhānam ca
translated: They succeed only through the path in one who possesses the support for them.🔽The acquisition of these should be understood to come about only through the attainment of the path.

original: paccekabodhisammāsambodhisamadhigamasadisā hi imesaṃ ariyānaṃ ime visesādhigamāti.
analyzed: pacceka bodhi sammāsambodhi samadhigama sadisāḥ hi imesam ariyānam ime visesa adhigamā ti
translated: For the acquisition of these special qualities by these Noble Ones is like the acquisition of the Hermit Enlightened One’s enlightenment and of the Fully Enlightened One’s enlightenment.

original: Vinayasuttābhidhammesu sammāpaṭipattiyā tevijjatādīnaṃ upanissayatāpi yathāvuttavidhinā veditabbā.
analyzed: vinaya sutta abhidhammesu sammā paṭipattiyā tevijja tā ādīnam upanissaya tā api yathā vutta vidhinā veditabbā
translated: And the fact that the three knowledges, etc., are the support for the right practice of the Vinaya, the Suttas, and the Abhidhamma should be understood in the way already stated.

original: Sampannasīlassa kāmasevanābhāvato sīlena paṭhamantavivajjanaṃ vuttaṃ. Yebhuyyena
analyzed: sampanna sīlassa kāma sevana abhāvataḥ sīlena paṭhama anta vivajjanam vuttam yebhuyyena
translated: It is said that virtue is the first warding off of wrongness because one whose virtue is fulfilled does not indulge in sexual intercourse.🔽For most beings are impure in their practice because of the performance of killing breathing things, etc., for the sake of sensual desires.

original: hi sattā kāmahetu pāṇātipātādivasenāpi asuddhapayogā honti. Jhānasukhalābhino kāyakilamathassa
analyzed: hi sattā kāma hetu pāṇātipāta ādi vasena api asuddha payogāḥ honti jhāna sukha lābhinaḥ kāya kilamathassa
translated: And one who has obtained the pleasure of jhāna has no need to be tormented by bodily pain.

original: sambhavo eva natthīti samādhinā dutiyantavivajjanaṃ vuttaṃ jhānasamuṭṭhānapaṇītarūpaphuṭakāyattā.
analyzed: sambhavaḥ eva natthi iti samādhinā dutiya anta vivajjanam vuttam jhāna samuṭṭhāna paṇīta rūpa phuṭaka āyattā
translated: The second case ending is omitted by the resolution of the compound in the sense of origination, since the body is pervaded by the sublime materiality originated by jhāna.

original: Paññāyāti maggapaññāya. Ukkaṭṭhaniddesena hi ekaṃsato ariyamaggova majjhimā paṭipatti
analyzed: paññāya ti magga paññāya ukkaṭṭha niddesena hi ekaṃsataḥ ariya maggaḥ uva majjhimā paṭipatti
translated: By understanding: by the understanding of the path. For the noble path is called the middle way in the sense of the extreme.

original: nāma. Evaṃ santepi lokiyapaññāvasenapi antadvayavivajjanaṃ vibhāvetabbaṃ.
analyzed: nāma evam sante pi lokiya paññā vasena api anta dvaya vivajjanam vibhāvetabbam
translated: Nevertheless, the avoidance of the two extremes should be illustrated also by means of mundane understanding.

original: Sīlaṃ taṃsamaṅgino kāmasugatīsuyeva nibbattāpanato catūhi apāyehi vimuttiyā kāraṇanti
analyzed: sīlam tad samaṅginaḥ kāma sugatīsu yeva nibbattāpanataḥ catūhi apāyehi vimuttiyāḥ kāraṇan ti
translated: That virtue is the cause of deliverance from the four states of loss, since it causes rebirth among deities and human beings who enjoy sensual pleasures.

original: āha “sīlena apāyasamatikkamanupāyo pakāsito hotī”ti. Na hi pāṇātipātādipaṭivirati
analyzed: āha sīlena pakāsitaḥ hoti iti na hi pāṇātipāta ādi paṭivirati
translated: Hence it is said: “The means of surmounting the states of loss is shown by virtue.” For the abstention from killing living beings, etc.,

original: duggatiparikilesaṃ āvahati. Samādhi taṃsamaṅgino mahaggatabhūmiyaṃyeva nibbattāpanena
analyzed: duggati parikilesam āvahati samādhi tad samaṅginaḥ mahaggata bhūmiyaṃ yā iva nibbattāpanena
translated: does not bring about the defilement of the states of loss.

original: sakalakāmabhavato vimocetīti vuttaṃ “samādhinā kāmadhātusamatikkamanupāyo pakāsito
analyzed: sakala kāma bhavataḥ vimoceti iti vuttam samādhinā kāmadhātu samatikkaman upāyaḥ pakāsito
translated: Concentration causes rebirth in the exalted planes of existence, and so it is said that it “is the means of surmounting the sense-desire element.”

original: hotī”ti. Na hi kāmāvacarakammassa anubalappadāyīnaṃ kāmacchandādīnaṃ vikkhambhakaṃ
analyzed: hoti iti na hi kāmāvacara kammassa anubala ppadāyīnam kāmacchanda ādīnam vikkhambhakam
translated: For the abandonment of sense desire, etc., which are the basis for the kamma of the sense-sphere,

original: jhānaṃ kāmadhātuparikilesāvahaṃ hoti. Na cettha upacārajjhānaṃ nidassetabbaṃ, appanāsamādhissa
analyzed: jhānam kāmadhātu parikilesa āvaham hoti na ca ittha upacāra jhānam nidassetabbam appanā samādhissa
translated: and the jhāna is the cause of the defilements of the sense sphere. And here the access jhāna should not be demonstrated, because it is the concentration of absorption that is intended here.

original: adhippetattā. Nāpi “sīleneva atikkamitabbassa apāyabhavassa samādhinā atikkamitabbatā”ti🔽vacanokāso. Sugatibhavampi atikkamantassa duggatisamatikkamane kā kathāti. Sabbabhavasamatikkamanupāyoti
analyzed: adhippeta ttā na api sīlena iva atikkamitabbassa apāya bhavassa samādhinā atikkamitabba tā ti  vacana ukāsaḥ sugati bhavam pi atikkamantassa duggati samatikkamane kā kathā ati sabba bhava samatikkaman upāyaḥ ti
translated: Nor is there room for the statement that “the unprofitable world is to be transcended by virtue and the world of neither-perception-nor-non-perception by concentration,”🔽since it is the world of the happy destiny that is being transcended.

original: kāmabhavādīnaṃ navannampi bhavānaṃ samatikkamanupāyo sīlasamādhīhi atikkantāpi bhavā
analyzed: kāma bhava ādīnam sīla samādhīhi atikkantā api
translated: The means to the transcending of all kinds of becoming is the virtue and concentration,

original: anatikkantā eva, kāraṇassa apahīnattā. Paññāya panassa suppahīnattā te samatikkantā eva.
analyzed: an atikkantāḥ eva kāraṇassa apahīna ttā paññāya panassa su pahīna ttā te samatikkantāḥ eva
translated: because although the kinds of becoming are transcended by virtue and concentration, they are not really transcended because the cause is not abandoned. But with the abandoning of that cause by means of understanding they are really transcended.

original: Tadaṅgappahānavasenāti dīpālokeneva tamassa puññakiriyavatthugatena tena tena kusalaṅgena
analyzed: tad aṅga ppahāna vasena ati dīpa ālokena iva tamassa puñña kiriya vatthu gatena tena tena kusalaṅgena
translated: By the abandoning of the states that are its concomitants: by means of the particular profitable states classed as virtue and concentration, which are like a lamp and light,🔽the particular unprofitable states are abandoned.

original: tassa tassa akusalaṅgassa pahānavasena. Samādhinā vikkhambhanappahānavasenāti upacārappanābhedena
analyzed: tassa tassa akusalaṅgassa pahāna vasena samādhinā vikkhambhana ppahāna vasena ati upacāra ppanā bhedena
translated: By the abandoning of the states that are its opponents: by means of the access and absorption jhānas, which are like the covering of a roof and the rain that wets it.

original: samādhinā pavattinivāraṇena ghaṭappahāreneva jalatale sevālassa tesaṃ tesaṃ nīvaraṇādidhammānaṃ
analyzed: samādhinā pavatti nivāraṇena ghaṭa pahārena iva jala tale sevālassa tesam tesam nīvaraṇa ādi dhammānam
translated: By concentration: by the prevention of occurrence, like the stopping of the waves by a dam.

original: pahānavasena. Paññāyāti ariyamaggapaññāya. Samucchedappahānavasenāti catunnaṃ ariyamaggānaṃ🔽bhāvitattā taṃtaṃmaggavato attano santāne “diṭṭhigatānaṃ pahānāyā”tiādinā vuttassa
analyzed: pahāna vasena paññāya ati ariya magga paññāya samuccheda ppahāna vasena ati catunnam ariya maggānam  bhāvita ttā taṃ taṃ maggavataḥ attano santāne diṭṭhi gatānam pahānāya iti ādinā vuttassa
translated: By wisdom: by the noble path-wisdom.

original: samudayapakkhiyassa kilesagaṇassa accantaṃ appavattisaṅkhātasamucchindanappahānavasena.
analyzed: samudaya pakkhiyassa kilesa gaṇassa accantam appavatti saṅkhāta samucchindana ppahāna vasena
translated: By the severance-abandoning: by the abandoning consisting in the complete non-occurrence of the mass of defilements belonging to the origin-side, which is stated thus: “For the abandoning of the false views” , etc.,🔽because the four noble paths have been developed.

original: Kilesānaṃ vītikkamapaṭipakkhoti saṃkilesadhammānaṃ, kammakilesānaṃ vā yo kāyavacīdvāresu
analyzed: kilesānam vītikkama paṭipakkho ti saṃkilesa dhammānam kamma kilesānam vā yaḥ kāya vacī dvāresu
translated: The opposite of transgression of defilements: virtue is manifested as the opposite of the transgression of defilements, or of the defilements of kamma, which is misconduct in body and speech.

original: vītikkamo ajjhācāro, tassa paṭipakkho sīlena pakāsito hoti, avītikkamasabhāvattā
analyzed: vītikkamaḥ ajjhācāraḥ tassa paṭipakkhaḥ sīlena pakāsitaḥ hoti a vītikkama sabhāva ttā
translated: Because virtue has the nature of non-transgression.

original: sīlassa. Okāsādānavasena kilesānaṃ citte kusalappavattiṃ pariyādiyitvā uṭṭhānaṃ pariyuṭṭhānaṃ.
analyzed: sīlassa okāsa ādāna vasena kilesānam citte kusala ppavattim pariyādiyitvā uṭṭhānam pariyuṭṭhānam
translated: The uprising of defilements: the uprising of defilements in the mind by way of the seizing of an opportunity, after the occurrence of profitable states has been interrupted.

original: Taṃ samādhi vikkhambhetīti āha “samādhinā pariyuṭṭhānapaṭipakkho pakāsito hotī”ti,🔽samādhissa pariyuṭṭhānappahāyakattā. Appahīnabhāvena santāne anu anu sayanato kāraṇalābhe🔽uppattirahā anusayā, te pana anurūpaṃ kāraṇaṃ laddhā uppajjanārahā thāmagatā kāmarāgādayo
analyzed: tam samādhi vikkhambheti iti āha samādhinā pariyuṭṭhāna paṭipakkhaḥ pakāsitaḥ hoti iti  samādhissa pariyuṭṭhāna pahāyaka ttā appahīna bhāvena santāne anu anu sayanataḥ kāraṇa lābhe  uppatti rahāḥ anusayā te pana anurūpam kāraṇam laddhāḥ uppajjana arahā kāma rāga ādayaḥ
translated: “It is the opposite of the pre-occupation of concentration” is said because it is the abandoning of the pre-occupation of concentration.🔽The latent tendencies are the seven defilements, lust, etc., which are capable of arising in the continuum of consciousness, because they have not been abandoned, and which are present in the continuum of consciousness, because they are constantly being renewed.🔽But when they obtain a suitable condition, they are capable of arising, and they are then called “tendencies that have reached the threshold” .

original: satta kilesā veditabbā. Te ariyamaggapaññāya sabbaso pahīyantīti āha “paññāya anusayapaṭipakkho pakāsito hotī”ti.
analyzed: satta kilesā veditabbā te ariya magga paññāya sabbaso pahīyanti iti āha paññāya anusaya paṭipakkho pakāsito hoti iti
translated: They are abandoned by the path of arahatship.

original: Kāyaduccaritādi duṭṭhu caritaṃ, kilesehi vā dūsitaṃ caritanti duccaritaṃ, tameva
analyzed: kāya duccarita ādi duṭṭhu caritam kilesehi vā dūsitam duccaritam tam eva
translated: Bad conduct is bodily misconduct, etc., or conduct that is corrupted by defilements.

original: yattha uppannaṃ, taṃ santānaṃ saṃkileseti vibādhati, upatāpeti cāti saṃkileso, tassa
analyzed: yattha uppannam tam santānam saṃkileseti vibādhati upatāpeti ca ati saṃkilesaḥ tassa
translated: It is a corruption because it corrupts the continuum in which it arises, and because it is a hindrance, an obstruction.🔽The purification of that is the abandoning of bad conduct by virtue through the abandoning of its associated states.

original: visodhanaṃ sīlena tadaṅgavasena pahānaṃ vītikkamapaṭipakkhattā sīlassa. Taṇhāsaṃkilesassa
analyzed: visodhanam sīlena tad aṅga vasena pahānam vītikkama paṭipakkha ttā sīlassa taṇhā saṃkilesassa
translated: The purification of the defilement of craving is the abandoning of that by virtue through the abandoning of its associated states.

original: visodhanaṃ vikkhambhanavasena pahānaṃ pariyuṭṭhānapaṭipakkhattā samādhissa, taṇhāya
analyzed: visodhanam vikkhambhana vasena pahānam pariyuṭṭhāna paṭipakkha ttā samādhissa taṇhāya
translated: Purification is abandoning by suppression and by substitution of opposites. It is purification of concentration because it is the opposite of the hindrances.🔽It is purification of craving because it is the opposite of the craving that is the cause of the hindrances.

original: cassa ujuvipaccanikabhāvato. Diṭṭhisaṃkilesassa visodhanaṃ samucchedavasena pahānaṃ
analyzed: cassa uju vipaccanika bhāvataḥ diṭṭhi saṃkilesassa visodhanam samuccheda vasena pahānam
translated: It is purification of defilements by cutting off because it is the opposite of the defilements of wrong view.🔽It is purification of wrong view because it is the opposite of the wrong views of those who misapprehend the way.

original: anusayapaṭipakkhattā paññāya, diṭṭhigatānañca ayāthāvagāhīnaṃ yāthāvagāhiniyā paññāya
analyzed: anusaya paṭipakkha ttā paññāya diṭṭhi gatānam ca a yāthāvagāhīnam yāthāvagāhiniyā paññāya
translated: It is purification of the way because it is the opposite of the misapprehension of the way.

original: ujuvipaccanikabhāvato.
analyzed: uju vi paccanika bhāvataḥ
translated: Cause is decisive-support condition.

original: Kāraṇanti upanissayapaccayo. Sīlesu paripūrakārīti maggabrahmacariyassa ādibhūtattā
analyzed: kāraṇam ti upanissaya paccayo sīlesu paripūra kārī ti magga brahmacariyassa ādi bhūta ttā
translated: One who has fulfilled virtue: one who has fulfilled, made ready, virtue that is to be developed by means of the first jhāna, etc.,

original: ādibrahmacariyakānaṃ pārājikasaṅghādisesasaṅkhātānaṃ mahāsīlasikkhāpadānaṃ avītikkamanato🔽khuddānukhuddakānaṃ āpajjane sahasāva tehi vuṭṭhānena sīlesu yaṃ kattabbaṃ, taṃ paripūraṃ
analyzed: ādibrahmacariyakānam pārājika saṅgha ādisesa saṅkhātānam mahā sīla sikkhāpadānam a vītikkamanataḥ  khuddānukhuddakānam āpajjane sahasā va tehi vuṭṭhānena sīlesu yam kattabbam tat paripūram
translated: by not transgressing the training precepts called Pārājika and Saṅghādisesa, which are the beginning of the life of purity that is the path,🔽and by quickly emerging from the minor and minor-minor offenses when they are committed, thus making ready the virtue that is to be developed by means of the path.

original: samatthaṃ karotīti sīlesu paripūrakārī. Tathā sakadāgāmīti “sīlesu paripūrakārī”ti
analyzed: samattham karoti iti sīlesu paripūra kārī tathā sakadāgāmī iti sīlesu paripūra kārī iti
translated: One who has fulfilled virtue is also a once-returner.

original: etaṃ upasaṃharati tathā-saddena. Ete hi dve ariyā samādhipāripanthikānaṃ kāmarāgabyāpādānaṃ🔽paññāpāripanthikassa saccapaṭicchādakamohassa sabbaso asamūhatattā samādhiṃ, paññañca
analyzed: etam upasaṃharati tathāsaddena ete hi dve ariyā samādhi pāripanthikānam kāma rāga byāpādānam  paññāpāripanthikassa sacca paṭicchādaka mohassa sabbasas a samūha tattā samādhim paññam ca
translated: For these two, the stream-enterer and the once-returner, have not completely eradicated sensual desire and ill will, which are the opponents of concentration,🔽and the delusion of concealment of the truths, which is the opponent of understanding.

original: bhāventāpi samādhipaññāsu yaṃ kattabbaṃ, taṃ mattaso pamāṇena padesamattameva karontīti
analyzed: bhāventā api samādhi paññāsu yam kattabbam tam mattasaḥ pamāṇena padesa mattam eva karonti iti
translated: So while they are developing concentration and understanding, they do so only to a limited extent, only a fraction, only a little.

original: samādhismiṃ, paññāya ca mattaso kārino “sīlesu paripūrakārino”icceva vuccanti. Anāgāmī
analyzed: samādhismim paññāya ca kārino sīlesu paripūra kārino icca iva vuccanti anāgāmī
translated: Thus they are called “those who have fulfilled virtue and are developing concentration and understanding to a limited extent.”
