original: pana kāmarāgabyāpādānaṃ samucchinnattā samādhismiṃ paripūrakārī. Arahā sabbaso sammohassa
analyzed: pana kāma rāga byāpādānam samucchinna ttā samādhismim paripūra kārī arahā sabbaso sammohassa
translated: But the non-returner is one who has fulfilled concentration because he has eradicated sensual desire and ill will.

original: susamūhatattā paññāya paripūrakārī.
analyzed: su samūha tattā paññāya paripūra kārī
translated: The Arahant is one who has fulfilled understanding because he has completely eradicated all delusion.

original: Vuttaṃ hetaṃ bhagavatā –
analyzed: vuttam ha itam bhagavatā
translated: For this is said by the Blessed One:

original: “Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu sīlesu paripūrakārī hoti, samādhismiṃ mattaso kārī, paññāya
analyzed: idha bhikkhave bhikkhu sīlesu paripūra kārī hoti samādhismim kārī paññāya
translated: “Here, bhikkhus, a bhikkhu has fulfilled virtue, fulfilled concentration,

original: mattaso kārī. So yāni tāni khuddānukhuddakāni sikkhāpadāni, tāni āpajjatipi vuṭṭhātipi.
analyzed: mattasaḥ kārī saḥ yāni tāni khuddānukhuddakāni sikkhāpadāni tāni āpajjati pi vuṭṭhāti pi
translated: and fulfilled understanding. He falls now and again into minor offenses and he recovers from them” .

original: Taṃ kissa hetu? Na hi mettha, bhikkhave, abhabbatā vuttā. Yāni ca kho tāni sikkhāpadāni
analyzed: tat kissa hetu na hi mā ittha bhikkhave abhabba tā vuttā yāni ca kho tāni sikkhāpadāni
translated: And why is that? Because here there is no statement of inability.

original: ādibrahmacariyakāni brahmacariyasāruppāni, tattha dhuvasīlo ca hoti ṭhitasīlo ca,
analyzed: ādibrahmacariyakāni brahmacariya sāruppāni tattha dhuva sīlo ca hoti ṭhita sīlo ca
translated: But there are training rules that are fundamental to the holy life, fit for the beginning, middling, and end. Herein, a bhikkhu is one of steady virtue, established virtue.

original: samādāya sikkhati sikkhāpadesu. So tiṇṇaṃ saṃyojanānaṃ parikkhayā sotāpanno hoti
analyzed: samādāya sikkhati sikkhāpadesu so tiṇṇam saṃyojanānam parikkhayā sotāpannaḥ hoti
translated: Having undertaken them, he trains in them. With the destruction of the three fetters he is a stream-enterer, no longer subject to the lower world, fixed in destiny, heading for enlightenment.

original: avinipātadhammo niyato sambodhiparāyaṇo. Idha pana, bhikkhave, bhikkhu sīlesu…pe…
analyzed: a vinipāta dhammaḥ niyataḥ sambodhi parāyaṇaḥ idha pana bhikkhave bhikkhu
translated: Herein, a bhikkhu is one of steady virtue, established virtue.

original: so tiṇṇaṃ saṃyojanānaṃ parikkhayā rāgadosamohānaṃ tanuttā sakadāgāmī hoti. Sakideva🔽imaṃ lokaṃ āgantvā dukkhassantaṃ karoti. Idha pana, bhikkhave, bhikkhu sīlesu paripūrakārī
analyzed: so tiṇṇam saṃyojanānam parikkhayā rāga dosa mohānam tanuttā sakadāgāmī hoti sakideva  imam lokam āgantvā dukkhassantam karoti idha pana bhikkhave bhikkhu sīlesu paripūra kārī
translated: With the destruction of three fetters and with the attenuation of lust, hate, and delusion, he is a once-returner who, after coming back to this world only one more time, will make an end of suffering.🔽Herein, a bhikkhu is one of steady virtue, established virtue, and he is one who gains internal serenity of mind but not the higher wisdom of insight into phenomena.

original: hoti, samādhismiṃ paripūrakārī, paññāya mattaso kārī. So yāni tāni…pe… sikkhati sikkhāpadesu.
analyzed: hoti samādhismim paripūra kārī paññāya kārī so yāni sikkhati sikkhāpadesu
translated: He trains in the training rules.

original: So pañcannaṃ orambhāgiyānaṃ…pe… anāvattidhammo tasmā lokā. Idha pana, bhikkhave,
analyzed: so pañcannam orambhāgiyānaṃ pe an āvatti dhammo tasmā idha pana bhikkhave
translated: With the destruction of the five lower fetters he is one due to reappear spontaneously in the Pure Abodes and there attain final Nibbana without ever returning from that world. Herein, a bhikkhu is one of steady virtue, established virtue.

original: bhikkhu sīlesu paripūrakārī hoti, samādhismiṃ paripūrakārī, paññāya paripūrakārī.🔽So yāni tāni khuddānukhuddakāni…pe… sikkhati sikkhāpadesu. So āsavānaṃ khayā…pe…
analyzed: bhikkhu sīlesu paripūrakārī hoti samādhismim paripūrakārī paññāya paripūrakārī  so yāni tāni sikkhati sikkhāpadesu saḥ āsavānam khaya āpe
translated: He trains in the training rules,

original: upasampajja viharatī”ti.
analyzed: upasampajja viharati iti
translated: and he abides in the ending of the corruptions through the destruction of the cankers.

original: “Katha”nti pucchitvā sikkhādike vibhajitvā vuttamevatthaṃ nigametuṃ “eva”ntiādi vuttaṃ.
analyzed: katham ti pucchitvā sikkhā ādike vibhajitvā vuttam eva attham nigametum eva ntiādi vuttaṃ
translated: “How?” He asks, and then he is told the distinction between the training rules and the rest. To sum up the matter he says “Thus.”

original: Tattha aññe cāti tayo vivekā, tīṇi kusalamūlāni, tīṇi vimokkhamukhāni, tīṇi indriyānīti
analyzed: tattha aññe ca ati tayo vivekā tīṇi kusala mūlāni tīṇi vimokkha mukhāni tīṇi indriyāni iti
translated: Herein, others are the three kinds of seclusion, the three roots of profit, the three doors to deliverance, the three faculties,🔽and so on. Such is the kind of virtue, etc.,

original: evamādayo, sikkhattikādīhi aññe ca guṇattikā. Evarūpāti yādisakā sikkhattikādayo🔽idha sīlādīhi pakāsitā honti, edisā.
analyzed: evamādayo sikkhattika ādīhi aññe ca guṇattikāḥ evarūpā ati yādisakā sikkhattika ādayo  idha sīla ādīhi pakāsitāḥ honti edisā
translated: that is here demonstrated by virtue, etc., as being of that kind.

original: Ettha hi vivaṭṭasannissitassa sīlassa idhādhippetattā sīlena kāyaviveko pakāsito
analyzed: ettha hi vivaṭṭa sannissitassa sīlassa idha adhippeta ttā sīlena kāya viveko pakāsito
translated: Herein, since virtue that is dependent on change-of-lineage is intended here, bodily seclusion is demonstrated by virtue,

original: hoti, samādhinā cittaviveko, paññāya upadhiviveko. Tathā sīlena adoso kusalamūlaṃ
analyzed: hoti samādhinā citta viveko paññāya upadhi viveko tathā sīlena adoso kusala mūlam
translated: seclusion of cognizance by concentration, and seclusion from acquisitions by understanding. Likewise, by virtue the root of non-hate is demonstrated,

original: pakāsitaṃ hoti, titikkhappadhānatāya, aparūpaghātasabhāvatāya ca sīlassa. Samādhinā
analyzed: pakāsitam hoti titikkha ppadhāna tāya aparūpa ghāta sabhāva tāya ca sīlassa samādhinā
translated: and by concentration,

original: alobho kusalamūlaṃ, lobhapaṭipakkhato, alobhapadhānatāya ca samādhissa. Paññāya pana🔽amohoyeva. Sīlena ca animittavimokkhamukhaṃ pakāsitaṃ hoti. Adosappadhānaṃ hi sīlasampadaṃ🔽nissāya dose ādīnavadassino aniccānupassanā sukheneva ijjhati, aniccānupassanā ca
analyzed: alobho kusala mūlam lobha paṭipakkhato alobha padhāna tāya ca samādhissa paññāya pana  sīlena ca animitta vimokkha mukham pakāsitam hoti a dosa padhānam hi sīla sampadam  nissāya dose ādīnava dassinaḥ anicca anupassanā sukhena iva ijjhati anicca anupassanā ca
translated: non-greed as a profitable root, since it is the opposite of greed and since concentration has non-greed as its principal constituent. But by understanding,🔽non-delusion alone.🔽And by virtue the door of deliverance called the signless is revealed,🔽for when one who has virtue and who has seen the danger in hate has the contemplation of impermanence, it succeeds easily for him, and the contemplation of impermanence is the door of deliverance called the signless.

original: animittavimokkhamukhaṃ. Samādhinā appaṇihitavimokkhamukhaṃ. Paññāya suññatavimokkhamukhaṃ.
analyzed: animitta vimokkha mukham samādhinā appaṇihita vimokkha mukham paññāya suññata vimokkha mukham
translated: And by concentration the door of deliverance called the desireless is revealed,

original: Alobhappadhānaṃ hi kāmanissaraṇaṃ samādhisampadaṃ nissāya kāmesu ādīnavadassino dukkhānupassanā🔽sukheneva ijjhati, dukkhānupassanā ca appaṇihitavimokkhamukhaṃ. Paññāsampadaṃ nissāya
analyzed: alobha ppadhānam hi kāma nissaraṇam samādhi sampadam nissāya kāmesu ādīnava dassinaḥ dukkha anupassanā  sukhena iva ijjhati dukkha anupassanā ca appaṇihita vimokkha mukham paññā sampadam nissāya
translated: for when one who has concentration and who has seen the danger in lust has the contemplation of pain, it succeeds easily for him, and the contemplation of pain is the door of deliverance called the desireless.🔽And by understanding the door of deliverance called the void is revealed,

original: anattānupassanā sukheneva ijjhati, anattānupassanā ca suññatavimokkhamukhaṃ. Tathā
analyzed: anatta anupassanā sukhena iva ijjhati anatta anupassanā ca suññata vimokkha mukham tathā
translated: for when one who has understanding and who has seen the danger in delusion has the contemplation of not-self, it succeeds easily for him, and the contemplation of not-self is the door of deliverance called the void.🔽And by virtue the escape from lust is revealed,

original: sīlena anaññātaññassāmītindriyaṃ pakāsitaṃ hoti. Taṃ hi sīlesu paripūrakārino aṭṭhamakassa
analyzed: sīlena anaññātaññassāmi iti indriyam pakāsitam hoti tam hi sīlesu paripūra kārino aṭṭhamakassa
translated: The faculty “I shall come to know the not yet known” is revealed by virtue. For that is possessed by one who has fulfilled the virtues of the eighth stage.

original: indriyaṃ. Samādhinā aññindriyaṃ. Taṃ hi ukkaṃsagataṃ samādhismiṃ paripūrakārino anāgāmino,🔽aggamaggaṭṭhassa ca indriyaṃ. Paññāya aññātāvindriyaṃ pakāsitaṃ hoti. Taduppattiyā
analyzed: indriyam samādhinā aññindriyam tam hi ukkaṃsa gatam samādhismim paripūra kārinaḥ anāgāminaḥ  ca indriyam paññāya aññātāvindriyam pakāsitam hoti tad uppattiyā
translated: The faculty “I shall come to know the not-yet-known” is revealed by virtue. For that is the faculty of the eighth man who fulfils virtue. The faculty of final knowledge is revealed by concentration. For that is the faculty of the non-returner who has reached the summit in concentration,🔽and it is the faculty of the one established in the path to the foremost fruit. The faculty of final knowledge is revealed by understanding. For the Arahant who has reached the summit in understanding fulfils understanding by the arising of that.

original: hi arahā paññāya paripūrakārīti. Iminā nayena aññe ca evarūpā guṇattikā sīlādīhi pakāsetabbā.
analyzed: hi arahā paññāya paripūra kārī iti iminā nayena aññe ca evarūpā guṇattikā sīla ādīhi pakāsetabbā
translated: In this way other such categories of virtue and so on can be revealed.

original: 1. Sīlaniddesavaṇṇanā
analyzed: sīla niddesa vaṇṇanā
translated: The explanation of the exposition of virtue

original: Sīlasarūpādikathāvaṇṇanā
analyzed: sīla sarūpa ādi kathā vaṇṇanā
translated: The explanation of the discussion of the form of virtue, etc.

original: 6. Evanti vuttappakārena. Anekaguṇasaṅgāhakenāti adhisīlasikkhādīnaṃ, aññesañca anekesaṃ
analyzed: evam ti vutta ppakārena aneka guṇa saṅgāhakena ati adhi sīla sikkhā ādīnam aññesam ca anekesam
translated: In this way: in the way stated. By the one that includes many special qualities: by the one that includes the training in the higher virtue, etc., and many other special qualities.

original: guṇānaṃ saṅgāhakena. Sīlasamādhipaññāmukhenāti “sabbe saṅkhārā aniccā”tiādīsu viya
analyzed: guṇānam saṅgāhakena sīla samādhi paññā mukhena ati sabbe saṅkhārāḥ anicca ati ādīsu viya
translated: By the door of virtue, concentration, and understanding: without teaching in brief by the door of mere insight, etc., as in the case of the passage beginning, “All formations are impermanent” ,

original: vipassanāmattādimukhena saṅkhepato adesetvā sīlasamādhipaññāmukhena desitopi, sattatiṃsāyapi
analyzed: vipassanā matta ādi mukhena saṅkhepataḥ a desetvā sīla samādhi paññā mukhena desitaḥ api
translated: he taught by the door of virtue, concentration, and understanding. He taught by the thirty-three aspects of virtue, etc.,

original: vā bodhipakkhiyadhammānaṃ visuddhimaggantogadhattā tattha sīlasamādhipaññā mukhaṃ
analyzed: vā bodhi pakkhiya dhammānam tattha sīla samādhi paññā mukham
translated: or of the ideas that are on the side of enlightenment, is the Thread’s footing for the path of purification. And it is taught with virtue, concentration, and understanding as the foremost,

original: pamukhaṃ katvā desitopi. Etena sīlasamādhipaññāsu avasesabodhipakkhiyadhammānaṃ sabhāvato,
analyzed: pamukham katvā desitaḥ api etena sīla samādhi paññāsu avasesa bodhi pakkhiya dhammānam sabhāvato
translated: as the chief, in it. And by this it can be understood that the remaining ideas that are on the side of enlightenment are included in virtue, concentration, and understanding,

original: upakārato ca antogadhabhāvo dīpitoti veditabbaṃ. Atisaṅkhepadesitoyeva hoti sabhāvavibhāgādito
analyzed: upakārato ca antogadha bhāvaḥ dīpito ti veditabbam sa bhāva vibhāga āditaḥ
translated: both as their own individual essences and as their helpers. It is taught in too concise a form,

original: avibhāvitattā. Nālanti na pariyattaṃ na samatthaṃ. Sabbesanti nātisaṅkhepanātivitthārarucīnampi,
analyzed: a vibhāvita ttā na alanti na pariyattam na samattham sabbesanti na ati saṅkhepana ati vitthāra rucīnam pi
translated: because it is not analyzed as to individual essences, etc., and so it is not enough, not adequate. For all: for those who like a brief teaching and those who like an extensive teaching,

original: vipañcitaññuneyyānampi vā. Saṅkhepadesanā hi saṃkhittarucīnaṃ, ugghaṭitaññūnaṃyeva
analyzed: vā saṅkhepa desanā hi saṃkhitta rucīnam ugghaṭita ññūnam yeva
translated: or for those who understand from an extended teaching. For a brief teaching is helpful only for those who like a brief teaching and for those who understand from a brief teaching,

original: ca upakārāya hoti, na panitaresaṃ. Assa visuddhimaggassa. Pucchanaṭṭhena pañhā, kiriyā
analyzed: ca upakārāya hoti na panitaresam assa visuddhi maggassa pucchana ṭṭhena pañhā kiriyā
translated: but not for the others. Of this Path of Purification. A question is a query,

original: karaṇaṃ kammaṃ, pañhāva kammaṃ pañhākammaṃ, pucchanapayogo.
analyzed: karaṇam kammam pañhāva kammam pañhākammam pucchana payogaḥ
translated: an action is an act of doing, a question-act is a query-act, a query-usage.

original: Kiṃ sīlanti sarūpapucchā. Kenaṭṭhena sīlanti kena atthena sīlanti vuccati, “sīla”nti
analyzed: kim sīlanti sarūpa pucchā kena aṭṭhena sīlanti kena atthena sīlanti vuccati sīlanti
translated: What is virtue? is a question about individual essence. In what sense is it virtue? is a question about pre-eminence.

original: padaṃ kaṃ abhidheyyaṃ nissāya pavattanti attho. Tayidaṃ sīlaṃ sabhāvato, kiccato,
analyzed: padam kam abhidheyyam nissāya pavattanti tayidam sīlam sabhāvataḥ kiccataḥ
translated: What is the meaning of the word “basis”? It is the meaning of what is depended on for occurrence.

original: upaṭṭhānākārato, āsannakāraṇato ca kathaṃ jānitabbanti āha “kānassa lakkhaṇarasapaccupaṭṭhānapadaṭṭhānānī”ti.
analyzed: upaṭṭhāna ākārataḥ āsanna kāraṇataḥ ca katham jānitabbanti āha kānassa lakkhaṇa rasa paccupaṭṭhāna padaṭṭhānāni iti
translated: Now, how is virtue to be known as to characteristic, function, manifestation, and proximate cause? Hence he said: “What are its characteristic, function, manifestation, and proximate cause?”🔽The answer to the question “What is its benefit?” is that the benefit of practice is only in the visible here and now.

original: Paṭipatti nāma diṭṭhānisaṃse eva hotīti āha “kimānisaṃsa”nti. Katividhanti pabhedapucchā.
analyzed: paṭipatti nāma diṭṭha anisaṃse eva hoti iti āha
translated: The question “How many kinds is it?” is a question about its classes.🔽For the exposition of the individual essences of things classed is effected by way of the demonstration of the classes.

original: Vibhāgavantānaṃ hi sabhāvavibhāvanaṃ vibhāgadassanamukheneva hotīti. Vodānaṃ visuddhi.
analyzed: vibhāgavantānam hi sabhāva vibhāvanam vibhāga dassana mukhena iva hoti iti vodānam visuddhi
translated: Purification is cleansing.

original: Sā ca saṃkilesamalavimutti. Taṃ icchantena yasmā upāyakosallatthinā anupāyakosallaṃ
analyzed: sā ca tam icchantena yasmai
translated: And that is the liberation from the stain of defilement. Since one who wants that must know defilement as well as non-defilement, as non-skill in means,

original: viya saṃkileso jānitabboti āha “ko cassa saṃkileso”ti.🔽Tatrāti tasmiṃ, tassa vā pañhākammassa. Vissajjananti vivaraṇaṃ. Pucchito hi attho
analyzed: viya saṃkilesaḥ jānitabbo ti āha kaḥ cassa saṃkileso ti  tatra ati tasmin tassa vā pañhā kammassa vissajjananti vivaraṇam pucchitaḥ hi attho
translated: he said: “What is its defilement?”🔽In that, in that question, or in that question’s answer.🔽The answer is the explanation. For when a question is asked, the matter asked about remains as if hidden away in a closed fist because it has not been disclosed.

original: avibhāvitattā nigūḷho muṭṭhiyaṃ kato viya tiṭṭhati. Tassa vivaraṇaṃ vissajjanaṃ vibhūtabhāvakāraṇato.
analyzed: a vibhāvita ttā nigūḷhaḥ muṭṭhiyam kataḥ viya tiṭṭhati tassa vivaraṇam vissajjanam vibhūta bhāva kāraṇato
translated: The explanation of it is the answer, since it is the cause for making it manifest.

original: Pāṇātipātādīhīti ettha pāṇoti vohārato satto, paramatthato jīvitindriyaṃ. Tassa saraseneva
analyzed: pāṇa atipāta ādīhi iti ettha pāṇo ti vohārato satto paramatthataḥ jīvitindriyam tassa sarasena iva
translated: In the case of killing breathing things, etc., a breathing thing is a being in the ordinary sense of the word, but in the ultimate sense it is the life faculty.🔽The act of killing is the act of causing it to fall away from its continuity, which is the state of its falling away by itself.

original: patanasabhāvassa antare eva ativa pātanaṃ atipāto, saṇikaṃ patituṃ adatvā sīghaṃ
analyzed: patana sabhāvassa antare eva pātanam atipāto saṇikam patitum a datvā sīgham
translated: The meaning is that it is the act of causing it to fall away quickly, not slowly.

original: pātananti attho, atikkamma vā satthādīhi abhibhavitvā pātanaṃ atipāto, pāṇaghāto.
analyzed: pātanam ti atthaḥ atikkamma vā sattha ādīhi abhibhavitvā pātanam atipātaḥ pāṇaghāto
translated: Or the act of killing is the act of causing it to fall away by overcoming it with a weapon, etc.🔽The word “etc.” includes taking what is not given, and so on.

original: Ādisaddena adinnādānādiṃ saṅgaṇhāti. Tehi pāṇātipātādīhi dussīlyakammehi. Viramantassāti
analyzed: ādi saddena adinnādāna ādim saṅgaṇhāti tehi pāṇa atipāta ādīhi dussīlya kammehi viramantassa ati
translated: He refrains from the bad deeds of killing breathing things, etc.,🔽by refraining through undertaking and by refraining through avoiding what is risky.

original: samādānavirativasena, sampattavirativasena ca oramantassa. Vattapaṭipattinti upajjhāyavattādivattakaraṇaṃ.
analyzed: samādāna virati vasena sampatta virati vasena ca oram antassa vatta paṭipatti nti upajjhāya vatta ādi vatta karaṇam
translated: He practices the proper conduct, which is the conduct of duties such as the duties to a preceptor.

original: Cetanādayo dhammāti saṅkhepato vuttamatthaṃ pāḷivasena vibhajitvā dassetuṃ “vuttañheta”ntiādi
analyzed: cetanā ādayaḥ dhammā ti saṅkhepataḥ vuttam attham pāḷi vasena vibhajitvā dassetum vuttam hetat tiādi
translated: The meaning stated in brief in the words “volition, etc.,” is analyzed and illustrated by the passage from the text beginning, “It is said.”

original: vuttaṃ. Tattha cetayatīti cetanā, attanā sampayuttadhammehi saddhiṃ ārammaṇe abhisandahatīti
analyzed: vuttam tattha cetayati iti cetanā attanā sampayutta dhammehi saddhim ārammaṇe abhisandahati iti
translated: Herein, volition is that which wills. It is the impulsion of associated states towards the object.

original: attho. Cetanāya anukūlavaseneva hi taṃsampayuttā dhammā ārammaṇe pavattanti. Cetanā
analyzed: atthaḥ cetanāya anukūla vasena iva hi tad sampayuttāḥ dhammāḥ ārammaṇe pavattanti cetanā
translated: For the states associated with it occur in regard to the object in accordance with the direction of the volition.

original: kāmaṃ kusalattikasādhāraṇā, idha pana sīlacetanā adhippetāti katvā “kusalā”ti veditabbā.
analyzed: kāmam kusala ttika sādhāraṇā idha pana sīla cetanā adhippetā ati katvā kusalā ati veditabbā
translated: Although volition is common to all the profitable groups, here it should be understood as profitable only in the sense of the volition of virtue.

original: Cetasi niyuttaṃ cetasikaṃ, cittasampayuttanti attho. Cetanāya satipi cetasikatte
analyzed: cetasi niyuttam cetasikam citta sampayuttanti attho cetanāya sati pi cetasika tte
translated: “Mental” is that which is applied to the mind; the meaning is that it is associated with consciousness.

original: “cetanā sīla”nti visuṃ gahitattā tadaññameva viratianabhijjhādikaṃ cetasikaṃ sīlaṃ🔽daṭṭhabbaṃ gobalībaddañāyena. Saṃvaraṇaṃ saṃvaro. Yathā akusalā dhammā citte na otaranti,
analyzed: cetanā sīlanti visum gahita ttā tad aññam eva virati anabhijjhā ādikam cetasikam sīlam  daṭṭhabbam go balī baddañāyena saṃvaraṇam saṃvaraḥ yathā akusalāḥ dhammāḥ citte na otaranti
translated: Although there is volition, still, since volition is included separately as “volition is virtue,” the virtue that should be regarded as the mental state is the other states beginning with non-greed that are associated with consciousness.🔽It should be regarded as the virtue of restraint in the way that a cowherd uses his stick.🔽Restraint is the restraining. It is the prevention of unprofit- able things from entering the mind in such a way that they are suppressed.

original: tathā pidahanaṃ. Avītikkamo vītikkamassa paṭipakkhabhūtā avītikkamavasena pavattacittacetasikā.
analyzed: tathā pidahanam avītikkamaḥ vītikkamassa paṭipakkha bhūtā avītikkama vasena pavatta citta cetasikā
translated: Non-transgression is the consciousness and consciousness-concomitants that occur in the mode of non-transgression, which is the opposite of transgression.

original: Tattha cetanā sīlaṃ nāmātiādi yathāvuttassa suttapadassa vivaraṇaṃ. Viramantassa
analyzed: tattha cetanā sīlam nāma atiādi yathāvuttassa sutta padassa vivaraṇam viramantassa
translated: Herein, the words “The virtue called volition, etc.,” are a commentary on the words of the text, “The virtue that has been laid down by the Blessed One after Him who has made an end to vanity” .🔽“The volition of one who refrains” is the volition that is associated with the refraining and is the principal factor in it.

original: cetanāti viratisampayuttaṃ padhānabhūtaṃ cetanamāha. Pūrentassa cetanāti vattapaṭipattiāyūhinī.
analyzed: cetanā ati virati sampayuttam padhāna bhūtam cetanam āha pūrentassa cetanā ati vatta paṭipatti āyūhinī
translated: “The volition of one who fulfils” is the volition that is the principal factor in the practice of the way.

original: Viramantassa viratīti viratiyā padhānabhāvaṃ gahetvā vuttaṃ.
analyzed: viramantassa virati iti viratiyā padhāna bhāvam gahetvā vuttam
translated: “Cessation” is said by taking the pre-eminent position of the restraint.

original: Ettha hi yadā “tividhā, bhikkhave, kāyasañcetanā kusalaṃ kāyakamma”ntiādi vacanato
analyzed: ettha hi yadā tividhā bhikkhave kāya sañcetanā kusalam kāya kamma nti ādi vacanato
translated: For in this passage, by the words, “Monks, there are three kinds of bodily volitions, a skillful bodily action,” etc.,

original: pāṇātipātādīnaṃ paṭipakkhabhūtā tabbirativisiṭṭhā cetanā tathāpavattā padhānabhāvena🔽pāṇātipātādipaṭiviratisādhikā hoti, tadā taṃsampayuttā viratianabhijjhādayo ca cetanāpakkhikā🔽vā, abbohārikā vāti imamatthaṃ sandhāya cetanāsīlaṃ vuttaṃ. Yadā pana pāṇātipātādīhi🔽saṅkocaṃ āpajjantassa tato viramaṇākārena pavattamānā cetanāvisiṭṭhā virati, anabhijjhādayo
analyzed: pāṇātipāta ādīnam paṭipakkha bhūtā tad virati visiṭṭhā cetanā tathā pavattā padhāna bhāvena  pāṇātipāta ādi paṭivirati sādhikā hoti tadā tad sampayuttāḥ virati anabhijjhā ādayaḥ ca cetanā pakkhikā  vā abbohārikā vā ti imam attham sandhāya cetanā sīlam vuttam yadā pana pāṇa atipāta ādīhi  saṅkocam āpajjantassa tatas viramaṇa ākārena pavattamānā cetanā visiṭṭhā virati anabhijjhā ādayaḥ
translated: the volitions that are the opposite of killing living beings, etc., and that are the most excellent of them all, when they occur in such a way as to be pre-eminent,🔽they become the cause of the restraint from killing living beings, etc. Then the volitions associated with that restraint, such as non-greed, etc., are either the side of volition or the side of non-transgression. With this meaning in mind, the passage speaks of virtue as volition.

original: ca tattha tattha padhānabhāvena kiccasādhikā honti, tadā taṃsampayuttā cetanā viratiādipakkhikā🔽vā hoti, abbohārikā vāti imamatthaṃ sandhāya cetasikasīlaṃ vuttaṃ.
analyzed: ca tattha tattha padhāna bhāvena kicca sādhikāḥ honti tadā tad sampayuttā cetanā virati ādi pakkhikā 🔽vā hoti abbohārikā vā ti imam attham sandhāya cetasika sīlam vuttaṃ
translated: But when the volitions occur in the mode of refraining from killing living beings, etc., in one who has become scrupulous about killing living beings, etc., then the restraint is distinguished by the pre-eminence of those volitions, and non-greed, etc., become the cause of the function there. Then the volitions associated with that restraint are either the side of restraint, etc., or the side of non-transgression. With this meaning in mind, the passage speaks of virtue as mental volition.

original: Idāni sutte āgatanayena kusalakammapathavasena cetanācetasikasīlāni vibhajitvā dassetuṃ
analyzed: idāni sutte āgata nayena kusala kammapatha vasena cetanā cetasika sīlāni vibhajitvā dassetuṃ
translated: Now, in order to show the virtue of volition and of the associated states by way of the profitable courses of action in the way stated in the Suttas, he said, “And furthermore,” etc.

original: “apicā”tiādi vuttaṃ. Pajahantassāti samādānavasena “ito paṭṭhāya na karissāmī”ti🔽sampattavatthukānipi anajjhācaraṇena pajahantassa. Satta kammapathacetanāti pāṇātipātādipahānasādhikā
analyzed: api ca atiādi vuttam pajahantassa ati samādāna vasena itas paṭṭhāya na karissāmi iti  sampatta vatthukāni pi an ajjhācaraṇena pajahantassa satta kammapatha cetanā ati pāṇātipāta ādi pahāna sādhikā
translated: In the passage beginning “in one who is abandoning” , “in one who is abandoning” means in one who is not doing by way of undertaking thus “From now on I shall not do it” ,🔽and in one who is abandoning by not repeating what has been done.

original: paṭipāṭiyā satta kusalakammapathacetanā. Abhijjhādivasena yaṃ paradāragamanādi karīyati,
analyzed: paṭipāṭiyā satta kusala kamma patha cetanāḥ abhijjhā ādi vasena yam para dāra gamana ādi
translated: The seven courses of action as volition are the seven profitable courses of action as volition, which are the conditions for the abandoning of killing living things, etc.,🔽respectively.

original: tassa pahāyakā anabhijjhādayo sīlanti āha “cetasikaṃ sīlaṃ nāma anabhijjhā…pe… sammādiṭṭhidhammā”ti.
analyzed: tassa pahāyakāḥ anabhijjhā ādayaḥ sīlanti āha cetasikam sīlam nāma anabhijjhāpe sammādiṭṭhi dhammā ti
translated: The virtue of associated states is the non-greed, etc., which are the conditions for the abandoning of the misconduct of sense-desires, etc., that is done by way of greed, etc., and he said “The virtue called associated states is the states of non-greed, etc., right view” .

original: Yathā hi abhijjhābyāpādavasena micchācārapāṇātipātādayo karīyanti, evaṃ micchādiṭṭhivasenāpi
analyzed: yathā hi abhijjhā byāpāda vasena micchācāra pāṇa atipāta ādayaḥ evam micchādiṭṭhi vasena api
translated: For just as killing living things, etc., are done by way of greed and ill will, so too they are done by way of wrong view,🔽and for the purpose of seeing the face of one’s son, etc.

original: te puttamukhadassanādiatthaṃ karīyanti. Tesañca pajahanakā anabhijjhādayoti. Pātimokkhasaṃvaro
analyzed: te putta mukha dassana ādi attham tesam ca pajahanakāḥ anabhijjha ādayaḥ ti pātimokkha saṃvaro
translated: And the non-greed, etc., which are the conditions for the abandoning of those are the virtue of associated states.🔽The virtue of restraint by the Pāṭimokkha

original: cārittavārittavibhāgaṃ vinayapariyāpannaṃ sikkhāpadasīlaṃ. Satisaṃvaro manacchaṭṭhānaṃ
analyzed: cāritta vāritta vibhāgam vinaya pariyāpannam sikkhāpada sīlam sati saṃvaraḥ manaccha ṭṭhānam
translated: The restraint of mindfulness is the guarding of the doors of the six sense faculties.

original: indriyānaṃ ārakkhā, sā ca tathāpavattā satiyeva. Ñāṇasaṃvaro paññā. Khantisaṃvaro
analyzed: indriyānaṃ ārakkhā sā ca tathā pavattā satiyā iva ñāṇa saṃvaro paññā khanti saṃvaro
translated: And that is mindfulness itself occurring thus. The restraint of knowledge is understanding.🔽The restraint of patience is acquiescence.

original: adhivāsanā, sā ca tathāpavattā adosapadhānā khandhā, adoso eva vā. Vīriyasaṃvaro
analyzed: adhivāsanā sā ca tathā pavattā adosa padhānā khandhāḥ adosaḥ eva vā vīriya saṃvaro
translated: And that is the aggregates headed by non-hate occurring thus, or it is non-hate itself. The restraint of energy is energy.

original: kāmavitakkādīnaṃ vinodanavasena pavattaṃ vīriyaṃ. Pātimokkhasaṃvarasatisaṃvarādīsu
analyzed: kāma vitakka ādīnam vinodana vasena pavattam vīriyam pātimokkha saṃvara sati saṃvara ādīsu
translated: It is energy occurring as the arousing of energy in order to dispel the thoughts of sensual desire, etc.

original: yaṃ vattabbaṃ, taṃ parato āvi bhavissati.🔽Sotānīti taṇhādiṭṭhiavijjāduccaritaavasiṭṭhakilesasotāni. “Sotānaṃ saṃvaraṃ brūmī”ti
analyzed: yam vattabbam tam paratas bhavissati  sotāni iti taṇhā diṭṭhi avijjā duccarita avasiṭṭha kilesa sotāni sotānam saṃvaram brūmi iti
translated: What should be said about the restraint of the Pāṭimokkha, the restraint of mindfulness, etc., will be said later.🔽The “streams” are the defilements remaining after the greed, etc., of the ear-opening have been abandoned.🔽After saying “I declare the restraint of the streams,”

original: vatvā “paññāyete pidhiyyare”ti vacanena sotānaṃ saṃvaro pidahanaṃ samucchedanaṃ ñāṇanti viññāyati.
analyzed: vatvā paññāyete pidhiyyare ti vacanena sotānam saṃvaraḥ pidahanam samucchedanam ñāṇanti viññāyati
translated: the words “By wisdom they are stopped” show that the restraint of the streams is the stopping, the cutting off, of the streams by wisdom.🔽The “reason” is the reason why the Blessed One said that.

original: Idamatthikataṃ manasi katvā yena ñāṇena yoniso paccavekkhitvā paccayā paṭisevīyanti.
analyzed: manasi katvā yena ñāṇena yonisas paccavekkhitvā paccayā paṭisevīyanti
translated: Having given attention to the reason, the knowledge by means of which one uses requisites after reviewing them wisely is the restraint of the reason.

original: Taṃ paccayapaṭisevanampi ñāṇasabhāvattā ettheva ñāṇasaṃvare eva samodhānaṃ saṅgahaṃ
analyzed: tam paccaya paṭisevanam pi ñāṇa sabhāvattā ettha iva ñāṇa saṃvare eva samodhānam saṅgaham
translated: And the toleration of the conditions that give rise to it is included here in the virtue of knowledge because it is of the nature of knowledge.

original: gacchati. Khamati adhivāsetīti khamo. Uppannanti tasmiṃ tasmiṃ ārammaṇe jātaṃ nibbattaṃ.🔽Kāmavitakkanti kāmūpasaṃhitaṃ vitakkaṃ. Nādhivāsetīti cittaṃ āropetvā abbhantare
analyzed: gacchati khamati adhivāseti iti khamaḥ uppannanti tasmim tasmim ārammaṇe jātam nibbattam  kāma vitakkanti kāma upasaṃhitam vitakkam na adhivāseti iti cittam āropetvā abbhantare
translated: He is tolerant : khamo = khamati adhivāseti. Of arisen : uppannā = uppannā nibbatta.

original: na vāseti. Ājīvapārisuddhipīti buddhapaṭikuṭṭhaṃ micchājīvaṃ pahāya anavajjena paccayapariyesanena
analyzed: na vāseti ājīva pārisuddhi pīti buddha paṭikuṭṭham micchājīvam pahāya anavajjena paccaya pariyesanena
translated: Of applied thought : vitakka = vitakkamānassa. Of sensual desire : kāma = kāmavitakka. He does not tolerate : na adhivāseti = cittaṃ āropetvā abbhantare na vāseti.

original: sijjhanakaṃ ājīvapārisuddhisīlampi ettheva vīriyasaṃvare eva samodhānaṃ gacchati
analyzed: sijjhanakam ājīva pārisuddhi sīlam pi etthā iva vīriya saṃvare eva samodhānam gacchati
translated: And the virtue of purity of livelihood is included here in the virtue of energy because it is accomplished by energy.

original: vīriyasādhanattā. Ettha ca yathā ñāṇaṃ taṇhādisotānaṃ pavattinivāraṇato pidahanaṭṭhena
analyzed: vīriya sādhana ttā ettha ca yathā ñāṇam taṇhā ādi sotānam pavatti nivāraṇataḥ pidahana ṭṭhena
translated: And here, just as knowledge is virtue in the sense of covering because it covers by preventing the occurrence of craving, etc.,

original: saṃvaraṇato saṃvaro ca, parato pavattanakaguṇānaṃ ādhārādibhāvato sīlanaṭṭhena sīlaṃ,
analyzed: saṃvaraṇato saṃvaro ca paratas pavattanaka guṇānaṃ ādhāra ādi bhāvato sīlana ṭṭhena sīlam
translated: and in the sense of wearing because it is the basis, etc., for the qualities that occur in one who wears it,

original: evaṃ khanti anadhivāsanena uppajjanakakilesānaṃ adhivāsanena saṃvaraṇato saṃvaro
analyzed: evam anadhivāsanena uppajjanaka kilesānam adhivāsanena saṃvaraṇataḥ saṃvaraḥ
translated: so too patience is virtue in the sense of covering because it covers by tolerating arisen defilements instead of allowing them to occur,🔽and in the sense of wearing because it is the basis, etc., for the qualities that occur in one who wears it.

original: ca, khamanahetu uppajjanakaguṇānaṃ ādhārādibhāvato sīlanaṭṭhena sīlaṃ, vīriyaṃ vinodetabbānaṃ🔽pāpadhammānaṃ vinodanena saṃvaraṇato saṃvaro ca, vinodanahetu uppajjanakaguṇānaṃ🔽ādhārādibhāvato sīlanaṭṭhena sīlanti veditabbaṃ. Yathā pana pātimokkhasīlādi tassa🔽tassa pāpadhammassa pavattituṃ appadānavasena saṃvaraṇaṃ pidahanaṃ, taṃ upādāya saṃvaro,🔽evaṃ asamādinnasīlassa āgatavatthuto viramaṇampīti āha “yā ca pāpabhīrukānaṃ…pe…🔽saṃvarasīlanti veditabba”nti. Na vītikkamati etenāti avītikkamo. Tathāpavatto kusalacittuppādo.
analyzed: ca khamana hetu uppajjanaka guṇānam ādhāra ādi bhāvataḥ sīlana ṭṭhena sīlam vīriyam vinodetabbānam  pāpa dhammānam vinodanena saṃvaraṇataḥ saṃvaro ca vinodana hetu uppajjanaka guṇānam  ādhāra ādi bhāvataḥ sīlana ṭṭhena sīlanti veditabbam yathā pana pātimokkha sīla ādi tassa  tassa pāpa dhammassa pavattitum appadāna vasena saṃvaraṇam pidahanam tam upādāya saṃvaro  evam asamādinna sīlassa āgata vatthutaḥ viramaṇam pi iti āha yā ca  saṃvara sīlanti veditabbanti na vītikkamati etena ati a vītikkamaḥ tathā pavattaḥ kusala cittuppādo
translated: and it is virtue in the sense of composing because it is the support, etc., for the special qualities that arise owing to the cause of the restraint. And it is virtue in the sense of composing because it is the support, etc., for the special qualities that arise owing to the cause of the restraint.🔽And it is virtue in the sense of composing because it is the support, etc., for the special qualities that arise owing to the cause of the restraint.🔽But just as virtue consisting in the Pātimokkha restraint is restraint by preventing the arising of misconduct of the various kinds, so too is abstinence from the offences given in the training precepts, which is the virtue of one who has undertaken the training precepts.🔽That is why it is said: restraint in the sense of preventing the arising of misconduct of the various kinds” .🔽And just as virtue consisting in the Pātimokkha restraint is restraint by preventing the arising of the

original: 7. Avasesesu pana pañhesu. Samādhānaṃ saṇṭhapanaṃ. Dussīlyavasena hi pavattā kāyakammādayo
analyzed: avasesesu pana pañhesu samādhānam saṇṭhapanam dussīlya vasena hi pavattā kāya kamma ādayo
translated: and it is virtue in the sense of composing because it is the support, etc., for the special qualities that arise owing to the cause of the restraint. And it is abstinence in the sense of composing because it is the support, etc., for the special qualities that arise owing to the cause of the restraint. And it is virtue in the sense of composing because it is the support, etc., for the special qualities that arise owing to the cause of the restraint. And it is abstinence in the sense of composing because it is the support, etc., for the special qualities that arise owing to the cause of the restraint. And it is virtue in the sense of composing because it is the support, etc., for the special qualities that arise owing to the cause of the restraint. But just as the virtue of the Pātimokkha restraint is abstinence in the sense of preventing the occurrence of any of the various kinds of states that should not be done, so too is the abstinence of one who has not undertaken the Pātimokkha restraint from the things that are the province of his abstinence. That is why “abstinence from such and such in one who is afraid of wrongdoing” is called “virtue of abstinence” . He does not transgress by means of this, thus it is non-transgression . It is a profitable consciousness that occurs in such a way. But in the case of the remaining questions, the meaning should be understood as follows. It is the establishment, the setting up, of the mind, because bodily actions, etc., that occur through lack of virtue

original: sampati, āyatiñca ahitadukkhāvahā, na sammā ṭhapitāti asaṇṭhapitā vippakiṇṇā visaṭā
analyzed: sampati āyatiñca ahita dukkha āvahā na sammā ṭhapitā ati a saṇṭhapitā vippakiṇṇā visaṭā
translated: are the cause of one’s own affliction, of others’ affliction, and of the affliction of both, and they entail harm and suffering for a long time, and they are not rightly set up, thus they are not established , scattered, dissipated,

original: ca nāma honti, susīlyavasena pana pavattā tabbipariyāyato saṇṭhapitā avippakiṇṇā🔽avisaṭā ca nāma honti yathā taṃ okkhittacakkhutā abāhuppacālanādi. Tenāha “kāyakammādīnaṃ
analyzed: ca nāma honti su sīlya vasena pana pavattā tad bipariyāyato saṇṭhapitā a vippakiṇṇā  ca nāma honti yathā tam okkhitta cakkhu tā a bāhu pacālana ādi tena āha kāya kamma ādīnam
translated: But when they occur through good virtue, they are called “collected” in the opposite sense, “not scattered,”

original: susīlyavasena avippakiṇṇatāti attho”ti. Etena samādhikiccato sīlanaṃ viseseti. Tassa
analyzed: su sīlya vasena a vippakiṇṇa tā ti attho ti etena samādhi kiccato sīlanam viseseti tassa
translated: “not diffused,” “not ramified,” as when one keeps one’s eyes down, does not prattle idly, and so on. Hence it is said with reference to this: “The meaning is that they are not scattered through good virtue” . This distinguishes the virtue consisting in purification of bodily action, etc., from that consisting in concentration,

original: hi samādhānaṃ sampayuttadhammānaṃ avikkhepahetutā. Idaṃ kāyakammādīnaṃ saṇṭhapanaṃ
analyzed: hi samādhānam sampayutta dhammānam avikkhepa hetu tā idam kāya kamma ādīnam saṇṭhapanam
translated: for the latter’s function of concentrating is a cause of non-distraction in the associated states. This is the “collecting” of bodily action, etc.,

original: saṃyamanaṃ. Upadhāraṇaṃ adhiṭṭhānaṃ mūlabhāvo. Tathā hissa ādicaraṇādibhāvo vutto.
analyzed: saṃyamanam upadhāraṇam adhiṭṭhānam mūla bhāvo tathā hissa ādi caraṇa ādi bhāvo vutto
translated: the “restraining,” the “guiding,” the “controlling,” the “founding,” the “rooting” of bodily action, etc. For that is called the “beginning,” and so on.

original: Tena pathavīdhātukiccato sīlanaṃ visesitaṃ hoti. Sā hi sahajātarūpadhammānaṃ sandhāraṇavasena
analyzed: tena pathavī dhātu kiccato sīlanam visesitam hoti sā hi sahajāta rūpa dhammānam sandhāraṇa vasena
translated: So the virtue consisting in purification of bodily action, etc., is distinguished from that consisting in the element of earth. For the latter occurs as the support of conascent material states,

original: pavattati. Idaṃ pana anavajjadhammānaṃ mūlādhiṭṭhānabhāvena. Tenāha “kusalānaṃ dhammāna”ntiādi.🔽Tattha kusaladhammā nāma sapubbabhāgā mahaggatānuttarā dhammā. Aññe pana ācariyā.
analyzed: pavattati idam pana anavajja dhammānam mūla adhiṭṭhāna bhāvena tena āha kusalānam dhammānam tiādi 🔽tattha kusala dhammāḥ nāma sa pubbabhāgāḥ mahaggata anuttarāḥ dhammāḥ aññe pana ācariyā
translated: but this is the foundation of the root of blameless states. Hence it is said with reference to this: “The profitable states” , and so on.🔽Herein, the profitable states are the states of the three paths and of fruition. But other teachers say that the profitable states are the states of the three paths and of the first three fruitions.

original: Siraṭṭhoti yathā sirasi chinne sabbo attabhāvo vinassati, evaṃ sīle bhinne sabbaṃ🔽guṇasarīraṃ vinassati. Tasmā tassa uttamaṅgaṭṭho sīlaṭṭho. “Siro sīsa”nti vā vattabbe🔽niruttinayena “sīla”nti vuttanti adhippāyo. Sītalaṭṭho pariḷāhavūpasamanaṭṭho. Tena
analyzed: siraṭṭhaḥ ti yathā sirasi chinne sabbaḥ atta bhāvaḥ vinassati evam sīle bhinne sabbam  guṇa sarīram vinassati tasmā tassa uttamaṅga aṭṭho sīla aṭṭho vā vattabbe  nirutti nayena sīlanti vuttanti adhippāyo sīta laṭṭho pariḷāha vūpasamana ṭṭho tena
translated: Head-like: just as when the head is cut off, the whole physical frame is ruined, so too when virtue is broken, the whole

original: ta-kārassa lopaṃ katvā niruttinayeneva “sīla”nti vuttanti dasseti. Tathā hidaṃ payogasampāditaṃ
analyzed: takārassa lopam katvā nirutti nayena iva sīlam ti vuttan ti dasseti tathā hi idam payoga sampāditam
translated: body of special qualities is ruined. That is why it has the meaning of head. Or alternatively, what should be said as “head- sīsa” is said as “sīla” by the method of etymology. The meaning of coolness: the meaning of allaying of fever. By that he shows that the letter ta has been dropped and that it is said as “sīla” by the method of etymology. For it is thus prepared by use

original: sabbakilesapariḷāhavūpasamakaraṃ hoti. Evamādināti ādi-saddena sayanti akusalā etasmiṃ🔽sati apaviṭṭhā hontīti sīlaṃ, supanti vā tena vihatussāhāni sabbaduccaritānīti sīlaṃ,
analyzed: sabba kilesa pariḷāha vūpasama karam hoti evamādinā iti ādi saddena sayanti akusalāḥ etasmin  sati apaviṭṭhāḥ honti iti sīlam supanti vā tena vihatussāhāni sabba duccaritāni iti sīlam
translated: that it is the allayer of all defilement-fever. So too, etc.: the word “etc.” should be understood to include such explanations as this:

original: sabbesaṃ vā kusaladhammānaṃ pavesārahasālāti sīlanti evamādīnaṃ saṅgaho daṭṭhabbo.
analyzed: sabbesam vā kusala dhammānam sīlam ti evamādīnam saṅgahaḥ daṭṭhabbo
translated: They lie down in it, that is, unwholesome states lie down in it, having entered it, thus it is virtue ; or they sleep in it, having destroyed the fever of striving, thus it is virtue ; or it is the royal road for the entry of all profitable states, thus it is virtue .

original: 8. “Sīlanaṭṭhena sīla”nti pubbe saddatthuddhārena pakāsitopi bhāvattho evāti āha
analyzed: sīlana ṭṭhena sīlanti pubbe saddattha uddhārena pakāsitaḥ api bhāvatthaḥ eva ati āha
translated: “It is virtue in the sense of burning up” : although this meaning has already been given in the explanation of the word’s derivation, still it is mentioned again as a meaning in the sense of a state.

original: “sīlanaṃ lakkhaṇaṃ tassā”ti. Na hi tassa cetanādibhedabhinnassa anavasesato saṅgāhako🔽tato añño attho atthi, yo lakkhaṇabhāvena vucceyya. Nanu ca anekabhedasaṅgāhakaṃ
analyzed: sīlanam lakkhaṇam tassa ati na hi tassa cetanā ādi bheda bhinnassa anavasesataḥ saṅgāhako  tatas aññaḥ atthaḥ atthi yaḥ lakkhaṇa bhāvena vucceyya nanu ca aneka bheda saṅgāhakam
translated: But has not the general characteristic of the formed, namely, the three characteristics beginning with that of the formed, the function of classing the various divisions?🔽So why is it said that there is no other meaning than that which is classed under the various divisions of volition, etc., that could be called its characteristic?🔽The intention in saying that is this: the general characteristic of the formed, namely, the three characteristics beginning with that of the formed, is not a characteristic of the formed that is peculiar to it and not shared by anything else, like the eye base, etc.,

original: sāmaññalakkhaṇaṃ nāma siyā, na visesalakkhaṇanti anuyogaṃ manasi katvā āha “sanidassanattaṃ
analyzed: sāmañña lakkhaṇam nāma siyā na visesa lakkhaṇan ti anuyogam manasi katvā āha sa nidassana ttam
translated: but rather it is a characteristic that is shared by many things, like the characteristic of being a formation, etc.

original: rūpassa, yathā bhinnassanekadhā”ti.
analyzed: rūpassa yathā bhinnassa anekadhā ati
translated: So it is said in the Paṭṭhāna: “The formed is the general basis for the three characteristics” .

original: Yathā hi nīlādivasena anekabhedabhinnassāpi rūpāyatanassa sanidassanattaṃ visesalakkhaṇaṃ🔽tadaññadhammāsādhāraṇato. Na aniccatādi viya, ruppanaṃ viya vā sāmaññalakkhaṇaṃ,🔽evamidhāpi daṭṭhabbaṃ. Kiṃ panetaṃ sanidassanattaṃ nāma? Daṭṭhabbatā cakkhuviññāṇassa
analyzed: yathā hi nīla ādi vasena aneka bheda bhinnassa api rūpa āyatanassa visesa lakkhaṇam  tad añña dhamma asādhāraṇataḥ na anicca tā ādi viya ruppanam viya vā sāmañña lakkhaṇam  evam idha api daṭṭhabbam kim pana etam sa nidassana ttam nāma daṭṭhabba tā cakkhu viññāṇassa
translated: But the characteristic of being visible, etc., is a characteristic of the visible-data base, etc., that is peculiar to it and not shared by anything else, like the eye base, etc.🔽So it is said in the Paṭṭhāna: “The eye base is the particular basis for the eye-consciousness element and for the states associated therewith” .🔽So too, the characteristic of being visible, etc., should be regarded as the characteristic of the visible-data base, etc., that is peculiar to it and not shared by anything else, like the eye base, etc.🔽But what is this “visibility,” etc.? It is the state of being visible, etc.,🔽the state of being the domain of the eye-consciousness, etc.

original: gocarabhāvo. Tassa pana rūpāyatanato anaññattepi aññehi dhammehi rūpāyatanaṃ visesetuṃ
analyzed: gocara bhāvo tassa pana rūpa āyatanataḥ anaññatte pi aññehi dhammehi rūpa āyatanam visesetuṃ
translated: But although this is not different from the visible-data base, etc., it is nevertheless said to be a characteristic that is peculiar to it and not shared by anything else, in order to distinguish the visible-data base, etc., from other things.

original: aññaṃ viya katvā saha nidassanena sanidassananti vuccati. Dhammasabhāvasāmaññena
analyzed: aññam viya katvā saha nidassanena sa nidassanan ti vuccati dhamma sabhāva sāmaññena
translated: It is called “with impingement” because it is as if it were made different by the demonstration.🔽For the individual essence of states is unified by their common characteristics,

original: hi ekībhūtesu dhammesu yo nānattakaro sabhāvo, so aññaṃ viya katvā upacarituṃ yutto.
analyzed: hi ekībhūtesu dhammesu yaḥ nānatta karaḥ sabhāvaḥ so aññam viya katvā upacaritum yuttaḥ
translated: but their individual essences, which make them different, are fit to be treated as if they were made different.🔽For thus there is an understanding of the difference in meaning.

original: Evaṃ hi atthavisesāvabodho hotīti. Atha vā “saha nidassanenā”ti ettha tabbhāvattho
analyzed: evam hi attha visesa avabodhaḥ hoti iti atha vā saha nidassanena ati ettha tad bhāva atthaḥ
translated: Or alternatively, in the phrase “with impingement” the word saha has the meaning of “in the nature of,”

original: saha-saddo yathā nandirāgasahagatāti.
analyzed: yathā nandi rāga sahagatā ti
translated: like the word saha in the passage, “United with joy” (S V 189).

original: Dussīlyaviddhaṃsanarasanti kāyikaasaṃvarādibhedassa dussīlyassa vidhamanakiccaṃ.
analyzed: kāyika asaṃvara ādi bhedassa dussīlyassa vidhamana kiccam
translated: The meaning of “destroying unvirtuousness” is the function of destroying unvirtuousness classed as bodily restraint, etc.🔽The meaning of “blameless” is the meaning of “faultless.” It is the cause of the attainment of excellence that is not to be blamed, or it is the cause of the attainment of the opposite of what is blameworthy.

original: Anavajjarasanti agārayhasampattikaṃ agarahitabbabhāvena sampajjanakaṃ, avajjapaṭipakkhabhāvena🔽vā sampajjanakaṃ. Lakkhaṇādīsūti lakkhaṇarasādīsu vuccamānesu kiccameva, sampatti
analyzed: anavajja rasanti agārayha sampattikam avajja paṭipakkha bhāvena  vā sampad janakam lakkhaṇa ādīsu iti lakkhaṇa rasa ādīsu vuccamānesu kiccam eva sampatti
translated: Or the meaning of “faultless” is the meaning of “blameless.”🔽The meaning of “function” is the meaning of “efficacy,”🔽or the meaning of “excellence,” when the characteristic, etc., are spoken of. The intention is that it is not the meaning of “taste” as the base consisting of taste, etc.

original: vā rasoti vuccati, na rasāyatanarasādīti adhippāyo. Keci pana “kiccamevā”ti avadhāraṇaṃ
analyzed: vā rasaḥ ti vuccati na rasa āyatana rasa ādi iti adhippāyaḥ keci pana kiccam eva ati avadhāraṇam
translated: But some say that the word “eva” is a restriction

original: tassa itararasato balavabhāvadassanatthanti vadanti, taṃ tesaṃ matimattaṃ, kiccameva,
analyzed: tassa itara rasataḥ balava bhāva dassana attham vadanti tam tesam matimattam kiccam eva
translated: They say that it is stated in this way in order to show the superiority of the other two. But that is mere opinion.

original: sampatti eva vā rasoti imassa atthassa adhippetattā.
analyzed: sampatti eva vā rasaḥ ti imassa atthassa adhippetattā
translated: For the meaning intended is “the excellence itself is the taste.”🔽“It is manifested as purity”: it is manifested as the pure state of the body, etc.

original: Soceyyapaccupaṭṭhānanti kāyādīhi sucibhāvena paccupaṭṭhāti. Gahaṇabhāvanti gahetabbabhāvaṃ.
analyzed: soceyya paccupaṭṭhānanti kāya ādīhi suci bhāvena paccupaṭṭhāti gahaṇa bhāvanti gahetabba bhāvam
translated: “It is to be developed by being taken up”: it is to be developed by being taken up.

original: Tena upaṭṭhānākāraṭṭhena paccupaṭṭhānaṃ vuttaṃ, phalaṭṭhena pana avippaṭisārapaccupaṭṭhānaṃ,
analyzed: tena upaṭṭhāna ākāra aṭṭhena paccupaṭṭhānam vuttam phala aṭṭhena pana a vippaṭisāra paccupaṭṭhānam
translated: By this he shows the manifestation of virtue as the mode of appearance. But as the fruit, it is manifested as non-remorse,

original: samādhipaccupaṭṭhānaṃ vā. Sīlaṃ hi sampatiyeva avippaṭisāraṃ paccupaṭṭhāpeti, paramparāya
analyzed: samādhi paccupaṭṭhānam vā sīlam hi sampatiyā iva a vippaṭisāram paccupaṭṭhāpeti paramparāya
translated: or as concentration. For virtue manifests non-remorse, and non-remorse manifests concentration.

original: samādhiṃ. Imassa pana ānisaṃsaphalassa ānisaṃsakathāyaṃ vakkhamānattā idha aggahaṇaṃ
analyzed: samādhim imassa pana ānisaṃsa phalassa ānisaṃsa kathā ayam vakkhamāna ttā idha aggahaṇam
translated: But since the fruit of virtue, which is the fruit of human effort, will be discussed in the section on the benefits of virtue, it is not mentioned here.

original: daṭṭhabbaṃ. Keci pana phalassa anicchitattā idha aggahaṇanti vadanti, tadayuttaṃ
analyzed: daṭṭhabbam keci pana phalassa an icchita ttā idha aggahaṇam ti vadanti tat ayuttam
translated: But some say that it is not mentioned here because the fruit is not intended. That is incorrect,

original: phalassa anekavidhattā, lokiyādisīlassāpi vibhajiyamānattā. Tathā hi vakkhati “nissitānissitavasenā”tiādi.
analyzed: phalassa anekavidha ttā lokiya ādi sīlassa api vibhajiyamāna ttā tathā hi vakkhati nissita a nissita vasena atiādi
translated: because the fruit is of many kinds, and because mundane virtue, etc., are also classified. For he says below: “According to whether it is related to the supramundane or not, etc.” .

original: Yathā pathavīdhātuyā kammādi dūrakāraṇaṃ, sesabhūtattayaṃ āsannakāraṇaṃ, yathā ca🔽vatthassa tantavāyaturivemasalākādi dūrakāraṇaṃ, tantavo āsannakāraṇaṃ, evaṃ sīlassa🔽saddhammassavanādi dūrakāraṇaṃ, hiriottappamassa āsannakāraṇanti dassento āha “hirottappañca
analyzed: yathā kamma ādi dūra kāraṇam āsanna kāraṇam yathā ca  vatthassa dūra kāraṇam tantavaḥ āsanna kāraṇam evam sīlassa  saddhamma ssavana ādi dūra kāraṇam hiri uttappam assa āsanna kāraṇan ti dassentaḥ āha hirottappam ca
translated: and as the warp and woof are a remote cause of the cloth, and the shuttle a proximate cause,🔽so the hearing of the good Dhamma is a remote cause of virtue, and shame and moral dread are a proximate cause.

original: panā”tiādi. Hirottappe hītiādi tassa āsannakāraṇabhāvasādhanaṃ. Tattha uppajjati
analyzed: pana atiādi hirottappe hi itiādi tassa āsanna kāraṇa bhāva sādhanam tattha uppajjati
translated: The passage beginning with the words “And shame and moral dread” shows this. The passage beginning with the words “In one who is possessed of shame and moral dread” proves that shame and moral dread are a proximate cause.

original: samādānavasena, tiṭṭhati avītikkamavasenāti veditabbaṃ.
analyzed: samādāna vasena tiṭṭhati avītikkama vasena āti veditabbam
translated: It should be understood that shame arises through the undertaking of virtue, and that it endures through the non-transgression of virtue.

original: Sīlānisaṃsakathāvaṇṇanā
analyzed: sīla nisaṃsa kathā vaṇṇanā
translated: The explanation of the section on the benefits of virtue.

original: 9. Avippaṭisārādīti ettha vippaṭisārapaṭipakkho kusalacittuppādo avippaṭisāro. So🔽pana visesato “lābhā vata me, suladdhaṃ vata me, yassa me suparisuddhaṃ sīla”nti
analyzed: a vippaṭisāra ādi iti ettha vippaṭisāra paṭipakkho kusala cittuppādaḥ a vippaṭisāraḥ so  pana visesato lābhāḥ vata me su laddham vata me yassa me su parisuddham sīlanti
translated: Non-remorse, etc.: remorse is the opposite of non-remorse. Non-remorse is the arising of wholesome consciousness.🔽But it should be understood that it occurs specifically through the reviewing of one’s own virtue in this way: “How fortunate I am, how successful I am, in that my virtue is so pure.”

original: attano sīlassa paccavekkhaṇavasena pavattoti veditabbo. Ādi-saddena pāmojjabhogasampattikittisaddādiṃ
analyzed: attano sīlassa paccavekkhaṇa vasena pavatto ti veditabbaḥ ādi saddena pāmojja bhoga sampatti kitti sadda ādim
translated: The word “etc.” in the text includes the attainment of joy, happiness, fame, and renown.

original: saṅgaṇhāti. Avippaṭisāratthānīti avippaṭisārappayojanāni. Kusalānīti anavajjāni.
analyzed: saṅgaṇhāti a vippaṭisāra atthāni iti a vippaṭisāra ppayojanāni kusalāni iti anavajjāni
translated: He gathers them. Are conducive to non-remorse: have non-remorse as their purpose. Are profitable: are blameless.

original: Avippaṭisārānisaṃsānīti avippaṭisāruddayāni. Etena avippaṭisāro nāma sīlassa uddayamattaṃ,
analyzed: avippaṭisāra anisaṃsāni iti avippaṭisāra uddayāni etena avippaṭisāraḥ nāma sīlassa uddaya mattam
translated: Have non-remorse as their fruit: have non-remorse as their outcome. By this he shows that non-remorse is merely the outcome of virtue,

original: saṃvaḍḍhitassa rukkhassa chāyāpupphasadisaṃ. Añño eva panānena nipphādetabbo samādhiādiguṇoti dasseti.
analyzed: saṃvaḍḍhitassa rukkhassa chāyā puppha sadisam aññaḥ eva pana anena nipphādetabbo samādhi ādi guṇaḥ ti dasseti
translated: like the shade and flowers of a tree that has been nourished. But it is a special quality called concentration, etc., that has to be produced by it.🔽For one who has virtue: for one who has perfected his virtue by making it quite pure and complete.🔽By that same virtue: by that same perfected virtue. The reason for heedfulness: the cause for heedfulness. A mass of sensual desires: a collection of sensual desires.

original: Sīlavato sīlasampadāyāti parisuddhaṃ paripuṇṇaṃ katvā sīlassa sampādanena sīlavato,🔽tāya eva sīlasampadāya. Appamādādhikaraṇanti appamādakāraṇā. Bhogakkhandhanti bhogarāsiṃ.🔽Kalyāṇo kittisaddo abbhuggacchatīti “itipi sīlavā, itipi kalyāṇadhammo”ti sundaro
analyzed: sīlavataḥ sīla sampadāya ati parisuddham paripuṇṇam katvā sīlassa sampādanena sīlavataḥ  tāya eva sīla sampadāya appamāda adhikaraṇanti appamāda kāraṇā bhoga kkhandhanti bhoga rāsim  kalyāṇaḥ kitti saddaḥ abbhuggacchati iti itipi sīlavā itipi kalyāṇa dhammaḥ ti sundaraḥ
translated: A good report runs: a good report,

original: thutighoso uṭṭhahati, lokaṃ pattharati. Visāradoti attani kiñci garahitabbaṃ upavaditabbaṃ
analyzed: thuti ghosaḥ uṭṭhahati lokam pattharati visāra do ti attani kiñci garahitabbam upavaditabbam
translated: a praise-worthy report, a report of what is good, a report of what is proper, a report of what is desirable, a report of what is lovely, a report of what is beautiful, a report of what is fair, a report of what is excellent, a report of what is noble, a report of what is sublime, a report of what is fine, a report of what is good, a report of what is good and proper, a report of what is good and lovely, a report of what is good and beautiful, a report of what is good and fair, a report of what is good and excellent, a report of what is good and noble, a report of what is good and sublime, a report of what is good and fine, a report of what is good and good, a report of what is good and good and proper, a report of what is good and good and lovely, a report of what is good and good and beautiful, a report of what is good and good and fair, a report of what is good and good and excellent, a report of what is good and good and noble, a report of what is good and good and sublime, a report of what is good and good and fine, a report of what is good and good and good, a report of what is good and good and good and proper, a report of what is good and good and good and lovely, a report of what is good and good and good and beautiful, a report of what is good and good and good and fair, a report of what is good and good and good and excellent, a report of what is good and good and good and noble, a report of what is good

original: apassanto vigatasārajjo nibbhayo. Amaṅkubhūtoti avilakkho. Asammūḷhoti “akataṃ vata🔽me kalyāṇa”ntiādinā vippaṭisārābhāvato, kusalakammādīnaṃyeva ca tadā upaṭṭhānato🔽amūḷho pasannamānaso eva kālaṃkaroti. Kāyassa bhedāti upādinnakkhandhapariccāgā,
analyzed: a passantaḥ vigata sārajjaḥ nibbhayaḥ a maṅku bhūtaḥ ti avilakkhaḥ a sammūḷhaḥ ti akatam vata  me vippaṭisāra abhāvato ca tadā upaṭṭhānato  amūḍhaḥ pasanna mānasaḥ eva kālaṃkaroti kāyassa bhedā ati upādinna kkhandha pariccāgā
translated: and he is free from anxiety, free from fear,🔽and he does not become confused.🔽He dies unconfused because he has no regrets, thinking, “I have not done what is bad,” and so on, and because only wholesome states present themselves to his mind.🔽He dies with a serene mind.🔽With the breakup of the body, after death,

original: jīvitindriyassa upacchedā. Paraṃ maraṇāti cutito uddhaṃ. Sugatinti sundaraṃ gatiṃ.
analyzed: jīvitindriyassa param cutitaḥ sundaram gatim
translated: and he is free from agitation, free from fear, and free from trembling. He is not confused: he is not confused about what he has done, thinking, “I have not done what is good” and so on. He is not confused because only wholesome kamma appears to him at that time. He dies with a serene mind. With the breakup of the body, after death: with the giving up of the clung-to aggregates, with the termination of the life faculty. He reappears in a happy destiny, in the heavenly world: he goes to a good destiny, to a heavenly world.

original: Tena manussagatipi saṅgayhati. Sagganti devagatiṃ. Sā hi rūpādīhi visayehi suṭṭhu
analyzed: tena manussa gati pi deva gatim sā hi rūpa ādīhi visayehi suṭṭhu
translated: By this he includes the human destiny as well. The heavenly world is the divine destiny. It is called “heavenly” because it is a good world,

original: aggoti saggo, lokiyati ettha uḷāraṃ puññaphalanti lokoti ca vuccati.
analyzed: aggo ti saggaḥ lokiyati ettha uḷāram puñña phalanti ca vuccati
translated: and it is called “world” because it is a lofty world of the fruit of abundant merit.

original: Ākaṅkheyya ceti yadi iccheyya. Piyo ca assanti piyāyitabbo piyacakkhūhi passitabbo
analyzed: ākaṅkheyya ca iti yadi iccheyya piyaḥ ca assanti piyāyitabbo piya cakkhūhi passitabbo
translated: If he should wish: if he should desire. He would be dear and beloved: he would be lovable, to be seen with love,

original: pemaniyo bhaveyyanti attho. Manāpoti sabrahmacārīnaṃ manavaḍḍhanako, tesaṃ vā manena
analyzed: pemaniyaḥ bhaveyyanti atthaḥ manāpā iti sabrahmacārīnam tesam vā manena
translated: to be desired, is the meaning. He would be pleasing: he would be a promoter of the minds of his fellow brahma-farers, or he would be pleasing to their minds,

original: pattabbo, mettacittena pharitabboti vuttaṃ hoti. Garūti garuṭṭhāniyo pāsāṇachattasadiso.🔽Bhāvanīyoti “addhā ayamāyasmā jānaṃ jānāti, passaṃ passatī”ti sambhāvanīyo. Sīlesvevassa
analyzed: pattabbaḥ metta cittena pharitabbaḥ iti vuttam hoti garu ti pāsāṇa chatta sadiso  bhāvanīyaḥ ti addhā ayam āyasmā jānam jānāti passam passati iti sambhāvanīyaḥ sīlesu evassa
translated: should be attained, should be pervaded with loving-kindness.🔽Worthy of respect: worthy of being treated with respect, like a stone image of the Buddha.🔽Worthy of offerings: worthy of being honoured, worthy of being treated with respect.

original: paripūrakārīti catupārisuddhisīlesu eva paripūrakārī assa, anūnakārī paripūraṇākārena🔽samannāgato bhaveyya. “Ādinā nayenā”ti etena “ajjhattaṃ cetosamathamanuyutto anirākatajjhāno
analyzed: paripūra kārī iti catu pārisuddhi sīlesu eva paripūra kārī assa anūna kārī paripūraṇa ākārena  samannāgataḥ bhaveyya ādinā nayena ati etena ajjhattam cetaḥ samatham anuyuttaḥ a nirākata jjhānaḥ
translated: Worthy of reverential salutation: worthy of being saluted with raised hands, like a stone image of the Buddha.🔽Worthy of the supreme homage: worthy of the supreme form of worship, which is the offering of material gifts.🔽Worthy of being an object of faith: worthy of being an object of faith, worthy of being an object of faith for the world with its gods.🔽Worthy of being an object of mental development: worthy of being an object of mental development, worthy of being an object of mental development for the world with its gods.🔽Worthy of being an object of reverential salutation: worthy of being an object of reverential salutation, worthy of being an object of reverential salutation for the world with its gods.🔽Worthy of being an object of the supreme homage: worthy of being an object of the supreme homage, worthy of being an object of the supreme homage for the world with its gods.

original: vipassanāya samannāgato brūhetā suññāgārāna”nti evamādike sīlathomanasuttāgate sattarasa
analyzed: vipassanāya samannāgataḥ evamādike sīla thomana sutta āgate sattarasa
translated: Worthy of being an object of mental development: worthy of being an object of mental development, worthy of being an object of mental development for the world with its gods.

original: sīlānisaṃse saṅgaṇhāti.🔽Idāni na kevalamime eva avippaṭisārādayo, atha kho aññepi bahū sīlānisaṃsā vijjantīti
analyzed: sīla nisaṃse saṅgaṇhāti  idāni na kevalam ime eva a vippaṭisāra ādayaḥ atha kho aññe pi bahū sīla anisaṃsāḥ vijjanti iti
translated: Worthy of being an object of reverential salutation: worthy of being an object of reverential salutation, worthy of being an object of reverential salutation for the world with its gods.🔽Worthy of being an object of the supreme homage: worthy of being an object of the supreme homage, worthy of being an object of the supreme homage for the world with its gods.🔽Worthy of being an object of mental development: worthy of being an object of mental development, worthy of being an object of mental development for the world with its gods.🔽Worthy of being an object of reverential salutation: worthy of being an object of reverential salutation, worthy of being an object of reverential salutation for the world with its gods.

original: te dassetuṃ “apicā”tiādi āraddhaṃ. Tattha sāsaneti imasmiṃ sakalalokiyalokuttaraguṇāvahe
analyzed: te dassetum apica atiādi āraddham tattha sāsane iti imasmim sakala lokiya lokuttara guṇa āvahe
translated: Worthy of being an object of the supreme homage: worthy of being an object of the supreme homage, worthy of being an object of the supreme homage for the world with its gods.🔽Worthy of being an object of mental development: worthy of being an object of mental development, worthy of being an object of mental development for the world with its gods.🔽Worth

original: satthusāsane. Ācārakulaputtānaṃ yaṃ sīlaṃ vinā patiṭṭhā avaṭṭhānaṃ natthi, tassa
analyzed: satthu sāsane ācāra kula puttānam yam sīlam vinā patiṭṭhā avaṭṭhānam natthi tassa
translated: In the Dispensation of the Master. For those of good conduct and noble birth, there is no stability and no foundation without virtue.

original: evaṃ mahānubhāvassa sīlassa ānisaṃsānaṃ paricchedaṃ parimāṇaṃ ko vade ko vattuṃ sakkuṇeyyāti
analyzed: evam mahā anubhāvassa sīlassa ānisaṃsānam paricchedam parimāṇam kaḥ vade kaḥ vattum sakkuṇeyya ati
translated: Who can tell, who can say, the measure and the limit of the benefits of such mighty virtue?

original: attho. Etena sabbesaṃyeva lokiyalokuttarānaṃ guṇānaṃ sīlameva mūlabhūtanti dassetvā🔽tato parampi malavisodhanena, pariḷāhavūpasamanena, sucigandhavāyanena, sagganibbānādhigamūpāyabhāvena,🔽sobhālaṅkārasādhanatāya bhayavidhamanena, kittipāmojjajanena ca sīlasadisaṃ aññaṃ
analyzed: attho etena sabbesam yeva lokiya lokuttarānam guṇānam sīlam eva mūla bhūtanti dassetvā  tato parampi mala visodhanena pariḷāha vūpasamanena suci gandha vāyanena sagga nibbāna adhigama upāya bhāvena  sobha alaṅkāra sādhana tāya bhaya vidhamanena kitti pāmojja janena ca sīla sadisam aññam
translated: This is the meaning. Having shown that virtue is the root of all mundane and supramundane qualities,🔽he then spoke the verse beginning with “Na Gaṅgā” in order to show that there is nothing else like virtue as a means of purifying stains, of alleviating fever, of wafting pure fragrance,

original: sattānaṃ hitasukhāvahaṃ natthīti dassento “na gaṅgā”tiādikā gāthā abhāsi.🔽Tattha sarabhūti ekā nadī, “yaṃ loke sarabhū”ti vadanti. Ninnagā vāciravatīti “aciravatī”ti
analyzed: sattānam hita sukha āvaham natthi iti dassentaḥ na gaṅgā ti ādikāḥ gāthāḥ abhāsi  tattha sarabhūti ekā nadī yam loke sarabhūti vadanti ninnagā vā aciravatī iti aciravatī iti
translated: of attaining heaven and Nibbana, of adorning and beautifying, of dispelling fear, and of generating fame and joy for beings.🔽Here, Sarabhū is a river called “Sarabhū” in the world. Ninnagā vāciravatī is a river named “Aciravatī.”

original: evaṃnāmikā nadī, vāti sabbattha vā-saddo aniyamattho. Tena avuttā godhāvarīcandabhāgādikā
analyzed: evaṃnāmikā nadī vā ti sabbattha vā saddaḥ aniyama atthaḥ tena avuttā godhāvarī canda bhāga ādikā
translated: The word vā in “vāciravatī” means “or.” Therefore, it refers to the Godhāvarī, Candabhāgā, and so on.

original: saṅgaṇhāti. Pāṇanaṭṭhena pāṇīnaṃ sattānaṃ yaṃ malaṃ sīlajalaṃ visodhayati, taṃ malaṃ
analyzed: saṅgaṇhāti pāṇana ṭṭhena pāṇīnam sattānam yam malam sīla jalam visodhayati tam malam
translated: He gathers. The dirt of beings, that is, of living beings, in the sense of their being born , he purifies with the water of virtue.🔽The Ganges and other rivers cannot purify that dirt.

original: visodhetuṃ na sakkuṇanti gaṅgādayo nadiyoti paṭhamagāthāya na-kāraṃ ānetvā sambandhitabbaṃ.
analyzed: visodhetum na gaṅgā ādayaḥ nadiyaḥ ti paṭhama gāthāya nakāram ānetvā sambandhitabbam
translated: The word “not” should be supplied to the first line.

original: Hārāti muttāhārā. Maṇayoti veḷuriyādimaṇayo. Ariyanti visuddhaṃ. Sīlasamuṭṭhāno kittisaddo
analyzed: hārā ati muttā hārāḥ maṇayaḥ ti veḷuriya ādi maṇayaḥ visuddham sīla samuṭṭhānaḥ kitti saddo
translated: Necklaces: pearl necklaces. Gems: gems such as cat’s eyes. Noble: pure. The sound of fame arising from virtue

original: gandho manoharabhāvato, disāsu abhibyāpanato ca “sīlagandho”ti vutto. So hi paṭivātepi
analyzed: gandhaḥ manohara bhāvato disāsu abhibyāpanato ca sīlagandho ti vutto saḥ hi paṭivāte pi
translated: is called “the fragrance of virtue” because it is delightful and spreads in all directions. For it spreads even against the wind.

original: pavattati. Tenāha bhagavā “satañca gandho paṭivātametī”ti. Dosānaṃ balaṃ nāma vatthujjhācāro,
analyzed: pavattati tena āha bhagavā satam ca gandho paṭivātam eti iti dosānam balam nāma vatthu ujjhācāro
translated: Hence the Blessed One said: “The good man’s fragrance spreads even against the wind” . The strength of the defilements is the object of their occurrence.

original: taṃ tesaṃ kātuṃ adentaṃ sīlaṃ dosānaṃ balaṃ ghātetīti veditabbaṃ.
analyzed: tam tesam kātum a dentam sīlam dosānam balam ghāteti iti veditabbam
translated: Virtue, by not giving them that, is said to “destroy the strength of the defilements.”

original: Sīlappabhedakathāvaṇṇanā
analyzed: sīla ppabheda kathā vaṇṇanā
translated: The explanation of the section on virtue is finished.

original: 10. “Katividha”nti ettha vidha-saddo koṭṭhāsapariyāyo “ekavidhena rūpasaṅgaho”tiādīsu
analyzed: katividhan ti ettha vidha saddo koṭṭhāsa pariyāyo ekavidhena rūpa saṅgaho ti ādīsu
translated: Here the word “kind” is a synonym for “class,” as in the passages “The classification of materiality is one kind of enumeration” ,

original: viya, pakārattho vā, katippakāraṃ kittakā sīlassa pakārabhedāti attho. Sīlanalakkhaṇenāti
analyzed: viya pakāra atthaḥ vā katippakāram kittakā sīlassa pakāra bhedā ati attho sīlana lakkhaṇena ati
translated: By the characteristic of virtue:

original: sīlanasaṅkhātena sabhāvena.
analyzed: sīlana saṅkhātena sa bhāvena
translated: by the individual essence called virtue.

original: Caranti tena sīlesu paripūrakāritaṃ upagacchantīti carittaṃ, carittameva cārittaṃ.
analyzed: caranti tena sīlesu paripūra kāritam upagacchanti iti carittam carittam eva cārittam
translated: They conduct themselves thus: they undertake the practice of fulfilling virtue.🔽They guard themselves thus: they protect themselves.

original: Vāritato tena attānaṃ tāyanti rakkhantīti vārittaṃ. Adhiko samācāro abhisamācāro,
analyzed: tena attānam tāyanti rakkhanti iti vārittam adhikaḥ samācāraḥ abhisamācāro
translated: The higher conduct is the special conduct.🔽It is applied to that, or that is its purpose, thus it is about the special conduct.

original: tattha niyuttaṃ, so vā payojanaṃ etassāti ābhisamācārikaṃ. Ādi brahmacariyassāti
analyzed: tattha niyuttam saḥ vā payojanam etassa ati ābhisamācārikam ādi brahmacariyassa ati
translated: The beginning of the holy life is the beginning of the life of purity.🔽It is that, thus it is about the beginning of the holy life.

original: ādibrahmacariyaṃ, tadeva ādibrahmacariyakaṃ. Viramati etāya, sayaṃ vā viramati, viramaṇaṃ
analyzed: ādibrahmacariyam tat eva ādibrahmacariyakam viramati etāya sayam vā viramati viramaṇam
translated: One refrains by means of this, or one oneself refrains, thus it is abstinence.🔽It is not abstinence, thus it is non-abstinence.

original: vā virati, na viratīti avirati. Nissayatīti nissitaṃ, na nissitanti anissitaṃ. Pariyanto
analyzed: vā virati na virati iti avirati nissayati iti nissitam na nissitam ti anissitam pariyantaḥ
translated: It is clung to, thus it is clung to. It is not clung to, thus it is unclung to.

original: etassa atthīti pariyantaṃ, kālena pariyantaṃ kālapariyantaṃ, yathāparicchinno vā
analyzed: etassa atthi iti pariyantam kālena pariyantam kāla pariyantam yathā paricchinnaḥ vā
translated: It has an end, thus it has an end. It has an end in time, thus it has an end in time. Or it is limited, thus it has an end.

original: kālo pariyanto etassāti kālapariyantaṃ. Yāva pāṇanaṃ jīvanaṃ koṭi etassāti āpāṇakoṭikaṃ.
analyzed: kālaḥ pariyantaḥ etassa ati kāla pariyantam yāva pāṇanam jīvanam koṭi etassa ati āpāṇa koṭikam
translated: it has a life-span of a hundred years.

original: Attano paccayehi loke niyuttaṃ, tattha vā viditanti lokiyaṃ. Lokaṃ uttaratīti lokuttaraṃ.
analyzed: attano paccayehi loke niyuttam tattha vā viditanti lokiyam lokam uttarati iti lokuttaram
translated: It is mundane because it is directed to the world of its own conditions, or because it is known there. It is supramundane because it goes beyond the world.

original: Paccayato, phalato ca majjhimapaṇītehi nihīnaṃ, tesaṃ vā guṇehi parihīnanti hīnaṃ.
analyzed: paccayataḥ phalataḥ ca majjhima paṇītehi nihīnam tesam vā guṇehi parihīnanti hīnam
translated: It is inferior because it is inferior to the middle and superior kinds by reason of its conditions and its fruit, or because it is devoid of their special qualities.

original: Attano paccayehi padhānabhāvaṃ nītanti paṇītaṃ. Ubhinnameva vemajjhe bhavaṃ majjhimaṃ.
analyzed: attanaḥ paccayehi padhāna bhāvam paṇītam ubhinnam eva vemajjhe bhavam majjhimam
translated: It is superior because it is directed to the pre-eminent state by reason of its own conditions. The middle is that which is between the two.

original: Attādhipatito āgataṃ attādhipateyyaṃ. Sesapadadvayepi eseva nayo. Taṇhāya, diṭṭhiyā
analyzed: atta adhipatitaḥ āgatam atta ādhipateyyam sesa pada dvaye pi esa iva nayaḥ taṇhāya diṭṭhiyā
translated: It is self-deter-mined because it comes from self-determination. The same method applies to the other two terms.🔽It is misapprehended because it is misapprehended by craving and by view.

original: vā parāmaṭṭhaṃ padhaṃsitanti parāmaṭṭhaṃ. Tappaṭikkhepato aparāmaṭṭhaṃ. Paṭippassaddhakilesaṃ
analyzed: vā parāmaṭṭham padhaṃsitanti parāmaṭṭham tad paṭikkhepataḥ aparāmaṭṭham paṭippassaddha kilesam
translated: It is not misapprehended because it is the opposite of that.🔽It is tranquillized because defilements are tranquillized in it.

original: paṭippassaddhaṃ. Sikkhāsu jātaṃ, sekkhassa idanti vā sekkhaṃ. Pariniṭṭhitasikkhākiccatāya
analyzed: paṭippassaddham sikkhāsu jātam sekkhassa idam ti vā sekkham pariniṭṭhita sikkhā kicca tāya
translated: It is the Initiate’s because it is born in the training, or because it is the Initiate’s own.

original: asekkhadhammapariyāpannaṃ asekkhaṃ. Tadubhayapaṭikkhepena nevasekkhanāsekkhaṃ. Hānaṃ
analyzed: asekkha dhamma pariyāpannam asekkham tad ubhaya paṭikkhepena nevasekkha nāsekkham hānam
translated: and that which is included in the noble one’s states is noble. That which is excluded from both is neither-trainee-nor-non-trainee. It is subject to loss because it is associated with loss,

original: bhajati, hānabhāgo vā etassa atthīti hānabhāgiyaṃ. Sesesupi eseva nayo. Appaparimāṇattā
analyzed: bhajati hāna bhāgaḥ va etassa atthi iti hānabhāgiyam sesesu pi esa eva nayaḥ appa parimāṇa ttā
translated: or it has the state of loss, thus it is subject to loss. The same method applies in each instance. It is limited and purified in virtue because it is limited in extent and purified.

original: pariyantavantaṃ, pārisuddhivantañca sīlaṃ pariyantapārisuddhisīlaṃ. Anappaparimāṇattā🔽apariyantaṃ, pārisuddhivantañca sīlaṃ apariyantapārisuddhisīlaṃ. Sabbaso puṇṇaṃ,🔽pārisuddhivantañca sīlaṃ paripuṇṇapārisuddhisīlaṃ.
analyzed: pariyantavantam pārisuddhivantam ca sīlam pariyanta pārisuddhi sīlam anappa parimāṇa ttā  apariyantam pārisuddhivantam ca sīlam apariyanta pārisuddhi sīlam sabbaso puṇṇam  pārisuddhivantam ca sīlam paripuṇṇa pārisuddhi sīlam
translated: It is unlimited and purified in virtue because it is unlimited in extent and purified. It is fulfilled and purified in virtue because it is entirely fulfilled and purified.

original: 11. Vuttanayenāti “sīlanaṭṭhena sīla”ntiādinā heṭṭhā vuttena nayena. Idaṃ kattabbanti🔽paññattasikkhāpadapūraṇanti idaṃ ābhisamācārikaṃ kattabbaṃ paṭipajjitabbanti evaṃ
analyzed: vutta nayena āti sīlana ṭṭhena sīlam ti ādinā heṭṭhā vuttena nayena idam kattabbanti  paññatta sikkhāpada pūraṇam ti idam ābhisamācārikam kattabbam paṭipajjitabbam ti evam
translated: In the way already stated: in the way stated below thus: “Virtue is virtue in the sense of composing” . This is what should be done:

original: paññattassa sikkhāpadasīlassa pūraṇaṃ. Sikkhāpadasīlaṃ hi pūrento sikkhāpadampi pūreti
analyzed: paññattassa sikkhāpada sīlassa pūraṇam sikkhāpada sīlam hi pūrentaḥ sikkhāpadam pi pūreti
translated: the fulfilling of the training precepts announced is this: the fulfilling of the virtue of the training precepts announced in this way: “This should be done, this should be developed, this should be realized” . For one who fulfils virtue of the training precepts announced also fulfils the training precepts announced.

original: pāleti nāma. Sikkhā eva vā sikkhitabbato, paṭipajjitabbato ca sikkhāpadaṃ. Tassa
analyzed: pāla iti nāma sikkhā eva vā sikkhitabbataḥ paṭipajjitabbataḥ ca sikkhāpadam tassa
translated: “Pāleti” means “it protects.” Or else “sikkhāpada” is the training precept because one should train in the training and practice it.

original: pūraṇantipi yojetabbaṃ. Idaṃ na kattabbanti paṭikkhittassa akaraṇanti idaṃ duccaritaṃ
analyzed: pūraṇam ti pi yojetabbam idam na kattabbanti paṭikkhittassa akaraṇanti idam duccaritam
translated: “Pūraṇa” should be construed as “fulfillment.” “Idaṃ na kattabba” means “not doing what is prohibited.” “Duccarita” means

original: na kattabbanti bhagavatā paṭikkhittassa akaraṇaṃ viramaṇaṃ. Caranti tasminti tasmiṃ🔽sīle taṃsamaṅgino carantīti sīlassa adhikaraṇataṃ vibhāvento tesaṃ pavattiṭṭhānabhāvaṃ🔽dasseti. Tenāha “sīlesu paripūrakāritāya pavattantī”ti. Vāritanti idaṃ na kattabbanti
analyzed: na kattabbanti bhagavatā paṭikkhittassa akaraṇam viramaṇam caranti tasmin ti tasmin  sīle tad samaṅgino caranti iti sīlassa adhikaraṇa tam vibhāvento tesam pavatti ṭṭhāna bhāvam  dasseti tena āha sīlesu paripūra kāri tāya pavattanti iti vāritam ti idam na kattabbanti
translated: “not doing what is prohibited by the Blessed One, abstaining from it.” “Caranti tasmin” means “they practice that.”🔽“Sīlassa adhikaraṇataṃ vibhāvento” means “showing the state of being the basis of virtue.” Therefore he says, “by practicing for the sake of fulfilling virtue.” “Vāritan” means “what is prohibited,”

original: paṭikkhittaṃ akappiyaṃ. Tāyantīti akaraṇeneva tāyanti. Tenāti vārittasīlamāha. Vāreti
analyzed: paṭikkhittam akappiyam tāyanti iti a karaṇena iva tāyanti tena ati vāritta sīlam āha vāra iti
translated: “not to be done,” “unallowable.” “Tāyanti” means “they protect by not doing it.” “Tenā” refers to the virtue that is prohibited.

original: vā satthā ettha, etena vāti vāritaṃ, sikkhāpadaṃ. Taṃ avikopento tāyanti tenāti vārittaṃ.
analyzed: vā satthā ettha etena vā ati vāritam sikkhāpadam tam a vikopento tāyanti tena ati
translated: The Teacher prohibits it, or it is prohibited by him, thus it is “vārita.” Not transgressing it, they protect by it, thus it is “vāritta.”

original: Saddhāvīriyasādhananti saddhāya, uṭṭhānavīriyena ca sādhetabbaṃ. Na hi asaddho, kusīto
analyzed: saddhā vīriya sādhanam ti saddhāya uṭṭhāna vīriyena ca sādhetabbam na hi asaddhaḥ kusītaḥ
translated: “Saddhāvīriyasādhana” means “to be accomplished by faith and by the energy of exertion.” For one who lacks faith and is lazy

original: ca vattapaṭipattiṃ paripūreti, saddho eva satthārā paṭikkhitte aṇumattepi vajje bhayadassāvī
analyzed: ca vatta paṭipattim paripūreti saddhaḥ eva satthārā paṭikkhitte aṇumatte api vajje bhaya dassāvī
translated: and he fulfills the practice of the proper conduct. The faithful one, seeing fear in the slightest fault, even in what is as small as the tip of a hair,

original: samādāya sikkhati sikkhāpadesūti āha “saddhāsādhanaṃ vāritta”nti.
analyzed: samādāya sikkhati sikkhāpadesu iti āha saddhā sādhanam vārittam ti
translated: undertakes and trains in the training rules. Thus it is said: “The proper conduct is fulfilled by faith.”

original: Adhisīlasikkhāpariyāpannattā abhivisiṭṭho samācāroti abhisamācāroti āha “uttamasamācāro”ti.🔽Abhisamācārova ābhisamācārikaṃ, yathā venayikoti adhippāyo. Abhisamācāro ukkaṭṭhaniddesato
