translated: This one who frequents such families of prostitutes, etc., families of kings, etc., and families lacking faith, etc., is not fit for the three kinds of resort, thus he is “not a resort” . For here the family of prostitutes, etc., is not a resort because of the five strands of sense pleasure, as it is said: “What, bhikkhus, is a family that is a resort? Here a family is wealthy, with great wealth and great possessions,

original: bhikkhuno agocaro paravisayo? Yadidaṃ pañca kāmaguṇā”ti. Rājādiko samaṇadhammassa
analyzed: bhikkhuno agocaraḥ para visayaḥ yat idam pañca rājā ādikaḥ samaṇa dhammassa
translated: Is the five strands of sense pleasure the domain of a bhikkhu? It is not. ”

original: anupanissayato, lābhasakkārāsanivicakkanippothanadiṭṭhivipattihetuto ca. Assaddhakulādiko🔽saddhāhānicittasantāsāvahato agocaro.
analyzed: an upanissayataḥ lābha sakkāra āsani vicakka nippothana diṭṭhi vipatti hetutaḥ ca assaddha kula ādiko  saddhā hāni citta santāsa avahataḥ agocaraḥ
translated: Because the king, etc., are not the support for the recluse-state, and because they are the cause for the loss of the recluse’s state by the destruction of gain and honour.🔽The families of the faithless, etc., are not the domain because they are the cause for the loss of the recluse’s state by the destruction of faith and confidence.

original: Gocaraniddese “na vesiyāgocaro”tiādīni vuttapaṭipakkhavasena veditabbāni. Opānabhūtānīti
analyzed: gocara niddese na vesiyā gocaraḥ ti ādīni vutta paṭipakkha vasena veditabbāni opāna bhūtāni iti
translated: In the description of the domain, the words “not the domain of a prostitute” and so forth should be understood as the opposite of what is stated.

original: udapānabhūtāni bhikkhusaṅghassa, bhikkhunīsaṅghassa ca catumahāpathe khatapokkharaṇī🔽viya yathāsukhaṃ ogāhanakkhamāni. Kāsāvapajjotānīti bhikkhūnaṃ, bhikkhunīnañca nivatthapārutakāsāvānaṃyeva
analyzed: udapāna bhūtāni bhikkhu saṅghassa bhikkhunī saṅghassa ca catu mahāpathe khata pokkharaṇī  viya yathāsukham ogāhana khamāni kāsāva pajjotāni iti bhikkhūnam bhikkhunīnam ca nivattha pāruta kāsāvānam yeva
translated: They are like a well for the Sangha of bhikkhus and the Sangha of bhikkhunis, like a public tank in the middle of a crossroads, open to everyone.🔽They are illuminated by the yellow robe, because they are illuminated by the yellow robes worn by the bhikkhus and bhikkhunis.

original: pabhāhi ekobhāsāni. Isivātapaṭivātānīti gehaṃ pavisantānaṃ, nikkhamantānañca bhikkhubhikkhunīsaṅkhātānaṃ
analyzed: pabhāhi ekobhāsāni isivāta paṭivātāni iti geham pavisantānam nikkhamantānam ca bhikkhu bhikkhunī saṅkhātānam
translated: They are wind-breaks for the bhikkhus and bhikkhunis who enter and leave the monastery,

original: isīnaṃ cīvaravātena ceva samiñjanapasāraṇādijanitasarīravātena ca paṭivātāni pavāyitāni
analyzed: isīnam cīvara vātena ca iva samiñjana pasāraṇa ādi janita sarīra vātena ca paṭivātāni pavāyitāni
translated: because they are open to the wind from the robes of the bhikkhus and bhikkhunis and to the wind from their bodies as they stretch their limbs.

original: viniddhutakibbisāni vā.🔽Idāni niddese āgatanayenāpi ācāragocare dassetuṃ “apicā”tiādi āraddhaṃ. Etthāti etasmiṃ🔽pātimokkhasīlaniddese. Imināpi nayenāti idāni vuccamānavidhināpi. Saṅghagatoti saṅghasannipātaṃ🔽gato. Acittīkārakatoti akatacittīkāro, akatagāravoti attho. Ghaṭṭayantoti sarīrena,🔽cīvarena vā ghaṃsanto. Puratopi tiṭṭhati acittīkārakatoti sambandhitabbaṃ. Ṭhitakopīti
analyzed: viniddhuta kibbisāni vā  idāni niddese āgata nayena api ācāra gocare dassetum apica atiādi āraddham ettha ati etasmin  pātimokkha sīla niddese iminā api nayena ati idāni vuccamāna vidhinā api saṅgha gataḥ iti saṅgha sannipātam  gataḥ a cittīkāra kato ti a kata cittīkāraḥ a kata gāravaḥ ti attho ghaṭṭayanto ti sarīrena  cīvarena vā ghaṃsantaḥ puratas pi tiṭṭhati acittīkārakato ti sambandhitabbam ṭhitako pi iti
translated: Or they are ‘cleared of defilements.’

original: upari tiṭṭhanto viya āsannataraṭṭhāne ṭhitakopi bhaṇati. Bāhāvikkhepakoti bāhuṃ vikkhipanto.🔽Anupāhanānanti anādare sāmivacanaṃ. Saupāhanoti upāhanāruḷho. There bhikkhū anupakhajjāti🔽therānaṃ bhikkhūnaṃ ṭhitaṭṭhānaṃ anupavisitvā tesaṃ āsannataraṭṭhānaṃ upagantvā.
analyzed: upari tiṭṭhantaḥ viya āsannatara ṭṭhāne ṭhitakaḥ api bhaṇati bāhā vikkhepakaḥ ti bāhum vikkhipantaḥ 🔽an upāhana ananti anādare sāmi vacanam sa upāhanaḥ ti upāhana āruḷho there bhikkhū 🔽therānam bhikkhūnam ṭhita ṭṭhānam an upavisitvā tesam āsannatara ṭṭhānam upagantvā
translated: Now, in order to point out the proper conduct and resort by the method given in the Niddesa, the following is stated: “Moreover, in this training rule on the Monastic Code” and so on. Herein, in this training rule on the Monastic Code. By this method: by the method that will now be given. In the midst of the Sangha: having gone to a gathering of the Sangha. Without showing respect: without making respect, without showing deference, is the meaning. Bumping into: touching with the body or with the robe. He stands in front without showing respect: this is how it should be connected. Standing: standing as if above, standing in a place that is higher up. He speaks: he speaks in a place that is closer. With his arms akimbo: with his arms extended. Without taking off his sandals: this is a term of contempt. Wearing his sandals: wearing sandals. He goes to the senior monks without approaching them: without going to the place where the senior monks are standing, he goes to a place that is closer to them.

original: Kaṭṭhaṃ pakkhipati aggikuṇḍe. Vokkammāti passato atikkamitvā. Gūḷhāni sabhāvato paṭicchannāni
analyzed: kaṭṭham pakkhipati aggikuṇḍe vokkamma ati passataḥ atikkamitvā gūḷhāni sabhāvataḥ paṭicchannāni
translated: He puts the wood in the fire-pan. He cooks: he cooks it by passing over it. Hidden: concealed by nature.

original: sāṇipākārādinā paṭicchāditāni. Anāpucchāti anāpucchitvā. Assāti anācārassa.
analyzed: sāṇi pākāra ādinā paṭicchāditāni an āpuccha ati an āpucchitvā assa ati anācārassa
translated: Covered: covered by a wall of leaves, etc. Without asking: without asking permission. He is a transgressor: he is one who has no conduct.

original: Apica bhikkhūtiādi sabbasseva bhikkhuno ācāradassanavasena pavattaṃ aṭṭhakathāvacanaṃ,
analyzed: apica bhikkhu iti ādi sabbassa eva bhikkhuno ācāra dassana vasena pavattam aṭṭhakathā vacanam
translated: Moreover, the words “a bhikkhu” and so on are the words of the commentary, which occur in order to show the conduct of any bhikkhu at all,

original: na niddesapāḷi. Saddhāsīlasutacāgādiguṇahetuko garubhāvo garukaraṇaṃ vā gāravo, saha🔽gāravenāti sagāravo. Garuṭṭhāniyesu gāravasārajjādivasena paṭissāyanā patissā, sappatissavapaṭipatti.
analyzed: na saddhā sīla suta cāga ādi guṇa hetukaḥ garu bhāvaḥ garu karaṇam vā saha  gāravena ati sa gāravaḥ garuṭṭha aniyesu gārava sārajja ādi vasena paṭissāyanā patissā sa patissava paṭipatti
translated: not in the text of the sutta. Respect: the state of being weighty, or the act of weighting, which is due to the qualities of faith, virtue, learning, generosity, etc.🔽With respect: with respect. With deference: with deference, by way of deference and humility towards those who are worthy of respect.

original: Saha patissāyāti sappatisso. Savisesaṃ hirimanatāya, ottappibhāvena ca hirottappasampanno.
analyzed: saha patissāya ati sappatissaḥ sa visesam hiri manatāya ottappi bhāvena ca hirā uttappa sampannaḥ
translated: With deference: with deference. He is endowed with shame and moral dread: he is endowed with shame and moral dread by reason of his special modesty and scrupulousness.

original: Sekhiyadhammapāripūrivasena sunivattho supāruto. Pāsādikenāti pasādāvahena, itthambhūtalakkhaṇe
analyzed: sekhiya dhamma pāripūri vasena sunivattho supāruto pāsādikena ati pasāda āvahena ittham bhūta lakkhaṇe
translated: Well-clothed: well-clothed by reason of his fulfilment of the virtue of training. He is inspiring: he is inspiring by reason of his inspiring nature.

original: cetaṃ karaṇavacanaṃ. Eseva nayo ito paresupi chasu padesu. Abhikkantenāti abhikkamena.
analyzed: karaṇa vacanam esā iva nayoḥ i taḥ paresu pi chasu padesu abhikkantena ati abhikkamena
translated: This is a verbal expression of the doing. The same method of explanation applies in the other six sections.

original: Iriyāpathasampannoti sampannairiyāpatho. Tena sesairiyāpathānampi pāsādikatamāha.
analyzed: iriyāpatha sampannaḥ ti sampanna eriyāpathaḥ tena sesa eriyāpathānam pi
translated: Possessed of good ways of livelihood: possessed of good ways of deportment. By that he shows that the other ways of deportment are also inspiring.

original: Indriyesu guttadvāroti cakkhundriyādīsu chasu dvāresu susaṃvihitārakkho. Bhojane🔽mattaññūti paribhuñjitabbato bhojanasaññite catubbidhepi paccaye pariyesanapaṭiggahaṇaparibhogādivasena🔽sabbaso pamāṇaññū. Jāgariyamanuyuttoti pubbarattāpararattaṃ bhāvanāmanasikārasaṅkhātaṃ
analyzed: indriyesu gutta dvāro ti cakkhu indriya ādīsu chasu dvāresu su saṃvihita ārakkhaḥ bhojane  mattaññu iti paribhuñjitabbataḥ bhojana saññite catubbidhe api paccaye pariyesana paṭiggahaṇa paribhoga ādi vasena  sabbaso pamāṇaññū jāgariyam anuyuttaḥ ti pubba ratta apara rattam bhāvanā manasikāra saṅkhātam
translated: Guarded in the doors of the sense faculties: well restrained in the six doors beginning with the eye faculty.🔽Knowing the right amount in eating: knowing the right amount in all the four kinds of requisites, which are called “food” in the sense that they are to be consumed, by way of seeking, receiving, using, etc.

original: jāgariyaṃ sātaccakāritāvasena anu anu yutto tattha yuttapayutto. Satisampajaññena
analyzed: jāgariyam sātacca kāri tā vasena anu anu yuttaḥ tattha yutta payuttaḥ sati sampajaññena
translated: Devoted to wakefulness: devoted to wakefulness consisting in the attention given to development, by way of the performance of that task continuously, night after night and day after day.

original: samannāgatotiādi yathāvuttassa ācārassa sambhāradassanaṃ. Tattha appicchoti niiccho.
analyzed: samannāgataḥ tiādi yathā vuttassa ācārassa sambhāra dassanam tattha appiccho ti niiccho
translated: Endowed with mindfulness and full awareness: etc. This shows the equipment of the way of life described above. Herein, he is unassuming in his desires, that is, he has few desires.

original: Santuṭṭhoti yathālābhādivasena santosena tuṭṭho. Sakkaccakārīti ādarakārī. Garucittīkārabahuloti
analyzed: santuṭṭhaḥ iti yathā lābha ādi vasena santosena tuṭṭhaḥ sakkacca kārī iti ādara kārī garu cittīkāra bahulaḥ ti
translated: One who is full of thoughts of deference : one who is full of reverence for those worthy of reverence.

original: garuṭṭhāniyesu garukaraṇabahulo. Ayaṃ vuccati ācāroti ayaṃ sagāravatādi atthakāmehi ācaritabbato ācāro.
analyzed: garu ṭhāniyesu garu karaṇa bahulaḥ ayam vuccati ācāro ti ayam sagārava tā ādi attha kāmehi ācaritabbataḥ ācāro
translated: This is called good conduct : this is good conduct because it should be conducted by those who desire welfare, beginning with reverence.🔽The object that is the support for the qualities beginning with virtue is the support object.

original: Sīlādīnaṃ guṇānaṃ upanissayabhūto upanissayagocaro. Satisaṅkhāto cittassa ārakkhabhūto
analyzed: sīla ādīnam guṇānam upanissaya bhūtaḥ upanissaya gocaraḥ sati saṅkhāto cittassa ārakkha bhūtaḥ
translated: The object that is the protection of consciousness by way of mindfulness is the protection object.

original: eva gocaro ārakkhagocaro. Kammaṭṭhānasaṅkhāto cittassa upanibandhanaṭṭhānabhūto gocaro🔽upanibandhagocaro. Appicchatādīhi dasahi vivaṭṭanissitāya kathāya vatthubhūtehi guṇehi
analyzed: eva gocaro ārakkha gocaro kammaṭṭhāna saṅkhāto cittassa upanibandhana ṭṭhāna bhūto gocaro  upanibandha gocaraḥ appiccha tā ādīhi dasahi vivaṭṭa nissitāya kathāya vatthu bhūtehi guṇehi
translated: The object that is the place of binding of consciousness by way of the meditation subject is the binding object.🔽Endowed with the ten qualities of talk dependent on the ten objects of talk beginning with fewness of wishes is endowed with the ten qualities of talk.🔽Because of that he is a good friend, a fine friend.

original: samannāgato dasakathāvatthuguṇasamannāgato. Tato eva kalyāṇo sundaro mittoti kalyāṇamitto.
analyzed: samannāgataḥ dasa kathā vatthu guṇa samannāgato tatas eva kalyāṇaḥ sundaraḥ mitto ti kalyāṇa mitto
translated: The characteristic of that will come in the description of the good friend below .

original: Tassa lakkhaṇaṃ parato āgamissati. Assutaṃ suttageyyādiṃ. Suṇātīti sutamayaṃ ñāṇaṃ
analyzed: tassa lakkhaṇam paratas āgamissati assutam sutta geyya ādim suṇāti iti suta mayam ñāṇam
translated: He hears what he has not heard, such as the discourses, mixed prose and verse, etc., thus he has knowledge consisting in what is heard.

original: uppādeti. Sutaṃ pariyodāpetīti tameva yathāsutaṃ avisadatāya apariyodātaṃ punappunaṃ
analyzed: uppādeti sutam pariyodāpeti iti tam eva yathā sutam a visada tāya a pariyodātam punappunam
translated: He causes to be heard. He causes to be purified what he has heard: what he has heard, being impure because of being indistinct, he makes pure again and again by reciting it.

original: paripucchanādinā visodheti nijjaṭaṃ nigumbaṃ karoti. Tattha ca ye kaṅkhaṭṭhāniyā🔽dhammā, tesu saṃsayaṃ chindanto kaṅkhaṃ vitarati. Kammakammaphalesu, ratanattaye
analyzed: paripucchana ādinā visodha iti nijjaṭam nigumbam karoti tattha ca ye  dhammā tesu saṃsayam chindantaḥ kaṅkham vitarati kamma kamma phalesu rata nattaye
translated: He purifies what he has learned: he purifies what he has learned by heart by removing its imperfections. He makes it his own by removing its faults. And here, in regard to those things that are doubtful,🔽he removes his doubts by cutting off his uncertainty about kamma, its results, and the Three Jewels.🔽He makes his view straight by means of right view in regard to kamma, its results, and the Three Jewels.

original: ca sammādiṭṭhiyā ujukaraṇena diṭṭhiṃ ujuṃ karoti. Tato eva ca duvidhāyapi saddhāsampadāya
analyzed: ca sammādiṭṭhiyāḥ uju karaṇena diṭṭhim ujum karoti eva ca saddhā sampadāya
translated: And by means of the twofold perfection of faith he makes his mind confident.

original: cittaṃ pasādeti. Atha vā yathāsutaṃ dhammaṃ pariyodapetvā tatthāgate rūpārūpadhamme
analyzed: cittam pasādeti atha vā yathāsutam dhammam pariyodapetvā tatthāgate rūpa arūpa dhamme
translated: Or alternatively, having purified the Dhamma as he has learned it by heart, he discerns the material and immaterial dhammas in the Buddha.

original: pariggahetvā sapaccayaṃ nāmarūpaṃ pariggaṇhanto sattadiṭṭhivaṅkavidhamanena diṭṭhiṃ
analyzed: pariggahetvā sa paccayam nāma rūpam pariggaṇhantaḥ satta diṭṭhi vaṅka vidhamanena diṭṭhim
translated: He makes his view straight by removing the seven kinds of wrongness of view.

original: ujuṃ karoti. Dhammānaṃ paccayapaccayuppannatāmattadassanena tīsupi addhāsu kaṅkhaṃ
analyzed: ujum karoti dhammānam paccaya paccaya uppanna tā matta dassanena tīsu pi addhāsu kaṅkham
translated: He removes his doubts by seeing the arising of dhammas through conditions in the three periods of time.

original: vitarati. Tato paraṃ ca udayabbayañāṇādivasena vipassanaṃ vaḍḍhetvā ariyabhūmiṃ okkamanto
analyzed: vitarati tato param ca udaya bbaya ñāṇa ādi vasena vipassanam vaḍḍhetvā ariya bhūmim okkamantaḥ
translated: And after that, by developing insight by means of the knowledge of rise and fall, etc., he enters upon the supramundane path.

original: aveccapasādena ratanattaye cittaṃ pasādeti. Tathābhūtova tassa kalyāṇamittassa anusikkhanena
analyzed: avecca pasādena rata nattaye cittam pasādeti tathābhūtaḥ uva tassa kalyāṇa mittassa anusikkhanena
translated: and he has confidence in the Triple Gem. He should then train himself in the following way:

original: saddhādīhi guṇehi na hāyati, aññadatthu vaḍḍhateva. Tenāha “yassa vā”tiādi.
analyzed: saddhā ādīhi guṇehi na hāyati aññadatthu vaḍḍha tā iva tena āha yassa
translated: He generates serene confidence in the Triple Gem. Being such, he does not diminish in the qualities of faith, etc., but rather increases in them by training himself in the way of his good friend. Hence the Master said: “Or else, when he enters a village for alms, etc.”

original: Antaragharanti antare antare gharāni ettha, taṃ etassāti vā “antaraghara”nti laddhanāmaṃ
analyzed: antaragharanti antare antare gharāni ettha tam etassa ati vā antaragharanti laddha nāmam
translated: “Between the houses” : between the houses here and there. He who has that is called “between-the-houses” .

original: gocaragāmaṃ paviṭṭho. Tattha ghare ghare bhikkhāpariyesanāya vīthiṃ paṭipanno. Okkhittacakkhūti
analyzed: gocara gāmam paviṭṭho tattha ghare ghare bhikkhā pariyesanāya vīthim paṭipanno okkhitta cakkhu iti
translated: He has entered the village where he goes for alms. There, as he goes along the streets seeking alms from house to house,

original: heṭṭhākhittacakkhu. Kittakena pana okkhittacakkhu hotīti āha “yugamattadassāvī”ti.🔽Susaṃvutoti saṃyato. Yathā panettha susaṃvuto nāma hoti, taṃ dassetuṃ “na hatthiṃ
analyzed: heṭṭhā ākhitta cakkhu kittakena pana okkhitta cakkhu hoti iti āha yuga matta dassāvi iti  su saṃvutaḥ iti saṃyataḥ yathā pana ittha su saṃvutaḥ nāma hoti tam dassetum na hatthim
translated: “With eyes lowered” : with eyes cast downward. But how far should one lower one’s eyes? The answer is: “looking a plough-yoke’s length in front” .

original: olokento”tiādi vuttaṃ.
analyzed: olokento tiādi vuttam
translated: “Well-restrained” : controlled. But how does one become well-restrained? To show this, the Master said: “Not looking at an elephant, etc.”

original: Yatthāti yesu satipaṭṭhānesu. Cittaṃ bhāvanācittaṃ. Upanibandhatīti upanetvā nibandhati. Vuttañhetaṃ –🔽“Yathā thambhe nibandheyya, vacchaṃ damaṃ naro idha;
analyzed: yattha ati yesu satipaṭṭhānesu cittam bhāvanā cittam upanibandhati iti upanetvā nibandhati vuttam ha etam 🔽yathā thambhe vaccham damam naraḥ idha
translated: “Therein” : in the foundations of mindfulness. “Mind” : the mind of development. “Is fixed” : is brought and fixed.

original: Bandheyyevaṃ sakaṃ cittaṃ, satiyārammaṇe daḷha”nti. ;
analyzed: bandheyya evam sakam cittam satiyā ārammaṇe daḷhanti
translated: He should bind his mind to the object with mindfulness.

original: Satipaṭṭhānānaṃ upanibandhagocarabhāvaṃ dassetuṃ “vuttañheta”ntiādi vuttaṃ. Tattha sako pettiko visayoti attano pitu sammāsambuddhassa santako, tena diṭṭho dassito ca visayo.
analyzed: sati paṭṭhānānam upanibandha gocara bhāvam dassetum vuttam hetat tiādi vuttam tattha sakaḥ pettikaḥ visayo ti attanaḥ pitu sammāsambuddhassa santako tena diṭṭhaḥ dassitaḥ ca visayo
translated: “It is said” is said in order to show the state of being the proximate cause and the domain of the foundations of mindfulness. Therein, “his own father’s domain” means the domain of his own father, the Perfectly Enlightened One, which was seen and shown by him.

original: Aṇuppamāṇesūti paramāṇuppamāṇesu. Asañciccaāpannasekhiyaakusalacittuppādādibhedesūti
analyzed: aṇu ppamāṇesu iti paramāṇu ppamāṇesu asañcicca āpanna sekhiya akusala cittuppāda ādi bhedesu iti
translated: “In the smallest” means in the atomic. “In the unintentional, in the training rules, in the arising of unwholesome thoughts, etc.”

original: asañcicca āpannasekhiyesu akusalacittuppādādibhedesūti evaṃ asañciccaggahaṇaṃ sekhiyavisesanaṃ
analyzed: asañcit ca āpanna sekhiyesu akusala cittuppāda ādi bhedesu iti evam asañcicca ggahaṇam sekhiya visesanam
translated: The phrase “in the unintentional” should be seen as a specification of the training rules.

original: daṭṭhabbaṃ. Sekhiyaggahaṇena cettha vattakkhandhakādīsu āgatavattādīnampi gahaṇaṃ.
analyzed: daṭṭhabbam sekhiya gahaṇena ca ittha vatta kkhandhaka ādīsu āgata vatta ādīnam pi gahaṇam
translated: By the mention of the training rules here, the conduct, etc., found in the chapter on conduct, etc., are also included.

original: Tepi hi sikkhitabbaṭṭhena “sekhiyā”ti icchitā. Tathā hi mātikāyaṃ pārājikādīnaṃ viya
analyzed: te api hi sikkhitabba ṭṭhena icchitā tathā hi mātikāyam pārājika ādīnam viya
translated: For they are also called “training rules” in the sense of being what should be trained in. Thus, in the mātikā,🔽the training rules are not treated separately as are the pārājikas, etc.

original: sekhiyānaṃ paricchedo na kato. Evañca katvā “asañcicca āpannasekhiyā”ti asañciccaggahaṇaṃ
analyzed: paricchedaḥ na kataḥ evam ca katvā asañcicca āpanna sekhiyā ati asañcicca ggahaṇam
translated: Thus, the phrase “in the unintentional, in the training rules” is

original: samatthitaṃ hoti. Na hi mātikāyaṃ āgatesu pañcasattatiyā sekhiyesu nosaññāvimokkho🔽nāma atthi, asañciccaggahaṇeneva cettha asatiajānanānampi saṅgaho kato. Keci panettha
analyzed: samatthitam hoti na hi mātikāyam āgatesu pañca sattatiyā sekhiyesu no saññā vimokkho  nāma atthi ca ittha asati a jānanānam pi saṅgahaḥ kataḥ keci pana ittha
translated: and it is finished. For in the seventy-five matters to be trained in given in the mātikā there is no “deliverance by the signless”

original: asiñcicca āpannaggahaṇena acittakāpattiyo gahitāti vadanti, taṃ tesaṃ matimattaṃ,
analyzed: āpanna ggahaṇena acittaka āpattiyaḥ gahitā iti vadanti tam tesam matimattam
translated: and so on. And by the inclusion of “deliberately” here, the inclusion of those who do not know there is an offence is also made. But some say that by the inclusion of “deliberately” here, the offences of those who are mindless are included. That is their opinion.

original: garukāpattīsupi kāsañci acittakabhāvasabbhāvato, adhiṭṭhānāvikammassa, desanāvikammasseva
analyzed: garuka āpattīsu pi kāsañci acittaka bhāva sabbhāvataḥ adhiṭṭhāna avikammassa desanā vikammassa iva
translated: For although some offences are grave, they are not included here because they are not committed by one who is mindless, or because they are not subject to reversal by determination, or because they are not subject to reversal by confession,

original: vā sabbalahukassa vajjassa idhādhippetattā. Tenāha “yāni tāni vajjāni appamattakāni🔽oramattakāni lahukāni lahusammatānī”tiādi. Ādisaddena pātimokkhasaṃvaravisuddhatthaṃ
analyzed: vā sabba lahukassa vajjassa idha adhippeta ttā tena āha yāni tāni vajjāni appamattakāni  ora mattakāni lahukāni lahu sammatāni itiādi ādi saddena pātimokkha saṃvara visuddha attham
translated: or because the fault that is most easily committed is intended here. Hence it is said, “Those faults that are slight,

original: anatikkamanīyānaṃ anāpattigamanīyānaṃ saṅgaho daṭṭhabbo. Bhayadassanasīloti paramāṇumattaṃ
analyzed: an atikkamanīyānam an āpatti gamanīyānam saṅgahaḥ daṭṭhabbo bhaya dassana sīlaḥ ti paramāṇumattam
translated: that are small, that are light, that are regarded as light” and so on. The meaning of the word “and so on” should be regarded as including those that are not to be transgressed and those that are not to be confessed, for the purpose of purification by restraint in the Pāṭimokkha.

original: vajjaṃ aṭṭhasaṭṭhiyojanasatasahassubbedhasinerupabbatasadisaṃ katvā dassanasabhāvo,
analyzed: vajjam aṭṭha saṭṭhi yojana sata sahassa ubbedha sineru pabbata sadisam katvā dassana sabhāvaḥ
translated: “One whose nature is to see fear” is one whose nature is to see a fault as big as Mount Sineru, which is 68,000 leagues high, as though it were a speck of dust.

original: sabbalahukaṃ vā dubbhāsitamattaṃ pārājikasadisaṃ katvā dassanasabhāvo. Yaṃ kiñcīti
analyzed: sabba lahukam vā dubbhāsita mattam pārājika sadisam katvā dassana sabhāvaḥ yam kiñci iti
translated: and the mere bad speech, which is the least of these, is shown as being like an offence entailing Defeat.

original: mūlapaññattianupaññattisabbatthapaññattipadesapaññattiādibhedaṃ yaṃ kiñci sikkhitabbaṃ
analyzed: mūla paññatti anupaññatti sabbattha paññatti padesa paññatti ādi bhedam yam kiñci sikkhitabbam
translated: Whatever training: whatever training there is of any kind, whether in the basic training rules, in the supplementary training rules, in the rules for all, in the rules for a group, in the rules for an individual, etc.,🔽that is to be undertaken, that is to be practised, that is to be fulfilled, is virtue.

original: paṭipajjitabbaṃ pūretabbaṃ sīlaṃ. Sammā ādāyāti sammadeva sakkaccaṃ, sabbaso ca ādiyitvā.
analyzed: paṭipajjitabbam pūretabbam sīlam sammā ādāya ati sammat eva sakkaccam sabbaso ca ādiyitvā
translated: Having undertaken: having undertaken rightly, properly, thoroughly.

original: Ayaṃ pana ācāragocarasampadā kiṃ pātimokkhasīle pariyāpannā, udāhu apariyāpannāti?
analyzed: ayam pana ācāra gocara sampadā kim pātimokkha sīle pariyāpannā udāhu a pariyāpannā ti
translated: But does this excellence of virtue and conduct come under the virtue of the Pāṭimokkha or not?🔽It comes under it. If so, why is it mentioned again?

original: Pariyāpannā. Yadi evaṃ kasmā puna vuttāti codanaṃ sandhāyāha “ettha cā”tiādi.🔽Indriyasaṃvarasīlavaṇṇanā
analyzed: pariyāpannā yadi evam kasmai puna vuttā iti codanam sandhāya āha ettha ca atiādi
translated: The answer to the question is given by “Herein, too” .

original: 15. Indriyasaṃvarasīlaṃ pātimokkhasaṃvarasīlassa sambhārabhūtaṃ, tasmiṃ satiyeva
analyzed: indriya saṃvara sīlam pātimokkha saṃvara sīlassa sambhāra bhūtam tasmim satiyā iva
translated: The virtue of restraint of the sense faculties is a requisite for the virtue of restraint by the Pāṭimokkha.🔽When that exists, the latter is desirable.

original: icchitabbanti vuttaṃ “soti pātimokkhasaṃvarasīle ṭhito bhikkhū”ti. Sampādite hi etasmiṃ
analyzed: icchitabbanti vuttam saḥ ti pātimokkha saṃvara sīle ṭhitaḥ bhikkhu iti sampādite hi etasmin
translated: Therefore it is said: “The bhikkhu who is possessed of virtue consisting in restraint by the Pāṭimokkha” .🔽For when this virtue of restraint of the sense faculties is fulfilled,

original: pātimokkhasaṃvarasīlaṃ suguttaṃ surakkhitameva hoti, susaṃvihitakaṇṭakavati viya
analyzed: pātimokkha saṃvara sīlam su guttam su rakkhitam eva hoti su saṃvihita kaṇṭakavati viya
translated: the virtue of restraint by the Pāṭimokkha is well guarded, well protected.

original: sassanti. Kāraṇavasenāti asādhāraṇakāraṇassa vasena. Asādhāraṇakāraṇavasena hi phalaṃ
analyzed: sassanti kāraṇa vasena ati asādhāraṇa kāraṇassa vasena asādhāraṇa kāraṇa vasena hi phalam
translated: “By reason of cause” means by reason of the cause that is not common to all. For the fruit is indicated by the cause that is not common to all,

original: apadisīyati, yathā yavaṅkuro bherisaddoti. Nissayavohārena vā etaṃ nissitavacanaṃ,
analyzed: apadisīyati yathā yavaṅkuraḥ bheri saddo ti nissaya vohārena vā etam nissita vacanam
translated: like the sprout of barley and the sound of a drum. Or else this is a locative of dependence,

original: yathā mañcā ukkuṭṭhiṃ karontīti. Rūpanti rūpāyatanaṃ. Cakkhunā rūpaṃ disvāti ettha
analyzed: yathā mañcāḥ ukkuṭṭhim karonti iti rūpanti rūpa āyatanam cakkhunā rūpam disvā ati ettha
translated: like “The beds make a noise.” “Materiality” is the materiality base. “Having seen materiality with the eye” :

original: yadi cakkhu rūpaṃ passeyya, aññaviññāṇasamaṅginopi passeyyuṃ, na cetaṃ atthi, kasmā?
analyzed: yadi cakkhu rūpam passeyya añña viññāṇa samaṅginaḥ api passeyyum na ca itam atthi kasmā
translated: if the eye saw materiality, then those possessing other kinds of consciousness would also see it. But that is not so. Why?

original: Acetanattā cakkhussa. Tenāha “cakkhu rūpaṃ na passati acittakattā”ti. Atha viññāṇaṃ
analyzed: acetana ttā cakkhussa tena āha cakkhu rūpam na passati acittaka ttā ati atha viññāṇam
translated: Because the eye is insensate. Therefore it is said: “The eye does not see, because it is without consciousness.”

original: rūpaṃ passeyya, tirokuṭṭādigatampi naṃ passeyya appaṭighabhāvato, idampi natthi sabbassa
analyzed: rūpam passeyya tiro kuṭṭa ādi gatam pi nam passeyya appaṭigha bhāvataḥ idam pi natthi sabbassa
translated: If consciousness saw materiality, then it would see it even when screened by a wall, etc., because it is not obstructed. But that is not so. Why?

original: viññāṇassa dassanābhāvato. Tenāha “cittaṃ na passati acakkhukattā”ti. Tattha yathā
analyzed: viññāṇassa dassana abhāvato tena āha cittam na passati acakkhuka ttā ti tattha yathā
translated: Because all consciousness is non-seeing. Therefore it is said: “Consciousness does not see, because it is without eye.”

original: cakkhusannissitaṃ viññāṇaṃ passati, na yaṃ kiñci. Tañca kenaci kuṭṭādinā antarite
analyzed: cakkhu sannissitam viññāṇam passati na yam kiñci tat ca kenacid kuṭṭa ādinā antarite
translated: Herein, just as it is consciousness dependent on the eye that sees, not just any consciousness, and that only sees what is screened by no obstruction,🔽so too it is only the eye that sees, not any other sense base.

original: na uppajjati, yattha ālokassa vibandho. Yattha pana na vibandho phalikagabbhapaṭalādike,
analyzed: na uppajjati yattha ālokassa vibandhaḥ yattha pana na vibandhaḥ phalika gabbha paṭala ādike
translated: It does not arise where there is an obstruction to light. But where there is no obstruction, as in a cave, etc.,

original: tattha antaritepi uppajjateva. Evaṃ viññāṇādhiṭṭhitaṃ cakkhu passati, na yaṃ kiñcīti
analyzed: tattha antarite api uppajjatā iva evam viññāṇa adhiṭṭhitam cakkhu passati na yam kiñci iti
translated: it arises even when there is an obstruction. So it is the eye that is determined by consciousness that sees, not just any eye.

original: viññāṇādhiṭṭhitaṃ cakkhuṃ sandhāyetaṃ vuttaṃ “cakkhunā rūpaṃ disvā”ti.
analyzed: viññāṇa adhiṭṭhitam cakkhum sandhāya itam vuttam cakkhunā rūpam disvā ti
translated: This is said with reference to the eye that is determined by consciousness.

original: Dvārārammaṇasaṅghaṭṭeti dvārassa ārammaṇena saṅghaṭṭe sati, cakkhussa rūpārammaṇe🔽āpāthagateti adhippāyo. Pasādavatthukena cittenāti cakkhupasādavatthukena tannissāya
analyzed: dvāra ārammaṇa saṅghaṭṭa iti dvārassa ārammaṇena saṅghaṭṭe sati cakkhussa rūpa ārammaṇe  āpātha gatā iti adhippāyaḥ pasāda vatthukena cittena ati cakkhu pasāda vatthukena tat nissāya
translated: When there is a conjunction of the door and the object, when the object, visible data, comes into focus in the eye,🔽is what is intended. With a consciousness that has sensitivity as its object: with a consciousness that has sensitivity of the eye as its object, that is supported by it and occurs by taking it as its proximate cause,

original: pavattena viññāṇena, yaṃ “cakkhuviññāṇa”nti vuccati. Passatīti oloketi. Cakkhupasādasannissaye
analyzed: pavattena viññāṇena yam cakkhu viññāṇanti vuccati passati iti oloketi cakkhu pasāda sannissaye
translated: which is called “eye-consciousness.” Sees: looks.

original: hi viññāṇe ālokānuggahitaṃ rūpārammaṇaṃ sannissayaguṇena obhāsente taṃsamaṅgipuggalo
analyzed: hi viññāṇe āloka anuggahitam rūpa ārammaṇam sannissaya guṇena obhāsente tad samaṅgi puggalo
translated: For it is when consciousness, which is supported by sensitivity of the eye, illuminates the object, visible data, assisted by light, by the quality of its support,

original: “rūpaṃ passatī”ti vuccati. Obhāsanañcettha ārammaṇassa yathāsabhāvato vibhāvanaṃ,
analyzed: rūpam passati iti vuccati obhāsanam ca ittha ārammaṇassa yathā sabhāvataḥ vibhāvanam
translated: that the person, as a component of that consciousness, is said to “see visible data.” And here illumination of the object is its making manifest according to its real individual essence,

original: yaṃ “paccakkhato gahaṇa”nti vuccati. Usunā lakkhassa vedhe sijjhante tassa sambhārabhūtena
analyzed: yam paccakkhataḥ gahaṇanti vuccati usunā lakkhassa vedhe sijjhante tassa sambhāra bhūtena
translated: Just as when it is said “He hits the target with the arrow,” and it is the bow that is the condition for the arrow,

original: dhanunā vijjhatīti vacanaṃ viya viññāṇena rūpadassane sijjhante cakkhunā rūpaṃ passatīti
analyzed: dhanunā vijjhati iti vacanam viya viññāṇena rūpa dassane sijjhante cakkhunā rūpam passati iti
translated: so too, when it is said “He sees visible objects with the eye,” it is the eye that is the condition for the consciousness.

original: īdisī sasambhārakathā nāmesā hoti. Sasambhārā kathā sasambhārakathā, dassanassa kāraṇasahitāti
analyzed: īdisī sa sambhāra kathā nāma isā hoti sa sambhārā kathā sa sambhāra kathā dassanassa kāraṇa sahitā ati
translated: This is called “a statement with its condition.” A statement with its condition is a statement with the cause of seeing.

original: attho. Sasambhārassa vā dassanassa kathā sasambhārakathā. Tasmāti yasmā kevalena
analyzed: attho sa sambhārassa vā dassanassa kathā sa sambhāra kathā tasmā ati yasmā kevalena
translated: Or alternatively, it is a statement about seeing with its condition.

original: cakkhunā, kevalena vā viññāṇena rūpadassanaṃ natthi, tasmā.
analyzed: cakkhunā kevalena vā viññāṇena rūpa dassanam na atthi tasmā
translated: Therefore: since there is no seeing of visible objects with the eye alone or with consciousness alone,

original: Itthipurisanimittaṃ vāti ettha itthisantānanissitarūpamukhena gayhamānaṃ saṇṭhānaṃ
analyzed: itthi purisa nimittam vā ati ettha itthi santāna nissita rūpa mukhena gayhamānam saṇṭhānam
translated: The sign of a woman or a man: the shape that is apprehended by making the visible-data object that is dependent on a woman’s continuity is the sign of a woman in the sense that it is a cause for the perception “woman.”

original: thanamaṃsāvisadatā nimmassumukhatā kesabandhanavatthaggahaṇaṃ avisadaṭṭhānagamanādi
analyzed: thana maṃsa avisada tā nimmassu mukha tā kesa bandhana vattha ggahaṇam avisada ṭṭhāna gamana ādi
translated: The shape, the position, the smoothness of the flesh, the lack of hair, the shape of the face, the wearing of hair-ornaments and girdles, the unsteadiness of the gait, and so on,

original: ca sabbaṃ “itthī”ti sañjānanassa kāraṇabhāvato itthinimittaṃ. Vuttavipariyāyato purisanimittaṃ
analyzed: ca sabbam itthi iti sañjānanassa kāraṇa bhāvataḥ itthi nimittam vutta vipariyāyato purisa nimittam
translated: are the sign of a woman. The sign of a man is the opposite of that.

original: veditabbaṃ. Subhanimittādikaṃ vāti ettha rāguppattihetubhūto iṭṭhākāro subhanimittaṃ.
analyzed: veditabbam subha nimitta ādikam vā ati ettha rāga uppatti hetu bhūtaḥ iṭṭha ākāraḥ subha nimittam
translated: and should be understood. The sign of the beautiful, etc., is the sign of the beautiful that is a cause for the arising of greed.

original: Ādi-saddena paṭighanimittādīnaṃ saṅgaho. So pana dosuppattiādihetubhūto aniṭṭhādiākāro
analyzed: ādi saddena paṭigha nimitta ādīnam saṅgahaḥ saḥ pana dosuppatti ādi hetu bhūtaḥ aniṭṭha ādi ākāro
translated: The “etc.” includes the sign of the repulsive, etc. That is a cause for the arising of hate, etc., and is the unlovely aspect, etc.

original: veditabbo. Kāmañcettha pāḷiyaṃ abhijjhādomanassāva sarūpato āgatā, upekkhānimittassāpi
analyzed: veditabbo kāmam ca ittha pāḷiyam abhijjhā domanassā ava sarūpataḥ āgatāḥ upekkhā nimittassa api
translated: Here, although only covetousness and grief are given in the text in their actual forms, the sign of equanimity should be included

original: pana saṅgaho icchitabbo, asamapekkhanena uppajjanakamohassāpi asaṃvarabhāvato. Tathā
analyzed: pana saṅgahaḥ icchitabbaḥ asamapekkhanena uppajjanaka mohassa api asaṃvara bhāvato tathā
translated: because delusion also arises through not looking on with equanimity, and because there is no restraint in that.

original: hi vakkhati “muṭṭhasaccaṃ vā aññāṇaṃ vā”ti. Upekkhānimittanti cettha aññāṇupekkhāya
analyzed: hi vakkhati muṭṭha saccam vā aññāṇam vā ati upekkhā nimittan ti ca ittha aññāṇa upekkhāya
translated: For it is said: “Lack of clear awareness or ignorance” .

original: vatthubhūtaṃ ārammaṇaṃ, tañcassa asamapekkhanavasena veditabbaṃ. Evaṃ saṅkhepato
analyzed: vatthu bhūtam ārammaṇam tat ca assa a samapekkhana vasena veditabbam evam saṅkhepato
translated: And here the sign of equanimity is the object that is the basis for the equanimity of unknowing, and that should be understood as the non-looking-on with equanimity. So in brief

original: rāgadosamohānaṃ kāraṇaṃ “subhanimittādika”nti vuttaṃ. Tenāha “kilesavatthubhūtaṃ
analyzed: rāga dosa mohānam kāraṇam subha nimitta ādikam ti vuttam tena āha kilesa vatthu bhūtam
translated: the cause of greed, hate, and delusion is said to be “the sign of the beautiful, etc.” Hence it is said: “The sign is the basis for the defilements” .

original: nimitta”nti. Diṭṭhamatteyeva saṇṭhātīti “diṭṭhe diṭṭhamattaṃ bhavissatī”ti sutte
analyzed: nimittam ti diṭṭha mattā iya iva saṇṭhāti iti diṭṭhe diṭṭha mattam bhavissati iti sutte
translated: “It settles down in mere seeing” : “In the seen there will only be what is seen” .

original: vuttanayena vaṇṇāyatane cakkhuviññāṇena, vīthicittehi ca gahitamatteyeva tiṭṭhati,
analyzed: vutta nayena vaṇṇa āyatane cakkhu viññāṇena vīthi cittehi ca tiṭṭhati
translated: It remains as it is apprehended by eye-consciousness and by the consciousnesses of the cognitive series in the way already described.🔽It does not go beyond that to construct any other mode such as the beautiful, etc.

original: na tato paraṃ kiñci subhādiākāraṃ parikappeti. Pākaṭabhāvakaraṇatoti paribyattabhāvakaraṇato🔽vibhūtabhāvakaraṇato. Visabhāgavatthuno hi hatthādiavayavesu subhādito parikappentassa
analyzed: na tatas param kiñci subha ādi ākāram parikappeti pākaṭa bhāva karaṇato ti paribyatta bhāva karaṇato  vibhūta bhāva karaṇataḥ visa bhāga vatthunaḥ hi hattha ādi avayavesu subha āditaḥ parikappentassa
translated: By making it evident: by making it manifest.🔽For when one constructs the beautiful, etc., in the various parts of the body such as the hands, the defilements that arise there one after another are evident,

original: aparāparaṃ tattha uppajjamānā kilesā paribyattā hontīti te tesaṃ anubyañjanā nāma.
analyzed: apara aparam tattha uppajjamānā kilesā paribyattāḥ honti iti te tesam anubyañjanāḥ nāma
translated: and so they are called its secondary characteristics.

original: Te pana yasmā tathā tathā sanniviṭṭhānaṃ bhūtupādāyarūpānaṃ sannivesākāro. Na hi
analyzed: te pana yasmai tathā tathā sanniviṭṭhānam sannivesa ākāraḥ na hi
translated: But they are the mode of appearance of the primary and derived materiality that is arranged in such and such a way.🔽For apart from that there is no such thing as a hand, etc., in the ultimate sense.

original: taṃ muñcitvā paramatthato hatthādi nāma koci atthi. Tasmā vuttaṃ “hatthapāda…pe…
analyzed: tam muñcitvā paramatthataḥ hattha ādi nāma koci atthi tasmā vuttam hattha pādape
translated: That is why it is said, “He does not apprehend the mode of the hand, the mode of the foot, …

original: ākāraṃ na gaṇhātī”ti. Kiṃ pana gaṇhātīti āha “yaṃ tattha bhūtaṃ, tadeva gaṇhātī”ti.
analyzed: ākāram na gaṇhāti iti kim pana gaṇhāti iti āha yam tattha bhūtam tat eva gaṇhāti iti
translated: But what does he apprehend? He apprehends only what is there.

original: Yaṃ tasmiṃ sarīre vijjamānaṃ kesalomādi bhūtupādāyamattaṃ vā, tadeva yāthāvato gaṇhāti.
analyzed: yam tasmin sarīre vijjamānam kesa loma ādi bhūtu pādāya mattam vā tat eva yāthāvataḥ gaṇhāti
translated: He apprehends only what is actually there in the body, namely, the mere primary and derived materiality consisting of head hairs, body hairs, etc., as it really is.

original: Tattha asubhākāragahaṇassa nidassanaṃ dassento “cetiyapabbatavāsī”tiādinā mahātissattheravatthuṃ āhari.
analyzed: tattha asubha ākāra gahaṇassa nidassanam dassento cetiya pabbata vāsī iti ādinā mahā tissa tthera vatthum āhari
translated: Herein, in order to show the taking of the aspect of foulness, he introduced the story of the Elder Maha Tissa, who lived on the Cetiya Mountain.

original: Tattha sumaṇḍitapasādhitāti suṭṭhu maṇḍitā pasādhitā ca. Ābharaṇādīhi āhārimehi maṇḍanaṃ.🔽Sarīrassa ucchādanādivasena paṭisaṅkharaṇaṃ pasādhananti vadanti, ābharaṇehi, pana
analyzed: tattha su maṇḍita pasādhitā ti suṭṭhu maṇḍitā pasādhitā ca ābharaṇa ādīhi maṇḍanam  sarīrassa ucchādana ādi vasena paṭisaṅkharaṇam vadanti ābharaṇehi pana
translated: Herein, well adorned and well anointed: well adorned and well anointed. Adorning is with ornaments, etc., and anointing is with scents, etc.🔽They say that adorning is the adorning of the body by rubbing it with scents, etc., and anointing is the adorning by filling in the hollows,

original: vatthālaṅkārādīhi ca alaṅkaraṇaṃ pasādhanaṃ. Ūnaṭṭhānapūraṇaṃ maṇḍanaṃ. Vipallatthacittāti🔽rāgavasena viparītacittā. Olokentoti thero kammaṭṭhānamanasikāreneva gacchanto saddakaṇṭakattā
analyzed: vattha alaṅkāra ādīhi ca alaṅkaraṇam pasādhanam ūna ṭṭhāna pūraṇam maṇḍanam vipallattha citta ati  rāga vasena viparīta cittā olokento ti thero kammaṭṭhāna manasikārena iva gacchanto sadda kaṇṭaka ttā
translated: but adorning is the adorning with ornaments, etc., and anointing is the adorning with clothes, adornments, etc.🔽With perverted mind: with a mind perverted by lust.

original: pubbabhāgamanasikārassa hasitasaddānusārena “kimeta”nti olokento. Asubhasaññanti
analyzed: pubba bhāga manasikārassa hasita sadda anusārena kim etat ti olokento asubha saññanti
translated: Looking: the elder was going along with his mind occupied with his meditation subject. But because the sound of laughter was a distraction to the preliminary stage of his meditation, he looked to see what it was.🔽With perception of foulness:🔽with the perception of a skeleton, for the elder was then practising the skeleton meditation.

original: aṭṭhikasaññaṃ. Aṭṭhikakammaṭṭhānaṃ hi thero tadā pariharati. Arahattaṃ pāpuṇīti thero
analyzed: aṭṭhika saññam aṭṭhika kammaṭṭhānam hi thero tadā pariharati arahattam pāpuṇi iti thero
translated: He reached Arahantship:

original: kira tassā hasantiyā dantaṭṭhidassaneneva pubbabhāgabhāvanāya subhāvitattā paṭibhāganimittaṃ,🔽sātisayañca upacārajjhānaṃ labhitvā yathāṭhitova tattha paṭhamajjhānaṃ adhigantvā
analyzed: kira tassāḥ hasantiyāḥ danta ṭṭhi dassanena iva pubbabhāga bhāvanāya su bhāvita ttā paṭibhāga nimittam  sa atisayam ca upacāra jhānam labhitvā yathā ṭhitaḥ uva tattha paṭhama jhānam adhigantvā
translated: and by the mere sight of her teeth as she laughed, the counterpart sign arose in him,

original: taṃ pādakaṃ katvā vipassanaṃ vaḍḍhetvā maggaparamparāya āsavakkhayaṃ pāpuṇi. Pubbasaññaṃ
analyzed: tam pādakam katvā vipassanam vaḍḍhetvā magga paramparāya āsava kkhayam pāpuṇi pubba saññam
translated: and he attained the first jhāna. Then, standing there, he developed insight and reached Arahantship.

original: anussarīti pubbakaṃ yathāraddhaṃ kālena kālaṃ anuyuñjiyamānaṃ aṭṭhikakammaṭṭhānaṃ
analyzed: anussarīti pubbakam yathā āraddham kālena kālam anuyuñjiyamānam aṭṭhika kammaṭṭhānam
translated: “Recollecting the former sign” means that he recalled the meditation subject of the skeleton, which he had previously undertaken from time to time.

original: anussari samannāhari. Anumagganti anupathaṃ tassā padānupadaṃ. Therassa kira bhāvanāya
analyzed: anussari samannāhari anumagganti anupatham tassā pada anupadam therassa kira bhāvanāya
translated: “The path she had gone along” means the path she had taken. The path she had taken was the same as the path he had taken.

original: paguṇabhāvato dantaṭṭhidassaneneva tassā sakalasarīraṃ aṭṭhikasaṅghātabhāvena upaṭṭhāsi.
analyzed: paguṇa bhāvataḥ danta ṭṭhi dassanena iva tassā sakala sarīram aṭṭhika saṅghāta bhāvena upaṭṭhāsi
translated: As the elder’s meditation had become proficient, her whole body appeared to him as a collection of bones by the mere sight of her teeth.

original: Na taṃ “itthī”ti vā “puriso”ti vā sañjāni. Tenāha “nābhijānāmi…pe… mahāpathe”ti.
analyzed: na tam itthī iti vā puriso ti vā tena āha na abhijānāmi pe mahāpatha iti
translated: He did not perceive her as a woman or a man. That is why he said: “I do not remember … on the highway.”

original: “Yassa cakkhundriyāsaṃvarassa hetū”ti vatvā puna “tassa cakkhundriyassa satikavāṭena
analyzed: yassa cakkhu indriya asaṃvarassa hetu uti vatvā puna tassa cakkhu indriyassa sati kavāṭena
translated: “The cause for the restraint of the eye faculty” means the mindfulness door of the eye faculty.

original: pidahanatthāyā”ti vuttaṃ, na asaṃvarassāti. Yadidaṃ yaṃ cakkhundriyāsaṃvarassa hetu🔽abhijjhādianvāssavanaṃ dassitaṃ, taṃ asaṃvutacakkhundriyasseva hetu pavattaṃ dassitanti
analyzed: pidahana tthāya ati vuttam na asaṃvarassa ati yat idam yam cakkhu indriya asaṃvarassa hetu  dassitam tam asaṃvuta cakkhu indriyassa iva hetu pavattam dassitanti
translated: “For the purpose of restraint” is said, not for the purpose of non-restraint.🔽The reason why the passage beginning with “because of the ear faculty” is given is this. The reason for the lack of restraint of the ear faculty is shown to be the occurrence of covetousness, etc.,

original: katvā vuttaṃ. Cakkhudvārikassa hi abhijjhādianvāssavanassa taṃdvārikaviññāṇassa viya🔽cakkhundriyaṃ padhānakāraṇaṃ. Cakkhundriyassa asaṃvutatte sati te anvāssavantīti
analyzed: katvā vuttam cakkhu dvārikassa hi abhijjhā ādi anvāssavanassa taṃdvārika viññāṇassa viya  cakkhu indriyam padhāna kāraṇam cakkhu indriyassa a saṃvuta tte sati te anvāssavanti iti
translated: and this is said because it is the reason for the lack of restraint of the ear faculty. For covetousness, etc., which occur through the door of the ear are the principal cause of the ear faculty,🔽just as the consciousness occurring through that door is. When there is lack of restraint of the ear faculty, covetousness, etc., occur.

original: asaṃvariyamānacakkhundriyahetuko so asaṃvaro tathā vuttoti. Yatvādhikaraṇanti hi
analyzed: a saṃvariyamāna cakkhu indriya hetuko so asaṃvaro tathā vutto ti yatvā adhikaraṇam ti hi
translated: Therefore the lack of restraint is said to be due to the ear faculty, which is not restrained. The words “because of the ear faculty”

original: yassa cakkhundriyassa kāraṇāti attho. Kīdisassa ca kāraṇāti? Asaṃvutassa, kiñca asaṃvutaṃ?
analyzed: yassa cakkhu indriyassa kāraṇā ati atthaḥ kīdisassa ca kāraṇā ati asaṃvutassa kiñca asaṃvutam
translated: mean “because of the ear faculty as the reason.” And what kind of ear faculty is the reason? The unrestrained ear faculty. And what is unrestrained?

original: Yassa cakkhundriyāsaṃvarassa hetu abhijjhādayo anvāssavanti, tassa saṃvarāyāti ayamettha yojanā.
analyzed: yassa cakkhu indriya asaṃvarassa hetu abhijjhā ādayaḥ anvāssavanti tassa saṃvarāya ati ayam ettha yojanā
translated: The lack of restraint of the ear faculty, because of which covetousness, etc., occur. “For the purpose of restraining that” is the construction here.

original: Javanakkhaṇe pana sace dussīlyaṃ vātiādi puna avacanatthaṃ idheva sabbaṃ vuttanti
analyzed: java nakkhaṇe pana sace dussīlyam vā ati ādi puna avacana attham idha iva sabbam vuttan ti
translated: But in order to avoid repetition, all this is said here in the passage beginning with “at the impulsion moment, if unvirtuous states flow in” .

original: chasu dvāresu yathāsambhavaṃ veditabbaṃ. Na hi pañcadvāre kāyavacīduccaritasaṅkhātaṃ🔽dussīlyaṃ atthi, tasmā dussīlyāsaṃvaro manodvāravasena, sesāsaṃvaro chadvāravasena🔽yojetabbo. Muṭṭhasaccādīnaṃ hi satipaṭipakkhākusaladhammādibhāvato siyā pañcadvāre🔽uppatti, na tveva kāyikavācasikavītikkamabhūtassa dussīlyassa tattha uppatti, pañcadvārikajavanānaṃ
analyzed: chasu dvāresu yathāsambhavam veditabbam na hi pañca dvāre kāya vacī duccarita saṅkhātam  dussīlyaṃ atthi tasmai dussīlya a saṃvaraḥ manaḥ dvāra vasena sesa a saṃvaraḥ cha dvāra vasena  yojetabbaḥ muṭṭha sacca ādīnam hi sati paṭipakkha akusala dhamma ādi bhāvato siyā pañca dvāre  uppatti na tu eva kāyika vācasika vītikkama bhūtassa dussīlyassa tattha uppatti pañcadvārika javanānaṃ
translated: It should be understood in the six doors as appropriate. For there is no misconduct called bodily and verbal misconduct in the five doors. Therefore the restraint of misconduct is to be understood by way of the mind door, and the other restraints by way of the six doors. For the unwholesome states that are the opposites of the mindfulnesses, etc., may arise in the five doors,🔽but the misconduct that consists in the transgression of bodily and verbal action does not arise there.🔽

original: aviññattijanakattā. Dussīlyādayo cettha pañca asaṃvarā sīlasaṃvarādīnaṃ pañcannaṃ🔽saṃvarānaṃ paṭipakkhabhāvena vuttā. Tasmiṃ satīti tasmiṃ asaṃvare sati.🔽Yathā kinti yena pakārena javane uppajjamāno asaṃvaro “cakkhundriye asaṃvaro”ti vuccati,
analyzed: a viññatti janaka ttā dussīlya ādayaḥ ca ittha pañca asaṃvarā sīla saṃvara ādīnam pañcannam  saṃvarānam paṭipakkha bhāvena vuttā tasmin sati iti tasmin asaṃvare sati  yathā kinti yena pakārena javane uppajjamānaḥ asaṃvaro cakkhu indriye asaṃvaro ti vuccati
translated: It should be understood in the six doors as appropriate. For there is no misconduct called bodily and verbal misconduct in the five doors. Therefore the restraint of misconduct should be combined with the mind door, and the other restraints with the six doors. For it is possible that forgetfulness, etc., arise in the five doors, since they are unwholesome states opposed to the foundations of mindfulness, and so on. But there is no arising there of misconduct consisting in transgression by body and speech, because the impulsions in the five doors do not generate intimation.1 And here the five kinds of non-restraint, namely, misconduct, etc., are mentioned as the opposites of the five kinds of restraint, namely, restraint by virtue, and so on. When there is that: when there is that non-restraint.

original: taṃ nidassanaṃ kinti attho. Yathātiādinā nagaradvāre asaṃvare sati taṃsambandhānaṃ
analyzed: tat nidassanam kim ti atthaḥ yathā āti ādinā nagara dvāre asaṃvare sati
translated: In what way? In what way does non-restraint, when it arises in impulsions, come to be called “non-restraint in the eye faculty”? That is the question. The meaning is: what is the illustration? In the way, etc.: when there is non-restraint in the city gate, then those who are connected with it

original: gharādīnaṃ asaṃvutatā viya javane asaṃvare sati taṃsambandhānaṃ dvārādīnaṃ asaṃvutatāti
analyzed: a saṃvuta tā javane a saṃvare sati dvāra ādīnam a saṃvuta tā ati
translated: Just as the house, etc., are unguarded when the door, etc., are unguarded, so too the associated states are unguarded when the impulsions are unguarded.

original: evaṃ aññāsaṃvare aññāsaṃvutatā sāmaññameva nidasseti, na pubbāparasāmaññaṃ, antobahisāmaññaṃ
analyzed: evam aññā saṃvare aññā a saṃvuta tā sāmaññam eva nidasseti na pubba apara sāmaññam antobahi sāmaññam
translated: Thus he shows the similarity of unguardedness in the two cases, not the similarity of guardedness.

original: vā. Sati vā dvārabhavaṅgādike puna uppajjamānaṃ javanaṃ bāhiraṃ viya katvā nagaradvārasamānaṃ🔽vuttaṃ, itarañca antonagare gharādisamānaṃ. Paccayabhāvena hi purimanipphannaṃ javanakāle
analyzed: vā sati vā dvāra bhavaṅga ādike punar uppajjamānam javanam bāhiram katvā nagara dvāra samānam  vuttam itarat ca antar nagare ghara ādi samānam paccaya bhāvena hi purima nipphannam javana kāle
translated: Or alternatively, the occurrence of the impulsions in the door of the life-continuum, etc., can be regarded as external, like a city gate,

original: asantampi bhavaṅgādi cakkhādi viya phalanipphattiyā santaṃyeva nāma hoti. Na hi dharamānaṃyeva
analyzed: asantam pi bhavaṅga ādi cakkha ādi viya phala nipphattiyā santam yā iva nāma hoti na hi dharamānam yā iva
translated: and the life-continuum, etc., as the house, etc., inside the city. For although the life-continuum, etc., are not actually present at the time of the occurrence of the prior-fruit kamma-process,

original: “santa”nti vuccati. “Bāhiraṃ viya katvā”ti ca paramatthato javanassa bāhirabhāve,
analyzed: santanti vuccati bāhiram viya katvā iti ca paramatthataḥ javanassa bāhira bhāve
translated: they are nevertheless called “present” because they are the cause of the fruit. For it is not only what is actually present that is called “present.”

original: itarassa ca abbhantarabhāve asatipi “pabhassaramidaṃ, bhikkhave, cittaṃ, tañca kho
analyzed: itarassa ca abbhantara bhāve asati pi pabhassaram idam bhikkhave cittam tat ca kho
translated: And although the impulsions are not actually external and the other states are not actually internal, still the impulsions are called “external” as if they were,🔽and the other states are called “internal” as if they were, because of their respective positions as condition and as conditionally arisen.

original: āgantukehi upakkiliṭṭha”ntiādi vacanato āgantukabhūtassa kadāci kadāci uppajjamānassa🔽javanassa bāhirabhāvo, tabbidhurasabhāvassa itarassa abbhantarabhāvo ekena pariyāyena
analyzed: āgantukehi vacanataḥ āgantuka bhūtassa kadāci kadāci uppajjamānassa  javanassa bāhira bhāvo tad bidhura sa bhāvassa itarassa abbhantara bhāvo ekena pariyāyena
translated: “The mind is defiled by adventitious defilements” .🔽So the occurrence of the impulsions, which are adventitious in the way stated, is external in one aspect,🔽and the occurrence of the other kind, which has that as its individual essence, is internal in one aspect.

original: hotīti katvā vuttaṃ. Javane vā asaṃvare uppanne tato paraṃ dvārabhavaṅgādīnaṃ asaṃvarahetubhāvāpattito.
analyzed: hoti iti katvā vuttam javane vā asaṃvare uppanne tatas param dvāra bhavaṅga ādīnam asaṃvara hetu bhāva āpattitaḥ
translated: Or alternatively, when the non-restraint occurs in the impulsions, then the doors, the life-continuum, etc., become the cause of that non-restraint.

original: Asaṃvarassa hi uppattiyā dvārabhavaṅgādīnaṃ tassa hetubhāvo paññāyatīti. Nagaradvārasadisena
analyzed: asaṃvarassa hi uppattiyā dvāra bhavaṅga ādīnam tassa hetu bhāvo paññāyati iti nagara dvāra sadisena
translated: For it is only when non-restraint occurs that the doors, the life-continuum, etc., are known as its cause.🔽The impulsions are like a city gate because they are the door for the entry of defilements such as unvirtuousness, etc.,

original: javanena pavisitvā dussīlyādicorānaṃ dvārabhavaṅgādīsu musanaṃ kusalabhaṇḍavināsanaṃ🔽kathitaṃ. Yasmiṃ hi dvāre asaṃvaro uppajjati, so tattha dvārādīnaṃ saṃvarūpanissayabhāvaṃ
analyzed: javanena pavisitvā dussīlya ādi corānam dvāra bhavaṅga ādīsu musanam kusala bhaṇḍa vināsanam  kathitam yasmin hi dvāre asaṃvaraḥ uppajjati saḥ tattha dvāra ādīnam
translated: and the doors, the life-continuum, etc., are like the destruction of the goods in the city gate by thieves, etc.,🔽because they are the door for the destruction of the goods consisting of profitable states. For the non-restraint occurs in a particular door, and it does so by interrupting the continuity of the door’s state of restraint.

original: upacchindantoyeva pavattatīti. Dvārabhavaṅgādīnaṃ javanena saha sambandho ekasantatipariyāpannato daṭṭhabbo.
analyzed: upacchindanto yā iva pavattati iti dvāra bhavaṅga ādīnam javanena saha sambandhaḥ eka santati pariyāpannataḥ daṭṭhabbo
translated: The connection between the doors, the life-continuum, etc., and the impulsions should be regarded as being in a single continuity.

original: Ettha ca cakkhudvāre rūpārammaṇe āpāthagate niyamitādivasena kusalākusalajavane sattakkhattuṃ
analyzed: ettha ca cakkhu dvāre rūpa ārammaṇe āpātha gate niyamita ādi vasena kusala akusala javane satta kkhattum
translated: And here, when a visible-data object has come into the focus of the eye door, then in the profitable and unprofitable impulsions that arise seven times in the manner of restraint, etc.,

original: uppajjitvā bhavaṅgaṃ otiṇṇe tadanurūpameva manodvārikajavane tasmiṃyevārammaṇe sattakkhattuṃyeva🔽uppajjitvā bhavaṅgaṃ otiṇṇe puna tasmiṃyeva dvāre tadevārammaṇaṃ nissāya “itthī puriso”tiādinā
analyzed: uppajjitvā bhavaṅgam otiṇṇe tad anurūpam eva manodvārika javane tasmin yeva ārammaṇe satta kkhattum yeva  uppajjitvā bhavaṅgam otiṇṇe puna tasmin yeva dvāre tat eva ārammaṇam nissāya itthī purisa iti ādinā
translated: after which the life-continuum enters, there is in the mind-door impulsion that is in conformity with them, which arises seven times only on that same object,🔽after which the life-continuum enters, and then again in the same door on that same object, which impulsion impels seven times in the manner of confidence, faith, etc., as it resolves “woman,” “man,” etc.

original: vavatthapentaṃ pasādarajjanādivasena sattakkhattuṃ javanaṃ javati. Evaṃ pavattamānaṃ
analyzed: vavatthapentam pasāda rajjana ādi vasena satta kkhattum javanam javati evam pavattamānam
translated: Impulsion that occurs thus

original: javanaṃ sandhāya “javane dussīlyādīsu uppannesu tasmiṃ asaṃvare sati dvārampi agutta”ntiādi vuttaṃ.
analyzed: javanam sandhāya javane dussīlya ādīsu uppannesu tasmin asaṃvare sati dvāram pi agutta nti ādi vuttam
translated: is what is referred to in the words, “When there is non-restraint in the arising of unvirtuousness, etc., then the door is unguarded too.”🔽But in that impulsion,

original: Tasmiṃ pana javane. Sīlādīsūti sīlasaṃvarasatisaṃvarañāṇasaṃvarakhantisaṃvaravīriyasaṃvaresu
analyzed: tasmin pana javane sīla ādīsu uti sīla saṃvara sati saṃvara ñāṇa saṃvara khanti saṃvara vīriya saṃvaresu
translated: in the arising of virtue, etc., in the restraint of virtue, restraint of mindfulness, restraint of knowledge, restraint of patience, and restraint of energy,

original: uppannesu. Yathā hi pageva satiārakkhaṃ anupaṭṭhapentassa dussīlyādīnaṃ uppatti,
analyzed: uppannesu yathā hi pageva sati ārakkham an upaṭṭhapentassa dussīlya ādīnam uppatti
translated: for just as there is the arising of unvirtuousness, etc., in one who does not maintain the protection of mindfulness,

original: evaṃ pageva satiārakkhaṃ upaṭṭhapentassa sīlādīnaṃ uppatti veditabbā. Saddādīsupi
analyzed: evam pageva sati ārakkham upaṭṭhapentassa sīla ādīnam uppatti veditabbā sadda ādīsu pi
translated: and so all the more so when he is maintaining the protection of mindfulness.

original: yathārahaṃ nimittānubyañjanāni veditabbāni. Sotaviññāṇena hi saddaṃ sutvā “itthisaddo”ti🔽vā “purisasaddo”ti vā iṭṭhāniṭṭhādikaṃ vā kilesavatthubhūtaṃ nimittaṃ na gaṇhāti,🔽sutamatte eva saṇṭhāti. Yo ca gītasaddādikassa kilesānaṃ anu anu byañjanato “anubyañjana”nti
analyzed: yathāraham nimitta anubyañjanāni veditabbāni sota viññāṇena hi saddam sutvā itthi saddo ti  vā purisa saddaḥ ti vā iṭṭha aniṭṭha ādikam vā kilesa vatthu bhūtam nimittam na gaṇhāti  suta matte eva yaḥ ca gīta sadda ādikassa kilesānam anu anu byañjanataḥ
translated: The sign and the particulars should be understood in the case of sounds, etc., too,🔽as appropriate. For when he has heard a sound with ear-consciousness, he does not apprehend the sign of a desirable or undesirable sound as “woman’s voice” or “man’s voice” or “pleasant” or “unpleasant,” etc., as a basis for defilements;

original: laddhavohāro mandatārādivasena vavatthito chajjādibhedabhinno ākāro, tampi na gaṇhātīti.
analyzed: laddha vohāraḥ manda tārā ādi vasena vavatthito chajja ādi bheda bhinno ākāro na gaṇhāti iti
translated: he is satisfied with mere hearing. And he does not apprehend the mode, called a “particular” because it is a particular of what is desirable or undesirable as a basis for defilements, as “soft,” “rough,” etc., or as classified as “song,” “prose,” and so on.🔽So too in the case of odours, etc., as appropriate.

original: Evaṃ gandhādīsupi yathārahaṃ vattabbaṃ. Manodvāre pana sāvajjanabhavaṅgaṃ manodvāraṃ
analyzed: evam yathāraham vattabbam manaḥ dvāre pana sa avajjana bhavaṅgam manaḥ dvāram
translated: But in the case of the mind door, the mind door is the rebirth-linking mind and the functional mind that has the characteristic of adverting.

original: tasmiṃ dvāre dhammārammaṇe āpāthagate taṃ javanamanasāva viññāya vijānitvātiādinā
analyzed: tasmin dvāre dhamma ārammaṇe āpātha gate tam javana manasā ava viññāya vijānitvā ati ādinā
translated: When an object comes into focus in that door, then, after adverting has been done, the consciousness that adverts to the object should be understood as “the adverting consciousness” in the following passages: “Having adverted, he comes to know an object” ,🔽“Having adverted, he sees an object” , and so on.

original: yojetabbaṃ. Kileso anubandho etassāti kilesānubandho, so eva nimittādigāho, tato
analyzed: yojetabbam kilesaḥ anubandhaḥ etassa ati kilesa anubandho saḥ eva nimitta ādi gāhaḥ tatas
translated: The apprehending of the sign, etc., is “accompanied by defilement” because it is followed by defilement.

original: parivajjanalakkhaṇaṃ kilesānubandhanimittādiggāhaparivajjanalakkhaṇaṃ. Ādi-saddena
analyzed: parivajjana lakkhaṇam kilesa anubandha nimitta ādi gāha parivajjana lakkhaṇam ādi saddena
translated: Its characteristic is avoiding, i.e. avoiding the sign of the defilements’ recurrence, and so on. The word ‘and so on’

original: anubyañjanaṃ saṅgaṇhāti.
analyzed: anubyañjanam saṅgaṇhāti
translated: includes the details.

original: Ājīvapārisuddhisīlavaṇṇanā🔽16. Vutteti idheva uddesavasena pubbe vutte. Tathā hi “ājīvahetu paññattānaṃ channaṃ
analyzed: ājīva pārisuddhi sīla vaṇṇanā  vutte ti idha iva uddesa vasena pubbe vutte tathā hi ājīva hetu paññattānam channam
translated: The commentary on the virtue of purity of livelihood.

original: sikkhāpadāna”nti paduddhāraṃ katvā tāni pāḷivaseneva dassetuṃ “yāni tānī”tiādi āraddhaṃ.
analyzed: sikkhāpadānam ti paduddhāram katvā tāni pāḷi vasena iva dassetum yāni tāni itiādi āraddham
translated: ‘Stated’ : stated here in the brief exposition given above. For after the words ‘the six training precepts announced on account of livelihood’ had been given in the brief exposition, the following was stated in the detailed explanation in order to show them by the text of the sutta: ‘What are the six training precepts? ‘

original: Tattha yāni tāni evaṃ paññattāni cha sikkhāpadānīti sambandho. Ājīvahetūti jīvikanimittaṃ,
analyzed: tattha yāni tāni evam paññattāni cha sikkhāpadāni iti sambandhaḥ ājīva hetū ti jīvika nimittam
translated: Herein, the construction is: ‘the six training precepts announced in this way’. ‘On account of livelihood’: for the sake of livelihood,

original: “evāhaṃ paccayehi akilamanto jīvissāmī”ti adhippāyena. Ājīvakāraṇāti tasseva vevacanaṃ.🔽Pāpicchoti pāpikāya asantaguṇasambhāvanicchāya samannāgato. Icchāpakatoti icchāya
analyzed: eva aham paccayehi a kilamantaḥ jīvissāmi iti adhippāyena ājīva kāraṇā ti tassa iva vevacanam  pāpa iccho ti pāpikāya asanta guṇa sambhāvan icchāya samannāgataḥ icchā pakato ti icchāya
translated: with the intention ‘In this way I shall live without trouble about requisites.’ ‘For the sake of livelihood’ is a synonym for that.🔽‘With evil desire’: possessed of evil desire, i.e. desire for the manifestation of non-existent good qualities. ‘With a mind overcome by desire’: overcome by desire,

original: apakato upadduto, abhibhūto vā. Asantanti avijjamānaṃ. Abhūtanti anuppannaṃ. Anuppannattā
analyzed: apakataḥ upaddutaḥ abhibhūtaḥ vā asantanti a vijjamānam a bhūtanti anuppannam an uppannattā
translated: oppressed, or dominated, by it. ‘Non-existent’: non-existent, unreal. ‘Unreal’: unarisen.

original: hi tassa taṃ asantanti purimassa pacchimaṃ kāraṇavacanaṃ. Uttarimanussadhammanti
analyzed: hi tassa tam asantam ti purimassa pacchimam kāraṇa vacanam uttari manussa dhammam ti
translated: “A superhuman state”:

original: uttarimanussānaṃ ukkaṭṭhapurisānaṃ dhammaṃ, manussadhammato vā uttari ukkaṭṭhaṃ.
analyzed: uttari manussānam ukkaṭṭha purisānam dhammam manussa dhammataḥ vā uttari ukkaṭṭham
translated: the state of those who are superior to human beings, the best of men, or a state that is superior to, better than, the human state.

original: Ullapatīti uggatāyuko lapati. Sīlaṃ hi bhikkhuno āyu, taṃ tassa tathālapanasamakālameva
analyzed: ullapati iti uggata āyukaḥ lapati sīlam hi bhikkhuno āyu tam tassa tathā ālapana sama kālam eva
translated: “Boasts”: he boasts about his longevity. For a bhikkhu’s virtue is his longevity. That is lost at the very moment he boasts about it.

original: vigacchati. Tenāha “āpatti pārājikassā”ti pārājikasaṅkhātā āpatti assa, pārājikasaññitassa🔽vā vītikkamassa āpajjanaṃ ullapananti attho. Sañcarittaṃ samāpajjatīti sañcaraṇabhāvaṃ
analyzed: vigacchati tena āha āpatti pārājikassa ati pārājika saṅkhātā āpatti assa pārājika saññitassa  vā vītikkamassa āpajjanam ullapananti attho sañcarittam samāpajjati iti sañcaraṇa bhāvam
translated: Hence it is said: “He commits an offense entailing expulsion”: he commits an offense entailing expulsion, an offense that is called “an offense entailing expulsion,”🔽or the transgression that is called “an offense entailing expulsion.” The meaning is: he commits boasting.

original: āpajjati, itthiyā vā purisamatiṃ, purisassa vā itthimatiṃ ārocetīti adhippāyo. “Imesaṃ
analyzed: āpajjati itthiyāḥ vā purisa matim purisassa vā itthi matim āroceti iti adhippāyaḥ imesam
translated: “Enters upon a course of conduct”: he enters upon a course of conduct that is a course of misconduct. The intention is that he informs a woman of a man’s intentions, or a man of a woman’s intentions.

original: channaṃ sikkhāpadānaṃ vītikkamassa vasenā”ti sambandho heṭṭhā dassito eva.
analyzed: channam sikkhāpadānam vītikkamassa vasena ati sambandhaḥ heṭṭhā dassitaḥ eva
translated: “In regard to the breach of any one of these six training rules”: the connection is shown below.🔽“Concealment, etc.”: the text is analyzed below.

original: Kuhanātiādīsūti heṭṭhā uddiṭṭhapāḷiyāva paduddhāro. Ayaṃ pāḷīti ayaṃ vibhaṅge āgatā niddesapāḷi.
analyzed: kuhanā ati ādīsu iti heṭṭhā pad uddhāraḥ ayam pāḷī iti ayam vibhaṅge āgatā niddesa pāḷi
translated: “This is the wording”: this is the description given in the Vibhanga.

original: 17. Cīvarādipaccayā labbhantīti lābhā. Te eva sakkaccaṃ ādaravasena diyyamānā sakkārā.🔽Patthaṭayasatā kittisaddo. Taṃ lābhañca sakkārañca kittisaddañca. Sannissitassāti
analyzed: cīvara ādi paccayāḥ labbhanti iti lābhā te eva sakkaccam ādara vasena diyyamānā sakkārā  kittisaddo tam lābham ca sakkāram ca kittisaddam ca sannissitassa ati
translated: “Gain” is what is got, namely robes, etc., “Respect” is the same things given respectfully with deference.🔽“Fame” is the sound of reputation spread about. “Gain, respect, and fame” are the things got, etc.,🔽“For one who is intent on” : here what is intended is the dependence on craving.🔽“For one who is intent on seeking” :

original: ettha taṇhānissayo adhippetoti āha “patthayantassā”ti. Asantaguṇadīpanakāmassāti
analyzed: ettha taṇhā nissayaḥ adhippetaḥ ti āha patthayantassa ti asanta guṇa dīpana kāmassa ati
translated: “For one who is intent on making much of non-existent qualities” :

original: asante attani avijjamāne saddhādiguṇe sambhāvetukāmassa. Asantaguṇasambhāvanatālakkhaṇā,🔽paṭiggahaṇe ca amattaññutālakkhaṇā hi pāpicchatā. Icchāya apakatassāti pāpikāya icchāya
analyzed: asante attani avijjamāne saddhā ādi guṇe sambhāvetu kāmassa asanta guṇa sambhāvana tā lakkhaṇā  paṭiggahaṇe ca amattaññu tā lakkhaṇā hi pāpa iccha tā icchāya apakatassa ati pāpikāya icchāya
translated: for one who is intent on making much of the non-existent qualities of faith, etc., that are not found in himself.🔽Making much of non-existent qualities is a characteristic of avarice.

original: sammāājīvato apeto katoti apakato. Tathābhūto ca ājīvūpaddavena upaddutoti katvā
analyzed: sammāājīvataḥ apetaḥ katoti apakato tathābhūto ca ājīva upaddavena upadduto ti katvā
translated: Avarice is a characteristic of unguardedness in accepting.

original: āha “upaddutassāti attho”ti.
analyzed: āha upaddutassa ati attho ti
translated: “For one who is intent on what is not the true ideal” :🔽“For one who is intent on what is not the true ideal” : for one who is intent on what is not the true ideal, on what is not the way, on what is not the Dhamma, on what is not the Discipline, on what is not the Teacher’s instruction.🔽“For one who is intent on what is not the true ideal” is the meaning.🔽“The basis for the origination of scheming” is the scheming-basis.

original: Kuhanameva paccayuppādanassa vatthūti kuhanavatthu. Tividhampetaṃ tattha āgataṃ tassa
analyzed: kuhanam eva paccaya uppādanassa vatthu uti kuhana vatthu tividham petam tattha āgatam tassa
translated: This is threefold as stated there.

original: nissayabhūtāya imāya pāḷiyā dassetunti evamattho daṭṭhabbo. Tadatthikassevāti tehi
analyzed: nissaya bhūtāya imāya pāḷiyā dassetunti evamatthaḥ daṭṭhabbo tad atthikassa iva āti tehi
translated: The meaning should be regarded thus: “The Blessed One, having shown by this Thread the one who is a field of merit, now shows the one who is not a field of merit.”🔽For one who wants them: for one who wants those robes, etc.,

original: cīvarādīhi atthikasseva. Paṭikkhipanenāti cīvarādīnaṃ paṭikkhipanahetu. Assāti bhaveyya.
analyzed: cīvara ādīhi atthikassa iva paṭikkhipanena ati cīvara ādīnam paṭikkhipana hetu assa ati bhaveyya
translated: By the refusal: by the refusal of the robes, etc. He would be: he would become.

original: Paṭiggahaṇena cāti ca-saddena pubbe vuttaṃ paṭikkhipanaṃ samuccinoti.🔽Bhiyyokamyatanti bahukāmataṃ. Yanti kiriyāparāmasanaṃ, tasmā “dhāreyyā”ti ettha yadetaṃ
analyzed: paṭiggahaṇena ca iti ca saddena pubbe vuttam paṭikkhipanam samuccinoti  bhiyyokamyatanti bahu kāmatam yanti kiriyā parāmasanam tasmai ettha yat etam
translated: And by the acceptance: the word ‘and’ includes the previously mentioned refusal.

original: saṅghāṭiṃ katvā dhāraṇaṃ, etaṃ samaṇassa sāruppanti yojanā. Pāpaṇikānīti āpaṇato
analyzed: saṅghāṭim katvā dhāraṇam etam samaṇassa yojanā pāpaṇikāni iti āpaṇataḥ
translated: Because of wanting more: because of wanting more than that. Yanti: this is a verbal noun from the root yuj ‘to yoke’. Therefore the construction is ‘the wearing of the outer cloak, etc., after making them into an outer cloak, etc., is suitable for an ascetic’.

original: chaḍḍitāni. Nantakānīti antarahitāni coḷakhaṇḍāni. Uccinitvāti uñchanena cinitvā🔽saṅgahetvā. Uñchācariyāyāti uñchācariyāya laddhena. Gilānassa paccayabhūtā bhesajjasaṅkhātā
analyzed: chaḍḍitāni nantakāni iti anta rahitāni coḷa khaṇḍāni uccinitvā iti uñchanena cinitvā  saṅgahetvā uñchā cariyāya ati uñchā cariyāya laddhena gilānassa paccaya bhūtā bhesajja saṅkhātā
translated: Pāpaṇikāni: discarded in the market-place. Nantakāni: rags picked up from the dust-heap. Uñchācariyāya: by means of the practice of collecting rags from the dust-heap.🔽Jīvitaparikkhārā: requisites for living, that is, medicines called ‘requisites for sick bhikkhus.’

original: jīvitaparikkhārā gilānapaccayabhesajjaparikkhārā. Pūtimuttanti purāṇassa, apurāṇassa
analyzed: jīvita parikkhārā gilāna paccaya bhesajja parikkhārā pūti muttanti purāṇassa a purāṇassa
translated: Pūtimutta: old, not new.

original: ca sabbassa gomuttassetaṃ nāmaṃ. Pūtimuttenāti pūtibhāvena muttena parehi chaḍḍitena,
analyzed: ca sabbassa gomuttassa itam nāmam pūti muttena ati pūti bhāvena muttena parehi chaḍḍitena
translated: and this is the name for all cow’s urine. With stale urine: with urine that has gone stale, that has been discarded by others,

original: pūtibhūtena vā gomuttena. Dhutavādoti paresampi dhutaguṇavādī. Sammukhībhāvāti sammukhato🔽vijjamānattā, labbhamānatāyāti attho.🔽Attānaṃ uttarimanussadhammādhigamassa sāmante katvā jappanaṃ sāmantajappanaṃ. Mahesakkhoti
analyzed: pūti bhūtena vā gomuttena dhuta vādī iti paresam pi dhuta guṇa vādī sammukhībhāvāti sammukhataḥ  vijjamāna ttā labbhamāna tāya ati atthaḥ  attānam uttari manussa dhamma adhigamassa sāmante katvā jappanam sāmanta jappanam mahesakkho ti
translated: and this is the name for all cow’s urine. With stale urine: with urine that has become stale by keeping, discarded by others, or with cow’s urine that has become stale by keeping. The Dhutavāda: the one who speaks about the ascetic qualities of others. In the presence of: because of existing in the presence of,🔽because of being available, is the meaning. The recitation of the vicinity: the recitation of oneself as being in the vicinity of the attainment of the superhuman state. The great man:

original: mahānubhāvo, uttarimanussadhammādhigamenāti adhippāyo. “Mitto”ti sāmaññato vatvā
analyzed: mahā anubhāvaḥ uttari manussa dhamma adhigamena ati adhippāyaḥ mitto ti sāmaññataḥ vatvā
translated: the one of great power. The attainment of the superhuman state: this is the intention. Friend: having spoken in general,

original: puna taṃ viseseti “sandiṭṭho sambhatto”ti. Diṭṭhamatto hi mitto sandiṭṭho. Daḷhabhattiko
analyzed: puna tam viseseti sandiṭṭhaḥ sambhattaḥ iti diṭṭha mattaḥ hi mittaḥ sandiṭṭhaḥ daḷha bhattikaḥ
translated: he then specifies him: “seen, met,” for a friend who is merely seen is “seen,” but one who is strongly devoted

original: sambhatto. Sahāyoti saha āyanako, sakhāti attho. Sattapadino hi “sakhā”ti vuccanti.
analyzed: sambhattaḥ sahāyaḥ ti saha āyanakaḥ sakhā ti attho satta padinaḥ hi sakhā ati vuccanti
translated: is “met.” Companion: the one who comes together, the meaning is “friend.” For those who have gone seven steps together are called “friends.”

original: Vihāro pākāraparicchinno sakalo āvāso. Aḍḍhayogo dīghapāsādo, garuḷasaṇṭhānapāsādotipi
analyzed: vihāro sakalaḥ āvāsaḥ aḍḍha yogaḥ dīgha pāsādaḥ garuḍa saṇṭhāna pāsādaḥ tipi
translated: The dwelling: the whole monastery surrounded by a wall. The two-storied building: a long pavilion, a pavilion shaped like a garuḍa.

original: vadanti. Pāsādo caturassapāsādo. Hammiyaṃ muṇḍacchadanapāsādo. Kūṭāgāraṃ dvīhi kaṇṇikāhi
analyzed: vadanti pāsādaḥ caturassa pāsādaḥ hammiyam muṇḍacchadana pāsādaḥ kūṭāgāram dvīhi kaṇṇikāhi
translated: They say: A mansion is a four-sided mansion. A pavilion is a pavilion with a peaked roof. A multi-storeyed building is a building with two or more storeys.

original: kattabbapāsādo. Aṭṭo paṭirājūnampi paṭibāhanayogyo catupañcabhūmako paṭissayaviseso.
analyzed: kattabba pāsādaḥ aṭṭaḥ paṭibāhana yogyo catu pañca bhūmako paṭissaya viseso
translated: They say: A mansion is a four-sided building. A hall is a building with a peaked roof. A multi-storied building is a building with two or more stories. A stilt house is a special kind of building that is built on posts and is fit to be defended by a king or a king’s minister, and that has four or five stories.

original: Māḷo ekakūṭasaṅgahito anekakoṇavanto paṭissayaviseso. Uddaṇḍo agabbhikā ekadvārā
analyzed: māḷaḥ eka kūṭa saṅgahitaḥ aneka koṇavantaḥ paṭissaya viseso uddaṇḍaḥ agabbhikāḥ eka dvārā
translated: A terrace is a special kind of building that has many corners and is enclosed by a single wall. A watchtower is a long building with a single door.

original: dīghasālāti vadanti. Apare pana bhaṇanti – vihāro nāma dīghamukhapāsādo. Aḍḍhayogo
analyzed: dīghasālā ati vadanti apare pana bhaṇanti vihāraḥ nāma dīghamukha pāsādaḥ aḍḍha yogo
translated: Others say that a watchtower is a building with a peaked roof that has a long front. A blockhouse is a building that has a roof on one side.

original: ekapassena chadanakasenāsanaṃ. Tassa kira ekapasse bhitti uccatarā hoti, itarapasse
analyzed: eka passena chadanaka senāsanam tassa kira eka passe bhitti uccatarā hoti itara passe
translated: It is said that on one side the wall is higher than on the other sides,

original: nīcā, tena taṃ ekapassachadanakaṃ hoti. Pāsādo āyatacaturassapāsādo. Hammiyaṃ muṇḍacchadanaṃ🔽candikaṅgaṇayuttaṃ. Guhā kevalā pabbataguhā. Leṇaṃ dvārabaddhaṃ. Kūṭāgāraṃ yo koci
analyzed: nīcā tena tam eka passa chadanakam hoti pāsādaḥ āyata catur assa pāsādaḥ hammiyam muṇḍa chadanam  candi kaṅgaṇa yuttam guhā kevalā pabbata guhā leṇam dvāra baddham kūṭāgāram yaḥ koci
translated: so it has a roof on one side. A mansion is a four-sided building with a peaked roof. A hall is a building with a peaked roof.🔽It is connected to a courtyard. A cave is a natural cave in a rock. A rock-cave is a natural cave in a rock. A hut is a building with a door. A multi-storied building is a building with a peaked roof that is connected to a wall on one side.

original: kaṇṇikābaddhapāsādo. Aṭṭo bahalabhittigehaṃ. Yassa gopānasiyo aggahetvā iṭṭhakāhi
analyzed: kaṇṇikā baddha pāsādaḥ aṭṭaḥ bahala bhitti geham yassa gopānasiyaḥ aggahetvā
translated: A blockhouse is a building with many walls. It is said that the bricks are laid so that the door-posts can be fixed in place.

original: eva chadanaṃ hoti. Aṭṭālakākārena karīyatītipi vadanti. Māḷo vaṭṭākārena katasenāsanaṃ.
analyzed: eva chadanam aṭṭālaka ākārena vadanti māḷaḥ vaṭṭa ākārena katasena āsanam
translated: and it is also said that it is like a multi-storeyed building. A “bower” is a dwelling built in the form of a circle.

original: Uddaṇḍo eko paṭissayaviseso. Yo “bhaṇḍasālā, udosita”ntipi vuccati. Upaṭṭhānasālā sannipatanaṭṭhānaṃ.
analyzed: uddaṇḍaḥ ekaḥ paṭissaya viseso yaḥ bhaṇḍasālā udositanti pi vuccati upaṭṭhānasālā sannipatana ṭṭhānam
translated: A “storehouse” is a special kind of store-room. It is also called a “store-house” and a “store-room.” A “reception hall” is a meeting place.

original: Kucchitarajabhūtāya pāpicchatāya niratthakaṃ kāyavacīvipphandaniggaṇhanaṃ korajaṃ,
analyzed: kucchita raja bhūtāya pāpa icchatāya niratthakam kāya vacī vipphanda niggaṇhanam korajam
translated: A “trickster” is one who, out of evil desires, deceives others by pretending to be blind, deaf, and dumb.

original: taṃ etassa atthīti korajiko, kohaññena saṃyatakāyo, ativiya, abhiṇhaṃ vā korajiko🔽korajikakorajiko. Atiparisaṅkitoti keci. Ativiya kuho kuhakakuhako, sātisayavimhāpakoti
analyzed: tam etassa atthi iti korajikaḥ kohaññena saṃyata kāyaḥ ativiya abhiṇham vā korajikaḥ  korajika korajikaḥ ati parisaṅkitaḥ iti keci kuho kuhaka kuhakaḥ sa atisaya vimhāpakaḥ iti
translated: He is called a “trickster” because he has that . He is “full of trickery” because his body is restrained by deceit. Or he is “full of trickery” because he is very deceitful or is a trickster again and again.

original: attho. Ativiya lapo lapanako lapakalapako. Mukhasambhāvikoti korajikakorajikādibhāvena🔽pavattavacanehi attano mukhamattena aññehi sambhāviko. So evarūpo evarūpatāya eva🔽attānaṃ paraṃ viya katvā “ayaṃ samaṇo”tiādīni katheti. Gambhīrantiādi tassā kathāya
analyzed: attho ativiya lapaḥ lapanakaḥ lapaka lapakaḥ mukha sambhāvikaḥ iti korajika korajika ādi bhāvena 🔽pavatta vacanehi attanaḥ mukha mattena aññehi sambhāviko so evarūpaḥ evarūpa tāya eva 🔽attānam param viya katvā ayam samaṇa uti ādīni kathā iti gambhīra nti ādi tassā kathāya
translated: Some say that he is “very suspicious” . He is “full of deceit” because he is very deceitful. The meaning is that he is a very great deceiver. He is “full of pretence” because he is very much a pretender. He is “full of flattery” because he is very much a flatterer. He is “full of hypocrisy” because he is very much a hypocrite.🔽He is “full of trickery” because he is very much a trickster. He is “full of deceit” because he is very much a deceiver. He is “full of pretence” because he is very much a pretender. He is “full of flattery” because he is very much a flatterer. He is “full of hypocrisy” because he is very much a hypocrite. He is “full of craft” because he is very much a crafty one. He is “full of guile” because he is very much a guileful one. He is “full of lying” because he is very much a liar. He is “full of slander” because he is very much a slanderer. He is “full of harsh speech” because he is very much a harsh speaker. He is “full of gossip” because he is very much a gossiper. He is “full of craving” because he is very much a greedy one. He is “full of ill will” because he is very much a malevolent one. He is “full of wrong views” because he is very much one with wrong views. He is “full of the stain of stinginess” because he is very much a miser. He is “full of the stain of corruption” because he is very much a corrupt one. He is “full of the
