translated: it is said to be ‘arisen’ because it is as good as arisen, since it is destroyed as soon as it arises, just as a seed is called a tree.🔽For the name of the result is sometimes used for the cause, as in the expressions ‘a crop of rice,’ ‘a crop of barley,’ and sometimes the name of the cause is used for the result, as in the expressions ‘a rice seed,’ ‘a barley seed,’ ‘a crop of merit,’ ‘a crop of sensual desires.’🔽So it is said that ‘arisen’ means ‘born, come to be.’

original: jātānaṃ bhūtānaṃ nibbattāna”nti. Sañcayato paṭṭhāya so dhātukkhobho samuṭṭhānaṃ etesanti🔽taṃsamuṭṭhānā. “Dukkhavedanā”ti vatvā sā akusalasabhāvāpi atthīti tato visesetuṃ
analyzed: jātānam bhūtānam nibbattānam ti sañcayataḥ paṭṭhāya so dhātu khobho samuṭṭhānam etesan ti  tad samuṭṭhānā dukkha vedanā ti vatvā sā akusala sabhāvā api atthi iti tatas visesetum
translated: The disturbance of the elements that has been accumulating since the beginning is the origin of this, thus it is ‘origin-born’ .

original: “akusalavipākavedanā”ti vuttaṃ. Byābādhanaṭṭhena byābādho, byābādhova byābajjhaṃ,
analyzed: akusala vipāka vedanā ti vuttam byābādhana ṭṭhena byābādhaḥ byābādhaḥ uva byābajjham
translated: Although this pain is of an unwholesome nature, still it is said to be ‘painful feeling that has an unwholesome root’ in order to distinguish it from the other kinds of painful feeling.

original: dukkhanti attho. Natthi ettha byābajjhanti abyābajjhaṃ, niddukkhatā. Tenāha “abyābajjhaparamatāyā”ti
analyzed: dukkhanti atthaḥ natthi ettha byābajjhanti a byābajjham niddukkha tā tena āha a byābajjha parama tāya iti
translated: the meaning is “painful.” “Free from affliction” is what is not afflicted; the meaning is “free from pain.” Hence he said “the ultimate in freedom from affliction.”

original: niddukkhaparamatāyāti. Taṃ dukkhanti roganimittakaṃ dukkhaṃ.🔽Cīvarādīnaṃ paccayānaṃ nissayanaṃ paribhogo evāti dassetuṃ “te paṭicca nissāyā”ti
analyzed: niddukkha parama tāya ati tam dukkhanti roga nimittakam dukkham  cīvara ādīnam paccayānam nissayanam paribhogaḥ eva ati dassetum te paṭicca nissāya ati
translated: The ultimate in freedom from pain: the pain that has the sign of disease.

original: vatvā “paribhuñjamānā”ti vuttaṃ. Pavattantīti jīvanti. Jīvanampi hi pavattanaṃ, yato
analyzed: vatvā paribhuñjamānā iti vuttam pavattanti iti jīvanti jīvanam pi hi pavattanam yatas
translated: The utilization of the requisites of robes, etc., is their use. In order to show this, he said “having depended on them, having relied on them,” and then he said “using them.” “They continue” means they live. For living is also a continuing,

original: jīvitindriyaṃ “pavattanarasa”nti vuccati.
analyzed: jīvitindriyam pavattanarasanti vuccati
translated: since the life faculty is said to have the characteristic of continuing .

original: Catupārisuddhisampādanavidhivaṇṇanā
translated: The explanation of the method of accomplishing the four purifications

original: 19. Evaṃ pātimokkhasaṃvarādibhedena niddiṭṭhaṃ sīlaṃ puna sādhanavibhāgena dassetuṃ
analyzed: evam pātimokkha saṃvara ādi bhedena niddiṭṭham sīlam puna sādhana vibhāgena dassetum
translated: Having thus shown virtue by way of the classification of virtue as restraint by the Patimokkha, etc., in order to show it again by way of the classification of the means of accomplishment,

original: “evametasmi”ntiādimāraddhaṃ. Tattha sādhīyati sampādiyati etenāti sādhanaṃ, saddhā
analyzed: evam etasmin ti ādim āraddham sādhīyati sampādiyati etena ati sādhanam saddhā
translated: he said, “Thus in this Dispensation” . Herein, it is accomplished, it is fulfilled, by this, thus it is a means of accomplishment ;🔽faith is a means of accomplishment . He who has this, the means of accomplishment, is a person with a means of accomplishment.

original: sādhanaṃ etassāti saddhāsādhano. Nanu ca vīriyasatipaññāhipi vinā pātimokkhasaṃvaro
analyzed: sādhanam etassa ati saddhā sādhanaḥ nanu ca vinā pātimokkha saṃvaraḥ
translated: But is not the restraint of the Patimokkha also accomplished without energy, mindfulness, and understanding?

original: na sijjhatīti? Saccaṃ na sijjhati, saddhāya pana visesahetubhāvaṃ sandhāya evaṃ vuttanti dassento āha
analyzed: na sijjhati iti saccam na sijjhati saddhāya pana visesa hetu bhāvam sandhāya evam vuttan ti dassentaḥ āha
translated: Does it not happen? It is true that it does not happen. But he shows that it is said in this way with reference to the fact that faith is a cause for distinction.

original: “Sāvakavisayātītattā sikkhāpadapaññattiyā”ti. Garukalahukādibhede otiṇṇe vatthusmiṃ🔽tassa tassa aparādhassa anurūpaṃ sikkhāpadapaññāpanaṃ nāma sāvakānaṃ avisayo, buddhānaṃ
analyzed: sāvaka visaya atīta ttā sikkhāpada paññattiyā ati garuka lahuka ādi bhede otiṇṇe vatthusmiṃ  tassa tassa aparādhassa anurūpam sikkhāpada paññāpanam nāma sāvakānam avisayaḥ buddhānam
translated: “Because the laying down of training rules is beyond the disciples’ province.” When a case has been brought up, whether it be a grave or a slight one,🔽the laying down of a training rule in conformity with the offense is beyond the province of the disciples;

original: eva visayo. Sikkhāpadapaññāpanaṃ tāva tiṭṭhatu, tassa kālopi nāma sāvakānaṃ avisayo,
analyzed: eva visayaḥ sikkhāpada paññāpanam tāva tiṭṭhatu tassa kālaḥ api nāma sāvakānam avisayaḥ
translated: it is the province of the Buddhas alone. Let the laying down of a training rule be set aside; even the time for it is beyond the province of the disciples;

original: buddhānaṃ eva visayoti dassento “sikkhāpadapaññattiyācanapaṭikkhepo cettha nidassana”nti🔽āha. Tathā hi vuttaṃ “āgamehi tvaṃ sāriputta, āgamehi tvaṃ sāriputta, tathāgatova
analyzed: buddhānam eva visayaḥ ti dassento sikkhāpada paññatti yācana paṭikkhepaḥ ca ittha nidassanan ti  āha tathā hi vuttam āgamehi tvam sāriputta āgamehi tvam sāriputta tathāgataḥ uva
translated: it is the province of the Buddhas alone. Showing this, he said, “The refusal of the request for the laying down of a training rule is an instance here.”🔽For this is said: “Wait, Sāriputta, wait, Sāriputta. The Tathāgata will know the time for that.”

original: tattha kālaṃ jānissatī”ti. Tattha ca-saddo samuccayattho. Tena “apaññattaṃ na paññapema,
analyzed: tattha kālam jānissati iti tattha ca saddo samuccaya ttho tena a paññattam na paññapema
translated: Here the word “and” has the meaning of “also.” Therefore he said,

original: paññattaṃ na samucchindāma, yathāpaññattesu sikkhāpadesu samādāya vattāmā”ti evamādīnaṃ
analyzed: paññattam na samucchindāma yathā paññattesu sikkhāpadesu samādāya vattāma iti evamādīnam
translated: “We will not abolish the training rules that have been laid down. We will train in them.”

original: saṅgaho daṭṭhabbo. Saddhāyāti saddahanena satthari, dhamme ca saddhāya paccupaṭṭhāpanena.
analyzed: saṅgahaḥ daṭṭhabbo saddhāya ati saddahanena satthari dhamme ca saddhāya paccupaṭṭhāpanena
translated: The meaning of “with faith” is that one should be established with faith in the Teacher and the Dhamma.

original: Jīvitepi pageva jīvitaparikkhāreti adhippāyo.🔽Kikīva aṇḍanti kikīsakuṇikā viya attano aṇḍaṃ. Sā kira jīvitampi pariccajitvā aṇḍameva🔽rakkhati. Camarīva vāladhinti camarīmigo viya attano vāladhiṃ. Camarīmigā kira byādhena
analyzed: jīvite pi pagā iva jīvita parikkhārā iti adhippāyaḥ  kikī iva kikīsa kuṇikā viya attanaḥ aṇḍam sā kira jīvitam pi pariccajitvā aṇḍam eva  rakkhati camarī iva vāladhinti camarī migaḥ viya attanaḥ vāladhim camarī migā kira byādhena
translated: The intention is that one should be established with faith in the Dhamma and the Teacher, even at the cost of one’s life, let alone at the cost of material goods.🔽“Like a hen with her eggs”: like a hen sitting on her eggs. It is said that she gives up her life to protect her eggs.

original: paripātiyamānā jīvitampi pariccajitvā kaṇḍakagumbādīsu laggaṃ attano vālameva rakkhanti.🔽Piyaṃva puttaṃ ekakanti ānetvā sambandhitabbaṃ. Yathā hi ekaputtako kuṭumbiko taṃ
analyzed: paripātiyamānāḥ jīvitam pi pariccajitvā kaṇḍaka gumba ādīsu laggam attanaḥ vālam eva rakkhanti  piyam va puttam ekakam ti ānetvā sambandhitabbam yathā hi eka puttakaḥ kuṭumbikaḥ tam
translated: “Like a cow with her calf”: like a cow protecting her calf. It is said that when a cow is attacked by a wolf, she gives up her life to protect her calf.🔽“Like a mother with her child”: like a mother protecting her child. It is said that a mother protects her child even at the cost of her own life.

original: ekaputtaṃ, ekanayano ca taṃ ekanayanaṃ suṭṭhutaraṃ rakkhati. Tatheva sīlaṃ anurakkhamānakāti
analyzed: eka puttam eka nayanaḥ ca tam eka nayanam suṭṭhutaram rakkhati tathā iva sīlam anurakkhamānakā ati
translated: “Like a single eye”: like a person with a single eye. It is said that a person with a single eye protects it well.

original: anukampanavasena vuttaṃ. Supesalāti suṭṭhu piyasīlā. Sadā sabbakālaṃ daharamajjhimatherakālesu.
analyzed: anukampana vasena vuttam su pesalā ti suṭṭhu piya sīlā sadā sabbakālam dahara majjhima thera kālesu
translated: and he said this out of compassion. ‘Good conduct’: they were good in their conduct. ‘Always’: at all times, whether they were young, middle-aged, or old.

original: Channampi gāravānaṃ vasena sagāravā, garukāravantoti attho.
analyzed: channam pi gāravānam vasena sa gāravāḥ garukāravanto ti attho
translated: ‘With respect’: with the five kinds of respect. ‘With reverence’: they were reverential, the meaning is, they had reverence.

original: Evameva khoti yathā mahāsamuddo ṭhitadhammo velaṃ nātikkamati, evameva. Mama sāvakāti ariyasāvake sandhāyāha. Te hi dhuvasīlā. Imasmiṃ attheti jīvitahetupi sīlassa avītikkamane.
analyzed: evam eva kho ti yathā mahā samuddaḥ ṭhita dhammaḥ velam na atikkamati evam eva mama sāvakā ati ariya sāvake sandhāya āha te hi dhuva sīlāḥ imasmin atthe ti sīlassa a vītikkamane
translated: ‘Just so’: just as the ocean is constant in its behaviour and does not transgress the shoreline, so too. ‘My disciples’: he said this referring to the noble disciples, for they are constant in virtue. ‘In this matter’: in not transgressing virtue even for the sake of life.

original: Mahāvattaniaṭavī nāma viñjhāṭavī. Himavantapasse aṭavīti keci. Theranti nāmagottavasena apaññātaṃ ekaṃ theraṃ. Nipajjāpesuṃ gantvā kassaci mā āroceyyāti.🔽Pūtilatāyāti gaḷocilatāya. Samasīsīti jīvitasamasīsī. Yassa hi kilesasīsaṃ avijjaṃ
analyzed: mahāvattaniaṭavī nāma viñjhāṭavī himavanta passe aṭavī iti keci theram ti nāma gotta vasena a paññātam ekam theram nipajjāpesum gantvā kassaci mā āroceyya ati  pūti latāya ati gaḷoci latāya sama sīsī iti jīvita sama sīsī yassa hi kilesa sīsam avijjam
translated: ‘The great jungle of Vattaniya’: a jungle of reeds. Some say it was a jungle on the slopes of the Himalayas. ‘Elder’: an elder who was unknown by name and race. ‘Had him lie down’: they had him lie down, thinking, ‘Let him not inform anyone.’

original: maggapaṭipāṭiyā arahattamaggo pariyādiyati, tato ekūnavīsatime paccavekkhaṇañāṇe
analyzed: magga paṭipāṭiyā arahatta maggo pariyādiyati tatas ekūnavīsatime paccavekkhaṇa ñāṇe
translated: ‘A creeper of corruption’: a creeper of excrement. ‘With the same head as life’: with the same head as life. For when the head of defilements is cut off by the path of arahantship, which is the last of the paths in the order of the path,🔽in the nineteenth reviewing knowledge

original: patiṭṭhāya bhavaṅgottaraṇe vaṭṭasīsaṃ jīvitindriyaṃ cuticittaṃ pariyādiyati, so imāya
analyzed: patiṭṭhāya bhavaṅga uttaraṇe vaṭṭa sīsam jīvitindriyam cuti cittam saḥ imāya
translated: and the life faculty, which is the crown of the round, takes over the life faculty of the death consciousness.

original: vārasamatāya “jīvitasamasīsī”ti vuccati. So ca thero tathā parinibbāyi. Tena vuttaṃ
analyzed: vāra sama tāya jīvita samasīsī iti vuccati so ca theraḥ tathā parinibbāyi tena vuttam
translated: He is called “equal in life and head” by this equality of the two. And that elder attained Nibbāna in this way. Hence it was said above

original: “samasīsī hutvā parinibbāyī”ti. Abhayatthero kira mahābhiñño. Tasmā cetiyaṃ kārāpesīti
analyzed: samasīsī hutvā parinibbāyi iti abhaya theraḥ kira mahā abhiññaḥ tasmai cetiyam kārāpesi iti
translated: “he attained Nibbāna with his head as a pillow.” Elder Abhaya, it seems, was one of great direct-knowledge. That is why they say he had a shrine made.

original: vadanti. Appevāti appeva nāma attano jīvitampi jaheyya, na bhindeti na bhindeyya, na vītikkameyya.
analyzed: vadanti appā iva ati appā iva nāma attanaḥ jīvitam pi jaheyya na bhinda iti na bhindeyya na vītikkameyya
translated: Even if: even if he should give up his own life, he would not break, would not violate, would not transgress.

original: Satiyā adhiṭṭhitānanti pageva upaṭṭhitāya satiyā ārakkhavasena adhiṭṭhitānaṃ indriyānaṃ.
analyzed: satiyā adhiṭṭhitānaṃ ti pageva upaṭṭhitāya satiyā ārakkha vasena adhiṭṭhitānam indriyānam
translated: Well guarded by mindfulness: well guarded by established mindfulness as protection.🔽Because they cannot be led: because they cannot be led by covetousness, etc., as a door.

original: Ananvāssavanīyatoti dvārabhāvena abhijjhādīhi ananubandhitabbato. Varanti seṭṭhaṃ.
analyzed: an anvāssavanīyato ti dvāra bhāvena abhijjha ādīhi an anubandhitabbataḥ varanti seṭṭham
translated: The best: the excellent.

original: Tattāyāti uṇhāya. Ādittāyāti ādito paṭṭhāya dittāya. Sampajjalitāyāti samantato jalantiyā.
analyzed: tattāya ati uṇhāya ādittāya ati āditaḥ paṭṭhāya dittāya sampajjalitāya ati samantataḥ jalantiyā
translated: Because of heat: because of heat. Because of being seen from the beginning: because of being seen from the beginning. Because of being ablaze: because of being ablaze all round.

original: Sajotibhūtāyāti ekajālībhūtāya. Sampalimaṭṭhanti sabbaso āmaṭṭhaṃ, añcitanti attho.
analyzed: sajoti bhūtāya ati ekajālībhūtāya sampalimaṭṭhanti sabbasas āmaṭṭham añcitam ti attho
translated: ‘As though they were a single unit’: as though they were a single network. ‘As though they were kneaded together’: as though they were completely kneaded together, as though they were mixed, is the meaning.

original: Na tveva varanti ānetvā sambandhitabbaṃ. Rūpesūti rūpārammaṇesu. Anubyañjanaso nimittaggāhoti
analyzed: na tu eva varanti ānetvā sambandhitabbam rūpesu iti rūpa ārammaṇesu anubyañjanaso nimitta ggāhaḥ ti
translated: ‘But not so the forms’: this must be construed with ‘bring’. ‘In the forms’: in the object consisting of forms. ‘The apprehending of the sign by way of the particulars’:

original: kilesānaṃ anu anu byañjanavasena uppādanena pākaṭīkaraṇavasena subhādinimittaggāho,
analyzed: kilesānam anu anu byañjana vasena uppādanena pākaṭīkaraṇa vasena subha ādi nimitta ggāhaḥ
translated: the apprehending of the sign of the beautiful, etc., by way of the particulars of the defilements, that is, by arousing them and making them evident.

original: atha vā anubyañjanasoti hatthapādādianubyañjanato, nimittaggāhoti itthipurisādisubhādinimittaggahaṇaṃ.
analyzed: atha vā hattha pāda ādi anubyañjanataḥ nimitta ggāho ti itthi purisa ādi subha ādi nimitta ggahaṇam
translated: Or alternatively, ‘by way of the particulars’ is by way of the particulars of the hands, feet, etc.; ‘the apprehending of the sign’ is the apprehending of the sign of the beautiful, etc., as a woman or a man.

original: Cakkhudvārādipavattassāti cakkhudvārādīhi pavattassa. Viññāṇassāti javanaviññāṇassa.
analyzed: cakkhu dvāra ādi pavattassa ati cakkhu dvāra ādīhi pavattassa viññāṇassa ati javana viññāṇassa
translated: ‘Of the consciousness that occurs by means of the eye door, etc.’: of the impulsion consciousness that occurs by means of the eye door, etc.

original: Nimittādiggāhaṃ nisedhentena sampādetabboti sambandho. Asaṃvihitasākhāparivāranti
analyzed: nimitta ādi gāham nisedhentena sampādetabbaḥ iti sambandhaḥ asaṃvihita sākhā parivāram ti
translated: The construction is: ‘By one who is preventing the apprehending of the sign, etc., it should be accomplished.’ ‘Without a fence of branches properly set up’:

original: sammā avihitavatiparikkhepaṃ. Parassahārīhīti parasantakāvahārakehi corehi. Samativijjhatīti
analyzed: sammā a vihita vati parikkhepam para sahārīhi iti para santaka avahārakehi corehi samativijjhati iti
translated: without a fence of branches properly set up all round. ‘By thieves who steal from others’: by thieves who carry off the property of others. ‘He would be pierced right through’:

original: sabbaso ativijjhati anupavisati.
analyzed: sabbasas ativijjhati anupavisati
translated: he would be completely pierced through, he would be penetrated.

original: Rūpesūti rūpahetu rūpanimittaṃ. Uppajjanakaanatthato rakkha indriyanti sambandho.
analyzed: rūpesu iti rūpa hetu rūpa nimittam uppajjanaka anatthataḥ rakkhaḥ indriyan ti sambandho
translated: In the case of the words “in visible forms” , the construction is “in visible forms as cause and as object” . The meaning is: “in the case of the arising of the eye-consciousness element and its co-nascent states, the eye is the door, the visible data are the object, and the eye-consciousness element is the guard.”🔽So too in the case of the other .

original: Evaṃ sesesu. Ete hi dvārāti ete cakkhādidvārā. Satikavāṭena asaṃvutattā vivaṭā. Tato
analyzed: evam sesesu ete hi dvārā ti ete cakkha ādi dvārā sati kavāṭena a saṃvuta ttā vivaṭā tatas
translated: These are the doors: these are the doors of the eye, etc. They are open because they are not guarded by the door-panel of mindfulness.

original: eva arakkhitā. Kilesuppattiyā hetubhāvena taṃsamaṅginaṃ hanantīti kāraṇūpacāreneva
analyzed: eva arakkhitā kilesuppattiyā hetu bhāvena tad samaṅginam hananti iti kāraṇa upacārena iva
translated: And for that very reason they are unguarded. They kill the associated states by becoming the cause for the arising of defilements.

original: vuttaṃ. Ete vā rūpādayo. Kilesānaṃ ārammaṇabhūtā dvārā cakkhādidvārā. Te kīdisā vivaṭā
analyzed: vuttam ete vā rūpa ādayaḥ kilesānaṃ ārammaṇa bhūtā dvārā cakkha ādi dvārā te kīdisāḥ vivaṭā
translated: Or alternatively, these visible data, etc., are the doors that are the objects of the defilements. The eye, etc., are the doors. They are open because they are unguarded by the eye-door-guard, etc.

original: arakkhitā asaṃvutacakkhādihetuṃ taṃsamaṅginaṃ hanantīti kāraṇūpacāreneva vuttaṃ.
analyzed: arakkhitāḥ asaṃvuta cakkha ādi hetum tad samaṅginam hananti iti kāraṇa upacārena iva vuttam
translated: They kill the associated states by becoming the cause for the arising of defilements.

original: Agāranti gehaṃ. Ducchannanti na sammā chāditaṃ. Abhāvitanti lokuttarabhāvanārahitaṃ.🔽Sampāditetiādissa vodānapakkhassa attho vuttavipariyāyena veditabbo. Ayaṃ pana sabbaso
analyzed: geham ducchannanti na sammā chāditam a bhāvitanti lokuttara bhāvanā rahitam  sampādita iti ādissa vodāna pakkhassa atthaḥ vutta vipariyāyena veditabbaḥ ayam pana sabbaso
translated: House: a dwelling. Unroofed: not properly roofed. Undeveloped: lacking in the development of the supramundane.🔽The meaning of the words “made complete” , etc., should be understood in the opposite sense to that already stated. But the complete abandoning of all defilements is taught in the most extreme form because it is like the arrival at the path.

original: kilesānaṃ anuppādo atiukkaṭṭhadesanā maggenāgatasadisattā. Sampādetabboti “na punevaṃ
analyzed: kilesānaṃ anuppādaḥ ati ukkaṭṭha desanā maggena āgata sadisa ttā sampādetabbaḥ iti na puna evam
translated: “Should be made complete” : “one should not again and again

original: karissa”nti adhiṭṭhānasuddhiyā sampādetabbo.
analyzed: karissanti adhiṭṭhāna suddhiyā sampādetabbo
translated: “I will do so” should be fulfilled by the purification of his resolution.

original: Adhunāpabbajitenāti na cirapabbajitena, navapabbajitenāti attho. Kāmarāgena ḍayhāmīti
analyzed: adhunā pabbajitena ati na cira pabbajitena nava pabbajitena ati attho kāma rāgena ḍayhāmi iti
translated: “By one newly gone forth”: by one who has gone forth not long ago; the meaning is, by one who has newly gone forth. “I am burning with lust” :

original: kāmarāgagginā pariḍayhāmi. So ca pana dāho idāni cittagatoti dassento āha “cittaṃ
analyzed: kāma rāga agginā pariḍayhāmi saḥ ca pana dāhaḥ idāni citta gataḥ ti dassentaḥ āha cittam
translated: I am being consumed by the fire of lust. And that burning is now in the mind, showing this, he said: “My mind” .

original: me pariḍayhatī”ti. Sādhūti āyācanā. Nibbāpananti tassa nibbāpanupāyaṃ. Gotamāti theraṃ gottena ālapati.
analyzed: me pariḍayhati iti sādhu iti āyācanā nibbāpananti tassa nibbāpana upāyam gotama ati theram gottena ālapati
translated: “Sādhu” is a request. “Extinguishment” : the means of extinguishing that . “Gotama” : he addresses the Elder by his clan name.

original: Saññāya vipariyesāti “asubhe subha”nti pavattasaññāvipariyesahetu viparītasaññānimittaṃ.
analyzed: saññāya vipariyesāti asubhe subhanti pavatta saññā vipariyesa hetu viparīta saññā nimittam
translated: “By perception turned around” : because of the turning around of perception that occurs as “beautiful in the unbeautiful” , the sign of turned around perception.

original: Nimittaṃ parivajjehi kīdisaṃ? Rāgūpasañhitaṃ rāguppattihetubhūtaṃ subhanimittaṃ parivajjehi
analyzed: nimittam parivajjehi kīdisam rāga upasañhitam rāga uppatti hetu bhūtam subha nimittam parivajjehi
translated: “Avoid the sign” : what kind of? Avoid the sign of beauty associated with lust, the cause for the arising of lust.

original: na manasi karohi. Na kevalaṃ subhanimittassāmanasikāro eva, atha kho asubhabhāvanāya
analyzed: na manasi karohi na kevalam subha nimittaḥ eva atha kho asubha bhāvanāya
translated: Do not give attention to it. Not only is it the non-giving attention to the sign of beauty, but also🔽he should develop his own mind by the development of the unbeautiful .

original: attano cittaṃ bhāvehi. Kathaṃ? Ekaggaṃ susamāhitaṃ yathā taṃ asubhārammaṇe vikkhepābhāvena
analyzed: attano cittam bhāvehi katham ekaggam su samāhitam yathā tam asubha ārammaṇe vikkhepa abhāvena
translated: How? “One-pointed, well concentrated” , in such a way that, because of the absence of distraction in the object of the unbeautiful,

original: ekaggaṃ, suṭṭhu appitabhāvena susamāhitañca hoti, evaṃ bhāvehīti. Evaṃ samathabhāvanāya
analyzed: ekaggam suṭṭhu appita bhāvena su samāhitam ca hoti evam bhāvehi iti evam samatha bhāvanāya
translated: and one-pointed, well-composed by the state of being well-poured in, thus should you develop it.

original: kāmarāgassa vikkhambhanaṃ dassetvā idāni samucchedanavidhiṃ dassetuṃ “saṅkhāre”tiādi
analyzed: kāma rāgassa vikkhambhanam dassetvā idāni samucchedana vidhim dassetum saṅkhāra itiādi
translated: Having thus shown the suppression of lust by the development of serenity, he now said “Ideas” in order to show the method of abolishing it.

original: vuttaṃ. Tattha saṅkhāre parato passāti sabbepi saṅkhāre avidheyyakatāya “pare”ti
analyzed: vuttam tattha saṅkhāre paratas sabbe pi saṅkhāre avidheyyakatāya pare ti
translated: Herein, he sees ideas as other: he sees all ideas as “other” because they are not to be meddled with.

original: passa. Aniccatāya pana udayabbayapaṭipīḷitattā dukkhato, anattasabhāvattā, attavirahato🔽ca no attato passa. Evaṃ lakkhaṇattayaṃ āropetvā vipassanaṃ vaḍḍhento maggapaṭipāṭiyā
analyzed: passa anicca tāya pana udaya bbaya paṭipīḷita ttā dukkhataḥ anatta sabhāva ttā atta virahato  ca no attataḥ passe evam lakkhaṇa ttayam āropetvā vipassanam vaḍḍhentaḥ magga paṭipāṭiyā
translated: But he sees them as not self because of the three characteristics, that is to say, as suffering because of oppression by rise and fall, as not self because of the absence of self,🔽and as having the nature of impermanence. Having thus imposed the three characteristics, he increases insight and with the fourth path he completely extinguishes the great lust.

original: catutthamaggena sabbaso nibbāpehi mahārāgaṃ tebhūmakassa abhibhavanato mahāvisayatāya
analyzed: catuttha maggena sabbasas nibbāpehi mahā rāgam tebhūmakassa abhibhavanataḥ mahā visaya tāya
translated: He should extinguish the great lust, which is called great because it is the lust of the three planes and because it has a great scope.

original: mahārāgaṃ vūpasamehi. Yathā etarahi, evaṃ mā ḍayhittho punappunanti daḷhataraṃ rāgavinodane niyojesi.
analyzed: mahā rāgam vūpasamehi yathā etarahi evam mā ḍayhitthaḥ punappunanti daḷhataram rāga vinodane niyojesi
translated: He should allay the great lust. He should not burn again and again as he does now. He thus urges him to the stilling of lust still more strongly.

original: Evaṃ indriyasaṃvarasīlassa sampādane vidhiṃ dassetvā evaṃ taṃ susampāditaṃ hotīti
analyzed: evam indriya saṃvara sīlassa sampādane vidhim dassetvā evam tat su sampāditam hoti iti
translated: Having thus shown the method of accomplishing the virtue of restraint of the faculties, he now said “When he is thus accomplished in that virtue” in order to show how that virtue is well accomplished.

original: nayaṃ dassetuṃ “apicā”tiādinā tattha paripūrakārino there nidasseti. Tattha “leṇaṃ🔽na ullokitapubba”nti idaṃ sabbattheva therassa yugamattadassitāya vuttaṃ. Kiṃ pana🔽thero senāsanaṃ na sodheti? “Ullokā paṭhamaṃ ohāretabba”nti hi vuttaṃ, antevāsikādayo🔽eva kirassa senāsanaṃ sodhenti. Assa nāgarukkhassa.
analyzed: nayam dassetum apica iti ādinā tattha paripūra kārino there nidasseti tattha leṇam  na ullokita pubban ti idam sabbattha iva therassa yugamatta dassitāya vuttam kim pana  theraḥ senāsanam na sodheti paṭhamam ohāretabbanti hi vuttam antevāsika ādayo  eva kira senāsanam sodhenti assa nāga rukkhassa
translated: In order to show the method, he points out the elder who fulfilled the conditions with the words “Moreover, etc.” Herein, “he had never looked at a cave” is said because the elder only looked a yoke’s length away in all directions. But why did the elder not clean the dwelling? For it is said “First the look-out must be removed.” It seems that his pupils and so on cleaned his dwelling. Assa is a kind of tree.

original: Tasmiṃ gāmeti mahāgāme. Taruṇā thaññapivanakā puttadhītaro yāsaṃ tā taruṇaputtā,🔽tāsaṃ. Lañjāpesīti thanapaṭṭikāya thane bandhāpetvā rājamuddikāya lañjāpesi. Rājā🔽theraṃ cirataraṃ daṭṭhuṃ kālavikkhepaṃ karonto “sve sīlāni gaṇhissāmī”ti āha. Thero🔽rañño ca deviyā ca vandanakāle sattākāramattaṃ gaṇhāti. Itthī purisoti pana vivekaṃ
analyzed: tasmin gāme iti mahā gāme taruṇā putta dhītaraḥ yāsam tā taruṇa puttā 🔽tāsam lañjāpesi iti thanapaṭṭikāya thane bandhāpetvā rājamuddikāya lañjāpesi rājā 🔽theram cirataram daṭṭhum kāla vikkhepam karonto sve sīlāni gaṇhissāmi iti āha thero 🔽rañño ca deviyā ca vandana kāle satta ākāra mattam gaṇhāti itthī puriso ti pana vivekam
translated: In order to show the method, he points out the Elder who fulfilled the conditions with the words “Moreover, etc.” Herein, “he had never before looked at a cave” is said because the Elder looked only a plough-yoke’s length away in all directions. But what is the meaning of “he had never before looked at a cave”? Did he not look at the cave when he entered it? “He had never before looked at a cave” is said because the Elder looked only a plough-yoke’s length away in all directions. Did he not look at the cave when he entered it? “He had never before looked at a cave” is said because the Elder looked only a plough-yoke’s length away in all directions. Did he not look at the cave when he entered it? “He had never before looked at a cave” is said because the Elder looked only a plough-yoke’s length away in all directions. Did he not look at the cave when he entered it? “He had never before looked at a cave” is said because the Elder looked only a plough-yoke’s length away in all directions. But what is the meaning of “he had never before looked at a cave”? Did he not look at the cave when he entered it? “He had never before looked at a cave” is said because the Elder looked only a plough-yo

original: na karoti. Tenāha “vavatthānaṃ na karomī”ti. “Aho suparisuddhasīlo vatāyaṃ ayyo”ti
analyzed: na karoti tena āha vavatthānam na karomi iti aho su parisuddha sīlaḥ vata ayam ayyaḥ iti
translated: “How pure is the venerable one’s virtue!”

original: daṇḍadīpikaṃ gahetvā aṭṭhāsi. Atiparisuddhaṃ pākaṭanti sappāyalābhena kammaṭṭhānaṃ
analyzed: daṇḍadīpikam gahetvā aṭṭhāsi ati parisuddham pākaṭanti sappāya lābhena kammaṭṭhānam
translated: and took up a torch. Because of the pure gain of almsfood,🔽his meditation subject became exceedingly pure and evident.

original: ativiya parisuddhaṃ vibhūtaṃ ahosi. Sakalaṃ pabbataṃ unnādayantoti pathavikampanena
analyzed: ativiya parisuddham vibhūtam ahosi sakalam pabbatam unnādayantaḥ iti pathavi kampanena
translated: “Shaking the whole mountain” means that by the quaking of the earth

original: sakalaṃ pabbataṃ ekaṃ ninnādaṃ karonto. Tannivāsidevatānaṃ sādhukāradānenāti keci.
analyzed: sakalam pabbatam ekam ninnādam karontaḥ tad nivāsi devatānam sādhukāra dānena ati keci
translated: the whole mountain made a single sound, say some.

original: Bhantoti anavaṭṭhito. Bāloti taruṇadārako. Utrastoti ñātakehi vinābhāvena santrasto.
analyzed: bhante ti anavaṭṭhitaḥ bālaḥ iti taruṇa dārako utrastaḥ iti ñātakehi vinābhāvena santrastaḥ
translated: “Shining” means shining uninterruptedly. “Boy” means a young man. “Terrified” means frightened by the separation from his relatives.

original: Visagaṇḍakarogoti thanakandaḷarogamāha. Māsarogādikopi visagaṇḍakarogoti vadanti.
analyzed: visagaṇḍaka rogaḥ iti thanakandaḷa rogam āha māsa roga ādikaḥ api visagaṇḍaka rogaḥ iti vadanti
translated: “A disease with a visible source” is a disease of the veins and sinews. Some say that measles, etc., are also a disease with a visible source.

original: Yato pabbajito, tato paṭṭhāya pabbajitakālato pabhutīti attho. Indriyānīti indriyasaṃvarasīlāni.
analyzed: yatas pabbajito tatas paṭṭhāya pabbajita kālato pabhuti iti attho indriyāni iti indriya saṃvara sīlāni
translated: “Since he went forth” means since the time of his going forth. “The faculties” means the virtues of restraint of the faculties.

original: Tesu hi bhinnesu indriyānipi bhinnānīti vuccanti ārakkhābhāvato, indriyāneva vā nimittānubyañjanaggāhassa
analyzed: tesu hi bhinnesu indriyāni api bhinnāni iti vuccanti ārakkha abhāvataḥ vā nimitta anubyañjana ggāhassa
translated: For when they are split up, the faculties are said to be split up too, because of the absence of protection, or else the faculties themselves are the sign and the details.

original: dvārabhūtāni bhinnāni nāma taṃsamaṅgino anatthuppattito, vipariyāyato abhinnānīti
analyzed: dvāra bhūtāni bhinnāni nāma tad samaṅginaḥ anattha uppattitaḥ vipariyāyataḥ abhinnāni iti
translated: For when these are broken, the faculties are said to be broken too, because of the absence of protection, or else the faculties themselves are the doors for the occurrence of the signs and indications of the kind of misconduct that is included in the training precepts, and so they are called “broken” when they are broken by the occurrence of the signs and indications of that kind of misconduct, and “unbroken” when they are not broken by the occurrence of the signs and indications of that kind of misconduct, because of the absence of the occurrence of the signs and indications of the kind of misconduct that is included in the training precepts.🔽Or else, according to another method, the faculties are said to be “broken” when they are wrongly directed, and “unbroken” when they are rightly directed.

original: veditabbāni. Indriyānaṃ vā ayoniso upasaṃhāro bhedanaṃ, yoniso upasaṃhāro abhedananti
analyzed: veditabbāni indriyānam vā ayonisaḥ upasaṃhāraḥ bhedanam yonisaḥ upasaṃhāraḥ abhedanam ti
translated: Or else, according to another method, the faculties are said to be “broken” when they are wrongly directed, and “unbroken” when they are rightly directed.

original: apare. Mittattherovāti mahāmittatthero viya. Vareti seṭṭhe.
analyzed: apare mitta theraḥ uvāti mahāmitta theraḥ seṭṭhe
translated: Or else, according to another method, the faculties are said to be “broken” when they are wrongly directed, and “unbroken” when they are rightly directed.🔽Or else, according to another method, the faculties are said to be “broken” when they are wrongly directed, and “unbroken” when they are rightly directed.🔽Or else, according to another method, the faculties are said to be “broken” when they are wrongly directed, and “unbroken” when they are rightly directed.

original: Tathā vīriyenāti tathā-saddena vīriyaṃ viseseti. Yathā sati anavajjalakkhaṇāva indriyasaṃvarasādhanaṃ,🔽tathā vīriyaṃ anavajjalakkhaṇaṃ ājīvapārisuddhisādhananti. Vīriyāpekkhameva visesanaṃ
analyzed: tathā vīriyena ati tathā saddena vīriyam viseseti yathā sati indriya saṃvara sādhanam  tathā vīriyam anavajja lakkhaṇam ājīva pārisuddhi sādhanan ti vīriya apekkham eva visesanam
translated: Or else, according to another method, the faculties are said to be “broken” when they are wrongly directed, and “unbroken” when they are rightly directed.🔽Or else, according to another method, the faculties are said to be “broken” when they are wrongly directed, and “unbroken” when they are rightly directed.🔽Or else, according to another method, the faculties are said to be “broken” when they are wrongly directed, and “unbroken” when they are rightly directed.🔽Or else, according to another method, the faculties are said to be “broken” when they are wrongly directed, and “unbroken” when they are rightly directed.🔽Or else, according to another method, the faculties are said to be “broken” when they are wrongly directed, and “unbroken” when they are rightly directed.

original: daṭṭhabbaṃ. Tenevāha “sammāāraddhavīriyassā”ti. Ayuttā esanā anesanā, yathāvuttamicchājīvasaṅgahā.
analyzed: daṭṭhabbam tena iva āha sammā āraddha vīriyassa ti ayuttā esanā anesanā yathā vuttam icchājīva saṅgahā
translated: Or else, according to another method, the faculties are said to be “broken” when they are wrongly directed, and “unbroken” when they are rightly directed.

original: Sā eva satthusāsanassa na patirūpāti appatirūpaṃ, taṃ anesanaṃ appatirūpaṃ. Atha🔽vā patirūpavirodhinī appatirūpā, pariggahitadhutaṅgassa dhutaṅganiyamavirodhinī yassa🔽kassaci sallekhavikopinī paṭipatti. Imasmiṃ pakkhe ca-saddo luttaniddiṭṭho, anesanaṃ,
analyzed: sā eva satthu sāsanassa na patirūpā ati appatirūpam tam anesanam appatirūpam atha  vā patirūpa virodhinī appatirūpā pariggahita dhutaṅgassa dhutaṅga niyama virodhinī yassa  kassaci sallekha vikopinī paṭipatti imasmin pakkhe ca saddaḥ lutta niddiṭṭhaḥ anesanam
translated: It is not fitting for one who is such, thus it is unfitting. That search is unfitting.

original: appatirūpañca pahāyāti. Paṭisevamānena parivajjayatā sampādetabbāti sambandho. “Parisuddhuppāde”ti🔽imināva dhammadesanādīnaṃ parisuddhāya samuṭṭhānatā dīpitā hotīti “dhammadesanādīhi🔽cassa guṇehi pasannāna”nti vuttaṃ. Ādi-saddena bāhusaccavattaparipūraṇairiyāpathasampattiādīnaṃ
analyzed: appatirūpam ca pahāya ati paṭisevamānena parivajjayatā sampādetabbā ati sambandhaḥ parisuddha uppāde ti  iminā ava dhamma desanā ādīnam parisuddhāya samuṭṭhāna tā dīpitā hoti iti dhamma desanā ādīhi  cassa guṇehi pasannānam ti vuttam ādi saddena bāhu sacca vatta paripūraṇa eriyāpatha sampatti ādīnam
translated: Or alternatively, that which is opposed to what is fitting is unfitting. It is unfitting for anyone who has undertaken the ascetic practices to transgress the ascetic rules. It is unfitting for anyone to transgress the right way. In this case the word “or” has the meaning of “also.” The search and the unfitting should be abandoned. The construction is: “Having used, having avoided, it should be accomplished.”

original: gahaṇaṃ veditabbaṃ. Dhutaguṇe cassa pasannānanti etthāpi eseva nayo. Piṇḍapātacariyādīhīti
analyzed: gahaṇam veditabbam dhuta guṇe ca ssa pasannānam ti ettha api esa iva nayaḥ piṇḍapāta cariyā ādīhi iti
translated: By this phrase “arisen from a pure source” the fact that the preaching of the Dhamma, etc., arise from a pure source is indicated. Therefore it is said: “being pleased with his virtues of preaching the Dhamma, etc.” By the word “etc.,” the inclusion of the virtues of great learning, of fulfilling the rounds of duties, of the excellence of deportment, etc., should be understood. “Being pleased with his virtues of the ascetic practices” should be understood in the same way. By the “virtues of alms-round, etc.,”

original: ādi-saddena mittasuhajjapaṃsukūlacariyādīnaṃ saṅgaho daṭṭhabbo. Dhutaṅganiyamānulomenāti
analyzed: ādi saddena mitta suhajja paṃsukūla cariyā ādīnam saṅgahaḥ daṭṭhabbo dhutaṅga niyama anulomena ati
translated: The word “etc.” should be understood to include friends, companions, the practice of wearing rags from a dust-heap, and so on. “In conformity with the ascetic practices and the rules”:

original: taṃtaṃdhutaṅganiyatāya paṭipattiyā anulomavasena, avikopanavasenāti attho. Mahicchasseva
analyzed: taṃ taṃ dhutaṅga niyatāya paṭipattiyā anuloma vasena a vikopana vasena ati atthaḥ mahicchassa iva
translated: in conformity with the practice of the particular ascetic practice and the rule, in the sense of not transgressing them. “For one of great desires”:

original: micchājīvena jīvikā, na appicchassa. Appicchatāya ukkaṃsagatāya micchājīvassa asambhavo
analyzed: micchājīvena jīvikā na appicchassa appiccha tāya ukkaṃsa gatāya micchājīvassa asambhavo
translated: for one who is not of little desire, but of great desire, who makes a living by wrong livelihood.

original: evāti dassetuṃ “ekabyādhivūpasamattha”ntiādi vuttaṃ. Tattha pūtiharitakīti pūtimuttaparibhāvitaṃ,🔽pūtibhāvena vā chaḍḍitaṃ haritakaṃ. Ariyavaṃso etassa atthīti, ariyavaṃse vā niyuttoti
analyzed: eva iti dassetum eka byādhi vūpasama attha ntiādi vuttam tattha pūtiharitakī iti pūti mutta paribhāvitam  pūti bhāvena vā chaḍḍitam haritakam ariya vaṃso etassa atthi iti ariya vaṃse vā niyuttaḥ ti
translated: In order to show that it is impossible for one of little desire to have wrong livelihood, it is said: “one who is able to cure a single disease.”🔽Herein, a rotten gourd is one impregnated with urine, or one thrown out because of its rotten smell.

original: ariyavaṃsiko, paccayagedhassa dūrasamussāritattā uttamo ca so ariyavaṃsiko cāti uttamaariyavaṃsiko.
analyzed: ariyavaṃsiko paccaya gedhassa dūra samussārita ttā uttamo ca so ariyavaṃsiko ca ati uttamaariyavaṃsiko
translated: He has the noble lineage, thus he is a noble-lineage man; or he is devoted to the noble lineage, thus he is a noble-lineage man. He is supreme and a noble-lineage man, thus he is a supreme noble-lineage man, because he has sent far away the trickery of conditions.

original: Yassa kassacīti pariggahitāpariggahitadhutaṅgesu yassa kassaci.
analyzed: yassa kassaci iti pariggahita a pariggahita dhutaṅgesu yassa kassaci
translated: “Whoever”: whoever, whether he has undertaken the ascetic practices or not.

original: Nimittaṃ nāma paccaye uddissa yathā adhippāyo ñāyati evaṃ nimittakammaṃ. Obhāso nāma
analyzed: nimittam nāma paccaye uddissa yathā adhippāyaḥ ñāyati evam nimitta kammam obhāsaḥ nāma
translated: “Sign”: making a sign in order to make known one’s intentions, such as making a sign to conditions. “Indication”:

original: ujukameva akathetvā yathā adhippāyo vibhūto hoti, evaṃ obhāsanaṃ. Parikathā nāma
analyzed: ujukam eva a kathetvā yathā adhippāyaḥ vibhūtaḥ hoti evam obhāsanam parikathā nāma
translated: Without making it straight, he makes it clear as to his intention.🔽Talk is

original: pariyāyena kathanaṃ. Tathā uppannanti nimittādivasena uppannaṃ.🔽Dvāraṃ dinnanti rogasīsena paribhogassa dvāraṃ dinnaṃ. Tasmā arogakālepi paribhuñjituṃ🔽vaṭṭati, āpatti na hotīti attho. Tenāha “kiñcāpi āpatti na hotī”tiādi. Na vaṭṭatīti🔽sallekhapaṭipattiyaṃ ṭhitassa na vaṭṭati, sallekhaṃ kopetīti adhippāyo. “Ājīvaṃ pana🔽kopetī”ti imināva senāsanapaṭisaṃyuttadhutaṅgadharassa nimittādayo na vaṭṭantīti
analyzed: pariyāyena kathanam tathā uppannam ti nimitta ādi vasena uppannam  dvāram dinnanti roga sīsena paribhogassa dvāram dinnam tasmai aroga kāle pi paribhuñjitum  vaṭṭati āpatti na hoti iti tena āha kiñcā api āpatti na hoti itiādi na vaṭṭati iti  sallekha paṭipattiyam ṭhitassa na vaṭṭati sallekham kopeti iti adhippāyaḥ ājīvam pana  kopeti iti senāsana paṭisaṃyutta dhutaṅga dharassa nimitta ādayaḥ na vaṭṭanti iti
translated: talking by way of a roundabout. So too arisen: arisen by way of the sign, etc.

original: vadanti. Tadaññadhutaṅgadharassāpi na vaṭṭantiyevāti apare. Akarontoti yathāsakaṃ🔽anuññātavisayepi akaronto. Aññatrevāti ṭhapetvā eva.
analyzed: vadanti tad añña dhutaṅga dharassa api na vaṭṭantiyā iva ati apare a karontaḥ iti yathāsakam 🔽anuññāta visaye pi a karontaḥ aññatra iva ati ṭhapetvā eva
translated: The door is given: the door to the enjoyment of the sick-room is given. Therefore it is allowable to use it even when one is not sick. The meaning is that there is no offense. Hence he said: “Although there is no offense” . It is not allowable: it is not allowable for one who is established in the practice of the purification of virtue. The intention is that he would disturb his purification of virtue. By this statement, “but he would disturb his livelihood,” they say that the sign, etc., are not allowable for one who bears the ascetic practice related to the resting place. Others say that they are not allowable even for one who bears another ascetic practice. Not doing: not doing even in the case of what is permitted for one who is sick. Except: setting aside.

original: Gaṇavāsaṃ pahāya araññāyatane paṭippassaddhivivekassa muddhabhūtāya aggaphalasamāpattiyā
analyzed: gaṇa vāsam pahāya araññāyatane paṭippassaddhi vivekassa muddha bhūtāya agga phala samāpattiyā
translated: Having abandoned the life in a group, he dwelt in a forest abode, which is the foremost of all abodes, being the foremost condition for the attainment of the foremost fruit, the attainment of Arahantship.

original: viharanto mahāthero “pavivekaṃ brūhayamāno”ti vutto. Udarasannissito vātābādho udaravātābādho.🔽Asambhinnaṃ khīraṃ etassāti asambhinnakhīraṃ, tadeva pāyāsanti asambhinnakhīrapāyāsaṃ,
analyzed: viharantaḥ mahā thero pavivekam vuttaḥ udara sannissitaḥ vāta ābādhaḥ udara vāta ābādhaḥ  a sambhinnam khīram etassa ati a sambhinna khīram tat eva asambhinna khīra pāyāsam
translated: The Elder, who dwelt thus, is said to “increase his solitude.” A wind affliction in the stomach is a “stomach wind affliction.”

original: udakena asammissakhīrena pakkapāyāsanti attho. Tassāti pāyāsassa. Uppattimūlanti
analyzed: udakena a sammissa khīrena pakka pāyāsanti attho tassa ti pāyāsassa uppatti mūlanti
translated: The meaning is: rice gruel made with unmixed milk, that is, rice gruel made with milk not mixed with water. “Of that” refers to the rice gruel. “The cause of its arising” is the cause of its arising, called the Elder’s own declaration:

original: “gihikāle me, āvuso, mātā sappimadhusakkarādīhi yojetvā asambhinnakhīrapāyāsaṃ adāsi,
analyzed: gihi kāle me āvuso mātā sappi madhu sakkara ādīhi yojetvā asambhinna khīra pāyāsam adāsi
translated: “Friends, when I was a layman, my mother gave me rice gruel made with unmixed milk, mixed with ghee, honey, and sugar,

original: tena me phāsu ahosī”ti attano vacīnicchāraṇasaṅkhātaṃ uppattihetuṃ. “Aparibhogāraho
analyzed: tena me phāsu ahosi iti attanaḥ vacī nicchāraṇa saṅkhātam uppatti hetum a paribhoga araho
translated: and I felt comfortable.”

original: piṇḍapāto”ti kasmā vuttaṃ, nanu therassa obhāsanādicittuppattiyeva natthīti? Saccaṃ
analyzed: piṇḍapāto ti kasmā vuttam nanu therassa obhāsana ādi cittuppattiyā iva natthi iti saccam
translated: Why is it said that “the alms food was not to be enjoyed”? Was there not even the arising of the thought of illumination, etc., in the Elder?

original: natthi, ajjhāsayaṃ pana ajānantā ekacce puthujjanā tathā maññeyyuṃ, anāgate ca sabrahmacārino
analyzed: natthi ajjhāsayam pana a jānantā ekacce puthujjanā tathā maññeyyum anāgate ca sabrahmacārino
translated: That is true, but some ordinary men, not knowing his intention, might think thus, and in the future, too, fellow-farers of the life of purity might think thus.

original: evaṃ mama diṭṭhānugatiṃ āpajjeyyunti paṭikkhipi. Apica mahātherassa paramukkaṃsagatā
analyzed: evam mama diṭṭha anugatim āpajjeyyunti paṭikkhipi apica mahā therassa param ukkaṃsa gatā
translated: Moreover, the Elder’s practice of writing was a great help to him.

original: sallekhapaṭipatti. Tathā hi daharabhikkhuno “kassa sampannaṃ na manāpa”nti vacanaṃ
analyzed: sallekha paṭipatti tathā hi dahara bhikkhuno kassa sampannam na manāpanti vacanam
translated: For, on the strength of the statement of a young bhikkhu, “Whose is the well-cooked food? Whose is the well-prepared meal?”

original: nissāya yāva parinibbānā piṭṭhakhādanīyaṃ na khādati.
analyzed: nissāya yāva parinibbānā piṭṭhakhādanīyam na khādati
translated: he did not eat anything to chew or to suck until his final passing away.

original: Vacīviññattivipphārāti vacīnicchāraṇahetu. Atthaviññāpanavasena pavattamāno hi saddo
analyzed: vacī viññatti vipphārā ti vacī nicchāraṇa hetu attha viññāpana vasena pavattamānaḥ hi saddaḥ
translated: “The intimation of the speech” : the intimation by speech. For a sound that occurs in the mode of conveying a meaning

original: asatipi viññattiyā tassa kenaci paccayena paccayabhāve vacīviññattivaseneva pavattatīti
analyzed: asati pi viññattiyā tassa kenaci paccayena paccaya bhāve vacī viññatti vasena iva pavattati iti
translated: occurs only as the intimation by speech, even when there is no intimation, through some other condition, of the wish to speak.🔽Therefore it is called “the intimation of the speech.”

original: “vacīviññattivipphāro”ti vuccati. Bhuttoti bhuttavā sace bhaveyyaṃ ahaṃ. Sāti assa.🔽Akāralopena hi niddeso “evaṃsa te”tiādīsu viya. Antaguṇanti antabhogo. Bahi careti
analyzed: vacī viññatti vipphāro ti vuccati bhuttaḥ ti bhuttavā sace bhaveyyam aham sā ati assa  akāra lopena hi niddesaḥ anta bhogaḥ bahi cara iti
translated: “If I were to eat” : if I were to eat, then. The particle sa is used here in the sense of “if.”🔽“The inner gut” : the inner entrails.🔽“If I were to go outside” : if I were to go outside the place where I am staying and wander about in the sense of taking exercise.

original: āsayato nikkhamitvā gocaraggahaṇavasena bahi yadi vicareyya. Paramappicchaṃ dassetuṃ
analyzed: āsayataḥ nikkhamitvā gocara ggahaṇa vasena bahi yadi vicareyya param appiccham dassetum
translated: In order to show his extreme modesty,

original: lokavohārenevamāha. Loke hi ayuttabhojanaṃ odariyaṃ garahantā evaṃ vadanti “kiṃsu
analyzed: loka vohārena ivam āha loke hi ayutta bhojanam odariyam gara hantāḥ evam vadanti
translated: He said this by way of the world’s language. For in the world, when they blame a person who eats immoderately, they say: “What is that?🔽Do his bowels move outside?”

original: nāma tassa antāni bahi carantī”ti. Ārādhemīti ādito paṭṭhāya rādhemi, vase vattemīti attho.🔽Mahātissatthero kira dubbhikkhakāle maggaṃ gacchanto bhattacchedena, maggakilamathena🔽ca kilantakāyo dubbalo aññatarassa phalitassa ambassa mūle nipajji, bahūni ambaphalāni
analyzed: nāma tassa antāni bahi caranti iti ārādhemi iti āditaḥ paṭṭhāya rādhemi vase vattemi iti attho  mahā tissa thero kira dubbhikkha kāle maggam gacchantaḥ bhatta chedena magga kilamathena  ca kilanta kāyaḥ dubbalaḥ aññatarassa phalitassa ambassa mūle nipajji bahūni amba phalāni
translated: I can endure it from the beginning: the meaning is, I can bear it, I can live with it.🔽It seems that the Elder Maha Tissa was travelling along the road in a time of famine. His body was weak and exhausted from lack of food and from the fatigue of travelling.🔽He lay down at the foot of a mango tree with ripe mangoes. Many mangoes had fallen here and there.

original: tahaṃ tahaṃ patitāni honti. Tattheko vuḍḍhataro upāsako therassa santikaṃ upagantvā
analyzed: taham taham patitāni honti tattha ikaḥ vuḍḍhataraḥ upāsakaḥ therassa santikam upagantvā
translated: A certain elderly lay devotee came to the elder,

original: parissamaṃ ñatvā ambapānaṃ pāyetvā attano piṭṭhiṃ āropetvā vasanaṭṭhānaṃ neti. Thero –
analyzed: parissamam ñatvā amba pānam pāyetvā attanaḥ piṭṭhim āropetvā vasanaṭṭhānam neti thero
translated: and finding out his trouble, he gave him a drink of mango juice and carried him on his back to his own dwelling place. The elder said:🔽“Neither your father nor your mother,

original: “Na pitā napi te mātā, na ñāti napi bandhavo;
analyzed: na pitā na api te mātā na ñāti na api bandhavaḥ
translated: Nor any kinsman or blood-relative,🔽Has done for you what you have done

original: Karotetādisaṃ kiccaṃ, sīlavantassa kāraṇā”ti. –
analyzed: karota etādisam kiccam sīlavantassa
translated: For one who is virtuous.”

original: Attānaṃ ovaditvā sammasanaṃ ārabhitvā vipassanaṃ vaḍḍhetvā tassa piṭṭhigato eva maggapaṭipāṭiyā
analyzed: attānam ovaditvā sammasanam ārabhitvā vipassanam vaḍḍhetvā tassa piṭṭhi gataḥ eva magga paṭipāṭiyā
translated: Having thus admonished himself, he began to reflect, and developing insight he reached Arahantship by the successive order of the paths.

original: arahattaṃ sacchākāsi. Imaṃ sandhāya vuttaṃ “ambakhādakamahātissattheravatthupi cettha
analyzed: arahattam imam sandhāya vuttam ca ittha
translated: This is the story referred to in the words “The story of the Elder Ambaṭṭha-Mahā Tissa should also be told here.”

original: kathetabba”nti. Sabbathāpīti sabbappakārenapi anesanavasena, cittuppattivasenapi,
analyzed: kathetabbam ti sabbathā api iti sabba ppakārena api anesana vasena citta uppatti vasena api
translated: In every way: in every manner, by way of the arising of consciousness,

original: pageva kāyavacīvipphanditavasenāti adhippāyo. Tenāha “anesanāyā”tiādi.
analyzed: pagā iva kāya vacī vipphandita vasena ati adhippāyo tena āha anesanāya atiādi
translated: and still more by way of the manifestation of body and speech. This is the purport. Therefore it is said: “By way of non-investigation, etc.”

original: Apaccavekkhitaparibhoge iṇaparibhogaāpattiādīnavassa, tabbipariyāyato paccavekkhitaparibhoge🔽ānisaṃsassa ca dassanaṃ ādīnavānisaṃsadassanaṃ. Tassa pana paccayādhikārattā vuttaṃ
analyzed: a paccavekkhita paribhoge iṇa paribhoga āpatti ādīnavassa tad vipariyāyato paccavekkhita paribhoge  ānisaṃsassa ca dassanam ādīnava anisaṃsa dassanam tassa pana paccaya adhikāra ttā vuttam
translated: The seeing of the danger in the use of requisites without reflection and the seeing of the benefit in the use of requisites with reflection.🔽But because of the predominance of the conditions, it is said: “By way of conditions.”

original: “paccayesū”ti. Kāraṇakāraṇampi hi kāraṇabhāvena vuccati yathā tiṇehi bhattaṃ siddhanti.
analyzed: paccayesu iti kāraṇa kāraṇam pi hi kāraṇa bhāvena vuccati yathā tiṇehi bhattam siddhan ti
translated: For a cause is also called a condition in the sense of a cause, just as in the statement: “The meal is ready with the grass.”

original: Yena kāraṇena bhikkhuno apaccavekkhitaparibhogo nāma siyā, tasmiṃ vajjite paccayasannissitasīlaṃ
analyzed: yena kāraṇena bhikkhuno apaccavekkhita paribhogaḥ nāma siyā tasmin vajjite paccaya sannissita sīlam
translated: When the fault of using requisites without reflection has been removed, virtue based on requisites

original: sijjhati, visujjhati cāti dassetuṃ “tasmā”tiādi vuttaṃ. Tattha paccayagedhanti gedhaggahaṇeneva
analyzed: sijjhati visujjhati ca ati dassetum tasmā itiādi vuttam tattha paccaya gedhanti gedha ggahaṇena iva
translated: In order to show that it is successful and purified, “Therefore” is said. Herein, the snare of conditions: by the word “snare”🔽

original: sammohopi gahitoti daṭṭhabbo tena saha pavattanato, tadupanissayato ca. Dhammena
analyzed: sammohaḥ api gahito ti daṭṭhabbo tena saha pavattanataḥ tad upanissayataḥ ca dhammena
translated: “It succeeds and is purified” is said to show this. Herein, the “snare of conditions” should be regarded as including delusion as well as grasping, because it occurs together with them and is their supporting condition.

original: samena uppanneti idaṃ paccayānaṃ āgamanasuddhidassanaṃ, na paccayasannissitasīlavisuddhidassanaṃ.
analyzed: samena uppannā iti idam āgamana suddhi dassanam na paccaya sannissita sīla visuddhi dassanam
translated: “When conditions arise in accordance with the True Idea”: this shows the purity of the source of the conditions, not the purity of the virtue dependent on conditions.

original: Paccayānaṃ hi idamatthitaṃ upadhāretvā paribhuñjanaṃ paccayasannissitasīlaṃ. Yasmā
analyzed: paccayānam hi idam atthitam upadhāretvā paribhuñjanam paccaya sannissita sīlam yasmā
translated: For the virtue dependent on conditions is the use of the conditions after determining their presence thus: “There is this.”

original: pana te paccayā ñāyādhigatā eva bhikkhunā paribhuñjitabbā, tasmā vuttaṃ “dhammena🔽samena uppanne paccaye”ti. Yathāvuttena vidhināti “sītassa paṭighātāyā”tiādinā vuttavidhinā.
analyzed: pana te paccayāḥ ñāya adhigatā eva bhikkhunā paribhuñjitabbā tasmā vuttam dhammena  samena uppanne paccaye iti yathā vuttena vidhinā ati sītassa paṭighātāya ati ādinā vutta vidhinā
translated: But since those conditions should be used by a bhikkhu only when they are acquired lawfully, it is said: “When conditions arise in accordance with the True Idea.”🔽“In the way stated”: in the way stated thus: “For the purpose of warding off cold” .

original: Dhātuvasena vāti “yathāpaccayaṃ vattamānaṃ dhātumattamevetaṃ, yadidaṃ cīvarādi, tadupabhuñjako
analyzed: dhātu vasena vāti yathāpaccayam vattamānam dhātumattam eva itam yat idam cīvara ādi tad upabhuñjakaḥ
translated: “In the mode of elements”: this mere element that is called a robe, etc., is only what has arisen in accordance with conditions. The user of it is a mere element too.

original: ca puggalo”ti evaṃ dhātumanasikāravasena vā. Paṭikūlavasena vāti piṇḍapāte tāva āhāre🔽paṭikūlasaññāvasena, “sabbāni pana imāni cīvarādīni ajigucchanīyāni, imaṃ pūtikāyaṃ
analyzed: ca evam dhātu manasikāra vasena vā paṭikūla vasena vā ati piṇḍapāte āhāre  paṭikūla saññā vasena sabbāni pana imāni cīvara ādīni a jigucchanīyāni imam pūti kāyam
translated: Or he can do so by means of the kinds of element, etc., as follows: “The alms food is the earth element, the water element, the fire element, and the air element, and the person who eats it.”🔽Or he can do so by means of the repulsive, as follows: “As regards the alms food, he should bring it to mind as repulsive by means of the perception of repulsiveness in nutriment,

original: patvā ativiya jigucchanīyāni jāyantī”ti evaṃ paṭikūlamanasikāravasena vā. Tato uttarīti
analyzed: patvā ativiya jigucchanīyāni jāyanti iti evam paṭikūla manasikāra vasena vā
translated: and he should bring it to mind as repulsive by means of the perception of repulsiveness in what is subject to turn, thinking ‘But all these robes, etc., which are not normally repulsive become quite repulsive when they come into contact with this putrid body’” .🔽After that: after the acquisition.

original: paṭilābhakālato upari. Anavajjova paribhogo āditova paññāya parisodhitattā adhiṭṭhahitvā🔽ṭhapitapattacīvarānaṃ viyāti. Paccavekkhaṇāya ādisuddhidassanaparametaṃ, na paribhogakāle
analyzed: paṭilābha kālato upari anavajjaḥ uva paribhogaḥ āditas iva paññāya parisodhita ttā adhiṭṭhahitvā  ṭhapita patta cīvarānam viyā ati paccavekkhaṇāya ādi suddhi dassana param etam na paribhoga kāle
translated: The use is blameless, because it was purified by wisdom from the beginning, like the robe and bowl that were set aside.🔽This is the highest purification of the beginning, the middle, and the end, which is called “the looking back.” But the prohibition of looking back at the time of use🔽is not the highest. Hence he said: “The looking back is at the time of use.”

original: paccavekkhaṇapaṭikkhepaparaṃ. Tenāha “paribhogakālepī”tiādi. Tatrāti tasmiṃ paribhogakāle
analyzed: paccavekkhaṇa paṭikkhepa param tena āha paribhoga kāle pi itiādi tatra ati tasmin paribhoga kāle
translated: There: at that time of use of the robe, etc.,

original: paccavekkhaṇe. Sanniṭṭhānakaroti asandehakaro ekantiko.🔽Theyyaparibhogo nāma anarahassa paribhogo. Bhagavatāpi attano sāsane sīlavato paccayā
analyzed: paccavekkhaṇe sanniṭṭhāna karo asandeha karo ekantiko 🔽theyya paribhogaḥ nāma anarahassa paribhogaḥ bhagavatā api attano sāsane sīlavato paccayā
translated: he makes sure: he makes it certain, free from doubt.

original: anuññātā, na dussīlassa. Dāyakānampi sīlavato eva pariccāgo, na dussīlassa. Attano🔽kārānaṃ mahapphalabhāvassa paccāsīsanato. Iti satthārā ananuññātattā, dāyakehi ca🔽apariccattattā dussīlassa paribhogo theyyāya paribhogo theyyaparibhogo. Iṇavasena🔽paribhogo iṇaparibhogo, paṭiggāhakato dakkhiṇāvisuddhiyā abhāvato iṇaṃ gahetvā paribhogo
analyzed: anuññātā na dussīlassa dāyakānam pi sīlavataḥ eva pariccāgaḥ na dussīlassa attanaḥ  kārānam mahat phala bhāvassa paccāsīsanataḥ iti satthārā an anuññāta ttā dāyakehi ca  a pariccatta ttā dussīlassa paribhogaḥ theyyāya paribhogaḥ theyya paribhogaḥ iṇa vasena  paribhogaḥ iṇa paribhogaḥ paṭiggāhakataḥ dakkhiṇā visuddhiyāḥ abhāvataḥ iṇam gahetvā paribhogaḥ
translated: It is not allowed for one who is immoral. And the giving of donors is only to one who is virtuous, not to one who is immoral. Because of the acknowledgment of the great fruitfulness of one’s own action. Thus, because it is not allowed by the Teacher, and because it is not given by donors, the use of one who is immoral is use by theft. Use by debt is use by taking on debt because of the absence of purification of offering by way of the receiver.🔽

original: viyāti attho. Tasmāti “sīlavato”tiādinā vuttamevatthaṃ kāraṇabhāvena paccāmasati.
analyzed: viyā ti attho tasmāti sīlavato ti ādinā vuttam evattham kāraṇa bhāvena paccāmasati
translated: It is not allowed for one who is immoral. And the giving of donors is only to one who is virtuous, not to one who is immoral. Because it is a repayment of the great fruitfulness of his own action. So it is because it is not allowed by the Master and because it is not given by donors that the use of one who is immoral is use as theft. Use as debt is use as a debt. The meaning is that it is use as though a debt were incurred because there is no purification of the offering by way of the receiver. So is the meaning. Because of that: he reminds the meaning stated by “of one who is virtuous” and so on as a reason.

original: Cīvaraṃ kāyato mocetvā paribhoge paribhoge purebhatta…pe… pacchimayāmesu paccavekkhitabbanti
analyzed: cīvaram kāyataḥ mocetvā paribhoge paribhoge purebhattape pacchima yāmesu paccavekkhitabbanti
translated: Having taken off the robe from the body, in each use of it, in the morning … in the last watch of the night, it should be reflected upon.

original: sambandho. Tathā asakkontena yathāvuttakālavisesavasena ekadivase catukkhattuṃ tikkhattuṃ
analyzed: sambandhaḥ tathā a sakkontena yathā vutta kāla visesa vasena eka divase catukkhattum tikkhattum
translated: The connection is this. And if he is unable to do so, it should be reflected upon four times, three times,

original: dvikkhattuṃ sakiṃyeva vā paccavekkhitabbaṃ. Sace aruṇaṃ uggacchati, iṇaparibhogaṭṭhāne
analyzed: dvi khattum vā paccavekkhitabbam sace aruṇam uggacchati iṇa paribhogaṭṭhāne
translated: two times, or once, on one day, according to the particular time stated. If dawn breaks, he is in the position of using as a debt.

original: tiṭṭhati. Hiyyo yaṃ mayā cīvaraṃ paribhuttaṃ, taṃ yāvadeva sītassa paṭighātāya…pe…
analyzed: tiṭṭhati hiyyas yam mayā cīvaram paribhuttam tam yāvat eva sītassa
translated: It is still there. The robe that I used yesterday was used by me for the purpose of warding off cold, for the purpose of warding off heat, for the purpose of warding off the touch of flies, mosquitoes, wind, sun and reptiles;

original: hirikopīnapaṭicchādanatthaṃ. Hiyyo yo mayā piṇḍapāto paribhutto, so “neva davāyā”tiādinā
analyzed: hiri kopīna paṭicchādana ttham hiyyaḥ yaḥ mayā piṇḍapātaḥ paribhuttaḥ saḥ na iva davāya ati ādinā
translated: for the purpose of concealing the private parts. The alms food that I used yesterday was used by me, not for the purpose of adorning myself, not for the purpose of adorning my body, not for the purpose of personal beauty, but for the purpose of the life of a recluse, for the purpose of warding off discomfort, for the purpose of assisting the life of purity, thinking ‘Thus this discomfort will not arise and if it has arisen it will be allayed, and I shall feel strong and light, and my life of purity will be undisturbed.’

original: sace atītaparibhogapaccavekkhaṇaṃ na kareyyāti vadanti, taṃ vīmaṃsitabbaṃ. Senāsanampi
analyzed: sace atīta paribhoga paccavekkhaṇam na kareyya ati vadanti tam vīmaṃsitabbam senāsanam pi
translated: If one does not do the reviewing of one’s use of the requisites as it should be done, it is said, one should review them in this way. As regards the dwelling,

original: paribhoge paribhogeti pavese pavese. Satipaccayatāti satiyā paccayabhāvo paṭiggahaṇassa,🔽paribhogassa ca paccavekkhaṇasatiyā paccayabhāvo yujjati, paccavekkhitvāva paṭiggahetabbaṃ,
analyzed: paribhoge paribhoge iti pavese pavese sati paccaya tā ati satiyā paccaya bhāvaḥ paṭiggahaṇassa  paribhogassa ca paccavekkhaṇa satiyā paccaya bhāvaḥ yujjati paccavekkhitvā ava paṭiggahetabbam
translated: one should review it at each use, that is, at each entry into it. The words “with mindfulness as condition” mean that the act of receiving and the act of using the requisites are conditioned by mindfulness.

original: paribhuñjitabbañcāti attho. Tenevāha “satiṃ katvā”tiādi. Evaṃ santepīti yadipi dvīsupi
analyzed: paribhuñjitabbam ca ati atthaḥ tena iva āha satim katvā atiādi evam sante pi iti yadi pi dvīsupi
translated: The meaning is that one should receive and use them after reviewing them. Hence it is said: “Having directed his mind to that object” , and so on.🔽Although this is so, although the reviewing is proper in both places, nevertheless,

original: ṭhānesu paccavekkhaṇā yuttā, evaṃ santepi. Apare panāhu – sati paccayatāti sati bhesajjaparibhogassa
analyzed: ṭhānesu paccavekkhaṇā yuttā evam sante pi apare pana āhu sati paccaya tā ati sati bhesajja paribhogassa
translated: others say that the words “with mindfulness as condition” refer to the reviewing of the use of the medicine.

original: paccayabhāve, sati paccayeti attho. Evaṃ santepīti paccaye satipīti. Taṃ tesaṃ matimattaṃ.
analyzed: paccaya bhāve sati paccaya iti atthaḥ evam sante api iti paccaye sati api iti tam tesam matimattam
translated: “When there is the state of condition, there is the state of conditionality” means that when there is the state of condition, there is the state of being a condition.🔽Even so, it is their mere opinion.

original: Tathā hi paccayasannissitasīlaṃ paccavekkhaṇāya visujjhati, na paccayassa bhāvamattena.🔽Evaṃ paccayasannissitasīlassa visuddhiṃ dassetvā teneva pasaṅgena sabbāpi visuddhiyo
analyzed: tathā hi paccaya sannissita sīlam paccavekkhaṇāya visujjhati na paccayassa bhāva mattena  evam paccaya sannissita sīlassa visuddhim dassetvā tena iva pasaṅgena sabbā api visuddhiyaḥ
translated: For virtue dependent on conditions is purified by reviewing, not by the mere existence of the conditions.

original: dassetuṃ “catubbidhā hi suddhī”tiādimāha. Tattha sujjhati etāyāti suddhi, yathādhammaṃ
analyzed: dassetum catubbidhā hi suddhi iti ādim āha tattha sujjhati etāya ati suddhi yathādhammam
translated: Having shown the purification of virtue dependent on conditions in this way, he now said “Purification is fourfold” in order to show all the kinds of purification by the same inspiration. Herein, it is purified by means of this, thus it is purification .🔽The teaching of the training precepts in the way they are is the purification of teaching.

original: desanāva suddhi desanāsuddhi. Vuṭṭhānassāpi cettha desanāya eva saṅgaho daṭṭhabbo.
analyzed: desanā va suddhi desanā suddhi vuṭṭhānassa api ca ittha desanāya eva saṅgahaḥ daṭṭhabbo
translated: And here the emergence should be regarded as included in the teaching.

original: Chinnamūlāpattīnaṃ pana abhikkhutāpaṭiññāva desanā. Adhiṭṭhānavisiṭṭho saṃvarova
analyzed: chinna mūla āpattīnam pana abhikkhu tā paṭiññā ava desanā adhiṭṭhāna visiṭṭhaḥ saṃvaraḥ va
translated: But the confession of a grave offence with the cutting off of the chances for its repetition is the teaching.🔽The restraint that is distinguished by the resolution is the purification of restraint.

original: suddhi saṃvarasuddhi. Dhammena samena paccayānaṃ pariyeṭṭhi eva suddhi pariyeṭṭhisuddhi.
analyzed: suddhi saṃvara suddhi dhammena samena paccayānam pariyeṭṭhi eva suddhi pariyeṭṭhi suddhi
translated: The search for the conditions in the right way is the purification of search.

original: Catūsupi paccayesu vuttavidhinā paccavekkhaṇāva suddhi paccavekkhaṇasuddhi. Esa tāva
analyzed: catūsu pi paccayesu vutta vidhinā
translated: And the reviewing in the four conditions in the way stated is the purification of reviewing. This, in the first place, is how the exposition should be known here as to the four kinds of purification.

original: suddhīsu samāsanayo. Suddhimantesu pana desanā suddhi etassāti desanāsuddhi. Sesesupi
analyzed: suddhīsu samāsanayo suddhimantesu pana desanā suddhi etassa ati desanā suddhi sesesu pi
translated: The method of the summary of the purities.🔽But among the purities of the reciters, the purity of the teaching is that which has the teaching as its purity. The same method applies in the case of the rest.

original: eseva nayo. Suddhi-saddo pana vuttanayova. Evanti saṃvarabhedaṃ sandhāyāha. Pahāyāti
analyzed: esa iva nayaḥ suddhi saddo pana vutta nayaḥ va evanti saṃvara bhedam sandhāya āha pahāya iti
translated: But the word purity is as already stated. Thus:

original: vajjetvā, akatvāti attho.
analyzed: vajjetvā a katvā iti attho
translated: Having abandoned, having rejected, having not done, is the meaning.🔽A gift is what is to be given. They take it, thus they are heirs.

original: Dātabbaṭṭhena dāyaṃ, taṃ ādiyantīti dāyādā. Ananuññātesu sabbena sabbaṃ paribhogābhāvato,
analyzed: dātabba ṭṭhena dāyam tam ādiyanti iti dāyādāḥ an anuññātesu sabbena sabbam paribhoga abhāvato
translated: Because there is no using at all in the case of those not permitted,

original: anuññātesu eva ca paribhogasambhavato bhikkhūhi paribhuñjitabbapaccayā bhagavato
analyzed: anuññātesu eva ca paribhoga sambhavataḥ bhikkhūhi paribhuñjitabba paccayāḥ bhagavataḥ
translated: and because there is the possibility of using only in the case of those permitted, they are the Blessed One’s own because they are to be used by bhikkhus.

original: santakā. “Dhammadāyādā me, bhikkhave, bhavatha mā āmisadāyādā. Atthi me tumhesu anukampā
analyzed: santakāḥ dhamma dāyādāḥ me bhikkhave bhavatha mā āmisa dāyādāḥ atthi me tumhesu anukampā
translated: “Bhikkhus, be heirs of my Dhamma, not heirs of my material things. I have compassion for you

original: ‘kinti me sāvakā dhammadāyādā bhaveyyuṃ no āmisadāyādā”’ti evaṃ pavattaṃ dhammadāyādasuttañca
analyzed: kinti me sāvakāḥ dhamma dāyādāḥ bhaveyyum no āmisa dāyādā ti evam pavattam dhamma dāyāda suttam ca
translated: ‘How can my disciples become heirs of my Dhamma and not heirs of my material things?’”

original: ettha etasmiṃ atthe sādhakaṃ.
analyzed: ettha etasmin atthe sādhakam
translated: This Dhamma-heir sutta is a proof here in this case.

original: Avītarāgānaṃ taṇhāparavasatāya paccayaparibhoge sāmibhāvo natthi, tadabhāvena vītarāgānaṃ
analyzed: avīta rāgānam taṇhā paravasa tāya paccaya paribhoge sāmibhāvaḥ natthi tad abhāvena vīta rāgānam
translated: Because of being dominated by craving, those who are not free from lust have no ownership in the use of requisites. Because of the absence of that, those who are free from lust

original: tattha sāmibhāvo yathāruciparibhogasambhavato. Tathā hi te paṭikūlampi appaṭikūlākārena,
analyzed: tattha sāmi bhāvaḥ yathāruci paribhoga sambhavato tathā hi te appaṭikūlam api appaṭikūla ākārena
translated: Herein, ownership is in the sense of the possibility of using as one wishes. For they use the requisites in a way that is not disagreeable,

original: appaṭikūlampi paṭikūlākārena, tadubhayampi vajjetvā ajjhupekkhanākārena paccaye paribhuñjanti,
analyzed: a paṭikūlam pi paṭikūla ākārena tat ubhayam pi vajjetvā ajjhupekkhana ākārena paccaye paribhuñjanti
translated: though they be disagreeable, and in a way that is agreeable, though they be agreeable, and in a way that is neither, though they be neither.

original: dāyakānañca manorathaṃ paripūrenti. Tenāha “te hi taṇhāya dāsabyaṃ atītattā sāmino🔽hutvā paribhuñjantī”ti.
analyzed: dāyakān añca manoratham paripūrenti tena āha te hi taṇhāya dāsabyam sāminaḥ  hutvā paribhuñjanti iti
translated: They fulfil the donors’ desire for merit. That is why it is said: “Because they have gone beyond being slaves to craving, they use the requisites as owners.

original: Sabbesanti ariyānaṃ, puthujjanānañca. Kathaṃ puthujjanānaṃ ime paribhogā sambhavanti?
analyzed: sabbesanti ariyānam puthujjanānam ca katham puthujjanānam ime paribhogā sambhavanti
translated: ” “All” means both noble persons and ordinary people. How is it that these uses of requisites are possible for ordinary people?

original: Upacāravasena. Yo hi puthujjanassāpi sallekhapaṭipattiyaṃ ṭhitassa paccayagedhaṃ
analyzed: upacāra vasena yaḥ hi puthujjanassa api sallekha paṭipattiyam ṭhitassa paccaya gedham
translated: They are possible in the sense of a conventional expression. For the use of requisites by an ordinary person who is established in the practice of renunciation,

original: pahāya tattha tattha anupalittena cittena paribhogo, so sāmiparibhogo viya hoti.
analyzed: pahāya tattha tattha an upalittena cittena paribhogo so sāmi paribhogaḥ viya hoti
translated: without his mind’s being attached to them, is like the use of requisites by an owner.

original: Sīlavato pana paccavekkhitaparibhogo dāyajjaparibhogo viya hoti, dāyakānaṃ manorathassa
analyzed: sīlavataḥ pana paccavekkhita paribhogaḥ dāyajja paribhogaḥ viya hoti dāyakānam manorathassa
translated: But the use of requisites by one who possesses virtue is like the use of a legacy, since it fulfils the desire of the donors.

original: avirādhanato. Tathā hi vuttaṃ “dāyajjaparibhogeyeva vā saṅgahaṃ gacchatī”ti. Kalyāṇaputhujjanassa
analyzed: a virādhanataḥ tathā hi vuttam vā saṅgaham gacchati iti kalyāṇa puthujjanassa
translated: and in the sense of non-contradiction. For it is said: “Or it is included in the enjoyment of an inheritance.”🔽There is nothing to be said about the enjoyment of a good ordinary man,

original: paribhoge vattabbameva natthi, tassa sekkhasaṅgahato. Sekkhasuttaṃ hetassatthassa
analyzed: paribhoge vattabbam eva na atthi tassa sekkha saṅgahato sekkha suttam ha itassa atthassa
translated: because he is included in the category of the trainee. The Trainee Discourse is a proof of this meaning.

original: sādhakaṃ. Tenāha “sīlavāpi hī”tiādi. Paccanīkattāti yathā iṇāyiko attano ruciyā icchitadesaṃ
analyzed: sādhakam tena āha sīlavā api hi itiādi paccanīka ttā iti yathā iṇāyikaḥ attanaḥ ruciyā icchita desam
translated: Therefore it is said: “The virtuous man too” and so on. As to the opposite: just as a debtor cannot go to the place he wants to go out of his own desire,

original: gantuṃ na labhati, evaṃ iṇaparibhogayutto lokato nissarituṃ na labhatīti tappaṭipakkhattā
analyzed: gantum na labhati evam iṇa paribhoga yuttaḥ lokataḥ nissaritum na labhati iti tad paṭipakkha ttā
translated: so one who is bound to the enjoyment of debt is unable to leave the world. Because this enjoyment is the opposite of that,

original: sīlavato paccavekkhitaparibhogo āṇaṇyaparibhogoti āha “āṇaṇyaparibhogo vā”ti. Etena
analyzed: sīlavataḥ paccavekkhita paribhogo āṇaṇya paribhogo ti āha āṇaṇya paribhogaḥ vā ati etena
translated: the enjoyment of the virtuous man when he reflects is called the enjoyment of freedom from debt. Therefore it is said: “Or the enjoyment of freedom from debt.” By this

original: nippariyāyato catuparibhogavinimutto visuṃyevāyaṃ paribhogoti dasseti. Imāya sikkhāyāti
analyzed: catu paribhoga vinimutto visum yeva ayam paribhogaḥ ti dasseti imāya sikkhāya ati
translated: he shows that this enjoyment is quite distinct, being excluded from the four enjoyments in the ultimate sense. By this training:

original: sīlasaṅkhātāya sikkhāya. Kiccakārīti paṭiññānurūpaṃ paṭipajjanato yuttapattakārī.
analyzed: sīla saṅkhātāya sikkhāya kicca kārī iti paṭiññā anurūpam paṭipajjanataḥ yutta patta kārī
translated: by the training called virtue. He does what should be done: he does what is proper by acting in accordance with his promise.

original: Idāni tameva kiccakāritaṃ suttapadena vibhāvetuṃ “vuttampi ceta”ntiādi vuttaṃ. Tattha🔽vihāranti patissayaṃ. Sayanāsananti mañcādiṃ. Ubhayenapi senāsanameva vuttaṃ. Āpanti
analyzed: idāni tam eva kicca kāritam sutta padena vibhāvetum vuttam pi cetan ti ādi vuttam tattha  vihāranti pati ssayam sayanāsananti mañca ādim ubhayena api senāsanam eva vuttam āpanti
translated: Now, in order to illustrate that very service with a passage from the scriptures, the following is said: “Though it is said” and so forth. Therein,🔽“dwelling” is a dwelling place. “Bed and chair” is a bed, etc. Both together are said to be a resting place. “Water”

original: udakaṃ. Saṅghāṭirajūpavāhananti paṃsumalādino saṅghāṭigatarajassa dhovanaṃ. Sutvāna🔽dhammaṃ sugatena desitanti cīvarādīsu “paṭisaṅkhā yoniso cīvaraṃ paṭisevati sītassa
analyzed: udakam saṅghāṭi rajū upavāhananti paṃsu mala ādinaḥ saṅghāṭi gata rajassa dhovanam sutvāna  dhammam sugatena desitanti cīvara ādīsu paṭisaṅkhā yonisas cīvaram paṭisevati sītassa
translated: is drinking water. “Washing the dirt from the robes” is washing the dirt from the robes, etc. “Having heard”🔽the Dhamma taught by the Sugata” means having heard the Dhamma taught by the Blessed One in such a way as: “Having reflected wisely, he makes use of robes for the purpose of warding off cold,

original: paṭighātāyā”tiādinā nayena bhagavatā desitaṃ dhammaṃ sutvā. Saṅkhāya seve varapaññasāvakoti🔽“piṇḍa”nti vuttaṃ piṇḍapātaṃ, vihārādipadehi vuttaṃ senāsanaṃ, “pipāsāgelaññassa
analyzed: paṭighātāya ati ādinā nayena bhagavatā desitam dhammam sutvā saṅkhāya seve vara paññasāvako ti  piṇḍanti vuttam piṇḍapātam vihāra ādi padehi vuttam senāsanam pipāsā gelaññassa
translated: for the purpose of warding off heat, for the purpose of warding off the touch of flies, mosquitoes, wind, sun, and reptiles,” and so forth. “The wise disciple makes use of it, reflecting”

original: vūpasamanato pānīyampi gilānapaccayo”ti āpamukhena dassitaṃ gilānapaccayaṃ, saṅghāṭiyādicīvaranti
analyzed: vūpasamanataḥ pānīyam pi gilāna paccayaḥ ti āpa mukhena dassitam gilāna paccayam saṅghāṭiya ādi cīvaranti
translated: means that the wise disciple makes use of the alms food, etc., that are mentioned by the words “alms food,” the resting place that is mentioned by the words “dwelling place,” etc., and the requisite of medicine for support that is shown by the words “water” and so forth, in the following way: “The requisite of medicine for support is for the purpose of warding off arisen bodily feelings of illness in order to preserve my life and promote my health.” “Robes” means

original: catubbidhaṃ paccayaṃ saṅkhāya “yāvadeva imassa kāyassa ṭhitiyā”tiādinā nayena paccavekkhitvā.
analyzed: catubbidham paccayam saṅkhāya yāvat eva imassa kāyassa ṭhitiyā ati ādinā nayena paccavekkhitvā
translated: Having reflected on the four kinds of conditions, in the way beginning, “For the support of this body,”

original: Seve sevituṃ sakkuṇeyya uttamapaññassa bhagavato sāvako sekho vā puthujjano vā.
analyzed: seve sevitum sakkuṇeyyaḥ uttama paññassa bhagavato sāvako sekhaḥ vā puthujjanaḥ vā
translated: The disciple of the One of Excellent Wisdom, whether he be a trainer or an ordinary man, is able to serve.🔽And because the disciple of the One of Excellent Wisdom serves after reflection,

original: Yasmā ca saṅkhāya sevī varapaññasāvako, tasmā hi piṇḍe…pe… pokkhare vāribindu, tathā
analyzed: ca saṅkhāya sevī vara paññasāvako tasmā hi piṇḍepe pokkhare vāri bindu tathā
translated: therefore, as a drop of water on a lotus leaf does not stick to it,

original: hoti. Kālenāti ariyānaṃ bhojanakāle. Laddhāti labhitvā. Paratoti aññato dāyakato.
analyzed: kālena ati ariyānam bhojana kāle laddhā ati labhitvā paratas ti aññatas dāyakato
translated: so does he not stick to sense desires. At the proper time: at the time of eating for the Noble Ones. Having received: having obtained. From another: from a donor.

original: Anuggahāti anukampāya bahumhi upanīte mattaṃ so jaññā jāneyya satataṃ sabbakālaṃ
analyzed: anuggahāti anukampāya bahumhi upanīte mattam saḥ jaññā jāneyya satatam sabbakālam
translated: He should know the measure: he should know the measure in the case of much that is brought. Always: at all times.🔽Attentively: with mindfulness established. As in the case of the application of ointment and the healing of a wound:

original: upaṭṭhito upaṭṭhitassati. Ālepanarūhane yathāti bhesajjalepanena vaṇassa ruhane viya,
analyzed: upaṭṭhitaḥ upaṭṭhitassati ālepana rūhane yathā ati bhesajja lepanena vaṇassa ruhane viya
translated: as in the case of the application of ointment to a wound and the healing of the wound,

original: mattaṃ jāneyyāti yojanā. Āhareti āhareyya. “Āhareyyāhāra”nti vā pāṭho. Yāpanatthanti
analyzed: mattam jāneyya ati yojanā āhara iti āhareyya āhareyya āhāram ti vā pāṭhaḥ yāpana ttham ti
translated: so he should know the measure. He should bring: he should bring food. Or the reading is āhareyya āhāraṃ . For the sake of sustenance:

original: sarīrassa yāpanāya. Amucchitoti taṇhāmucchāya amucchito gedhaṃ taṇhaṃ anāpanno.
analyzed: sarīrassa yāpanāya amucchito ti taṇhā mucchāya amucchitaḥ gedham taṇham an āpannaḥ
translated: for the sake of sustaining the body. Without craving: without being moistened by craving, without having brought craving into the mouth.

original: Attano mātulassa saṅgharakkhitattherasseva nāmassa gahitattā bhāgineyyasaṅgharakkhitasāmaṇero.
analyzed: attanaḥ mātulassa saṅgharakkhita therassa iva nāmassa gahita ttā bhāgineyya saṅgharakkhita sāmaṇero
translated: He was called the novice Sangha-rakkhita the nephew because he had taken the name of his maternal uncle, the Elder Sangha-rakkhita.

original: Sālikūranti sālibhattaṃ. Sunibbutanti susītalaṃ. Asaññatoti apaccavekkhaṇaṃ sandhāyāha.
analyzed: sālikūranti sālibhattam su nibbutam ti su sītalam asaññato ti apaccavekkhaṇam sandhāya āha
translated: Rice-gruel: rice-water. Well-cooked: well-boiled. Unmindful: he said this referring to lack of reflection.

original: Sabbāsavaparikkhīṇoti parikkhīṇasabbāsavo.
analyzed: sabba āsava parikkhīṇoti parikkhīṇa sabba āsavaḥ
translated: All cankers destroyed: he whose cankers are destroyed.

original: Paṭhamasīlapañcakavaṇṇanā
analyzed: paṭhama sīla pañcaka vaṇṇanā
translated: The first section on the five training precepts🔽They have an end, thus they are limited; they are limited training precepts, thus they are limited training precepts.

original: 20. Pariyanto etesaṃ atthīti pariyantāni, pariyantāni sikkhāpadāni yesaṃ te pariyantasikkhāpadā,
analyzed: pariyantaḥ etesam atthi iti pariyantāni pariyantāni sikkhāpadāni yesam te pariyanta sikkhāpadā
translated: Of those limited training precepts,

original: tesaṃ pariyantasikkhāpadānaṃ. Upasampannānanti ṭhapetvā kalyāṇaputhujjanasekkhāsekkhe🔽tadaññesaṃ upasampannānaṃ. Sāmaññajotanāpi hi visese tiṭṭhati. Kusaladhamme yuttānanti
