analyzed: tesam pariyanta sikkhāpadānam upasampannānam ti ṭhapetvā kalyāṇa puthujjana sekkhā sekkhe  tad aññesam upasampannānam sāmañña jotanā api hi visese tiṭṭhati kusala dhamme yuttānam ti
translated: of those who have been ordained, except for the good ordinary men, the trainers, and the adepts,🔽the rest are called “ordained.” For the designation of a recluse is established in a distinction.🔽Who are devoted to profitable things: who are devoted to the practice of insight.

original: vipassanācāre yuttapayuttānaṃ. Sekkhadhammā pariyantā paramā mariyādā etassāti sekkhapariyanto.
analyzed: vipassanā ācāre yutta payuttānam sekkha dhammā pariyantā paramā mariyādā etassa ati sekkha pariyantaḥ
translated: The end of the trainers is the limit, the extreme, the boundary, of the trainers.

original: Nāmarūpaparicchedato, kusaladhammasamādānato vā pana paṭṭhāya yāva gotrabhū, tāva
analyzed: nāma rūpa paricchedato kusala dhamma samādānato vā pana paṭṭhāya yāva tāva
translated: From the delimitation of mentality-materiality, or from the undertaking of profitable things up to the stage of the lineage,

original: pavattakusaladhammappabandho sekkhadhamme āhacca ṭhito sekkhapariyanto. Sekkhadhammānaṃ
analyzed: pavatta kusala dhamma ppabandhaḥ sekkha dhamme āhacca ṭhitaḥ sekkha pariyantaḥ sekkha dhammānam
translated: The “end of training” is the end of the training in virtue, etc., which is reached when the aggregates of virtue, etc., are brought to fulfilment. The “end of training” is also the three kinds of mundane training that are to be undertaken as the lower limit of the aggregates of virtue, etc., in one who is still in training.

original: vā heṭṭhimantabhūtā sikkhitabbā lokiyā tisso sikkhā sekkhapariyanto, tasmiṃ sekkhapariyante.
analyzed: vā heṭṭhimanta bhūtā sikkhitabbā lokiyā tisso sikkhā sekkha pariyanto tasmin sekkha pariyante
translated: “In the end of training”: in the end of the training.🔽“Who have fulfilled virtue”: who have fulfilled virtue without omitting any part of it.

original: Paripūrakārīnanti kiñcipi sikkhaṃ ahāpetvā pūrentānaṃ. Uparivisesādhigamatthaṃ kāye
analyzed: paripūra kārīnam ti kiñcipi sikkham ahāpetvā pūrentānam upari visesa adhigama attham kāye
translated: “Who are intent on the attainment of the higher path”: who are intent on the attainment of the higher path by being unconcerned about both their bodies and their lives.🔽“Who have renounced the life of the household life”: who have renounced the life of the household life by being unconcerned about their lives.

original: ca jīvite ca anapekkhānaṃ. Tato eva sīlapāripūriatthaṃ pariccattajīvitānaṃ. Diṭṭhisaṃkilesena
analyzed: ca jīvite ca an apekkhānam tatas eva sīla pāripūri attham pariccatta jīvitānam diṭṭhi saṃkilesena
translated: “Whose virtue is purified by being free from the stain of wrong view”: whose virtue is purified by being free from the stain of wrong view.🔽“Whose virtue is purified by being free from the stain of wrong view”: whose virtue is purified by being free from the stain of wrong view.🔽“Whose virtue is purified by being free from the stain of wrong view”: whose virtue is purified by being free from the stain of wrong view.🔽“Whose virtue is purified by being free from the stain of wrong view”: whose virtue is purified by being free from the stain of wrong view.🔽“Whose virtue is purified by being free from the stain of wrong view”: whose virtue is purified by being free from the stain of wrong view.🔽“Whose virtue is purified by being free from the stain of wrong view”: whose virtue is purified by being free from the stain of wrong view.

original: aparāmasanīyato pārisuddhivantaṃ sīlaṃ aparāmaṭṭhapārisuddhisīlaṃ. Kilesānaṃ sabbaso🔽paṭippassaddhiyā pārisuddhivantaṃ sīlaṃ paṭippassaddhipārisuddhisīlaṃ.
analyzed: a parāmasanīyataḥ pārisuddhivantam sīlam a parāmaṭṭha pārisuddhi sīlam kilesānam sabbaso  paṭippassaddhiyā pārisuddhivantam sīlam paṭippassaddhi pārisuddhi sīlam
translated: “Whose virtue is purified by being free from the stain of wrong view”: whose virtue is purified by being free from the stain of wrong view.🔽“Whose virtue is purified by being free from the stain of wrong view”: whose virtue is purified by being free from the stain of wrong view.🔽“Whose virtue is purified by being free from the stain of wrong view”: whose virtue is purified by being free from the stain of wrong view.🔽“Whose virtue is purified by being free from the stain of wrong view”: whose virtue is purified by being free from the stain of wrong view.

original: Anupasampannānaṃ asekkhānaṃ, sekkhānaṃ, kalyāṇaputhujjanānañca sīlaṃ mahānubhāvatāya🔽ānubhāvato apariyantamevāti āha “gaṇanavasena sapariyantattā”ti. Kāyavācānaṃ saṃvaraṇato,
analyzed: an upasampannānam asekkhānam sekkhānam kalyāṇa puthujjanānam ca sīlam mahā anubhāva tāya 🔽ānubhāvataḥ a pariyantam eva iti āha gaṇana vasena sa pariyanta ttā iti kāya vācānam saṃvaraṇataḥ
translated: “Whose virtue is purified by being free from the stain of wrong view”: whose virtue is purified by being free from the stain of wrong view.🔽“Whose virtue is purified by being free from the stain of

original: vinayanato ca saṃvaravinayā. Peyyālamukhena niddiṭṭhāti tattha tattha satthārā desitavitthāranayena
analyzed: vinayanato ca saṃvara vinayā peyyāla mukhena niddiṭṭhā ati tattha tattha satthārā desita vitthāra nayena
translated: They are shown by way of the number of the fully admitted monks, and the virtue of the fully admitted monks is to be brought down and connected with what was said above.🔽For whatever virtue is to be trained in by a fully admitted monk is called virtue.🔽In that, by way of the non-remainder of anyone,🔽by way of the non-remainder of any virtue,🔽the non-remainder of the virtue that is to be trained in by a fully admitted monk is called the non-remainder of virtue.

original: yathāvuttagaṇanato niddiṭṭhā. Sikkhāti sīlasaṅkhātā sikkhā. Vinayasaṃvareti vinayapiṭake.🔽Gaṇanavasena sapariyantampi upasampannānaṃ sīlanti heṭṭhā vuttaṃ ānetvā sambandhitabbaṃ.
analyzed: yathāvutta gaṇanataḥ niddiṭṭhā sikkhā ati sīla saṅkhātā sikkhā vinaya saṃvare ti vinaya piṭake  gaṇana vasena sapariyantam pi upasampannānam sīlanti heṭṭhā vuttam ānetvā sambandhitabbam
translated: The non-remainder of the virtue that is to be trained in by a fully admitted monk is called the non-remainder of virtue.

original: Yaṃ kiñci hi upasampannena sikkhitabbaṃ sīlaṃ nāma, tattha kassacipi anavasesato🔽anavasesavasena. Samādānabhāvanti samādānasabbhāvaṃ. Lābha…pe… vasena adiṭṭhapariyantabhāvo🔽lābhādihetu sīlassa avītikkamo.
analyzed: yam kiñci hi upasampannena sikkhitabbam sīlam nāma tattha kassaci pi anavasesato  anavasesa vasena samādāna bhāvanti samādāna sabbhāvam lābha pe vasena a diṭṭha pariyanta bhāvo  lābha ādi hetu sīlassa a vītikkamaḥ
translated: The non-remainder of the virtue that is to be trained in by a fully admitted monk is called the non-remainder of virtue.🔽The non-remainder of the virtue that is to be trained in by a fully admitted monk is called the non-remainder of virtue.🔽The non-remainder of the virtue that is to be trained in by a fully admitted monk is called the non-remainder of virtue.🔽The non-remainder of the virtue that is to be trained in by a fully admitted monk is called the non-remainder of virtue.

original: Dhanaṃ caje aṅgavarassa hetu pāripanthikacorādīhi upadduto. Aṅgaṃ caje jīvitaṃ rakkhamāno
analyzed: dhanam caje aṅga varassa hetu pāripanthika cora ādīhi upaddutaḥ aṅgam caje jīvitam rakkhamāno
translated: The non-remainder of the virtue that is to be trained in by a fully admitted monk is called the non-remainder of virtue.🔽The non-remainder of the virtue that is to be trained in by a fully admitted monk is called the non-remainder of virtue.🔽The non-remainder of the virtue that is to be trained in by a fully admitted monk is called the non-remainder of virtue.🔽The non-remainder of the virtue that is to be trained in by a fully admitted monk is called the non-remainder of virtue.🔽The non-remainder of the virtue that is to be trained in by a fully admitted monk is called the non-remainder of virtue.🔽The non-remainder of the virtue that is to be trained in by a fully admitted monk is called the non-remainder of virtue.🔽The non-remainder of the virtue that is to be trained in by a fully admitted monk is called the non-remainder of virtue.🔽The non-remainder of the virtue that is to be trained in by a fully admitted monk is called the non-remainder of virtue.

original: sappadaṭṭhādikāle. Aṅgaṃ dhanaṃ jīvitañcāpi sabbaṃ, caje naro dhammamanussaranto
analyzed: sappadaṭṭha ādi kāle aṅgam dhanam jīvitam ca api sabbam caje naraḥ dhammam anussarantaḥ
translated: The non-remainder of the virtue

original: sutasomamahābodhisattādayo viya. Tenāha “imaṃ sappurisānussatiṃ avijahanto”ti. Jighacchāparissamena
analyzed: sutasoma mahābodhisatta ādayaḥ viya tena āha imam sappurisa anussatim a vijahantaḥ iti jighacchā parissamena
translated: like Sutasoma, the Great Being, and so on. Hence it was said: “Not abandoning this recollection of a True Man.”🔽Even though there was doubt about his life because of the suffering of hunger,

original: jīvitasaṃsaye satipi. Sikkhāpadaṃ avītikkammāti assāmikesu ambaphalesu bhūmiyaṃ patitesu
analyzed: jīvita saṃsaye sati pi sikkhāpadam a vītikkamma ati assāmikesu amba phalesu bhūmiyam patitesu
translated: he did not transgress the training precept. When the mango fruits fell on the ground

original: samīpeyeva santesupi paṭiggāhakābhāvena aparibhuñjanto paṭiggahaṇasikkhāpadaṃ avītikkamitvā.
analyzed: samīpeya iva santesu pi paṭiggāhaka abhāvena a paribhuñjantaḥ paṭiggahaṇa sikkhāpadam a vītikkamitvā
translated: and were near him, he did not eat them because there was no one to receive them.

original: Sīlavantassāti sīlavantabhāvassa kāraṇā, sīlavantassa vā tuyhaṃ etādisaṃ aṃsena vāhaṇādikaṃ
analyzed: sīlavantassa ati sīlavanta bhāvassa kāraṇā sīlavantassa vā tuyham etādisam aṃsena vāhaṇa ādikam
translated: He did not transgress the training precept of receiving. “Because of your virtue”: because of the state of being virtuous, or because of your virtue, this kind of service, such as carrying on your shoulder, is done.

original: kiccaṃ karoti, kāraṇā sīlassāti adhippāyo. Sudhotajātimaṇi viyāti catūsu pāsāṇesu🔽sammadeva dhotajātimaṇi viya. Mahāsaṅgharakkhitabhāgineyyasaṅgharakkhitattherānaṃ
analyzed: kiccam karoti kāraṇā sīlassa ati adhippāyaḥ sudhota jāti maṇi viyāti catūsu pāsāṇesu  sammat eva dhota jāti maṇi viya mahā saṅgharakkhita bhāgineyya saṅgharakkhita ttherānam
translated: The meaning intended is: “Because of virtue.” “Like a gem of pure origin”: like a gem of pure origin that is well washed in the four stones.🔽Like the Elder Saṅgharakkhita, the nephew of the Elder Mahāsaṅgharakkhita,🔽like the Elder Saṅgharakkhita, the nephew of the Elder Mahāsaṅgharakkhita,

original: viyāti mahāsaṅgharakkhitattherassa, tasseva bhāgineyyasaṅgharakkhitattherassa viya
analyzed: viyā ati mahā saṅgharakkhita therassa tassa iva bhāgineyya saṅgharakkhita therassa viya
translated: and like the Elder Mahāsaṅgharakkhita himself.

original: ca. “Kimatthaṃ mayaṃ idhāgatā”ti mahājanassa vippaṭisāro bhavissatīti adhippāyo.
analyzed: ca kimattham mayam idha āgatā ati mahājanassa vippaṭisāraḥ bhavissati iti adhippāyaḥ
translated: “What is the purpose of our coming here?” There will be a great deal of grumbling among the people.

original: Accharikāyāti aṅguliphoṭanena. Asatiyāti satisammosena. Aññāṇapakatanti aññāṇena
analyzed: accharikāya ati aṅguli phoṭanena asatiyā ati sati sammosena aññāṇa pakatanti aññāṇena
translated: “With a mere gesture” means with a mere snap of the fingers. “With a mere thought” means with a mere lapse of mindfulness. “With a mere act of unknowing” means

original: aparajjhitvā kataṃ, ajānitvā katanti attho.🔽Appassutopi ce hotīti suttageyyādisutarahito hoti ce. Sīlesu asamāhitoti pātimokkhasaṃvarādisīlesupi
analyzed: aparajjhitvā katam a jānitvā katanti attho  appassutaḥ pi ce hoti iti sutta geyya ādi suta rahitaḥ hoti ce sīlesu asamāhito ti pātimokkha saṃvara ādi sīlesu pi
translated: with a mere act of ignorance. The meaning is: without being aware of it, without knowing it.🔽“Even if he is not learned” means even if he is devoid of learning, of the study of the scriptures, etc. “If he is not concentrated in virtue” means if he is not well established in virtue, in the restraint of the Pāṭimokkha, etc.

original: na sammā patiṭṭhito hoti ce. Nāssa sampajjate sutanti assa sīlarahitassa puggalassa🔽sutaṃ attano, paresañca katthaci bhavasampattiāvahaṃ na hoti. “Dussīloyaṃ purisapuggalo”ti
analyzed: na sammā patiṭṭhitaḥ hoti ce na assa sampajjate sutanti assa sīla rahitassa puggalassa  sutam attano paresam ca katthaci bhava sampatti āvaham na hoti dussīlaḥ yam purisa puggalo ti
translated: “His learning will not succeed” means that learning of that person who is devoid of virtue🔽will not bring about any excellence for himself or others. For those who desire training do not approach one who is “an unvirtuous person.”

original: hi sikkhākāmā na tassa santikaṃ upasaṅkamanti. Bahussutopi ceti ettha ce-ti nipātamattaṃ.
analyzed: hi sikkhā kāmāḥ na tassa santikam upasaṅkamanti bahu sutaḥ api ca iti ettha ca iti nipāta mattam
translated: “Even if he is learned” means that the word “even” is merely a particle.

original: Pasaṃsitoti pasaṃsito eva nāma.
analyzed: pasaṃsitā iti pasaṃsitaḥ eva nāma
translated: “He is praised” means he is praised just because he is praised.

original: Rāgavasena aparāmaṭṭhagahaṇena taṇhāparāmāsābhāvamāha. Tathārūpanti rāgavasena aparāmaṭṭhaṃ.
analyzed: rāga vasena aparāmaṭṭha gahaṇena taṇhā parāmāsa abhāvam āha tathārūpam ti rāga vasena aparāmaṭṭham
translated: By the phrase “he does not grasp through lust,” he shows the absence of grasping through craving. “Such a one” means one who does not grasp through lust.

original: Bhinditvāti hanitvā. Saññapessāmīti saññattiṃ karissāmi, appakaṃ velaṃ maṃ vissejjetunti
analyzed: bhinditvā ati hanitvā saññapessāmi iti saññattim karissāmi appakam velam mama vissejjetunti
translated: “Having killed” means having slain. “I will have him executed” means I will have him sentenced to death. “For a short time” means for a short period.

original: adhippāyo. Aṭṭiyāmīti jigucchāmi. Harāyāmīti lajjāmi.
analyzed: adhippāyaḥ aṭṭiyāmi iti jigucchāmi harāyāmi iti lajjāmi
translated: ‘I will break it’ means ‘I will kill it.’ ‘I will make it known’ means ‘I will make it known that I have done this.’ ‘I will not be sent away for a long time’ is the intention. ‘I am disgusted’ means ‘I am nauseated.’ ‘I am ashamed’ means ‘I am embarrassed.’

original: Palipannoti sīdanto, sammakkhito vā. Sīleneva saddhiṃ marissāmīti sīlaṃ avināsento🔽tena saheva marissāmi, na idāni kadācipi taṃ pariccajissāmi. Sati hi bhavādāne sīlena
analyzed: palipannaḥ ti sīdantaḥ sammakkhitaḥ vā sīlena iva saddhim marissāmi iti sīlam a vināsentaḥ  tena saha iva marissāmi na idāni kadācipi tam pariccajissāmi sati hi bhava ādāne sīlena
translated: ‘I am entangled’ means ‘I am sinking down, I am smeared.’ ‘I will die with virtue’ means ‘without destroying virtue

original: viyogo siyā, bhavameva nādiyissāmīti adhippāyo. Rogaṃ sammasantoti rogabhūtaṃ vedanaṃ
analyzed: viyogaḥ siyā bhavam eva na ādiyissāmi iti adhippāyaḥ rogam sammasantaḥ ti roga bhūtam vedanam
translated: I will die with it, I will never abandon it.’ For it is possible that virtue will be separated from me at the time of death. The intention is that ‘I will not accept existence.’ ‘Contemplating the disease’ means contemplating the feeling that is the disease,

original: vedanāmukhena sesārūpadhamme, rūpadhamme ca pariggahetvā vipassanto.🔽Ruppatoti vikāraṃ āpādiyamānasarīrassa. Parisussatīti samantato sussati. Yathā kiṃ?
analyzed: vedanā mukhena sesa arūpa dhamme rūpa dhamme ca pariggahetvā vipassanto  ruppataḥ ti vikāram āpādiyamāna sarīrassa parisussati iti samantataḥ sussati yathā kim
translated: and contemplating the remaining material phenomena and immaterial phenomena by way of feeling, grasping them.🔽‘From its appearance’ means from the appearance of the body. ‘It dries up all over’ means it dries up all around. How?🔽Like a flower in the dust in the sun. A flower such as a sirisa flower, etc.,

original: Pupphaṃ yathā paṃsuni ātape kataṃ sūriyātapasantatte paṃsuni ṭhapitaṃ sirīsādipupphaṃ
analyzed: puppham yathā paṃsuni ātape katam sūriya ātapa santatte paṃsuni ṭhapitam sirīsa ādi puppham
translated: placed in the dust in the sun, heated by the sun’s rays,

original: viyāti attho. Ajaññanti amanuññaṃ jigucchanīyaṃ. Jaññasaṅkhātanti bālehi “jañña”nti🔽evaṃ kittitaṃ. Jaññarūpaṃ apassatoti yathābhūtaṃ appassato aviddasuno “jañña”nti🔽pasaṃsitaṃ. Dhiratthumanti dhi atthu imaṃ, dhi-saddayogena sabbattha upayogavacanaṃ,
analyzed: viyā ti atthaḥ a jaññanti amanuññam jigucchanīyam jañña saṅkhātanti bālehi jaññanti  evam kittitam jañña rūpam a passataḥ ti yathābhūtam a passataḥ a viddasunaḥ jaññanti  pasaṃsitam dhi ratthumanti dhi atthu imam dhi sadda yogena sabbattha upayoga vacanam
translated: the meaning is, ‘in the way stated.’ ‘Not approved’ : not approved, not liked. ‘Called approved’ : approved by fools,

original: imassa pūtikāyassa dhikāro hotūti attho. Duggandhiyanti duggandhikaṃ duggandhavantaṃ.
analyzed: imassa pūti kāyassa dhikāraḥ hotu uti attho duggandhiyanti duggandhikam duggandhavantam
translated: praised by them as ‘approved.’ ‘Not seeing the nature of what is approved’ : not seeing it as it really is, not penetrating it, ‘approved’ is praised. ‘Fie on this skeleton’ : fie on this, this is the meaning. ‘Fie’ is a term of censure. ‘Fie on this skeleton’ is said with the word ‘fie’ in all instances. ‘Fie on this foul body’ is the meaning. ‘Stinking’ : stinking, foul-smelling.

original: Yattha yathāvutte pūtikāye rāgahetu pamattā pamādaṃ āpannā. Pajāti sattā. Hāpenti
analyzed: yattha yathā vutte pūti kāye rāga hetu pamattā pamādam āpannā pajāti sattāḥ hāpenti
translated: where, in the foul body stated thus, the heedless, the negligent, because of lust,

original: maggaṃ sugatūpapattiyāti sugatūpapattiyā maggaṃ, sīlampi hāpenti, pageva jhānādinti
analyzed: maggam sugata upapattiyā ati sugata upapattiyā maggam sīlam pi hāpenti pagā iva jhāna ādinti
translated: lose the path to good destinations, to rebirth in the happy realms. ‘They lose the path’ : the path to rebirth in the happy realms, they lose morality, to say nothing of the jhānas, etc.

original: adhippāyo. Kevalaṃ “arahanto”ti vattabbā sāvakakhīṇāsavā, itare pana paccekabuddhā
analyzed: adhippāyaḥ kevalam arahanto ti vattabbā sāvaka khīṇa āsavāḥ itare pana paccekabuddhā
translated: This is the purport. ‘Worthy Ones’ should be said only of disciples and of those who have destroyed the taints, but the others are Paccekabuddhas and

original: sammāsambuddhāti saha visesanenāti āha “arahantādīna”nti. Sabbadarathappaṭippassaddhiyāti
analyzed: sammāsambuddhā iti saha visesanena ati āha arahanta ādīnam ti sabbadaratha ppaṭippassaddhiyā ti
translated: fully enlightened Buddhas. ‘With the distinction’ is said in order to show this. ‘The complete subsiding of all suffering’ :

original: sabbakilesadarathappaṭippassaddhiyā.
analyzed: sabba kilesa daratha paṭippassaddhiyā
translated: and the stilling of the entire current of defilement.

original: Dutiyasīlapañcakavaṇṇanā
analyzed: dutiya sīla pañcaka vaṇṇanā
translated: The second set of five training precepts🔽The first of the training precepts is called “abstaining from killing breathing things.”

original: Pāṇātipātādīnanti ādi-saddena adinnādānādīnaṃ aggamaggavajjhakilesapariyosānānaṃ🔽saṅgaho daṭṭhabbo. Pahānādīti ādi-saddena veramaṇiādīnaṃ catunnaṃ. Kesuci potthakesu
analyzed: pāṇa atipāta ādīnam ti ādi saddena adinnādāna ādīnam agga magga vajjha kilesa pariyosānānam  saṅgahaḥ daṭṭhabbo pahāna ādi iti ādi saddena veramaṇi ādīnam catunnam kesuci potthakesu
translated: The word “etc.” in the phrase “killing breathing things, etc.” should be understood to include taking what is not given, etc., down to the defilements that end in the foremost and the supreme.🔽The word “etc.” in the phrase “abandoning, etc.” should be understood to include the four beginning with “abstaining.”🔽In some books it is written “in the sense of abandoning,” but that is a careless omission.

original: “pahānavasenā”ti likhanti, sā pamādalekhā. Pāṇātipātassa pahānaṃ sīlanti hirottappakaruṇālobhādipamukhena
analyzed: pahāna vasena ati likhanti sā pamāda lekhā pāṇātipātassa pahānam hira uttappa karuṇā lobha ādi pamukhena
translated: The abandoning of killing breathing things is virtue in the sense of wearing out ;

original: yena kusalacittuppādena pāṇātipāto pahīyati, taṃ pāṇātipātassa pahānaṃ sīlanaṭṭhena
analyzed: yena kusala cittuppādena pāṇātipāto pahīyati tam pāṇātipātassa pahānam sīlana ṭṭhena
translated: by means of which profitable cognizance the killing of breathing things is abandoned, that is virtue in the sense of wearing out .🔽Likewise, abstaining from killing breathing things is virtue in the sense of abstaining ;

original: sīlaṃ. Tathā pāṇātipātā virati veramaṇī sīlaṃ. Pāṇātipātassa paṭipakkhacetanā cetanā
analyzed: sīlam tathā pāṇātipātā virati veramaṇī sīlam pāṇātipātassa paṭipakkha cetanā cetanā
translated: the volition that is the opposite of killing breathing things is virtue in the sense of volition ;

original: sīlaṃ. Pāṇātipātassa saṃvaraṇaṃ pavesadvārapidhānaṃ saṃvaro sīlaṃ. Pāṇātipātassa
analyzed: sīlam pāṇātipātassa saṃvaraṇam pavesa dvāra pidhānam saṃvaraḥ sīlam pāṇātipātassa
translated: the guarding, the closing of the door, the storing up of the six bases of contact is virtue in the sense of guarding ;

original: avītikkamanaṃ avītikkamo sīlaṃ. Adinnādānassātiādīsupi eseva nayo. Abhijjhādīnaṃ
analyzed: avītikkamanam avītikkamaḥ sīlam adinna ādānassa ati ādīsu pi esa iva nayaḥ abhijjhā ādīnam
translated: the not transgressing of killing breathing things is virtue in the sense of not transgressing . So too in the case of the rest beginning with taking what is not given.

original: pana anabhijjhādivasena pahānaṃ veditabbaṃ. Veramaṇī cetanā taṃsampayuttā saṃvarāvītikkamā tappamukhā dhammā.🔽Evaṃ dasakusalakammapathavasena pahānasīlādīni dassetvā idāni saupāyānaṃ aṭṭhannaṃ
analyzed: pana anabhijjhā ādi vasena pahānam veditabbam veramaṇī cetanā tad sampayuttā saṃvara avītikkamā tad pamukhāḥ dhammāḥ  evam dasa kusala kammapatha vasena pahāna sīla ādīni dassetvā idāni sa upāyānam aṭṭhannam
translated: and the volition of restraint and the states associated with it and the states of the kind of abandoning that occur in the place of the transgression of restraint.

original: samāpattīnaṃ, aṭṭhārasannaṃ mahāvipassanānaṃ, ariyamaggānañca vasena tāni dassetuṃ
analyzed: samāpattīnam mahāvipassanānam ariya maggānam ca vasena tāni dassetuṃ
translated: Having thus shown abandoning virtue, etc., under the ten profitable courses of action, he now showed them under the eight liberations, the eighteen principal insights, and the noble paths,

original: “nekkhammenā”tiādi āraddhaṃ. Tattha nekkhammenāti alobhappadhānena kusalacittuppādena.🔽Kusalā hi dhammā kāmapaṭipakkhā idha “nekkhamma”nti adhippetā. Tenāha “kāmacchandassa
analyzed: nekkhammena ati ādi āraddham tattha nekkhammena ati alobha ppadhānena kusala cittuppādena  kusalāḥ hi dhammāḥ kāma paṭipakkhāḥ idha nekkhamman ti adhippetā tena āha kāmacchandassa
translated: beginning with “With renunciation” . Herein, with renunciation is with non-greed, with the profitable root non-greed, with the arising of profitable consciousness.

original: pahānaṃ sīla”ntiādi. Tattha pahānasīlādīni heṭṭhā vuttanayeneva veditabbāni. Visesameva
analyzed: pahānam sīlam tiādi tattha pahāna sīla ādīni heṭṭhā vutta nayena iva veditabbāni visesam eva
translated: For profitable ideas, which are opposed to sense desire, are intended here by “renunciation.” That is why he said “Abandoning of sense desire is virtue” , and so on. Herein, abandoning virtue, etc., should be understood in the way already stated.🔽We shall only mention the difference.🔽With non-ill will is with loving-kindness.

original: vakkhāma. Abyāpādenāti mettāya. Ālokasaññāyāti vibhūtaṃ katvā manasikaraṇena upaṭṭhitaālokasañjānanena.
analyzed: vakkhāma a byāpādena ati mettāya āloka saññāya ati vibhūtam katvā manasikaraṇena upaṭṭhita āloka sañjānanena
translated: With perception of light is with the perception of light that has been made to appear by giving attention to it.

original: Avikkhepenāti samādhinā. Dhammavavatthānenāti kusalādidhammānaṃ yāthāvanicchayena.
analyzed: avikkhepena ati samādhinā dhamma vavatthānena ati kusala ādi dhammānam yāthāva nicchayena
translated: By non-distraction: by concentration. By defining of ideas: by the seeing of profitable, etc., ideas as they are.

original: Sapaccayanāmarūpavavatthānenātipi vadanti.🔽Evaṃ kāmacchandādinīvaraṇappahānena “abhijjhaṃ loke pahāyā”tiādinā vuttāya paṭhamajjhānādhigamassa
analyzed: vadanti  evam kāmacchanda ādi nīvaraṇa ppahānena abhijjham loke pahāya ati ādinā vuttāya paṭhama jhāna adhigamassa
translated: They also say: “By defining of mentality-materiality with its conditions.”

original: upāyabhūtāya pubbabhāgapaṭipadāya vasena pahānasīlādīni dassetvā idāni saupāyānaṃ
analyzed: upāya bhūtāya pubbabhāga paṭipadāya vasena pahāna sīla ādīni dassetvā idāni sa upāyānam
translated: So after showing the virtues of abandoning, etc., by the way of the preliminary-work practice which is the means to the attainment of the first jhana stated in the way beginning “Having abandoned covetousness for the world” ,

original: aṭṭhasamāpattiādīnaṃ vasena dassetuṃ “ñāṇenā”tiādi vuttaṃ. Nāmarūpapariggahakaṅkhāvitaraṇānaṃ
analyzed: aṭṭha samāpatti ādīnam vasena dassetum ñāṇena atiādi vuttam nāma rūpa pariggaha kaṅkhā vitaraṇānam
translated: now in order to show the virtues by the way of the eight attainments, etc., with their means, it was said, “By knowledge” , etc.

original: hi vibandhabhūtassa mohassa dūrīkaraṇena ñātapariññāya ṭhitassa aniccasaññādayo sijjhanti.
analyzed: hi vibandha bhūtassa mohassa dūrīkaraṇena ñāta pariññāya ṭhitassa anicca saññā ādayo sijjhanti
translated: For the perception of impermanence, etc., succeed when a man is established in the full-understanding of what is to be known by the removal of delusion which is an obstruction to the full-understanding of mentality-materiality and to the surmounting of doubt.🔽And so too the happiness called rapture, which is the cause for delighting in the jhana attainments.

original: Tathā jhānasamāpattīsu abhiratinimittena pāmojjena. Tattha anabhiratiyā vinoditāya
analyzed: tathā jhāna samāpattīsu abhirati nimittena pāmojjena tattha an abhiratiyā vinoditāya
translated: Herein, when non-delight is removed,

original: jhānādīnaṃ samadhigamoti samāpattivipassanānaṃ arativinodanaavijjāpadālanādinā upāyoti
analyzed: jhāna ādīnam samadhigamaḥ ti samāpatti vipassanānam arati vinodana avijjā padālana ādinā upāyaḥ ti
translated: the attainment of jhana, etc., is the means to the realization of the jhana, etc., since it is the dispelling of non-delight, the cleaving asunder of ignorance, and so on.

original: vuttaṃ “ñāṇena avijjāya, pāmojjena aratiyā”ti. Uppaṭipāṭiniddeso pana nīvaraṇasabhāvāya🔽avijjāya heṭṭhānīvaraṇesupi saṅgahadassanatthanti daṭṭhabbaṃ.🔽“Paṭhamena jhānena nīvaraṇāna”ntiādīsu kathaṃ jhānānaṃ sīlabhāvo, kathaṃ vā tattha🔽viratiyā sambhavo. Suvisuddhakāyakammādikassa hi cittasamādānavasena imāni jhānāni🔽pavattanti, na parittakusalāni viya kāyakammādivisodhanavasena, nāpi maggaphaladhammā
analyzed: vuttam ñāṇena avijjāya pāmojjena aratiyā ti uppaṭi pāṭi niddesaḥ pana nīvaraṇa sabhāvāya  avijjāya heṭṭhā nīvaraṇesu pi saṅgaha dassana ttham ti daṭṭhabbam  paṭhamena jhānena nīvaraṇa ananti ādīsu katham jhānānam sīla bhāvo katham vā tattha  viratiyā sambhavaḥ su visuddha kāya kamma ādikassa hi citta samādāna vasena imāni jhānāni  pavattanti na paritta kusalāni viya kāya kamma ādi visodhana vasena na api magga phala dhammā
translated: “By knowledge, by ignorance; by gladness, by grief” . But the explanation of the order should be understood as given in the Paṭṭhāna.

original: viya duccaritadurājīvasamucchedapaṭippassambhanavasenāti? Saccametaṃ. Mahaggatadhammesu🔽nippariyāyena natthi sīlanaṭṭho, kuto viramaṇaṭṭho. Pariyāyena panetaṃ vuttanti daṭṭhabbaṃ.
analyzed: viya duccarita durājīva samuccheda paṭippassambhana vasena ati saccam etam mahaggata dhammesu  nippariyāyena na atthi sīlana ṭṭho kutas viramaṇa ṭṭho pariyāyena pana etam vuttanti daṭṭhabbaṃ
translated: “By the first jhāna, by the hindrances” , etc.: how is there virtue in the jhānas, or how is there non-restraint in them? For these jhānas occur by the mind’s being well steadied, not by the steadying of bodily and verbal action as in the case of the minor forms of virtue. Nor do they occur by the cutting off and tranquilizing of misconduct of body, speech and mind as in the case of the path and fruition dhammas.

original: Ko pana so pariyāyo? Yadaggena mahaggatā kusaladhammā paṭipakkhe pajahanti, tadaggena
analyzed: kaḥ pana saḥ pariyāyaḥ yad aggena mahaggatāḥ kusala dhammāḥ paṭipakkhe pajahanti tad aggena
translated: So how can there be virtue in them? It is true that there is no virtue in the exalted states in the ultimate sense, so how should there be non-restraint? But it can be so called figuratively.🔽And in what way? In the way beginning, “Inasmuch as the profitable states called exalted states abandon and surmount the unprofitable states called hindrances” .

original: tato oratā. Te ca yathā cittaṃ nārohanti, evaṃ saṃvutā nāma honti. Pariyuṭṭhānasaṅkhāto
analyzed: tatas oratā te ca yathā cittam na ārohanti evam saṃvutāḥ nāma honti pariyuṭṭhāna saṅkhātaḥ
translated: and then the chest. And they are called “restrained” in that they do not ascend the mind in that way.🔽They are called “not to be transgressed” since there is no transgression of them by way of the mind-door in the mode of adverting, etc.,

original: manodvāre vītikkamo natthi etesūti avītikkamāti ca vuccanti, cetanā pana taṃsampayuttāti.
analyzed: manaḥ dvāre vītikkamaḥ natthi etesu iti avītikkamā ati ca vuccanti cetanā pana tad sampayuttā ti
translated: but the volition is associated with them.

original: Soyamattho parato āgamissati. Evañca katvā vitakkādipahānavacanampi samatthitaṃ hoti.
analyzed: saḥ yam atthaḥ paratas āgamissati evam ca katvā vitakka ādi pahāna vacanam pi samatthitam hoti
translated: This meaning will come up later. And it is only thus that the words “abandoning applied thoughts … and sustained thoughts” can be justified.🔽For it is not proper to say that virtue is the abandoning of profitable states in the absolute sense,

original: Na hi nippariyāyato sīlaṃ kusaladhammānaṃ pahāyakaṃ yujjati, na cettha akusalavitakkādayo🔽adhippetā. Kiñcāpi paṭhamajjhānūpacāreyeva dukkhassa, catutthajjhānūpacāre ca sukhassa🔽pahānaṃ hoti, atisayapahānaṃ pana sandhāya vuttaṃ “catutthena jhānena sukhadukkhānaṃ
analyzed: na hi nippariyāyataḥ sīlam kusala dhammānam pahāyakam yujjati na ca ittha akusala vitakka ādayaḥ  adhippetā kiñcā api paṭhama jhānu upacāreyeva dukkhassa catuttha jhānu upacāre ca sukhassa  pahānam hoti atisaya pahānam pana sandhāya vuttam catutthena jhānena sukha dukkhānam
translated: and here it is not unprofitable applied thoughts, etc., that are intended.🔽And although there is abandoning of pain in the neighbourhood of the first jhāna and of pleasure in the neighbourhood of the fourth,🔽it is the outstanding abandoning that is meant when it is said that “with the attainment of the fourth jhāna there is an abandoning of pleasure and pain” .

original: pahāna”nti. “Ākāsānañcāyatanasamāpattiyā”tiādīsu yaṃ vattabbaṃ, taṃ āruppakathāyaṃ āgamissati.
analyzed: pahānam ti ākāsa anañcāyatana samāpattiyā ati ādīsu yat vattabbam tat āruppa kathāyam āgamissati
translated: As to the words “with the attainment of the base consisting of boundless space” and so on, what should be said has already been said in the Description of the Formless States .

original: Aniccassa, aniccanti vā anupassanā aniccānupassanā. Tebhūmikadhammānaṃ aniccataṃ🔽gahetvā pavattāya vipassanāyetaṃ nāmaṃ. Niccasaññāyāti “saṅkhatadhammā niccā sassatā”ti
analyzed: aniccassa aniccanti vā anupassanā anicca anupassanā tebhūmika dhammānam anicca taṃ  gahetvā pavattāya vipassanāya itam nāmam nicca saññāya ati saṅkhata dhammā niccā sassatā ati
translated: Or the contemplation of what is impermanent as impermanent is the contemplation of impermanence. This is a name for insight that occurs by way of apprehending the impermanence of states in the three planes.🔽As to the perception of permanence: the perception that occurs thus, “Compounded things are permanent, everlasting,”

original: evaṃ pavattāya micchāsaññāya, saññāggahaṇeneva diṭṭhicittānampi gahaṇaṃ daṭṭhabbaṃ.
analyzed: evam pavattāya micchāsaññāya saññā ggahaṇena iva diṭṭhi cittānam pi gahaṇam daṭṭhabbaṃ
translated: is a wrong perception. The words “perception of permanence” should be understood to include the view and the thought associated with that perception.🔽The same method of explanation applies to the rest of the text.

original: Esa nayo ito parāsupi. Nibbidānupassanāyāti saṅkhāresu nibbindanākārena pavattāya
analyzed: esa nayaḥ itas parāsu pi nibbida anupassanāya ati saṅkhāresu nibbindana ākārena pavattāya
translated: As to the contemplation of dispassion: the contemplation that occurs by way of dispassion towards formations.🔽As to delight: as to craving accompanied by happiness.

original: anupassanāya. Nandiyāti sappītikataṇhāya. Virāgānupassanāyāti virajjanākārena pavattāya
analyzed: anupassanāya nandiyā ati sappītika taṇhāya virāga anupassanāya ati virajjana ākārena pavattāya
translated: As to the contemplation of fading away: the contemplation that occurs by way of fading away.🔽As to lust: as to lust for formations.

original: anupassanāya. Rāgassāti saṅkhāresu rāgassa. Nirodhānupassanāyāti saṅkhārānaṃ nirodhassa
analyzed: anupassanāya rāgassa ati saṅkhāresu rāgassa nirodha anupassanāya ati saṅkhārānam nirodhassa
translated: As to the contemplation of cessation: the contemplation of the cessation of formations.

original: anupassanāya. Yathā vā saṅkhārā nirujjhantiyeva, āyatiṃ punabbhavavasena na uppajjanti,
analyzed: anupassanāya yathā vā saṅkhārāḥ nirujjhantiyā iva āyatim punabbhava vasena na uppajjanti
translated: Or alternatively, the contemplation that occurs thus, “Formations cease, they do not arise again in the future,”

original: evaṃ anupassanā nirodhānupassanā. Tenevāha “nirodhānupassanāya nirodheti no samudetī”ti.
analyzed: evam anupassanā nirodha anupassanā tena iva āha nirodha anupassanāya nirodheti no samudeti iti
translated: is the contemplation of cessation. Hence it is said, “He abandons by means of the contemplation of cessation, not by means of the contemplation of uprising” .

original: Muñcitukāmatāya hi ayaṃ balappattā. Saṅkhārānaṃ paṭinissajjanākārena pavattā anupassanā
analyzed: muñcitu kāma tāya hi ayam bala ppattā saṅkhārānam paṭinissajjana ākārena pavattā anupassanā
translated: Contemplation that occurs in the mode of relinquishing formations is🔽relinquishment-contemplation. For this is the one that stands by way of reflection.

original: paṭinissaggānupassanā. Paṭisaṅkhā santiṭṭhanā hi ayaṃ. Ādānassāti niccādivasena gahaṇassa.
analyzed: paṭinissagga anupassanā paṭisaṅkhā santiṭṭhanā hi ayam ādānassa ati nicca ādi vasena gahaṇassa
translated: As clinging is to the taking of them as permanent, etc.,

original: Santatisamūhakiccārammaṇavasena ekattagahaṇaṃ ghanasaññā, tassā ghanasaññāya. Āyūhanassāti
analyzed: santati samūha kicca ārammaṇa vasena ekatta gahaṇam ghana saññā tassā ghana saññāya āyūhanassa ati
translated: The perception of compactness is the taking of formations as one thing by continuity, mass, function, and object. As to the accumulation is

original: abhisaṅkharaṇassa. Saṅkhārānaṃ avatthādivisesāpatti vipariṇāmo. Dhuvasaññāyāti thirabhāvagahaṇassa.
analyzed: abhisaṅkharaṇassa saṅkhārānaṃ avattha ādi visesa āpatti vipariṇāmaḥ dhuva saññāya ati thira bhāva gahaṇassa
translated: to the act of accumulating. The alteration of formations is the assumption of different states, etc. As to the perception of permanence is to the taking of them as stable.

original: Nimittassāti samūhādighanavasena sakiccaparicchedatāya ca saṅkhārānaṃ saviggahatāya.
analyzed: nimittassa ati samūha ādi ghana vasena sa kicca pariccheda tāya ca saṅkhārāṇam sa viggaha tāya
translated: As to the sign is to the formations’ individual essences as delimited by their functions, etc., and as not dissociated from the mass, etc., and compactness.

original: Paṇidhiyāti rāgādipaṇidhiyā, taṇhāvasena saṅkhāresu ninnatāyāti attho. Abhinivesassāti
analyzed: paṇidhiyā iti rāga ādi paṇidhiyā taṇhā vasena saṅkhāresu ninna tāya ati atthaḥ abhinivesassa ati
translated: As to the wish is to the formations’ inclination due to craving, which is the wish of lust, etc.; the meaning is, as to their being bent on formations by craving. As to the assumption is

original: attānudiṭṭhiyā. Aniccadukkhādivasena sabbatebhūmakadhammatiraṇā adhipaññādhammavipassanā.
analyzed: attānudiṭṭhiyā anicca dukkha ādi vasena adhipaññā dhamma vipassanā
translated: to the assumption of a self by the view of self. The higher wisdom of insight into states is the piercing of all states in all their modes as impermanent, painful, and not-self.

original: Sārādānābhinivesassāti asāresu sāragahaṇavipallāsassa. Yathābhūtañāṇadassanaṃ thirabhāvapattā
analyzed: sāra ādāna abhinivesassa ati asāresu sāra gahaṇa vipallāsassa yathā bhūta ñāṇa dassanam thira bhāva pattā
translated: “Clinging to rules and observances” is the perversion of clinging to what is unbeneficial as beneficial.🔽The knowledge and vision of things as they really are is the penetration of impermanence, etc., according to some.

original: aniccādianupassanāva. Udayabbayañāṇanti keci. Sappaccayanāmarūpadassananti apare.
analyzed: anicca ādi anupassanā āva udaya bbaya ñāṇanti keci sappaccaya nāma rūpa dassananti apare
translated: According to others, it is the knowledge of rise and fall. According to others, it is the seeing of mentality-materiality with its conditions.

original: “Issarakuttādivasena loko samuppanno”ti abhiniveso sammohābhiniveso. Ucchedasassatābhinivesoti🔽keci. “Ahosiṃ nu kho ahamatītamaddhāna”ntiādinayappavattā saṃsayāpatti sammohābhinivesoti
analyzed: issara kutta ādi vasena loko samuppanno ti abhiniveso sammoha abhiniveso uccheda sassata abhiniveso ti  keci ahosim nu kho aham atītam addhā ananti ādi naya ppavattā saṃsaya āpatti sammoha abhiniveso ti
translated: “Clinging to a doctrine of self” is the adherence to the view that the world and self originated from a deity, etc.🔽According to some, it is the adherence to eternalism and annihilationism.🔽According to others, it is the state of doubt that occurs in the form of “Was I in the past? Did I not exist in the past?”🔽“Clinging to a false view of deliverance” is the clinging to formations as a refuge and a protection.

original: apare. Saṅkhāresu tāṇaleṇabhāvagahaṇaṃ ālayābhiniveso. “Ālayaratā ālayasammuditā”ti
analyzed: apare saṅkhāresu ālaya abhinivesaḥ ālaya ratā ālaya sammuditā ati
translated: “Clinging to a false view of deliverance” is craving, since it is said: “They delight in clinging, rejoice in clinging” .

original: vacanato ālayo taṇhā. Sā eva cakkhādīsu, rūpādīsu ca abhinivisanavasena pavattiyā
analyzed: vacanataḥ ālayaḥ taṇhā sā eva cakkhu ādīsu rūpa ādīsu ca abhinivisana vasena pavattiyā
translated: According to others, it is the occurrence of craving in the form of adherence to the eye, etc., and visible objects, etc.

original: ālayābhinivesoti apare. “Evaṃ ṭhitā te saṅkhārā paṭinissajjīyantī”ti pavattaṃ ñāṇaṃ
analyzed: ālaya abhinivesaḥ ti apare evam ṭhitā te saṅkhārā paṭinissajjīyanti iti pavattam ñāṇam
translated: “The knowledge that occurs thus: ‘These formations, thus existing, are relinquished’ ”

original: paṭisaṅkhānupassanā. Appaṭisaṅkhā paṭisaṅkhāya paṭipakkhabhūtā mohappadhānā akusaladhammā.🔽Vaṭṭato vigatattā vivaṭṭaṃ nibbānaṃ, tattha ninnabhāvasaṅkhātena anupassanena pavatti
analyzed: paṭisaṅkhā anupassanā appaṭisaṅkhā paṭisaṅkhāya paṭipakkha bhūtā moha ppadhānāḥ akusala dhammā  vaṭṭataḥ vigata ttā vivaṭṭam nibbānam tattha ninna bhāva saṅkhātena anupassanena pavatti
translated: Contemplation as a state of being is the contemplation of the state of being of the path. Contemplation as a state of non-being is the contemplation of the state of non-being of the defilements abandoned by the path.🔽The escape is Nibbāna, which is the escape from the round of rebirths. Contemplation as an escape is the contemplation of Nibbāna as a state of being.🔽Contemplation as a state of being is the contemplation of the state of being of the path. Contemplation as a state of non-being is the contemplation of the state of non-being of the defilements abandoned by the path.

original: vivaṭṭānupassanā, saṅkhārupekkhā ceva anulomañāṇañca. Saññogābhiniveso saṃyujjanavasena🔽saṅkhāresu abhinivisanaṃ.🔽Diṭṭhekaṭṭhānanti diṭṭhiyā sahajekaṭṭhānañca pahānekaṭṭhānañca. Oḷārikānanti uparimaggavajjhe
analyzed: vivaṭṭā anupassanā saṅkhāra upekkhā ca iva anuloma ñāṇañca saññoga abhiniveso saṃyujjana vasena  saṅkhāresu  diṭṭhekaṭṭhānanti diṭṭhiyā sahajā ika ṭṭhānañca pahāneka ṭṭhānañca oḷārikānam ti upari magga vajjhe
translated: The escape is Nibbāna, which is the escape from the round of rebirths. Contemplation as an escape is the contemplation of Nibbāna as a state of being.🔽Contemplation as a state of being is the contemplation of the state of being of the path. Contemplation as a state of non-being is the contemplation of the state of non-being of the defilements abandoned by the path.🔽The escape is Nibbāna, which is the escape from the round of rebirths. Contemplation as an escape is the contemplation of Nibbāna as a state of being.

original: kilese upādāya vuttaṃ. Aññathā dassanena pahātabbāpi dutiyamaggavajjhehi oḷārikā.🔽Aṇusahagatānanti aṇubhūtānaṃ, idaṃ heṭṭhimamaggavajjhe upādāya vuttaṃ. Sabbakilesānanti
analyzed: kilese upādāya vuttam aññathā dassanena pahātabbā api dutiya magga vajjhehi oḷārikā  aṇu sahagatānam ti aṇu bhūtānam idam heṭṭhima magga vajjhe upādāya vuttam sabba kilesānam ti
translated: Contemplation as a state of being is the contemplation of the state of being of the path. Contemplation as a state of non-being is the contemplation of the state of non-being of the defilements abandoned by the path.🔽The escape is Nibbāna, which is the escape from the round of rebirths. Contemplation as an escape is the contemplation of Nibbāna as a state of being.🔽Contemplation as a state of being is the contemplation of the state of being of the path. Contemplation as a state of non-being is the contemplation of the state of non-being of the defilements abandoned by the path.🔽The escape is Nibbāna, which is the escape from the round of rebirths. Contemplation as an escape is the contemplation of Nibbāna as a state of being.

original: avasiṭṭhasabbakilesānaṃ. Na hi paṭhamamaggādīhi pahīnā kilesā puna pahīyanti.
analyzed: avasiṭṭha sabba kilesānam na hi paṭhama magga ādīhi pahīnā kilesā puna pahīyanti
translated: Contemplation as a state of being is the contemplation of the state of being of the path. Contemplation as a state of non-being is the contemplation of the state of non-being of the defilements abandoned by the path.🔽The escape is Nibbāna, which is the escape from the round of rebir

original: “Cittassa avippaṭisārāya saṃvattantī”tiādīsu saṃvaro avippaṭisāratthāya. “Avippaṭisāratthāni🔽kho, ānanda, kusalāni sīlānī”ti vacanato cetaso avippaṭisāratthāya bhavanti. Avippaṭisāro
analyzed: cittassa a vippaṭisārāya saṃvattanti itiādīsu saṃvaraḥ a vippaṭisāra tthāya a vippaṭisāra tthāni  kho ānanda kusalāni sīlāni iti vacanato cetasaḥ a vippaṭisāra tthāya bhavanti a vippaṭisāro
translated: In the passage beginning, “They lead to non-remorse of mind” , restraint is for the purpose of non-remorse. For it is said: “Non-remorse, Ananda, is the profitable state of consciousness” . So they are for the purpose of non-remorse of mind. Non-remorse

original: pāmojjatthāya. “Yoniso manasi karoto pāmojjaṃ jāyatī”ti vacanato pāmojjāya saṃvattanti.
analyzed: pāmojja atthāya yonisaḥ manasi karotaḥ pāmojjam jāyati iti vacanataḥ pāmojjāya saṃvattanti
translated: is for the purpose of gladness. For it is said: “Gladness arises in one who is without remorse” . So they lead to gladness.

original: Pāmojjaṃ pītiyā. “Pamuditassa pīti jāyatī”ti vacanato pītiyā saṃvattanti. Pīti passaddhatthāya.🔽“Pītimanassa kāyo passambhatī”ti vacanato passaddhiyā saṃvattanti. Passaddhi sukhatthāya.🔽“Passaddhakāyo sukhaṃ vedetī”ti vacanato somanassāya saṃvattantīti. “Sukhatthāya
analyzed: pāmojjam pītiyā pamuditassa pīti jāyati iti vacanataḥ pītiyā saṃvattanti pīti passaddha tthāya  pīti manassa kāyaḥ passambhati iti vacanataḥ passaddhiyā saṃvattanti passaddhi sukha atthāya  passaddha kāyaḥ sukham vedeti iti vacanataḥ somanassāya saṃvattanti iti sukha atthāya
translated: Gladness is for the purpose of happiness. For it is said: “In one who is glad, happiness arises” . So they lead to happiness.🔽Happiness is for the purpose of tranquillity. For it is said: “When the mind is happy the body becomes tranquil” . So they lead to tranquillity. Tranquillity is for the purpose of bliss.🔽For it is said: “When the body is tranquil one feels bliss” . So they lead to bliss. “For the purpose of bliss” is said in the text. But here bliss is the joy .

original: sukhaṃ vedetī”ti cettha somanassaṃ “sukha”nti vuttaṃ. Āsevanāyāti samādhissa āsevanāya.
analyzed: sukham vedeti iti ca ittha somanassam sukham ti vuttam āsevanāya ati samādhissa āsevanāya
translated: “He feels bliss with the body” . “For the purpose of concentration” is for the purpose of the development of concentration.

original: Nirāmise hi sukhe siddhe “sukhino cittaṃ samādhiyatī”ti vacanato samādhi siddhoyeva
analyzed: nirāmise hi sukhe siddhe sukhinaḥ cittam samādhiyati iti vacanataḥ
translated: For when the happiness in the immaterial sphere is accomplished, concentration is accomplished too, since it is said, “When he is happy, a bhikkhu’s mind becomes concentrated” .

original: hoti, tasmā samādhissa āsevanāya paguṇabalavabhāvāya saṃvattantīti attho. Bhāvanāyāti
analyzed: hoti tasmā samādhissa āsevanāya paguṇa balava bhāvāya saṃvattanti iti atthaḥ bhāvanāya ati
translated: So the meaning is that they lead to the development of concentration, to its being strengthened by repetition.🔽By development :🔽by the increase of that same concentration.

original: tasseva samādhissa vaḍḍhiyā. Bahulīkammāyāti punappunaṃ kiriyāya. Alaṅkārāyāti tasseva
analyzed: tassa iva samādhissa vaḍḍhiyā bahulīkammāya ati punappunam kiriyāya alaṅkārāya ati tassa iva
translated: By making much of : by making it arise again and again.

original: samādhissa pasādhanabhūtasaddhindriyādinipphattiyā alaṅkārāya saṃvattanti. Parikkhārāyāti
analyzed: samādhissa pasādhana bhūta saddhi indriya ādi nipphattiyā alaṅkārāya saṃvattanti parikkhārāya ati
translated: By adorning : by producing the faith faculty, etc., which are the adornment of that same concentration.

original: avippaṭisārādikassa samādhisambhārassa siddhiyā tasseva samādhissa parikkhārāya saṃvattanti.🔽Sambhārattho hi idha parikkhāra-saddo. “Ye ca kho ime pabbajitena jīvitaparikkhārā
analyzed: a vippaṭisāra ādikassa samādhi sambhārassa siddhiyā tassa iva samādhissa parikkhārāya saṃvattanti  sambhāra atthaḥ hi idha parikkhāra saddaḥ ye ca kho ime pabbajitena jīvita parikkhārā
translated: By perfecting : by perfecting the requisites of concentration such as non-remorse, etc., they lead to the perfecting of that same concentration.🔽For the word “requisite” here has the meaning of “equipment.”

original: samudānetabbā”tiādīsu viya sambhāroti ca paccayo veditabbo. Kāmañcāyaṃ parikkhāra-saddo
analyzed: samudānetabba ati ādīsu viya sambhāraḥ ti ca paccayaḥ veditabbaḥ kāmam ca ayam parikkhāra saddo
translated: And the word “requisite” should be understood as a condition in the sense of “that by which something is accomplished” , as in the passage, “The requisites of life that should be sought by one gone forth” .🔽And in such passages as “The chariot is adorned with virtue” the word “requisite” has the meaning of “ornament.”

original: “ratho sīlaparikkhāro”tiādīsu alaṅkārattho. “Sattahi nagaraparikkhārehi suparikkhattaṃ
analyzed: ratho sīla parikkhāraḥ ti ādīsu alaṅkāra atthaḥ sattahi nagara parikkhārehi su parikkhattam
translated: “The city is well supplied with the seven requisites of a city” .

original: hotī”tiādīsu parivārattho vutto. Idha pana alaṅkāraparivārānaṃ visuṃ gahitattā “sambhārattho”ti🔽vuttaṃ. Parivārāyāti mūlakāraṇabhāveneva samādhissa parivārabhūtasativīriyādidhammavisesasādhanena🔽parivārasampattiyā saṃvattanti. Pāripūriyāti vasībhāvasampāpanena, vipassanāya padaṭṭhānabhāvāpādanena
analyzed: hoti itiādīsu parivāra atthaḥ vuttaḥ idha pana alaṅkāra parivārānam visum gahita ttā sambhāra atthaḥ ti  vuttam parivārāya ati mūla kāraṇa bhāvena iva samādhissa parivāra bhūta sati vīriya ādi dhamma visesa sādhanena  parivāra sampattiyā saṃvattanti pāripūriyā ati vasībhāva sampāpanena vipassanāya padaṭṭhāna bhāva āpādanena
translated: In such passages as “The four foundations of mindfulness are the supreme field of merit” , the meaning of “surrounding” is stated. But here, since the adornments and the surrounding factors are taken separately, the meaning of “equipment” is stated.🔽“They lead to the equipment of surrounding factors”: they lead to the equipment of surrounding factors by the accomplishment of the special qualities of mindfulness, energy, etc., which are the surrounding factors of concentration by being its root cause.

original: ca paripuṇṇabhāvasādhanato samādhissa pāripūriyā saṃvattanti.🔽Evaṃ suparisuddhasīlamūlakaṃ sabbākāraparipūraṃ samādhiṃ dassetvā idāni “samāhito🔽pajānāti passati, yathābhūtaṃ jānaṃ passaṃ nibbindati, nibbindaṃ virajjati, virāgā
analyzed: ca paripuṇṇa bhāva sādhanataḥ samādhissa pāripūriyā saṃvattanti  evam su parisuddha sīla mūlakam sabba ākāra paripūram samādhim dassetvā idāni samāhitaḥ  pajānāti passati yathābhūtam jānam passam nibbindati nibbindam virajjati virāgā
translated: “They lead to the fulfilment of concentration”: they lead to the fulfilment of concentration by the accomplishment of the fulfilment of concentration through the attainment of mastery and through the establishment of concentration as the basis for insight.

original: vimuccatī”ti vacanato sīlamūlakāni samādhipadaṭṭhānāni payojanāni dassetuṃ “ekantanibbidāyā”tiādi
analyzed: vimuccati iti vacanato sīla mūlakāni samādhi padaṭṭhānāni payojanāni dassetum ekanta nibbidāya atiādi
translated: Having thus shown concentration with its roots in virtue, and with all its aspects fulfilled, he now said “the state of dispassion” in order to show the root, the basis, and the purpose of concentration, in accordance with the passage: “One who is concentrated knows and sees correctly. Knowing and seeing correctly, he becomes dispassionate. Through dispassion his mind is liberated. Through liberation comes the knowledge and vision of liberation” .🔽“The state of dispassion” is the root of concentration.

original: vuttaṃ. Nibbidāya hi dassitāya tassā padaṭṭhānabhūtaṃ yathābhūtañāṇadassanaṃ dassitameva🔽hoti, tasmiṃ asati nibbidāya asijjhanato. Nibbidādayo atthato vibhattā eva. Yathābhūtañāṇadassananti
analyzed: vuttam nibbidāya hi dassitāya tassā padaṭṭhāna bhūtam yathā bhūta ñāṇa dassanam dassitam eva  hoti tasmin asati nibbidāya nibbida ādayaḥ atthataḥ vibhattāḥ eva yathā bhūta ñāṇa dassananti
translated: For when dispassion is shown, then the knowledge and vision of things as they really are, which is the footing for it, is shown too,🔽since dispassion is impossible without that. And the meaning of dispassion and so on has already been explained.

original: panettha sappaccayanāmarūpadassanaṃ adhippetaṃ. Evamettha amatamahānibbānapariyosānaṃ
analyzed: pana ittha sappaccaya nāma rūpa dassanam adhippetam evam ettha amata mahānibbāna pariyosānam
translated: The knowledge and vision of things as they really are is the seeing of mentality-materiality with its conditions.

original: sīlassa payojanaṃ dassitanti veditabbaṃ.
analyzed: sīlassa payojanam dassitan ti veditabbam
translated: So it should be understood that the virtue here has the great Nibbāna as its culmination.

original: Idāni pahānādīsu sīlatthaṃ dassetuṃ “ettha cā”tiādi āraddhaṃ. Tattha pajahanaṃ anuppādanirodho
analyzed: idāni pahāna ādīsu sīla attham dassetum ettha ca ati ādi āraddham tattha pajahanam anuppāda nirodho
translated: Now, in order to show the purpose of virtue in the abandoning of the defilements and so on, he began the paragraph with the words “And here” . Herein, abandoning is non-arising and cessation.

original: pahānanti tassa bhāvasādhanataṃ sandhāya “pahānanti koci dhammo nāma natthī”ti vuttaṃ.
analyzed: pahānam ti tassa bhāva sādhanataṃ sandhāya pahānam ti koci dhammo nāma natthi iti vuttam
translated: Abandoning is not a certain existent thing, is what is meant by “There is no such existent thing as abandoning” .🔽But how it is possible for it to be a state of dhamma has been explained already in the Paṭisambhidā .

original: Yathā panassa dhammabhāvo sambhavati, tathā heṭṭhā saṃvaṇṇitameva. Evaṃ hissa sīlabhāvo
analyzed: yathā panassa dhamma bhāvaḥ sambhavati tathā heṭṭhā saṃvaṇṇitam eva evam hissa sīla bhāvaḥ
translated: For in this way the state of virtue is well justified.

original: suṭṭhu yujjati. Taṃ taṃ pahānanti “pāṇātipātassa pahānaṃ, adinnādānassa pahāna”nti
analyzed: suṭṭhu yujjati tam tam pahānanti pāṇa atipātassa pahānam adinnādānassa pahānanti
translated: The abandoning of this and that is the abandoning of killing living beings, the abandoning of taking what is not given, and so on.

original: evaṃ vuttaṃ taṃ taṃ pahānaṃ. Tassa tassa kusaladhammassāti pāṇātipātassa pahānaṃ🔽mettādikusaladhammassa, adinnādānassa pahānaṃ cāgādikusaladhammassāti evaṃ tassa🔽tassa kusaladhammassa. Patiṭṭhānaṭṭhenāti patiṭṭhānabhāvena. Pahānaṃ hi tasmiṃ sati🔽hoti, asati na hoti, tassa “patiṭṭhāna”nti vattabbataṃ labhatīti katvā yasmiṃ santāne🔽pāṇātipātādayo tassa pakampahetavoti tappahānaṃ vikampābhāvakaraṇena ca samādhānaṃ
analyzed: evam vuttam tam tam pahānam tassa tassa kusala dhammassa ati pāṇātipātassa pahānam  mettā ādi kusala dhammassa adinna adānassa pahānam cāga ādi kusala dhammassa ati evam tassa  tassa kusala dhammassa patiṭṭhāna ṭṭhena ati patiṭṭhāna bhāvena pahānam hi tasmin sati  hoti asati na hoti tassa patiṭṭhānan ti vattabba tam labhati iti katvā yasmin santāne  pāṇa atipāta ādayaḥ tassa pakampa hetavaḥ ti tad pahānam vikampā bhāva karaṇena ca samādhānam
translated: This is the abandoning of this or that. Of this or that profitable idea: the abandoning of killing breathing things is the profitable idea of loving-kindness, etc.,🔽and the abandoning of taking what is not given is the profitable idea of giving, and so on. This is the profitable idea of this or that. As a footing: as a footing. For when that is, abandoning is, and when that is not, abandoning is not. So it is as if it were the abandoning’s “ footing” that is meant. In whatever continuity of existence🔽killing breathing things, etc., are a cause of trembling, that abandoning is the steadying of that continuity by making it free from trembling.

original: vuttaṃ. Evaṃ sesapahānesupi vattabbaṃ. Samādhānaṃ saṇṭhapanaṃ, saṃyamanaṃ vā. Itare🔽cattāroti veramaṇiādayo cattāro dhammā na pahānaṃ viya vohāramattanti adhippāyo.🔽Tato tatoti tamhā tamhā pāṇātipātādito. Tassa tassāti pāṇātipātādikassa saṃvaraṇavasena,
analyzed: vuttam evam sesa pahānesu pi vattabbam samādhānam saṇṭhapanam saṃyamanam vā itare 🔽cattāro ti veramaṇi ādayo cattāro dhammā na pahānam viya vohāra mattam ti adhippāyo 🔽tatas tatas iti tamhā tamhā pāṇa atipāta āditaḥ tassa tassa ati pāṇa atipāta ādikassa saṃvaraṇa vasena
translated: This is the abandoning of this or that. Of this or that profitable idea: the abandoning of killing breathing things is the profitable idea of loving-kindness, etc.; the abandoning of taking what is not given is the profitable idea of giving, etc.; thus it is of this or that profitable idea. As a footing: as a footing-state. For when that is, abandoning is, and when that is not, abandoning is not; thus it is as if it were to get the description “a footing” . So in the case of the abandoning of killing breathing things, etc., in a given continuity, it is the cause of the non-shaking of that, and so it is called “ consolidation” since it makes non-shaking. This is how it should be construed in the case of the other abandonings. Consolidation is the fixing or the restraining. The other four, namely, abstinence, etc., are not abandoning, but are merely terms for it, is the intention. From here and there: from killing breathing things, etc. Of this or that: by way of restraint of killing breathing things, etc.

original: tassa tassa vā saṃvarassa vasena. Tadubhayasampayuttacetanāvasenāti veramaṇīhi, saṃvaradhammehi🔽ca sampayuttāya cetanāya vasena. Taṃ taṃ avītikkamantassāti taṃ taṃ pāṇātipātādiṃ
analyzed: tassa tassa vā saṃvarassa vasena tad ubhaya sampayutta cetanā vasena ati veramaṇīhi saṃvara dhammehi  ca sampayuttāya cetanāya vasena tam tam a vītikkamantassa ati tam tam pāṇātipāta ādiṃ
translated: and by the restraint of each one. By the volition associated with both: by the volition associated with the abstentions and the states of restraint.🔽Of one who does not transgress that and that: of the person or of the aggregate of states of one who does not transgress that and that killing-breathing-things, etc.

original: avītikkamantassa puggalassa, dhammasamūhassa vā vasena cetaso pavattisabbhāvaṃ sandhāya
analyzed: a vītikkamantassa puggalassa dhamma samūhassa vā vasena cetasaḥ pavatti sabbhāvam sandhāya
translated: The meaning of the words is this: “with reference to the state of the occurrence of consciousness by the influence of that and that person or aggregate of states.”

original: vuttā. Tasmā ekakkhaṇepi labbhantīti adhippāyo.
analyzed: vuttā tasmai eka kkhaṇe pi labbhanti iti adhippāyaḥ
translated: Therefore the intention is that they are found even in a single conscious moment.

original: Sīlasaṃkilesavodānavaṇṇanā
analyzed: sīla saṃkilesa vodāna vaṇṇanā
translated: The explanation of the defilement and cleansing of virtue

original: 21. Saṃkilissati tenāti saṃkileso. Ko pana soti āha “khaṇḍādibhāvo sīlassa saṃkileso”ti.
analyzed: saṃkilissati tena ati saṃkileso kaḥ pana saḥ ti āha khaṇḍa ādi bhāvo sīlassa saṃkileso ti
translated: It is defiled by that, thus it is defilement. But what is that? He said: “The virtue of one who is cracked, etc., is defiled.”

original: Vodāyati visujjhati etenāti vodānaṃ, akhaṇḍādibhāvo. Lābhayasādīti ādi-saddena ñātiaṅgajīvitādīnaṃ
analyzed: vodāyati visujjhati etena ati vodānam akhaṇḍa ādi bhāvaḥ lābha yasa ādi iti ādi saddena ñāti aṅga jīvita ādīnam
translated: It is cleansed, purified, by that, thus it is cleansing. The virtue of one who is not cracked, etc., is cleansing. By gain, etc.,: by gain, fame, loss, ill-fame, etc. By relatives, limbs, life, etc., is the meaning.

original: saṅgaho. Sattasu āpattikkhandhesu ādimhi vā ante vā vemajjheti ca idaṃ tesaṃ uddesādipāḷivasena
analyzed: saṅgahaḥ sattasu āpatti kkhandhesu ādimhi vā ante vā vemajjha iti ca idam tesam uddesa ādi pāḷi vasena
translated: The beginning, middle, and end of the seven classes of offence: this is said with reference to the text of the summary, etc.,

original: vuttaṃ. Na hi añño koci āpattikkhandhānaṃ anukkamo atthi. Khaṇḍanti khaṇḍavantaṃ,
analyzed: vuttam na hi aññaḥ koci āpatti khandhānam anukkamaḥ atthi khaṇḍanti khaṇḍavantam
translated: For there is no other sequence of the classes of offenses.🔽They split: they are split, or they are being split.🔽They tear: the same method applies here.

original: khaṇḍitaṃ vā. Chiddanti etthāpi eseva nayo. Pariyante chinnasāṭako viyāti vatthante,
analyzed: khaṇḍitam vā ettha api esā iva nayaḥ pariyante chinna sāṭakaḥ viyāti
translated: Like a cloth at the edge: like a cloth that is torn at the edge,

original: dasante vā chinnavatthaṃ viya.
analyzed: dasante vā chinna vattham viya
translated: or like a cloth that is torn at the end.🔽Thus: in the manner now being described.

original: Evanti idāni vuccamānākārena. Methunasaṃyogavasenāti rāgapariyuṭṭhānena sadisabhāvāpattiyā
analyzed: evam ti idāni vuccamāna ākārena methuna saṃyoga vasena ati rāga pariyuṭṭhānena sadisa bhāva āpattiyā
translated: By means of sexual intercourse: by means of the state of being a couple, by means of the state of being joined together as a couple.

original: mithunānaṃ idanti methunaṃ, nibandhanaṃ. Methunavasena samāyogo methunasaṃyogo. Idha
analyzed: methunam nibandhanam methuna vasena samāyogaḥ methuna saṃyogaḥ
translated: A couple is a pair. Sexual intercourse is the joining together of a couple.🔽But here, by means of sexual intercourse means by means of sexual intercourse. Here means in this world.

original: pana methunasaṃyogo viyāti methunasaṃyogo, tassa vasena. Idhāti imasmiṃ loke. Ekaccoti🔽eko. Samaṇo vā brāhmaṇo vāti pabbajjāmattena samaṇo vā jātimattena brāhmaṇo vā. Dvayaṃdvayasamāpattinti
analyzed: pana methuna saṃyogaḥ viyāti methuna saṃyogaḥ tassa vasena idha ati imasmin loke ekacco ti  ekaḥ samaṇaḥ vā brāhmaṇaḥ vā ati pabbajjā mattena samaṇaḥ vā jāti mattena brāhmaṇaḥ vā dvayaṃdvaya samāpattin ti
translated: Someone: a certain person.🔽A monk or a brahman: a monk by virtue of his going forth, or a brahman by virtue of his birth.🔽By means of a coupling: by means of a coupling with two at a time. The meaning is: by means of sexual intercourse with two at a time.

original: dvīhi dvīhi samāpajjitabbaṃ, methunanti attho. Na heva kho samāpajjatīti sambandho.
analyzed: dvīhi dvīhi samāpajjitabbam methunanti atthaḥ na ha iva kho samāpajjati iti sambandhaḥ
translated: He does not even couple: the connection is with the above.

original: Ucchādanaṃ ubbattanaṃ. Sambāhanaṃ parimaddanaṃ. Sādiyatīti adhivāseti. Tadassādetīti🔽taṃ ucchādanādiṃ abhiramati. Nikāmetīti icchati. Vittinti tuṭṭhiṃ. Idampi khoti ettha
analyzed: ucchādanam ubbattanam sambāhanam parimaddanam sādiyati iti adhivāseti tat assādeti iti  tam ucchādana ādim abhiramati nikāmeti iti icchati tuṭṭhim idam pi kho ti ettha
translated: To wish for is to long for.🔽The satisfaction is the satisfaction of the lust.🔽Herein, as to the words “This too is a kind of … ” :🔽the “this” is what has just been stated, namely, consenting to rubbing in, etc., which is spoken of as one by making it into a unity by way of the state of being rubbed in, etc.

original: idanti yathāvuttaṃ sādiyanādiṃ khaṇḍabhāvādivasena ekaṃ katvā vuttaṃ. Pi-saddo vakkhamānaṃ
analyzed: idam ti yathāvuttam sādi yan ādim khaṇḍa bhāva ādi vasena ekam katvā vuttam pi saddaḥ vakkhamānam
translated: The “too” is a particle in the sense of including.🔽The word “kho” is a particle in the sense of limitation.

original: upādāya samuccayattho. Kho-saddo avadhāraṇattho. Idaṃ vuttaṃ hoti – yadetaṃ brahmacārīpaṭiññassa
analyzed: upādāya samuccaya tthaḥ kho saddo avadhāraṇa atthaḥ idam vuttam hoti yat etam brahmacārī paṭiññassa
translated: The meaning is this: although there is no actual sexual intercourse in the case of one who professes to be a celibate,

original: asatipi dvayaṃdvayasamāpattiyaṃ mātugāmassa ucchādananhāpanasambāhanasādiyanādi,
analyzed: asati pi mātugāmassa ucchādana nhāpana sambāhana sādiya nādi
translated: yet the consenting to the rubbing in, bathing, massaging, and consenting to the touch of a woman,

original: idampi ekaṃsena tassa brahmacariyassa khaṇḍādibhāvāpādanato khaṇḍampi chiddampi sabalampi
analyzed: idam pi ekaṃsena tassa brahmacariyassa khaṇḍa ādi bhāva āpādanato khaṇḍam pi chiddam pi sabalam pi
translated: is a kind of breaking, a kind of crack, a kind of crevice, a kind of flaw in that celibate life,🔽in the sense that it leads to the breaking, etc., of it.

original: kammāsampīti. Evaṃ pana khaṇḍādibhāvāpattiyā so aparisuddhaṃ brahmacariyaṃ carati,
analyzed: evam pana khaṇḍa ādi bhāva āpattiyā saḥ aparisuddham brahmacariyam carati
translated: But in this way he lives an impure life,🔽not a pure life, and he is bound by the bond of sexual intercourse, not un-bound.

original: na parisuddhaṃ, saṃyutto methunasaṃyogena, na visaṃyutto. Tato cassa na jātiādīhi
analyzed: na parisuddham saṃyuttaḥ methuna saṃyogena na visaṃyuttaḥ tatas ca ssa na jāti ādīhi
translated: And because of that he is not freed from birth, etc.

original: parimuttīti dassento “ayaṃ vuccatī”tiādimāha.
analyzed: parimutti iti dassentaḥ ayam vuccati itiādim āha
translated: Pointing out the escape from them, he said, “This is called the escape” .

original: Sañjagghatīti kilesavasena mahāhasitaṃ hasati. Saṃkīḷatīti kāyasaṃsaggavasena kīḷati.🔽Saṃkelāyatīti sabbaso mātugāmaṃ kelāyanto viharati. Cakkhunāti attano cakkhunā. Cakkhunti🔽mātugāmassa cakkhuṃ. Upanijjhāyatīti upecca nijjhāyati oloketi. Tirokuṭṭāti kuṭṭassa
analyzed: sañjagghati iti kilesa vasena mahāhasitam hasati saṃkīḷati iti kāya saṃsagga vasena kīḷati  saṃkelāyati iti sabbasas mātugāmam kelāyantaḥ viharati cakkhunā ati attanaḥ cakkhunā cakkhunti  mātugāmassa cakkhum upanijjhāyati iti upecca nijjhāyati oloketi kuṭṭassa
translated: He laughs loudly with defilements. He plays with bodily contact.🔽He dallies with a woman entirely. With his own eye: with his own eye.🔽The woman’s eye: with the woman’s eye. He looks on: he looks on, looking over. Beyond a wall: beyond a wall.

original: parato. Tathā tiropākārā. Mattikāmayā bhitti kuṭṭaṃ, iṭṭhakāmayā pākāroti vadanti.
analyzed: paratas tathā tiropākārā matti kāmayā bhitti kuṭṭam iṭṭhakāmayā vadanti
translated: Beyond a fence: beyond a fence. They say that a wall made of clay is a wall and a fence made of bricks is a fence.

original: Yā kāci vā bhitti porisato diyaḍḍharatanuccappamāṇā kuṭṭaṃ, kuṭṭato adhiko pākāro.
analyzed: yā kāci vā bhitti porisataḥ kuṭṭam kuṭṭataḥ adhikaḥ pākāraḥ
translated: Or any wall that is two and a half cubits high is a wall, and one higher than that is a fence.

original: Assāti brahmacārīpaṭiññassa. Pubbeti vatasamādānato pubbe. Kāmaguṇehīti kāmakoṭṭhāsehi.
analyzed: assa ati brahmacārī paṭiññassa pubbe iti vata samādānataḥ pubbe kāma guṇehi iti kāma koṭṭhāsehi
translated: A horse: one who pretends to be celibate. In the past: before the undertaking of the training rules. With the five cords of sensual pleasure: with the five parts of sensual pleasure.

original: Samappitanti suṭṭhu appitaṃ sahitaṃ. Samaṅgībhūtanti samannāgataṃ. Paricārayamānanti
analyzed: samappitanti suṭṭhu appitam sahitam samaṅgībhūtanti samannāgatam paricārayamānanti
translated: Well sprinkled: well sprinkled, well mixed. Endowed: possessed. Enjoying: enjoying.

original: kīḷantaṃ, upaṭṭhahiyamānaṃ vā. Paṇidhāyāti patthetvā. Sīlenātiādīsu yamaniyamādisamādānavasena
analyzed: kīḷantam upaṭṭhahiyamānam vā paṇidhāya ati patthetvā sīlena ati ādīsu yama niyama ādi samādāna vasena
translated: and he was playing or being attended to. He made a wish: he made a wish for it. By means of virtue: virtue is the undertaking of the training precepts consisting in restraint and endurance.

original: sīlaṃ. Avītikkamavasena vataṃ. Ubhayampi sīlaṃ. Dukkaracariyavasena pavattitaṃ vataṃ.
analyzed: sīlam avītikkama vasena ubhayam pi sīlam dukkara cariya vasena pavattitam
translated: It is also virtue in the sense of non-transgression. Austerity is the practice of the difficult things.

original: Taṃtaṃakiccasammatato vā nivattilakkhaṇaṃ sīlaṃ. Taṃtaṃsamādānavato vesabhojanakiccakaraṇādivisesapaṭipatti
analyzed: taṃtaṃ a kicca sammatataḥ vā nivatti lakkhaṇam sīlam taṃtaṃ samādānavataḥ vesa bhojana kicca karaṇa ādi visesa paṭipatti
translated: Or virtue is the characteristic of refraining from what is disapproved by oneself. Austerity is the special practice of one who has undertaken the training precepts, such as the avoidance of eating at the wrong time, etc.

original: vataṃ. Sabbathāpi dukkaracariyā tapo. Methunavirati brahmacariyaṃ.
analyzed: vatam sabbathā api dukkara cariyā tapaḥ methuna virati brahmacariyam
translated: Austerity is the practice of the difficult things in every way. The holy life is the avoidance of sexual intercourse.

original: Sabbasoti anavasesato, sabbesaṃ vā. Abhedenāti avītikkamena. Aparāya ca pāpadhammānaṃ
analyzed: sabbaso ti anavasesato sabbesam vā abhedena ati avītikkamena aparāya ca pāpa dhammānam
translated: All: without exception, or all. By means of non-transgression: by means of non-transgression of the training precepts. And by means of the inclusion of the non-arising of other bad qualities

original: anuppattiyā, guṇānaṃ uppattiyā saṅgahitoti yojanā. Tattha kujjhanalakkhaṇo kodho.🔽Upanandhanalakkhaṇo upanāho. Paresaṃ guṇamakkhanalakkhaṇo makkho. Yugaggāhalakkhaṇo
analyzed: anuppattiyāḥ guṇānaṃ uppattiyā saṅgahitaḥ iti yojanā tattha kujjhana lakkhaṇaḥ kodho  upanandhana lakkhaṇaḥ upanāhaḥ paresam guṇa makkhana lakkhaṇaḥ makkhaḥ yuga ggāha lakkhaṇaḥ
translated: and the arising of good qualities. Herein, anger has the characteristic of annoyance.🔽Spite has the characteristic of holding on. Contempt has the characteristic of despising the good qualities of others.

original: paḷāso. Parasampattiusūyanalakkhaṇā issā. Attasampattinigūhanalakkhaṇaṃ macchariyaṃ.
analyzed: paḷāsaḥ para sampatti usūyana lakkhaṇā issā atta sampatti nigūhana lakkhaṇam macchariyam
translated: Jealousy has the characteristic of envy of the success of others. Stinginess has the characteristic of concealing one’s own success.

original: Santadosapaṭicchādanalakkhaṇā māyā. Asantaguṇasambhāvanalakkhaṇaṃ sāṭheyyaṃ. Cittassa🔽thaddhabhāvalakkhaṇo thambho. Karaṇuttariyalakkhaṇo sārambho. Unnatilakkhaṇo māno.
analyzed: santa dosa paṭicchādana lakkhaṇā māyā asanta guṇa sambhāvana lakkhaṇam sāṭheyyam cittassa  thaddha bhāva lakkhaṇo thambho karaṇa uttariya lakkhaṇo sa ārambhaḥ unnati lakkhaṇaḥ māno
translated: Deceit has the characteristic of concealing one’s own faults. Pretence has the characteristic of misrepresenting one’s own good qualities. Stiffness has the characteristic of rigidity of mind. Insolence has the characteristic of overbearingness. Pride has the characteristic of haughtiness.

original: Abbhunnatilakkhaṇo atimāno. Majjanalakkhaṇo mado. Cittavosaggalakkhaṇo pamādo. Ādi-saddena
analyzed: abbhunnati lakkhaṇaḥ atimānaḥ majjana lakkhaṇaḥ madaḥ citta vosagga lakkhaṇaḥ pamādaḥ ādi saddena
translated: Arrogance has the characteristic of overweening conceit. Intoxication has the characteristic of mental giddiness. Negligence has the characteristic of mental unsteadiness. The word “etc.”

original: lobhamohaviparītamanasikārādīnaṃ saṅgaho.
analyzed: saṅgaho
translated: includes wrong reflection, etc.

original: Idāni “akhaṇḍādibhāvo panā”tiādinā vuttamevatthaṃ pākaṭataraṃ kātuṃ “yāni hī”tiādimāha.
analyzed: idāni akhaṇḍa ādi bhāvaḥ pana iti ādinā pākaṭataram kātum yāni hi iti ādim āha
translated: Now, in order to make clearer the meaning stated in the words “the state of being unbroken, etc.,” he says, “For these, etc.”

original: Tattha anupahatānīti anupaddutāni. Vivaṭṭūpanissayatāya taṇhādāsabyato mocanena bhujissabhāvakaraṇaṃ.🔽Aviññūnaṃ appamāṇattā vuttaṃ “viññūhi pasatthattā”ti. Samādhisaṃvattanaṃ vā etesaṃ
analyzed: tattha anupahatāni iti anupaddutāni vivaṭṭu upanissaya tāya taṇhā dāsabyataḥ mocanena bhujissa bhāva karaṇam  a viññūnam appamāṇa ttā vuttam viññūhi pasattha ttā ti samādhi saṃvattanam vā etesam
translated: Herein, unmutilated means undamaged. The making of oneself a lord by the liberation from being a slave to craving through the condition of being a support for the turning of the wheel .

original: payojanaṃ, samādhisaṃvattane vā niyuttānīti samādhisaṃvattanikāni. Niddānena sassasampatti
analyzed: payojanam samādhi saṃvattane vā niyuttāni iti samādhisaṃvattanikāni niddānena sassa sampatti
translated: Since they are immeasurable to the ignorant, it is said, “because of being praised by the wise.” Or their purpose is the arousing of concentration, or they are devoted to the arousing of concentration, thus they are conducive to concentration . The purpose of the jhānas is the attainment of the fruit of asceticism,

original: viya paṭipakkhavigamena sīlasampadā, sā ca tattha sati dosadassaneti āha “sīlavipattiyā🔽ca ādīnavadassanenā”ti. Nisammakārīnaṃ payojanagarukatāya diṭṭhaguṇeyeva sammāpaṭipattīti
analyzed: viya paṭipakkha vigamena sīla sampadā sā ca tattha sati dosa dassanā iti āha sīla vipattiyā  ca ādīnava dassanena ati payojana garuka tāya diṭṭha guṇā iva sammā paṭipatti iti
translated: and the perfection of virtue is the opposite of that. And that is seen there as a fault. Hence he said, “by seeing the danger in failure in virtue” .🔽Since those who act after due consideration are intent on the purpose, the right practice is only in the visible here and now.

original: vuttaṃ “sīlasampattiyā ca ānisaṃsadassanenā”ti.
analyzed: vuttam sīla sampattiyā ca ānisaṃsa dassanena ati
translated: Hence it was said: “by seeing the benefit in the perfection of virtue” .

original: Tattha sīlavipattiyā ādīnavo sīlasampadāya heṭṭhā dassitaānisaṃsapaṭipakkhato veditabbo,
analyzed: tattha sīla vipattiyāḥ ādīnavaḥ sīla sampadāya heṭṭhā dassita ānisaṃsa paṭipakkhato veditabbo
translated: Herein, the danger in failure in virtue should be understood as the opposite of the benefit in the perfection of virtue shown above .

original: taṃ suviññeyyanti avitthāretvā pakārantarehi dassetuṃ “apicā”ti āraddhaṃ. Tattha
analyzed: tam su viññeyyam ti a vitthāretvā pakāra antarehi dassetum api ca iti āraddham tattha
translated: But that is easy to understand, so instead of expatiating here, he will show it in a separate section later on. Hence he said: “Besides” .

original: yathā sīlasampadā sattānaṃ manuññabhāvakāraṇaṃ, evaṃ sīlavipatti amanuññabhāvakāraṇanti
analyzed: yathā sīla sampadā sattānam manuñña bhāva kāraṇam evam sīla vipatti amanuñña bhāva kāraṇam ti
translated: Herein, just as the perfection of virtue is the cause for beings’ being lovable, so failure in virtue is the cause for their being unlovable.

original: āha “dussīlo…pe… devamanussāna”nti. Ananusāsanīyo jigucchitabbato. Dukkhitoti sañjātadukkho.
analyzed: āha dussī lope deva manussānanti an anusāsanīyaḥ jigucchitabbataḥ dukkhitaḥ ti sañjāta dukkhaḥ
translated: Hence he said: “The unvirtuous man … is not loved by gods and men” . He is not to be advised, because he is to be despised. He is miserable, having generated misery.

original: Vippaṭisārīti “akataṃ vata me kalyāṇa”ntiādinā paccānutāpī. Dubbaṇṇoti guṇavaṇṇena,
analyzed: vippaṭisārī iti akatam vata me kalyāṇam ti ādinā pacca anutāpī dubbaṇṇo ti guṇa vaṇṇena
translated: He has remorse, being one who repents thus: “I have done what is not good” . He is ugly, lacking the beauty of virtue,

original: kāyavaṇṇena ca virahito. Assāti dussīlassa. Samphassitānaṃ dukkho dukkhāvaho samphasso🔽etassāti dukkhasamphasso. Guṇānubhāvābhāvato appaṃ agghatīti appaggho. Anekavassagaṇikagūthakūpo
analyzed: kāya vaṇṇena ca virahitaḥ assa ati dussīlassa samphassitānam dukkhaḥ dukkha āvahaḥ samphasso  etassa ati dukkha samphassaḥ guṇa anubhāva abhāvataḥ appam agghati iti appagghaḥ aneka vassa gaṇika gūthakūpaḥ
translated: and he is devoid of bodily beauty. ‘Assa’ means ‘of the unvirtuous’. ‘Contact’ is painful for those who have contact with him, and he brings pain.🔽‘Dukkha-samphasso’ means ‘having painful contact’. ‘Appaggo’ means ‘of little value’, because of the absence of the power of good qualities. ‘Like a cesspit full of ordure for many years’

original: viyāti anekavassasamūhe sañcitukkārāvāṭo viya. Dubbisodhano sodhetuṃ asakkuṇeyyo.
analyzed: viyā ati aneka vassa samūhe viya dubbisodhano sodhetum a sakkuṇeyyaḥ
translated: means ‘like a pit full of ordure accumulated over many years’. ‘Difficult to purify’ means ‘impossible to purify’.

original: Chavālātaṃ chavaḍāhe santajjanummukkaṃ. Ubhato paribāhiroti sāmaññato, gihibhogato
analyzed: chava alātam chava ḍāhe santajjanummukkam ubhatas sāmaññataḥ gihi bhogato
translated: ‘A skull’ means a skull that has been burnt in a fire. ‘Ubhato paribāhiro’ means ‘excluded from both sides’, excluded from the enjoyments of the household life

original: ca parihīno. Sabbesaṃ verī, sabbe vā verī etassāti sabbaverī, so eva sabbaveriko,
analyzed: ca parihīno sabbesam verī sabbe vā verī etassa ati sabba verī saḥ eva sabba verikaḥ
translated: and from the enjoyments of the monk. ‘Sabbaverī’ means ‘having all as enemies’, or ‘having enemies everywhere’. ‘Sabbaveriko’ is the same.

original: puriso. Saṃvāsaṃ nārahatīti asaṃvāsāraho. Saddhammeti paṭipattisaddhamme, paṭivedhasaddhamme ca.
analyzed: puriso saṃvāsam na ārahati iti a saṃvāsa arahaḥ saddhamme iti paṭipatti saddhamme paṭivedha saddhamme ca
translated: ‘Puriso’ means ‘man’. ‘Nārahatī’ means ‘is not fit’. ‘Saddhamma’ means the true Dhamma of practice and the true Dhamma of penetration.

original: “Aggikkhandhapariyāye vuttadukkhabhāgitāyā”ti saṅkhepena vuttamatthaṃ vitthārato
analyzed: aggi kkhandha pariyāye vutta dukkha bhāgi tāya iti saṅkhepena vuttam attham vitthārato
translated: “In the discourse on the mass of fire, he shares in the suffering that was stated” means that the meaning stated in brief

original: dassetuṃ “dussīlānañhī”tiādi āraddhaṃ. Pañcakāmaguṇaparibhogasukhe, parehi kayiramānavandanamānanādisukhe
analyzed: dassetum āraddham pañca kāma guṇa paribhoga sukhe parehi kayira māna vandana mānana ādi sukhe
translated: “Of the unvirtuous” is stated to show that. In the pleasure of enjoying the five strands of sense pleasure and in the pleasure of being worshipped, honored, etc., by others,

original: ca assādena gadhitacittā pañcakāma…pe… gadhitacittā, tesaṃ. Te yathāvuttasukhassādā
analyzed: ca assādena gadhita cittā pañca kāmape gadhita cittā tesam te yathāvutta sukha ssādā
translated: their minds are infatuated with the five strands of sense pleasure … their minds are infatuated. They,

original: paccayā etassāti tappaccayaṃ. Dukkhanti sambandho.
analyzed: paccayāḥ etassa ti tad paccayam dukkham ti sambandho
translated: having the pleasure stated in the way already described as their condition, is the construction of the terms tappaccayaṃ dukkhaṃ.

original: Passatha noti passatha nu, api passatha. Mahantanti vipulaṃ. Aggikkhandhanti aggisamūhaṃ.
analyzed: passatha naḥ ti passatha nu api passatha mahantanti vipulam aggi kkhandhanti aggi samūham
translated: Passatha = passatha nu, api passatha. Mahantaṃ = extensive. Aggikkhandhaṃ = a mass of fire.

original: Ādittanti padittaṃ. Sampajjalitanti samantato pajjalitaṃ acchivipphuliṅgāni muccantaṃ.
analyzed: ādittanti padittam sampajjalitanti samantataḥ pajjalitam acchi vipphuliṅgāni muccantam
translated: Ādittaṃ = blazing. Sampajjalitaṃ = burning all around, with sparks flying off.

original: Sajotibhūtanti sapabhaṃ samantato uṭṭhitāhi jālāhi ekappabhāsamudayabhūtaṃ. Taṃ kiṃ
analyzed: sajoti bhūtam ti sa pabham samantataḥ uṭṭhitāhi jālāhi eka ppabhā samudaya bhūtam tam kim
translated: Sajotibhūtaṃ = having become a single flame with the flames rising all around. What is that?

original: maññathāti taṃ idāni mayā vuccamānamatthaṃ kiṃ maññathāti anumatigahaṇatthaṃ pucchati.
analyzed: maññatha ati tam idāni mayā vuccamānam attham kim maññatha ati anumati gahaṇa attham pucchati
translated: Taṃ kiṃ maññathāti = taṃ idāni mayā vuccamānamatthaṃ kiṃ maññathāti he asks in order to get their agreement.

original: Āliṅgetvāti upagūhitvā. Upanisīdeyyāti teneva āliṅganena upecca nisīdeyya. Yadatthamettha
analyzed: āliṅgetvā ati upagūhitvā upanisīdeyya iti tena iva āliṅganena upa icca nisīdeyya yadattham ettha
