translated: it is said that “the village itself is the dwelling in a village area.” Any place at all is called a village

original: adinnādānapārājike āgataṃ. Tattha hi “gāmā vā araññā vā”ti anavasesato avahāraṭṭhānapariggahe
analyzed: adinnādāna pārājike āgatam tattha hi gāmā vā araññā vā ti anavasesataḥ avahāra ṭṭhāna pariggahe
translated: in relation to that. “The boundary post” is the ummāra. “That” refers to the stone slab. The characteristic of the forest is given in the Vinaya in the case of the offense entailing expulsion for stealing. For there, in order to show without exception the places where things are taken,

original: tadubhayaṃ asaṅkarato dassetuṃ “ṭhapetvā gāmañcā”tiādi vuttaṃ. Gāmūpacāro hi loke
analyzed: tat ubhayam asaṅkarataḥ dassetum ṭhapetvā gāmañca atiādi vuttam gāmu upacāraḥ hi loke
translated: both of them are shown without confusion by the words “Excepting the village and its precincts.” For in the world, the precincts of a village

original: gāmasaṅkhameva gacchatīti. Nippariyāyato pana gāmavinimuttaṃ ṭhānaṃ araññameva hotīti
analyzed: gāma saṅkham eva gacchati iti nippariyāyataḥ pana gāma vinimuttam ṭhānam araññam eva hoti iti
translated: are reckoned as the village itself. But in the ultimate sense, a place that is free from the village is the forest itself.

original: abhidhamme gāmā “nikkhamitvā bahi indakhīlā, sabbametaṃ arañña”nti vuttaṃ. Suttantikapariyāyena
analyzed: abhidhamme gāmā nikkhamitvā bahi inda khīlā sabbam etam araññanti vuttam suttantika pariyāyena
translated: In the Abhidhamma it is said that “having gone out of the village, outside the boundary post, all that is forest.”🔽In the Suttanta method it is said in the training precept on the forest-dweller’s practice that “the forest is five hundred bow-lengths away” .

original: āraññakasikkhāpade “pañcadhanusatikaṃ pacchima”nti āgataṃ āraññikaṃ bhikkhuṃ sandhāya.
analyzed: āraññaka sikkhāpade pañcadhanusatikam pacchimanti āgatam āraññikam bhikkhum sandhāya
translated: This refers to a bhikkhu who is a forest-dweller.

original: Na hi so vinayapariyāyike “araññe vasanato āraññiko pantasenāsano”ti sutte vutto.
analyzed: na hi so vinaya pariyāyike araññe vasanataḥ āraññikaḥ panta senāsanaḥ ti sutte vutto
translated: For he is not referred to in the Vinaya method in the passage: “The forest-dweller is one who lives in the forest and has the forest as his abode.”

original: Ayañca suttasaṃvaṇṇanāti idha sabbattha suttantakathāva pamāṇaṃ. Tasmā tattha āgatameva
analyzed: ayam ca sutta saṃvaṇṇanā ti idha sabbattha pamāṇam tasmā tattha āgatam eva
translated: And this commentary on the Suttas is authoritative everywhere here. Therefore the characteristic given there should be taken.

original: lakkhaṇaṃ gahetabbanti dassento “taṃ āropitena ācariyadhanunā”tiādinā minanavidhiṃ
analyzed: lakkhaṇam gahetabbanti dassento tam āropitena ācariya dhanunā ati ādinā minana vidhim
translated: In order to show this he says “with the teacher’s bow” and so on,

original: āha. Teneva hi majjhimaṭṭhakathānayova idamettha pamāṇanti ca vutto.
analyzed: āha tena iva hi idam ettha pamāṇa nti ca vutto
translated: and so the method in the Majjhima commentary is authoritative here.🔽“From here and there” : he blocks off a small path here and there.

original: Tato tato magganti tattha tattha khuddakamaggaṃ pidahati. Dhutaṅgasuddhikena dhutaṅgasodhanapasutena.
analyzed: tatas tatas magganti tattha tattha khuddaka maggam pidahati dhutaṅga suddhikena dhutaṅga sodhanapa sutena
translated: “By one who is pure in the ascetic practices” : by one who is skilled in purifying the ascetic practices.

original: Yathāparicchinne kāleti ukkaṭṭhassa tayopi utū, majjhimassa dve, mudukassa eko utu.
analyzed: yathā a paricchinne kāle ti ukkaṭṭhassa tayo pi utū majjhimassa dve mudukassa ekaḥ utu
translated: “In the delimited time” : for the strict one, all three seasons; for the medium one, two; for the mild one, one season.

original: Tatthapi dhutaṅgaṃ na bhijjati saussāhattā. Nipajjitvā gamissāmāti cittassa sithilabhāvena
analyzed: tattha api dhutaṅgam na bhijjati saussāha ttā nipajjitvā gamissāma ati cittassa sithila bhāvena
translated: Here too the ascetic practice is not broken because of the absence of any lack of keenness.🔽But it is said that the ascetic practice is broken because of the slackness of mind in the thought, “I’ll lie down and then go.”

original: dhutaṅgaṃ bhijjatīti vuttaṃ. Araññasaññaṃ manasi karontoti “ahaṃ vivekavāsaṃ vasissāmi,
analyzed: dhutaṅgam bhijjati iti vuttam arañña saññam manasi karontaḥ iti aham viveka vāsam vasissāmi
translated: “He gives attention to the perception of the forest” means that he gives attention to the perception of the forest in the sense of “I shall live in a place of solitude,

original: yathāladdhova kāyaviveko sātthako kātabbo”ti manasikārasabbhāvato “bhabbo…pe… rakkhitu”nti
analyzed: yathā laddhaḥ uva kāya viveko sātthako kātabbo ti manasikāra sabbhāvataḥ bhabba upe rakkhitunti
translated: and the bodily solitude that is obtained will be fruitful” . “He is capable of … guarding it” is said because of the absence of attention of the kind already mentioned.🔽The mind of the forest-dweller is not distracted because of the absence of the range of the hindrances.

original: vuttaṃ. Assa āraññikassa cittaṃ na vikkhipanti āpāthamanupagamanato. Vigatasantāso
analyzed: vuttam assa āraññikassa cittam na vikkhipanti āpātham an upagamanataḥ vigata santāsaḥ
translated: He is free from anxiety because of his familiarity with solitude.

original: hoti vivekaparicayato. Jīvitanikantiṃ jahati bahuparissaye araññe nivāseneva maraṇabhayassa
analyzed: hoti viveka paricayataḥ jīvita nikantim jahati bahu parissaye araññe nivāsena iva maraṇa bhayassa
translated: He abandons attachment to life because of his making death certain by living in the forest with its many perils.🔽He enjoys the taste of the bliss of seclusion because of the absence of society.

original: dūrīkaraṇato. Pavivekasukharasaṃ assādeti anubhavati janasaṃsaggābhāvato. Ārādhayantoti
analyzed: dūrīkaraṇataḥ paviveka sukha rasam assādeti anubhavati jana saṃsagga abhāvataḥ ārādhayanto ti
translated: “He cultivates” means he approves.

original: anunayanto. Yathānusiṭṭhaṃ paṭipattiyā vivekassa adhiṭṭhānabhāvato āraññikaṅgayogino
analyzed: anunayantaḥ yathānusiṭṭham paṭipattiyāḥ vivekassa adhiṭṭhāna bhāvataḥ āraññikaṅga yoginaḥ
translated: Because of the state of being the basis for solitude through practice in the way of practice of the training in the way taught, the forest-dweller’s practice is called “the best.”

original: vāhanasadisanti katvā vuttaṃ “avasesadhutāyudho”ti, avasiṭṭhadhutadhammāyudhoti attho.
analyzed: vāhana sadisanti katvā vuttam avasesa dhuta āyudho ti avasiṭṭha dhuta dhamma āyudho ti attho
translated: The rest of the austerities are his weapons, is said figuratively, as if they were his vehicles. The meaning is: the rest of the austerities are his weapons.

original: Iti āraññikaṅgakathāvaṇṇanā.
analyzed: iti āraññika aṅga kathā vaṇṇanā
translated: So much for the commentary on the clause “he resorts to a forest.”

original: 9. Rukkhamūlikaṅgakathāvaṇṇanā🔽32. Channanti iṭṭhakāchadanādīhi chāditaṃ, āvasathanti attho. Sīmantarikarukkhoti
analyzed: rukkhamūlika aṅga kathā vaṇṇanā  channam ti iṭṭhaka āchadana ādīhi chāditam āvasatham ti attho sīmantarika rukkho ti
translated: On the root of a tree

original: dvinnaṃ rājūnaṃ rajjasīmāya ṭhitarukkho. Tattha hi tesaṃ rājūnaṃ balakāyo upagantvā🔽antarantarā yuddhaṃ kareyya, corāpi pāripanthikā samosarantā bhikkhussa sukhena nisīdituṃ🔽na denti. Cetiyarukkho “devatādhiṭṭhito”ti manussehi sammatarukkho pūjetuṃ upagatehi
analyzed: dvinnam rājūnam rajja sīmāya ṭhita rukkhaḥ tattha hi tesam rājūnam balakāyaḥ upagantvā  antar antarā yuddham kareyya corā api pāripanthikā samosarantā bhikkhussa sukhena nisīdituṃ  na denti cetiya rukkhaḥ devatā dhiṭṭhito ti manussehi sammata rukkhaḥ pūjetum upagatehi
translated: “Roofed”: covered with bricks, tiles, etc.; the meaning is, “a dwelling.” A boundary tree is a tree standing on the border of two kingdoms. For the armies of the two kings, having gone there,🔽would fight from time to time. And thieves, too, meeting there, would not allow the bhikkhu to sit in comfort. A shrine tree is a tree accepted by people as sacred and frequented by people who go there to worship.

original: manussehi avivitto hoti. Niyyāsarukkho sajjarukkhādi. Vaggulirukkho vaggulinisevito.
analyzed: manussehi a vivittaḥ hoti niyyāsa rukkhaḥ sajja rukkha ādi vagguli rukkhaḥ vagguli nisevito
translated: It is not secluded. A tree in a place for spreading out requisites is a tree in a place for spreading out requisites, etc. A tree frequented by bark-peelers is a tree frequented by bark-peelers, etc.

original: Sīmantarikarukkhādayo saparissayā, dullabhavivekā cāti āha “ime rukkhe vivajjetvā”ti.
analyzed: sīmantarika rukkha ādayo sa parissayā dullabha vivekā ca ati āha ime rukkhe vivajjetvā ati
translated: Boundary trees, etc., are attended by risks and are not easily secluded. That is why he said “avoiding these trees.”

original: Paṇṇasaṭanti rukkhato patitapaṇṇaṃ. Paṭicchanne ṭhāne nisīditabbaṃ rukkhamūlikabhāvassa
analyzed: paṇṇa saṭanti rukkhato patita paṇṇam paṭicchanne ṭhāne nisīditabbam rukkhamūlika bhāvassa
translated: The leaves of trees are called “leaves of trees.” He should sit in a concealed place,

original: paṭicchādanatthaṃ. Channe vāsakappanā dhammassavanādīnamatthāyapi hoti. Tasmā “jānitvā
analyzed: paṭicchādana attham channe vāsa kappanā hoti tasmā jānitvā
translated: in order to conceal the fact that he is living at the foot of a tree. He may live in the open in order to listen to Dhamma, etc. Therefore it is said:

original: aruṇaṃ uṭṭhāpitamatte”ti vuttaṃ.🔽Abhiṇhaṃ tarupaṇṇavikāradassanenāti abhikkhaṇaṃ tarūsu, tarūnaṃ vā paṇṇesu vikārassa
analyzed: aruṇam uṭṭhāpita matta iti vuttam  abhiṇham taru paṇṇa vikāra dassanena ati abhikkhaṇam tarūsu vā paṇṇesu vikārassa
translated: “When the dawn has appeared, he should know . . . ”🔽By the frequent seeing of the change in the leaves of trees: by the frequent seeing of the change, the momentary dissolution, of the leaves of trees, or of the trees themselves.

original: khaṇabhaṅgassa dassanena. Senāsanamaccherakammārāmatānanti āvāsamacchariyanavakammaratabhāvānaṃ.
analyzed: khaṇabhaṅgassa dassanena senāsana macchera kamma ārāma tānanti āvāsa macchariya nava kamma rata bhāvānam
translated: By the delight in the work of hoarding and storing: by the delight in the work of hoarding and storing of dwellings.

original: Devatāhīti rukkhadevatāhi. Tāpi hi rukkhaṭṭhavimānesu vasantiyo rukkhesu vasanti.🔽Ayampi rukkheti sahavāsitā. Vaṇṇitoti “appāni cevā”tiādinā pasaṃsito. “Rukkhamūlasenāsanaṃ
analyzed: devatāhi iti rukkha devatāhi tāḥ api hi rukkha aṭṭhavimānesu vasantiyaḥ rukkhesu vasanti  ayam pi rukkha iti sahavāsitā vaṇṇito ti appāni ca iva āti ādinā pasaṃsito rukkha mūla senāsanam
translated: By the deities: by the deities of the trees. For they too, living in the divine mansions in the trees, live in the trees.

original: nissāya pabbajjā”ti evaṃ nissayoti ca bhāsito. Abhirattāni taruṇakāle, nīlāni majjhimakāle,
analyzed: nissāya pabbajjā ti evam nissayaḥ ti ca bhāsitaḥ abhirattāni taruṇa kāle nīlāni majjhima kāle
translated: This is the “living together” with the tree. “Praised” means praised in such passages as “Those who delight in the forest life . . . ” “The going forth is based upon the dwelling at the foot of a tree” — thus it is “spoken of as a support.” The trees are “lovely” in the early stage of their growth, “blue” in the middle stage, and “red” in the final stage.

original: paṇḍūni jiṇṇakāle. Patitāni milāyanavasena. Evaṃ passanto tarupaṇṇāni paccakkhato
analyzed: paṇḍūni jiṇṇa kāle patitāni milāyana vasena evam passantaḥ taru paṇṇāni paccakkhataḥ
translated: They are ‘fallen’ in the sense of having withered away. Seeing them thus, he abandons, dispels, the perception of permanence in tree leaves, which he has seen thus in reality, and the perception of impermanence becomes settled down in him.

original: eva niccasaññaṃ panūdati pajahati, aniccasaññā evassa saṇṭhāti. Yasmā bhagavato jātibodhidhammacakkapavattanaparinibbānāni
analyzed: eva nicca saññam panūdati pajahati anicca saññā evassa saṇṭhāti yasmai bhagavato jāti bodhi dhamma cakka pavattana parinibbānāni
translated: Since the Blessed One’s birth, enlightenment, setting in motion of the Wheel of the Dhamma, and final extinction all occurred at the foot of trees,

original: rukkhamūleyeva jātāni, tasmā vuttaṃ “buddhadāyajjaṃ rukkhamūla”nti.🔽Iti rukkhamūlikaṅgakathāvaṇṇanā.🔽10. Abbhokāsikaṅgakathāvaṇṇanā
analyzed: rukkha mūleya iva jātāni tasmai vuttam buddha dāyajjam rukkha mūlan ti  iti rukkhamūlika aṅga kathā vaṇṇanā
translated: therefore it is said that the foot of a tree is the inheritance of the Enlightened One.🔽So much for the commentary on the clause “He abides in a state of perception …”🔽. The clause “He abides in the open air” is next.

original: 33. “Rukkhamūlaṃ paṭikkhipāmī”ti ettake vutte channaṃ appaṭikkhittameva hotīti “channañca🔽rukkhamūlañca paṭikkhipāmī”ti vuttaṃ. Dhutaṅgassa sabbaso paṭiyogipaṭikkhepena hi🔽samādānaṃ ijjhati, no aññathāti. “Dhammassavanāyā”ti imināva dhammaṃ kathentenāpi
analyzed: rukkha mūlam paṭikkhipāmi iti ettake vutte channam appaṭikkhittam eva hoti iti channam ca  rukkha mūlañca paṭikkhipāmi iti vuttam dhutaṅgassa sabbaso paṭiyogi paṭikkhepena hi  samādānam ijjhati no aññathā ati dhamma ssavanāya ati iminā ava dhammam kathentena api
translated: When he said “I refuse the foot of a tree,” he did not refuse the six things, so he said “I refuse the interior of a wood and the foot of a tree.”🔽For the undertaking of the ascetic practice succeeds by the complete refusal of what is incompatible with it, not otherwise.🔽By the words “for the purpose of hearing the Dhamma” he allows entry to the interior of a wood for the purpose of hearing the Dhamma preached by someone else,

original: uposathadivasādīsu suṇantānaṃ cittānurakkhaṇatthaṃ tehi yācitena channaṃ pavisituṃ
analyzed: uposatha divasa ādīsu suṇantānam citta anurakkhaṇa attham tehi yācitena channam pavisitum
translated: and also for the purpose of preserving the minds of those who are listening on the observance day, etc., when he is preaching the Dhamma, if they ask for it.

original: vaṭṭati, dhammaṃ pana kathetvā abbhokāsova gantabbo. Rukkhamūlikassāpi eseva nayo.
analyzed: vaṭṭati dhammam pana kathetvā abbhokāsaḥ iva gantabbaḥ rukkhamūlikassa api esā iva nayo
translated: It is allowable to go to the open air after giving a talk on the Dhamma. The same method applies to the tree-root dweller.

original: Uposathatthāyāti uposathakammāya. Uddisantenāti paresaṃ uddesaṃ dentena. Uddisāpentenāti🔽sayaṃ uddesaṃ gaṇhantena. Maggamajjhe ṭhitaṃ sālanti sīhaḷadīpe viya maggā anokkamma🔽ujukameva pavisitabbasālaṃ. Vegena gantuṃ na vaṭṭati asāruppattā. Yāva vassūparamā
analyzed: uposatha atthāya ati uposatha kammāya uddisantena ati paresam uddesam dentena uddisāpentena ati  sayam uddesam gaṇhantena magga majjhe ṭhitam sālanti sīhaḷa dīpe viya maggāḥ an ukkamma  ujukam eva pavisitabba sālam vegena gantum na vaṭṭati a sāruppa ttā yāva vassūparamā
translated: For the observance day: for the observance-day ceremony. If he is giving the recitation to others: if he is giving the recitation to others. If he is receiving the recitation:

original: ṭhatvā gantabbaṃ, na tāva dhutaṅgabhedo hotīti adhippāyo.
analyzed: ṭhatvā gantabbam na tāva dhutaṅga bhedo hoti iti adhippāyaḥ
translated: if he is receiving the recitation himself. In the middle of the road: not deviating from the road, as in the case of the road in the island of Sri Lanka, he should enter the hall that is open to the sky. It is not allowable to go quickly, because it is unbecoming. The intention is that he should go staying as long as it takes to finish the rains, and that there is no breach of the ascetic practice until then.

original: Rukkhassa anto nāma rukkhamūlaṃ. Pabbatassa pana pabbhārasadiso pabbatapadeso. Acchannamariyādanti
analyzed: rukkhassa antaḥ nāma rukkha mūlam pabbatassa pana pabbhāra sadisaḥ pabbata padeso
translated: In the tree: at the foot of the tree. In the rock: a place in the rock like the surface of a rock. Not roofed:

original: yathā vassodakaṃ anto na pavisati, evaṃ chadanasaṅkhepena upari akatamariyādaṃ. Anto
analyzed: yathā vassa udakam antar na pavisati evam chadana saṅkhepena upari akatamariyādam antar
translated: not roofed over with a covering such as a thatch of grass or tiles, so that rain water does not enter inside. If rain water enters inside a rock overhang,

original: pana pabbhārassa vassodakaṃ pavisati ce, abbhokāsasaṅkhepamevāti tattha pavisituṃ
analyzed: pana pabbhārassa vassa udakam pavisati ce abbhokāsa saṅkhepam eva ati tattha pavisitum
translated: it is allowable to enter there,

original: vaṭṭati. Sākhāmaṇḍapoti rukkhasākhāhi viraḷacchannamaṇḍapo. Pīṭhapaṭo khalitthaddhasāṭako.
analyzed: vaṭṭati sākhāmaṇḍapo ti rukkha sākhāhi viraḷa channa maṇḍapo pīṭha paṭaḥ
translated: It is allowable. A tree-roof means a roof of branches made by spreading them out. A cloth for a seat means a cloth for sitting on.

original: Paviṭṭhakkhaṇe dhutaṅgaṃ bhijjati yathāvuttapabbhārādike ṭhapetvāti adhippāyo. Jānitvāti
analyzed: paviṭṭha kkhaṇe dhutaṅgam bhijjati yathā vutta pabbhāra ādike ṭhapetvā iti adhippāyaḥ jānitvā iti
translated: The intention is that the ascetic practice is broken at the moment of entering, except for the time stated, beginning with “a night.” Knowing means

original: dhammassavanādiatthaṃ channaṃ rukkhamūlaṃ pavisitvā nisinno “idāni aruṇo uṭṭhahatī”ti🔽jānitvā. Rukkhamūlepi katthaci attheva nivāsaphāsukatāti siyā tattha āsaṅgapubbako
analyzed: dhammassavana ādi attham channam rukkha mūlam pavisitvā nisinnaḥ idāni aruṇaḥ uṭṭhahati iti  jānitvā rukkha mūle pi katthaci atthā iva nivāsa phāsuka tā ati siyā tattha āsaṅga pubbako
translated: knowing that the dawn is breaking while sitting in a tree-root dwelling entered for the purpose of listening to the Dhamma, and so on.🔽Even in a tree-root dwelling there is comfort in the sense of a dwelling place. It may be thought that there is an obstruction to the dwelling place there in the form of a prior occupant,

original: āvāsapalibodho, na pana abbhokāseti idheva āvāsapalibodhupacchedo ānisaṃso vutto.
analyzed: āvāsa palibodhaḥ na pana abbhokāse iti idha iva āvāsa palibodha upacchedaḥ ānisaṃsaḥ vutto
translated: but the benefit here stated is the cutting off of the obstruction to the dwelling place by staying right there in the open air.

original: Pasaṃsāyānurūpatāti aniketāti vuttapasaṃsāya anālayabhāvena anucchavikatā. Nissaṅgatāti
analyzed: pasaṃsāya anurūpa tā ati aniketā ati vutta pasaṃsāya an ālaya bhāvena anucchavika tā nissaṅga tā ati
translated: In conformity with the praise means suitability to the praise stated thus “He is not tied to any quarter” by being without attachment. Unfettered means🔽unfettered there by the mere fact of not taking up a dwelling place. He has no abode in such a direction as the east,

original: āvāsapariggahābhāveneva tattha nissaṅgatā. Asukadisāya vasanaṭṭhānaṃ natthi, tasmā
analyzed: āvāsa pariggaha abhāvena iva tattha nissaṅga tā asuka disāya vasana ṭṭhānam natthi tasmā
translated: because there is no place to live in such a direction. Therefore

original: tattha gantuṃ neva sakkāti edisassa parivitakkassa abhāvato cātuddiso. Migabhūtenāti
analyzed: tattha gantum na iva sakkā ati edisassa parivitakkassa abhāvataḥ cātuddisaḥ miga bhūtena ati
translated: he is not able to go there. He is free from such thoughts as these. He is a person who has gone for shelter to the forest,🔽and so on.

original: pariggahābhāvena migassa viya bhūtena. Sitoti nissito. Vindatīti labhati.
analyzed: pariggaha abhāvena migassa viya bhūtena sitaḥ iti nissitaḥ vindati iti labhati
translated: He is like a deer in that he is unattached through the absence of grasping. He finds: he obtains.

original: Iti abbhokāsikaṅgakathāvaṇṇanā.
analyzed: iti abbhokāsikaṅga kathā vaṇṇanā
translated: Thus ends the commentary on the section on the open-air dweller.

original: 11. Sosānikaṅgakathāvaṇṇanā🔽34. Na susānanti asusānaṃ. Aññattho na-kāro, susānalakkhaṇarahitaṃ vasanaṭṭhānanti🔽adhippāyo. Na tatthāti “susāna”nti vavatthapitamatte ṭhāne na vasitabbaṃ. Na hi nāmamattena🔽susānalakkhaṇaṃ sijjhati. Tenāha “na hī”tiādi. Jhāpitakālato pana paṭṭhāya…pe… susānameva
analyzed: na susānam ti a susānam aññatthaḥ nakāraḥ susāna lakkhaṇa rahitam vasanaṭṭhānam ti  adhippāyaḥ na tattha ati su sānam ti vavatthapita matte ṭhāne na vasitabbam na hi nāma mattena  susāna lakkhaṇam sijjhati tena āha na hi itiādi jhāpita kālato pana susānam eva
translated: On the charnel-ground dweller🔽Not a charnel ground: not a place for a charnel ground. The negative is for the purpose of excluding another meaning. The intention is this: a dwelling place devoid of the characteristics of a charnel ground.

original: chavena sayitamattāya susānalakkhaṇappattito. Chavasayanaṃ hi “susāna”nti vuccati.🔽Sosānikena nāma appakiccena sallahukavuttinā bhavitabbanti dassetuṃ “tasmiṃ pana
analyzed: chavena sayita mattāya susāna lakkhaṇa ppattitaḥ chava sayanam hi susānanti vuccati  sosānikena nāma appa kiccena sat lahuka vuttinā bhavitabbanti dassetum tasmim pana
translated: Not there: he should not dwell in a place defined as “a charnel ground.” For the characteristic of a charnel ground is not established by the mere name “charnel ground.” Hence he said, “Not by the mere name” , etc. But from the time it is dug up … a charnel ground is established by the presence of the characteristics of a charnel ground.🔽For a charnel ground is so called because corpses are laid there.

original: vasantenā”tiādi vuttaṃ. Garukanti dupparihāraṃ. Tameva hi dupparihārabhāvaṃ dassetuṃ
analyzed: vasantena atiādi vuttam garukam ti dupparihāram tam eva hi dupparihāra bhāvam dassetum
translated: In order to show that the charnel-ground dweller should be one who makes little effort and lives simply, it is said: “But he who dwells there” , and so on. Difficult to resort to: hard to resort to. In order to show that it is hard to resort to,

original: “tasmā”tiādi vuttaṃ. Tattha uppannaparissayavighātatthāyāti “susānaṃ nāma manussarāhasseyyaka”nti
analyzed: tasmā itiādi vuttam tattha uppanna parissaya vighāta atthāya ati susānam nāma manussa rāhasseyyakanti
translated: “Therefore” and so on is said. Herein, for the purpose of warding off the danger that has arisen: “A charnel ground is a place where people hide corpses” .

original: corā katakammāpi akatakammāpi osaranti, tattha coresu bhaṇḍasāmike disvā bhikkhusamīpe
analyzed: corā kata kammā api a kata kammā api osaranti tattha coresu bhaṇḍa sāmike disvā bhikkhu samīpe
translated: Even thieves who have done their job and those who have not done it come down there. If the owners of the goods see the bhikkhu there

original: bhaṇḍaṃ chaḍḍetvā palātesu manussā bhikkhuṃ “coro”ti gahetvā potheyyuṃ, tasmā vihāre
analyzed: bhaṇḍam chaḍḍetvā palātesu manussāḥ bhikkhum coro ti gahetvā potheyyum tasmai vihāre
translated: and abandon the goods near him and flee, people might seize the bhikkhu, thinking he is a thief, and beat him. Therefore he should live there carefully

original: saṅghattheraṃ vā gocaragāme raññā niyuttaṃ rājayuttakaṃ vā attano sosānikabhāvaṃ🔽jānāpetvā yathā tādiso, añño vā parissayo na hoti, tathā appamattena vasitabbaṃ.
analyzed: saṅghattheram vā gocaragāme raññā niyuttam rājayuttakam vā attano sosānika bhāvam  jānāpetvā yathā tādisaḥ aññaḥ vā parissayaḥ na hoti tathā appamattena vasitabbam
translated: after informing the senior elder of the monastery or a royal servant appointed by the king in the village where he goes for alms of his being a charnel-ground dweller,🔽so that no such danger or any other may arise.

original: Caṅkamantassa yadā āḷahanaṃ abhimukhaṃ na hoti, tadāpi saṃvegajananatthaṃ tattha
analyzed: caṅkamantassa yadā āḷahanam abhimukham na hoti tadā api saṃvega janana attham tattha
translated: When he is walking up and down, he should look at the burning-ground in this way in order to arouse his own sense of urgency even when the charnel-house is not in view.

original: diṭṭhi vissajjetabbāti dassetuṃ “addhakkhikena āḷahanaṃ olokentenā”ti vuttaṃ.
analyzed: diṭṭhi vissajjetabbā ti dassetum addhakkhikena āḷahanam olokentena ati vuttam
translated: “Looking at the charnel-house with half an eye” is said in order to show that he should look at it in this way in order to arouse his own sense of urgency even when the charnel-house is not in view.

original: Uppathamaggena gantabbaṃ attano sosānikabhāvassa apākaṭabhāvatthaṃ. Ārammaṇanti tasmiṃ
analyzed: uppatha maggena gantabbam attano sosānika bhāvassa apākaṭa bhāva ttham ārammaṇanti tasmin
translated: He should go by the direct way in order not to make his being a charnel-ground dweller obvious. As object:

original: susāne “ayaṃ vammiko, ayaṃ rukkho, ayaṃ khāṇuko”tiādinā divāyeva ārammaṇaṃ vavatthapetabbaṃ.
analyzed: susāne ayam vammikaḥ ayam rukkhaḥ ayam khāṇuko ti ādinā divāya iva ārammaṇam vavatthapetabbam
translated: He should define the object by day, saying, “This is a termite- mound, this a tree, this a stump,” and so on.

original: Bhayānakanti bhayajanakaṃ vammikādiṃ. Kenaci leḍḍupāsāṇādinā āsanne vicarantīti na
analyzed: bhayānakam ti bhaya janakam vammika ādim kenacid leḍḍu pāsāṇa ādinā āsanne vicaranti iti na
translated: “A frightening place” is one that causes fear, such as a termite-mound, and so on. He should not go near it with a clod or a stick in his hand.

original: paharitabbā. Tilapiṭṭhaṃ vuccati palalaṃ. Māsamissaṃ bhattaṃ māsabhattaṃ. Guḷādīti🔽ādi-saddena tilasaṃguḷikādighanapūvañca saṅgaṇhāti. Kulagehaṃ na pavisitabbanti petadhūmena
analyzed: paharitabbā tila piṭṭham vuccati palalam māsa missam bhattam māsa bhattam guḷa ādi iti  ādi saddena saṅgaṇhāti kulageham na pavisitabbanti peta dhūmena
translated: “Bran” is chaff. “Rice and curry” is rice with curry. “Sugar, etc.” includes solid sweets such as sweetmeats made with sesame seed.

original: vāsitattā, pisācānubandhattā ca kulagehassa abbhantaraṃ na pavisitabbaṃ. Devasikaṃ
analyzed: vāsita ttā pisāca anubandha ttā ca kula gehassa abbhantaram na pavisitabbam devasikam
translated: He should not enter a house where there is a corpse because it is perfumed with the smell of the corpse-bearer’s clothes and because it is haunted by evil spirits.

original: chavaḍāho dhuvaḍāho. Matañātakānaṃ tattha gantvā devasikaṃ rodanaṃ dhuvarodanaṃ.🔽Vuttanayenāti “jhāpitakālato pana paṭṭhāyā”ti vuttanayena. “Pacchimayāme paṭikkamituṃ
analyzed: chava ḍāhaḥ dhuva ḍāhaḥ matañātakānam tattha gantvā devasikam rodanam dhuva rodanam  vutta nayena āti jhāpita kālataḥ pana paṭṭhāya ati vutta nayena pacchima yāme paṭikkamitum
translated: “Daily cremation” is cremation every day. “Constant weeping” is the weeping of the relatives who go there every day.🔽“In the way stated” is in the way stated in the passage beginning, “But from the time when he has had the pyre lit” .

original: vaṭṭatī”ti icchitattā “susānaṃ agatadivase”ti aṅguttarabhāṇakā.
analyzed: vaṭṭati iti susānam agata divasā iti aṅguttara bhāṇakā
translated: The reciters of the Aṅguttara say that the words “on the day he goes to the charnel ground” are meant to show that it is proper to leave the charnel ground in the last watch of the night.

original: Susāne niccakālaṃ sivathikadassanena maraṇassatipaṭilābho. Tato eva appamādavihāritā.
analyzed: susāne niccakālam sivathika dassanena maraṇa ssati paṭilābho tatas eva appamāda vihāri tā
translated: He acquires mindfulness of death by constantly seeing corpses in the charnel ground. And he lives heedfully because of that.

original: Tattha chaḍḍitassa matakaḷevarassa dassanena asubhanimittādhigamo. Tato eva kāmarāgavinodanaṃ.
analyzed: tattha chaḍḍitassa mataka ḷevarassa dassanena asubha nimitta adhigamaḥ tatas eva kāma rāga vinodanam
translated: He acquires the sign of foulness by seeing a dead body thrown aside there. And he dispels lust for sensual pleasures because of that.

original: Bahulaṃ sarīrassa asuciduggandhajegucchabhāvasallakkhaṇato abhiṇhaṃ kāyasabhāvadassanaṃ.🔽Tato maraṇassatipaṭilābhato ca saṃvegabahulatā. Byādhikānaṃ, jarājiṇṇānañca matānaṃ
analyzed: bahulam sarīrassa asuci duggandha jeguccha bhāva sat lakkhaṇataḥ abhiṇham kāya sabhāva dassanam  tatas maraṇa ssati paṭilābhato ca saṃvega bahula tā byādhikānam jarā jiṇṇānam ca matānam
translated: He frequently sees the true nature of the body by constantly observing the body’s impurity, foul smell, and loathsome state.🔽And he has a sense of urgency because he acquires mindfulness of death.🔽He abandons vanity about his health, youth, life, and beauty by seeing the sick, the aged, and the dead there.

original: tattha dassanena ārogyayobbanajīvitamadappahānaṃ. Khuddakassa, mahato ca bhayassa🔽abhibhavanato bhayabheravasahanatā. Saṃviggassa yoniso padahanaṃ sambhavatīti amanussānaṃ
analyzed: tattha dassanena ārogya yobbana jīvita mada ppahānam khuddakassa mahataḥ ca bhayassa  abhibhavanataḥ bhaya bherava sahana tā saṃviggassa yonisaḥ padahanam sambhavati iti amanussānam
translated: He is not frightened or terrified by fear or terror, whether slight or much,🔽because he has overcome it. And it is possible for him to make a proper effort because he is stirred to urgency. So he is respected and revered by non-human beings

original: garubhāvanīyatā. Niddāgatampīti suttampi, supinantepīti adhippāyo.🔽Iti sosānikaṅgakathāvaṇṇanā.
analyzed: garu bhāvanīya tā niddā gatam pi iti suttam pi  iti sosānika aṅga kathā vaṇṇanā
translated: because he is a burden to them. “Even when asleep” means even when awake. The intention is that even when dreaming.🔽This is the commentary on the section on the charnel-ground dweller.

original: 12. Yathāsanthatikaṅgakathāvaṇṇanā
analyzed: yathā santhati kaṅga kathā vaṇṇanā
translated: The section on the sitter

original: 35. Senāsanagāhaṇe pare uṭṭhāpetvā gahaṇaṃ, “idaṃ sundaraṃ, idaṃ na sundara”nti paritulayitvā
analyzed: senāsana gāhaṇe pare uṭṭhāpetvā gahaṇam idam sundaram idam na paritulayitvā
translated: 35. In the choosing of dwellings, to choose after having had others get up. “This is good, this is not good,” to choose after having weighed.

original: pucchanā, olokanā ca senāsanaloluppaṃ. Tuṭṭhabbanti tussitabbaṃ. Vihārassa pariyantabhāvena🔽dūreti vā bahūnaṃ sannipātaṭṭhānādīnaṃ accāsanneti vā pucchituṃ na labhati, pucchanenapissa
analyzed: pucchanā olokanā ca senāsana loluppam tuṭṭhabbanti tussitabbam vihārassa pariyanta bhāvena  dūrā iti vā bahūnam sannipāta ṭṭhāna ādīnam acca āsannā iti vā pucchitum na labhati
translated: He should not get others to rise up and then choose a lodging, nor should he choose after weighing up the lodging thus, “This is good, this is not good,” nor should he ask about it, nor should he look around. He should be satisfied with whatever he gets.🔽He should not ask about a lodging that is too far away, that is, one that is too far from the place where the alms resort is available, etc., because it is defiled by the stain of greed.

original: dhutaṅgassa saṃkilissanato. Oloketunti loluppavasena passituṃ. Sacassa taṃ na ruccatīti
analyzed: dhutaṅgassa saṃkilissanataḥ oloketum ti loluppa vasena passitum sacassa tam na ruccati iti
translated: He should not look around for a lodging with greed. If he does not like the lodging he has been given,

original: assa yathāsanthatikassa taṃ yathāgāhitaṃ senāsanaṃ aphāsukabhāvena sace na ruccati,🔽mudukassa asati roge yathāgāhitaṃ pahāya aññassa senāsanassa gahaṇaṃ loluppaṃ, majjhimassa
analyzed: assa yathāsanthatikassa tam yathā gāhitam senāsanam a phāsuka bhāvena sace na ruccati  mudukassa asati roge yathāgāhitam pahāya aññassa senāsanassa gahaṇam loluppam majjhimassa
translated: then, if he is of the kind that needs a comfortable lodging, he should give up the one he has been given and choose another.

original: gantvā olokanā, ukkaṭṭhassa pucchanā. Sabbesampi uṭṭhāpetvā gahaṇe vattabbameva natthi.
analyzed: gantvā olokanā ukkaṭṭhassa pucchanā sabbesam pi uṭṭhāpetvā gahaṇe vattabbam eva natthi
translated: If he is of the middle kind, he may look around for another after going there himself. If he is of the keen kind, he may ask about another. But in no case may he get others to rise up and then choose.

original: Upaṭṭhāpanīyānampi anuṭṭhāpanena sabrahmacārīnaṃ hitesitā. Tāya karuṇāvihārānuguṇatā.
analyzed: anuṭṭhāpanena sabrahmacārīnam hita īsitā tāya karuṇā vihāra anuguṇa tā
translated: And the benefitting of his fellows in the life of purity by not being a burden to them is the quality of being a good person. That is in conformity with the dwelling in compassion.

original: Sundarāsundaravibhāgākaraṇato hīnapaṇītavikappapariccāgo. Tena tādilakkhaṇānuguṇatā.
analyzed: sundara asundara vibhāga akaraṇataḥ hīna paṇīta vikappa pariccāgaḥ tena tad ādi lakkhaṇa anuguṇa tā
translated: The giving up of the discrimination of low and high is the giving up of the discrimination of what is despised and what is esteemed. That is in conformity with the characteristic of equanimity.

original: Tato eva anurodhavirodhappahānaṃ. Dvārapidahanaṃ okāsādānato. Yathāsanthatarāmatanti
analyzed: tatas eva anurodha virodha pahānam dvāra pidahanam okāsa ādānataḥ
translated: And the giving up of approval and resistance is the burning up of the two, because of the taking of opportunity. The meaning is that he is content with whatever resting place he gets, with whatever is assigned to him.

original: yathāgāhite yathāniddiṭṭhe senāsane abhiratabhāvaṃ.🔽Iti yathāsanthatikaṅgakathāvaṇṇanā.
analyzed: yathā gāhite yathā niddiṭṭhe senāsane abhirata bhāvam  iti yathā santhati kaṅga kathā vaṇṇanā
translated: The explanation of the section on the one who resorts to what is spatially limited is ended.

original: 13. Nesajjikaṅgakathāvaṇṇanā
translated: The explanation of the section on the one who resorts to the posture that is spatially limited

original: 36. Seyyanti iriyāpathalakkhaṇaṃ seyyaṃ. Tappaṭikkhepeneva hi tadatthā “mañco bhisī”ti🔽evamādikā seyyā paṭikkhittā eva honti. “Nesajjiko”ti ca sayanaṃ paṭikkhipitvā nisajjāya
analyzed: seyyanti iriyāpatha lakkhaṇam seyyam tad paṭikkhepena iva hi tad atthā mañcaḥ bhisī iti  evamādikā seyyā paṭikkhittāḥ eva honti nesajjikā iti ca sayanam paṭikkhipitvā nisajjāya
translated: is as follows. “Seated”: the posture that is spatially limited is characterized by sitting. For the purpose of that posture, “a bed, a couch,” etc.,

original: eva viharituṃ sīlamassāti imassa atthassa idha adhippetattā seyyā evettha paṭiyoginī,
analyzed: eva viharitum sīlam assa ati imassa atthassa idha adhippeta ttā seyyā eva ittha paṭiyoginī
translated: are prohibited by the mere prohibition of lying down. “The one who resorts to the posture that is spatially limited” is one whose habit is to live by resorting to a posture that is spatially limited, having prohibited lying down and having made sitting🔽the basis for the attainment of distinction.

original: na itare tathā aniṭṭhattā, asambhavato ca. Kosajjapakkhiyo hi iriyāpatho idha paṭiyogibhāvena
analyzed: na itare tathā aniṭṭhattā asambhavataḥ ca kosajja pakkhiyaḥ hi iriyāpathaḥ idha paṭiyogi bhāvena
translated: not the other postures, because they are not so undesirable and because it is impossible.🔽For the posture that is a companion to laziness is intended here as the counter-part, not the others.

original: icchito, na itare. Na ca sakkā ṭhānagamanehi vinā nisajjāya eva yāpetuṃ tathā pavattetunti
analyzed: icchitaḥ na itare na ca sakkā ṭhāna gamanehi vinā nisajjāya eva yāpetum tathā pavattetum ti
translated: And it is not possible to spend the whole night sitting without standing and walking.

original: seyyāvettha paṭiyoginī. Tenāha “tena panā”tiādi. Caṅkamitabbaṃ na “nesajjiko aha”nti
analyzed: sā iyyāva ettha paṭiyoginī tena āha tena pana atiādi caṅkamitabbam na nesajjikaḥ ahanti
translated: So lying down is the counter-part here. That is why he said, “But he should not think, ‘I will lie down. I am not a recline-at-any-time man.’

original: sabbarattiṃ nisīditabbaṃ. Iriyāpathantarānuggahito hi kāyo manasikārakkhamo hoti.
analyzed: sabbarattim nisīditabbam iriyāpatha antara anuggahitaḥ hi kāyaḥ manasikāra kkhamaḥ hoti
translated: He should not sit all night. For when the body is supported by a change of posture, it is fit for the work of attention.🔽The four feet and the back and sides: it has five parts with these five parts.

original: Cattāro pādā, piṭṭhiapassayo cāti imehi pañcahi aṅgehi pañcaṅgo. Catūhi aṭṭanīhi,🔽piṭṭhiapassayena ca pañcaṅgoti apare. Ubhosu passesu piṭṭhipasse ca yathāsukhaṃ apassāya
analyzed: cattāro pādā piṭṭhi apassayo ca ati imehi pañcahi aṅgehi pañcaṅgo catūhi aṭṭanīhi  piṭṭhi apassayena ca apare ubhosu passesu piṭṭhi passe ca yathāsukham a passāya
translated: Others say that it has four feet, the back and sides as the fifth part.🔽When he lives with the back and sides turned in whichever way is comfortable,

original: viharato nesajjikassa “anesajjikato ko viseso”ti gāhaṃ nivāretuṃ abhayatthero nidassito
analyzed: viharataḥ nesajjikassa anesajjikato kaḥ visesaḥ ti gāham nivāretum abhaya theraḥ nidassitaḥ
translated: the Elder Abhaya was pointed out to stop him from thinking, “What is the difference between a man who does not lie down and a man who does not recline?”

original: “thero anāgāmī hutvā parinibbāyī”ti.
analyzed: theraḥ anāgāmī hutvā parinibbāyi iti
translated: “The elder attained Nibbāna as a non-returner.”

original: Upacchedīyati etenāti upacchedananti vinibandhupacchedassa sādhakatamabhāvo daṭṭhabbo.
analyzed: etena ati upacchedanam ti vinibandha upacchedassa sādhakatama bhāvaḥ daṭṭhabbo
translated: The meaning of “cutting off” should be regarded as the state of being the means of effecting the cutting off of the bond.

original: Sabbakammaṭṭhānānuyogasappāyatā alīnānuddhaccapakkhikattā nisajjāya. Tato eva pāsādikairiyāpathatā.
analyzed: sabba kammaṭṭhāna anuyoga sappāya tā alīna anuddhacca pakkhika ttā nisajjāya tatas eva pāsādika eriyāpatha tā
translated: The suitability of the posture for the practice of all meditation subjects is because it is on the side of non-distraction and non-agitation. And because of that it is the posture that is inspiring.

original: Vīriyārambhānukūlatā vīriyasamatāyojanassa anucchavikatā. Tato eva sammāpaṭipattiyā🔽anubrūhanatā. Paṇidhāyāti ṭhapetvā. Tanunti uparimakāyaṃ. Vikampetīti cāleti, icchāvighātaṃ
analyzed: vīriya ārambha anukūla tā vīriya sama tā yojanassa anucchavika tā tatas eva sammā paṭipattiyā  anubrūhana tā uparima kāyam vikampeti iti cāleti icchā vighātam
translated: The suitability of the posture for the development of equanimity is because it is suitable for the arousing of energy. And because of that it is the posture that is conducive to the increase of rightness.🔽“He resolves” means he determines. “That” means the upper body. “He makes it tremble” means he moves it. The meaning is that he causes an obstruction to his wish.

original: karotīti adhippāyo. Vatanti dhutaṅgaṃ.
analyzed: karoti iti adhippāyaḥ vatanti dhutaṅgam
translated: “They say” means the ascetic practices.

original: Iti nesajjikaṅgakathāvaṇṇanā.🔽Dhutaṅgapakiṇṇakakathāvaṇṇanā🔽37. Sekkhaputhujjanānaṃ vasena siyā kusalāni, khīṇāsavānaṃ vasena siyā abyākatāni.
analyzed: iti nesajjikaṅga kathā vaṇṇanā  dhutaṅga pakiṇṇaka kathā vaṇṇanā  sekkha puthujjanānam vasena siyā kusalāni khīṇa āsavānam vasena siyā abyākatāni
translated: So much for the explanation of the exposition of the “no-lying” ascetic practice.🔽As to the “no-couch” practice, it is profitable for those in training and for ordinary men, and it is indeterminate for those whose cankers are destroyed.

original: Tattha sekkhaputhujjanā paṭipattipūraṇatthaṃ, khīṇāsavā phāsuvihāratthaṃ dhutaṅgāni
analyzed: tattha sekkha puthujjanā paṭipatti pūraṇa attham khīṇa āsavā phāsu vihāra attham dhutaṅgāni
translated: Herein, those in training and ordinary men undertake it for the purpose of fulfilling practice, while those whose cankers are destroyed undertake it for the purpose of living comfortably.

original: pariharanti. Akusalampi dhutaṅganti akusalacittenāpi dhutaṅgasevanā atthīti adhippāyo.
analyzed: pariharanti akusalam pi dhutaṅgam ti akusala cittena api dhutaṅga sevanā atthi iti adhippāyaḥ
translated: They maintain that there is an unprofitable ascetic practice. The intention is that there is the practice of an ascetic practice by one with an unprofitable cognizance.

original: Taṃ na yuttaṃ, yena akusalacittena pabbajitassa āraññikattaṃ, taṃ dhutaṅgaṃ nāma
analyzed: tat na yuttam yena akusala cittena pabbajitassa āraññika ttam tam dhutaṅgam nāma
translated: That is incorrect. For the state of being a forest-dweller in one gone forth with an unprofitable cognizance is not called an ascetic practice.

original: na hoti. Kasmā? Lakkhaṇābhāvato. Yaṃ hidaṃ kilesānaṃ dhunanato dhutassa puggalassa,
analyzed: na hoti kasmā lakkhaṇa abhāvataḥ yam hi dam kilesānam dhunanataḥ dhutassa puggalassa
translated: Why? Because of absence of the characteristic. For that which is a condition for shaking off defilements in a person who is a shaker-off,

original: ñāṇassa, cetanāya vā aṅgattaṃ, na taṃ akusaladhammesu sambhavati. Tasmā araññavāsādimattena🔽āraññikādayo tāva hontu, āraññikaṅgādīni pana na hontīti imamatthaṃ dassetuṃ “na
analyzed: ñāṇassa cetanāya vā aṅga ttam na tam akusala dhammesu sambhavati tasmai arañña vāsa ādimattena  āraññika ādayaḥ tāva hontu āraññika aṅga ādīni pana na honti iti imam attham dassetum na
translated: which is a condition for knowledge or for volition, is not found in unprofitable states. So let there be forest-dwellers, etc., in the mere sense of dwelling in the forest, etc.,

original: maya”ntiādi vuttaṃ. Tattha imānīti dhutaṅgāni. Vuttaṃ heṭṭhā vacanatthaniddese. Na
analyzed: maya ntiādi vuttam tattha imāni iti vuttam heṭṭhā vacana attha niddese na
translated: but the forest-dweller’s practice, etc., are not. This is the meaning intended by the words “But we do not say that there is no unprofitable ascetic practice” and so on. Herein, these are the ascetic practices. This is said in the Description of the Terms.

original: ca akusalena koci dhuto nāma hoti, kilesānaṃ dhunanaṭṭhenāti adhippāyo. Yassa bhikkhuno
analyzed: ca akusalena koci dhutaḥ nāma hoti kilesānam dhunana ṭṭhena ati adhippāyaḥ yassa bhikkhuno
translated: And no one is a shaker-off by means of the unprofitable. The intention is that it is because of the shaking off of defilements. In the case of a bhikkhu who has the undertaking of these and the practice of them,

original: etāni samādānāni aṅgāni, etena paṭhamenāpi atthavikappena “natthi akusalaṃ dhutaṅga”nti
analyzed: etāni samādānāni aṅgāni etena paṭhamena api attha vikappena na atthi akusalam dhutaṅganti
translated: by this first interpretation too there is no unprofitable ascetic practice.

original: dasseti. Na ca akusalaṃ kiñci dhunātīti akusalaṃ kiñci pāpaṃ na ca dhunāti eva appaṭipakkhato.
analyzed: dasseti na ca akusalam kiñci dhunāti iti akusalam kiñci pāpam na ca dhunāti eva appaṭipakkhato
translated: and it does not shake off any of the unprofitable.

original: Yesaṃ samādānānaṃ taṃ akusalaṃ ñāṇaṃ viya aṅganti katvā tāni dhutaṅgānīti vucceyyuṃ.
analyzed: tam akusalam ñāṇam viya aṅganti katvā tāni dhutaṅgāni iti vucceyyuṃ
translated: If it did, it would be like knowledge, and then it could be called an ascetic practice in the sense of shaking off the unprofitable.

original: Iminā dutiyenāpi atthavikappena “natthi akusalaṃ dhutaṅga”nti dasseti. Nāpi akusalantiādi
analyzed: iminā dutiyena api attha vikappena natthi akusalam dhutaṅganti dasseti nā api akusala ntiādi
translated: By this second method of interpretation he shows that there is no unprofitable ascetic practice. And it is not unprofitable, etc.

original: tatiyaatthavikappavasena yojanā. Tasmātiādi vuttassevatthassa nigamanaṃ.
analyzed: tatiya attha vikappa vasena yojanā tasmā atiādi vuttassa iva atthassa nigamanam
translated: is the application of the third method of interpretation. Because of that, etc. is the conclusion to the meaning already stated.

original: Yesanti abhayagirivāsike sandhāyāha. Te hi dhutaṅgaṃ nāma paññattīti vadanti. Tathā
analyzed: abhayagiri vāsike sandhāya āha te hi dhutaṅgam nāma paññattī iti vadanti tathā
translated: They are the residents of the Abhayagiri Monastery, who say that an ascetic practice is a designation.

original: sati tassa paramatthato avijjamānattā kilesānaṃ dhunanaṭṭhopi na siyā, samādātabbatā
analyzed: sati tassa paramatthataḥ avijjamāna ttā kilesānam dhunana ṭṭhaḥ upi na siyā samādātabba tā
translated: If that were so, then because it would not exist in the ultimate sense, it would not have the meaning of shaking off defilements, and it would not be something to be undertaken.

original: cāti tesaṃ vacanaṃ pāḷiyā virujjhatīti dassetuṃ “kusalattikavinimutta”ntiādi vuttaṃ.
analyzed: ca ati tesam vacanam pāḷiyā virujjhati iti dassetum kusala ttika vinimutta ntiādi vuttam
translated: That is why he says, “Excluded from the profitable triad,” in order to show that their statement contradicts the texts.

original: Tasmāti yasmā paññattipakkhe ete dosā dunnivārā, tasmā taṃ tesaṃ vacanaṃ na gahetabbaṃ,
analyzed: tasmā iti yasmā paññatti pakkhe ete dosāḥ dunnivārā tasmā tam tesam vacanam na gahetabbam
translated: Because of that, etc. is this: because these faults are hard to refute in the case of the designation, therefore that statement of theirs should not be accepted,

original: vuttanayo cetanāpakkhoyeva gahetabboti attho. Yasmā ete dhutaguṇā kusalattike paṭhamatatiyapadasaṅgahitā,
analyzed: vutta nayaḥ cetanā pakkhaḥ yā iva gahetabbaḥ ti atthaḥ yasmai ete dhuta guṇā kusala ttike paṭhama tatiya pada saṅgahitā
translated: Since these ascetic practices are included in the first and third terms of the profitable triad,

original: tasmā siyā sukhāya vedanāya sampayuttā, siyā adukkhamasukhāya vedanāya sampayuttā,
analyzed: tasmā siyā sukhāya vedanāya sampayuttā siyā adukkhamasukhāya vedanāya sampayuttā
translated: they may be connected with pleasant feeling, or they may be connected with neither-painful-nor-pleasant feeling.🔽They may be states subject to cankers, or they may be states not subject to cankers. They may be states that are a basis for cankers, or they may be states that are not a basis for cankers.

original: siyā vipākadhammadhammā, siyā nevavipākanavipākadhammadhammā, siyā anupādinnupādāniyā,🔽siyā asaṃkiliṭṭhasaṃkilesikāti evaṃ sesatikadukapadehipi nesaṃ yathārahaṃ saṅgaho vibhāvetabbo.🔽Kāmaṃ sabbopi arahā dhutakileso, idha pana dhutaṅgasevanāmukhena kilese vidhunitvā
analyzed: siyā vipāka dhamma dhammā siyā neva vipāka na vipāka dhamma dhammā siyā anupādinnupādāniyā  siyā a saṃkiliṭṭha saṃkilesikā ti evam sesa tika duka padehi pi na īsam yathāraham saṅgahaḥ vibhāvetabbo  kāmam sabbaḥ api arahā dhuta kilesaḥ idha pana dhutaṅga sevanā mukhena kilese vidhunitvā
translated: They may be states that are defiled and subject to cankers, or they may be states that are not defiled and not subject to cankers.🔽So too with the remaining dyads and triads. Their inclusion should be worked out in each case as appropriate.🔽Of course, all Arahants are ascetic in being purified of defilements, but here an Arahant who is established by means of the practice of the ascetic qualities in the destruction of the taints

original: ṭhito khīṇāsavo “dhutakileso puggalo”ti adhippeto. Tathā sabbopi ariyamaggo nippariyāyena
analyzed: ṭhitaḥ khīṇāsavaḥ dhuta kileso puggalo ti adhippeto tathā sabbaḥ api ariya maggaḥ nippariyāyena
translated: is intended as “an ascetic person.” So too, all noble paths are in the ultimate sense a state that is an ascetic practice,

original: kilesadhunano dhammo, visesato aggamaggo. Pariyāyena pana vipassanāñāṇādi. Heṭṭhimaparicchedena
translated: but the supreme path is pre-eminent. But in the conventional sense it is insight knowledge, etc.,

original: dhutaṅgacetanāsampayuttañāṇaṃ daṭṭhabbaṃ. Evaṃ dhutaṃ dassetvā dhutavāde dassetabbe
analyzed: dhutaṅga cetanā sampayutta ñāṇam daṭṭhabbam evam dhutam dassetvā dhuta vāde dassetabbe
translated: Having thus shown the ascetic practices, the ascetic’s state should be shown in the section on the ascetic’s state.

original: yasmā dhutavādabhedena dhuto viya dhutabhedena dhutavādopi duvidho, tasmā tesaṃ,
analyzed: yasmā dhutavāda bhedena dhutaḥ dhuta bhedena dhutavādaḥ api duvidhaḥ tasmā
translated: Since the ascetic’s state is twofold, like the ascetic, by way of the division of the ascetic’s state,

original: tadubhayapaṭikkhepassa ca vasena catukkamettha sambhavatīti taṃ dassetuṃ “atthi dhuto”tiādi vuttaṃ.🔽Tayidanti nipāto, tassa “so aya”nti attho. Dhutadhammā nāmāti dhutaṅgasevanāya paṭipakkhabhūtānaṃ
analyzed: tad ubhaya paṭikkhepassa ca vasena catukkam ettha sambhavati iti tam dassetum atthi dhuto tiādi vuttam  nipātaḥ tassa saḥ ayanti atthaḥ dhutadhammā nāma ati dhutaṅga sevanāya paṭipakkha bhūtānam
translated: therefore the tetrad is possible here by way of the denial of both of them. In order to show that, “There is an ascetic” and so on is said.🔽The word tayidam is a particle, the meaning of which is “this.”

original: pāpadhammānaṃ dhunanavasena pavattiyā “dhuto”ti laddhanāmāya dhutaṅgacetanāya upakārakā🔽dhammāti katvā dhutadhammā nāma. Asampattasampattesu paccayesu alubbhanākārena pavattanato
analyzed: pāpa dhammānam dhunana vasena pavattiyā dhutoti laddha nāmāya dhutaṅga cetanāya upakārakā  dhammā ti katvā dhutadhammā nāma a sampatta sampattesu paccayesu a lubbhana ākārena pavattanato
translated: The ascetic practices are called “ascetic practices” because they are called “ascetic” by the occurrence of the volition of the ascetic practices by way of shaking off evil states that are opposed to the practice of the ascetic practices.🔽They are called “ascetic practices” because they are states that assist the volition of the ascetic practices.🔽Since they occur by way of not submitting to conditions that are not yet obtained and that are obtained,🔽they are non-greed in meaning.

original: appicchatā santuṭṭhitā ca atthato alobho. Paccayagedhādihetukānaṃ lolatādīnaṃ saṃkilesānaṃ
analyzed: appiccha tā santuṭṭhi tā ca atthataḥ alobho paccaya gedhā ādi hetukānam lola tā ādīnam saṃkilesānam
translated: The defilements of restlessness, etc., which have as their cause the clinging to conditions, etc.,

original: sammadeva likhanato chedanato gaṇasaṅgaṇikādibhedato saṃsaggato cittassa vivecanato🔽sallekhatā pavivekatā ca alobho amohoti imesu dvīsu dhammesu anupatanti tadantogadhā
analyzed: sammat eva likhanataḥ chedanataḥ gaṇa saṅgaṇikā ādi bhedato saṃsaggato cittassa vivecanato  sallekha tā paviveka tā ca alobhaḥ amoho ti imesu dvīsu dhammesu anupatanti tad antogadhā
translated: and by the right kind of writing, by cutting, by the kind of company kept, and so on, by association, and by the mind’s being secluded,

original: tappariyāpannā honti, tadubhayasseva pavattivisesabhāvato. Imehi kusaladhammehi atthī
analyzed: tad pariyāpannāḥ honti tad ubhayassa iva pavatti visesa bhāvataḥ imehi kusala dhammehi
translated: and the state of reflection and the state of seclusion are included in the two ideas of non-greed and non-delusion, they are included in them, they are comprised in them, because they are a special kind of occurrence of those two. There is this,

original: idamatthī, yena ñāṇena pabbajitena nāma paṃsukūlikaṅgādīsu patiṭṭhitena bhavitabbanti
analyzed: idam atthī yena ñāṇena pabbajitena nāma paṃsukūlikaṅga ādīsu patiṭṭhitena bhavitabbanti
translated: there is this profit, by means of which knowledge a man who has gone forth should be established in the refuse-rag-wearer’s practice, and so on.

original: yathānusiṭṭhaṃ dhutaguṇe samādiyati ceva pariharati ca, taṃ ñāṇaṃ idamatthitā. Tenāha🔽“idamatthitā ñāṇamevā”ti. Paṭikkhepavatthūsūti gahapaticīvarādīsu tehi tehi dhutaṅgehi
analyzed: yathā anusiṭṭham dhuta guṇe samādiyati ca iva pariharati ca tam ñāṇam idam atthitā tena āha  idam atthitā ñāṇam evā ti paṭikkhepa vatthūsu iti gaha pati cīvara ādīsu tehi tehi dhutaṅgehi
translated: He undertakes and carries out the ascetic practices as instructed, and that knowledge is the knowledge of this profit. Hence it is said

original: paṭikkhipitabbavatthūsu. Lobhanti taṇhaṃ. Tesveva vāti paṭikkhepavatthūsu eva. Ādīnavapaṭicchādakanti
analyzed: paṭikkhipitabba vatthūsu taṇham tesu eva vāti paṭikkhepa vatthūsu eva ādīnava paṭicchādakam ti
translated: “The knowledge of this profit is the same as the knowledge of this profit” . In the grounds for refusal: in the grounds for refusing the householder’s robe, and so on, in the various ascetic practices. Greed: craving. In them: in the grounds for refusal. Concealer of danger:

original: ārakkhadukkhaparādhīnavutticorabhayādiādīnavapaṭicchādakaṃ. Anuññātānanti satthārā
analyzed: ārakkha dukkha para adhīna vutti cora bhaya ādi ādīnava paṭicchādakam satthārā
translated: concealer of the danger consisting in the suffering of guarding, of being subject to others, of being a target for criticism, of fear of thieves, and so on. In what is permitted:

original: nicchandarāgaparibhogavasena anuññātānaṃ sukhasamphassaattharaṇapāvuraṇādīnaṃ. Paṭisevanamukhenāti🔽paṭisevanadvārena, tena lesenāti attho. Atisallekhamukhenāti ativiya sallekhapaṭipattimukhena,
analyzed: nicchanda rāga paribhoga vasena anuññātānam sukha samphassa attharaṇa pāvuraṇa ādīnam paṭisevana mukhena ati  paṭisevana dvārena tena lesena ati attho ati sallekha mukhena ati ativiya sallekha paṭipatti mukhena
translated: By the means of enjoyment: by the means of enjoyment of the kind already described.🔽By the means of extreme effacement: by the means of the practice of extreme effacement.

original: ukkaṭṭhassa vattanakānampi paṭikkhipanavasenāti attho.
analyzed: ukkaṭṭhassa vattanakānam pi paṭikkhipana vasena āti attho
translated: The meaning is: by the means of the practice of extreme effacement, which is the opposite of the practice of the kind already described.

original: Sukhumakaraṇasannissayo rāgo dukkhāya paṭipattiyā patiṭṭhaṃ na labhatīti āha “dukkhāpaṭipadañca🔽nissāya rāgo vūpasammatī”ti. Sallekho nāma sampajānassa hoti, satisampajaññe moho
analyzed: sukhuma karaṇa sannissayaḥ rāgaḥ dukkhāya paṭipattiyā patiṭṭham na labhati iti āha dukkha apaṭipadam ca  nissāya rāgaḥ vūpasammati iti sallekho nāma sampajānassa hoti sati sampajaññe moho
translated: Lust, which is dependent on refinement, does not find a footing in the practice of austerity. Therefore it is said: “Lust is subdued by dependence on the practice of austerity.”

original: apatiṭṭhova appamādasambhavatoti vuttaṃ “sallekhaṃ nissāya appamattassa moho pahīyatī”ti.🔽Etthāti etesu dhutaṅgesu. Tatthāti araññarukkhamūlesu.
analyzed: apatiṭṭhaḥ uva appamāda sambhavato ti vuttam sallekham nissāya appamattassa moho pahīyati iti  ettha ati etesu dhutaṅgesu tattha ati arañña rukkha mūlesu
translated: Effacement is for one who is fully aware. Delusion is abandoned in one who is not negligent, because of the possibility of non-negligence in one who is established in mindfulness and full awareness. Therefore it is said: “Delusion is abandoned in one who is not negligent by dependence on effacement.”🔽Herein: among these ascetic practices. There: in the forest, at the foot of a tree, etc.

original: Sīsaṅgānīti sīsabhūtāni aṅgāni, paresampi kesañci nānantarikatāya, sukaratāya ca
analyzed: sīsaṅgāni iti sīsa bhūtāni aṅgāni na ānantarika tāya sukara tāya ca
translated: The head-hairs, etc.: the head-hairs, etc., are the limbs of the head, etc., because they are not separate from them, and because they are easy to see.

original: saṅgaṇhanato uttamaṅgānīti attho. Asambhinnaṅgānīti kehici sambhedarahitāni, visuṃyeva
analyzed: saṅgaṇhanataḥ uttamaṅgāni iti attho a sambhinna aṅgāni iti kehici sambheda rahitāni
translated: Unmixed limbs: without admixture with any other, that is, separate limbs.

original: aṅgānīti vuttaṃ hoti. Kammaṭṭhānaṃ vaḍḍhati rāgacaritassa mohacaritassa dosacaritassāpi,
analyzed: aṅgāni iti vuttam hoti kammaṭṭhānam vaḍḍhati rāga caritassa moha caritassa dosa caritassa api
translated: The meditation subject increases in one of greedy temperament, in one of deluded temperament, and in one of hating temperament too,🔽when he is practising one of the ascetic practices. The meaning is that it is the intention that it does so.

original: taṃ ekaccaṃ dhutaṅgaṃ sevantassāti adhippāyo. Hāyati kammaṭṭhānaṃ sukumārabhāvenalūkhapaṭipattiṃ
analyzed: tam ekaccam dhutaṅgam sevantassa ati adhippāyaḥ hāyati kammaṭṭhānam su kumāra bhāvena lūkha paṭipattim
translated: It decreases in one who cannot stand the rigours of the practice because of his delicacy.🔽The meaning is that it is the intention that it does so in one of great man’s temperament.

original: asahantassa. Vaḍḍhateva mahāpurisajātikassāti adhippāyo. Na vaḍḍhati kammaṭṭhānaṃ
analyzed: a sahantassa vaḍḍhatā iva mahāpurisa jātikassa ati adhippāyaḥ na vaḍḍhati kammaṭṭhānam
translated: It does not increase in one who lacks the right conditions.

original: upanissayarahitassa. Ekameva hi dhutaṅgaṃ yathā kilesadhunanaṭṭhena, evaṃ cetanāsabhāvattā.
analyzed: upanissaya rahitassa ekam eva hi dhutaṅgam yathā kilesa dhunana ṭṭhena evam cetanā sabhāva ttā
translated: For a single ascetic practice is enough to crush the defilements, as it is the state of his volition.

original: Tenāha “samādānacetanā”ti.
analyzed: tena āha samādāna cetanā ati
translated: That is why he said, “The volition of undertaking” .

original: Terasāpi dhutaṅgāni samādāya pariharantānaṃ puggalānaṃ vasena “dvācattālīsa hontī”ti
analyzed: terasa api dhutaṅgāni samādāya pariharantānam puggalānam vasena dvācattālīsa honti iti
translated: There are forty-two kinds of ascetic in virtue of the persons who undertake and carry out the thirteen ascetic practices.

original: vatvā bhikkhūnaṃ terasannampi pariharaṇassa ekajjhaṃyeva sambhavaṃ dassetuṃ “sace
analyzed: vatvā bhikkhūnam pariharaṇassa ekajjhaṃyā iva sambhavam dassetum sace
translated: Having said that, in order to show that it is only possible for monks to carry out all thirteen, he said, “If a monk undertakes all the thirteen” .

original: hī”tiādi vuttaṃ. Tattha “ekappahārena sabbadhutaṅgāni paribhuñjituṃ sakkotī”ti vuttaṃ.🔽Kathaṃ abbhokāse viharantassa rukkhamūlikaṅgaṃ? “Channaṃ paṭikkhipāmi, rukkhamūlikaṅgaṃ
analyzed: hi itiādi vuttam tattha eka ppahārena sabba dhutaṅgāni paribhuñjitum sakkoti iti vuttam  katham abbhokāse viharantassa rukkha mūlika aṅgam channam paṭikkhipāmi rukkha mūlika aṅgam
translated: “He is able to enjoy all the ascetic practices by the relinquishing of one” .

original: samādiyāmī”ti vacanato channe aruṇaṃ uṭṭhāpitamatte dhutaṅgaṃ bhijjati, na abbhokāse,
analyzed: samādiyāmi iti vacanataḥ channe aruṇam uṭṭhāpita matte dhutaṅgam bhijjati na abbhokāse
translated: How is it that the tree-root-dweller’s practice is included in the open-air-dweller’s practice? When one who lives in the open air makes a resolution thus, “I will not use a roof for so long as it rains or for so long as it is dark,” and then enters a tree root, his ascetic practice is not broken, but it is broken when the dawn has appeared.🔽But when one who is a tree-root-dweller makes a resolution thus, “I will not use a roof for so long as I live,” and then enters a house, his ascetic practice is broken.

original: tasmā bhedahetuno abhāvena tampi arogameva. Tathā senāsanaloluppassa abhāvena yathāsanthatikaṅganti
analyzed: tasmā bheda hetuno abhāvena tam pi arogam eva tathā senāsana loluppassa abhāvena yathā santhati kaṅganti
translated: So too with the “follower of what is given by donation”’s practice.🔽The “forest-dweller’s practice” is prohibited by the training precept about “giving up the dwelling” .

original: daṭṭhabbaṃ. Āraññikaṅgaṃ gaṇamhā ohīyanasikkhāpadena paṭikkhittaṃ, khalupacchābhattikaṅgaṃ🔽anatirittabhojanasikkhāpadena. Pavāritāya hi bhikkhuniyā atirittaṃ katvā bhuñjituṃ
analyzed: daṭṭhabbam āraññika aṅgam gaṇamhā ohīyana sikkhāpadena paṭikkhittam khalu pacchābhattika aṅgam  anatiritta bhojana sikkhāpadena pavāritāya hi bhikkhuniyā atirittam katvā bhuñjitum
translated: The “later-food-refuser’s practice” is prohibited by the training precept about “eating what has been accepted” .🔽For when a bhikkhuni has refused later food, she is not allowed to eat what has been accepted.

original: na labbhati. Kappiye ca vatthusmiṃ lolatāpahānāya dhutaṅgasamādānaṃ, na akappiye,
analyzed: na labbhati kappiye ca vatthusmim lola tā apahānāya dhutaṅga samādānam na a kappiye
translated: And the undertaking of an ascetic practice is for the purpose of abandoning greed for fine things, not for the purpose of using what is not allowable.

original: sikkhāpadeneva paṭikkhittattā. Aṭṭheva honti bhikkhuniyā saṃkaccikacīvarādīhi saddhiṃ
analyzed: sikkhāpadena iva paṭikkhitta ttā aṭṭhā iva honti bhikkhuniyā saṃkaccika cīvara ādīhi saddhim
translated: There are eight for the bhikkhunīs together with the “wrapped in one’s inner-robe” offence, etc.,🔽and five, making thirteen in all, which are reckoned as the triple-robe-material offence.

original: pañcapi ticīvarasaṅkhameva gacchantīti katvā. Yathāvuttesūti bhikkhūnaṃ vuttesu terasasu
analyzed: pañca api ti cīvara saṅkham eva gacchanti iti katvā yathāvuttesu iti bhikkhūnam vuttesu terasasu
translated: In the thirteen mentioned for the bhikkhus,

original: ticīvarādhiṭṭhānavinayakammābhāvato ṭhapetvā tecīvarikaṅgaṃ dvādasa sāmaṇerānaṃ.
analyzed: ti cīvara adhiṭṭhāna vinaya kamma abhāvataḥ ṭhapetvā tecīvarika aṅgam dvādasa sāmaṇerānam
translated: excepting the triple-robe-material condition, there are twelve for the male novices.🔽In the eight mentioned for the bhikkhunīs,

original: Sattāti bhikkhunīnaṃ vuttesu aṭṭhasu ekaṃ pahāya satta ticīvarādhiṭṭhānavinayakammābhāvato.🔽“Ṭhapetvā tecīvarikaṅga”nti hi imaṃ anuvattamānameva katvā “satta sikkhamānasāmaṇerīna”nti
analyzed: satta ti bhikkhunīnam vuttesu aṭṭhasu ekam pahāya satta ti cīvara adhiṭṭhāna vinaya kamma abhāvato  ṭhapetvā hi imam anuvattamānam eva katvā satta
translated: excepting one, there are seven for the female novices, because there is no triple-robe-material condition.🔽For the seven female novices, the female training-novices,🔽and the female novices, there are seven, making ten in all, which are reckoned as the triple-robe-material offence.🔽The words “excepting the triple-robe-material condition” are repeated in the text, and so it says “seven female training-novices and female novices.”🔽“Suitable” means suitable for the state of lay follower.

original: vuttaṃ. Patirūpānīti upāsakabhāvassa anucchavikāni.🔽Dhutaṅganiddesavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: vuttam patirūpāni iti upāsaka bhāvassa anucchavikāni  dhutaṅga niddesa vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The commentary on the description of the ascetic practices is finished.

original: Iti dutiyaparicchedavaṇṇanā.🔽3. Kammaṭṭhānaggahaṇaniddesavaṇṇanā
analyzed: iti dutiya pariccheda vaṇṇanā
translated: The commentary on the second chapter is finished.🔽The commentary on the description of the taking of meditation subjects

original: 38. Appicchatādīhīti appicchatāsantuṭṭhisallekhapavivekāpacayavīriyārambhādīhi. Pariyodāteti
analyzed: appiccha tā ādīhi iti appiccha tā santuṭṭhi sallekha paviveka apacaya vīriya ārambha ādīhi
translated: The words “in fewness of wishes, etc.” refer to fewness of wishes, contentment, effacement, seclusion, decrease in activity, and the undertaking of the ascetic practices.

original: suvisuddhe nirupakkilese. Imasmiṃ sīleti yathāvutte catupārisuddhisīle. “Cittaṃ bhāvaya”nti🔽imameva desanaṃ sandhāyāha “atisaṅkhepadesitattā”ti. Ko samādhīti sarūpapucchā. Kenaṭṭhena🔽samādhīti kena atthena samādhīti vuccati, “samādhī”ti padaṃ kaṃ abhidheyyatthaṃ nissāya🔽pavattanti attho. Katividhoti pabhedapucchā.
analyzed: su visuddhe nirupakkilese imasmin sīla iti yathā vutte catu pārisuddhi sīle cittam bhāvayanti  imam eva desanam sandhāya āha ati saṅkhepa desi tattā ati kaḥ samādhi iti sarūpa pucchā kenaṭṭhena  samādhi iti kena atthena samādhi iti vuccati samādhi iti padam kam abhidheyya ttham nissāya  pavattanti attho katividhaḥ ti pabheda pucchā
translated: he says this referring to this very teaching. “Because it is taught in brief”:

original: “Ko samādhī”ti kāmañcāyaṃ sarūpapucchā, vibhāgavantānaṃ pana sarūpavibhāvanaṃ vibhāgadassanamukheneva🔽hotīti vibhāgo tāva anavasesato dassetabbo. Taṃdassane ca ayamādīnavoti dassetuṃ🔽“samādhi bahuvidho”tiādi vuttaṃ. Tattha bahuvidhoti kusalādivasena anekavidho. Nānappakārakoti🔽ālambanamanasikārachandapaṇidhiadhimokkhaabhinīhārasaññānānattādinānappakāro. Na
analyzed: sarūpa pucchā vibhāgavantānam pana sarūpa vibhāvanam vibhāga dassana mukhena iva 🔽hoti iti vibhāgo tāva anavasesataḥ dassetabbo tad dassane ca ayam ādīnavaḥ ti dassetum 🔽samādhi bahuvidhaḥ tiādi vuttam tattha bahuvidhaḥ nānā pakārako ti 🔽ālambana manasikāra chanda paṇidhi adhimokkha abhinīhāra saññā nānatta ādi nānā pakāraḥ na
