original: sādheyyāti lokiyasamādhissa bhāvanā idha adhippetattho, tañca na sādheyya. Jhānavimokkhādīsu
analyzed: sādheyya ati lokiya samādhissa bhāvanā idha tat ca na sādheyya jhāna vimokkha ādīsu
translated: For if, in the case of the jhānas, etc.,

original: hi samādhiṃ uddharitvā tassa labbhamānehi vibhāgehi vissajjane kariyamāne jhānavibhaṅgādīsu🔽āgato sabbo samādhipabhedo vissajjetabbo siyā. Tathā ca sati yvāyaṃ lokiyasamādhissa
analyzed: hi samādhim uddharitvā tassa labbhamānehi vibhāgehi vissajjane kariyamāne jhāna vibhaṅga ādīsu  āgataḥ sabbaḥ samādhi pabhedaḥ vissajjetabbaḥ siyā tathā ca sati yvā ayam lokiya samādhissa
translated: concentration were extracted and answered by the various divisions that are applicable to it, then🔽all the divisions of concentration that occur in the Vibhaṅga, etc.,🔽would have to be answered. And if that were so, there would be no opportunity to answer the question about the development of mundane concentration,

original: bhāvanāvidhi adhippeto, tassa vissajjanāya okāsova na bhaveyya. Kiñca yenassa tikacatukkajhānikena🔽hīnādibhedabhinnena pavattivibhāgena brahmapārisajjādivasena navavidho, pañcamajjhānikena
analyzed: bhāvanā vidhi adhippeto tassa vissajjanāya okāsaḥ uva na bhaveyya kiñca yena assa tika catukka jhānikena  hīna ādi bheda bhinnena pavatti vibhāgena brahma pārisajja ādi vasena pañcamajjhānikena
translated: which is what is intended here. And further, the method of answering would be confused, since the method of answering would be this: ‘The method of answering is this: “The kind of manifestation of the jhāna that is of the first jhāna, etc.,

original: vehapphalādivasena dasavidho vā ekādasavidho vā bhavappabhedo nippajjati. Svāssa🔽pavattivibhāgo ayaṃ soti niddhāretvā vuccamāno vikkhepāya siyā, yathā taṃ avisaye.
analyzed: vehapphala ādi vasena dasavidhaḥ vā ekādasavidhaḥ vā bhava ppabhedaḥ nippajjati 🔽pavatti vibhāgaḥ ayam saḥ ti niddhāretvā vuccamānaḥ vikkhepāya siyā yathā tam avisaye
translated: is of nine kinds as the divine abodes of the Brahmā-world, etc., by the method of the first jhāna, etc., with applied thought and sustained thought, etc., and it is of ten kinds or of eleven kinds by the method of the fine-material sphere, etc., with the fifth jhāna, etc., and it is of twenty-two kinds or of thirty-three kinds by the method of the immaterial sphere, etc., with the base consisting of boundless space, etc.”’

original: Tenāha “uttari ca vikkhepāya saṃvatteyyā”ti. Kusalacittekaggatāti kusalā anavajjasukhavipākalakkhaṇā cittekaggatā.
analyzed: tena āha uttari ca vikkhepāya saṃvatteyyā ti kusala citta ekagga tā ati kusalā anavajja sukha vipāka lakkhaṇā citta ekagga tā
translated: Hence he said, “and it would be a condition for distraction” . “Concentration of cognizance that is profitable” : concentration of cognizance that is profitable, blameless, and of happy outcome.🔽“Fixing” is the fixing of the various kinds of cognizance and cognizance-concomitant that are not distracted in a single object.

original: Cittacetasikānaṃ samaṃ avisāravasena sampiṇḍentassa viya ādhānaṃ samādhānaṃ. Avisāralakkhaṇo
analyzed: citta cetasikānam samam avisāra vasena sampiṇḍentassa viya ādhānam samādhānam avisāra lakkhaṇo
translated: For concentration has the characteristic of non-distraction;🔽and its function is to unify.🔽Or concentration has the characteristic of non-distraction;

original: hi samādhi, sampiṇḍanaraso ca. Sammā avikkhipanavasena ādhānaṃ samādhānaṃ. Avikkhepalakkhaṇo
analyzed: hi samādhi sampiṇḍana raso ca sammā a vikkhipana vasena ādhānam samādhānam avikkhepa lakkhaṇo
translated: and its function is to crush distraction.

original: vā hi samādhi, vikkhepaviddhaṃsanaraso cāti. Svāyaṃ yasmā ekārammaṇe cittassa ṭhitihetu,
analyzed: vā hi samādhi vikkhepa viddhaṃsana rasaḥ ca ati yasmai eka ārammaṇe cittassa ṭhiti hetu
translated: And since it is the cause for the steadying of cognizance on a single object,🔽he said “ steadying is what is meant” .

original: tasmā “ṭhapananti vuttaṃ hotī”ti āha. Tathā hesa “cittassa ṭhiti saṇṭhiti avaṭṭhitī”ti
analyzed: tasmā ṭhapanam ti vuttam hoti iti āha tathā ha esa cittassa ṭhiti saṇṭhiti avaṭṭhiti iti
translated: For it is described thus: “ steadying of cognizance, steadying on, steadying in, steadying of cognizance” .

original: niddiṭṭho. Ekārammaṇaggahaṇañcettha samādhissa santānaṭṭhitibhāvadassanatthaṃ. Tathā
analyzed: niddiṭṭhaḥ eka ārammaṇa ggahaṇam ca ittha samādhissa santāna ṭṭhiti bhāva dassana ttham tathā
translated: And the mention of a single object here is in order to show that concentration is the steadying of the continuity of cognizance.

original: hissa aṭṭhakathāyaṃ dīpacciṭṭhiti nidassitā. Ānubhāvenāti balena, paccayabhāvenāti
analyzed: hissa aṭṭhakathā ayam nidassitā ānubhāvena ati balena paccaya bhāvena ati
translated: For in the commentary the steadying of the flame is demonstrated.🔽“By its influence” : by its power, by its conditionality.

original: attho. Avikkhipamānāti na vikkhipamānā vūpasamamānā. Upasamapaccupaṭṭhāno hi samādhi.
analyzed: atthaḥ a vikkhipamānā ti na vikkhipamānā vūpasamamānā upasama paccupaṭṭhānaḥ hi samādhi
translated: “Meaning” is the same as “purpose.” “Not distracted” means not distracted, not scattered. For concentration is the establishment of peace.

original: Etenassa vikkhepapaṭipakkhataṃ dasseti. Avippakiṇṇāti avisaṭā. Etena avisāralakkhaṇataṃ.🔽Sayaṃ na vikkhipati, sampayuttā vā na vikkhipanti etenāti avikkhepo, so lakkhaṇaṃ
analyzed: etena assa vikkhepa paṭipakkha tam dasseti a vippakiṇṇā ati a visaṭā etena a visāra lakkhaṇa tam  sayam na vikkhipati sampayuttāḥ vā na vikkhipanti etena ati avikkhepaḥ saḥ lakkhaṇam
translated: By this he shows its opposite to distraction. “Not scattered” means not diffused. By this he shows its characteristic of nondiffusion.🔽It is non-distraction because it does not itself distract or because it does not allow the associated states to distract. That is its characteristic.

original: etassāti avikkhepalakkhaṇo. Vikkhepaṃ viddhaṃseti, tathā vā sampajjatīti vikkhepaviddhaṃsanaraso.
analyzed: etassa iti avikkhepa lakkhaṇaḥ vikkhepam viddhaṃseti tathā vā sampajjati iti vikkhepa viddhaṃsana rasaḥ
translated: It is the characteristic of non-distraction. Its function is to dispel distraction, or it functions by causing that to come to be.

original: Uddhacce avikampanavasena paccupatiṭṭhati, sampayuttānaṃ vā taṃ paccupaṭṭhapetīti
analyzed: uddhacce a vikampana vasena paccupatiṭṭhati sampayuttānam vā tam paccupaṭṭhapeti iti
translated: It is the establishment of non-wavering, or it establishes the associated states in non-wavering, by means of the absence of agitation.

original: avikampanapaccupaṭṭhāno. Sukhanti nirāmisaṃ sukhaṃ daṭṭhabbaṃ.🔽39. Avikkhepalakkhaṇaṃ nāma samādhissa āveṇiko sabhāvo, na tenassa koci vibhāgo labbhatīti
analyzed: avikampana paccupaṭṭhānaḥ sukham ti nirāmisam sukham daṭṭhabbam  avikkhepa lakkhaṇam nāma samādhissa āveṇikaḥ sabhāvaḥ na tena assa koci vibhāgaḥ labbhati iti
translated: “Happiness” should be understood as the kind of happiness that is not sensual.🔽The characteristic of non-distraction is the individual essence of concentration. There is no division of it at all.🔽Hence he said, “It is singlefold as the characteristic of non-distraction.”

original: āha “avikkhepalakkhaṇena tāva ekavidho”ti. Sampayuttadhamme ārammaṇe appento viya
analyzed: āha avikkhepa lakkhaṇena tāva ekavidhaḥ ti sampayutta dhamme ārammaṇe appentaḥ viya
translated: It is as if it were drawing in the associated states and the object.

original: pavattatīti vitakko appanā. Tathā hi so “appanā byappanā”ti niddiṭṭho. Tappamukhatāvasena
analyzed: pavattati iti vitakkaḥ appanā tathā hi saḥ appanā byappanā iti niddiṭṭhaḥ tad pamukha tā vasena
translated: “It occurs” is absorption. For it is described as “absorption, full absorption” .

original: pana sabbasmiṃ mahaggatānuttare jhānadhamme “appanā”ti aṭṭhakathāvohāro. Tathā tassa
analyzed: pana sabbasmim mahaggata anuttare jhāna dhamme aṭṭhakathā vohāro tathā tassa
translated: But in the Commentaries the term “absorption” is used for all the jhāna factors in the four jhānas of the fine-material sphere and the four immaterial ones, which are called “great” and “supreme” respectively, according to the method of exposition in the Paṭisambhidā.🔽And the term “access” is used for the preliminary-work concentration that is the proximate basis for that absorption.

original: anuppattiṭṭhānabhūte parittajhāne upacāravohāro. Gāmādīnaṃ samīpaṭṭhāne gāmūpacārādisamaññā
analyzed: an uppatti ṭṭhāna bhūte paritta jhāne upacāra vohāraḥ gāma ādīnam samīpa ṭṭhāne gāma upacāra ādi samaññā
translated: Just as the term “access to a village” is used for a place near a village, etc.,

original: viyāti āha “upacārappanāvasena duvidho”ti. Idha pana samādhivasena veditabbaṃ. Lujjanapalujjanaṭṭhena🔽lokoti vuccati vaṭṭaṃ, tappariyāpannatāya loke niyutto, tattha vā viditoti lokiyo.
analyzed: viyā ti āha upacāra ppanā vasena duvidhaḥ ti idha pana samādhi vasena veditabbam lujjana palujjana ṭṭhena  loko ti vuccati vaṭṭam tad pariyāpanna tāya loke niyuttaḥ tattha vā viditaḥ iti lokiyaḥ
translated: so it is said that it is “of two kinds as access and absorption.” But here it should be understood as concentration.🔽The round of rebirths is called “the world” in the sense of being crushed , and he is called “worldly” because he is occupied with the world or because he is known in the world.

original: Tattha apariyāpannatāya lokato uttaro uttiṇṇoti lokuttaro. Kāmañcettha lokiyasamādhi🔽bhāvetabbabhāvena gayhati, ubhayaṃ pana ekajjhaṃ gahetvā tato itaraṃ niddhāretuṃ
analyzed: tattha a pariyāpanna tāya lokataḥ uttaraḥ uttiṇṇo ti lokuttaraḥ kāmañca ittha lokiya samādhi  bhāvetabba bhāvena gayhati ubhayam pana ekajjham gahetvā tatas itaram niddhāretum
translated: He is called “supramundane” because he is not included in the world or because he has risen above the world.

original: “lokiyalokuttaravasena duvidho”ti vuttaṃ. Sappītikanippītikavasenāti saha pītiyā
analyzed: lokiya lokuttara vasena duvidhaḥ iti vuttam sappītika nippītika vasena ati saha pītiyā
translated: Although it is the mundane concentration that is intended here, still the supramundane is mentioned because it is the latter that is primarily intended. But both are included in the single term “supramundane” in order to show that it is the culmination of the mundane.🔽“With happiness and bliss” .

original: vattatīti sappītiko, pītisampayutto. Natthi etassa pītīti nippītiko, pītivippayutto.
analyzed: vattati iti sappītikaḥ pīti sampayutto natthi etassa pīti iti nippītikaḥ pīti vippayutto
translated: It is accompanied by happiness because it is associated with happiness. It is not accompanied by happiness because it is not associated with happiness.

original: Tesaṃ vasena. Sukhena saha ekuppādādibhāvaṃ gatoti sukhasahagato, sukhasampayuttoti
analyzed: tesam vasena sukhena saha eka uppāda ādi bhāvam gataḥ ti sukha sahagataḥ sukha sampayuttaḥ ti
translated: It is accompanied by pleasure because it has gone over to the state of arising, etc., together with pleasure. It is associated with pleasure.

original: attho. Upekkhāsahagatepi eseva nayo. Upekkhāti cettha adukkhamasukhavedanā adhippetā.🔽Sā hi sukhadukkhākārapavattiṃ upekkhati majjhattākārasaṇṭhitattā. Sukhasahagata-padena
analyzed: atthaḥ upekkhā sahagate pi esā iva nayaḥ upekkhā ati ca ittha adukkham asukha vedanā adhippetā  sā hi sukha dukkha ākāra pavattim upekkhati majjhatta ākāra saṇṭhita ttā sukha sahagata padena
translated: The meaning is that. The same method applies in the case of that “accompanied by equanimity.” Herein, equanimity is intended as neither-painful-nor-pleasant feeling.🔽For that is indifferent to the occurrence of the aspect of pleasure and pain because it is placed in the middle.🔽By the phrase “accompanied by pleasure”

original: cettha sappītiko, nippītikekadeso ca saṅgahito, upekkhāsahagata-padena pana nippītikekadesovāti
analyzed: ca ittha sappītikaḥ nippītika ekadeso ca saṅgahitaḥ upekkhā sahagata padena pana nippītika ekadeso uvā ti
translated: the kind accompanied by happiness and the kind not accompanied by happiness are included. But by the phrase “accompanied by equanimity” only the kind not accompanied by happiness is included.

original: ayametesaṃ padānaṃ viseso.
analyzed: ayam etesam padānam visesaḥ
translated: This is the difference between the phrases.

original: Sabhāvato, paccayato, phalato ca majjhimapaṇītehi nihīno, tesaṃ vā guṇehi parihīnoti
analyzed: sabhāvataḥ paccayataḥ phalato ca majjhima paṇītehi nihīnaḥ tesam vā guṇehi parihīnaḥ ti
translated: It is inferior because it is inferior to the middle and superior kinds respectively as regards individual essence, condition, and fruit, or because it is deprived of their special qualities.

original: hīno, attano paccayehi padhānabhāvaṃ nīto paṇīto, ubhinnaṃ majjhe bhavo majjhimo.
analyzed: hīnaḥ attanaḥ paccayehi padhāna bhāvam nītaḥ paṇītaḥ ubhinnam majjhe bhavaḥ majjhimaḥ
translated: It is superior because it has been brought to the state of predominance of its own conditions. It is middle because it is between the other two.

original: Sampayogavasena pavattamānena saha vitakkena savitakko, saha vicārena savicāro, savitakko
analyzed: sampayoga vasena pavattamānena saha vitakkena sa vitakkaḥ saha vicārena sa vicāraḥ sa vitakkaḥ
translated: It is accompanied by applied thought, and it is accompanied by sustained thought, and it is accompanied by both applied and sustained thought.🔽The word “and” indicates that the jhāna is accompanied by happiness and bliss, and it is accompanied by unification of mind, and it is accompanied by all the other associated states such as the faculties, etc.🔽It is accompanied by applied thought because it occurs in association with applied thought, which is present.🔽It is accompanied by sustained thought because it is accompanied by sustained thought, which is present.

original: ca so savicāro cāti savitakkasavicāro. Ādi-saddena avitakkavicāramatto, avitakkāvicāro
analyzed: ca saḥ sa vicāro ca ati sa vitakka sa vicāraḥ ādi saddena a vitakka vicāra mattaḥ a vitakka avicāro
translated: It is accompanied by both applied and sustained thought because it is accompanied by both applied and sustained thought, which are present.🔽The word “and” indicates that the jhāna is accompanied by happiness and bliss, and it is accompanied by unification of mind, and it is accompanied by all the other associated states such as the faculties, etc.🔽It is accompanied by applied thought because it is accompanied by applied thought, which is present.🔽It is accompanied by sustained thought because it is accompanied by sustained thought, which is present.

original: ca gahito. Tattha vicārato uttari vitakkena sampayogābhāvato avitakko ca so vicāramatto
analyzed: ca gahitaḥ tattha vicārataḥ uttari vitakkena sampayoga abhāvataḥ avitakkaḥ ca saḥ vicāra matto
translated: It is accompanied by both applied and sustained thought because it is accompanied by both applied and sustained thought, which are present.🔽The word “and” indicates that the jhāna is accompanied by happiness and bliss, and it is accompanied by unification of mind, and it is accompanied by all the other associated states such as the faculties, etc.🔽It is accompanied by applied thought because it is accompanied by applied thought, which is present.🔽It is accompanied by sustained thought because it is accompanied by sustained thought, which is present.

original: cāti avitakkavicāramatto. Visesanivattiattho vā matta-saddo. Savitakkasavicāro hi
analyzed: ca ati a vitakka vicāra mattaḥ visesa nivatti atthaḥ vā matta saddo sa vitakka sa vicāraḥ hi
translated: It is accompanied by both applied and sustained thought because it is accompanied by both applied and sustained thought, which are present.🔽The word “and” indicates that the jhāna is accompanied by happiness and bliss, and it is accompanied by unification of mind, and it is accompanied by all the other associated states such as the faculties, etc.🔽It is accompanied by applied thought because it is accompanied by applied thought, which is present.🔽It is accompanied by sustained thought because it is accompanied by sustained thought, which is present.

original: samādhi vitakkavisiṭṭhena vicārena savicāro, ayaṃ pana vicāramattena vitakkasaṅkhātavisesarahitena,
analyzed: samādhi vitakka visiṭṭhena vicārena sa vicāraḥ ayam pana vicāra mattena vitakka saṅkhāta visesa rahitena
translated: It is accompanied by both applied and sustained thought because it is accompanied by both applied and sustained thought, which are present.🔽The word “and” indicates that the jhāna is accompanied by happiness and bliss, and it is accompanied by unification of mind, and it is accompanied by all the other associated states such as the faculties, etc.

original: tasmā avitakkavicāramatto. Atha vā bhāvanāya pahīnattā vitakkābhāvenāyaṃ vicāramatto,🔽na vicārato aññassa attano sampayuttadhammassa kassaci abhāvāti dassetuṃ avitakka-vacanena
analyzed: tasmai a vitakka vicāra mattaḥ atha vā bhāvanāya vitakka abhāvena ayam vicāra mattaḥ 🔽na vicārataḥ aññassa attanaḥ sampayutta dhammassa kassaci abhāvā ti dassetum a vitakka vacanena
translated: It is accompanied by applied thought because

original: vicāramatta-padaṃ visesetvā vuttaṃ. Ubhayarahito avitakkāvicāro. Pītisahagatādivasenāti
translated: and the plane of mere applied thought is distinguished. The plane without either is the fourth.🔽With the kinds of happiness, etc.,

original: pītisahagatasukhasahagataupekkhāsahagatavasena. Yadettha vattabbaṃ, taṃ sukhasahagataduke
analyzed: pīti sahagata sukha sahagata aupekkhā sahagata vasena yat ettha vattabbam tat sukha sahagata duke
translated: means with the kinds of happiness, bliss, and equanimity. What is to be said here has already been said in the case of the third jhāna.

original: vuttanayameva. Paṭipakkhehi samantato khaṇḍitattā paritto. Parittanti vā appamattakaṃ🔽vuccati, ayampi appānubhāvatāya paritto viyāti paritto. Kilesavikkhambhanato, vipulaphalato,
analyzed: vutta nayam eva paṭipakkhehi samantataḥ khaṇḍita ttā parittaḥ parittam ti vā appamattakam  vuccati ayam pi appa anubhāva tāya parittaḥ viyāti parittaḥ kilesa vikkhambhanato vipula phalato
translated: It is limited because it is completely shattered by its opposite. Or alternatively, it is called limited because it is small. This fourth jhāna is called limited because it is limited by the smallness of its domain, like a small pool.

original: dīghasantānato ca mahantabhāvaṃ gato, mahantehi vā uḷāracchandādīhi gato paṭipannoti
analyzed: dīgha santānataḥ ca mahanta bhāvam gataḥ mahantehi vā uḷāracchanda ādīhi gataḥ paṭipanno ti
translated: It has gone to greatness, or is entered upon the great, because it has reached a state of greatness through the suppression of defilements, through the fruit of greatness, and through the length of its continuity. Or alternatively, it has gone to the great, the great desire, etc., that is to say, the great faith, energy, mindfulness, concentration, and wisdom, and it is entered upon them.

original: mahaggato. Ārammaṇakaraṇavasenāpi natthi etassa pamāṇakaradhammā, tesaṃ vā paṭipakkhoti appamāṇo.
analyzed: mahaggataḥ ārammaṇa karaṇa vasena api na atthi etassa pamāṇa kara dhammā tesam vā paṭipakkho ti appamāṇaḥ
translated: It is immeasurable because there is no measuring it by thinking, “It is this,” or because there is no measuring of the things that cause it to be measured, or because its opposite is not measurable.

original: Paṭipajjati jhānaṃ etāyāti paṭipadā, pubbabhāgabhāvanā. Dukkhā kicchā paṭipadā etassāti
analyzed: paṭipajjati jhānam etāya ati paṭipadā pubbabhāga bhāvanā dukkhā kicchā paṭipadā etassa ati
translated: The way is the development in the prior stage. It is difficult and slow because it is difficult and slow for one of lust, etc., to enter upon and because it is difficult and slow to surmount the defilements there.

original: dukkhāpaṭipado. Pakatipaññāya abhivisiṭṭhattā abhiññā nāma appanāvahā bhāvanāpaññā,
analyzed: dukkha apaṭipadaḥ pakati paññāya abhivisiṭṭha ttā abhiññā nāma appanā vahā bhāvanā paññā
translated: and difficult progress. Understanding that is called direct-knowledge because it is distinguished by its natural keenness. It is understanding consisting in keeping in being, which leads to absorption.🔽He is of sluggish direct-knowledge because his direct-knowledge is sluggish, slow. He has difficult progress and sluggish direct-knowledge,

original: dandhā mandā abhiññā etassāti dandhābhiñño. Dukkhāpaṭipado ca so dandhābhiñño cāti🔽dukkhāpaṭipadādandhābhiñño, samādhi. Tadādivasena. Catujhānaṅgavasenāti catunnaṃ
analyzed: dandhā mandā abhiññā etassa ati dandha abhiññaḥ dukkha apaṭipado ca so dandha abhiñño ca ati  samādhi tad ādi vasena catujhā anaṅga vasena ati catunnam
translated: so he is of difficult progress and sluggish direct-knowledge.🔽By means of the four jhanas: by means of the factors of the four jhanas. This is said by way of the fourfold method.

original: jhānānaṃ aṅgabhāvavasena, catukkanayavasena cetaṃ vuttaṃ. Hānabhāgiyādivasenāti hānakoṭṭhāsikādivasena.🔽Samādhiekakadukavaṇṇanā
analyzed: jhānānam aṅga bhāva vasena catukka naya vasena ca itam vuttam hāna bhāgiya ādi vasena ati hāna koṭṭhāsika ādi vasena
translated: By means of the kinds of direct-knowledge: by means of the kinds of direct-knowledge beginning with the knowledge of pene-tration of hearts.🔽By means of the six kinds of direct-knowledge: by means of the six kinds of direct-knowledge beginning with the knowledge of recollection of past lives.

original: Channaṃ anussatiṭṭhānānanti buddhānussatiādīnaṃ channaṃ anussatikammaṭṭhānānaṃ. Imesaṃ
analyzed: channam anussati ṭṭhānānam ti buddha anussati ādīnam channam anussati kammaṭṭhānānam imesam
translated: By means of the six recollections: by means of the six kinds of meditation as subject of meditation beginning with recollection of the Buddha.

original: vasenāti imesaṃ dasannaṃ kammaṭṭhānānaṃ vasena. “Pubbabhāge ekaggatā”ti iminā appanāya
analyzed: vasena āti imesam dasannam kammaṭṭhānānam vasena pubbabhāge ekagga tā ti iminā appanāya
translated: By means of these ten kinds of meditation: by means of these ten kinds of meditation beginning with mindfulness occupied with the body.🔽By means of the four roads to power: by means of the four kinds of concentration of thought as a basis for success beginning with the concentration of desire.🔽By means of the four jhanas: by means of the four jhanas beginning with the first.🔽By means of the four immaterial states: by means of the four immaterial states beginning with the base consisting of boundless space.🔽By means of the six kinds of direct-knowledge: by means of the six kinds of direct-knowledge beginning with the knowledge of penetration of hearts.🔽By means of the eight liberations: by means of the eight kinds of concentration beginning with the attainment of the first jhana in the form realm after leaving the form of the fine-material-sphere jhana.

original: upakārakanānāvajjanupacārassapi saṅgaho daṭṭhabbo, na ekāvajjanasseva. Appanāsamādhīnanti
analyzed: upakāraka nānā vajjan upacārassa api saṅgahaḥ daṭṭhabbaḥ na eka āvajjanassa iva appanā samādhīnam ti
translated: By means of the nine successive cessations: by means of the nine kinds of concentration beginning with the attainment of the base consisting of neither perception nor non-perception after leaving the attainment of the cessation of perception and feeling.

original: upakattabbaupakārakasambandhe sāmivacanaṃ “purisassa attho”tiādīsu viya. Parikammanti
analyzed: upakattabba aupakāraka sambandhe sāmi vacanam purisassa atthaḥ ti ādīsu viya parikammanti
translated: The word “master” is used in the sense of one who has the right to employ another, as in the expression “the master’s business” .🔽The “preliminary work” is the “change-of-lineage” knowledge.

original: gotrabhu. Aparitto samādhīti dassetuṃ “paṭhamassa jhānassā”tiādi vuttaṃ.
analyzed: aparitto samādhi iti dassetum paṭhamassa jhānassa atiādi vuttam
translated: The words “of the first jhāna” and so on are stated in order to show that the concentration is not limited to the first jhāna only.🔽In the three planes: in the sense-desire, fine-material, and immaterial planes.

original: Tīsu bhūmīsūti kāmarūpārūpabhūmīsu. Kusalacittekaggatāya adhippetattā “ariyamaggasampayuttā”ti🔽vuttaṃ. Siyā sappītiko, siyā nippītikoti aniyamavacanaṃ upacārasamādhisāmaññena sabbesampi
analyzed: tīsu bhūmīsu uti kāmarūpa arūpa bhūmīsu kusala citta ekagga tāya adhippeta ttā ariya magga sampayuttā ati  vuttam siyā sappītiko siyā nippītiko ti aniyama vacanam upacāra samādhi sāmaññena sabbesam pi
translated: The words “associated with noble paths” are stated because the unification of mind is intended here as a profitable unification.🔽It may be accompanied by rapture or it may be accompanied by equanimity: this is said because there is no certainty.

original: vā jhānānaṃ nānāvajjanavīthiyaṃ upacārasamādhi siyā sappītiko, siyā nippītiko. Ekāvajjanavīthiyaṃ
analyzed: vā jhānānam nānā vajjana vīthiyam upacāra samādhi siyā sappītikaḥ siyā nippītikaḥ eka āvajjana vīthiyam
translated: Or else, in the case of all jhānas, the preliminary-work concentration may be accompanied by rapture or it may be accompanied by equanimity, because of the similarity of the preliminary-work concentration to the access concentration.

original: pana ādito dukatikajjhānānaṃ upacārasamādhi sappītikova, itaresaṃ nippītikova, visabhāgavedanassa
analyzed: pana āditas dukatika jhānānam upacāra samādhi sappītikaḥ uva itaresam nippītikaḥ uva visa bhāga vedanassa
translated: But in the case of the first three jhānas, the preliminary-work concentration is only accompanied by rapture in the course of a series of consciousnesses that have different objects.🔽In a series of consciousnesses that have the same object, it is only accompanied by equanimity, because a consciousness that has a different object cannot be a condition by way of repetition for the first three jhānas, and because there is no alternation of feeling in a single cognitive series.

original: cittassa āsevanapaccayatābhāvato, ekavīthiyaṃ vedanāparivattanābhāvato ca. Siyā sukhasahagato,
analyzed: cittassa āsevana paccaya tā bhāvataḥ eka vīthiyam vedanā parivattana abhāvataḥ ca siyā sukha sahagataḥ
translated: It may be connected with pleasure,

original: siyā upekkhāsahagatoti etthāpi vuttanayeneva attho veditabbo. Tattha pana “dukatikajjhānāna”nti
analyzed: siyā upekkhā sahagataḥ ti ettha api vutta nayena iva atthaḥ veditabbo tattha pana dukatika jhānānam ti
translated: and may be accompanied by equanimity. The meaning should be understood here in the way already stated. But there it is said “in the three kinds of jhāna,”

original: vuttaṃ, idha “tikacatukkajjhānāna”nti vattabbaṃ.
analyzed: vuttam idha tika catukka jjhānānam ti vattabbam
translated: while here it should be said “in the three and four kinds of jhāna.”

original: Samādhitikavaṇṇanā🔽Paṭiladdhamattoti adhigatamatto anāsevito abahulīkato. So hi paridubbalabhāvena hīno
analyzed: samādhitika vaṇṇanā  paṭiladdha mattaḥ iti adhigata mattaḥ anāsevitaḥ a bahulīkataḥ saḥ hi paridubbala bhāvena hīnaḥ
translated: The explanation of the three kinds of concentration🔽Has only been acquired: has only been reached, only been attained, only been obtained, only been mastered, only been brought to. It is inferior because it is weak.

original: hoti. Nātisubhāvitoti ativiya paguṇabhāvaṃ apāpito. Subhāvitoti suṭṭhu bhāvito sammadeva
analyzed: hoti na ati su bhāvito ti ativiya paguṇa bhāvam a pāpito su bhāvito ti suṭṭhu bhāvito sammad eva
translated: Not well developed: not made very familiar. Well developed: well made familiar, well completed.

original: paguṇataṃ upanīto. Tenāha “vasippatto”ti. Chandādīnaṃ hīnatādivasenāpi imesaṃ hīnāditā🔽veditabbā. Tathā hi uḷārapuññaphalakāmatāvasena pavattito hīno, lokiyābhiññāsampādanāya
analyzed: tena āha vasi ppatto tena āha vasi ppatto ti chanda ādīnam hīna tā ādi vasena api imesam hīna ādi tā  veditabbā tathā hi uḷāra puñña phala kāma tā vasena pavattitaḥ hīnaḥ lokiya abhiññā sampādanāya
translated: Hence it is said, “he has mastery in attaining it.”🔽It should be understood that these are inferior, medium, and superior according to inferiority, etc., of desire, etc.,

original: pavattito majjhimo, vivekakāmatāya ariyabhāve ṭhitena pavattito paṇīto. Attahitāya
analyzed: pavattitaḥ majjhimaḥ viveka kāmatāya ariya bhāve ṭhitena pavattitaḥ paṇītaḥ atta hitāya
translated: for it is inferior when it occurs with a desire for the fruit of abundant merit, medium when it occurs for the sake of mundane direct-knowledge,🔽and superior when it occurs in one who is a noble person and has a desire for seclusion.

original: bhavasampattiatthaṃ pavattito vā hīno, kevalaṃ alobhajjhāsayena pavattito majjhimo,
analyzed: bhava sampatti attham pavattitaḥ vā hīnaḥ kevalam alobha ajjhāsayena pavattitaḥ majjhimo
translated: Or it is inferior when it occurs for the sake of one’s own welfare, medium when it occurs for the sake of wealth,

original: parahitāya pavattito paṇīto. Vaṭṭajjhāsayena vā pavattito hīno, vivekajjhāsayena
analyzed: para hitāya pavattitaḥ paṇītaḥ vaṭṭa ajjhāsayena vā pavattitaḥ hīnaḥ viveka jjhāsayena
translated: It is inferior when it occurs with the inclination to the round of rebirths,

original: pavattito majjhimo, vivaṭṭajjhāsayena lokuttarapādakatthaṃ pavattito paṇīto.
analyzed: pavattitaḥ majjhimaḥ lokuttara pādaka ttham pavattitaḥ paṇītaḥ
translated: medium when it occurs with the inclination to seclusion, and superior when it occurs with the inclination to the supramundane path that leads out of the round of rebirths.

original: Saddhiṃ upacārasamādhināti sabbesampi jhānānaṃ upacārasamādhinā saha. Vitakkamatteyeva🔽ādīnavaṃ disvāti vitakkeyeva oḷārikato upaṭṭhahante “cittassa khobhakaradhammo aya”nti
analyzed: saddhim upacāra samādhinā ti sabbesam pi jhānānam upacāra samādhinā saha  ādīnavam disvā ati oḷārikataḥ upaṭṭhahante cittassa khobha kara dhammo ayanti
translated: “Together with access concentration”: together with the concentration of the neighbourhood of jhāna.🔽Seeing danger in applied thought alone: seeing danger in applied thought only, which appears gross,🔽he sees danger in it thus: “It disturbs the mind.”

original: ādīnavaṃ disvā vicārañca santato manasi karitvā. Tenāha “vicāre adisvā”ti. Taṃ sandhāyāti
analyzed: ādīnavam disvā vicāram ca santataḥ manasi karitvā tena āha vicāre tam sandhāya ati
translated: With reference to that: with reference to that concentration thus acquired.

original: taṃ evaṃ paṭiladdhaṃ samādhiṃ sandhāya. Etaṃ “avitakkavicāramatto samādhī”ti dutiyapadaṃ🔽vuttaṃ. Tīsūti ādito tīsu.
analyzed: tam evam paṭiladdham samādhim sandhāya etam samādhi iti dutiya padam  vuttam tīsu iti āditaḥ tīsu
translated: The second phrase “the jhāna that is access concentration accompanied by happiness and applied thought” is stated.🔽In the first three: in the first three of the four kinds of fine-material-sphere jhāna.

original: Tesvevāti tesu eva catukkapañcakanayesu. Tatiye catuttheti catukkanaye tatiye, pañcakanaye
analyzed: tesu eva ati tesu eva catukka pañcaka nayesu tatiye catuttha iti catukka naye tatiye pañcaka naye
translated: In the third and fourth: in the third of the four kinds and in the fourth of the five kinds.

original: catuttheti yojetabbaṃ. Avasāneti dvīsupi nayesu pariyosānajjhāne. Yathākkamaṃ catutthe,
analyzed: catutthe iti yojetabbam avasāne iti dvīsu pi nayesu pariyosāna jhāne yathākkamam catutthe
translated: and the fourth should be construed in each case. The end is the last jhāna in each of the two ways. In the first way it is the fourth,

original: pañcame vā. Pītisukhasahagato vāti etthāpi heṭṭhā vuttanayeneva attho veditabbo.
analyzed: pañcame vā pīti sukha sahagataḥ vā ti ettha api heṭṭhā vutta nayena iva atthaḥ veditabbo
translated: in the second way it is the fifth. Associated with happiness and bliss: the meaning should be understood here in the way already stated.

original: Ettha ca satipi pītisahagatassāpi samādhissa sukhasahagatatte tīṇipi padāni asaṅkarato
analyzed: ettha ca sati pi pīti sahagatassa api samādhissa sukha sahagata tte tīṇi pi padāni asaṅkarato
translated: And although concentration associated with happiness exists, the three terms are given in order to show that it is not confused with the bliss associated with happiness.

original: dassetuṃ nippītikasukhato sappītikasukhassa visesadassanatthaṃ satthu pītitikadesanāti
analyzed: dassetum nippītika sukhataḥ sat pītika sukhassa visesa dassana tham satthu pītitika desanā ti
translated: And the Master’s teaching of the words “happiness” , etc., is for the purpose of showing the difference between the bliss without happiness and the bliss with happiness.

original: nippītikasseva sukhassa vasena sukhasahagato samādhi gahitoti daṭṭhabbo.🔽Upacārabhūmiyanti upacārajjhānasampayuttacittuppāde. Cittuppādo hi sahajātadhammānaṃ
analyzed: nippītikassa iva sukhassa vasena sukha sahagataḥ samādhi gahito ti daṭṭhabbo  upacāra bhūmiyanti upacāra jhāna sampayutta cittuppāde cittuppādaḥ hi sahajāta dhammānam
translated: So it should be regarded as concentration associated with bliss in the sense of the bliss without happiness that is stated.

original: uppattiṭṭhānatāya “bhūmī”ti vuccati “sukhabhūmiyaṃ kāmāvacare”tiādīsu viya. Paritto
analyzed: uppatti ṭṭhāna tāya bhūmī iti vuccati sukha bhūmiyam kāmāvacara iti ādīsu viya parittaḥ
translated: The plane of access: in the consciousness associated with the access jhāna. For the arising of consciousness is called “the plane” of the states that are conascent with it, as in such passages as “In the plane of pleasure, in the plane of neither-perception-nor-non-perception” .

original: samādhi kāmāvacarabhāvato.
analyzed: samādhi kāma avacara bhāvataḥ
translated: The limited concentration is so called because it is limited by the sense sphere.

original: Samādhicatukkavaṇṇanā
translated: The Description of the Four Kinds of Concentration

original: Paṭhamasamannāhāro bhāvanaṃ ārabhantassa “pathavī pathavī”tiādinā kammaṭṭhāne paṭhamābhiniveso.🔽Tassa tassa jhānassa upacāranti nīvaraṇavitakkavicāranikantiādīnaṃ vūpasame thirabhūtaṃ
analyzed: paṭhama samannāhāraḥ bhāvanam ārabhantassa pathavī pathavī iti ādinā kammaṭṭhāne paṭhama abhiniveso  tassa tassa jhānassa nīvaraṇa vitakka vicāra nikanti ādīnam vūpasame thira bhūtam
translated: The first is the first directing of attention to the meditation subject in the words “earth, earth” and so on.🔽The access of each jhāna is the jhāna of the base pertaining to sense desire that is firm in the stilling of the hindrances, applied thought, and sustained thought, and so on.

original: kāmāvacarajjhānaṃ. “Yāva appanā”ti iminā pubbabhāgapaññāya eva abhiññābhāvo vutto🔽viya dissatīti vadanti. Appanāpaññā pana abhiññāva. Yadaggena hi pubbabhāgapaññāya
analyzed: kāmāvacara jhānam yāva appanā ti iminā pubbabhāga paññāya eva abhiññā bhāvaḥ vutto  viya dissati iti vadanti appanā paññā pana abhiññā ava yad aggena hi pubbabhāga paññāya
translated: By the words “up to absorption” it is shown that the understanding of the preliminary-work stage is like the direct-knowledge,🔽they say. But the understanding of absorption is direct-knowledge. For just as the understanding of the preliminary-work stage is sluggish and slow,

original: dandhasīghatā, tadaggena appanāpaññāyapīti. Samudācāragahaṇatāyāti samudācārassa🔽gahaṇabhāvena, pavattibāhullatoti attho. Asukhāsevanāti kasirabhāvanā.
analyzed: tad aggena samudācāra gahaṇa tāya ati samudācārassa  gahaṇa bhāvena pavatti bāhullato ti attho asukha āsevanā ati kasira bhāvanā
translated: so too is the understanding of absorption. “By the inclusion of the occurrence” means by the inclusion of the occurrence, that is, by the abundance of occurrence.🔽“Not easy to practice” is slow development.

original: Palibodhupacchedādīnīti ādi-saddena bhāvanāvidhānāparihāpanādiṃ saṅgaṇhāti. Asappāyasevīti
analyzed: pali bodha upaccheda ādīni iti ādi saddena bhāvanā vidhāna a parihāpana ādim saṅgaṇhāti a sappāya sevī iti
translated: By the inclusion of the cutting off of hindrances, and so on: the word “and so on” includes the non-abandoning of the development method, and so on. “By the use of what is unsuitable” means that the painful practice is due to the use of what is unsuitable before the attainment of access.

original: upacārādhigamato pubbe asappāyasevitāya dukkhā paṭipadā. Pacchā asappāyasevitāya
analyzed: upacāra adhigamataḥ pubbe a sappāya sevitāya dukkhā paṭipadā pacchā a sappāya sevitāya
translated: After that, the painful practice is due to the use of what is unsuitable.

original: dandhā abhiññā hoti. Sappāyasevinoti etthāpi eseva nayo. Pubbabhāgeti upacārajjhānādhigamato🔽orabhāge. Aparabhāgeti tato uddhaṃ. Tassa vomissakatāti yo pubbabhāge asappāyaṃ sevitvā
analyzed: dandhā abhiññā hoti sappāya sevino ti ettha api esa iva nayaḥ pubbabhāge iti upacāra jhāna adhigamato  ora bhāge apara bhāge iti tatas uddham tassa yaḥ pubba bhāge asappāyam sevitvā
translated: and his direct-knowledge is sluggish. The same method applies here. The first part is the part prior to the attainment of access concentration.🔽The second part is the part after that. The first type is one who, after cultivating the unprofitable,🔽cultivates the profitable in the second part. His way is painful and his direct-knowledge is sluggish. The second type is one who, after cultivating the unprofitable in the first part,

original: aparabhāge sappāyasevī, tassa dukkhā paṭipadā khippābhiññā. Itarassa sukhā paṭipadā🔽dandhābhiññā hoti. Evaṃ paṭhamacatutthānaṃ vomissakatāya dutiyatatiyāti attho. Akatapalibodhupacchedassa
analyzed: aparabhāge sappāya sevī tassa dukkhā paṭipadā khippa abhiññā itarassa sukhā paṭipadā  dandha abhiññā hoti evam paṭhama catutthānam vomissaka tāya dutiya tatiyā ti atthaḥ a kata palibodha upacchedassa
translated: cultivates the profitable in the second part. His way is pleasant and his direct-knowledge is sluggish. The third type is one who, after cultivating the profitable in the first part,🔽cultivates the profitable in the second part. His way is pleasant and his direct-knowledge is sluggish. The fourth type is one who, after cultivating the profitable in the first part,🔽cultivates the profitable in the second part. His way is painful and his direct-knowledge is sluggish. The fifth type is one who, after cultivating the profitable in the first part,🔽cultivates the profitable in the second part. His way is painful and his direct-knowledge is sluggish. The sixth type is one who, after cultivating the profitable in the first part,

original: saparipanthatāya paṭipadā dukkhā hoti, itarassa sukhā. Asampāditaappanākosallassa🔽ñāṇassa avisadatāya dandhā abhiññā hoti, visadatāya khippā abhiññā.
analyzed: sa paripantha tāya paṭipadā dukkhā hoti itarassa sukhā a sampādita appanā kosallassa  ñāṇassa a visada tāya dandhā abhiññā hoti visada tāya khippā abhiññā
translated: cultivates the profitable in the second part. His way is pleasant and his direct-knowledge is sluggish. The seventh type is one who, after cultivating the profitable in the first part,🔽cultivates the profitable in the second part. His way is pleasant and his direct-knowledge is sluggish. The eighth type is one who, after cultivating the profitable in the first part,🔽cultivates the profitable in the second part. His way is pleasant and his direct-knowledge is sluggish. The ninth type is one who, after cultivating the profitable in the first part,🔽cultivates the profitable in the second part. His way is pleasant and his direct-knowledge is sluggish. The tenth type is one who, after cultivating the profitable in the first part,🔽cultivates the profitable in the second part. His way is pleasant and his direct-knowledge is sluggish. The eleventh type is one who, after cultivating the profitable in the first part,

original: Taṇhāavijjāvasenāti taṇhāavijjānaṃ abhibhavānabhibhavavasena. Samathavipassanādhikāravasenāti
analyzed: taṇhā avijjā vasena ati taṇhā avijjānam abhibhava anabhibhava vasena samatha vipassanā adhikāra vasena ati
translated: cultivates the profitable in the second part. His way is pleasant and his direct-knowledge is sluggish. The twelfth type is one who, after cultivating the profitable in the first part,🔽cultivates the profitable in the second part. His way is pleasant and his direct-knowledge is sluggish. The thirteenth type is one who, after cultivating the

original: samathavipassanāsu asato, sato ca adhikārassa vasena. Taṇhāya samādhissa ujupaṭipakkhattā
analyzed: samatha vipassanāsu asataḥ sataḥ ca adhikārassa vasena taṇhāya samādhissa uju paṭipakkha ttā
translated: Because craving is the direct opponent of concentration,

original: sā samathapaṭipadāya paripanthinīti āha “taṇhābhibhūtassa hi dukkhā paṭipadā hotī”ti.
analyzed: sā samatha paṭipadāya paripanthinī iti āha taṇhā abhibhūtassa hi dukkhā paṭipadā hoti iti
translated: it is said that “the path is difficult for one overcome by craving” .

original: Abhibhavo cassā itarakilesehi adhikatāya anabhibhūtassa taṇhāyāti adhikārato veditabbaṃ.
analyzed: abhibhavaḥ ca assāḥ itara kilesehi adhikatāya an abhibhūtassa taṇhāya ati adhikārataḥ veditabbam
translated: And the overcoming of it by other defilements should be understood as the practice of insight, since it is not overcome by craving.

original: Tathā avijjā paññāya ujupaṭipakkhāti tadabhibhūtassa dandhābhiññatā vuttā. Akatādhikāroti
analyzed: tathā avijjā paññāya uju paṭipakkhā ati tad abhibhūtassa dandhābhiñña tā vuttā a kata adhikāraḥ ti
translated: Similarly, ignorance is the direct opponent of understanding, so the path is said to be slow for one overcome by it.

original: bhavantare akataparicayo yathā paguṇaṃ katvā vissaṭṭhagantho appamattakena payogena
analyzed: bhavantare a kata paricayaḥ yathā paguṇam katvā vissaṭṭha gantho appamattakena payogena
translated: One who has not previously practiced is like a text that has not been used for a long time and is all stuck together, which, though it may be unfolded with little difficulty,

original: suppavatti vācuggatova hoti, evaṃ pubbe kataparicayassa bhāvanā appakasireneva ijjhatīti
analyzed: su pavatti vācuggataḥ va hoti evam pubbe kata paricayassa bhāvanā appa kasirena iva ijjhati iti
translated: yet is hard to handle because the letters do not move freely. So too, the development of insight is successful with difficulty for one who has not previously practiced.

original: āha “katādhikārassa sukhā”ti. Svāyaṃ akato, kato ca adhikāro samathanissito paṭipadāyaṃ
analyzed: āha kata adhikārassa sukhāti svāyam akataḥ kataḥ ca adhikāro samatha nissito paṭipadā ayam
translated: That is why it is said that “the path is difficult for one who has not previously practiced” .🔽And this practice, whether previously done or not, is said to be in the path of serenity, which is based on concentration,

original: vutto samādhippadhānattā paṭipadāya. Vipassanānissito abhiññāyaṃ ñāṇappadhānattā
analyzed: vuttaḥ samādhi ppadhāna ttā paṭipadāya vipassanā nissitaḥ abhiññāyam ñāṇa ppadhāna ttā
translated: and in the path of insight, which is based on understanding.

original: appanāya. Kilesindriyavasenāti tikkhātikkhānaṃ kilesindriyānaṃ vasena. Tenāha “tibbakilesassā”tiādi.
analyzed: appanāya kilesa indriya vasena āti tikkha atikkhānam kilesa indriyānam vasena tena āha tibba kilesassa ātiādi
translated: and absorption. “By the defilements and the faculties”: by the defilements and the faculties that are sharp or very sharp. Hence he says: “of one with strong defilements” and so on.

original: Tattha kilesā kāmacchandādayo, indriyāni saddhādīni.🔽Yathāvuttā paṭipadābhiññā puggalādhiṭṭhānāti dhammaniddesampi puggalādhiṭṭhānamukhena
analyzed: kilesā kāma chanda ādayaḥ indriyāni saddhā ādīni  yathā vuttā paṭipadābhiññā puggala adhiṭṭhānā ti dhamma niddesam pi puggala adhiṭṭhāna mukhena
translated: Herein, the defilements are lust, etc., and the faculties are faith, etc.🔽The path and direct-knowledge as stated are illustrated by way of the person.

original: dassetuṃ “yo puggalo”tiādi vuttaṃ. Appaguṇoti na subhāvito vasībhāvaṃ apāpito. Tenāha
analyzed: dassetum yaḥ puggalaḥ tiādi vuttam appaguṇo ti na su bhāvitaḥ vasībhāvam tena āha
translated: To show the exposition of the Dhamma by way of the person, he says: “The person who” and so on. “Not developed” : not well cultivated, not brought to mastery. Hence he says:

original: “uparijhānassa paccayo bhavituṃ na sakkotī”ti. Ayaṃ parittoti ayaṃ samādhi appānubhāvatāya
analyzed: upari jhānassa paccayaḥ bhavitum na sakkoti iti ayam parittaḥ ti ayam samādhi appa anubhāva tāya
translated: “is not able to be a condition for the higher jhāna.” “This is limited” : this concentration is limited because of its small potency.

original: paritto. Avaḍḍhiteti ekaṅguladvaṅgulamattampi na vaḍḍhite yathāupaṭṭhite ārammaṇe.
analyzed: parittaḥ a vaḍḍhita iti ekaṅgula dvaṅgula mattam pi na vaḍḍhite yathā upaṭṭhite ārammaṇe
translated: “Not extended” : not extended even to the extent of an inch or two, but only to the extent that it occurs in the object as it is placed.

original: Ekaṅgulamattampi hi vaḍḍhitaṃ appamāṇamevāti vadanti. “Paguṇo subhāvito”ti vatvā
analyzed: eka aṅgula mattam pi hi vaḍḍhitam appamāṇam eva ati vadanti paguṇaḥ su bhāvitaḥ iti vatvā
translated: For they say that even an inch extended is immeasurable. “Having made it familiar and well developed”

original: “uparijhānassa paccayo bhavituṃ sakkotī”ti iminā yathā paguṇopi uparijhānassa paccayo
analyzed: upari jhānassa paccayaḥ bhavitum sakkoti iti iminā yathā paguṇaḥ api upari jhānassa paccayaḥ
translated: and “is able to be a condition for the higher jhāna” he shows how, even though familiar, it is able to be a condition for the higher jhāna

original: bhavituṃ asakkonto samādhi parittoyeva hoti, na appamāṇo, evaṃ ñāṇuttarassa ekāsaneneva🔽uparijhānanibbattanenāti subhāvitopi uparijhānassa paccayabhāvasaṅkhātāya subhāvitakiccasiddhiyā
analyzed: bhavitum a sakkontaḥ samādhi hoti na appamāṇaḥ evam ñāṇuttarassa eka āsanena iva  upari jhāna nibbattanena ati su bhāvitaḥ api upari jhānassa paccaya bhāva saṅkhātāya su bhāvita kicca siddhiyā
translated: If it cannot do so, it is only limited, not measureless. So too with knowledge- supremacy.🔽With the production of the higher jhāna: even though it is well developed, it is called “limited” if it is not successful in accomplishing the function of being the proximate cause for the higher jhāna.

original: “appamāṇo”tveva vuccati. Apare pana sace subhāvito paguṇo vasībhāvaṃ patto uparijhānassa
analyzed: appamāṇaḥ tu eva vuccati apare pana sace su bhāvito paguṇaḥ vasībhāvam patto upari jhānassa
translated: But others say that even if it is not the proximate cause for the higher jhāna, it is measureless if it has reached the state of being well developed, purified, and matured.

original: paccayo ahontopi appamāṇo eva, pamāṇakarānaṃ rāgādipaṭipakkhānaṃ suvidūrabhāvatoti🔽vadanti. Vuttalakkhaṇavomissatāyāti yo appaguṇo uparijhānassa paccayo bhavituṃ na🔽sakkoti, vaḍḍhite ārammaṇe pavatto, ayaṃ paritto appamāṇārammaṇo. Yo pana paguṇo
analyzed: paccayaḥ a hontaḥ api appamāṇaḥ eva pamāṇa karānam rāga ādi paṭipakkhānam su vidūra bhāvato ti  vadanti vutta lakkhaṇa vomissa tāya ati yaḥ appaguṇaḥ upari jhānassa paccayaḥ bhavitum na  sakkoti vaḍḍhite ārammaṇe pavatto ayam parittaḥ appamāṇa ārammaṇaḥ yaḥ pana paguṇaḥ
translated: Because it is far removed from the opposing states of greed, etc., which are the cause for the limited.

original: uparijhānassa paccayo bhavituṃ sakkoti, avaḍḍhite ārammaṇe pavatto, ayaṃ appamāṇo
analyzed: upari jhānassa paccayaḥ bhavitum sakkoti avaḍḍhite ārammaṇe pavattaḥ ayam appamāṇo
translated: With the omission of the characteristic: that which is not well developed, which is not purified, which is not matured, which cannot be the proximate cause for the higher jhāna, which occurs with a limited object, is limited. But that which is well developed, purified, matured, which can be the proximate cause for the higher jhāna, which occurs with an immeasurable object, is measureless.

original: parittārammaṇoti evaṃ paṭhamacatutthasamādhīnaṃ vuttalakkhaṇassa vomissakabhāvena
analyzed: paritta ārammaṇaḥ ti evam paṭhama catuttha samādhīnam vutta lakkhaṇassa vomissaka bhāvena
translated: So the first and fourth jhānas are respectively limited and measureless because of the omission of the characteristic stated in the way already given.

original: dutiyatatiyasamādhisaṅgāhako vomissakanayo veditabbo.
analyzed: dutiya tatiya samādhi saṅgāhakaḥ vomissaka nayaḥ veditabbo
translated: The method of omission should be understood as the second and third jhānas’ inclusion of the first jhāna’s factors.

original: Tatoti tato paṭhamajjhānato uddhaṃ. Virattapītikanti atikkantapītikaṃ vā jigucchitapītikaṃ
analyzed: tatas ti tatas paṭhamajjhānataḥ uddham viratta pītikam ti atikkanta pītikam vā jigucchita pītikam

analyzed: patiṭṭhāna vasena sā pana tad assāda saṅkhātā tad assāda sampayutta kkhandha saṅkhātā

analyzed: vā micchā satī ti sammoha vinodaniyam vuttam tattha sa apekkhassa upari visesam nibbattetum

analyzed: satiyā vā nikantiyā vā ti vikappa vacanam ca yuttam hoti visesa adhigama vasena ati visesa adhigamassa

analyzed: nibbidā sahagata saññā manasikāra samudācāra vasena ati ādīnava dassana pubbaṅgama nibbindana ñāṇa sampayutta saññāya
translated: It is called “wrong reflection” because it is the cause of the arising of wrong view.🔽But it is called “wrong reflection” because it is associated with wrong view, or because it is the cause of wrong view.🔽It is called “wrong reflection” because it is the cause of the arising of wrong view.

analyzed: ca ābhogassa ca pavatti vasena nibbedha bhāgiya tā ati saccānam nibbijjhana pakkhika tā
translated: But it is called “wrong reflection” because it is associated with wrong view, or because it is the cause of wrong view.

original: vipassanāya saṃvattatīti attho.
analyzed: vipassanāya saṃvattati iti atthaḥ
translated: It is called “wrong reflection” because it is the cause of the arising of wrong view.🔽But it is called “wrong reflection” because it is associated with wrong view, or because it is the cause of wrong view.🔽It is called “wrong reflection” because it is the cause of the arising of wrong view.🔽But it is called “wrong reflection” because it is associated with wrong view, or because it is the

original: Kāmasahagatāti kāmārammaṇā, kāmasaññāhi vā vokiṇṇā. Avitakkasahagatāti “kathaṃ nu
analyzed: kāma sahagatā ati kāma ārammaṇā kāma saññāhi vā vokiṇṇā avitakka sahagatā ati katham nu
translated: Associated with sensual desire means: having sensual desire as object, or mixed up with perceptions of sensual desire. Associated with no applied thought means: “How is it that there is no applied thought?

original: kho me avitakkaṃ jhānaṃ bhaveyyā”ti evaṃ avitakkārammaṇā avitakkavisayā. Kāmañcāyaṃ
analyzed: kho me avitakkam jhānam bhaveyya ati evam avitakka ārammaṇā avitakka visayā kāmañca ayam
translated: Associated with the sense sphere means having the sense sphere as its object or mixed with perceptions of the sense sphere. Associated with thought-free jhana means having thought-free jhana as its object, having thought-free jhana as its domain, thinking: “How can I make my jhana thought-free?”🔽Although the reading “of the first jhana” is given in terms of understanding,

original: “paṭhamassa jhānassā”tiādiko pāṭho paññāvasena āgato, samādhissāpi panettha saṅgaho🔽atthevāti udāharaṇassa sātthakataṃ dassetuṃ “tāya pana paññāya sampayuttā samādhīpi
analyzed: paṭhamassa jhānassa ati ādikaḥ pāṭho paññā vasena āgataḥ samādhissa api pana ittha saṅgahaḥ  atthā iva āti udāharaṇassa sātthakatam dassetum tāya pana paññāya sampayuttā
translated: still it is included in concentration.

original: cattāro hontī”ti tesaṃ vasena evaṃ vuttanti attho.
analyzed: cattāro honti iti tesam vasena evam vuttan ti attho
translated: The meaning is that it is said thus in terms of those concentrations associated with that understanding in order to show that the example is not pointless.

original: Bhāvanāmayassa samādhissa idhādhippetattā upacārekaggatā “kāmāvacaro samādhī”ti vuttaṃ.
analyzed: bhāvanā mayassa samādhissa idha adhippeta ttā upacāra ekagga tā kāmāvacaraḥ samādhi iti vuttam
translated: Since concentration consisting in development is intended here, the unification of mind consisting in access concentration is called “sense-sphere concentration.”

original: Adhipatiṃ karitvāti “chandavato ce samādhi hoti, mayhampi evaṃ hotī”ti chandaṃ adhipatiṃ,
analyzed: adhipatim karitvā ati chandavataḥ ced evam hoti iti chandam adhipatim
translated: Having made predominance : having made zeal predominant, thinking: “If concentration is in one who has zeal, then it will be in me too”;

original: chandaṃ dhuraṃ jeṭṭhakaṃ pubbaṅgamaṃ katvā. Labhati samādhinti evaṃ yaṃ samādhiṃ
analyzed: chandam dhuram jeṭṭhakam pubbaṅgamam katvā labhati samādhin ti evam yam samādhim
translated: having made zeal the leader, the chief, the forerunner. He obtains concentration: he obtains that concentration

original: labhati, ayaṃ vuccati chandasamādhi, chandādhipatisamādhīti attho. Evaṃ vīriyasamādhiādayopi veditabbā.🔽Catukkabhedeti catukkavasena samādhippabhedaniddese. Aññattha sampayogavasena vicārena
analyzed: labhati ayam vuccati chanda samādhi chanda adhipati samādhi iti attho evam vīriya samādhi ādayaḥ api veditabbā  catukka bheda iti catukka vasena samādhi ppabheda niddese aññattha sampayoga vasena vicārena
translated: This is called concentration due to zeal. The meaning is: concentration with zeal as its overlord. So too with concentration due to energy, etc.🔽In the description of the kinds of concentration according to the fourfold reckoning, etc.: in the analysis of the kinds of concentration according to the fivefold reckoning, etc.,🔽the kind of concentration called “with happiness and bliss born of concentration” is the second jhāna.🔽The kind called “accompanied by equanimity and associated with bliss” is the third jhāna.

original: saha vattamāno vitakko pañcakanaye dutiyajjhāne viyojitopi na suṭṭhu viyojitoti,
analyzed: saha vattamānaḥ vitakko pañcaka naye dutiya jhāne viyojitaḥ api na suṭṭhu viyojito ti
translated: The kind called “accompanied by equanimity and associated with neither-pain-nor-pleasure” is the fourth jhāna.🔽The kind called “accompanied by equanimity and associated with the sphere of boundless space” is the attainment of the base consisting of boundless space.🔽The kind called “accompanied by equanimity and associated with the sphere of boundless consciousness” is the attainment of the base consisting of boundless consciousness.🔽The kind called “accompanied by equanimity and associated with the sphere of nothingness” is the attainment of the base consisting of nothingness.🔽The kind called “accompanied by equanimity and associated with the sphere of neither-perception-nor-non-perception” is the attainment of the base consisting of neither-perception-nor-non-perception.🔽The kind called “accompanied by equanimity and associated with the cessation of perception and feeling” is the attainment of the cessation of perception and feeling.🔽The kind called “accompanied by equanimity and associated with the sphere of neither-perception-nor-non-perception” is the attainment of the base consisting of neither-perception-nor-non-perception.🔽The kind called “accompanied by equanimity and associated with the sphere of nothingness” is the attainment of the base consisting of nothingness.🔽The kind called “accompanied by equanimity and associated with the sphere of boundless consciousness” is the attainment of the base consisting of boundless consciousness.🔽The kind called “accompanied by equanimity and associated with the sphere of boundless space” is the attainment of the base consisting of boundless space.

original: tena saddhiṃyeva vicārasamatikkamaṃ dassetuṃ vuttaṃ “vitakkavicārātikkamena tatiya”nti.
analyzed: tena saddhiṃyeva vicāra samatikkamam dassetum vuttam vitakka vicāra atikkamena tatiyanti
translated: The kind called “accompanied by equanimity and associated with the third jhāna” is the third jhāna.🔽The kind called “accompanied by equanimity and associated with the second jhāna” is the second jhāna.🔽The kind called “accompanied by equanimity and associated with the first jhāna” is the first jhāna.

original: Dvidhā bhinditvā catukkabhede vuttaṃ dutiyaṃ jhānanti yojanā. Pañcajhānaṅgavasenāti🔽pañcannaṃ jhānānaṃ aṅgabhāvavasena samādhissa pañcavidhatā veditabbā.🔽40. Vibhaṅgeti ñāṇavibhaṅge. Tattha hi “jhānavimokkhasamādhisamāpattīnaṃ saṃkilesavodāna”nti,🔽ettha “saṃkilesa”ntiādi vuttaṃ. Tattha hānabhāgiyo dhammoti apaguṇehi paṭhamajjhānādīhi
analyzed: dvidhā bhinditvā catukka bhede vuttam dutiyam jhānan ti yojanā pañcajhā anaṅga vasena āti 🔽pañcannam jhānānam aṅga bhāva vasena samādhissa pañcavidha tā veditabbā 🔽vibhaṅga iti ñāṇa vibhaṅge tattha hi jhāna vimokkha samādhi samāpattīnam saṃkilesa vodānan ti 🔽ettha saṃkilesa ntiādi vuttam tattha hāna bhāgiyaḥ dhammo ti apaguṇehi paṭhamajjhāna ādīhi
translated: The kind called “accompanied by equanimity and associated with applied thought” is

original: vuṭṭhitassa saññāmanasikārānaṃ kāmādianupakkhandanaṃ. Visesabhāgiyo dhammoti paguṇehi
analyzed: vuṭṭhitassa saññā manasikārānam kāma ādi anupakkhandanam visesa bhāgiyaḥ dhammaḥ ti paguṇehi
translated: When he has emerged from the first jhāna, the non-suppressing of the perception and attention associated with the first jhāna is the state of things partaking of diminution.

original: paṭhamajjhānādīhi vuṭṭhitassa saññāmanasikārānaṃ dutiyajjhānādianupakkhandanaṃ. Tenāha🔽“paṭhamassa jhānassa lābhi”ntiādi. Tassattho – apaguṇassa paṭhamassa jhānassa lābhīnaṃ
analyzed: paṭhama jhāna ādīhi vuṭṭhitassa saññā manasikārānam dutiya jhāna ādi anupakkhandanam tena āha  paṭhamassa jhānassa lābhin tiādi tassa atthaḥ apaguṇassa paṭhamassa jhānassa lābhīnam
translated: When he has emerged from the second jhāna, etc., the non-suppressing of the perception and attention associated with the second jhāna, etc., is the state of things partaking of distinction. Hence it is said:

original: tato vuṭṭhitaṃ ārammaṇavasena kāmasahagatā hutvā saññāmanasikārā samudācaranti codenti🔽tudanti, tassa kāmānupakkhandānaṃ saññāmanasikārānaṃ vasena sā paṭhamajjhānapaññā
analyzed: tatas vuṭṭhitam ārammaṇa vasena kāma sahagatā hutvā saññā manasikārā samudācaranti codenti  tudanti tassa kāma anupakkhandānam saññā manasikārānam vasena sā paṭhamajjhāna paññā
translated: “One who has attained the first jhāna” and so on. The meaning is this: when those who have attained the first jhāna but have not made it familiar emerge from it, the perception and attention associated with the first jhāna, which are accompanied by applied thought, approach and beset him through the object,🔽and they oppress him. Because of the perception and attention associated with the first jhāna, which approach and beset him in this way, his knowledge partakes of diminution.

original: hāyati, tasmā hānabhāginī paññā. Avitakkasahagatāti avitakkaṃ dutiyaṃ jhānaṃ santato🔽paṇītato manasi karoto ārammaṇavasena avitakkasahagatā samudācaranti paguṇapaṭhamajjhānato
analyzed: hāyati tasmā hāna bhāginī paññā a vitakka sahagatā ati avitakkam dutiyam jhānam santataḥ  paṇītataḥ manasi karotaḥ ārammaṇa vasena avitakka sahagatā samudācaranti paguṇa paṭhama jhānato
translated: When he gives attention to the second jhāna as peaceful, which he has already attained and made familiar, as being without applied thought, the perception and attention associated with the second jhāna approach and beset him through the object,

original: vuṭṭhitaṃ dutiyajjhānādhigamatthāya codenti tudanti, tassa dutiyajjhānānupakkhandānaṃ
analyzed: vuṭṭhitam dutiya jhāna adhigama atthāya codenti tudanti tassa dutiya jhāna an upakkhandānam
translated: and they oppress him. Because of the perception and attention associated with the second jhāna, which approach and beset him in this way, his knowledge partakes of distinction.

original: saññāmanasikārānaṃ vasena paṭhamajjhānapaññā visesabhūtassa dutiyajjhānassa uppattiyā
analyzed: saññā manasikārānaṃ vasena paṭhama jhāna paññā visesa bhūtassa dutiya jhānassa uppattiyā
translated: The understanding that is a partaker of distinction is the understanding that is the footing for the arising of the second jhana, which is a distinction from the first jhana, by means of the second-jhāna-concomitant perception.

original: padaṭṭhānatāya visesabhāginī paññā. Taṃsampayutto samādhi idhādhippeto. Iminā nayenāti
analyzed: padaṭṭhāna tāya visesa bhāginī paññā tad sampayuttaḥ samādhi idha adhippetaḥ iminā nayena ati
translated: The concentration associated with that is intended here.

original: iminā paṭhamajjhāne vuttena vidhinā dutiyajjhānādīsupi hānabhāgiyadhammo, visesabhāgiyadhammo ca veditabbo.
analyzed: iminā paṭhama jhāne vuttena vidhinā dutiya jhāna ādīsu pi hāna bhāgiya dhammo visesa bhāgiya dhammo ca veditabbo
translated: By this method: by the method stated in the case of the first jhana, the states partaking of diminution and the states partaking of distinction should be understood in the second jhana, and so on.

original: Dasapalibodhavaṇṇanā🔽41. Ariyamaggasampayuttoti lokuttaraappamāṇaapariyāpannaggahaṇena lokiyehi asādhāraṇato,
analyzed: dasa pali bodha vaṇṇanā  ariya magga sampayuttaḥ ti lokuttara appamāṇa apariyāpanna ggahaṇena lokiyehi asādhāraṇataḥ
translated: The ten impediments🔽“Concentration associated with the noble path” is said because it is not shared by worldlings, since it is not included in the supramundane jhanas and the measureless states,

original: sappītikādiggahaṇena sādhāraṇato ca ariyamaggasampayutto samādhi vutto. Bhāvito hoti
analyzed: sappītika ādi gahaṇena sādhāraṇato ca ariya magga sampayutto samādhi vutto bhāvito hoti
translated: and because it is shared, since it is included in the jhanas and measureless states that are shared by worldlings and noble ones. It is developed

original: saññāya sampayuttattā. Tanti ariyamaggasamādhiṃ. Visunti paññābhāvanāya visuṃ katvā na vadāma.
analyzed: saññāya sampayutta ttā tanti ariya magga samādhim visunti paññā bhāvanāya visum katvā na vadāma
translated: because it is associated with perception. “That” : noble-path concentration. “Distinction” : we do not say “distinction” as a separate thing from the development of understanding.

original: Kammaṭṭhānabhāvanaṃ paribundheti uparodheti pavattituṃ na detīti palibodho ra-kārassa
analyzed: kammaṭṭhāna bhāvanam paribundheti uparodheti pavattitum na deti iti palibodhaḥ rakārassa
translated: “It obstructs the development of the meditation subject” : an impediment is that which obstructs the development of the meditation subject by preventing it from reaching absorption. The letter ra

original: la-kāraṃ katvā, paripanthoti attho. Upacchinditvāti samāpanena, saṅgahaṇena vā uparundhitvā,
analyzed: lakāram katvā upacchinditvā ati samāpanena saṅgahaṇena vā uparundhitvā
translated: The meaning is: having made the letter la, the obstacle. Having cut off: having cut off by the attainment, or having cut off by the collection,

original: apalibodhaṃ katvāti attho.🔽Āvasanti etthāti āvāso. Paricchedavasena veṇiyati dissatīti pariveṇaṃ. Vihāre bhikkhūnaṃ
analyzed: apalibodham katvā iti  āvasanti ettha ati āvāso pariccheda vasena dissati iti pariveṇam vihāre bhikkhūnam
translated: the meaning is: having made an obstruction.🔽They dwell here: a dwelling. It is seen as a boundary: a surrounding area. In the monastery

original: taṃ taṃ vasanaṭṭhānaṃ. Svāyaṃ āvāso. Navakammādīsūti ādi-saddena āvāsassa tadaññaṃ
analyzed: tam tam vasanaṭṭhānam svāyam āvāsaḥ nava kamma ādīsu iti ādi saddena āvāsassa tad aññam
translated: is the place for the monks to live. This is a dwelling. In the building work, etc.: the word “etc.” includes the other

original: abhivuddhikāraṇaṃ saṅgaṇhāti. Kāraṇenāti “chāyūdakasampannaṃ sulabhabhikkha”ntiādinā
analyzed: abhivuddhi kāraṇam saṅgaṇhāti kāraṇena ati chāyūdaka sampannam sulabha bhikkhanti ādinā
translated: causes of the increase of the dwelling. By the reason: by the reason “it is endowed with shade and water, alms food is easily obtained,” etc.

original: kāraṇena. Apekkhavāti sālayo.
analyzed: kāraṇena sa ālayaḥ
translated: The meaning is: by the reason. The people who are looking on: the inhabitants.

original: Tatrāti tasmiṃ palibodhābhāve. Pācīnakhaṇḍarājinti puratthimadisāyaṃ pabbatakhaṇḍānaṃ
analyzed: tatra ati tasmin palibodha abhāve pācīna khaṇḍa rājin ti puratthima disāyam pabbata khaṇḍānam
translated: There: in that absence of an obstacle. The eastern range of hills: in the eastern direction, between the mountain ranges,

original: antare vanarājiṭṭhānaṃ. “Nāmā”ti iminā tassa padesassa ayaṃ samaññāti dasseti. Paṭisāmitamevāti
analyzed: antare vana rājiṭṭhānam nāma ati iminā tassa padesassa ayam samaññā ati dasseti paṭisāmitam eva ati
translated: in the place of the forest range. “Name”: by this he shows that this is the name of that place. It is only reserved:

original: niccakālaṃ paṭisāmetvāva vihārato nikkhamāmīti dasseti. Dhātunidhānaṭṭhānanti kāyabandhanadhammakaraṇanhānasāṭikaakkhakadhātusaṅkhātānaṃ
analyzed: nicca kālam paṭisāmetvā ava vihārataḥ nikkhamāmi iti dasseti dhātu nidhāna ṭṭhānam ti kāya bandhana dhamma karaṇa nhāna sāṭika akkhaka dhātu saṅkhātānam
translated: He shows that he will go out from the dwelling only after he has put away the requisites at the proper time. The place for storing the elements: the place for storing the elements of the requisites for the body’s support, that is to say, the waist-band, the water-strainer, the bathing-cloth, the razor, the needle, and the key.

original: paribhogasarīradhātūnaṃ nidahitaṭṭhānaṃ. Īdisassa ayaṃ thero viya alaggacittassa.🔽Etena “bhikkhunā nāma āvāse evarūpena bhavitabba”nti ovādo dinno hoti. Ito paresupi
analyzed: paribhoga sarīra dhātūnam nidahita ṭṭhānam īdisassa ayam theraḥ viya a lagga cittassa  etena bhikkhunā nāma āvāse evarūpena bhavitabbanti ovādaḥ dinnaḥ hoti itas paresu pi
translated: This elder’s mind was not stuck even in this way.

original: vatthūsu eseva nayo.🔽Kulanti kulaggahaṇena kulamanussānaṃ gahaṇaṃ gāmaggahaṇena gāmavāsīnaṃ viya. Upaṭṭhākakulampīti
analyzed: vatthūsu esa iva nayo  kulam ti kula ggahaṇena kula manussānam gahaṇam gāma ggahaṇena gāma vāsīnam viya upaṭṭhāka kulam pi iti
translated: By this he gave the advice: “A bhikkhu should be of this kind in a residence.” The same method applies in the following cases.🔽Family: by the word “family” he shows that he means human families, just as by the word “village” he means the inhabitants of the village.🔽A family that looks after him: by the word “also” he shows that he means a family of his relatives as well.

original: pi-saddena pageva ñātikulanti dasseti. Uddesatthanti uddisāpanatthaṃ, pāṭhaṃ uddisāpetvā
analyzed: pi saddena pagā iva ñāti kulanti dasseti uddesa attham ti uddisāpana attham pāṭham uddisāpetvā
translated: For the purpose of recitation: for the purpose of getting it recited, the meaning being that he gets the recitation learnt.

original: sajjhāyitunti attho. Idhevāti imasmiṃyeva padese, yattha katthaci vihāreti attho.
analyzed: attho idha iva ati imasmin yeva padese yattha katthaci vihāreti attho
translated: Right there: in that very place; the meaning is, anywhere.

original: Taṃ vihāranti taṃ koraṇḍakavihāraṃ.
analyzed: tam tam koraṇḍaka vihāram
translated: That dwelling: that Korandaka Monastery.

original: Upagatoti vassaṃ upagato. Sadāti gatakālato pabhuti visesato pavāritadivasato paṭṭhāya
analyzed: upagato ti vassam upagato sadā iti gata kālataḥ visesato pavārita divasataḥ paṭṭhāya
translated: Upagato means “having entered upon the rains.” Sadā means “always,” from the time of going there up to the day of the Invitation.

original: sabbadā divase divase. Paridevamānāti taṃtaṃvilapanavasena vividhaṃ paridevantī.
analyzed: sabbadā divase divase paridevamānā ati taṃtaṃvilapana vasena vividham paridevantī
translated: Paridevamānā means “lamenting,” lamenting in various ways by various kinds of lamentations.

original: Sabbaṃ pavattinti attanā tattha diṭṭhakālato paṭṭhāya pacchā samāgamapariyosānaṃ🔽daharassa sabbaṃ pavattiṃ.🔽Kāyasakkhinti “passa ima”nti mukhapaṭiggāhakaṃ katvā. Rathavinītapaṭipadanti dasakathāvatthukittanapubbikaṃ
analyzed: sabbam pavattinti attanā tattha diṭṭha kālato paṭṭhāya pacchā samāgama pariyosānam  daharassa sabbam pavattim  kāya sakkhinti passe imanti mukha paṭiggāhakam katvā ratha vinīta paṭipadanti dasa kathā vatthu kittana pubbikam
translated: Sabbaṃ pavattiṃ means “all the events,” from the time of his seeing her there up to the time of their subsequent reunion.

original: rathavinītūpamāhi vibhāvitaṃ rathavinītasutte āgataṃ sattavisuddhipaṭipadaṃ. Nālakapaṭipadanti
analyzed: ratha vinīta upamā hi vibhāvitam ratha vinīta sutte āgatam satta visuddhi paṭipadam nālaka paṭipadanti
translated: Kāyasakkhin means “one who has seen with the body,” one who has made it a direct experience. Rathavinītapaṭipadā means “the way of training in the chariot,” the way of training in the chariot as described in the Rathavinīta Sutta, which is the way of purification consisting of the seven factors of the way, beginning with the ten contemplations of the body.

original: “moneyyaṃ te upaññissa”ntiādinā satthārā nālakattherassa desitapaṭipadaṃ. Tuvaṭakapaṭipadanti
analyzed: moneyyam te upaññissanti ādinā satthārā nālaka ttherassa desita paṭipadam tuvaṭaka paṭipadam ti
translated: Nālakapaṭipadā means “the way of training of the Elder Nālaka,” the way of training taught by the Teacher to the Elder Nālaka with the words: “I will give you a way of training.”

original: “mūlaṃ papañcasaṅkhāyā”tiādinā bhagavatā desitapaṭipadaṃ. Tattha hi yathākkamaṃ –🔽“Na munī gāmamāgamma, kulesu sahasā care;
analyzed: mūlam bhagavatā desita paṭipadam tattha hi yathākkamam 🔽na munī kulesu sahasā care
translated: Tuvaṭakapaṭipadā means “the way of training of Tuvaṭaka,” the way of training taught by the Blessed One with the words: “The root of the whirl of the round of rebirths is ignorance” .🔽Herein, the following are the ways of training in the three suttas respectively:

original: Ghāsesanaṃ chinnakatho, na vācaṃ payutaṃ bhaṇe”. ;
analyzed: chinna kathaḥ na vācam bhaṇe
translated: He should not speak with a forked tongue.

original: “Gāme ca nābhisajjeyya, lābhakamyā janaṃ na lapayeyyā”ti. –
analyzed: gāme ca na abhisajjeyya lābha kamyā janam na lapayeyya ati
translated: He should not be greedy for the village, nor should he flatter people for the sake of gain.🔽Such is the talk of one who is extremely greedy.

original: Evamādikā paramappicchakathā āgatā. Catupaccayasantosabhāvanārāmatādīpakanti cīvarādīsu catūsu paccayesu santosassa, bhāvanārāmatāya ca pakāsakaṃ.
analyzed: evamādikā param appiccha kathā āgatā catu paccaya santosa bhāvanā ārāma tā dīpakam ti cīvara ādīsu catūsu paccayesu santosassa bhāvanā ārāma tāya ca pakāsakam
translated: The word “content” is a term for the four requisites, namely, robes, alms food, resting place, and medicine for support in sickness.🔽“Gain” is what is obtained.

original: Labbhatīti lābho. Tenāha “cattāro paccayā”ti. Mahāparivāreti vipulaparivāre. Piṇḍapātaṃ
analyzed: labbhati iti lābhaḥ tena āha cattāro mahā parivāre iti vipula parivāre piṇḍapātam
translated: “Great retinue” means a large retinue.🔽When they give alms food, they give robes, bowls, etc., as its retinue.

original: tāva dentā buddhapūjāpattacīvarādīni tassa parivārāni katvā denti, tathā cīvarādidānepi.
analyzed: tāva dentā buddha pūjā patta cīvara ādīni tassa parivārāni katvā denti tathā cīvara ādi dāne pi
translated: So too with the giving of robes, etc.🔽“Alms-food eaters who are luxurious with requisites”: they are alms-food eaters who are luxurious with requisites.

original: Bāhullikapiṇḍapātikāti piṇḍapātikā hutvā paccayabāhullikā. Vadantīti purimadivase
analyzed: bāhullika piṇḍapātikā ati piṇḍapātikāḥ hutvā paccaya bāhullikāḥ vadanti iti purima divase
translated: “They say”: when they go for alms on the previous day, they say what they have heard.

original: bhikkhāya āhiṇḍanakāle yathāsutaṃ vadanti. Niccabyāvaṭo upāsakādīnaṃ saṅgaṇhane.
analyzed: bhikkhāyaḥ āhiṇḍana kāle yathāsutam vadanti nicca byāvaṭaḥ upāsaka ādīnam saṅgaṇhane
translated: “Always on the move”: they are always on the move in the sense of being constantly occupied with the business of socializing with lay supporters, etc.🔽“That” refers to the group.🔽“That hindrance to the group”: the hindrance to the group.

original: Tassāti gaṇassa. Soti gaṇapalibodho. Evanti idāni vuccamānākārena gaṇavācakassa pariyesanampi
analyzed: tassa ati gaṇassa saḥ ti gaṇa palibodhaḥ evam ti idāni vuccamāna ākārena gaṇa vācakassa pariyesanam pi
translated: “In this way”: in the way now being described. The search for a term to denote a group is

original: lahukameva icchitabbanti āha “yojanato paraṃ agantvā”ti. Attano kammanti samaṇadhammamāha.
analyzed: lahukam eva icchitabbanti āha yojanataḥ param a gantvā iti attanaḥ kamman ti samaṇa dhammam āha
translated: He says “without going beyond a league” because it is easy to find. “His own work” is his ascetic duties.🔽“What is done and what is not done” is what is done and not done in the way of duties. He should make an effort to know what is done and not done.

original: Katākateti kate ca akate ca kamme jānanavasena ussukkaṃ āpajjitabbaṃ, katākateti🔽vā appake ca mahante ca kate, yathā “phalāphale”ti. Sace bahuṃ avasiṭṭhanti sambandho.🔽Bhārahārā saṅghakiccapariṇāyakā.
analyzed: kata akata iti kate ca a kate ca kamme jānana vasena ussukkam āpajjitabbam kata akata iti  vā appake ca mahante ca kate yathā phala aphala iti sace bahum avasiṭṭhanti sambandho
translated: “What is done and what is not done” is what is done and not done in the way of duties. He should make an effort to know what is done and not done.🔽“What is done and what is not done” is what is done and not done in the way of duties. He should make an effort to know what is done and not done.🔽“What is done and what is not done” is what is done and not done in the way of duties. He should make an effort to know what is done and not done.🔽“What is done and what is not done” is what is done and not done in the way of duties. He should make an effort to know what is done and not done.

original: Pabbajjāpekkhoti sīhaḷadīpe kira kuladārakānaṃ pabbajjā āvāhavivāhasadisā, tasmā
analyzed: pabbajja apekkho ti sīhaḷadīpe kira kula dārakānam pabbajjā āvāha vivāha sadisā tasmā
translated: “What is done and what is not done” is what is done and not done in the way of duties. He should make an effort to know what is done and not done.🔽“What is done and what is not done” is what is done and not done in the way of duties. He should make an effort to know what is done and not done.

original: taṃ paricchinnadivasaṃ atikkametuṃ na sakkā. “Sace taṃ alabhanto na sakkoti adhivāsetu”ntiādinā🔽samāpanena palibodhupacchedo vutto, byatirekato pana “sace taṃ alabhanto sakkoti
analyzed: tam paricchinna divasam atikkametum na sakkā sace tam a labhantaḥ na sakkā iti adhivāsetun ti ādinā  samāpanena palibodha upacchedaḥ vuttaḥ byatirekato pana sace tam a labhanto sakkoti
translated: “What is done and what is not done” is what is done and not done in the way of duties. He should make an effort to know what is done and not done.🔽“What is done and what is not done” is what is done and not done in the way of duties. He should make an effort to know what is done and not done.🔽“What is done and what is not done” is what is done and not done in the way of duties. He should make an effort to know what is done and not done.

original: adhivāsetuṃ, araññaṃ pavisitvā samaṇadhammova kātabbo”ti ayamattho dassitoti saṅgahaṇena
analyzed: adhivāsetum araññam pavisitvā samaṇa dhammaḥ uva kātabbaḥ ti ayam attho dassito ti saṅgahaṇena
translated: “What is done and what is not done” is what is done and not done in the way of duties. He should make an effort to know what is done and not done.

original: palibodhupacchedo veditabbo. Esa nayo sesesupi.
analyzed: palibodha upacchedaḥ veditabbaḥ esa nayo sesesu pi
translated: “What is done and what is not done” is what is done and not done in the way of duties. He should make an effort to know what is done and not done.🔽“What is done and what is not done” is what is done and not done in the way of duties. He should make an effort to

original: Tathāti yathā upajjhāyo gilāno yāvajīvaṃ upaṭṭhātabbo, tathā upasampāditaantevāsiko attano kammavācaṃ vatvā upasampādito.
analyzed: tathā ti yathā upajjhāyaḥ gilānaḥ yāvajīvam upaṭṭhātabbaḥ tathā upasampādita antevāsikaḥ attanaḥ kamma vācam vatvā upasampāditaḥ
translated: “Just as”: just as the preceptor should be looked after as long as he lives when he is sick, so too the pupil who has been given the full ordination by the one who has given his own declaration of the three facts.

original: Yo koci rogoti mūlabhūto, anubandho vā attano uppanno. Anamataggeti anu anu amatagge anādimati.
analyzed: yaḥ koci mūla bhūtaḥ anubandhaḥ vā attanaḥ uppannaḥ anamatagge iti anu anu amatagge anādimati
translated: “Any sickness” is the basic sickness or any sickness that has arisen in addition to it. “Without beginning”: without end, without beginning.🔽“The burden of texts”: the hindrance of texts is what is meant here. “The burden of learning” is said with reference to the learning sign.

original: “Gantho”ti iminā ganthapalibodho idha vuttoti āha “pariyattiharaṇa”nti. Sajjhāyādīhīti🔽sajjhāyadhāraṇaparicayapucchādīhi. Itarassāti abyāvaṭassa. Yassa ganthadhuraṃ vissajjetvā🔽ṭhitassāpi gantho vattateva, na tassa gantho palibodho. Yathā tamhi tamhi vatthumhi
analyzed: gantho ti iminā gantha palibodho idha vutto ti āha pariyatti haraṇam ti sajjhāya ādīhi iti  sajjhāya dhāraṇa paricaya puccha ādīhi itarassa ati a byāvaṭassa yassa gantha dhuram vissajjetvā  ṭhitassa api ganthaḥ na tassa gantho palibodhaḥ yathā tamhi tamhi vatthumhi
translated: “In learning, etc.”: in learning, memorizing, and reviewing.🔽“The other”: the one who is not burdened with texts.🔽When the burden of texts has been laid aside by one who is not burdened with texts, the texts still go on going round in his mind. The texts are not a hindrance to him.🔽Just as they are not a hindrance to the elder who has come to the stage of the learning sign in the case of the learning sign, and to the elder who has come to the stage of the counterpart sign in the case of the counterpart sign, and just as they are not a hindrance to one who has not learned the texts at all.

original: āgatattherānaṃ, nāpi sabbena sabbaṃ aganthapasutassa. Majjhimapaṇṇāsako āgacchati,🔽suttapadesānaṃ vārānañca sadisatāya byāmuyhanato. Puna na olokessāmīti kammaṭṭhānaṃ
analyzed: āgata therānam na api sabbena sabbam aganthapasutassa majjhima paṇṇāsakaḥ āgacchati  sutta padesānam vārānam ca sadisa tāya byāmuyhanataḥ puna na olokessāmi iti kammaṭṭhānam
translated: The middle fifty is coming to an end.🔽Because of the similarity of the number of times the passages have to be repeated, the learning sign is reached by “digging in.”

original: gahetvā ganthadhuraṃ vissajjemīti attho.
analyzed: gahetvā gantha dhuram vissajjemi iti attho
translated: “I shall not look at it again”: the meaning is that he lays aside the burden of texts after taking up the meditation subject.

original: Gāmavāsikattherehīti anurādhapuravāsīhi. Anuggahetvāti aggahetvā tattha paricayaṃ
analyzed: gāmavāsika therehi iti anurādhapura vāsīhi anuggahetvā ati aggahetvā tattha paricayam
translated: Gāmavāsikattherehīti anurādhapuravāsīhi. Anuggahetvāti aggahetvā tattha paricayaṃ
