original: akatvā. Pañcanikāyamaṇḍaleti dīghāgamādike pañcapi nikāye sikkhitaparisāya. Parivattessāmīti🔽vaṇṇayissāmi. Suvaṇṇabherinti seṭṭhabheriṃ. Katamācariyānaṃ uggahoti katamesaṃ ācariyānaṃ🔽uggaho, kena parivattīyatīti adhippāyo. Ācariyamaggoti ācariyānaṃ kathāmaggo. Attano
analyzed: a katvā pañca nikāya maṇḍalā iti dīgha āgama ādike pañca api nikāye sikkhita parisāya parivattessāmi iti  vaṇṇayissāmi suvaṇṇa bherin ti seṭṭha bherim katama ācariyānam uggahaḥ ti katamesam ācariyānam  uggahaḥ kena parivattīyati iti adhippāyaḥ ācariya maggo ti ācariyānam kathā maggo attano
translated: ‘In the presence of the residents of the village’ means in the presence of the residents of Anurādhapura. ‘Having not accepted’ means having not accepted, having not made acquaintance there. ‘In the assembly of the five collections’ means in the assembly of those who have studied the five collections beginning with the Dīgha Nikāya. ‘I will turn’ means

original: ācariyānanti attano kathetuṃ yuttānaṃ ācariyānaṃ. Suvinicchitā sabbā tipiṭakapariyatti
analyzed: ācariyānam ti attanaḥ kathetum yuttānam ācariyānam su vinicchitā sabbā tipiṭaka pariyatti
translated: I will explain. ‘Golden drum’ means the best drum. ‘The acceptance of which teachers’ means what teachers’ acceptance? By whom is it turned? This is the meaning. ‘The path of the teachers’ means the path of the teachers’ talk. ‘My own teachers’ means my own suitable teachers. ‘All well-ascertained’ means all the three-basket recitation

original: etasmiṃ atthīti sabbapariyattiko, tepiṭakoti attho. Pīṭhe nisinno tato otaritvā bhūmiyaṃ🔽taṭṭikāya nisīditvā. Gatakassāti paṭipattigamanena gatassa diṭṭhasaccassa. Cīvaraṃ
analyzed: etasmin atthi iti sabbapariyattiko tepiṭako ti attho pīṭhe nisinno tatas otaritvā  taṭṭikāya nisīditvā gatakassa ati paṭipatti gamanena gatassa diṭṭhasaccassa cīvaram
translated: is in this, therefore it is all-recitation, the meaning is all-basket. ‘Having sat on the seat’ means having sat on the seat and then descended to the ground

original: pārupitvāti ācariyassa apacitidassanatthaṃ parimaṇḍalaṃ cīvaraṃ pārupitvā. Sāṭheyyābhāvato
analyzed: pārupitvā ti ācariyassa apaciti dassana attham parimaṇḍalam cīvaram pārupitvā sāṭheyya abhāvato
translated: and sat on the mat. ‘Having gone by the path’ means having gone by the path of practice, having seen the truth. ‘Having put on the robe’ means having put on the robe in a circular way in order to show respect to the teacher. ‘Because of the absence of deceit’ means

original: uju. Kāraṇākāraṇassa ājānanato ājānīyo.
analyzed: uju kāraṇa akāraṇassa ājānanataḥ ājānīyaḥ
translated: Straight. The thoroughbred is so called because of its knowledge of what is a cause and what is not a cause.

original: Pothujjanikāti puthujjane bhavā. Dupparihārā bahuparissayatāya. Tathā hissā uttānaseyyakadārako,
analyzed: pothujjanikā ati puthujjane bhavā dupparihārā bahu parissaya tāya tathā hissa uttānaseyyaka dārako
translated: They are called “of the world” because they exist in the world. They are hard to avoid because they have many conditions. For they are like a child with a sucking disease,

original: taruṇasassañca nidassitaṃ. Vipassanāya palibodho samathayānikassa, na vipassanāyānikassa.
analyzed: taruṇa sassam ca nidassitam vipassanāya palibodhaḥ samatha yānikassa na vipassanāyānikassa
translated: and like a young calf, as shown. They are an impediment to one whose vehicle is serenity, not to one whose vehicle is insight.

original: Yebhuyyena hi jhānalābhī samathayānikova hoti vipassanāsukhato. Itarenāti samathatthikena.
analyzed: yebhuyyena hi jhāna lābhī samatha yānikaḥ uva hoti vipassanā sukhataḥ itarena ati samathatthikena
translated: For one who has obtained jhāna is generally one whose vehicle is serenity, and he is happy with insight. The opposite is the case with the other.

original: Avasesā nava palibodhā.
analyzed: avasesā nava palibodhā
translated: The remaining nine are impediments.

original: Kammaṭṭhānadāyakavaṇṇanā
analyzed: kammaṭṭhāna dāyaka vaṇṇanā
translated: The explanation of the one who gives the meditation subject

original: 42. Kammaṭṭhāne niyutto kammaṭṭhāniko, bhāvanamanuyuñjanto. Tena kammaṭṭhānikena.
analyzed: kammaṭṭhāne niyuttaḥ kammaṭṭhānikaḥ bhāvanam anuyuñjanto tena kammaṭṭhānikena
translated: The one who is devoted to the meditation subject is the meditator who is devoted to the development of the meditation subject.🔽Having defined them thus: “All the bhikkhus in this monastery” he should define the bhikkhus living with him

original: Paricchinditvāti “imasmiṃ vihāre sabbe bhikkhū”ti evaṃ paricchinditvā. Sahavāsīnaṃ
analyzed: paricchinditvā ti imasmin vihāre sabbe bhikkhū iti evam paricchinditvā sahavāsīnam
translated: as “fellow-residents.”

original: bhikkhūnaṃ. Muducittatanti attani muducittataṃ janeti, ayañca sahavāsīnaṃ cittamaddavajananādiattho
analyzed: bhikkhūnam attani mudu citta tam janeti ayam ca sahavāsīnam citta maddava janana ādi attho
translated: He should generate a sense of endearment towards them. And the meaning of the words “He should generate a sense of endearment towards them” is this: he should generate a sense of endearment towards the minds of his fellow-residents,

original: “manussānaṃ piyo hotī”tiādinayappavattena mettānisaṃsasuttena dīpetabbo. Anolīnavuttiko
analyzed: manussānam piyaḥ hoti iti ādi naya ppavattena mettānisaṃsa suttena dīpetabbaḥ anolīna vuttikaḥ
translated: “He is dear to human beings” and so on, which is the way to expound it by means of the Discourse on the Benefits of Loving-kindness .🔽He is not a man of unpunctual conduct in the right way of practice.

original: hoti sammāpaṭipattiyaṃ. Dibbānipi ārammaṇāni pageva itarāni. Sabbattha sabbasmiṃ
analyzed: hoti sammāpaṭipattiyam dibbāni api ārammaṇāni pageva itarāni sabbattha sabbasmin
translated: Divine objects of meditation are easy to obtain, to say nothing of the others.🔽In all ways, in all the duties of a recluse, or in all the practice of meditation subjects.

original: samaṇakaraṇīye, sabbasmiṃ vā kammaṭṭhānānuyoge. Pubbāsevanavasena atthayitabbaṃ.
analyzed: samaṇa karaṇīye sabbasmim vā kammaṭṭhāna anuyoge pubba āsevana vasena
translated: It should be undertaken by one who has previously made it familiar.🔽The practice of development is the practice of the meditation subject. That itself is what is to be done, thus it is a “work” .

original: Yogassa bhāvanāya anuyuñjanaṃ yogānuyogo, tadeva karaṇīyaṭṭhena kammaṃ, tassa yogānuyogakammassa
analyzed: yogassa bhāvanāya anuyuñjanam yoga anuyogaḥ tat eva karaṇīya ṭṭhena kammam tassa yoga anuyoga kammassa
translated: The “basis” for that work of practice is the cause of its accomplishment.

original: ṭhānaṃ nipphattihetu.🔽Niccaṃ pariharitabbattāti sabbatthakakammaṭṭhānaṃ viya ekadāva ananuyuñjitvā sabbakālaṃ
analyzed: ṭhānam nipphatti hetu  niccam pariharitabba ttā ti sabbatthaka kammaṭṭhānam viya ekadā ava an anuyuñjitvā sabbakālam
translated: Because it should always be borne in mind, it is called “to be borne in mind” .

original: pariharaṇīyattā anuyuñjitabbattā. Evamādiguṇasamannāgatanti piyabhāvādīhi guṇehi
analyzed: pariharaṇīya ttā anuyuñjitabba ttā evamādi guṇa samannāgatanti piya bhāva ādīhi guṇehi
translated: It is endowed with such and such special qualities, that is to say, it is provided with the special qualities of dearness, and so on.

original: sampannaṃ. Kalyāṇamitto hi saddhāsampanno hoti sīlasampanno sutasampanno cāgasampanno
analyzed: sampannam kalyāṇa mittaḥ hi saddhā sampannaḥ hoti sīla sampanno suta sampanno cāga sampannaḥ
translated: For a good friend is possessed of faith, possessed of virtue, possessed of learning, possessed of generosity,

original: vīriyasampanno satisampanno samādhisampanno paññāsampanno. Tattha saddhāsampattiyā🔽saddahati tathāgatassa bodhiṃ, kammaphalañca, tena sammāsambodhiyā hetubhūtaṃ sattesu
analyzed: vīriya sampanno sati sampanno samādhi sampanno paññā sampanno tattha saddhā sampattiyā  saddahati tathāgatassa bodhim kamma phalam ca tena sammāsambodhiyāḥ hetu bhūtam sattesu
translated: He is endowed with energy, with mindfulness, with concentration, with wisdom. Herein, through the endowment with faith🔽he has confidence in the enlightenment of the Realised One, and in kamma and its fruits. Therefore he does not abandon the welfare of beings,

original: hitesitaṃ na pariccajati. Sīlasampattiyā sattānaṃ piyo hoti garu bhāvanīyo codako🔽pāpagarahī vattā vacanakkhamo, sutasampattiyā saccapaṭiccasamuppādādipaṭisaṃyuttānaṃ
analyzed: hita isitam na pariccajati sīla sampattiyā sattānam piyaḥ hoti garu bhāvanīyo codako  pāpa garahī vattā vacana kkhamaḥ suta sampattiyā sacca paṭiccasamuppāda ādi paṭisaṃyuttānam
translated: which is the cause for the Supreme Enlightenment. Through the endowment with virtue he is dear and agreeable to beings, he is respected, he is an admonisher,🔽he is a reprover of faults, he is a speaker, he is one who can be spoken to, through the endowment with learning he is a speaker of profound

original: gambhīrānaṃ kathānaṃ kattā hoti, cāgasampattiyā appiccho hoti santuṭṭho pavivitto
analyzed: gambhīrānam kathānam kattā hoti cāga sampattiyāḥ appicchaḥ hoti santuṭṭhaḥ pavivitto
translated: discourses connected with the Truths, Dependent Origination, etc. Through the endowment with generosity he is one who is few in wishes, who is content, who is secluded,

original: asaṃsaṭṭho, vīriyasampattiyā āraddhavīriyo hoti attahitaparahitapaṭipattiyaṃ, satisampattiyā
analyzed: a saṃsaṭṭhaḥ vīriya sampattiyā āraddha vīriyaḥ hoti atta hita para hita paṭipattiyam sati sampattiyā
translated: who is aloof from society. Through the endowment with energy he is one who has begun energy, in the practice of what is beneficial for himself and others. Through the endowment with mindfulness he is

original: upaṭṭhitassati hoti, samādhisampattiyā avikkhitto samāhitacitto, paññāsampattiyā
analyzed: upaṭṭhita sati hoti samādhi sampattiyā a vikkhittaḥ samāhita citto paññā sampattiyā
translated: one who is established in mindfulness, through the endowment with concentration he is one who is not distracted, whose mind is composed, through the endowment with wisdom he understands

original: aviparītaṃ pajānāti. So satiyā kusalākusalānaṃ dhammānaṃ gatiyo samannesamāno paññāya
analyzed: a viparītam pajānāti so satiyā kusala akusalānam dhammānam gatiyaḥ samannesamāno paññāya
translated: without perversion. He, investigating by means of mindfulness the destinations of wholesome and unwholesome things, by means of wisdom

original: sattānaṃ hitāhitaṃ yathābhūtaṃ jānitvā samādhinā tattha ekaggacitto hutvā vīriyena🔽satte ahitaṃ nisedhetvā hite niyojeti. Tena vuttaṃ “piyo…pe… niyojakoti evamādiguṇasamannāgata”nti.
analyzed: sattānam hita ahitam yathābhūtam jānitvā samādhinā tattha ekagga cittaḥ hutvā vīriyena  satte ahitam nisedhetvā hite niyojeti tena vuttam evamādi guṇa samannāgatanti
translated: Having known the benefit and harm of beings as they really are, he, with concentration, being one-pointed in mind in that, by energy🔽he removes harm from beings and establishes them in benefit. Therefore it was said: “Dear … he is endowed with such and such good qualities as a leader.”

original: Taṃ pana kalyāṇamittaṃ paramukkaṃsagataṃ dassetuṃ “mamaṃ hī”tiādi vuttaṃ. Kārakabhāvaṃ
analyzed: tam pana kalyāṇa mittam param ukkaṃsa gatam dassetum mamam hi itiādi vuttam kāraka bhāvam
translated: But in order to show that good friend who has gone to the highest stage, it was said: “My … ” The state of being a doer

original: yogakammassa. Pakāseti attānaṃ paṭipattiyā amoghabhāvadassanena samuttejanāya, sampahaṃsanāya
analyzed: yogakammassa pakāseti attānam paṭipattiyā amogha bhāva dassanena samuttejanāya sampahaṃsanāya
translated: of the work of yoga. He shows himself by the seeing of the fruitlessness of practice, by the arousing of zeal,

original: ca, nanu kathesi paveṇipālanatthanti adhippāyo. Evarūpoti pesalo hutvā bahussuto.🔽Tantidharoti suttadharo tattha kehicipi asaṃhīro. Vaṃsānurakkhakoti buddhānubuddhavaṃsassa
analyzed: ca nanu kathesi paveṇi pālana atthanti adhippāyaḥ evarūpaḥ iti pesalaḥ hutvā bahu sutaḥ  tantidharo ti suttadharo tattha kehici pi asaṃhīraḥ vaṃsa anurakkhako ti buddha anubuddha vaṃsassa
translated: and by the comforting of the mind. The intention is: “Did he not speak for the sake of the preservation of the lineage?” Thus: “Such a one … ” being a good man, he is learned.🔽“He who has the Dhamma in his heart” is one who has the Dhamma in his heart, not confused about anything there. “He who preserves the lineage”

original: anurakkhako. Paveṇipālakoti paveṇiyā ācariyuggahaṇassa anupālako. Ācariyamatikoti
analyzed: anurakkhako paveṇi pālako ti paveṇiyāḥ ācariya uggahaṇassa anupālako ācariya matiko ti
translated: is one who preserves the lineage of the Buddhas and Paccekabuddhas. “He who preserves the lineage” is one who preserves the lineage of the teacher’s instruction. “He who has the teacher’s mind”🔽is one who has the teacher’s mind.

original: ācariyamatiyaṃ niyutto tassā anativattanato. Na attanomatiṃ pakāseti kathetīti na
analyzed: ācariya matiyam niyuttaḥ tassāḥ an ativattanataḥ na attanomatim pakāseti katheti iti na
translated: because he is bound by the teacher’s opinion and does not transgress it. He does not make his own opinion known, does not speak out.

original: attanomatiko, attano matiṃ paggayha vattā na hotīti attho.
analyzed: attanomatikaḥ attanaḥ matim paggayha vattā na hoti iti attho
translated: He is not one who follows his own ideas because he does not transgress the teacher’s opinion. He does not make known his own ideas, that is, he does not expound them,🔽thinking, “I will not go beyond the teacher’s opinion.”

original: “Pubbe vuttakhīṇāsavādayo”tiādi ekaccakhīṇāsavato bahussutova kammaṭṭhānadāne seyyoti🔽dassanatthaṃ āraddhaṃ. Tattha pubbe vuttakhīṇāsavādayoti “yaṃ kammaṭṭhānaṃ gahetukāmo”tiādinā🔽vuttakhīṇāsavādikā. Uggahaparipucchānaṃ visodhitattāti uggahetabbato “uggaho”ti laddhanāmāya
analyzed: pubbe vutta khīṇāsava ādayo tiādi ekacca khīṇāsavataḥ bahu ssutaḥ uva kammaṭṭhāna dāne seyyo ti  dassana attham āraddham tattha pubbe vutta khīṇāsava ādayo ti yam kammaṭṭhānam ga hetu kāmaḥ ti ādinā  vutta khīṇāsava ādikā uggaha paripucchānam visodhita ttā ati uggahetabbataḥ uggaho ti laddha nāmāya
translated: “Those whose cankers are exhausted, etc.,” etc. is stated in order to show that one who is a great deal learned is better than one whose cankers are exhausted but who is not a great deal learned in giving the meditation subject.🔽Herein, those whose cankers are exhausted, etc., are those whose cankers are exhausted, etc., as described in the passage beginning, “One who is going to take up the meditation subject” .

original: kammaṭṭhānupakārāya pāḷiyā, tadatthaṃ paripucchanato “paripucchā”ti laddhasamaññāya
analyzed: kamma ṭṭhāna upakārāya pāḷiyā tad attham paripucchanataḥ paripucchāti laddha samaññāya
translated: The meaning is: he has well investigated the scriptures, which are called “rehearsals” because they are to be rehearsed, and the commentaries on their meaning, which are called “enquiries” because they are to be enquired into.

original: atthasaṃvaṇṇanāya ca visesato sodhitattā niggumbaṃ nijjaṭaṃ katvā gahitattā. Ito
analyzed: attha saṃvaṇṇanāya ca visesataḥ sodhita ttā niggumbam nijjaṭam katvā gahita ttā itas
translated: He has made them his own by unravelling them and disentangling them,

original: cito ca suttañca kāraṇañca sallakkhetvāti pañcasupi nikāyesu ito cito ca tassa tassa
analyzed: cito ca suttañca kāraṇañca sallakkhetvā ati pañcasu pi nikāyesu itas citas ca tassa tassa
translated: and he has considered the suttas and reasons here and there in the five Nikāyas.

original: kammaṭṭhānassa anurūpaṃ suttapadañceva suttānugataṃ yuttiñca suṭṭhu upalakkhetvā.
analyzed: kammaṭṭhānassa anurūpam sutta padam ca iva sutta anugatam yuttim ca suṭṭhu upalakkhetvā
translated: He should carefully note the terms of the meditation subject and the reasoning based on the suttas that is in conformity with it.

original: Sappāyāsappāyaṃ yojetvāti yassa kammaṭṭhānaṃ ācikkhati, tassa upakārānupakāraṃ yuttiṃ
analyzed: sappāya asappāyam yojetvā ati yassa kammaṭṭhānam ācikkhati tassa upakāra anupakāram yuttim
translated: He should apply the right and wrong conditions: he should apply the reasoning about what is helpful and harmful to the person to whom he is teaching the meditation subject.🔽Or the meaning can be taken as “having taken it up, having placed it properly in his heart.”

original: magganena yojetvā, samādāya vā sammadeva hadaye ṭhapetvāti attho. Mahāmaggaṃ dassentoti
analyzed: magganena yojetvā samādāya vā sammadā eva hadaye ṭhapetvā ati atthaḥ mahā maggam dassento ti
translated: Showing the main road:

original: kammaṭṭhānavidhiṃ mahāmaggaṃ katvā dassento.
analyzed: kammaṭṭhāna vidhim mahā maggam katvā dassento
translated: making the directions for the meditation subject the main road.🔽Everywhere: in this and that monastery.

original: Sabbatthāti tattha tattha vihāre. Vattapaṭipattiṃ kurumānenāti paviṭṭhakāle āgantukavattaṃ,🔽nikkhamanakāle gamikavattanti yathārahaṃ taṃ taṃ vattaṃ pūrentena. Sabbapārihāriyatelanti
analyzed: sabbattha āti tattha tattha vihāre vatta paṭipattim kurumānena ati paviṭṭha kāle āgantuka vattam  nikkhamana kāle gamika vattanti yathāraham tam tam vattam pūrentena sabba pārihāriya telanti
translated: Who is practicing the proper conduct: who is fulfilling this or that proper conduct as required, the conduct for an incoming monk on entering,🔽and the conduct for an outgoing monk on leaving.🔽Oil for all: oil to be kept for the limbs or for all the monks.

original: sabbesaṃ aṅgānaṃ, sabbesaṃ vā bhikkhūnaṃ atthāya pariharitabbatelaṃ. Ṭhapemīti anujānāpanaṃ.
analyzed: sabbesam aṅgānam sabbesam vā bhikkhūnam atthāya pariharitabba telam ṭhapemi iti anujānāpanaṃ
translated: I allow: I give permission.

original: Yaṃ taṃ sammāvattaṃ paññattanti sambandho. Ekadivasaṃ sāyaṃ vissajjitenāpīti yojanā.
analyzed: yam tam sammāvattam paññattanti sambandhaḥ eka divasam sāyam vissajjitena api iti yojanā
translated: The connection is this: “The proper conduct has been laid down.” The construction is: “Even by one who has been dismissed in the evening for one day.”

original: Ārocetabbaṃ āgamanakāraṇaṃ. Sappāyavelā sarīracittānaṃ kallasamayo.
analyzed: ārocetabbam āgamana kāraṇam sa ppāya velā sarīra cittānam kalla samayaḥ
translated: The reason for coming should be announced. The time is suitable for the body and mind.

original: Cariyāvaṇṇanā🔽43. Santāne rāgassa ussannabhāvena caraṇaṃ pavatti rāgacariyā, sā sassatāsayādayo🔽viya daṭṭhabbā. Tathā dosacariyādayo. Saṃsaggo sampayogārahavasena veditabbo, yathā🔽“rāgamohacariyā dosamohacariyā”tiādi. Sannipāto ekasantatipariyāpannatāvasena, yathā🔽“rāgadosacariyā rāgadosamohacariyā”tiādi. Imā eva hi sandhāya “aparāpi catasso”ti
analyzed: cariyā vaṇṇanā  santāne rāgassa ussanna bhāvena caraṇam pavatti rāga cariyā sā  viya daṭṭhabbā tathā dosa cariyā ādayo saṃsaggaḥ sampayoga āraha vasena veditabbaḥ yathā  rāga moha cariyā dosa moha cariyā atiādi sannipātaḥ eka santati pariyāpanna tā vasena yathā  rāga dosa cariyā rāga dosa moha cariyā atiādi imāḥ eva hi sandhāya aparā api catassā ti
translated: The Commentary on the Practice

original: vuttaṃ. Tathāti yathā rāgādīnaṃ, tathā saddhādīnaṃ saṃsaggasannipātavasena saddhābuddhicariyā🔽saddhāvitakkacariyā buddhivitakkacariyā saddhābuddhivitakkacariyāti. Imā aparāpi🔽catasso. Evanti saṃsaggasannipātavasena. Saṃsagganti saṃsajjanaṃ missīkaraṇaṃ “rāgasaddhācariyā
analyzed: vuttam tathā iti yathā rāga ādīnam tathā saddhā ādīnam saṃsagga sannipāta vasena saddhā buddhi cariyā 🔽saddhā vitakka cariyā buddhi vitakka cariyā saddhā buddhi vitakka cariyā ati imā aparā api 🔽catasso evanti saṃsagga sannipāta vasena saṃsagganti saṃsajjanam missīkaraṇam rāga saddhā cariyā
translated: Practice of lust is the occurrence of lust by the state of its uprising in the continuum. It should be seen as the abode of eternalism, etc. Likewise, the practice of hate, etc. Association should be understood as the worthiness of association. As it is said: “The practice of lust and delusion, the practice of hate and delusion,” etc. Combination is the state of being included in one continuum. As it is said: “The practice of lust, hate, and delusion, the practice of lust, hate, and delusion,” etc. It is with reference to these that it is said: “There are four other kinds.” Likewise means as lust, etc., so also faith, etc. The practice of faith and understanding, the practice of faith and applied thought, the practice of understanding and applied thought, the practice of faith, understanding, and applied thought—these are the other four. Thus means by association and combination. Association is the associating, the mixing together, of the practice of lust and faith,

original: dosasaddhācariyā”tiādinā. Anekāti tesaṭṭhi, tato atirekāpi vā, tā pana asammohantena
analyzed: dosa saddhā cariyā ati ādinā anekā ati tatas atirekā api vā tā pana asammoha antena
translated: and the teacher’s faith, and so on.

original: saṃyuttasuttaṭīkāyaṃ vitthārato dassitāti tattha vuttanayena veditabbā. “Pakatī”ti
analyzed: saṃyutta sutta ṭīkā ayam vitthārataḥ dassitā ati tattha vutta nayena veditabbā pakatī iti
translated: Many: there are sixty-three, or more than that. But they are shown in detail in the Commentary on the Saṃyutta Nikāya, which should be consulted.

original: iminā asati paṭipakkhabhāvanāyaṃ tattha tattha santāne cariyāya sabhāvabhūtataṃ dasseti.🔽Ussannatā aññadhammehi rāgādīnaṃ adhikatā, yato rāgacariyādīnaṃ paccayasamavāye rāgādayo
analyzed: iminā asati paṭipakkha bhāvanā ayam tattha tattha santāne cariyāya sabhāva bhūta tam dasseti  ussanna tā añña dhammehi rāga ādīnam adhika tā yatas rāga cariyā ādīnam paccaya samavāye rāga ādayo
translated: By “comes to be” he shows that the temperaments are natural to the respective continuities only when there is no development of their opposites.

original: balavanto honti, abhiṇhañca pavattanti. Tāsaṃ vasenāti channaṃ mūlacariyānaṃ vasena🔽chaḷeva puggalā honti. Aññathā anekapuggalā siyuṃ, tathā ca sati adhippetatthasiddhi
analyzed: balavantaḥ honti abhiṇhan ca pavattanti tāsam vasena ati channam mūla cariyānam vasena  chaḍ eva puggalāḥ honti aññathā aneka puggalā siyum tathā ca sati
translated: The “predominance” of greed, etc., is their excess over other states, by which greed, etc., become strong and frequently occur when the conditions for the greed temperament, etc., are present.🔽By “according as” he shows that there are only six kinds of persons according to the six basic temperaments;

original: ca na siyāti adhippāyo.
analyzed: ca na siyāti adhippāyaḥ
translated: otherwise there would be many kinds of persons, and in that case the purpose of the exposition would not be served.

original: Saddhā balavatī hoti rāgussanne santāne tadanuguṇassa dhammassa niyogato adhikabhāvasambhavato.
analyzed: saddhā balavatī hoti rāga ussanne santāne tad anuguṇassa dhammassa niyogataḥ adhika bhāva sambhavato
translated: Faith is strong in a continuity in which greed is predominant, because it is possible for a state that is in conformity with greed to be strong by being frequently repeated.

original: Tenāha “rāgassa āsannaguṇattā”ti, sinehapariyesanāpariccajanehi sabhāgadhammattāti
analyzed: tena āha rāgassa āsanna guṇa ttā ati sineha pariyesanā pariccajanehi sa bhāga dhamma ttā ati
translated: The meaning is that it is a state similar to the seeking and the not abandoning of affection.

original: attho. Sabhāgo hi dūrepi āsanneyevāti sabhāgatālakkhaṇamidha āsannaggahaṇaṃ. Tattha🔽saddhāya siniyhanaṃ pasādavasena akālussiyaṃ alūkhatā, rāgassa pana rañjanavasena.🔽Saddhāya pariyesanaṃ adhimuccanavasena tanninnatā, rāgassa taṇhāyanavasena. Saddhāya
analyzed: attho sabhāgaḥ hi dūre pi āsannā iya iva ati sabhāga tā lakkhaṇam idha āsanna ggahaṇam tattha  saddhāya siniyhanam pasāda vasena akālussiyam a lūkha tā rāgassa pana rañjana vasena  saddhāya pariyesanam adhimuccana vasena tad ninna tā rāgassa taṇhāyana vasena saddhāya
translated: For what is similar is called “near” even when far away. So the characteristic of similarity is what is meant here by “nearness.”🔽Herein, the “sticking” by faith is non-timorousness in the sense of confidence, while that by lust is in the sense of delight.

original: apariccajanaṃ okappanavasena anupakkhandanaṃ, rāgassa abhisaṅgavasenāti evaṃ bhinnasabhāvānampi
analyzed: a pariccajanam okappana vasena an upakkhandanam rāgassa abhisaṅga vasena ati evam bhinna sabhāvānam pi
translated: The “seeking” by faith is bent on it in the sense of resolution, while that by lust is in the sense of craving. The “not abandoning” by faith is not turning away from it in the sense of reliance, while that by lust is in the sense of attachment.🔽So although they are different in nature,

original: tesaṃ yathā alūkhatādisāmaññena sabhāgatā, evaṃ taṃsamaṅgīnampi puggalānanti āha
analyzed: tesam yathā a lūkha tā ādi sāmaññena sabhā gatāḥ evam tad samaṅgīnam pi āha
translated: they are similar in being non-timorousness, etc., and so they are similar in the way that the persons who possess them are.

original: “rāgacaritassa saddhācarito sabhāgo”ti.
analyzed: rāga caritassa saddhā carito sabhāgaḥ ti
translated: That is why it is said: “One of lusting temperament has a similar nature to one of faithful temperament” .

original: Paññā balavatī hoti dosussanne santāne tadanuguṇassa dhammassa niyogato adhikabhāvasambhavato.
analyzed: paññā balavatī hoti dosa ussanne santāne tad anuguṇassa dhammassa niyogataḥ adhika bhāva sambhavato
translated: Understanding is strong in a stream of consciousness that is clear owing to hate’s absence, because of the possibility of its being more evident owing to the presence of a state that is in conformity with it.

original: Tenāha “dosassa āsannaguṇattā”ti, anallīyanapariyesanaparivajjanehi sabhāgadhammattāti
analyzed: tena āha dosassa āsanna guṇa ttā ati an allīyana pariyesana parivajjanehi sabhāga dhamma ttā ati
translated: Hence he said: “because hate is a proximate characteristic. ” The meaning is: because of the similarity of state in the absence of cleaving, in the search, and in the avoidance.

original: attho. Tattha paññāya ārammaṇassa anallīyanaṃ tassa yathāsabhāvāvabodhavasena visaṃsaṭṭhatā,🔽dosassa pana byāpajjanavasena. Paññāya pariyesanaṃ yathābhūtadosapavicayo, dosassa
analyzed: atthaḥ tattha paññāyaḥ ārammaṇassa tassa yathā sabhāva avabodha vasena visaṃsaṭṭha tā  dosassa pana byāpajjana vasena paññāya pariyesanam yathābhūta dosa pavicayaḥ dosassa
translated: Herein, the absence of cleaving to an object by understanding is the non-admixture of it by the penetration of its specific nature,🔽but hate is the admixture by the state of annoyance. The search by understanding is the investigation of the specific nature of what is,

original: abhūtadosanijigīsā. Paññāya parivajjanaṃ nibbindanādivasena ñāṇutrāso, dosassa ahitādhānavasena
analyzed: abhūta dosa nijigīsā paññāya parivajjanam nibbindana ādi vasena dosassa ahita ādhāna vasena
translated: but hate is the desire to investigate what is not. The avoidance by understanding is the fear of knowledge by the state of dispassion, etc.,

original: chaḍḍananti evaṃ bhinnasabhāvānampi tesaṃ yathā anallīyanādisāmaññena sabhāgatā,
analyzed: evam bhinna sabhāvānam pi tesam yathā an allīyana ādi sāmaññena sabhā gatā
translated: but hate is the casting aside by the state of doing harm. So, although these are dissimilar in specific nature, they are similar in the absence of cleaving, etc.,

original: evaṃ taṃsamaṅgīnampi puggalānanti āha “dosacaritassa buddhicarito sabhāgo”ti.
analyzed: evam tad samaṅgīnam pi puggalānam ti āha dosa caritassa buddhi caritaḥ sabhāgaḥ ti
translated: and in the same way the persons who possess them are similar. Hence he said: “One of hating temperament is similar to one of speculative temperament. ”

original: Antarāyakarā vitakkāti micchāvitakkā micchāsaṅkappā uppajjanti mohussanne santāne
analyzed: antarāya karāḥ micchāvitakkāḥ micchāsaṅkappāḥ uppajjanti mohut sanne santāne
translated: Thoughts that are obstructive: wrong thoughts, wrong intentions, arise in a mental continuity that is flooded with delusion,

original: tadanuguṇassa dhammassa yebhuyyena pavattisabbhāvato. Tenāha “mohassa āsannalakkhaṇattā”ti,
analyzed: tad anuguṇassa dhammassa yebhuyyena pavatti sabbhāvato tena āha mohassa āsanna lakkhaṇa ttā ti
translated: because of the predominance of the occurrence of states that are in conformity with that. Hence he said: “because delusion is a proximate characteristic. ”

original: anavaṭṭhānacañcalabhāvehi sabhāgadhammattāti attho. Tattha vitakkassa anavaṭṭhānaṃ🔽parikappavasena savipphāratāya, mohassa sammūḷhatāvasena byākulatāya. Tathā vitakkassa
analyzed: anavaṭṭhāna cañcala bhāvehi sa bhāga dhamma ttā ti atthaḥ tattha vitakkassa anavaṭṭhānam  parikappa vasena sa vipphāra tāya mohassa sammūḷha tā vasena byākula tāya tathā vitakkassa
translated: The meaning is that they are similar in being unfixed and unsteady. Herein, applied thought is unfixed🔽because it is associated with change of state by way of modification. Delusion is unfixed because it is confused by being associated with confusion. So too, applied thought is unsteady

original: lahuparivitakkanena tadaṅgacalatāya cañcalatā, mohassa anogāḷhatāyāti evaṃ bhinnasabhāvānampi🔽tesaṃ yathā anavaṭṭhānādisāmaññena sabhāgatā, evaṃ taṃsamaṅgīnampi puggalānanti āha
analyzed: lahu parivitakkanena tad aṅga calatāya cañcala tā mohassa anogāḷha tāya ati evam bhinna sabhāvānam pi  tesam yathā anavaṭṭhāna ādi sāmaññena sabhā gatāḥ evam tad samaṅgīnam pi puggalānam ti āha
translated: because it is associated with instability by being associated with quick change. Delusion is unsteady because it is unsuppressed. So although they are dissimilar in individual essence,

original: “mohacaritassa vitakkacarito sabhāgo”ti.🔽Taṇhā rāgoyeva sabhāvato, tasmā rāgacariyāvinimuttā taṇhācariyā natthīti attho. Taṃsampayuttoti🔽tena rāgena sampayutto, dosādayo viya tena vippayutto natthīti adhippāyo. Tadubhayanti
analyzed: moha caritassa vitakka carito sabhāgaḥ ti  taṇhā rāgo yā iva sabhāvato tasmā rāga cariyā vinimuttā taṇhā cariyā na atthi iti attho tad sampayutto ti  tena rāgena sampayuttaḥ dosa ādayaḥ viya tena vippayuttaḥ natthi iti adhippāyaḥ tat ubhayam ti
translated: they are similar in being unfixed, etc., and so they are similar in that respect. So too with the persons who possess them. Hence it was said above: “The type of person of deluded temperament is similar to the type of person of discursive temperament.”🔽Craving is just greed by nature. So the meaning is that there is no type of person of craving temperament that is not included in the type of person of greed temperament. Associated with that: the meaning is that there is no one not associated with that greed, as there is with hate, etc. Both of those:

original: taṇhāmānadvayaṃ. Nātivattatīti sabhāvato, sampayogavasena ca na atikkamitvā vaṭṭati.
analyzed: taṇhā māna dvayam na ativattati iti sabhāvataḥ sampayoga vasena ca na atikkamitvā vaṭṭati
translated: the meaning is that there is no one not included in the two types of temperament due to craving and conceit. He does not exceed: he does not go beyond them in individual essence or in association.

original: Kāmañcettha yathā rāgadosehi sampayogavasena saha vattamānassapi mohassa ussannatāvasena
analyzed: kāmam ca itthā yathā rāga dosehi sampayoga vasena saha vattamānassa api mohassa ussanna tā vasena
translated: But though delusion occurs together with greed and hate by association, it is nevertheless a separate type of temperament because of its prominence.

original: visuṃ cariyābhāvo, na kevalaṃ mohasseva, tathā saddhābuddhivitakkānaṃ. Evaṃ rāgena🔽satipi sampayoge mānassāpi visuṃ cariyābhāvo yutto siyā, evaṃ santepi rāgapaṭighamānadiṭṭhivicikicchāvijjānaṃ
analyzed: visum cariyā bhāvaḥ na kevalam mohassa iva tathā saddhā buddhi vitakkānaṃ evam rāgena  sati api sampayoge mānassa api visum cariyā bhāvaḥ yuttaḥ siyā evam sante pi rāga paṭigha māna diṭṭhi vicikicchā vijjānam
translated: And so too are faith, understanding, and thinking.🔽So too, though conceit occurs together with greed by association, it is nevertheless a separate type of temperament.

original: viya anusayaṭṭho imesaṃ rāgādīnaṃyeva āveṇiko cariyaṭṭhoti, nattheva mānacariyā.
analyzed: anusaya ṭṭho imesam rāga ādīnaṃ yeva āveṇiko cariya ṭṭho ti nattha iva māna cariyā
translated: But although that is so, the state of being a temperament is a special quality of these, greed, etc., only, as latent tendencies, as is the state of being a root of profit and so on; it is not a quality of conceit, etc.,🔽so it is said, “Temperament is a state of being of defilements.”🔽But the state of being a temperament is said of them because it is evident in them. And the state of being is the nature.

original: Yato cariyā “pakatī”ti vuttā. Pakati ca sabhāvoti. Eteneva diṭṭhiyāpi visuṃ cariyābhāvābhāvo
analyzed: yatas cariyā pakatīti vuttā pakati ca sabhāvo ti etena iva diṭṭhiyā api visum cariyā bhāva abhāvo
translated: This is how it should be regarded as stated in the Commentaries.

original: saṃvaṇṇitoti daṭṭhabbo. Aṭṭhakathāyaṃ pana mohacariyantogadhāva diṭṭhicariyāti dassetuṃ🔽“mohanidānattā cā”tiādi vuttaṃ. Tattha ca-saddena sampayogaṃ samuccinoti mohanidānattā,
analyzed: saṃvaṇṇitoti daṭṭhabbaḥ aṭṭhakathā ayam pana diṭṭhi cariyā ti dassetuṃ  moha nidāna ttā ca ati ādi vuttam tattha ca saddena sampayogam samuccinoti moha nidāna ttā
translated: But in the Commentary the words “and because it is the source of delusion” are said in order to show that the temperament of views is included in the temperament of delusion.🔽And the word “and” in the Commentary is meant to include association.

original: mohasampayuttattā cāti.
analyzed: moha sampayutta ttā ca ati
translated: So the words “because it is the source of delusion” and “because it is associated with delusion” should be understood as said.

original: 44. Kiṃ sappāyanti kīdisaṃ senāsanādisappāyaṃ. Pubbāciṇṇaṃ purimajātīsu ācaritaṃ.
analyzed: kim sappāyanti kīdisam senāsana ādi sappāyam pubba āciṇṇam purima jātīsu ācaritam
translated: What is suitable? What kind of suitable dwelling-place, etc., is there? What was done in the past? What was done in previous births.

original: Ekacceti upatissattheraṃ sandhāyāha. Tena hi vimuttimagge tathā vuttaṃ. Pubbe kirāti🔽kira-saddo arucisūcanattho. Iṭṭhappayogo manāpakiriyā. Subhakammabahulo yebhuyyena
analyzed: ekaccā iti upatissa theram sandhāya āha tena hi vimutti magge tathā vuttam pubbe  kira saddaḥ aruci sūcana atthaḥ iṭṭha ppayogaḥ manāpa kiriyā subha kamma bahulaḥ yebhuyyena
translated: “Some”: he refers to the Elder Upatissa, since it is said accordingly in the Vimuttimagga. “In the past, it seems”:🔽the word “it seems” shows that he does not assert it. “What was done in the past” is the doing of what is pleasing and the doing of what is beautiful.

original: sobhanakammakārī. Na sabbe rāgacaritā eva honti, aluddhānampi pubbe iṭṭhappayogasubhakammabahulatāsambhavato,
analyzed: sobhana kamma kārī na sabbe rāga caritāḥ eva honti aluddhānam pi pubbe iṭṭha ppayoga subha kamma bahula tā sambhavato
translated: Those who have done much that is beautiful are not all lustful by nature; for it is possible that those who are not greedy may do what is pleasing and do much that is beautiful in the past,🔽and it is possible that they may be reborn here after dying in heaven.

original: saggā cavitvā idhūpapattisambhavato ca. Etena asati pubbahetuniyāme yathāvuttakāraṇamattena
analyzed: cavitvā idhu upapatti sambhavataḥ ca etena asati pubba hetu niyāme yathā vutta kāraṇa mattena
translated: By this he shows that, in the absence of a fixed cause in the past, their greediness is due to the mere reason stated,

original: na tesaṃ luddhatā, luddhabhāvahetukā ca rāgacariyāti imamatthaṃ dasseti.🔽Itareti chedanādikammabahulā nirayādito idhūpapannā ca na sabbe dosamohacaritā eva
analyzed: na tesam luddha tā luddha bhāva hetukā ca rāga cariyā ati imam attham dasseti  itarā iti chedana ādi kamma bahulā niraya āditaḥ idhu upapannā ca na sabbe dosa moha caritāḥ eva
translated: and that their lustful nature is due to the cause of their greediness.🔽“The others”: those who have done much cutting down, etc., and who have been reborn here after dying in hell, etc., are not all by nature hateful and deluded.

original: hontīti yojanā. Idhāpi yathāvuttakāraṇassa kodhanabhāve, mūḷhabhāve ca anekantikattā
analyzed: honti iti yojanā idha api yathā vutta kāraṇassa kodhana bhāve mūḷha bhāve ca anekantika ttā
translated: This is how the construction should be understood. Here too, since the state of being angry and the state of being deluded are not invariable in one who has the reason stated,

original: dosamohacaritatāyapi anekaṃsikatā veditabbā. Dhātūnaṃ ussadaniyamo yadi pamāṇato,🔽so natthi, atha sāmatthiyato, sopi ekaṃsiko na upalabbhatīti dassento āha “yathāvutteneva
analyzed: anekaṃsikatā veditabbā dhātūnam ussada niyamaḥ yadi pamāṇataḥ  so natthi atha sāmatthiyato saḥ api ekaṃsikaḥ na upalabbhati iti dassentaḥ āha yathā vuttena iva
translated: If the predominance of elements is according to measure,🔽then it does not exist; if it is according to capacity, then that is not found to be one-sided. Showing this, he says, “There is no such thing as a predominance of elements in the way stated.”

original: nayena ussadaniyamo nāma natthī”ti. Tattha yathāvuttenevāti “dvinnaṃ pana dhātūna”ntiādinā
analyzed: nayena ussada niyamaḥ nāma natthi iti tattha yathā vuttena iva ati dvinnam pana
translated: Herein, in the way stated means in the way stated thus, “But in the case of the two elements” ,

original: vuttappakāreneva. Dosaniyameti semhādidosādhikatāya rāgādicarito hotīti dosavasena🔽cariyāniyame “semhādhiko rāgacarito”ti vatvā puna “semhādhiko mohacarito”ti, “vātādhiko
analyzed: vutta ppakārena iva dosa niyama iti semha ādi dosa adhikatāya rāga ādi caritaḥ hoti iti dosa vasena  cariyā niyame semha adhikaḥ rāga caritā iti vatvā punar semha adhikaḥ moha caritā iti vāta adhikaḥ
translated: etc. . In the case of the predominance of bile, one is of greedy temperament because of the predominance of bile.

original: mohacarito”ti vatvā puna “vātādhiko rāgacarito”ti ca vuttattā tampi dosavasena niyamavacanaṃ🔽pubbāparaviruddhameva. Aparicchinnavacananti paricchedakārikāya paññāya na paricchinditvā
analyzed: moha caritā iti vatvā puna vāta adhikaḥ rāga caritā iti ca dosa vasena niyama vacanam  pubba apara viruddham eva aparicchinna vacananti pariccheda kārikāya paññāya na paricchinditvā
translated: After saying, “One with a predominance of phlegm is of greedy temperament,” he again says, “One with a predominance of phlegm is of deluded temperament,” and after saying, “One with a predominance of wind is of deluded temperament,” he again says, “One with a predominance of wind is of greedy temperament.”🔽Therefore that statement of predominance according to bile is contradictory to what precedes and what follows.

original: vuttavacanaṃ, anupaparikkhitavacananti attho.
analyzed: vutta vacanam anupaparikkhita vacanan ti attho
translated: Unrestricted statement means a statement that is not restricted by the function of discrimination. The meaning is: a statement that is not investigated.

original: Ussadakittaneti vipākakathāyaṃ gahitaussadakittane. Pubbahetuniyāmenāti purimabhave🔽pavattalobhādihetuniyāmena. Niyāmoti ca tesaṃyeva lobhādīnaṃ paṭiniyato lubbhanādisabhāvo🔽daṭṭhabbo. Lobho ussado etesanti lobhussadā, ussannalobhā, lobhādhikāti attho. Amohussadā
analyzed: ussada kittana iti vipāka kathā ayam gahita ossada kittane pubba hetu niyāmena ati purima bhave  pavatta lobha ādi hetu niyāmena ca tesam yeva lobha ādīnam paṭiniyataḥ lubbhana ādi sabhāvaḥ  daṭṭhabbaḥ lobhaḥ ussadaḥ etesanti lobhussadāḥ ussanna lobhā lobha adhikā iti atthaḥ a mohussadā
translated: In the order of the prior cause,🔽The “order” is the fixed nature of greed, etc., which is seen as the fixed nature of greed, etc.🔽Those who have greed and conceit are greedy and conceited. The meaning is: they have excessive greed. Those who have non-delusion and conceit are non-deluded and conceited.

original: cāti ettha ca-saddo sampiṇḍanattho. Tena ye ime lobhussadatādīnaṃ paccekaṃ vomissato🔽ca cuddasa pabhedā icchitā, te anavasesato sampiṇḍeti yathāvuttesu chasveva tesaṃ
analyzed: ca ati ettha ca saddo sampiṇḍana attho tena ye ime lobhussada tā ādīnam paccekam  ca cuddasa pabhedāḥ icchitā te anavasesataḥ sampiṇḍā iti yathā vuttesu chasu eva tesam
translated: The word “and” in the phrase “non-delusion and conceit” has the meaning of “together with.” Therefore, it includes without exception🔽the fourteen kinds of greed, conceit, etc., which are mentioned separately,

original: antogadhattā. Phalabhūtā cettha lobhussadatādayo daṭṭhabbā.
analyzed: phala bhūtā ca ittha lobhussada tā ādayaḥ daṭṭhabbā
translated: in the six mentioned above, because they are included in them. The fruits should be seen as greed, conceit, etc.

original: Idāni taṃ nesaṃ lobhussadatādīnaṃ paccekaṃ vomissakatādiṃ vibhāgena dassetuṃ “yassa
analyzed: idāni tam nesam lobhussada tā ādīnam paccekam vomissaka tā ādim vibhāgena dassetum yassa
translated: Now, in order to show the separate mention, etc., of greed, conceit, etc., the text begins with “If a person” and so on.

original: hī”tiādi āraddhaṃ. Kammāyūhanakkhaṇeti kammakaraṇavelāyaṃ. Lobho balavāti lobho tajjāya
analyzed: hi itiādi āraddham lobho
translated: The moment of accumulating kamma is the time of doing kamma. Greed is strong. Greed is the cause of the arising of the kamma.

original: paccayasāmaggiyā sāmatthiyato adhiko hoti. Alobho mandoti tappaṭipakkho alobho dubbalo.
analyzed: paccaya sāmaggiyā sāmatthiyataḥ adhikaḥ hoti alobhaḥ mandaḥ ti tad paṭipakkho alobhaḥ dubbalaḥ
translated: Non-greed is weak: the opposite of greed, non-greed, is weak.

original: Kathaṃ panete lobhālobhā aññamaññaṃ ujuvipaccanīkabhūtā ekakkhaṇe pavattantīti? Na
analyzed: katham pana ete lobha alobhāḥ aññam aññam uju vipaccanīka bhūtāḥ eka kkhaṇe pavattanti iti na
translated: But how can these greed and non-greed, which are mutually incompatible, occur in the same consciousness?

original: kho panetaṃ evaṃ daṭṭhabbaṃ “ekakkhaṇe pavattantī”ti. Nikantikkhaṇaṃ pana āyūhanapakkhiyameva
analyzed: kho pana itam evam daṭṭhabbam eka khaṇe pavattanti iti nikanti khaṇam pana āyūhana pakkhiyam eva
translated: They should not be regarded as occurring in the same moment. But it is said in this way because the moment of attachment is reckoned as the accumulation stage.🔽The same method applies in the other cases.

original: katvā evaṃ vuttaṃ. Eseva nayo sesesupi. Pariyādātunti abhibhavituṃ na sakkoti. Yo
analyzed: katvā evam vuttam esā iva nayaḥ sesesu pi pariyādātum na sakkoti yaḥ
translated: He cannot overcome: he cannot surpass.

original: hi “evaṃsundaraṃ evaṃvipulaṃ evaṃmahagghañca na sakkā dātu”ntiādinā amuttacāgatādivasena
analyzed: hi evam sundaram evam vipulam evam mahat han ca na sakkā dātum ti ādinā amutta ca āgata ādi vasena
translated: For non-greed associated with the volition that occurs as “I cannot give such a beautiful, such a large, such an expensive thing” and so on, with the character of stinginess, etc.,

original: pavattāya cetanāya sampayutto alobho, so sammadeva lobhaṃ pariyādātuṃ na sakkoti.🔽Dosamohānaṃ anuppattiyā, tādisapaccayalābhena ca adosāmohā balavanto. Tasmāti lobhādosāmohānaṃ
analyzed: pavattāya cetanāya sampayutto alobho so sammat eva lobham pariyādātum na sakkoti  dosa mohānam anuppattiyā tādisa paccaya lābhena ca a dosa a mohāḥ balavantaḥ tasmā ati lobha a dosa a mohānam
translated: cannot overcome greed properly.🔽Because of the non-arising of hate and delusion, and because of the strength of non-hate and non-delusion due to the obtaining of such conditions,

original: balavabhāvato, alobhadosamohānañca dubbalabhāvatoti vuttameva kāraṇaṃ paccāmasati.
analyzed: balava bhāvataḥ alobha dosa mohānam ca dubbala bhāvataḥ ti vuttam eva kāraṇam paccāmasati
translated: we reply that the reason stated is the same, namely, “because of the strength of greed, hate, and delusion, and the weakness of non-greed, non-hate, and non-delusion.”

original: Soti taṃsamaṅgīpuggalo. Tena kammenāti tena lobhādiupanissayavatā kusalakammunā.
analyzed: saḥ ti tad samaṅgī puggalaḥ tena kammena ati tena lobha ādi upanissayavatā kusala kammunā
translated: “He” is the person who has the same limbs. “By that action”: by that profitable action which has greed, etc., as its decisive-support.

original: Sukhasīloti sakhilo. Tamevatthaṃ “akkodhano”ti pariyāyena vadati.
analyzed: sukha sīlaḥ iti tam evattham akkodhanaḥ ti pariyāyena vadati
translated: “Good-natured”: gentle. He says the same thing in a different way when he says “not angry.”

original: Purimanayenevāti pubbe vuttanayānusārena mandā alobhādosā lobhadose pariyādātuṃ na🔽sakkonti, amoho pana balavā mohaṃ pariyādātuṃ sakkotīti evaṃ tattha tattha vāre yathārahaṃ
analyzed: purima nayena iva āti pubbe vutta naya anusārena mandāḥ alobha adosāḥ lobha dose pariyādātum na  sakkonti amohaḥ pana balavā moham pariyādātum sakkoti iti evam tattha tattha vāre yathāraham
translated: “In the same way”: in the same way as stated above. The weak greed and hatred are unable to overcome greed and hatred,

original: atidesattho veditabbo. Duṭṭhoti kodhano. Dandhoti mandapañño. Sīlakoti sukhasīlo.🔽Ettha ca lobhavasena, dosamohalobhadosalobhamohadosamohalobhadosamohavasenāti tayo
analyzed: atidesa atthaḥ veditabbaḥ duṭṭhaḥ iti kodhanaḥ dandhaḥ iti manda pañño sīlako ti sukha sīlaḥ  ettha ca lobha vasena dosa moha lobha dosa lobha moha dosa moha lobha dosa moha vasena ati tayoḥ
translated: but the strong delusion is able to overcome delusion. Thus the meaning should be understood in each case according to the context. “Angry” means hating. “Slow-witted” means dull-witted. “Good-natured” means gentle.

original: ekakā, tayo dukā, eko tikoti lobhādiussadavasena akusalapakkheyeva satta vārā, tathā
analyzed: ekakā tayaḥ dukā ekaḥ tikaḥ ti lobha ādi ussada vasena satta vārā tathā
translated: And here, by way of the predominance of greed, hatred, delusion, greed-hatred, greed-delusion, hatred-delusion, greed-hatred-delusion, there are three single factors, three pairs, and one triplet. Thus there are seven permutations in the unprofitable section by way of the predominance of greed, etc.

original: kusalapakkhe alobhādiussadavasenāti cuddasa vārā labbhanti. Tattha alobhadosāmohā,
analyzed: kusala pakkhe alobha ādi ussada vasena ati cuddasa vārāḥ labbhanti tattha alobha dosa amohā
translated: Likewise, in the profitable section, by way of the predominance of non-greed, etc., there are fourteen permutations. Herein, non-greed, non-hatred, and non-delusion,

original: alobhādosamohā, alobhadosamohā balavantoti āgatehi kusalapakkhe tatiyadutiyapaṭhamavārehi🔽dosussadamohussadadosamohussadavārā gahitā eva honti, tathā akusalapakkhe lobhādosamohā,
analyzed: alobha a dosa mohāḥ alobha dosa mohāḥ balavanto ti āgatehi kusala pakkhe tatiya dutiya paṭhama vārehi  dosussada mohussada dosa mohussada vārāḥ gahitāḥ eva honti tathā akusala pakkhe lobhā dosa mohā
translated: When the three triads beginning with “non-greed, non-hate, non-delusion” and “non-greed, non-hate, non-delusion are strong” are stated,🔽the triads beginning with “hate-dominated delusion,” “delusion-dominated hate,” and “delusion-dominated hate” are included in the profitable side,

original: lobhadosāmohā, lobhādosāmohā balavantoti āgatehi tatiyadutiyapaṭhamavārehi adosussadaamohussadaadosāmohussadavārā
analyzed: lobha dosa amohāḥ lobha a dosa amohāḥ balavantaḥ ti āgatehi tatiya dutiya paṭhama vārehi a dosussada a mohussada a dosa a mohussada vārāḥ
translated: and when the three triads beginning with “greed, hate, delusion” and “greed, hate, delusion are strong” are stated, the triads beginning with “hate-dominated delusion,” “delusion-dominated hate,” and “hate-dominated delusion” are included in the unprofitable side.

original: gahitā evāti akusalakusalapakkhesu tayo tayo vāre antogadhe katvā aṭṭheva vārā dassitā.🔽Ye pana ubhayesaṃ missatāvasena lobhālobhussadavārādayo apare ekūnapaññāsa vārā dassetabbā,
analyzed: gahitāḥ eva ati akusala kusala pakkhesu tayo tayo vāre antogadhe katvā aṭṭhā iva vārāḥ dassitā  ye pana ubhayesam missa tā vasena apare ekūnapaññāsa vārāḥ dassetabbā
translated: So the eight triads are shown by including three triads in each of the profitable and unprofitable sides.

original: te alabbhanato eva na dassitā. Na hi ekasmiṃ santāne antarena avatthantaraṃ “lobho
analyzed: te alabbhanataḥ eva na dassitāḥ na hi ekasmin santāne antarena avattha antaram lobho
translated: But the remaining forty-nine triads beginning with “greed-dominated greed” and “non-greed-dominated non-greed” that could be shown by taking them in pairs from both sides are not shown because they are impossible. For it is not proper to say “greed and non-greed are strong” in a single continuity without distinguishing the states.

original: ca balavā, alobho cā”tiādi yujjatīti, paṭipakkhavasena vā hi etesaṃ balavadubbalabhāvo,
analyzed: ca balavā alobho ca ati ādi yujjati iti paṭipakkha vasena vā hi etesam balavat ubbala bhāvaḥ
translated: Or alternatively, their strength and weakness is according to opposition.

original: sahajātadhammavasena vā. Tattha lobhassa tāva paṭipakkhavasena alobhena anadhibhūtatāya
analyzed: sahajāta dhamma vasena vā tattha lobhassa tāva paṭipakkha vasena alobhena anadhibhūtatāya
translated: or by the presence of conascent states. Herein, greed has strength by virtue of its being unconquered by non-greed, which is the opposite of greed.

original: balavabhāvo, tathā dosamohānaṃ adosāmohehi. Alobhādīnaṃ pana lobhādiabhibhavanato,
analyzed: tathā dosa mohānam a dosa a mohehi alobha ādīnam pana lobha ādi abhibhavanataḥ
translated: Likewise, hate and delusion have strength by virtue of their being unconquered by non-hate and non-delusion. But non-greed, etc., have strength by virtue of their conquest of greed, etc.,

original: sabbesañca samānajātiyamabhibhuyya pavattivasena sahajātadhammato balavabhāvo. Tena
analyzed: sabbesam ca samāna jātiyam abhibhuyya pavatti vasena sahajāta dhammataḥ balava bhāvaḥ tena
translated: and by the presence of conascent states in them, which is the reason for their being strong by conquering states of the same kind.

original: vuttaṃ aṭṭhakathāyaṃ “lobho balavā alobho mando, adosāmohā balavanto dosamohā mandā”ti.
analyzed: vuttam aṭṭhakathāyam lobhaḥ balavā alobhaḥ mandaḥ a dosa a mohāḥ balavantaḥ dosa mohāḥ mandā ti
translated: Hence it is said in the Paṭisambhidā: “Greed is strong, non-greed is weak; non-hate and non-delusion are strong, hate and delusion are weak” .

original: So ca nesaṃ mandabalavabhāvo purimūpanissayato tathā āsayassa paribhāvitatāya veditabbo.🔽Yo luddhoti vuttoti yo ussadakittane “luddho”ti vutto, ayaṃ idha cariyāvicāre “rāgacarito”ti
analyzed: so ca nesam manda balava bhāvo purima upanissayato tathā āsayassa paribhāvita tāya veditabbo  yaḥ luddhaḥ ti vuttaḥ ti yaḥ ussada kittane luddhaḥ iti vuttaḥ ayam idha cariyā vicāre rāga carito ti
translated: And this weakness and strength of theirs should be understood as due to the fact that the underlying tendency has been fully matured or not fully matured in the way already stated .🔽“The greedy” : those called “greedy” in the above passage beginning, “The greedy are for gains devoted” , should be understood here as “characterized by greed” .

original: veditabbo. Duṭṭhadandhāti “duṭṭho, dandho”ti ca vuttā yathākkamaṃ dosamohacaritā.
analyzed: veditabbaḥ duṭṭhadandhā ati duṭṭhaḥ dandho ti ca vuttā yathākkamam dosa moha caritā
translated: “The hating and the deluded” are respectively those called “the hating” and “the deluded” .

original: Paññavāti sātisayaṃ sappañño. Yato saddhāvitakkesu vijjamānesupi buddhicaritoti vuccati.
analyzed: paññavā ati sa atisayam sappaññaḥ yatas saddhā vitakkesu vijjamānesu pi buddhi carito ti vuccati
translated: “The wise” : the very wise, since he is called “characterized by understanding” even though faith and thought are present.

original: Alobhādosānaṃ balavabhāvo saddhūpanissayatāya vinā na hotīti āha “aluddhaaduṭṭhā
analyzed: alobha a dosānam balava bhāvaḥ saddhu upanissaya tāya vinā na hoti iti āha aluddha aduṭṭhā
translated: The strength of non-greed and non-hate does not exist without the support of faith. Therefore it is said: “Not greedy, not hating,

original: pasannapakatitāya saddhācaritā”ti.🔽Ayañca nayo sādhāraṇato vuttoti nibbattitapubbahetuniyāmavaseneva buddhicaritādikepi
analyzed: pasanna pakatitāya saddhā ācaritā ati  ayam ca nayaḥ sādhāraṇataḥ vuttaḥ ti nibbattita pubba hetu niyāma vasena iva buddhi carita ādike pi
translated: The state of being strong in non-greed and non-hate is not without the support of faith. Therefore it is said: “The faithful are those whose habit is to be free from greed and hate, being purified in mind.”

original: dassetuṃ “yathā vā”tiādi vuttaṃ. Tattha amohaparivārenāti amohaparikkhittena, upanissayato
analyzed: dassetum yathā vā tiādi vuttam tattha amoha parivārena ati amoha parikkhittena upanissayato
translated: And this method is stated in general. In order to show the faith-follower, etc., according to the rule of previous cause, it is said: “Or, according to the rule of previous cause, etc.” Herein, “surrounded by non-delusion” means surrounded by non-delusion as decisive support and as conascence.

original: sampayogato ca paññāya abhisaṅkhatenāti attho. Sesapadattayepi eseva nayo. Lobhādinā
analyzed: sampayogato ca paññāya abhisaṅkhatena ati attho sesa pada ttaye pi esa iva nayaḥ lobha ādinā
translated: This is the meaning. The same method applies to the other three terms.

original: vomissaparivārenāti ettha lobhamohādinā aññamaññaaviruddhavomissaparivārenāti attho.🔽Avirodho ca yugaggāhavasena appavattiyā veditabbo. Tathā hi saddhānusāridhammānusārigottāni
analyzed: vomissa parivārena āti ettha lobha moha ādinā aññamañña aviruddha vomissa parivārena āti attho  avirodhaḥ ca yugaggāha vasena appavattiyā veditabbaḥ tathā hi saddhā anusāri dhamma anusāri gottāni
translated: “Surrounded by a mixture of greed, etc.”: here the meaning is: surrounded by a mixture of greed, delusion, etc., which are mutually incompatible.🔽And the non-incompatibility should be understood as occurring by way of the simultaneous occurrence of the two. For thus the types of persons who are faith-followers and those who are Dhamma-followers

original: aññamaññampi bhinnasabhāvāneva. Ekaṃsena ca missakacariyāpi sampaṭicchitabbā pubbahetuniyāmena
analyzed: aññam aññam pi bhinna sabhāvāna eva ekaṃsena ca missaka cariyā api sampaṭicchitabbā pubba hetu niyāmena
translated: are of different natures. And the practice of a mixture should be admitted according to the rule of previous cause.

original: cariyāsiddhito. Tathā ceva ussadakittanaṃ pavattaṃ yathārahaṃ lobhālobhādīnaṃ vipākassa
analyzed: cariyā siddhitaḥ tathā ca iva ussada kittanam pavattam yathāraham lobha alobha ādīnam vipākassa
translated: And the exposition is made in such a way that the states of greed, etc., are conditions for the ripening of their respective kinds of kamma,

original: paccayabhāvato. Tenāha paṭisambhidāmagge –
analyzed: paccaya bhāvato tena āha paṭisambhidā magge
translated: as follows. Thus it is said in the Paṭisambhidā:

original: “Gatisampattiyā ñāṇasampayutte katamesaṃ aṭṭhannaṃ hetūnaṃ paccayā upapatti hoti?
analyzed: gati sampattiyā ñāṇa sampayutte katamesam aṭṭhannam hetūnam paccayā upapatti hoti
translated: “When rebirth-linking is due to the attainment of a happy destiny, what are the conditions for the rebirth-linking?

original: Kusalakammassa javanakkhaṇe tayo hetū kusalā tasmiṃ khaṇe jātacetanāya sahajātapaccayā
analyzed: kusala kammassa javana khaṇe tayo hetū kusalā tasmin khaṇe jāta cetanāya sahajāta paccayā
translated: At the moment of the impulsion of profitable kamma there are three profitable roots as conascent conditions for the volition arisen at that moment.

original: honti, tena vuccati kusalamūlapaccayāpi saṅkhārā. Nikantikkhaṇe dve hetū akusalā🔽tasmiṃ khaṇe jātacetanāya sahajātapaccayā honti, tena vuccati akusalamūlapaccayāpi
analyzed: honti tena vuccati kusala mūla paccayā api saṅkhārāḥ nikanti khaṇe dve hetū akusalā  tasmin khaṇe jāta cetanāya sahajāta paccayāḥ honti tena vuccati akusala mūla paccayā api
translated: It is said, ‘Through the condition of profitable roots, too, formations come to be.’ At the moment of attachment there are two unprofitable roots

original: saṅkhārā. Paṭisandhikkhaṇe tayo hetū abyākatā tasmiṃ khaṇe jātacetanāya sahajātapaccayā
analyzed: saṅkhārā paṭisandhi kkhaṇe tayo hetū abyākatā tasmin khaṇe jāta cetanāya sahajāta paccayā
translated: as conascent conditions for the volition arisen at that moment. It is said, ‘Through the condition of unprofitable roots, too, formations come to be.’ At the moment of rebirth-linking there are three indeterminate roots

original: honti, tena vuccati nāmarūpapaccayāpi viññāṇaṃ, viññāṇapaccayāpi nāmarūpa”nti –
analyzed: honti tena vuccati nāma rūpa paccayā api viññāṇam viññāṇa paccayā api nāma rūpan ti
translated: as conascent conditions for the volition arisen at that moment. It is said, ‘Through the condition of mentality-materiality, too, consciousness comes to be; through the condition of consciousness, too, mentality-materiality comes to be’” .

original: Ādi. Pubbahetuniyāmena ca yathā tihetukassa paññāveyyattiyaṃ, na tathā duhetukassa.
analyzed: ādi pubba hetu niyāmena ca yathā ti hetukassa paññā veyyattiyam na tathā du hetukassa
translated: “And so on” includes the prior condition. And the way in which the three-rootedness of the understanding faculty is determined is not the way in which the two-rootedness is determined.

original: Yathā ca duhetukassa itikattabbatā nepakkaṃ, na tathā ahetukassa. Evaṃ lobhussadādayo
analyzed: yathā ca du hetukassa iti kattabba tā nepakkam na tathā ahetukassa evam lobhussad ādayaḥ
translated: And the way in which the two-rootedness is determined is not the way in which the unrootedness is determined. So too with greediness, etc.,

original: puggalā rāgacaritādayo hontīti niṭṭhamettha gantabbanti. Yathāvuttamatthaṃ nigamavasena
analyzed: puggalāḥ rāga carita ādayaḥ honti iti niṭṭham ettha gantabbanti yathāvuttam attham nigama vasena
translated: and the types of person beginning with the lustful. The conclusion here is that this is how it should be understood. In order to show the meaning stated in terms of the summing up,

original: dassetuṃ “evaṃ lobhādīsū”tiādi vuttaṃ.🔽45. Tatrāti tasmiṃ pucchāvacane. Nayoti jānananayo. Puggalādhiṭṭhānena vuttopi attho🔽dhammamukheneva paññāyatīti dhammādhiṭṭhānenāha “cariyāyo vibhāvaye”ti. Pakatigamanenāti
analyzed: dassetum evam lobha ādīsu itiādi vuttam  tatra ati tasmin pucchāvacane nayo ti jānana nayo puggala adhiṭṭhānena vuttaḥ api attho  dhamma mukhena iva paññāyati iti dhamma adhiṭṭhānena āha cariyāyaḥ vibhāvaya iti pakati gamanena ati
translated: he said “Thus with greediness, etc.”🔽“There” : in the question. “The method” : the method of knowing. Although the meaning is stated with reference to the person,🔽it is evident only through the idea, so he said “the types of temperament” with reference to the idea. “By the way of going”

original: akittimena sabhāvagamanena. Cāturiyenāti cāturabhāvena siṅgārena. Ukkuṭikanti asamphuṭṭhamajjhaṃ.🔽Khaṇanto viyāti bhūmiṃ khaṇanto viya. Anukaḍḍhitanti pādanikkhepasamaye kaḍḍhanto
analyzed: akittimena sabhāva gamanena cāturiyena ati cāturabhāvena siṅgārena ukkuṭikanti a samphuṭṭha majjham 🔽khaṇantaḥ viya iti bhūmim khaṇantaḥ viya pāda nikkhepa samaye kaḍḍhantaḥ
translated: means by the way of the individual essence. “By the way of the fourfold method” means by the way of the fourfold method of skill in the aggregates, etc. “By the way of the fourfold method” means by the way of the fourfold method of skill in the aggregates, etc. “By the way of the fourfold method” means by the way of the fourfold method of skill in the aggregates, etc. “By the way of the fourfold method” means by the way of the fourfold method of skill in the aggregates, etc. “By the way of the fourfold method” means by the way of the fourfold method of skill in the aggregates, etc. “By the way of the fourfold method” means by the way of the fourfold method of skill in the aggregates, etc. “By the way of the fourfold method” means by the way of the fourfold method of skill in the aggregates, etc. “By the way of the fourfold method” means by the way of the fourfold method of skill in the aggregates, etc. “By the way of the fourfold method” means by the way of the fourfold method of skill in the aggregates, etc. “By the way of the fourfold method” means by the way of the fourfold method of skill in the aggregates, etc. “By the way of the fourfold method” means by the way of the fourfold method of skill in the aggregates, etc. “By the way of the fourfold method” means by the way of the fourfold method of

original: viya pādaṃ nikkhipati. Tenassa padaṃ anukaḍḍhitaṃ pacchato añchitaṃ hoti. Paribyākulāyāti
analyzed: viya pādam nikkhipati tena assa padam anukaḍḍhitam pacchatas añchitam hoti paribyākulāya ati
translated: he puts down his foot as if he were afraid. Thus his foot is drawn back and bent down. ‘With its sides torn’ means

original: parito āluḷitāya. Chambhito viyāti vitthāyanto viya. Bhīto viyāti keci. Sahasānupīḷitanti
analyzed: paritas āluḷitāya chambhitaḥ viyāti bhītaḥ viyāti keci
translated: with its sides torn off all round. ‘As if frightened’ means as if stretching out. ‘As if afraid’ say some. ‘With its joints crushed’ means

original: aggapādena, paṇhiyā ca sahasāva sannirujjhitaṃ. Vivaṭṭacchadassāti vinivaṭṭacchadanassa
analyzed: agga pādena paṇhiyā ca sahasā ava sannirujjhitam vivaṭṭa chadassa ati vinivaṭṭa chadanassa
translated: with its joints crushed suddenly by the forepart and the hindpart. ‘With its covering torn off’ means with its covering torn off.

original: pahīnakilesassa. Idamīdisaṃ padanti bhagavato padaṃ disvā vadati.
analyzed: pahīna kilesassa idam īdisam bhagavataḥ padam disvā vadati
translated: ‘With its defilements given up’ means with its defilements given up. ‘Such a footprint’ means he speaks having seen the Blessed One’s footprint.

original: Pāsādikanti pasādāvahaṃ. Madhurākāranti iṭṭhākāraṃ. Thaddhākāranti thambhitākāraṃ.
analyzed: pāsādikanti pasāda āvaham madhura ākāranti iṭṭha ākāram thaddha ākāranti thambhita ākāram
translated: ‘Inspiring confidence’ means inspiring confidence. ‘With a pleasant appearance’ means with a desirable appearance. ‘With a firm appearance’ means with a stiff appearance.

original: Ataramānoti nataramāno, saṇikanti attho. Samodhāyāti sammadeva odhāya avikkhipitvā.🔽Nipajjitvāti kāyapasāraṇalakkhaṇāya nipajjāya seyyāya nipajjitvā sayati niddāyati.
analyzed: a taramānaḥ iti attho samodhāya ati sammadeva odhāya a vikkhipitvā  nipajjitvā ati kāya pasāraṇa lakkhaṇāya nipajjāya seyyāya nipajjitvā sayati niddāyati
translated: ‘Without hurry’ means without hurry, the meaning is without haste. ‘Having well covered’ means having well covered without distraction.🔽‘Having lain down’ means having lain down on a bed for the purpose of relaxing the body, he lies down, he sleeps.

original: Pakkhittakāyoti avakkhittakāyo avaso viya sahasā patitakāyo. Dussaṇṭhānanti virūpasannivesaṃ.
analyzed: pakkhitta kāyaḥ ti avakkhitta kāyaḥ avasaḥ viya sahasā patita kāyaḥ dussaṇṭhānam ti virūpa sannivesam
translated: ‘With his body thrown away’ means with his body thrown away as if it were a piece of wood, suddenly fallen. ‘With an ugly appearance’ means with an ugly arrangement.

original: Vikkhittakāyoti ito cito ca khittaaṅgapaccaṅgo.
analyzed: vikkhitta kāyo ti itas ca itas ca khitta aṅga paccaṅgo
translated: ‘Scattered’ means having its limbs and members scattered here and there.

original: Samparivattakanti samparivattitvā. Āloḷayamāno vālikākacavarāni ākulayanto.
analyzed: samparivattakam ti samparivattitvā āloḍayamānaḥ vālikā kaca varāni ākulayantaḥ
translated: ‘Rolling about’ means rolling about in the sand and gravel, or else rolling about while scratching itself.

original: Nipuṇamadhurasamasakkaccakārīti sukosallaṃ sundaraṃ avisamaṃ sābhisaṅkhārañca karaṇasīlo.
analyzed: nipuṇa madhura sama sakkacca kārī iti su kosallam sundaram avisamam sa abhisaṅkhāram ca karaṇa sīlaḥ
translated: ‘Skilful, sweet, even, and respectful’ means having a habit of doing things well, beautifully, evenly, and with effort.

original: Gāḷhathaddhavisamakārīti thiraṃ asithilaṃ visamañca karaṇasīlo. Aparicchinnaṃ apariniṭṭhitaṃ.
analyzed: gāḷha thaddha visama kārī iti thiram a sithilam visamam ca karaṇa sīlaḥ aparicchinnam a pariniṭṭhitam
translated: ‘Rough, hard, uneven, and unskillful’ means having a habit of doing things firmly, loosely, unevenly, and without effort.

original: Mukhapūrakanti mukhassa pūraṇaṃ mahantaṃ. Arasapaṭisaṃvedīti narasapaṭisaṃvedī. Bhājane chaḍḍentoti bhojanabhājane sitthāni chaḍḍento. Mukhaṃ makkhentoti bahimukhaṃ makkhento.
analyzed: mukhapūrakanti mukhassa pūraṇam mahantam a rasa paṭisaṃvedī iti na rasa paṭisaṃvedī bhājane chaḍḍento ti bhojana bhājane sitthāni chaḍḍentaḥ mukham makkhentaḥ iti bahi mukham makkhentaḥ
translated: ‘Filling the mouth’ means filling the mouth to capacity. ‘Tasting the flavour’ means tasting the flavour. ‘Throwing out into the dish’ means throwing out the rice into the food dish. ‘Smearing the mouth’ means smearing the outside of the mouth.

original: Kilantarūpo viyāti tassa asahanena khedappatto viya. Aññāṇupekkhāyāti aññāṇabhūtāya upekkhāya. Aññāṇasaṅkhātāya upekkhāyāti keci.
analyzed: kilanta rūpaḥ viya ati tassa a sahanena kheda ppatto viya aññāṇa upekkhāya ati aññāṇa bhūtāya upekkhāya aññāṇa saṅkhātāya upekkhāya ati keci
translated: ‘As if exhausted’ means as if overcome by fatigue because of being unable to bear it. ‘Indifferent through ignorance’ means indifference that is a form of ignorance. According to some, ‘indifference called ignorance.’

original: Māyādīsu santadosapaṭicchadanalakkhaṇā māyā. Asantaguṇapakāsanalakkhaṇaṃ sāṭheyyaṃ.
analyzed: māyā ādīsu santa dosa paṭicchadana lakkhaṇā māyā asanta guṇa pakāsana lakkhaṇam sāṭheyyam
translated: In the case of deceit, etc., deceit has the characteristic of concealing one’s own faults. Pretence has the characteristic of exhibiting non-existent good qualities.

original: Unnatilakkhaṇo māno. Asantaguṇasambhāvanāmukhena paṭiggahaṇe amattaññutālakkhaṇā🔽pāpicchatā. Santaguṇasambhāvanāmukhena paṭiggahaṇe amattaññutālakkhaṇā mahicchatā.
analyzed: unnati lakkhaṇaḥ mānaḥ asanta guṇa sambhāvanā mukhena paṭiggahaṇe amattaññu tā lakkhaṇā  pāpa icchā tā santa guṇa sambhāvanā mukhena paṭiggahaṇe amattaññu tā lakkhaṇā mahiccha tā
translated: Conceit has the characteristic of exaltation.🔽Evilness of wishes has the characteristic of ungraspingness in receiving by way of esteeming non-existent special qualities. Great desires have the characteristic of ungraspingness in receiving by way of esteeming existent special qualities.🔽Discontent has the characteristic of dissatisfaction with the whole lot.

original: Sakalābhena asantussanalakkhaṇā asantuṭṭhitā. Vijjhanaṭṭhena siṅgaṃ, siṅgāratānāgarikabhāvasaṅkhātaṃ
analyzed: saka lābhena a santussana lakkhaṇāḥ a santuṭṭhitāḥ vijjhana ṭṭhena siṅgam siṅgāra tā nāgarika bhāva saṅkhātam
translated: The rut is a rut in the sense of a state of corruption.🔽Frivolity is a kind of greed that occurs as the adorning of one’s own body and of one’s requisites such as the robe, etc.

original: kilesasiṅgaṃ. Attano sarīrassa, cīvarādiparikkhārassa ca maṇḍanavasena pavattaṃ loluppaṃ
analyzed: kilesa siṅgam attano sarīrassa cīvara ādi parikkhārassa ca maṇḍana vasena pavattam loluppam
translated: Levity is a kind of greed that occurs as the adorning of one’s own body and of one’s requisites such as the robe, etc.

original: cāpalyaṃ. Evamādayoti ettha ādi-saddena ahirikānottappamadappamādādayo saṅgayhanti.🔽Parāparādhassa upanayhanalakkhaṇo upanāho. Paresaṃ guṇamakkhaṇalakkhaṇo makkho. Parassa🔽guṇe ḍaṃsitvā apanento viya yugaggāhalakkhaṇo paḷāso. Parasampattiusūyanalakkhaṇā
analyzed: cāpalyam evamādayaḥ ti ettha ādi saddena ahirika anottappa mada ppamāda ādayaḥ saṅgayhanti 🔽para aparādhassa upanayhana lakkhaṇaḥ upanāhaḥ paresam guṇa makkhaṇa lakkhaṇaḥ makkhaḥ parassa 🔽guṇe ḍaṃsitvā apanentaḥ viya yuga ggāha lakkhaṇaḥ paḷāsaḥ para sampatti usūyana lakkhaṇā
translated: The words “and so on” include shamelessness, lack of abashment, agitation, and negligence.

original: issā. Attasampattinigūhanalakkhaṇaṃ macchariyaṃ. Idha ādi-saddena dovacassatāpāpamittatādīnaṃ saṅgaho daṭṭhabbo.
analyzed: issā atta sampatti nigūhana lakkhaṇam macchariyam idha ādi saddena dovacassatā pāpa apamitta tā ādīnam saṅgahaḥ daṭṭhabbo
translated: Envy. Stinginess has the characteristic of concealing one’s own excellence. The word “etc.” should be understood to include bad friends, etc.

original: Anussāhanaṃ thinaṃ. Asattivighāto middhaṃ. Cetaso avūpasamo uddhaccaṃ. Vippaṭisāro🔽kukkuccaṃ. Saṃsayo vicikicchā. Ayoniso daḷhaggāho ādhānaggāhitā. Yathāgahitassa micchāgāhassa🔽dubbiveṭhiyatā duppaṭinissaggiyatā. Idha ādi-saddena muṭṭhasaccaasampajaññādīnaṃ saṅgaho daṭṭhabbo.🔽Muttacāgatāti vissaṭṭhacāgatā nissaṅgapariccāgo. Yathā māyādayo, tathā pavattā akusalakkhandhā, yathā ariyānaṃ dassanakāmatādayo, tathā pavattā kusalakkhandhā veditabbā.
analyzed: anussāhanam thinam asatti vighātaḥ middham cetasaḥ a vūpasamaḥ uddhaccam vippaṭisāro  kukkuccam saṃsayaḥ vicikicchā ayonisaḥ daḷhaggāhaḥ ādhāna ggāhi tā yathā gahitassa micchāgāhassa  dubbiveṭhiya tā duppaṭinissaggiya tā idha ādi saddena muṭṭha sacca asampajaññā ādīnam saṅgahaḥ daṭṭhabbaḥ  mutta cāgatā ati nissaṅga pariccāgaḥ yathā māyā ādayaḥ tathā pavattā akusala khandhā yathā ariyānam dassana kāma tā ādayo tathā pavattā kusala kkhandhā veditabbā
translated: Sloth is the state of being hard to arouse. Drowsiness is the state of being hard to dispel. Restlessness is the state of being hard to calm down. Worry is the state of being hard to settle.🔽Doubt is the state of being hard to decide. Grasping is the state of being hard to let go. The word “etc.” should be understood to include lack of clear awareness, etc.

original: Pasādanīyaṭṭhānaṃ nāma vatthuttayaṃ. Saṃvejanīyaṭṭhānāni jātiādīni. Kusalānuyogeti
analyzed: pasādanīya ṭṭhānam nāma vatthuttayam saṃvejanīya ṭṭhānāni jāti ādīni kusala anuyoge ti
translated: The phrase “the unprofitable aggregates that occur in the way beginning with deceit” should be understood to include the unprofitable aggregates that occur in the way beginning with deceit, pretence, fraud, craft, hypocrisy, self-concealment, taking of what is not given, taking of the sign of what is not given, taking of the name of what is not given, taking of the class of what is not given, taking of the genus of what is not given, taking of the species of what is not given, taking of the property of what is not given, taking of the characteristics of what is not given, taking of the manifestation of what is not given, taking of the association of what is not given, taking of the dissociation of what is not given, taking of the condition of what is not given, taking of the unconditioned of what is not given, taking of the aggregates of what is not given, taking of the elements of what is not given, taking of the sense bases of what is not given, taking of the faculties of what is not given, taking of the truths of what is not given, taking of the dependent origination of what is not given, taking of the perfection of giving of what is not given, taking of the perfection of virtue of what is not given, taking of the perfection of patience of what is not given, taking of the perfection of energy of what is not given, taking of the perfection of concentration of what is not given, taking of the perfection of wisdom of what is not given, taking of the perfection of skill in means of what is not given, taking of the perfection of vow of what is not given, taking of the perfection of power of what is not given, taking of the perfection of knowledge of what is not given, taking of the thirty-seven states partaking of enlightenment of what is not given, taking of the four paths of what is not given, taking of the four fruits of what is not

original: kusaladhammabhāvanāyaṃ. “Evañca evañca karissāmī”ti kiccānaṃ rattibhāge parivitakkanaṃ
analyzed: kusala dhamma bhāvanāyam evañca evañca karissāmi iti ratti bhāge parivitakkanaṃ
translated: in the development of profitable ideas. “I shall do this and that” is the thinking over of duties in the night-time.

original: rattiṃ dhūmāyanā. Tathāvitakkitānaṃ tesaṃ divasabhāge anuṭṭhānaṃ divā pajjalanā.
analyzed: rattim dhūmāyanā tathā vitakkitānam tesam divasa bhāge anuṭṭhānam divā pajjalanā
translated: “Smoking by night” is the non-rising in the day-time of those who have thus thought. “Flaming by day” is the non-thinking over of duties in the night-time.

original: Hurāhuraṃ dhāvanāti ito cito ca tattha tattha ārammaṇe cittavosaggo. Tenevāha “idaṃ
analyzed: hurāhuram itas citas ca tattha tattha ārammaṇe citta vosaggo tena iva āha idam
translated: “Running to and fro” is the mind’s being distracted here and there, to this and that object. Hence it is said:

original: pure cittamacāri cārikaṃ, yenicchakaṃ yatthakāmaṃ yathāsukha”nti, “cittamassa vidhāvatī”ti ca.
analyzed: pure cittam acāri cārikam yenicchakam yatthakāmam yathāsukhanti cittam assa vidhāvati iti ca
translated: “The mind has wandered in the past, as it liked, as it wished, as it was pleased” , and “His mind runs hither and thither” .

original: Dhammappavattidassanādi ca pāḷiyaṃ, aṭṭhakathāyañca anāgatamevāti na sakkā vattunti
analyzed: dhamma ppavatti dassana ādi ca pāḷiyam aṭṭhakathāyam ca anāgatam eva ati na sakkā vattun ti
translated: And the demonstration of the occurrence of ideas, etc., is only in the texts and in the commentaries, and so it cannot be said to be in the texts.

original: “sabbākārenā”ti vuttaṃ. Kiñci kiñci āgatampi atthevāti hi adhippāyo. “Na sārato paccetabba”nti
analyzed: sabba ākārena ati vuttam kiñci kiñci āgatam pi attha eva ati hi adhippāyaḥ na sārataḥ paccetabbanti
translated: “In every way” is said because the intention is that whatever is stated is indeed the meaning. “It should not be taken as the essential” .

original: vatvā tattha kāraṇaṃ dassento “rāgacaritassa hī”tiādimāha. Appamādavihārinoti tattha
analyzed: vatvā tattha kāraṇam dassentaḥ rāga caritassa hi itiādim āha appamāda vihārino ti tattha
translated: Having said this, he shows the reason for it thus “For the lust-prone” , etc. “Who abide diligent” :

original: vinidhāya bhāvaṃ paṭipajjanena appamādakārino. Bhinnalakkhaṇā iriyāpathādayoti cāturiyena
analyzed: vinidhāya bhāvam paṭipajjanena appamāda kārinaḥ bhinna lakkhaṇāḥ iriyāpatha ādayaḥ ti cāturiyena
translated: and by undertaking with a sense of urgency, with a sense of urgency in the practice. The postures, etc., are not mixed up in the fourfold way.

original: acāturiyena saṇikaṃ, sahasā ca gamanādayo. Na upapajjantīti na yujjanti. Pucchitvā
analyzed: a cāturiyena saṇikam sahasā ca gamana ādayaḥ na upapajjanti iti na yujjanti pucchitvā
translated: In the fourfold way, i.e. in the fourfold way of going, etc., slowly and quickly. They do not occur, they are not appropriate.

original: jānitabbanti dhammappavattiādiṃ pucchitvā jānitabbaṃ.
analyzed: jānitabbanti dhamma ppavatti ādim pucchitvā jānitabbam
translated: Should be known by asking. The occurrence of dhammas, etc., should be known by asking.

original: 46. Sappāyaṃ hitaṃ, kilesavighātīti attho. Adhotavedikanti aparisuddhaparikkhepavedikaṃ.
analyzed: sappāyam hitam kilesa vighāti iti attho adhota vedikam ti aparisuddha parikkhepa vedikam
translated: Helpful, beneficial. The meaning is: destroying defilements. Without a washed rail. The surrounding wall is not purified.

original: Bhūmaṭṭhakanti bhūmitaleyeva uṭṭhāpitaṃ uparimatalarahitaṃ. Ekato onatassa pabbatapādassa🔽heṭṭhābhāgo akatabhittibhūmiparikammo akatapabbhāro. Jatukābharitanti adhomukhāhi🔽olambamānamukhāhi khuddakavaggulīhi paripuṇṇaṃ. Oluggavilugganti chinnabhinnaṃ. Ujjaṅgalaṃ
analyzed: bhūmaṭṭhakanti bhūmi tale iya iva uṭṭhāpitam uparima tala rahitam ekatas onatassa pabbata pādassa  heṭṭhābhāgaḥ a kata bhitti bhūmi parikammaḥ a kata pabbhāraḥ adhomukhāhi  olambamāna mukhāhi khuddaka vaggulīhi paripuṇṇam olugga vilugganti chinna bhinnam ujjaṅgalam
translated: On the ground. It is erected on the ground alone, without an upper surface. The foot of a mountain that is bent on one side.🔽The part below the foot of a mountain that is not made into a wall, not made into a slope. Filled with creepers. It is full of small pieces of wood hanging down with their mouths facing downwards.🔽Broken and torn. A wilderness.

original: lūkhadhūsaraṃ chāyūdakarahitaṃ. Sīhabyagghādibhayena sāsaṅkaṃ. Durūpanti virūpaṃ.
analyzed: lūkha dhūsaram chāyu udaka rahitam sīha byaggha ādi bhayena sa āsaṅkam virūpam
translated: Rough, harsh, without shade or water. Dangerous because of the danger from lions, tigers, etc. Ugly.

original: Dubbaṇṇanti asundaravaṇṇaṃ, dussaṇṭhānaṃ vā. Jālākārena katapūvaṃ jālapūvaṃ. Sāṇi🔽viya kharasamphassanti sāṇiphalako viya dukkhasamphassaṃ. Bhārikabhāvena, antarantarā🔽tunnakaraṇena ca kicchapariharaṇaṃ. Āṇigaṇṭhikāhatoti āṇinā, gaṇṭhiyā ca hatasobho.
analyzed: dubbaṇṇam ti asundara vaṇṇam dussaṇṭhānam vā jāla ākārena kata pūvam jāla pūvam sāṇi  viya khara samphassanti sāṇi phalakaḥ viya dukkha samphassam bhārika bhāvena antar antarā  tunna karaṇena ca kiccha pariharaṇam āṇi gaṇṭhikā hataḥ ti āṇinā gaṇṭhiyā ca
translated: Ugly means ugly in colour, or ugly in shape. A cake made with a net is a net-cake. Rough to the touch like a hemp-cloth means rough to the touch like a hemp-cloth. Heavy means heavy in weight. Difficult to carry means difficult to carry because of the weight and because of the holes in the middle. Beaten with a stick and a rope means beaten with a stick and with a rope.

original: Idaṃ rāgacaritassa sappāyaṃ, evamassa kilesasamudācāro na hotīti adhippāyo. Eseva nayo sesesupi.🔽Disāmukhanti disābhimukhaṃ, abbhokāsābhimukhanti adhippāyo. Mahākasiṇanti mahantaṃ🔽kasiṇamaṇḍalaṃ. Sesaṃ senāsanādīsu yaṃ vattabbaṃ mohacaritassa, taṃ dosacaritassa vuttasadisameva.
analyzed: idam rāga caritassa sappāyam evam assa kilesa samudācāraḥ na hoti iti adhippāyaḥ esa iva nayo sesesu pi  disāmukhanti disā abhimukham abbhokāsa abhimukhanti adhippāyaḥ mahā kasiṇanti mahantam  kasiṇa maṇḍalam sesam senāsana ādīsu yam vattabbam moha caritassa tam dosa caritassa vutta sadisam eva
translated: Ugly: ugly in colour, or ugly in shape. A cake made with a net is a net-cake. Rough to the touch like a hemp-cloth: rough to the touch like a cloth of hemp. Heavy: heavy in weight. Difficult to handle: difficult to handle because of its bulk and because of the difficulty of turning it over. Battered by the rope’s end: battered in appearance by the rope and by the end. This is suitable for one of greedy temperament, since it does not arouse the defilements in him. This is the intention. The same method applies in the other cases.🔽Facing in a direction: facing in a direction. The intention is that it faces in the direction of the open air. A great kasiṇa: a great kasiṇa disk. The rest should be told as follows: what should be said about the bed, etc., for one of deluded temperament is the same as for one of hating temperament.

original: Vitakkavidhāvanasseva paccayo hoti yathā taṃ āyasmato meghiyattherassa. Darīmukheti pabbatavivare. Parittanti suppasarāvamattaṃ.
