analyzed: vitakka vidhāvanassa iva paccayaḥ hoti yathā tam āyasmataḥ meghiya therassa darīmukhe iti pabbata vivare parittanti su pasara avamattam
translated: It is a condition for the running hither and thither of thoughts, as it was for the venerable Elder Meghiya. A crevice: a fissure in a rock. Small: the size of a hen’s egg.

original: Pabhedaparicchedato nidānaparicchedato vibhāvanaparicchedato sappāyaparicchedatoti
analyzed: nidāna paricchedataḥ vibhāvana paricchedataḥ sappāya paricchedato ti
translated: As to analysis, as to the chapter of the text, as to the chapter of exposition, and as to the chapter of what is suitable.

original: paccekaṃ pariccheda-saddo yojetabbo. Vibhāvanāti “ayaṃ rāgacarito”tiādinā jānanavibhāvanā.🔽Ekaccakasiṇānussatiṭṭhānamattassa pasaṅgena kathitattā vuttaṃ “na ca tāva cariyānukūlaṃ
analyzed: paccekam pariccheda saddaḥ yojetabbaḥ vibhāvanā ti ayam rāga caritā iti ādinā jānana vibhāvanā  ekacca kasiṇa anussati ṭhāna mattassa pasaṅgena kathita ttā vuttam na ca tāva cariyā anukūlam
translated: The word “chapter” should be construed with each of these. As to the chapter of exposition: the exposition of the knowing of “one of greedy temperament” and so on.

original: kammaṭṭhānaṃ sabbākārena āvikata”nti.
analyzed: kammaṭṭhānam sabba ākārena āvikatanti
translated: Since it is told by way of the mere meditation subject of the recollection of the Thirty-two-fold Aspect, it is said, “but the meditation subject that is suitable to temperament is not revealed in all ways.”

original: Cattālīsakammaṭṭhānavaṇṇanā
analyzed: cattālīsa kammaṭṭhāna vaṇṇanā
translated: The forty meditation subjects

original: 47. Saṅkhātaniddesatoti saṅkhātānaṃ “cattālīsāyā”ti saṅkhyāvasena gahitānaṃ uddiṭṭhānaṃ
analyzed: saṅkhāta niddesato ti saṅkhātānam cattālīsāya ati saṅkhyā vasena gahitānam uddiṭṭhānam
translated: As to the demonstration of the classification: as to the demonstration of the forty mentioned by way of the number “forty.”

original: niddesato. “Ettha ettakāni upacārajjhānāvahāni, ettakāni appanājjhānāvahānī”ti upacārappanāvahato.🔽“Ettakāni ekajjhānikāni, ettakāni dukatikajjhānikāni, ettakāni sakalajjhānikānī”ti
analyzed: niddesataḥ ettha ettakāni upacāra jhāna āvahāni ettakāni appanā jhāna āvahāni iti upacāra ppanā āvahato  ettakāni eka jjhānikāni ettakāni dukatika jhānikāni ettakāni sakala jjhānikāni iti
translated: As to what leads to access concentration and what leads to absorption concentration.🔽As to the kinds of jhāna: as to how many are of only one kind of jhāna, how many of two kinds of jhāna, and how many of all five kinds of jhāna.

original: jhānappabhedato. “Etesu aṅgasamatikkamo, etesu ārammaṇasamatikkamo”ti evaṃ samatikkamato.
analyzed: jhāna ppabhedataḥ etesu aṅga samatikkamaḥ etesu ārammaṇa samatikkamo ti evam samatikkamato
translated: As to surmounting: as to which have surmounting of factors and which have surmounting of object.

original: “Ettakānettha vaḍḍhetabbāni, ettakāni na vaḍḍhetabbānī”ti vaḍḍhanāvaḍḍhanato. Ārammaṇatoti
analyzed: ettakāni ittha vaḍḍhetabbāni ettakāni na vaḍḍhetabbāni iti vaḍḍhana avaḍḍhanato ārammaṇato ti
translated: By object:

original: sabhāvadhammanimittanavattabbavasena, calitācalitavasena ca ārammaṇavibhāgato. Bhūmitoti
analyzed: sa bhāva dhamma nimitta navattabba vasena calita acalita vasena ca ārammaṇa vibhāgataḥ
translated: by classification of the object as the sign of an individual essence, a dhammārammaṇa, a non-existent, a visible datum, etc., and as a moving or unmoving object.🔽By plane:🔽by classification of the plane as the sense sphere, and so on.🔽By apprehending:

original: kāmāvacarādibhūmivibhāgato. Gahaṇatoti diṭṭhādivasena gahaṇavibhāgato. Paccayatoti
analyzed: kāmāvacara ādi bhūmi vibhāgataḥ gahaṇato ti diṭṭha ādi vasena gahaṇa vibhāgato paccayato ti
translated: by classification of apprehending as seeing, and so on.🔽By condition:🔽by classification of the conditions for the immaterial states, and so on, as appropriate.🔽By conformity to temperament:

original: āruppādīnaṃ yathārahaṃ paccayabhāvato. Cariyānukūlatoti rāgacariyādīnaṃ anukūlabhāvato.
analyzed: āruppa ādīnam yathāraham paccaya bhāvato cariyā anukūlato ti rāga cariyā ādīnam anukūla bhāvato
translated: by classification of the kinds of meditation subject as suitable for the greedy temperament, etc.

original: Kammaṭṭhānānīti ārammaṇabhāvena yogakammassa pavattiṭṭhānāni. Catukkajjhānikāti catubbidharūpāvacarajjhānavanto,
analyzed: kammaṭṭhānāni iti ārammaṇa bhāvena yoga kammassa pavatti ṭṭhānāni catukkajjhānikā ti catubbidha rūpāvacara jhānavanto
translated: Meditation subjects: the meditation subjects as objects for the occurrence of the yogi’s consciousness. Possessing the four jhānas: possessing the four kinds of fine-material-sphere jhāna.

original: tesaṃ ārammaṇabhūtāti attho. Catukkanayavasena cetaṃ vuttaṃ. Tikacatukkajjhānikesūti
analyzed: tesam ārammaṇa bhūtā ti attho catukka naya vasena ca itam vuttam tika catukka ajjhānikesu
translated: The meaning is that they are the objects of those jhānas. This is said with reference to the method of the fourfold jhāna.🔽In the three and four:

original: tikajjhānikesu purimesu brahmavihāresu, catukkajjhānikesu ānāpānakasiṇesu. Sesesūti
analyzed: tika jhānikesu purimesu brahmavihāresu catukka jhānikesu ānā apāna kasiṇesu sesesu uti
translated: in the first three divine abidings, which are threefold, and in the mindfulness occupied with the body, which is fourfold.🔽In the rest:

original: vuttāvasesesu ekavīsatiyā kammaṭṭhānesu.
analyzed: vutta avasesesu ekavīsatiyā kammaṭṭhānesu
translated: in the remaining twenty-one meditation subjects.

original: Dibbacakkhunā diṭṭhahadayarūpassa sattassa cittaṃ ādikammiko cetopariyañāṇena paricchindituṃ
analyzed: dibba cakkhunā diṭṭhahadaya rūpassa sattassa cittam ādikammiko cetaḥ pariya ñāṇena paricchinditum
translated: If he has seen the heart-reflection with the divine eye, he can discern the consciousness of a being with the knowledge of penetration of hearts.

original: sakkoti, na itarassāti kasiṇapharaṇaṃ cetopariyañāṇassa paccayo hoti. Tena vuttaṃ
analyzed: sakkoti na itarassa ti kasiṇa pharaṇam cetaḥ pariya ñāṇassa paccayo hoti tena vuttam
translated: But if he has not, he cannot. So the extension of the kasiṇa is a condition for the knowledge of penetration of hearts. That is why it is said,

original: “parasattānañca cetasā cittamaññātuṃ samattho hotī”ti. Okāsena paricchinnattāti attano
analyzed: para sattānam ca cetasā cittam aññātum samatthaḥ hoti iti okāsena attano
translated: “He is able to know the minds of other beings, of other persons, having encompassed them with his own mind.”🔽By delimitation of the location: because they are delimited by the location in which they are placed in one’s own person.

original: ṭhitokāsena paricchinnattā. Tathā uggahakosallassa sampāditattā paricchinnākāreneva
analyzed: ṭhita ukāsena paricchinna ttā tathā uggaha kosallassa sampādita ttā paricchinna ākārena iva
translated: And because the skill in learning has been perfected in the same way, they appear to him as delimited in aspect.

original: tāni upatiṭṭhanti, tasmā na tattha vaḍḍhanāti adhippāyo. Sace pana koci vaḍḍheyya,
analyzed: tāni upatiṭṭhanti tasmā na tattha vaḍḍhanā ati adhippāyaḥ sace pana koci vaḍḍheyya
translated: The intention is that they do not extend beyond that. But if they were to extend beyond,🔽he would not gain any special quality by that. To show this he said, “And there is no advantage in that.”

original: na tena koci guṇoti dassento āha “ānisaṃsābhāvā cā”ti. “Tesu panā”tiādinā tameva
analyzed: na tena koci guṇo ti dassentaḥ āha ānisaṃsa abhāvā ca ati tesu pana ati ādinā tam eva
translated: He explains that very absence of advantage with the words “In the first place,”

original: ānisaṃsābhāvaṃ vivarati. Yasmā vaḍḍhitesu kuṇaparāsiyeva vaḍḍhati, avaḍḍhitepi kāmarāgavikkhambhanā
analyzed: ānisaṃsa abhāvam vivarati yasmai vaḍḍhitesu kuṇapa rāsiyā iva vaḍḍhati a vaḍḍhite pi kāma rāga vikkhambhanā
translated: and so on. For if they were to extend beyond, only a corpse would extend beyond, and if they did not extend beyond, there would be suppression of lust for sensual desires.

original: hotiyeva, tasmā ānisaṃsābhāvo. Vibhūtāti vipulārammaṇatāya supākaṭā, vaḍḍhitanimittatāya
analyzed: tasmai ānisaṃsā abhāvaḥ vibhūtā ati vipula ārammaṇa tāya su pākaṭā vaḍḍhita nimitta tāya
translated: Well defined: very evident because of the extensive object, and because of the sign of extension.

original: appamāṇārammaṇabhāvena paribyattāti attho.
analyzed: appamāṇa ārammaṇa bhāvena paribyattā ati attho
translated: The meaning is that it is purified by having a measureless object.

original: Kevalanti sakalaṃ anavasesaṃ. “Pathaviṃ ima”nti vacanaṃ upaṭṭhānākārena vuttaṃ, na🔽nimittassa vaḍḍhanenāti adhippāyo. Lābhittāti sātisayaṃ lābhitāya, ukkaṃsagatavasibhāvatoti🔽attho. Thero hi paramāya vasipattiyā assamaṇḍale assaṃ sārento viya yattha tattha
analyzed: kevalam ti sakalam anavasesam pathavim iman ti vacanam upaṭṭhāna ākārena vuttam na  nimittassa vaḍḍhanena ati adhippāyaḥ lābhittā ati sa atisayam lābhitāya ukkaṃsa gata vasi bhāvato ti  theraḥ hi paramāya vasi pattiyā assa maṇḍale assam sārentaḥ viya yattha tattha
translated: “Entire”: all, without exception. The meaning is that the words “this earth” are said by way of the appearance of the kasiṇa, not by way of the extension of the sign.

original: nisinnopi ṭhitopi taṃ jhānaṃ samāpajjateva. Tenassa samantato nimittaṃ vaḍḍhitaṃ
analyzed: nisinnaḥ api ṭhitaḥ api tam jhānam samāpajjatā iva tena assa samantataḥ nimittam vaḍḍhitam
translated: “Attained”: attained to a high degree; the meaning is that he had reached the acme of mastery. For the elder, like a horse in a circus track, entered upon that jhāna wherever he sat or stood.

original: viya upaṭṭhāsi. Tena vuttaṃ “sabbadisāsū”tiādi.🔽Vuttāti dhammasaṅgahe vuttā. Mahanteti vipule. Ninnathalādivasena hi ekadese aṭṭhatvā
analyzed: viya upaṭṭhāsi tena vuttam sabba disāsu itiādi  vuttā ti dhamma saṅgahe vuttā mahantā iti vipule ninna thala ādi vasena hi eka dese
translated: Therefore the sign appeared to him as if extended all round. Hence he said: “In all directions” .🔽“In the Dhammasanganī” : in the Dhammasanganī of the Abhidhamma Piṭaka.

original: samantato gahaṇavasena sakalasarīre nimittaṃ gaṇhantassa taṃ mahantaṃ hoti. Mahante
analyzed: samantataḥ gahaṇa vasena sakala sarīre nimittam gaṇhantassa tam mahantam hoti mahante
translated: “Large”: extensive. For when one apprehends the sign in the whole body by apprehending it all over without leaving out any part, as if turning the body over and over, then it is large. Or it is large in the sense of being in a large body.

original: vā sarīre. Appaketi sarīrassa ekadese nimittaṃ gaṇhātīti yojanā. Appake vā khuddake
analyzed: vā sarīre appake iti sarīrassa eka dese nimittam gaṇhāti iti yojanā appake vā khuddake
translated: “Small”: the construction is “he apprehends the sign in one part of the body.” Or it is small in the sense of being in a small body.

original: dārakasarīre. Etanti asubhanimittaṃ. Ādīnavanti “asubharāsi eva vaḍḍhati, na ca koci
analyzed: dāraka sarīre asubha nimittam ādīnavanti eva vaḍḍhati na ca koci
translated: in the body of a child. The sign of foulness: the sign of foulness. The danger: the mass of foulness increases, but no one

original: ānisaṃso”ti vuttaṃ ādīnavaṃ.
analyzed: ānisaṃso ti vuttam ādīnavam
translated: In a child’s body. The sign: the sign of foulness. Disadvantage: the disadvantage is said to be that “only the mass of foulness increases, and no benefit whatever arises.”

original: Sesānipi na vaḍḍhetabbānīti saṅkhepato vuttamatthaṃ upapattito vivarituṃ “kasmā”tiādi🔽vuttaṃ. Picupiṇḍādivasena upaṭṭhahantampi nimittaṃ vātasaṅghātasannissayanti katvā
analyzed: sesāni api na vaḍḍhetabbāni iti saṅkhepataḥ vuttam attham upapattitaḥ vivaritum kasmā itiādi  vuttam picu piṇḍa ādi vasena upaṭṭhahantam pi nimittam vāta saṅghāta sannissayanti katvā
translated: The rest should not be increased: the meaning of what is said in brief is made clear by the derivation in order to show how it should not be increased. Why?🔽Although the sign appears as a lump of flesh, etc., it is said that “only the mass of wind increases” because it is dependent on a mass of winds.

original: vuttaṃ “vātarāsiyeva vaḍḍhatī”ti. Okāsena paricchinnanti nāsikaggamukhanimittādiokāsena
analyzed: vuttam vāta rāsiyā iva vaḍḍhati iti okāsena paricchinnanti nāsikagga mukha nimitta ādi okāsena
translated: Limited by a location: it has a location limited by the nostrils, the sign of the mouth, and so on.

original: saparicchedaṃ. Vāyokasiṇavaḍḍhane viya na ettha koci guṇo, kevalaṃ vātavaḍḍhanamevāti🔽āha “sādīnavattā”ti. Tesanti brahmavihārānaṃ. Nimittanti ārammaṇaṃ. Na ca tena attho
analyzed: sa paricchedam vāyo kasiṇa vaḍḍhane viya na ettha koci guṇo kevalam vāta vaḍḍhanam eva ati  āha sādīnava ttā iti tesanti brahmavihārānam nimittam ti ārammaṇam na ca tena attho
translated: There is no merit in increasing it as in the case of the air kasiṇa. It is only the wind that increases.🔽That is why it is said that “it has the disadvantage of being a mass of wind.”

original: atthīti tena sattarāsivaḍḍhanena pathavīkasiṇādivaḍḍhane viya kiñci payojanaṃ natthi.
analyzed: atthi iti tena satta rāsi vaḍḍhanena pathavī kasiṇa ādi vaḍḍhane viya kiñci payojanam natthi
translated: The divine abidings: the sign is the object. There is no need for it: there is no purpose in increasing the mass of beings as there is in increasing the earth kasiṇa, and so on.

original: Pariggahavasenāti apariggahitassa bhāvanāvisayassa pariggahavasena, na nimittavaḍḍhanavasena.
analyzed: pariggaha vasena ati a pariggahitassa bhāvanā visayassa pariggaha vasena na nimitta vaḍḍhana vasena
translated: By delimitation: by delimiting the object of jhāna, which is not yet delimited, and not by extending the sign.

original: Tenāha “ekāvāsadviāvāsādinā”tiādi. Etthāti brahmavihārabhāvanāyaṃ. Yadayanti yaṃ
analyzed: tena āha ettha ati brahmavihāra bhāvanā ayam yat ayanti yam
translated: Hence he said “by the delimitation of the ‘one who has virtue’ and the ‘one who has no virtue’ and so on” . Herein, in the development of the divine abidings: in the development of the divine abidings. This meditator: this meditator who is developing the divine abidings.

original: paṭibhāganimittaṃ ayaṃ yogī. Sīmāsambhedeneva hettha upacārajjhānuppatti, na nimittuppattiyā.
analyzed: paṭibhāga nimittam ayam yogī sīmā sambhedena iva ha ittha upacāra jhāna uppatti na nimitta uppattiyā
translated: The access is due to the delimitation of the area, not to the arising of the sign.

original: Yadi evaṃ kathaṃ parittādiārammaṇatā jhānassāti āha “parittaappamāṇārammaṇatāpettha
analyzed: yadi evam katham paritta ādi ārammaṇa tā jhānassa ati āha paritta appamāṇa ārammaṇa tā api ittha
translated: If that is so, how is it that the jhāna has a limited or measureless object? He said “The limited and measureless object here is due to delimitation” .🔽The limited object is the limited object of the limited jhāna. The measureless object is the measureless object of the measureless jhāna.

original: pariggahavasenā”ti, katipaye satte pariggahetvā pavattā mettādayo parittārammaṇā,
analyzed: pariggaha vasena ati katipaye satte pariggahetvā pavattāḥ metta ādayo paritta ārammaṇā
translated: The meaning is that loving-kindness, etc., that occur by taking as their object a few beings are with a limited object,🔽and that they are with a measureless object when they occur by taking as their object many beings.

original: bahuke appamāṇārammaṇāti attho. Ākāsaṃ kasiṇugghāṭimattā na vaḍḍhetabbanti yojanā.
analyzed: bahuke appamāṇa ārammaṇā ti attho ākāsam na vaḍḍhetabbam ti yojanā
translated: The construction is that the space kasiṇa should not be extended beyond the measure of the earth kasiṇa.🔽Or it can be connected with what is said in the Paṭisambhidā.

original: Vakkhati vā yaṃ tena sambandhitabbaṃ. Parikappajameva ārammaṇaṃ vaḍḍhetuṃ sakkā,
analyzed: vakkhati vā yam tena sambandhitabbam parikappa jam eva ārammaṇam vaḍḍhetum sakkā
translated: Only an object consisting of conceptual thoughts can be extended,🔽not an object consisting of real individual essences. That is why he said “for it is not possible to extend an individual essence” .

original: na itaranti āha “na hi sakkā sabhāvadhammaṃ vaḍḍhetu”nti. Āruppānaṃ parittaappamāṇārammaṇatā
analyzed: na itarat ti āha na hi sakkā sa bhāva dhammam vaḍḍhetunti āruppānam paritta appamāṇa ārammaṇa tā
translated: The measureless object of the immaterial states is due to the measurelessness of the object.

original: parittakasiṇugghāṭimākāse, vipulakasiṇugghāṭimākāse ca pavattiyā veditabbā. Sesāni
analyzed: parittaka siṇugghāṭim ākāse vipulaka siṇugghāṭim ākāse ca pavattiyā veditabbā sesāni
translated: It should be understood to occur in the space element that is the opposite of the limited kasiṇa and in the space element that is the opposite of the measureless kasiṇa. The remaining

original: buddhānussatiādīni dasa kammaṭṭhānāni. Animittattāti paṭibhāganimittābhāvā.
analyzed: buddha anussati ādīni dasa kammaṭṭhānāni animitta ttā ati paṭibhāga nimitta abhāvā
translated: ten meditation subjects are the recollection of the Buddha and the rest. Because of the absence of a counterpart sign: because of the absence of a counterpart sign.🔽Because of the signless: because of the absence of a sign. Because of the absence of a counterpart sign: because of the absence of a counterpart sign as object. The remaining

original: Paṭibhāganimittārammaṇānīti paṭibhāganimittabhūtāni ārammaṇāni. Sesāni aṭṭhārasa.
analyzed: paṭibhāga nimitta ārammaṇāni iti paṭibhāga nimitta bhūtāni ārammaṇāni sesāni aṭṭhārasa
translated: eighteen.

original: Sesāni chāti cattāro brahmavihārā, ākāsānañcāyatanaṃ, ākiñcaññāyatananti imāni sesāni🔽cha. Vissandamānapubbatāya vipubbakaṃ. Paggharamānalohitatāya lohitakaṃ. Kimīnaṃ🔽pacalanena puḷuvakaṃ, calitārammaṇaṃ vuttaṃ. Vātapānavivarādīhi antopaviṭṭhassa sūriyālokādikassa
analyzed: sesāni cha ati cattāraḥ brahmavihārāḥ ākāsānañcāyatanam ākiñcaññāyatananti imāni sesāni  cha vissandamāna pubba tāya vipubbakam paggharamāna lohita tāya lohitakam kimīnam  pacalanena puḷuvakam calita ārammaṇam vuttam vāta pāna vivara ādīhi anta upaviṭṭhassa sūriya āloka ādikassa
translated: The remaining six: the four divine abidings, the base consisting of boundless space, and the base consisting of nothingness. The remaining

original: calanākāro paññāyatīti obhāsamaṇḍalārammaṇampi calitārammaṇaṃ vuttaṃ. Pubbabhāgeti
analyzed: calana ākāro paññāyati iti obhāsa maṇḍala ārammaṇam pi calita ārammaṇam vuttam pubba bhāge ti
translated: six. Because of the shaking of the preceding: because of the shaking of the preceding sign. Because of the shaking of the object: because of the shaking of the object. The shaking of the object is known in the case of the sign of the element of fire as the shaking of the flame, in the case of the sign of the element of air as the shaking of the object, and in the case of the sign of the element of earth as the shaking of the earth. The shaking of the object is also said to be the shaking of the circle of light that has entered inside through a window opening, etc.,

original: paṭibhāganimittappavattiyā pubbabhāge. Sannisinnamevāti santaṃ niccalameva.
analyzed: paṭibhāga nimitta ppavattiyā pubba bhāge sannisinnam eva ati santam niccalam eva
translated: because the mode of appearance of the light of the sun, etc., that has entered inside through a window opening, etc., is discerned as shaking. In the earlier stage: in the earlier stage of the occurrence of the counterpart sign. Remaining still: remaining steady.

original: Devesūti kāmāvacaradevesu, tattha asubhānaṃ paṭikūlassa ca āhārassa abhāvato. Assāsapassāsānaṃ brahmaloke abhāvato “ānāpānassati cā”ti vuttaṃ.🔽Diṭṭhenāti diṭṭhena vatthunā kāraṇabhūtena. Gahetabbānīti uggahetabbāni, uppādetabbauggahanimittānīti🔽attho. Tenāha “pubbabhāge”tiādi. Tassāti kāyagatāsatiyā. Ucchusassādīnaṃ pattesu
analyzed: devesu uti kāmāvacara devesu tattha asubhānam paṭikūlassa ca āhārassa abhāvataḥ assāsa passāsānam brahma loke abhāvataḥ ca ati vuttam  diṭṭhena ati diṭṭhena vatthunā kāraṇa bhūtena gahetabbāni iti uggahetabbāni uppādetabba auggaha nimittāni iti  atthaḥ tena āha pubba bhāga itiādi tassa ti kāya gata asatiyā ucchu sassa ādīnam pattesu
translated: ‘Among deities’ means among sense-sphere deities, because there is no foulness there nor any physical nutriment as an object of revulsion. And because there is no in-breath and out-breath in the Brahmā-world, it is said ‘and mindfulness of breathing’ .

original: pacalamānavaṇṇaggahaṇamukhena vā tassa gahetabbattā vuttaṃ “vāyokasiṇaṃ diṭṭhaphuṭṭhenā”ti.🔽Na ādikammikena gahetabbānīti ādikammikena na gahetabbāni, bhāvanārambhavasena na🔽paṭṭhapetabbāni, heṭṭhime tayo brahmavihāre, kasiṇesu rūpāvacaracatutthajjhānañca
analyzed: pacalamāna vaṇṇa ggahaṇa mukhena vā tassa gahetabba ttā vuttam vāyokasiṇam diṭṭha phuṭṭhena ati  na ādikammikena gahetabbāni iti ādikammikena na gahetabbāni bhāvanā ārambha vasena na  paṭṭhapetabbāni heṭṭhime tayaḥ brahmavihāre kasiṇesu rūpāvacara catuttha jhānam ca
translated: ‘By what is seen’: by what is seen as a basis, as a cause. ‘Can be undertaken’: can be taken up, can be generated, is the meaning. Hence he said ‘in the earlier stage’ . ‘His’: of mindfulness occupied with the body. ‘By what is seen and touched in the case of the kasiṇa of air’: because his can be taken up by the method of apprehending the colour of the moving surface of the water.

original: anadhigantvā sampādetuṃ asakkuṇeyyattā.
analyzed: an adhigantvā sampādetum
translated: ‘Not by a beginner’: not by one who has not already done the development, not by one who has not already begun the development. ‘The first three divine abidings and the fine-material-sphere fourth jhāna in the kasiṇas cannot be undertaken’: they cannot be undertaken, cannot be begun, because they cannot be accomplished without attaining them.

original: Imesu pana kammaṭṭhānesūti ettha kammaṭṭhānaggahaṇena yathārahaṃ ārammaṇānaṃ, jhānānañca gahaṇaṃ veditabbaṃ. Sukhavihārassāti diṭṭhadhammasukhavihārassa.
analyzed: imesu pana kammaṭṭhānesu ti ettha kammaṭṭhāna ggahaṇena yathāraham ārammaṇānam jhānānam ca gahaṇam veditabbam sukha vihārassa ati diṭṭhadhamma sukha vihārassa
translated: In these meditation subjects: here the mention of meditation subjects should be understood as the mention of objects of meditation and jhānas according to the kind of person. For the pleasant abiding here and now: for the pleasant abiding in this very life.

original: “Ekādasa kammaṭṭhānāni anukūlānī”ti ujuvipaccanīkavasena cetaṃ vuttaṃ. Evaṃ sesesupi.
analyzed: ekādasa kammaṭṭhānāni anukūlāni iti uju vipaccanīka vasena ca itam vuttam evam sesesu pi
translated: The eleven meditation subjects are favourable: this is said with reference to the direct opposition. So too with the rest.

original: Vakkhati hi “sabbañceta”ntiādi. Anukūlāni rāgavikkhambhanassa upāyabhāvato. Aṭṭha
analyzed: vakkhati hi sabbañcetanti ādi anukūlāni rāga vikkhambhanassa upāya bhāvataḥ aṭṭha
translated: For it is said: “All are profitable” , and so on. They are favourable because they are the means for suppressing greed.🔽  Eight are favourable: the construction is to be understood in this way. So too with the rest.

original: anukūlānīti yojanā. Evaṃ sesesu. Ekanti idaṃ anussatiapekkhaṃ anussatīsu ekanti,
analyzed: anukūlāni iti yojanā evam sesesu ekam ti idam anussati apekkham anussatīsu ekam ti
translated: One: this is one of the recollections when one is looking for a recollection,

original: na mohacaritavitakkacaritāpekkhaṃ tesaṃ aññassāpi anukūlassa alabbhanato. “Saddhācaritassa
analyzed: na moha carita vitakka carita apekkham tesam aññassa api anukūlassa a labbhanato saddhā caritassa
translated: not when one is looking for one of the kinds of temperament or for one of the kinds of thinking, since there is no other that is favourable.🔽  For one of faithful temperament

original: purimā cha anussatiyo”ti idaṃ atisappāyavasena vuttaṃ. Imasseva ujuvipaccanīkaṃ imassa
analyzed: purimā cha anussatiyaḥ ti idam ati sappāya vasena vuttam imassa iva uju vipaccanīkam imassa
translated: the first six recollections are favourable: this is said with reference to their extreme suitability.🔽  The direct opposites of these are unfavourable to him.

original: atisappāyanti gahetabbassa visesassa abhāvato sabbacaritānaṃ anukūlāni. Parittanti
analyzed: ati sappāyanti gahetabbassa visesassa abhāvataḥ sabba caritānam anukūlāni parittanti
translated: The limited:

original: sarāvamattaṃ, appamāṇanti tato adhikapamāṇaṃ. Parittaṃ vā suppasarāvamattaṃ, appamāṇaṃ
analyzed: sarāva mattam appamāṇam ti tatas adhika pamāṇam parittam vā suppasarāva mattam appamāṇam
translated: ‘A limited amount’ is less than a full bowl. ‘An unlimited amount’ is more than a full bowl. A limited amount is a small bowlful, an unlimited amount is more than that.

original: adhikapamāṇaṃ khalamaṇḍalādikasiṇabhāvena pariggahitaṃ.
analyzed: adhika pamāṇam khala maṇḍala ādi kasiṇa bhāvena pariggahitam
translated: ‘A limited area’ is a limited area of the kasiṇa such as a circle of cow-dung or a circle of white soil.

original: Cattāro dhammāti cattāro manasikaraṇīyā dhammā. Uttarīti sīlasampadā, kalyāṇamittatā,🔽sappāyadhammassavanaṃ, vīriyaṃ; paññāti imesu pañcasu dhammesu patiṭṭhānato upari.
analyzed: cattāraḥ dhammā ti cattāraḥ manasikaraṇīyāḥ dhammāḥ uttarī iti sīla sampadā kalyāṇa mitta tā  sappāya dhamma ssavanam vīriyam paññā ti imesu pañcasu dhammesu patiṭṭhānato upari
translated: ‘Four ideas’: four ideas to be given attention. ‘More than that’: virtue, good friends,

original: Asubhāti asubhabhāvanā ekādasasu asubhakammaṭṭhānesu bhāvanānuyogā. Mettāti anodhiso,
analyzed: asubhā ati asubha bhāvanā ekādasasu asubha kammaṭṭhānesu bhāvanā anuyogā mettā iti anodhiso
translated: hearing the Dhamma, energy, and understanding. ‘In these five ideas’: because of being established in these five ideas. ‘The contemplation of foulness’: the development of the meditation subject consisting of the ten kinds of foulness in the eleven aspects. ‘Loving-kindness’: boundless loving-kindness,

original: odhiso vā pavattā mettābhāvanā. Ānāpānassatīti soḷasavatthukā ānāpānassatisamādhibhāvanā.🔽Vitakkupacchedāyāti micchāvitakkānaṃ upacchindanatthāya. Aniccasaññāti “sabbe saṅkhārā
analyzed: odhisaḥ vā pavattā mettā bhāvanā ānāpāna ssatī iti soḷasa vatthukā ānāpāna ssati samādhi bhāvanā  vitakka upacchedāya ati micchā vitakkānaṃ upacchindana tthāya anicca saññā ati sabbe saṅkhārāḥ
translated: whether developed with a measure or without a measure. ‘Mindfulness of breathing’: the development of concentration by mindfulness of breathing with its sixteen bases.

original: aniccā”ti evaṃ pavattā aniccānupassanā. Asmimānasamugghātāyāti “asmī”ti uppajjanakassa
analyzed: aniccā ati evam pavattā anicca anupassanā asmimāna samugghātāya ati asmi iti uppajjanakassa
translated: ‘For the cutting off of applied thoughts’: for the purpose of cutting off wrong thoughts. ‘Perception of impermanence’: the contemplation of impermanence that occurs thus, ‘All formations are impermanent.’ ‘For the uprooting of the conceit “I am”’: for the purpose of uprooting the conceit ‘I am’ that arises thus,🔽‘I am.’

original: navavidhassāpi mānassa samucchindanāya. Ettha hi ekasseva cattāro dhammā bhāvetabbā
analyzed: navavidhassa api mānassa samucchindanāya ettha hi ekassa iva cattāraḥ dhammāḥ bhāvetabbā
translated: for the purpose of uprooting the nine kinds of conceit. For here four things are stated to be developed by one,

original: vuttā, na ekassa catucariyatāya. Tena viññāyati “sabbānipi kammaṭṭhānāni sabbākusalavikkhambhanāni
analyzed: vuttāḥ na ekassa catu cariya tāya tena viññāyati sabbāni api kammaṭṭhānāni sabba akusala vikkhambhanāni
translated: not by four by one. Therefore it can be understood that all meditation subjects suppress all unprofitable things

original: sabbakusalaparibrūhanānī”ti.
analyzed: sabba kusala paribrūhanāni iti
translated: and promote all profitable things.

original: Ekasseva satta kammaṭṭhānāni vuttāni, na cāyasmā rāhulo sabbacaritoti adhippāyo.
analyzed: ekassa iva satta kammaṭṭhānāni vuttāni na ca āyasmā rāhulaḥ sabba carito ti adhippāyaḥ
translated: Seven meditation subjects are stated for one, but the venerable Rāhula’s practice is not all of them: this is the purport.

original: Vacanamatteti “asukakammaṭṭhānaṃ asukacaritassa anukūla”nti evaṃ vuttavacanamatte.
analyzed: vacana matta iti asuka kammaṭṭhānam asuka caritassa anukūlan ti evam vutta vacana matte
translated: In the mere words: “This meditation subject is suitable for one of such a temperament” is what is meant.

original: Adhippāyoti tathāvacanassa adhippāyo. So pana “sabbañceta”ntiādinā vibhāvito eva.
analyzed: adhippāyaḥ ti tathāvacanassa adhippāyo so pana sabbañcetan ti ādinā vibhāvitaḥ eva
translated: In the purport: the purport of the words. But that is made clear by the passage beginning, “If all” .

original: 48. “Piyo garū”tiādinā vuttappakāraṃ kalyāṇamittaṃ. “Attano pattacīvaraṃ sayameva🔽gahetvā”tiādinā vuttanayena upasaṅkamitvā. Somanassameva uppajjati “evaṃ bahuparissayoyaṃ
analyzed: piyaḥ garu ti ādinā vutta ppakāram kalyāṇa mittam patta cīvaram sayam eva  gahetvā ati ādinā vutta nayena upasaṅkamitvā somanassam eva uppajjati evam bahu parissayaḥ yam
translated: A good friend of the kind described in the passage beginning, “Dear to the good” .🔽Approaching in the way described in the passage beginning, “Taking his own bowl and robe” .

original: attabhāvo ṭhāneyeva mayā niyyātito”ti. Tenāha “yathā hī”tiādi.
analyzed: atta bhāvaḥ mayā niyyātito ti tena āha yathā hi itiādi
translated: He is glad, thinking, “This selfhood of mine has been handed over to a place of safety among all these dangers.” That is why he said, “Just as a man,” etc.

original: Atajjanīyoti na tajjetabbo na niggahetabbo. Svāyaṃ atajjanīyabhāvo dovacassatāya
analyzed: a tajjanīyaḥ iti na tajjetabbaḥ na niggahetabbaḥ su ayam a tajjanīya bhāvaḥ dovacassatāya
translated: He should not be despised: he should not be despised, should not be suppressed. This quality of not being despised is either due to his being difficult to admonish or

original: vā siyā, ācariye aniviṭṭhapematāya vāti tadubhayaṃ dassetuṃ “dubbaco vā”tiādi vuttaṃ.
analyzed: vā siyā ācariye a niviṭṭha pematāya vā ati tat ubhayam dassetum dubbacaḥ vā itiādi vuttam
translated: due to his not being intent on the teacher. In order to show both of these, the following is said.🔽For one who, when admonished by the teacher, shows anger, hate, and contempt, or one who leaves, thinking, “What do I care about him?”—both of these are despised.

original: Yo hi ācariyena tajjiyamāno kopañca dosañca apaccayañca pātukaroti, yo vā “kimassa🔽santike vāsenā”ti pakkamati, ayaṃ duvidhopi atajjanīyo. Dhammenāti ovādānusāsanidhammena.
analyzed: yaḥ hi ācariyena tajjiyamāno kopañca dosañca apaccayañca pātukaroti yaḥ vā kimassa  santike vāsena ati pakkamati ayam duvidhaḥ pi a tajjanīyaḥ dhammena ati ovāda anusāsani dhammena
translated: By the Dhamma: by the Dhamma of instruction and counsel.

original: Gūḷhaṃ ganthanti kammaṭṭhānaganthaṃ, saccapaṭiccasamuppādādisahitaṃ gambhīraṃ suññatāpaṭisaṃyuttañca.🔽Tumhākamatthāyāti vutteti “sataporise papāte patanena tumhākaṃ koci attho hotī”ti
analyzed: gūḷham ganthanti kammaṭṭhāna gantham sacca paṭiccasamuppāda ādi sahitam gambhīram suñña tā paṭisaṃyuttam ca  tumhākam atthāya ati vuttā iti sataporise papāte patanena tumhākam koci attho hoti iti
translated: The knot: the knot of the meditation subject, the profound teaching of the Four Truths, dependent origination, etc., and the teaching of emptiness.🔽When it is said, “For your sake”: when it is said by someone, “For your sake I will fall into a pit of burning embers twenty leagues across.”🔽When it is said, “For your sake”: when it is said by someone, “For your sake I will fall into a pit of burning embers twenty leagues across.”

original: kenaci vutte. Ghaṃsentoti “manussakakkena tumhākaṃ koci attho”ti vutte ghaṃsento🔽niravasesaṃ attabhāvaṃ khepetuṃ ussaheyyaṃ. “Mama assāsapassāsanirundhanena tumhākaṃ
analyzed: kenaci vutte ghaṃsento ti manussa kakkena tumhākam koci atthaḥ ti vutte ghaṃsento 🔽niravasesam atta bhāvam khepetum ussaheyyam mama assāsa passāsa nirundhanena tumhākam
translated: When it is said, “For your sake”: when it is said by someone, “For your sake I will fall into a pit of burning embers twenty leagues across.”🔽When it is said, “For your sake”: when it is said by someone, “For your sake I will fall into a pit of burning embers twenty leagues across.”🔽When it is said, “For your sake”: when it is said by someone, “For your sake I will fall into a pit of burning embers twenty leagues across.”🔽When it is said, “For your sake”: when it is said by someone, “For your sake I will fall into a pit of burning embers twenty leagues across.”🔽When it is said, “For your sake”: when it is said by someone, “For your sake I will fall into a pit of burning embers twenty leagues across.”🔽When it is said, “For your sake”: when it is said by someone, “For your sake I will fall into a pit of burning embers twenty leagues across.”🔽When it is said, “For your sake”: when it is said by someone, “For your sake I will fall into a pit of burning embers twenty leagues across.”

original: koci rogavūpasamādiko attho atthī”ti kenaci vutte. Tīhipi bhikkhūhi ācariye bhattipavedanamukhena🔽vīriyārambho eva pavedito.
analyzed: koci roga vūpasama ādikaḥ atthaḥ atthi iti kenaci vutte tīhi pi bhikkhūhi ācariye bhatti pavedana mukhena  vīriya ārambhaḥ eva paveditaḥ
translated: and the three bhikkhus announced their teacher’s exertion by way of the announcement of the meal.

original: 49. Aññattha pavattitvāpi cittaṃ āgamma yattha seti, so tassa āsayo “migāsayo” viya,🔽āsayo eva ajjhāsayo. So duvidho vipanno, sampannoti. Tattha vipanno sassatādimicchābhinivesanissito.
analyzed: aññattha pavattitvā api cittam āgamma yattha seti so tassa āsayaḥ migāsayaḥ viya  āsayaḥ eva ajjhāsayaḥ so duvidhaḥ vipannaḥ sampannaḥ ti tattha vipannaḥ
translated: And though the mind occurs elsewhere, the place where it lies is its lair, like the lair of a deer.🔽The lair itself is the inmost lair. That is of two kinds: failed and successful. Herein, the failed kind is that which is based on the perversions consisting in the wrong convictions about eternalism, etc.,

original: Sampanno duvidho vaṭṭanissito, vivaṭṭanissitoti. Tesu vivaṭṭanissito ajjhāsayo “sampannajjhāsayenā”ti
analyzed: sampannaḥ duvidhaḥ vaṭṭa nissitaḥ vivaṭṭa nissitaḥ ti tesu vivaṭṭa nissitaḥ ajjhāsayaḥ sampanna jhāsayena ati
translated: The successful kind is of two kinds: that which is based on the round of rebirths and that which is based on the cessation of the round. Herein, the inmost lair based on the cessation of the round is intended by the words “with a successful inmost lair” .

original: idhādhippeto. Idāni naṃ vibhāgena dassetuṃ “alobhādīnaṃ vasenā”tiādi vuttaṃ. Tattha🔽chahākārehīti alubbhanādīhi chahi ākārehi. Sampannajjhāsayenāti pubbabhāgiyānaṃ sīlasampadādīnaṃ
analyzed: idha adhippetaḥ idāni nam vibhāgena dassetum alobha ādīnam vasena atiādi vuttam tattha  chahi ākārehi iti a lubbhana ādīhi chahi ākārehi pubbabhāgiyānam sīla sampad ādīnam
translated: Now, in order to show that by analysis, “Through non-greed, etc.,” is said. Herein,🔽through the six modes is through the six modes beginning with non-greed.🔽With a successful inmost lair: he has a successful inmost lair since his inmost lair is successful in the sense of the accomplishment of the requisites of virtue, etc.,

original: sādhanavasena, lokuttarānaṃ upanissayabhāvena ca sampanno ajjhāsayo etassāti sampannajjhāsayo,
analyzed: sādhana vasena lokuttarānam upanissaya bhāvena ca sampannaḥ ajjhāsayo etassa ati sampannajjhāsayo
translated: in the sense of the condition for the supramundane states.

original: tena. Alobhādayo hi anekadosavidhamanato, anekaguṇāvahato ca sattānaṃ bahukārā visesato
analyzed: tena alobha ādayaḥ hi aneka dosa vidhamanataḥ aneka guṇa āvahataḥ ca sattānam bahu kārāḥ visesataḥ
translated: For non-greed, etc., are of great service to beings in many ways, by the elimination of the many kinds of faults and by the arousing of the many kinds of virtues.

original: yogino. Tathā hi alobhādayo maccheramalādīnaṃ paṭipakkhabhāvena pavattanti. Vuttaṃ hetaṃ –
analyzed: yoginaḥ tathā hi alobha ādayaḥ macchera mala ādīnam paṭipakkha bhāvena pavattanti vuttam ha etam
translated: And that is especially so in the case of meditators. For non-greed, etc., occur as the opposites of stinginess, ill will, and stiffness of understanding. For this is said:

original: “Alobho maccheramalassa paṭipakkho, adoso dussīlyamalassa, amoho kusalesu dhammesu
analyzed: alobho macchera malassa paṭipakkhaḥ adosaḥ dussīlya malassa amoho kusalesu dhammesu
translated: “Non-greed is the opposite of the stain of stinginess, non-hate of the stain of depravity, and non-delusion of the stain of stiffness in regard to virtue, etc.,

original: abhāvanāya. Alobho cettha dānahetu, adoso sīlahetu, amoho bhāvanāhetu. Tesu ca alobhena
analyzed: abhāvanāya alobho ca ittha dāna hetu adoso sīla hetu amohaḥ bhāvanā hetu tesu ca alobhena
translated: and of the stain of non-development in regard to profitable things” . And here non-greed is the cause of giving, non-hate the cause of virtue, and non-delusion the cause of development.🔽And by means of non-greed he takes no more than is his due, unlike the greedy man who takes too much;

original: anadhikaṃ gaṇhāti luddhassa adhikaggahaṇato, adosena anūnaṃ duṭṭhassa ūnaggahaṇato,
analyzed: anadhikam gaṇhāti luddhassa adhika ggahaṇataḥ adosena anūnam duṭṭhassa ūna ggahaṇataḥ
translated: by means of non-hate he takes nothing less, unlike the hating man who takes too little;

original: amohena aviparītaṃ mūḷhassa viparītaggahaṇato.🔽“Alobhena cettha vijjamānaṃ dosaṃ dosato dhārento dose pavattati, luddho hi dosaṃ
analyzed: a mohena a viparītam mūḷhassa viparīta ggahaṇato  alobhena ca ittha vijjamānam dosam dosataḥ dhārentaḥ dose pavattati luddhaḥ hi dosam
translated: by means of non-delusion he takes without misapprehending, unlike the deluded man who misapprehends.🔽And here he is not greedy for what is not his due, unlike the greedy man who is greedy for what is not his due. He does not take less than his due, unlike the hating man who takes less than his due.

original: paṭicchādeti. Adosena vijjamānaṃ guṇaṃ guṇato dhārento guṇe pavattati, duṭṭho hi
analyzed: paṭicchādeti adosena vijjamānam guṇam guṇataḥ dhārentaḥ guṇe pavattati duṭṭhaḥ hi
translated: He takes without misapprehending, unlike the deluded man who misapprehends.

original: guṇaṃ makkheti. Amohena yāthāvasabhāvaṃ yāthāvasabhāvato dhārento yāthāvasabhāve
analyzed: guṇam makkheti amohena yāthāvasa bhāvam yāthāvasa bhāvataḥ dhārentaḥ yāthāvasa bhāve
translated: He misrepresents a virtue.🔽Through non-delusion, bearing the real basic nature as the real basic nature, he bears the real basic nature🔽

original: pavattati, mūḷho hi tacchaṃ ‘ataccha’nti, atacchañca ‘taccha’nti gaṇhāti. Alobhena
analyzed: pavattati mūḍhaḥ hi taccham a tacchanti a tacchan ca tacchanti gaṇhāti alobhena
translated: He misconstrues a quality. Through non-delusion he maintains the true nature of things as it is in actuality and occurs in the true nature of things. For the deluded person takes what is not a reason to be a reason and what is a reason to be not a reason. Through non-greed

original: ca piyavippayogadukkhaṃ na hoti luddhassa piyasabbhāvato, piyavippayogāsahanato ca,
analyzed: ca piya vippayoga dukkham na hoti luddhassa piya sabbhāvataḥ piya vippayoga asahanato ca
translated: he does not have the suffering of separation from the loved, for the greedy person loves the loved and cannot bear to be separated from them.

original: adosena appiyasampayogadukkhaṃ na hoti duṭṭhassa appiyasabbhāvato, appiyasampayogāsahanato
analyzed: adosena appiya sampayoga dukkham na hoti duṭṭhassa appiya sabbhāvataḥ appiya sampayoga asahanato
translated: Through non-hate he does not have the suffering of association with the unloved, for the hateful person hates the unloved and cannot bear to be associated with them.

original: ca, amohena icchitālābhadukkhaṃ na hoti, amūḷhassa hi ‘taṃ kutettha labbhā’ti evamādipaccavekkhaṇasabbhāvato.🔽“Alobhena cettha jātidukkhaṃ na hoti alobhassa taṇhāpaṭipakkhato, taṇhāmūlakattā🔽ca jātidukkhassa, adosena jarādukkhaṃ na hoti tikkhadosassa khippaṃ jarāsambhavato,
analyzed: ca amohena icchita alābha dukkham na hoti amūḷhassa hi tam kuta ittha evamādi paccavekkhaṇa sabbhāvato  alobhena ca ittha jāti dukkham na hoti alobhassa taṇhā paṭipakkhato taṇhā mūlaka ttā  ca jāti dukkhassa adosena jarā dukkham na hoti tikkha dosassa khippam jarā sambhavato
translated: Through non-delusion he does not have the suffering of not getting what is wanted, for the non-deluded person reflects thus: “How can I get what I want?”🔽“Through non-greed he does not have the suffering of birth, for non-greed is the opposite of craving, and the suffering of birth has craving as its root.🔽Through non-hate he does not have the suffering of aging, for one who is full of hate ages quickly.

original: amohena maraṇadukkhaṃ na hoti, sammohamaraṇañhi dukkhaṃ, na ca taṃ amūḷhassa hoti.
analyzed: amohena maraṇa dukkham na hoti sammoha maraṇam hi dukkham na ca tam amūḷhassa hoti
translated: Through non-delusion he does not have the suffering of death, for death through delusion is suffering, and the non-deluded person does not die thus.

original: Alobhena ca gahaṭṭhānaṃ, amohena pabbajitānaṃ, adosena pana sabbesampi sukhasaṃvāsatā hoti.🔽“Visesato cettha alobhena pettivisaye upapatti na hoti, yebhuyyena hi sattā taṇhāya
analyzed: alobhena ca gaha ṭṭhānam amohena pabbajitānam adosena pana sabbesam pi sukha saṃvāsa tā hoti  visesataḥ ca ittha alobhena petti visaye upapatti na hoti yebhuyyena hi sattā taṇhāya
translated: And it is through non-greed that householders live happily together, and through non-delusion that those gone forth live happily together, and through non-hate that all live happily together.

original: pettivisayaṃ upapajjanti, taṇhāya ca paṭipakkho alobho. Adosena niraye upapatti na🔽hoti, dosena hi caṇḍajātitāya dosasadisaṃ nirayaṃ upapajjanti, dosassa ca paṭipakkho🔽adoso. Amohena tiracchānayoniyaṃ nibbatti na hoti, mohena hi niccasammūḷhaṃ tiracchānayoniṃ
analyzed: petti visayam upapajjanti taṇhāya ca paṭipakkhaḥ alobho adosena niraye upapatti na  hoti dosena hi caṇḍa jāti tāya dosa sadisam nirayam upapajjanti dosassa ca paṭipakkhaḥ  adosaḥ a mohena tiracchānayoniyam nibbatti na hoti mohena hi nicca sammūḷham tiracchānayonim
translated: “And here, through non-greed there is no rebirth in the realm of the ghosts, for it is by craving that beings are reborn in the ghost realm, and non-greed is the opposite of craving. Through non-hate there is no rebirth in hell,🔽for it is by hate that beings are reborn in hell, which is like a place of ghosts, because of their violent nature, and non-hate is the opposite of hate. Through non-delusion there is no rebirth in the animal realm,

original: upapajjanti, mohapaṭipakkho ca amoho. Etesu ca alobho rāgavasena upagamanassa abhāvakaro,
analyzed: upapajjanti moha paṭipakkho ca amoho etesu ca alobho rāga vasena upagamanassa abhāva karo
translated: for it is by delusion that beings are reborn in the animal realm, being constantly confused, and non-delusion is the opposite of delusion. And of these three, non-greed prevents one from going by the way of lust,

original: adoso dosavasena apagamanassa, amoho mohavasena amajjhattabhāvassa.
analyzed: a dosaḥ dosa vasena apagamanassa a mohaḥ moha vasena a majjhatta bhāvassa
translated: non-hate prevents one from going by the way of hate, and non-delusion prevents one from going by the way of delusion.

original: “Tīhipi cetehi yathāpaṭipāṭiyā nekkhammasaññā abyāpādasaññā avihiṃsāsaññāti imā tisso,
analyzed: tīhi pi ca itehi yathā paṭipāṭiyā nekkhamma saññā a byāpāda saññā a vihiṃsā saññā ati imāḥ tisso
translated: “And by these three, respectively, in the order in which they are given, there are the three perceptions, namely, the perception of renunciation, the perception of non-ill will, and the perception of non-cruelty.

original: asubhasaññā appamāṇasaññā dhātusaññāti imā ca tisso saññāyo honti. Alobhena pana
analyzed: asubha saññā appamāṇa saññā dhātu saññā ati imāḥ ca tisso saññāyaḥ honti alobhena pana
translated: and the three perceptions of foulness, of the measureless, and of elements.

original: kāmasukhallikānuyogaantassa, adosena attakilamathānuyogaantassa parivajjanaṃ hoti,
analyzed: kāma sukhallikā anuyoga antassa adosena atta kilamatha anuyoga antassa parivajjanam hoti
translated: But the avoidance of indulgence in pleasure and of self- mortification is through non-greed and through non-hate respectively,

original: amohena majjhimāya paṭipattiyā paṭipajjanaṃ. Tathā alobhena abhijjhākāyaganthassa
analyzed: amohena majjhimāya paṭipattiyā paṭipajjanam tathā alobhena abhijjhā kāya ganthassa
translated: and the undertaking of the middle way is through non-delusion.

original: pabhedanaṃ hoti, adosena byāpādakāyaganthassa, amohena sesaganthadvayassa. Purimāni
analyzed: pabhedanam hoti adosena byāpāda kāya ganthassa amohena sesa gantha dvayassa purimāni
translated: And the bursting asunder of the bodily tie of covetousness is through non-greed, of the bodily tie of ill will through non-hate, and of the other two bodily ties through non-delusion.

original: ca dve satipaṭṭhānāni purimānaṃ dvinnaṃ ānubhāvena, pacchimāni pacchimasseva ānubhāvena ijjhanti.🔽“Alobho cettha ārogyassa paccayo hoti, aluddho hi lobhanīyampi asappāyaṃ na sevati,
analyzed: ca dve satipaṭṭhānāni purimānam dvinnam ānubhāvena pacchimāni pacchimassa iva ānubhāvena ijjhanti  alobho ca ittha ārogyassa paccayaḥ hoti a luddhaḥ hi lobhanīyam pi a sappāyam na sevati
translated: And the first two foundations of mindfulness succeed through the power of the first two of these three, and the last two through the power of the last one.🔽Herein, non-greed is a condition for health, for one who is not greedy does not frequent what is unsuitable, and so he is healthy.

original: tena arogo hoti. Adoso yobbanassa, aduṭṭho hi valitapalitāvahena dosagginā aḍayhamāno
analyzed: tena arogaḥ hoti a dosaḥ yobbanassa aduṭṭhaḥ hi valita palita āvahena dosagginā a ḍayhamāno
translated: Non-hate is a condition for youthfulness, for one who is not hateful is not burnt by the fire of hate that consumes those subject to hate, and so

original: dīgharattaṃ yuvā hoti. Amoho dīghāyukatāya, amūḷho hi hitāhitaṃ ñatvā ahitaṃ parivajjento,
analyzed: dīgharattam yuvā hoti amohaḥ dīgha āyuka tāya amūḍhaḥ hi hita ahitam ñatvā ahitam parivajjentaḥ
translated: he is youthful for a long time. Non-delusion is a condition for longevity, for one who is not deluded knows what is good and harmful and so avoids what is harmful,🔽and so

original: hitañca paṭisevamāno dīghāyuko hoti.🔽“Alobho cettha bhogasampattiyā paccayo cāgena bhogapaṭilābhato, adoso mittasampattiyā
analyzed: hitam ca paṭisevamānaḥ dīgha āyukaḥ hoti  alobho ca ittha bhoga sampattiyāḥ paccayaḥ cāgena bhoga paṭilābhato adoso mitta sampattiyāḥ
translated: and by practicing what is beneficial, he becomes long-lived.🔽“Non-greed is a condition for the acquisition of wealth through non-covetousness, non-hate for the acquisition of friends through loving-kindness,

original: mettāya mittānaṃ paṭilābhato, aparihānato ca, amoho attasampattiyā, amūḷho hi attano🔽hitameva karonto attānaṃ sampādeti. Alobho ca dibbavihārassa paccayo hoti, adoso
analyzed: mettāya mittānam paṭilābhataḥ a parihānataḥ ca amohaḥ atta sampattiyāḥ amūḍhaḥ hi attano  hitam eva karontaḥ attānam sampādeti alobho ca dibba vihārassa paccayaḥ hoti adoso
translated: and non-delusion for the acquisition of oneself through non-delusion. For one who is not deluded accomplishes his own welfare. Non-greed is a condition for the divine life through non-greed,

original: brahmavihārassa, amoho ariyavihārassa.🔽“Alobhena cettha sakapakkhesu sattasaṅkhāresu nibbuto hoti tesaṃ vināsena abhisaṅgahetukassa
analyzed: brahmavihārassa amohaḥ ariya vihārassa  alobhena ca ittha saka pakkhesu satta saṅkhāresu nibbutaḥ hoti tesam vināsena abhisaṅga hetukassa
translated: non-hate for the divine abidings, and non-delusion for the noble life.

original: dukkhassa abhāvā, adosena parapakkhesu, aduṭṭhassa hi verīsupi verisaññāya abhāvato,
analyzed: dukkhassa abhāvā adosena parapakkhesu aduṭṭhassa hi verī supi veri saññāya abhāvato
translated: “Herein, through non-greed one is quenched towards the beings in one’s own faction, because of the absence of the suffering due to the grasping that occurs through their destruction. Through non-hate one is quenched towards the beings in the faction of others, because of the absence of the perception of enemies in those who are not hateful,

original: amohena udāsīnapakkhesu amūḷhassa sabbābhisaṅgatāya abhāvato.
analyzed: amohena udāsīna pakkhesu amūḷhassa sabba abhisaṅga tāya abhāvato
translated: and through non-delusion towards the beings in the neutral faction, because of the absence of grasping in all ways on the part of one who is not deluded.

original: “Alobhena ca aniccadassanaṃ hoti, luddho hi upabhogāsāya aniccepi saṅkhāre aniccato
analyzed: alobhena ca anicca dassanam hoti luddhaḥ hi anicce pi saṅkhāre aniccato
translated: “And through non-greed there is the seeing of impermanence, because the greedy person, being intent on enjoyment, does not see formations as impermanent, even though they are impermanent,

original: na passati. Adosena dukkhadassanaṃ, adosajjhāsayo hi pariccattaāghātavatthupariggaho
analyzed: na passati adosena dukkha dassanam a dosa ajjhāsayaḥ hi pariccatta āghāta vatthu pariggaho
translated: He does not see them as pleasant. Through non-hate he sees them as painful. For one whose habit is non-hate, who has taken up the practice of not retaliating for injuries done to him,

original: saṅkhāreyeva dukkhato passati. Amohena anattadassanaṃ, amūḷho hi yāthāvagahaṇakusalo
analyzed: saṅkhāreya iva dukkhataḥ passati amohena anatta dassanam amūḷhaḥ hi yāthāva gahaṇa kusalaḥ
translated: sees formations as painful. Through non-delusion he sees them as not-self. For one who is undeluded, who is skilled in apprehending things as they really are,

original: apariṇāyakaṃ khandhapañcakaṃ apariṇāyakato bujjhati. Yathā ca etehi aniccadassanādīni,
analyzed: apariṇāyakam khandha pañcakam apariṇāyakataḥ bujjhati yathā ca etehi anicca dassana ādīni
translated: awakens to the five aggregates as objects of clinging as not a self. And just as through the three contemplations beginning with that on impermanence he comes to the three kinds of direct knowledge beginning with that of the kinds of knowledge,

original: evaṃ etepi aniccadassanādīhi honti. Aniccadassanena hi alobho hoti, dukkhadassanena🔽adoso, anattadassanena amoho. Ko hi nāma ‘aniccamida’nti sammā ñatvā tassatthāya🔽pihaṃ uppādeyya, saṅkhāre vā ‘dukkha’nti jānanto aparampi accantatikhiṇaṃ kodhadukkhaṃ
analyzed: evam ete api anicca dassana ādīhi honti anicca dassanena hi alobho hoti dukkha dassanena  adosaḥ anatta dassanena amohaḥ kaḥ hi nāma aniccam idam ti sammā ñatvā tassa atthāya  piham uppādeyya saṅkhāre vā dukkhanti jānantaḥ aparam pi accanta tikhiṇam kodha dukkham
translated: so too through the three kinds of direct knowledge beginning with that of the kinds of knowledge he comes to the three contemplations beginning with that on impermanence. For through the direct knowledge of the kinds of knowledge there is the contemplation of impermanence,🔽through the direct knowledge of the mind’s disposition there is the contemplation of pain,🔽through the direct knowledge of the way things are there is the contemplation of not-self. For who that knows “This is impermanent” will arouse greed for it, or who that knows “Formations are painful” will arouse anger, which is the most virulent of all pains,

original: uppādeyya, attasuññatañca bujjhitvā puna sammohaṃ āpajjeyyā”ti.
analyzed: uppādeyya atta suñña tañca bujjhitvā puna sammoham āpajjeyya ati
translated: or who that knows “All this is not-self” will fall into delusion?🔽Hence it was said: “They are conditions for the supramundane states as fulfilment of the requisites in the earlier stages,

original: Tena vuttaṃ “pubbabhāgiyānaṃ sīlasampadādīnaṃ sādhanavasena lokuttarānaṃ, upanissayabhāvena
analyzed: tena vuttam pubbabhāgiyānam sīla sampad ādīnam sādhana vasena lokuttarānam upanissaya bhāvena
translated: and as support in the later stages.”

original: ca sampanno ajjhāsayo etassāti sampannajjhāsayo”ti. Tenāha “evaṃ tissannaṃ bodhīnaṃ🔽aññataraṃ pāpuṇātī”ti.
analyzed: ca sampannaḥ ajjhāsayaḥ etassa ati sampanna jhāsayaḥ tena āha evam bodhīnam  aññataram pāpuṇāti iti
translated: Hence it is said: “He reaches one of the three kinds of enlightenment.”

original: Idāni te ajjhāsaye pāḷiyāva vibhāvetuṃ “yathāhā”tiādi vuttaṃ. Tattha chāti gaṇanaparicchedo.
analyzed: idāni te ajjhāsaye vibhāvetum yathā āha atiādi vuttam tattha chā ti gaṇana paricchedo
translated: Now, in order to demonstrate those intentions in the texts themselves, the Master said, “As it is said,” and so on. Herein, “six” is the delimitation by number.

original: Ajjhāsayāti paricchinnadhammanidassanaṃ. Ubhayaṃ pana ekajjhaṃ katvā chabbidhā ajjhāsayāti
analyzed: ajjhāsayā ati paricchinna dhamma nidassanam ubhayam pana ekajjham katvā chabbidhā ajjhāsayā ati
translated: “Intentions” is the demonstration of the limited state of the ideas. But taking both together, the meaning is: “sixfold intentions.”

original: attho. Bodhisattāti bujjhanakasattā, bodhiyā vā niyatabhāvena sattā laggā, adhimuttā
analyzed: atthaḥ bodhisattā ati bujjhanaka sattā bodhiyā vā niyata bhāvena sattā laggā adhimuttā
translated: “Bodhisattas”: beings who are awakened , or beings who are attached by being destined for enlightenment , or beings who are bent on enlightenment , who are inclined to enlightenment, who are intent on enlightenment.

original: tanninnā tappoṇāti attho. Bodhiparipākāya saṃvattantīti yathābhinīhāraṃ attanā pattabbabodhiyā🔽paripācanāya bhavanti. Alobhajjhāsayāti alubbhanākārena pavattaajjhāsayā, ādito “kathaṃ
analyzed: tad ninnā tad poṇā ati atthaḥ bodhi paripākāya saṃvattanti iti yathā abhinīhāram attanā pattabba bodhiyā  paripācanāya bhavanti alobha jhāsayā ati alubbhana ākārena pavatta ajjhāsayā āditas katham
translated: “They lead to the ripening of enlightenment”: they lead to the ripening of the enlightenment that is to be attained by oneself in accordance with the aspiration .

original: nu kho mayaṃ sabbattha, sabbadā ca aluddhā eva hessāmā”ti, majjhe ca alubbhanavaseneva,
analyzed: nu kho mayam sabbattha sabbadā ca a luddhāḥ eva hessāma ati majjhe ca a lubbhana vasena iva
translated: “Non-greed intentions”: intentions that occur in the mode of non-greed . At the beginning, “How may we be non-greedy everywhere and at all times?” and in the middle, by the mode of non-greed ,

original: pacchā ca tasseva rocanavasena pavattaajjhāsayā. Lobhe dosadassāvinoti lubbhanalakkhaṇe
analyzed: pacchā ca tassa iva rocana vasena pavatta ajjhāsayā lobhe lubbhana lakkhaṇe
translated: and afterwards, by way of his inclination towards it.🔽Seeing danger in greed: seeing the danger in greed in all its aspects,

original: lobhe sabbappakārena ādīnavadassāvino. Idaṃ tassa ajjhāsayassa ekadesato brūhanākāradassanaṃ.
analyzed: lobhe sabba ppakārena ādīnava dassāvino idam tassa ajjhāsayassa eka desataḥ brūhana ākāra dassanam
translated: which has the characteristic of lust. This is the seeing of the mode of development of that inclination in part.

original: Lobhe hi ādīnavaṃ, alobhe ca ānisaṃsaṃ passantassa alobhajjhāsayo parivaḍḍhati, svāyaṃ🔽tattha ādīnavānisaṃsadassanavidhi vibhāvitoyeva. Sesapadesupi iminā nayena attho
analyzed: lobhe hi ādīnavam alobhe ca ānisaṃsam passantassa alobha ajjhāsayo parivaḍḍhati  tattha ādīnava anisaṃsa dassana vidhi sesa padesu pi iminā nayena atthaḥ
translated: For when one sees the danger in greed and the benefit in non-greed, his inclination towards non-greed increases.🔽The method of seeing the danger and the benefit here has already been elucidated. The meaning of the other terms should be understood in the same way.

original: veditabbo. Ayaṃ pana viseso – nekkhammanti idha pabbajjā. Paviveko tadaṅgaviveko,
analyzed: veditabbaḥ ayam pana visesaḥ nekkhamman ti idha pabbajjā paviveko tad aṅga viveko
translated: But there is this difference: renunciation here is the going forth.🔽Seclusion is seclusion as a factor of the path, seclusion by suppression, bodily seclusion, and mental seclusion.

original: vikkhambhanaviveko, kāyaviveko, cittaviveko ca. Nissaraṇaṃ nibbānaṃ. Sabbabhavagatīsūti
analyzed: vikkhambhana viveko kāya viveko citta viveko ca nissaraṇam nibbānam sabba bhava gatīsu iti
translated: Deliverance is Nibbāna.🔽In all kinds of becoming and destiny: in all kinds of becoming and in all kinds of destiny.

original: sabbesu bhavesu, sabbāsu ca gatīsu. Tadadhimuttatāyāti yadatthaṃ bhāvanānuyogo, yadatthā
analyzed: sabbesu bhavesu sabbāsu ca gatīsu tad adhimutta tāya ati yadattham bhāvanā anuyogaḥ yadatthā
translated: Inclined to that: inclined to the practice of development, and inclined to the going forth, for the sake of which the practice of development is undertaken and the going forth is done.

original: ca pabbajjā, tadadhimuttena. Tenevāha “samādhādhimuttenā”tiādi.
analyzed: ca pabbajjā tad adhimuttena tena iva āha samādha adhimuttena atiādi
translated: Therefore it is said: “inclined to concentration,” etc.

original: 50. “Kiṃ caritosī”ti pucchito sace “na jānāmī”ti vadeyya, “ke vā te dhammā bahulaṃ
analyzed: kim carito asi iti pucchito sace na jānāmi iti vadeyya ke vā te dhammā bahulam
translated: When asked, “What sort of practice?” if he says, “I do not know,” he should be asked, “What sort of things do you usually do?

original: samudācarantī”ti pucchitabbo. Kiṃ vāti kiṃ asubhaṃ vā anussatiṭṭhānaṃ vā aññaṃ vā.
analyzed: samudācaranti iti pucchitabbaḥ kim vā ati kim asubham vā anussati ṭhānam vā aññam vā
translated: What foulness meditation or other meditation subject?

original: Kiṃ te manasi karoto phāsu hotīti cittassa ekaggabhāvena sukhaṃ hoti. Cittaṃ namatīti
analyzed: kim te manasi karoto phāsu hoti iti cittassa ekagga bhāvena sukham hoti cittam namati iti
translated: What do you find comfortable to attend to? Is it comfortable when the mind becomes unified? Does the mind incline to?

original: pakatiyāva abhirativasena namati. Evamādīhīti ādi-saddena iriyāpathādīnaṃ saṅgaho
analyzed: abhirati vasena namati evamādīhi iti ādi saddena iriyāpatha ādīnam saṅgahaḥ
translated: The word “etc.” in the phrase “such as” includes the postures, etc.,

original: daṭṭhabbo. Tepi hi na sabbassa ekaṃsato byabhicārino eva. Tathā hi samudācāro pucchitabbo
analyzed: daṭṭhabbo te pi hi na sabbassa ekaṃsataḥ byabhicārinaḥ eva tathā hi samudācāraḥ pucchitabbo
translated: for these too are not invariably opposed to all kinds of jhāna. For it is said that the practice should be questioned about them too,

original: vutto. “Asukañca asukañca manasikāravidhiṃ katipayadivasaṃ anuyuñjāhī”ti ca vattabbo.🔽“Pakatiyā uggahitakammaṭṭhānassā”ti idaṃ yaṃ kammaṭṭhānaṃ gahetukāmo, tattha sajjhāyavasena
analyzed: vuttaḥ asukam ca asukam ca manasikāra vidhim katipaya divasam anuyuñjāhi iti ca vattabbaḥ  pakatiyā uggahita kammaṭṭhānassa ati idam yam kammaṭṭhānam gahetu kāmo tattha sajjhāya vasena
translated: and he should be told, “Try for a few days to apply your mind in this way and that way to this meditation subject and to that.”🔽“One who has already learned a meditation subject”: this refers to one who has already had practice in learning a meditation subject by recitation or by attending to it with the mind.

original: vā manasikāravasena vā kataparicayaṃ sandhāya vuttaṃ. Ekaṃ dve nisajjānīti ekaṃ vā
analyzed: vā manasikāra vasena vā kata paricayam sandhāya vuttam ekam dve nisajjāni iti ekam vā
translated: “One or two sessions”:

original: dve vā uṇhāsanāni. Sajjhāyaṃ kāretvā attano sammukhāva adhīyāpetvā dātabbaṃ, so ce
analyzed: dve vā uṇhāsanāni sajjhāyam kāretvā attanaḥ sammukhāva adhīyāpetvā dātabbam saḥ ce
translated: Two hot seats. He should have it recited by heart in his presence after having it recited by heart for him. If he wants to go elsewhere,

original: aññattha gantukāmoti adhippāyo. Tenāha “santike vasantassā”ti. Āgatāgatakkhaṇe kathetabbaṃ,
analyzed: aññattha gantu kāmo ti adhippāyaḥ tena āha santike vasantassa āti āgata āgata khaṇe kathetabbam
translated: the meaning is, that is the intention. Therefore he said, “while living near him.” He should talk to him at the time he comes.

original: pavattiṃ sutvāti adhippāyo.🔽Pathavīkasiṇanti pathavīkasiṇakammaṭṭhānaṃ. Katassāti katassa kasiṇassa. Taṃ taṃ🔽ākāranti ācariyena kammaṭṭhāne vuccamāne padapadatthādhippāyaopammādikaṃ attano ñāṇassa
analyzed: pavattim sutvā iti adhippāyaḥ  pathavī kasiṇanti pathavī kasiṇa kammaṭṭhānam katassa ati katassa kasiṇassa tam tam  ākāranti ācariyena kammaṭṭhāne vuccamāne pada pada attha adhippāya opamma ādikam attanaḥ ñāṇassa
translated: The meaning is, after hearing his progress.

original: paccupaṭṭhitaṃ taṃ taṃ ākāraṃ, yaṃ yaṃ nimittanti vuttaṃ. Upanibandhitvāti upanetvā🔽nibaddhaṃ viya katvā, hadaye ṭhapetvā apamussantaṃ katvāti attho. Evaṃ suṭṭhu upaṭṭhitassatitāya
analyzed: paccupaṭṭhitam tam tam ākāram yam yam nimittam ti vuttam upanibandhitvā iti upanetvā  nibaddham viya katvā hadaye ṭhapetvā apamussantam katvā iti atthaḥ evam suṭṭhu upaṭṭhita sati tāya
translated: The earth kasiṇa: the earth kasiṇa meditation subject. To one who has made it: to one who has made the kasiṇa. In this way and that: when the teacher is expounding the meditation subject, the pupil should attend to the meaning, the letter, the purport, the sequence, the connexion, the heading, the subsumption, the detailed explanation, the brief description, and the removal of doubt, as stated in the Description of the Kinds of Knowledge .

original: nimittaṃ gahetvā tattha sampajānakāritāya sakkaccaṃ suṇantena. Tanti taṃ yathāvuttaṃ
analyzed: nimittam gahetvā tattha sampajāna kāritāya sakkaccam suṇantena tanti tam yathāvuttam
translated: Having fixed it: having brought it, made it as if fixed, placed it in the heart, not letting it go, is the meaning. By one who listens well, by one who has well established mindfulness in this way, by one who has taken up the sign and is conscious of it there, by one who listens attentively. To him: to the pupil who is thus endowed,

original: suggahitaṃ nissāya. Itarassāti tathā agaṇhantassa. Sabbākārenāti kassacipi pakārassa
analyzed: suggahitam nissāya itarassa ati tathā a gaṇhantassa sabba ākārena ati kassaci pi pakārassa
translated: and by the right taking up of the meditation subject. The other: the one who does not take it up in this way. In every way:

original: tattha asesitattā vuttaṃ.
analyzed: tattha a sesita ttā vuttam
translated: because there is nothing left out.

original: Kammaṭṭhānaggahaṇaniddesavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: kammaṭṭhāna ggahaṇa niddesa vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The description of the taking up of the meditation subject is ended.

original: Iti tatiyaparicchedavaṇṇanā.
analyzed: iti tatiya pariccheda vaṇṇanā
translated: The commentary on the third chapter is ended.

original: 4. Pathavīkasiṇaniddesavaṇṇanā🔽51. Phāsu hotīti āvāsasappāyādilābhena manasikāraphāsutā bhāvanānukūlatā hoti. Parisodhentenāti
analyzed: phāsu hoti iti āvāsa sappāya ādi lābhena manasikāra phāsu tā bhāvanā anukūla tā
translated: The description of the earth kasiṇa

original: tesaṃ tesaṃ gaṇṭhiṭṭhānānaṃ chindanavasena visodhentena. Akilamantoyevāti akilantakāyo
analyzed: tesam tesam gaṇṭhi ṭṭhānānam chindana vasena a kilamantaḥ yā iva ati a kilanta kāyaḥ
translated: He feels at ease: he feels ease in giving attention because he has obtained a suitable abode, etc., and he is favourable to development. As he is purifying: as he is purifying by cutting away the knots in the various ways. Without weariness: without bodily weariness.

original: eva. Sati hi kāyakilamathe siyā kammaṭṭhānamanasikārassa antarāyoti adhippāyo. Gaṇṭhiṭṭhānanti🔽atthato, adhippāyato ca dubbinivedhatāya gaṇṭhibhūtaṃ ṭhānaṃ. Chinditvāti yāthāvato
analyzed: eva sati hi kāya kilamathe siyā kammaṭṭhāna manasikārassa antarāyaḥ ti adhippāyaḥ gaṇṭhi ṭṭhānam ti  atthataḥ adhippāyato ca dubbinivedha tāya gaṇṭhi bhūtam ṭhānam chinditvā ati yāthāvato
translated: The intention is that if there is bodily weariness, it may be an obstacle to giving attention to the meditation subject. Knots:

original: atthassa, adhippāyassa ca vibhāvanena chinditvā, vibhūtaṃ supākaṭaṃ katvāti adhippāyo.
analyzed: atthassa adhippāyassa ca vibhāvanena chinditvā vibhūtam su pākaṭam katvā ati adhippāyaḥ
translated: a knot is a place that is difficult to untie because of the difficulty of discerning the right meaning and the right intention. Having cut: having cut by discerning the right meaning and the right intention. Having made it clear: the intention is that he has made it quite plain.

original: Suvisuddhanti suṭṭhu visuddhaṃ, nigumbaṃ nijjaṭanti attho.🔽Ananurūpavihāravaṇṇanā
analyzed: su visuddham ti suṭṭhu visuddham nigumbam nijjaṭanti attho  ananurūpa vihāra vaṇṇanā
translated: “Very pure”: very well purified; the meaning is, “free from the stain of avarice.”

original: 52. Aññatarenāti aññatarenāpi, pageva anekehīti adhippāyo. Mahantabhāvo mahattaṃ.
analyzed: aññatarena ati aññatarena api pagā iva anekehi iti adhippāyaḥ mahantabhāvaḥ mahattaṃ
translated: “In a place that is not suitable”: the intention is that it is so even if there are only a few, let alone many. “Magnificence” is greatness.

original: Tathā sesesu. Soṇḍavā soṇḍī. Tathā paṇṇantiādīsu. Bodhiaṅgaṇādīsu kātabbaṃ idha “vatta”nti
analyzed: tathā sesesu soṇḍavā soṇḍī tathā paṇṇanti ādīsu bodhi aṅgaṇa ādīsu kātabbam idha vattanti
translated: So too in the case of the rest. “A drinking-water pot” is a pot for drinking water. “A leaf” is a leaf of a certain kind. “In the courtyard of the Bodhi Tree” is in the courtyard of the Bodhi Tree. “What should be done” is what should be done in the places mentioned.

original: adhippetanti āha “pānīyaghaṭaṃ vā ritta”nti. Niṭṭhitāyāti paviṭṭhapaviṭṭhānaṃ dānena
analyzed: adhippetanti āha pānīya ghaṭam vā rittam ti niṭṭhitāya ati paviṭṭha paviṭṭhānam dānena
translated: “An empty water-pot” is a water-pot that is empty. “When it is finished” is when it is finished by giving to those who have entered.

original: parikkhīṇāya. Jiṇṇavihārepi yatra bhikkhū evaṃ vadanti “āyasmā, yathāsukhaṃ samaṇadhammaṃ
analyzed: parikkhīṇāya jiṇṇa vihāre pi yatra bhikkhū evam vadanti āyasmai yathāsukham samaṇa dhammaṃ
translated: “In a dilapidated monastery” is in a monastery that is dilapidated. “The bhikkhus say” is the bhikkhus say. “Venerable sir, you may do the ascetic’s duties as you like.

original: karotu, mayaṃ paṭijaggissāmā”ti. Evarūpe vihātabbanti ayampi nayo labbhati, vuttanayattā pana na vutto.🔽Mahāpathavihāreti mahāpathasamīpe vihāre. Bhājanadārudoṇikādīnīti rajanabhājanāni,
analyzed: karotu mayam paṭijaggissāma ati evarūpe vihātabbanti ayam pi nayaḥ labbhati vutta naya ttā pana na vuttaḥ  mahāpatha vihāra iti mahāpatha samīpe vihāre bhājana dāru doṇikā ādīni iti rajana bhājanāni
translated: We will look after you.” “In such a place” is in a place of that kind. This method is also applicable, but it is not mentioned because it is already stated in the way already mentioned.

original: rajanatthāya dāru, dārumayadoṇikā, rajanapacanaṭṭhānaṃ, dhovanaphalakanti evamādīni.
analyzed: rajana atthāya dāru dāru maya doṇikā rajana pacana ṭṭhānam dhovana phalakanti evamādīni
translated: “In a monastery near a great highway” is in a monastery near a great highway. “Vessels, wood, tubs, etc.” are vessels for dyeing, wood for dyeing, wooden tubs, a place for boiling the dye, a washing board, and so on.

original: Sākahārikāti sākahāriniyo itthiyo. Visabhāgasaddo kāmaguṇūpasaṃhito gītasaddoti vadanti,
analyzed: sākahārikā ati sākahāriniyaḥ itthiyaḥ visabhāga saddo kāma guṇa upasaṃhito gīta saddo ti vadanti
translated: “Women gatherers of vegetables” : women who gather vegetables. “Unfamiliar sounds” : they say that this refers to sounds of singing associated with the five cords of sensual pleasure.

original: kevalopi itthisaddo visabhāgasaddo eva. Tatrāti pupphavante vihāre. Tādisoyevāti
analyzed: kevalaḥ pi itthi saddaḥ visabhāga saddaḥ eva tatra ati pupphavante vihāre tādisaḥ yā iva ati
translated: But the mere sound of a woman’s voice is also an “unfamiliar sound.” “There” : in the Flower Garden Monastery. “Just the same” :

original: “tatthassa kammaṭṭhānaṃ gahetvā”tiādinā yādiso paṇṇavante vihāre upaddavo vutto,
analyzed: tattha assa kammaṭṭhānam gahetvā iti ādinā yādisaḥ paṇṇava ante vihāre upaddavaḥ vutto
translated: just as the danger in the Leaf-thatched Cottage Monastery was described in the passage beginning, “Having taken up his meditation subject there” ,

original: tādisoyeva. “Pupphahārikāyo pupphaṃ ocinantiyo”ti pana vattabbaṃ. Ayamidha viseso.
analyzed: tādisaḥ yeva puppha hārikāyo puppham ocinantiyo ti pana vattabbam ayam idha viseso
translated: so it is here too. But it should be said that the women were gathering flowers and plucking them. This is the difference here.

original: Patthanīyeti tattha vasantesu sambhāvanāvasena upasaṅkamanādinā patthetabbe. Tenāha “leṇasammate”ti. Dakkhiṇāgirīti magadhavisaye dakkhiṇāgirīti vadanti.
analyzed: patthanīyā iti tattha vasantesu sambhāvanā vasena upasaṅkamana ādinā patthetabbe tena āha leṇa sammata iti dakkhiṇāgirī iti magadha visaye dakkhiṇāgirī iti vadanti
translated: “Worthy of being sought” : worthy of being sought by those living there through their esteem for him. Hence it is said, “in a place considered a shelter.” “The Southern Hill” : they say that this is the Southern Hill in the Magadha country.

original: Visabhāgārammaṇāni iṭṭhāni, aniṭṭhāni ca. Aniṭṭhānaṃ hi dassanatthaṃ “ghaṭehi nighaṃsantiyo”tiādi vuttaṃ. Dabbūpakaraṇayoggā rukkhā dabbūpakaraṇarukkhā.
analyzed: visa bhāga ārammaṇāni iṭṭhāni aniṭṭhāni ca aniṭṭhānam hi dassana attham ghaṭehi vuttam dabba upakaraṇa yoggāḥ rukkhāḥ dabba upakaraṇa rukkhāḥ
translated: “Familiar and unfamiliar objects” : desirable and undesirable objects. For the purpose of showing the undesirable objects, it is said, “beating with pots.” “Trees suitable for scraping” : trees for scratching the itch.

original: Yo pana vihāro. Khalanti dhaññakaraṇaṭṭhānaṃ. Gāvo rundhanti “sassaṃ khādiṃsū”ti.
analyzed: yaḥ pana vihāraḥ khalanti dhañña karaṇa ṭṭhānam gāvaḥ rundhanti sassam khādiṃsu iti
translated: But a monastery is a monastery. “The cattle are penned” means that the cattle are penned in the threshing-floor. “The cattle are penned” means that the cattle are penned in the threshing-floor.

original: Udakavāranti kedāresu sassānaṃ dātabbaudakavāraṃ. Ayampīti mahāsaṅghabhogopi vihāro.
analyzed: udaka vāram ti kedāresu sassānam dātabba odaka vāram ayam pi iti mahā saṅgha bhogaḥ api vihāraḥ
translated: “The water-share” is the water-share to be given to the crops in the paddy fields. “This too” is a monastery that is a great community’s property.

original: Vāriyamānā kammaṭṭhānikena bhikkhunā.🔽Samuddasāmuddikanadīnissitaṃ udakapaṭṭanaṃ. Mahānagarānaṃ āyadvārabhūtaṃ aṭavimukhādinissitaṃ
analyzed: vāriyamānā kammaṭṭhānikena bhikkhunā  samudda sāmuddika nadī nissitam udaka paṭṭanam mahā nagarānam āya dvāra bhūtam aṭavi mukha ādi nissitam
translated: When a bhikkhu who is a meditator is asked for it,🔽A seaport is a place on the sea-shore or on a great river where ships are moored and which is the gateway for the import and export of goods from the great cities. A head-port is a place on the sea-shore or on a great river where ships are moored and which is the gateway for the import and export of goods from the great cities.

original: thalapaṭṭanaṃ. Appasannā honti. Tenassa tattha phāsuvihāro na hotīti adhippāyo. Maññamānā rājamanussā.🔽Samosaraṇenāti ito cito sañcaraṇena. Papāteti papātasīse ṭhatvā gāyi “gītasaddena
analyzed: thala paṭṭanam appasannāḥ honti tena assa tattha phāsu vihāraḥ na hoti iti adhippāyaḥ maññamānāḥ rāja manussāḥ  samosaraṇena ati itas citas sañcaraṇena papāta iti papāta sīse gāyi gīta saddena
translated: The king’s men, thinking, “He is a spy,”🔽By “by association” is meant by moving about here and there. “In a precipice” means on the edge of a precipice. “A bird” is a bird that is singing.

original: idhāgataṃ papāte pātetvā khādissāmī”ti. Vegena gahetvāti vegenāgantvā “kuhiṃ yāsī”ti khandhe gahetvā.
analyzed: idha āgatam papāte pātetvā khādissāmi iti vegena gahetvā ati vegena āgantvā kuhim yāsi iti khandhe gahetvā
translated: “Having seized him quickly” means having seized him by the body, saying, “Where are you going?”

original: Yatthāti yasmiṃ vihāre, vihārasāmantā vā na sakkā hoti kalyāṇamittaṃ laddhuṃ, tattha vihāre so alābho mahādosoti yojanā.
analyzed: yattha ati yasmin vihāre vihāra sāmantāḥ vā na sakkā hoti kalyāṇa mittam laddhum tattha vihāre saḥ alābhaḥ mahā doso ti yojanā
translated: Where: in what monastery, or in the vicinity of what monastery, it is not possible to get a good friend, there the non-acquisition of a good friend is a great disadvantage.🔽On a highway: a monastery situated on a highway is a highway.

original: Panthaninti panthe nīto pavattitoti panthanī, magganissito vihāro. Taṃ panthaniṃ.
analyzed: panthaninti panthe nītaḥ pavattito ti panthanī magga nissitaḥ vihāraḥ tam panthanim
translated: With a crowd: a monastery with a crowd is a crowd.🔽With leaves: a monastery situated in a town is a town.

original: Soṇḍinti soṇḍisahito vihāro soṇḍī, taṃ soṇḍiṃ. Tathā paṇṇantiādīsu. Nagaranissitaṃ🔽nagaranti vuttaṃ uttarapadalopena yathā “bhīmaseno bhīmo”ti. Dārunāti dārunissitena
analyzed: soṇḍin ti soṇḍi sahitaḥ vihāraḥ soṇḍī tam soṇḍim tathā paṇṇanti ādīsu nagara nissitam  nagaran ti vuttam uttara pada lopena yathā bhīmasenaḥ bhīmaḥ iti dārunā ati dāru nissitena
translated: With timber: with timber situated nearby.

original: saha. Visabhāgenāti yo visabhāgehi vusīyati, visabhāgānaṃ vā nivāso, so vihāro visabhāgo.
analyzed: saha visabhāgena ati yaḥ visabhāgehi vusīyati visabhāgānam vā nivāsaḥ saḥ vihāraḥ visabhāgaḥ
translated: With the unsuitable: a monastery where one lives with unsuitable people, or a monastery that is the abode of unsuitable people, is unsuitable.

original: Tena visabhāgena saddhiṃ. Paccantanissitañca sīmānissitañca asappāyañca paccantasīmāsappāyaṃ.
analyzed: tena visabhāgena saddhim paccanta nissitañca sīmā nissitañca asappāyañca paccanta sīmā asappāyam
translated: With the unsuitable. And a monastery situated near the border, situated near a boundary, and unsuitable is near-border-boundary-unsuitable.

original: Yattha mitto na labbhati, tampīti sabbattha ṭhāna-saddāpekkhāya napuṃsakaniddeso.
analyzed: yattha mittaḥ na labbhati tam pi iti sabbattha ṭhāna sadda apekkhāya napuṃsaka niddeso
translated: Where a friend is not to be found, that too: the feminine form is used here because of the word “place” in the expression “where a friend is not to be found.”

original: Iti viññāyāti “bhāvanāya ananurūpānī”ti evaṃ vijānitvā.
analyzed: iti viññāya ati bhāvanāya ananurūpāni iti evam vijānitvā
translated: Having thus discerned: having thus discerned that they are not conducive to development.

original: Anurūpavihāravaṇṇanā
analyzed: anurūpa vihāra vaṇṇanā
translated: Description of a suitable lodging

original: 53. Ayaṃ anurūpo nāmāti ayaṃ vihāro bhāvanāya anurūpo nāma. Nātidūranti gocaraṭṭhānato
analyzed: ayam anurūpaḥ nāma ati ayam vihāraḥ bhāvanāya anurūpaḥ nāma na ati dūram ti gocara ṭṭhānato
translated: This is called suitable: this lodging is called suitable for development.🔽Not too far: not too far from the place for wandering for alms,

original: aḍḍhagāvutato orabhāgatāya na atidūraṃ. Nāccāsannanti pacchimena pamāṇena gocaraṭṭhānato
analyzed: na atidūram pacchimena pamāṇena gocara ṭṭhānato
translated: being in the direction from which the wind blows.🔽Not too near: not too near the place for wandering for alms,

original: pañcadhanusatikatāya na atiāsannaṃ. Tāya ca pana nātidūranāccāsannatāya, gocaraṭṭhānaṃ
analyzed: pañca dhanusatika tāya na ati āsannam tāya ca pana na ati dūra nācca āsanna tāya gocara ṭṭhānam
translated: being five hundred bow-lengths distant.🔽And because it is not too far and not too near, and because the path to the place for wandering for alms is free from dangers, etc.,

original: parissayādirahitamaggatāya ca gamanassa ca āgamanassa ca yuttarūpattā gamanāgamanasampannaṃ.
analyzed: parissaya ādi rahita magga tāya ca gamanassa ca āgamanassa ca yutta rūpa ttā gamana āgamana sampannam
translated: it is endowed with paths suitable for going and coming.🔽It is uncrowded by day because there are few people about in the daytime.

original: Divasabhāge mahājanasaṃkiṇṇatābhāvena divā appākiṇṇaṃ. Abhāvattho hi ayaṃ appa-saddo
analyzed: divasa bhāge mahājana saṃkiṇṇa tā bhāvena divā appa ākiṇṇam abhāva tthaḥ hi ayam appa saddaḥ
translated: For the word “uncrowded” has the meaning of “free from”🔽as in such passages as “of little wants” .

original: “appiccho”tiādīsu viya. Rattiyaṃ janālāpasaddābhāvena rattiṃ appasaddaṃ. Sabbadāpi
analyzed: appiccho ti ādīsu viya rattiyam jana ālāpa sadda abhāvena rattim appasaddam sabbadā api
translated: It is secluded for sound by night because there is no noise of people talking at night.🔽And it is secluded for sign by day because there is no noise of people talking by day.

original: janasannipātanigghosābhāvena appanigghosaṃ. Appakasirenāti akasirena sukheneva. Sīlādiguṇānaṃ
analyzed: jana sannipāta nigghosa abhāvena appa nigghosam appa kasirena ati akasirena sukhena iva
translated: It is easy to get alms because it is easy to get them without difficulty or trouble.

original: thirabhāvappattiyā therā. Suttageyyādi bahu sutaṃ etesanti bahussutā. Vācuggatakaraṇena,🔽sammadeva garūnaṃ santike āgamitabhāvena ca āgato pariyattidhammasaṅkhāto āgamo etesanti🔽āgatāgamā. Suttābhidhammasaṅkhātassa dhammassa dhāraṇena dhammadharā. Vinayassa dhāraṇena🔽vinayadharā. Tesaṃyeva dhammavinayānaṃ mātikāya dhāraṇena mātikādharā. Tattha tattha
analyzed: thira bhāva ppattiyā therā bahu sutam etesanti bahussutāḥ  sammat eva santike āgamita bhāvena ca āgataḥ pariyatti dhamma saṅkhāto āgamaḥ etesan ti  āgata āgamā sutta abhidhamma saṅkhātassa dhammassa dhāraṇena dhammadharāḥ vinayassa dhāraṇena  vinaya dharā tesam yeva dhamma vinayānam mātikāya dhāraṇena mātikādharā tattha tattha
translated: By the making of speech,🔽and by the fact that they have come to the Teachers’ side in the true way, they have come to the tradition called the “tradition of the scriptures” , and so they are “those who have come to the tradition” . Those who bear the Dhamma called the Sutta and the Abhidhamma are “bearers of the Dhamma” . Those who bear the Discipline are “bearers of the Discipline” . Those who bear the Schedule of the Dhamma and Discipline are “bearers of the Schedule” .

original: dhammaparipucchāya paripucchati. Atthaparipucchāya paripañhati vīmaṃsati vicāreti.
analyzed: dhamma paripucchāya paripucchati attha paripucchāya paripañhati vīmaṃsati vicāreti
translated: There, in the case of the Dhamma, he asks questions about the text, and in the case of the Discipline he asks questions about the meaning. He asks questions about the text in the case of the Dhamma and he asks questions about the meaning in the case of the Discipline.

original: Idaṃ, bhante, kathaṃ imassa ko atthoti paripucchanaparipañhākāradassanaṃ. Avivaṭañceva
