translated: For just as the development of tranquillity, etc., protects the excess of the concentration faculty from falling into the sloth and torpor extremes, and just as the development of energy, etc., protects it from falling into the agitation and worry extremes, so too the development of tranquillity, etc., protects the excess of the energy faculty from falling into the agitation and worry extremes, and it abandons it one-sidedly.

original: vuttaṃ “passaddhādibhāvanāya hāpetabba”nti.
analyzed: vuttam passaddha ādi bhāvanāya hāpetabbanti
translated: Therefore it is said that it is to be abandoned by the development of tranquillity, etc.🔽The story of the Elder Soṇa: the story of the Elder Soṇa, who was delicate.

original: Soṇattherassa vatthūti sukumārassa soṇattherassa vatthu. So hi āyasmā satthu santike
analyzed: soṇa ttherassa vatthu iti sukumārassa soṇa ttherassa vatthu so hi āyasmā satthu santike
translated: For this venerable elder, after taking a meditation subject from the Teacher,

original: kammaṭṭhānaṃ gahetvā sītavane viharanto “mama sarīraṃ sukhumālaṃ, na ca sakkā sukheneva
analyzed: kammaṭṭhānam gahetvā sītavane viharantaḥ mama sarīram sukhumālam na ca sakkā sukhena iva
translated: while living in the Cool Grove, thought thus: “My body is delicate. It is not possible for me to attain arahantship and Nibbāna in this life.

original: sukhaṃ adhigantuṃ, kāyaṃ kilametvāpi samaṇadhammo kātabbo”ti ṭhānacaṅkamameva adhiṭṭhāya
analyzed: sukham adhigantum kāyam kilametvā api samaṇa dhammo kātabbo ti ṭhāna caṅkamam eva adhiṭṭhāya
translated: “It is easy to attain happiness. Even if you have to tire your body, you should still practice the ascetic life.” He resolved to practice walking meditation and standing meditation.

original: padhānamanuyuñjanto pādatalesu phoṭesu uṭṭhitesupi vedanaṃ ajjhupekkhitvā daḷhaṃ
analyzed: padhānam anuyuñjantaḥ pāda talesu phoṭesu uṭṭhitesu pi vedanam ajjhupekkhitvā daḷham
translated: He applied himself to striving. Even when blisters arose on the soles of his feet, he looked on with equanimity. He exerted himself with great

original: vīriyaṃ karonto accāraddhavīriyatāya visesaṃ nibbattetuṃ nāsakkhi. Satthā tattha🔽gantvā vīṇovādena ovaditvā vīriyasamatāyojanavidhiṃ dassento kammaṭṭhānaṃ sodhetvā
analyzed: vīriyam karontaḥ accāraddha vīriya tāya visesam nibbattetum na asakkhi satthā tattha  gantvā vīṇā vādena ovaditvā vīriya sama tā yojana vidhim dassento kammaṭṭhānam sodhetvā
translated: energy, but because his energy was excessive, he was unable to produce any distinction. The Teacher went there🔽and advised him with a simile about a lute. He showed him how to apply himself to the balance of energy. He purified his meditation subject

original: gijjhakūṭaṃ gato. Theropi satthārā dinnanayena vīriyasamataṃ yojento vipassanaṃ ussukkāpetvā
analyzed: gijjhakūṭam gataḥ theraḥ api satthārā dinna nayena vīriya samatam yojentaḥ vipassanam
translated: and went to the Vulture Peak. The elder applied himself to the balance of energy in the way the Teacher had shown him. He developed insight and

original: arahatte patiṭṭhāsi. Tena vuttaṃ “soṇattherassa vatthu dassetabba”nti.
analyzed: arahatte patiṭṭhāsi tena vuttam soṇa therassa vatthu dassetabbanti
translated: was established in Arahantship. Therefore it is said: “The story of the Elder Soṇa should be told.”

original: Sesesupīti satisamādhipaññindriyesupi. Ekassāti ekekassa. Sāmaññaniddesovāyaṃ daṭṭhabbo.
analyzed: sesesu pi iti sati samādhi paññindriyesu pi ekassa ati ekekassa sāmañña niddesaḥ uva ayam daṭṭhabbo
translated: In the rest: in the case of the faculties of mindfulness, concentration, and wisdom. Of each: of each one. This is the general statement.

original: Evaṃ pañcannaṃ indriyānaṃ paccekaṃ adhimattatāya pana hāpanavasena samataṃ dassetvā
analyzed: evam pañcannam indriyānam paccekam adhimatta tāya pana hāpana vasena samatam dassetvā
translated: Having thus shown the balance of the faculties by way of the excess and reduction of each of the five faculties,

original: idāni tattha yesaṃ visesato asādhāraṇato, sādhāraṇato ca samatā icchitabbā, taṃ dassetuṃ
analyzed: idāni tattha yesam visesataḥ asādhāraṇataḥ sādhāraṇataḥ ca sama tā icchitabbā tam dassetuṃ
translated: Now, in order to point out the equality of those that are wanted in the sense of distinction, in the sense of the uncommon, and in the sense of the common, it is said:

original: “visesato panā”tiādi vuttaṃ. Etthāti etesu pañcasu indriyesu. Samatanti saddhāpaññānaṃ🔽aññamaññaṃ anūnānadhikabhāvaṃ. Tathā samādhivīriyānaṃ. Yathā hi saddhāpaññānaṃ visuṃ🔽visuṃ dhuriyadhammabhūtānaṃ kiccato aññamaññānativattanaṃ visesato icchitabbameva,
analyzed: visesataḥ pana atiādi vuttam ettha ati etesu pañcasu indriyesu samatanti saddhā paññānam  aññamaññam anūna anadhika bhāvam tathā samādhi vīriyānam yathā hi saddhā paññānam visum  visum dhuriya dhamma bhūtānam kiccataḥ aññamañña anativattanam visesataḥ icchitabbam eva
translated: “But in the sense of distinction” , etc. Herein, in these five faculties, equality is the non-excess and non-deficiency of one in comparison with another of faith and understanding,🔽and likewise of concentration and energy. For just as it is proper to want a distinction in the case of faith and understanding, which are respectively the dhamma of non-remorse and the dhamma of non-delusion, because of their different functions,

original: yato nesaṃ samadhuratāya appanā sampajjatīti, evaṃ samādhivīriyānaṃ kosajjauddhaccapakkhikānaṃ
analyzed: yatas na esam samadhura tāya appanā sampajjati iti evam samādhi vīriyānam kosajja auddhacca pakkhikānam
translated: since their combined function is the attainment of absorption, so too it is proper to want a distinction in the case of concentration and energy, which are respectively the dhamma of non-distraction and the dhamma of non- slackness,

original: samarasatāya sati aññamaññūpatthambhanato sampayuttadhammānaṃ antadvayapātābhāvena
analyzed: samarasa tāya sati aññamaññu upatthambhanato sampayutta dhammānam anta dvaya pāta abhāvena
translated: because of their different natures, since their combined function is the support of associated states by preventing them from falling into the two extremes of over-exertion and over- slackness,

original: sammadeva appanā ijjhati.
analyzed: sammadeva appanāḥ ijjhati
translated: and thus the attainment of absorption is successful.

original: “Balavasaddho hī”tiādi nidassanavasena vuttaṃ. Tassattho – yo balavatiyā saddhāya
analyzed: hi itiādi nidassana vasena vuttam tassa atthaḥ yaḥ balavatiyā saddhāya
translated: “The man of strong faith” , etc., is said by way of illustration. Its meaning is this:

original: samannāgato avisadañāṇo, so muddhappasanno hoti, na aveccappasanno. Tathā hi so avatthusmiṃ🔽pasīdati seyyathāpi titthiyasāvakā. Kerāṭikapakkhanti sāṭheyyapakkhaṃ bhajati. Saddhāhīnāya🔽paññāya atidhāvanto “deyyavatthupariccāgena vinā cittuppādamattenapi dānamayaṃ puññaṃ🔽hotī”tiādīni parikappeti hetupaṭirūpakehi vañcito. Evaṃbhūto pana sukkhatakkaviluttacitto
analyzed: samannāgataḥ a visada ñāṇo so muddha ppasannaḥ hoti na avecca ppasanno tathā hi so avatthusmim  pasīdati sā iyyathā api titthiya sāvakā kerāṭika pakkhanti sāṭheyya pakkham bhajati saddhā hīnāya  paññāya atidhāvantaḥ deyya vatthu pariccāgena vinā cittuppāda mattena api dāna mayam puññam  hoti itiādīni parikappeti hetu paṭirūpakehi vañcitaḥ evaṃbhūtaḥ pana sukkha takka vilutta citto
translated: He is not a person of clear understanding. He is a person who is confident in the Dhamma, not a person who is not confident in the Dhamma. He is a person who is confident in the Saṅgha, not a person who is not confident in the Saṅgha. He is a person who is confident in the training, not a person who is not confident in the training. He is a person who is confident in virtue, not a person who is not confident in virtue. He is a person who is confident in generosity, not a person who is not confident in generosity. He is a person who is confident in wisdom, not a person who is not confident in wisdom. He is a person who is not a sectarian, not a person who is a sectarian. He is a person who is not a sectarian in his views, not a person who is a sectarian in his views. He is a person who is not a sectarian in his beliefs, not a person who is a sectarian in his beliefs. He is a person who is not a sectarian in his allegiances, not a person who is a sectarian in his allegiances. He is a person who is not a sectarian in his preferences, not a person who is a sectarian in his preferences. He is a person who is not a sectarian in his inclinations, not a person who is a sectarian in his inclinations. He is a person who is not a sectarian in his persuasion, not a person who is a sectarian in his persuasion. He is a person who is not a sectarian in his convictions, not a person who is a sectarian in his convictions. He is a person who is not a sectarian in his aspirations, not a person who is a sectarian in his aspirations. He is a person who is not a sectarian in his faith, not a person who is a sectarian in his faith. He is a person who is not a sectarian in his devotion, not a person who is a sectarian in his devotion. He is a person who is not a sectarian in his homage, not a person who is a sectarian in his homage. He is a person who is not a sectarian in his salutations, not a person who is a sectarian in his salutations. He is a person who is not a sectarian in his obeisances, not a person who is a sectarian in his obeisances. He is a person who is not a sectarian in his practice, not a person who is a sectarian in his practice. He is a person who is not

original: paṇḍitānaṃ vacanaṃ nādiyati, saññattiṃ na gacchati. Tenāha “bhesajjasamuṭṭhito viya🔽rogo atekiccho hotī”ti. Yathā cettha saddhāpaññānaṃ aññamaññaviraho na atthāvaho
analyzed: paṇḍitānam vacanam na ādiyati saññattim na gacchati tena āha bhesajja samuṭṭhitaḥ viya  rogaḥ atekicchaḥ hoti iti yathā ca ittha saddhā paññānam aññamañña virahaḥ na attha āvahaḥ
translated: He is not a person of clear understanding. He is muddle-minded, not fully concentrated. For he has confidence in a non-cause as a cause, like the disciples of the sectarians. He is a partisan of the Kerāṭikas. He associates with the faction of the deceitful. He misrepresents the Dhamma by saying that one can make merit by mere intention without giving anything away, and so on. He is deceived by mere semblance of a reason. Such a person, with his mind turned to the wrong course, does not accept the word of the wise; he does not go by the advice of others. Therefore it is said that he is incurable like a disease arising from a poisoned wound.

original: anatthāvaho ca, evamidhāpi samādhivīriyānaṃ aññamaññaviraho na avikkhepāvaho vikkhepāvaho
analyzed: anattha āvahaḥ ca evam idha api samādhi vīriyānam aññamañña virahaḥ na avikkhepa āvahaḥ vikkhepa āvahaḥ
translated: Just as the absence of faith and understanding is neither beneficial nor harmful, so too the absence of concentration and energy is neither conducive to non-distraction nor to distraction.

original: cāti veditabbaṃ. Kosajjaṃ abhibhavati, tena appanaṃ na pāpuṇātīti adhippāyo. Uddhaccaṃ
analyzed: ca ati veditabbam kosajjam abhibhavati tena appanam na pāpuṇāti iti adhippāyaḥ uddhaccam
translated: should be understood. The intention is that restlessness overcomes him, and so he does not reach absorption.

original: abhibhavatīti etthāpi eseva nayo. Tadubhayanti taṃ saddhāpaññādvayaṃ, samādhivīriyadvayañca.
analyzed: abhibhavati iti ettha api tat ubhayam ti tam saddhā paññā dvayam samādhi vīriya dvayam ca
translated: and it should be understood that he is not strong in concentration. The intention is that he does not reach absorption because he is overcome by idleness. When he is overcome by agitation, he is not strong in concentration. The meaning should be understood in the same way. The two: the two, faith and understanding, and concentration and energy.

original: Samaṃ kātabbanti samarasaṃ kātabbaṃ.
analyzed: samam kātabbanti sama rasam kātabbam
translated: Should be made equal: should be made of equal strength.🔽One whose meditation subject is concentration: one whose meditation subject is serenity.

original: Samādhikammikassāti samathakammaṭṭhānikassa. Evanti evaṃ sante, saddhāya tesaṃ balavabhāve🔽satīti attho. Saddahantoti “pathavī pathavī”ti manasikaraṇamattena kathaṃ jhānuppattīti
analyzed: samādhi kammikassa ati samatha kammaṭṭhānikassa evam ti evam sante saddhāya tesam balava bhāve  satī iti attho saddahanto ti pathavī pathavī iti manasikaraṇa mattena katham jhāna uppatti iti
translated: If it is like this: if it is so that faith is strong in them,🔽then, he should be told: the meaning is, he should be told this.

original: acintetvā “addhā sammāsambuddhena vuttavidhi ijjhissatī”ti saddahanto saddhaṃ janento.
analyzed: a cintetvā addhā sammāsambuddhena vutta vidhi ijjhissati iti saddahantaḥ saddham janentaḥ
translated: Confident: without wondering how he will reach absorption by just giving his attention in this way, “earth, earth,” he should be confident, he should have faith, thinking, “Surely the method stated by the Fully Enlightened One will succeed.”

original: Okappentoti ārammaṇaṃ anupavisitvā viya adhimuccanavasena okappento pakkhandanto.
analyzed: okappentaḥ ti ārammaṇam an upavisitvā viya adhimuccana vasena okappentaḥ pakkhandantaḥ
translated: Looking: looking by way of resolution as if penetrating the object.

original: Ekaggatā balavatī vaṭṭati samādhipadhānattā jhānassa. Ubhinnanti samādhipaññānaṃ,
analyzed: ekagga tā balavatī vaṭṭati samādhi padhāna ttā jhānassa samādhi paññānam
translated: Concentration is strong, and that is right, because concentration is the principal factor in jhāna. The two: concentration and understanding.

original: samādhikammikassa samādhino adhimattatāpi icchitabbāti āha “samatāyapī”ti, samabhāvenāpīti
analyzed: samādhi kammikassa samādhinaḥ adhimatta tā api icchitabbā ati āha samatāya api iti sama bhāvena api iti
translated: The meaning is: in the state of balance too.🔽Absorption here is the absorption intended as the fourth jhāna.

original: attho. Appanāti idhādhippetaappanā. Tathā hi “hotiyevā”ti sāsaṅkaṃ vadati, lokuttarappanā
analyzed: atthaḥ appanā ti idha adhippeta appanā tathā hi hotiyā iva ati sa āsaṅkam vadati lokuttara ppanā
translated: For he says “there is” with some doubt,🔽but the supramundane absorption is required in the state of balance only, according to:

original: pana tesaṃ samabhāveneva icchitā. Yathāha – “samathavipassanaṃ yuganaddhaṃ bhāvetī”ti.
analyzed: pana tesam sama bhāvena iva icchitā yathā āha samatha vipassanam yuga naddham bhāveti iti
translated: “He develops serenity and insight coupled together” .

original: Yadi visesato saddhāpaññānaṃ, samādhivīriyānañca samatā icchitā, kathaṃ satīti āha
analyzed: yadi visesato saddhā paññānam samādhi vīriyānam ca sama tā icchitā katham satī iti āha
translated: If the balance of faith and understanding and of concentration and energy is required in preference, why does he say🔽“but mindfulness is strong in all cases”?

original: “sati pana sabbattha balavatī vaṭṭatī”ti. Sabbatthāti līnuddhaccapakkhesu pañcasu
analyzed: sati pana sabbattha balavatī vaṭṭati iti sabbattha ati līn uddhacca pakkhesu pañcasu
translated: In all cases means in the five faculties beginning with faith.

original: indriyesu. Uddhaccapakkhiye gaṇhanto “saddhāvīriyapaññāna”nti āha. Aññathāpīti ca
analyzed: indriyesu uddhacca pakkhiye gaṇhanto saddhā vīriya paññānan ti āha aññathā api iti ca
translated: Taking the case of the factors on the side of agitation, he says “faith, energy, and understanding.”🔽But they can be taken in another way too.

original: gahetabbā siyā. Tathā hi “kosajjapakkhena samādhinā” icceva vuttaṃ, na “passaddhisamādhiupekkhāhī”ti.
analyzed: gahetabbā siyā tathā hi kosajja pakkhena samādhinā icca eva vuttam na passaddhi samādhi upekkhāhi iti
translated: For thus it is said: “with concentration on the side of idleness” , not “with tranquillity, concentration, and equanimity.”

original: Sā sati. Sabbesu rājakammesu niyutto sabbakammiko. Tena kāraṇena sabbattha icchitabbatthena.
analyzed: sā sati sabbesu rāja kammesu niyuttaḥ sabba kammikaḥ tena kāraṇena sabbattha icchitabbatthena
translated: That is mindfulness. He is appointed to all royal duties, he is a doer of all duties. For that reason he is to be desired everywhere.

original: Āha aṭṭhakathāyaṃ. Sabbattha niyuttā sabbatthikā, sabbena vā līnuddhaccapakkhiyena
analyzed: āha aṭṭhakathā ayam sabbattha niyuttā sabbatthikā sabbena vā līn uddhacca pakkhiyena
translated: The commentary says, “Appointed everywhere, he is everywhere useful. Or he is to be sought everywhere by means of the factors of complete enlightement, which are not partial to either slackness or agitation.

original: bojjhaṅgaggahaṇena atthetabbā sabbatthiyā, sabbatthiyāva sabbatthikā. Cittanti kusalacittaṃ.
analyzed: bojjhaṅga ggahaṇena atthetabbā sabbatthiyā sabbatthiyā ava sabbatthikā cittam ti kusala cittam
translated: He is useful everywhere, useful everywhere only, by means of the useful everywhere. Mind is profitable consciousness.

original: Tassa hi sati paṭisaraṇaṃ parāyaṇaṃ appattassa pattiyā anadhigatassa adhigamāya.
analyzed: tassa hi sati paṭisaraṇam parāyaṇam appattassa pattiyā anadhigatassa adhigamāya
translated: For that is the refuge and the support of mindfulness in attaining what has not been attained and in reaching what has not been reached.

original: Tenāha “ārakkhapaccupaṭṭhānā”tiādi.🔽63. Cittekaggatānimittassāti cittekaggatāya nimittassa, cittekaggatāsaṅkhātassa ca
analyzed: tena āha ārakkha paccupaṭṭhāna atiādi  citta ekagga tā nimittassa ati citta ekagga tāya nimittassa citta ekagga tā saṅkhātassa ca
translated: That is why it is said that it is “established in protection” and so on.🔽Sign of unification of cognizance: of the sign of unification of cognizance, and of the sign called unification of cognizance.

original: nimittassa. Cittassa hi samāhitākāraṃ sallakkhetvā samathanimittaṃ rakkhantoyeva
analyzed: nimittassa cittassa hi samāhita ākāram sat lakkhetvā samatha nimittam rakkhantaḥ yeva
translated: For by observing the state of concentration in the mind and by guarding the sign of serenity,🔽he guards the sign of the kasiṇa. That is why it is said “the sign of the earth kasiṇa, and so on.” The words “and so on”

original: kasiṇanimittaṃ rakkhati. Tasmā pathavīkasiṇādikassāti ādi-saddena na kevalaṃ paṭibhāganimittasseva,
analyzed: kasiṇa nimittam rakkhati tasmā pathavī kasiṇa ādikassa āti ādi saddena na kevalam paṭibhāga nimittassa iva
translated: include not only the counterpart sign,

original: atha kho samathanimittassāpi gahaṇaṃ daṭṭhabbaṃ. Tanti rakkhaṇakosallaṃ. Idha appanākosallakathāyaṃ
analyzed: atha kho samatha nimittassa api gahaṇam daṭṭhabbam tanti rakkhaṇa kosallam idha appanā kosalla kathāyam
translated: But the apprehending of the sign of serenity should be understood here too. T means skill in guarding. Here, in the discussion of skill in absorption,

original: “nimittakosalla”nti adhippetaṃ, karaṇabhāvanākosallānaṃ pageva siddhattāti adhippāyo.🔽64. Atisithilavīriyatādīhīti ādi-saddena pamodanasaṃvejanavipariyāye saṅgaṇhāti.
analyzed: nimitta kosallanti adhippetam karaṇa bhāvanā kosallānam pagā iva adhippāyaḥ  ati sithila vīriya tā ādīhi iti ādi saddena pamodana saṃvejana vipariyāye saṅgaṇhāti
translated: “skill in the sign” is intended, since skill in the function of development is already established.🔽“With excessive slackness, etc.”: the word “etc.” includes the opposites of joy and urgency.

original: Līnanti saṅkucitaṃ kosajjapakkhapatitaṃ. Cittanti bhāvanācittaṃ. Dhammavicayasambojjhaṅgādayo
analyzed: līnam ti saṅkucitam kosajja pakkha patitam cittam ti bhāvanā cittam dhammavicaya sambojjhaṅga ādayaḥ
translated: “Dull” means contracted, fallen into the side of idleness. “Mind” means the mind of development. The enlightenment factors of investigation of mental objects, etc.,

original: bhāvetīti ettha “tayo”ti padaṃ ānetvā sambandhitabbaṃ. Yathā pana te bhāvetabbā,
analyzed: bhāveti iti ettha tayā iti padam ānetvā sambandhitabbam yathā pana te bhāvetabbā
translated: are “developed” here. The word “three” should be brought in and the construction completed. But how they are to be developed

original: taṃ sayameva vakkhati.🔽Parittanti appakaṃ. Ujjāletukāmoti padīpetukāmo. Udakavātaṃ dadeyyāti udakamissaṃ
analyzed: tam sayam eva vakkhati  parittam ti appakam ujjāletu kāmaḥ iti padīpetu kāmaḥ udaka vātam dadeyyāti udaka missam
translated: he will explain of his own accord.

original: vātaṃ upaneyya. Akāloti nakālo, ayuttakālo vā. Satiādidhammasāmaggisaṅkhātāya bodhiyā
analyzed: vātam upaneyya akālo ti na kālaḥ ayutta kālaḥ vā sati ādi dhamma sāmaggi saṅkhātāya bodhiyā
translated: “Slight”: small. “To brighten”: to illuminate. “Should fan it with water” means should apply a breeze mixed with water. “Not the time” means not the occasion, not the proper occasion. “Enlightenment” is the concurrence of the states beginning with mindfulness.

original: bujjhati etāyāti katvā, taṃsamaṅgino vā bujjhatīti bodhino yogino aṅganti bojjhaṅgo,
analyzed: bujjhati katvā taṃsamaṅginaḥ vā bujjhati iti bodhinaḥ yoginaḥ aṅganti bojjhaṅgaḥ
translated: The factor of that is a factor of enlightenment .

original: pasattho, sundaro vā bojjhaṅgo sambojjhaṅgo. Kāyacittadarathavūpasamalakkhaṇā passaddhiyeva🔽sambojjhaṅgo passaddhisambojjhaṅgo, tassa passaddhisambojjhaṅgassa. Samādhisambojjhaṅgādīsupi
analyzed: pasattho sundaraḥ vā bojjhaṅgo sambojjhaṅgo kāya citta daratha vūpasama lakkhaṇā passaddhiyā iva  sambojjhaṅgo passaddhi sambojjhaṅgo tassa passaddhi sambojjhaṅgassa samādhi sambojjhaṅga ādīsu pi
translated: The enlightenment factor of serenity is serenity itself, which has the characteristic of quieting the disturbance of body and mind.🔽The enlightenment factor of concentration is concentration itself, which has the characteristic of steadying the mind on a single object.

original: eseva nayo. Ayaṃ pana viseso – samādhissa tāva padatthalakkhaṇāni heṭṭhā āgatāneva.
analyzed: esa iva nayaḥ ayam pana visesaḥ samādhissa tāva padattha lakkhaṇāni heṭṭhā āgatāna eva
translated: The enlightenment factor of equanimity is equanimity itself, which has the characteristic of looking on with impartiality at things that should be looked on with equanimity.

original: Upapattito ikkhatīti upekkhā. Sā panāyaṃ atthato tatramajjhattupekkhāva idha bojjhaṅgupekkhā🔽veditabbā. Dusamuṭṭhāpayanti samuṭṭhāpetuṃ uppādetuṃ asakkuṇeyyaṃ. Dhammānaṃ, dhammesu
analyzed: upapattito ikkhati iti upekkhā sā pana ayam atthato idha bojjhaṅgu pekkhā  veditabbā du samuṭṭhāpayanti samuṭṭhāpetum uppādetum a sakkuṇeyyam dhammānam dhammesu
translated: The enlightenment factor of mindfulness is mindfulness itself, which has the characteristic of remembering the thing to be known as already known.

original: vā vicayo dhammavicayo, paññāti attho. Vīrassa bhāvo, kammaṃ vā, vidhinā vā īretabbaṃ
analyzed: vā vicayaḥ dhamma vicayo paññā ati atthaḥ vīrassa bhāvaḥ kammam vā vidhinā vā īretabbam
translated: The enlightenment factor of investigation of states is investigation of states itself, which has the characteristic of penetrating the specific and general characteristics of states.🔽The enlightenment factor of energy is energy itself, which has the characteristic of exerting to put forth the right endeavour.

original: pavattetabbanti vīriyaṃ, ussāho. Pīṇeti kāyaṃ, cittaṃ ca santappetīti pīti.
analyzed: pavattetabbanti vīriyam ussāhaḥ pīṇeti kāyam cittam ca santappeti iti pīti
translated: The enlightenment factor of rapture is rapture itself, which has the characteristic of gladdening body and mind.

original: Yaṃ yaṃ sakaṃ yathāsakaṃ, attano attanoti attho. Āhāravasenāti paccayavasena. Bhāvanāti
analyzed: yam yam sakam yathāsakam attanaḥ attanaḥ iti atthaḥ āhāra vasena ati paccaya vasena bhāvanā ati
translated: Each one’s own, each one’s respective, is the meaning of yathāsakaṃ . By way of nutriment: by way of condition. Development:

original: uppādanā, vaḍḍhanā ca. Kusalākusalāti kosallasambhūtaṭṭhena kusalā, tappaṭipakkhato
analyzed: uppādanā vaḍḍhanā ca kusala akusalā ati kosalla sambhūta ṭṭhena kusalā tad paṭipakkhato
translated: production and increase. Wholesome and unwholesome: they are wholesome in the sense of being originated by skillfulness ;🔽they are unwholesome in the sense of being the opposite of that. Those that are unwholesome are reprehensible ;

original: akusalā. Ye akusalā, te sāvajjā. Ye kusalā, te anavajjā. Akusalā hīnā, itare paṇītā.
analyzed: akusalāḥ ye akusalā te sāvajjāḥ ye kusalā te anavajjāḥ akusalāḥ hīnāḥ itare paṇītā
translated: those that are wholesome are blameless . The unwholesome are inferior ; the others are superior.

original: Kusalāpi vā hīnehi chandādīhi āraddhā hīnā, itare paṇītā. Kaṇhāti kāḷakā cittassa🔽apabhassarabhāvakaraṇā, sukkāti odātā cittassa pabhassarabhāvakaraṇā. Kaṇhābhijātihetuto
analyzed: vā hīnehi chanda ādīhi āraddhāḥ hīnāḥ itare paṇītā cittassa  a pabhassara bhāva karaṇā cittassa pabhassara bhāva karaṇā kaṇha abhijāti hetuto
translated: Or the wholesome that are begun with weak desire, etc., are inferior; the others are superior. Dark: black, causing the manifestation of what is black in the mind;🔽bright: white, causing the manifestation of what is white in the mind. Or they are dark because of the cause of the dark class of beings, bright because of the cause of the bright class of beings. They are the opposites of each other.

original: vā kaṇhā, sukkābhijātihetuto sukkā. Te eva sappaṭibhāgā. Kaṇhā hi ujuvipaccanīkatāya
analyzed: vā kaṇhā sukka abhijāti hetuto sukkā te eva sa paṭibhāgā kaṇhā hi uju vipaccanīka tāya
translated: For the dark is the opposite of the bright because it is the direct opposite.

original: sukkehi sappaṭibhāgā. Tathā sukkāpi itarehi. Atha vā kaṇhā ca sukkā ca sappaṭibhāgā
analyzed: sukkehi sappaṭibhāgā tathā sukkā api itarehi atha vā kaṇhā ca sukkā ca sappaṭibhāgā
translated: And so the bright is the opposite of the others. Or alternatively, they are dark and bright and also opposites;

original: ca kaṇhasukkasappaṭibhāgā. Sukhā hi vedanā dukkhāya vedanāya sappaṭibhāgā, dukkhā
analyzed: ca kaṇha sukka sappaṭibhāgā sukhā hi vedanā dukkhāya vedanāya sappaṭibhāgā dukkhā
translated: thus they are dark-bright-opposites. For pleasant feeling is the opposite of painful feeling, and painful feeling is the opposite of pleasant feeling.

original: ca vedanā sukhāya sappaṭibhāgāti. Anuppannassāti anibbattassa. Uppādāyāti uppādanatthāya.
analyzed: ca vedanā sukhāya sappaṭibhāgā ati anuppannassa ati anibbattassa uppādāya ati uppādana tthāya
translated: and feeling is pleasant and has an individual essence. As to “unrisen”: not arisen. “For the sake of causing to arise”: for the purpose of causing to arise.

original: Uppannassāti nibbattassa. Bhiyyobhāvāyāti punappunabhāvāya. Vepullāyāti vipulabhāvāya.
analyzed: uppannassa ati nibbattassa bhiyyobhāvāya ati punappunabhāvāya vepullāya ati vipula bhāvāya
translated: As to “risen”: arisen. “For the sake of increase”: for the purpose of repeated occurrence. “For the sake of abundance”: for the purpose of abundant occurrence.

original: Bhāvanāyāti vaḍḍhiyā. Pāripūriyāti paripūraṇatthāya.
analyzed: bhāvanāya ati vaḍḍhiyā pāripūriyā ati paripūraṇa atthāya
translated: “For the sake of development”: for the purpose of growth. “For the sake of fulfilment”: for the purpose of fulfilment.

original: Tatthāti “atthi bhikkhave”tiādinā dassitapāṭhe. Sabhāvasāmaññalakkhaṇapaṭivedhavasenāti🔽ekajjhaṃ katvā gahaṇe anavajjasukhavipākādikassa visuṃ visuṃ pana phusanādikassa🔽sabhāvalakkhaṇassa, aniccādikassa sāmaññalakkhaṇassa ca paṭivijjhanavasena. Pavattamanasikāroti
analyzed: tattha ati atthi bhikkhave iti ādinā dassita pāṭhe sabhāva sāmañña lakkhaṇa paṭivedha vasena ati  ekajjham katvā gahaṇe anavajja sukha vipāka ādikassa visum visum pana phusana ādikassa  sabhāva lakkhaṇassa anicca ādikassa sāmañña lakkhaṇassa ca paṭivijjhana vasena pavatta manasikāraḥ ti
translated: “Therein”: in the passage beginning, “Bhikkhus, there are these five aggregates” . “By the penetration of the individual essences and of the general characteristics”:🔽by the penetration of the individual essences of the various things such as the blameless, the profitable, etc., and of the general characteristics such as impermanence, etc.

original: kusalādīnaṃ taṃtaṃsabhāvalakkhaṇādikassa yāthāvato avabujjhanavasena uppannajavanacittuppādo.
analyzed: kusala ādīnam taṃ taṃsa bhāva lakkhaṇa ādikassa yāthāvataḥ avabujjhana vasena uppanna javana cittuppādaḥ
translated: “The attention given to it”: the occurrence of the javanas of consciousness that arise by the right understanding of the individual essences, etc., of the profitable, etc.

original: So hi aviparītamanasikāratāya “yonisomanasikāro”ti vutto. Tadābhogatāya āvajjanāpi
analyzed: saḥ hi aviparīta manasikāra tāya yoniso manasikāraḥ ti vuttaḥ tad ābhoga tāya
translated: For this is called “right reflection” because it is non-delusion, and it is called “attention” because it is the bringing of the object into the focus of the mind.🔽“The adverting” is the first adverting that occurs in the mind-door process.

original: taggatikāva. Ruppanalakkhaṇādikampi idha sāmaññalakkhaṇeneva saṅgahitanti daṭṭhabbaṃ.
analyzed: taggatikā ava ruppana lakkhaṇa ādikam pi idha sāmañña lakkhaṇena iva saṅgahitan ti daṭṭhabbam
translated: and it is only the general characteristic that is intended here.

original: Kusalakiriyāya ādiārambhavasena pavattavīriyaṃ dhitisabhāvatāya “dhātū”ti vuttanti
analyzed: kusala kiriyāya ādi ārambha vasena pavatta vīriyam dhiti sabhāva tāya dhātu iti vuttam ti
translated: The energy that occurs as the beginning of profitable action is called a “root” because it has the nature of resolution.

original: āha “ārambhadhātūti paṭhamavīriyaṃ vuccatī”ti. Laddhāsevanaṃ vīriyaṃ balappattaṃ🔽hutvā paṭipakkhaṃ vidhamatīti āha “kosajjato nikkhantattā tato balavatara”nti. Adhimattādhimattatarānaṃ
analyzed: āha ārambha dhātu uti paṭhama vīriyam vuccati iti laddha āsevanam vīriyam bala ppattam  hutvā paṭipakkham vidhamati iti āha kosajjataḥ nikkhanta ttā tatas balavataranti
translated: So it is said: “The first energy is called the root of energy because it is the beginning of profitable action.”🔽Energy that is developed by practice becomes strong.

original: paṭipakkhadhammānaṃ vidhamanasamatthaṃ paṭupaṭutarādibhāvappattaṃ hotīti vuttaṃ “paraṃ
analyzed: paṭipakkha dhammānam vidhamana samattham paṭu paṭutara ādi bhāva ppattam hoti iti vuttam param
translated: It overcomes its opposite, which is laziness, and so it is said: “It is stronger than the first because it has emerged from laziness.”

original: paraṃ ṭhānaṃ akkamanato tatopi balavatara”nti. Tiṭṭhati pavattati etthāti ṭhāniyā,
analyzed: param ṭhānam akkamanataḥ tatas pi balavataranti tiṭṭhati pavattati ettha ati ṭhāniyā
translated: It becomes stronger and stronger as it reaches the highest and highest stage in its ability to overcome the opposing states, which are the hindrances.🔽So it is said: “It is stronger than the second because it reaches a higher and higher stage.”🔽The “basis” is that in which it stands, that by which it stands, that on which it is dependent.

original: pītisambojjhaṅgassa ṭhāniyā pītisambojjhaṅgaṭṭhāniyā. Ṭhātabbo vā ṭhāniyo, pītisambojjhaṅgo
analyzed: pīti sambojjhaṅgassa ṭhāniyā pīti sambojjhaṅga ṭhāniyā ṭhātabbaḥ vā ṭhāniyaḥ pīti sambojjhaṅgo
translated: The “basis of the enlightenment factor of rapture” is the rapture itself or the things that make for the arising of the enlightenment factor of rapture.

original: ṭhāniyo etesūti pītisambojjhaṅgaṭṭhāniyā, aparāparaṃ vattamānā pītisambojjhaṅgasampayuttā
analyzed: etesu iti pīti sambojjhaṅga ṭṭhāniyā apara aparam vattamānā pīti sambojjhaṅga sampayuttā
translated: The words “the pīti factor of complete awakening has a footing in these” mean that the states associated with the pīti factor of complete awakening have a footing in these states.

original: dhammā. Yasmā pana tesu pītiyeva pītisambojjhaṅgassa visesakāraṇaṃ, tasmā vuttaṃ🔽“pītiyā eva etaṃ nāma”nti. Uppādakamanasikāroti yathā manasi karoto anuppanno pītisambojjhaṅgo
analyzed: dhammā yasmā pana tesu pītiyā iva pīti sambojjhaṅgassa visesa kāraṇam tasmā vuttam  pītiyāḥ eva etam nāmanti uppādaka manasikāraḥ ti yathā manasi karotaḥ anuppannaḥ pīti sambojjhaṅgaḥ
translated: But since it is only pīti that is the specific cause of the pīti factor of complete awakening, it is said:🔽“It is called pīti only because of pīti.”

original: uppajjati, uppanno ca vaḍḍhati, tathā pavattamanasikāro.🔽Paripucchakatāti pariyogāhetvā pucchakabhāvo. Pañcapi hi nikāye uggahetvā ācariye
analyzed: uppajjati uppannaḥ ca vaḍḍhati tathā pavatta manasikāraḥ  paripucchaka tā ati pariyogāhetvā pucchaka bhāvaḥ hi nikāye uggahetvā ācariye
translated: The attention that produces it: the attention occurring in such wise that the unarisen pīti factor of complete awakening arises and the arisen pīti factor of complete awakening comes to fulfilment by development.🔽The questioning: the state of one who questions after having studied the five Nikāyas and after having attended on a teacher.

original: pariyupāsitvā tassa tassa atthaṃ paripucchantassa, te vā saha aṭṭhakathāya pariyogāhetvā
analyzed: pariyupāsitvā tassa tassa attham paripucchantassa te vā saha aṭṭhakathāya pariyogāhetvā
translated: Or the questioning of one who, after having studied the five Nikāyas together with the commentaries,

original: yaṃ yaṃ tattha gaṇṭhiṭṭhānaṃ, taṃ taṃ “idaṃ, bhante, kathaṃ, imassa ko attho”ti pucchantassa
analyzed: yam yam tattha gaṇṭhi ṭṭhānam tam tam idam bhante katham imassa kaḥ atthaḥ ti pucchantassa
translated: questions about the difficult passages thus, “What is the meaning of this, venerable sir?”🔽The pīti factor of complete awakening arises in one who questions in this way.

original: dhammavicayasambojjhaṅgo uppajjatīti. Vatthuvisadakiriyā indriyasamattapaṭipādanā
analyzed: dhammavicaya sambojjhaṅgaḥ uppajjati iti vatthu visada kiriyā indriya samatta paṭipādanā
translated: The clearing up of the object, the bringing about of balance in the faculties,

original: saṅkhepato, vitthārato ca pakāsitā eva. Tattha pana samādhisaṃvattaniyabhāvena āgatā,🔽idha paññāsaṃvattaniyabhāvena. Yadaggena hi samādhisaṃvattanikā, tadaggena paññāsaṃvattanikā
analyzed: saṅkhepataḥ vitthārato ca pakāsitā eva tattha pana samādhi saṃvattaniya bhāvena āgatā  idha paññā saṃvattaniya bhāvena yad aggena hi samādhi saṃvattanikā tad aggena paññā saṃvattanikā
translated: and they have been explained in brief and detail. Herein, they are given as conducive to concentration,🔽but there they are given as conducive to understanding. For what is conducive to concentration in one instance is conducive to understanding in another.

original: samādhissa ñāṇapaccupaṭṭhānato. “Samāhito yathābhūtaṃ pajānātī”ti vuttaṃ. Duppaññapuggalaparivajjanā🔽nāma duppaññānaṃ mandabuddhīnaṃ bhattanikkhittakākamaṃsanikkhittasunakhasadisānaṃ
analyzed: samādhissa ñāṇa paccupaṭṭhānato samāhitaḥ yathābhūtam pajānāti iti vuttam duppañña puggala parivajjanā  nāma duppaññānam manda buddhīnam bhatta nikkhitta kākamaṃsa nikkhitta sunakha sadisānam
translated: Because concentration is the establishment of knowledge, and it is said, “He who is concentrated knows and sees correctly” .🔽Avoiding people without understanding: avoiding from afar people who are without understanding, who are dull, like a dog lying by a filled trough,🔽who are stupid.

original: momūhapuggalānaṃ dūrato pariccajanā. Paññavantapuggalasevanā nāma paññāya katādhikārānaṃ
analyzed: momūha puggalānam dūratas pariccajanā paññavanta puggala sevanā nāma paññāya kata adhikārānam
translated: Keeping company with people who have understanding: from time to time approaching people who have understanding, who are skilled,

original: saccapaṭiccasamuppādādīsu kusalānaṃ ariyānaṃ, vipassanākammikānaṃ vā mahāpaññānaṃ
analyzed: sacca paṭiccasamuppāda ādīsu kusalānam ariyānam vipassanā kammikānam vā mahāpaññānam
translated: who are noble individuals, or meditators who have great understanding, in the truths, dependent origination, and so on.

original: kālena kālaṃ upasaṅkamanaṃ. Gambhīrañāṇacariyapaccavekkhaṇāti gambhīrañāṇehi caritabbānaṃ
analyzed: kālena kālam upasaṅkamanam gambhīra ñāṇa cariya paccavekkhaṇā ati gambhīra ñāṇehi caritabbānaṃ
translated: Reviewing the profundity of the way of knowledge: reviewing the profundity of the way of knowledge that is to be practised by one who has understanding.

original: khandhāyatanadhātādīnaṃ, saccapaccayākārādidīpanānaṃ vā suññatāpaṭisaṃyuttānaṃ suttantānaṃ
analyzed: khandha āyatana dhāta ādīnam sacca paccaya ākāra ādi dīpanānam vā suñña tā paṭisaṃyuttānam suttantānam
translated: Or else, “the void” is the voidness of the aggregates, sense bases, elements, etc., or else the voidness of the aspects of the truths, etc., and the voidness-related discourses are those that illuminate these.

original: paccavekkhaṇā. Tadadhimuttatāti paññādhimuttatā, paññāya ninnapoṇapabbhāratāti attho.🔽Apāyādīti ādi-saddena jātiādiṃ atīte vaṭṭamūlakaṃ dukkhaṃ, anāgate vaṭṭamūlakaṃ dukkhaṃ,
analyzed: paccavekkhaṇā tad adhimutta tā ati paññā adhimutta tā paññāya ninna poṇa pabbhāra tā ti attho  apāya ādi iti ādi saddena jāti ādim atīte vaṭṭamūlakam dukkham anāgate vaṭṭamūlakam dukkham
translated: “Inclined to wisdom”: “inclined to wisdom” means “inclined to the wisdom of the four noble truths.”

original: paccuppanne āhārapariyeṭṭhimūlakañca dukkhaṃ saṅgaṇhāti. Vīriyāyattassa lokiyalokuttaravisesassa🔽adhigamo eva ānisaṃso, tassa dassanasīlatā vīriyāyatta…pe… dassitā. Sapubbabhāgo
analyzed: paccuppanne āhāra pariyeṭṭhi mūlakam ca dukkham saṅgaṇhāti vīriya āyattassa lokiya lokuttara visesassa  adhigamaḥ eva ānisaṃsaḥ tassa dassana sīla tā vīriya āyatta pe dassi tā sa pubbabhāgaḥ
translated: “The lower realms, etc.”: the word “etc.” includes birth, etc., the suffering rooted in the past round, the suffering rooted in the future round, and the suffering rooted in the present round of seeking nutriment.🔽The benefit is the attainment of the distinction of the mundane and supramundane, which is dependent on energy.🔽The virtue of the path is shown by the words “the path to be travelled, the way to be followed, the practice to be undertaken.”

original: nibbānagāmimaggo gamanavīthi gantabbā paṭipajjitabbā paṭipadāti katvā. Dāyakānaṃ
analyzed: nibbāna gāmi maggaḥ gamana vīthi gantabbā paṭipajjitabbā paṭipadā ati katvā dāyakānam
translated: By making the donors’ gift fruitful, by honouring the alms.

original: mahapphalabhāvakaraṇena piṇḍāpacāyanatāti paccayadāyakānaṃ attani kārassa attano🔽sammāpaṭipattiyā mahapphalakārabhāvassa karaṇena piṇḍassa bhikkhāya paṭipūjanā. Itarathāti
analyzed: mahat phala bhāva karaṇena piṇḍa apacāyana tā ati paccaya dāyakānam attani kārassa attano 🔽sammā paṭipattiyāḥ mahapphalakāra bhāvassa karaṇena piṇḍassa bhikkhāya paṭipūjanā itarathā ati
translated: By making the donors’ gift fruitful by one’s own right practice, by honouring the alms, the food given in alms.🔽Otherwise,

original: āmisapūjāya. Kusītapuggalaparivajjanatāti alasānaṃ bhāvanāya nāmamattampi ajānantānaṃ
analyzed: āmisa pūjāya alasānam bhāvanāya a mattam pi a jānantānam
translated: and material offerings. 10. Avoidance of lazy people: avoidance of people who are lazy, who do not know the name of a meditation subject,

original: kāyadaḷhībahulānaṃ yāvadatthaṃ bhuñjitvā seyyasukhādianuyuñjanakānaṃ tiracchānakathikānaṃ
analyzed: kāya daḷhī bahulānam yāvadattham bhuñjitvā seyya sukha ādi anuyuñjanakānam tiracchāna kathikānam
translated: who are full of bodily affliction, who eat as much as they can to satisfy greed for food and then indulge in the pleasures of sleep, lying, and so on, who talk like animals,

original: puggalānaṃ dūrato pariccajanā. Āraddhavīriyapuggalasevanatāti “divasaṃ caṅkamena
analyzed: puggalānam dūratas pariccajanā āraddha vīriya puggala sevana tā ati divasam caṅkamena
translated: and who live far away from the monastery. 11. Attendance on people of right action: attendance from time to time on people who have begun to make effort by undertaking meditation, who are resolute,

original: nisajjāyā”tiādinā bhāvanārambhavasena āraddhavīriyānaṃ daḷhaparakkamānaṃ puggalānaṃ
analyzed: nisajja āyāti ādinā bhāvanā ārambha vasena āraddha vīriyānam daḷha parakkamānam puggalānam
translated: who are not lazy, who are not satisfied with merely nominal attainment, who are not full of bodily affliction, who do not eat as much as they can to satisfy greed for food, who do not indulge in the pleasures of sleep, lying, and so on, who do not talk like animals,

original: kālena kālaṃ upasaṅkamanā. Sammappadhānapaccavekkhaṇatāti catubbidhasammappadhānānubhāvassa🔽paccavekkhaṇatā. Tadadhimuttatāti tasmiṃ vīriyasambojjhaṅge adhimutti sabbiriyāpathesu
analyzed: kālena kālam upasaṅkamanā sammappadhāna paccavekkhaṇa tā ati catubbidha sammappadhāna anubhāvassa  paccavekkhaṇa tā tad adhimutta tā ati tasmin vīriya sambojjhaṅge adhimutti sa viriyāpathesu
translated: and who live near the monastery. 12. Review of right endeavour: reviewing the influence of the four right endeavours. 13. Resolution upon that: resolution upon the enlightenment factor of energy in all postures.

original: ninnapoṇapabbhāratā. Ettha ca thinamiddhavinodanakusītapuggalaparivajjanaāraddhavīriyapuggalasevanatadadhimuttatā
analyzed: ettha ca thinam iddha vinodana kusīta puggala parivajjana āraddha vīriya puggala sevana tad adhimutta tā
translated: Herein, the avoidance of sloth-and-torpor, the avoidance of lazy people, the attendance on energetic people, and the resolution upon energy are common to all the kinds of right endeavour.

original: paṭipakkhavidhamanapaccayūpasaṃhāravasena, apāyādibhayapaccavekkhaṇādayo samuttejanavasena🔽vīriyasambojjhaṅgassa uppādakā daṭṭhabbā.🔽Buddhādīsu pasādasinehābhāvena thusakharahadayā lūkhapuggalā, tabbipariyāyena siniddhapuggalā
analyzed: paṭipakkha vidhamana paccayu upasaṃhāra vasena apāya ādi bhaya paccavekkhaṇa ādayo samuttejana vasena  vīriya sambojjhaṅgassa uppādakā daṭṭhabbā  buddha ādīsu pasāda sineha abhāvena thusa khara hadayā lūkha puggalā tad vipariyāyena siniddha puggalā
translated: and the reviewing of the dangers in the states of loss, etc., should be understood as arousing.🔽The person who is rough should be understood as one whose heart is as hard as a grain of wheat, lacking in confidence in the Buddha, etc., and the person who is refined as the opposite.

original: veditabbā. Buddhādīnaṃ guṇaparidīpanā sampasādanīyasuttādayo pasādanīyasuttantā.🔽Imehi ākārehīti yathāvuttehi kusalādīnaṃ sabhāvasāmaññalakkhaṇapaṭivijjhanādiākārehi
analyzed: veditabbā buddha ādīnam guṇa paridīpanā sampasādanīya sutta ādayaḥ pasādanīya suttantā  imehi ākārehi iti yathā vuttehi kusala ādīnam sabhāva sāmañña lakkhaṇa paṭivijjhana ādi ākārehi
translated: The inspiring discourses are the discourses that reveal the special qualities of the Buddha, etc., such as the Sampasādanīya Sutta .🔽By these means: by the means consisting in the penetration of the general characteristics of the wholesome, etc., as actualities, and by the means consisting in the questioning of the teachers, etc.

original: ceva paripucchakatādiākārehi ca. Ete dhammeti ete kusalādīsu yonisomanasikārādike
analyzed: ca iva paripucchaka tā ādi ākārehi ca ete dhammā iti ete kusala ādīsu yoni so manasikāra ādike
translated: These ideas: the ideas of the right reflection, etc.,

original: ceva dhammatthaññutādike ca.🔽65. Accāraddhavīriyatādīhīti ativiya paggahitavīriyatādīhi. Ādi-saddena saṃvejanapamodanādiṃ
analyzed: ca iva dhamma tthaññu tā ādike ca  acca āraddha vīriya tā ādīhi iti ādi saddena saṃvejana pamodana ādim
translated: and the ideas of the knowledge of the True Idea, etc.🔽By those who are over-strenuous, etc.: by those who are over-strenuous in energy, etc. The word “etc.” includes those who are over-zealous, over-confident, and over-hasty.

original: saṅgaṇhāti. Uddhatanti samādhiādīnaṃ mandatāya avūpasantaṃ. Duvūpasamayanti vūpasametuṃ
analyzed: saṅgaṇhāti samādhi ādīnam manda tāya a vūpasantam vūpasametum
translated: Agitated: unquiet owing to slackness in concentration, etc. Difficult to tend: difficult to look after, difficult to tend.

original: samādhātuṃ asakkuṇeyyaṃ.🔽Taṃ ākāraṃ sallakkhetvāti yenākārena assa yogino passaddhi samādhi upekkhāti ime🔽passaddhiādayo dhammā pubbe yathārahaṃ tasmiṃ tasmiṃ kāle uppannapubbā, taṃ cittataṃsampayuttadhammānaṃ
analyzed: samādhātum a sakkuṇeyyam  tam ākāram sallakkhetvā ati yena ākārena assa yogino passaddhi samādhi upekkhāti ime  passaddhi ādayaḥ dhammā pubbe yathāraham tasmim tasmim kāle uppanna pubbā tam citta tad sampayutta dhammānam
translated: and he is unable to attain it.

original: passaddhākāraṃ, samāhitākāraṃ, ajjhupekkhitākārañca upalakkhetvā upadhāretvā. Tīsupi🔽padesūti “atthi, bhikkhave, kāyappassaddhī”tiādinā āgatesu tīsupi vākyesu, tehi vā
analyzed: passaddha ākāram samāhita ākāram ajjhupekkhita ākāram ca upalakkhetvā upadhāretvā tīsupi  padesu uti atthi bhikkhave kāya ppassaddhi iti ādinā āgatesu tīsu pi vākyesu tehi vā
translated: Having defined the mode: having defined, having noticed, the mode in which the states of tranquillity, concentration, and equanimity arose in him previously on appropriate occasions. The mode of those states is the mode of the states associated with the consciousness.

original: pakāsitesu tīsu dhammakoṭṭhāsesu. Yathāsamāhitākāraṃ sallakkhetvā gayhamāno samatho
analyzed: pakāsitesu tīsu dhammakoṭṭhāsesu yathā samāhita ākāram sallakkhetvā gayhamāno samathaḥ
translated: Having defined the mode of tranquillity, the mode of concentration, and the mode of equanimity. In the three passages: in the three passages stated thus: “There is, bhikkhus, tranquillity of body” , etc., or in the three instances of dhammas stated in those three passages.🔽Having defined the mode of concentration: having defined the mode of concentration by apprehending it as it is concentrated.

original: eva samathanimittanti āha “samathanimittanti ca samathassevetamadhivacana”nti. Nānārammaṇe
analyzed: eva samatha nimittan ti āha samatha nimittan ti ca samathassa iva itam adhivacanan ti na anārammaṇe
translated: The sign of serenity: the sign of serenity is a term for serenity itself.

original: paribbhamanena vividhaṃ aggaṃ etassāti byaggo, vikkhepo. Tathā hi so anavaṭṭhānaraso,
analyzed: paribbhamanena vividham aggam etassa ati byaggaḥ vikkhepaḥ tathā hi so anavaṭṭhāna rasaḥ
translated: Distraction: it is called distraction because it scatters the mind over various objects. For its characteristic is non-stopping.

original: bhantatāpaccupaṭṭhāno ca vutto. Ekaggatābhāvato byaggapaṭipakkhoti abyaggo, samādhi.
analyzed: bhanta tā paccupaṭṭhāno ca vuttaḥ ekagga tā bhāvataḥ byagga paṭipakkho ti abyaggaḥ samādhi
translated: It is not distracted because it is the opposite of distraction owing to the absence of distraction.

original: So eva nimittanti pubbe viya vattabbaṃ. Tenāha “avikkhepaṭṭhena ca tasseva abyagganimittanti adhivacana”nti.
analyzed: saḥ eva nimittam ti pubbe viya vattabbam tena āha avikkhepa ṭṭhena ca tassa iva abyagga nimittam ti adhivacananti
translated: The sign of that should be told as before. Hence he said: “It is a term for the sign of that, in the sense of non-distraction.”

original: Sarīrāvatthaṃ ñatvā mattaso paribhutto paṇītāhāro kāyalahutādīnaṃ samuṭṭhāpanena
analyzed: sarīra avattham ñatvā paribhuttaḥ paṇīta āhāraḥ kāya lahu ta ādīnam samuṭṭhāpanena
translated: Having known the state of the body, the use of superior food is a condition for tranquillity by arousing lightness of body, etc.,

original: passaddhiyā paccayo hoti, tathā utusappāyaṃ, iriyāpathasappāyañca sevitaṃ, payogo
analyzed: passaddhiyā paccayaḥ hoti tathā utu sappāyam iriyāpatha sappāyam ca sevitam payogo
translated: and likewise the use of suitable climate and suitable posture.

original: ca kāyiko pavattitoti āha “paṇītabhojanasevanatā”tiādi. Payogasamatādīnaṃ abhāvena
analyzed: ca kāyikaḥ pavattito ti āha paṇīta bhojana sevana tā atiādi payoga sama tā ādīnam abhāvena
translated: The bodily use is the use of the body.

original: sadarathakāyacittā puggalā sāraddhapuggalā. Vuttavipariyāyena passaddhakāyā puggalā veditabbā.
analyzed: puggalā sāraddha puggalā vutta vipariyāyena passaddha kāyā puggalā veditabbā
translated: Persons with heavy bodies and heavy minds are persons with sluggishness. Persons with light bodies should be understood in the opposite sense.

original: Nirassādassāti bhāvanassādarahitassa. Bhāvanā hi vīthipaṭipannā pubbenāparaṃ visesavatī
analyzed: nirassādassa ati bhāvanā ssāda rahitassa bhāvanā hi vīthi paṭipannā pubbena aparam visesavatī
translated: Of what is without relish: of what is without relish for development. For development is distinguished by what follows as compared with what precedes when it has entered the course.

original: pavattamānā cittassa assādaṃ upasamasukhaṃ āvahati, tadabhāvato nirassādaṃ cittaṃ
analyzed: pavattamānā cittassa assādam upasama sukham āvahati tad abhāvataḥ nirassādam cittam
translated: and when it is doing so it brings to the mind the satisfaction and the bliss of peace, but when it is not doing so the mind is dissatisfied.

original: hoti. Saddhāsaṃvegavasenāti saddhāvasena, saṃvegavasena ca. Sampahaṃsanatāti sammadeva🔽pahaṃsanatā saṃvejanapubbakapasāduppādanena bhāvanā cittassa tosanā. Sammāpavattassāti🔽līnuddhaccavirahena, samathavīthipaṭipattiyā ca samaṃ, savisesañca pavattiyā sammadeva
analyzed: hoti saddhā saṃvega vasena ati saddhā vasena saṃvega vasena ca sampahaṃsana tā ati sammad eva  pahaṃsana tā saṃvejana pubbaka pasāda uppādanena bhāvanā cittassa tosanā sammā pavattassa ati  līn uddhacca virahena samatha vīthi paṭipattiyā ca samam sa visesam ca pavattiyā sammat eva
translated: By means of faith and urgency: by means of faith and by means of urgency.🔽By means of encouragement: by means of encouragement that is proper, that is, by means of the arousing of confidence preceded by urgency.🔽By means of right progress: by means of right progress in the development of the mind, which is even and distinguished, being free from both sluggishness and restlessness and being practice along the path of serenity.

original: pavattassa bhāvanācittassa. Ajjhupekkhanatāti paggahaniggahasampahaṃsanesu abyāvaṭatā.🔽Jhānavimokkhapaccavekkhaṇatāti paṭhamādīni jhānāni paccanīkadhammehi suṭṭhu vimuttatādinā
analyzed: pavattassa bhāvanā cittassa ajjhupekkhana tā ati paggaha niggaha sampahaṃsanesu a byāvaṭa tā  jhāna vimokkha paccavekkhaṇa tā ti paṭhama ādīni jhānāni paccanīka dhammehi suṭṭhu vimutta tā ādinā
translated: By means of equanimity: by means of equanimity in the sense of non-involvement in the arousing, the restraining, and the encouraging.

original: teyeva vimokkhā tesaṃ “evaṃ bhāvanā, evaṃ samāpajjanā, evaṃ adhiṭṭhānaṃ, evaṃ vuṭṭhānaṃ,
analyzed: te yeva vimokkhā tesam evam bhāvanā evam samāpajjanā evam adhiṭṭhānam evam vuṭṭhānam
translated: By means of reviewing the jhānas and the liberations: by means of reviewing the jhānas, etc., in each instance thus, “Development is like this, attainment is like this, determination is like this, emergence is like this,

original: evaṃ saṃkileso, evaṃ vodāna”nti pati pati avekkhaṇā.
analyzed: evam saṃkilesaḥ evam vodānanti pati pati avekkhaṇā
translated: defilement is like this, cleansing is like this.”

original: Sattamajjhattatāti sattesu piyaṭṭhāniyesupi gahaṭṭhapabbajitesu majjhattākāro ajjhupekkhanā.
analyzed: satta majjhatta tā ti sattesu piya ṭṭhāniyesu pi gaha ṭṭha pabbajitesu majjhatta ākāraḥ ajjhupekkhanā
translated: Equanimity about beings: equanimity consisting in looking on impartially at beings who are dear and endearing, both householders and those gone forth.

original: Saṅkhāramajjhattatāti ajjhattikesu cakkhādīsu, bāhiresu pattacīvarādīsu majjhattākāro
analyzed: saṅkhāra majjhatta tā ti ajjhattikesu cakkha ādīsu bāhiresu patta cīvara ādīsu majjhatta ākāro
translated: Equanimity about formations: equanimity consisting in looking on impartially at internal and external formations, that is, at the eye, etc., and at the visible data, etc.

original: ajjhupekkhanā. Sattasaṅkhārānaṃ mamāyanaṃ sattasaṅkhārakelāyanaṃ. Imehākārehīti imehi
analyzed: ajjhupekkhanā satta saṅkhārānam mamāyanam satta saṅkhāra kelāyanam imehi ākārehi iti imehi
translated: The equanimity about formations is the equanimity about the six kinds of objects of craving, about the six kinds of search, and about the six kinds of craving.

original: yathāvuttehi kāyacittānaṃ passaddhākārasallakkhaṇādiākārehi ceva sappāyāhārasevanādiākārehi
analyzed: yathā vuttehi kāya cittānam passaddha ākāra sallakkhaṇa ādi ākārehi ca iva sappāya āhāra sevana ādi ākārehi
translated: By these means: by means of the means consisting in the characteristics of serenity, etc., of the body and mind, and in the use of suitable foods, etc., as already described.

original: ca. Ete dhammeti ete passaddhiādidhamme.🔽66. Paññāpayogamandatāyāti paññābyāpārassa appabhāvena. Yathā hi dānasīlāni alobhādosappadhānāni,🔽evaṃ bhāvanā amohappadhānā visesato appanāvahā. Tattha yadā paññā na balavatī hoti,
analyzed: ca ete dhamme iti ete passaddhi ādi dhamme  paññā apayoga manda tāya ati paññā byāpārassa appabhāvena yathā hi dāna sīlāni alobha adosa ppadhānāni  evam bhāvanā amoha padhānā visesataḥ appanā āvahā tattha yadā paññā na balavatī hoti
translated: These states: these states of serenity, etc.🔽Because of the weakness of the application of understanding: because of the weakness of the activity of understanding. For just as generosity and virtue have non-greed and non-hate as their predominance,🔽so too development has non-delusion as its predominance, and it is especially productive of absorption. Herein, when understanding is not strong,

original: tadā bhāvanācittassa anabhisaṅkhato viya āhāro purisassa abhiruciṃ na janeti, tena
analyzed: tadā bhāvanā cittassa an abhisaṅkhataḥ viya āhāraḥ purisassa abhirucim na janeti tena
translated: then, as if food were not digested because it had not been properly cooked, it does not give rise to the desired appreciation in the mind that is being developed.

original: taṃ nirassādaṃ hoti. Yadā ca bhāvanā pubbenāparaṃ visesāvahā na hoti sammadeva avīthipaṭipattiyā,
analyzed: tam nirassādam hoti yadā ca bhāvanā pubbena aparam visesa āvahā na hoti sammad eva a vīthi paṭipattiyā
translated: And when the development does not bring a higher distinction later on, and the right way is not entered upon,

original: tadā upasamasukhassa alābhena cittaṃ nirassādaṃ hoti. Tadubhayaṃ sandhāyāha “paññāpayogamandatāyā”tiādi.
analyzed: tadā upasama sukhassa alābhena cittam nirassādam hoti tat ubhayam sandhāya āha paññā apayoga manda tāya atiādi
translated: then his mind is dispirited through failure to obtain the bliss of peace. The words “weakness of the means of knowledge” and so on refer to both these kinds of dispiritedness.

original: Nanti cittaṃ. Jātijarābyādhimaraṇāni yathārahaṃ sugatiyaṃ, duggatiyañca hontīti tadaññameva
analyzed: cittam jāti jarā byādhi maraṇāni yathāraham sugatiyam duggatiyam ca honti iti tad aññam eva
translated: “That” is the mind. Birth, ageing, disease, and death are in the happy destinies and in the unhappy destinies respectively.

original: pañcavidhabandhanādikhuppipāsādiaññamaññavibādhanādihetukaṃ apāyadukkhaṃ daṭṭhabbaṃ.🔽Tayidaṃ sabbaṃ tesaṃ tesaṃ sattānaṃ paccuppannabhavanissitaṃ gahitanti atīte, anāgate
analyzed: pañcavidha bandhana ādi khuppipāsā ādi aññamañña vibādhana ādi hetukam apāya dukkham daṭṭhabbaṃ  tayā idam sabbam tesam tesam sattānam paccuppanna bhava nissitam gahitam ti atīte anāgate
translated: The suffering of the unhappy destinies should be regarded as having as its cause the five kinds of bondage, etc., and the various kinds of mutual injury, etc.,

original: ca kāle vaṭṭamūlakadukkhāni visuṃ gahitāni. Ye pana sattā āhārūpajīvino, tattha ca
analyzed: ca kāle vaṭṭa mūlaka dukkhāni visum gahitāni ye pana sattāḥ āhāra upajīvino tattha ca
translated: All this is included in the present life of the various kinds of beings. So the suffering rooted in the round is included in the present, past, and future.

original: uṭṭhānaphalūpajīvino, tesaṃ aññehi asādhāraṇaṃ jīvitadukkhaṃ aṭṭhamaṃ saṃvegavatthu🔽vuttanti daṭṭhabbaṃ.
analyzed: uṭṭhāna phala upajīvino tesam aññehi asādhāraṇam jīvita dukkham aṭṭhamam saṃvega vatthu 🔽vuttam ti daṭṭhabbam
translated: But the suffering of life is the eighth ground for the arousal of a sense of urgency, and it is mentioned as a special kind of suffering common to all beings who live by nutriment.

original: Assāti cittassa. Alīnantiādīsu kosajjapakkhiyānaṃ dhammānaṃ anadhimattatāya alīnaṃ.
analyzed: assa ti cittassa alīna nti ādīsu kosajja pakkhiyānam dhammānam anadhimatta tāya alīnam
translated: “Mind” is consciousness. “Not slack” : because of the absence of any excess of states on the side of indolence.

original: Uddhaccapakkhikānaṃ dhammānaṃ anadhimattatāya anuddhataṃ. Paññāpayogasampattiyā,🔽upasamasukhādhigamena ca anirassādaṃ. Pubbenāparaṃ savisesaṃ tato eva ārammaṇe samappavattaṃ,
analyzed: uddhacca pakkhikānam dhammānam anadhimatta tāya anuddhatam paññā apayoga sampattiyā  upasama sukha adhigamena ca a nirassādam pubbena aparam sa visesam tatas eva ārammaṇe sama ppavattam
translated: “Not restless” : because of the absence of any excess of states on the side of restlessness. “Not disinclined” : because of the presence of the equipment of wisdom,🔽and because of the attainment of the bliss of serenity. “With higher and higher progress” : because of the occurrence of the object in each successive meditation with a higher and higher degree of subtlety.

original: samathavīthipaṭipannañca. Tattha alīnatāya paggahe, anuddhatatāya niggahe, anirassādatāya🔽sampahaṃsane na byāpāraṃ āpajjati. Alīnānuddhatatāya hi ārammaṇe samappavattaṃ anirassādatāya
analyzed: samatha vīthi paṭipannam ca tattha a līna tāya paggahe an uddhata tāya niggahe a nirassāda tāya  sampahaṃsane na byāpāram āpajjati alīna anuddhata tāya hi ārammaṇe sama ppavattam a nirassāda tāya
translated: “With direct experience of the highest” : because of the entry into the path of serenity. Herein, it is not slack because of the absence of slackness;🔽it is not restless because of the absence of restlessness; it is not disinclined because of the absence of disinclination.🔽Or alternatively, it is not slack because of the occurrence of the object; it is not restless because of the absence of disinclination; it is not disinclined because of the entry into the path of serenity.

original: samathavīthipaṭipannaṃ. Samappavattiyā vā alīnaṃ anuddhataṃ, samathavīthipaṭipattiyā🔽anirassādanti daṭṭhabbaṃ.
analyzed: samatha vīthi paṭipannam sama pavattiyā vā alīnam anuddhatam samatha vīthi paṭipattiyā  a nirassādanti daṭṭhabbam
translated: Or alternatively, it is not slack because of the occurrence of the object; it is not restless because of the absence of disinclination; it is not disinclined because of the entry into the path of serenity.

original: Nekkhammapaṭipadanti jhānapaṭipattiṃ. Samādhiadhimuttatāti samādhinibbattane jhānādhigame
analyzed: nekkhamma paṭipadanti jhāna paṭipattim samādhi adhimutta tā ati samādhi nibbattane jhāna adhigame
translated: “The way of renunciation” is the way of meditation. “With concentration as its sovereign” : with the attainment of jhāna, which is produced by concentration, as its sovereign.

original: yuttappayuttatā. Sā pana yasmā samādhiṃ garuṃ katvā tattha ninnapoṇapabbhārabhāvena
analyzed: sā pana yasmā samādhim garum katvā tattha ninna poṇa pabbhāra bhāvena
translated: and the state of being yoked and harnessed to that. But that is so because of the occurrence of the sign as a state of being with a tendency to descend, enter and incline towards that concentration.

original: pavattiyā hoti, tasmā “samādhigarū”tiādi vuttaṃ.
analyzed: pavattiyā hoti tasmā samādhi garu utiādi vuttam
translated: That is why it is said, “With the sign as its object” and so on.🔽When the sign has been obtained, then when he develops it in this way, the skill in attaining consists in this: the attainment comes about thus.

original: 67. Paṭiladdhe nimittasmiṃ evaṃ hi sampādayato appanākosallaṃ imaṃ appanā sampavattatīti
analyzed: paṭiladdhe nimittasmin evam hi sampādayataḥ appanā kosallam imam appanā sampavattati iti
translated: The “it” is the attainment.🔽The word “but” has the meaning of a reason.🔽Since there is no room for it,

original: sambandho. Sāti appanā. Hitvā hīti hi-saddo hetuattho. Yasmā ṭhānametaṃ na vijjati,
analyzed: sambandhaḥ sā ati appanā hitvā hi iti hi saddaḥ hetu atthaḥ yasmā ṭhānam etam na vijjati
translated: he should advert to the sign and look at it and review it, and he should do so with a measure of energy that is neither too slack nor too tense.🔽For if he looks at the sign with too much energy, then his consciousness tends to distraction and he is unable to look at the sign.🔽If he looks at it with too little energy, then his consciousness tends to lethargy and he is unable to look at the sign.🔽So he should look at the sign with a measure of energy that is neither too slack nor too tense.

original: tasmā cittappavattiākāraṃ bhāvanācittassa līnuddhatādivasena pavattiākāraṃ sallakkhayaṃ🔽upadhārento. Samataṃ vīriyasseva vīriyassa samādhinā samarasataṃyeva yojayetha. Kathaṃ🔽pana yojayethāti āha “īsakampī”tiādi. Tattha layanti līnabhāvaṃ, saṅkocanti attho.
analyzed: tasmā citta ppavatti ākāram bhāvanā cittassa līn uddhata ādi vasena pavatti ākāram sat lakkhayam  upadhārentaḥ samatam vīriyassa iva vīriyassa samādhinā yojayetha katham  pana yojayetha iti āha īsakampi itiādi tattha layanti līna bhāvam saṅkocanti attho
translated: And he should do so with a measure of mindfulness that is neither too slack nor too tense.🔽For if he looks at the sign with too much mindfulness, then his consciousness tends to distraction and he is unable to look at the sign.🔽If he looks at it with too little mindfulness, then his consciousness tends to lethargy and he is unable to look at the sign.

original: Yantanti gacchantaṃ, paggaṇhetheva samabhāvāyāti adhippāyo. Tenāha “accāraddhaṃ nisedhetvā
analyzed: yantanti gacchantam paggaṇhetha iva sama bhāvāya ati adhippāyaḥ tena āha acca āraddham nisedhetvā
translated: So he should look at the sign with a measure of mindfulness that is neither too slack nor too tense.

original: samameva pavattaye”ti. Kathaṃ pana samameva pavattayeti āha “reṇumhī”tiādi. Yathāti
analyzed: samam eva pavattayā iti katham pana samam eva pavattayā iti āha yathā iti
translated: But how should he make it proceed evenly?

original: reṇuādīsu yathā madhukarādīnaṃ pavatti upamābhāvena aṭṭhakathāyaṃ sammavaṇṇitā, evaṃ
analyzed: reṇu ādīsu yathā madhukara ādīnam upamā bhāvena aṭṭhakathā ayam samma vaṇṇitā evam
translated: As in the case of the dust, etc., the way in which the bees, etc., proceed has been well described in the commentary by way of simile.

original: līnuddhatabhāvehi mocayitvā vīriyasamatāyojanena nimittābhimukhaṃ mānasaṃ paṭipādaye
analyzed: mocayitvā vīriya samatā yojanena nimitta abhimukham mānasam paṭipādaye
translated: So too, he should make the mind face the sign by directing it there with the evenness of energy, after liberating it from depression and excitement.

original: paṭibhāganimittābhimukhaṃ bhāvanācittaṃ sampādeyyāti attho.🔽Nimittābhimukhapaṭipādanavaṇṇanā
analyzed: paṭibhāga nimitta abhimukham bhāvanā cittam sampādeyya attho  nimitta abhimukha paṭipādana vaṇṇanā
translated: The meaning is that he should perfect the development of the mind by making it face the counterpart sign.

original: 68. Tatrāti tasmiṃ “reṇumhī”tiādinā vuttagāthādvaye. Atthadīpanā upamūpameyyatthavibhāvanā.
analyzed: tatra ati tasmin reṇumhi iti ādinā vutta gāthā dvaye attha dīpanā
translated: Herein, in the two verses beginning, “As in the case of the dust,” the explanation of the meaning is the elucidation of the meaning of the simile and the object compared.🔽Unskilled: unskilled in the way of proceeding.

original: Achekoti akusalo. Pakkhandoti dhāvituṃ āraddho. Vikasanakkhaṇeyeva sarasaṃ kusumaparāgaṃ🔽hoti, pacchā vātādīhi paripatati, virasaṃ vā hoti. Tasmā nivattane reṇu khīyatīti
analyzed: achekaḥ iti akusalaḥ pakkhandaḥ ti dhāvitum āraddhaḥ vikasana khaṇeya iva sarasam kusuma parāgam  hoti pacchā vāta ādīhi paripatati virasam vā hoti tasmā nivattane reṇu khīyati iti
translated: Set out: started running.🔽The fresh pollen of the flowers is fragrant, but after that it becomes stale and loses its fragrance, or it is scattered by the wind, etc.,🔽So the dust tires him when he turns back.

original: āha “khīṇe reṇumhi sampāpuṇātī”ti. Puppharāsinti rukkhasākhāsu nissitaṃ pupphasañcayaṃ.
analyzed: āha khīṇe reṇumhi sampāpuṇāti iti puppha rāsim ti rukkha sākhāsu nissitam puppha sañcayam
translated: Therefore it is said: “When the dust is gone, he reaches the flowers.”🔽A mass of flowers: a collection of flowers growing on the branches of a tree.

original: Sallakattaantevāsikesūti sallakattaācariyassa antevāsikesu. Udakathālagateti udakathāliyaṃ
analyzed: sallakatta antevāsikesu iti sallakatta ācariyassa antevāsikesu udakathāla gatā iti udakathāliyam
translated: Among the pupils of the master surgeon: among the pupils of the master surgeon. In the water-pot: in the water-pot.

original: ṭhapite. Satthakammanti sirāvedhanādisatthakammaṃ. Phusitumpi uppalapattanti sambandho.🔽Samenāti purimakā viya garuṃ, mandañca payogaṃ akatvā samappamāṇena payogena. Tatthāti
analyzed: ṭhapite satthakammanti sirāvedhana ādi satthakammam phusitum pi uppala pattanti sambandho  samena ati purimakāḥ viya garum mandam ca payogam a katvā samappamāṇena payogena tattha ati
translated: Among the pupils of the barber: among the pupils of the barber-teacher. In the water-pot: in the water-pot that was set down. The barber’s work: the barber’s work of opening veins, etc. The lotus leaf: the connection is with “to touch.”🔽Evenly: without making the application heavy or slow like the previous ones. There:

original: uppalapatte. Pariyodātasippoti suvisuddhasippo nipphannasippo.
analyzed: uppala patte pariyodāta sippo ti su visuddha sippo nipphanna sippo
translated: in the lotus leaf. A well-polished blade: a very well-polished blade, a finished blade.

original: Makkaṭakasuttanti lūtasuttaṃ. Niyāmako nāvāsārathī. Laṅkāranti kilañjādimayaṃ nāvākaṭasārakaṃ.
analyzed: makkaṭaka suttanti lūta suttam niyāmakaḥ nāvā sārathī laṅkāranti kilañja ādi mayam nāvā kaṭasārakam
translated: The monkey-trick sutta: the sutta about the monkey. The helmsman: the captain of the ship. The ship: a ship made of kilañja wood, etc.

original: Telena achaḍḍento nāḷiṃ pūretīti sarāvādigatena telena achaḍḍento sukhumacchiddakaṃ
analyzed: telena a chaḍḍentaḥ nāḷim pūreti iti sarāva ādi gatena telena a chaḍḍentaḥ sukhuma chiddakam
translated: Without spilling any oil: without spilling any oil from the oil-barrel, etc., he fills the oil-tube.

original: telanāḷiṃ pūreti. Evamevāti yathā te ādito vuttamadhukarasallakattaantevāsisuttākaḍḍhakaniyāmakatelapūrakā
analyzed: tela nāḷim pūra iti evam eva ati yathā te āditas vutta madhukara sallakatta antevāsi suttā kaḍḍhaka niyāmaka telapūrakā
translated: In the same way: just as those who were mentioned at the beginning—the honey-licker, the barber, the pupil, the carrier, the helmsman, and the oil-filler—make their application quickly,

original: vegena payogaṃ karonti, evameva yo bhikkhu “sīghaṃ appanaṃ pāpuṇissāmī”ti gāḷhaṃ
analyzed: vegena payogam karonti evam eva yaḥ bhikkhu sīgham appanam pāpuṇissāmi iti gāḷham
translated: so too, if a bhikkhu thinks “I shall reach absorption quickly” and makes his application too strongly,

original: vīriyaṃ karoti, yo majjhe vuttamadhukarādayo viya vīriyaṃ na karoti, ime dvepi vīriyasamatābhāvena🔽appanaṃ pāpuṇituṃ na sakkonti. Yo pana avasāne vuttamadhukarādayo viya samappayogo,
analyzed: vīriyam karoti yaḥ majjhe vutta madhukara ādayaḥ viya vīriyam na karoti ime dve api vīriya samatā bhāvena  appanam pāpuṇitum na sakkonti yaḥ pana avasāne vutta madhukara ādayaḥ viya sama ppayogaḥ
translated: He who does not exert himself like the bee in the middle is the second. Both these are unable to reach absorption because of the equality of their energy.

original: ayaṃ appanaṃ pāpuṇituṃ sakkoti vīriyasamatāyogatoti upamāsaṃsandanaṃ veditabbaṃ.
analyzed: ayam appanam pāpuṇitum sakkoti vīriya sama tā yogato ti upamā saṃsandanam veditabbam
translated: But he who exerts himself like the bee at the end is the third. He is able to reach absorption because of the equality of his energy. The application of the simile should be understood as follows.

original: Tena vuttaṃ “eko bhikkhū”tiādi. Līnaṃ bhāvanācittanti adhippāyo.
analyzed: tena vuttam ekaḥ bhikkhu iti ādi līnam bhāvanā cittan ti adhippāyaḥ
translated: The meaning intended is that the development of consciousness is slack.

original: Paṭhamajjhānakathāvaṇṇanā
translated: The first jhāna

original: 69. Evanti vuttappakārena. Vīriyasamatāyojanavasena vīthipaṭipannaṃ bhāvanāmānasaṃ
analyzed: evam ti vutta ppakārena vīriya samatā yojana vasena vīthi paṭipannam bhāvanā mānasam
translated: In this way: by the application of the equality of energy, the development of consciousness that has entered the path

original: paṭibhāganimitteyeva ṭhapanavasena nimittābhimukhaṃ paṭipādayato assa yogino. Ijjhissatīti
analyzed: paṭibhāga nimittā iya iva ṭhapana vasena nimitta abhimukham paṭipādayataḥ assa yoginaḥ ijjhissati iti
translated: is brought to face the sign by stopping in the counterpart sign in the meditator.

original: samijjhissati, uppajjissatīti attho. Anuyogavasenāti bhāvanāvasena. Sesānīti sesāni
analyzed: samijjhissati uppajjissati iti attho anuyoga vasena ati bhāvanā vasena sesāni iti sesāni
translated: It will succeed: it will be successful; it will arise, is the meaning. By the method of practice: by the method of development. The rest: the other three.

original: tīṇi, cattāri vā. Pakaticittehīti pākatikehi kāmāvacaracittehi. Balava…pe… cittekaggatāni🔽bhāvanābalena paṭutarasabhāvappattiyā. Parikammattāti paṭisaṅkhārakattā. Yadi āsannattā🔽upacāratā, gotrabhuno eva upacārasamaññā siyāti āha “samīpacārittā vā”ti. Anaccāsannopi🔽hi nātidūrapavattī samīpacārī nāma hoti. Appanaṃ upecca carantīti upacārāni. Ito🔽pubbe parikammānanti nānāvajjanavīthiyaṃ parikammānaṃ. Etthāti etesu parikammupacārānulomasaññitesu.
analyzed: tīṇi cattāri vā pakati cittehi iti pākatikehi kāmāvacara cittehi bala vape citta ekaggatāni  bhāvanā balena paṭuta rasa bhāva ppattiyā parikamma ttā ati paṭisaṅkhāraka ttā yadi āsanna ttā  upacāra tā gotrabhunaḥ eva upacāra samaññā siyāti āha samīpa cārittā vā ati anacca āsannaḥ pi  hi na ati dūra pavattī samīpa cārī nāma hoti appanam upecca caranti iti itas  pubbe parikammānanti nānā vajjana vīthiyam parikammānam ettha ati etesu parikamma upacāra anuloma saññitesu
translated: Three or four. With normal consciousnesses: with normal sense-sphere consciousnesses. By the power of development: by the power of development that has reached a more keen state. By the act of reviewing: by the act of reviewing. If it is called access because of proximity, then only the path of stream-entry should be called access. That is why he says “or because of nearness.” For even though it is not near, if it occurs not too far away it is called near. They occur near to absorption: thus they are called access. Before absorption: before the path of stream-entry. The reviewing: the reviewing in the course of the succession of the various kinds of insight. Here: among those called reviewing, access, and conformity.

original: Sabbantimanti tatiyaṃ, catutthaṃ vā. Parittagottābhibhavanatoti parittassa gottassa🔽abhibhavanato. Gaṃtāyatīti hi gottaṃ, “paritta”nti pavattamānaṃ abhidhānaṃ, buddhiñca
analyzed: sabbantimanti tatiyam catuttham vā paritta gotta abhibhavanato ti parittassa gottassa 🔽abhibhavanataḥ hi gottam parittam ti pavattamānam abhidhānam buddhim ca
translated: and three or four. With normal consciousness: with normal sense-sphere consciousness. By the power of development: by the power of development of the meditation subject. By the act of reviewing: by the act of reviewing. If it is called access because of proximity, then only the first jhāna would have the name of access. So he says: “Or because of nearness to the occurrence of the jhāna.” For although it is not near in the way of proximity, still it is called near because it occurs not far away. They occur approaching jhāna, thus they are access; they are called access because they occur approaching jhāna. Before: prior to. The reviewing: the reviewing in the course of the various kinds of insight. Here: in the kinds of reviewing called “access” and “threshold of the first jhāna.” All: the third or the fourth. By surmounting the limited: by surmounting the limited class.

original: ekaṃsikavisayatāya rakkhatīti parittagottaṃ. Yathā hi buddhi ārammaṇabhūtena atthena
analyzed: ekaṃsika visaya tāya rakkhati iti paritta gottam yathā hi buddhi ārammaṇa bhūtena atthena
translated: It is a limited lineage since it protects by being the province of the one-sidedness .🔽For just as understanding does not occur without a meaning that is its object,

original: vinā na pavattati, evaṃ abhidhānaṃ abhidheyyabhūtena. Tasmā so tāni tāyati rakkhatīti
analyzed: vinā na pavattati evam abhidhānam abhidheyya bhūtena tasmā so tāni tāyati rakkhati iti
translated: so too expression does not occur without a name that is its object. Therefore it is said that it protects, it guards, those .

original: vuccati. Taṃ pana mahaggatānuttaravidhuraṃ kāmataṇhāya gocarabhūtaṃ kāmāvacaradhammānaṃ
analyzed: vuccati tam pana mahaggata anuttara vidhuram kāma taṇhāya gocara bhūtam kāmāvacara dhammānam
translated: But it should be regarded as the unique materiality that is the province of craving for sense desires among the states of the sense-sphere.🔽The meaning should be understood in this way too in the case of the exalted lineage.

original: āveṇikarūpaṃ daṭṭhabbaṃ. Mahaggatagottepi iminā nayena attho veditabbo. Bhāvanatoti uppādanato.
analyzed: āveṇika rūpam daṭṭhabbam mahaggata gotte pi iminā nayena atthaḥ veditabbaḥ bhāvanataḥ ti uppādanataḥ
translated: By development : by giving rise to.

original: Avisesena sabbesaṃ sabbā samaññāti paṭhamanayo gahitaggahaṇaṃ hotīti āha “aggahitaggahaṇenā”tiādi.
analyzed: avisesena sabbesam sabbā samaññā ti paṭhama nayaḥ gahita ggahaṇam hoti iti āha aggahita ggahaṇena atiādi
translated: The first method is a method of taking what is not already taken since it is a method of taking all of all without distinction.

original: Nānāvajjanaparikammameva parikammanti adhippāyena “paṭhamaṃ vā upacāra”ntiādi vuttaṃ.
analyzed: nānā vajjana parikammam eva parikammanti adhippāyena paṭhamam vā upacāra ntiādi vuttam
translated: The intention is that the preliminary work is the preliminary work of the various kinds of adverting.🔽The fourth or the fifth jhāna consciousness is the absorption.

original: Catutthaṃ appanācittaṃ, pañcamaṃ vā appanācittaṃ pubbe vuttanayena sace catutthaṃ
analyzed: catuttham appanā cittam pañcamam vā appanā cittam pubbe vutta nayena sace catuttham
translated: If it is the fourth,

original: gotrabhu hotīti attho. Pañcamaṃ vāti vā-saddo aniyame. Svāyaṃ aniyamo iminā kāraṇenāti
analyzed: gotrabhu hoti iti attho pañcamam vāti vā saddaḥ aniyame aniyamaḥ iminā kāraṇena ati
translated: The word “or” in the fifth line shows that the statement is not restricted.

original: dassetuṃ “tañca kho khippābhiññadandhābhiññavasenā”ti vuttaṃ. Tattha khippābhiññassa
analyzed: dassetum tat ca kho khippābhiñña dandhābhiñña vasena ati vuttam tattha khippābhiññassa
translated: In order to show that this is so, he says, “And that is according to quick and slow direct-knowledge.” Herein,🔽the quick direct-knower reaches the fourth,

original: catutthaṃ appeti, dandhābhiññassa pañcamaṃ. Kasmā pana catutthaṃ, pañcamaṃ vā appeti,🔽na tato paranti āha “tato paraṃ javanaṃ patatī”ti. Tato pañcamato paraṃ chaṭṭhaṃ,
analyzed: catuttham appeti dandha abhiññassa pañcamam kasmā pana catuttham pañcamam vā appeti  na tatas paranti āha tatas param javanam patati iti tatas pañcamatas param chaṭṭham
translated: and the slow direct-knower reaches the fifth. But why does he reach the fourth or the fifth and no further?🔽He says, “The impulsion falls away beyond that.” The intention is that the sixth and seventh impulsions fall away as if falling on the fifth,

original: sattamañca javanaṃ patantaṃ viya hoti parikkhīṇajavattāti adhippāyo.
analyzed: sattamam ca javanam patantam viya hoti parikkhīṇa java ttā ati adhippāyo
translated: because their impulsion is exhausted.

original: Yathā aladdhāsevanaṃ paṭhamajavanaṃ dubbalattā gotrabhuṃ na uppādeti, laddhāsevanaṃ
analyzed: yathā a laddha āsevanam paṭhama javanam dubbala ttā gotrabhum na uppādeti laddha āsevanam
translated: Just as the first impulsion, which is not yet habitual, does not originate the lineage because it is weak,

original: pana balavabhāvato dutiyaṃ, tatiyaṃ vā gotrabhuṃ uppādeti, evaṃ laddhāsevanatāya
analyzed: pana balava bhāvataḥ dutiyam tatiyam vā gotrabhum uppādeti evam laddha āsevana tāya
translated: but the second or the third does originate it because it is strong, being habitual,

original: balavabhāvato chaṭṭhaṃ, sattamampi appetīti therassa adhippāyo. Tenāha “tasmā chaṭṭhepi
analyzed: balava bhāvataḥ chaṭṭham sattamam pi appeti iti therassa adhippāyo tena āha tasmā chaṭṭhe pi
translated: so too the sixth and the seventh reach because they are strong, being habitual. This is the Elder’s opinion. Hence he said:🔽“Therefore, in the sixth

original: sattamepi appanā hotī”ti. Tanti therassa vacanaṃ. Suttasuttānulomaācariyavādehi anupatthambhitattā
analyzed: sattame pi appanā hoti iti tanti therassa vacanam sutta sutta anuloma ācariya vādehi an upatthambhita ttā
translated: and the seventh is absorption.” “Tanti” is the Elder’s words. “By himself” is said because they are not supported by the suttas, the commentaries, and the teacher’s words.

original: vuttaṃ “attanomatimatta”nti. “Purimā purimā kusalā dhammā”ti pana suttapadamakāraṇaṃ
analyzed: vuttam attano matimattanti purimā purimā kusalāḥ dhammā ti pana sutta padam akāraṇam
translated: “The former profitable states” is not a sutta passage.🔽It is a reason for the strength of the condition consisting in repetition. For the first impulsion

original: āsevanapaccayalābhassa balavabhāve anekantikattā. Tathā hi aladdhāsevanāpi paṭhamacetanā
analyzed: āsevana paccaya lābhassa balava bhāve anekantika ttā tathā hi aladdha āsevanā api paṭhama cetanā
translated: is kamma to be experienced here and now even though it has not been repeated, and the second impulsion is kamma to be experienced in some future life even though it has been repeated.🔽The third and fourth impulsions are kamma to be experienced in some future life.🔽The fifth is kamma of which the result is to be experienced in a next birth.🔽The sixth and seventh are kamma to be experienced in some future life.🔽The seventh impulsion is kamma of which the result is to be experienced in a next birth.🔽The eighth is kamma to be experienced in some future life.🔽The ninth is kamma of which the result is to be experienced in a next birth.🔽The tenth is kamma to be experienced here and now.🔽The eleventh is kamma of which the result is to be experienced in some future life.🔽The twelfth is kamma of which the result is to be experienced in a next birth.

original: diṭṭhadhammavedanīyā hoti, laddhāsevanā dutiyacetanā yāva chaṭṭhacetanā aparāpariyavedanīyā.
analyzed: diṭṭhadhamma vedanīyā hoti laddha āsevanā dutiya cetanā yāva chaṭṭha cetanā apara apariya vedanīyā
