translated: The thirteenth is kamma to be experienced here and now.🔽The fourteenth is kamma of which the result is to be experienced in some future life.

original: Catutthapañcamesuyevātiādi vuttassevatthassa yuttidassanamukhena nigamanatthaṃ vuttaṃ.
analyzed: catuttha pañcamesu yeva atiādi yutti dassana mukhena nigamana attham vuttam
translated: The fifteenth is kamma of which the result is to be experienced in a next birth.🔽The sixteenth is kamma to be experienced here and now.🔽The seventeenth is kamma of which the result is to be experienced in some future life.

original: Tattha yadi chaṭṭhasattamaṃ javanaṃ patitaṃ nāma hoti parikkhīṇajavattā, kathaṃ sattamajavanacetanā
analyzed: tattha yadi chaṭṭha sattamam javanam patitam nāma hoti parikkhīṇa java tā katham sattama javana cetanā
translated: The eighteenth is kamma of which the result is to be experienced in a next birth.🔽The nineteenth is kamma to be experienced here and now.🔽The twentieth is kamma of which the result is to be experienced in some future life.

original: upapajjavedanīyā, ānantariyā ca hotīti? Nāyaṃ viseso āsevanapaccayalābhena balappattiyā.
analyzed: upapajja vedanīyā ānantariyā ca hoti iti na ayam visesaḥ āsevana paccaya lābhena bala ppattiyā
translated: The twenty-first is kamma of which the result is to be experienced in a next birth.🔽The twenty-second is kamma to be experienced here and now.🔽The twenty-third is kamma of which the result is to be experienced in some future life.🔽The twenty-fourth is kamma of which the result is to be experienced in a next birth.🔽The twenty-fifth is kamma to be experienced here and now.🔽The twenty-sixth is kamma of which

original: Kiñcarahi kiriyāvatthāvisesato. Kiriyāvatthā hi ārambhamajjhapariyosānavasena tividhā.
analyzed: kiñcarahi kiriyā vatthā avisesato kiriyā vatthā hi ārambha majjha pariyosāna vasena tividhā
translated: And what else? By the difference in the plane of action. For the plane of action is threefold as beginning, middle, and end.

original: Tattha ca pariyosānāvatthāya sanniṭṭhāpakacetanābhāvena upapajjavedanīyāditā hoti,
analyzed: tattha ca pariyosāna avatthāya sanniṭṭhāpaka cetanā bhāvena upapajja vedanīya ādi tā hoti
translated: And here the state of being kamma-resultant to be experienced in the next existence, etc., is due to the presence of the volition that brings the action to its conclusion,

original: na balavabhāvenāti daṭṭhabbaṃ. Paṭisandhiyā anantarapaccayabhāvino vipākasantānassa🔽anantarapaccayabhāvena tathā abhisaṅkhatattāti ca vadanti. Tasmā chaṭṭhasattamānaṃ
analyzed: na balava bhāvena ati daṭṭhabbam paṭisandhiyā anantara paccaya bhāvinaḥ vipāka santānassa  anantara paccaya bhāvena tathā ca vadanti tasmā chaṭṭha sattamānam
translated: not to its strength. And they say that it is “so determined” because of the condition being next to the rebirth-linking.🔽For the continuity of kamma-result that is next to the rebirth-linking is next to the condition that is next to the volition that determines the kind of existence.🔽Therefore, although the sixth and seventh are facing the abyss, they cannot be stopped, just as the man with exhausted merit cannot be stopped from falling into the abyss. That is why it is said, “Just as a man” , and so on.

original: papātābhimukhatāya parikkhīṇajavatā na sakkā nivāretuṃ. Tathā hi “yathā hi puriso”tiādi vuttaṃ.
analyzed: papāta abhimukha tāya parikkhīṇa java tā na sakkā nivāretum tathā hi yathā hi purisaḥ itiādi vuttam
translated: And that absorption is the delimitation of the extent of the life span.

original: Sā ca pana appanā. Addhānaparicchedoti kālaparicchedo. So panettha sattasu ṭhānesu
analyzed: sā ca pana appanā addhāna paricchedo ti kāla paricchedo saḥ pana ittha sattasu ṭhānesu
translated: But that is not found in the seven instances,

original: katthaci aparimāṇacittakkhaṇatāya, katthaci atiittarakhaṇatāya natthīti vutto. Na
analyzed: katthaci aparimāṇa citta khaṇatāya katthaci ati ittara khaṇatāya natthi iti vuttaḥ na
translated: it is said, because in some instances there are immeasurable mind-moments, and in some instances there are too many moments.

original: hettha sampuṇṇajavanavīthi addhā labbhati. Tenevāha “ettha maggānantaraphala”ntiādi.
analyzed: ha ittha sampuṇṇa javana vīthi addhā labbhati tena iva āha ettha magga anantara phala nti ādi
translated: For here the extent of the life span is not found in the complete course of the impulsions. That is why it is said, “Here the fruit is next to the path” , and so on.

original: Sesaṭṭhānesūti paṭhamappanā, lokiyābhiññā, maggakkhaṇo, nirodhā vuṭṭhahantassa phalakkhaṇoti
analyzed: sesa ṭṭhānesu uti paṭhama ppanā lokiya abhiññā magga kkhaṇaḥ nirodhā vuṭṭhahantassa phala kkhaṇaḥ ti
translated: In the remaining instances: in the first application, in mundane direct- knowledge, in the moment of the path, and in the fruition moment of one emerging from cessation.

original: etesu catūsu ṭhānesu.
analyzed: etesu catūsu ṭhānesu
translated: In these four instances.🔽To this extent: by this much of the process of development.

original: Ettāvatāti ettakena bhāvanākkamena esa yogāvacaro paṭhamaṃ jhānaṃ upasampajja viharati. Evaṃ viharatā ca anena tadeva paṭhamaṃ jhānaṃ adhigataṃ hoti pathavīkasiṇanti sambandho.
analyzed: ettāvatā ati ettakena bhāvanā kkamena esa yogāvacaraḥ paṭhamam jhānam upasampajja viharati evam viharatā ca anena tat eva paṭhamam jhānam adhigatam hoti sambandho
translated: This meditator enters upon and dwells in the first jhāna. And by his so doing the first jhāna is reached by him, is attained by him, is achieved by him, is entered upon and dwelt in by him.🔽Herein, in the text:🔽Having thus made it a basis by giving it attention in the various ways, he should next sever his hesitations.

original: 70. Tatthāti tasmiṃ jhānapāṭhe. Viviccitvāti visuṃ hutvā. Tenāha “vinā hutvā apakkamitvā”ti,🔽pajahanavasena apasakkitvāti attho. Vivicceva kāmehīti ettha “viviccā”ti iminā vivecanaṃ
analyzed: tattha iti tasmin jhāna pāṭhe viviccitvā ati visum hutvā tena āha vinā hutvā a pakkamitvā iti  pajahana vasena apasakkitvā ti atthaḥ vivicca iva kāmehi iti ettha vivicca ati iminā vivecanam
translated: Having thus made it a basis by giving it attention in the various ways, he should next sever his hesitations.

original: jhānakkhaṇe kāmānaṃ abhāvamattaṃ vuttaṃ. “Viviccevā”ti pana iminā ekaṃsato kāmānaṃ
analyzed: jhāna kkhaṇe kāmānam abhāva mattam vuttam vivicca iva ati pana iminā ekaṃsataḥ kāmānam
translated: Herein, having thus made it a basis by giving it attention in the various ways: having thus made it a basis by giving attention to it in the various ways beginning with the defining of the extent of the kasiṇa as “The earth is earth” and ending with the surmounting of materiality, he should next sever his hesitations.

original: vivecetabbatādīpanena tappaṭipakkhatā jhānassa, kāmavivekassa ca jhānādhigamūpāyatā
analyzed: vivecetabba tā dīpanena tad paṭipakkha tā jhānassa kāma vivekassa ca jhāna adhigama upāya tā
translated: Having thus made it a basis by giving it attention in the various ways: having thus made it a basis by giving attention to it in the various ways beginning with the defining of the extent of the kasiṇa as “The earth is earth” and ending with the surmounting of materiality, he should next sever his hesitations.🔽Herein, having thus made it a basis by giving it attention in the various ways: having thus made it a basis by giving attention to it in the various ways beginning with the defining of the extent of the kasiṇa as “The earth is earth” and ending with the surmounting of materiality, he should next sever his hesitations.

original: dassitā hotīti imamatthaṃ dassetuṃ “paṭhamaṃ jhāna”ntiādiṃ vatvā tamevatthaṃ pākaṭataraṃ🔽kātuṃ “katha”ntiādi vuttaṃ. “Andhakāre sati padīpobhāso viyā”ti etena yathā padīpobhāsābhāvena
analyzed: dassitā hoti iti imam attham dassetum paṭhamam jhāna ntiādim vatvā tam eva attham pākaṭataram  kātum katham tiādi vuttam andhakāre sati padīpa ubhāsaḥ viyāti etena yathā padīpa ubhāsa abhāvena
translated: The meaning of the words “is seen” is shown by the words “The first jhāna” and so on.

original: rattiyaṃ andhakārābhibhavo, evaṃ jhānābhāvena sattasantatiyaṃ kāmābhibhavoti dasseti.
analyzed: rattiyam andhakāra abhibhavo evam jhāna abhāvena satta santatiyam kāma abhibhavo ti dasseti
translated: The meaning is made clearer by the question “How?” and the answer “As when a light is lit in a dark place.” This shows that just as the darkness in a place is overcome by the existence of the light, so too the sensual desire in the continuity of the person is overcome by the existence of the jhāna.

original: Etanti pubbapadeyeva avadhāraṇavacanaṃ. Na kho pana evaṃ daṭṭhabbaṃ “kāmehi evā”ti
analyzed: etat ti avadhāraṇa vacanam na kho pana evam daṭṭhabbam kāmehi eva ati
translated: The word “only” is to be construed with the preceding word “sensual desires.” It should not be taken as “only sensual desires,”🔽because the word “only” is not expressed.

original: avadhāraṇassa akatattā. Nissaranti niggacchanti etena, ettha vāti nissaraṇaṃ. Ke
analyzed: avadhāraṇassa a kata ttā nissaranti niggacchanti etena ettha vāti nissaraṇam ke
translated: They go out, they depart, by means of this, or they go out in this, thus it is going out .

original: niggacchanti? Kāmā, tesaṃ kāmānaṃ nissaraṇaṃ pahānaṃ tannissaraṇaṃ, tato. Kathaṃ
analyzed: niggacchanti kāmā tesam kāmānam nissaraṇam pahānam tat nissaraṇam tatas katham
translated: What goes out? Sensual desires. The going out of those sensual desires is their abandoning, that is, the escape from them.

original: pana samāne vikkhambhane kāmānamevetaṃ nissaraṇaṃ, na byāpādādīnanti codanaṃ yuttito,
analyzed: pana samāne vikkhambhane kāmānam eva etam nissaraṇam na codanam yuttitaḥ
translated: But why is this escape only from sensual desires and not from ill will, etc., too? The question is answered by the words “because of the words ‘from the sense-desire element’ and so on.”

original: āgamato ca sodhetuṃ “kāmadhātū”tiādi vuttaṃ. Tattha kāmadhātusamatikkamanatoti sakalassapi
analyzed: āgamataḥ ca sodhetum kāmadhātu utiādi vuttam tattha kāmadhātu samatikkamanato ti sakalassa api
translated: Herein, because of the words “from the sense-desire element” and so on: because of the words “from the sense-desire element, from the form element, from the formless element” .

original: kāmabhavassa samatikkamapaṭipadābhāvato. Tena imassa jhānassa kāmapariññābhāvamāha.🔽Kāmarāgapaṭipakkhatoti vakkhamānavibhāgassa kilesakāmassa paccatthikabhāvato. Tena🔽yathā mettā byāpādassa, karuṇā vihiṃsāya, evamidaṃ jhānaṃ kāmarāgassa ujuvipaccanīkabhūtanti
analyzed: kāma bhavassa samatikkama paṭipadā abhāvato tena imassa jhānassa kāma pariññā bhāvam āha  kāma rāga paṭipakkhato ti vakkhamāna vibhāgassa kilesa kāmassa paccatthika bhāvato tena  yathā mettā byāpādassa karuṇā vihiṃsāya evam idam jhānam kāma rāgassa uju vipaccanīka bhūtanti
translated: because it is not a way of practice that surmounts sense-desire existence. So he says that this jhāna does not surmount sense desire.🔽Because it is the opposite of sense-desire lust: because it is the enemy of the defilement called sense-desire lust, which is going to be analysed. So he shows that this jhāna is the direct opponent of sense-desire lust,

original: dasseti. Evamattano pavattiyā, vipākappavattiyā ca kāmarāgato, kāmadhātuto ca vinivattasabhāvattā
analyzed: dasseti evam attanaḥ pavattiyā vipāka ppavattiyā ca kāma rāgataḥ kāmadhātutaḥ ca vinivatta sabhāva ttā
translated: like loving-kindness of ill will, and compassion of cruelty. And because it has the nature of turning away from sense desire both in its occurrence and in its result,

original: idaṃ jhānaṃ visesato kāmānameva nissaraṇaṃ. Svāyamattho pāṭhagato evāti āha “yathāhā”tiādi.
analyzed: idam jhānam visesataḥ kāmānam eva nissaraṇam eva ati āha yathā āha atiādi
translated: this jhāna is the specific outlet from sense desire. And the meaning is stated in the text itself, so he says “As it is said” .

original: Kāmañcetamatthaṃ dīpetuṃ purimapadeyeva avadhāraṇaṃ gahitaṃ, uttarapadepi pana taṃ
analyzed: dīpetum avadhāraṇam gahitam uttara pade pi pana tam
translated: But although the specification is made in the first phrase in order to illustrate that meaning, it should be taken as applying also to the second phrase,

original: gahetabbameva tathā atthasambhavatoti dassetuṃ “uttarapadepī”tiādi vuttaṃ. Itoti
analyzed: gahetabbam eva tathā attha sambhavato ti dassetum uttara pade pi itiādi vuttam itas ti
translated: because the meaning is there too. That is why “In the second phrase too” is said. From here:

original: kāmacchandato. Esa niyamo. Sādhāraṇavacanenāti avisesavacanena. Tadaṅgavikkhambhanasamucchedappaṭipassaddhinissaraṇavivekā🔽tadaṅgavivekādayo. Cittakāyaupadhivivekā cittavivekādayo. Tayo eva idha jhānakathāyaṃ
analyzed: kāma chandataḥ esa niyamaḥ sādhāraṇa vacanena ati avisesa vacanena tad aṅga vikkhambhana samuccheda paṭipassaddhi nissaraṇa vivekā  tad aṅga viveka ādayaḥ citta kāya opadhi vivekā citta viveka ādayaḥ
translated: “From sense desire” is the limitation. “By the words ‘in common’” means by the words without distinction. The three kinds of seclusion, namely, seclusion of the sense faculty, seclusion of the body, and seclusion of the mind, are the seclusion of the sense faculty, etc., the abandoning of the factors of sensual pleasure, the cutting off of the defilements, the surmounting of the hindrances, and the tranquilizing of the applied-thoughts.🔽The three kinds of seclusion, namely, seclusion of the sense faculty, seclusion of the body, and seclusion of the mind, are the seclusion of the sense faculty, etc., the abandoning of the factors of sensual pleasure, the cutting off of the defilements, the surmounting of the hindrances, and the tranquilizing of the applied-thoughts.🔽

original: daṭṭhabbā samucchedavivekādīnaṃ asambhavato.
analyzed: daṭṭhabbā samuccheda viveka ādīnam asambhavataḥ
translated: and from sensual desire. This is the restriction. By the words “in common” is meant by the words without distinction. The kinds of seclusion called “seclusion by surmounting” and so on are the kinds of seclusion called “seclusion by surmounting the jhāna factors” and so on. The kinds of seclusion called “seclusion of the mind” and so on are the three kinds of seclusion called “seclusion of the mind,” “seclusion of the body,” and “seclusion of the physical basis” .🔽These should be understood as the three kinds of seclusion in this Thread dealing with jhāna.

original: Niddeseti mahāniddese. Tattha hi “uddānato dve kāmā – vatthukāmā kilesakāmā cā”ti
analyzed: niddese ti mahāniddese tattha hi uddānataḥ dve kāmā vatthu kāmā kilesa kāmā ca ati
translated: In the Description is the Great Description . For there, after the summary verse has stated two kinds of sensual desires thus, “Sensual desires are twofold, that is to say, as objects and as defilement” ,

original: uddisitvā “tattha katame vatthukāmā? Manāpiyā rūpā…pe… manāpiyā phoṭṭhabbā”tiādinā
analyzed: uddisitvā tattha katame vatthu kāmāḥ manāpiyā rūpa āpe manāpiyā phoṭṭhabba ati ādinā
translated: the objects of sensual desire are described in the passage beginning, “What are the objects of sensual desire? They are pleasing visible objects … pleasing tangible objects” .

original: vatthukāmā niddiṭṭhā. Te pana kāmīyantīti kāmāti veditabbā. Tatthevāti niddese eva.🔽Vibhaṅgeti jhānavibhaṅge. Patthanākārena pavatto dubbalo lobho chandanaṭṭhena chando,
analyzed: vatthu kāmā niddiṭṭhā te pana kāmīyanti iti kāmā ati veditabbā tattha iva ati niddese eva  vibhaṅge iti jhāna vibhaṅge patthanā ākārena pavattaḥ dubbalaḥ lobho chandana ṭṭhena chando
translated: But they should be understood as sensual desires in the sense that one who is desirous goes desiringly .🔽In the Vibhaṅga is the Jhana Vibhaṅga . Desire is weak when it occurs in the form of aspiration. It is then desire in the sense of wishing .🔽It is stronger when it occurs in the form of longing. It is then sensual desire in the sense of relishing .

original: tato balavā rañjanaṭṭhena rāgo, tatopi balavataro bahalarāgo chandarāgo. Nimittānubyañjanāni
analyzed: tatas balavā rañjana ṭṭhena rāgo tatas api balavataraḥ bahala rāgo chanda rāgaḥ nimitta anubyañjanāni
translated: The sign and the particulars

original: saṅkappeti etenāti saṅkappo, tathāpavatto lobho, tato balavā rañjanaṭṭhena rāgo,🔽saṅkappanavaseneva pavatto tatopi balavataro saṅkapparāgoti. Svāyaṃ pabhedo ekasseva
analyzed: saṅkappeti etena ati saṅkappo tathā pavattaḥ lobho tatas balavā rañjana ṭṭhena rāgaḥ  saṅkappana vasena iva pavattaḥ tatas pi balavataraḥ saṅkappa rāgaḥ iti su ayam pabhedaḥ ekassa iva
translated: “It is a resolve because of that” is a greed that occurs thus; “lust” is stronger than that, in the sense of delighting; “lusting” is stronger than that, in the sense of occurrence by way of resolve.

original: lobhassa pavattiākāravasena, avatthābhedavasena ca veditabbo yathā “vaccho dammo
analyzed: lobhassa pavatti ākāra vasena avatthā bheda vasena ca veditabbaḥ yathā vacchaḥ dammaḥ
translated: This is the classification of greed itself, which should be understood as the mode of occurrence and the difference in the object. Just as “calf,” “ox,”🔽“bull,” and “ox for ploughing” are different modes of occurrence of one and the same ox. These are the defilement-lusts.

original: balībaddo”ti. Ime kilesakāmā. Kāmentīti kāmā, kāmenti etehīti vā.🔽Evañhi satīti evaṃ ubhayesampi kāmānaṃ saṅgahe sati. Vatthukāmehipīti “vatthukāmehi
analyzed: ime kilesa kāmā kāmenti iti kāmā kāmenti etehi iti vā  evam hi sati iti evam ubhayesam pi kāmānam saṅgahe sati vatthu kāmehi iti vatthu kāmehi
translated: “They cause to lust” is lust; “they cause to lust by means of these” is lust.

original: viviccevā”tipi attho yujjatīti evaṃ yujjamānatthantarasamuccayattho pi-saddo, na🔽kilesakāmasamuccayattho. Kasmā? Imasmiṃ atthe kilesakāmehi vivekassa dutiyapadena
analyzed: vivicca iva atipi atthaḥ yujjati iti evam yujjamāna ttha antara samuccaya tthaḥ pi saddaḥ na  kilesa kāma samuccaya atthaḥ kasmai imasmin atthe kilesa kāmehi vivekassa dutiya padena
translated: “Thus” means thus, when there is the inclusion of both kinds of lusts. “By means of the sense desires” means that the meaning “apart from the sense desires” is also appropriate. Thus the word “also” has the meaning of including the other meaning that is appropriate, not the meaning of including the defilement-lusts.

original: vuttattā. Tenāti vatthukāmavivekena. Kāyaviveko vutto hoti puttadārādipariggahavivekadīpanato.
analyzed: vutta ttā tena ati vatthu kāma vivekena kāya vivekaḥ vuttaḥ hoti putta dāra ādi pariggaha viveka dīpanato
translated: Why? Because in this meaning the second line states the separation from the defilement-lusts. “By that” means by the separation from the sense desires. The separation of the body is stated because it shows the separation from the possession of children, wife, and so on.

original: Purimenāti kāyavivekena. Etthāti “vivicceva kāmehi, vivicca akusalehi dhammehī”ti🔽etasmiṃ padadvaye, ito vā niddhārite vivekadvaye. Akusala-saddena yadipi kilesakāmā,🔽sabbākusalāpi vā gahitā, sabbathā pana kilesakāmehi viveko vuttoti āha “dutiyena🔽kilesakāmehi vivekavacanato”ti. Dutiyenāti ca cittavivekenāti attho. Etesanti yathāvuttānaṃ
analyzed: purimena ati kāya vivekena ettha ati vivicca iva kāmehi vivicca akusalehi dhammehi iti  etasmin pada dvaye itas vā niddhārite viveka dvaye yadi pi kilesa kāmā  sabba akusalā api vā gahitā sabbathā pana kilesa kāmehi vivekaḥ vuttaḥ ti āha dutiyena  kilesa kāmehi viveka vacanato ti dutiyena ati ca citta vivekena ati attho etesan ti yathā vuttānam
translated: “The former” is the seclusion of the body. “Here” is in the two terms “quite secluded from sense desires, secluded from unprofitable things.”🔽Although the word “unprofitable” includes sense desires as defilements,🔽or all unprofitable things, seclusion from sense desires as defilements is stated. That is why it is said, “Because of the statement of seclusion from sense desires as defilements in the second term.”🔽The second term is the seclusion of cognizance. “These” is a demonstrative pronoun referring to the two terms stated thus.

original: dvinnaṃ padānaṃ, niddhāraṇe cetaṃ sāmivacanaṃ. Taṇhādisaṃkilesānaṃ vatthuno pahānaṃ
analyzed: dvinnam padānam niddhāraṇe sāmi vacanam taṇhā ādi saṃkilesānam vatthuno pahānam
translated: The abandoning of the basis for defilement such as craving is

original: saṃkilesavatthuppahānaṃ. Lolabhāvo nāma tattha tattha rūpādīsu taṇhuppādo, tassa
analyzed: saṃkilesa vatthu ppahānam lola bhāvaḥ nāma tattha tattha rūpa ādīsu taṇhā uppādo tassa
translated: the abandoning of the basis for defilement. The state of being greedy is the arising of craving here and there for visible forms, etc.;

original: hetu vatthukāmā eva veditabbā. Bālabhāvo avijjā, duccintitacintitādi vā, tassa ayonisomanasikāro,
analyzed: hetu vatthu kāmāḥ eva veditabbāḥ bāla bhāvaḥ avijjā duccintita cintita ādi vā tassa a yoniso manasikāro
translated: the cause of that should be understood as sense desires as object. The state of being foolish is ignorance, or wrong reflection, etc.,

original: sabbepi vā akusalā dhammā hetu. Kāmaguṇādhigamahetupi pāṇātipātādiasuddhapayogo hotīti
analyzed: sabbe pi vā akusalāḥ dhammāḥ hetu kāma guṇa adhigama hetu pi pāṇātipāta ādi asuddha payogo hoti iti
translated: or all unprofitable things are the cause of that. And the unprofitable action of killing breathing things, etc., has as its cause the obtaining of the sense desires.

original: tabbivekena payogasuddhi vibhāvitā. Taṇhāsaṃkilesasodhanena, vivaṭṭūpanissayasaṃvaḍḍhanena
analyzed: tad bivekena payoga suddhi vibhāvitā taṇhā saṃkilesa sodhanena vivaṭṭu upanissaya saṃvaḍḍhanena
translated: and by the former, the purification of the means. By the purification of the defilement of craving, and by the increase of the support for the turning away from it,

original: ca ajjhāsayavisodhanaṃ āsayaposanaṃ. Kāmesūti niddhāraṇe bhummaṃ.
analyzed: ca ajjhāsaya visodhanam āsaya posanam kāmesu iti niddhāraṇe bhummam
translated: the purification of the inclination is the nourishing of the disposition. In the phrase “in the sense-pleasures” the word “sense-pleasures” is a locative.

original: Anekabhedoti kāmāsavakāmarāgasaṃyojanādivasena, rūpataṇhādivasena ca anekappabhedo.
analyzed: aneka bhedaḥ ti kāma āsava kāma rāga saṃyojana ādi vasena rūpa taṇhā ādi vasena ca aneka ppabhedaḥ
translated: “Of many kinds” means of many kinds such as the canker of sense-desire, the fetter of sense-desire, etc., and the craving for the material, etc.

original: Kāmacchandoyevāti kāmasabhāvoyeva chando, na kattukamyatāchando, nāpi kusalacchandoti
analyzed: kāma chandoyā iva ati chandaḥ na kattu kamyatā chandaḥ na api kusala chandaḥ iti
translated: “Sense-desire itself” is the desire that has the nature of sense-desire, not the desire to do, nor the desire for the wholesome.

original: adhippāyo. Jhānapaṭipakkhatoti jhānassa paṭipakkhabhāvato taṃhetu tannimittaṃ visuṃ
analyzed: adhippāyaḥ jhāna paṭipakkhato ti jhānassa paṭipakkha bhāvataḥ tad hetu tad nimittam visum
translated: This is the purport. “The opposite of jhana” is stated separately because it is the opposite of jhana, and for that reason and for that cause it is stated separately

original: vutto. Akusalabhāvasāmaññena aggahetvā visuṃ sarūpena gahito. Yadi kilesakāmova purimapade
analyzed: vuttaḥ akusala bhāva sāmaññena aggahetvā visum sarūpena gahitaḥ yadi purima pade
translated: without being included in the unwholesome. If sense-desire is stated in the first place as a defilement,

original: vutto, kathaṃ bahuvacananti āha “anekabhedato”tiādi.
analyzed: katham bahuvacanan ti āha aneka bhedataḥ tiādi
translated: how is it stated in the plural? He says “of many kinds,” etc.

original: Aññesampi diṭṭhimānaahirikānottappādīnaṃ, taṃsahitaphassādīnañca. Upari vuccamānāni
analyzed: aññesam pi diṭṭhi māna ahirika anottappa ādīnam tad sahita phassa ādīnam ca upari vuccamānāni
translated: and also of the other things associated with it such as the false view of individuality, conceit, lack of shame, lack of fear of wrongdoing, etc., and contact, etc.🔽The following is stated.

original: jhānaṅgāni uparijhānaṅgāni, tesaṃ attano paccanīkānaṃ paṭipakkhabhāvadassanato tappaccanīkanīvaraṇavacanaṃ.🔽Nīvaraṇāni hi jhānaṅgapaccanīkāni tesaṃ pavattinivāraṇato. Samādhi kāmacchandassa🔽paṭipakkho rāgappaṇidhiyā ujuvipaccanīkabhāvato, nānārammaṇehi palobhitassa paribbhamantassa
analyzed: jhāna aṅgāni upari jhāna aṅgāni tesam attanaḥ paccanīkānam paṭipakkha bhāva dassanato tad paccanīka nīvaraṇa vacanam  nīvaraṇāni hi jhāna aṅga paccanīkāni tesam pavatti nivāraṇato samādhi kāmacchandassa  paṭipakkhaḥ rāga ppaṇidhiyā uju vipaccanīka bhāvataḥ nānā ārammaṇehi palobhitassa paribbhamantassa
translated: The jhāna factors are the higher jhāna factors. The words “the hindrances that are their opposites” are said because they show the opposite, the incompatible, of those.🔽For the hindrances are incompatible with the jhāna factors because they prevent their occurrence. Concentration is the opposite of lust because it is the direct incompatible of greed for sense desires.

original: cittassa samādhānato ca. Pīti byāpādassa paṭipakkhā pāmojjena samānayogakkhemattā.🔽Vitakko thinamiddhassa paṭipakkho yoniso saṅkappanavasena savipphārapavattito. Sukhaṃ
analyzed: cittassa samādhānato ca pīti byāpādassa paṭipakkhā pāmojjena samāna yogakkhema ttā  vitakkaḥ thinamiddhassa paṭipakkhaḥ yonisas saṅkappana vasena sa vipphāra pavattito sukham
translated: And because it concentrates the mind that is being dragged hither and thither by the various sense objects. Happiness is the opposite of ill will because it is the direct opposite of the wish for injury.

original: avūpasamānutāpasabhāvassa uddhaccakukkuccassa paṭipakkhaṃ vūpasantasītalasabhāvattā.
analyzed: a vūpasama anutāpa sabhāvassa uddhacca kukkuccassa paṭipakkham vūpasanta sītala sabhāva ttā
translated: Rapture is the opposite of stiffness and torpor because it is the opposite of unwieldiness, which is characterized by lack of keenness and by flabbiness. Bliss is the opposite of restlessness and worry because it is characterized by peace and by coolness.

original: Vicāro vicikicchāya paṭipakkho ārammaṇe anumajjanavasena paññāpaṭirūpasabhāvattā.
analyzed: vicāraḥ vicikicchāya paṭipakkhaḥ ārammaṇe anumajjana vasena paññā paṭirūpa sabhāva ttā
translated: Applied thought is the opposite of uncertainty because it is the opposite of the unwieldiness due to the occurrence of the various kinds of indecision about the object.

original: Mahākaccānattherena desitaṃ piṭakānaṃ saṃvaṇṇanā peṭakaṃ, tasmiṃ peṭake.
analyzed: mahākaccāna therena desitam piṭakānam saṃvaṇṇanā peṭakam tasmim peṭake
translated: The Basket is the commentary on the three Piṭakas taught by the Elder Mahākaccāna. In that Basket.

original: Pañcakāmaguṇabhedavisayassāti rūpādipañcakāmaguṇavisesavisayassa. Āghātavatthubhedādivisayānanti
analyzed: pañca kāmaguṇa bheda visayassa ati rūpa ādi pañca kāmaguṇa visesa visayassa
translated: “With the five strands of sense pleasure as its object” means with the particular five strands of sense pleasure as its object. “With the various grounds for annoyance as its object” means with the various grounds for annoyance such as ill will,🔽which has the form of “He has done me harm,” etc., as its object.

original: byāpādavivekavacanena “anatthaṃ me acarī”ti ādiāghātavatthubhedavisayassa dosassa,
analyzed: byāpāda viveka vacanena anattham me acari iti ādi āghāta vatthu bheda visayassa dosassa
translated: “With the various grounds for annoyance as its object” means with the various grounds for annoyance such as ill will,🔽which has the form of “He has done me harm,” etc., as its object.🔽“With the various grounds for annoyance as its object” means with the various grounds for annoyance such as ill will,🔽which has the form of “He has done me harm,” etc., as its object.

original: mohādhikehi thinamiddhādīhi vivekavacanena paṭicchādanavasena dukkhādipubbantādibhedavisayassa
analyzed: moha adhikehi thinam iddha ādīhi viveka vacanena paṭicchādana vasena dukkha ādi pubbanta ādi bheda visayassa
translated: “With the various grounds for annoyance as its object” means with the various grounds for annoyance such as ill will,🔽which has the form of “He has done me harm,” etc., as its object.🔽“With the various grounds for annoyance as its object” means with the various grounds for annoyance such as ill will,🔽which has the form of “He has done me harm,” etc., as its object.

original: mohassa vikkhambhanaviveko vutto. Kāmarāgabyāpādatadekaṭṭhathinamiddhādivikkhambhakañcetaṃ
analyzed: mohassa vikkhambhana vivekaḥ vutto kāma rāga byāpāda tad eka ṭṭhathina middha ādi vikkhambhakam ca etat
translated: “With the various grounds for annoyance as its object” means with the various grounds for annoyance such as ill will,🔽which has the form of “He has done me harm,” etc., as its object.

original: sabbākusalapaṭipakkhasabhāvattā. Sabbakusalānaṃ tena sabhāvena sabbākusalappahāyakaṃ
analyzed: sabba akusala paṭipakkha sabhāva ttā sabba kusalānam tena sabhāvena sabba akusala ppahāyakam
translated: “With the various grounds for annoyance as its object” means with the various grounds for annoyance such as ill will,🔽which has the form of “He has done me harm,” etc., as its object.🔽“With the various grounds for annoyance as its object” means with the various grounds for annoyance such as ill will,🔽which has the form of “He has done me harm,” etc., as its object.

original: hoti, hontampi kāmarāgādivikkhambhanasabhāvameva hoti taṃsabhāvattāti avisesetvā
analyzed: hoti hontam pi kāma rāga ādi vikkhambhana sabhāvam eva hoti tad sabhāva ttā ati a visesetvā
translated: “With the various grounds for annoyance as its object” means with the various grounds for annoyance such as ill will,

original: nīvaraṇākusalamūlādīnaṃ “vikkhambhanaviveko vutto hotī”ti āha.
analyzed: nīvaraṇa akusala mūla ādīnam vikkhambhana vivekaḥ vuttaḥ hoti iti āha
translated: which has the form of “He has done me harm,” etc., as its object.🔽“With the various grounds for annoyance as its object” means with the various grounds for annoyance such as ill will,🔽which has the form of “He has done me harm,” etc., as its object.🔽“With the various grounds for annoyance as its object” means with the various grounds for annoyance such as ill will,🔽which has the form of “He has done me harm,” etc., as its object.

original: 71. Yathāpaccayaṃ pavattamānānaṃ sabhāvadhammānaṃ natthi kāci vasavattitāti vasavattibhāvanivāraṇatthaṃ
analyzed: yathāpaccayam pavattamānānam sabhāva dhammānam na atthi kāci vasa vatti tā ati vasa vatti bhāva nivāraṇa attham
translated: “With the various grounds for annoyance as its object” means with the

original: “vitakkanaṃ vitakko”ti vuttaṃ. Tayidaṃ “vitakkanaṃ īdisamida”nti ārammaṇassa parikappananti
analyzed: vitakkanam vitakko ti vuttam tayidam vitakkanam īdisam idam ti ārammaṇassa parikappananti
translated: “Thinking is what is meant by thinking,”🔽and this is the surmising of an object in this way.🔽Hence he said, “It is said to be the stirring up of the mind.”

original: āha “ūhananti vuttaṃ hotī”ti. Yasmā cittaṃ vitakkabalena ārammaṇaṃ abhiniruḷhaṃ viya
analyzed: āha ūhanam ti vuttam hoti iti yasmā cittam vitakka balena ārammaṇam abhiniruḷham viya
translated: Since the mind is as if fixed on the object by the force of thinking,

original: hoti, tasmā so ārammaṇābhiniropanalakkhaṇo vutto. Yathā hi koci rājavallabhaṃ, taṃsambandhinaṃ
analyzed: hoti tasmā saḥ ārammaṇa abhiniropana lakkhaṇaḥ vuttaḥ yathā hi koci rājavallabham tad sambandhinam
translated: it is said to have the characteristic of fixing on an object.

original: mittaṃ vā nissāya rājagehaṃ ārohati anupavisati, evaṃ vitakkaṃ nissāya cittaṃ ārammaṇaṃ
analyzed: mittam vā nissāya rāja geham ārohati anupavisati evam vitakkam nissāya cittam ārammaṇam
translated: Just as a man climbs up to a royal palace and enters it by depending on a royal favourite or a friend of his,🔽so too the mind climbs up to the object and enters it by depending on thinking.🔽If that is so, how does a thought-free mind climb up to the object?

original: ārohati. Yadi evaṃ, kathaṃ avitakkaṃ cittaṃ ārammaṇaṃ ārohatīti? Vitakkabaleneva.🔽Yathā hi so puriso paricayena tena vināpi nirāsaṅko rājagehaṃ pavisati, evaṃ paricayena
analyzed: ārohati yadi evam katham avitakkam cittam ārammaṇam ārohati iti vitakka balena iva  yathā hi saḥ purisaḥ paricayena tena vinā api nirāsaṅkaḥ rāja geham pavisati evam paricayena
translated: It does so by the force of thinking.

original: vitakkena vināpi avitakkaṃ cittaṃ ārammaṇaṃ ārohati. Paricayenāti ca santāne pavattavitakkabhāvanāsaṅkhātena
analyzed: vitakkena vinā api avitakkam cittam ārammaṇam ārohati paricayena ati ca santāne pavatta vitakka bhāvanā saṅkhātena
translated: Just as the man, being familiar with it, enters the royal palace without hesitation even without the other, so too the thought-free mind climbs up to the object by the force of thinking, which is familiar with it.🔽By the force of thinking is what is meant.

original: paricayena. Vitakkassa hi santāne abhiṇhaṃ pavattassa vasena cittassa ārammaṇābhiruhaṇaṃ🔽ciraparicitaṃ. Tena taṃ kadāci vitakkena vināpi tattha pavattateva. Yathā taṃ ñāṇasahitaṃ🔽hutvā sammasanavasena ciraparicitaṃ kadāci ñāṇavirahitampi sammasanavasena pavattati,
analyzed: paricayena vitakkassa hi santāne abhiṇham pavattassa vasena cittassa ārammaṇa abhiruhaṇam  cira paricitam tena tam kadācid vitakkena vinā api tattha pavattatā iva yathā tam ñāṇa sahitam  hutvā sammasana vasena cira paricitam kadāci ñāṇa virahitam pi sammasana vasena pavattati
translated: By repetition. For the mind’s repeated occurrence in the sign’s aspect by the force of the repeated occurrence of applied thought is called “long-practised.”🔽Therefore it sometimes occurs there even without applied thought, as does knowledge accompanied by applied thought.🔽Or just as, when it has occurred accompanied by defilements, it sometimes occurs even without knowledge, by the force of repetition, by the habit of defilements,

original: yathā vā kilesasahitaṃ hutvā pavattaṃ sabbaso kilesarahitampi paricayena kilesavāsanāvasena🔽pavattati, evaṃsampadamidaṃ daṭṭhabbaṃ. Ādito, abhimukhaṃ vā hananaṃ āhananaṃ. Parito,
analyzed: yathā vā kilesa sahitam hutvā pavattam sabbaso kilesa rahitam pi paricayena kilesa vāsanā vasena  pavattati evaṃsampadam idam daṭṭhabbam āditas abhimukham vā hananam āhananam paritas
translated: so too this should be regarded. Striking is the repeated occurrence of the consciousnesses in the sign by the force of the repeated occurrence of applied thought.

original: parivattetvā vā āhananaṃ pariyāhananaṃ. “Rūpaṃ rūpaṃ, pathavī pathavī”ti ākoṭentassa
analyzed: parivattetvā vā āhananam pariyāhananam rūpam rūpam pathavī pathavī iti ākoṭentassa
translated: It is like the occurrence of one who is striking at a post or a stump, thinking, “Wood, wood,” or like the occurrence of one who is striking at a rock, thinking, “Stone, stone.”

original: viya pavatti “āhananaṃ, pariyāhanana”nti ca veditabbaṃ. Ānayanaṃ cittassa ārammaṇe
analyzed: viya pavatti āhananam pariyāhanananti ca veditabbam ānayanam cittassa ārammaṇe
translated: Striking and striking again is the occurrence of the consciousnesses in the sign by the force of the repeated occurrence of sustained thought.🔽It is like the occurrence of one who is striking at a post or a stump, thinking, “Wood, wood,” or like the occurrence of one who is striking at a rock, thinking, “Stone, stone.”

original: upanayanaṃ, ākaḍḍhanaṃ vā.
analyzed: upanayanam ākaḍḍhanam vā
translated: Bringing is the bringing of the mind on to the object, or the dragging of the object on to the mind.

original: Anusañcaraṇaṃ anuparibbhamanaṃ. Svāyaṃ viseso santānamhi labbhamāno eva santāne pākaṭo
analyzed: anusañcaraṇam anuparibbhamanam su ayam viseso santānamhi labbhamānaḥ eva santāne pākaṭaḥ
translated: “Wandering” is wandering about. This difference, which is found in the continuity, is evident in the continuity itself.

original: hotīti daṭṭhabbo. Sesesupi eseva nayo. Anumajjanaṃ ārammaṇe cittassa anumasanaṃ,🔽parimajjananti attho. Tathā hi vicāro “parimajjanahattho viya, sañcaraṇahattho viyā”ti
analyzed: hoti iti daṭṭhabbo sesesu pi esa eva nayaḥ anumajjanam ārammaṇe cittassa anumasanam  parimajjananti attho tathā hi vicāraḥ parimajjana hatthaḥ viya sañcaraṇa hatthaḥ viya ati
translated: It should be regarded thus. The same method applies in the other cases. “Roaming” is the mind’s roaming about in the object;🔽the meaning is, “wandering about.” For thus it is said: “applied thought is like a hand for wandering about, like a hand for roaming about” .

original: ca vutto. Tatthāti ārammaṇe. Sahajātānaṃ anuyojanaṃ ārammaṇe anuvicāraṇasaṅkhātaanumajjanavaseneva
analyzed: ca vuttaḥ tattha ati ārammaṇe sahajātānam anuyojanam ārammaṇe anuvicāraṇa saṅkhāta anumajjana vasena iva
translated: “There” in the object. “Linking up” should be understood as the mind’s linking up of associated states in the object by means of the roaming about called sustained thought.

original: veditabbaṃ. Anuppabandhanaṃ ārammaṇe cittassa avicchinnassa viya pavatti. Tathā hi
analyzed: veditabbam anuppabandhanam ārammaṇe cittassa avicchinnassa viya pavatti tathā hi
translated: “Bonding” is the mind’s occurrence in the object as if uninterruptedly. For thus

original: so “anusandhānatā”ti niddiṭṭho. Teneva ca “ghaṇḍānuravo viya, paribbhamanaṃ viyā”ti ca vutto.
analyzed: saḥ anusandhāna tā iti niddiṭṭhaḥ tena iva ca ghaṇḍa anuravaḥ viya paribbhamanam viya iti ca vutto
translated: it is described as “continuity.” And it is said: “like the sound of a drum, like wandering about” .

original: Katthacīti paṭhamajjhāne, parittacittuppādesu ca. Vicārato oḷārikaṭṭhena, vicārasseva
analyzed: katthaci iti paṭhama jhāne paritta cittuppādesu ca vicārataḥ oḷārika ṭṭhena vicārassa iva
translated: “Somewhere” in the first jhāna and in the limited consciousness.🔽It is only applied thought that is called “gross” in the sense of grossness.

original: ca pubbaṅgamaṭṭhena anuravato oḷāriko, tassa ca pubbaṅgamo ghaṇḍābhighāto viya vitakko.🔽Yathā hi ghaṇḍābhighāto paṭhamābhinipāto hoti, evaṃ ārammaṇābhimukhaniropanaṭṭhena
analyzed: ca pubbaṅgama ṭṭhena anuravataḥ oḷārikaḥ tassa ca pubbaṅgamaḥ ghaṇḍa abhighātaḥ viya vitakko  yathā hi ghaṇḍa abhighāto paṭhama abhinipātaḥ hoti evam ārammaṇa abhimukha niropana ṭṭhena
translated: And applied thought is gross in the sense of being the forerunner of the two, and sustained thought is gross in the sense of being its successor, like the stroke of a hammer and the sound of the bell.🔽For just as the stroke of a hammer is the first impact, so applied thought is the first impact of the mind on the object.🔽And by the word “stroke” here the sound produced by the stroke is also included.🔽It is “vibrant” because it is associated with vibration, which is like the reverberation.

original: vitakko cetaso paṭhamābhinipāto hoti. Abhighāta-ggahaṇena cettha abhighātajo saddo
analyzed: vitakko cetasaḥ paṭhama abhinipātaḥ hoti abhighāta ggahaṇena ca ittha abhighāta jo saddo
translated: It is “vibrant” because it is associated with vibration, which is like the reverberation.🔽It is “vibrant” because it is associated with vibration, which is like the reverberation.🔽It is “vibrant” because it is associated with vibration, which is like the reverberation.

original: gahitoti veditabbo. Vipphāravāti vicalanayutto saparipphando. Paribbhamanaṃ viya
analyzed: gahito ti veditabbo vipphāravā ati vicalana yutto sa paripphandaḥ paribbhamanam viya
translated: It is “vibrant” because it is associated with vibration, which is like the reverberation.🔽It is “vibrant” because it is associated with vibration, which is like the reverberation.

original: parissayābhāvavīmaṃsanatthaṃ. Anuppabandhena pavattiyanti upacāre vā appanāyaṃ vā
analyzed: parissaya abhāva vīmaṃsana attham an uppabandhena pavattiyanti upacāre vā appanāyam vā
translated: It is “vibrant” because it is associated with vibration, which is like the reverberation.🔽It is “vibrant” because it is associated with vibration, which is like the reverberation.🔽It is “vibrant” because it is associated with vibration, which is like the reverberation.🔽It is “vibrant” because it is associated with vibration, which is like the reverberation.

original: santānena pavattiyaṃ. Tattha hi vitakko niccalo hutvā ārammaṇaṃ anupavisitvā viya
analyzed: santānena pavattiyam tattha hi vitakkaḥ niccalaḥ hutvā ārammaṇam anupavisitvā viya
translated: It is “vibrant” because it is associated with vibration, which is like the reverberation.🔽It is “vibrant” because it is associated with vibration, which is like the reverberation.🔽It is “vibrant” because it is associated with vibration, which is like the reverberation.

original: pavattati, na paṭhamābhinipāte. Pākaṭo hotīti vitakkassa viseso abhiniropanākāro🔽oḷārikattā paṭhamajjhāne pākaṭo hoti, tadabhāvato pañcakanaye dutiyajjhāne vicārassa
analyzed: pavattati na paṭhama abhinipāte pākaṭaḥ hoti iti vitakkassa visesaḥ abhiniropana ākāraḥ  oḷārika ttā paṭhama jjhāne pākaṭaḥ hoti tad abhāvato pañcaka naye dutiya jjhāne vicārassa
translated: It is “vibrant” because it is associated with vibration, which is like the reverberation.🔽It is “vibrant” because it is associated with vibration, which is like the reverberation.🔽It is “vibrant” because it is associated with vibration, which is like the reverberation.🔽It is “vibrant” because it is associated with vibration, which is like the reverberation.🔽It is “vibrant” because it is associated with vibration, which is like the reverberation.🔽It is “vibrant” because it is associated with vibration, which is like the reverberation.

original: viseso anumajjanākāro pākaṭo hoti.
analyzed: visesaḥ anumajjana ākāraḥ pākaṭaḥ hoti
translated: It is “vibrant” because it is associated with vibration, which is like the reverberation.🔽It is

original: Vālaṇḍupakaṃ eḷakalomādīhi katacumbaṭakaṃ. Uppīḷanahatthoti piṇḍassa uppīḷanahattho.
analyzed: vālaṇḍupakam eḷaka loma ādīhi kata cumbaṭakam uppīḷana hattho ti piṇḍassa uppīḷana hattho
translated: A ‘hair-blanket’ is a mattress made of goat’s hair, etc. ‘A hand for turning up the soil’ is a hand for turning up the soil.

original: Tasseva ito cito ca sañcaraṇahattho. Maṇḍalanti kaṃsabhājanādīsu kiñci maṇḍalaṃ vaṭṭalekhaṃ🔽karontassa. Yathā pupphaphalasākhādiavayavavinimutto avijjamānopi rukkho “sapuppho🔽saphalo”ti voharīyati, evaṃ vitakkādiaṅgavinimuttaṃ avijjamānampi jhānaṃ “savitakkaṃ
analyzed: tassa iva itas citas ca sañcaraṇa hatthaḥ maṇḍalanti kaṃsa bhājana ādīsu kiñci maṇḍalam vaṭṭa lekham  karontassa yathā puppha phala sākhā ādi avayava vinimuttaḥ a vijjamānaḥ api rukkhaḥ sa pupphaḥ  evam vitakka ādi aṅga vinimuttam avijjamānam pi jhānam sa vitakkam
translated: ‘A hand for moving it about’ is a hand for moving it about here and there. ‘A circle’ is a circle, a ring, that he makes on dishes of metal, etc.

original: savicāra”nti voharīyatīti dassetuṃ “rukkho viyā”tiādi vuttaṃ. Jhānabhāvanāya puggalavasena
analyzed: sa vicāranti voharīyati iti dassetum rukkhaḥ viya iti ādi vuttam jhāna bhāvanāya puggala vasena
translated: Just as a tree, though devoid of parts such as flowers, fruits, branches, etc., and not existing as such, is nevertheless spoken of as ‘with flowers’ or ‘with fruits,’ so too, jhāna, though devoid of the factors of applied thought, etc., and not existing as such, is nevertheless spoken of as ‘with applied thought’ and ‘with sustained thought.’ The words ‘as does a tree’ are stated in order to illustrate this.

original: desetabbattā “idha bhikkhu vivicceva kāmehī”tiādinā puggalādhiṭṭhānena jhānāni uddiṭṭhānīti.🔽Yadipi vibhaṅge puggalādhiṭṭhānā desanā katā, attho pana tatrāpi vibhaṅgepi yathā
analyzed: desetabba ttā idha bhikkhu vivicca iva kāmehi itiādinā puggala adhiṭṭhānena jhānāni uddiṭṭhāni iti  yadi api vibhaṅge puggala adhiṭṭhānā desanā katā attho pana tatra api vibhaṅge pi yathā
translated: The jhānas are stated with reference to a person in the way beginning, ‘Quite secluded from sense desires, secluded from unprofitable things’ , because they should be taught with reference to a person by one who is himself developing the jhāna.

original: idha “iminā ca vitakkenā”tiādinā dhammavasena vutto, evameva daṭṭhabbo, paramatthato
analyzed: idha iminā ca vitakkena ati ādinā dhamma vasena vuttaḥ evam eva daṭṭhabbo paramatthato
translated: Although the teaching is given with reference to a person in the Vibhaṅga, nevertheless the meaning there should be regarded as being just as stated here in the way beginning, ‘With the abandoning of pleasure and pain’ .

original: puggalasseva abhāvatoti adhippāyo. Attho…pe… daṭṭhabbo jhānasamaṅgino vitakkavicārasamaṅgitādassanena,
analyzed: puggalassa iva abhāvato ti adhippāyaḥ daṭṭhabbo jhāna samaṅginaḥ vitakka vicāra samaṅgi tā dassanena
translated: The intention is that there is no such person at all.

original: jhānasseva ca savitakkasavicāratāya vuttattāti evaṃ vā ettha attho daṭṭhabbo.
analyzed: jhānassa iva ca sa vitakka sa vicāra tāya vuttattā ati evam vā ettha atthaḥ daṭṭhabbo
translated: The meaning should be regarded as stated in the way beginning, “Because of the seeing of applied thought and sustained thought in one possessing jhāna” and ending, “Because jhāna is said to be with applied thought and sustained thought.”🔽The meaning should be regarded in this way.

original: Vivekāti vivekā hetubhūtāti viveka-saddassa bhāvasādhanataṃ sandhāyāha. Viveketi🔽kattusādhanataṃ, kammasādhanataṃ vā. “Vivitto”ti hi iminā nīvaraṇehi vinābhūto tehi🔽vivecitoti ca sādhanadvayampi saṅgahitamevāti.
analyzed: vivekā ati vivekā hetu bhūtā ati viveka saddassa bhāva sādhanatam sandhāya āha viveka iti  kattu sādhana tam kamma sādhana tam vā hi iminā nīvaraṇehi tehi  ca sādhana dvayam pi saṅgahitam evā ati
translated: “The cause of seclusion”: the cause of seclusion is the meaning of the word “seclusion.”🔽The meaning of the word “seclusion” is the meaning of the word “seclusion.”

original: 72. Pīṇayatīti tappeti, vaḍḍheti vā. Sampiyāyanalakkhaṇāti paritussanalakkhaṇā. Pīṇanarasāti
analyzed: pīṇayati iti tappeti vaḍḍheti vā sampiyāyana lakkhaṇā ati paritussana lakkhaṇā pīṇana rasā ati
translated: “It refreshes”: it refreshes, it increases.🔽The characteristic of confidence is confidence-inspiring.🔽The function is to remove depression.🔽It is manifested as elation.🔽The characteristic of happiness is the experience of pleasure.🔽The function is to refresh the body.

original: paribrūhanarasā. Pharaṇarasāti paṇītarūpehi kāyassa byāpanarasā. Udaggabhāvo odagyaṃ.🔽Khuddikā lahuṃ lomahaṃsanamattaṃ katvā bhinnā na puna uppajjati. Khaṇikā bahulaṃ
analyzed: paribrūhana rasā pharaṇa rasā ati paṇīta rūpehi kāyassa udagga bhāvaḥ odagyam 🔽khuddikā lahum loma haṃsana mattam katvā bhinnā na punar uppajjati khaṇikā bahulam
translated: It is manifested as bodily suppleness.

original: uppajjati. Ubbegato pharaṇā niccalattā, ciraṭṭhitikattā ca paṇītatarā. Cetiyaṅgaṇaṃ
analyzed: uppajjati ubbegataḥ pharaṇā niccala ttā ciraṭṭhitika ttā ca paṇītatarā cetiyaṅgaṇam
translated: It is more excellent because it arises in a more excellent object, because it is more steady, and because it lasts longer.

original: gantvāti puṇṇavallikavihāre cetiyaṅgaṇaṃ gantvā. Pakatiyā diṭṭhārammaṇavasenāti pubbe
analyzed: gantvā iti puṇṇavallika vihāre cetiya ṅgaṇam gantvā pakatiyā diṭṭha ārammaṇa vasena ati pubbe
translated: Having gone to the shrine enclosure: having gone to the shrine enclosure of the Puṇṇavallikā Monastery.🔽By means of a familiar object: by means of an object that had been apprehended previously.

original: mahācetiyaṃ gahitārammaṇavasena. Citrageṇḍuko vicitrākārena katageṇḍuko. Upanissayeti
analyzed: mahā cetiyam gahita ārammaṇa vasena citra geṇḍukaḥ vicitra ākārena kata geṇḍukaḥ upanissayā iti
translated: A variegated cloth: a cloth of variegated design.

original: samīpe, tassa vā vihārassa nissayabhūte, gocaraṭṭhānabhūteti attho.
analyzed: samīpe tassa vā vihārassa nissaya bhūte gocara ṭṭhāna bhūtā iti attho
translated: In the vicinity: in the vicinity of that monastery, in the place where it is situated.

original: Gharājireti gehaṅgaṇe. Pabbatasikhare katacetiyaṃ “ākāsacetiya”nti vuttaṃ. Gahitanimittenevāti
analyzed: ghara ajira iti gehaṅgaṇe pabbata sikhare kata cetiyam ākāsa cetiyanti vuttam gahita nimittena iva ati
translated: In the courtyard: in the courtyard of the house. The shrine built on the top of the mountain peak is called “the shrine in the sky.”

original: cetiyavandanaṃ, dhammassavanañca uddissa “dhaññā vatime”tiādinā gahitakusalanimitteneva
analyzed: cetiya vandanam dhammassavanañca uddissa dhaññā vatimā iti ādinā gahita kusala nimittena iva
translated: By means of a familiar sign: by means of a sign of wholesome kamma that is familiar, such as “May I be endowed with wealth,” etc.,🔽which is the reason for going to the shrine and listening to the Dhamma.

original: kāraṇabhūtena. Gahitaṃ vā nimittaṃ etenāti gahitanimittaṃ, vuttākārena pavattacittaṃ,
analyzed: kāraṇa bhūtena gahitam vā nimittam etena ati gahita nimittam vutta ākārena pavatta cittam
translated: Or else: that by which a sign is apprehended is the familiar sign. The consciousness that occurs in the way described🔽goes together with the consciousness that is accompanied by the familiar sign.

original: tena gahitanimitteneva cittena saha. Pakkhandanti anupaviṭṭhaṃ. Anuparipphuṭanti
analyzed: tena gahita nimittena iva cittena saha pakkhandanti anupaviṭṭham anuparipphuṭanti
translated: It is “settled down” when it is not agitated.

original: anu anu samantato phuṭaṃ, sabbaso anuvisaṭanti attho.🔽Passaddhiyā nimittabhāvena gabbhaṃ gaṇhantī. Paripācanavasena paripākaṃ gacchantī.
analyzed: anu anu samantataḥ phuṭam sabbasas attho  passaddhiyāḥ nimitta bhāvena gabbham gaṇhantī paripācana vasena paripākam gacchantī
translated: It is pervaded by it, is the meaning.🔽It conceives the sign of tranquillity. It reaches maturity by way of ripening.

original: Appanāsampayuttāva pīti appanāsamādhipūrikā. Khaṇikasamādhipūrikā ca upacārasamādhipūrikā
analyzed: pi iti appanā samādhi pūrikā khaṇika samādhi pūrikā ca upacāra samādhi pūrikā
translated: The happiness associated with absorption is a fulfiller of absorption in the sense of absorption in the attainment of the fine-material sphere. And that associated with access is a fulfiller of absorption in the sense of momentary absorption.

original: ca appanāsamādhissa vidūratarāti tadubhayaṃ anāmasanto “tāsu yā appanāsamādhissā”tiādimāha.
analyzed: ca appanā samādhissa vidūratarā ti tat ubhayam an āmasantaḥ tāsu yā appanā samādhissa ati ādim āha
translated: Since the latter two are further removed from absorption in the attainment of the fine-material sphere, he does not mention them, but he says, “Among them, that which is a fulfiller of absorption in the attainment of the fine-material sphere is the happiness associated with absorption.”

original: Samādhisampayogaṃ gatāti pubbe upacārasamādhinā sampayuttā hutvā anukkamena vaḍḍhitvā
analyzed: samādhi sampayogam gatā ati pubbe upacāra samādhinā sampayuttā hutvā anukkamena vaḍḍhitvā
translated: It has come to association with concentration: having previously been associated with access concentration, it has gradually increased

original: appanāsamādhinā sampayogaṃ gatā.
analyzed: appanā samādhinā sampayogam gatā
translated: and come to association with absorption concentration.

original: 73. Sukhayatīti sukhaṃ, attanā sampayuttadhamme laddhassāde karotīti attho. Svāyaṃ
analyzed: sukhayati iti sukham attanā sampayutta dhamme laddha ssāde karoti iti
translated: It makes glad , thus it is happiness . The meaning is that it makes the states associated with itself glad by bestowing satisfaction. This🔽is a verbal noun formed by adding the suffix -ana to the gerundive of the🔽verb sukhayati . But the verbal noun is taken in the sense of the action of the🔽agent, which is excluded by the word anya in the rule “A verbal noun

original: kattuniddeso pariyāyaladdho dhammato aññassa kattu nivattanattho, nippariyāyena pana
analyzed: kattu niddesaḥ pariyāya laddhaḥ dhammataḥ aññassa kattu nivattana atthaḥ nippariyāyena pana
translated: takes the suffix -ana when the agent is excluded” . However, it is only the🔽meaning of the verbal noun that is excluded, not the meaning of the verbal🔽adjective. Therefore it is said, “The word sukha is a verbal adjective” . It makes

original: bhāvasādhanameva labbhatīti “sukhanaṃ sukha”nti vuttaṃ. Iṭṭhasabhāvattā taṃsamaṅgīpuggalaṃ,
analyzed: bhāva sādhanam eva labbhati iti sukhanam sukham ti vuttam iṭṭha sabhāva ttā tad samaṅgī puggalam
translated: glad the person who possesses it, because it has the nature of being desirable.

original: sampayuttadhamme vā attani sādayatīti sātaṃ da-kārassa ta-kāraṃ katvā. Sātaṃ “madhura”nti🔽vadanti. Sātaṃ lakkhaṇaṃ etassāti sātalakkhaṇaṃ. Upabrūhanaṃ sampayuttadhammānaṃ🔽saṃvaḍḍhanaṃ. Dukkhaṃ viya avissajjetvā adukkhamasukhā viya anajjhupekkhitvā anu🔽anu gaṇhanaṃ, upakāritā vā anuggaho. Katthaci paṭhamajjhānādike. Paṭilābhatuṭṭhīti🔽paṭilābhavasena uppajjanakatuṭṭhi. Paṭiladdharasānubhavananti paṭiladdhassa ārammaṇarasassa🔽anubhavananti sabhāvato pītisukhāni vibhajitvā dasseti. Yattha pīti, tattha sukhanti🔽vitakkassa viya itarena pītiyā sukhena accantasaṃyogamāha. “Yattha sukhaṃ, tattha
analyzed: sampayutta dhamme vā attani sādayati iti sātam dakārassa takāram katvā sātam madhuranti  vadanti sātam lakkhaṇam etassa ati sāta lakkhaṇam upabrūhanam sampayutta dhammānam  saṃvaḍḍhanam dukkham viya a vissajjetvā adukkham asukhāḥ viya an ajjhupekkhitvā anu  anu gaṇhanam upakāri tā vā anuggahaḥ katthaci paṭhamajjhāna ādike paṭilābha tuṭṭhi iti  paṭilābha vasena uppajjanaka tuṭṭhi paṭiladdha rasa anubhavanan ti paṭiladdhassa ārammaṇa rasassa  anubhavananti sabhāvataḥ pīti sukhāni vibhajitvā dasseti yattha pīti tattha sukhanti  vitakkassa itarena pītiyā sukhena yattha sukham tattha
translated: Or it is satisfaction because it satisfies either the associated states or itself by the substitution of ta for da. Satisfaction is called “sweet” .🔽It has satisfaction as its characteristic.🔽Its function is to promote the associated states.🔽It is manifested as non-abandonment, like non-abandonment of pain, or as non- disregard, like non-disregard of pleasure.🔽Or its manifestation is as helpfulness, as assistance. In some places it is the joy of acquisition.🔽The joy that arises as acquisition is the joy of acquisition.🔽The experiencing of the taste of what has been acquired is the experiencing of the taste of the object that has been acquired.🔽He shows the difference between the three, namely, happiness, pleasure, and equanimity, in their individual characteristics.🔽Where there is happiness there is pleasure, he says, and he shows that there is absolute conjunction of happiness with pleasure, as of applied thought, and so on.🔽Where there is pleasure there is equanimity.

original: na niyamato pītī”ti vicārassa viya vitakkena sukhassa pītiyā anaccantasaṃyogaṃ. Tena
analyzed: na niyamataḥ pīti iti vicārassa viya vitakkena sukhassa pītiyāḥ anaccanta saṃyogam tena
translated: Or it is satisfaction because it satisfies by placing the associated states in itself, changing the da to ta. Satisfaction is called “sweet” . It has satisfaction as its characteristic. Its function is to intensify. It is manifested as non-grief. It is helpful as assistance. In some places, such as the first jhāna, etc., it is the joy that arises as acquisition. The experiencing of the taste of what has been acquired is the experiencing of the taste of the object that has been acquired. He shows the difference between the three in their individual characteristics thus. Where there is joy there is happiness, he says, there is complete association of joy with happiness, as there is of applied thought with happiness. Where there is happiness there is not necessarily joy, he says, there is no complete association of happiness with joy, as there is of sustained thought with happiness.

original: accantānaccantasaṃyogitāya pītisukhānaṃ visesaṃ dasseti. Kaṃ tārenti etthāti kantāraṃ,
analyzed: accanta anaccanta saṃyogi tāya pīti sukhānam visesam dasseti kam tārenti ettha ati kantāram
translated: He shows the difference between the happiness and the bliss by the words “in the highest degree” and “in the extreme degree.”🔽A desert is a place where there is no water and which is uninhabited.

original: nirudakamaruṭṭhānaṃ. Vanameva vanantaṃ. Tasmiṃ tasmiṃ samayeti iṭṭhārammaṇassa paṭilābhasamaye,
analyzed: nirudakam aruṭṭhānam vanam eva vanantam tasmin tasmin samaye iti iṭṭha ārammaṇassa paṭilābha samaye
translated: A forest is a place where there are trees. In that place, at the time of obtaining a desirable object,

original: paṭiladdhassa rasānubhavanasamaye, vanacchāyādīnaṃ savanadassanasamaye, pavesaparibhogasamaye🔽ca. Pākaṭabhāvatoti yathākkamaṃ pītisukhānaṃ vibhūtabhāvato.
analyzed: paṭiladdhassa rasa anubhavana samaye vana chāyā ādīnam savana dassana samaye pavesa paribhoga samaye  ca pākaṭa bhāvataḥ ti vibhūta bhāvataḥ
translated: at the time of experiencing the taste of what has been obtained, at the time of hearing and seeing the shade of the trees, etc., and at the time of entering and enjoying them,🔽the happiness and bliss become evident.

original: Vivekajaṃ pītisukhanti ettha purimasmiṃ atthe vivekajanti jhānaṃ vuttaṃ. Pītisukhasaddato🔽ca atthiatthavisesato “assa jhānassa, asmiṃ vā jhāne”ti ettha a-kāro daṭṭhabbo. Dutiye
analyzed: viveka jam pīti sukhanti ettha purimasmin atthe viveka janti jhānam vuttam pīti sukha saddato  ca atthi attha visesataḥ assa jhānassa asmim vā jhāne ti ettha akāraḥ daṭṭhabbaḥ dutiye
translated: In the phrase “born of seclusion, happiness, and bliss,” in the first sense of the word “seclusion,” seclusion is the jhāna itself that is spoken of.🔽And in the phrase “of that jhāna, in that jhāna,” the letter a should be regarded as a mere vowel sign devoid of meaning.🔽In the second sense of the word “seclusion,” it is the happiness and bliss that are born of seclusion.🔽The compound “born-of-seclusion-happiness-and-bliss” is a copulative compound, and the nominative ending is elided.

original: pītisukhameva vivekajaṃ. “Vivekajaṃpītisukha”nti ca aññapadatthasamāso, paccattaniddesassa🔽ca alopo kato. Lope vā sati “vivekajapītisukha”nti pāṭhoti ayaṃ viseso.
analyzed: pīti sukham eva viveka jam viveka jam pīti sukham ti ca añña padattha samāsaḥ paccatta niddesassa 🔽ca a lopaḥ kataḥ lope vā sati viveka ja pīti sukhanti ayam visesaḥ
translated: Or if the nominative is not elided, the reading is “born-of-seclusion-happiness-and-bliss.” This is the difference.

original: Upasampajjāti ettha upa-saṃ-saddā “upalabbhati, saṃbhuñjatī”tiādīsu viya niratthakāti🔽dassetuṃ “upagantvā”tiādiṃ vatvā puna tesaṃ sātthakabhāvaṃ dassetuṃ “upasampādayitvā”tiādi
analyzed: upasampajja ati ettha upasaṃsaddā upalabbhati saṃbhuñjati iti ādīsu viya niratthakā ati  dassetum upagantvā atiādim vatvā puna tesam sātthaka bhāvam dassetum upasampādayitvā atiādi
translated: “He attains” : here the prefix upa in the word upasampajja is meaningless, like the prefix upa in the words upajjhati and upabhuñjati.🔽In order to show this, the author says “having gone up to” . Then, in order to show that the prefix upa is not meaningless, he says “having attained” .🔽Therefore the meaning is “having gone up to” or “having accomplished” .

original: vuttaṃ, tasmā patvā, sādhetvāti vā attho. Iriyanti kiriyaṃ. Vuttiādīni tasseva vevacanāni.🔽Pālanāti hi ekaṃ iriyāpathabādhanaṃ iriyāpathantarehi rakkhaṇā.
analyzed: vuttam tasmā patvā sādhetvā ati vā attho iriyanti kiriyam vutti ādīni tassa iva vevacanāni  hi ekam iriyāpatha bādhanam iriyāpatha antarehi rakkhaṇā
translated: “Posture” : action. “Mode of life” , etc., are synonyms for it.

original: Pañcaṅgavippahīnādivaṇṇanā🔽74. Pañca aṅgāni vikkhambhanavasena pahīnāni etassāti pañcaṅgavippahīnaṃ. “Agyāhito”ti🔽ettha āhita-saddassa viya vippahīna-saddassettha paravacanaṃ daṭṭhabbaṃ, pañcahi🔽aṅgehi vippahīnanti vā pañcaṅgavippahīnaṃ. Nanu aññepi akusalā dhammā iminā jhānena🔽pahīyanti, atha kasmā pañcaṅgavippahīnatāva vuccatīti āha “kiñcāpī”tiādi. Jhānalābhinopi
analyzed: 🔽pañca aṅgāni vikkhambhana vasena pahīnāni etassa ati pañcaṅga vippahīnam a gyāhito ti 🔽ettha āhita saddassa viya vippahīna saddassa ittha para vacanam daṭṭhabbam pañcahi 🔽aṅgehi vippahīnanti vā pañcaṅga vippahīnam nanu aññe pi akusalāḥ dhammāḥ iminā jhānena 🔽pahīyanti atha kasmā pañcaṅga vippahīna tā ava vuccati iti āha kiñcā api itiādi jhāna lābhinaḥ api
translated: “Preservation” : the prevention of the disturbance of one posture by another.

original: ajhānasamaṅgikāle jhānapaṭipakkhalobhacittādīnaṃ pavattisabbhāvato “jhānakkhaṇe”ti
analyzed: ajhāna samaṅgi kāle jhāna paṭipakkha lobha citta ādīnam pavatti sabbhāvataḥ jhāna kkhaṇa iti
translated: At the time of the jhāna attainment, greed for the things opposed to jhāna, such as sensual desires, is absent owing to the absence of occurrence of such states.

original: vuttaṃ. Pahīyantīti vigacchanti, nappavattantīti attho. Ekattārammaṇeti pathavīkasiṇādivasena
analyzed: vuttam pahīyanti iti vigacchanti na ppavattanti iti attho ekatta ārammaṇā iti pathavī kasiṇa ādi vasena
translated: So it is said that “at the moment of jhāna” it is “abandoned.” The meaning is that it does not occur.

original: ekasabhāve, ekaggatāsaṅkhāte ekattāvahe vā ārammaṇe. Tanti taṃ nānāvisayapalobhitaṃ
analyzed: eka sabhāve ekagga tā saṅkhāte ekatta āvahe vā ārammaṇe tanti tam nānā visaya palobhitam
translated: On a single object: on a single-consistently-perceived object such as the earth kasiṇa, or on an object consisting of unification, that is, on an object that is a cause of unification.🔽That mind: that mind enticed by the various objects.

original: cittaṃ. Kāmadhātuppahānāyāti nānāvisayasamūpabyūḷhāya kāmadhātuyā pahānāya samatikkamāya
analyzed: cittam kāmadhātu pahānāya ati nānā visaya samūpa byūḍhāya kāmadhātuyā pahānāya samatikkamāya
translated: For the purpose of abandoning the sense-desire element: for the purpose of abandoning the sense-desire element that is mixed up with the various objects, for the purpose of surmounting it.🔽He does not enter upon the way: he does not enter upon the jhāna as the way.

original: paṭipadaṃ jhānaṃ nappaṭipajjati. Nirantaranti vikkhepena anantaritaṃ, sahitanti attho.
analyzed: paṭipadam jhānam na paṭipajjati nirantaram ti vikkhepena anantaritam sahitam ti attho
translated: Uninterrupted: not interrupted by distraction; that is the meaning.🔽Unmanageable: unserviceable; that is the meaning.🔽Overwhelmed by agitation and worry:

original: Akammaññanti akammanīyaṃ, bhāvanākammassa ayogyanti attho. Uddhaccakukkuccaparetanti
analyzed: akammaññanti akammanīyam bhāvanā kammassa ayogyanti attho uddhacca kukkucca paretanti
translated: it wanders about without steadiness, is the meaning.🔽Because there is no steadiness, that is, because there is no concentration.

original: uddhaccakukkuccena abhibhūtaṃ. Paribbhamati anavaṭṭhānato, avaṭṭhānassa samādhānassa🔽abhāvatoti attho. Vicikicchāya upahatanti sātisayassa vicārassa abhāvato “sammāsambuddho
analyzed: uddhacca kukkuccena abhibhūtam paribbhamati an avaṭṭhānataḥ avaṭṭhānassa samādhānassa 🔽abhāvato ti atthaḥ vicikicchāya upahatanti sa atisayassa vicārassa abhāvataḥ sammāsambuddho
translated: Afflicted by doubt: because of the absence of any strong surmise.

original: nu kho bhagavā, na nu kho”ti, “pathavī pathavī”tiādinā manasikārena, “jhānaṃ siyā
analyzed: nu kho bhagavā na nu kha uti pathavī pathavī iti ādinā manasikārena jhānam siyā
translated: “Is it the earth, or is it not?” “Earth, earth,” and so on, and “jhāna is possible

original: nu kho, na nu kho”tiādinā ca pavattāya vicikicchāya upahataṃ. Nārohati appaṭipattinimittattā.🔽Visesena jhānantarāyakarattāti samādhiādīnaṃ ujuvipaccanīkabhāvena jhānādhigamassa antarāyakaraṇato.
analyzed: nu kho na nu kha uti ādinā ca pavattāya vicikicchāya upahatam na ārohati a paṭipatti nimitta ttā  visesena samādhi ādīnam uju vipaccanīka bhāvena jhāna adhigamassa antarāya karaṇato
translated: “Is there jhāna or isn’t there?” and so on, and it is obstructed by doubt that occurs thus, “Is there jhāna or isn’t there?” It does not ascend because it is not a sign of practice.🔽Because it is a special hindrance to jhāna: because it is a hindrance to the obtaining of jhāna by being a direct opponent to concentration, etc.,🔽Because of the applied thought and sustained thought that are the conditions for the obtaining of jhāna.

original: Tehīti jhānādhigamassa paccayabhūtehi vitakkavicārehi. Avikkhepāya sampāditappayogassāti
analyzed: tehi iti jhāna adhigamassa paccaya bhūtehi vitakka vicārehi avikkhepāya sampādita ppayogassa ati
translated: To non-distraction: to the non-distraction of the mind that has had its energy aroused in this way.🔽To the possibility of success of the mind’s effort:🔽to the arising of the success of the effort consisting in the aforementioned development.

original: tato evaṃ samādhānāya nipphāditabhāvanāpayogassa. Cetaso payogasampattisambhavāti
analyzed: tatas evam samādhānāya nipphādita bhāvanā apayogassa cetasaḥ payoga sampatti
translated: It makes the mind, which is full of happiness,🔽swell,🔽suffuse,

original: yathāvuttabhāvanāpayogasampattisamuṭṭhānā. Pīti pīṇanaṃ bhāvanāvasena tappanaṃ. Upabrūhanaṃ
analyzed: yathā vutta bhāvanā apayoga sampatti samuṭṭhānā pīti pīṇanam bhāvanā vasena tappanam upabrūhanam
translated: and overspread with happiness that has arisen through development.

original: bhāvanāvasena parivuddhiṃ cetaso karotīti sambandho. Nanti cittaṃ. Sasesasampayuttadhammanti
analyzed: bhāvanā vasena parivuddhim cetaso karoti iti sambandhaḥ cittam
translated: The construction of the words is as follows: “It makes the mind, which is full of happiness, swell with happiness that has arisen through development; it suffuses the body with happiness that has arisen through development; it overspreads the whole body and makes it full of happiness that has arisen through development.”

original: avasiṭṭhaphassādidhammasahitaṃ, samaṃ sammā ca ādhiyatīti sambandho. Indriyasamatāvasena
analyzed: avasiṭṭha phassa ādi dhamma sahitam samam sammā ca ādhiyati iti sambandhaḥ indriya sama tā vasena
translated: and what remains is associated with the remaining states beginning with contact. It is “equanimous” because of the equality of the faculties.

original: samaṃ, paṭipakkhadhammānaṃ. Dūrībhāve līnuddhaccābhāvena sammā ca ṭhapetīti attho.
analyzed: samam paṭipakkha dhammānam dūrībhāve līn uddhacca abhāvena sammā ca ṭhapeti iti attho
translated: The meaning is that it is “well-established” by the absence of greed and hate in the form of depression and agitation respectively, which are opposed to equanimity.

original: Ekaggatā hi samādhānakiccena cittaṃ, sampayuttadhamme ca attānaṃ anuvattāpentī jhānakkhaṇe
analyzed: ekagga tā hi samādhāna kiccena cittam sampayutta dhamme ca attānam anuvattāpentī jhāna kkhaṇe
translated: For unification is the function of concentration, and it makes the mind and its associated states act in conformity with itself.🔽It makes them occur in a state of unification that is more outstanding than before.

original: sātisayaṃ samāhite karotīti. Uppattivasenāti yathāpaccayaṃ uppajjanavasena. Etesu
analyzed: sa atisayam samāhite karoti iti uppatti vasena ati yathāpaccayam uppajjana vasena etesu
translated: “By its arising”: by its arising according to conditions.

original: vitakkādīsu jhānaṃ uppannaṃ nāma hoti tattheva jhānavohārato. Tenāha “tasmā”tiādi.
analyzed: vitakka ādīsu jhānam uppannam nāma hoti tattha iva jhāna vohārato tena āha tasmā itiādi
translated: It is said that jhāna has arisen in regard to these states of applied thought, etc., only when it has arisen in association with them.

original: “Yathā panā”tiādināpi upamāvasena tamevatthaṃ pākaṭataraṃ karoti.
analyzed: yathā panāti ādinā api upamā vasena pākaṭataram karoti
translated: “But just as” and what follows is stated by way of a simile in order to make the same point still clearer.🔽“From the normal consciousness”: from the normal sense-sphere consciousness.

original: Pakaticittatoti pākatikakāmāvacaracittato. Suvisadenāti suṭṭhu visadena, paṭutarenāti
analyzed: pakati cittato ti pākatika kāmāvacara cittato su visadena ati suṭṭhu visadena paṭutarena ati
translated: “Well pervaded”: well suffused; the meaning is, with a strong infusion.

original: attho. Sabbāvantanti sabbāvayavavantaṃ, anavasesanti attho. Apphuṭanti asamphuṭṭhaṃ.
analyzed: attho sabbāvantam ti sabba avayavavantam anavasesam ti attho apphuṭanti a samphuṭṭham
translated: “Throughout all its parts”: the meaning is, without exception.

original: Ārammaṇesu phusitāti appanāvasena pavattamānā cittekaggatā samantato ārammaṇaṃ pharantī🔽viya hotīti katvā vuttaṃ. Kasmā panettha jhānapāṭhe aggahitā cittekaggatā gahitāti
analyzed: ārammaṇesu phusitā ati appanā vasena pavattamānā citta ekagga tā samantataḥ ārammaṇam pharantī  viya hoti iti katvā vuttam kasmā pana ittha jhāna pāṭhe aggahitā citta ekagga tā gahitā ti
translated: “It touches the object” is said because the unification of mind occurring by means of absorption appears as though it were touching the object all round.🔽But why is unification of mind mentioned here when it is not mentioned in the jhāna definition?

original: anuyogaṃ sandhāya “tattha cittekaggatā”tiādi vuttaṃ. Tatthāti tesu jhānaṅgesu. Na🔽niddiṭṭhāti sarūpato na niddiṭṭhā, sāmaññato pana jhānaggahaṇena gahitā. Evaṃ vuttattāti
analyzed: anuyogam sandhāya tattha citta ekagga tā ti ādi vuttam tattha ati tesu jhāna aṅgesu na  niddiṭṭhā ati sarūpataḥ na niddiṭṭhā sāmaññato pana jhāna ggahaṇena gahitā evam vutta ttā ti
translated: The answer to that is as follows. “Therein” means among those jhāna factors.

original: sarūpeneva vuttattā, aṅgameva cittekaggatāti sambandho. Yena adhippāyenāti yena vitakkādīhi
analyzed: sarūpena iva vutta ttā aṅgam eva citta ekagga tā iti sambandhaḥ yena adhippāyena ati yena vitakka ādīhi
translated: Not specified: not specified by its individual essence, but mentioned by mentioning the jhāna in general. “Because it is said” means because it is said in the Vibhaṅga in the way beginning, “‘Unification of mind’: this is a term for the four jhānas” .🔽By what intention? By the intention to reveal a state that occurs along with applied thought, etc.,

original: saha vattantaṃ dhammaṃ dīpetuṃ tassa pakāsanādhippāyena “savitakkaṃ savicāra”ntiādinā
analyzed: saha vattantam dhammam dīpetum tassa pakāsana adhippāyena sa vitakkam sa vicāra nti ādinā
translated: the exposition was made in the way beginning, “Possessing applied thought, possessing sustained thought” .

original: uddeso kato. So eva adhippāyo tena bhagavatā vibhaṅge “cittekaggatā”ti niddisantena
analyzed: uddeso kato saḥ eva adhippāyo tena bhagavatā vibhaṅge citta ekagga tā iti niddisantena
translated: That same intention was revealed by the Blessed One when he specified unification of mind in the Vibhaṅga thus, “‘Unification of mind’: this is a term for the four jhānas” .

original: pakāsito. Tasmā sā jhānapāṭhe aggahitāti na cintetabbaṃ.🔽Tividhakalyāṇavaṇṇanā
analyzed: pakāsitaḥ tasmā sā jhāna pāṭhe aggahitā iti na cintetabbam 🔽tividha kalyāṇa vaṇṇanā
translated: So it should not be thought that it is not mentioned in the jhāna definition.

original: 75. Ādimajjhapariyosānavasenāti jhānassa ādimajjhapariyosānavasena. Lakkhaṇavasenāti tesaṃyeva appanāyaṃ lakkhitabbabhāvavasena.🔽Tatrāti tasmiṃ kalyāṇatālakkhaṇānaṃ vibhāvane. Paṭipadāvisuddhīti paṭipajjati jhānaṃ
analyzed: ādi majjha pariyosāna vasena ati jhānassa ādi majjha pariyosāna vasena lakkhaṇa vasena ati tesam yeva appanāyam lakkhitabba bhāva vasena  tatra ati tasmim kalyāṇa tā lakkhaṇānam vibhāvane paṭipadā visuddhī iti paṭipajjati jhānam
translated: By way of beginning, middle, and end: by way of the beginning, middle, and end of the jhāna. By way of its characteristics: by way of the characterizing of those same three sections as the three characteristics.

original: etāyāti paṭipadā, gotrabhupariyosāno pubbabhāgiyo bhāvanānayo. Paripanthato visujjhanaṃ🔽visuddhi, paṭipadāya visuddhi paṭipadāvisuddhi. Sā panāyaṃ yasmā jhānassa uppādakkhaṇe🔽labbhati, tasmā vuttaṃ “paṭipadāvisuddhi ādī”ti. Upekkhānubrūhanāti visodhetabbatādīnaṃ
analyzed: etāya ati paṭipadā gotrabhu pariyosānaḥ pubbabhāgiyaḥ bhāvanā nayaḥ paripanthataḥ visujjhanam  visuddhi paṭipadāya visuddhi paṭipadā visuddhi sā pana ayam yasmā jhānassa uppāda kkhaṇe  labbhati tasmā vuttam paṭipadā visuddhi ādi iti upekkhā anubrūhanā ti visodhetabba tā ādīnam
translated: There: in the exposition of the good qualities of the characteristics. Purification of the way: the way is the method of development consisting of the prior and subsequent parts that one goes by in entering upon jhāna. Purification is the getting clear of that way from obstruction. Purification of the way is the purification of that by the way.

original: abhāvato jhānapariyāpannāya tatramajjhattupekkhāya kiccanipphattiyā anubrūhanā. Sā
analyzed: abhāvataḥ jhāna pariyāpannāya tatram ajjhatta upekkhāya kicca nipphattiyāḥ anubrūhanā sā
translated: But this is found only at the moment of the jhāna’s arising, which is why it is said, “The beginning is purification of the way.” Increase of equanimity: because there is no longer any need to purify what has been purified, and so on, there is an increase of the equanimity that is concerned with that and belongs with the jhāna, which is to say, there is an increase of the function of that equanimity.

original: panāyaṃ visesato jhānassa ṭhitikkhaṇe labbhati. Tena vuttaṃ “upekkhānubrūhanā majjhe”ti.
analyzed: pana ayam visesataḥ jhānassa ṭhiti kkhaṇe labbhati tena vuttam upekkhā anubrūhanā majjhe ti
translated: This is found especially at the moment of the jhāna’s steadiness, which is why it is said, “The middle is increase of equanimity.”

original: Sampahaṃsanāti tattha dhammānaṃ anativattanādisādhakassa ñāṇassa kiccanipphattivasena🔽pariyodapanā. Sā pana yasmā jhānassa osānakkhaṇe pākaṭā hoti, tasmā vuttaṃ “sampahaṃsanā🔽pariyosāna”nti. Imāni tīṇi lakkhaṇānīti paripanthato cittassa visujjhanākāro, majjhimassa🔽samathanimittassa paṭipajjanākāro, tattha pakkhandanākāroti imāni tīṇi jhānassa ādito
analyzed: sampahaṃsanā ti tattha dhammānam anativattana ādi sādhakassa ñāṇassa kicca nipphatti vasena  pariyodapanā sā pana yasmā jhānassa osāna kkhaṇe pākaṭā hoti tasmā vuttam sampahaṃsanā  pariyosānam ti imāni tīṇi lakkhaṇāni iti paripanthataḥ cittassa visujjhana ākāraḥ majjhimassa  samatha nimittassa paṭipajjana ākāro tattha pakkhandana ākāro ti imāni tīṇi jhānassa āditaḥ
translated: “Consolidation” is the cleansing of the jhāna by the occurrence of the function of the knowledge that succeeds it, which knowledge is the means to the non-excess of states. But that is evident only at the moment of the end of the jhāna, so it is said, “consolidation is the end” .🔽These are the three characteristics: the purification of the mind from hindrances is the sign of stilling; the mind’s going is the sign of occurrence; the mind’s steadying is the sign of change.🔽These are the three characteristics of the first jhāna.🔽

original: uppādakkhaṇe appanāpattilakkhaṇāni tehi ākārehi vinā appanāpattiyā abhāvato, asati🔽ca appanāya tadabhāvato. Ādikalyāṇañceva visuddhipaṭipadattā. Yathāvuttehi lakkhaṇehi🔽samannāgatattā, sampannalakkhaṇattā ca tilakkhaṇasampannañca. Iminā nayena majjhapariyosānalakkhaṇānañca yojanā veditabbā.
analyzed: uppāda khaṇe appanāpatti lakkhaṇāni tehi ākārehi vinā appanāpattiyāḥ abhāvataḥ asati 🔽ca appanāya tad abhāvato ādi kalyāṇam ca iva visuddhi paṭipada ttā yathā vuttehi lakkhaṇehi 🔽samannāgata ttā sampanna lakkhaṇa ttā ca ti lakkhaṇa sampannam ca iminā nayena yojanā veditabbā
translated: The “consummation” is the cleansing of the mind of hindrances, etc., by the manifestation of the function of the knowledge that accomplishes the non-transgression of the dhammas, etc. But since that is evident at the moment of conclusion of the jhāna, it is said, “The consummation is the end.” These are the three characteristics: the mode of the mind’s cleansing from the hindrances, etc., the mode of the arising of the central state of equilibrium, and the mode of entry upon that. These are the three characteristics of the attainment of absorption at the moment of the arising of the jhāna at the beginning. For there is no attainment of absorption without these modes. And when there is no attainment of absorption, there is none of that either. And it is good in the beginning because it has the three characteristics stated thus, “The mode of the mind’s cleansing from the hindrances, etc., the mode of the arising of the central state of equilibrium, and the mode of entry upon that,” and it is good in the middle and good in the end because it has the three characteristics stated thus, “The mode of the mind’s cleansing from the hindrances, etc., the mode of the arising of the central state of equilibrium, and the mode of entry upon that,” and because it is furnished with the three characteristics stated thus, “The mode of the mind’s cleansing from the hindrances, etc., the mode of the arising of the central state of equilibrium, and the mode of entry upon that.” The application of the method here should be understood in the same way as in the case of the first jhāna.

original: Sambharīyati jhānaṃ etenāti sambhāro, nānāvajjanaparikammaṃ. Saha sambhārenāti sasambhāro,
analyzed: sambharīyati jhānam etena ati sambhāraḥ nānā vajjana parikammam saha sambhārena ati sa sambhāraḥ
translated: The jhāna is “collected” by that, thus it is “collection” , which is the preliminary work consisting of the various kinds of knowledge. “With collection” is “with collection” ,

original: so eva sasambhāriko. Upacāroti ekāvajjanūpacāramāha. Paggahādikiccassa pubbabhāge
analyzed: saḥ eva sa sambhārikaḥ upacāraḥ iti ekāvajjana upacāram āha paggaha ādi kiccassa pubba bhāge
translated: which is the same as “with collection” . “Approach” is the approach consisting in a single application.🔽Because it is accomplished by development only in the earlier stage of the preliminary work consisting of the learning sign, etc.,

original: bhāvanāya eva sādhitattā yā tattha ekāvajjanūpacāre siddhā ajjhupekkhanā, sā jhānakkhaṇe
analyzed: bhāvanāya eva sādhita ttā yā tattha ekāvajjana upacāre siddhā ajjhupekkhanā sā jhāna kkhaṇe
translated: the equanimity that is established there in the approach consisting in a single application is🔽what is called “intensified” at the moment of the jhāna.

original: paribrūhitā nāma hotīti vuttaṃ “upekkhānubrūhanā nāma appanā”ti. Yathādhigataṃ jhānaṃ
analyzed: paribrūhitā nāma hoti iti vuttam upekkhā anubrūhanā nāma appanā iti yathā adhigatam jhānam
translated: That is why it is said that absorption is “intensification of equanimity.”

original: nissāya yo pahaṭṭhākāro cittassa paritoso, taṃ paccavekkhaṇāvasena pavattaṃ sandhāyāha🔽“sampahaṃsanā nāma paccavekkhaṇā”ti. Eketi abhayagirivāsino. Te hi evaṃ paṭipadāvisuddhiādike
analyzed: nissāya yaḥ pahaṭṭha ākāro cittassa paritoso tam paccavekkhaṇā vasena pavattam sandhāya āha  sampahaṃsanā nāma paccavekkhaṇā ati eke iti abhayagiri vāsino te hi evam paṭipadā visuddhi ādike
translated: The mental elation that is the manifestation of joy in the mind when the jhāna is attained by depending on the jhāna already acquired is what is meant by “satisfaction” .🔽The “reviewing” is that which occurs by looking back on that.🔽Some, namely the residents of the Abhayagiri Monastery, explain the “purity of the path” and so on as follows:

original: vaṇṇayanti, tadayuttaṃ. Tathā hi sati ajjhānadhammehi jhānassa guṇasaṃkittanaṃ nāma
