analyzed: vuttā hoti iti ce ekodi bhāvanti padam uddharitvā ekodissa niddeso na kātabbaḥ siyāti
translated: then it may be replied that the phrase “in the unification” should not be construed as “in the unification called jhāna.”

original: ekodibhāvasaddo eva samādhimhi pavatto sampasādanasaddo viya jhāne pavattatīti yuttaṃ.
analyzed: eka udi bhāva saddo eva samādhimhi pavatto sampasādana saddaḥ viya jhāne pavattati iti yuttam
translated: So it is proper to take it that the word “unification” is used in the sense of concentration, like the word “confidence” in the phrase “confidence in jhāna” .

original: Imasmiñca atthavikappeti “cetaso sampasādayatī”ti etasmiṃ pakkhe “cetaso”ti ca upayogatthe
analyzed: imasmin ca attha vikappe ti cetasaḥ sampasādayati iti etasmin pakkhe cetasaḥ iti ca upayoga tthe
translated: And in the phrase “in this meaning” the word “cetaso” is a locative in the sense of “source”

original: sāmivacanaṃ. Purimasminti “sampasādanayogato jhānaṃ sampasādana”nti vuttapakkhe.
analyzed: sāmi vacanam purimasmin ti sampasādana yogataḥ jhānam sampasādananti vutta pakkhe
translated: in the case of the explanation by “confidence” as “confidence in jhāna by means of confidence.”

original: Cetasoti sambandhe sāmivacanaṃ.
analyzed: cetasā iti sambandhe sāmi vacanam
translated: In the other case, the word “cetaso” is a locative in the sense of “in relation to” .

original: Seṭṭhopi loke “eko”ti vuccati “yāva pare ekāhaṃ te karomī”tiādīsu. Eko adutiyo “ekākībhi
analyzed: seṭṭhaḥ api loke ekaḥ ti vuccati yāva pare ekā aham te karomi iti ādīsu ekaḥ adutiyaḥ
translated: The best in the world is called “one” , as in the passage “I will be your one for a day” , and “one” is also used in the sense of “alone” , as in the passage “He goes alone and returns alone” .

original: khuddakehi jita”ntiādīsu asahāyatthopi eka-saddo diṭṭhoti āha “eko asahāyo hutvā”ti.
analyzed: khuddakehi jita nti ādīsu asahāya tthaḥ api eka saddo diṭṭho ti āha ekaḥ asahāyaḥ hutvā iti
translated: In such passages as “The small have conquered the great” the word “one” is also seen in the sense of “without a companion.”

original: Saddhādayopi kāmaṃ sampayuttadhammānaṃ sādhāraṇato, asādhāraṇato ca paccayā hontiyeva,
analyzed: saddhā ādayaḥ api kāmam sampayutta dhammānam sādhāraṇataḥ asādhāraṇataḥ ca paccayāḥ honti yeva
translated: Although faith, etc., are certainly conditions for associated states both in the sense of being shared and in the sense of being unshared,

original: samādhi pana jhānakkhaṇe sampayuttadhammānaṃ avikkhepalakkhaṇe indaṭṭhakaraṇena sātisayaṃ
analyzed: samādhi pana jhāna kkhaṇe sampayutta dhammānam avikkhepa lakkhaṇe indaṭṭha karaṇena sa atisayam
translated: concentration is a condition for associated states in the sense of being shared by being the cause of their specific quality of non-distraction at the moment of jhāna.

original: paccayo hotīti dassento “sampayuttadhamme…pe… adhivacana”nti āha.
analyzed: paccayaḥ hoti iti dassento sampayutta dhamma īpe adhivacanan ti āha
translated: Showing this, he says, “Associated states … are called ‘the expression of the specific nature of the jhāna’ … “🔽The two specifications “confidence” and “unification of the mind” are taken

original: “Sampasādanaṃ, cetaso ekodibhāva”nti visesanadvayaṃ jhānassa atisayavacanicchāvasena
analyzed: sampasādanam cetasaḥ eka udi bhāvanti visesana dvayam jhānassa atisaya vacanicchā vasena
translated: in order to show the specific nature of the jhāna by the word “confidence” and its special qualities by the word “unification of the mind.”

original: gahitaṃ. Svāyamatisayo yathā imasmiṃ jhāne labbhati, na tathā paṭhamajjhāneti imaṃ🔽visesaṃ dassetuṃ “nanu cā”tiādi vuttaṃ. Ārammaṇe āhananapariyāhananavasena, anumajjanaanuyojanavasena
analyzed: gahitam svāyam atisayaḥ yathā imasmin jhāne labbhati na tathā paṭhamajjhāna iti imam  visesam dassetum nanu ca atiādi vuttam ārammaṇe āhanana pariyāhanana vasena anumajjana anuyojana vasena
translated: This is the special quality that is not found in the first jhāna in the way it is found in this jhāna.🔽In order to point out this special quality, the following is said: “But is not confidence also a factor of the first jhāna?”🔽The states that occur in the act of striking at and felling the object and in the act of kneading and mixing it up,

original: ca pavattamānā dhammā satipi nīvaraṇappahānena kilesakālussiyāpagame sampayuttānaṃ
analyzed: ca pavattamānāḥ dhammāḥ sati pi nīvaraṇa pahānena kilesa kālussiya apagame sampayuttānam
translated: although they are present, are not mentioned because they are obscured by the grossness of the first jhāna.

original: kañci khobhaṃ karontā viya tehi ca te na sannisinnā hontīti vuttaṃ “vitakkavicārakkhobhena
analyzed: kañci khobham karontāḥ viya tehi ca te na sannisinnāḥ honti iti vuttam vitakka vicāra khobhena
translated: It is said that they are not well-composed because of the disturbance of applied and sustained thought.

original: na suppasanna”nti. Khuddikā ūmiyo vīciyo. Mahatiyo taraṅgā. Satipi indriyasamatte,
analyzed: na suppasannanti khuddikāḥ ūmiyaḥ vīciyaḥ mahatiyaḥ taraṅgā indriya samatte
translated: The small waves are the ripples, the big waves are the billows.

original: vīriyasamatāya ca teneva khobhena, sampasādābhāvena ca samādhipi na suṭṭhu pākaṭo
analyzed: vīriya samatāya ca tena iva khobhena sampasāda abhāvena ca na suṭṭhu pākaṭaḥ
translated: Even though there is equality of the faculties, still, because of that disturbance and because of the absence of confidence, concentration is not well-manifested,🔽like a fish in shallow water. The disturbance as already described is the hindrance.

original: bahale viya jale maccho. Yathāvuttakkhobho eva palibodho. Evaṃ vuttenāti yassā saddhāya🔽vasena sampasādanaṃ, yassā ca cittekaggatāya vasena ekodibhāvanti ca jhānaṃ vuttaṃ.🔽Tāsaṃ eva “saddahanā”tiādinā pavattiākārassa visesavibhāvanāvasena vuttena. Tena
analyzed: bahale viya jale macchaḥ yathā vutta kkhobhaḥ eva palibodhaḥ evam vuttena ati yassā saddhāya  vasena sampasādanam yassā ca citta ekagga tāya vasena ekodibhāvanti ca jhānam vuttaṃ  tāsam eva saddahana ati ādinā pavatti ākārassa visesa vibhāvanā vasena vuttena tena
translated: Thus it is said: “The confidence by means of which there is confidence is confidence.🔽And the unification of mind by means of which there is singleness of mind is singleness. The jhāna in which there is that confidence and that singleness is said to be ‘endowed with confidence and singleness’ ” .

original: vibhaṅgapāṭhena. “Sampasādanayogato, sampasādanato vā sampasādanaṃ, ekodiṃ bhāvetīti
analyzed: vibhaṅga pāṭhena sampasādana yogataḥ sampasādanataḥ vā sampasādanam eka ūdim bhāveti iti
translated: The explanation of the meaning in the Vibh-a is not inconsistent with the words of the text, which are stated in order to show the difference in the way of occurrence of the confidence and the singleness of mind.

original: ekodibhāvanti jhānaṃ vutta”nti evaṃ pavattā ayaṃ atthavaṇṇanā na virujjhati. Yathā
analyzed: eka udi bhāvanti jhānam vuttanti evam pavattā ayam attha vaṇṇanā na virujjhati yathā
translated: The explanation of the meaning in the Vibh-a is not inconsistent with the words of the text, which are stated in order to show the difference in the way of occurrence of the confidence and the singleness of mind.

original: pana avirodho, so vutto eva.
analyzed: pana avirodho so vutto eva
translated: but there is no contradiction, and that has already been stated.

original: 81. Santāti samaṃ nirodhaṃ gatā. Samitāti bhāvanāya samaṃ gamitā nirodhitā. Vūpasantāti🔽tato eva suṭṭhu upasantā. Atthaṅgatāti atthaṃ vināsaṃ gatā. Abbhatthaṅgatāti upasaggena
analyzed: santā ati samam nirodham gatā samitā ati bhāvanāya samam gamitā nirodhitā vūpasantā ati  tatas eva suṭṭhu upasantāḥ atthaṅgatā ati attham vināsam gatāḥ abbhatthaṅgatā ati upasaggena
translated: “Ceased” : they have gone to cessation equally. “Become quiet” : they have gone to cessation equally by means of development. “Become stilled” :🔽they have become stilled well by means of that . “Become subsided” : they have gone to destruction. “Become completely subsided” : the word is extended by the prefix abhi-

original: padaṃ vaḍḍhetvā vuttaṃ. Appitāti vināsaṃ gamitā. Sositāti pavattisaṅkhātassa santānassa🔽abhāvena sosaṃ sukkhabhāvaṃ itā. Byantikatāti vigatantakatā.
analyzed: padam vaḍḍhetvā vuttam appitā ati vināsam gamitā sositā ati pavatti saṅkhātassa santānassa  abhāvena sosam sukkha bhāvam itā byantika tā ati vigata antaka tā
translated: . “Become extinguished” : they have gone to destruction. “Become cooled” : they have gone to the state of dryness by the absence of the continuum called occurrence. “Become blissful” :

original: Ayamatthoti bhāvanāya pahīnattā vitakkavicārānaṃ abhāvo. Codakena vuttamatthaṃ sampaṭicchitvā
analyzed: ayam atthaḥ ti bhāvanāya pahīna ttā vitakka vicārānaṃ abhāvaḥ codakena vuttam attham sampaṭicchitvā
translated: they have become free from the state of being. “This is the meaning” : the absence of applied thought and sustained thought by their being abandoned by means of development. Having assented to the meaning stated by the questioner,

original: pariharituṃ “evametaṃ siddhovāyamattho”ti vatvā “na paneta”ntiādi vuttaṃ. Tattha
analyzed: pariharitum evam etam siddhaḥ uva ayam atthaḥ ti vatvā na pana itantiādi vuttam tattha
translated: in order to reply he said “This meaning is established thus” and then said “But this is not so” , etc. Herein,

original: etanti “vitakkavicārānaṃ vūpasamā”ti etaṃ vacanaṃ. Tadatthadīpakanti tassa vitakkavicārābhāvamattasaṅkhātassa
analyzed: etam ti etam vacanam tad attha dīpakam ti tassa vitakka vicāra abhāva matta saṅkhātassa
translated: “this” : this statement “with the stilling of applied and sustained thought” . “Illuminates that meaning” : it illuminates that meaning called the mere absence of applied and sustained thought.

original: atthassa dīpakaṃ. Ayañhettha attho – dutiyajjhānādiadhigamūpāyadīpakena ajjhattasampasādanatāya,
analyzed: atthassa dīpakam ayam ha ittha atthaḥ dutiya jhāna ādi adhigama upāya dīpakena ajjhatta sampasādana tāya
translated: and it illuminates the meaning. The meaning here is this. By the words “with thinking and pondering” the first jhāna is illuminated as the footing for the arising of the second jhāna, etc.,🔽and by the words “born of seclusion” it is illuminated as the footing for the arising of the second jhāna, etc.,🔽and by the words “born of concentration” it is illuminated as the footing for the arising of the second jhāna, etc.,

original: cetaso ekodibhāvatāya ca hetudīpakena, avitakkaavicārabhāvahetudīpakena ca vitakkavicāravūpasamavacaneneva🔽vitakkavicārābhāvo dīpitoti kiṃ puna avitakkaavicāravacanena katenāti? Na, adīpitattā.
analyzed: cetasaḥ eka udi bhāva tāya ca hetu dīpakena avitakka avicāra bhāva hetu dīpakena ca vitakka vicāra vūpa sama vacanena iva  vitakka vicāra abhāvaḥ kim punar a vitakka avicāra vacanena katena ati na
translated: and by the words “accompanied by enjoyment” it is illuminated as the footing for the arising of the second jhāna, etc.,🔽and by the words “accompanied by pleasure” it is illuminated as the footing for the arising of the second jhāna, etc.,🔽and by the words “accompanied by the equanimity of pleasure” it is illuminated as the footing for the arising of the second jhāna, etc.,🔽and by the words “accompanied by the equanimity of neither pain nor pleasure” it is illuminated as the footing for the arising of the second jhāna, etc.,🔽and by the words “accompanied by the equanimity of renunciation” it is illuminated as the footing for the arising of the second jhāna, etc.,🔽and by the words “accompanied by the equanimity of the sphere of nothingness” it is illuminated as the footing for the arising of the second jhāna, etc.,

original: Na hi vitakkavicāravūpasamavacanena vitakkavicārānaṃ appavatti vuttā hoti. Vitakkavicāresu🔽hi taṇhāppahānaṃ etesaṃ vūpasamanaṃ, ye ca saṅkhāresu taṇhāppahānaṃ karonti, tesu🔽maggesu, pahīnataṇhesu ca phalesu saṅkhārapavatti hoti eva, evamevidhāpi vikkhambhitavitakkavicārataṇhassa
analyzed: na hi vitakka vicāra vūpasama vacanena vitakka vicārānaṃ appavatti vuttā hoti vitakka vicāresu  hi taṇhā ppahānam etesam vūpasamanam ye ca saṅkhāresu taṇhā ppahānam karonti tesu  maggesu pahīna taṇhesu ca phalesu saṅkhāra pavatti hoti eva evam evidhā api vikkhambhita vitakka vicāra taṇhassa
translated: and by the words “accompanied by the equanimity of the sphere of neither perception nor non-perception” it is illuminated as the footing for the arising of the second jhāna, etc.,🔽and by the words “accompanied by the equanimity of the attainment of cessation” it is illuminated as the footing for the arising of the second jhāna, etc.,🔽and by the words “accompanied by the equanimity of the fruit of stream-entry” it is illuminated as the footing for the arising of the second jhāna, etc.,🔽and by the words “accompanied by the equanimity of the fruit of once-return” it is illuminated as the footing for the arising of the second jhāna, etc.,

original: dutiyajjhānassa vitakkavicārasampayogo purimena na nivārito siyāti taṃnivāraṇatthaṃ,
analyzed: dutiya jhānassa vitakka vicāra sampayogaḥ purimena na nivāritaḥ siyāti tad nivāraṇa attham
translated: and by the words “accompanied by the equanimity of the fruit of non-return” it is illuminated as the footing for the arising of the second jhāna, etc.,🔽and by the words “accompanied by the equanimity of the fruit of arahantship” it is illuminated as the footing for the arising of the second jhāna, etc.,

original: āvajjitukāmatādiatikkamova tesaṃ vūpasamoti dassanatthañca “avitakkaṃ avicāra”nti
analyzed: āvajjitu kāma tā ādi atikkamaḥ uva tesam vūpasamaḥ ti dassana ttham ca a vitakkam a vicāranti
translated: And in order to show that their subsiding is merely the surmounting of the desire to advert, etc., he said ‘without thinking, without pondering. ’

original: vuttaṃ. Paṭhamampīti paṭhamaṃ jhānampi.
analyzed: vuttam paṭhamam pi iti paṭhamam jhānam api
translated: ‘The first’: the first jhāna too.

original: “Dutiyaṃ uppannantipi dutiya”nti vattuṃ vaṭṭatiyeva. Na tathā imassa vitakkavicārāti
analyzed: dutiyam uppannam ti pi dutiyanti vattum vaṭṭatiyā iva na tathā imassa vitakka vicārā ti
translated: It is proper to say that the second is arisen in the second, but not that the second is of the first.

original: yathā paṭhamajjhānassa upacārakkhaṇe nīvaraṇāni pahīyanti, tathā imassa dutiyajjhānassa
analyzed: yathā paṭhama jhānassa upacāra kkhaṇe nīvaraṇāni pahīyanti tathā imassa dutiya jhānassa
translated: But the second jhāna’s access is not without thinking and pondering, as is the first jhāna’s, because it is of the same class as that jhāna.

original: upacārakkhaṇe vitakkavicārā na pahīyanti asaṃkiliṭṭhasabhāvattā, upacārabhāvanāya
analyzed: upacāra kkhaṇe vitakka vicārāḥ na pahīyanti a saṃkiliṭṭha sabhāva tā upacāra bhāvanāya
translated: And it is incapable of abandoning thinking and pondering because it is developed only as access.

original: ca te pahātuṃ asamatthabhāvato. Yadipi tāya tesu taṇhā pahīyati, na pana savisesaṃ.
analyzed: ca te pahātum asamattha bhāvataḥ yadi pi tāya tesu taṇhā pahīyati na pana sa visesam
translated: Although craving for the first jhāna is abandoned in it, that is not decisively.🔽For decisive abandonment of craving there is only absorption.

original: Savisesañhi tattha taṇhāppahānaṃ appanāya eva hoti. Tena vuttaṃ “appanākkhaṇeyevā”tiādi.
analyzed: sa visesam hi tattha taṇhā appahānam appanāya eva hoti tena vuttam appanā khaṇe iva ātiādi
translated: That is why it is said that the second jhāna is without thinking and without pondering only at the moment of absorption.

original: Pahānaṅgatāpi atisayappahānavaseneva veditabbā yathā nīvaraṇānaṃ paṭhamajjhānassa.
analyzed: pahāna aṅga tā api atisaya ppahāna vasena iva veditabbā yathā nīvaraṇānam paṭhama jhānassa
translated: And the ‘without thinking’ and ‘without pondering’ should be understood as said of decisive abandonment of thinking and pondering, as in the case of the first jhāna.

original: Tasmāti yasmā tivaṅgamevetaṃ jhānaṃ, tasmā. Tanti vibhaṅge vacanaṃ. Rathassa paṇḍukambalaṃ
analyzed: tasmāti jhānam jhānam vibhaṅge
translated: “Therefore”: because the jhāna has only five factors, “that” is the statement in the Vibhaṅga. The chariot’s white canopy

original: viya sampasādo jhānassa parikkhāro, na jhānaṅganti āha “saparikkhāraṃ jhānaṃ dassetu”nti.
analyzed: viya sampasādaḥ jhānassa parikkhāraḥ na jhānaṅganti āha sa parikkhāram jhānam dassetunti
translated: “Therefore”: because the jhāna has only five factors, “that” is the text in the Vibhaṅga. “In order to show the jhāna together with its requisites”: confidence is a requisite of the jhāna like the white cloth is a requisite of the dye.

original: Tatiyajjhānakathāvaṇṇanā🔽82. Uppilāvitanti kāmañcāyaṃ pariggahesu apariccattapemassa anādīnavadassino taṇhāsahagatāya🔽pītiyā pavattiākāro, idha pana dutiyajjhānapīti adhippetā. Tathāpi sabbaso pītiyaṃ🔽avirattaṃ, sāpi anubandheyyāti vuttaṃ. Uppilāvitaṃ viyāti vā uppilāvitaṃ. Ādīnavaṃ
analyzed: tatiya jhāna kathā vaṇṇanā  kāmam ca ayam pariggahesu a pariccatta pemassa anādīnava dassinaḥ taṇhā sahagatāya  pītiyā pavatti ākāraḥ idha pana dutiya jjhāna pīti adhippetā tathā api sabbaso pītiyam  a virattam sā api anubandheyya iti vuttam uppilāvitam viya ati vā uppilāvitam ādīnavam
translated: The explanation of the third jhāna

original: hi tattha pākaṭataraṃ katvā dassetuṃ evaṃ vuttanti daṭṭhabbaṃ.
analyzed: hi tattha pākaṭataram katvā dassetum evam vuttan ti daṭṭhabbam
translated: “Agitation”: this is the mode of occurrence of the kind of happiness accompanied by craving in one who has not relinquished passion for happiness and does not see its danger. But here the happiness of the second jhāna is intended. Still, it is said thus because it would follow if there were no complete dispassion for happiness. Or alternatively, “agitation” can be taken as agitation. And it can be regarded as said in this way in order to point out the danger in it by making it evident.

original: 83. Virajjanaṃ virāgo. Taṃ pana virajjanaṃ nibbindanamukhena hīḷanaṃ vā tappaṭibaddharāgappahānaṃ
analyzed: virajjanam virāgaḥ tam pana virajjanam nibbindana mukhena hīḷanam vā tad paṭibaddha rāga ppahānam
translated: “Dispassion”: fading away of greed. But this fading away of greed is the slighting of greed by means of the turning away from it or it is the abandoning of the greed that is bound up with the slighting.

original: vāti tadubhayaṃ dassetuṃ “vuttappakārāya pītiyā jigucchanaṃ vā samatikkamo vā”ti
analyzed: vā ti tat ubhayam dassetum vutta ppakārāya pītiyāḥ jigucchanam vā samatikkamaḥ vā ati
translated: In order to show both of these, he said, “disgust with or surmounting of the happiness described” .🔽 Described thus: described as “the happiness there” , etc.

original: āha. Vuttappakārāyāti “yadeva tattha pītī”tiādinā vuttappakārāya. Sampiṇḍanaṃ samuccayo.
analyzed: āha vutta ppakārāya iti yat eva tattha pi iti ādinā vutta ppakārāya sampiṇḍanam samuccayaḥ
translated: The combination is the concurrence.🔽Path: means: means of attaining.

original: Maggoti upāyo. Tadadhigamāyāti tatiyamaggādhigamāya.
analyzed: maggaḥ uti upāyaḥ tad adhigamāya ati tatiya magga adhigamāya
translated: For attaining the third path: for attaining the third jhāna.🔽By rebirth: by rebirth in the form of a natural consequence.

original: 84. Upapattitoti samavāhitabhāvena patirūpato. Jhānupekkhāpi samavāhitameva antonītaṃ
analyzed: upapattitaḥ ti samavāhita bhāvena patirūpataḥ jhānu pekkhā api samavāhitam eva antonītam
translated: Jhāna equanimity occurs after it has been brought to the same level by being drawn in and made to occur in the same way throughout.🔽That is why it is said, “he looks on with equanimity” .

original: katvā pavattatīti āha “samaṃ passatī”ti. Visadāyāti paribyattāya saṃkilesavigamena.
analyzed: katvā pavattati iti āha samam passati iti visadāya ati paribyattāya saṃkilesa vigamena
translated: Clear: purified by the disappearance of defilements.🔽Wide: great, having reached a higher level.

original: Vipulāyāti mahatiyā sātisayaṃ mahaggatabhāvappattiyā. Thāmagatāyāti pītivigamena thirabhāvappattāya.
analyzed: vipulāya ati mahatiyā sa atisayam mahaggata bhāvappattiyā thāma gatāya ati pīti vigamena thira bhāva ppattāya
translated: Unmoved: having reached steadiness by the disappearance of happiness.🔽The natural purity of the cankers’ destruction is the absence of defilements.

original: Parisuddhapakati khīṇāsavapakati nikkilesatā. Sattesu kammassakatādassanahetuko samabhāvadassanākāro majjhattākāro brahmavihārupekkhā.
analyzed: parisuddha pakati khīṇāsava pakati nikkilesa tā sattesu kammassaka tā dassana hetukaḥ sama bhāva dassana ākāraḥ majjhatta ākāraḥ brahmavihāra upekkhā
translated: The equanimity of the divine abidings is the mode of looking on with impartiality that has as its cause the seeing of the ownership of kamma by beings.

original: Sahajātadhammānanti niddhāraṇe sāmivacanaṃ. Samappavattiyā bhāvanāya vīthipaṭipannāya🔽alīnānuddhatā nirassādatāya paggahaniggahasampahaṃsanesu byāpārābhāvato sampayuttadhammesu
analyzed: sahajāta dhammānan ti niddhāraṇe sāmi vacanam sama pavattiyā bhāvanāya vīthi paṭipannāya  alīna anuddhatāḥ nirassāda tāya paggaha niggaha sampahaṃsanesu byāpāra abhāvato sampayutta dhammesu
translated: When the development of equanimity is occurring in the way already described,

original: majjhattākārabhūtā bojjhaṅgupekkhā.
analyzed: majjhatta ākāra bhūtā
translated: equanimity as a factor for Awakening is the state of equilibrium among the associated states, because there is no activity of exertion, restraint, or encouragement due to the absence of disquiet and restlessness and to the absence of dissatisfaction.

original: Upekkhānimittanti ettha līnuddhaccapakkhapātarahitaṃ majjhattaṃ vīriyaṃ upekkhā.
analyzed: upekkhā nimittam ti ettha līn uddhacca pakkhapāta rahitam majjhattam vīriyam upekkhā
translated: “Sign of equanimity”: here equanimity is the middle way free from the extremes of disquiet and restlessness.

original: Tadeva taṃ ākāraṃ gahetvā pavattetabbassa tādisassa vīriyassa nimittabhāvato upekkhānimittaṃ
analyzed: tat eva tam ākāram gahetvā pavattetabbassa tādisassa vīriyassa nimitta bhāvataḥ upekkhā nimittam
translated: It is the sign of equanimity because it is the cause for the occurrence of equanimity in the form of energy that occurs by apprehending that same state.

original: bhāvanāya samappavattikāle upekkhīyatīti upekkhā, vīriyameva upekkhā vīriyupekkhā.🔽“Paṭhamaṃ jhānaṃ paṭilābhatthāya nīvaraṇe…pe… nevasaññānāsaññāyatanasamāpattiṃ paṭilābhatthāya
analyzed: bhāvanāya sama ppavatti kāle upekkhīyati iti upekkhā vīriyam eva upekkhā vīriya upekkhā  paṭhamam jhānam paṭilābha tthāya nīvaraṇepe nevasaññānāsaññāyatana samāpattim paṭilābha tthāya
translated: At the time of the occurrence of development, equanimity is equanimity in the sense of being even, and it is energy, thus it is equanimity-energy.🔽“The understanding that is applied to surmounting the hindrances … to attaining the first jhāna … to attaining the base of neither-perception-nor-non-perception …

original: ākiñcaññāyatanasaññaṃ paṭisaṅkhā santiṭṭhanā paññā saṅkhārupekkhāsu ñāṇa”nti evamāgatā
analyzed: ākiñcaññāyatana saññam paṭisaṅkhā santiṭṭhanā paññā saṅkhāra upekkhāsu ñāṇan ti evam āgatā
translated: to surmounting the perception of the base of nothingness and continuing in the perception of the sphere of nothingness is knowledge of equanimity about formations” .

original: imā aṭṭha samādhivasena uppajjanti. “Sotāpattimaggaṃ paṭilābhatthāya uppādaṃ pavattaṃ🔽nimittaṃ āyūhanaṃ paṭisandhiṃ gatiṃ nibbattiṃ upapattiṃ jātiṃ jaraṃ byādhiṃ maraṇaṃ
analyzed: imāḥ aṭṭha samādhi vasena uppajjanti sotāpatti maggam paṭilābha atthāya uppādam pavattam  nimittam āyūhanam paṭisandhim gatim nibbattim upapattim jātim jaram byādhim maraṇam
translated: “The knowledge of contemplation of dissolution is the knowledge of contemplation of rise in the case of the contemplation of dissolution of the five aggregates as objects.🔽“The knowledge of contemplation of rise and fall is the knowledge of contemplation of rise and fall in the case of the contemplation of rise and fall of the five aggregates as objects.🔽“The knowledge of contemplation of rise and fall is the knowledge of contemplation of rise and fall in the case of the contemplation of rise and fall of the five aggregates as objects.🔽“The knowledge of contemplation of rise and fall is the knowledge of contemplation of rise and fall in the case of the contemplation of rise and fall of the five aggregates as objects.

original: sokaṃ paridevaṃ upāyāsaṃ. Sotāpattiphalasamāpattatthāya uppādaṃ pavattaṃ…pe… arahattamaggaṃ🔽paṭilābhatthāya uppādaṃ…pe… upāyāsaṃ…pe… arahattaphalasamāpattatthāya suññatāvihārasamāpattatthāya
analyzed: sokam paridevam upāyāsam sotāpatti phala samāpatta tthāya uppādam arahatta maggaṃ  paṭilābha tthāya uppāda aṃpe upāyāsaṃpe arahatta phala samāpatta tthāya suññatā vihāra samāpatta tthāya
translated: “The knowledge of contemplation of rise and fall is the knowledge of contemplation of rise and fall in the case of the contemplation of rise and fall of the five aggregates as objects.🔽“The knowledge of contemplation of rise and fall is the knowledge of contemplation of rise and fall in the case of the contemplation of rise and fall of the five aggregates as objects.🔽“The knowledge of contemplation of rise and fall is the knowledge of contemplation of rise and fall in the case of the contemplation of rise and fall of the five aggregates as objects.🔽“The knowledge of contemplation of rise and fall is the knowledge of contemplation of rise and fall in the case of the contemplation of rise and fall of the five aggregates as objects.

original: animittavihārasamāpattatthāya uppādaṃ pavattaṃ nimittaṃ āyūhanaṃ paṭisandhiṃ gatiṃ🔽nibbattiṃ upapattiṃ jātiṃ jaraṃ byādhiṃ maraṇaṃ sokaṃ paridevaṃ upāyāsaṃ paṭisaṅkhā🔽santiṭṭhanā paññā saṅkhārupekkhāsu ñāṇa”nti evamāgatā imā dasa vipassanāvasena uppajjanti.
analyzed: animitta vihāra samāpatta tthāya uppādam pavattam nimittam āyūhanam paṭisandhim gatim  nibbattim upapattim jātim jaram byādhim maraṇam sokam paridevam upāyāsam paṭisaṅkhā  santiṭṭhanā paññā saṅkhāra upekkhāsu ñāṇan ti evam āgatā imā dasa vipassanā vasena uppajjanti
translated: “The knowledge of contemplation of rise and fall is the knowledge of contemplation of rise and fall in the case of the contemplation of rise and fall of the five aggregates as objects.🔽“The knowledge of contemplation of rise and fall is the knowledge of contemplation of rise and fall in the case of the contemplation of rise and fall of the five aggregates as objects.🔽“The knowledge of contemplation of rise and fall is the knowledge of contemplation of rise and fall in the case of the contemplation of rise and fall of the five aggregates as objects.🔽“The knowledge of contemplation of rise and fall is the knowledge of contemplation of rise and fall in the case of the contemplation of rise and fall of the five aggregates as objects.

original: Ettha ca paṭhamajjhānādīhi vikkhambhitāni nīvaraṇavitakkavicārādīni paṭisaṅkhāya
analyzed: ettha ca paṭhama jhāna ādīhi vikkhambhitāni nīvaraṇa vitakka vicāra ādīni paṭisaṅkhāya
translated: “The knowledge of contemplation of rise and fall is the knowledge of contemplation of rise and fall in the case of the contemplation of rise and fall of the five aggregates as objects.🔽“The knowledge of contemplation of

original: sabhāvato upaparikkhitvā sanniṭṭhānavasena tiṭṭhamānā nīvaraṇādipaṭisaṅkhāsantiṭṭhanā
analyzed: sabhāvataḥ upaparikkhitvā sanniṭṭhāna vasena tiṭṭhamānā nīvaraṇa ādi paṭisaṅkhā santiṭṭhanā
translated: And the equanimity that is the state of standing-point in the sense of the state of decision when it stands as the state of standing-point consisting in reflection on the hindrances, etc.,

original: diṭṭhādīnavattā tesaṃ gahaṇe uppādane ajjhupekkhantī vipassanāpaññā gahaṇe majjhattabhūtā upekkhā.🔽Tattha uppādanti purimakammapaccayā khandhānaṃ idha uppattimāha. Pavattanti tathāuppannassa
analyzed: diṭṭha ādīnava ttā tesam gahaṇe uppādane ajjhupekkhantī vipassanā paññā gahaṇe majjhatta bhūtā upekkhā  tattha uppādanti purima kamma paccayā khandhānam idha uppattim āha pavattanti tathāuppannassa
translated: is the equanimity that is neutrality in apprehending, which is understanding by insight into the danger in seeing, etc., in producing, and in looking on at them.

original: pavattiṃ. Nimittanti sabbampi tebhūmakasaṅkhāragataṃ nimittabhāvena upaṭṭhānato.
analyzed: pavattim nimittam ti sabbam pi tebhūmaka saṅkhāra gatam nimitta bhāvena upaṭṭhānato
translated: Herein, “arising” is the arising of the aggregates here through former kamma as condition. “Occurrence” is the occurrence of what has arisen in that way. “Sign” is all that is included in the three kinds of becoming as a sign since it appears as a sign.

original: Āyūhananti āyatiṃ paṭisandhihetubhūtaṃ kammaṃ. Paṭisandhinti āyatiṃ uppattiṃ. Gatinti🔽yāya gatiyā sā paṭisandhi hoti. Nibbattinti khandhānaṃ nibbattanaṃ. Upapattinti “samāpannassa
analyzed: āyūhananti āyatim paṭisandhi hetu bhūtam kammam paṭisandhim ti āyatim uppattim gatim ti  yāya gatiyā sā paṭisandhi hoti nibbattin ti khandhānam nibbattanam upapattin ti samāpannassa
translated: “Accumulation” is kamma that is a condition for rebirth-linking in the future. “Rebirth-linking” is future arising. “Destiny” is🔽the destiny by means of which there is that rebirth-linking. “Generation” is the generation of the aggregates. “Re-arising” is the occurrence of the result stated thus, “In one who has attained, or in one who has been reborn” . “Birth” is

original: vā upapannassa vā”ti ettha “upapannassā”ti vuttavipākappavattiṃ. Jātinti jarādīnaṃ
analyzed: vā upapannassa vā ti ettha upapannassa ati vutta vipāka ppavattim jātim ti jarā ādīnam
translated: the birth of ageing, etc.,

original: paccayabhūtaṃ bhavapaccayā jātiṃ. Jarābyādhimaraṇādayo pākaṭā eva. Ettha ca uppādādayo
analyzed: paccaya bhūtam bhava paccayāḥ jātim jarā byādhi maraṇa ādayaḥ pākaṭāḥ eva ettha ca uppāda ādayaḥ
translated: and the condition is stated as “With becoming as condition: birth.” Aging, sickness, death, etc., are obvious. Herein,

original: pañceva saṅkhārupekkhāñāṇassa visayavasena vuttā, sesā tesaṃ vevacanavasena. “Nibbatti,🔽jātī”ti idañhi dvayaṃ uppādassa ceva paṭisandhiyā ca vevacanaṃ, “gati, upapatti cā”ti
analyzed: pañca iva saṅkhāra upekkhā ñāṇassa visaya vasena vuttā sesā tesam vevacana vasena nibbatti  jāti iti idam hi dvayam uppādassa ca iva paṭisandhiyā ca vevacanam gati upapatti ca ati
translated: the five, namely, arising, etc., are stated as the province of the knowledge of equanimity about formations, and the rest are synonyms for them.🔽“Generation” and “birth” are synonyms for arising and rebirth-linking.

original: idaṃ dvayaṃ pavattassa, jarādayo nimittassāti veditabbaṃ. Appaṇihitavimokkhavasena
analyzed: idam dvayam pavattassa jarā ādayaḥ nimittassa ati veditabbam appaṇihita vimokkha vasena
translated: “Destiny” and “reappearance” are synonyms for occurrence. Aging, etc., are synonyms for the sign.🔽The four that are the cause for the arising of the path through the signless deliverance,

original: magguppattihetubhūtā catasso, tathā phalasamāpattiyā catasso, suññatavihāraanimittavihāravasena
analyzed: magga uppatti hetu bhūtā catasso tathā phala samāpattiyā catasso suññata vihāra animitta vihāra vasena
translated: and the four that are the cause for the attainment of fruition, and the two that are the cause for the void abiding and the signless abiding,

original: dveti dasa saṅkhārupekkhā.🔽Yāti vipassanāpaññā. Yadatthīti yaṃ aniccādilakkhaṇattayaṃ upalabbhati. Yaṃ bhūtanti
analyzed: dve iti dasa saṅkhārupekkhā  yā ati vipassanā paññā yat atthi iti yam anicca ādi lakkhaṇa ttayam upalabbhati yam bhūta nti
translated: make ten kinds of equanimity about formations.

original: yaṃ paccayanibbattattā bhūtaṃ khandhapañcakaṃ. Taṃ pajahatīti aniccānupassanādīhi
analyzed: yam paccaya nibbatta ttā bhūtam khandha pañcakam tam pajahati iti anicca anupassanā ādīhi
translated: “Yā” is insight knowledge. “Yadatthi” is the triple characteristic of impermanence, etc., which is found. “Yaṃ bhūtaṃ” is the five aggregates that have come into being because they have been generated by conditions. “Taṃ pajahā” means “Abandon that” by means of the contemplations of impermanence, etc.

original: niccasaññādayo pajahanto sammadeva diṭṭhādīnavattā tappaṭibaddhacchandarāgappahānena
analyzed: nicca saññā ādayo pajahanto sammat eva diṭṭha ādīnava ttā tad paṭibaddha chanda rāga ppahānena
translated: He abandons the perception of permanence, etc., by seeing the danger in them and by abandoning the desire and lust for them.

original: pajahati, yathā āyatiṃ ādānaṃ na hoti, tathā paṭipattiyā pajahati. Tathābhūto ca
analyzed: pajahati yathā āyatim ādānam na hoti tathā paṭipattiyā pajahati tathābhūtaḥ ca
translated: He abandons them in the sense that he does not grasp them again in the future by practising the way in which they are abandoned.🔽And he obtains equanimity towards them in the sense that he is neutral towards them.

original: tattha upekkhaṃ paṭilabhati. Vicinaneti aniccādivasena sammasanepi.
analyzed: tattha upekkham paṭilabhati vicinana iti anicca ādi vasena sammasane pi
translated: He discerns them by comprehending them as impermanent, etc.

original: Sampayuttadhammānaṃ samappavattihetutāya samavāhitabhūtā. Nīvaraṇavitakkavicārādisabbapaccanīkehi
analyzed: sampayutta dhammānam sama pavatti hetutāya samavāhita bhūtāḥ nīvaraṇa vitakka vicāra ādi sabba paccanīkehi
translated: They are unified because they are the cause of the occurrence of the associated states in a unified way.

original: vimuttattā sabbapaccanīkaparisuddhā. Tesaṃ vūpasantattā paccanīkavūpasamanepi abyāpārabhūtā
analyzed: vimutta ttā sabba paccanīka parisuddhā tesam vūpasanta ttā paccanīka vūpasamane pi a byāpāra bhūtā
translated: They are purified from opposition because they are freed from all opposition such as the hindrances, applied thought, sustained thought, etc.🔽They are tranquillized in the sense that the opposition has been tranquillized.

original: abyāpārabhāvena pavattā, abyāpārataṃ vā pattā.
analyzed: a byāpāra bhāvena pavattā a byāpāratam vā pattā
translated: They occur with non-opposition, or they have attained non-opposition.🔽If they are identical in meaning, how is there this distinction?

original: Yadi atthato ekā, kathamayaṃ bhedoti āha “tena tenā”tiādi. Tasmāti yasmā satipi sabhāvato
analyzed: yadi atthataḥ ekā katham ayam bhedo ti āha tena tena atiādi tasmā ati sabhāvato
translated: Therefore, although they are undifferentiated in meaning,

original: abhede yehi pana paccayavisesehi svāyamimāsaṃ avatthābhedo, tesaṃ ekajjhaṃ appavattito
analyzed: abhede yehi pana paccaya visesehi avatthā bhedaḥ tesam ekajjham appavattitaḥ
translated: they are not undifferentiated in function because of the difference in conditions.

original: na tāsaṃ abhedo, ekajjhaṃ vā pavatti, tasmā. Tenāha “yattha chaḷaṅgupekkhā”tiādi.🔽Ekībhāvoti ekatā. Satipi majjhattābhāvasāmaññe visayabhedena panassā bhedo. Yamatthaṃ
analyzed: na tāsam abhedaḥ ekajjham vā pavatti tasmā tena āha yattha chaḍaṅgu pekkhā atiādi  ekībhāvaḥ ti ekatā sati pi majjhattā bhāva sāmaññe visaya bhedena pana assā bhedaḥ yam attham
translated: But they are not mixed up or combined, so it was said above, “Where there are six kinds of equanimity. ”

original: sandhāya “kiccavasena dvidhā bhinnā”ti vuttaṃ, taṃ vitthārato dassento “yathā hī”tiādimāha.
analyzed: sandhāya kicca vasena dvidhā bhinnā iti vuttam tam vitthārataḥ dassentaḥ yathā hi iti ādim āha
translated: “Unity” is oneness. Although equanimity is the same in being the mere middle, it is divided up according to its object. The meaning of the words “is twofold as to function” is given in detail in the passage beginning, “For example.”

original: Ayaṃ vipassanupekkhā. Yaṃ sandhāya vuttaṃ pāḷiyaṃ “yadatthi yaṃ bhūtaṃ, taṃ pajahati,
analyzed: ayam vipassanā upekkhā yam sandhāya vuttam pāḷiyam yat atthi yam bhūtam tam pajahati
translated: This is insight equanimity. It is with reference to this that it is said in the text, “Whatever exists and is subject to origination he abandons,

original: upekkhaṃ paṭilabhatī”ti. Tattha yadatthi yaṃ bhūtanti khandhapañcakaṃ, taṃ muñcitukamyatāñāṇena🔽pajahati. Diṭṭhasovattikattayassa sabbalakkhaṇavicinane viya diṭṭhalakkhaṇattayassa
analyzed: upekkham paṭilabhati iti tattha yat atthi yam khandha pañcakam tam muñcitu kamya tā ñāṇena  pajahati diṭṭha sovattika ttayassa sabba lakkhaṇa vicinane viya diṭṭha lakkhaṇa ttayassa
translated: and he obtains equanimity” . Herein, whatever exists and is subject to origination is the five aggregates. He abandons them with the knowledge of desire for deliverance.🔽He obtains equanimity in the investigation of the characteristics of what exists and is subject to origination, as he does in the investigation of the three characteristics of what is seen and heard.

original: bhūtassa saṅkhāralakkhaṇavicinane upekkhaṃ paṭilabhati. Saṅkhārānaṃ aniccādilakkhaṇassa
analyzed: bhūtassa saṅkhāra lakkhaṇa vicinane upekkham paṭilabhati saṅkhārānaṃ anicca ādi lakkhaṇassa
translated: He obtains equanimity in the investigation of the characteristics of formations, which are subject to origination, as he does in the investigation of the three characteristics of what is seen and heard.

original: sudiṭṭhattā tesaṃ vicinane majjhattabhūtāya vipassanupekkhāya siddhāya tathā diṭṭhādīnavānaṃ
analyzed: su diṭṭha ttā tesam vicinane majjhatta bhūtāya vipassana upekkhāya siddhāya tathā diṭṭha ādīnavānam
translated: Because they are well seen, equanimity about insight is successful as neutrality in the investigation of them.🔽

original: tesaṃ gahaṇepi ajjhupekkhanā siddhāva hoti, sabbaso visaṅkhāraninnattā ajjhāsayassa.🔽Anābhogarasāti paṇītasukhepi tasmiṃ avanatipaṭipakkhakiccāti attho. Abyāpārapaccupaṭṭhānāti🔽satipi sukhapāramippattiyaṃ tasmiṃ sukhe abyāvaṭā hutvā paccupatiṭṭhati, sampayuttānaṃ
analyzed: tesam gahaṇe pi ajjhupekkhanā siddhau a hoti sabbaso visaṅkhāra ninna ttā ajjhāsayassa  anābhoga rasā ati paṇīta sukhe pi tasmim avanati paṭipakkha kiccā ati atthaḥ a byāpāra paccupaṭṭhānā ti  sati pi sukha pārami pattiyam tasmim sukhe abyāvaṭāḥ hutvā paccupatiṭṭhati sampayuttānam
translated: Since they have been well seen, the equanimity of insight, which is neutral in the investigation of them, is established. And so too the looking on at the danger in them, which is the opposite of the relishing of them, is established, since the mind’s inclination to all relishing is completely eliminated.🔽The meaning is that it has the function of opposing the inclination to that refined pleasure.

original: vā tattha abyāpāraṃ paccupaṭṭhapetīti attho. Sampayuttadhammānaṃ khobhaṃ, uppilavañca
analyzed: vā tattha a byāpāram paccupaṭṭhapeti iti attho sampayutta dhammānam khobham uppilavant ca
translated: It is manifested as non-ill will: it is manifested by not turning away from that pleasure even when it has reached the limit of pleasure, or the meaning is that it manifests non- relishing in the associated states.

original: āvahantehi vitakkādīhi abhibhūtattā aparibyattaṃ. Tattha tatramajjhattatāya kiccaṃ.
analyzed: āvahantehi vitakka ādīhi abhibhūta ttā a paribyattam tattha tatram ajjhatta tāya kiccam
translated: It is unmoved: it is unmoved by the agitation and excitement caused by applied thoughts, etc., which are opposed to it. Its function is to be neutral in regard to those.

original: Tadabhāvato idha paribyattaṃ.
analyzed: tad abhāvataḥ u idha paribyattam
translated: It is moved here because it is devoid of that.

original: Niṭṭhitā “upekkhako ca viharatī”ti etassa
analyzed: niṭṭhitā upekkhako ca viharati iti etassa
translated: The explanation of “he dwells in equanimity” is ended.

original: Sabbaso atthavaṇṇanā.
analyzed: sabbaso attha vaṇṇanā
translated: The commentary on the meaning of the whole section is ended.

original: 85. “Saratīti sato”ti padassa kattusādhanatamāha. Sampajānātīti sammadeva pajānāti.
analyzed: sarati iti satā iti padassa kattu sādhanatam āha sampajānāti iti sammat eva pajānāti
translated: “Mindful” is the agent of the verb “is mindful.” “Clearly comprehending” is comprehending by means of clear comprehension.🔽The characteristic of mindfulness is the characteristic of remembering, of thinking about, of keeping in being.

original: Saraṇaṃ cintanaṃ upaṭṭhānaṃ lakkhaṇametissāti saraṇalakkhaṇā. Sammussanapaṭipakkho🔽asammussanaṃ, taṃ kiccaṃ etissāti asammussanarasā. Kilesehi ārakkhā hutvā paccupatiṭṭhati,
analyzed: saraṇam cintanam upaṭṭhānam lakkhaṇam etissa ati saraṇa lakkhaṇā sammussana paṭipakkho  a sammussanam tat kiccam etissa ati a sammussana rasā kilesehi ārakkhā hutvā paccupatiṭṭhati
translated: The function of mindfulness is the opposite of that of forgetfulness.🔽Its manifestation is non-forgetfulness. It is the protection of the mind,

original: tato vā ārakkhaṃ paccupaṭṭhapetīti ārakkhapaccupaṭṭhānā. Asammuyhanaṃ sammadeva pajānanaṃ,🔽sammohapaṭipakkho vā asammoho. Tīraṇaṃ kiccassa pāragamanaṃ. Pavicayo vīmaṃsā.
analyzed: tatas vā ārakkham paccupaṭṭhapeti iti ārakkha paccupaṭṭhānā a sammuyhanam sammat eva pajānanam  sammoha paṭipakkhaḥ vā asammohaḥ tīraṇam kiccassa pāra gamanam pavicayaḥ vīmaṃsā
translated: or it establishes protection, thus it is the establishment of protection. Non-confusion is clear comprehension,🔽or non-delusion is the opposite of confusion. Its proximate cause is the object that is being scrutinized.🔽The third jhāna is superior to the second because of the absence of rapture, and it is also described as “seclusion of the mind” since it is associated with equanimity, which is described as “seclusion” .

original: Kāmaṃ upacārajjhānādīni upādāya paṭhamadutiyajjhānānipi sukhumāneva, imaṃ pana uparijhānaṃ
analyzed: kāmam upacāra jhāna ādīni upādāya paṭhama dutiya jhānāni pi imam pana upari jhānam
translated: The fourth jhāna is superior to the third because of the absence of happiness, and it is also described as “neither-pain-nor-pleasure” since it is associated with equanimity, which is described as “neither-pain-nor-pleasure” .🔽The fifth jhāna is superior to the fourth because of the absence of agitation, and it is also described as “peaceful” since it is associated with the peacefulness of the mind that has reached mastery of the fourfold and fivefold jhāna.

original: upādāya “oḷārikattā”ti vuttaṃ. Sā ca oḷārikatā vitakkādithūlaṅgatāya veditabbā. Keci
analyzed: upādāya oḷārika ttā iti vuttam sā ca oḷārika tā vitakka ādi thūlaṅgatāya veditabbā keci
translated: The sixth jhāna is superior to the fifth because of the absence of the sign of the fifth jhāna, and it is also described as “signless” since it is associated with the signless concentration .🔽The seventh jhāna is superior to the sixth because of the absence of the sixth jhāna’s desire for the signless, and it is also described as “desireless” since it is associated with desire for the desireless .🔽The eighth jhāna is superior to the seventh because of the absence of the seventh jhāna’s desire for the desireless, and it is also described as “empty” since it is associated with emptiness .

original: “bahucetasikatāyā”ti ca vadanti. Gati sukhā hoti tattha jhānesūti adhippāyo. Abyattaṃ
analyzed: ca vadanti gati sukhā hoti tattha jhānesu iti adhippāyaḥ abyattam
translated: The ninth jhāna is superior to the eighth because of the absence of the eighth jhāna’s desire for the empty, and it is also described as “wish” since it is associated with the wish for the attainment of the supramundane jhāna.

original: tattha satisampajaññakiccaṃ “idaṃ nāma dukkaraṃ karīyatī”ti vattabbassa abhāvato.
analyzed: tattha sati sampajañña kiccam idam nāma dukkaram karīyati iti vattabbassa abhāvataḥ
translated: Herein, the function of mindfulness and full awareness is not mentioned because there is no need to say “This is difficult to do” as there was in the case of the first jhāna.

original: Oḷārikaṅgappahānena sukhumattāti ayamattho kāmaṃ dutiyajjhānepi sambhavati, tathāpi🔽yebhuyyena avippayogībhāvena vattamānesu pītisukhesu pītisaṅkhātassa oḷārikaṅgassa
analyzed: oḷārika aṅga pahānena sukhuma tā ti ayam attho kāmam dutiya jhāne pi sambhavati tathā api  yebhuyyena a vippayogībhāvena vattamānesu pīti sukhesu pīti saṅkhātassa oḷārikaṅgassa
translated: The meaning of “subtle” is that the gross factor is abandoned. This meaning is applicable also in the case of the second jhāna, but

original: pahānena sukhumatāya idha sātisayo satisampajaññabyāpāroti vuttaṃ “purisassā”tiādi.
analyzed: pahānena sukhuma tāya idha sa atisayaḥ sati sampajañña byāpāraḥ ti vuttam purisassa atiādi
translated: it is stated here with special reference to the joy and happiness which are present there without separation.🔽The meaning is that he might enter and emerge from the second jhāna again and again.

original: Punadeva pītiṃ upagaccheyyāti hānabhāgiyaṃ jhānaṃ siyā dutiyajjhānameva sampajjeyyāti🔽attho. Tenāha “pītisampayuttameva siyā”ti. “Idañca atimadhuraṃ sukha”nti tatiyajjhānasukhaṃ
analyzed: punar eva pītim upagaccheyya ati hāna bhāgiyam jhānam siyā dutiya jhānam eva sampajjeyya iti  tena āha pīti sampayuttam eva siyā ti idam ca ati madhuram sukhanti tatiya jhāna sukham
translated: The words “he should see that it has the joy-factor” are stated with reference to the second jhāna.🔽The words “he should see that it has the happiness-factor” are stated with reference to the third jhāna.🔽The words “he should see that it has the unification-factor” are stated with reference to the fourth jhāna.

original: sandhāyāha. Atimadhuratā cassa pahāsodagyasabhāvāya pītiyā abhāveneva veditabbā.
analyzed: sandhāya āha ati madhura tā ca ssa pahāsa udagyasa bhāvāya pītiyāḥ abhāvena iva veditabbā
translated: The words “he should see that it has the neither-pain-nor-pleasure-factor” are stated with reference to the fourth jhāna.

original: Idanti “sato, sampajāno”ti padadvayaṃ.
analyzed: id anti sataḥ sampajānoti pada dvayam
translated: The words “he should see that it has the equanimity-factor” are stated with reference to the fourth jhāna.🔽The words “he should see that it has the purity-of-mindfulness-factor” are stated with reference to the fourth jhāna.🔽The words “he should see that it has the equanimity-of-mind-factor” are stated with reference to the fourth jhāna.🔽The words “he should see that it has the neither-perception-nor-non-perception-factor” are stated with reference to the base consisting of neither perception nor non-perception.

original: Tasmā etamatthaṃ dassentoti yasmā tassa jhānasamaṅgino yaṃ nāmakāyena sampayuttaṃ
analyzed: tasmai etam attham dassento ti yasmā tassa jhāna samaṅginaḥ yam nāmakāyena sampayuttam
translated: Therefore, showing this meaning,🔽because of the fact that the one who possesses that jhāna has a name-group associated with it,

original: sukhaṃ, taṃ so paṭisaṃvedeyya. Yaṃ vā tanti atha vā yaṃ taṃ yathāvuttaṃ nāmakāyasampayuttaṃ🔽sukhaṃ. Taṃsamuṭṭhānena tato samuṭṭhitena atipaṇītena rūpena assa jhānasamaṅgino🔽rūpakāyo yasmā phuṭo. Yassa rūpakāyassa phuṭattā jhānā vuṭṭhitopi jhānasamaṅgī kāyikaṃ🔽sukhaṃ paṭisaṃvedeyya. Tasmā etaṃ cetasikakāyikasukhapaṭisaṃvedanasaṅkhātaṃ atthaṃ🔽dassento “sukhañca kāyena paṭisaṃvedetīti āhā”ti yojanā. Ayañhettha saṅkhepattho🔽– nāmakāyena cetasikasukhaṃ, kāyikasukhaheturūpasamuṭṭhāpanena kāyikasukhañca jhānasamaṅgī
analyzed: sukham tam saḥ paṭisaṃvedeyya yam vā atha vā yam tam yathāvuttam nāmakāya sampayuttam  sukham tad samuṭṭhānena tatas samuṭṭhitena atipaṇītena rūpena assa jhāna samaṅginaḥ  rūpa kāyaḥ phuṭaḥ yassa rūpa kāyassa phuṭa ttā jhānā vuṭṭhitaḥ api jhāna samaṅgī kāyikam  sukham paṭisaṃvedeyya tasmai etam cetasika kāyika sukha paṭisaṃvedana saṅkhātam attham  dassentaḥ sukham ca kāyena paṭisaṃvedeti iti āha ati yojanā ayan ha ittha saṅkhepa atthaḥ  nāmakāyena cetasika sukham kāyika sukha hetu rūpa samuṭṭhāpanena kāyika sukham ca jhāna samaṅgī
translated: Therefore, showing this meaning, etc. Since the pleasant feeling associated with the mental body is experienced by one who possesses jhāna, or alternatively, the pleasant feeling associated with the mental body mentioned in the way already given,

original: paṭisaṃvedetīti vuccati. Phuṭattāti byāpitattāti attho. Yathā hi udakena phuṭasarīrassa
analyzed: paṭisaṃvedeti iti vuccati phuṭa ttā ati byāpita ttā ati atthaḥ yathā hi udakena phuṭa sarīrassa
translated: by the arising of that, by the most excellent materiality arisen from that, the material body of one who possesses jhāna is pervaded. Because of the pervasion of the material body, even when one who possesses jhāna has emerged from the jhāna, he experiences bodily pleasant feeling. Therefore, showing this meaning, which is called the experience of mental and bodily pleasant feeling, he said, “And he experiences pleasure with the body.” This is the construction here. The meaning in brief is this: The mental pleasant feeling by means of the mental body and the bodily pleasant feeling by the generation of the materiality that is the cause of bodily pleasant feeling are said to be experienced by one who possesses jhāna. Pervasion means pervasion. For just as the body of one whose body is pervaded by water

original: tādise nātipaccanīke vātādiphoṭṭhabbe phuṭe sukhaṃ uppajjati, evametehi phuṭasarīrassāti.
analyzed: tādise na ati paccanīke vāta ādi phoṭṭhabbe phuṭe sukham uppajjati evam etehi phuṭa sarīrassa ati
translated: When the body is touched by such not-too-opposed tactile objects as air, etc., pleasure arises. So it is said that pleasure is experienced with the body when the body is touched by them.

original: Aparo nayo – sukhañca kāyena paṭisaṃvedetīti ettha kathamābhogena vinā sukhapaṭisaṃvedanāti🔽codanāyaṃ “kiñcāpi…pe… evaṃ santepī”ti. Yasmā tassa nāmakāyena sampayuttaṃ sukhaṃ,
analyzed: aparaḥ nayaḥ sukham ca kāyena paṭisaṃvedeti iti ettha katham ābhogena vinā sukha paṭisaṃvedanā ati  evam sante pi iti yasmā tassa nāmakāyena sampayuttam sukham
translated: Another method: in the passage, “He experiences pleasure with the body” , since it is asked, “How can there be the experience of pleasure without contact? ”🔽and the answer is given, “Although this is so, nevertheless” , it is said that pleasure is associated with the body-consciousness.

original: tasmā sukhañca kāyena paṭisaṃvedetīti yojanā. Idāni sahāpi ābhogena sukhapaṭisaṃvedanaṃ
analyzed: sukham ca kāyena paṭisaṃveda iti yojanā idāni saha api ābhogena sukha paṭisaṃvedanam
translated: Therefore the construction is: “He experiences pleasure with the body” . Now, in order to show the experience of pleasure even with contact,

original: dassetuṃ “yaṃ vā ta”ntiādi vuttaṃ.
analyzed: dassetum yam vā tanti ādi vuttam
translated: “Or whatever” is said.

original: 86. Yanti hetuatthe nipāto, yasmāti attho. Tenāha “yaṃjhānahetū”ti. “Ācikkhantī”tiādīni
analyzed: yanti hetu atthe nipātaḥ yasmā iti tena āha ācikkhanti itiādīni
translated: The particle “yaṃ” has the meaning of cause; the meaning is “since.” Therefore it is said, “since it is the cause of jhāna.” The words “he extols” , etc.,

original: padāni kittanatthānīti adhippāyenāha “pasaṃsantīti adhippāyo”ti. Kintīti pasaṃsanākārapucchā.
analyzed: padāni kittana atthāni iti adhippāyena āha pasaṃsanti iti adhippāyo iti pasaṃsana ākāra pucchā
translated: are words of praise. The intention is: “he extols.” “What?” is a question asking in what way he extols.

original: Edisesu ṭhānesu satiggahaṇeneva sampajaññampi gahitaṃ hotīti idha pāḷiyaṃ satiyā
analyzed: edisesu ṭhānesu sati ggahaṇena iva sampajaññam pi gahitam hoti iti idha pāḷiyam satiyā
translated: In such passages, clear comprehension is included by the mention of mindfulness. Therefore here in the text, by the word “mindfulness” ,

original: eva gahitattā evaṃ upaṭṭhitasatitāya “satimā” icceva vuttaṃ, “sampajāno”ti heṭṭhā vuttattā vā.
analyzed: eva gahita ttā evam upaṭṭhita sati tāya satimā icca iva vuttam sampajānoti heṭṭhā vutta ttā vā
translated: “Mindful” is said because he is thus possessed of and endowed with mindfulness. Or alternatively, “fully aware” is said below, and so it is said here only as “mindful.”

original: Jhānakkhaṇe cetasikasukhameva labbhatīti “sukhaṃ nāmakāyena paṭisaṃvedetī”ti ca vuttaṃ.
analyzed: jhāna kkhaṇe cetasika sukham eva labbhati iti sukham nāmakāyena paṭisaṃvedeti iti ca vuttam
translated: At the moment of jhāna, only mental pleasure is obtained, and so it is said that he “experiences with the mental body the pleasure that is a quality of jhāna.”

original: Tatiyanti gaṇanānupubbatāti ito paṭṭhāya dutiyatatiyajjhānakathāhi aviseso, viseso ca vuttoti.
analyzed: tatiyam ti gaṇanā anupubba tā ti itas paṭṭhāya dutiya tatiya jhāna kathāhi avisesaḥ viseso ca vutto ti
translated: Third: in the order of enumeration. From here on there is no difference in the description of the second and third jhānas, but the difference is stated.

original: Catutthajjhānakathāvaṇṇanā
analyzed: catuttha jhāna kathā vaṇṇanā
translated: The fourth jhāna

original: 87. Idāni nibbattitavisesaṃ dassento “ayaṃ pana viseso”ti vatvā “yasmā”tiādimāha.
analyzed: idāni nibbattita visesam dassentaḥ ayam pana visesaḥ iti vatvā yasmā iti ādim āha
translated: Now, in order to point out the special quality produced in this jhāna, he said, “This is the distinguishing mark of the fourth jhāna.”

original: Āsevanapaccayena paccayo na hoti, aniṭṭhe ṭhāne padantarasaṅgahitassa āsevanapaccayattābhāvato.
analyzed: āsevana paccayena paccayaḥ na hoti aniṭṭhe ṭhāne pada antara saṅgahitassa āsevana paccaya tta abhāvato
translated: It is not a condition by repetition because the repetition condition does not exist for what is included in the next clause in an undesirable place.

original: Adukkhamasukhāya vedanāya uppajjitabbaṃ sātisayaṃ sukhavirāgabhāvanābhāvato. Tānīti
analyzed: adukkham asukhāya vedanāya uppajjitabbam sa atisayam sukha virāga bhāvanā bhāvataḥ tāni iti
translated: Because there is no development of the surmounting of the neither-painful-nor-pleasant in the sense of the surmounting of the neither-painful-nor-pleasant feeling that arises. The “those”

original: appanāvīthiyaṃ javanāni sandhāyāha.
analyzed: appanāvīthiyam javanāni sandhāya āha
translated: refers to the impulsion processes in the cognitive series.

original: 88. “Pubbevā”ti vuttattā kadā pana tesaṃ pahānaṃ hotīti codanāyaṃ āha “catunnaṃ jhānānaṃ
analyzed: pubbā iva ati vutta ttā kadā pana tesam pahānam hoti iti codanāyam āha catunnam jhānānam
translated: Since it is said “previously,” the question arises, “When then is their abandoning?” and so he said, “The abandoning of these three is in the four jhānas.

original: upacārakkhaṇe”ti. Evaṃ veditabbanti sambandho. Pahānakkamo nāma pahāyakadhammānaṃ
analyzed: upacāra khaṇe iti evam veditabbam ti sambandhaḥ pahāna kkamaḥ nāma pahāyaka dhammānam
translated: At the moment of access. This is how it should be understood. The order of abandoning is the order of arising of the states to be abandoned.🔽But if that is so, then “pain, grief, pleasure, and joy” should be stated

original: uppattipaṭipāṭi. Tena pana vuccamāne “dukkhaṃ domanassaṃ sukhaṃ somanassa”nti vattabbaṃ🔽siyā. Kasmā ito aññathā vacananti āha “indriyavibhaṅge”tiādi. Atha kasmā jhānesveva
analyzed: uppatti paṭipāṭi tena pana vuccamāne dukkham domanassam sukham somanassanti vattabbam  siyā kasmai itas aññathā vacananti āha indriya vibhaṅga itiādi atha kasmai jhānesu eva
translated: instead of “sorrow, lamentation, pain, grief, and despair.”🔽Why is it stated otherwise? He said “in the Description of the Faculties” .

original: nirodho vuttoti sambandho.🔽Kattha cuppannaṃ dukkhindriyanti attano paccayehi uppannaṃ dukkhindriyaṃ. Kattha
analyzed: nirodhaḥ vutto ti sambandho  kattha ca uppannam dukkha indriyanti attanaḥ paccayehi uppannam dukkha indriyam kattha
translated: But why is cessation stated only in the jhānas?🔽Where does the arisen pain faculty cease without remainder?🔽He asks where the pain faculty, which has arisen through its own conditions,

original: ca aparisesaṃ nirujjhatīti nirodhaṭṭhānaṃ pucchati. Tena “katthā”ti pucchāyaṃ, “etthā”ti🔽vissajjanepi hetumhi bhummavacanaṃ daṭṭhabbaṃ. Jhānānubhāvanimittaṃ hi anuppajjantaṃ
analyzed: ca aparisesam nirujjhati iti nirodha ṭṭhānam pucchati tena kattha iti puccha ayam ettha ati  vissajjane pi hetumhi bhumma vacanam daṭṭhabbam jhāna anubhāva nimittam hi an uppajjantam
translated: ceases. “Where” is a locative of place. “Here” is a locative of cause.🔽For it is said that the pain faculty ceases without remainder when the cause of its arising is not produced.

original: “dukkhindriyaṃ aparisesaṃ nirujjhatī”ti vuttaṃ. Atisayanirodho suṭṭhu pahānaṃ ujupaṭipakkhena vūpasamo.
analyzed: dukkha indriyam aparisesam nirujjhati iti vuttam atisaya nirodhaḥ suṭṭhu pahānam uju paṭipakkhena vūpasamaḥ
translated: Complete cessation is complete abandoning, complete subsiding through substitution of opposites.

original: Nānāvajjaneti yena āvajjanena appanāvīthi, tato bhinnāvajjane, anekāvajjane vā. Appanāvīthiyañhi
analyzed: nānā āvajjana iti yena āvajjanena appanā vīthi tatas bhinna āvajjane aneka āvajjane vā appanā vīthiyam hi
translated: In different kinds of adverting: in different kinds of adverting from that by which the cognitive series is entered upon absorption. Or in many kinds of adverting. For

original: upacāro ekāvajjano, itaro anekāvajjano anekakkhattuṃ pavattanato. Visamanisajjāya🔽uppannakilamatho visamāsanupatāpo. Pītipharaṇenāti pītiyā pharaṇarasattā, pītisamuṭṭhānānaṃ
analyzed: upacāraḥ eka āvajjanaḥ itaraḥ aneka āvajjanaḥ aneka khattum pavattanataḥ visama nisajjāya  uppanna kilamathaḥ pīti pharaṇena ati pītiyā pharaṇa rasa ttā pīti samuṭṭhānānam
translated: the access state is with single adverting, while the other is with many kinds of adverting because it occurs many times. The fatigue that arises from sitting in the uncomfortable posture is the discomfort of sitting in the uncomfortable posture.

original: vā paṇītarūpānaṃ kāyassa byāpanato vuttaṃ. Tenāha “sabbo kāyo sukhokkanto hotī”ti.🔽Vitakkavicārapaccayepīti pi-saddo aṭṭhānappayutto, so “pahīnassā”ti ettha ānetvā
analyzed: vā paṇīta rūpānam kāyassa byāpanataḥ vuttam tena āha sabbaḥ kāyo sukha ukkanto hoti iti  vitakka vicāra paccaye pi iti pi saddaḥ aṭṭhāna ppayuttaḥ saḥ pahīnassa ati ettha ānetvā
translated: With the pervasion of happiness: because of the state of pervasion by happiness, or because of the pervading of the body with the exquisite materiality originated by happiness. Hence it is said, “The whole body is as if full of happiness” .🔽The word “also” is out of its regular place; it should be brought to “abandoned” .🔽The construction is: “In one in whom the faculty of grief is abandoned, that faculty of grief does not exist. But this faculty of grief arises” .🔽The construction is: “In one in whom the faculty of grief is abandoned, that faculty of grief does not exist. But this faculty of grief arises” .

original: sambandhitabbo “pahīnassāpi domanassindriyassā”ti. Etaṃ domanassindriyaṃ uppajjatīti🔽sambandho. “Tassa mayhaṃ aticiraṃ vitakkayato vicārayato kāyopi kilamicittampi uhaññī”ti
analyzed: sambandhitabbo pahīnassa api domanassa indriyassa ati etam domanassa indriyam uppajjati iti  sambandhaḥ tassa mayham aticiram vitakkayataḥ vicārayataḥ kāyaḥ api kilami cittam pi
translated: The construction is: “In one in whom the faculty of grief is abandoned, that faculty of grief does not exist. But this faculty of grief arises” .🔽The construction is: “In one in whom the faculty of grief is abandoned, that faculty of grief does not exist. But this faculty of grief arises” .🔽The construction is: “In one in whom the faculty of grief is abandoned, that faculty of grief does not exist. But this faculty of grief arises” .🔽The construction is: “In one in whom the faculty of grief is abandoned, that faculty of grief does not exist. But this faculty of grief arises” .🔽The construction is: “In one in whom the faculty of grief is abandoned, that faculty of grief does not exist. But this faculty of grief arises” .🔽The construction is: “In one in whom the faculty of grief is abandoned, that faculty of grief does not exist. But this faculty of grief arises” .🔽The construction is: “In one in whom the faculty of grief is abandoned, that faculty of grief does not exist. But this faculty of grief arises” .

original: vacanato kāyacittakhedānaṃ vitakkavicārappaccayatā veditabbā. “Vitakkavicārabhāve
analyzed: vacanataḥ kāya citta khedānam vitakka vicāra ppaccaya tā veditabbā vitakka vicāra bhāve
translated: The construction is: “In one in whom the faculty of grief is abandoned, that faculty of grief does not exist. But this faculty of grief arises” .

original: uppajjati domanassindriya”nti ānetvā sambandhitabbaṃ. Tatthassa siyā uppattīti tattha
analyzed: uppajjati domanassindriyan ti ānetvā sambandhitabbam tatthassa siyā uppatti iti tattha
translated: and the faculty of grief arises” should be brought in and connected. Herein, it might arise there:

original: dutiyajjhānūpacāre assa domanassassa uppatti bhaveyya.
analyzed: dutiya jhānu upacāre assa domanassassa uppatti bhaveyya
translated: it might arise there in the preliminary-work concentration of the second jhāna.

original: Ettha ca yadeke “tatthassa siyā uppattī”ti vadantena jhānalābhīnampi domanussuppatti
analyzed: ettha ca yat eke tatthassa siyā uppatti iti vadantena jhāna lābhīnam pi domanussa uppatti
translated: And here some say that the words “it might arise there” show that grief arises in one who has obtained the jhānas too.

original: atthīti dassitaṃ hoti. Tena ca anīvaraṇasabhāvo lobho viya dosopi atthīti dīpeti.
analyzed: atthi iti dassitam hoti tena ca anīvaraṇa sabhāvaḥ lobhaḥ viya dosaḥ api atthi iti dīpeti
translated: And by that he shows that hate is a root of profit like greed.

original: Na hi dosena vinā domanassaṃ pavattati. Na cettha paṭṭhānapāḷiyā virodho cintetabbo.
analyzed: na hi dosena vinā domanassam pavattati na ca ittha paṭṭhāna pāḷiyā virodhaḥ cintetabbo
translated: For grief does not occur without hate. And here the words of the text should not be taken as a contradiction.

original: Yasmā tattha parihīnaṃ jhānaṃ ārammaṇaṃ katvā pavattamānaṃ domanassaṃ dassitaṃ, aparihīnajjhānamārammaṇaṃ🔽katvā uppajjamānassa domanassassa asambhavato. Jhānalābhīnaṃ sabbaso domanassaṃ nuppajjatīti
analyzed: yasmā tattha parihīnam jhānam ārammaṇam katvā pavattamānam domanassam dassitam a parihīna jhānam ārammaṇam  katvā uppajjamānassa domanassassa asambhavataḥ jhāna lābhīnam sabbasas domanassam nuppajjati iti
translated: For what is shown there is grief occurring with the jhāna that has been obtained as its object,🔽and it is impossible for grief to arise with the jhāna that has not been obtained as its object.🔽And it cannot be said that grief does not arise in one who has obtained the jhāna at all,

original: ca na sakkā vattuṃ, aṭṭhasamāpattilābhino api tassa uppannattā. Na heva kho so pahīnajjhāno
analyzed: ca na sakkā vattum aṭṭha samāpatti lābhinaḥ api tassa uppanna ttā na ha iva kho so pahīna jjhānaḥ
translated: for it arises in one who has obtained the eight attainments.🔽And it is not that he is one who has lost the jhāna,

original: ahosīti vadanti, taṃ ayuttaṃ anīvaraṇasabhāvassa dosassa abhāvato. Yadi siyā, rūpārūpāvacarasattānampi
analyzed: vadanti tam ayuttam anīvaraṇa sabhāvassa dosassa abhāvataḥ yadi siyā rūpa arūpa avacara sattānam pi
translated: they say that it is. But that is not tenable, because hate has no existence as a hindrance. If it did, it would arise in beings in the fine-material and immaterial realms too,🔽and it does not do so. For in the following passages: “With the sense-desire element and the sense-desire property as decisive support there arises in dependence on wrong view the hindrance of ill will … the hindrance of stiffness and torpor … the hindrance of worry and flurry … the hindrance of uncertainty” ,

original: uppajjeyya, na ca uppajjati. Tathā hi “arūpe kāmacchandanīvaraṇaṃ paṭicca thinamiddhanīvaraṇaṃ🔽uddhaccanīvaraṇaṃ avijjānīvaraṇa”ntiādīsu byāpādakukkuccanīvaraṇāni anuddhaṭāni.
analyzed: uppajjeyya na ca uppajjati tathā hi arūpe kāmacchanda nīvaraṇam paṭicca thinamiddha nīvaraṇam  uddhacca nīvaraṇam avijjā nīvaraṇa nti ādīsu byāpāda kukkucca nīvaraṇāni an uddhaṭāni
translated: and “With the formless-world element and the formless-world property as decisive support there arises in dependence on wrong view the hindrance of ill will … the hindrance of stiffness and torpor … the hindrance of worry and flurry … the hindrance of uncertainty” ,🔽the hindrances of ill will and worry and flurry are not mentioned.🔽And here the fact that they are hindrances is not a reason, because sense desire, etc., which are not hindrances are mentioned in the way they are because they resemble hindrances.

original: Na cettha nīvaraṇattā parihāro, kāmacchandādīnampi anīvaraṇānaṃyeva nīvaraṇasadisatāya🔽nīvaraṇapariyāyassa vuttattā. Yaṃ pana vuttaṃ “aṭṭhasamāpattilābhino api tassa uppannattā”ti,
analyzed: na ca ittha nīvaraṇa ttā parihāraḥ kāmacchanda ādīnam pi nīvaraṇa sadisa tāya  nīvaraṇa pariyāyassa vutta ttā yat pana vuttam aṭṭha samāpatti lābhinaḥ api tassa uppanna ttā ti
translated: But it was said that it is wrong to say that worry and flurry are not hindrances because they are not mentioned as such in the description of the hindrances in the Vibhaṅga .🔽That is not a reason, because the hindrances are mentioned there in the way best calculated to show the way in which they are hindrances.🔽And it was said that it is wrong to say that worry and flurry are not hindrances because they are not mentioned as such in the description of the hindrances in the Abhidhamma .🔽That is not a reason, because the Abhidhamma is not concerned with what is not a mental factor.🔽And it was said that it is wrong to say that worry and flurry are not hindrances because they are not mentioned as such in the description of the hindrances in the Suttanta .

original: tampi akāraṇaṃ uppajjamānena ca domanassena jhānato parihāyanato. Lahukena pana paccayena🔽parihīnaṃ tādisā appakasireneva paṭipākatikaṃ karontīti daṭṭhabbaṃ. “Tatthassa siyā
analyzed: tam pi akāraṇam uppajjamānena ca domanassena jhānataḥ parihāyanataḥ lahukena pana paccayena 🔽parihīnam tādisāḥ appa kasirena iva paṭipākatikam karonti iti daṭṭhabbam tatthassa siyā
translated: That is not a reason, because the Suttanta is not concerned with what is not a mental factor.

original: uppattī”ti idaṃ pana parikappavacanaṃ upacārakkhaṇe domanassassa appahīnabhāvadassanatthaṃ.
analyzed: uppatti iti idam pana parikappa vacanam upacāra kkhaṇe domanassassa appahīna bhāva dassana attham
translated: But this is said by way of a simile in order to show that grief is not abandoned at the moment of access.

original: Tathā hi vuttaṃ “na tveva antoappanāya”nti. Yadi pana tadā domanassaṃ uppajjeyya,
analyzed: tathā hi vuttam na tu eva antoappanāyanti yadi pana tadā domanassam uppajjeyya
translated: For it is said, “But not by the attainment of absorption” . If grief arose then,🔽it would be necessary to regard the first jhāna as having been lost.

original: paṭhamajjhānampissa parihīnamevāti daṭṭhabbaṃ. Pahīnampi somanassindriyaṃ pīti viya🔽na dūreti katvā “āsannattā”ti vuttaṃ. Nānāvajjanūpacāre pahīnampi pahānaṅgaṃ paṭipakkhena
analyzed: paṭhamajjhānam pissa parihīnam eva ati daṭṭhabbam pahīnam pi somanassindriyam pīti viya  na dūra iti katvā āsanna ttā iti vuttam nānā vajjana upacāre pahīnam pi pahāna aṅgam paṭipakkhena
translated: And although the faculty of joy is abandoned, it is not far from the jhāna, like the happiness.🔽So it is said to be “near” . And although the factor of abandoning is abandoned in the case of one who has entered upon the process of change of lineage, it would arise again from time to time, since it is not suppressed by its opposite.

original: avihatattā antarantarā uppajjeyya vāti imamatthaṃ dassento “appanāppattāyā”tiādimāha.🔽Tādisāya āsevanāya icchitabbattā yathā maggavīthito pubbe dve tayo javanavārā sadisānupassanāva
analyzed: avihata ttā antarantarā uppajjeyya vā ti imam attham dassentaḥ appanā appattāya iti ādim āha  tādisāya āsevanāya icchitabba ttā yathā magga vīthitaḥ pubbe dve tayo javana vārā
translated: So, in order to show this, he said, “When it has reached absorption” .

original: pavattanti, evamidhāpi appanāvārato pubbe dve tayo javanavārā upekkhāsahagatāva pavattantīti vadanti.
analyzed: pavattanti evam idha api appanā vārato pubbe dve tayo javana vārāḥ upekkhā sahagatāḥ ava pavattanti iti vadanti
translated: And since it is necessary to desire such practice, they say that just as in the case of the path, two or three impulsions of a kind similar to that of the contemplation of pain occur previously to the actual path, so too in this case two or three impulsions accompanied by equanimity occur previously to the actual absorption.

original: Samāhaṭāti samānītā, saṅgahetvā vuttāti attho. Sukhadukkhāni viya anoḷārikattā avibhūtatāya
analyzed: samāhaṭā iti samānītā saṅgahetvā vuttā ati attho sukha dukkhāni viya anoḷārika ttā avibhūta tāya
translated: They are ‘subtle’ because they are not gross like pleasure and pain, because they are not evident.🔽And because they can only be inferred, they are ‘hard to see.’

original: sukhumā. Tato eva anuminitabbasabhāvattā duviññeyyā. Duṭṭhassāti duṭṭhapayogassa,
analyzed: sukhumā tatas eva anuminitabba sabhāva ttā du viññeyyā duṭṭhassa ati duṭṭha payogassa
translated: ‘For one of evil wishes’: for one of evil means.🔽The meaning is: for one hard to tame.

original: duddammassāti attho. Sakkā hoti esā gāhayituṃ aññāpohananayenāti adhippāyo.
analyzed: duddammassa ati attho sakkā hoti esā gāhayitum aññāpohana nayena ati adhippāyo
translated: The intention is that it is possible to understand it by the method of exclusion of the other.

original: Adukkhamasukhāya cetovimuttiyāti idameva catutthajjhānaṃ daṭṭhabbaṃ. Paccayadassanatthanti
analyzed: adukkham asukhāya cetaḥ vimuttiyā ti idam eva catuttha jhānam daṭṭhabbam paccaya dassana ttham ti
translated: ‘The liberation of the mind through neither-pain-nor-pleasure’: this should be regarded as the fourth jhāna.🔽‘For the purpose of showing the conditions’:

original: adhigamassa upāyabhūtapaccayadassanatthaṃ. Tenāha “dukkhappahānādayo hi tassā paccayā”ti.
analyzed: adhigamassa upāya bhūta paccaya dassana attham tena āha dukkha ppahāna ādayaḥ hi tassā paccayā ti
translated: for the purpose of showing the conditions that are the means to its attainment. Hence he said: ‘For its conditions are the abandoning of pleasure, and so on.’

original: Dukkhappahānādayoti ca sopacārā paṭhamajjhānādayovettha adhippetā.
analyzed: dukkha ppahāna ādayaḥ ti ca sa upacārā adhippetā
translated: And ‘the abandoning of pleasure, and so on’ includes the first jhāna, and so on, with their adjuncts.🔽‘Abandoned’: ‘with the destruction of the five lower fetters’ .

original: Pahīnāti vuttā “pañcannaṃ orambhāgiyānaṃ saṃyojanānaṃ parikkhayā”ti. Etāti sukhādayo vedanā.🔽Somanassaṃ rāgassa paccayo. Vuttañhi “sukhāya kho, āvuso visākha, vedanāya rāgānusayo
analyzed: pahīnā ati vuttā pañcannam orambhāgiyānam saṃyojanānam parikkhayā ati etā ati sukha ādayaḥ vedanā 🔽somanassam rāgassa paccayaḥ vuttam hi sukhāya kho āvuso visākha vedanāya rāga anusayaḥ
translated: ‘This’: the kinds of feeling such as pleasure.

original: anusetī”ti. Domanassaṃ dosassa paccayo. Vuttampi cetaṃ “dukkhāya kho, āvuso visākha,
analyzed: anuseti iti domanassam dosassa paccayaḥ vuttam pi ca itam dukkhāya kho āvuso visākha
translated: and it is said: “In painful feeling, friend Visāka, the underlying tendency to resistance underlies” .

original: vedanāya paṭighānusayo anusetī”ti. Sukhādighātenāti sukhādīnaṃ pahānena. Assa jhānassa.🔽Na dukkhanti adukkhaṃ, dukkhavidhuraṃ. Yasmā tattha dukkhaṃ natthi, tasmā vuttaṃ
analyzed: vedanāya paṭigha anusayaḥ anuseti iti sukha ādi ghātena ati sukha ādīnam pahānena assa jhānassa  na dukkhanti adukkham dukkha vidhuram yasmā tattha dukkham na atthi tasmā vuttam
translated: And “by the abandoning of pleasure” is by the abandoning of pleasure, etc., and “of the jhāna” is of the jhāna.🔽“Not painful”: not painful, free from pain. Since there is no pain there, it is said:🔽“because of the absence of pain.” “Not pleasant”: the same explanation applies here.

original: “dukkhābhāvenā”ti. Asukhanti etthapi eseva nayo. Etenāti dukkhasukhapaṭikkhepavacanena.
analyzed: dukkha abhāvena ati asukhanti ettha api esa iva nayaḥ etena ati dukkha sukha paṭikkhepa vacanena
translated: “By the words that reject pain and pleasure”: by the words that reject pain and pleasure.

original: “Paṭipakkhabhūta”nti idaṃ idha tatiyavedanāya dukkhādīnaṃ samatikkamavasena pattabbattā
analyzed: paṭipakkha bhūtanti idam idha tatiya vedanāya dukkha ādīnam samatikkama vasena pattabba ttā
translated: “The opposite of”: this is said here because the third kind of feeling is to be reached by surmounting pain, etc.,

original: vuttaṃ, na kusalākusalānaṃ viya ujuvipaccanīkatāya. Iṭṭhāniṭṭhaviparītassa majjhattārammaṇassa,
analyzed: vuttam na kusala akusalānam viya uju vipaccanīka tāya iṭṭha aniṭṭha viparītassa majjhatta ārammaṇassa
translated: not because it is the direct opposite of profitable and unprofitable kinds as the case of pain and pleasure is.🔽The characteristic of the experience of the opposite of what is desired and not desired is the characteristic of the experience of the opposite of what is desired and not desired in the form of the neutral state,

original: iṭṭhāniṭṭhaviparītaṃ vā majjhattākārena anubhavanalakkhaṇā iṭṭhāniṭṭhaviparītānubhavanalakkhaṇā.
analyzed: iṭṭha aniṭṭha viparītam vā majjhatta ākārena anubhavana lakkhaṇā iṭṭha aniṭṭha viparīta anubhavana lakkhaṇā
translated: or the characteristic of the experience of the opposite of what is desired and not desired in the form of the neutral state.

original: Tato eva majjhattarasā. Avibhūtapaccupaṭṭhānāti sukhadukkhāni viya na vibhūtākārā,
analyzed: tatas eva majjhatta rasā avibhūta paccupaṭṭhānā ati sukha dukkhāni viya na vibhūta ākārā
translated: And that is why it is of the middle pitch. Its manifestation is not evident: it is not evident in the way that pleasure and pain are.

original: piṭṭhipāsāṇe migagatamaggo viya tehi anumātabbā avibhūtākāropaṭṭhānā. Sukhanirodho
analyzed: piṭṭhi pāsāṇe miga gata maggaḥ viya tehi anumātabbā avibhūta ākāra upaṭṭhānā sukha nirodho
translated: It is manifested in a way that is not evident, like the path made by a deer on the surface of a rock. It has the cessation of pleasure as its proximate cause.

original: nāma idha catutthajjhānūpacāro, so padaṭṭhānaṃ etissāti sukhanirodhapadaṭṭhānā.
analyzed: nāma idha catuttha jhāna upacāro so padaṭṭhānam etissa ati sukha nirodha padaṭṭhānā
translated: The “cessation of pleasure” here is the neighbourhood of the fourth jhāna. It is the proximate cause of that, thus it is “having the cessation of pleasure as its proximate cause.”

original: 89. “Upekkhāsatipārisuddhi”nti purimapade uttarapadalopenetaṃ samāsapadanti āha “upekkhāya🔽janitasatipārisuddhi”nti. Sabbapaccanīkadhammaparisuddhāya paccanīkasamanepi abyāvaṭāya
analyzed: upekkhā sati pārisuddhim ti purima pade uttara pada lopena itam samāsa padam ti āha upekkhāya  janita sati pārisuddhinti sabba paccanīka dhamma parisuddhāya paccanīka samane pi a byāvaṭāya
translated: The purification of mindfulness due to equanimity: this is a compound consisting of the first and last words only, the middle words being omitted, thus he said “the purification of mindfulness due to equanimity.”

original: pārisuddhiupekkhāya vattamānāya catutthajjhāne sati sampahaṃsanapaññā viya suparisuddhā,
analyzed: pārisuddhi upekkhāya vattamānāya catuttha jhāne sati sampahaṃsana paññā viya su parisuddhā
translated: When the purification of mindfulness occurs in the fourth jhāna, which is purified by the equanimity that is purified from all states of greed and hate that are hindrances, and is not sluggish like that of the first three jhānas,🔽it is very purified, very bright, as if it were cleansed with some cleansing substance.

original: suvisadā ca hotīti āha “yā ca tassā satiyā pārisuddhi, sā upekkhāya katā, na aññenā”ti.
analyzed: su visadā ca hoti iti āha yā ca tassā satiyā pārisuddhi sā upekkhāya katā na aññena ati
translated: And that is why he said: “And that purification of mindfulness is due to equanimity, not to anything else.”

original: Yadi tatramajjhattatā idha “upekkhā”ti adhippetā, kathaṃ satiyeva “parisuddhā”ti
analyzed: yadi tatram ajjhatta tā idha upekkhā ati adhippetā katham satiyā iva parisuddhā ati
translated: If the state of equilibrium here is intended as “equanimity,” how is it that only mindfulness is “purified”?

original: vuttāti āha “na kevala”ntiādi.
analyzed: vuttā iti āha na kevala ntiādi
translated: “Not only” is said in order to show that it is not only the equanimity of the fourth jhāna that is purified of the hindrances.

original: Evampi kasmā ayameva sati “upekkhāsatipārisuddhī”ti vuttāti anuyogaṃ sandhāya “tattha
analyzed: evam pi kasmai ayam eva sati upekkhā sati pārisuddhī iti vuttā ati anuyogam sandhāya tattha
translated: “But even though” is said in order to show that the question “Why is this equanimity called the purification by knowledge and vision of the way?”

original: kiñcāpī”tiādi vuttaṃ. Tattha heṭṭhā tīsu jhānesu vijjamānāyapi tatramajjhattatāya
analyzed: kiñcā api itiādi vuttam tattha heṭṭhā tīsu jhānesu tatram ajjhatta tāya
translated: is pertinent.

original: paccanīkābhibhavato, sahāyapaccayavekallato ca apārisuddhi, tathā taṃsampayuttānaṃ.
analyzed: paccanīka abhibhavataḥ sahāya paccaya vekallataḥ ca tathā tad sampayuttānam
translated: The purification of equanimity and the equanimity associated with it in the three lower jhānas is not complete because of the presence of opposition, because of the deficiency of the condition of a friend, and because of the deficiency of the condition of assistance.

original: Tadabhāvato idha pārisuddhīti imamatthaṃ rūpakavasena dassetuṃ “yathā panā”tiādi
analyzed: tad abhāvataḥ idha pārisuddhī iti imam attham rūpaka vasena dassetum yathā pana atiādi
translated: But here it is complete because of the absence of that opposition, etc. In order to show this meaning by means of a simile, he said, “Just as, when the sun rises …”🔽“Overpowered by the sun’s rays”: because it is overpowered by the sun’s rays.

original: vuttaṃ. Sūriyappabhābhibhavāti sūriyappabhāya abhibhuyyamānattā. Atikkhatāya candalekhā
analyzed: vuttam sūriyappabha abhibhavā ti sūriyappabhāya atikkhatāya canda lekhā
translated: The moon’s disk is like the night in that it is similar to it in being the cause of the manifestation of the night.

original: viya rattipi sommasabhāvā sabhāgāya rattiyameva ca candalekhā samujjalatīti sā tassā
analyzed: somma sabhāvā sabhāgāya rattiyam eva ca canda lekhā samujjalati iti sā tassā
translated: And the moon’s disk shines forth in the night, which is similar to it in being of the same nature as itself.

original: sabhāgāti dassento “sommabhāvena ca attano upakārakattena vā sabhāgāya rattiyā”ti āha.
analyzed: sabhāgā iti dassentaḥ somma bhāvena ca attanaḥ upakāraka ttena vā sabhāgāya rattiyā iti āha
translated: “In the night, which is similar to it in being of the same nature as itself” is said in order to show that the night is similar to the moon’s disk in being of the same nature as itself, or in being helpful to it.

original: “Ekavīthiya”nti idaṃ tattha somanassassa ekaṃsena abhāvato vuttaṃ, na tato purimataresu
analyzed: eka vīthiyam ti idam tattha somanassassa ekaṃsena abhāvataḥ vuttam na tatas purimataresu
