translated: “In one idea” is said because joy is not in one sense in that jhāna, not because it is not in the earlier impulsions.🔽But just as applied thought, etc., are only in the second jhāna onwards and not in the first jhāna,

original: ekaṃsena bhāvato. Yathā pana vitakkādayo dutiyādijjhānakkhaṇeyeva pahīyanti, na tesaṃ🔽ekavīthiyaṃ purimajavanesu, na evametanti dassetuṃ vuttaṃ. Catukkajjhāneti catukkanayavasena
analyzed: ekaṃsena bhāvataḥ yathā pana vitakka ādayaḥ dutiya ādi jhāna kkhaṇe yeva pahīyanti na tesam  eka vīthiyam purima javanesu na evam etat ti dassetum vuttam catukka jjhāne iti catukka naya vasena
translated: so too joy is only in the first jhāna and not in the second jhāna onwards.

original: nibbattitajjhānacatukke.🔽Pañcakajjhānakathāvaṇṇanā
translated: The fourfold jhāna is the fourfold jhāna classed according to the fourfold reckoning.🔽The fivefold jhāna is the fivefold jhāna classed according to the fivefold reckoning.🔽The fivefold jhāna is the fivefold jhāna classed according to the fivefold reckoning.🔽The fivefold jhāna is the fivefold jhāna classed according to the fivefold reckoning.🔽The fivefold jhāna is the fivefold jhāna classed according to the fivefold reckoning.

original: 90. Tatthāti paṭhamajjhāne. Catukkanayassa dutiyajjhāne viyāti catukkanayasambandhini🔽dutiyajjhāne viya. Taṃ dvidhā bhinditvāti catukkanaye dutiyaṃ “avitakkaṃ vicāramattaṃ,
analyzed: tattha ati paṭhama jhāne catukka nayassa dutiya jhāne viya ti catukka naya sambandhini  dutiya jhāne tam dvidhā bhinditvā ati catukka naye dutiyam a vitakkam vicāra mattam
translated: The fivefold jhāna is the fivefold jhāna classed according to the fivefold reckoning.🔽The fivefold jhāna is the fivefold jhāna classed according to the fivefold reckoning.🔽The fivefold jhāna is the fivefold jhāna classed according to the fivefold reckoning.🔽The fivefold jhāna is the fivefold jhāna classed according to the fivefold reckoning.🔽The fivefold jhāna is the fivefold jhāna classed according to the fivefold reckoning.🔽The fivefold jhāna is the fivefold jhāna classed according to the fivefold reckoning.🔽The fivefold jhāna is the fivefold jhāna classed according to the fivefold reckoning.🔽The fivefold jhāna is the fivefold jhāna classed according to the fivefold reckoning.🔽The fivefold jhāna is the fivefold jhāna classed according to the fivefold reckoning.🔽The fivefold jhāna is the fivefold jhāna classed according to the fivefold reckoning.🔽The fivefold jhāna is the fivefold jhāna classed according to the fivefold reckoning.

original: avitakkaṃ avicāra”nti ca evaṃ dvidhā bhinditvā pañcakanaye dutiyañceva tatiyañca
analyzed: a vitakkam ca evam dvidhā bhinditvā pañcaka naye dutiyam ca iva tatiyam ca
translated: The fivefold jhāna is the fivefold jhāna classed according to the fivefold reckoning.🔽The fivefold jhāna is the fivefold jhāna classed according to the fivefold reckoning.

original: hoti abhidhammeti adhippāyo. Suttantesu pana sarūpato pañcakanayo na gahito.
analyzed: hoti abhidhamme iti adhippāyaḥ suttantesu pana sarūpataḥ pañcaka nayaḥ na gahito
translated: The fivefold jhāna is the fivefold jhāna classed according to the fivefold reckoning.🔽The fivefold jhāna is the fivefold jhāna

original: Kasmā panettha nayadvayavibhāgo gahitoti? Abhidhamme nayadvayavasena jhānānaṃ desitattā.
analyzed: kasmā pana ittha naya dvaya vibhāgaḥ gahito ti abhidhamme naya dvaya vasena jhānānam desita ttā
translated: But why is the division into two methods stated here? Because the jhānas are taught in the Abhidhamma by way of the two methods.

original: Kasmā ca tattha tathā tāni desitāni? Puggalajjhāsayato, desanāvilāsato ca. Sannipatitadevaparisāya
analyzed: kasmā ca tattha tathā tāni desitāni puggala jjhāsayataḥ desanā vilāsataḥ ca sannipatita deva parisāya
translated: And why are they taught there in those ways? Because of the inclination of individuals and because of the beauty of the teaching.🔽For it seems that in the assembly of devas that had gathered together,

original: kira yesaṃ yathādesite paṭhamajjhāne vitakko eva oḷārikato upaṭṭhāsi, itare santato.
analyzed: kira yesam yathā desite paṭhama jhāne vitakkaḥ eva oḷārikataḥ upaṭṭhāsi itare santataḥ
translated: some perceived applied thought as gross and the other factors as peaceful.

original: Tesaṃ ajjhāsayavasena ca caturaṅgikaṃ avitakkaṃ vicāramattaṃ jhānaṃ desitaṃ. Yesaṃ
analyzed: tesam ajjhāsaya vasena ca caturaṅgikam avitakkam vicāra mattam jhānam desitam yesam
translated: So the jhāna with four factors, namely, without applied thought and with sustained thought only, was taught to them in accordance with their inclination.

original: vicāro, yesaṃ pīti, yesaṃ sukhaṃ oḷārikato upaṭṭhāsi, itare santato. Tesaṃ tesaṃ
analyzed: vicāraḥ yesam pīti yesam sukham oḷārikataḥ upaṭṭhāsi itare santataḥ tesam tesam
translated: Some perceived sustained thought, some happiness, and some bliss as gross and the other factors as peaceful.

original: ajjhāsayavasena tatiyādīni jhānāni desitāni. Ayaṃ tāva puggalajjhāsayo.
analyzed: ajjhāsaya vasena tatiya ādīni jhānāni desitāni ayam tāva puggala jhāsayo
translated: So the third and fourth jhānas were taught to them in accordance with their inclinations. This is the “inclination of individuals.”

original: Yassā pana dhammadhātuyā suppaṭividdhattā bhagavā yasmā desanāvilāsappatto, tasmā
analyzed: yassā pana dhammadhātuyā bhagavā yasmai desanā vilāsa ppatto tasmai
translated: But the Blessed One, who had reached the peak of the beauty of teaching by virtue of his thorough penetration of the Dhamma,

original: ñāṇamahantatāya desanāya sukusalo yaṃ yaṃ aṅgaṃ labbhati, tassa tassa vasena yathāruciṃ
analyzed: ñāṇa mahantatāya desanāya su kusalaḥ yam yam aṅgam labbhati tassa tassa vasena yathāruciṃ
translated: was so skilled in teaching that he could teach by way of any factor that was available.

original: desanaṃ niyāmento catukkanayavasena, pañcakanayavasena ca. Tattha ca pañcaṅgikaṃ
analyzed: desanam catukka naya vasena pañcaka naya vasena ca tattha ca pañcaṅgikam
translated: He taught the first jhāna by means of the fourfold reckoning and the fivefold reckoning. Herein,

original: paṭhamaṃ, caturaṅgikaṃ dutiyaṃ, tivaṅgikaṃ tatiyaṃ, duvaṅgikaṃ catutthaṃ, duvaṅgikameva
analyzed: paṭhamam catur aṅgikam dutiyam tivaṅgikam tatiyam duvaṅgikam catuttham duvaṅgikam eva
translated: the first is fivefold, the second is fourfold, the third is threefold, the fourth is twofold, and the fifth is twofold.

original: pañcamaṃ jhānaṃ desesīti ayaṃ desanāvilāso. Ettha ca pañcakanaye dutiyajjhānaṃ catukkanaye
analyzed: pañcamam jhānam desesi iti ayam desanā vilāsaḥ ettha ca pañcaka naye dutiya jhānam catukka naye
translated: This is the teaching’s beauty. And here, in the fivefold reckoning, the second jhāna is distributed under the second jhāna in the fourfold reckoning,

original: dutiyajjhānapakkhikaṃ katvā vibhattaṃ “yasmiṃ samaye rūpūpapattiyā maggaṃ bhāveti🔽avitakkaṃ vicāramattaṃ samādhijaṃ pītisukhaṃ dutiyaṃ jhānaṃ upasampajja viharatī”ti.
analyzed: dutiya jhāna pakkhikam katvā vibhattam yasmin samaye rūpa upapattiyā maggam bhāveti  a vitakkam vicāra mattam samādhi jam pīti sukham dutiyam jhānam upasampajja viharati iti
translated: as follows: “When … he develops the way to the attainment of … the second jhāna … he is one who develops the way to the attainment of … the second jhāna” .

original: Kasmā? Ekattakāyanānattasaññīsattāvāsaphalatāya dutiyajjhānena samānaphalattā, paṭhamajjhānasamādhito
analyzed: kasmai ekatta kāya nānatta saññī sattā vāsa phalatāya dutiya jhānena samāna phalattā paṭhama jhāna samādhitaḥ
translated: Why is this? Because it has the same fruit as the second jhāna in the fourfold reckoning, since it is the abode of beings who have the perception of unity in multiplicity, and because it arises from the same concentration as the first jhāna in the fourfold reckoning.

original: jātattā ca. Paṭhamajjhānameva hi “kāmehi akusalehi ca vivitta”nti tadabhāvā na idha
analyzed: jāta ttā ca paṭhama jhānam eva hi kāmehi akusalehi ca tad abhāvāḥ na idha
translated: For the first jhāna in the fourfold reckoning is called “void” because of the absence there of the hindrances, which are classed as defilements, and because of the absence there of the gross- and-subtle aspect, which is classed as ignorance.

original: “vivicceva kāmehi vivicca akusalehī”ti sakkā vattuṃ, nāpi “vivekaja”nti. Suttantadesanāsu🔽ca pañcakanaye dutiyatatiyajjhānāni dutiyajjhānameva bhajanti vitakkavūpasamā vicāravūpasamā
analyzed: vivicca iva kāmehi vivicca akusalehi iti sakkā vattum na api viveka janti suttanta desanāsu  ca pañcaka naye dutiya tatiya jhānāni dutiya jhānam eva bhajanti vitakka vūpasamāḥ vicāra vūpasamā
translated: And in the teaching of the five aggregates in the Suttas,🔽the second and third jhānas belong to the second jhāna,🔽because of the cessation of applied thought and because of the absence of applied thought and because of the absence of sustained thought.

original: avitakkattā, avicārattā ca. Evañca katvā suttantadesanāyapi pañcakanayo labbhatevāti
analyzed: a vitakka ttā a vicāra ttā ca evam ca katvā pañcaka nayaḥ labbhate iva ati
translated: And it is only when this is so that the teaching of the five aggregates in the Suttas is also in accord with the fivefold reckoning.

original: siddhaṃ hoti. Nanu suttante cattāriyeva jhānāni vibhattānīti pañcakanayo na labbhatīti?
analyzed: siddham hoti nanu suttante cattāriya iva jhānāni vibhattāni iti pañcaka nayaḥ na labbhati iti
translated: But is it not said in the Suttas that there are only four jhānas? So how can the fivefold reckoning be found there?

original: Na, “savitakkasavicāro samādhī”tiādinā samādhittayāpadesena pañcakanayassa labbhamānattā.
analyzed: na sa vitakka sa vicāraḥ samādhi iti ādinā samādhi ttayā apadesena pañcaka nayassa labbhamāna ttā
translated: No; for the fivefold reckoning is found there by the teaching of the three kinds of concentration, namely, “Concentration with thinking and exploring” , etc.

original: Catukkanayanissito pana katvā pañcakanayo vibhattoti suttantadesanāyapi pañcakanayo
analyzed: catukka naya nissitaḥ pana katvā pañcaka nayaḥ vibhattaḥ ti pañcaka nayaḥ
translated: But the fivefold reckoning is given there by taking the fourfold reckoning as the basis. So the fivefold reckoning

original: niddhāretabbo. “Vitakkavicārānaṃ vūpasamā”ti hi vitakkassa, vicārassa, vitakkavicārānañca
analyzed: niddhāretabbaḥ vitakka vicārānam vūpasamā ati hi vitakkassa vicārassa vitakka vicārānam ca
translated: can be deduced from the teaching of the five aggregates in the Suttas too. For the words “With the stilling of applied and sustained thought” refer to the cessation of applied thought, to the cessation of sustained thought, and to the cessation of both applied and sustained thought.

original: “vitakkavicārāna”nti sakkā vattuṃ. Tathā “avitakkaṃ, avicāra”nti ca vinā, saha ca
analyzed: sakkāḥ vattum tathā avitakkam a vicāranti ca vinā saha ca
translated: “With thinking and exploring” can be said. So too, “without thinking, without exploring” can be said.🔽Without thinking, with exploring, can be said. Without exploring, with thinking, can be said.

original: vicārena vitakkappahānena avitakkaṃ, saha, vinā ca vitakkena vicārappahānena avicāranti
analyzed: vicārena vitakka ppahānena avitakkam saha vinā ca vitakkena vicāra ppahānena a vicāranti
translated: Without thinking, without exploring, can be said. Without thinking, with exploring, can be said. Without exploring, with thinking, can be said.

original: avitakkaṃ, avicāraṃ, avitakkañca avicārañcāti vā tividhampi sakkā saṅgahetuṃ.
analyzed: a vitakkam a vicāram a vitakkam ca a vicāram ca ati vā tividham pi sakkā saṅga hetum
translated: So it can be classed in three ways.

original: Dutiyanti ca vitakkarahite, vitakkavicāradvayarahite ca ñāyāgatā desanā dutiyaṃ adhigantabbattā,
analyzed: ca vitakka rahite vitakka vicāra dvaya rahite ca ñāya āgatā desanā dutiyam adhigantabba ttā
translated: And the second is so called because the teaching arrived at by the method comes second to the first, which is without thinking and with exploring only, and also because the second is similar to the first in the abandoning of the two, that is, in the abandoning of thinking and exploring.

original: vicāramattarahitepi dvayappahānādhigatasamānadhammattā. Evañca katvā pañcakanayaniddese
analyzed: vicāra matta rahite api dvaya ppahāna adhigata samāna dhamma ttā evam ca katvā pañcakanaya niddese
translated: And when it is so classed, the second is said to be “without thinking, with exploring” in the description of the five- grouped method in the Paṭṭhāna.🔽And the second is said to be “without thinking, without exploring” in the description of the four-grouped method in the Paṭṭhāna.

original: dutiye vūpasantopi vitakko sahāyabhūtavicārāvūpasamena na sammā vūpasantoti vitakkavicāradvayarahite🔽viya vicāravūpasameneva tadupasamaṃ, sesadhammānaṃ samānatañca dassentena “vitakkavicārānaṃ
analyzed: dutiye vūpasanto pi vitakko sahāya bhūta vicāra a vūpasamena na sammā vūpasanto ti vitakka vicāra dvaya rahite 🔽vicāra vūpasamena iva tad upasamam sesa dhammānam samāna tat ca dassentena
translated: And the second is said to be “without thinking, with exploring” in the description of the six-grouped method in the Paṭṭhāna.🔽And the second is said to be “without thinking, without exploring” in the description of the five-grouped method in the Paṭṭhāna.🔽And the second is said to be “without thinking, with exploring” in the description of the four-grouped method in the Paṭṭhāna.🔽And the second is said to be “without thinking, without exploring” in the description of the six-grouped method in the Paṭṭhāna.

original: vūpasamā ajjhattaṃ sampasādanaṃ cetaso ekodibhāvaṃ avitakkaṃ avicāraṃ samādhijaṃ
analyzed: vūpasamāḥ ajjhattam sampasādanam cetasaḥ eka udi bhāvam a vitakkam a vicāram samādhi jam
translated: and on the cessation of happiness and on the non-presence of happiness in him, on the disappearance of pain and on the prior disappearance of pleasure and on the non-presence of displeasure in him, he dwells in a state of neither-pain-nor-pleasure and in complete purity of mindfulness owing to equanimity” .

original: pītisukhaṃ tatiyaṃ jhānaṃ upasampajja viharatī”ti tatiyaṃ catukkanaye dutiyena nibbisesaṃ🔽vibhattaṃ. Duvidhassāpi sahāyavirahena, aññathā ca vitakkappahānena avitakkattaṃ,
analyzed: pīti sukham tatiyam jhānam upasampajja viharati iti tatiyam catukka naye dutiyena nibbisesam  vibhattam duvidhassa api sahāya virahena aññathā ca vitakka ppahānena avitakka ttam
translated: The third jhana is stated in the first tetrad without distinction from the second by the words “without happiness” .🔽But in the second tetrad it is stated with the distinction that it is without applied thought by the words “without happiness, and by leaving out applied thought” ,

original: samādhijaṃ pītisukhattañca samānanti samānadhammattāpi dutiyanti niddeso. Vicāramattampi🔽hi vitakkavicāradvayarahitaṃ viya “yasmiṃ samaye rūpūpapattiyā maggaṃ bhāveti avitakkaṃ🔽vicāramattaṃ samādhijaṃ pītisukhaṃ dutiyaṃ jhānaṃ upasampajja viharatī”ti avitakkaṃ
analyzed: samādhi jam pīti sukha ttam ca samāna nti samāna dhamma ttā api dutiya nti niddesaḥ vicāra mattam pi  hi vitakka vicāra dvaya rahitam viya yasmin samaye rūpa upapattiyā maggam bhāveti avitakkam  vicāra mattam samādhi jam pīti sukham dutiyam jhānam upasampajja viharati iti avitakkam
translated: and it is stated with the distinction that it has the same pleasure by the words “the pleasure divested of happiness” .🔽For in the first tetrad the words “without happiness” distinguish the third jhana from the second,🔽and in the second tetrad the words “without happiness and by leaving out applied thought” distinguish it from the second by the absence of applied thought and by the presence of sustained thought.

original: samādhijaṃ pītisukhanti vibhattaṃ. Paṭhamajjhāne vā sahacārīsu vitakkavicāresu ekaṃ
analyzed: samādhi jam pīti sukhanti vibhattam paṭhama jhāne vā sahacārīsu vitakka vicāresu ekam
translated: Or in the first tetrad the words “without happiness” distinguish the third jhana from the second,

original: atikkamitvā dutiyampi tatraṭṭhameva dosato disvā ubhayampi sahātikkamantassa pañcakanaye
analyzed: atikkamitvā dutiyam pi tatraṭṭham eva dosataḥ disvā ubhayam pi saha a tikkamantassa pañcaka naye
translated: and in the second tetrad the words “without happiness and by leaving out applied thought” distinguish it from the second by the absence of applied thought and by the presence of sustained thought.

original: tatiyaṃ vuttaṃ, tatiyaṃ adhigantabbattā. Paṭhamato anantarabhāvena panassa dutiyabhāvo
analyzed: tatiyam vuttam tatiyam adhigantabba ttā paṭhamatas anantara bhāvena pana assa dutiya bhāvaḥ
translated: The third is stated for the purpose of attaining the third jhāna. But its second jhāna state arises by way of immediate continuity.

original: ca uppajjatīti. Kasmā panevaṃ sarūpato pañcakanayo na vibhattoti? Vineyyajjhāsayato.
analyzed: ca uppajjati iti kasmā pana ivam sarūpataḥ pañcaka nayaḥ na vibhatto ti
translated: Why is the fivefold reckoning not worked out in detail in the same way? Because of the inclination of those requiring training.

original: Yathānulomadesanā hi suttantadesanāti.
analyzed: yathā anuloma desanā hi suttanta desanā ati
translated: For the teaching is in conformity with the inclinations of those requiring training.

original: Pathavīkasiṇaniddesavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: pathavīkasiṇa niddesa vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The description of the earth kasiṇa is ended.

original: Iti catutthaparicchedavaṇṇanā.
analyzed: iti catuttha pariccheda vaṇṇanā
translated: The commentary on the fourth chapter is ended.

original: 5. Sesakasiṇaniddesavaṇṇanā
translated: The description of the remaining kasiṇas

original: Āpokasiṇakathāvaṇṇanā
analyzed: āpokasiṇa kathā vaṇṇanā
translated: The description of the water kasiṇa

original: 91. Yathāvitthāritassa atthassa atidesopi vitthāraṭṭhāneyeva tiṭṭhatīti āha “vitthārakathā
analyzed: yathā vitthāritassa atthassa atidesaḥ api vitthāra ṭṭhāneya iva tiṭṭhati iti āha vitthāra kathā
translated: The explanation of the words “The explanation of the meaning in detail is given in the Description of the Jhana of the Earth Kasiṇa” is this: “The explanation of the meaning in detail is given in the Description of the Jhana of the Earth Kasiṇa” .🔽The water kasiṇa is the jhāna whose kasiṇa is water or the meditation subject consisting of water.

original: hotī”ti. Āpokasiṇanti āpokasiṇajjhānaṃ, āpokasiṇakammaṭṭhānaṃ vā. Sabbaṃ vitthāretabbanti
analyzed: hoti iti āpokasiṇanti āpokasiṇa jhānam āpokasiṇa kammaṭṭhānam vā sabbam vitthāretabbanti
translated: All should be done as in the case of the earth kasiṇa.

original: pathavīkasiṇakammaṭṭhāne vuttanayena vitthāretabbaṃ. Ettakampīti “kate vā akate vāti🔽sabbaṃ vitthāretabba”nti ettakampi avatvā. Sāmuddikena loṇudakena bharito jalāsayo
analyzed: pathavī kasiṇa kammaṭṭhāne vutta nayena vitthāretabbam ettakam pi iti kate vā a kate vā ti 🔽sabbam vitthāretabbanti ettakam pi avatvā sāmuddikena loṇa udakena bharitaḥ jalāsayaḥ
translated: The words “even this much” are said in order to show that the explanation should not be given in the way beginning “When it has been made, or when it has not been made” .🔽A water tank filled with sea water

original: loṇī. Nīlādivaṇṇasaṅkarapariharaṇatthaṃ “suddhavatthena gahita”nti vuttaṃ. Aññanti
analyzed: loṇī nīla ādi vaṇṇa saṅkara pariharaṇa attham suddha vatthena gahitanti vuttam aññam ti
translated: “With a clean cloth” is said in order to avoid the confusion of colors such as blue. “Any other”

original: bhūmiṃ sampattaṃ. Tathārūpanti yādisaṃ ākāsajaṃ udakaṃ, tādisaṃ. Tenāha “vippasannaṃ
analyzed: bhūmim sampattam tathārūpanti yādisam ākāsa jam udakam tādisam tena āha vippasannam
translated: means that which has reached the ground. “Of that kind” means like the water in the sky. Hence he said: “clear and

original: anāvila”nti, yaṃ pana udakanti sambandho. “Na vaṇṇo paccavekkhitabbo”tiādīsu yaṃ
analyzed: anāvilam ti yam pana udakanti sambandhaḥ na vaṇṇaḥ paccavekkhitabbaḥ iti ādīsu yam
translated: unruffled.” But the construction is: “that which is water.” As to what should be said in regard to the words: “The color should not be reviewed,” etc.,

original: vattabbaṃ, taṃ pathavīkasiṇakathāyaṃ vuttameva. Lakkhaṇaṃ pana idha paggharaṇalakkhaṇaṃ veditabbaṃ.🔽Vuttanayenevāti pathavīkasiṇabhāvanāyaṃ vuttanayeneva. Taraṅguṭṭhānādi, pheṇamissatādi ca idha kasiṇadoso. Soti yogāvacaro. Tassāti paṭibhāganimittassa.🔽Tejokasiṇakathāvaṇṇanā
analyzed: vattabbam tam pathavī kasiṇa kathā ayam vuttam eva lakkhaṇam pana idha paggharaṇa lakkhaṇam veditabbam  vutta nayena iva ati pathavī kasiṇa bhāvanāyam vutta nayena iva taraṅgu ṭṭhāna ādi pheṇa missa tā ādi ca idha kasiṇa doso saḥ ti yoga avacaraḥ tassa ati paṭibhāga nimittassa  tejokasiṇa kathā vaṇṇanā
translated: that has already been said in the section on the earth kasiṇa. But the characteristic here should be understood as the characteristic of flowing.

original: 92. Siniddhāni sinehavantāni. Sāradārūni na pheggudārūni. Jālāya ciraṭṭhitatthaṃ🔽siniddhasāradāruggahaṇaṃ. Ghaṭikaṃ ghaṭikaṃ katvāti khandhaso karitvā. Ālimpetvāti
analyzed: siniddhāni sinehavantāni sāra dārūni na pheggu dārūni jālāya cira ṭṭhita ttham 🔽siniddha sāra dāru gahaṇam ghaṭikam ghaṭikam katvā ati khandhasaḥ karitvā ālimpetvā ati
translated: “In the way already described” means in the way described in the development of the earth kasiṇa. The faults in the kasiṇa here are the appearance of waves, etc., and the appearance of foam, etc. “He”: the meditator. “Of that”: of the counterpart sign.

original: jāletvā. Ghanajālāyāti aviraḷavasena pavattaaggijālāyaṃ.
analyzed: jāletvā ghana jālāya ati aviraḷa vasena
translated: and it is ‘densely netted’ because it is a network of flames without interstices.

original: Patanasadisanti patamānasadisaṃ. Akate gaṇhantassāti vuttanayena yathā kasiṇamaṇḍalaṃ paññāyati, evaṃ anabhisaṅkhate kevale tejasmiṃ nimittaṃ gaṇhantassa.
analyzed: patana sadisam ti patamāna sadisam akate gaṇhantassa ati vutta nayena yathā kasiṇa maṇḍalam paññāyati evam anabhisaṅkhate kevale tejasmin nimittam gaṇhantassa
translated: ‘Like falling’: like what is falling. ‘When he apprehends the sign in bare flame without defining it’: when he apprehends the sign in bare flame not defined in the way described thus ‘as far as the kasiṇa is evident.’

original: Vāyokasiṇakathāvaṇṇanā
analyzed: vāyokasiṇa kathā vaṇṇanā
translated: The description of the air kasiṇa

original: 93. Vuttañhetanti ettha hi-saddo hetuattho, yasmāti attho. Tassa “tasmā”ti iminā
analyzed: vuttam hetan ti ettha hi saddaḥ hetu atthaḥ yasmā iti atthaḥ tassa tasmā iti iminā
translated: For it is said: here the word ‘for’ has the meaning of ‘because’; the meaning is ‘since.’ It is connected with the word ‘therefore’ .

original: sambandho. Ucchagganti ucchukhette yathāṭhitānaṃ aggaṃ. Eritanti vātena calitaṃ.
analyzed: sambandhaḥ aggam vātena calitam
translated: ‘The top of the sugar-cane’: the top of the sugar-canes standing in the field. ‘Is stirred’: is moved by the wind.

original: Sameritanti sabbaso calitaṃ. Tasmāti yasmā “vāyokasiṇaṃ…pe… upalakkhetī”ti evaṃ vuttaṃ
analyzed: sameritam ti sabbaso calitam tasmā ti yasmā upalakkheti iti evam vuttam
translated: ‘Is shaken’: is moved all over. ‘Therefore’: since it is said in the commentary thus, ‘The air kasiṇa … is apprehended’ .

original: aṭṭhakathāyaṃ, tasmā. Samasīsaṭṭhitanti upari pattānaṃ vasena samasīsaṃ hutvā ṭhitaṃ.
analyzed: tasmā sama sīsa ṭhitam ti upari pattānam vasena sama sīsam hutvā ṭhitam
translated: ‘Standing with its top even’: standing with its top even by reason of the evenness of the leaves above.

original: Veḷuṃ vā rukkhaṃ vāti etthāpi “samasīsaṃ ṭhitaṃ ghanapattaveḷuṃ vā ghanapattarukkhaṃ
analyzed: veḷum vā rukkham vā ati ettha api sama sīsam ṭhitam ghana patta veḷum vā ghana patta rukkham
translated: ‘A thicket of grass or a tree’: here too ‘standing with its top even’ should be understood as said before.

original: vā”ti ānetvā yojetabbaṃ. Ekaṅgulādippamāṇesu kesesu rassabhāvato, dīghataresu olambanato,🔽viraḷesu anuppavesato vātappahāro na paññāyatīti caturaṅgulappamāṇaggahaṇaṃ, ghanaggahaṇañca
analyzed: vā ti ānetvā yojetabbam eka aṅgula ādi ppamāṇesu kesesu rassa bhāvataḥ dīghataresu olambanato  viraḷesu an uppavesataḥ vāta ppahāraḥ na paññāyati iti catur aṅgula ppamāṇa ggahaṇam ghana ggahaṇañca
translated: and he should be brought and made to join them.🔽In the case of hair a finger’s breadth long, etc., the fanning is not evident because of the thinness of the hair, and because of its hanging down if it is longer than a finger’s breadth,

original: kataṃ. Etasmiṃ ṭhāne paharatīti satiṃ ṭhapetvāti ucchaggādīnaṃ pacalanākāraggahaṇamukhena🔽tesaṃ pahārake vātasaṅghāte satiṃ upaṭṭhapetvā. Tattha satiṃ ṭhapetvāti tasmiṃ kāyapadesassa🔽saṅghaṭṭanavasena pavatte vāyupiṇḍe saṅghaṭṭanākāraggahaṇamukhena satiṃ upaṭṭhapetvā.
analyzed: etasmin ṭhāne paharati iti satim ṭhapetvā ati ucchagga ādīnam  tesam pahārake vāta saṅghāte satim upaṭṭhapetvā tattha satim ṭhapetvā ti tasmim kāya padesassa  saṅghaṭṭana vasena pavatte vāyu piṇḍe saṅghaṭṭana ākāra ggahaṇa mukhena satim upaṭṭhapetvā
translated: and because it does not make contact if it is wiry. That is why the measure “four fingerbreadths” and the word “dense” are given.🔽“He places mindfulness on the place where it is fanned”: having established mindfulness by apprehending the mode of movement of the rising and falling, etc.,🔽he should establish mindfulness upon the current of air that is the fanner of the rising and falling, etc.🔽Herein, “having placed mindfulness” means having established mindfulness by apprehending the mode of movement of the air unit that occurs by making contact with that part of the body.

original: “Usumavaṭṭisadisa”nti etena purimakasiṇassa viya imassāpi nimittassa saṃviggahataṃ🔽dasseti. “Niccala”nti iminā niccalabhāvoyeva uggahanimittato imassa visesoti paṭibhāganimittassāpi
analyzed: usuma vaṭṭi sadisanti etena purima kasiṇassa viya imassa api nimittassa saṃvigga hatam  dasseti niccalanti iminā uggaha nimittataḥ imassa visesaḥ ti paṭibhāga nimittassa api
translated: “Like a heated oven” shows that the sign should be apprehended as in the case of the preceding kasiṇa.🔽“Unmoving” shows that the difference between the learning sign and the counterpart sign is only that the latter is unmoving.

original: usumavaṭṭisadisatāva vibhāvitā hoti.
analyzed: vibhāvitā
translated: So the counterpart sign of the fire kasiṇa is also shown to be like a heated oven.

original: Nīlakasiṇakathāvaṇṇanā
translated: Description of the blue kasiṇa

original: 94. Añjanarājivaṭṭādi vaṇṇadhātuyā vā. Tathārūpaṃ mālāgacchanti aviraḷavikasitanīlavaṇṇapupphasañchannaṃ
analyzed: añjana rāji vaṭṭa ādi vaṇṇa dhātuyāḥ vā tathārūpam aviraḷa vikasita nīla vaṇṇa puppha sañchannam
translated: A garland of flowers comes in such a way that the blue-coloured flowers are not mixed up but are spread out separately.🔽With the other: with what is not made up.🔽The blue mountain ebony is called “blue” because of its resemblance to the blue mountain ebony.

original: pupphagacchaṃ. Itarenāti akatādhikārena. Girikaṇṇikaggahanena nīlaṃ girikaṇṇikamāha.
analyzed: pupphagaccham itarena ati a kata adhikārena girikaṇṇika ggahanena nīlam girikaṇṇikam āha
translated: A box-lid is a covering for a box.🔽With leaves only: having removed the filaments and stalks of the blue water lily, etc.,

original: Karaṇḍapaṭalaṃ samuggapidhānaṃ. Pattehiyevāti nīluppalādīnaṃ kesaravaṇṭāni apanetvā🔽kevalehi pattehiyeva. Pūretabbanti nīlavaṇṇaṃ vatthaṃ gahetvā bhaṇḍikaṃ viya bandhitvā🔽yathā nīlamaṇḍalaṃ hutvā paññāyati, tathā caṅkoṭakaṃ vā karaṇḍapaṭalaṃ vā pūretabbaṃ.
analyzed: karaṇḍa paṭalam samugga pidhānam nīluppala ādīnam kesara vaṇṭāni apanetvā  kevalehi pattehi yeva pūretabbanti nīla vaṇṇam vattham gahetvā bhaṇḍikam viya bandhitvā  yathā nīla maṇḍalam hutvā paññāyati tathā caṅkoṭakam vā karaṇḍa paṭalam vā pūretabbam
translated: it should be filled with the leaves only.🔽It should be bound like a bundle,🔽and it should be filled with the blue cloth, making a blue circle, in such a way that it shows up as a blue circle, either in a box-lid or in a box.

original: Mukhavaṭṭiyaṃ vā assāti assa caṅkoṭakassa, karaṇḍapaṭalassa vā mukhavaṭṭiyaṃ bandhitabbaṃ.
analyzed: mukhavaṭṭiyam vā assa ati assa caṅkoṭakassa karaṇḍapaṭalassa vā mukhavaṭṭiyam bandhitabbam
translated: Or else, in the mouth of the box: in the mouth of the box-lid or of the box.

original: Maṇitālavaṇṭaṃ indanīlamaṇimayaṃ tālavaṇṭaṃ.
analyzed: maṇi tāla vaṇṭam indanīla maṇi mayam tāla vaṇṭam
translated: A gem-studded palm-tree is a palm-tree studded with gems.

original: Pītakasiṇakathāvaṇṇanā
translated: Description of the exposition of the kasiṇa of the blue

original: 95. Pītakasiṇe mālāgacchanti ikkaṭādimālāgacchaṃ. Haritālaṃ, manosilā vā dhātu. Pattaṅgapupphehīti🔽pattaṅganāmikā pītavaṇṇapupphā ekā gacchajāti, tassa pupphehi. Āsanapūjanti cetiyaṅgaṇe
analyzed: pīta kasiṇe mālāgacchanti ikkaṭa ādi mālāgaccham haritālam manosilāḥ vā dhātu pattaṅga pupphehi iti  pattaṅga nāmikā pīta vaṇṇa pupphā ekā cetiyaṅgaṇe
translated: Haritala and manasila are the minerals called “yellow orpiment” and “realgar.”🔽Pattaṅga flowers: the species called “pattaṅga” has yellow flowers;🔽the flowers of that are meant. A seat honour: a seat honour made in a shrine terrace.

original: kataṃ āsanapūjaṃ. Kaṇikārapupphādināti ādi-saddena ākulikiṅkirātapupphādīnaṃ saṅgaho daṭṭhabbo.
analyzed: katam āsana pūjam kaṇikāra puppha ādinā iti ādi saddena ākuli kiṅkirāta puppha ādīnam saṅgahaḥ daṭṭhabbo
translated: Kaṇikāra flowers, etc.: the word “etc.” should be understood to include ākulakiṅkiṇika flowers, etc.

original: Lohitakasiṇakathāvaṇṇanā
analyzed: lohitakasiṇa kathā vaṇṇanā
translated: Description of the section on the red kasiṇa🔽A red gem: a ruby, etc.

original: 96. Lohitamaṇi lohitaṅgamaṇiādi. Lohitadhātu gerukajātihiṅgulikādi.
translated: A red mineral: the species called “geruka,” “hiṅgulī,” etc.

original: Odātakasiṇakathāvaṇṇanā
analyzed: odāta kasiṇa kathā vaṇṇanā
translated: Description of the section on the white kasiṇa🔽In the white kasiṇa, garlands: the garlands called “nandiyāvattha,” etc., are the species called “nandiyāvattha,” etc., in the genus “creeper.”

original: 97. Odātakasiṇe mālāgacchanti nandiyāvattādimālāgacchaṃ. Dhātu kakkaṭimuttasetikādi.
analyzed: odāta kasiṇe mālāgacchanti nandiyāvatta ādi mālāgaccham dhātu kakkaṭi mutta setikā ādi
translated: A mineral: the species called “kakkaṭimutta,” “setika,” etc.

original: Ālokakasiṇakathāvaṇṇanā🔽98. Tathā asakkontenāti yathā sūriyālokādivasena obhāsanimittuppādanaṃ vuttaṃ, tassa
analyzed: āloka kasiṇa kathā vaṇṇanā  tathā a sakkontena iti yathā sūriya āloka ādi vasena obhāsa nimitta uppādanam vuttam tassa
translated: Description of the section on the light kasiṇa🔽If he is unable to do that: if he is unable to produce the sign in that way because the circle of light does not last long,

original: obhāsamaṇḍalassa na ciraṭṭhititāya tathā nimittuppādanaṃ kātuṃ asakkontena. Ghaṭamukhena
analyzed: obhāsa maṇḍalassa na cira ṭṭhiti tāya tathā nimitta uppādanam kātum a sakkontena ghaṭa mukhena
translated: then by the mouth of a water pot

original: niggacchanakaobhāsassa mahantabhāvato “ghaṭamukhaṃ pidahitvā”ti vuttaṃ. Bhittimukhanti
analyzed: mahanta bhāvataḥ ghaṭa mukham pidahitvā iti vuttam bhitti mukham ti
translated: “As though it were a mouth” is said because of the magnitude of the light that is issuing forth. “Facing the wall” means

original: bhittiabhimukhaṃ. Uṭṭhitamaṇḍalasadisanti bhittiādīsu uṭṭhitapākatikaālokamaṇḍalasadisaṃ.
analyzed: bhitti abhimukham uṭṭhita maṇḍala sadisanti bhitti ādīsu uṭṭhita pākatika āloka maṇḍala sadisam
translated: facing the wall. “Like a circle of light” means like a circle of light that has arisen on the wall, etc.

original: Ghanavippasannaṃ ālokapuñjasadisanti bhagavato byāmappabhā viya bahalo, vippasanno
analyzed: ghana vippasannam āloka puñja sadisanti bhagavataḥ byāma ppabhā viya bahalaḥ vippasanno
translated: “Dense and clear, like a mass of light” means like the Blessed One’s all-round light, which is thick, clear,

original: ca hutvā puñjabhūto āloko atthi ce, taṃsadisoti attho.
analyzed: ca hutvā puñja bhūtaḥ ālokaḥ atthi ce tad sadiso ti attho
translated: and like a mass of light. If there is such light, it is like that.

original: Paricchinnākāsakasiṇakathāvaṇṇanā
translated: The explanation of the description of the kasiṇa of the limited space

original: 99. Chiddasadisameva hotīti yehi bhittipariyantādīhi paricchinnaṃ, taṃ chiddaṃ, taṃsadisaṃ,🔽tenavākārena uggahanimittaṃ upaṭṭhātīti attho. “Vaḍḍhiyamānampi na vaḍḍhatī”ti uggahanimittassa
analyzed: chidda sadisam eva hoti iti yehi bhitti pariyanta ādīhi paricchinnam tam chiddam taṃsadisam  tena vā ākārena uggaha nimittam upaṭṭhāti iti atthaḥ vaḍḍhiyamānam pi na vaḍḍhati iti uggaha nimittassa
translated: . “It is like a hole” means it is like a hole that is limited by the wall, etc.🔽The meaning is that the learning sign appears in that form. “Even when it is extended it does not extend” is said to show that the learning sign

original: avaḍḍhanīyataṃ dassetuṃ vuttaṃ. Sabbampi hi uggahanimittaṃ vaḍḍhiyamānaṃ na vaḍḍhatiyeva.
analyzed: a vaḍḍhanīya tam dassetum vuttam sabbam pi hi uggaha nimittam vaḍḍhiyamānam na vaḍḍhatiyā iva
translated: cannot be extended. For all learning signs do not extend even when extended.

original: Satipi ca vaḍḍhetukāmatāyaṃ vaḍḍhanā na sambhavati bhāvanāya paridubbalattā. Bhāvanāvasena
analyzed: sati pi ca vaḍḍhetu kāma tā ayam vaḍḍhanā na sambhavati bhāvanāya paridubbala ttā bhāvanā vasena
translated: And even though there is a desire to extend it, it does not extend because the development is too weak.🔽For the extension of the sign is by means of development.

original: hi nimittavaḍḍhanā. Paṭibhāganimittaṃ pana tasmiṃ uppanne bhāvanā thirāti katvā “vaḍḍhiyamānaṃ vaḍḍhatī”ti vuttaṃ.
analyzed: hi nimitta vaḍḍhanā paṭibhāga nimittam pana tasmin uppanne bhāvanā thirā iti katvā vaḍḍhiyamānam vaḍḍhati iti vuttam
translated: But when the counterpart sign has arisen, development is reckoned as “extended” and so it is said, “It extends as it extends” .

original: Kiñcāpi pāḷiyaṃ “pathavīkasiṇādīni rūpajhānārammaṇāni aṭṭheva kasiṇāni sarūpato āgatāni,
analyzed: kiñca api pāḷiyam pathavī kasiṇa ādīni rūpa jhāna ārammaṇāni aṭṭha iva kasiṇāni sarūpataḥ āgatāni
translated: And although only eight kasiṇas beginning with the earth kasiṇa are given in the text as the object of the fine-material jhāna,

original: odātakasiṇe pana ālokakasiṇaṃ, ākāsakasiṇe ca paricchinnākāsakasiṇaṃ antogadhaṃ katvā🔽desanā katā”ti adhippāyenāha “iti kasiṇāni dasabalo, dasa yāni avocā”ti. Pakiṇṇakakathāpi
analyzed: odāta kasiṇe pana āloka kasiṇam ākāsa kasiṇe ca paricchinna ākāsa kasiṇam antogadham katvā  desanā katā ati adhippāyena āha iti kasiṇāni dasabalaḥ dasa yāni avoca ati pakiṇṇaka kathā api
translated: nevertheless the light kasiṇa is included in the white kasiṇa and the limited-space kasiṇa is included in the space kasiṇa.

original: viññeyyāti pubbe viya asādhāraṇaṃ tasmiṃ tasmiṃ kasiṇe paṭiniyatameva atthaṃ aggahetvā🔽asādhāraṇato, sādhāraṇato ca tattha tattha pakiṇṇakaṃ visaṭaṃ atthaṃ gahetvā pavattā
analyzed: viññeyyā ti pubbe viya asādhāraṇam tasmim tasmim kasiṇe paṭiniyatam eva attham aggahetvā  asādhāraṇato sādhāraṇato ca tattha tattha pakiṇṇakam visaṭam attham gahetvā pavattā
translated: So the intention in the text is to include the light and the space kasiṇas as well, and that is why it is said in the Paṭisambhidā: “The Master, the Kinsman of the Sun, declared ten kasiṇas, which are tenfold.”🔽The miscellaneous discussion

original: pakiṇṇakakathāpi vijānitabbā.
analyzed: pakiṇṇaka kathā api vijānitabbā
translated: should be understood too.🔽As in the case of the earth kasiṇa, so too in the case of the remaining kasiṇas the miscellaneous discussion should be understood to occur in the way appropriate to each case, without confusion, by one who is skilled in the methods of teaching.

original: Pakiṇṇakakathāvaṇṇanā
analyzed: pakiṇṇaka kathā vaṇṇanā
translated: The miscellaneous discussion

original: 100. Ādibhāvoti ettha ādi-saddena yassa kassaci pathavīpakkhiyassa vatthuno nimmānādiṃ
analyzed: ādi bhāvaḥ ti ettha ādi saddena yassa kassaci pathavīpakkhiyassa vatthuno nimmāna ādim
translated: As to the beginning: here the word “beginning” includes the creation of any kind of material form belonging to the earth kasiṇa, such as a mountain, a rock, a tree, etc.,

original: saṅgaṇhāti. Ṭhānanisajjādikappanaṃ vāti etthāpi “ākāse vā udake vā”ti ānetvā sambandhitabbaṃ.
analyzed: saṅgaṇhāti ṭhāna nisajja ādi kappanam vā ati ettha api ākāse vā udake vā ati ānetvā sambandhitabbam
translated: and the creation of the posture of standing, sitting, etc., which should be construed as “in the air or in the water.”

original: Parittaappamāṇanayenāti nīlādivaṇṇaṃ anāmasitvā parittaappamāṇanayeneva. Evamādīnīti
analyzed: paritta appamāṇa nayena ati nīla ādi vaṇṇam an āmasitvā paritta appamāṇa nayena iva evamādīni iti
translated: By the method of small and large: without specifying the colour as blue, etc., by the method of small and large only.

original: ādi-saddena sarīrato udakadhārānimmānādiṃ saṅgaṇhāti.
analyzed: ādi saddena sarīrataḥ udaka dhārā nimmāna ādim saṅgaṇhāti
translated: By the word “etc.,” the creation of a stream of water from the body, etc., is included.

original: Yadeva so icchati tassa ḍahanasamatthatāti bahūsu kappāsapicusāradāruādīsu ekajjhaṃ
analyzed: yat eva saḥ icchati tassa bahūsu kappāsa picu sāra dāru ādīsu ekajjham
translated: Whatever he wishes to burn: when many things such as cotton, silk, wood, etc., are collected together in a heap,

original: rāsibhūtesu ṭhitesu yaṃ yadeva icchati, tassa tasseva ḍahanasamatthatā. Idha ādi-saddena
analyzed: rāsi bhūtesu ṭhitesu yam yat eva icchati tassa tassa iva ḍahana samattha tā idha ādi saddena
translated: whatever he wishes to burn, that he can make burn. Here the word “etc.,”

original: andhakāravidhamanādiṃ saṅgaṇhāti.
analyzed: andhakāra vidhamana ādim saṅgaṇhāti
translated: includes the dispelling of darkness, etc.

original: Vāyugatiyā gamanaṃ vāyugatigamanaṃ, atisīghagamanaṃ. Idha ādi-saddena yadicchitadesantaraṃ pāpuṇanādiṃ saṅgaṇhāti.
analyzed: vāyu gatiyā gamanam vāyu gati gamanam ati sīgha gamanam ādi saddena yat icchita desantaram pāpuṇana ādim saṅgaṇhāti
translated: Motion by the speed of the wind: swift motion. Here the word “etc.,” includes the reaching of whatever place he wishes to go to.

original: Suvaṇṇanti adhimuccanā suvaṇṇabhāvādhiṭṭhānaṃ seyyathāpi āyasmā pilindavaccho tiṇaṇḍupagapāsādādīnaṃ. Vuttanayenāti suvaṇṇadubbaṇṇanayena.
analyzed: suvaṇṇam ti adhimuccanā suvaṇṇa bhāva adhiṭṭhānam sā iyyathā api āyasmā pilindavaccho tiṇaṇḍu paga pāsāda ādīnam vutta nayena ati suvaṇṇa dubbaṇṇa nayena
translated: ‘Gold’: the resolution is the determining of the state of gold, as in the case of the venerable Pilindavaccha with the grass-blade hut, the pavilion, and so on. ‘In the way already described’: in the way beginning ‘ugly or beautiful’.

original: Vaṇṇakasiṇesu tattha tattha ādi-saddena nīlobhāsanimmānādīnaṃ saṅgaho daṭṭhabbo. Pathavīpabbatādīti ādi-saddena samuddādīnaṃ saṅgaho daṭṭhabbo.
analyzed: vaṇṇa kasiṇesu tattha tattha ādi saddena nīla ubhāsa nimmāna ādīnam saṅgahaḥ daṭṭhabbo pathavī pabbata ādi iti ādi saddena samudda ādīnam saṅgahaḥ daṭṭhabbo
translated: In the case of the colour kasiṇas, the words ‘and so on’ should be understood to include the infinite space of blue, the infinite space of yellow, and so on. In the case of the earth kasiṇa, the words ‘and so on’ should be understood to include the ocean, and so on.

original: Sabbāneva dasapi kasiṇāni. Imaṃ pabhedaṃ labhantīti imaṃ vaḍḍhanādivisesaṃ pāpuṇanti.
analyzed: sabbān eva dasa api kasiṇāni imam pabhedam labhanti iti imam vaḍḍhana ādi visesam pāpuṇanti
translated: All the ten kasiṇas

original: Ekoti ekacco. Sañjānātīti bhāvanāpaññāya sañjānāti. Ādi-saddena “āpokasiṇa”ntiādipāḷiṃ saṅgaṇhāti.
analyzed: ekaḥ iti ekaccaḥ sañjānāti iti bhāvanā paññāya sañjānāti ādi saddena saṅgaṇhāti
translated: ‘One’: a certain meditator. ‘Perceives’: he perceives with the understanding consisting in development. The words ‘and so on’ include the text beginning ‘The water kasiṇa’ .

original: Uparigaganatalābhimukhaṃ “pathavīkasiṇameko sañjānātī”ti pāḷipadāni ānetvā sambandhitabbaṃ.
analyzed: upari gagana tala abhimukham pathavī kasiṇam ekaḥ sañjānāti iti pāḷi padāni ānetvā sambandhitabbam
translated: The passage ‘One perceives the earth kasiṇa above and below, with nothing beyond, thus it is measureless’ should be brought in here.

original: Tañca kho vaḍḍhanavasena. Tenāha “ekacco hi uddhameva kasiṇaṃ vaḍḍhetī”ti. Heṭṭhābhūmitalābhimukhantiādīsupi
analyzed: tat ca kho vaḍḍhana vasena tena āha ekaccaḥ hi uddham eva kasiṇam vaḍḍheti iti heṭṭhā bhūmi tala abhimukha nti ādīsupi
translated: And that is by means of extension. That is why he said ‘One extends the kasiṇa only upwards’ .🔽In the passages beginning ‘One perceives the earth kasiṇa above and below, with nothing beyond, thus it is measureless’ ,

original: eseva nayo. Pubbe vaḍḍhanakāle payojanaṃ anapekkhitvā vaḍḍhentānaṃ vasena vuttattā
analyzed: esa iva nayaḥ pubbe vaḍḍhana kāle payojanam an apekkhitvā vaḍḍhentānam vasena vutta ttā
translated: Because it is stated in this way in order to show the extension of the kasiṇa by one who extends it without regard for the purpose for which it is being extended at the time of the preliminary work,

original: idāni “tena tena vā kāraṇena evaṃ pasāretī”ti āha, kasiṇaṃ vaḍḍhetīti attho. Yathā🔽kinti āha “ālokamiva dibbacakkhunā rūpadassanakāmo”ti. Uddhañce rūpaṃ daṭṭhukāmo🔽uddhaṃ ālokaṃ pasāreti, adho ce rūpaṃ daṭṭhukāmo adho ālokaṃ pasāreti, samantato
analyzed: idāni tena tena vā kāraṇena evam pasāreti iti āha kasiṇam vaḍḍheti iti atthaḥ yathā  kim ti āha ālokam iva dibba cakkhunā rūpa dassana kāmaḥ ti uddhañce rūpam daṭṭhu kāmaḥ  uddham ālokam pasāreti adhas ce rūpam daṭṭhu kāmaḥ adhas ālokam pasāreti samantataḥ
translated: he now says, “By this or that reason it extends thus,” the meaning of which is, “He extends the kasiṇa.”

original: ce rūpaṃ daṭṭhukāmo samantato ālokaṃ pasāreti, evamayaṃ kasiṇanti attho.
analyzed: ce rūpam daṭṭhu kāmo samantataḥ ālokam pasāreti evam ayam kasiṇanti attho
translated: As to how, he says, “As one who desires to see visible objects with the divine eye extends the light.” If he wants to see visible objects above, he extends the light upwards; if he wants to see visible objects below, he extends the light downwards; if he wants to see visible objects all round, he extends the light all round. This is the meaning.🔽In one: in each one of the earth kasiṇa, etc.,

original: Ekassāti pathavīkasiṇādīsu ekekassa. Aññabhāvānupagamanatthanti aññakasiṇabhāvānupagamanadīpanatthaṃ,
analyzed: ekassa ati pathavī kasiṇa ādīsu ekekassa añña bhāva anupagamana attham ti añña kasiṇa bhāva anupagamana dīpana ttham
translated: For the purpose of not taking up another’s aspect: for the purpose of showing that he does not take up the aspect of another kasiṇa,

original: na aññaṃ pathavīādi. Na hi udakena ṭhitaṭṭhāne sasambhārapathavī atthi. Añño kasiṇasambhedoti
analyzed: na aññam pathavī ādi na hi udakena ṭhita ṭṭhāne sa sambhāra pathavī atthi aññaḥ kasiṇa sambhedo ti
translated: not another earth, etc., for there is no earth with its accessories in the place occupied by water. Another kind of confusion of kasiṇas:

original: āpokasiṇādinā saṅkaro. Sabbatthāti sabbesu āpokasiṇādīsu sesakasiṇesu. Ekadese aṭṭhatvā
analyzed: āpokasiṇa ādinā saṅkaro sabbattha ati sabbesu āpokasiṇa ādīsu sesa kasiṇesu eka dese
translated: confusion with the water kasiṇa, etc. Everywhere: in all the remaining kasiṇas beginning with the water kasiṇa. Without staying in one place:

original: anavasesena pharaṇappamāṇassa aggahaṇato pharaṇaṃ appamāṇaṃ. Teneva hi nesaṃ kasiṇasamaññā.
analyzed: anavasesena pharaṇa ppamāṇassa aggahaṇato pharaṇam appamāṇam tena iva hi na isam kasiṇa samaññā
translated: It is measureless because it is not apprehended as having a measure of extension. That is why they are called kasiṇas.

original: Tathā cāha “tañhī”tiādi. Tattha cetasā pharantoti bhāvanācittena ālambanaṃ karonto.
analyzed: tathā ca āha tat hi itiādi tattha cetasā pharantaḥ iti bhāvanā cittena ālambanam karontaḥ
translated: And he says this: “He extends it with his mind” means he makes it his object with the development consciousness.

original: Bhāvanācittañhi kasiṇaṃ parittaṃ vā vipulaṃ vā ekakkhaṇe sakalameva manasi karoti, na ekadesanti.
analyzed: bhāvanā cittam hi kasiṇam parittam vā vipulam vā eka khaṇe sakalam eva manasi karoti na
translated: For the development consciousness takes the kasiṇa as its object in its entirety in a single moment, whether it is limited or measureless, and not part by part.

original: 101. Ānantariyakammasamaṅginoti pañcasu ānantariyakammesu yena kenaci samannāgatā.
analyzed: ānantariya kamma samaṅgino ti pañcasu ānantariya kammesu yena kenacid samannāgatā
translated: “Endowed with a immediately-rewarded-after-death action” means endowed with any one of the five immediately-rewarded-after-death actions.

original: Niyatamicchādiṭṭhikāti ahetukadiṭṭhi akiriyadiṭṭhi natthikadiṭṭhīti tīsu micchādiṭṭhīsu🔽yāya kāyaci niyatāya micchādiṭṭhiyā samannāgatā. Ubhatobyañjanakapaṇḍakāti ubhatobyañjanakā,
analyzed: niyata micchādiṭṭhikā ati ahetuka diṭṭhi akiriya diṭṭhi natthika diṭṭhī iti tīsu micchādiṭṭhīsu  yāya kāyaci niyatāya micchādiṭṭhiyā samannāgatā ubhatobyañjanaka paṇḍakā ati ubhatobyañjanakā
translated: “Fixed in a wrong view” means fixed in any one of the three kinds of wrong view, namely, the view of no cause, the view of no doing, and the view of annihilation.

original: paṇḍakā ca. Kāmañcete ahetukapaṭisandhikattā vipākāvaraṇena samannāgatā honti, tathāpi
analyzed: ca kāmañca ite ahetuka paṭisandhi kattāḥ vipāka āvaraṇena samannāgatāḥ honti tathā api
translated: “Hermaphrodite, eunuch” means hermaphrodites and eunuchs. Although these are endowed with the obscuration consisting in the result because of their rebirth-linking without root-cause, still,

original: tibbakilesattā kilesāvaraṇena samannāgatā vuttā. Ahetukadvihetukapaṭisandhikāti ahetukapaṭisandhikā,
analyzed: tibba kilesa ttā kilesa āvaraṇena samannāgatā vuttā ahetuka dvi hetuka paṭisandhikā ati ahetuka paṭisandhikā
translated: They are said to be “endowed with the hindrance of defilements” because of the intensity of their defilements. “With rebirth-linking that is without root-cause or with rebirth-linking that is due to two root-causes”: with rebirth-linking that is without root-cause,

original: dvihetukapaṭisandhikā ca. Duhetukapaṭisandhikānampi hi ariyamaggapaṭivedho, jhānapaṭilābho
analyzed: dvi hetuka paṭisandhikā ca du hetuka paṭisandhikānam pi hi ariya magga paṭivedhaḥ jhāna paṭilābhaḥ
translated: and with rebirth-linking that is due to two root-causes. For those with rebirth-linking due to two root-causes also have neither the penetration of the noble path nor the attainment of jhāna,

original: ca natthi, tasmā tepi vipākāvaraṇena samannāgatā eva.
analyzed: ca natthi tasmā te pi vipāka āvaraṇena samannāgatāḥ eva
translated: and so they too are “endowed with the hindrance of kamma-result.”

original: Apaccanīkapaṭipadāyanti maggassa anulomapaṭipadāyaṃ saccānulomikāyaṃ vipassanāyaṃ.
analyzed: apaccanīka paṭipadāyanti maggassa anuloma paṭipadāyam sacca ānulomikāyam vipassanāyam
translated: “With a contrary way of practice”: with a way of practice contrary to the path, with insight that is contrary to the truths.

original: Acchandikāti “kattukamyatāchandarahitā”ti sammohavinodaniyaṃ vuttaṃ, tampi nibbānādhigamatthameva
analyzed: acchandikā iti kattu kamyatā chanda rahitā ti sammoha vinodaniyam vuttam tat pi nibbāna adhigama attham eva
translated: “Without aspiration”: they are said to be “without aspiration for the kind of activity that is desire to act” in the explanation of confusion . But that should be regarded as said with reference to the desire to act for the purpose of attaining Nibbāna.

original: kattukamyatāchandaṃ sandhāya vuttanti daṭṭhabbaṃ. Uttarakurukāpi manussā mārādayo🔽viya acchandikaṭṭhānaṃ paviṭṭhā nibbutichandarahitattā. Duppaññāti bhavaṅgapaññāya
analyzed: kattu kamya tā chandam sandhāya vuttan ti daṭṭhabbam manussāḥ māra ādayaḥ  viya acchandika ṭṭhānam paviṭṭhā nibbuti chanda rahita ttā duppaññā ati bhavaṅga paññāya
translated: The human beings of Uttarakuru are also “without aspiration” because they lack the aspiration for extinction, like Māra and his retinue.🔽“With deficient wisdom”: they are deficient in the wisdom of the life-continuum.

original: parihīnā. “Bhavaṅgapaññāya paripuṇṇāyapi yassa bhavaṅgaṃ lokuttarassa pādakaṃ na
analyzed: parihīnā bhavaṅga paññāya yassa bhavaṅgam lokuttarassa pādakam na
translated: Even though their wisdom of the life-continuum is complete, their life-continuum does not serve as a basis for the supramundane.

original: hoti, sopi duppaññoyevā”ti sammohavinodaniyaṃ vuttaṃ. Yasmiṃ hi bhavaṅge vattamāne
analyzed: hoti sā api duppaññoyā iva ati sammoha vinodaniyam vuttam yasmin hi bhavaṅge vattamāne
translated: In the case of any rebirth-linking consciousness

original: taṃsantatiyaṃ lokuttaraṃ nibbattati, taṃ tassa pādakaṃ nāma hoti.
analyzed: tad santatiyam lokuttaram nibbattati tam tassa pādakam nāma hoti
translated: that is the footing for the supramundane,🔽In profitable states: in blameless states or in states with happy results.

original: Kusalesu dhammesūti anavajjadhammesu, sukhavipākadhammesu vā. Okkamitunti adhigantuṃ.
analyzed: kusalesu dhammesu iti anavajja dhammesu sukha vipāka dhammesu vā okkamitum ti adhigantum
translated: To emerge: to reach.🔽In the kasiṇas: in the kasiṇas as meditation subjects.

original: Kasiṇeyevāti kasiṇakammaṭṭhāneyeva. Etesanti kammāvaraṇasamannāgatādīnaṃ. Tasmāti🔽yasmā ete vipākantarāyādayo evaṃ atthajānikarā, anatthahetubhūtā ca, tasmā. Tiṇṇameva
analyzed: kasiṇā iya iva ati kamma āvaraṇa samannāgata ādīnam tasmā iti  yasmai ete vipāka antarāya ādayaḥ evam attha jānikarāḥ anattha hetu bhūtā ca tasmai tiṇṇam eva
translated: These: those who are hindered by kamma, etc.,🔽Therefore: because these hindrances to fruition, etc., are the cause of such and such results and are the cause of what is unprofitable.

original: cettha antarāyānaṃ gahaṇaṃ itarassa sappaṭikārattā, kammantarāyapakkhikattā vāti
analyzed: ca ittha antarāyānam gahaṇam itarassa sa paṭikāra ttā kamma antarāya pakkhika ttā vā ti
translated: Only three hindrances are mentioned here because the other one can be countered, and it is included in the hindrance of kamma.

original: daṭṭhabbaṃ. Sappurisūpanissayādīhīti ādi-saddena tajjaṃ yonisomanasikārādiṃ saṅgaṇhāti.
analyzed: daṭṭhabbam sappurisa upanissaya ādīhi iti ādi saddena tajjam yoni somanasikāra ādim saṅgaṇhāti
translated: By the support of good men, etc.: the word “etc.” includes the appropriate direction of endeavour, etc.🔽Faith: faith in kamma and its fruits and faith in the Three Jewels.

original: Saddhanti kammaphalasaddhaṃ, ratanattayasaddhañca. Chandanti bhāvanānuyoge tibbakattukamyatāsaṅkhātaṃ
analyzed: saddhanti kamma phala saddham rata nattaya saddham ca chandanti bhāvanā anuyoge tibba kattu kamya tā saṅkhātam
translated: Desire: the desire called “keenness” for undertaking development,

original: kusalacchandaṃ. Paññanti pārihāriyapaññaṃ. Vaḍḍhetvāti yathā bhāvanā ijjhati, tathā
analyzed: kusala chandam paññanti pārihāriya paññam vaḍḍhetvā iti yathā bhāvanāḥ ijjhati tathā
translated: and wholesome desire. “Wisdom” is the wisdom of learning. “Having developed” means having developed it to the extent necessary for success in the meditation.

original: paribrūhetvā. Yaṃ panettha atthato na vibhattaṃ, taṃ suviññeyyattā, heṭṭhā vuttanayattā ca na vibhattaṃ.
analyzed: yam pana ittha atthataḥ na vibhattam tam su viññeyya ttā heṭṭhā vutta naya ttā ca na vibhattam
translated: But what has not been explained here can be understood from the explanation given below, and so it is not explained.

original: Sesakasiṇaniddesavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: sesa kasiṇa niddesa vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The commentary on the description of the remaining kasiṇas is finished.

original: Iti pañcamaparicchedavaṇṇanā.
analyzed: iti pañcama pariccheda vaṇṇanā
translated: The commentary on the fifth chapter is finished.

original: 6. Asubhakammaṭṭhānaniddesavaṇṇanā
analyzed: asubha kammaṭṭhāna niddesa vaṇṇanā
translated: The Description of the Foulness Meditation

original: Uddhumātakādipadatthavaṇṇanā
analyzed: uddhumātaka ādi pada attha vaṇṇanā
translated: The meaning of the terms “bloated” and the rest

original: 102. “Aviññāṇakāsubhesū”ti idaṃ uddhumātakādīnaṃ sabhāvadassanavasena vuttaṃ. Tasmā
analyzed: aviññāṇaka asubhesu iti idam uddhumātaka ādīnam sabhāva dassana vasena vuttam tasmā
translated: “Among the foulnesses without consciousness”: this is said with reference to the bloated and the rest. Therefore

original: bhūtakathanamattaṃ daṭṭhabbaṃ, na saviññāṇakaasubhassa akammaṭṭhānabhāvato. Tathā🔽hi vakkhati “na kevalaṃ matasarīra”ntiādi. Uddhaṃ jīvitapariyādānāti jīvitakkhayato
analyzed: bhūta kathana mattam daṭṭhabbam na sa viññāṇaka asubhassa a kammaṭṭhāna bhāvato tathā  hi vakkhati na kevalam mata sarīra nti ādi uddham jīvita pariyādānā ati jīvita kkhayato
translated: it should be regarded as a mere description of the facts, not as a statement that the foulness with consciousness is not a meditation subject, for he says later, “Not only the dead body,” etc.🔽“After the dissolution of the body” means after the end of life, after death.🔽“When it is thrown aside” means when it is thrown out.

original: upari maraṇato paraṃ. Samuggatenāti uṭṭhitena. Uddhumātattāti uddhaṃ uddhaṃ dhumātattā
analyzed: upari maraṇataḥ param samuggatena ati uṭṭhitena uddhumātattā ati uddham uddham dhumātattā
translated: “The bloated” is so called because of the distension (uddhunamāna) of the various parts (dhātu) of the body.

original: sūnattā. Uddhumātameva uddhumātakanti ka-kārena padavaḍḍhanamāha anatthantarato yathā🔽“pītakaṃ lohitaka”nti. Paṭikkūlattāti jigucchanīyattā. Kucchitaṃ uddhumātaṃ uddhumātakanti
analyzed: sūnattā uddhumātam eva uddhumātakam ti kakārena pada vaḍḍhanam āha anatthantarataḥ yathā  pītakam lohitakanti paṭikkūla ttā ati jigucchanīya ttā kucchitam uddhumātam uddhumātakanti
translated: as void. The crow’s adding of the word “corpse” is for the purpose of showing that there is no other meaning.🔽As in the case of “yellow” and “red.” As repulsive: as disgusting. The word “corpse” is added to “swollen” and “bloated” in order to show that they are swollen and bloated corpses,🔽

original: kucchanatthe vā ayaṃ ka-kāroti dassetuṃ vuttaṃ yathā “pāpako kittisaddo abbhuggacchatī”ti.
analyzed: kucchana tthe vā ayam kakāraḥ iti dassetum vuttam yathā pāpakaḥ kitti saddaḥ abbhuggacchati iti
translated: and because of its voidness. The repetition of the word “bloated” is a form of word-multiplication. It is like such expressions as “yellow-red” in the sense of “red.” As to “loathsome”: it is repulsive. Or the repetition of the word “bloated” is a form of word-multiplication in the sense of “disgusting.” It is like such expressions as “a disgusting sound of infamy” .

original: Tathārūpassāti “bhastā viya vāyunā”tiādinā yathārūpaṃ vuttaṃ, tathārūpassa.🔽Setarattehi paribhinnaṃ vimissitaṃ nīlaṃ vinīlaṃ, purimavaṇṇavipariṇāmabhūtaṃ vā nīlaṃ vinīlaṃ.
analyzed: tathārūpassa iti bhastā viya vāyunā iti ādinā yathārūpam vuttam tathārūpassa  seta rattehi paribhinnam vimissitam nīlam vinīlam purima vaṇṇa vipariṇāma bhūtam vā nīlam vinīlam
translated: As to “of that kind”: of the kind stated thus, “like a bellows.”🔽Blue-spotted means mixed with blue, or blue that has changed from its original colour.

original: Paribhinnaṭṭhānesu kākakaṅkādīhi. Vissandamānapubbanti vissavantapubbaṃ, tahaṃ tahaṃ paggharantapubbanti attho.
analyzed: paribhinna ṭṭhānesu kāka kaṅka ādīhi vissandamāna pubbam ti vissavanta pubbam taham taham paggharanta pubbam ti attho
translated: By crows, herons, etc., in the places where it has been torn open. With its entrails protruding means with its entrails oozing out; the meaning is, with its entrails trickling here and there.

original: Apadhāritanti vivaṭaṃ ugghāṭitaṃ. Khittanti chaḍḍitaṃ, soṇasiṅgālādīhi visuṃ katvā khādanena sarīrasaṅghātato luñcitvā tahaṃ tahaṃ chaḍḍitaṃ. Vividhaṃ khittanti vikkhittaṃ.🔽Purimanayenāti “vividhaṃ khitta”ntiādinā pubbe vuttanayena. Satthena hanitvāti verīhi
analyzed: apadhāritanti vivaṭam ugghāṭitam khittanti chaḍḍitam soṇa siṅgāla ādīhi visum katvā khādanena sarīra saṅghātataḥ luñcitvā tahaṃ taham chaḍḍitam vividham khittanti vikkhittam  purima nayena āti vividham khitta nti ādinā pubbe vutta nayena satthena hanitvā ati verīhi
translated: “Thrown away” means opened up and thrown away. “Cast away” means discarded, thrown away here and there by dogs, jackals, etc., after tearing the body to pieces and devouring it. “Scattered” means thrown about in various ways.🔽“In the way already stated” means in the way stated previously with the words “Cast away, scattered” , etc. “By a weapon” means by a sword, a spear, etc.

original: khaggakaravālādinā satthena paharitvā. Vuttanayenāti “aññena hattha”ntiādinā pubbe vuttanayena.🔽Abbhantarato nikkhamantehi kimīhi paggharantakimikulaṃ puḷavakanti āha “kimiparipuṇṇassā”ti.
analyzed: khagga karavāla ādinā satthena paharitvā vutta nayena āti aññena hattha nti ādinā pubbe vutta nayena  abbhantarataḥ nikkhamantehi kimīhi paggharanta kimi kulam puḷavakam ti āha kimi paripuṇṇassa ati
translated: “In the way already stated” means in the way stated previously with the words “By another’s hand” , etc.🔽“Full of worms” means a body from which worms are oozing out as it decomposes from within.

original: Uddhumātakādīni āmakasusānādīsu chaḍḍitāsubhāni. Nissāyāti paṭicca tānipi ārabbha. Nimittānanti uggahapaṭibhāganimittānaṃ. Etāneva uddhumātakādīneva nāmāni.
analyzed: uddhumātaka ādīni āmaka susāna ādīsu chaḍḍita asubhāni nissāya ati paṭicca tāni pi ārabbha nimittānam ti uggaha paṭibhāga nimittānam etān eva uddhumātaka ādīn eva nāmāni
translated: “The bloated, etc.,” are the unbeautiful things discarded in the charnel ground, etc. “Depending on” means taking as the basis. “The signs” are the learning sign and the counterpart sign. These are the same as the bloated, etc.

original: Uddhumātakakammaṭṭhānavaṇṇanā
analyzed: uddhumātaka kammaṭṭhāna vaṇṇanā
translated: The description of the meditation subject consisting of a bloated corpse, etc.

original: 103. Bhāvetukāmenāti uppādetukāmena. Tenāti ācariyena. Assāti yogino. Asubhanimittatthāyāti🔽asubhanimittassa uggaṇhanatthāya, asubhe vā uggahanimittassa atthāya. Gamanavidhānanti
analyzed: bhāvetu kāmena ati uppādetu kāmena tena ati ācariyena assa ati yoginaḥ asubha nimitta thāya ati  asubha nimittassa uggaṇhana atthāya asubhe vā uggaha nimittassa atthāya gamana vidhānan ti
translated: ‘Who wants to develop it’: who wants to generate it. ‘By that teacher’: by the teacher. ‘The meditator’: the yogin. ‘For the purpose of a meditation subject consisting of foulness’: for the purpose of learning a meditation subject consisting of foulness, or for the purpose of the sign of learning in foulness. ‘The directions for going’:

original: gamanavidhi. Yena vidhinā gantabbaṃ, so vidhi. Uggahanimittassa uppannakālato paṭṭhāya
analyzed: gamana vidhi yena vidhinā gantabbam so vidhi uggaha nimittassa uppanna kālataḥ paṭṭhāya
translated: the directions for going. The directions by which he should go are the directions for going. ‘From the time when the sign of learning has arisen’ means from the time when the learning sign has arisen.

original: pathavīkasiṇe vuttaṃ paṭipajjanavidhiṃ sandhāyāha “appanāvidhānapariyosāna”nti.
analyzed: pathavīkasiṇe vuttam paṭipajjana vidhim sandhāya āha appanā vidhāna pariyosānam
translated: ‘The directions for attaining’ is said referring to the directions for practice stated in the case of the earth kasiṇa.

original: 104. Tāvadevāti sutakkhaṇeyeva. Atitthena puṇṇanadīādiṃ pakkhandantena viya anupavisantena
analyzed: tāvat eva ati sutakkhaṇeya iva atitthena puṇṇa nadī ādim pakkhandantena viya anupavisantena
translated: ‘Just there’: in the very place where he is sitting. ‘As though descending into a river with his hands’: as though descending into a river that is full to the brim with his hands for support.

original: viya. Kedārakoṭiyāti kedāramariyādāya. Visabhāgarūpanti khettarakkhikādivisabhāgavatthurūpaṃ.
analyzed: kedāra koṭiyā ti kedāra mariyādāya visabhāga rūpanti khetta rakkhikā ādi visabhāga vatthu rūpam
translated: ‘At the edge of a field’: at the boundary of a field. ‘Different kinds of corpses’: corpses of different kinds, such as those of field workers.

original: Sarīranti uddhumātakakaḷevaraṃ. Adhunāmatanti aciramataṃ uddhumātakabhāvaṃ appattaṃ.
analyzed: uddhumātaka kaḷevaram adhunāmatanti aciramatam uddhumātaka bhāvam appattam
translated: ‘A corpse’: a bloated dead body. ‘Not long dead’: not long since dead, not yet having reached the stage of the bloated.

original: Takkayatīti sambhāveti bhāriyaṃ katvā na maññati.
analyzed: takkayati iti sambhāveti bhāriyam katvā na maññati
translated: ‘He does not assume’ means he does not think of it as heavy, he does not assume it.

original: 105. Rūpasaddādīti ettha amanussānaṃ rūpehi, sīhabyagghādīnaṃ saddādīhi, amanussānampi
analyzed: rūpa sadda ādi iti ettha amanussānam rūpehi sīha byaggha ādīnam sadda ādīhi amanussānam pi
translated: “Forms, sounds, etc.”: by the forms of non-human beings, by the sounds, etc., of lions, tigers, etc., or by the forms, sounds, etc., of non-human beings.

original: vā rūpasaddādīhi. Tathā sīhabyagghādīnanti yathārahaṃ yojetabbaṃ. Aniṭṭhārammaṇābhibhūtassāti🔽bheravādibhāvena aniṭṭhehi ārammaṇehi abhibhūtassa ajjhotthaṭassa. Na paṭisaṇṭhātīti🔽vidāhavasena āsaye na tiṭṭhati, ucchaḍḍetabbaṃ hotīti attho. Aññoti amanussādīnaṃ🔽vasena vā aññathā vā vuttappakārato añño ābādho hoti. Soti saṅghatthero, abhiññātabhikkhu
analyzed: vā rūpa sadda ādīhi tathā yathāraham yojetabbam aniṭṭha ārammaṇa abhibhūtassa ati  bherava ādi bhāvena aniṭṭhehi ārammaṇehi abhibhūtassa ajjhotthaṭassa na paṭisaṇṭhāti iti  vidāha vasena āsaye na tiṭṭhati ucchaḍḍetabbam hoti iti attho aññaḥ ti amanussa ādīnam  vasena vā aññathā vā vutta ppakārataḥ aññaḥ ābādhaḥ hoti saḥ ti saṅgha ttheraḥ abhiññāta bhikkhu
translated: Likewise, “lions, tigers, etc.” should be construed as appropriate. “Overpowered by unpleasant objects”: overwhelmed, overcome by unpleasant objects such as fearful forms, etc.🔽“Does not subside”: it does not remain in the abode by way of burning; the meaning is, it must be expelled. “Another affliction”: an affliction other than that described above, whether due to non-human beings, etc., or otherwise.

original: vā. Yassānena ārocitaṃ, so. Katakammāti katatheyyakammā. Akatakammāti theyyakammaṃ🔽kātukāmā. Katakammā pana idhādhippetā. Tasmā teti katakammā corā. Saha oḍḍhenāti
analyzed: vā yassa anena ārocitam saḥ kata kammā ati kata theyya kammā a kata kammā ati theyya kammam  kātu kāmā katakammā pana idha adhippetā tasmā te iti katakammā corā saha oḍḍhena ati
translated: “He”: the elder of the Saṅgha or the bhikkhu who has attained direct knowledge. “The offense he has committed”: the offense he has committed by theft. “The offense he has not committed”: the offense he is about to commit by theft.

original: sahoḍḍhaṃ, thenetvā gahiyamānabhaṇḍena saddhinti attho. Yajamānoti yaññaṃ yajanto
analyzed: sahoḍḍham thenetvā gahiyamāna bhaṇḍena atthaḥ yajamāno ti yaññam yajantaḥ
translated: But here the offense he has committed is intended. Therefore “they” refers to the thieves who have committed the offense. “Together with the loot”: together with the loot, the meaning is, together with the goods being carried off after they have been seized. “The sacrificer”: one who sacrifices at a sacrifice.

original: yaññasāmiko. “Addhā imāya paṭipattiyā jarāmaraṇato muccissāmī”ti pītisomanassaṃ uppādetvā.🔽Evaṃ gamanavidhānaṃ ekadesena vatvā idāni aṭṭhakathāsu āgatanayena taṃ dassetuṃ “aṭṭhakathāsu
analyzed: yaññasāmikaḥ addhā imāya paṭipattiyā jarā maraṇataḥ muccissāmi iti pīti somanassam uppādetvā  evam gamana vidhānam eka desena vatvā idāni aṭṭhakathāsu āgata nayena tam dassetum aṭṭhakathāsu
translated: and the sacrificer. “Surely by this practice I shall be released from ageing-and-death” and he arouses rapture and gladness.

original: vuttena vidhinā”tiādimāha. Tattha uggaṇhantoti uggaṇhanahetu. Ekoti ayaṃ eka-saddo🔽asahāyattho, na aññādiatthoti “adutiyo”ti vuttaṃ. Yathā vaṇṇādito vavatthānaṃ ekaṃsato
analyzed: vuttena vidhinā iti ādim āha tattha uggaṇhantaḥ ti uggaṇhana hetu ekaḥ ti ayam eka saddaḥ  a sahāya tthaḥ na añña ādi attho ti adutiyaḥ ti vuttam yathā vaṇṇa āditaḥ vavatthānam ekaṃsataḥ
translated: Having thus stated the method of going in part, he now said “by the method stated in the Commentaries” in order to show it according to the method given in the Commentaries. Herein, learning is the cause of learning. Alone means without a companion. The word alone has the meaning of “without a second” .

original: samuditameva icchitabbaṃ sabbatthakabhāvato, na tathā sandhiāditoti dassanatthaṃ
analyzed: samuditam eva icchitabbam sabbatthaka bhāvataḥ na tathā sandhi ādito ti dassana ttham
translated: Just as the definition of colour, etc., is accepted as being complete in every way by the single statement “by colour, etc.,” so it is not by the single statement “by the joints, etc.”

original: “vaṇṇatopī”tiādinā chasu ṭhānesu sampiṇḍanattho pi-saddo gahito. Puna eko adutiyotiādi
analyzed: vaṇṇataḥ pi iti ādinā chasu ṭhānesu sampiṇḍana atthaḥ pi saddaḥ gahitaḥ puna ekaḥ adutiyaḥ iti ādi
translated: The word “also” is used in the six instances beginning with “by colour” in order to include the meaning of “and” . Again, alone, without a second, etc.,

original: gahitanimittassa yogino nivattitvā vasanaṭṭhānagamanaṃ sandhāya vuttaṃ. Tabbhāgiyaññevāti
analyzed: gahita nimittassa yogino nivattitvā vasana ṭṭhāna gamanam sandhāya vuttam tad bhāgiyam eva iti
translated: is said with reference to the meditator’s return and going to his dwelling place after apprehending the sign. Only what is similar to it means

original: tappakkhiyaṃyeva asubhanimittamanasikārasahitameva. Āsanaṃ paññapetīti nisajjaṃ kappeti.
analyzed: tad pakkhiyam yeva asubha nimitta manasikāra sahitam eva āsanam paññapeti iti nisajjam kappeti
translated: He prepares a seat: he makes ready a seat.

original: Yaṃ pana “asubhanimittadisābhimukhe bhūmippadese”ti vakkhati, tampi imamevatthaṃ
analyzed: yam pana asubha nimitta disa abhimukhe bhūmi ppadese ti vakkhati tam pi imam eva attham
translated: But when it is said, “on a site for developing the recollection of the Buddha, etc., that is favourable to him,” that refers to this same meaning.

original: sandhāya vuttaṃ. Na hi kevalena disābhimukhabhāvena kiñci ijjhati.🔽Samantā nimittupalakkhaṇāti uddhumātakassa samantā pāsāṇādinimittasallakkhaṇā. Asammohatthāti
analyzed: sandhāya vuttam na hi kevalena disā abhimukha bhāvena kiñci  samantā nimitta upalakkhaṇā ati uddhumātakassa samantā pāsāṇa ādi nimitta sallakkhaṇā a sammoha atthā ti
translated: For nothing is accomplished by mere facing of the direction.🔽The delimitation of the sign all round: the delimitation of the stone, etc., all round the bloated corpse.🔽For the purpose of non-delusion: for the purpose of removing the delusion that arises when the learning sign appears.

original: uggahanimitte upaṭṭhite uppajjanakasammohavigamatthā. Ekādasavidhenāti vaṇṇādivasena
analyzed: uggaha nimitte upaṭṭhite uppajjanaka sammoha vigama tthā ekādasavidhena ati vaṇṇa ādi vasena
translated: In the eleven ways: in the eleven ways beginning with colour.

original: ekādasavidhena. Upanibandhanatthoti asubhārammaṇe cittaṃ upanetvā nibandhanattho.🔽Vīthisampaṭipādanatthāti kammaṭṭhānavīthiyā sammadeva paṭipādanatthā. Puññakiriyavatthu
analyzed: ekādasavidhena upanibandhana attho ti asubha ārammaṇe cittam upanetvā nibandhana attho  vīthi sampaṭipādana tthā ti kammaṭṭhāna vīthiyā sammat eva paṭipādana tthā puñña kiriya vatthu
translated: For the purpose of directing: for the purpose of directing the mind onto the object foulness.🔽For the purpose of making the path traverse it: for the purpose of making the path traverse it properly.

original: adhigataṃ hotīti sambandho.
analyzed: adhigatam hoti iti sambandhaḥ
translated: The object of the profitable becomes evident: the construction is with this meaning.

original: 106. Tasmāti yasmā asubhanimittassa uggaṇhanaṃ ariyamaggapadaṭṭhānassa paṭhamajjhānassa
analyzed: tasmā iti yasmai asubha nimittassa uggaṇhanam ariya magga padaṭṭhānassa paṭhama jhānassa
translated: Therefore: because the learning of the meditation subject is the means to attaining the first jhāna, which is a footing for the noble path,

original: adhigamupāyo, yasmā vā “asubhanimittaṃ uggaṇhanto eko adutiyo gacchatī”ti vuttaṃ,
analyzed: adhigama upāyaḥ yasmai vā asubha nimittam uggaṇhantaḥ ekaḥ adutiyaḥ gacchati iti vuttam
translated: or because it is said that “he who learns the meditation subject goes alone with no companion” ,

original: tasmā. Cittasaññattatthāyāti sarīrasabhāvasallakkhaṇena, saṃvegajananena ca attano🔽cittassa saññattiatthaṃ saññāpanatthaṃ. “Cittasaññatatthāyā”ti vā pāṭho, kilesavasena
analyzed: tasmā citta saññatta tthāya ati sarīra sabhāva sat lakkhaṇena saṃvega jananena ca attano  cittassa saññatti attham saññāpana attham citta saññata tthāya iti vā pāṭhaḥ kilesa vasena
translated: therefore, for the purpose of disciplining his mind: for the purpose of disciplining his own mind by discerning the nature of the body and by arousing a sense of urgency,

original: asaṃyatassa cittassa saṃyamanatthaṃ damanatthaṃ, na kammaṭṭhānatthanti attho. Kammaṭṭhānasīsenāti
analyzed: asaṃyatassa cittassa saṃyamana attham damana attham na kammaṭṭhāna attham ti attho kammaṭṭhāna sīsena ati
translated: or the reading is “for the purpose of disciplining his mind” , for the purpose of restraining and controlling his mind which is undisciplined by defilements, not for the purpose of the meditation subject.

original: kammaṭṭhānena sīsabhūtena, taṃ uttamaṅgaṃ padhānaṃ kāraṇaṃ katvā. Mūlakammaṭṭhānanti
analyzed: kammaṭṭhānena sīsa bhūtena tam uttamaṅgam padhānam kāraṇam katvā mūla kammaṭṭhānanti
translated: With the meditation subject as his head: with the meditation subject as his chief, making that his chief limb, his chief cause.

original: pakatiyā attanā kālena kālaṃ parihariyamānaṃ buddhānussatiādisabbatthakakammaṭṭhānaṃ.
analyzed: pakatiyā attanā kālena kālam parihariyamānam buddha anussati ādi sabbatthaka kammaṭṭhānam
translated: The basic meditation subject: the meditation subject of any of the ten kinds beginning with the recollection of the Buddha, which he normally cultivates from time to time.

original: “Kammaṭṭhānasīsena gacchāmī”ti taṃ avissajjetvā. Tenāha “taṃ manasikarontenevā”ti.
analyzed: kammaṭṭhāna sīsena gacchāmi iti tam a vissajjetvā tena āha tam manasikarontena iva iti
translated: “I shall go with the meditation subject as my head” without leaving it behind. That is why he said “by giving attention to it” .

original: Sūpaṭṭhitabhāvasampādanenāti mūlakammaṭṭhāne suṭṭhu upaṭṭhitabhāvassa sampādanena.🔽Evaṃ hi sati asammuṭṭhā nāma hoti. Bahiddhā puthuttārammaṇe appavattitvā kammaṭṭhāneyeva
analyzed: su upaṭṭhita bhāva sampādanena ati mūla kammaṭṭhāne suṭṭhu upaṭṭhita bhāvassa sampādanena  evam hi sati asammuṭṭhā nāma hoti bahiddhā puthutta ārammaṇe a pavatti tvā
translated: “By perfecting the state of being well established”: by perfecting the state of being well established in the basic meditation subject.🔽For when that is so, it is called “undeluded.”🔽The mind that occurs only in the meditation subject without going outside to other external objects is called “not gone outside.”

original: pavattamānaṃ mānasaṃ abahigataṃ nāma. Tathābhūtena cānena rūpindriyāni appavattakiccāni
analyzed: pavattamānam mānasam abahigatam nāma tathābhūtena ca anena rūpindriyāni appavatta kiccāni
translated: And when it is like that, the five physical sense faculties have their functions suspended,

original: katāni hontīti āha “manacchaṭṭhānaṃ…pe… gantabba”nti.🔽Dvāraṃ sallakkhetabbanti vihāre puratthimādīsu disāsu asukadisāya idaṃ dvāraṃ, tato
analyzed: katāni honti iti āha gantabbanti  dvāram sallakkhetabbanti vihāre puratthima ādīsu disāsu asuka disāya idam dvāram tatas
translated: which is why he said “the mind and the mental phenomena associated with it should go to the door of the physical heart-basis and stand there without going any further.”🔽“The door should be defined”: in the monastery the door to such and such a direction should be defined by him thus: “This is the eastern door,” etc.,🔽and he should advert to it thus, “I shall go out by that door.”

original: eva tāya disāya sallakkhitena asukadvārena nikkhantomhīti dvāraṃ upadhāretabbaṃ.
analyzed: eva tāya disāya sallakkhitena asuka dvārena nikkhantaḥ amhi iti dvāram upadhāretabbam
translated: “After that”: after defining the door.

original: Tatoti dvārasallakkhaṇato pacchā. Yena maggena gacchati sayaṃ. Nimittaṭṭhānanti asubhanimittassa
analyzed: tatas ti dvāra sallakkhaṇato pacchā yena maggena gacchati sayam nimitta ṭṭhānam ti asubha nimittassa
translated: “The path”: the path by which he himself goes.🔽“The place for the sign”: the place for apprehending the sign of foulness.🔽“He should get rid of the food”: he should get rid of it by vomiting.

original: gaṇhanaṭṭhānaṃ. Āhāraṃ chaḍḍāpeyyāti vamanaṃ kārāpeyya. Kaṇṭakaṭṭhānanti kaṇṭakavantaṃ ṭhānaṃ.
analyzed: gaṇhana ṭṭhānam āhāram chaḍḍāpeyya ati vamanam kārāpeyya kaṇṭaka ṭṭhānam ti kaṇṭakavantam ṭhānam
translated: “The place with stumps”: the place with stumps and thorns.

original: 107. Disā vavatthapetabbāti saṅkhepato vuttamatthaṃ vivarituṃ “ekasmiṃ hī”tiādi vuttaṃ.
analyzed: disā vavatthapetabbā iti saṅkhepataḥ vuttam attham vivaritum ekasmin hi itiādi vuttam
translated: ‘The directions should be defined’: to explain the meaning of what was said in brief here, ‘In one direction’ is said.

original: Khāyatīti upaṭṭhāti. Kammaniyanti bhāvanāya kammakkhamaṃ. Ubbāḷhassāti bādhitassa.
analyzed: khāyati iti upaṭṭhāti kamma niyanti bhāvanāya kamma kkhamam ubbāḷhassa ati bādhitassa
translated: ‘Appears’: is evident. ‘Conducive to development’: fit for development. ‘Oppressed’: afflicted.

original: Vidhāvatīti nānārammaṇe visarati. Ukkammāti ujukaṃ anuvātato apakkamma. Matakaḷevaraṃ
analyzed: vidhāvati iti nānā ārammaṇe visarati ukkamma ati ujukam anuvātataḥ apakkamma mata kaḷevaram
translated: ‘Wandering’: wandering among various objects. ‘Straight on’: not deviating from the straight course. A dead body

original: puthujjanassa yebhuyyena bhayato upaṭṭhātīti āha “accāsanne bhayamuppajjatī”ti. Anupādanti
analyzed: puthujjanassa yebhuyyena bhayataḥ upaṭṭhāti iti āha acca āsanne bhayam uppajjati iti
translated: appears fearful to most worldlings, thus it is said: ‘Fear arises when it is near’. ‘Not far away’:

original: pādasamīpaṃ. Yattha ṭhitassa sukhena oloketuṃ sakkā, taṃ olokentassa phāsukaṭṭhānaṃ.
analyzed: pāda samīpam yattha ṭhitassa sukhena oloketum sakkā tam olokentassa phāsuka ṭṭhānam
translated: near the foot. Where one can look at it comfortably when standing, that is a comfortable place to look at it.

original: 108. Samantāti samantato. Puna samantāti sāmantā samīpe. Kacchakoti kāḷakacchako,🔽“pilakkho”tipi vadanti. Kapītanoti pippalirukkho. Sindīti khuddakakhajjurī. Karamandādayo
analyzed: samantā ati samantataḥ punar samantā ati sāmantā samīpe kacchako ti  pilakkhaḥ tipi vadanti kapītano ti pippali rukkhaḥ sindī iti khuddaka khajjurī karamanda ādayaḥ
translated: ‘All round’: all round. ‘Again, all round’: in the vicinity. ‘Tortoise’: a black tortoise.🔽Some say ‘porcupine’. ‘Snake’: a pipphali tree. ‘Vine’: a small date palm. ‘Karamanda’

original: pākaṭā eva. Sāmāti sāmalatā. Kāḷavallīti kāḷavaṇṇā apattikā ekā latājāti. Pūtilatāti
analyzed: pākaṭā eva sāmā ati sāmalatā kāḷavallī iti kāḷavaṇṇā apattikā ekā latā jāti pūtilatā ati
translated: and the rest are well known. ‘Sāma’: a sāma creeper. ‘Black creeper’: a creeper species that is black and not edible. ‘Rotten creeper’:

original: jīvanavalli, yā “galocī”ti vuccati.
analyzed: jīvanavalli yā galocī iti vuccati
translated: The “life-rope” is what is called the “windpipe.”

original: 109. Taṃ nimittakaraṇādi idheva yathāvutte pāsāṇādinimittakaraṇe eva antogadhaṃ pariyāpannaṃ.🔽Sanimittaṃ karotīti saha nimittaṃ karoti, asubhaṃ pāsāṇādinimittena saha karoti vavatthapeti.
analyzed: tam nimitta karaṇa ādi idha iva yathā vutte pāsāṇa ādi nimitta karaṇe eva antogadham pariyāpannam  sa nimittam karoti iti saha nimittam karoti asubham pāsāṇa ādi nimittena saha karoti vavatthapeti
translated: The making of the sign is included in the making of the sign of a stone, etc., as already described.🔽He makes the sign along with: he makes the sign together with the sign of a stone, etc., he defines it.

original: Atha vā asubhanimittaṃ, pāsāṇādinimittañca saha ekajjhaṃ karonto vavatthapento “sanimittaṃ🔽karotī”ti vutto. Samānakālatādīpakena hi saha-saddena ayaṃ samāso yathā “sacakkaṃ
analyzed: atha vā asubha nimittam pāsāṇa ādi nimittam ca saha ekajjham karontaḥ sa nimittam  karoti iti vuttaḥ samāna kāla tā dīpakena hi saha saddena ayam samāsaḥ yathā sa cakkam
translated: Or alternatively, he makes the sign along with the sign of foulness and the sign of a stone, etc., by treating them as one, by defining them together.🔽For this compound is made up of the words saha and nimitta, which are in apposition, like the compound sacakka in the passage, “Give me a cupful” .

original: dehī”ti. Tayidaṃ nimittakaraṇaṃ aparāparaṃ sallakkhaṇena hoti, na ekavāramevāti āha
analyzed: dehi iti tayā idam nimitta karaṇam apara aparam sat lakkhaṇena hoti na eka vāram eva ati āha
translated: This making of the sign is done by successive observation, not in a single act of consciousness. So he said:🔽“He makes the sign along with by defining it again and again.”

original: “punappunaṃ vavatthapento hi sanimittaṃ karotī”ti. Dveti pāsāṇāsubhanimittāni. Samāsetvā
analyzed: punar punar vavatthapentaḥ hi sa nimittam karoti iti dve iti pāsāṇa asubha nimittāni samāsetvā
translated: The two signs, that is to say, the sign of a stone, etc., and the sign of foulness.🔽Having combined them, having brought them together, having made them one.

original: saṅgahetvā ekajjhaṃ katvā. Sārammaṇanti asubhārammaṇena saddhiṃ pāsāṇādiṃ samānārammaṇaṃ
analyzed: saṅgahetvā ekajjham katvā sa ārammaṇanti asubha ārammaṇena saddhim pāsāṇa ādim samāna ārammaṇam
translated: With the same object: with the same object as the sign of foulness, he combines the sign of a stone, etc., and defines them together.

original: karoti, saha vā ārammaṇaṃ karoti, ekārammaṇaṃ viya ubhayaṃ ārammaṇaṃ karoti, ekajjhaṃ
analyzed: karoti saha vā ārammaṇam karoti eka ārammaṇam viya ubhayam ārammaṇam karoti ekajjham
translated: He makes it the object together, he makes the object of both as of one, he makes it the object in one way,

original: viya ca aparāparaṃ sallakkhento pāsāṇādiṃ, asubhanimittañcāti dvayaṃ ārammaṇaṃ karotīti attho.
analyzed: viya ca apara aparam sallakkhentaḥ pāsāṇa ādim asubha nimittam ca ati dvayam ārammaṇam karoti iti attho
