translated: He makes it the object either together or separately. The meaning is that he makes the object of his mind both the sign of foulness and the stone, etc., as he observes them in turn, as if they were a single object, or as if they were two separate objects.

original: Attaniyoti sako. Vaṇitanti sūnaṃ. Sabhāvena sarasenāti uddhumātakabhāvasaṅkhātena🔽attano lakkhaṇena, paresaṃ jigucchuppādanasaṅkhātena attano kiccena ca, sabhāvo eva
analyzed: sakaḥ sūnam sa bhāvena sa rasena ati uddhumātaka bhāva saṅkhātena  attanaḥ lakkhaṇena paresam jigucchu uppādana saṅkhātena attanaḥ kiccena ca sabhāvaḥ eva
translated: In oneself: in one’s own body. A corpse: a bloated one. By its individual essence and by its specific properties: by its own characteristic as the bloatedness of a corpse,

original: vā tathā nipphajjanato “raso”ti vutto.
analyzed: vā tathā nipphajjanato rasaḥ ti vutto
translated: and by its own function as the arousing of loathing in others. Or the individual essence itself is called “property” because it is what is arrived at in the sense of a property.

original: 110. Chabbidhena nimittaṃ gahetabbanti vaṇṇādinā chappakārena tāva uddhumātakaasubhanimittaṃ
analyzed: chabbidhena nimittam gahetabbanti vaṇṇa ādinā cha ppakārena tāva uddhumātaka asubha nimittam
translated: The sign should be apprehended in six ways: the sign of foulness as a bloated corpse should be apprehended in the first place by its colour, etc., in the six ways beginning with “discoloured” .

original: gahetabbaṃ. Keci “kaḷevarassa dīgharassādippamāṇena saddhiṃ sattavidhenā”ti vadanti,
analyzed: gahetabbam keci kaḷevarassa dīgha rassa ādi ppamāṇena saddhim sattavidhena ati vadanti
translated: Some say that it should be apprehended in seven ways, adding “long” and “short” to that.

original: taṃ aṭṭhakathāyaṃ natthi. Liṅgatoti ettha liṅgaṃ nāma vayo liṅgaṃ, na thanamassuādi
analyzed: tam aṭṭhakathāyam na atthi liṅgato ti ettha liṅgam nāma vayaḥ liṅgam na thana massu ādi
translated: But that is not in the commentary. As to sex: here sex is age, not the sex as male or female.

original: itthipurisaliṅganti dassentena “itthiliṅgaṃ vā”tiādi vuttaṃ. Ṭhitassa sattassa idaṃ
analyzed: itthi purisa liṅgan ti dassentena itthi liṅgam vā tiādi vuttam ṭhitassa sattassa idam
translated: The construction is: “This is the body of a living being.”

original: sarīranti sambandho. Uddhumātakasaṇṭhānavaseneva, na pākatikasaṇṭhānavasena. Etena
analyzed: sarīram iti sambandhaḥ uddhumātaka saṇṭhāna vasena iva na pākatika saṇṭhāna vasena etena
translated: It is only by the bloated’s shape, not by its natural shape. This shows

original: yadi tattha koci anuddhumātakabhāvappatto padeso siyā, so na gahetabboti dasseti.🔽Oḷārikāvayavavasena idaṃ saṇṭhānavavatthānaṃ, na sukhumāvayavavasenāti sīsasaṇṭhānādikaṃ
analyzed: yadi tattha koci an uddhumātaka bhāva patto padeso siyā saḥ na gahetabbaḥ iti dasseti  oḷārikā avayava vasena idam saṇṭhāna vavatthānam na sukhuma avayava vasena ati sīsa saṇṭhāna ādikam
translated: that if there is any part of it that has not reached the bloated state, that should not be taken.

original: navavidhameva saṇṭhānaṃ gahitaṃ.
analyzed: navavidham eva saṇṭhānam
translated: This is a definition of shape by gross parts, not by subtle parts. So only the nine kinds of shape beginning with the head’s shape are included.

original: Imissā disāyāti imissā puratthimāya, dakkhiṇapacchimauttarāya disāya, anudisāya vā🔽ṭhitoti yojanā. Imasmiṃ nāma okāse hatthāti imasmiṃ nāma bhūmippadese imassa kaḷevarassa
analyzed: imissā disāya ati imissā puratthimāya dakkhiṇa pacchima uttarāya disāya anudisāya vā  ṭhitaḥ iti yojanā imasmin nāma okāse hattha ati imasmin nāma bhūmi ppadese imassa kaḷevarassa
translated: “In this direction” means in this eastern, southern, western, or northern direction, or in the intermediate direction.

original: hatthā ṭhitāti vavatthapetabbanti yojanā.
analyzed: hatthā ṭhitā ati vavatthapetabbanti yojanā
translated: “Standing” is interpreted as “standing in such a place.” “In such a place” means in such a part of the ground. “The hand of this body” is interpreted as “is placed.”

original: Adho pādatalenātiādi nābhiyā heṭṭhā adho, tato uddhaṃ uparīti imassa vavatthānassa
analyzed: adhas pāda talena atiādi nābhiyā heṭṭhā adhas tatas uddham upari iti imassa vavatthānassa
translated: “Below with the sole of the foot” and so on. Below the navel is “below,” and above it is “above.” This is the definition.

original: vasena vuttaṃ. Hatthaparicchedo heṭṭhā aṅguliaggena upari aṃsakūṭasandhinā tiriyaṃ
analyzed: vasena vuttam hattha paricchedaḥ heṭṭhā aṅguli aggena upari aṃsakūṭa sandhinā tiriyam
translated: and the word “aspect” is stated in the sense of mode. The definition of a hand is that it is to be taken as far as the tip of the finger and the joint of the shoulder, and on the other side as far as the wrist and the elbow, and all round as far as the skin.

original: tacapariyantena gahetabbo. Esa nayo pādaparicchedādīsupi. Yattakaṃ vā pana ṭhānaṃ🔽gaṇhatīti sace sabbaṃ sarīraṃ paricchinditvā gahetuṃ na sakkoti, padeso tassa uddhumāto,
analyzed: taca pariyantena gahetabbo esa nayaḥ pāda pariccheda ādīsu pi yattakam vā pana ṭhānam  gaṇhati iti sace sabbam sarīram paricchinditvā gahetum na sakkoti padesaḥ tassa uddhumāto
translated: So too with the definition of a foot, and so on.🔽Or whatever part he apprehends: if he is unable to apprehend the whole body by defining it all round, then the bloated part is the part of his body that he apprehends.

original: so yattakaṃ sarīrappadesaṃ uddhumātakavasena ñāṇena pariggaṇhāti, tattakameva yathāpariggahitameva.
analyzed: saḥ yattakam sarīra ppadesam uddhumātaka vasena ñāṇena pariggaṇhāti tattakam eva yathā pariggahitam eva
translated: He should define that by means of the bloated perception.

original: Idaṃ īdisanti idaṃ hatthādikaṃ īdisaṃ evamākāraṃ. Uddhumātakanti yathāsabhāvato paricchinditabbaṃ.
analyzed: idam īdisanti idam hattha ādikam īdisam evam ākāram uddhumātakanti yathā sabhāvataḥ paricchinditabbam
translated: This is like this: this hand, etc., is like this, of this nature. It should be defined according to its individual essence as “the bloated.”

original: Visabhāge sarīre ārammaṇanti kammaṭṭhānaṃ paṭikkūlākāro na upaṭṭhāti na khāyati,
analyzed: visabhāge sarīre ārammaṇanti kammaṭṭhānam paṭikkūla ākāraḥ na upaṭṭhāti na khāyati
translated: In a different body: the meditation subject does not appear, does not become evident, in a different body.

original: subhato upaṭṭhaheyya. Tenāha “vipphandanasseva paccayo hotī”ti, kilesaparipphandanasseva
analyzed: subhataḥ upaṭṭhaheyya tena āha vipphandanassa iva paccayaḥ hoti iti kilesa paripphandanassa iva
translated: It would appear as beautiful. Therefore it is said, “It becomes a condition for the proliferation of defilements.”

original: nimittaṃ hotīti attho. Ugghāṭitāpīti uddhumātabhāvappattāpi, sabbaso kuthitasarīrāpīti
analyzed: nimittam hoti iti attho ugghāṭitā api iti uddhumāta bhāva ppattā api sabbaso kuthita sarīrā api iti
translated: the meaning is, it is a sign. Even when it is opened up: even when it has reached the stage of the bloated, even when the body is all decomposed,

original: vā attho. Svāyamattho paṭhamapārājike vinītavatthūhi dīpetabbo.
analyzed: vā atthaḥ svāyamatthaḥ paṭhama pārājike vinīta vatthūhi dīpetabbo
translated: the meaning is, it is a sign. Even when it is opened up: even when it has reached the stage of the bloated, or the meaning is, even when the whole body is scattered. This meaning should be illustrated by the stories of the training rules in the first chapter of the Pārājika section.🔽One who has developed the meditation subject: one who has had experience of the meditation subject consisting of foulness.

original: 111. Āsevitakammaṭṭhānoti asubhakammaṭṭhāne kataparicayo. Sosānikaṅgādīnaṃ vasena
analyzed: āsevita kammaṭṭhāno ti asubha kammaṭṭhāne kata paricayo sosānika ṅga ādīnam vasena
translated: One who has reduced his activities: one who has reduced his activities by means of the “cemetery contemplations,” etc.🔽One who has well explored the great primaries: one who has explored the four great primaries by means of the “contemplation of the four great primaries” .

original: parihatadhutaṅgo. Catudhātuvavatthānavasena parimadditamahābhūto. Salakkhaṇato ñāṇena🔽pariggahitasaṅkhāro. Paccayapariggahavasena vavatthāpitanāmarūpo. Salakkhaṇārammaṇikavipassanāya
analyzed: parihata dhutaṅgo catu dhātu vavatthāna vasena parimaddita mahābhūto sa lakkhaṇataḥ ñāṇena  pariggahita saṅkhāro paccaya pariggaha vasena vavatthāpita nāma rūpo sa lakkhaṇa ārammaṇika vipassanāya
translated: One who has discerned formations by means of the knowledge of their characteristics: one who has discerned formations by means of the knowledge of their characteristics.🔽One who has defined mentality-materiality by means of discerning conditions: one who has defined mentality-materiality by means of discerning conditions.🔽One who has removed the perception of living beings by means of the contemplation of repulsiveness: one who has removed the perception of living beings by means of the contemplation of repulsiveness in the sense of the specific characteristics.

original: ukkaṃsanena suññatānupassanābalena ugghāṭitasattasañño. Vipassanāya paṭipadāñāṇadassanavisuddhisampāpanena
analyzed: ukkaṃsanena suññatā anupassanā balena ugghāṭita satta saññaḥ vipassanāya paṭipadā ñāṇa dassana visuddhi sampāpanena
translated: One who has accomplished the purification of the way by knowledge and vision: one who has accomplished the purification of the way by knowledge and vision.

original: katasamaṇadhammo. Tato eva sabbaso kusalavāsanāya, kusalabhāvanāya ca pūraṇena vāsitavāsano
analyzed: kata samaṇa dhammo tatas eva sabbaso kusala vāsanāya kusala bhāvanāya ca pūraṇena vāsita vāsano
translated: One who has saturated the world by means of the development of the meditation subject: one who has saturated the world by means of the development of the meditation subject by completely filling it with profitable states and profitable intentions.

original: bhāvitabhāvano. Vivaṭṭūpanissayakusalabījena sabījo. Ñāṇassa paripakkabhāvena ñāṇuttaro.🔽Yathāvuttāya paṭipattiyā kilesānaṃ tanukaraṇena appakileso. Olokitolokitaṭṭhāneyevāti
analyzed: bhāvita bhāvanaḥ vivaṭṭu upanissaya kusala bījena sa bījaḥ ñāṇassa paripakka bhāvena ñāṇuttaro  yathā vuttāya paṭipattiyā kilesānam tanu karaṇena appa kilesaḥ olokita ulokita ṭṭhānā iya iva ati
translated: and the development of the meditation subject is the seed. He is “one who has the seed” because he has the seed of profitable action that has the support of the turning away from sensual pleasures. He is “one of superior knowledge” because his knowledge is ripe.🔽He is “one of little defilement” because his defilements are weak owing to his practice of the way of practice described.

original: uddhumātakādiasubhassa yattha yattha olokitolokitaṭṭhāne eva, tādisassa kālaviseso,
analyzed: uddhumātaka ādi asubhassa yattha yattha olokita ulokita ṭṭhāne eva tādisassa kāla viseso
translated: “In whatever place he looks” means that there is no need to look for a particular place for the foulness beginning with the bloated corpse;🔽the time is suitable in whatever place he looks, or the place is suitable in whatever time he looks.

original: asubhassa padesaviseso vā apekkhitabbo natthīti attho. No ce evaṃ upaṭṭhātīti evaṃ
analyzed: asubhassa padesa visesaḥ vā apekkhitabbaḥ natthi iti atthaḥ no ce evam upaṭṭhāti iti evam
translated: If it does not appear thus,

original: yathāvuttapurisavisesassa viya paṭibhāganimittaṃ no ce upaṭṭhāti. Evaṃ chabbidhenāti
analyzed: yathā vutta purisa visesassa viya paṭibhāga nimittam no ce upaṭṭhāti evam chabbidhena ati
translated: if the counterpart sign does not appear to him in the way it does to the person described,

original: evaṃ vuttākārena vaṇṇādivasena chabbidhena. Punapīti pi-saddo sampiṇḍanattho. Tena
analyzed: evam vutta ākārena vaṇṇa ādi vasena chabbidhena puna pi iti pi saddaḥ sampiṇḍana ttho tena
translated: “In six ways” means in the six ways already described, namely, as to colour, etc. The word “again” has the meaning of “also.”🔽It combines the method of apprehending the sign with the sixfold aspect, not the fivefold aspect.

original: nimittaggahaṇavidhiṃ sampiṇḍeti, na pañcavidhataṃ. Chabbidhena hi pubbe nimittaggahaṇaṃ vihitaṃ.
analyzed: nimitta ggahaṇa vidhim sampiṇḍeti na chabbidhena hi pubbe nimitta ggahaṇam vihitam
translated: For the apprehending of the sign was previously stated in the sixfold aspect.

original: 112. Asītisatasandhitoti sabbepi sandhayo tadāpi atthevāti dassanatthaṃ vatvā uddhumātabhāvena
analyzed: asīti sata sandhito ti sabbe pi sandhayaḥ tadā api atthā iva ati dassana attham vatvā uddhumāta bhāvena
translated: The purpose of the words “in the eighty-two-jointed one” is to show that all the joints are still there at that time.

original: yebhuyyena na paññāyanti. Ye pana paññāyanti, te vavatthapetabbāti dassetuṃ “uddhumātake🔽panā”tiādi vuttaṃ. Tattha tayo dakkhiṇahatthasandhīti aṃsakapparamaṇibandhānaṃ vasena🔽tayo dakkhiṇahatthasandhayo. Tathā vāmahatthasandhayo. Kaṭijaṇṇugopphakānaṃ vasena
analyzed: yebhuyyena na paññāyanti ye pana paññāyanti te vavatthapetabbā ti dassetum uddhumātake  pana atiādi vuttam tattha tayaḥ dakkhiṇa hattha sandhī iti aṃsakappara maṇibandhānam vasena  tayo dakkhiṇa hattha sandhayo tathā vāma hattha sandhayo kaṭi jaṇṇu gopphakānam vasena
translated: But they are not evident because of the bloated state. But those that are evident should be defined, so to show them the text has been stated thus, “In the bloated, however, …🔽” Herein, three joints of the right hand: three joints of the right hand by way of the shoulder-pith, the elbow, and the wrist.🔽Likewise three of the left hand. Three of the right foot: three joints of the right foot by way of the hip, the knee, and the ankle.

original: tayo dakkhiṇapādasandhayo. Tathā vāmapādasandhayo. Eko kaṭisandhīti kaṭiyā saddhiṃ🔽piṭṭhikaṇṭakasandhiṃ sandhāya vadati. Hatthantaranti dakkhiṇahatthadakkhiṇapassānaṃ,
analyzed: tayo dakkhiṇa pāda sandhayo tathā vāma pāda sandhayo eko kaṭi sandhī iti kaṭiyā saddhiṃ  piṭṭhikaṇṭaka sandhim sandhāya vadati hatthantaram ti dakkhiṇa hattha dakkhiṇa passānam
translated: Likewise three of the left foot. One of the hip: he speaks with reference to the joint of the spine with the hip.🔽The space between the hands: the space, the interval, between the right side of the right hand and the left side of the left hand.

original: vāmahatthavāmapassānañca antaraṃ vivaraṃ. Pādantaranti ubhinnaṃ pādānaṃ vemajjhaṃ.
analyzed: vāma hattha vāma passānam ca antaram vivaram pāda antaranti ubhinnam pādānam vemajjham
translated: The space between the feet: the middle of the two feet.

original: Udarantaranti nābhiṭṭhānasaññitaṃ kucchivemajjhaṃ, udarassa vā abbhantaraṃ. Kaṇṇantaranti
analyzed: udarantaranti nābhiṭṭhāna saññitam kucchi vemajjham udarassa vā abbhantaram kaṇṇantaranti
translated: The space between the breasts: the middle of the belly between the navel and the diaphragm, or the inside of the belly. The space between the ears:

original: kaṇṇachiddaṃ. Iti-saddo ādiattho, tena nāsacchiddādīnampi saṅgaho daṭṭhabbo. Akkhīnaṃ,
analyzed: kaṇṇa chiddam iti saddo ādi attho tena nāsa chidda ādīnam pi saṅgahaḥ daṭṭhabbo akkhīnam
translated: The word “and” has the meaning of “etc.,” so the nostrils and so on should be taken as well.

original: mukhassa ca vasenāpi vivaraṃ labbhatevāti dassetuṃ “akkhīnampī”tiādi vuttaṃ. Samantatoti
analyzed: mukhassa ca vasena api vivaram labbhate iva ati dassetum akkhīnam pi itiādi vuttam samantataḥ ti
translated: The word “also” is said in order to show that the eye and the mouth can also be the door.🔽“All round” means all round the body.

original: evaṃ sandhiādito uddhumātakaṃ vavatthapentassa ce nimittaṃ upatiṭṭhati, iccetaṃ kusalaṃ.
analyzed: evam sandhi āditaḥ uddhu mātakam vavatthapentassa ce nimittam upatiṭṭhati iccā itam kusalam
translated: If the sign becomes evident to him when he defines the bloated thus “from the joints outwards,” that is good.

original: No ce, samantato vavatthapetabbanti vavatthāpanavidhiṃ dassetuṃ “sakalasarīre”tiādi
analyzed: no ce samantataḥ vavatthapetabbanti vavatthāpana vidhim dassetum sakala sarīra itiādi
translated: If not, he should define it “all over the body” as follows, in order to show the method of defining it.

original: vuttaṃ. Tattha ñāṇaṃ cāretvāti sabbatthakameva sarīraṃ āvajjetvā tattha paṭikkūlākārasahitaṃ
analyzed: vuttam tattha ñāṇam cāretvā iti sabbatthakam eva sarīram āvajjetvā tattha paṭikkūla ākāra sahitam
translated: “Having directed perception”: having directed the whole of his consciousness to the whole of the body.

original: uddhumātakabhāvaṃ ārabbha nirantaraṃ bhāvanāñāṇaṃ pavattetvā. Yaṃ ṭhānanti evaṃ pana
analyzed: uddhumātaka bhāvam ārabbha nirantaram bhāvanā ñāṇam pavattetvā yam evam pana
translated: “Having extended knowledge”: having continuously directed the knowledge of development to the state of the bloated, which is associated with the aspect of repulsiveness in that .

original: ñāṇaṃ cārentassa tasmiṃ sarīre yo padeso vibhūto hutvā uddhumātakākārena vibhūtabhāvena
analyzed: ñāṇam cārentassa tasmin sarīre yaḥ padesaḥ vibhūtaḥ hutvā uddhumātaka ākārena vibhūta bhāvena
translated: “That place”: but when he directs his knowledge in this way, that part of the body which is discoloured and appears as the bloated aspect through its bloatedness

original: upaṭṭhāti. Udarapariyosānaṃ uparimasarīraṃ.🔽Vinicchayakathāvaṇṇanā
analyzed: upaṭṭhāti udara pariyosānam uparima sarīram 🔽vinicchaya kathā vaṇṇanā
translated: is the upper part of the body, ending with the belly.

original: 113. Vinicchayakathāti vinicchayasahitā atthavaṇṇanā. Yathāvuttanimittaggāhavasenāti
analyzed: vinicchaya kathā ati vinicchaya sahitā attha vaṇṇanā yathā vutta nimitta ggāha vasena ati
translated: 113. The commentary with the exposition is the commentary with the exposition of the judgment. By apprehending the sign in the way stated:

original: vaṇṇādito, sandhiādito ca vuttappakārauddhumātakanimittaggahaṇavasena. Suṭṭhu nimittaṃ
analyzed: vaṇṇa āditaḥ sandhi āditaḥ ca vutta ppakāra oddhumātaka nimitta ggahaṇa vasena suṭṭhu nimittam
translated: by apprehending the sign of the bloated corpse in the way stated under the headings of colour, etc., and the joints, etc.

original: gaṇhitabbanti yathā uggahanimittaṃ upaṭṭhahati, evaṃ sammadeva asubhanimittaṃ gahetabbaṃ.
analyzed: gaṇhitabbanti yathā uggaha nimittam upaṭṭhahati evam sammat eva asubha nimittam gahetabbam
translated: The sign should be well apprehended: the sign of foulness should be properly apprehended in the way the learning sign appears.

original: Idāni tameva nimittassa suṭṭhu gahaṇākāraṃ upadisanto “satiṃ sūpaṭṭhitaṃ katvā”tiādimāha.
analyzed: idāni tam eva nimittassa suṭṭhu gahaṇa ākāram upadisantaḥ satim su upaṭṭhitam katvā ati ādim āha
translated: Now, in order to teach the way in which that sign should be well apprehended, he said: “Having established mindfulness well” and so on.

original: Tattha evaṃ punappunaṃ karontenāti yathā “imāya paṭipadāya jarāmaraṇato muccissāmī”ti🔽sañjātādarena satisampajaññañca suṭṭhu upaṭṭhapetvā uddhumātakaasubhaṃ paṭhamaṃ āvajjitaṃ,
analyzed: tattha evam punappunam karontena ati yathā imāya paṭipadāya jarā maraṇataḥ muccissāmi iti  sañjāta ādarena sati sampajaññam ca suṭṭhu upaṭṭhapetvā uddhumātaka asubham paṭhamam āvajjitam
translated: Herein, he should do it again and again thus: “By this way I shall be liberated from ageing-and-death”🔽and he should establish mindfulness and full awareness well with the desire to learn, and he should advert again and again to the bloated corpse as foulness.

original: evaṃ punappunaṃ tattha āvajjanaṃ karontena. Sādhukaṃ upadhāretabbañceva vavatthapetabbañcāti
analyzed: evam punappunam tattha āvajjanam karontena sādhukam upadhāretabbam ca iva vavatthapetabbam ca ati
translated: He should thoroughly investigate and define it:

original: sakkaccaṃ satiyā sallakkhetabbañceva paññāya nicchetabbañca. Sati hi “dhāraṇā”ti
analyzed: sakkaccam satiyā sallakkhetabbam ca iva paññāya nicchetabbam ca sati hi dhāraṇā ati
translated: and should be looked over carefully with mindfulness and decided upon with understanding. For mindfulness is described as “bearing in mind” ,

original: niddiṭṭhā, dhāraṇañcettha sallakkhaṇaṃ. Paññā “pavicayo”ti niddiṭṭhā, pavicayo cettha🔽nicchayoti. Atha vā upadhāretabbanti satipubbaṅgamāya paññāya upalakkhetabbaṃ. Na
analyzed: niddiṭṭhā dhāraṇam ca ittha sat lakkhaṇam paññā pavicayo ti niddiṭṭhā pavicayo ca ittha  nicchayo ti atha vā upadhāretabbam ti sati pubbaṅgamāya paññāya upalakkhetabbam na
translated: and “looking over” is included in that; and understanding is described as “discernment” , and “deciding upon” is included in that.

original: hi kadāci satirahitā paññā atthi. Vavatthapetabbanti paññāpubbaṅgamāya satiyā nicchinitabbaṃ.
analyzed: hi kadāci sati rahitā paññā atthi vavatthapetabbanti paññā pubbaṅgamāya satiyā nicchinitabbam
translated: Or alternatively, it should be borne in mind that “looking over” is done with understanding that has mindfulness as its forerunner, for there is never understanding without mindfulness.

original: Paññāsahitā eva hi sati idhādhippetā, na tabbirahitā. Addhakkhiapaṅgādivasenāpi olokanaṃ🔽atthīti “ummīletvā oloketvā”ti vuttaṃ. Tena paribyattameva olokanaṃ dasseti. Evaṃ
analyzed: paññā sahitāḥ eva hi sati idha adhippetāḥ na tad virahitāḥ olokanam  atthi iti ummīletvā oloketvā iti vuttam tena paribyattam eva olokanam dasseti evam
translated: And “deciding upon” is done with mindfulness that has understanding as its forerunner, for it is mindfulness accompanied by understanding that is intended here, not mindfulness without understanding.

original: punappunaṃ karontassāti vuttappakārena cakkhuṃ ummīletvā olokanaṃ, nimmīletvā āvajjanañca🔽aparāparaṃ anekavāraṃ karontassa. Uggahanimittanti uddhumātake uggaṇhananimittaṃ.
analyzed: punappunam karontassa ati vutta ppakārena cakkhum ummīletvā olokanam nimmīletvā āvajjanam ca 🔽apara aparam aneka vāram karontassa uggaha nimittam ti uddhu mātake uggaṇhana nimittam
translated: And although there is looking with the eye in the way stated, nevertheless it is said that “he should open his eyes and look” in order to show that the looking should be done with the eye directed to one side, not by turning the whole body.

original: Suggahitanti suṭṭhu gahitaṃ. Yathā na vinassati na pamuṭṭhaṃ hoti, evaṃ gahitaṃ.🔽Ekasadisanti samānasadisaṃ. Samānattho hi ayaṃ eka-saddo, yathā “ariyavinayeti vā,
analyzed: suggahitanti suṭṭhu gahitam yathā na vinassati na pamuṭṭham hoti evam gahitam  eka sadisam ti samāna sadisam samāna atthaḥ hi ayam eka saddaḥ yathā ariya vinaya iti vā
translated: Well apprehended: well taken up, so that it is not lost or forgotten.🔽Of the same kind: similar, the same. For the word eka has the meaning of sameness, as in such passages as “in the Dispensation of the Noble Ones” ,

original: sappurisavinayeti vā, esese eke ekaṭṭhe same samabhāge tajjāte taññe vā”ti.
analyzed: sappurisa vinaya iti vā esese eke ekaṭṭhe same sama bhāge tad jāte taññe vā ati
translated: “in the Dispensation of the Good Men” , “these are the same, single, united, of one and the same opinion” .

original: Āgamanakāleti vihārato susānaṃ uddissa āgamanakāle. Vuttanayenevāti atidesavasena
analyzed: āgamana kāle iti vihārataḥ susānam uddissa āgamana kāle vutta nayena iva āti atidesa vasena
translated: On the way as he goes: on the way from the monastery to the charnel ground, in the way already described.

original: dīpitampi atthaṃ “ekakenā”tiādinā sarūpato dasseti. Tattha tadeva kammaṭṭhānanti
analyzed: dīpitam pi attham ekakena ati ādinā sarūpataḥ dasseti tattha tat eva kammaṭṭhānam ti
translated: As he goes: he shows the meaning by the word eka in the way already described.🔽Herein, the same meditation subject: the meditation subject of the bloated.

original: uddhumātakakammaṭṭhānaṃ. Mūlakammaṭṭhānanti eke, tadayuttaṃ. Upaṭṭhitanimittaṃ hi
analyzed: uddhumātaka kammaṭṭhānam mūla kammaṭṭhānam ti eke tat ayuttam upaṭṭhita nimittam hi
translated: Some say that the word “same” is a term for the basic meditation subject.🔽But that is inappropriate, for the meditation subject is the sign of foulness.

original: kammaṭṭhānaṃ vissajjetvā kammaṭṭhānantaramanasikāro rañño rajjaṃ chaḍḍetvā videsagamanaṃ🔽viyāti. Āgatenāti attano vasanaṭṭhānaṃ āgatena.
analyzed: kammaṭṭhānam vissajjetvā kammaṭṭhāna antara manasikāraḥ raññaḥ rajjam chaḍḍetvā videsa gamanam 🔽viya ati āgatena ati attanaḥ vasana ṭhānam āgatena
translated: The attention given to the meditation subject after the meditation subject has been relinquished is like a king’s going into exile after he has abdicated the kingdom.

original: 114. Avelāyanti sañjhāvelādiayuttavelāyaṃ. Bībhacchanti virūpaṃ. Bheravārammaṇanti🔽vetāḷasadisaṃ bhayānakaṃ visayaṃ. Vikkhittacittoti bhīrukapuriso viya pisācādiṃ disvā🔽cittavikkhepaṃ patto. Ummattako viyāti yakkhummattako viya ekacco hoti. Jhānavibbhantakoti🔽jhānato viccutako sīlavibbhantakamantavibbhantakā viya. Santhambhetvāti uppannaparittāsavūpasamanena
analyzed: avelāyanti sañjhā velā ādi ayuttavelāyam bībhacchanti virūpam  vetāḷa sadisam bhayānakam visayam vikkhitta cittaḥ iti bhīruka purisaḥ viya pisāca ādim disvā  citta vikkhepam pattaḥ ummattakaḥ viyā ti yakkha ummattakaḥ viya ekaccaḥ hoti jhāna vibbhantakaḥ ti  jhānataḥ viccutakaḥ sīla vibbhantaka manta vibbhantakāḥ viya santhambhetvā ati uppanna paritta āsava upasamanena
translated: ‘At the wrong time’ means at a time unsuitable for the twilight meditation, etc. ‘They are afraid’ means they are frightened. ‘A frightening object’ means a terrifying object like a goblin. ‘His mind is distracted’ means that he is like a timid man who, on seeing a goblin, etc.,🔽has a distracted mind. ‘He is like one demented’ means that he is like one who is demented by spirits. ‘He is like one fallen from the state of mindfulness’ means that he is like one who has fallen from the jhāna, or from virtue, or from the state of mindfulness. ‘Having steadied himself’ means having allayed the slight fear that has arisen.

original: vigatakampatāya niccalo hutvā. Satiṃ sūpaṭṭhitantiādi santhambhanassa upāyadassanaṃ.🔽Matasarīraṃ uṭṭhahitvā anubandhanakaṃ nāma natthi asati tādise mantappayoge. Sopi🔽uddhumātakādibhāvamappatte avinaṭṭharūpe eva ijjhati, tathā devatādhiggaho, na evarūpeti
analyzed: vigata kampa tāya niccalaḥ hutvā satim su upaṭṭhita ntiādi santhambhanassa upāya dassanam 🔽mata sarīram uṭṭhahitvā anubandhanakam nāma natthi asati tādise manta ppayoge so api 🔽uddhumātaka ādi bhāvam appatte a vinaṭṭha rūpe eva ijjhati tathā devatā adhiggahaḥ na evarūpā iti
translated: ‘At the wrong time’ means at a time unsuitable for the twilight meditation, etc. ‘He is afraid’ means he is frightened. ‘A fearful object’ means a terrifying object like a goblin. ‘With his mind distracted’ means that he has become distracted in mind like a timid man who sees a goblin, etc. ‘Like one demented’ means that he is like one who is possessed by a spirit. ‘One who has lost his meditation’ means one who has lost his jhāna, like one who has lost his virtue or his mind. ‘Composing himself’ means that he is steady, free from trembling, by suppressing the fear that has arisen. ‘Well established mindfulness’ and so on show the means for composing himself.

original: adhippāyo. Saññajoti bhāvanāparikappasaññāya jāto. Tato eva saññāsambhavo saññāmattasamuṭṭhāno.
analyzed: adhippāyaḥ sañña jo ti bhāvanā parikappa saññāya jāto tatas eva saññā sambhavo saññā matta samuṭṭhāno
translated: The intention is the perception arisen from the contemplation of the meditation subject. The origination of perception is the origination of mere perception.

original: Tāsaṃ vinodetvāti nimittupaṭṭhānanimittaṃ uppannacittasantāsaṃ vuttappakārena vinodetvā
analyzed: tāsam vinodetvā ti nimitta upaṭṭhāna nimittam uppanna citta santāsam vutta ppakārena vinodetvā
translated: Having dispelled their fear: having dispelled the fear of the occurrence of the sign in the form of a mental agitation of the kind already described.

original: vūpasametvā. “Idāni tava parissamo sapphalo jāto”ti hāsaṃ pītiṃ pamodanaṃ uppādetvā.
analyzed: vūpasametvā idāni tava parissamaḥ sapphalaḥ jātaḥ iti hāsam pītim pamodanam uppādetvā
translated: Having allayed it: having aroused laughter, rapture, and gladness, thinking, “Now your trouble has borne fruit.”

original: Cittaṃ sañcarāpetabbanti bhāvanācittaṃ pavattetabbaṃ manasikātabbaṃ.🔽Nimittaggāhanti nimittassa uggaṇhanaṃ, uggahanimittaṃ. Sampādentoti sādhento nipphādento.
analyzed: cittam sañcarāpetabbanti bhāvanā cittam pavattetabbam manasikātabbam  nimitta ggāhanti nimittassa uggaṇhanam uggaha nimittam sampādentaḥ iti sādhentaḥ nipphādentaḥ
translated: The mind should be directed: the development of the meditation subject should be undertaken, it should be given attention.🔽Seizing the sign: apprehending the sign, the learning sign.🔽Mastering it: perfecting it, accomplishing it.

original: Kammaṭṭhānaṃ upanibandhatīti bhāvanaṃ yathāvutte nimitte upanento nibandhati. Yogakammaṃ
analyzed: kammaṭṭhānam upanibandhati iti bhāvanam yathā vutte nimitte upanentaḥ nibandhati yogakammaṃ
translated: He anchors his mind: he directs his mind to the meditation subject and anchors it there.

original: hi yogino sukhavisesānaṃ kāraṇabhāvato “kammaṭṭhāna”nti adhippetaṃ, yogakammassa
analyzed: hi yoginaḥ sukha visesānam kāraṇa bhāvato kammaṭṭhānan ti adhippetam yoga kammassa
translated: For the meditation subject is intended as a “work of yoga” because it is the cause for the special distinction of the yogin’s happiness.

original: vā pavattiṭṭhānatāya yathāupaṭṭhitanimittaṃ kammaṭṭhānaṃ, taṃ bhāvanācitte upanibandhati.
analyzed: vā pavatti ṭṭhāna tāya yathā upaṭṭhita nimittam kammaṭṭhānam tam bhāvanā citte upanibandhati
translated: Or the meditation subject is the sign as it appears, which is the basis for the occurrence of the work of yoga. He anchors his mind on that in the development of the meditation subject.

original: Taṃ panassa upanibandhanaṃ sandhāya cittaṃ sañcarāpetabbaṃ. Evaṃ “visesamadhigacchatī”ti
analyzed: tam panassa upanibandhanam sandhāya cittam sañcara apetabbam evam visesam adhigacchati iti
translated: And he should direct his mind to the sign as the condition for that.🔽Showing how he “makes progress” in this way, the Master said:

original: vuttanti dassento “tassa hī”tiādimāha. Tattha tassāti yogino, tassa vā uddhumātakāsubhassa.🔽Mānasaṃ cārentassāti bhāvanācittaṃ aparāparaṃ pavattentassa, uggahanimittaṃ punappunaṃ
analyzed: vuttanti dassentaḥ tassa hi iti ādim āha tattha tassa ati yoginaḥ tassa vā uddhumātaka subhassa  mānasam cārentassa ati bhāvanā cittam apara aparam pavattentassa uggaha nimittam punappunam
translated: “If he does this, his mind moves along the path of the sign.”🔽Herein, his mind moves along the path of the sign: his consciousness moves along the path of the sign.

original: manasi karontassāti attho.
analyzed: manasi karontassa ati attho
translated: The meaning is that his development consciousness moves along in succession.🔽The meaning of the words “in order to make the path of the sign manifest” is “in order to make the sign’s path manifest.”

original: 115. “Vīthisampaṭipādanatthā”ti padassa “kammaṭṭhānavīthiyā sampaṭipādanatthā”ti
analyzed: vīthi sampaṭipādana tthā ati padassa kammaṭṭhāna vīthiyā sampaṭipādana tthā ati
translated: The sign’s path is the sign’s way.🔽The meaning is that he makes the sign’s way manifest, evident, clear.

original: atthaṃ vatvā taṃ pana kammaṭṭhānavīthiṃ, tassā ca sampaṭipādanavidhiṃ vitthārato
analyzed: attham vatvā tam pana kammaṭṭhāna vīthim tassā ca sampaṭipādana vidhim vitthārato
translated: Having stated the meaning in this way, the Master said “If he does this” in order to show in detail the sign’s way and the method of making it manifest.🔽Herein, which fortnight? Which half-month? Which of the two, the bright or the dark fortnight?

original: dassetuṃ “sace hī”tiādi vuttaṃ. Tattha katimīti pakkhassa katamī, kiṃ dutiyā, tatiyādīsu
analyzed: dassetum sace hi itiādi vuttam tattha katimī iti pakkhassa katamī kim dutiyā tatiya ādīsu
translated: The meaning is which of the first or the second fortnight.

original: vā aññatarāti attho. Tuṇhībhūtena gantuṃ na vaṭṭati pucchantānaṃ cittassa aññathattapariharaṇatthaṃ.
analyzed: vā aññatarā ti attho tuṇhībhūtena gantum na vaṭṭati pucchantānam cittassa aññathatta pariharaṇa attham
translated: He should not go silently. He should not go without saying anything. He should not go without telling.

original: Appasannānañhi pasādāya, pasannānañca bhiyyobhāvāya sāsanasampaṭipatti. Nassatīti
analyzed: appasannānam hi pasādāya pasannānam ca bhiyyobhāvāya sāsana sampaṭipatti nassati iti
translated: Vanishes:🔽is not seen, is not evident, is the meaning.

original: na dissati, na upaṭṭhātīti attho. “Āgantukapaṭisanthāro kātabbo”ti iminā āgantukavattaṃ
analyzed: na dissati na upaṭṭhāti iti attho āgantuka paṭisanthāraḥ kātabbaḥ iti iminā āgantuka vattam
translated: By the words “the duties towards a newly arrived bhikkhu should be performed,” the duties towards a newly arrived bhikkhu are shown in part.

original: ekadesena dassitanti “avasesānipī”ti vatvā āgantukavattaṃ paripuṇṇaṃ gahetuṃ puna
analyzed: eka desena dassitanti avasesāni pi iti vatvā āgantuka vattam paripuṇṇam gahetum puna
translated: Therefore, after saying “the rest too,” the newly arrived bhikkhu is mentioned again in order to take the duties towards a newly arrived bhikkhu in their entirety.

original: āgantukaggahaṇaṃ kataṃ. Gamikavattādīnīti ādi-saddena āvāsikaanumodanapiṇḍacārikaanumodanapiṇḍacārikaāraññikasenāsanavaccakuṭivattādīnaṃ
analyzed: āgantuka ggahaṇam katam gamika vatta ādīni iti ādi saddena āvāsika anumodana piṇḍacārika anumodana piṇḍacārika āraññika senāsana vacca kuṭi vatta ādīnam
translated: The duties towards one who is going away, etc.: the word “etc.” should be understood to include the duties towards a resident bhikkhu, the duties towards one who is expressing his appreciation for being offered food, the duties towards a forest-dwelling bhikkhu, the duties towards one who is expressing his appreciation for being offered a dwelling, the duties towards one who is expressing his appreciation for being offered a bed, the duties towards one who is expressing his appreciation for being offered a monastery, and so on.

original: saṅgaho daṭṭhabbo. Vattakkhandhake hi āgatāni mahāvattāni idha “khandhakavattānī”ti🔽vuttāni. Tajjanīyakammakatādikāle pana pārivāsikādikāle ca caritabbāni imassa bhikkhuno
analyzed: saṅgahaḥ daṭṭhabbaḥ vatta khandhake hi āgatāni mahā vattāni idha khandhaka vattāni iti  vuttāni tajjanīya kammakata ādi kāle pana pārivāsika ādi kāle ca caritabbāni imassa bhikkhuno
translated: For the major duties given in the Duties Section are called here “the duties of the sections.”

original: asambhavato idha nādhippetāni. Nimittaṃ vā antaradhāyatīti susāne ṭhitaṃ asubhanimittaṃ
analyzed: a sambhavataḥ idha na adhippetāni nimittam vai antaradhāyati iti su sāne ṭhitam asubha nimittam
translated: But those that should be performed at the time of the transaction of a meeting of the Order, such as the transaction of a meeting of the Order consisting of a motion only, etc., and at the time of the transaction of a meeting of the Order consisting of a motion and announcement, etc., are not included here because they are not possible for this bhikkhu.🔽The sign disappears: the sign of foulness in the charnel ground

original: uddhumātakabhāvāpagamena antaradhāyati. Tenāha “uddhumātaka”ntiādi. Tasmāti tena
analyzed: uddhumātaka bhāva apagamena tena āha tena
translated: and it disappears with the disappearance of the bloated state. Hence ‘bloated’ is said, and so on. Therefore

original: kāraṇena, imassa kammaṭṭhānassa dullabhattāti attho. Nisīditvā paccavekkhitabboti sambandho.🔽Nimittaṃ gahetuṃ gamane viya nimittaṃ gahetvā nivattanepi yathāsallakkhitadisādipaccavekkhaṇaṃ🔽yāva nimittavināsā pavattitakiriyāya avicchedena upadhāraṇatthaṃ. Sati hi tassa nirantarūpadhāraṇe
analyzed: kāraṇena imassa kammaṭṭhānassa dullabha ttā ti attho nisīditvā paccavekkhitabbaḥ ti sambandho  nimittam gahetum gamane viya nimittam gahetvā nivattane pi yathā sat lakkhita disa ādi paccavekkhaṇam  yāva nimitta vināsā avicchedena upadhāraṇa attham sati hi tassa nirantara upadhāraṇe
translated: and it disappears with the disappearance of the bloated state. Hence “bloated” is said, and so on. For that reason: for that reason, for this reason, this meditation subject is hard to come by, is the meaning. He should review it while sitting down: the construction is with the verb “should review.”🔽Just as when he went to get the sign he reviewed the directions, etc., so too when he has got the sign and is returning, he should keep on reviewing the directions, etc., until he reaches the place where the sign disappeared.🔽For if he does so, then when he enters the monastery and sits down the aspect of the meditation subject will appear as it was seen by him,

original: vihāraṃ pavisitvā nisinnakāle kammaṭṭhānassa upaṭṭhitākāro samathanimittassa gahaṇe
analyzed: vihāram pavisitvā nisinna kāle kammaṭṭhānassa upaṭṭhita ākāraḥ samatha nimittassa gahaṇe
translated: just as the aspect of the sign in the state of composure appears when he has attained it.

original: cittassa samāhitākāro viya pākaṭo hutvā upatiṭṭheyyāti. Tenāha “tassevaṃ…pe… vīthiṃ🔽paṭipajjatī”ti. Purimākārena nimittassa pākaṭabhāvena upaṭṭhitattā purimākāreneva
analyzed: cittassa samāhita ākāraḥ viya pākaṭaḥ hutvā upatiṭṭheyya iti tena āha vīthim  paṭipajjati iti purima ākārena nimittassa pākaṭa bhāvena upaṭṭhita ttā purima ākārena iva
translated: Hence it is said: “He should direct his mind upon it in this way … and enter upon the way to development.”🔽Since the sign has appeared to him in the aspect in which it was originally seen,

original: kammaṭṭhānamanasikāro bhāvanāvīthiṃ paṭipajjati.
analyzed: kammaṭṭhāna manasikāraḥ bhāvanā vīthim paṭipajjati
translated: he enters upon the way to development of the meditation subject by giving his attention to it in the original way.

original: 116. Uddhumātakaṃ nāma ativiya asuciduggandhajegucchapaṭikkūlaṃ bībhacchaṃ bhayānakañca,
analyzed: uddhumātakam nāma asuci duggandha jeguccha paṭikkūlam bībhaccham bhayānakam ca
translated: The bloated is the most contemptible, disgusting, repulsive, fearful, and terrifying of all corpses.

original: evarūpe ārammaṇe bhāvanamanuyuñjantassa evaṃ ābaddhaparikammassa thirībhūtasseva
analyzed: evarūpe ārammaṇe bhāvanam anuyuñjantassa evam ābaddha parikammassa thirībhūtassa iva
translated: When one is devoted to the development of meditation subject consisting of a bloated corpse as object, then, as one who has made a fence round himself,

original: yogino adhippāyo samijjhatīti dassetuṃ “ānisaṃsadassāvī”tiādi vuttaṃ. Evanti evameva
analyzed: yoginaḥ adhippāyaḥ samijjhati iti dassetum ānisaṃsa dassāvī itiādi vuttam evam ti evam eva
translated: the meditator’s purpose succeeds. In order to show this, it is said: “Seeing the advantages in this” and so on. In this way: in this very way.

original: vuttappakāreneva ānisaṃsadassāvinā. Taṃ rakkheyyāti “addhā iminā sukhaṃ jīvissāmī”ti🔽attano jīvitaṃ viya taṃ maṇiratanaṃ rakkheyya. Catudhātukammaṭṭhānikotiādi nesaṃ🔽kammaṭṭhānānaṃ sulabhatādassanaṃ. Tattha catudhātukammaṭṭhānikoti catudhātukammaṭṭhānaṃ🔽vā tattha vā niyutto, catudhātukammaṭṭhānaṃ vā pariharanto. Itarānīti vuttāvasiṭṭhāni
analyzed: vutta ppakārena iva ānisaṃsa dassāvinā tam rakkheyya ati addhā iminā sukham jīvissāmi iti  attanaḥ jīvitam viya tam maṇi ratanam rakkheyya catu dhātu kammaṭṭhānika uti ādi nesam  kammaṭṭhānānam sulabha tā dassanam tattha catu dhātu kammaṭṭhānikaḥ ti catu dhātu kammaṭṭhānam  vā tattha vā niyuttaḥ catu dhātu kammaṭṭhānam vā pariharantaḥ itarāni iti vutta avasiṭṭhāni
translated: Seeing the advantages: seeing the advantages in this meditation subject in this way. He should guard it: he should guard that gem of a meditation subject as he would his life, thinking, “Surely, by this I shall live happily.”

original: anussatibrahmavihārādīni. Taṃ nimittanti taṃ yathāladdhaṃ uggahanimittaṃ. “Rakkhitabba”nti
analyzed: anussati brahmavihāra ādīni tam nimittam ti tam yathā laddham uggaha nimittam rakkhitabbanti
translated: The words “one who has a meditation subject consisting of a four-element meditation object” and so on show that these meditation subjects are easy to obtain. Herein, one who has a meditation subject consisting of a four-element meditation object: one who has a meditation subject consisting of the four elements, or who is devoted to it, or who deals with it. The others: the remaining meditation subjects consisting of mindfulness of the body, etc., and the recollections, divine abidings, etc. That sign: that sign of the meditation object as acquired. Should guard it:

original: vatvā rakkhaṇavidhiṃ puna dassetuṃ “rattiṭṭhāne”tiādi vuttaṃ.
analyzed: vatvā rakkhaṇa vidhim puna dassetum ratti ṭṭhāna itiādi vuttaṃ
translated: Having said this, he now said “in the place where he is to stand guard” in order to point out the method of guarding.🔽It is a differentiation because it is differentiated, that is, it is divided.

original: 117. Nānā karīyati etenāti nānākaraṇaṃ, bhedo. Bībhacchaṃ bheravadassanaṃ hutvā upaṭṭhāti
analyzed: nānā etena ati nānākaraṇam bhedaḥ bībhaccham bherava dassanam hutvā upaṭṭhāti
translated: It appears as though terrifying, as though dreadful.

original: manasikārassa anuḷāratāya, anupasantatāya ca ārammaṇassa. Tabbipariyāyato “paṭibhāganimittaṃ
analyzed: manasikārassa anuḷāra tāya anupasanta tāya ca ārammaṇassa tad vipariyāyataḥ paṭibhāga nimittam
translated: Because of the coarseness and lack of peacefulness of the attention and the object.🔽The counterpart sign appears in the opposite way.

original: thūlaṅgapaccaṅgapuriso viya upaṭṭhātī”ti ānetvā sambandhitabbaṃ. Bahiddhāti gocarajjhattato
analyzed: thūlaṅga paccaṅga purisaḥ viya upaṭṭhāti iti ānetvā sambandhitabbam bahiddhā iti gocara jjhattataḥ
translated: It should be connected with the words “like a man with a large body and limbs.”🔽Outside: outside the range of the kasiṇa .

original: bahiddhā. Kāmānaṃ amanasikārāti asubhabhāvanānubhāvena kāmasaññāya dūrasamussāritattā
analyzed: bahiddhā kāmānam a manasikārāti asubha bhāvanā anubhāvena kāma saññāya dūra samussārita ttā
translated: Because of non-attention to sense desires: because of the sense desires’ being sent far away by the influence of the meditation on foulness,🔽because of the mere non-existence of attention to the strands of sense desire.

original: kāmaguṇe ārabbha manasikārasseva abhāvā. Amanasikārāti vā manasikārapaṭipakkhahetu.
analyzed: kāma guṇe ārabbha manasikārassa iva abhāvāḥ amanasikārā ati vā manasikāra paṭipakkha hetu
translated: Or non-attention is the cause that is the opposite of attention.

original: Yāya hi kāmasaññāya vasena sattā kāme manasi karonti, tassā paṭipakkhabhūtā asubhasaññā
analyzed: yāya hi kāma saññāya vasena sattā kāme manasi karonti tassā paṭipakkha bhūtā asubha saññā
translated: For it is by the perception of sense desires that beings pay attention to sense desires. The perception of foulness, which is the opposite of that,

original: kāmānaṃ amanasikāro, tannimittanti attho. Tenāha “vikkhambhanavasena kāmacchando
analyzed: kāmānam amanasikāraḥ tad nimittam ti attho tena āha vikkhambhana vasena kāmacchando
translated: is non-attention to sense desires. The meaning is that it is the sign of that. Hence it is said: “Non-attention to sense desires is the perception of foulness, which abandons the perception of beauty” .

original: pahīyatī”ti. Paṭibhāganimittārammaṇāya hi asubhasaññāya saddhiṃ balappatto samādhi
analyzed: pahīyati iti paṭibhāga nimitta ārammaṇāya hi asubha saññāya saddhim bala ppatto samādhi
translated: for the jhāna is strong enough to suppress applied thought, and applied thought is the root of investigation.🔽When the root is suppressed, the branch is suppressed too. That is why he said, “disappears” .

original: uppajjamānova kāmacchandaṃ vikkhambheti, anurodhamūlako āghāto mūlakāraṇe vikkhambhite
analyzed: uppajjamānaḥ iva kāmacchandam vikkhambheti anurodha mūlakaḥ āghātaḥ mūla kāraṇe vikkhambhite
translated: For the jhāna, which is accompanied by the perception of foulness and by the associated mindfulness and full awareness, is strong enough to suppress lust, and anger is suppressed too because it has no object since there is no gratification to be grasped.

original: vikkhambhitoyeva hotīti āha “anunaya…pe… pahīyatī”ti. Na hi kadāci pahīnānunayassa🔽byāpādo sambhavati. Yathāvuttaasubhasaññāsahagatā hi pīti sātisayā pavattamānāva
analyzed: hoti iti āha anunaya pe pahīyati iti na hi kadāci pahīna anunayassa  byāpādaḥ sambhavati yathāvutta asubha saññā sahagatā hi pīti sa atisayā pavattamānā ava
translated: That is why he said, “disappears” . For when lust is suppressed, anger has no scope.🔽And the happiness associated with the perception of foulness, which occurs in excess, suppresses anger.

original: byāpādaṃ vikkhambhentī pavattati. Tathā āraddhavīriyatāyāti yathā upacārajjhānaṃ🔽uppajjati, tathā kammaṭṭhānamanasikāravasena paggahitavīriyatāya. Vīriyañhi paggaṇhantassa
analyzed: byāpādam vikkhambhentī pavattati tathā āraddha vīriya tāya ati yathā upacāra jhānam  uppajjati tathā kammaṭṭhāna manasikāra vasena paggahita vīriya tāya vīriyam hi paggaṇhantassa
translated: And the energy that is aroused in the same way as the jhāna arises to suppress stiffness and torpor.

original: sammāsaṅkappo micchāsaṅkappaṃ viya savipphāratāya thinamiddhaṃ vikkhambhentameva uppajjati.
analyzed: sammāsaṅkappaḥ micchāsaṅkappam viya sa vipphāra tāya thinam iddham vikkhambhentam eva uppajjati
translated: For when energy is aroused, it arises to suppress stiffness and torpor just as right thinking does wrong thinking.

original: Vippaṭisāro pacchānutāpo, tappaṭipakkhato avippaṭisāro darathapariḷāhābhāvena cittassa
analyzed: vippaṭisāraḥ pacchā anutāpaḥ tad paṭipakkhato a vippaṭisāraḥ daratha pariḷāha abhāvena cittassa
translated: Regret is subsequent repentance; non-regret is the opposite of that, since there is no absence of satisfaction and no fever of anxiety.

original: nibbutatā. Tassa avippaṭisārassa paccayabhūtaṃ sīlaṃ, taṃsahagatā tadupanissayā ca
analyzed: nibbuta tā tassa a vippaṭisārassa paccaya bhūtam sīlam tad sahagatā tad upanissayā ca
translated: and the state of peace. The virtue that is the condition for that non-remorse is, together with that,

original: pītipassaddhisukhādayo sabhāvato, hetuto ca santasabhāvā, tesaṃ anuyuñjanena avūpasantasabhāvaṃ
analyzed: pīti passaddhi sukha ādayo sabhāvataḥ hetuto ca santa sabhāvā tesam anuyuñjanena a vūpasanta sabhāvam
translated: tranquil by nature and by cause, and the joy, tranquillity, happiness, etc., that are associated with it and are its concomitants. The agitation and worry that are the opposite of that tranquillity are abandoned by the practice of insight.

original: uddhaccakukkuccaṃ pahīyatīti āha “avippaṭisārakarasantadhammānuyogavasena uddhaccakukkuccaṃ🔽pahīyatī”ti. Bhāvanāya hi pubbenāparaṃ visesaṃ āvahantiyā yaṃ sātisayaṃ sukhaṃ labbhati,
analyzed: uddhacca kukkuccam pahīyati iti āha a vippaṭisāraka rasanta dhamma anuyoga vasena uddhacca kukkuccam  pahīyati iti bhāvanāya hi pubbena aparam visesam āvahantiyā yam sa atisayam sukham labbhati
translated: Therefore it is said: “By the practice of the tranquil dhammas that cause non-remorse, agitation and worry are abandoned.”🔽For when the development of insight brings about a higher distinction in the next stage, the superior happiness that is obtained arises only by suppressing the agitation and worry that are the opposite of tranquillity.

original: taṃ anupasantasabhāvaṃ uddhaccakukkuccaṃ vikkhambhentameva uppajjati. Adhigatavisesassāti
analyzed: tam an upasanta sabhāvam uddhacca kukkuccam vikkhambhentam eva uppajjati adhigata visesassa ati
translated: “By the attainment of distinction” means by the distinction in the development of what has already been attained.

original: yathādhigatassa bhāvanāvisesassa. Paccakkhatāyāti paṭipajjantassa yogino paccakkhabhāvato
analyzed: yathā adhigatassa bhāvanā visesassa paccakkha tāya ati paṭipajjantassa yogino paccakkha bhāvato
translated: “By the manifestation” means by the manifestation of the practice to the yogin who is practising.

original: “sammāsambuddho vata so bhagavā, yo evarūpiṃ sammāpaṭipattiṃ desetī”ti paṭipattidesake
analyzed: sammāsambuddhaḥ vata saḥ bhagavā yaḥ evarūpim sammā paṭipattim deseti iti paṭipatti desake
translated: “The perfectly enlightened Blessed One, who teaches such a right practice, is indeed perfectly enlightened.”

original: satthari. Paṭipattiyanti paṭipajjamānajjhānapaṭipattiyaṃ. Paṭipattiphaleti tāya sādhetabbe
analyzed: satthari paṭipattiyanti paṭipajjamāna jhāna paṭipattiyam paṭipatti phale iti tāya sādhetabbe
translated: In the Master, in the practice, in the fruit of the practice, in the attainment, in the realization, in the penetration, in the development, in the abandoning, in the eradication, in the quieting, in the fading away, in the cessation, in the giving up, in the relinquishing.

original: lokiyalokuttaraphale. Vicikicchā pahīyati dhammanvayavicārāhitabalena vicārabalena.🔽Iti pañca nīvaraṇāni pahīyantīti evaṃ paṭibhāganimittapaṭilābhasamakālameva heṭṭhā🔽pavattabhāvanānubhāvanipphannehi samādhiādīhi kāmacchandādīni pañca nīvaraṇāni vikkhambhanavasena
analyzed: lokiya lokuttara phale vicikicchā pahīyati dhamma anvaya vicāra āhita balena vicāra balena  iti pañca nīvaraṇāni pahīyanti iti evam paṭibhāga nimitta paṭilābha sama kālam eva heṭṭhā  pavatta bhāvanā anubhāva nipphannehi samādhi ādīhi kāmacchanda ādīni pañca nīvaraṇāni vikkhambhana vasena
translated: Doubt is abandoned by the power of investigation and the power of sustained application, which are the means of investigating the Dhamma.🔽Thus the five hindrances are abandoned. In this way, at the very moment of the acquisition of the counterpart sign, the five hindrances are abandoned by suppression through the power of concentration, etc., which are the fruit of the development of the preliminary stage.

original: pahīyanti. Na hi paṭipakkhena vinā pahātabbassa pahānaṃ sambhavati, paṭipakkhā ca
analyzed: pahīyanti na hi paṭipakkhena vinā pahātabbassa pahānam sambhavati paṭipakkhā ca
translated: For it is not possible to abandon what is to be abandoned without its opposite. And concentration, etc., are the opposites of sensual desire, etc.

original: samādhiādayo kāmacchandādīnaṃ. Yathāha peṭake “samādhi kāmacchandassa paṭipakkho”tiādi.
analyzed: samādhi ādayaḥ kāmacchanda ādīnam yathā āha peṭake samādhi kāmacchandassa paṭipakkhaḥ tiādi
translated: As it is said in the Peṭaka: “Concentration is the opposite of sensual desire” , and so on.

original: Teneva ca “imehi tesaṃ nīvaraṇānaṃ pahāna”nti pahānaparidīpanamukhena jhānaṅgāni
analyzed: tena iva ca imehi tesam nīvaraṇānam pahānanti pahāna paridīpana mukhena jhān aṅgāni
translated: And it is precisely because of this that the jhāna factors are shown under the heading of “the abandoning of these hindrances” .

original: sarūpato dassetuṃ “tasmiññeva cā”tiādi vuttaṃ. Tattha tasmiññeva cāti yaṃ taṃ yathāupaṭṭhitaṃ🔽uggahanimittaṃ bhinditvā viya upaṭṭhitaṃ, tassa paṭicchannabhūtaṃ paṭibhāganimittaṃ,
analyzed: sarūpataḥ dassetum tasmin ñeva ca atiādi vuttam tattha tasmin ñeva ca ati yam tam yathā upaṭṭhitam  uggaha nimittam bhinditvā viya upaṭṭhitam tassa paṭicchanna bhūtam paṭibhāga nimittam
translated: In that same sign: in that same counterpart sign.🔽In the mind: in the mind associated with itself.🔽The characteristic of absorption: the characteristic of absorption is the state of absorption.🔽The characteristic of absorption is the state of absorption.🔽The characteristic of absorption is the state of absorption.

original: tasmiññeva nimitte. Cetasoti attanā sampayuttacittassa. Abhiniropanalakkhaṇoti āropanalakkhaṇo,
analyzed: tasmin ñeva nimitte cetasaḥ ti attanā sampayutta cittassa abhiniropana lakkhaṇo ti āropana lakkhaṇo
translated: The characteristic of absorption is the state of absorption.🔽The characteristic of absorption is the state of absorption.🔽The characteristic of absorption is the state of absorption.🔽The characteristic of absorption is the state of absorption.🔽The characteristic of absorption is the state of absorption.🔽The characteristic of absorption is the state of absorption.🔽The characteristic of absorption is the state of absorption.🔽The characteristic of absorption is the state of absorption.🔽The characteristic of absorption is the state of absorption.🔽The characteristic of absorption is the state of absorption.🔽The characteristic of absorption is the state of absorption.🔽The characteristic of absorption is the state of absorption.🔽The characteristic of absorption is the state of absorption.🔽The characteristic of absorption is the state of absorption.🔽The characteristic of absorption is the state of absorption.🔽The characteristic of absorption is the state of absorption.🔽The characteristic of absorption is the state of absorption.🔽The characteristic of absorption is the state of absorption.🔽The characteristic of absorption is the state of absorption.🔽The characteristic of absorption is the state of absorption.🔽The characteristic of absorption is the state of absorption.🔽The characteristic of absorption is the state of absorption.🔽The characteristic of absorption is the state of absorption.🔽The characteristic of absorption is the state of absorption.

original: appanāsabhāvoti attho. Nimittānumajjanaṃ paṭibhāganimitte anuvicaraṇaṃ. Ārammaṇe
analyzed: appanāsa bhāvaḥ ti atthaḥ nimitta anumajjanam paṭibhāga nimitte anuvicaraṇam ārammaṇe
translated: The characteristic of absorption is the state of absorption.🔽The characteristic of absorption is the state of absorption.🔽The characteristic of absorption is the state of absorption.🔽The characteristic of absorption is the state of absorption.🔽The characteristic of absorption is the state of absorption.

original: hi bhamarassa padumassūpari anuparibbhamanaṃ viya vicārassa anuvicāraṇākārena pavatti
analyzed: hi bhamarassa padumassa upari anuparibbhamanam viya vicārassa anuvicāraṇā ākārena pavatti
translated: The characteristic of absorption is the state of absorption.🔽The characteristic of absorption is the state of absorption.

original: anumajjanakiccaṃ. Viseso eva adhigantabbato visesādhigamo, paṭiladdho ca so visesādhigamo
analyzed: anumajjana kiccam visesaḥ eva adhigantabbataḥ visesa adhigamaḥ paṭiladdhaḥ ca saḥ visesa adhigamaḥ
translated: The characteristic of absorption is the state of absorption.🔽The characteristic of absorption is the state of absorption.🔽The characteristic of absorption is the state of absorption.🔽The characteristic of absorption is the state of absorption.🔽The characteristic of absorption is the state of absorption.

original: cāti paṭi…pe… gamo, tappaccayā taṃhetukā paṭiladdhavisesādhigamapaccayā pīti. Pītimanassa
analyzed: ca ati paṭipe gamo tad paccayā taṃhetukā paṭiladdha visesa adhigama paccayā pīti pīti manassa
translated: The characteristic of absorption is the

original: pītisahitacittassa. Passaddhisambhavatoti kāyacittapassaddhīnaṃ saṃsijjhanato. “Pītimanassa🔽kāyo passambhatī”ti hi vuttaṃ. Passaddhinimittaṃ passaddhihetukaṃ sukhaṃ “passaddhakāyo🔽sukhaṃ vediyatī”ti vacanato. Sukhanimittā sukhapaccayā ekaggatā. “Sukhino cittaṃ🔽samādhiyatī”ti hi vuttaṃ. Iti jhānaṅgāni pātubhavantīti evaṃ etāni vitakkādīni jhānaṅgāni
analyzed: pīti sahita cittassa passaddhi sambhavato ti kāya citta passaddhīnam saṃsijjhanataḥ pīti manassa  kāyaḥ passambhati iti hi vuttam passaddhi nimittam passaddhi hetukam sukham passaddha kāyaḥ  sukham vediyati iti vacanataḥ sukha nimittā sukha paccayā ekagga tā sukhino cittam  samādhiyati iti hi vuttam iti jhāna aṅgāni pātubhavanti iti evam etāni vitakka ādīni jhān aṅgāni
translated: and of consciousness accompanied by happiness. Because of the possibility of serenity: because of the quieting of bodily and mental disturbance. For it is said: “When the mind is uplifted with happiness the body becomes tranquil, the mind becomes tranquil” . Serenity is the cause of bliss, and bliss is the sign of serenity, according to the words: “When the body has become tranquil, he feels bliss” . Concentration is the sign of bliss, and bliss is the condition for concentration, according to the words: “When he feels bliss his mind becomes concentrated” . So the jhāna factors arise in this way.

original: tasmiṃyeva nimitte uppajjanti. Paṭhamajjhānapaṭibimbabhūtanti paṭhamajjhānassa paṭicchannabhūtaṃ.🔽Taṅkhaṇaññeva paṭibhāganimittapaṭilābhasamakālameva upacārajjhānampi nibbattati,🔽na nīvaraṇappahānamevāti adhippāyo.🔽Vinīlakādikammaṭṭhānavaṇṇanā
analyzed: tasmin yeva nimitte uppajjanti paṭhamajjhāna paṭibimba bhūtanti paṭhamajjhānassa paṭicchanna bhūtan  taṅkhaṇañca eva paṭibhāga nimitta paṭilābha sama kālam eva upacāra jhānam pi nibbattati  na nīvaraṇa ppahānam eva ti adhippāyaḥ  vinīlaka ādi kammaṭṭhāna vaṇṇanā
translated: and the mind is accompanied by happiness. Because of the possibility of serenity: because of the occurrence of bodily and mental serenity. For it is said: “When the mind is uplifted with happiness, the body becomes serene” . Serenity is the sign for bliss, which is the cause of serenity, since it is said: “When the body is serene, he feels bliss” . Bliss is the sign for unification, which is the condition for bliss, since it is said: “When he is blissful, the mind becomes concentrated” . Thus the jhāna factors arise: thus these jhāna factors of applied thought, etc., arise in that same sign. It becomes the counterpart of the first jhāna: it becomes the counterpart of the first jhāna by concealing it. The access jhāna arises too: the access jhāna arises too at the same moment as the acquisition of the counterpart sign. The meaning is that it is not only the abandoning of the hindrances.🔽The Description of the Meditation Subject Beginning with the Discoloured Corpse

original: 118. Vinīlakādīsupi kammaṭṭhānesu. Lakkhaṇaṃ vuttanti yaṃ taṃ nimittaggahaṇalakkhaṇaṃ
analyzed: vinīlaka ādīsu pi kammaṭṭhānesu lakkhaṇam vuttan ti yam tam nimitta ggahaṇa lakkhaṇam
translated: In the case of the meditation subjects beginning with the discoloured corpse, etc., the characteristic has been stated.

original: vuttaṃ. Vuttanayenevāti uddhumātake vuttanayeneva. Saha vinicchayena, adhippāyena
analyzed: vuttam vutta nayena iva āti uddhumātake vutta nayena iva saha vinicchayena adhippāyena
translated: This has been said. In the way already stated: in the way stated under the bloated. Together with the exposition, the intention,

original: cāti savinicchayādhippāyaṃ. Taṃ sabbaṃ lakkhaṇaṃ veditabbanti sambandho.
analyzed: ca ati sa vinicchaya adhippāyam tam sabbam lakkhaṇam veditabban ti sambandho
translated: That has been said. By the method stated: by the method stated in the case of the bloated. Together with the analysis and the purport: together with the analysis and the purport. All that characteristic should be understood: this is the construction.

original: Kabarakabaravaṇṇanti yebhuyyena sabalavaṇṇaṃ. Ussadavasenāti rattasetanīlavaṇṇesu ussadassa vaṇṇassa vasena.
analyzed: kabara kabara vaṇṇam ti yebhuyyena sabala vaṇṇam ussada vasena ati ratta seta nīla vaṇṇesu ussadassa vaṇṇassa vasena
translated: The colour of the festering: the colour of most of the putrid. By the prominence: by the prominence of the colour of the red, the white, and the black.

original: Sannisinnanti niccalabhāveneva sabbaso thirataṃ.🔽Corāṭaviyanti corehi pariyuṭṭhitaaraññe. Yatthāti yasmiṃ āghātane. Chinnapurisaṭṭhāneti
analyzed: sannisinnanti niccala bhāvena iva sabbaso thiratam  corāṭaviyanti corehi pariyuṭṭhita araññe yattha ati yasmin āghātane chinna purisa ṭṭhāne iti
translated: It is strewn: it is covered all over as if with a spread.🔽In a forest haunted by wild beasts: in a forest haunted by wild beasts. In a place where there is a charnel ground:

original: chinnapurisavante ṭhāne. Nānādisāyaṃ patitampīti chinnaṃ hutvā sarīrassa khaṇḍadvayaṃ
analyzed: chinna purisavante ṭhāne nānādisāyam chinnam hutvā sarīrassa khaṇḍa dvayam
translated: in a place where there is a charnel ground. In a place where there are corpses cut up into pieces:🔽in a place where there are two or three pieces of a corpse fallen separately in different directions.

original: visuṃ disāsu patitampi. Ekāvajjanenāti ekasamannāhārena. Āpāthamāgacchatīti ekajjhaṃ
analyzed: visum disāsu patitam pi ekāvajjanena ati eka samannāhārena āpātham āgacchati iti
translated: By a single adverting: by a single attention. Comes into focus: comes into focus all at once.

original: āpāthaṃ āgacchati. Vissāsaṃ āpajjatīti ajegucchitaṃ upagaccheyya seyyathāpi chavaḍāhako.
analyzed: āpātham āgacchati vissāsam āpajjati iti ajegucchitam upagaccheyya sā iyyathā api chava ḍāhakaḥ
translated: He comes to trust it: he comes to have no disgust for it, as a scavenger would.

original: Sahatthā aparāmasane jigucchā saṇṭhātiyevāti āha “kattarayaṭṭhiyā vā daṇḍakena vā…pe…🔽upanāmetabba”nti. Vicchiddakabhāvapaññāyanatthaṃ ekaṅgulantarakaraṇaṃ. Upanāmetabbanti upanetabbaṃ.
analyzed: sahatthā a parāmasane jigucchā saṇṭhātiyā iva iti āha kattarayaṭṭhiyā vā daṇḍakena vāpe  upanāmetabbanti vicchiddaka bhāva paññāyana ttham eka aṅgula antara karaṇam upanāmetabbanti upanetabbam
translated: “Disgust arises in him when he touches it with his hand” means that he should not touch it with his hand. “He should have it brought to him with a stick or a piece of string” means that he should have it brought to him with a stick or a piece of string. “He should make a hole in it the size of a finger joint” means that he should make a hole in it the size of a finger joint in order to show the state of being perforated. “He should have it brought to him” means that he should have it brought to him.

original: Khāyitasadisamevāti khāyitāsubhasadisameva. Aṅgulaṅgulantaranti vividhaṃ khittaṃ sarīrāvayavaṃ aṅgulantaraṃ aṅgulantaraṃ. Katvā vāti kattarayaṭṭhiyā vā daṇḍakena vā sayaṃ katvā vā.
analyzed: khāyita sadisam eva ati khāyita asubha sadisam eva aṅgula aṅgula antaram iti vividham khittam sarīra avayavam aṅgula antaram aṅgula antaram katvā vā ati vā daṇḍakena vā sayam katvā vā
translated: “Like a piece of chewed food” means like a piece of chewed food that is good. “He should make a hole in it the size of a finger joint” means that he should make a hole in it the size of a finger joint. “He should have it brought to him with a stick or a piece of string” means that he should have it brought to him with a stick or a piece of string.

original: Laddhappahārānanti laddhāvudhappahārānaṃ mukhatoti sambandho. Mukhatoti pahārādimukhato. Paggharamānakāleti lohitaṃ paggharamānakāle. Lohitakaṃ labbhatīti yojanā.
analyzed: laddha pahārānam ti mukhato ti sambandhaḥ mukhato ti pahāra ādi mukhato paggharamāna kāla iti lohitam paggharamāna kāle lohitakam labbhati iti yojanā
translated: “The mouth of those who have received blows” means that the mouth of those who have received blows is connected. “The mouth” means the mouth of those who have received blows. “When blood is flowing” means when blood is flowing. “He will obtain blood” is the construction.

original: Tanti puḷavakaṃ. Tesūti soṇādisarīresu. Aṭṭhikanti aṭṭhikaasubhaṃ nānappakārato vuttanti sambandho. Purimanayenevāti pubbe uddhumātake vuttanayeneva.
analyzed: tat ti puḷavakam tesu iti soṇa ādi sarīresu aṭṭhikanti aṭṭhika asubham nānā pakārataḥ vuttanti sambandhaḥ purima nayena iva āti pubbe uddhu mātake vutta nayena iva
translated: “It” means a piece of meat. “In those” means in the bodies of the dead. “A skeleton” means that a skeleton is spoken of in various ways. “In the same way as before” means in the same way as was said previously with regard to the bloated.

original: 119. Tanti aṭṭhikaṃ. Na upaṭṭhātīti sabhāvato na upaṭṭhāti, paṭikkūlavasena na upaṭṭhātīti🔽attho. Tenāha “odātakasiṇasambhedo hotī”ti. Aṭṭhike paṭhamavayādisaṃlakkhaṇaṃ na🔽sakkāti “liṅganti idha hatthādīnaṃ nāma”nti vuttaṃ. Aṭṭhikasaṅkhalikā pana “ayaṃ🔽daharassa, ayaṃ yobbane ṭhitassa, ayaṃ avayavehi vuddhipattissā”ti evaṃ vayavasena
analyzed: tanti aṭṭhikam na upaṭṭhāti iti sabhāvataḥ na upaṭṭhāti paṭikkūla vasena na upaṭṭhāti iti  atthaḥ tena āha odāta kasiṇa sambhedaḥ hoti iti aṭṭhike paṭhama vayā ādi saṃlakkhaṇam na  sakkā iti liṅganti idha hattha ādīnam nāman ti vuttam aṭṭhika saṅkhalikā pana ayaṃ  daharassa ayam yobbane ṭhitassa ayam avayavehi vuddhi pattissa ati evam vaya vasena
translated: “Bone” is a skeleton. “Does not appear” means does not appear as it actually is; the meaning is that it does not appear as repulsive. Hence it is said, “it is mixed up with the white kasiṇa.” “The distinguishing of the stages, etc., of the skeleton cannot be done” because the skeleton is not a living being. “The term ‘sign’ here stands for the name of the hand, etc.” The skeleton, however, can be distinguished by age thus: “This is the skeleton of a small child, this is the skeleton of a youth, this is the skeleton of an old man” .

original: vavatthapetuṃ sakkuṇeyyāva, abyāpitāya pana na gahitanti veditabbaṃ. Yadipi aṭṭhikasaṅkhalikāyaṃ🔽sandhito vavatthāpanaṃ labbhati, aṭṭhike pana na labbhatīti tassa aniyatabhāvadīpanatthaṃ🔽kamavilaṅghanaṃ katvā “tassa tassa aṭṭhino ninnaṭṭhānathalaṭṭhānavasenā”tiādi vuttaṃ.
analyzed: vavatthapetum a byāpitāya pana na gahitan ti veditabbam yadi pi aṭṭhika saṅkhalikāyam 🔽sandhitaḥ vavatthāpanam labbhati aṭṭhike pana na labbhati iti tassa aniyata bhāva dīpana attham 🔽kama vilaṅghanam katvā tassa tassa aṭṭhinaḥ ninna ṭṭhāna thala ṭṭhāna vasena atiādi vuttaṃ
translated: “Bone” is a skeleton. “Does not appear” means does not appear as it actually is; the meaning is that it does not appear as repulsive. Hence it is said, “It is a mere variant of the white kasiṇa.” “The distinguishing of the first part, etc., cannot be done to the skeleton” . “The term ‘sign’ here is a name for the hand, etc.” . “But the skeleton-as-a-series can be defined by age thus: ‘This is that of a young child, this is that of a youth, this is that of an old man’” . “But it should be understood that it cannot be apprehended if it is not spread out.” “Although it is possible to define the skeleton-as-a-series by the joints, it is not possible to define the skeleton in that way. So in order to illustrate its indefinite state” . “Having omitted the ‘and’ , ‘according as the bone is depressed or prominent’” is said.

original: Tattha ninnaṭṭhānaṃ nāma aṭṭhino vinatappadeso. Thalaṭṭhānaṃ unnatappadeso. Ghaṭitaghaṭitaṭṭhānavasenāti
analyzed: tattha ninna ṭṭhānam nāma aṭṭhinaḥ vinata ppadesaḥ thala ṭṭhānam unnata ppadesaḥ ghaṭita ghaṭita ṭhāna vasena ati
translated: Herein, a low place is a depressed place. A high place is an elevated place. As a place where bones are jumbled up:

original: anupagatanhārubandhānaṃ, itaresañca aññamaññaṃ saṃkiliṭṭhasaṃkiliṭṭhaṭṭhānavasena.
analyzed: itaresam ca aññam aññam saṃkiliṭṭha saṃkiliṭṭha ṭṭhāna vasena
translated: as a place where the bones of those whose craving has not yet been cut are mixed up with those of others whose craving has been cut.

original: Antaravasenāti aññamaññassa antaravasena, susiravasena ca. Sabbatthevāti sakalāya
analyzed: antara vasena ati aññamaññassa antara vasena susira vasena ca sabbattha iva ati sakalāya
translated: As between: as between one another, as in a reed bed. In every way:

original: aṭṭhisaṅkhalikāya, sabbasmiṃ vā aṭṭhike.
analyzed: aṭṭhi saṅkhalikāya sabbasmim vā aṭṭhike
translated: in the whole skeleton, or in all the bones.

original: 120. Etthāti etasmiṃ aṭṭhikāsubhe. Yujjamānavasena sallakkhetabbanti yaṃ nimittaggahaṇaṃ🔽yattha yujjati, taṃ tattha uggaṇhanatthaṃ nimittaggahaṇavasena upalakkhetabbaṃ. Sakalāyāti
analyzed: ettha iti etasmin aṭṭhikā subhe yujjamāna vasena sallakkhetabbam ti yam nimitta ggahaṇam  yattha yujjati tam tattha uggaṇhana attham nimitta ggahaṇa vasena upalakkhetabbam sakalāya ati
translated: Herein: in this skeleton beauty. Should be defined: the sign should be defined by apprehending it as a sign in order to learn it by the method appropriate to the place where it is found.

original: anavasesabhāgāya paripuṇṇāvayavāya. Sampajjati nimittupaṭṭhānavasena. Tesūti aṭṭhikasaṅkhalikaṭṭhikesu.
analyzed: anavasesa bhāgāya paripuṇṇa avayavāya sampajjati nimitta upaṭṭhāna vasena tesu iti aṭṭhika saṅkhalikaṭṭhikesu
translated: As a whole: as a whole without remainder, as complete in its component parts. It comes to fulfilment: by the appearance of the sign. In them: in the skeleton, the bones, the shin-bone, the thigh-bone, the hip-bone, the rib, the spine, the breast-bone, the arm-bone, the skull.

original: Vuttaṃ aṭṭhakathāyaṃ. Tanti “ekasadisamevā”ti vacanaṃ. Ekasmiṃ aṭṭhike yuttanti idaṃ
analyzed: vuttam aṭṭhakathā ayam tat ti eka sadisam eva ati vacanam ekasmin aṭṭhike yuttam ti idam
translated: This is said in the commentary.

original: yathā vinīlakādīsu ubhinnaṃ nimittānaṃ yathārahaṃ vaṇṇavisesato, paripuṇṇāparipuṇṇato,
analyzed: yathā vinīlaka ādīsu ubhinnam nimittānam yathāraham vaṇṇa visesataḥ paripuṇṇa aparipuṇṇataḥ
translated: As in the case of the bloated and so on, the difference between the two is that the difference between the signs is one of colour, of completeness or incompleteness,

original: savivarāvivarato, calācalato ca viseso labbhati, na evametassāti katvā vuttaṃ, na
analyzed: sa vivara avivarataḥ cala acalataḥ ca visesaḥ labbhati na evam etassa ati katvā vuttam na
translated: of being with or without gaps, and of being shaky or unshaky, as appropriate. But this is not so in the case of the skeleton.

original: pana sabbena sabbaṃ visesābhāvato. Tenevāha “ekaṭṭhikepi cā”tiādi. Tattha bībhacchenāti
analyzed: pana sabbena sabbam visesa abhāvataḥ tena iva āha ekaṭṭhike pi ca atiādi tattha bībhacchena ati
translated: However, it is not because there is no difference at all. That is why he said, “In the case of the skeleton too” and so on.

original: suvibhūtaaṭṭhirūpattā aṭṭhibhāveneva virūpena. Bhayānakenāti teneva pākatikasattānaṃ🔽bhayāvahena. Pītisomanassajanakenāti saṇhamaṭṭhabhāvena upaṭṭhānato, bhāvanāya ca
analyzed: su vibhūta aṭṭhi rūpattā aṭṭhi bhāvena iva virūpena bhayānakena ati tena iva pākatika sattānam  bhaya āvahena pīti somanassa janakena ati saṇha maṭṭha bhāvena upaṭṭhānataḥ bhāvanāya ca
translated: Herein, it is repulsive because of its bones: because of its being a mere mass of bones. It is dreadful because it is dreadful🔽to ordinary living beings by reason of its very repulsiveness. It causes a sense of urgency because it causes the arising of joy and happiness by appearing in a peaceful aspect and because it is the cause of the arising of the happiness and joy of development.

original: savisesattā pītiyā, somanassassa ca uppādakena. Tenevāha “upacārāvahattā”ti.🔽Imasmiṃ okāseti uggahapaṭibhāganimittānaṃ vuttaṭṭhāne. Dvāraṃ datvā vāti “paṭikkūlabhāveyeva
analyzed: sa visesa ttā pītiyā somanassassa ca uppādakena tena iva āha upacāra āvaha ttā iti  imasmin okāse iti uggaha paṭibhāga nimittānam vutta ṭṭhāne dvāram da tvā vāti
translated: That is why he said, “because it is the cause of the manifestation of happiness and joy.”🔽In this place: in the place stated for the learning sign and the counterpart sign.

original: diṭṭhe nimittaṃ nāma hotī”ti ettake eva aṭṭhatvā anantarameva “duvidhaṃ idha nimitta”ntiādinā
analyzed: diṭṭhe nimittam nāma hoti iti ettake eva anantaram eva duvidham nimitta nti ādinā
translated: Having given a sign: having given a sign to the extent of “The sign is only what is seen in the state of foulness,” he did not stop there, but he went on to say, “The sign here is twofold” and so on.

original: uggahapaṭibhāganimittāni vibhajitvā vacanena yathāvuttassa nimittavibhāgassa dvāraṃ
analyzed: uggaha paṭibhāga nimittāni vibhajitvā vacanena yathā vuttassa nimitta vibhāgassa dvāram
translated: Having analyzed the learning sign and the counterpart sign, he gives the door to the learning sign as stated,

original: datvāva vuttaṃ. Nibbikappanti “subha”nti vikappena nibbikappaṃ, asubhantvevāti attho.
analyzed: datvā ava vuttam nibbikappanti subhanti vikappena nibbikappam a subhantu eva ati attho
translated: saying “without defining it.” “Without defining it” means without defining it as “beautiful.” The meaning is that it is “impure.”

original: Vicāretvāti “ekasmiṃ aṭṭhike yutta”ntiādinā vicāretvā.🔽Mahātissattherassāti cetiyapabbatavāsīmahātissattherassa. Nidassanānīti dantaṭṭhikamattadassanena
analyzed: vicāretvā iti ekasmin aṭṭhike yut tanti ādinā vicāretvā  mahā tissa therassa ati cetiya pabbata vāsī mahā tissa therassa nidassanāni iti dantaṭṭhika matta dassanena
translated: “Having investigated”: having investigated it thus, “This bone is connected to that one.”

original: sakalassāpi tassā itthiyā sarīrassa aṭṭhisaṅghātabhāvena upaṭṭhānādīni ettha aṭṭhikakammaṭṭhāne
analyzed: sakalassa api tassā itthiyā sarīrassa aṭṭhi saṅghāta bhāvena upaṭṭhāna ādīni ettha aṭṭhika kammaṭṭhāne
translated: “The Elder Maha Tissa”: the Elder Maha Tissa who lived at Cetiyapabbata. “The illustrations”: the illustrations of the difference between the learning sign and the counterpart sign in the case of the skeleton meditation subject are the appearances of the whole body as a skeleton, etc.,

original: uggahapaṭibhāganimittānaṃ visesavibhāvanāni udāharaṇāni.
analyzed: uggaha paṭibhāga nimittānam visesa vibhāvanāni udāharaṇāni
translated: beginning with the appearance of the bones joined together in pairs.

original: Subhaguṇoti savāsanānaṃ kilesānaṃ pahīnattā suparisuddhaguṇo. Dasasatalocanenāti
analyzed: subha guṇaḥ ti sa vāsanānam kilesānam pahīna ttā su parisuddha guṇaḥ dasa sata locanena ati
translated: “The quality of beauty”: the quality of complete purity, because the defilements together with their underlying tendencies have been abandoned. “By the one with eyes of a thousand petals”:🔽by Sakka Ruler of Gods, who has a thousand petals to his eyes,

original: sahassakkhena devānamindena. So hi ekāsaneneva sahassaatthānaṃ vicāraṇasamatthena
analyzed: sahassakkhena devānamindena saḥ hi eka āsanena iva sahassa atthānam vicāraṇa samatthena
translated: for he is able to investigate a thousand places while sitting in one place.

original: paññācakkhunā samannāgatattā “sahassakkho”ti vuccati. Thutakittīti “yo dhīro sabbadhi
analyzed: paññācakkhunā samannāgata ttā sahassakkho ti vuccati thuta kittī iti yaḥ dhīro sabbadhi
translated: He is called “thousand-eyed” because he is endowed with the eye of wisdom. He is “praised and lauded” because he is praised and lauded with such verses as:

original: danto”tiādinā abhitthutakittisaddo.
analyzed: danta iti ādinā
translated: “The wise one, everywhere tamed,

original: Pakiṇṇakakathāvaṇṇanā🔽121. Ujupaṭipakkhena pahīnabhāvaṃ sandhāyāha “suvikkhambhitarāgattā”ti. Asubhappabhedoti
analyzed: pakiṇṇaka kathā vaṇṇanā  uju paṭipakkhena pahīna bhāvam sandhāya āha su vikkhambhita rāga ttā iti asubha ppabhedaḥ ti
translated: The commentary on the miscellaneous section.🔽The phrase “because of the complete destruction of lust” refers to the fact that lust has been abandoned by the path of direct knowledge.🔽The phrase “the classification of foulness” refers to the classification of foulness as a bloated corpse, etc.

original: uddhumātakādiasubhavibhāgo. Sarīrasabhāvappattivasenāti sarīrassa attano sabhāvūpagamanavasena.🔽Sarīrañhi vinassamānaṃ aññarūpena ṭhitassa rakkhasassa viya sabhāvappattivaseneva
analyzed: uddhumātaka ādi asubha vibhāgaḥ sarīra sabhāva ppatti vasena ati sarīrassa attanaḥ sabhāva upagamana vasena  sarīram hi vinassamānam añña rūpena ṭhitassa rakkhasassa viya sabhāva ppatti vasena iva
translated: The phrase “by the attainment of the natural state of the body” means by the attainment of the body’s natural state.🔽For the body, when it is decaying, is destroyed by the attainment of its natural state, just as a demon is destroyed by the attainment of its natural state when it seizes hold of someone else’s body.

original: vinassati. Rāgacaritabhedavasenāti rāgacaritavibhāgavasena. Yadi sarīrasabhāvappattivasena
analyzed: vinassati rāga carita bheda vasena ati rāga carita vibhāga vasena yadi sarīra sabhāva ppatti vasena
translated: The phrase “by the classification of the types of lust” refers to the classification of the types of lust.

original: ayamasubhappabhedo vutto, mahāsatipaṭṭhānādīsu kathaṃ navappabhedoti? So sarasato
analyzed: ayam asubha ppabhedaḥ vuttaḥ mahāsati paṭṭhāna ādīsu katham nava ppabhedaḥ iti so sarasataḥ
translated: If the classification of foulness is stated by the attainment of the natural state of the body, how is it a ninefold classification in the Mahāsatipaṭṭhāna Sutta?🔽That classification is stated by the attainment of the natural state of the body in its entirety. But this classification is stated by the attainment of the natural state of the body even in part.

original: eva sabhāvappattivasena vutto, ayaṃ pana parūpakkamenāpi. Tattha ca idhāgatesu dasasu
analyzed: eva sabhāva ppatti vasena vuttaḥ ayam pana parūpakkamena api tattha ca idhāgatesu dasasu
translated: And in the ten kinds of foulness that are included here,

original: asubhesu ekaccāneva gahitāni, aṭṭhikañca pañcavidhā vibhattaṃ. Tāni ca vipassanāvasena,
analyzed: asubhesu gahitāni aṭṭhikañca pañcavidhā vibhattam tāni ca vipassanā vasena
translated: And these are the kinds of foulness that are suitable for the development of insight,

original: imāni samathavasenāti pākaṭoyaṃ bhedoti.
analyzed: imāni
translated: while these are the kinds that are suitable for serenity.

original: Imesaṃ pana dassanampi asubhabhāvasāmaññena satipi avisesato rāgacaritānaṃ sappāyabhāve
analyzed: imesam pana dassanam pi asubha bhāva sāmaññena sati pi avisesataḥ rāga caritānam sappāya bhāve
translated: And although there is no distinction in their suitability for the tranquilizing of lust because of the similarity of foulness in all of them,🔽still, the distinction in the kinds of foulness that is stated thus, “And according to the distinction of the kinds of lust” ,

original: yaṃ vuttaṃ “rāgacaritabhedavasena cā”ti, taṃ vibhajitvā dassetuṃ “visesato”tiādi
analyzed: yam vuttam rāga carita bheda vasena ca ati tam vibhajitvā dassetum visesataḥ tiādi
translated: is shown by the words “In particular” , etc.

original: vuttaṃ. Sūnabhāvena susaṇṭhitampi sarīraṃ dussaṇṭhitameva hotīti uddhumātakasarīre🔽saṇṭhānavipattiṃ dīpetīti āha “sarīrasaṇṭhānavipattippakāsanato”ti. Saṇṭhānasampattiyaṃ🔽ratto saṇṭhānarāgī, tassa sappāyaṃ saṇṭhānarāgassa vikkhambhanupāyabhāvato. Kāyo
analyzed: vuttam sūna bhāvena su saṇṭhitam pi sarīram dussaṇṭhitam eva hoti iti uddhumātaka sarīre  saṇṭhāna vipattim dīpeti iti āha sarīra saṇṭhāna vipatti pakāsanataḥ ti  rattaḥ saṇṭhāna rāgī tassa sappāyam saṇṭhāna rāgassa vikkhambhana upāya bhāvataḥ kāyo
translated: The body, though well-proportioned in its parts, is ill-proportioned because of its state of being a void, and so the bloated body is shown as a failure in bodily proportion.🔽The lustful man is one who lusts after shape.🔽The body is the body’s cavity, and what is attached to it and clings to it is inside it.

original: eva kāyavaṇo, tattha paṭibaddhassa nissitassa. Susirabhāvappakāsanatoti susirassa
analyzed: eva tattha paṭibaddhassa nissitassa susira bhāva ppakāsanato ti susirassa
translated: The bloated body is shown as a failure in bodily shape because it is the state of a void.

original: vivarassa atthibhāvappakāsanato. Sarīre ghanabhāvarāginoti sarīre aṅgapaccaṅgānaṃ
