analyzed: vivarassa atthi bhāva ppakāsanato sarīre ghana bhāva rāgino ti sarīre aṅga paccaṅgānaṃ
translated: because it shows the existence of the cavities. “One who is lustful for compactness in the body” is one who is lustful because of the compactness of the limbs and minor parts in the body.

original: thirabhāvaṃ paṭicca uppajjanakarāgavato. Vikkhepappakāsanatoti soṇasiṅgālādīhi ito🔽cito ca vikkhepassa pakāsanato aṅgapaccaṅgalīlārāgino sappāyaṃ. Īdisānaṃ kira anavaṭṭhitarūpānaṃ🔽avayavānaṃ ko līḷāvilāsoti virāgasambhavato. Saṅghātabhedavikārappakāsanatoti saṅghātassa
analyzed: thira bhāvam paṭicca uppajjanaka rāgavataḥ vikkhepa ppakāsanato ti soṇa siṅgāla ādīhi itas  citaḥ ca vikkhepassa pakāsanataḥ aṅga paccaṅga līlā rāgino sappāyam īdisānam kira anavaṭṭhita rūpānam  avayavānam kaḥ līḷā vilāsaḥ ti virāga sambhavato saṅghāta bheda vikāra ppakāsanato ti saṅghātassa
translated: “Because it shows the scattering” : because it shows the scattering here and there by dogs, jackals, etc.,🔽“One who is lustful for the play of the limbs” is one who is lustful for the play of the limbs and minor parts. It is suitable for him because of the possibility of the arising of dispassion thus: “What play and enjoyment can there be in these unmoving parts of the body?”

original: aṅgapaccaṅgānaṃ saṃhatabhāvassa susambandhatāya bhedo eva vikāro saṅghātabhedavikāro,
analyzed: aṅga paccaṅgānam saṃhata bhāvassa su sambandha tāya bhedaḥ eva vikāro saṅghāta bheda vikāro
translated: “Because it shows the dissolution and change of the aggregate” : the dissolution of the aggregate is just the change of the aggregate. The aggregate is the collection of the limbs and minor parts. Because of their close connection, their dissolution is just their change.

original: tassa pakāsanato. Lohitaṃ makkhitaṃ hutvā paṭikkūlabhāvo lohitamakkhitapaṭikkūlabhāvo,
analyzed: tassa pakāsanataḥ lohitam makkhitam hutvā paṭikkūla bhāvaḥ lohita makkhita paṭikkūla bhāvaḥ
translated: “Because it shows the repulsiveness of the blood and the pus” : the repulsiveness of the blood and the pus is the repulsiveness that arises when the blood and the pus are mixed.

original: tassa pakāsanato. Mamattarāginoti “mama aya”nti uppajjanakarāgavato. Dantasampattirāginoti🔽dantasampattiyaṃ rajjanasīlassa.
analyzed: tassa pakāsanataḥ mamatta rāginaḥ ti mama ayanti uppajjanaka rāgavataḥ danta sampatti rāginaḥ ti 🔽danta sampattiyam rajjana sīlassa
translated: “One who is lustful for the fullness” is one who is lustful because of the arising of the thought “This is mine.” “One who is lustful for the perfection of the teeth” is one who is in the habit of lusting after the perfection of the teeth.

original: Kasmā panettha uddhumātakādike paṭhamajjhānameva uppajjati, na dutiyādīnīti anuyogaṃ🔽manasi katvā āha “yasmā panā”tiādi. Aparisaṇṭhitajalāyāti sotavasena pavattiyā samantato
analyzed: kasmā pana ittha uddhumātaka ādike paṭhama jhānam eva uppajjati na dutiya ādīni iti anuyogam  manasi katvā āha sota vasena pavattiyā samantataḥ
translated: Why does the first jhāna arise in the bloated, etc., and not the second, etc.?

original: aṭṭhitajalāya asannisinnasalilāya. Arittabalenāti pājanadaṇḍabalena. Dubbalattā ārammaṇassāti
analyzed: a ṭṭhita jalāya a sannisinna salilāya aritta balena ati pājana daṇḍa balena dubbala ttā ārammaṇassa ati
translated: The bloated, etc., are not a condition for the second jhāna, etc., because they are weak in the opposite qualities.

original: paṭikkūlabhāvena attani cittaṃ ṭhapetuṃ asamatthabhāvo ārammaṇassa dubbalatā. Paṭikkūle🔽hi ārammaṇe sarasato cittaṃ pavattituṃ na sakkoti, abhiniropanalakkhaṇena pana vitakkena🔽abhiniropiyamānameva cittaṃ ekaggataṃ labhati. Na vinā vitakkenāti vitakkarahitāni
analyzed: paṭikkūla bhāvena attani cittam ṭhapetum asamattha bhāvaḥ ārammaṇassa dubbala tā paṭikkūle  hi ārammaṇe sarasataḥ cittam pavattitum na sakkoti abhiniropana lakkhaṇena pana vitakkena  abhiniropiyamānam eva cittam ekagga tam labhati na vinā vitakkena ati vitakka rahitāni
translated: The bloated, etc., are weak in the opposite qualities, that is to say, in applied thought and sustained thought, happiness and bliss, and they are weak in the object too.🔽For the mind cannot be steadied on an object that is repulsive.

original: dutiyādijjhānāni tattha patiṭṭhaṃ na labhanti. Tenāha “vitakkabalenevā”tiādi.
analyzed: dutiya ādi jhānāni tattha patiṭṭham na labhanti tena āha vitakka balena iva atiādi
translated: But it is only when the object is being pressed by applied thought that the mind becomes concentrated in the second jhāna, etc.,🔽and so on.

original: Yadi paṭikkūlabhāvato uddhumātādiārammaṇe dutiyādijjhānāni na pavattanti, evaṃ sante
analyzed: yadi paṭikkūla bhāvataḥ uddhumātā ādi ārammaṇe dutiya ādi jhānāni na pavattanti evam sante
translated: If the second jhāna, etc., do not arise in the bloated, etc., because of their repulsiveness,

original: paṭhamajjhānenāpi tattha na uppajjitabbaṃ. Na hi tattha pītisomanassānaṃ sambhavo🔽yuttoti codanaṃ sandhāyāha “paṭikkūlepi ca etasmi”ntiādi. Tattha ānisaṃsadassāvitānīvaraṇasantāparogavūpasamānaṃ
analyzed: paṭhama jhānena api tattha na uppajjitabbam na hi tattha pīti somanassānam sambhavaḥ  yuttā iti codanam sandhāya āha paṭikkūle pi ca etasmin tiādi tattha
translated: It should not arise there even through the first jhāna. For it is not proper that happiness and joy should arise there.

original: yathākkamaṃ pupphacchaḍḍaka, vamanavirecanaupamā yojetabbā.🔽122. Yathāvuttakāraṇena dasadhā vavatthitampi sabhāvato ekavidhamevāti dassetuṃ “dasavidhampi
analyzed: yathākkamam pupphacchaḍḍaka vamana virecana opamā yojetabbā  yathā vutta kāraṇena dasadhā vavatthitam pi sabhāvataḥ ekavidham evā ati dassetum dasavidham pi
translated: With reference to this objection he says, “And in this repulsive object too,” etc. Herein, the similes of the flower garland, the vomit, and the medicine should be construed respectively with the words “the quieting of the fever of the hindrances” and “the cure of the disease of defilement” in the way in which they are given in the Commentaries.

original: ceta”ntiādiṃ vatvā svāyaṃ sabhāvo yathā aviññāṇakesu, evaṃ saviññāṇakesupi labbhateva.
analyzed: cetanti ādim vatvā svāyam sabhāvaḥ yathā aviññāṇakesu evam saviññāṇakesu pi labbhateva
translated: Although it is differentiated into ten kinds for the reasons stated, it is in reality of one kind only. In order to show this he says, “Although it is of ten kinds,” etc. Now, this one kind of repulsiveness is found in the case of the living body just as it is in the case of the dead body.

original: Tasmā tatthāpi yonisomanasikāravato bhāvanā ijjhatevāti dassento “tadetaṃ iminā lakkhaṇenā”tiādimāha.
analyzed: tasmā tattha api yoniso manasikāravataḥ bhāvanā ijjha tā iva iti dassentaḥ tat etam iminā lakkhaṇena ati ādim āha
translated: Therefore, even there, when one directs attention properly, development succeeds. In order to show this he says, “This repulsiveness, characterized thus,” etc.

original: Etthāti etasmiṃ jīvamānakasarīre. Alaṅkārenāti paṭijagganapubbakena alaṅkaraṇena.
analyzed: ettha ati etasmim jīvamānaka sarīre alaṅkārena ati paṭijaggana pubbakena alaṅkaraṇena
translated: “There” means in that living body. “Adornment” is the beautifying by means of cosmetics, etc., preceded by acceptance.

original: Na paññāyati pacurajanassāti adhippāyo. Atirekatisataaṭṭhikasamussayaṃ dantaṭṭhikehi
analyzed: na paññāyati pacurajanassa ati adhippāyaḥ atireka tisata aṭṭhika samussayam dantaṭṭhikehi
translated: The meaning is that it is not evident to ordinary people.🔽The skeleton of more than three hundred bones, with the teeth-bones,

original: saddhiṃ, tehi pana vinā “timattāni aṭṭhisatānī”ti kāyagatāsatiyaṃ vakkhati. Chiddāvachiddanti🔽khuddānukhuddachiddavantaṃ. Medakathālikā medabharitabhājanaṃ. Niccuggharitapaggharitanti🔽niccakālaṃ upari, heṭṭhā ca vissavantaṃ. Vemattanti nānattaṃ. Nānāvatthehīti nānāvaṇṇehi🔽vatthehi. Hiriyā lajjāya kopanato vināsanato hirikopinaṃ, uccārapassāvamaggaṃ. Yāthāvasarasanti🔽yathābhūtaṃ sabhāvaṃ. Yāthāvato rasīyati ñāyatīti hi raso, sabhāvo. Ratinti abhiratiṃ
analyzed: saddhim tehi pana vinā ti mattāni aṭṭhi satāni iti kāyagata asatiyam vakkhati chidda avachiddam ti  khudda anukhudda chiddavantam meda kathālikāḥ meda bharita bhājanam  niccakālam upari heṭṭhā ca vissavantam vemattanti nānattam nānā vatthehi iti nānā vaṇṇehi  vatthehi hiriyā lajjāya kopanataḥ vināsanataḥ hiri kopinam uccāra passa avamaggam yāthāvasa rasanti  yathābhūtam sabhāvam yāthāvataḥ rasīyati ñāyati iti hi rasaḥ sabhāvaḥ abhiratim
translated: The intention is that it is not evident to ordinary people. In the section on mindfulness of the body he says, “There are three hundred and twenty bones,” including the teeth-bones,

original: abhiruciṃ. Attasinehasaṅkhātena rāgena rattā attasineharāgarattā. Vihaññamānenāti🔽icchitālābhena vighātaṃ āpajjantena.
analyzed: abhirucim atta sineha saṅkhātena rāgena rattā atta sineha rāga rattā vihaññamānena ati 🔽icchita alābhena vighātam āpajjantena
translated: but excluding the teeth-bones, “There are three hundred bones” . “With holes and without holes” : with small and large holes. “With the oil-tube” : with the oil-tube filled with fat. “Always trickling and dripping” : always oozing above and below. “With various kinds of ordure” : with various kinds of impurities. “With various kinds of refuse” : with various kinds of refuse. “With the covering of skin” : with the covering of the skin. “With the covering of flesh” : with the covering of the flesh. “With the covering of the net of sinews” : with the covering of the net of sinews. “With the covering of strips of meat” : with the covering of strips of meat. “With the covering of the outer film of the body” : with the covering of the outer film of the body. “With the covering of the inner film of the body” : with the covering of the inner film of the body. “With the covering of the outer skin” : with the covering of the outer skin. “With the covering of the inner skin” : with the covering of the inner skin. “With the covering of flesh” : with the covering of flesh. “With the covering of the net of sinews” : with the covering of the net of sinews. “With the covering of strips of meat” : with the covering of strips of meat. “With the covering of the outer film of the body” : with the covering of the outer film of the body. “With the covering of the inner film of the body” : with the covering of the inner film of the body. “With the covering of the outer skin” : with the covering of the outer skin. “With the covering of the inner skin” : with the covering of the inner skin. “With the covering of flesh” : with the covering of flesh. “With the covering of the net of sinews” : with the covering of the net of sinews. “With the covering of strips of meat” : with the covering of strips of meat. “With the covering of the outer film of the body” : with the covering of the outer film of the body. “With the covering of the inner film of the body” :

original: Kiṃsukanti pālibhaddakaṃ, palāsoti keci, simbalīti apare. Atilolupoti ativiya lolasabhāvo.
analyzed: kiṃsukanti pālibhaddakam palāsaḥ iti keci simbalī iti apare atilolupaḥ ti
translated: “Kinsuka” is a kind of tree, “palāsa” according to some, and “siṃbali” according to others. “Very greedy” : of a very greedy nature.

original: Adunti etaṃ. Nanti kesādisarīrakoṭṭhāsaṃ. Mucchitāti mohitā, mucchāpāpikāya vā taṇhāya🔽vasena mucchaṃ pattā. Sabhāvanti paṭikkūlabhāvaṃ.🔽Ukkarūpamoti uccārapassāvaṭṭhānasamo, vaccakūpasamo vā. Cakkhubhūtehīti cakkhuṃ pattehi
analyzed: etam kesa ādi sarīra koṭṭhāsam mucchitā ati mohitā mucchā pāpikāya vā taṇhāya  vasena muccham pattā paṭikkūla bhāvam  ukkara upamaḥ ti uccāra passa avaṭṭhāna samaḥ vaccakūpa samaḥ vā cakkhu bhūtehi iti cakkhum pattehi
translated: “This” : this body. “That” : the parts of the body beginning with head hairs. “Deluded” : infatuated, or fallen into the delusion of craving.🔽“Nature” : repulsiveness.

original: paṭiladdhapaññācakkhukehi, lokassa vā cakkhubhūtehi. Allacammapaṭicchannoti allacammapariyonaddho.
analyzed: paṭiladdha paññā cakkhukehi lokassa vā cakkhu bhūtehi alla camma paṭicchannaḥ ti alla camma pariyonaddho
translated: “Like a cesspool” : like a place for excrement and urine, or like a privy. “With eyes” : with the eye of wisdom attained by means of the eye of flesh, or with those who are the eyes of the world. “Covered with moist skin” : covered with moist skin.

original: Dabbajātikenāti uttarimanussadhamme paṭiladdhuṃ bhabbarūpena. Yattha yattha sarīre,
analyzed: dabba jātikena ati uttari manussa dhamme paṭiladdhum bhabba rūpena yattha yattha sarīre
translated: “Of the kind to be eaten by worms” : of the kind capable of attaining the superhuman states. “In whatever part of the body”

original: sarīrassa vā yattha yattha koṭṭhāse. Nimittaṃ gahetvāti asubhākārassa suṭṭhu sallakkhaṇavasena
analyzed: sarīrassa vā yattha yattha koṭṭhāse nimittam gahetvā ati asubha ākārassa suṭṭhu sat lakkhaṇa vasena
translated: or “in whatever part of the body” . “Having taken a sign” : having taken a sign by way of proper observation of the aspect of foulness,

original: yathā uggahanimittaṃ uppajjati, evaṃ uggaṇhanavasena nimittaṃ gahetvā, uggahanimittaṃ
analyzed: yathā uggaha nimittam uppajjati evam uggaṇhana vasena nimittam gahetvā uggaha nimittam
translated: in the way that the learning sign arises, or by way of learning the learning sign.

original: uppādetvāti attho. Kammaṭṭhānaṃ appanaṃ pāpetabbanti yathāladdhe uggahanimitte kammaṃ🔽karontena paṭibhāganimittaṃ uppādetvā upacārajjhāne ṭhitena tameva bhāvanaṃ ussukkāpentena🔽asubhakammaṭṭhānaṃ appanaṃ pāpetabbaṃ. Adhigatappano hi paṭhamajjhāne ṭhito tameva
analyzed: uppādetvā ti attho kammaṭṭhānam appanam pāpetabbanti yathāladdhe uggaha nimitte kammaṃ  karontena paṭibhāga nimittam uppādetvā upacāra jjhāne ṭhitena tam eva bhāvanam ussukkāpentena  asubha kammaṭṭhānam appanam pāpetabbam adhigata ppanaḥ hi paṭhama jhāne ṭhitaḥ tam eva
translated: The meaning is: having aroused.

original: jhānaṃ pādakaṃ katvā vipassanaṃ ārabhitvā saṅkhāre sammasanto nacirasseva sabbāsave khepetīti.
analyzed: jhānam pādakam katvā vipassanam ārabhitvā saṅkhāre sammasantaḥ nacirassa iva sabba āsave khepeti iti
translated: The meditation subject should be brought to Arahantship: one who is doing the work of development with the sign of the similes obtained in the way already stated should arouse the counterpart sign, and then, by persevering in developing that sign, he should bring the foulness meditation to Arahantship. For one who has reached absorption by means of the first jhāna and then, standing upon that, begins insight, and who, by comprehending formations, soon exhausts the taints, does so by means of this meditation subject.

original: Asubhakammaṭṭhānaniddesavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: asubha kammaṭṭhāna niddesa vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The description of the foulness meditation is ended.

original: Iti chaṭṭhaparicchedavaṇṇanā.
analyzed: iti chaṭṭha pariccheda vaṇṇanā
translated: The commentary on the sixth chapter is ended.

original: 7. Chaanussatiniddesavaṇṇanā
translated: The six recollections

original: 1. Buddhānussatikathāvaṇṇanā
analyzed: buddha anussati kathā vaṇṇanā
translated: The recollection of the Buddha

original: 123. Asubhānantaranti asubhakammaṭṭhānānantaraṃ. Anussatīsūti anussatikammaṭṭhānesu.
analyzed: asubha anantaram ti asubha kammaṭṭhāna anantaram anussatīsu ti anussati kammaṭṭhānesu
translated: After the foul meditation: after the foulness meditation. The recollection sutta: in the meditation subjects consisting in recollections.

original: “Anu anu sati anussatī”ti imamatthaṃ dassetuṃ “punappunaṃ uppajjanato”ti vatvā na
analyzed: anu anu sati anussati iti imam attham dassetum punappunam uppajjanato ti vatvā na
translated: In order to show the meaning of “recollecting again and again” he says “because of occurring again and again” .

original: ettha anu-saddayogena sati-saddo atthantaravācakoti dassetuṃ “satiyeva anussatī”ti🔽vuttaṃ. Tena nāyamanu-saddo “upalabbhatī”tiādīsu upa-saddo viya anatthako, nāpi “sañjānanaṃ
analyzed: ettha anusadda yogena sati saddo atthantara vācako ti dassetum satiyā iva anussatī ti  vuttam tena na ayam anusaddaḥ upalabbhati iti ādīsu upasaddaḥ viya anatthakaḥ nā api sañjānanam
translated: Thus it is said: “Recollection is mindfulness itself.”🔽The word “after” is not meaningless here, as in the case of the word “up” in the expression “he is found” . Nor does it indicate a different meaning, as in the case of the words “saṃ” , etc., in the expressions “he understands” , “he knows” .

original: pajānana”ntiādīsu saṃ-saddādayo viya atthantaradīpakoti dasseti. “Pavattitabbaṭṭhānamhiyeva🔽vā pavattattā”ti iminā ca anussatiyā anussaritabbānurūpatā vuttā hotīti pavattakasseva🔽anurūpataṃ dassetuṃ “kulaputtassa anurūpā”ti vuttaṃ, saddhāpabbajitassa vā kulaputtassa.
analyzed: pajānana nti ādīsu saṃsadda ādayaḥ viya atthantara dīpakaḥ ti dasseti pavattitabba ṭṭhānamhi yeva  vā pavattattā ti iminā ca anussatiyāḥ anussaritabba anurūpa tā vuttā hoti iti pavattakassa iva  anurūpa tam dassetum kula puttassa anurūpā iti vuttam saddhāpabbajitassa vā kula puttassa
translated: It is said that the word “after” indicates the object of recollection, which is the same as the object of mindfulness.🔽The word “after” is used to show that the object of recollection is the same as the object of mindfulness.🔽The word “after” is used to show that the object of recollection is the same as the object of mindfulness.🔽The word “after” is used to show that the object of recollection is the same as the object of mindfulness.

original: Anurūpatā nāma pavattitabbaṭṭhānassa anurūpatāya eva hotīti pavattakasseva anurūpatā🔽vuttā, na ubhayassa. Anurūpāti ca yuttāti attho. Buddhanti ye guṇe upādāya bhagavati
analyzed: anurūpa tā nāma pavattitabba ṭṭhānassa anurūpa tāya eva hoti iti pavattakassa iva anurūpa tā  vuttā na ubhayassa anurūpā ati ca yuttā ati atthaḥ buddha nti ye guṇe upādāya bhagavati
translated: The word “after” is used to show that the object of recollection is the same as the object of mindfulness.🔽The word “after” is used to show that the object of recollection is the same as the object of mindfulness.

original: “buddho”ti paññatti, te guṇe ekajjhaṃ gahetvā vuttaṃ. Tenāha “buddhaguṇārammaṇāya
analyzed: buddhaḥ ti paññatti te guṇe ekajjham gahetvā vuttam tena āha buddha guṇa ārammaṇāya
translated: The word “after” is used to show that the object of recollection is the same as the object of mindfulness.🔽The word “after” is used to show that the object of recollection is the same as the object of mindfulness.🔽The word “after” is used to show that the object of recollection is the same as the object of mindfulness.

original: satiyā etamadhivacana”nti. Ārabbhāti ālambitvā. Dhammanti pariyattidhammena saddhiṃ
analyzed: satiyāḥ etam adhivacanam ti ārabbha ati ālambitvā dhammanti pariyatti dhammena saddhiṃ
translated: “In regard to”: having taken as object.🔽“The Dhamma”: the ninefold supramundane Dhamma together with the Dhamma of the scriptures.

original: navavidhampi lokuttaradhammaṃ. Nanu ca nibbānaṃ visuṃ kammaṭṭhānabhāvena vakkhati?🔽Kiñcāpi vakkhati, dhammabhāvasāmaññena pana maggaphalehi saddhiṃ idha pāḷiyā saṅgahitattā🔽tassāpi dhammānussatikammaṭṭhāne gahaṇaṃ daṭṭhabbaṃ, asaṅkhatāmatādibhāvena pana
analyzed: navavidham pi lokuttara dhammam nanu ca nibbānam visum kammaṭṭhāna bhāvena vakkhati  kiñcā api vakkhati dhamma bhāva sāmaññena pana magga phalehi saddhim idha pāḷiyā saṅgahita ttā  tassa api dhamma anussati kammaṭṭhāne gahaṇam daṭṭhabbam asaṅkhata amata ādi bhāvena pana
translated: But is not Nibbāna taught as a meditation subject in its own right?🔽Although it is so taught, it is included here in the text under the recollection of the Dhamma because it is similar to the Dhamma in being a state of non-confusion, etc.,

original: maggaphalehi visiṭṭhatāya tassa visuṃ kammaṭṭhānabhāvena gahaṇaṃ kataṃ. Sīlānussatiādīnaṃ🔽pana tissannaṃ anussatīnaṃ visuṃ kammaṭṭhānabhāvena gahaṇaṃ yogāvacarassa attano
analyzed: magga phalehi visiṭṭha tāya tassa visum kammaṭṭhāna bhāvena gahaṇam katam sīla anussati ādīnam  pana tissannam anussatīnam visum kammaṭṭhāna bhāvena gahaṇam yogāvacarassa attano
translated: and because it is included in the text together with the path and fruition. But it is also taught as a meditation subject in its own right because it is distinguished from the path and fruition by its being unformed, etc.,🔽The three recollections, however, of virtue, generosity, and the deities, are included as meditation subjects in their own right only for the ordinary man,

original: eva sīlassa cāgassa saddhādīnañca anussatiṭṭhānabhāvena gahetabbattā. Rūpakāyaṃ gatāti
analyzed: eva sīlassa cāgassa saddhā ādīnam ca anussati ṭṭhāna bhāvena gahetabba ttā rūpakāyam gatā ati
translated: because they can be brought to mind by him as objects of recollection in the way stated.🔽“In regard to the body”: occurring by making the body consisting of four great primaries that is present in oneself the object.

original: attano karajakāyaṃ ārabbha ārammaṇakaraṇavasena pavattā. Kāyeti kāye visayabhūte.
analyzed: attano karaja kāyam ārabbha ārammaṇa karaṇa vasena pavattā kāya iti kāye visaya bhūte
translated: “The body”: the body as the objective field.

original: Koṭṭhāsanimittārammaṇāyāti kesādikoṭṭhāsesu paṭikkūlanimittārammaṇāya. Ito purimāsu
analyzed: koṭṭhāsa nimitta ārammaṇāya ati kesa ādi koṭṭhāsesu paṭikkūla nimitta ārammaṇāya itas purimāsu
translated: “With the sign of the anatomical parts as the object” means with the sign of repulsiveness in the anatomical parts as the object. The preceding three kinds of meditation subjects are called “external” because they are given in the texts in external form thus, “One who makes use of a meditation subject consisting of kasina should attain jhana in an external kasiṇa” , and “One who makes use of a meditation subject consisting of the unattractive should attain jhana in an external sign of the unattractive” , and “One who makes use of a meditation subject consisting of the anatomical parts should attain jhana in an external sign of the anatomical parts” .

original: sattasu anussatīsu natthi nimittuppatti, idha atthīti dassanatthaṃ nimitta-ggahaṇaṃ.
analyzed: sattasu anussatīsu natthi nimitta uppatti idha atthi iti dassana ttham nimitta ggahaṇam
translated: “With the sign of the head hairs as the object” means with the sign of repulsiveness in the head hairs as the object. In the first seven recollections there is no arising of a sign, but in order to show that there is a sign here, the sign is mentioned.

original: Tathā assāsapassāsanimittārammaṇāyāti etthāpi. Upasamanti sabbasaṅkhārūpasamaṃ, nibbānanti attho.🔽124. Avecca buddhaguṇe yāthāvato ñatvā uppanno pasādo aveccappasādo, ariyamaggena
analyzed: tathā assāsa passāsa nimitta ārammaṇāya ati ettha api upasamanti sabba saṅkhāra upasamam nibbānam ti attho  avecca buddha guṇe yāthāvataḥ ñatvā uppannaḥ pasādaḥ aveccappasādaḥ ariya maggena
translated: “With the sign of the in-breaths and out-breaths as the object” means with the sign of the in-breaths and out-breaths as the object. They are calmed, i.e. they are calmed by the calming of all formations, which is what is meant by “Nibbāna.”

original: āgatappasādo, taṃsadisopi vā yo diṭṭhigatavātehi acalo asampakampiyo, tena samannāgatena.🔽Tādisassa buddhānussatibhāvanā ijjhati, na itarassa. Patirūpasenāsaneti yathāvuttaaṭṭhārasadosavajjite
analyzed: āgata ppasādaḥ tad sadisaḥ api vā yaḥ diṭṭhi gata vātehi acalaḥ tena samannāgatena  tādisassa buddha anussati bhāvanā ijjhati na itarassa pati rūpa senāsanā iti yathāvutta aṭṭhārasa dosa vajjite
translated: “With full confidence” : confidence is the faith that arises when the special qualities of the Buddha are known as they really are. Or alternatively, confidence is the faith that arises through the noble path. Or it is like that faith. It is unshaken by the winds of views, by the winds of doubt, and by the winds of lust. One who possesses that confidence is one “with full confidence.”

original: pañcaṅgasamannāgate senāsane. Rahogatenāti rahasi gatena. Tena kāyavivekaṃ dasseti.
analyzed: pañcaṅga samannāgate senāsane rahogatena ati rahasi gatena tena kāya vivekam dasseti
translated: The development of the recollection of the Buddha succeeds for one such as this, not for others. “In a suitable place” : in a place free from the eighteen faults mentioned in the description of the posture for concentration and possessing the five constituents beginning with seclusion. “In private” : this shows bodily seclusion.

original: Paṭisallīnenāti nānārammaṇato paṭisallīnena, bahiddhā puthuttārammaṇato paṭikkamāpetvā
analyzed: paṭisallīnena ati nānā ārammaṇataḥ paṭisallīnena bahiddhā puthutta ārammaṇato paṭikkamāpetvā
translated: “Who has secluded himself”: who has secluded himself from the various objects of sense desire, who has turned away from the variety of external objects.

original: kammaṭṭhāne sallīnena, susiliṭṭhacittenāti attho. Evanti imāya pāḷiyā āgatanayena.
analyzed: kammaṭṭhāne sallīnena su siliṭṭha cittena ati attho evam ti imāya pāḷiyā āgata nayena
translated: “Who has entered upon the inner tranquillity and the signless concentration”: who has entered upon the meditation subject, who has his mind well composed. “Thus”: in the way stated in the text.

original: So bhagavāti ettha soti yo so samatiṃsa pāramiyo pūretvā sabbakilese bhañjitvā anuttaraṃ🔽sammāsambodhiṃ abhisambuddho devānaṃ atidevo brahmānaṃ atibrahmā lokanātho bhāgyavantatādīhi
analyzed: saḥ bhagavā ati ettha saḥ ti yaḥ so pāramiyo pūretvā sabba kilese bhañjitvā anuttaram  sammāsambodhim abhisambuddhaḥ devānam atidevaḥ brahmānam atibrahmā lokanāthaḥ
translated: “The Blessed One”: here “the” refers to the One who, having fulfilled the thirty pāramīs, destroyed all the defilements and reached the supreme enlightenment,

original: kāraṇehi sadevake loke “bhagavā”ti patthaṭakittisaddo, so. Bhagavāti idaṃ satthu
analyzed: kāraṇehi sa devake loke bhagavā ati patthaṭa kitti saddaḥ saḥ bhagavā ati idam satthu
translated: and whose name is well known in the world of men and gods as “the Blessed One” because of his good fortune, etc.🔽“Blessed One” is a title of the Master.

original: nāmakittanaṃ. Tathā hi vuttaṃ “bhagavāti netaṃ nāmaṃ mātarā kata”ntiādi. Parato pana
analyzed: nāma kittanam tathā hi vuttam bhagavā ati na itam nāmam mātarā kata nti ādi paratas pana
translated: For it is said: “‘Blessed One’ is not a name made by a mother, a father, a relative, or a friend” , etc.🔽But “Blessed One” is a title of praise.

original: bhagavāti guṇakittanaṃ. Arahantiādīsu navasu ṭhānesu paccekaṃ itipi-saddaṃ yojetvā
analyzed: bhagavā iti guṇa kittanam arahanti ādīsu navasu ṭhānesu paccekam iti pi saddam yojetvā
translated: The words “thus indeed” should be construed with each of the nine terms beginning with “worthy one.”

original: buddhaguṇā anussaritabbāti dassento “itipi arahaṃ…pe… itipi bhagavāti anussaratī”ti
analyzed: buddha guṇāḥ anussaritabbā ati dassento iti pi arahaṃpe iti pi bhagavā ati anussarati iti
translated: Showing that the Buddha’s special qualities are to be recollected, the Exalted One says: “He recollects the special qualities of the Buddha thus: ‘The Blessed One is an arahant, a fully enlightened one … a blessed one.’“

original: āha. “Itipetaṃ bhūtaṃ itipetaṃ taccha”ntiādīsu viya iti-saddo āsannapaccakkhakaraṇattho,
analyzed: āha iti petam bhūtam iti petam tat śanti ādīsu viya iti saddaḥ āsanna paccakkha karaṇa atthaḥ
translated: The word “thus” has the meaning of “I have seen it thus,” “I have heard it thus,” etc., and it shows that the speaker is a witness.

original: pi-saddo sampiṇḍanattho. Tena nesaṃ bahubhāvo dīpito, tāni ca guṇasallakkhaṇakāraṇāni
analyzed: pi saddaḥ sampiṇḍana atthaḥ tena nesam bahu bhāvaḥ dīpitaḥ tāni ca guṇa sat lakkhaṇa kāraṇāni
translated: The word “and” has the meaning of “and also.” It shows that there are many such reasons.

original: bhāventena cittassa sammukhībhūtāni kātabbānīti dassento “iminā ca iminā ca kāraṇenāti vuttaṃ hotī”ti āha.🔽125. Dūratā nāma āsannatā viya upādāyupādāya vuccatīti paramukkaṃsagataṃ dūrabhāvaṃ
analyzed: bhāventena cittassa sammukhībhūtāni kātabbāni iti dassentaḥ iminā ca iminā ca kāraṇena ati vuttam hoti iti āha  dūra tā nāma āsanna tā viya upādāya upādāya vuccati iti param ukkaṃsa gatam dūra bhāvam
translated: The reasons should be brought to mind by one who develops the recollection of the Buddha’s special qualities.🔽“Farness” is said in the same way as “nearness,” according to the context.🔽The word “far” shows the farness of the Buddha from the far shore of the ocean of the special qualities of virtue, etc.

original: dassento “suvidūravidūre”ti āha, suṭṭhu vidūrabhāveneva vidūreti attho. Sā panassa🔽kilesato dūratā tesaṃ sabbaso pahīnattāti dassento āha “maggena kilesānaṃ viddhaṃsitattā”ti.
analyzed: dassentaḥ su vidūra vidūrā iti āha suṭṭhu vidūra bhāvena iva vidūrā iti attho sā pana assa  kilesataḥ dūra tā tesam sabbaso pahīna ttā ati dassentaḥ āha maggena kilesānam viddhaṃsita ttā ati
translated: The word “far” means “very far,” “extremely far.”🔽The farness of the Buddha from the defilements is shown by the words “because the defilements have been destroyed by the path.”

original: Nanu aññesampi khīṇāsavānaṃ te pahīnā evāti anuyogaṃ manasi katvā vuttaṃ “savāsanāna”nti.
analyzed: nanu aññesam pi khīṇāsavānam te pahīnāḥ evā ti anuyogam manasi katvā vuttam sa vāsanānam ti
translated: But since the defilements have been destroyed in other arahants as well, the word “together with the cankers” is stated in order to show that the Buddha is far from the defilements together with their residual cankers.

original: Na hi bhagavantaṃ ṭhapetvā aññe saha vāsanāya kilese pahātuṃ sakkonti, etena aññehi🔽asādhāraṇaṃ bhagavato arahattanti dassitaṃ hoti. Kā panāyaṃ vāsanā nāma? Pahīnakilesassāpi
analyzed: na hi bhagavantam ṭhapetvā aññe saha vāsanāya kilese pahātum sakkonti etena aññehi  asādhāraṇam bhagavato arahattanti dassitam hoti kā pana ayam vāsanā nāma pahīna kilesassa api
translated: For no one else can destroy the defilements together with their residual impressions except the Blessed One. This shows that the Blessed One’s arahanthood is not shared by others.

original: appahīnakilesassa payogasadisapayogahetubhūto kilesanihito sāmatthiyaviseso āyasmato🔽pilindavacchassa vasalasamudācāranimittaṃ viya. Kathaṃ pana “ārakā”ti vutte “kilesehī”ti
analyzed: appahīna kilesassa payoga sadisa payoga hetu bhūtaḥ kilesa nihitaḥ sāmatthiya visesaḥ āyasmataḥ  pilinda vacchassa vasala samudācāra nimittam viya katham pana ārakā ati vutte kilesehi iti
translated: But what is this residual impression? It is a special kind of potency that is deposited by the defilements in one who has not destroyed the defilements,🔽which acts as a cause for the occurrence of similar activities. It is like the sign of the venerable Pilindavaccha’s former habit of stealing,

original: ayamattho labbhatīti? Sāmaññajotanāya visese avaṭṭhānato, visesatthinā ca visesassa
analyzed: ayam atthaḥ labbhati iti sāmañña jotanāya visese avaṭṭhānataḥ visesatthinā ca visesassa
translated: How is it that the meaning “from the defilements” is obtained when “from far away” is said? Because of the non-occurrence of the general indication in the particular,

original: anupayojetabbato, “ārakāssa honti pāpakā akusalā dhammā”tiādīni suttapadānettha udāharitabbāni.
analyzed: an upayojetabbataḥ ārakāssa honti pāpakāḥ akusalāḥ dhammā ti ādīni sutta padāni ittha udāharitabbāni
translated: and because the particular cannot be applied by one who seeks the particular, the following sutta passages should be quoted here: “Evil unwholesome states are far away for him” , etc.

original: Ārakāti cettha ā-kārassa rassattaṃ, ka-kārassa ca ha-kāraṃ, sānusāraṃ katvā niruttinayena
analyzed: ārakā ati ca ittha ākārassa rassa ttam kakārassa ca hakāram sa anusāram katvā nirutti nayena
translated: Here, in the word ārakā , the letter ā is a substitute for the letter ra, and the letter ka is a substitute for the letter ha. By the method of word derivation,

original: “araha”nti padasiddhi veditabbā. Vuttamevatthaṃ sukhaggahaṇatthaṃ “so tato ārakā
analyzed: veditabbā vuttam eva attham sukha ggahaṇa attham saḥ tatas ārakā
translated: the derivation of the word araha should be understood as follows. In order to facilitate easy comprehension of the meaning already stated, it is said: “He is far away from that,

original: nāmā”ti gāthābandhamāha. Tattha samañjanasīlo samaṅgī, na samaṅgitā asamaṅgitā asamannāgamo asahavuttitā.
analyzed: nāma iti gāthābandham āha tattha samañjana sīlaḥ samaṅgī na samaṅgi tā asamaṅgi tā a samannāgamaḥ a sahavutti tā
translated: Herein, one of equal virtue is an equal, not an unequal, not one not having virtue, not one not living together with it.

original: 126. Anatthacaraṇena kilesā eva arayoti kilesārayo. “Arīnaṃ hatattā arihā”ti vattabbe niruttinayena “araha”nti vuttaṃ.
analyzed: anattha caraṇena kilesāḥ eva arayaḥ ti kilesa arayaḥ arīnam hata ttā ari hā ati vattabbe nirutti nayena arahanti vuttam
translated: The defilements themselves are enemies because they do what is unprofitable, thus they are defilement-enemies. What should be said as ‘enemy-smasher’ is said as ‘worthy’ by the method of derivation.🔽And this is the connection with the wheel of becoming:

original: 127. Yañcetaṃ saṃsāracakkanti sambandho. Rathacakkassa nābhi viya mūlāvayavabhūtaṃ
analyzed: yat ca itam saṃsāra cakkanti sambandhaḥ ratha cakkassa nābhi viya mūla avayava bhūtam
translated: The root-constituent, which is like the nave of a chariot-wheel,

original: anto, bahi ca samavaṭṭhitaṃ avijjābhavataṇhāmayaṃ dvayanti vuttaṃ “avijjābhavataṇhāmayanābhī”ti.
analyzed: antar bahi ca samavaṭṭhitam avijjā bhava taṇhā mayam dvayanti vuttam avijjā bhava taṇhā maya nābhi iti
translated: is the twofold ignorance and craving for being, which is described as ‘the nave of ignorance and craving for being’ because it is surrounded inside and outside.

original: Nābhiyā, nemiyā ca sambandhā arasadisā paccayaphalabhūtehi avijjātaṇhājarāmaraṇehi🔽sambandhā puññādisaṅkhārāti vuttaṃ “puññādiabhisaṅkhārāra”nti. Tattha tattha bhave
analyzed: nābhiyā nemiyā ca sambandhāḥ a rasa disā paccaya phala bhūtehi avijjā taṇhā jarā maraṇehi  sambandhā puñña ādi saṅkhārā ti vuttam tattha tattha bhave
translated: The conditions and results, which are like the spokes, are ignorance, craving, birth, and ageing-and-death,🔽which are connected with the nave and the rim. The formations consisting of merit, etc., are described as ‘the spokes of merit, etc.’ because they are connected with the spokes. Herein, ageing-and-death is evident as the boundary in each case in becoming,

original: pariyantabhāvena pākaṭaṃ jarāmaraṇanti taṃ nemiṭṭhāniyaṃ katvā āha “jarāmaraṇanemī”ti.
analyzed: pariyanta bhāvena pākaṭam tam nemiṭṭhāniyam katvā āha jarāmaraṇanemī iti
translated: so he described it as ‘the rim of ageing-and-death’ by making it occupy the place of the rim.

original: Yathā ca rathacakkapavattiyā padhānakāraṇaṃ akkho, evaṃ saṃsāracakkapavattiyā āsavasamudayoti
analyzed: yathā ca ratha cakka pavattiyā padhāna kāraṇam akkhaḥ evam saṃsāra cakka pavattiyā āsava samudayaḥ ti
translated: And just as the axle is the principal cause of the wheel’s rolling, so too the origin of cankers is the principal cause of the wheel of the round of rebirths rolling.

original: āha “āsavasamudayamayena akkhena vijjhitvā”ti. Āsavā eva avijjādīnaṃ kāraṇattā āsavasamudayo.
analyzed: āha āsava samudaya mayena akkhena vijjhitvā iti āsavāḥ eva avijjā ādīnam kāraṇa ttā āsava samudayaḥ
translated: So it is said: “pierced by the axle of the origin of cankers.” The origin of cankers is the cankers themselves, since they are the cause of ignorance, etc.,

original: Yathāha “āsavasamudayā avijjāsamudayo”ti. Vipākakaṭattārūpappabhedo kāmabhavādiko
analyzed: yathā āha āsava samudayā avijjā samudayo ti vipāka kaṭattā rūpa ppabhedo kāma bhava ādiko
translated: as it is said: “With the arising of cankers there is the arising of ignorance” . The triple becoming consisting of the five aggregates of aggregates of form, etc., classed as resultant and functional,

original: tibhavo eva ratho, tasmiṃ tibhavarathe. Attano paccayehi samaṃ, sabbaso vā ādito
analyzed: tibhavaḥ eva rathaḥ tasmin tibhava rathe attanaḥ paccayehi samam sabbasas vā āditaḥ
translated: is the chariot. In that chariot of the triple becoming,

original: paṭṭhāya yojitanti samāyojitaṃ. Ādirahitaṃ kālaṃ pavattatīti katvā anādikālappavattaṃ.
analyzed: paṭṭhāya yojitanti samāyojitam ādi rahitam kālam pavattati iti katvā anādi kāla ppavattam
translated: or else it is yoked from the beginning onwards with its own conditions, completely or partially. It occurs without beginning in time, since it occurs without a beginning in time.

original: “Khandhānañca paṭipāṭi, dhātuāyatanāna ca;
analyzed: khandhānam ca paṭipāṭi dhātu āyatanāna ca
translated: “The succession of aggregates, Elements, and sense bases,

original: Abbocchinnaṃ vattamānā, ‘saṃsāro’ti pavuccatī”ti. –🔽Evaṃ vuttasaṃsārova saṃsāracakkaṃ. Anenāti bhagavatā. Bodhimaṇḍeti bodhisaṅkhātassa
analyzed: abbocchinnam vattamānā saṃsāro iti pavuccati iti  evam vutta saṃsāraḥ iva saṃsāra cakkam anena ati bhagavatā bodhimaṇḍā iti bodhi saṅkhātassa
translated: Occurring without break, Is called the round of rebirths.”

original: ñāṇassa maṇḍabhāvappatte ṭhāne, kāle vā. Vīriyapādehīti saṃkilesavodānapakkhiyesu
analyzed: ñāṇassa maṇḍa bhāva patte ṭhāne kāle vā vīriya pādehi iti saṃkilesa vodāna pakkhiyesu
translated: The round of rebirths described in this way is the wheel of the round of rebirths. By this: by the Blessed One. At the foot of the Bodhi Tree: in the place or at the time when the state of a basis for the knowledge called “enlightenment” was reached. With the exertion of energy: with the exertion of energy that is included in the purification of virtue and the purification of consciousness.

original: sannirumbhanasannikkhipanakiccatāya dvidhā pavattehi attano vīriyasaṅkhātehi pādehi.
analyzed: sannirumbhana sannikkhipana kicca tāya dvidhā pavattehi attanaḥ vīriya saṅkhātehi pādehi
translated: With its two feet, which are called energy, that is, with the two feet that occur in the two modes of exertion, namely, arousing and exerting.

original: Sīlapathaviyanti patiṭṭhaṭṭhena sīlameva pathavī, tassaṃ. Patiṭṭhāyāti sampādanavasena
analyzed: sīla pathaviyanti patiṭṭha ṭṭhena sīlam eva pathavī patiṭṭhāya āti sampādana vasena
translated: On the ground of virtue: virtue itself is the ground in the sense of basis;

original: patiṭṭhahitvā. Saddhāhatthenāti anavajjadhammādānasādhanato saddhāva hattho, tena.
analyzed: patiṭṭhahitvā saddhā hatthena ati anavajja dhamma ādāna sādhanato saddhā va hatthaḥ tena
translated: on that. With the hand of faith: faith itself is the hand in the sense of taking what is not blamed by the wise;

original: Kammakkhayakaranti kāyakammādibhedassa sabbassapi kammassa khayakaraṇato kammakkhayakaraṃ.
analyzed: kamma khaya karanti kāya kamma ādi bhedassa sabbassa api kammassa khaya karaṇataḥ kamma khaya karam
translated: with that. Which cuts off action: which cuts off all action classed as bodily, etc.;

original: Ñāṇapharasunti samādhisilāyaṃ sunisitamaggañāṇapharasuṃ gahetvā.
analyzed: samādhi silāyam su nisita magga ñāṇa pharasum gahetvā
translated: With the sword of knowledge: having taken the sword of knowledge of the path, which is sharp in the sense of concentration and virtue.

original: 128. Evaṃ “arānaṃ hatattā”ti ettha vuttaaraghāte saṃsāraṃ cakkaṃ viya cakkanti gahetvā🔽atthayojanaṃ katvā idāni paṭiccasamuppādadesanākkamenapi taṃ dassetuṃ “atha vā”tiādi
analyzed: evam ettha vutta araghāte saṃsāram cakkam viya cakkanti gahetvā  attha yojanam katvā idāni paṭiccasamuppāda desanā kkamena api tam dassetum atha vā ati ādi
translated: Thus, having taken the wheel of existence as a wheel in the way stated in the stanza, “Because the spokes are destroyed” ,

original: vuttaṃ. Tattha anamataggaṃ saṃsāravaṭṭanti anu anu amataggaṃ aviññātakoṭikaṃ saṃsāramaṇḍalaṃ.
analyzed: vuttam tattha anamataggam saṃsāra vaṭṭanti anu anu amataggam aviññātakoṭikam saṃsāra maṇḍalam
translated: and having explained its meaning in ten ways, he now sets forth that wheel by the order of the teaching of dependent origination with the words “Or else, the wheel of becoming” , etc. Herein, the wheel of becoming without known beginning is the wheel of the round of rebirths that has no known end or beginning.

original: Sesā dasa dhammā saṅkhārādayo jātipariyosānā arā. Kathaṃ? Nābhiyā avijjāya mūlato,
analyzed: sesā dasa dhammā saṅkhāra ādayaḥ jāti pariyosānāḥ arāḥ katham avijjāya mūlataḥ
translated: How? From the hub of ignorance,🔽and from the rim of ageing-and-death,

original: nemiyā jarāmaraṇena antato sambandhattāti dassento āha “avijjāmūlakattā jarāmaraṇapariyantattā
analyzed: nemiyā jarā maraṇena antatas sambandha ttā ati dassentaḥ āha avijjā mūlaka ttā jarā maraṇa pariyanta ttā
translated: showing this, he said “because it has ignorance for its hub” and so on.

original: cā”ti. Dukkhādīsūti dukkhasamudayanirodhamaggesu. Tattha dukkhe aññāṇaṃ tadantogadhattā,
analyzed: ca ati dukkha ādīsu iti dukkha samudaya nirodha maggesu tattha dukkhe aññāṇam tad anta gadha tā
translated: In the four noble truths beginning with suffering: here ignorance of suffering is because it is included in that and because it conceals it,🔽and in the rest it is only because it conceals.

original: tappaṭicchādanato ca, sesesu paṭicchādanatova. Dukkhanti cettha dukkhaṃ ariyasaccaṃ🔽adhippetanti taṃ kāmabhavādivasena tidhā bhinditvā tathā tappaṭicchādikaṃ avijjaṃ,
analyzed: tad paṭicchādanato ca sesesu paṭicchādanato va dukkhanti ca ittha dukkham ariya saccam  tam kāma bhava ādi vasena tidhā bhinditvā tathā tad paṭicchādikam avijjam
translated: As to suffering, the noble truth of suffering is intended.

original: avijjādipaccaye tīsu bhavesu saṅkhārādike ca paṭipāṭiyā dassento “kāmabhave ca avijjā”tiādimāha.
analyzed: avijjā ādi paccaye tīsu bhavesu saṅkhāra ādike ca paṭipāṭiyā dassentaḥ kāma bhave ca avijjā āti ādim āha
translated: Having divided that into three kinds as sense-desire becoming, etc., he said “In sense-desire becoming ignorance” and so on, showing the spokes beginning with formations in the three kinds of becoming in the order stated, and the ignorance that conceals each one.

original: Tattha kāmabhave avijjāti kāmabhave ādīnavappaṭicchādikā avijjā. Rūpabhave arūpabhave
analyzed: tattha kāma bhave avijjā ati kāma bhave ādīnava paṭicchādikā avijjā rūpa bhave arūpa bhave
translated: Herein, ignorance in sense-desire becoming is ignorance that conceals the danger in sense-desire becoming. In fine-material becoming, in immaterial becoming,

original: avijjāti etthāpi eseva nayo. Kāmabhave saṅkhārānanti kāmabhūmipariyāpannānaṃ saṅkhārānaṃ,
analyzed: ettha api esa iva nayaḥ kāma bhave kāma bhūmi pariyāpannānam saṅkhārānam
translated: Here too the same method of explanation applies. In the sense sphere as a condition for determinations: for determinations included in the sense-sphere plane,

original: kāmabhave vā nipphādetabbā ye saṅkhārā, tesaṃ kāmabhavūpapattinibbattakasaṅkhārānanti🔽attho. Paccayo hotīti puññābhisaṅkhārānaṃ tāva ārammaṇapaccayena ceva upanissayapaccayena
analyzed: kāma bhave vā nipphādetabbāḥ ye saṅkhārā tesam  atthaḥ paccayaḥ hoti iti puñña abhisaṅkhārānam tāva ārammaṇa paccayena ca iva upanissaya paccayena
translated: or for those determinations that have to be produced in the sense-sphere plane. The meaning is: for determinations that cause rebirth in the sense-sphere plane.

original: cāti dvidhā paccayo hoti. Apuññābhisaṅkhāresu sahajātassa sahajātādivasena, asahajātassa🔽anantarasamanantarādivasena, nānantarassa pana ārammaṇavasena ceva upanissayavasena
analyzed: ca ati dvidhā paccayaḥ hoti apuñña abhisaṅkhāresu sahajātassa sahajāta ādi vasena asahajātassa  anantara samanantara ādi vasena nānantarassa pana ārammaṇa vasena ca iva upanissaya vasena
translated: It is a condition: for meritorious determinations it is a condition in two ways, as object condition and as decisive-support condition.🔽For demeritorious determinations it is a condition for conascent states as conascence, etc., and for non-conascent states as prenascence, postnascence, support, and faculty conditions.

original: ca paccayo hoti. Arūpabhave saṅkhārānanti āneñjābhisaṅkhārānaṃ. Paccayo hoti upanissayavaseneva.
analyzed: ca paccayaḥ hoti arūpa bhave saṅkhārānam ti āneñja abhisaṅkhārānam paccayaḥ hoti upanissaya vasena eva
translated: For determinations in the fine-material and immaterial planes it is a condition only as a decisive-support condition.

original: Imasmiṃ panatthe ettha vitthāriyamāne atippapañco hoti, sayameva ca parato āgamissatīti
analyzed: imasmin pana atthe ettha vitthāriyamāne atippapañcaḥ hoti sayam eva ca paratas āgamissati iti
translated: But if we were to explain this matter in detail, there would be too much, and so, with the thought that it will come up later by itself,

original: na naṃ vitthārayāma.
analyzed: na nam vitthārayāma
translated: we shall not elaborate it here.

original: Tiṇṇaṃ āyatanānanti cakkhusotamanāyatanānaṃ. Ekassāyatanassāti manāyatanassa. Iminā🔽nayena phassādīnampi vibhāgo veditabbo. Tattha tattha sā sā taṇhāti rūpataṇhādibhedā
analyzed: tiṇṇam āyatanānanti cakkhu sota mana āyatanānam ekassa āyatanassa ati mana āyatanassa iminā  nayena phassa ādīnam pi vibhāgaḥ veditabbaḥ tattha tattha sā sā taṇhā ati rūpa taṇhā ādi bhedā
translated: “Of three bases” : of the eye, ear, and mind bases. “Of one base” : of the mind base.🔽In this way, the analysis of contact, etc., should be understood.🔽“Craving in regard to that and that” : craving classified as craving for visible forms, etc.,

original: tattha tattha kāmabhavādīsu uppajjanakā taṇhā.
analyzed: tattha tattha kāma bhava ādīsu uppajjanakā taṇhā
translated: which arises in regard to that and that, i.e., in the sense-sphere existence, etc.

original: Taṇhādimūlikā kathā atisaṃkhittāti taṃ, upādānabhave ca vibhajitvā vitthāretvā dassetuṃ
analyzed: taṇhā ādi mūlikā kathā atisaṃkhittā ati tam upādāna bhave ca vibhajitvā vitthāretvā dassetum
translated: The discussion beginning with the words “craving, etc.,” is extremely brief. In order to show it in detail, after analyzing the existence through clinging,

original: “katha”ntiādi vuttaṃ. Tattha “kāme paribhuñjissāmī”ti iminā kāmataṇhāpavattimāha.
analyzed: katham tiādi vuttam tattha kāme paribhuñjissāmi iti iminā kāma taṇhā pavattim āha
translated: “How?” and so on is said. Here, by the words “I will enjoy sensual pleasures,” he shows the occurrence of craving for sensual pleasures.

original: Tathā “saggasampattiṃ anubhavissāmī”tiādīhi. Sā pana taṇhā yasmā bhusamādānavasena
analyzed: tathā sagga sampattim anubhavissāmi itiādīhi sā pana taṇhā yasmā bhu samādāna vasena
translated: Likewise, by the words “I will experience the bliss of the heavenly worlds,” and so on.

original: pavattamānā kāmupādānaṃ nāma hoti, tasmā vuttaṃ “kāmupādānapaccayā”ti. Tathevāti
analyzed: pavattamānā kāma upādānam nāma hoti tasmā vuttam kāma upādāna paccayā ati tathā iva ati
translated: But that craving, when it occurs by way of the grasping of requisites, is called sensual-desire clinging. Therefore it is said: “With the perishing of clinging that has sensual desires as its condition.”

original: kāmupādānapaccayā eva.
analyzed: kāma upādāna paccayāḥ eva
translated: “Just so” : with the perishing of clinging that has sensual desires as its condition.

original: Brahmalokasampattinti rūpībrahmaloke sampattiṃ. “Sabbepi tebhūmakā dhammā kāmanīyaṭṭhena
analyzed: brahma loka sampattim ti rūpī brahma loke sampattim sabbe api tebhūmakāḥ dhammāḥ kāmanīya ṭṭhena
translated: “The attainment of the Brahma-world” : the attainment of the bliss of the Brahma-world of the fine-material sphere. “All dhammas of the three planes of existence are desirable.

original: kāmā”ti vacanato bhavarāgopi kāmupādānamevāti katvā “kāmupādānapaccayā eva mettaṃ
analyzed: kāma ati vacanataḥ bhava rāgaḥ api kāma upādānam evā ati katvā kāma upādāna paccayāḥ eva mettam
translated: and since the craving for becoming is included in the term “sense desires,” it is said that “he develops loving-kindness … with clinging to sense desires as condition.”

original: bhāvetī”tiādi vuttaṃ. Sesupādānamūlikāsupīti etthāyaṃ yojanā – idhekacco “natthi
analyzed: bhāveti itiādi vuttam sesa upādāna mūlikāsu pi iti ettha ayam yojanā idha ekaccaḥ na atthi
translated: The other kinds of clinging should be illustrated in the same way.

original: paro loko”ti natthikadiṭṭhiṃ gaṇhāti, so diṭṭhupādānapaccayā kāyena duccaritaṃ caratītiādi🔽vuttanayena yojetabbaṃ. Aparo “asukasmiṃ sampattibhave attā ucchijjatī”ti ucchedadiṭṭhiṃ
analyzed: paraḥ loko ti natthika diṭṭhim gaṇhāti saḥ diṭṭha upādāna paccayā kāyena duccaritam carati itiādi  vutta nayena yojetabbam aparaḥ asukasmin sampatti bhave attā ucchijjati iti uccheda diṭṭhim
translated: Here someone holds the annihilationist view that “there is no other world,” and he acts unvirtuously in body, etc., with clinging to that view as condition.

original: gaṇhāti, so tatrūpapattiyā kāyena sucaritaṃ caratītiādi vuttanayeneva yojetabbaṃ.🔽Aparo “rūpī manomayo hutvā attā ucchijjatī”ti rūpūpapattiyā maggaṃ bhāveti. Bhāvanāpāripūriyāti🔽sabbaṃ vuttanayeneva veditabbaṃ. Aparo “arūpabhave uppajjitvā attā ucchijjatī”ti
analyzed: gaṇhāti saḥ tatra upapattiyā kāyena su caritam carati itiādi vutta nayena iva yojetabbam  aparaḥ rūpī manaḥ mayaḥ hutvā attā ucchijjati iti rūpa upapattiyā maggam bhāveti bhāvanā pāripūriyā ati  sabbam vutta nayena iva veditabbam aparaḥ arūpa bhave uppajjitvā attā ucchijjati iti
translated: Or someone holds the annihilationist view that “the self is annihilated and destroyed with the breakup of the body,” and he acts virtuously in body, etc., with clinging to that view as condition.🔽Or someone develops the path to rebirth in the fine-material sphere with the view that “the self, having become material, is annihilated and destroyed.”

original: arūpūpapattiyā maggaṃ bhāveti. Bhāvanāpāripūriyāti sabbaṃ vuttanayeneva veditabbaṃ.
analyzed: arūpa upapattiyā maggam bhāveti bhāvanā pāripūriyā ti sabbam vutta nayena iva veditabbam
translated: Or someone develops the path to rebirth in the immaterial sphere with the view that “the self, having become immaterial, is annihilated and destroyed.”

original: Etāhiyeva attavādupādānamūlikāpi yojanā saṃvaṇṇitāti daṭṭhabbaṃ. Evaṃ diṭṭhadhammanibbānavādavasenāpi
analyzed: etāhiyā iva atta vāda upādāna mūlikā api yojanā saṃvaṇṇitā iti daṭṭhabbam evam diṭṭhadhamma nibbāna vāda vasena api
translated: And the interpretation based on the root of the conceit “I am” should be understood in the same way. This is how the interpretation should be understood as to the view of annihilation in this very life.

original: yojanā veditabbā. Aparo “sīlena suddhī”ti “asuddhimaggaṃ suddhimaggo”ti parāmasanto
analyzed: yojanā veditabbā aparaḥ sīlena suddhi iti a suddhi maggam suddhi maggaḥ ti parāmasantaḥ
translated: Another, misapprehending the way to purity as the way to impurity, as “Purity by virtue,”

original: sīlabbatupādānapaccayā kāyena duccaritaṃ caratītiādinā sabbaṃ vuttanayeneva yojetabbaṃ.🔽Idāni yvāyaṃ saṃsāracakkaṃ dassentena “kāmabhave avijjā kāmabhave saṅkhārānaṃ paccayo
analyzed: sīla bbata upādāna paccayā kāyena duccaritam carati iti ādinā sabbam vutta nayena iva yojetabbam  idāni yvā ayam saṃsāra cakkam dassentena kāma bhave avijjā kāma bhave saṅkhārānam paccayaḥ
translated: should be interpreted in the same way as above, beginning with “With the adherence to rules and observances as condition, he performs acts of body, speech, and mind that are unwholesome” .

original: hotī”tiādinā avijjādīnaṃ paccayabhāvo, saṅkhārādīnaṃ paccayuppannabhāvo ca dassito,
analyzed: hoti iti ādinā avijjā ādīnam paccaya bhāvo saṅkhāra ādīnam paccaya uppanna bhāvo ca dassitaḥ
translated: Now, the Blessed One, in showing the wheel of becoming, has shown how ignorance, etc., are conditions for formations, etc., and how formations, etc., are the conditionally arisen.

original: tameva paṭisambhidāmaggapāḷiṃ ānetvā nigamanavasena dassento “evaṃ aya”ntiādimāha.🔽Tattha yathā saṅkhārā hetunibbattā, evaṃ avijjāpi kāmāsavādinā sahetukā evāti āha
analyzed: tam eva paṭisambhidā magga pāḷim ānetvā nigamana vasena dassentaḥ evam ayanti ādim āha  tattha yathā saṅkhārāḥ hetu nibbattāḥ evam avijjā api kāma āsava ādinā sa hetukā eva iti āha
translated: And in order to show that same conditionally arisen state by way of conclusion after bringing in the text of the Paṭisambhidā, he said: “Thus this is conditionally arisen” .🔽Herein, just as formations are produced with ignorance as their cause, so too ignorance is with the taints of sense desire, etc., as its cause. Thus he said: “Both are produced with a cause” .

original: “ubhopete hetusamuppannā”ti. Paccayapariggaheti nāmarūpassa paccayānaṃ avijjādīnaṃ
analyzed: ubho upete hetu samuppannā ati paccaya pariggahā iti nāma rūpassa paccayānam avijjā ādīnam
translated: As to the analysis of conditions, ignorance is the condition for formations, etc.,

original: paricchijja gahaṇe, nipphādetabbe bhummaṃ. Paññāti kaṅkhāvitaraṇavisuddhisaṅkhātā
analyzed: paricchijja gahaṇe nipphādetabbe bhummam paññāti kaṅkhā vitaraṇa visuddhi saṅkhātā
translated: And in the definition of the aggregates, in the production of the earth kasiṇa,🔽“Understanding” is the knowing of the exposition of the three characteristics.🔽“Knowledge of the state of the dhammas” is the knowledge of the dependent origination.

original: pakārato jānanā. Dhammaṭṭhitiñāṇanti paṭiccasamuppādāvabodho. Idañca dhammaṭṭhitiñāṇaṃ
analyzed: pakārataḥ jānanā dhamma ṭṭhiti ñāṇanti paṭiccasamuppāda avabodhaḥ idam ca dhamma ṭṭhiti ñāṇam
translated: And since this knowledge of the state of the dhammas occurs by the surmounting of the stain of doubt about the three periods of time,

original: yasmā addhāttaye kaṅkhāmalavitaraṇavasena pavattati, tasmā “atītampi addhāna”ntiādi
analyzed: yasmai addhāttaye kaṅkhā mala vitaraṇa vasena pavattati tasmai atītam pi addhā ananti ādi
translated: it is said: “The past period of time too” and so on.

original: vuttaṃ. Eteneva nayenāti etena “avijjā hetū”tiādinā avijjāyaṃ vuttena nayena. “Saṅkhārā
analyzed: vuttam etena iva nayena ati etena avijjā hetu uti ādinā avijjā ayam vuttena nayena saṅkhārāḥ
translated: “By the same method”: by the method stated in the case of ignorance, namely, “ignorance is a cause, formations are caused” and so on.

original: hetu, viññāṇaṃ hetusamuppanna”ntiādinā sabbapadāni vitthāretabbāni.
analyzed: hetu viññāṇam hetu samuppanna nti ādinā sabba padāni vitthāretabbāni
translated: All the other terms should be expanded in the same way, namely, “formations are a cause, consciousness is caused” and so on.🔽“Briefly”: here ignorance, etc., and consciousness, etc., are the brief ;

original: Saṃkhippanti ettha avijjādayo, viññāṇādayo cāti saṅkhepo, hetu, vipāko ca. Hetu vipākoti
analyzed: ettha avijjā ādayaḥ viññāṇa ādayaḥ ca ati saṅkhepaḥ hetu vipāko ca hetu vipāko ti
translated: the cause and the result are the brief ;

original: vā saṃkhippatīti saṅkhepo, avijjādayo viññāṇādayo ca. Saṅkhepabhāvasāmaññena pana
analyzed: vā saṃkhippati iti saṅkhepaḥ avijjā ādayo viññāṇa ādayo ca saṅkhepa bhāva sāmaññena pana
translated: or the cause and the result are the brief , and ignorance, etc., and consciousness, etc., are the brief . But the singular number in “the brief ” should be understood to be used because of the similarity of the brief state in all cases.

original: ekavacanaṃ katanti daṭṭhabbaṃ. Te pana saṅkhepā atīte hetu, etarahi vipāko, etarahi
analyzed: eka vacanam katam ti daṭṭhabbam te pana saṅkhepāḥ atīte hetu etarahi vipākaḥ etarahi
translated: And these brief states are the cause in the past, the result in the present, and the cause again in the future.

original: hetu, āyatiṃ vipākoti evaṃ kālavibhāgena cattāro jātā. Tenāha “purimasaṅkhepo cettha
analyzed: hetu āyatim evam kāla vibhāgena cattāraḥ jātā tena āha purima saṅkhepaḥ ca ittha
translated: and the cause, which is the future result. Thus they are fourfold by way of the division of time. Therefore it is said: “The first summary here is the past, the far shore.”

original: atīto addhā”tiādi. Saṅkhepa-saddo vā bhāgādhivacananti atīto hetubhāgo paṭhamo saṅkhepo.
analyzed: atītaḥ addhā atiādi saṅkhepa saddo vā bhāga adhivacananti atītaḥ hetu bhāgaḥ paṭhamo saṅkhepo
translated: Or the word “summary” is a term for a part. Thus the past part, which is the cause, is the first summary.

original: Esa nayo sesesupi. Taṇhupādānabhavā gahitāva honti kilesakammabhāvasāmaññato, tehi
analyzed: esa nayo sesesu pi taṇhu pādāna bhavāḥ gahitā ava honti kilesa kamma bhāva sāmaññato tehi
translated: The same method applies to the rest. Craving, grasping, and becoming are included because they are similar to the defilements and kamma,

original: vinā avijjāsaṅkhārānaṃ sakiccākaraṇato ca. Kammaṃ taṇhā ca tassa sahakārīkāraṇaṃ
analyzed: vinā avijjā saṅkhārānam sa kicca akaraṇato ca kammam taṇhā ca tassa sahakārīkāraṇam
translated: and because ignorance and formations cannot perform their functions without them. Kamma and craving are the co-operating conditions for becoming.

original: hutvā vaṭṭanatthena kammavaṭṭaṃ.
analyzed: hutvā vaṭṭana atthena kammavaṭṭam
translated: The round of kamma is so called because it revolves by burning.

original: Viññāṇanāmarūpasaḷāyatanaphassavedanānaṃ jātijarābhaṅgāvatthā “jātijarāmaraṇa”nti
analyzed: viññāṇa nāma rūpa saṅgāyatana phassa vedanānam jāti jarā bhaṅga avatthāḥ jāti jarā maraṇanti
translated: The states of birth, ageing, and death of consciousness, mentality-materiality, the sixfold base, contact, and feeling are called “birth, ageing, and death.”

original: vuttāti āha “jātijarāmaraṇāpadesena viññāṇādīnaṃ niddiṭṭhattā”ti. Imeti viññāṇādayo.
analyzed: vuttā iti āha jāti jarā maraṇa apadesena viññāṇa ādīnam niddiṭṭha ttā ti ime ti viññāṇa ādayaḥ
translated: Therefore it is said: “Because consciousness and the rest are indicated by the words ‘birth, ageing, and death.’ ” These are consciousness and the rest.

original: Āyatiṃ vipākavaṭṭaṃ paccuppannahetuto bhāvīnaṃ anāgatānaṃ gahitattā. Teti avijjādayo.
analyzed: āyatim vipāka vaṭṭam paccuppanna hetutaḥ bhāvīnam anāgatānam gahita ttā te iti avijja ādayaḥ
translated: The future round of results is included because the future states that will arise from the present cause are included. These are ignorance and the rest.

original: Ākāratoti sarūpato avuttāpi tasmiṃ tasmiṃ saṅgahe ākirīyanti avijjāsaṅkhārādiggahaṇehi
analyzed: ākārato ti sarūpataḥ a vuttā api tasmin tasmin saṅgahe avijjā saṅkhāra ādi gahaṇehi
translated: As to manner: although not stated in the actual nature of the aggregates, they are collected in this or that aggregate, and so they are manifested by the inclusion of ignorance, formations, and so on.

original: pakāsīyantīti ākārā, atītahetuādīnaṃ vā pakārā ākārā, tato ākārato. Vīsatividhā honti
analyzed: ākārāḥ vā pakārāḥ ākārāḥ tatas ākārataḥ vīsatividhāḥ honti
translated: Or the modes are the modes of the past cause, etc.; as to manner: they are of twenty kinds,

original: atītehetupañcakādibhedato.🔽Saṅkhāraviññāṇānaṃ antarā eko sandhīti hetuto phalassa avicchedappavattibhāvato hetuphalasambandhabhūto
analyzed: atīte hetu pañcaka ādi bhedataḥ  saṅkhāra viññāṇānaṃ antarā ekaḥ sandhi iti hetuto phalassa aviccheda pavatti bhāvataḥ hetu phala sambandha bhūto
translated: as past-cause pentad, etc.🔽There is one link between formations and consciousness, because the occurrence of the effect is not cut off from the cause.

original: eko sandhi. Tathā bhavajātīnamantarā. Vedanātaṇhānamantarā pana phalato hetuno avicchedappavattibhāvato
analyzed: tathā bhava jātīnam antarā vedanā taṇhānam antarā pana phalataḥ hetuno a viccheda pavatti bhāvato
translated: So the link between cause and effect is one. Likewise there is one between becoming and birth. But there is one link between feeling and craving, because the occurrence of the cause is not cut off from the effect.

original: phalahetusambandhabhūto eko sandhi. Phalabhūtopi hi dhammo aññassa hetusabhāvassa🔽dhammassa paccayo hotīti.
analyzed: phala hetu sambandha bhūtaḥ ekaḥ sandhi phala bhūtaḥ api hi dhammo aññassa hetu sabhāvassa  dhammassa paccayaḥ hoti iti
translated: So the link between effect and cause is one. For a state that is an effect is a condition for a state that is a cause.🔽Thus: he defines the aggregates by way of the aggregates’ own characteristics, etc.

original: Itīti vuttappakāraparāmasanaṃ. Tenāha “catusaṅkhepa”ntiādi. Sabbākāratoti idha vuttehi,
analyzed: iti iti vutta ppakāra parāmasanam tena āha catu saṅkhepa ntiādi sabba ākārataḥ ti idha vuttehi
translated: As to all aspects: here the twenty kinds are stated,

original: avuttehi ca paṭiccasamuppādavibhaṅge, anantanayasamantapaṭṭhānādīsu ca āgatehi sabbehi
analyzed: avuttehi ca paṭiccasamuppāda vibhaṅge ananta naya samanta paṭṭhāna ādīsu ca āgatehi sabbehi
translated: but in the Dependent Origination in detail, in the “Endless Circle,” in the “Intermeshing of the Factors,” etc., they are stated in all aspects, both by way of what is stated and what is unstated.

original: ākārehi. Jānātīti avabujjhati. Passatīti dassanabhūtena ñāṇacakkhunā paccakkhato🔽passati. Aññāti paṭivijjhatīti tesaṃyeva vevacanaṃ. Tanti taṃ jānanaṃ. Ñātaṭṭhenāti
analyzed: ākārehi jānāti iti avabujjhati passati iti dassana bhūtena ñāṇa cakkhunā paccakkhataḥ  passati aññā ati paṭivijjhati iti tesam yeva vevacanam tam ti tam jānanam ñāta ṭṭhena ati
translated: He knows: he understands. He sees: he sees with the eye of knowledge that is the state of seeing.🔽He understands: he penetrates. These are synonyms for the same thing. That knowledge: that knowledge of the way things are.

original: yathāsabhāvato jānanaṭṭhena. Pajānanaṭṭhenāti aniccādīhi pakārehi paṭivijjhanaṭṭhena.
analyzed: yathā sabhāvataḥ jānana ṭhena pajānana ṭṭhena ati anicca ādīhi pakārehi paṭivijjhana ṭṭhena
translated: The meaning of knowing: the meaning of knowing according to the specific nature. The meaning of understanding: the meaning of penetrating by way of the aspects of impermanence, etc.

original: Idāni yadatthamidaṃ bhavacakkaṃ idhānītaṃ, taṃ dassetuṃ “iminā”tiādi vuttaṃ. Tattha
analyzed: idāni yad attham idam bhava cakkam idha ānītam tam dassetum iminā atiādi vuttam tattha
translated: Now, in order to show the purpose for which the wheel of existence is brought in here, it is said: “By this … he destroys … .” Herein,

original: te dhammeti te avijjādike dhamme. Yathābhūtaṃ ñatvāti mahāvajirañāṇena yāthāvato
analyzed: te dhamme iti te avijjā ādike dhamme yathābhūtam ñatvā ati mahā vajira ñāṇena yāthāvato
translated: those ideas: those ideas beginning with ignorance. Having known as they really are: having known by means of the great-sword knowledge according to actuality.

original: jānitvā. Nibbindanto balavavipassanāya virajjanto vimuccanto ariyamaggehi are hanīti
analyzed: jānitvā nibbindantaḥ balava vipassanāya virajjantaḥ vimuccantaḥ ariya maggehi are hani iti
translated: Disenchanting, dispassioning, and liberating: by means of strong insight he is disenchanting, dispassioning, and liberating by means of the noble paths.

original: yojanā. Tattha yadā bhagavā virajjati vimuccati, tadā are hanati nāma. Tato paraṃ
analyzed: yojanā yadā bhagavā virajjati vimuccati tadā are hanati nāma tatas param
translated: He destroys: the construction is this. Herein, when the Blessed One is disenchanting, dispassioning, and liberating, then he is said to be destroying.

original: pana abhisambuddhakkhaṇaṃ gahetvā vuttaṃ “hani vihani viddhaṃsesī”ti.
analyzed: pana abhisambuddha kkhaṇam gahetvā vuttam hani vihani viddhaṃsesi iti
translated: After that, however, it is said: “He has destroyed, quite destroyed, quite demolished” , taking the moment of his full enlightenment .

original: 129. Cakkavattino acetane cakkaratane uppanne tattheva loko pūjaṃ karoti, aññattha🔽pūjāvisesā pacchijjanti, kimaṅgaṃ pana sammāsambuddhe uppanneti dassento “uppanne🔽tathāgate”tiādimāha. Ko pana vādo aññesaṃ pūjāvisesānanti yathāvuttato aññesaṃ amahesakkhehi
analyzed: cakkavattino acetane cakkaratane uppanne tattha iva loko pūjam karoti aññattha  pūjā visesā pacchijjanti kim aṅgam pana sammāsambuddhe uppannā iti dassento uppanne  tathāgata itiādim āha kaḥ pana vādaḥ aññesam pūjā visesānam ti yathā vuttataḥ aññesam amahesakkhehi
translated: When the wheel-treasure appears, the world worships it there, and the other kinds of worship are eclipsed. How much more so when the Fully Enlightened One appears? Showing this, he said “When the Tathāgata appears” . And what need is there to speak of other kinds of worship?🔽

original: devamanussehi kariyamānānaṃ nātiuḷārānaṃ pūjāvisesānaṃ arahabhāve kā nāma kathā.
analyzed: deva manussehi kariyamānānam na ati uḷārānam pūjā visesānam araha bhāve kā nāma kathā
translated: When the inanimate Wheel-Treasure appears to a Wheel-turning Monarch, the world worships it right there, and other kinds of worship are eclipsed. How much more so when a Perfect Buddha appears? Showing this, he said ‘When a Perfect One appears’ . And what need is there to speak of other kinds of worship? There is no need to speak of other kinds of worship that are not very great and are performed by gods and men of no great distinction.

original: Atthānurūpanti arahattatthassa anurūpaṃ anvatthaṃ.🔽130. Asilokabhayenāti akittibhayena. Raho pāpaṃ karonti “mā naṃ koci jaññā”ti esa🔽bhagavā na kadāci karoti pāpahetūnaṃ bodhimaṇḍe eva suppahīnattā. Aparo nayo – ārakāti
analyzed: attha anurūpam ti arahatta atthassa anurūpam anvattham  asi loka bhayena ati akitti bhayena raho pāpam karonti mā nam koci jaññāti esa  bhagavā na kadāci karoti pāpa hetūnam bodhimaṇḍe eva su pahīna ttā aparaḥ nayaḥ ārakā ati
translated: In accordance with the meaning: in accordance with the meaning of worthiness.

original: arahaṃ, suvidūrabhāvatoicceva attho. Kuto pana suvidūrabhāvatoti? Ye abhāvitakāyā
analyzed: araham su vidūra bhāvato iccā iva attho kuto pana su vidūra bhāvato ti ye abhāvita kāyā
translated: Out of fear of a bad report: out of fear of infamy. People who do evil secretly think ‘Let no one know me.’ But the Blessed One never does so. Because the causes for evil have been quite abandoned by him at the very moment of his enlightenment. Another method: He is far away , thus he is worthy . The meaning is that he is very far away. But how is he very far away?🔽He is far away from those who have not developed the body,

original: abhāvitasīlā abhāvitacittā abhāvitapaññā, tato eva appahīnarāgadosamohā ariyadhammassa
analyzed: abhāvita sīlā abhāvita cittā abhāvita paññā tatas eva appahīna rāga dosa mohā ariya dhammassa
translated: and their virtue, concentration, and wisdom have not been developed, and they have not abandoned lust, hate, and delusion in regard to the five aggregates as objects of clinging,

original: akovidā ariyadhamme avinītā ariyadhammassa adassāvino appaṭipannā micchāpaṭipannā
analyzed: akovidāḥ ariya dhamme avinītāḥ ariya dhammassa a dassāvinaḥ appaṭipannāḥ micchāpaṭipannāḥ
translated: and they are unskilled in the noble Dhamma and undisciplined in the noble Dhamma, and they have not seen the noble truths and are untrained in the noble Dhamma, and they are practising wrongly and perversely,

original: ca, tato suvidūrabhāvato. Vuttañhetaṃ bhagavatā –
analyzed: ca tatas su vidūra bhāvataḥ vuttam ha etam bhagavatā
translated: then they are far from me, and I am far from them. For this is said:

original: “Saṅghāṭikaṇṇecepi me, bhikkhave, bhikkhu gahetvā piṭṭhito piṭṭhito anubandho assa🔽pāde pādaṃ nikkhipanto, so ca hoti abhijjhālu kāmesu tibbasārāgo byāpannacitto paduṭṭhamanasaṅkappo
analyzed: me bhikkhave bhikkhu gahetvā piṭṭhitaḥ piṭṭhitaḥ anubandhaḥ assa  pāde pādam nikkhipanto so ca hoti abhijjhālu kāmesu tibba sārāgaḥ byāpanna cittaḥ paduṭṭha mana saṅkappo
translated: “Monks, if a monk were to take hold of the corner of my outer robe and follow right behind me,

original: muṭṭhassati asampajāno asamāhito vibbhantacitto pākatindriyo. Atha kho so ārakāva
analyzed: muṭṭhaḥ sati asampajānaḥ asamāhitaḥ vibbhanta cittaḥ pākatindriyaḥ atha kho saḥ ārakāva
translated: and if he were covetous, full of lust, with a mind of malice, corrupt in the ways of mind, forgetful, lacking in clear comprehension, unconcentrated, with a wandering mind, and with faculties uncontrolled,

original: mayhaṃ, ahañca tassa. Taṃ kissa hetu? Dhammaṃ hi so, bhikkhave, bhikkhu na passati,
analyzed: mayham aham ca tassa tam kissa hetu dhammam hi saḥ bhikkhave bhikkhu na passati
translated: then he would be far from me, and I from him. And why is that? Because, monks, that monk does not see the Dhamma.

original: dhammaṃ apassanto maṃ na passatī”ti.
analyzed: dhammaṃ a passantaḥ mama na passati iti
translated: Not seeing the Dhamma, he does not see me.”

original: Yathāvuttapuggalā hi sacepi sāyaṃ pātaṃ satthu santikāvacarāva siyuṃ, na te tāvatā “satthu santikā”ti vattabbā, tathā satthāpi nesaṃ. Iti asappurisānaṃ ārakā dūreti arahaṃ.
analyzed: yathā vutta puggalāḥ hi sace pi sāyam pātam satthu santikā avacarāva siyum na te tāvatā satthu santikā ati vattabbā tathā satthā api na īsam iti asappurisānam ārakā dūrā iti araham
translated: For even if such persons were to live with the Master day and night, still they could not be called “living with the Master,” nor could the Master be called “living with them.” So he is “worthy” in the sense of being far from bad persons.🔽“They who are low in aspiration

original: “Sammā na paṭipajjanti, ye nihīnāsayā narā;
analyzed: sammā na paṭipajjanti ye nihīna āsayā narā
translated: Do not practice rightly;🔽The Blessed One is far from them,

original: Ārakā tehi bhagavā, dūre tenārahaṃ mato”ti.
analyzed: ārakā bhagavā dūre
translated: So he is reckoned “worthy” .

original: Tathā ārakāti arahaṃ, āsannabhāvatoti attho. Kuto pana āsannabhāvatoti? Ye bhāvitakāyā🔽bhāvitasīlā bhāvitacittā bhāvitapaññā, tato eva pahīnarāgadosamohā ariyadhammassa
analyzed: tathā ārakā ati araham āsanna bhāvato ti attho kutas pana āsanna bhāvato ti ye bhāvita kāyā  bhāvita sīlā bhāvita cittā bhāvita paññā tatas eva pahīna rāga dosa mohā ariya dhammassa
translated: And likewise he is “worthy” in the sense of being near. In what sense is he near? He is near to those who have developed their bodies,

original: kovidā ariyadhamme suvinītā ariyadhammassa dassāvino sammāpaṭipannā, tato āsannabhāvato.
analyzed: kovidāḥ ariya dhamme su vinītāḥ ariya dhammassa dassāvinaḥ sammā paṭipannāḥ tatas āsanna bhāvato
translated: developed their virtue, developed their cognizance, developed their understanding, and thereby have abandoned lust, hate and delusion, who are skilled in the ariyan Dhamma, well trained in the ariyan Dhamma, who are the Blessed One’s witnesses and messengers, and who practice in accordance with the Dhamma.

original: Vuttampi cetaṃ bhagavatā –
analyzed: vuttam pi ca itam bhagavatā
translated: And this is said by the Blessed One:

original: “Yojanasate cepi me, bhikkhave, bhikkhu vihareyya, so ca hoti anabhijjhālu kāmesu
analyzed: yojana sate ce ipi me bhikkhave bhikkhu vihareyya saḥ ca hoti kāmesu
translated: “Bhikkhus, even if a bhikkhu were to live a hundred leagues away, if he is greedy for sensual desires,

original: na tibbasārāgo abyāpannacitto appaduṭṭhamanasaṅkappo upaṭṭhitassati sampajāno samāhito🔽ekaggacitto saṃvutindriyo. Atha kho so santikeva mayhaṃ, ahañca tassa. Taṃ kissa
analyzed: na tibba sārāgaḥ a byāpanna cittaḥ appaduṭṭha mana saṅkappaḥ upaṭṭhita sati sampajānaḥ samāhitaḥ  ekagga cittaḥ saṃvuta indriyaḥ atha kho saḥ santikā iva mayham aham ca tassa tam kissa
translated: not with strong lust, not with a mind of ill will, not with a mind of cruelty, but with mindfulness established, with full awareness, with a mind of good will, with a mind of loving-kindness.

original: hetu? Dhammaṃ hi so, bhikkhave, bhikkhu passati, dhammaṃ passanto maṃ passatī”ti.
analyzed: hetu dhammam hi saḥ bhikkhave bhikkhu passati dhammam passantaḥ mama passati iti
translated: Then he is near to me, and I to him. And why is that? Because, bhikkhus, that bhikkhu sees Dhamma, and he who sees Dhamma sees me.”

original: Tathārūpā hi puggalā satthu yojanasahassantarikāpi honti, na tāvatā te “satthu dūracārino”ti vattabbā, tathā satthāpi nesaṃ. Iti sappurisānaṃ ārakā āsanneti arahaṃ.
analyzed: tathārūpāḥ hi satthu yojana sahassa antarikā api honti na tāvatā te satthu dūra cārino ti vattabbā tathā satthā api na isam iti sappurisānam ārakā āsannā iti arahaṃ
translated: For such persons are a thousand leagues away from the Teacher, yet they are not to be called “those who live far away from the Teacher,” nor is the Teacher to be called “far away” from them. Thus the Accomplished One is “far away” from bad persons and “near” to good persons.

original: Ye sammā paṭipajjanti, suppaṇītādhimuttikā;
analyzed: ye sammā paṭipajjanti su paṇīta adhimuttikā
translated: Those who practice rightly, who are intent on what is well proclaimed,

original: Ārakā tehi āsanne, tenāpi arahaṃ jino.
analyzed: ārakā tehi āsanne tena api araham jino
translated: Are far from them, and near to them; thus the Victor is the Accomplished One.

original: Ye ime rāgādayo pāpadhammā yasmiṃ santāne uppajjanti, tassa diṭṭhadhammikampi samparāyikampi
analyzed: ye ime rāga ādayaḥ pāpa dhammāḥ yasmin santāne uppajjanti tassa diṭṭhadhammikam pi samparāyikam pi
translated: These bad things, lust, etc., which arise in a given continuity bring misfortune both in this world and in the next.

original: anatthaṃ āvahanti. Nibbānagāminiyā paṭipadāya ekaṃseneva ujuvipaccanīkabhūtā ca,
analyzed: anattham āvahanti nibbāna gāminiyā paṭipadāya ekaṃsena iva uju vipaccanīka bhūtā ca
translated: And they are directly opposed to the way leading to Nibbāna.

original: te attahitaṃ, parahitañca paripūretuṃ sammā paṭipajjantehi sādhūhi dūrato rahitabbā🔽pariccajitabbā pahātabbāti rahā nāma, te ca yasmā bhagavato bodhimūleyeva ariyamaggena
analyzed: te atta hitam para hitam ca paripūretum sammā paṭipajjantehi sādhūhi dūratas rahitabbā  pariccajitabbā pahātabbā iti rahā nāma te ca yasmai bhagavataḥ bodhi mūleya iva ariya maggena
translated: They should be avoided from afar by good people who are rightly practising for the sake of their own welfare and the welfare of others.🔽They should be abandoned, given up, done away with. Thus ‘rahā’ means ‘to be avoided’. And because they were completely abandoned by the Blessed One at the foot of the Bodhi Tree by means of the Noble Path,

original: sabbaso pahīnā samucchinnā. Yathāha –
analyzed: sabbaso pahīnā samucchinnā yathā āha
translated: as it is said:

original: “Tathāgatassa kho, brāhmaṇa, rāgo pahīno doso moho, sabbepi pāpakā akusalā dhammā pahīnā ucchinnamūlā tālāvatthukatā anabhāvaṃkatā āyatiṃ anuppādadhammā”ti.
analyzed: tathāgatassa kho brāhmaṇa rāgaḥ pahīnaḥ dosaḥ mohaḥ sabbe api pāpakā akusalā dhammā pahīnā ucchinna mūlā tālāvatthukatā anabhāvaṃkatā āyatim an uppāda dhammā ti
translated: “Brahmin, the Tathagata has abandoned passion, hatred, and delusion; all bad and unwholesome states have been abandoned by him, cut off at the root, made like a palm stump, done away with so that they are no longer subject to future arising” .

original: Tasmā sabbaso na santi etassa rahāti arahoti vattabbe okārassa sānusāraṃ a-kārādesaṃ katvā “araha”nti vuttaṃ.
analyzed: tasmā sabbasas na santi etassa rahā ati arahā iti vattabbe okārassa sa anusāram akāra ādesam katvā arahā iti vuttam
translated: Therefore, because they are completely non-existent in him, he is to be called ‘arahant’ . But the vowel a of the first syllable has been changed to o in accordance with the rule:🔽“The vowel a becomes o before the consonants r and h” .

original: Pāpadhammā rahā nāma, sādhūhi rahitabbato;
analyzed: pāpa dhammā rahā nāma sādhūhi rahitabbataḥ
translated: Bad states are called ‘rahā’ because they are to be avoided by good people;

original: Tesaṃ suṭṭhu pahīnattā, bhagavā arahaṃ mato.
analyzed: tesam suṭṭhu pahīna ttā bhagavā araham mataḥ
translated: The Blessed One is considered an arahant because they are well abandoned by him.

original: Ye te sabbaso pariññātakkhandhā pahīnakilesā bhāvitamaggā sacchikatanirodhā arahanto
analyzed: ye te sabbaso pariññāta kkhandhāḥ pahīna kilesāḥ bhāvita maggāḥ sacchikata nirodhāḥ arahantaḥ
translated: Those who have completely understood the aggregates, abandoned the defilements, developed the path, and realized cessation, are arahants.

original: khīṇāsavā, ye ca sekkhā appattamānasā anuttaraṃ yogakkhemaṃ patthayamānā viharanti,
analyzed: khīṇa āsavāḥ ye ca sekkhāḥ appatta mānasāḥ anuttaram yogakkhemam patthayamānāḥ viharanti
translated: and those who are in training, who have not attained their heart’s ideal, who dwell aspiring for the unsurpassed security from bondage,

original: ye ca parisuddhapayogā kalyāṇajjhāsayā saddhāsīlasutādiguṇasampannā puggalā, tehi
analyzed: ye ca parisuddha payogā kalyāṇa ajjhāsayā saddhā sīla suta ādi guṇa sampannā puggalā tehi
translated: and those who are of purified livelihood, of good disposition, who are endowed with faith, virtue, learning, generosity, and wisdom,

original: na rahitabbo na pariccajitabbo, te ca bhagavatāti arahaṃ. Tathā hi ariyapuggalā satthārā
analyzed: na rahitabbaḥ na pariccajitabbaḥ te ca bhagavatā ati araham tathā hi ariya puggalā satthārā
translated: they should not be abandoned, they should not be rejected. And the Blessed One is so. For the noble persons

original: diṭṭhadhammassa paccakkhakaraṇato satthu dhammasarīrena avirahitā eva honti. Yathāha āyasmā piṅgiyo –
analyzed: diṭṭhadhammassa paccakkha karaṇataḥ satthu dhamma sarīrena avirahitāḥ eva honti yathā āha āyasmā piṅgiyaḥ
translated: are not separated from the Master’s Dhamma body by seeing the visible-data object. As it is said by the venerable Piṅgiyānī:

original: “Passāmi naṃ manasā cakkhunāva,
analyzed: passāmi nam manasā cakkhunā ava
translated: “I see him with the mind as with the eye,

original: Rattindivaṃ brāhmaṇa appamatto;
analyzed: rattindivam brāhmaṇa appamatto
translated: Ever mindful, O brahmin, day and night.

original: Namassamāno vivasemi rattiṃ,
analyzed: namassamānaḥ vivasemi rattim
translated: I spend the night in worship of him,

original: Teneva maññāmi avippavāsaṃ.
analyzed: tena iva maññāmi a vippavāsam
translated: And so I think I am not far from him.

original: “Saddhā ca pīti ca mano sati ca,
analyzed: saddhā ca pīti ca manaḥ sati ca
translated: “Faith, rapture, mind, and mindfulness,

original: Nāpentime gotamasāsanamhā;
analyzed: na apenti ime gotama sāsanamhā
translated: These do not leave me, Gotama’s disciple.

original: Yaṃ yaṃ disaṃ vajati bhūripañño,
analyzed: yam yam disam vajati bhūri paññaḥ
translated: Whichever way the wise one goes,

original: Sa tena teneva natohamasmī”ti. ;
analyzed: sa tena tena iva nataḥ ham asmi iti
translated: In that direction I bow down.”

original: Teneva ca te aññaṃ satthāraṃ na uddisanti. Yathāha –
analyzed: tena iva ca te aññam satthāram na uddisanti yathā āha
translated: And for that reason they do not take another teacher. As it is said:

original: “Aṭṭhānametaṃ, bhikkhave, anavakāso, yaṃ diṭṭhisampanno puggalo aññaṃ satthāraṃ uddiseyyāti netaṃ ṭhānaṃ vijjatī”ti.🔽Kalyāṇaputhujjanāpi yebhuyyena satthari niccalasaddhā eva honti. Iti suppaṭipannehi
analyzed: aṭṭhānam etam bhikkhave anavakāsaḥ yam diṭṭhi sampannaḥ puggalaḥ aññam satthāram uddiseyya ati na itam ṭhānam vijjati iti  kalyāṇa puthujjana api yebhuyyena satthari niccala saddhāḥ eva honti iti suppaṭipannehi
