translated: “Monks, it is impossible that a person possessed of right view should seek another teacher, there is no such possibility.”

original: purisavisesehi avirahitabbato, tesañca avirahanato na santi etassa rahā pariccajanakā,
analyzed: purisa visesehi avirahitabbataḥ tesam ca avirahanataḥ na santi etassa rahā pariccajanakā
translated: Even good worldlings are for the most part unshakably faithful to the Master. So the Blessed One is not to be forsaken by those who have entered upon the way to distinction,

original: natthi vā etassa raho sādhūhi pariccajitabbatāti arahaṃ.
analyzed: natthi vai etassa rahaḥ sādhūhi pariccajitabba tā ati araham
translated: and he does not forsake them. Therefore he is the one “not to be forsaken by the good.”🔽Those who have realized the true Dhamma,

original: “Ye sacchikatasaddhammā, ariyā suddhagocarā;
analyzed: ye sacchikata saddhammā ariyā suddha gocarā
translated: The noble ones whose range is pure,🔽Are never forsaken by them,

original: Na tehi rahito hoti, nātho tenārahaṃ mato”ti.
analyzed: na tehi rahitaḥ hoti tena araham matoti
translated: So the Master is esteemed as “not to be forsaken by the good.”

original: Rahoti ca gamanaṃ vuccati, bhagavato ca nānāgatīsu paribbhamanasaṅkhātaṃ saṃsāre🔽gamanaṃ natthi kammakkhayakarena ariyamaggena bodhimūleyeva sabbaso sasambhārassa
analyzed: raho ti ca gamanam vuccati bhagavato ca nānā gatīsu paribbhamana saṅkhātam saṃsāre  gamanam natthi kamma khaya karena ariya maggena bodhi mūleya iva sabbaso sa sambhārassa
translated: “Going” is said to be “forsaking.” But the Blessed One has no “going” in the various existences, that is to say, no wandering in saṃsāra,🔽because at the foot of the Bodhi Tree he completely destroyed with the noble path that ends action the round of kamma and its result together with the underlying tendencies,

original: kammavaṭṭassa viddhaṃsitattā. Yathāha –
analyzed: kamma vaṭṭassa yathā āha
translated: as it is said:🔽“By which one might be reborn as a god,

original: “Yena devūpapatyassa, gandhabbo vā vihaṅgamo;
analyzed: yena deva upapatyassa gandhabbaḥ vā vihaṅgamaḥ
translated: Or as a gandhabba or a bird,

original: Yakkhattaṃ yena gaccheyyaṃ, manussattañca abbaje;🔽Te mayhaṃ āsavā khīṇā, viddhastā vinaḷīkatā”ti. ;
analyzed: yakkhattam yena gaccheyyam manussattam ca abbaje  te mayham āsavā khīṇāḥ vid hastāḥ vinaḷīka tā ati
translated: I’d go to the state of a ghost, or I’d fall to the state of a human being.

original: Evaṃ natthi etassa rahogamanaṃ gatīsu paccājātītipi arahaṃ.
analyzed: evam na atthi etassa rahogamanam gatīsu araham
translated: But my effluents are ended, destroyed, uprooted, and eradicated, so that they will not arise again in the future.”🔽Thus he is worthy of a secluded lodging in the present life, and he is worthy of the non-returning that is his future destination.

original: Raho vā gamanaṃ yassa, saṃsāre natthi sabbaso;
analyzed: rahaḥ vā gamanam yassa saṃsāre na atthi sabbaso
translated: He has no secluded lodging in the round,

original: Pahīnajātimaraṇo, arahaṃ sugato mato.
analyzed: pahīna jāti maraṇaḥ araham sugataḥ mataḥ
translated: having abandoned birth and death, he is worthy, gone to heaven.

original: Pāsaṃsattā vā bhagavā arahaṃ. Akkharacintakā hi pasaṃsāyaṃ araha-saddaṃ vaṇṇenti.🔽Pāsaṃsabhāvo ca bhagavato anaññasādhāraṇo yathābhuccaguṇādhigato sadevake loke suppatiṭṭhito.
analyzed: pāsaṃsattā vā bhagavā araham akkhara cintakāḥ hi pasaṃsāyam araha saddam vaṇṇenti  pāsaṃsa bhāvaḥ ca bhagavataḥ anañña sādhāraṇaḥ yathābhucca guṇa adhigato sa devake loke suppatiṭṭhito
translated: Or else he is worthy of praise, for those who analyze the words praise him with the word “worthy.”

original: Tathā hesa anuttarena sīlena anuttarena samādhinā anuttarāya paññāya anuttarāya vimuttiyā🔽asamo asamasamo appaṭimo appaṭibhāgo appaṭipuggaloti evaṃ tasmiṃ tasmiṃ guṇe vibhajitvā🔽vuccamāne paṇḍitapurisehi devehi brahmehi bhagavatā vā pana pariyosāpetuṃ asakkuṇeyyarūpo.
analyzed: tathā ha isa anuttarena sīlena anuttarena samādhinā anuttarāya paññāya anuttarāya vimuttiyā 🔽asamaḥ asamasamaḥ appaṭimaḥ appaṭibhāgaḥ appaṭipuggalaḥ ti evam tasmin tasmin guṇe vibhajitvā 🔽vuccamāne paṇḍita purisehi devehi brahmehi bhagavatā vā pana pariyosāpetum asakkuṇeyya rūpaḥ
translated: And the Blessed One’s worthiness of praise is not shared by anyone else. It is attained through his qualities as they actually are, and it is well-established in the cosmos with its gods.

original: Iti pāsaṃsattāpi bhagavā arahaṃ.
analyzed: iti bhagavā arahan
translated: So the Blessed One is worthy of praise because of being a Worthy One.

original: Guṇehi sadiso natthi, yasmā loke sadevake;
analyzed: guṇehi sadisaḥ na atthi yasmā loke sa devake
translated: Since there is no equal to him in the world with its deities,

original: Tasmā pāsaṃsiyattāpi, arahaṃ dvipaduttamo.
analyzed: araham dvipad uttamaḥ
translated: Therefore he is worthy of praise because of being worthy, the most excellent of bipeds.

original: Evaṃ sabbathāpi –🔽“Ārakā mandabuddhīnaṃ, ārakā ca vijānataṃ;
analyzed: evam sabbathā api  ārakā manda buddhīnam ārakā ca vijānatam
translated: So in all ways🔽He is far from the foolish, and he is far from the ignorant,

original: Rahānaṃ suppahīnattā, vidūnamaraheyyato;
analyzed: rahānam su ppahīna ttā vidūnam araheyyataḥ
translated: Because of his abandonment of the faring on, and because of his worthiness of worship by the wise,

original: Bhavesu ca rahābhāvā, pāsaṃsā arahaṃ jino”ti.🔽131. Sammāti aviparītaṃ. Sāmanti sayameva. Sambuddhoti hi ettha saṃ-saddo “saya”nti
analyzed: bhavesu ca pāsaṃsāḥ araham jinoti  sammā iti aviparītam sāmanti sayam eva sambuddhaḥ ti hi ettha saṃsaddaḥ sayanti
translated: And because of his absence of faring on in the kinds of becoming, the Victor is worthy of praise.

original: etassa atthassa bodhako daṭṭhabbo. Sabbadhammānanti anavasesānaṃ ñeyyadhammānaṃ.
analyzed: etassa atthassa bodhakaḥ daṭṭhabbaḥ sabba dhammānam ti anavasesānam ñeyya dhammānam
translated: Right: not wrong. By himself: by means of his own intuitive wisdom. For the word “self” in the sense of “own” is what is expressed by the prefix sam in the word “self-awakened” . All things: all things that can be known without exception.

original: Kathaṃ panettha sabbadhammāvabodho labbhatīti? Ekadesassa aggahaṇato. Padesaggahaṇe
analyzed: katham pana ittha sabba dhamma avabodhaḥ labbhati iti eka desassa a gahaṇato padesa ggahaṇe
translated: But how is it that the self-awakening of all things is obtained? Because of the non-apprehending of a part.

original: hi asati gahetabbassa nippadesatāva viññāyati yathā “dikkhito na dadātī”ti. Evañca
analyzed: hi asati gahetabbassa nippadesa tā ava viññāyati yathā dikkhitaḥ na dadāti iti evam ca
translated: For when there is no apprehending of a part, it is known that what is to be apprehended is partless, as in the case of the expression “The one pointed at by the finger does not give” .

original: katvā atthavisesānapekkhā kattari eva buddhasaddasiddhi veditabbā kammavacanicchāya
analyzed: katvā attha visesa anapekkhā kattari eva buddha sadda siddhi veditabbā kamma vacana icchāya
translated: And when it is put like this, it should be understood that the word “awakened” is established in the agent only, with reference to the particular meaning of “awakened to all things,” according to the rule that the verbal noun has the same meaning as the verb .

original: abhāvato. “Sammā sāmaṃ buddhattā sammāsambuddho”ti ettakameva hi idha saddato labbhati,
analyzed: abhāvataḥ sammā sāmam buddha ttā sammāsambuddhaḥ ti ettakam eva hi idha saddataḥ labbhati
translated: “As to non-existence” : only this much can be taken as to the meaning of the word “Buddha” here, namely, “He is fully enlightened as to non-existence” .

original: “sabbadhammāna”nti pana atthato labbhamānaṃ gahetvā vuttaṃ. Na hi bujjhanakiriyā avisayā yujjati.🔽Idāni tassā visayaṃ “sabbadhamme”ti sāmaññato vuttaṃ vibhajitvā dassetuṃ “abhiññeyye
analyzed: sabba dhammānam ti pana atthataḥ labbhamānam gahetvā vuttam na hi bujjhana kiriyā avisayā yujjati  idāni tassāḥ visayam sabba dhamma iti sāmaññataḥ vuttam vibhajitvā dassetum abhiññeyye
translated: But the words “as to all dhammas” are stated by taking what can be taken as to the meaning, for it is not proper that the act of enlightenment should be without an object.

original: dhamme”tiādi vuttaṃ. Tattha abhiññeyyeti abhivisiṭṭhena ñāṇena jānitabbe. Ke pana🔽teti? Catusaccadhamme. Abhiññeyyato buddhoti abhiññeyyabhāvato bujjhi. Pubbabhāge🔽vipassanāpaññāya, adhigamakkhaṇe maggapaññāya, aparabhāge sabbaññutaññāṇādīhi aññāsīti
analyzed: dhamma itiādi vuttam tattha abhiññeyyā iti abhivisiṭṭhena ñāṇena jānitabbe ke pana  te iti catu sacca dhamme abhiññeyyataḥ buddho ti abhiññeyya bhāvataḥ pubba bhāge  vipassanā paññāya adhigama kkhaṇe magga paññāya apara bhāge sabbaññuta ññāṇa ādīhi aññāsi iti
translated: Now, in order to show by analysis the object of that, which is stated in the general way as “all dhammas,” it is said “as to dhammas that can be directly known” , and so on. Herein, “as to dhammas that can be directly known” : that can be known by the knowledge called “direct knowledge” . But what are they?

original: attho. Ito paresupi eseva nayo. Pariññeyye dhammeti dukkhaṃ ariyasaccamāha. Pahātabbeti
analyzed: atthaḥ itas paresu pi esa iva nayaḥ pariññeyye dhamme ti dukkham ariya saccam āha pahātabba iti
translated: They are the four noble truths. He is enlightened as to what can be directly known: he has awakened to the fact that they can be directly known. In the earlier stage he did so by means of the understanding consisting in insight; at the moment of actual breakthrough by means of the understanding consisting in the path; and in the later stage by means of the knowledge of omniscience, etc. This is the meaning. The same method applies in each instance. “As to dhammas that can be fully understood” : he calls the noble truth of suffering. “As to dhammas that can be abandoned” : he calls the noble truth of the origin of suffering.

original: samudayapakkhiye. Sacchikātabbeti nibbānaṃ sandhāyāha. Bahuvacananiddeso pana sopādisesādikaṃ🔽pariyāyasiddhaṃ bhedaṃ gahetvā kato, uddeso vā ayaṃ catusaccadhammānanti. Tathā hi
analyzed: samudaya pakkhiye sacchikātabbā iti nibbānam sandhāya āha bahuvacana niddesaḥ pana sa upādisesa ādikam  pariyāya siddham bhedam gahetvā kataḥ uddesaḥ vā ayam tathā hi
translated: because the division is established by way of the various kinds of Nibbāna, such as that with a residue of clinging left, etc.🔽Or this heading is given in terms of the four noble Truths. For he says: “The eye is the truth of suffering,” etc.

original: vakkhati “cakkhuṃ dukkhasacca”ntiādi. Uddeso ca avinicchitatthaparicchedassa dhammassa
analyzed: vakkhati cakkhum uddeso ca avinicchita attha paricchedassa dhammassa
translated: And a heading is given in terms of a state whose meaning has not been analyzed.

original: vasena karīyati. Uddesena hi uddisiyamānānaṃ dhammānaṃ atthitāmattaṃ vuccati, na
analyzed: vasena karīyati uddesena hi uddisiyamānānam dhammānam atthi tā mattam vuccati na
translated: For when a heading is given, the mere existence of the states headed is stated, not their analysis.

original: paricchedoti aparicchedena bahuvacanena vuttaṃ yathā “appaccayā dhammā, asaṅkhatā
analyzed: paricchedaḥ ti aparicchedena bahuvacanena vuttam yathā appaccayāḥ dhammāḥ asaṅkhatā
translated: Therefore the plural is used without analysis, as in the passages: “There are unconditioned dhammas,” “There are dhammas without condition,”🔽“There are dhammas that are not the basis for contact,” “There are dhammas that are not mental” .

original: dhammā”ti. Sacchikātabbeti vā phalavimuttīnampi gahaṇaṃ, na nibbānassevāti bahuvacananiddeso
analyzed: dhammā ati sacchikātabbā iti vā phala vimuttīnam pi gahaṇam na nibbānassa iva āti bahuvacana niddesaḥ
translated: Or the plural is used because what is to be realized includes not only Nibbāna but also the fruit of liberation.

original: kato. Evañca bhāvetabbeti ettha jhānānampi gahaṇaṃ daṭṭhabbaṃ.🔽Gāthāyaṃ bhāvetabbañcāti ettha ca-saddo avuttasamuccayattho, tena sacchikātabbassa
analyzed: kataḥ evam ca bhāvetabbā iti ettha jhānānam pi gahaṇam daṭṭhabbam 🔽gāthāyam bhāvetabbam ca iti ettha ca saddo a vutta samuccaya tthaḥ tena sacchikātabbassa
translated: As to “what is to be developed,” the jhānas should be understood as included.

original: gahaṇaṃ veditabbaṃ. Tasmā buddhosmīti yasmā cattāri saccāni mayā buddhāni, saccavinimuttañca
analyzed: gahaṇam veditabbam tasmai buddhaḥ asmi iti yasmai cattāri saccāni mayā buddhāni sacca vinimuttam ca
translated: should be understood. Therefore, because the four Truths have been awakened to by me, and because I have been awakened to the Deathless which is free from the Truths,

original: kiñci ñeyyaṃ natthi, tasmā sabbampi ñeyyaṃ buddhosmi, abbhaññāsinti attho.
analyzed: kiñci ñeyyam na atthi tasmā sabbam pi ñeyyam buddhaḥ asmi abbhaññāsin ti attho
translated: and the apprehending should be understood. Therefore, since the four Truths have been awakened to by me, and there is nothing knowable that is free from the Truths, therefore I am awakened to all that is knowable. The meaning is: I have awakened to.

original: 132. Evaṃ saccavasena sāmaññato vuttamatthaṃ dvārārammaṇehi saddhiṃ dvārappavattadhammehi,🔽khandhādīhi ca saccavaseneva vibhajitvā dassetuṃ “api cā”tiādi āraddhaṃ. Tattha mūlakāraṇabhāvenāti
analyzed: evam sacca vasena sāmaññataḥ vuttam attham dvāra ārammaṇehi saddhim dvāra ppavatta dhammehi  khandha ādīhi ca sacca vasena iva vibhajitvā dassetum api ca ati ādi āraddham tattha mūla kāraṇa bhāvena ati
translated: Thus, after showing the meaning in a general way by way of the Truths, he now shows it by way of the doors, objects, and states occurring through the doors,

original: santesupi avijjādīsu aññesu kāraṇesu tesampi mūlabhūtakāraṇabhāvena. Taṇhā hi kammassa
analyzed: santesu pi avijjā ādīsu aññesu kāraṇesu tesam pi mūla bhūta kāraṇa bhāvena taṇhā hi kammassa
translated: and by way of the aggregates, etc., by way of the Truths, with the words “Moreover,” etc. Herein, as the root cause means as the cause that is the root. Although there are other causes such as ignorance, etc., craving is the root cause of those as well.

original: vicittabhāvahetuto, sahāyabhāvūpagamanato ca dukkhavicittatāya padhānakāraṇaṃ. Samuṭṭhāpikāti
analyzed: vicitta bhāva hetutaḥ sahāya bhāva upagamanataḥ ca dukkha vicitta tāya padhāna kāraṇam samuṭṭhāpikā ati
translated: For craving is the principal cause of the variety of suffering because it is the cause of the variety of kamma, and because it is the cause of the variety of suffering by becoming a companion .

original: uppādikā. Purimataṇhāti purimabhavasiddhā taṇhā. Ubhinnanti cakkhussa, taṃsamudayassa
analyzed: uppādikā purima taṇhā āti purima bhava siddhā taṇhā cakkhussa tad samudayassa
translated: Originating means giving rise to. Craving in the past means craving that has existed in a previous existence. Both means of the eye and of the arising of that .

original: ca. Appavattīti appavattinimittaṃ. Nirodhapajānanāti sacchikiriyābhisamayavasena
analyzed: ca appavatti iti appavatti nimittam nirodha pajānanā ati sacchikiriyā abhisamaya vasena
translated: ‘Non-occurrence’ is the sign of non-occurrence. ‘Understanding cessation’ is understanding cessation by way of realization.

original: nirodhassa paṭivijjhanā. Ekekapaduddhārenāti “cakkhuṃ cakkhusamudayo”tiādinā ekekakoṭṭhāsaniddhāraṇena.
analyzed: nirodhassa ekeka paduddhārena ati cakkhum cakkhu samudaya uti ādinā ekeka koṭṭhāsa niddhāraṇena
translated: ‘Non-occurrence’ is the sign of non-occurrence. ‘Understanding cessation’ is the penetration of cessation by way of realization-comprehension. ‘By the removal of each term’ is by the definition of each part, ‘Eye, origin of eye’ and so on.

original: Taṇhāyapi pariññeyyabhāvasabbhāvato, upādānakkhandhantogadhattā ca dukkhasaccasaṅgahaṃ
analyzed: pariññeyya bhāva sabbhāvataḥ ca dukkha sacca saṅgaham
translated: Because craving also has the same nature as what should be fully understood, and because it is included in the truth of suffering as a constituent of the aggregates of clinging,

original: dassetuṃ “rūpataṇhādayo cha taṇhākāyā”ti vuttaṃ.
analyzed: dassetum rūpa taṇhā ādayaḥ cha taṇhā kāyā ti vuttam
translated: it is said: ‘The six bodies of craving, beginning with craving for visible forms’ .

original: Kasiṇānīti kasiṇajjhānāni. Dvattiṃsākārāti dvattiṃsa koṭṭhāsā, tadārammaṇajjhānāni
analyzed: kasiṇāni iti kasiṇa jhānāni dvattiṃsa ākārā ati dvattiṃsa koṭṭhāsā tad ārammaṇa jhānāni
translated: ‘The kasiṇas’ are the jhānas with kasiṇas as their object. ‘Thirty-two aspects’ are the thirty-two parts and the jhānas with those as their object.

original: ca. Nava bhavāti kāmabhavādayo tayo, saññībhavādayo tayo, ekavokārabhavādayo tayoti
analyzed: ca nava kāma bhava ādayo tayo saññībhava ādayo tayo ekavokāra bhava ādayo tayo ti
translated: ‘Nine existences’ are the three kinds of existence as sense-desire, form, and formless, the three kinds of existence as percipient of unity, diversity, and not so, and the three kinds of existence as having a limited, exalted, or measureless object.

original: nava bhavā. Cattāri jhānānīti aggahitārammaṇavisesāni cattāri rūpāvacarajjhānāni,
analyzed: nava bhavā cattāri jhānāni iti aggahita ārammaṇa visesāni cattāri rūpāvacara jhānāni
translated: ‘Four jhānas’ are the four jhānas of the fine-material sphere, which are not distinguished by their special objects,

original: vipākajjhānānaṃ vā etaṃ gahaṇaṃ. Ettha ca kusaladhammānaṃ upanissayabhūtā taṇhā samuṭṭhāpikā
analyzed: vipāka jhānānam vā etam gahaṇam ettha ca kusala dhammānam upanissaya bhūtā taṇhā samuṭṭhāpikā
translated: or else it includes the resultant jhānas. And here craving, which is a condition for profitable states, is their origin.

original: purimataṇhāti veditabbā. Kiriyadhammānaṃ pana yattha te tassa attabhāvassa kāraṇabhūtā.
analyzed: purima taṇhā ti veditabbā kiriya dhammānam pana yattha te tassa atta bhāvassa kāraṇa bhūtā
translated: It should be understood as the former craving. But the things that are done are the cause of that individual existence.

original: Anubuddhoti bujjhitabbadhammassa anurūpato buddho. Tenāti tasmā. Yasmā sāmaññato,
analyzed: anubuddhaḥ ti bujjhitabba dhammassa anurūpataḥ buddhaḥ tena ati tasmai yasmai sāmaññato
translated: Enlightened: enlightened in conformity with the things to be enlightened about. For that reason: for that reason, because he is enlightened about all things by way of their general characteristics

original: visesato ca ekekapaduddhārena sabbadhamme buddho, tasmā vuttaṃ. Kinti āha “sammā🔽sāmañca sabbadhammānaṃ buddhattā”ti, sabbassapi ñeyyassa sabbākārato aviparītaṃ sayameva
analyzed: visesataḥ ca ekeka pada uddhārena sabba dhamme buddhaḥ tasmā vuttam kim ti āha sammā  sāmañca sabba dhammānam buddha ttā ati sabbassa api ñeyyassa sabba ākārataḥ aviparītam sayam eva
translated: and by way of their specific characteristics by the extraction of each individual term. Therefore it was said: “Because of his being enlightened about all things in general and in particular.”

original: abhisambuddhattāti attho. Imināssa paropadesarahitassa sabbākārena sabbadhammāvabodhanasamatthassa
analyzed: abhisambuddha ttā ti attho iminā assa para upadesa rahitassa sabba ākārena sabba dhamma avabodhana samatthassa
translated: All knowables: the meaning is, because of his being enlightened by himself, without error, in all modes, about all knowables. By this it is shown that he has attained the knowledge called “omniscience,” which is unobstructed knowledge and which occurs in accordance with desire,

original: ākaṅkhappaṭibaddhavuttino anāvaraṇañāṇasaṅkhātassa sabbaññutaññāṇassa adhigamo dassito.
analyzed: ākaṅkha paṭibaddha vuttinaḥ anāvaraṇa ñāṇa saṅkhātassa sabbaññuta ññāṇassa adhigamaḥ dassito
translated: and which is capable of penetrating to the understanding of all things in all modes without dependence on the instruction of another.🔽But is not “unobstructed knowledge” something different from “omniscience”? For it is said:

original: Nanu ca sabbaññutaññāṇato aññaṃ anāvaraṇañāṇaṃ, aññathā “cha asādhāraṇañāṇāni buddhañāṇānī”ti
analyzed: nanu ca sabbaññu tad ññāṇataḥ aññam anāvaraṇa ñāṇam aññathā cha asādhāraṇa ñāṇāni buddha ñāṇāni iti
translated: “The six kinds of knowledge not held in common

original: vacanaṃ virujjheyyāti? Na virujjhati, visayapavattibhedavasena aññehi asādhāraṇabhāvadassanatthaṃ
analyzed: vacanam virujjheyyāti na virujjhati visaya pavatti bheda vasena aññehi a sādhāraṇa bhāva dassana attham
translated: “How is it that the statement does not contradict the suttas?” It does not contradict them, because it is said in order to show that the knowledge of the Omniscient One is not shared by others, since it occurs in a different way, by way of the distinction of its object.

original: ekasseva ñāṇassa dvidhā vuttattā. Ekameva hi taṃ ñāṇaṃ anavasesasaṅkhatāsaṅkhatasammutidhammavisayatāya
analyzed: ekassa iva ñāṇassa dvidhā vutta ttā ekam eva hi tam ñāṇam anavasesa saṅkhata asaṅkhata sammuti dhamma visaya tāya
translated: For that one knowledge is called “knowledge of omniscience” because it is the object of all conditioned and unconditioned things, of all things conventional and ultimate, without exception.

original: sabbaññutaññāṇaṃ, tattha ca āvaraṇābhāvato nissaṅgacāramupādāya “anāvaraṇañāṇa”nti
analyzed: sabbaññuta ññāṇam tattha ca āvaraṇa abhāvataḥ nissaṅga cāram upādāya anāvaraṇa ñāṇam ti
translated: And because there is no obstruction in it, it is called “knowledge without obstruction” in the sense of unobstructed occurrence.

original: vuttaṃ. Yathāha paṭisambhidāyaṃ “sabbaṃ saṅkhatamasaṅkhataṃ anavasesaṃ jānātīti sabbaññutaññāṇaṃ,
analyzed: vuttam yathā āha paṭisambhidā ayam sabbam saṅkhatam asaṅkhatam anavasesam jānāti iti sabbaññuta ññāṇam
translated: As it is said in the Paṭisambhidā: “It knows all conditioned and unconditioned things without exception, thus it is knowledge of omniscience.

original: tattha āvaraṇaṃ natthīti anāvaraṇañāṇa”ntiādi. Tasmā natthi nesaṃ atthato bhedo,
analyzed: tattha āvaraṇam natthi iti anāvaraṇa ñāṇa ntiādi tasmā natthi na īsam atthatas bhedaḥ
translated: There is no obstruction in it, thus it is knowledge without obstruction” . Therefore there is no difference in meaning between the two terms.

original: ekantena cetaṃ evamicchitabbaṃ. Aññathā sabbaññutānāvaraṇañāṇānaṃ sādhāraṇatā, asabbadhammārammaṇatā
analyzed: ekantena ca itam evam icchitabbam aññathā sabbaññu tā anāvaraṇa ñāṇānam sādhāraṇa tā asabba dhamma ārammaṇa tā
translated: But this must be admitted in every way. Otherwise, the knowledge of omniscience and the knowledge without obstruction would be common to all, and they would not have as their object all dhammas.

original: ca āpajjeyya. Na hi bhagavato ñāṇassa aṇumattampi āvaraṇaṃ atthi, anāvaraṇañāṇassa
analyzed: ca āpajjeyya na hi bhagavataḥ ñāṇassa aṇumattam pi āvaraṇam atthi anāvaraṇa ñāṇassa
translated: For there is not the slightest obstruction to the knowledge of the Blessed One, and the knowledge of omniscience and the knowledge without obstruction are not common to all.

original: ca asabbadhammārammaṇabhāve yattha taṃ na pavattati, tatthāvaraṇasabbhāvato anāvaraṇabhāvoyeva🔽na siyā. Atha vā pana hotu aññameva anāvaraṇañāṇaṃ sabbaññutaññāṇato, idha pana sabbattha
analyzed: ca asabba dhamma ārammaṇa bhāve yattha tam na pavattati tattha āvaraṇa sabbhāvataḥ  na siyā atha vā pana hotu aññam eva anāvaraṇa ñāṇam sabbaññuta ññāṇato idha pana sabbattha
translated: And if it were not the object of all dhammas, it would not be the absence of obstruction in the sense of the absence of obstruction to the seeing of all dhammas.

original: appaṭihatavuttitāya anāvaraṇañāṇanti sabbaññutaññāṇameva adhippetaṃ. Tassa cādhigamena
analyzed: appaṭihata vutti tāya anāvaraṇa ñāṇam ti sabbaññu ta ññāṇam eva adhippetam tassa ca adhigamena
translated: Or let it be that the knowledge of the absence of obstruction is different from omniscient knowledge. But here the knowledge of the absence of obstruction is intended as omniscient knowledge itself, because it occurs unobstructedly everywhere.

original: bhagavā “sabbaññū, sabbavidū, sammāsambuddho”ti ca vuccati na sakiṃyeva sabbadhammāvabodhato.🔽Tathā ca vuttaṃ paṭisambhidāyaṃ “vimokkhantikametaṃ buddhānaṃ bhagavantānaṃ bodhiyā
analyzed: bhagavā sabbaññū sabba vidū sammāsambuddhaḥ ti ca vuccati na sakiṃyeva sabba dhamma avabodhato  tathā ca vuttam paṭisambhidā ayam vimokkha antikam etam buddhānam bhagavantānam bodhiyā
translated: And it is by the attainment of that that the Blessed One is called “omniscient,” “all-seeing,” and “fully enlightened,” not by the mere understanding of all dhammas at one time.

original: mūle saha sabbaññutaññāṇassa paṭilābhā sacchikā paññatti yadidaṃ “buddho”ti. Sabbadhammāvabodhanasamatthañāṇasamadhigamena
analyzed: mūle saha sabbaññu ta ññāṇassa paṭilābhā sacchikā paññatti yat idam buddhaḥ iti sabba dhamma avabodhana samattha ñāṇa samadhigamena
translated: And it is said in the Paṭisambhidā: “This is a designation that is realized by the Buddhas, the Blessed Ones, on the occasion of enlightenment, together with the acquisition of omniscient knowledge, that is to say, ‘Buddha.’ ”

original: hi bhagavato santāne anavasesadhamme paṭivijjhituṃ samatthatā ahosīti.
analyzed: hi bhagavato santāne anavasesa dhamme paṭivijjhitum samattha tā ahosi iti
translated: For by the mere acquisition of the knowledge able to understand all dhammas, the Blessed One’s continuity became capable of penetrating all dhammas without remainder.

original: Etthāha – kiṃ panidaṃ ñāṇaṃ pavattamānaṃ sakiṃyeva sabbasmiṃ visaye pavattati, udāhu
analyzed: ettha āha kim panidam ñāṇam pavattamānam sakiṃyeva sabbasmin visaye pavattati udāhu
translated: Question: But does this knowledge, when it occurs, occur all at once with regard to all objects, or🔽does it occur in part?

original: kamenāti? Kiñcettha – yadi tāva sakiṃyeva sabbasmiṃ visaye pavattati, atītānāgatapaccuppannaajjhattabahiddhādibhedabhinnānaṃ
analyzed: kamena ati kiñca ittha yadi tāva sa kiṃyeva sabbasmin visaye pavattati atīta anāgata paccuppanna ajjhatta bahiddha ādi bheda bhinnānam
translated: What is the point here? If it occurs all at once with regard to all objects, then there would be no discernment of the difference between the formed dhammas, which are divided into past, future, and present, internal and external, etc.,

original: saṅkhatadhammānaṃ, asaṅkhatasammutidhammānañca ekajjhaṃ upaṭṭhāne dūrato cittapaṭaṃ🔽pekkhantassa viya paṭivibhāgenāvabodho na siyā, tathā ca sati “sabbe dhammā anattā”ti🔽vipassantānaṃ anattākārena viya sabbadhammā anirūpitarūpena bhagavato ñāṇassa visayā
analyzed: saṅkhata dhammānam asaṅkhata sammuti dhammānam ca ekajjham upaṭṭhāne dūratas citta paṭam  pekkhantassa viya paṭivibhāgena avabodho na siyā tathā ca sati sabbe dhammā anattā ti  vipassantānam anatta ākārena viya sabba dhammāḥ anirūpita rūpena bhagavataḥ ñāṇassa visayāḥ
translated: and the unformed dhammas and the conventional dhammas. It would be like looking at a painted cloth from a distance.🔽If that were so, then all dhammas would be the object of the Blessed One’s knowledge without being distinguished by the aspect of non-self, just as they are distinguished by the aspect of non-self when those who are developing insight see them.

original: hontīti āpajjati. Yepi “sabbañeyyadhammānaṃ ṭhitalakkhaṇavisayaṃ vikapparahitaṃ sabbakālaṃ
analyzed: honti iti āpajjati ye pi sabba ñeyya dhammānam ṭhita lakkhaṇa visayam vikappa rahitam sabbakālam
translated: But if it occurs in part, then the Blessed One’s knowledge occurs with regard to all objects without conceptual differentiation, having as its object the specific characteristics of all knowable dhammas.

original: buddhānaṃ ñāṇaṃ pavattati, tena te ‘sabbavidū’ti vuccanti, evañca katvā ‘caraṃ samāhito
analyzed: buddhānam ñāṇam pavattati tena te sabba vidū ti vuccanti evam ca katvā caram samāhitaḥ
translated: Thus it is said that “the knowledge of the Buddhas occurs all the time without conceptual differentiation with regard to the specific characteristics of all knowable dhammas. They are called ‘omniscient’ because of that. And it is in this way that the Blessed One is said to be ‘concentrated when he moves’ and so on.

original: nāgo, tiṭṭhantopi samāhito’ti idampi vacanaṃ suvuttaṃ hotī”ti vadanti, tesampi vuttadosānātivatti,🔽ṭhitalakkhaṇārammaṇatāya ca atītānāgatasammutidhammānaṃ tadabhāvato ekadesavisayameva
analyzed: nāgaḥ tiṭṭhantaḥ api samāhitaḥ ti idam pi vacanam su vuttam hoti iti vadanti tesam pi vutta dosa anātivatti  ṭhita lakkhaṇa ārammaṇa tāya ca atīta anāgata sammuti dhammānam tad abhāvataḥ eka desa visayam eva
translated: But this is not so, because it is subject to the objections already stated.

original: bhagavato ñāṇaṃ siyā. Tasmā sakiṃyeva ñāṇaṃ pavattatīti na yujjati.🔽Atha kamena sabbasmiṃ visaye ñāṇaṃ pavattati? Evampi na yujjati. Na hi jātibhūmisabhāvādivasena,
analyzed: bhagavataḥ ñāṇam siyā tasmā sakiṃya iva ñāṇam pavattati iti na yujjati  atha kamena sabbasmin visaye ñāṇam pavattati evam pi na yujjati na hi jāti bhūmi sabhāva ādi vasena
translated: And because the characteristic of standing is the object of the knowledge, the Exalted One’s knowledge would have only a part of the past and future for its domain, since those states do not have the characteristic of standing.🔽Therefore it is not reasonable to say that the knowledge occurs all at once.

original: disādesakālādivasena ca anekabhedabhinne ñeyye kamena gayhamāne tassa anavasesapaṭivedho🔽sambhavati, apariyantabhāvato ñeyyassa. Ye pana “atthassa avisaṃvādanato ñeyyassa
analyzed: disā desa kāla ādi vasena ca aneka bheda bhinne ñeyye kamena gayhamāne tassa anavasesa paṭivedho  sambhavati a pariyanta bhāvataḥ ñeyyassa ye pana atthassa a visaṃvādanataḥ ñeyyassa
translated: If it occurs in succession with regard to the entire domain, that is not reasonable either, for when the knowable, which is differentiated in many ways by way of species, plane, nature, etc.,🔽and by way of direction, place, time, etc., is apprehended in succession, it is impossible to penetrate it without remainder,

original: ekadesaṃ paccakkhaṃ katvā ‘sesepi eva’nti adhimuccitvā vavatthāpanena sabbaññū bhagavā,
analyzed: eka desam paccakkham katvā sese pi evanti adhimuccitvā vavatthāpanena sabbaññū bhagavā
translated: because the knowable is infinite. But those who say, “The Exalted One is omniscient because he has penetrated all by determining, ‘The rest is also thus,’ having made one part of the knowable evident to himself by not deceiving about the meaning,

original: tañca ñāṇaṃ na anumānikaṃ saṃsayābhāvato. Saṃsayānubaddhaṃ hi loke anumānañāṇa”nti
analyzed: tat ca ñāṇam na anumānikam saṃsaya abhāvataḥ saṃsaya anubaddham hi loke anumāna ñāṇam ti
translated: and because his knowledge is not inferential, since there is no doubt , for in the world, inferential knowledge is accompanied by doubt” —

original: vadanti, tesampi taṃ na yuttaṃ. Sabbassa hi appaccakkhabhāve atthāvisaṃvādanena ñeyyassa
analyzed: vadanti tesam pi tam na yuttam sabbassa hi appaccakkha bhāve attha avisaṃvādanena ñeyyassa
translated: and they say that, but that is not right. For if all is not evident to him, then, since the object of knowledge is not contradicted by the fact that it is not evident,

original: ekadesaṃ paccakkhaṃ katvā “sesepi eva”nti adhimuccitvā vavatthāpanassa asambhavato.
analyzed: eka desam paccakkham katvā sese pi evanti adhimuccitvā vavatthāpanassa asambhavato
translated: he would have to conclude and determine that the rest is the same as that part which is evident, but that is impossible.

original: Yañhi taṃ sesaṃ, taṃ appaccakkhanti.
analyzed: yat hi tam sesam tam appaccakkhanti
translated: For what is left is not evident.🔽Or if that is evident, then it is not what is left.

original: Atha tampi paccakkhaṃ, tassa sesabhāvo eva na siyāti? Sabbametaṃ akāraṇaṃ. Kasmā?
analyzed: atha tam pi paccakkham tassa sesa bhāvaḥ eva na siyāti sabbam etam akāraṇam kasmā
translated: All this is no reason. Why?

original: Avisayavicāraṇabhāvato. Vuttaṃ hetaṃ bhagavatā “buddhavisayo, bhikkhave, acinteyyo
analyzed: avisaya vicāraṇa bhāvataḥ vuttam ha etam bhagavatā buddha visayaḥ bhikkhave a cinteyyaḥ
translated: Because it is not an object of thought. For this is said by the Blessed One: “The domain of the Enlightened One is inconceivable, bhikkhus,

original: na cintetabbo. Yo cinteyya, ummādassa vighātassa bhāgī assā”ti. Idaṃ panettha sanniṭṭhānaṃ🔽– yaṃkiñci bhagavatā ñātuṃ icchitaṃ sakalaṃ, ekadeso vā, tattha appaṭihatavuttitāya
analyzed: na cintetabbaḥ yaḥ cinteyya ummādassa vighātassa bhāgī assa ati idam pana ittha sanniṭṭhānam  yaṃ kiñci bhagavatā ñātum icchitam sakalam eka desaḥ vā tattha appaṭihata vutti tāya
translated: it is not to be thought out (by the ordinary man). Whoever might think it out would get madness and bewilderment” .🔽This is the decision here:🔽whatever the Blessed One wishes to know, whether all or part, there his knowledge occurs as evident, with unobstructed occurrence,

original: paccakkhato ñāṇaṃ pavattati, niccasamādhānañca vikkhepābhāvato. Ñātuṃ icchitassa
analyzed: paccakkhataḥ ñāṇam pavattati nicca samādhānam ca vikkhepa abhāvataḥ ñātum icchitassa
translated: and it is constantly concentrated because it is free from distraction.

original: ca sakalassa avisayabhāve tassa ākaṅkhappaṭibaddhavuttitā na siyā, ekanteneva sā
analyzed: ca sakalassa avisaya bhāve tassa ākaṅkha paṭibaddha vutti tā na siyā ekantena iva sā
translated: and if it were not so, then the Blessed One’s knowledge would not occur bound up with his wish, as it is agreed that it is.🔽It must be agreed that all states are bound up with the Blessed One’s adverting, bound up with his wish,

original: icchitabbā “sabbe dhammā buddhassa bhagavato āvajjanappaṭibaddhā ākaṅkhappaṭibaddhā🔽manasikārappaṭibaddhā cittuppādappaṭibaddhā”ti vacanato. Atītānāgatavisayampi bhagavato
analyzed: icchitabbā sabbe dhammā buddhassa bhagavataḥ āvajjana ppaṭibaddhā ākaṅkha ppaṭibaddhā  manasikāra ppaṭibaddhā citta uppāda ppaṭibaddhā ati vacanataḥ atīta anāgata visayam pi bhagavato
translated: bound up with his attention, bound up with his consciousness-arising, according to the text, “All states are bound up with the Blessed One’s adverting, bound up with his wish,🔽bound up with his attention, bound up with his consciousness- arising” . And the Blessed One’s knowledge of the past and future is also direct-known, not inferred, not conjectural,

original: ñāṇaṃ anumānāgamatakkaggahaṇavirahitattā paccakkhameva.
analyzed: ñāṇam anumāna āgama takka ggahaṇa virahita ttā paccakkham eva
translated: because it is free from inference, from testimony, from conjecture.

original: Nanu ca etasmiṃ pakkhe yadā sakalaṃ ñātuṃ icchitaṃ, tadā sakiṃyeva sakalavisayatāya
analyzed: nanu ca etasmin pakkhe yadā sakalam ñātum icchitam tadā sakala visaya tāya
translated: But in this case, when he wishes to know the whole of something, then his knowledge occurs at one time with the whole of the objective field as its object,

original: anirūpitarūpena bhagavato ñāṇaṃ pavatteyyāti vuttadosānātivattiyevāti? Na, tassa
analyzed: anirūpita rūpena bhagavataḥ ñāṇam pavatteyya ati vutta dosa anātivattiyā iva ati na tassa
translated: so the stated fault is unavoidable, is it not? No, it is not unavoidable,

original: visodhitattā. Visodhito hi so buddhavisayo acinteyyoti. Aññathā pacurajanañāṇasamānavuttitāya
analyzed: visodhita ttā visodhitaḥ hi so buddha visayaḥ acinteyyaḥ ti aññathā pacura jana ñāṇa samāna vutti tāya
translated: because that objective field is purified. For that objective field of the Enlightened One is purified and inconceivable. Otherwise,

original: buddhānaṃ bhagavantānaṃ ñāṇassa acinteyyatā na siyā. Tasmā sakaladhammārammaṇampi
analyzed: buddhānam bhagavantānam ñāṇassa acinteyya tā na siyā tasmā sakala dhamma ārammaṇam pi
translated: if it occurred in the same way as the knowledge of ordinary people, the knowledge of the Enlightened Ones would not be inconceivable. So although the object is all states,

original: taṃ ekadhammārammaṇaṃ viya suvavatthāpiteyeva te dhamme katvā pavattatīti idamettha🔽acinteyyaṃ. Vuttañhetaṃ “yāvatakaṃ ñeyyaṃ, tāvatakaṃ ñāṇaṃ. Yāvatakaṃ ñāṇaṃ, tāvatakaṃ🔽ñeyyaṃ. Ñeyyapariyantikaṃ ñāṇaṃ, ñāṇapariyantikaṃ ñeyya”nti. Evamekajjhaṃ, visuṃ,
analyzed: tam eka dhamma ārammaṇam viya te dhamme katvā pavattati iti idam ettha  acinteyyam vuttam hetam yāvatakam ñeyyam tāvatakam ñāṇam yāvatakam ñāṇam tāvatakam  ñeyyam ñeyya pariyantikam ñāṇam ñāṇa pariyantikam ñeyya nti evam ekajjham visum
translated: It occurs only after the two things have been well defined, as if they were the object of a single idea. This is the

original: sakiṃ, kamena vā icchānurūpaṃ sammā sāmañca sabbadhammānaṃ buddhattā sammāsambuddho.🔽133. Vijjāhīti ettha vindiyaṃ vindatīti vijjā, yāthāvato upalabbhatīti attho. Attano
analyzed: sakim kamena vā icchā anurūpam sammā sāmañca sabba dhammānam buddha ttā sammāsambuddhaḥ  vijjāhi iti ettha vindiyam vindati iti vijjā yāthāvataḥ upalabbhati iti atthaḥ attanaḥ
translated: inconceivable thing here. For this is said: “As far as there is the knowable, there is knowledge to that extent. As far as there is knowledge, there is the knowable to that extent. The knowable is bounded by knowledge, knowledge is bounded by the knowable” . Thus he is fully enlightened because he has fully enlightened himself in all dhammas, according to his wish, rightly and by himself, either all together or separately, either all at once or in due course.

original: vā paṭipakkhassa vijjhanaṭṭhena vijjā, tamokkhandhādikassa padālanaṭṭhenāti attho.🔽Tato eva attano visayassa viditakaraṇaṭṭhenapi vijjā. Sampannattāti samannāgatattā,
analyzed: vā paṭipakkhassa vijjhana ṭhena vijjā tamaḥ khandha ādikassa padālana ṭṭhena ati attho  tatas eva attanaḥ visayassa vidita karaṇa ṭṭhena api vijjā sampannattā ati samannāgata ttā
translated: He is a discoverer of the unknown: here vijjā is what is discovered in the act of finding out , the meaning is, what is experienced in accordance with actuality. Or vijjā is what discovers , the meaning is, what destroys the mass of darkness, etc., in the sense of demolishing its opposite.

original: paripuṇṇattā vā, avikalattāti attho. Tissannaṃ, aṭṭhannaṃ ca vijjānaṃ tattha tattha
analyzed: paripuṇṇa ttā vā a vikala ttā ti attho tissannam aṭṭhannam ca vijjānam tattha tattha
translated: And it is also vijjā in the sense of making known its own province. He is endowed with that vijjā, is what is meant. He is endowed with it because it is perfected, is complete, is unadulterated, is what is meant. He is endowed with the three kinds of vijjā and the eight kinds of vijjā, respectively, in the three instances

original: sutte gahaṇaṃ vineyyajjhāsayavasenāti daṭṭhabbaṃ. Satta saddhammā nāma saddhā hirī
analyzed: sutte gahaṇam daṭṭhabbam satta saddhammāḥ nāma saddhā hirī
translated: The “grasping of the suttas” should be understood as the inclination to train. The seven good principles are faith, conscience,

original: ottappaṃ bāhusaccaṃ vīriyaṃ sati paññā ca. Ye sandhāya vuttaṃ “idha bhikkhu saddho
analyzed: ottappam bāhusaccam vīriyam sati paññā ca ye sandhāya vuttam idha bhikkhu saddho
translated: The “grasping of the suttas” should be understood as the inclination to train. The “seven good qualities” are faith, conscience, shame, learning, energy, mindfulness, and understanding. It is with reference to these that it is said: “Here a bhikkhu has faith,

original: hotī”tiādi. Cattāri jhānānīti yāni kānici cattāri rūpāvacarajjhānāni.🔽Kasmā panettha sīlādayo pannaraseva “caraṇa”nti vuttāti codanaṃ sandhāyāha “imeyeva
analyzed: hoti itiādi cattāri jhānāni iti yāni kānici cattāri rūpāvacara jhānāni  kasmā pana ittha sīla ādayaḥ pannarasā iva caraṇanti vuttā iti codanam sandhāya āha imeyā iva
translated: he is confident that the Tathāgata is fully enlightened, the Dhamma is well proclaimed, and the Sangha is practising the good way” . The “four jhanas” are any of the four fine-material-sphere jhanas.

original: hī”tiādi. Tena tesaṃ sikkhattayasaṅgahato nibbānupagamane ekaṃsato sādhanabhāvamāha.
analyzed: hi itiādi tena tesam sikkhattaya saṅgahataḥ nibbāna upagamane ekaṃsataḥ sādhana bhāvam āha
translated: Why are only the fifteen beginning with virtue called “conduct”? Anticipating this question, he says, “For these,” etc. He shows that they are the means of attaining nibbana in a single way by being included in the three trainings.

original: Idāni tadatthasādhanāya āgamaṃ dassento “yathāhā”tiādimāha. Bhagavātiādi vuttassevatthassa
analyzed: idāni tad attha sādhanāya āgamam dassentaḥ yathā āha atiādim āha bhagavā atiādi
translated: Now, in order to establish their meaning, he shows the texts with the words “As it is said,” etc. The words “The Blessed One,” etc.,

original: nigamanavasena vuttaṃ.
analyzed: nigamana vasena vuttam
translated: are said by way of conclusion of the meaning already stated.

original: Nanu cāyaṃ vijjācaraṇasampadā sāvakesupi labbhatīti? Kiñcāpi labbhati, na pana tathā,
analyzed: nanu ca ayam vijjā caraṇa sampadā sāvakesu pi labbhati iti kiñcā api labbhati na pana tathā
translated: But isn’t this perfection of knowledge and conduct found also among disciples? Although it is found, it is not so

analyzed: yathā bhagavato ti dassetum tattha vijjā sampadā tiādi vuttam caraṇa dhamma pariyāpanna ttā
translated: great as that of the Blessed One. In order to show this, he says, “Herein, the perfection of knowledge,” etc. The perfection of conduct is included in the Dhamma of conduct.

original: karuṇābrahmavihārassa, so cettha mahaggatabhāvappattā sādhāraṇabhāvoti āha “caraṇasampadā🔽mahākāruṇikataṃ pūretvā ṭhitā”ti. Yathā sattānaṃ anatthaṃ parivajjetvā atthe niyojanaṃ
analyzed: karuṇā brahmavihārassa saḥ ca ittha mahaggata bhāva ppattā sādhāraṇa bhāvaḥ ti āha caraṇa sampadā  mahā kāruṇika tam pūretvā ṭhitā ati yathā sattānam anattham parivajjetvā atthe niyojanam
translated: The Buddha’s knowledge of what is good and bad for disciples is due to his Great Compassion.🔽The Buddha’s knowledge of what is good and bad for disciples is due to his Great Compassion.🔽The Buddha’s knowledge of what is good and bad for disciples is due to his Great Compassion.🔽The Buddha’s knowledge of what is good and bad for disciples is due to his Great Compassion.

analyzed: paññāya vinā na hoti evam na isam attha anattha jānanam satthu karuṇāya vinā na hoti iti  ubhayam pi ubhayattha sa kiccakam eva siyā yattha pana yassā padhāna bhāvaḥ tam dassetum
translated: The Buddha’s knowledge of what is good and bad for disciples is due to his Great Compassion.🔽The Buddha’s knowledge of what is good and bad for disciples is due to his Great Compassion.🔽The Buddha’s knowledge of what is good and bad for disciples is due to his Great Compassion.🔽The Buddha’s knowledge of what is good and bad for disciples is due to his Great Compassion.

translated: The Buddha’s knowledge of what is good and bad for disciples is due to his Great Compassion.🔽The Buddha’s knowledge of what is good and bad for disciples is due to his Great Compassion.🔽The Buddha’s knowledge of what is good and bad for disciples is due to his Great Compassion.🔽The Buddha’s knowledge of what is good and bad for disciples is due to his Great Compassion.🔽The Buddha’s knowledge of what is good and bad for disciples is due to his Great Compassion.🔽The Buddha’s knowledge of what is good and bad for disciples is due to his Great Compassion.🔽The Buddha’s knowledge of what is good and bad for disciples is due to his Great Compassion.🔽The Buddha’s knowledge of what is good and bad for disciples is due to his Great Compassion.🔽The Buddha’s knowledge of what is good and bad for disciples is due to his Great Compassion.🔽The Buddha’s knowledge of what is good and bad for disciples is due to his Great Compassion.🔽The Buddha’s knowledge of what is good and bad for disciples is due to his Great Compassion.🔽The Buddha’s knowledge of what is good and bad for disciples is due to his Great Compassion.

original: Sā panāyaṃ satthu vijjācaraṇasampadā sāsanassa niyyānikatāya sāvakānaṃ sammāpaṭipattiyā🔽ekantakāraṇanti dassetuṃ “tenassā”tiādi vuttaṃ. Taṃ suviññeyyameva.
analyzed: sā pana ayam satthu vijjā caraṇa sampadā sāsanassa niyyānika tāya sāvakānam sammā paṭipattiyā 🔽ekanta kāraṇanti dassetum tena assa atiādi vuttam tam su viññeyyam eva
translated: The Buddha’s knowledge of what is good and bad for disciples is due to his Great Compassion.🔽The Buddha’s knowledge of what is good and bad for disciples is due to his Great Compassion.🔽The Buddha’s knowledge of what is good and bad for disciples is due to his Great Compassion.

original: Ettha ca vijjāsampadāya satthu paññāmahattaṃ pakāsitaṃ hoti, caraṇasampadāya karuṇāmahattaṃ.
analyzed: ettha ca vijjā sampadāya satthu paññā mahattam pakāsitam hoti caraṇa sampadāya karuṇā mahattam
translated: And here the greatness of the Master’s understanding is revealed by the perfection of his knowledge, and the greatness of his compassion is revealed by the perfection of his conduct.🔽Of these, the Master’s attainment of the sovereignty of the Dhamma is due to his understanding, and his sharing of the Dhamma is due to his compassion.

original: Tesu paññāya bhagavato dhammarajjappatti, karuṇāya dhammasaṃvibhāgo. Paññāya saṃsāradukkhanibbidā,
analyzed: tesu paññāya bhagavataḥ dhamma rajja ppatti karuṇāya dhamma saṃvibhāgaḥ paññāya saṃsāra dukkha nibbidā
translated: His disenchantment with the suffering of the round of rebirths is due to his understanding,🔽and his endurance of the suffering of the round of rebirths is due to his compassion. His full-understanding of others’ suffering is due to his understanding,

original: karuṇāya saṃsāradukkhasahanaṃ. Paññāya paradukkhaparijānanaṃ, karuṇāya paradukkhapatikārārambho.
analyzed: karuṇāya saṃsāra dukkha sahanam paññāya para dukkha parijānanam karuṇāya para dukkha patikāra ārambhaḥ
translated: and his undertaking of the task of remedying others’ suffering is due to his compassion.🔽His inclination towards final Nibbāna is due to his understanding,

original: Paññāya parinibbānābhimukhabhāvo, karuṇāya tadadhigamo. Paññāya sayaṃ taraṇaṃ, karuṇāya
analyzed: paññāya parinibbāna abhimukha bhāvaḥ karuṇāya tad adhigamaḥ paññāya sayam taraṇam karuṇāya
translated: and his attainment of it is due to his compassion. His own deliverance is due to his understanding,🔽and the deliverance of others is due to his compassion. His success as a Buddha is due to his understanding,

original: paresaṃ tāraṇaṃ. Paññāya buddhabhāvasiddhi, karuṇāya buddhakiccasiddhi. Karuṇāya
analyzed: paresam tāraṇam paññāya buddha bhāva siddhi karuṇāya buddha kicca siddhi karuṇāya
translated: and his success in the Buddha-task is due to his compassion.

original: vā bodhisattabhūmiyaṃ saṃsārābhimukhabhāvo, paññāya tattha anabhirati. Tathā karuṇāya
analyzed: vā bodhisatta bhūmiyam saṃsāra abhimukha bhāvo paññāya tattha an abhirati tathā karuṇāya
translated: Or his inclination towards the round of rebirths is due to his compassion,🔽and his disinclination for it is due to his understanding. So too, his non-harming of others is due to his compassion,

original: paresaṃ abhiṃsāpanaṃ, paññāya sayaṃ parehi abhāyanaṃ. Karuṇāya paraṃ rakkhanto attānaṃ
analyzed: paresam abhiṃsāpanam paññāya sayam parehi abhāyanam karuṇāya param rakkhantaḥ attānam
translated: and his own non-harming by others is due to his understanding. His protection of others is due to his compassion,

original: rakkhati, paññāya attānaṃ rakkhanto paraṃ rakkhati. Tathā karuṇāya aparantapo, paññāya
analyzed: rakkhati paññāya attānam rakkhantaḥ param rakkhati tathā karuṇāya aparantapaḥ paññāya
translated: He is not a tormentor of himself through compassion, and not a tormentor of others through wisdom.

original: anattantapo. Tena attahitāya paṭipannādīsu catūsu puggalesu catutthapuggalabhāvo
analyzed: tena atta hitāya paṭipanna ādīsu catūsu puggalesu catuttha puggala bhāvaḥ
translated: Thus the fourth kind of person is established among the four kinds of persons who practice for their own welfare, etc.🔽And he is a protector of the world through compassion, and a protector of himself through wisdom.

original: siddho hoti. Tathā karuṇāya lokanāthatā, paññāya attanāthatā. Karuṇāya cassa ninnatābhāvo,🔽paññāya unnamābhāvo. Tathā karuṇāya sabbasattesu janitānuggaho paññānugatattā na🔽ca na sabbattha virattacitto, paññāya sabbadhammesu virattacitto karuṇānugatattā
analyzed: siddhaḥ hoti tathā karuṇāya loka nātha tā paññāya atta nātha tā karuṇāya cassa ninna tā bhāvo  paññāya unnama abhāvo tathā karuṇāya sabba sattesu janita anuggaho paññā anugata ttā na  ca na sabbattha viratta citto paññāya sabba dhammesu viratta citto karuṇā anugata ttā
translated: He is humble through compassion, and exalted through wisdom.🔽And he is devoted to the help of all beings through compassion, and his mind is not attached to anything through wisdom.

original: na ca na sabbasattānuggahāya pavatto. Yathā hi karuṇā bhagavato sinehasokavirahitā,
analyzed: na ca na sabba satta anuggahāya pavattaḥ yathā hi karuṇā bhagavataḥ sineha soka virahitā
translated: His mind is not attached to anything through wisdom, and he is not unengaged in helping all beings through compassion.🔽For just as his compassion is free from affection and sorrow,

original: evaṃ paññā ahaṃkāramamaṃkāravinimuttāti aññamaññavisodhitā paramavisuddhā guṇavisesā
analyzed: evam paññā ahaṃkāra mamaṃkāra vinimuttā ati añña mañña visodhitā parama visuddhā guṇa visesā
translated: so his wisdom is free from the conceit “I am” and the conceit “mine.” Thus his special qualities, purified by their mutual purification, are supremely purified.

original: vijjācaraṇasampadāhi pakāsitāti daṭṭhabbaṃ.
analyzed: vijjā ācaraṇa sampadā hi pakāsitā iti daṭṭhabbam
translated: They are revealed by the perfection of his knowledge and conduct.

original: 134. Gamanampi hi gatanti vuccati “gate ṭhite”tiādīsu. Sobhananti subhaṃ. Subhabhāvo
analyzed: gamanam pi hi gatanti vuccati gate ṭhita iti ādīsu sobhananti subham subha bhāvaḥ
translated: For going is called “gone” in such passages as “When he has gone and stood” . Beautiful is subha .

original: visuddhatāya, visuddhatā dosavigamenāti āha “parisuddhamanavajja”nti. Gamanañca nāma🔽bahuvidhanti idhādhippetaṃ gamanaṃ dassento “ariyamaggo”ti āha. So hi nibbānassa
analyzed: visuddha tāya visuddha tā dosa vigamena ati āha gamanam ca nāma  bahuvidham ti idha adhippetam gamanam dassentaḥ ariya maggo ti āha saḥ hi nibbānassa
translated: The state of being subha is purity. Purity is the absence of hate.🔽Therefore he said “pure and blameless” . And going is of many kinds.

original: gati adhigamoti katvā “gataṃ, gamana”nti ca vuccati. Idāni tasseva gahaṇe kāraṇaṃ
analyzed: gati adhigamaḥ ti katvā gatam gamananti ca vuccati idāni tassa iva gahaṇe kāraṇam
translated: In order to show the kind of going intended here, he said “the Noble Path” . For that is called “gone” and “going” in the sense of being the destination and the arrival at Nibbāna.

original: dassetuṃ “tena hesā”tiādi vuttaṃ. Khemaṃ disanti nibbānaṃ. Asajjamānoti paripanthābhāvena🔽sugatigamanepi asajjanto saṅgaṃ akaronto, pageva itarattha. Atha vā ekāsane nisīditvā
analyzed: dassetum tena ha isā tiādi vuttam khemam disanti nibbānam asajjamānaḥ ti paripantha abhāvena  sugati gamane pi a sajjantaḥ saṅgam a karontaḥ atha vā eka āsane nisīditvā
translated: Now, in order to show the reason for its being taken in this way, he said “Therefore it is said” , etc. The secure place is Nibbāna.

original: khippabhiññāvaseneva catunnampi maggānaṃ paṭiladdhabhāvato asajjamāno asajjanto gato.
analyzed: khippa abhiññā vasena iva catunnam pi maggānam paṭiladdha bhāvataḥ a sajjamānaḥ a sajjantaḥ gataḥ
translated: Without stumbling: without stumbling even in going to a good destination, because there is no obstacle, much less elsewhere. Or alternatively, he went without stumbling, without stumbling even in sitting in one session and obtaining all four paths by the method of quick direct-knowledge.

original: Yaṃ gamanaṃ gacchanto sabbamanatthaṃ apaharati, sabbañca anuttaraṃ sampattiṃ āvahati,
analyzed: yam gamanam gacchantaḥ sabbam anattham apaharati sabbam ca anuttaram sampattim āvahati
translated: The going that, while going, removes all misfortune and brings all the unsurpassed attainments

original: tadeva sobhanaṃ nāma. Tena ca bhagavā gatoti āha “iti sobhanagamanattā sugato”ti
analyzed: tat eva sobhanam nāma tena ca bhagavā gatā iti āha iti sobhana gamana ttā sugatā iti
translated: and that is what is called beautiful. And the Blessed One has gone there, thus he is the Well-Gone because of going in a beautiful way.

original: sobhanattho su-saddoti katvā.
analyzed: sobhanattho su saddo ti katvā
translated: Taking the word su- in the sense of beautiful.

original: Asundarānaṃ dukkhānaṃ saṅkhārappavattīnaṃ abhāvato accantasukhattā ekantato sundaraṃ
analyzed: asundarānam dukkhānam saṅkhāra ppavattīnam abhāvataḥ accanta sukhattā ekantataḥ sundaram
translated: Because of the absence of the ugly, that is, of suffering, of formations that occur, and because of the extreme beauty of the deathless Nibbāna, which is entirely beautiful,

original: nāma asaṅkhatā dhātūti āha “sundarañcesa ṭhānaṃ gato amataṃ nibbāna”nti. Tenāha bhagavā
analyzed: nāma asaṅkhatā dhātu iti āha sundaram ca isa ṭhānam gataḥ amatam nibbānam ti tena āha bhagavā
translated: he is the Well-Gone because of going to the beautiful, that is, to the unformed element. Thus he said: “He has gone to the beautiful place, the deathless Nibbāna.” And the Blessed One said:🔽“Nibbāna is the highest bliss.”

original: “nibbānaṃ paramaṃ sukha”nti. Sammāti suṭṭhu. Suṭṭhu gamanañca nāma paṭipakkhena anabhibhūtassa
analyzed: nibbānam paramam sukhanti sammā ati suṭṭhu suṭṭhu gamanam ca nāma paṭipakkhena an abhibhūtassa
translated: Rightly: well. And “going” is going that is not overcome by its opposite.

original: gamananti āha “pahīne kilese puna apaccāgacchanto”ti. Idañca sikhāppattaṃ sammāgamanaṃ,
analyzed: gamanam ti āha pahīne kilese puna apaccāgacchanto ti idam ca sikhāppattam sammāgamanam
translated: Thus he said: “Having abandoned defilements he does not return to them again.” And this right going that has reached its culmination,

original: yāya āgamanīyapaṭipadāya siddhaṃ, sāpi sammāgamanamevāti evampi bhagavā sugatoti
analyzed: yāya āgamanīya paṭipadāya siddham sā api sammāgamanam eva ati evam pi bhagavā sugataḥ iti
translated: and the right going that is successful through the way of practice that should be gone, is also right going. Thus also the Blessed One is the Well-Gone🔽in order to show that he is the Well-Gone, it is said: “He has gone rightly.”

original: dassetuṃ “sammā vā gato”tiādi vuttaṃ. Sammāpaṭipattiyāti sammāsambodhiyā sampāpane
analyzed: dassetum sammā vā gataḥ ti ādi vuttam sammā paṭipattiyā ti sammāsambodhiyā sampāpane
translated: By right practice: by the practice that brings about right perfect enlightenment.

original: aviparītapaṭipattiyā. “Sabbalokassa hitasukhameva karonto”ti etena mahābodhiyā paṭipadā🔽avibhāgena sabbasattānaṃ sabbadā hitasukhāvahabhāveneva pavattatīti dasseti. “Sassataṃ🔽ucchedanti ime ante anupagacchanto gato”ti etena paṭiccasamuppādagatiṃ dasseti. “Kāmasukhaṃ
analyzed: aviparīta paṭipattiyā sabba lokassa hita sukham eva karonto ti etena mahā bodhiyā paṭipadā  avibhāgena sabba sattānam sabbadā hita sukha āvaha bhāvena iva pavattati iti dasseti sassatam  ime ante an upagacchantaḥ gataḥ ti etena paṭiccasamuppāda gatim dasseti kāma sukham
translated: By the practice that is not perverse. By “bringing welfare and pleasure to the whole world” he shows that the practice of the Great Being

original: attakilamathanti ime anupagacchanto gato”ti etena ariyamaggagatiṃ dasseti.🔽Tatrāti yuttaṭṭhāne yuttasseva bhāsane nipphādetabbe, sādhetabbe cetaṃ bhummaṃ. Abhūtanti
analyzed: atta kilamathanti ime an upagacchantaḥ gataḥ ti etena ariya magga gatim dasseti  tatra ati yutta ṭṭhāne yuttassa iva bhāsane nipphādetabbe sādhetabbe ca itam bhummam a bhūta ti
translated: proceeds by bringing welfare and pleasure to all beings at all times without distinction. By “gone beyond the extremes of eternalism and annihilationism” he shows the going of dependent origination. By “gone beyond sense-desire and ill-will” he shows the going of the noble path.

original: abhūtatthaṃ. Atthamukhena hi vācāya abhūtatā, bhūtatā vā. Atacchanti tasseva vevacanaṃ.🔽Abhūtanti vā asantaṃ avijjamānaṃ. Atacchanti atathākāraṃ aññathāsantaṃ. Anatthasañhitanti
analyzed: a bhūta ttham attha mukhena hi vācāya a bhūta tā bhūta tā vai a tacchanti tassa iva vevacanam  a bhūta nti vai asantam a vijjamānam a tacchanti a tathākāram aññathā asantam anattha sañhita nti
translated: Herein, the locative case in “here” indicates the place where the teaching should be given, the place where the teaching should be produced and accomplished. “False” means having a false meaning. For the falsity of speech is by way of meaning, or it is by way of truth. “False” is a synonym for that.

original: diṭṭhadhammikena, samparāyikena vā anatthena sañhitaṃ, anatthāvahaṃ. Na atthoti anattho,
analyzed: diṭṭhadhammikena samparāyikena vā anatthena sañhitam anattha āvaham na attho ti anatthaḥ
translated: Or else, “false” means non-existent, non-present. “False” means having a form other than that, having a form different from that. “Devoid of benefit” means connected with harm, either in the present life or in the life to come. “Not benefit” is harm.

original: atthassa paṭipakkho, abhāvo ca, tena sañhitaṃ, pisuṇavācaṃ, samphappalāpañcāti attho.
analyzed: atthassa paṭipakkhaḥ abhāvaḥ ca tena sañhitam pisuṇa vācam samphappalāpam ca ati attho
translated: and the opposite of what is, and non-existence, and what is connected with that, and malicious speech, and idle chatter: this is the meaning.

original: Evamettha catubbidhassāpi vacīduccaritassa saṅgaho daṭṭhabbo. Ettha ca paṭhamā vācā🔽sīlavantaṃ “dussīlo”ti, acaṇḍālādimeva “caṇḍālo”tiādinā bhāsamānassa daṭṭhabbā. Dutiyā
analyzed: evam ettha catubbidhassa api vacī duccaritassa saṅgahaḥ daṭṭhabbaḥ ettha ca paṭhamā vācā  sīlavantam dussīlaḥ ti a caṇḍāla ādim eva caṇḍāla uti ādinā bhāsamānassa daṭṭhabbā dutiyā
translated: So the inclusion of the four kinds of verbal misconduct should be understood here. And here the first kind of speech🔽is to be understood as that of one who says of one who is virtuous that he is not virtuous, and of one who is not a caṇḍāla, and so on, that he is a caṇḍāla, and so on. The second kind of speech

original: dussīlaṃ “dussīlo”ti, caṇḍālādimeva “caṇḍālo”tiādinā avinayena bhāsamānassa. Tatiyā
analyzed: dussīlam dussīlaḥ ti caṇḍāla ādim eva caṇḍāla uti ādinā avinayena bhāsamānassa tatiyā
translated: is that of one who says of one who is not virtuous that he is not virtuous, and of one who is not a caṇḍāla, and so on, that he is not a caṇḍāla, and so on, by a method of exposition that is not in accordance with the way things are. The third kind of speech

original: nerayikādikassa nerayikādibhāvavibhāvanīkathā yathā “āpāyiko devadatto nerayiko”tiādikā.
analyzed: nerayika ādikassa nerayika ādi bhāva vibhāvanī kathā yathā āpāyikaḥ devadattaḥ nerayikā iti ādikā
translated: is talk that describes the state of those in the hells, and so on, as it really is, such as the following: “Devadatta has been reborn in an apāya, in hell,” and so on.

original: Catutthī “vedavihitena yaññavidhinā pāṇātipātādikataṃ sugatiṃ āvahatī”ti lokassa
analyzed: catutthī veda vihitena yañña vidhinā pāṇa atipāta ādi katam sugatim āvahati iti lokassa
translated: The fourth kind of speech is talk that deceives the world, such as the following: “By the performance of sacrifices laid down in the Vedas, killing living beings brings good rebirth.”

original: byāmohanakathā. Pañcamī bhūtena pesuññūpasaṃhārādikathā. Chaṭṭhā yuttappattaṭṭhāne
analyzed: byāmohana kathā pañcamī bhūtena pesuññu upasaṃhāra ādi kathā chaṭṭhā yutta pattaṭṭhāne
translated: The fifth kind of speech is talk that brings together malicious persons, and so on. The sixth kind of speech

original: pavattitā dānasīlādikathā veditabbā. Evaṃ sammā gadattāti yathāvuttaṃ abhūtādiṃ vajjetvā
analyzed: pavatti tā dāna sīla ādi kathā veditabbā evam sammā gadatta iti yathā vuttam abhūta ādim vajjetvā
translated: is to be understood as talk about generosity, virtue, and so on, that occurs in a proper context. Thus he speaks rightly: avoiding what has been mentioned above, that is, the four kinds of verbal misconduct, and so on.

original: bhūtaṃ tacchaṃ atthasañhitaṃ piyaṃ manāpaṃ tato eva sammā suṭṭhu gadanato sugato🔽da-kārassa ta-kāraṃ katvā. Āpāthagamanamattena kassaci appiyampi hi bhagavato vacanaṃ
analyzed: bhūtam taccham attha sañhitam piyam manāpam tatas eva sammā suṭṭhu gadanataḥ sugataḥ  dakārassa takāram katvā āpātha gamana mattena kassaci appiyam pi hi bhagavataḥ vacanam
translated: liberation, and the vision and knowledge of liberation; because he has gone to the destruction of the impurities; because he has gone to the attainment of the unexcelled rest for the yoke; and because he has gone to the realization of the supreme welfare and happiness of those who look up to him.🔽He is well-gone because he has gone well to the destruction of the impurities.🔽He is well-gone because he has gone well to the attainment of the unexcelled rest for the yoke.

original: piyaṃ manāpameva atthasiddhiyā lokassa hitasukhāvahattā.
analyzed: piyam manāpam eva attha siddhiyā lokassa hita sukha āvaha tā
translated: He is well-gone because he has gone well to the realization of the supreme welfare and happiness of those who look up to him.🔽He is well-gone because he has gone well to the destruction of the impurities.🔽He is well-gone because he has gone well to the attainment of the unexcelled rest for the yoke.

original: Apica sobhanaṃ gataṃ gamanaṃ etassāti sugato. Bhagavato hi veneyyajanupasaṅkamanaṃ
analyzed: apica sobhanam gatam gamanam etassa ati sugataḥ bhagavataḥ hi veneyya jana upasaṅkamanam
translated: He is well-gone because he has gone well to the realization of the supreme welfare and happiness of those who look up to him.🔽He is well-gone because he has gone well to the destruction of the impurities.🔽He is well-gone because he has gone well to the attainment of the unexcelled rest for the yoke.🔽He is well-gone because he has gone well to the realization of the supreme welfare and happiness of those who look up to him.🔽He is well-gone because he has gone well to the destruction of the impurities.🔽He is well-gone because he has gone well to the attainment of the unexcelled rest for the yoke.

original: ekantena tesaṃ hitasukhanipphādanato sobhanaṃ bhaddakaṃ. Tathā lakkhaṇānubyañjanapaṭimaṇḍitarūpakāyatāya
analyzed: ekantena tesam hita sukha nipphādanato sobhanam bhaddakam tathā lakkhaṇa anubyañjana paṭimaṇḍita rūpa kāya tāya
translated: He is well-gone because he has gone well to the realization of the supreme welfare and happiness of those who look up to him.🔽He is well-gone because he has gone well to the destruction of the impurities.

original: dutavilambitakhalitānukaḍḍhananippīḷanukkuṭikakuṭilākulatādidosarahitavilāsitarājahaṃsavasabhavāraṇamigarājagamanaṃ
analyzed: duta vilambita khalita anukaḍḍhana nippīḍa nukkuṭika kuṭila ākula tā ādi dosa rahita vilāsita rājahaṃsa vasabha vāraṇa miga rāja gamanam
translated: He is well-gone because he has gone well to the attainment of the unexcelled rest for the yoke.🔽He is well-gone because he has gone well to the realization of the supreme welfare and happiness of those who look up to him.🔽He is well-gone because he has gone well to the destruction of the impurities.🔽He is well-gone because he has gone well to the attainment of the unexcelled rest for the yoke.

original: kāyagamanaṃ, ñāṇagamanañca vipulanimmalakaruṇāsativīriyādiguṇavisesasahitaṃ abhinīhārato
analyzed: kāya gamanam ñāṇa gamanam ca vipula nimmala karuṇā sati vīriya ādi guṇa visesa sahitam abhinīhārato
translated: He is well-gone because he has gone well to the realization of the supreme welfare and happiness of those who look up to him.🔽He is well-gone because he has

original: yāva mahābodhi anavajjatāya, sattānaṃ hitasukhāvahatāya ca sobhanameva. Atha vā sayambhūñāṇena
analyzed: yāva mahā bodhi anavajja tāya sattānam hita sukha avahatāya ca sobhanam eva atha vā sayambhu ñāṇena
translated: Or alternatively, he is well gone as rightly gone, rightly understood, in that he, by his own super-knowledge,

original: sakalampi lokaṃ pariññābhisamayavasena parijānanto sammā gato avagatoti sugato. Tathā🔽lokasamudayaṃ pahānābhisamayavasena pajahanto anuppattidhammataṃ āpādento sammā gato🔽atītoti sugato. Lokanirodhaṃ nibbānaṃ sacchikiriyābhisamayavasena sammā gato adhigatoti
analyzed: sakalam pi lokam pariññā abhisamaya vasena parijānanto sammā gataḥ avagataḥ iti sugataḥ tathā  loka samudayam pahāna abhisamaya vasena pajahantaḥ an uppatti dhamma tam āpādentaḥ sammā gataḥ  atītaḥ iti sugataḥ loka nirodham nibbānam sacchikiriyā abhisamaya vasena sammā gataḥ adhigataḥ iti
translated: fully understands the whole world by means of the kinds of understanding consisting in direct knowledge and penetration.🔽And he is well gone as passed away, as attained the state of non- reappearance, in that he abandons the world’s origin by means of the kind of understanding consisting in the penetration of the abandonment of the world’s origin.🔽And he is well gone as well come, as rightly come, in that he has rightly come to, rightly attained, the world’s cessation, which is extinction, by means of the kind of understanding consisting in the penetration of the realization of the world’s cessation.

original: sugato. Lokanirodhagāminiṃ paṭipadaṃ bhāvanābhisamayavasena sammā gato paṭipannoti🔽sugato. Tathā yaṃ imassa sadevakassa lokassa diṭṭhaṃ sutaṃ mutaṃ viññātaṃ pattaṃ
analyzed: sugataḥ loka nirodha gāminim paṭipadam bhāvanā abhisamaya vasena sammā gataḥ paṭipanno ti  sugataḥ tathā yam imassa sa devakassa lokassa diṭṭham sutam mutam viññātam pattam
translated: And he is well gone as rightly gone, as rightly fared, in that he has rightly gone, rightly fared, the way leading to the cessation of the world, by means of the kind of understanding consisting in the penetration of the development of the way leading to the cessation of the world.🔽And he is well gone as well seen, as rightly seen, in that he has rightly seen, has seen with his own knowledge, all this world, which is to be seen by a Tathagata, as being in the palm of his hand, as it were, by means of the kind of understanding consisting in the penetration of the development of the way leading to the cessation of the world.

original: pariyesitaṃ anuvicaritaṃ manasā, sabbaṃ taṃ hatthatale āmalakaṃ viya sammā paccakkhato
analyzed: pariyesitam anuvicaritam manasā sabbam tam hattha tale āmalakam viya sammā paccakkhataḥ
translated: And he is well gone as well known, as rightly known, in that he has rightly known, has known rightly, all this world, which is to be known by a Tathagata, as being in the palm of his hand, as it were, by means of the kind of understanding consisting in the penetration of the development of the way leading to the cessation of the world.🔽And he is well gone as well seen, as rightly seen, in that he has rightly seen, has seen with his own knowledge, all this world, which is to be seen by a Tathagata, as being in the palm of his hand, as it were, by means of the kind of understanding consisting in the penetration of the development of the way leading to the cessation of the world.

original: gato abbhaññāsīti sugato.
analyzed: gataḥ abbhaññāsi iti sugataḥ
translated: And he is well gone as well known, as rightly known, in that he has rightly known, has known rightly, all this world, which is to be known by a Tathagata,

original: 135. Sabbathāti sabbappakārena. Yo yo loko yathā yathā veditabbo, tathā tathā. Te
analyzed: sabbathā ati sabba ppakārena yaḥ yaḥ lokaḥ yathā yathā veditabbaḥ tathā tathā te
translated: 135. In all ways: in all modes. In whatever way the world should be known, in that way.

original: pana pakāre dassetuṃ “sabhāvato”tiādi vuttaṃ. Tattha sabhāvatoti dukkhasabhāvato.
analyzed: pana pakāre dassetum sabhāvato tiādi vuttam tattha sabhāvato ti dukkha sabhāvato
translated: But in order to show those modes, “in actuality” is said, etc. Herein, in actuality: in the actuality of suffering.

original: Sabbo hi loko dukkhasabhāvo. Yathāha “saṃkhittena pañcupādānakkhandhā dukkhā”ti.
analyzed: sabbaḥ hi lokaḥ dukkha sabhāvaḥ yathā āha saṃkhittena pañca upādānakkhandhāḥ dukkhā ti
translated: For the whole world is in the actuality of suffering, as it is said: “In brief, the five aggregates as objects of clinging are suffering” .

original: Samudayatoti yato so samudeti, tato taṇhādito. Nirodhatoti yattha so nirujjhati,
analyzed: samudayato ti yatas saḥ samudeti tatas taṇhā āditaḥ nirodhato ti yattha saḥ nirujjhati
translated: In origination: from where it originates, from that, from craving, etc. In cessation: where it ceases,

original: tato visaṅkhārato. Nirodhūpāyatoti yena vidhinā so nirodho pattabbo, tato ariyamaggato,
analyzed: tatas visaṅkhārataḥ nirodha upāyataḥ ti yena vidhinā saḥ nirodho pattabbaḥ tatas ariya maggato
translated: from that, from the cessation of formations, etc. In the way leading to cessation: by what method that cessation is to be reached, from that, from the noble path,

original: ito aññassa pakārassa abhāvā.
analyzed: i taḥ aññassa pakārassa abhāvā
translated: because there is no other mode than this.

original: Iti “sabbathā lokaṃ avedī”ti vatvā tadatthasādhakaṃ suttaṃ dassento “yattha kho āvuso”tiādimāha.
analyzed: iti sabbathā lokam avedi iti vatvā tad attha sādhakam suttam dassentaḥ yattha kho āvuso tiādim āha
translated: Thus, having said “he knew the world in all ways,” he said “Where, friends, there is the eye” in order to show the sutta that proves that meaning.

original: Tattha “na jāyatī”tiādinā ujukaṃ jātiādīni paṭikkhipitvā “na cavati na upapajjatī”ti
analyzed: tattha na jāyati itiādinā ujukam jāti ādīni paṭikkhipitvā na cavati na upapajjati iti
translated: Herein, after directly negating birth, etc., with “does not arise,” etc., he said “does not pass away, is not reborn” .

original: padadvayena aparāparaṃ cavanupapajjanāni paṭikkhipati. Keci pana “na jāyatītiādi
analyzed: pada dvayena apara aparam cava nupapajjanāni paṭikkhipati keci pana na jāyati itiādi
translated: By the two phrases beginning with “not born” he rejects the other two alternatives of dying and not dying.

original: gabbhaseyyakavasena vuttaṃ, itaraṃ opapātikavasenā”ti vadanti. Tanti jātiādirahitaṃ.
analyzed: gabbhaseyyaka vasena vuttam itaram opapātika vasena ati vadanti tanti jāti ādi rahitam
translated: By the two phrases beginning with “not born” he rejects the idea of coming and going. But some say that the first phrase is stated with reference to one who is born in the womb, and the second with reference to one who is not so born. “That” : that which is devoid of birth, etc.

original: Gamanenāti padasā gamanena. Ñāteyyanti jānitabbaṃ. “Ñātāya”nti vā pāṭho, ñātā ayaṃ
analyzed: gamanena ati padasā gamanena ñāteyyanti jānitabbam ñātāyanti vā pāṭhaḥ ñātā ayam
translated: “By going” : by walking. “To be known” : to be known. Or the reading is “ñātāya,” which means “having known.”

original: nibbānatthikoti adhippāyo.🔽Kāmaṃ pādagamanena gantvā lokassantaṃ ñātuṃ, daṭṭhuṃ, pattuṃ vā na sakkā, apica parimitaparicchinnaṭṭhāne
analyzed: nibbāna atthiko ti adhippāyaḥ  kāmam pāda gamanena gantvā lokaḥ santam ñātum daṭṭhum pattum vā na sakkā apica parimita paricchinna ṭhāne
translated: The meaning is: “having known that it is Nibbana.”

original: taṃ paññāpetvā dassemīti dassento “apicā”tiādimāha. Tattha sasaññimhīti saññāsahite.
analyzed: tam paññāpetvā dassemi iti dassentaḥ apica atiādim āha tattha sa saññimhi iti saññā sahite
translated: Of course, it is not possible to know, see, or reach the end of the world by going there on foot. Nevertheless, in order to show that he can point it out and teach it in a limited, circumscribed place, he says, “And yet,” etc. Herein, “with consciousness” means with the associated consciousness.

original: Tato eva samanake saviññāṇake. Aviññāṇake pana utusamuṭṭhānarūpasamudāyamatte paññāpetuṃ
analyzed: tatas eva samanake sa viññāṇake aviññāṇake pana utu samuṭṭhāna rūpa samudāya matte paññāpetum
translated: Therefore, “with mind” means with the associated mind. But in the case of the “unconscious,” it is not possible to point out the mere mass of materiality originated by temperature.

original: na sakkāti adhippāyo. Lokanti khandhādilokaṃ. Lokanirodhanti tassa lokassa nirujjhanaṃ,
analyzed: na sakkā ati adhippāyaḥ lokanti khandha ādi lokam loka nirodhanti tassa lokassa nirujjhanam
translated: The meaning is: “I can point it out in a place where there is consciousness.” “The world” : the world of aggregates, etc. “The cessation of the world” : the cessation of that world,

original: nibbānameva vā. Adesampi hi taṃ yesaṃ nirodho, tesaṃ vasena upacārato, desatopi niddisīyati
analyzed: nibbānam eva vā adesam pi hi tam yesam nirodho tesam vasena upacārataḥ desatas pi
translated: Or else it is Nibbāna itself. For that is called “the end of the world” figuratively in the sense that cessation comes to those who reach Nibbāna, and it is also called “the end of the world” literally as the place where cessation occurs.

original: yathā “cakkhuṃ loke piyarūpaṃ sātarūpaṃ, etthesā taṇhā pahīyamānā pahīyati, ettha
analyzed: yathā cakkhum loke piya rūpam sāta rūpam etthā isā taṇhā pahīyamānā pahīyati ettha
translated: “The eye, bhikkhus, in the world is pleasant and agreeable, and it is through attachment thereto that the world is in bondage.

original: nirujjhamānā nirujjhatī”ti.
analyzed: nirujjhamānā nirujjhati iti
translated: “The ear … the nose … the tongue … the body … the mind … “

original: Gamanenāti pākatikagamanena. Lokassantoti saṅkhāralokassa anto antakiriyāhetubhūtaṃ🔽nibbānaṃ. Kudācananti kadācipi. Apatvāti aggamaggena anadhigantvā. Pamocananti pamutti🔽nissaraṇaṃ. Tasmāti yasmā lokassantaṃ apatvā vaṭṭadukkhato mutti natthi, tasmā. Haveti🔽nipātamattaṃ. Lokavidūti sabhāvādito sabbaṃ lokaṃ jānanto. Sumedhoti sundarapañño.
analyzed: gamanena āti pākatika gamanena lokaḥ antaḥ ti saṅkhāra lokassa antaḥ anta kiriyā hetu bhūtam  nibbānam kudācana nti a patvā ati aggamaggena an adhigantvā pamocana nti pamutti  nissaraṇam tasmā iti yasmā lokaḥ santam a patvā vaṭṭa dukkhataḥ mutti natthi tasmā hava iti  nipāta mattam loka vidū iti sabhā vāditaḥ sabbam lokam jānantaḥ sumedhaḥ iti sundara pañño
translated: “Going” is going by the normal path. “The end of the world” is Nibbāna, which is the cause of the ending of the world of formations.🔽“Without having reached” means without having attained by the path that leads to it. “Liberation” is the deliverance, the escape,🔽“Therefore” means since there is no liberation from the suffering of the round without reaching the end of the world. “Indeed” is a particle. “The world’s knower” is he who knows the world in all its modes. “The wise one” is he who has beautiful wisdom.🔽“The world’s ender” is he who, having known the world by the penetration of understanding, has ended the world by the penetration of abandoning.

original: Lokantagūti pariññābhisamayena lokaṃ viditvā pahānābhisamayena lokantagū. Maggabrahmacariyavāsassa
analyzed: lokantagū ti pariññā abhisamayena lokam viditvā pahāna abhisamayena lokantagū magga brahmacariya vāsassa
translated: “The world’s seer” is he who has seen the world by the penetration of understanding. “The world’s knower” is he who knows the world in all its modes. “The wise one” is he who has beautiful wisdom.

original: pariniṭṭhitattā vusitabrahmacariyo. Sabbesaṃ kilesānaṃ samitattā, catusaccadhammānaṃ
analyzed: pariniṭṭhita ttā vusita brahmacariyaḥ sabbesam kilesānam samita ttā catu sacca dhammānam
translated: and he had lived the life and done his task, and so had fulfilled the holy life. He had quelled all the corruptions,

original: vā abhisamitattā samitāvī. Nāsīsati na pattheti. Yathā imaṃ lokaṃ, evaṃ parañca lokaṃ appaṭisandhikattā.
analyzed: vā abhisamita ttā samitāvī na āsīsati na pattheti yathā imam lokam evam param ca lokam appaṭisandhika ttā
translated: He has lived the spiritual life because he has brought it to its culmination. He is a sage because he has quieted all defilements or because he has quieted the four noble truths. He does not long for the world, i.e. he does not long for the world beyond, because he does not grasp after it.

original: 136. Evaṃ yadipi lokavidutā anavasesato dassitā sabhāvato dassitattā, loko pana ekadeseneva
analyzed: evam yadi pi loka vidu tā anavasesataḥ dassitā sabhāvataḥ dassita ttā loko pana eka desena iva
translated: Although the state of being a knower of the worlds has been shown here in its entirety by the word “world,” the word “world” itself has been shown only in part.

original: vuttoti taṃ anavasesato dassetuṃ “apica tayo lokā”tiādi vuttaṃ. Tattha indriyabaddhānaṃ🔽khandhānaṃ samūho, santāno ca sattaloko. Rūpādīsu sattavisattatāya satto, lokīyanti
analyzed: vuttaḥ ti tam anavasesataḥ dassetum api ca tayo lokā tiādi vuttam tattha indriya baddhānam  khandhānam samūhaḥ santāno ca satta lokaḥ rūpa ādīsu satta visatta tāya sattaḥ
translated: Therefore, in order to show it in its entirety, he said: “Moreover, there are three worlds.” Herein, the world of beings is the collection and continuity of aggregates bound by the life-faculty.🔽It is a being because it is made up of seven or twenty aspects, and it is a world because good and bad states and their ripening occur in it.

original: ettha kusalākusalaṃ, tabbipāko cāti lokoti. Anindriyabaddhānaṃ rūpādīnaṃ samūho,
analyzed: ettha kusala akusalam tad vipāko ca ati anindriya baddhānam rūpa ādīnam samūhaḥ
translated: The world of the physical cosmos is the collection and continuity of the forms, etc., not bound by the life-faculty.🔽It is a world because the physical cosmos occurs in it.

original: santāno ca okāsaloko lokiyanti ettha tasā, thāvarā ca, tesañca okāsabhūtoti. Tadādhāratāya
analyzed: ca okāsa lokaḥ ettha tasā thāvarā ca tesam ca okāsa bhūtā iti tad ādhāra tāya
translated: The world of designation is the world of the physical cosmos itself, because it is the basis for the designation of the world of beings.

original: hesa “bhājanaloko”tipi vuccati. Ubhayepi khandhā saṅkhāraloko paccayehi saṅkharīyanti,🔽lujjanti palujjanti cāti. Āhāraṭṭhitikāti paccayaṭṭhitikā, paccayāyattavuttikāti
analyzed: hesa bhājana lokaḥ ti pi vuccati ubhaye pi khandhā saṅkhāra lokaḥ paccayehi saṅkharīyanti  lujjanti palujjanti ca ati āhāra ṭṭhitikā ati paccaya ṭṭhitikā paccaya āyatta vuttikā ati
translated: It is also called the world of the physical basis. Both the aggregates and the world of formations are the world of formations because they are formed by conditions,

original: attho. Paccayattho hettha āhāra-saddo “ayamāhāro anuppannassa vā kāmacchandassa uppādāyā”tiādīsu
analyzed: atthaḥ paccaya tthaḥ ha ittha āhāra saddaḥ ayam āhāraḥ anuppannassa vā kāmacchandassa uppādāya ati ādīsu
translated: and because they break up and fall away. “By nutriment maintained” : maintained by conditions; dependent on conditions is the meaning. The word “nutriment” here has the meaning of condition, as in the passage: “This nutriment is for the arising of unarisen passion, and for the increase, expansion, and fulfilment by growth of arisen passion” .

original: viya. Evaṃ hi “sabbe sattā”ti iminā asaññasattāpi pariggahitā honti. Sā panāyaṃ āhāraṭṭhitikatā
