analyzed: viya evam hi sabbe sattā ti iminā asañña sattā api pariggahitāḥ honti sā pana ayam āhāra ṭṭhitika tā
translated: For if it were not so, then the “all beings” would include the non-percipient beings. And this being maintained by nutriment is,

original: nippariyāyato saṅkhāradhammo, na sattadhammoti āha “āhāraṭṭhitikāti āgataṭṭhāne saṅkhāraloko veditabbo”ti.
analyzed: nippariyāyataḥ saṅkhāra dhammaḥ na satta dhammaḥ ti āha āhāra ṭṭhitikā ati āgata ṭṭhāne saṅkhāra loko veditabbo ti
translated: in the ultimate sense, a state of the formations aggregate, not of the life faculty. That is why it is said: “Where it is said ‘by nutriment maintained,’ the world of formations should be understood.”

original: Yadi evaṃ “sabbe sattā”ti idaṃ kathanti? Puggalādhiṭṭhānā desanāti nāyaṃ doso. Yathā
analyzed: yadi evam sabbe sattā ati idam kathanti puggala adhiṭṭhānā desanā ati na ayam dosaḥ yathā
translated: If that is so, why is it said “all beings”? —There is no fault here, because the teaching is based on the individual.

original: aññatthāpi “ekadhamme, bhikkhave, bhikkhu sammā nibbindamāno sammā virajjamāno sammā
analyzed: aññattha api eka dhamme bhikkhave bhikkhu sammā nibbindamānaḥ sammā virajjamānaḥ sammā
translated: For elsewhere too it is said: “Bhikkhus, when a bhikkhu becomes completely dispassionate towards one thing, when he sees its drawbacks and abandons infatuation with it, then, I say, he is incapable of any breach of moral discipline that would cause his downfall” .

original: vimuccamāno sammā pariyantadassāvī sammadatthaṃ abhisamecca diṭṭheva dhamme dukkhassantakaro
analyzed: vimuccamānaḥ sammā pariyanta dassāvī sammad attham abhisamecca diṭṭhe iva dhamme dukkha ssanta karo
translated: He is liberated, seeing the end of suffering as it really is.🔽What is the one thing? All beings subsist by nutriment.’

original: hoti. Katamasmiṃ ekadhamme? Sabbe sattā āhāraṭṭhitikā”ti. Diṭṭhigatikānaṃ sassatādivasena🔽“attā, loko”ti ca parikappanā yebhuyyena sattavisayā, na saṅkhāravisayāti āha “sassato
analyzed: hoti katamasmin eka dhamme sabbe sattā āhāra ṭṭhitikā ati diṭṭhi gatikānam sassata ādi vasena  ca parikappanā yebhuyyena satta visayā na saṅkhāra visayā ti āha sassataḥ
translated: The theorists’ assumption of a self and world as eternal, etc.,

original: lokoti vā asassato lokoti vā āgataṭṭhāne sattaloko veditabbo”ti.
analyzed: loko iti vā a sassataḥ loko iti vā āgata ṭṭhāne satta loko veditabbo ti
translated: is for the most part based on the living being, not on formations. That is why he said: ‘The world of living beings should be understood as the “world” in the passage: “The world is eternal” or “The world is not eternal.” ’

original: Yāvatā candimasūriyā pariharantīti yattake ṭhāne candimasūriyā parivattanti paribbhamanti.
analyzed: yāvatā candima sūriyā pariharanti iti yattake ṭhāne candima sūriyā parivattanti paribbhamanti
translated: As far as the sun and moon revolve: in the region where the sun and moon move and revolve.

original: Disā bhanti virocamānāti tesaṃ paribbhamaneneva tā disā pabhassarā hutvā virocanti.
analyzed: disāḥ bhanti virocamānā ati tesam paribbhamanena iva tāḥ disāḥ pabhassarāḥ hutvā virocanti
translated: The quarters shine and glow: by their moving and revolving, those quarters become bright and glow.

original: Tāva sahassadhā lokoti tattakaṃ sahassappakāro okāsaloko, sahassalokadhātuyoti attho.
analyzed: tāva sahassadhā loko ti tattakam sahassa ppakāro okāsa loko sahassa lokadhātuyo ti attho
translated: The world is so great: the world-sphere is so great, consisting of a thousand worlds.

original: “Tāva sahassavā”ti vā pāṭho.
analyzed: tāva sahassavāti vā pāṭhaḥ
translated: The reading is also “Tāva sahassavā” .

original: Tampīti taṃ tividhampi lokaṃ. Tathā hissa sabbathāpi viditoti sambandho. Eko lokoti🔽“sabbe sattā āhāraṭṭhitikā”ti yāya puggalādhiṭṭhānāya kathāya sabbesaṃ saṅkhārānaṃ
analyzed: tam pi iti tam tividham pi lokam tathā hi ssa sabbathā api viditaḥ iti sambandho ekaḥ loko ti  sabbe sattāḥ āhāra ṭṭhitikā ati yāya puggala adhiṭṭhānāya kathāya sabbesam saṅkhārānaṃ
translated: “That” : that threefold world. For it is known in every way by him, thus the construction. “One world” :

original: paccayāyattavuttitā vuttā, tāya sabbo saṅkhāraloko eko ekavidho pakārantarassa abhāvato.
analyzed: paccaya āyatta vutti tā vuttā tāya sabbaḥ saṅkhāra lokaḥ ekaḥ ekavidhaḥ pakāra antarassa abhāvato
translated: “All beings subsist by nutriment” : by this statement of the teaching based on persons, the dependence on conditions of all formations is stated. By that, the whole world of formations is one, of one kind, because there is no other division.

original: Dve lokātiādīsupi iminā nayena attho veditabbo. Nāma-ggahaṇena cettha nibbānassa🔽aggahaṇaṃ, tassa alokasabhāvattā. Nanu ca “āhāraṭṭhitikā”ti ettha paccayāyattavuttitāya
analyzed: dve lokā ti ādīsu pi iminā nayena atthaḥ veditabbaḥ nāma ggahaṇena ca ittha nibbānassa  aggahaṇam tassa a loka sabhāva ttā nanu ca āhāra ṭṭhitikā ti ettha paccaya āyatta vutti tāya
translated: The meaning should be understood in this way also in the case of “two worlds” and so on. The non-grasping of nibbana here by the term “name” is because it does not have the nature of light.🔽But is it not the case that by the words “subsist by nutriment” the states of the path and fruit also come to be called “world” because they subsist in dependence on conditions?

original: maggaphaladhammānampi lokatā āpajjatīti? Nāpajjati, pariññeyyānaṃ dukkhasaccadhammānaṃ🔽idha “loko”ti adhippetattā. Atha vā “na lujjati na palujjatī”ti yo gahito tathā na
analyzed: magga phala dhammānam pi loka tā āpajjati iti na āpajjati pariññeyyānam dukkha sacca dhammānam  idha loko ti adhippeta ttā atha vā na lujjati na palujjati iti yaḥ gahito tathā na
translated: They do not come to be so called, because in this context the world is intended as the states of the truth of suffering that are to be fully understood.🔽Or alternatively, that which is grasped as “not subject to destruction or falling away” is not so, and therefore the supramundane states, which are devoid of that grasping, are not the world.

original: hoti, so lokoti taṃgahaṇarahitānaṃ lokuttarānaṃ natthi lokatā. Upādānānaṃ ārammaṇabhūtā
analyzed: hoti saḥ ti tad gahaṇa rahitānam lokuttarānam natthi lokatā upādānānam ārammaṇa bhūtā
translated: The states that are the objects of clinging are the world in the sense of being the foundation for the defilements of clinging.

original: khandhā upādānakkhandhā. Dasāyatanānīti dasa rūpāyatanāni.
analyzed: khandhāḥ upādāna kkhandhāḥ dasa āyatanāni iti dasa rūpāyatanāni
translated: The aggregates are the clinging-aggregates. The twelve bases are the ten physical bases.

original: Ettha ca “āhāraṭṭhitikā”ti paccayāyattavuttitāvacanena saṅkhārānaṃ aniccatā. Tāya
analyzed: ettha ca āhāra ṭṭhitikā ati paccaya āyatta vutti tā vacanena saṅkhārānam anicca tā tāya
translated: And here the words “the condition for the maintenance of nutriment” indicate the impermanence of formations by the fact that they exist in dependence on conditions.

original: ca “yadaniccaṃ, taṃ dukkhaṃ. Yaṃ dukkhaṃ, tadanattā”ti vacanato dukkhānattatā ca
analyzed: ca yat aniccam tam dukkham yam dukkham tat anattā ati vacanataḥ dukkha anatta tā ca
translated: And by that fact their suffering and their non-self are also indicated, since it is said, “What is impermanent is suffering; what is suffering is non-self” .

original: pakāsitā hontīti tīṇipi sāmaññalakkhaṇāni gahitāni. Nāmanti cattāro arūpino khandhā,
analyzed: pakāsitāḥ honti iti tīṇi pi sāmañña lakkhaṇāni gahitāni nāmanti cattāro arūpino khandhāḥ
translated: So the three general characteristics are included. The “mental” is the four immaterial aggregates,🔽and they are, in fact, contact, etc.;🔽the “material” is the primary and secondary

original: te ca atthato phassādayo. Rūpanti bhūtupādāyarūpāni, tāni ca atthato pathavīādayoti
analyzed: te ca atthato phassa ādayaḥ bhūta upādāya rūpāni tāni ca atthato pathavī ādayaḥ ti
translated: forms, and they are, in fact, the earth element, etc.

original: aviseseneva salakkhaṇato saṅkhārā gahitā. Taggahaṇeneva ye tesaṃ visesā kusalādayo,
analyzed: avisesena iva sa lakkhaṇato saṅkhārāḥ gahitā tad gahaṇena iva ye tesam visesā kusala ādayaḥ
translated: So formations are included by their individual essences without distinction. And by their inclusion their specific categories, such as the wholesome, etc.,

original: hetuādayo ca, tepi gahitā eva hontīti āha “iti ayaṃ saṅkhāralokopi sabbathā vidito”ti.
analyzed: hetu ādayo ca te api gahitāḥ eva honti iti āha iti ayam saṅkhāra lokaḥ api sabbathā viditaḥ ti
translated: and their causes, etc., are also included. That is why it is said, “Thus this world of formations is known in all ways.”🔽The mind “settles” in the sense of “coming to rest” in the eye, etc., as a dwelling is “settled” in the sense of “coming to rest” in a deer,

original: Āgamma cittaṃ seti etthāti āsayo migāsayo viya. Yathā migo gocarāya gantvā paccāgantvā
analyzed: āgamma cittam sa iti ettha ati āsayaḥ miga āsayaḥ viya yathā migaḥ gocarāya gantvā paccā āgantvā
translated: as a deer “settles” in its lair.

original: tattheva vanagahane sayatīti so tassa āsayo, evaṃ aññathā pavattitvāpi cittaṃ āgamma
analyzed: tattha iva vana gahane sayati iti saḥ tassa āsayaḥ evam aññathā pavattitvā api cittam āgamma
translated: He lies down there in the wood, thus it is his lair. So too, the mind, though it occurs otherwise, is said to lie down, to be, in a certain state,

original: yattha seti, so tassa āsayoti vuccati. So pana sassatadiṭṭhiādivasena catubbidho. Vuttañca –
analyzed: yattha sa iti so tassa āsayo ti vuccati so pana sassata diṭṭhi ādi vasena catubbidhaḥ vuttam ca
translated: when it comes to that state. And that is twofold as the eternalist view and the annihilationist view. It is said:🔽“The eternalist and annihilationist views,

original: “Sassatucchedadiṭṭhi ca, khanti cevānulomikā;
analyzed: ca khanti ca iva ānulomikā
translated: And the assent that is in conformity,

original: Yathābhūtañca yaṃ ñāṇaṃ, etaṃ āsayasaddita”nti.
analyzed: yathābhūtam ca yam etam
translated: And the knowledge of how it is: this is called the lair.”

original: Tattha sabbadiṭṭhīnaṃ sassatucchedadiṭṭhīhi saṅgahitattā sabbepi diṭṭhigatikā sattā
analyzed: tattha sabba diṭṭhīnam sassatu cheda diṭṭhīhi saṅgahita ttā sabbe pi diṭṭhi gatikā sattā
translated: Herein, all those who hold views are dependent on these two views, the eternalist and the annihilationist views, because all views are included in these two.

original: imā eva dve diṭṭhiyo sannissitā. Yathāha “dvayanissito khvāyaṃ, kaccāna, loko yebhuyyena
analyzed: imāḥ eva dve diṭṭhiyaḥ sannissitāḥ yathā āha dvaya nissitaḥ khvā ayam kaccāna lokaḥ yebhuyyena
translated: As it is said: “This world, Kaccāna, for the most part depends upon a duality,

original: atthitañca natthitañcā”ti. Atthitāti hi sassataggāho adhippeto, natthitāti ucchedaggāho.
analyzed: atthitañca na tthitañca ati atthitā ati hi sassata ggāhaḥ adhippetaḥ na tthitā ati uccheda ggāhaḥ
translated: upon the eternal and the non-eternal” . For the eternal is the assumption of eternalness, and the non-eternal is the assumption of annihilation.

original: Ayaṃ tāva vaṭṭanissitānaṃ puthujjanānaṃ āsayo. Vivaṭṭanissitānaṃ pana suddhasattānaṃ
analyzed: ayam tāva vaṭṭa nissitānam puthujjanānam āsayaḥ vivaṭṭa nissitānam pana suddha sattānam
translated: This, firstly, is the lair of ordinary people who are dependent on the round of rebirths. But the lair of those pure beings who are dependent on the cessation of the round is twofold:

original: anulomikā khanti, yathābhūtañāṇanti duvidho āsayo.
analyzed: duvidhaḥ
translated: assent that is in conformity and knowledge of how it is.

original: Āsayaṃ jānātīti catubbidhampi sattānaṃ āsayaṃ jānāti. Jānanto ca tesaṃ diṭṭhigatānaṃ, tesañca ñāṇānaṃ appavattikkhaṇepi jānāti. Vuttañhetaṃ –
analyzed: āsayam jānāti iti catubbidham pi sattānam āsayam jānāti jānantaḥ ca tesam diṭṭhi gatānam tesam ca ñāṇānam appavatti khaṇe pi jānāti vuttam ha etam
translated: He knows the inclination of beings in the four modes. And knowing, he knows even the moment of their non-occurrence of the views and the knowledges. For this is said:

original: “Kāmaṃ sevantaññeva jānāti ‘ayaṃ puggalo kāmagaruko kāmāsayo kāmādhimutto’ti, kāmaṃ sevantaññeva jānāti ‘ayaṃ puggalo nekkhammagaruko nekkhammāsayo nekkhammādhimutto’ti”ādi.
analyzed: kāmam sevantañca eva jānāti ayam puggalo kāma garukaḥ kāma āsayaḥ kāma adhimuttaḥ iti kāmam sevantañca eva jānāti ayam puggalo nekkhamma garukaḥ nekkhamma āsayaḥ nekkhamma adhimuttaḥ tiādi
translated: “He knows only one who indulges in sense desires that this person is one who is devoted to sense desires, has the inclination to sense desires, is intent on sense desires. He knows only one who indulges in renunciation that this person is one who is devoted to renunciation, has the inclination to renunciation, is intent on renunciation” .

original: Appahīnabhāvena santāne anu anu sayantīti anusayā, anurūpaṃ kāraṇaṃ labhitvā uppajjantīti🔽attho. Etena nesaṃ kāraṇalābhe uppajjanārahataṃ dasseti. Appahīnā hi kilesā kāraṇalābhe🔽sati uppajjanti. Ke pana te? Rāgādayo satta anāgatā kilesā, atītā, paccuppannā ca
analyzed: appahīna bhāvena santāne anu anu sayanti iti anusayāḥ anurūpam kāraṇam labhitvā uppajjanti iti  attho etena nesam kāraṇa lābhe uppajjana araha tam dasseti appahīnāḥ hi kilesā kāraṇa lābhe  sati uppajjanti ke pana te rāga ādayo satta anāgatā kilesāḥ atītā paccuppannā ca
translated: They lie in wait in the sense of lying in wait in the continuum by way of non-abandonment. The meaning is that they arise when a suitable condition is obtained.🔽This shows that they are ready to arise when a condition is obtained. For defilements that are not abandoned arise when a condition is obtained.

original: taṃsabhāvattā tathā vuccanti. Na hi dhammānaṃ kālabhedena sabhāvabhedo atthi. Taṃ
analyzed: tad sabhāva ttā tathā vuccanti na hi dhammānam kāla bhedena sabhāva bhedaḥ atthi taṃ
translated: But which are they? They are the seven future defilements, the past and present ones being called that because they have that as their nature. For there is no difference in the nature of things according to the distinction of time.

original: sattavidhaṃ anusayaṃ tassa tassa sattassa santāne paroparabhāvena pavattamānaṃ jānāti.
analyzed: sattavidham anusayam tassa tassa sattassa santāne para upara bhāvena pavattamānam jānāti
translated: He knows the seven kinds of underlying tendency that occur in the continuity of this or that being in the form of higher and lower stages.

original: Caritanti sucaritaduccaritaṃ. Taṃ hi vibhaṅge caritaniddese niddiṭṭhaṃ. Atha vā caritanti
analyzed: tam hi vibhaṅge carita niddese niddiṭṭham atha vā
translated: “Conduct” is good conduct and bad conduct. That is described in the Description of Conduct in the Vibhaṅga. Or alternatively,

original: cariyā veditabbā. Tā pana rāgadosamohasaddhābuddhivitakkavasena cha mūlacariyā, tāsaṃ
analyzed: cariyā veditabbā tā pana rāga dosa moha saddhā buddhi vitakka vasena cha mūla cariyā tāsam
translated: “conduct” should be understood as “habit.” But there are six basic habits according to greed, hate, delusion, faith, understanding, and views,

original: apariyanto antarabhedo, saṃsaggabhedo pana tesaṭṭhividho. Taṃ caritaṃ sabhāvato saṃkilesavodānato
analyzed: apariyantaḥ antara bhedo saṃsagga bhedo pana tesaṭṭhividhaḥ tam caritam sabhāvato saṃkilesa vodānato
translated: and their infinite subdivisions according to the distinctions of association. But the classification according to association is thirty-six kinds. He knows that conduct according to its individual essence, according to its defilement and cleansing,

original: samuṭṭhānato phalato nissandatoti evamādinā pakārena jānāti.
analyzed: samuṭṭhānataḥ phalataḥ nissandataḥ ti evamādinā pakārena jānāti
translated: according to its root, according to its fruit, according to its outcome, and so on.

original: Adhimutti ajjhāsayadhātu. Sā duvidhā hīnādhimutti paṇītādhimuttīti. Yāya hīnādhimuttikā
analyzed: adhimutti sā duvidhā hīna adhimutti paṇīta adhimutti iti hīna adhimuttikā
translated: “Disposition” is the element of inclination. It is twofold as low and high. By means of the low disposition

original: sattā hīnādhimuttikeyeva sevanti, paṇītādhimuttikā ca paṇītādhimuttikeyeva. Sā ajjhāsayadhātu
analyzed: sattāḥ hīna adhimuttikā iya iva sevanti paṇīta adhimuttikā ca paṇīta adhimuttikā iya iva sā ajjhāsaya dhātu
translated: beings resort only to those of low disposition, and by means of the high disposition they resort only to those of high disposition. That element of inclination

original: ajjhāsayasabhāvo adhimutti. Taṃ adhimuttiṃ jānāti “imassa adhimutti hīnā, imassa
analyzed: adhimutti tam adhimuttim jānāti imassa adhimutti hīnā imassa
translated: is the individual essence of inclination. He knows that inclination thus: “This inclination is low in this person,🔽this inclination is high in this person.

original: paṇītā”ti, tatthāpi “imassa mudu, imassa mudutarā, imassa mudutamā”tiādinā. Indriyānaṃ
analyzed: paṇītā ati tattha api imassa mudu imassa mudutarā imassa mudutamā iti ādinā
translated: and “superior” , then there too “this is weak, this is weaker, this is weakest” , and so on.

original: hi tikkhamudubhāvādinā yathārahaṃ adhimuttiyā tikkhamudubhāvādiko veditabbo. Tathā
analyzed: hi tikkha mudu bhāva ādinā yathāraham adhimuttiyā tikkha mudu bhāva ādikaḥ veditabbaḥ tathā
translated: For the weak and strong, etc., state of the faculties should be understood according to the weak and strong, etc., state of the resolution.

original: hi vuttaṃ sammohavinodanīyaṃ “heṭṭhā gahitāpi adhimutti idha sattānaṃ tikkhindriyamudindriyabhāvadassanatthaṃ puna gahitā”ti.🔽Apparajaṃ akkhaṃ etesanti apparajakkhā, appaṃ vā rajaṃ paññāmaye akkhimhi etesanti
analyzed: hi vuttam sammoha vinodanīyam heṭṭhā gahitā api adhimutti idha sattānam tikkhindriya mud indriya bhāva dassana attham puna gahitā ati  apparajam akkham etesanti apparajakkhāḥ appam vā rajam paññā maye akkhimhi etesanti
translated: For this is said in the Sammohavinodani: “Resolution, though already included in the faculties, is mentioned again here in order to show beings’ weak and strong faculties” .

original: apparajakkhā, anussadarāgādirajā sattā, te apparajakkhe. Mahārajakkheti etthāpi eseva
analyzed: apparajakkhāḥ anussada rāga ādi rajā sattā te apparajakkhe mahārajakkha iti ettha api esā eva
translated: They have little dust in their eyes: apparajakkha . Or alternatively, they have little dust, that is, defilement, in the eye of understanding: apparajakkha . Beings have much dust in the eye of understanding in the form of greed, etc., but these have little dust in the eye of understanding in the form of greed, etc.

original: nayo. Ussadarāgādirajā mahārajakkhā.🔽Tikkhindriyeti tikhiṇehi saddhādīhi indriyehi samannāgate. Mudindriyeti mudukehi
analyzed: nayaḥ ussada rāga ādi rajā mahārajakkhā  tikkha indriya iti tikhiṇehi saddhā ādīhi indriyehi samannāgate mud indriya iti mudukehi
translated: They have much dust in the eye of understanding: mahārajakkha .🔽They have keen faculties: tikhindriya . They have weak faculties: mudindriya . The faculties that are conditions are what are intended here.

original: saddhādīhi indriyehi samannāgate. Upanissayaindriyāni nāma idhādhippetāni. Svākāreti
analyzed: saddhā ādīhi indriyehi samannāgate upanissaya aindriyāni nāma idha adhippetāni su ākāra iti
translated: They have good faculties: svākārin .

original: sundarākāre kalyāṇapakatike, vivaṭṭajjhāsayeti attho. Suviññāpayeti sammattaniyāmaṃ
analyzed: sundara ākāre kalyāṇa pakatike attho su viññāpaya iti sammatta niyāmam
translated: who are of beautiful appearance, of good nature, of open mind, is the meaning.🔽🔽Suvinñāpaye means

original: viññāpetuṃ sukare saddhe, paññavante ca. Bhabbe abhabbeti ettha bhabbeti kammāvaraṇakilesāvaraṇavipākāvaraṇarahite.🔽Vuttavipariyāyena dvākāraduviññāpayābhabbā veditabbā. Ettha ca “imassa rāgarajo appo,
analyzed: viññāpetum sukare saddhe paññavante ca bhabbe abhabbā iti ettha bhabbā iti kamma āvaraṇa kilesa āvaraṇa vipāka āvaraṇa rahite  vutta vipariyāyena veditabbā ettha ca imassa rāga rajaḥ appo
translated: “Of good disposition” means of open disposition. “Easy to teach” means easy to cause to make the right kind of affirmation, to cause to affirm rightly. “Worthy and unworthy” : here “worthy” means free from the obscurations of kamma, defilements, and kamma result.

original: imassa dosarajo appo”tiādinā apparajakkhesu jānanaṃ veditabbaṃ. Sesesupi eseva nayo.
analyzed: imassa dosa rajaḥ appaḥ ti ādinā apparajakkhesu jānanam veditabbam sesesu pi esa iva nayaḥ
translated: The opposite of this is “unworthy.” “Of little dust” and “of much dust” should be understood as the knowledge of those who have little defilement and those who have much defilement, respectively. The same method applies to the rest.

original: Tasmāti yasmā bhagavā aparimāṇe satte āsayādito anavasesetvā jānāti, tasmā assa bhagavato
analyzed: tasmā iti yasmai bhagavā aparimāṇe satte āsaya āditas an avasesetvā jānāti tasmai assa bhagavataḥ
translated: “Therefore” : because the Exalted One knows the dispositions, etc., of beings without exception,

original: sattalokopi sabbathā vidito.
analyzed: satta lokaḥ api sabbathā viditaḥ
translated: the world of beings is also known to him in all ways.

original: Nanu ca sattesu pamāṇādipi jānitabbo atthīti? Atthi. Tassa pana jānanaṃ na nibbidāya
analyzed: nanu ca sattesu pamāṇa ādi api jānitabbaḥ atthi iti atthi tassa pana jānanam na nibbidāya
translated: But is it not necessary to know the measure, etc., of beings? It is. But that knowledge does not lead to disenchantment,

original: virāgāya nirodhāyāti idha na gahitaṃ, bhagavato pana tampi suviditaṃ suvavatthāpitameva,
analyzed: virāgāya nirodhāya ati na gahitam bhagavataḥ pana tat su viditam
translated: detachment, and cessation, and therefore it is not included here. But the Exalted One knows it well and has well penetrated it.

original: payojanābhāvā desanaṃ nāruḷhaṃ. Tena vuttaṃ –🔽“Atha kho bhagavā parittaṃ nakhasikhāyaṃ paṃsuṃ āropetvā bhikkhū āmantesi ‘taṃ kiṃ🔽maññatha, bhikkhave, katamaṃ nu kho bahutaraṃ – yo vāyaṃ mayā paritto nakhasikhāyaṃ
analyzed: payojana abhāvāḥ desanam na āruḷham tena vuttam  atha kho bhagavā parittam nakha sikhāyam paṃsum āropetvā bhikkhū āmantesi tam kim  maññatha bhikkhave katamam nu kho bahutaram yaḥ vā ayam mayā parittaḥ nakha sikhāyam
translated: and so he did not expound it. Hence it was said:

original: paṃsu āropito, ayaṃ vā mahāpathavī”’tiādi.🔽137. Okāsalokopi sabbathā viditoti sambandho. Cakkavāḷanti lokadhātu. Sā hi nemimaṇḍalasadisena
analyzed: āropitaḥ ayam vā mahā pathavī iti ādi  okāsa lokaḥ api sabbathā vidito ti sambandho cakkavāḷanti lokadhātu sā hi nemi maṇḍala sadisena
translated: “Then the Blessed One took a little dust on the tip of his nail and addressed the bhikkhus thus: ‘What do you think, bhikkhus, which is more: the little dust on the tip of my nail or the great earth? ‘”

original: cakkavāḷapabbatena samantato parikkhittattā “cakkavāḷa”nti vuccati. Catutiṃsasatāni🔽cāti catuadhikāni tiṃsasatāni, tīṇisahassāni, cattārisatāni cāti attho. Aḍḍhuḍḍhānīti
analyzed: cakkavāḷa pabbatena samantataḥ parikkhitta ttā cakkavāḷanti vuccati catutiṃsa satāni  ca ati catu adhikāni tiṃsa satāni tīṇi sahassāni cattāri satāni ca ati atthaḥ aḍḍhuḍḍhāni iti
translated: The world-system is known in all its aspects. The world-sphere is the world-system. It is called “world-sphere” because it is surrounded by a circular mountain like the rim of a wheel.

original: upaḍḍhacatutthāni, tīṇisatāni, paññāsañcāti attho. Nahutānīti dasasahassāni. Saṅkhātāti🔽kathitā. Saṇṭhitīti heṭṭhā, uparito cāti sabbaso ṭhiti.
analyzed: upaḍḍha catutthāni tīṇi satāni paññāsan ca ati attho nahutāni iti dasa sahassāni saṅkhātā ati 🔽kathitā saṇṭhiti iti heṭṭhā uparitas ca ati sabbaso

original: Evaṃ saṇṭhiteti evamavaṭṭhite. Etthāti cakkavāḷe. Accuggato tāvadevāti tattakameva
analyzed: evam saṇṭhitā iti evam avaṭṭhite ettha ati cakkavāḷe accuggato tāvat eva ati tattakam eva
translated: ‘Thus disposed’: thus arranged. ‘Here’: in the world-sphere. ‘So high’: just that much high.

original: caturāsīti yojanasahassāniyeva ubbedho. Na kevalaṃ cettha ubbedhova, atha kho āyāmavitthārāpissa
analyzed: catur āsīti yojana sahassāniyā iva ubbedhaḥ na kevalam ca ittha ubbedhaḥ uva atha kho āyāma vitthārā api issa
translated: The height is only eighty-four thousand leagues. Not only is the height just that much, but also the breadth and the width are

original: tattakāyeva. Vuttañhetaṃ –
analyzed: tattakāya iva vuttam ha etam
translated: just that much. For this is said:

original: “Sineru, bhikkhave, pabbatarājā caturāsīti yojanasahassāni āyāmena, caturāsīti yojanasahassāni vitthārenā”ti.
analyzed: sineru bhikkhave pabbata rājā caturāsīti yojana sahassāni āyāmena caturāsīti yojana sahassāni vitthārena ati
translated: “Bhikkhus, the king of mountains, Sineru, is eighty-four thousand leagues in height and eighty-four thousand leagues in breadth and width.”

original: Tatoti sinerussa heṭṭhā, upari ca vuttappamāṇato. Upaḍḍhupaḍḍhenāti upaḍḍhena upaḍḍhena.
analyzed: tatas ti sinerussa heṭṭhā upari ca vutta ppamāṇataḥ upaḍḍhupaḍḍhena ati upaḍḍhena upaḍḍhena
translated: ‘Beyond that’: below Sineru and above the measure stated. ‘By a half each time’: by a half each time.

original: Idaṃ vuttaṃ hoti – dvācattālīsa yojanasahassāni samudde ajjhogāḷho tattakameva ca
analyzed: idam vuttam hoti dvācattālīsa yojana sahassāni samudde ajjhogāḷhaḥ tattakam eva ca
translated: This is what is meant: the ocean is forty-two thousand leagues deep and just that much above the surface of the water

original: upari uggato yugandharapabbato, ekavīsa yojanasahassāni samudde ajjhogāḷho tattakameva
analyzed: upari uggataḥ yugandhara pabbataḥ ekavīsa yojana sahassāni samudde ajjhogāḷho tattakam eva
translated: Yugandhara Mountain rises up. The ocean is twenty-one thousand leagues deep and just that much above the surface of the water

original: ca upari uggato īsadharo pabbatoti iminā nayena sesesupi upaḍḍhupaḍḍhapamāṇatā veditabbā.
analyzed: ca upari uggataḥ īsadharaḥ pabbato ti iminā nayena sesesu pi upaḍḍhupaḍḍha pamāṇa tā veditabbā
translated: Īsadhara Mountain rises up. In this way the measure of each one should be understood to be half the previous one.

original: Yathā mahāsamuddo yāva cakkavāḷapādamūlā anupubbaninno, evaṃ yāva sinerupādamūlāti
analyzed: yathā mahā samuddaḥ yāva cakkavāḷa pāda mūlā anupubba ninnaḥ evam yāva sineru pāda mūlā ati
translated: Just as the great ocean slopes gradually, so too the mountain slopes gradually down to the foot of the Yugandhara range.

original: heṭṭhā sinerupamāṇato upaḍḍhapamāṇopi yugandharapabbato pathaviyaṃ suppatiṭṭhito,🔽evaṃ īsadharādayopīti daṭṭhabbaṃ. Vuttaṃ hetaṃ “mahāsamuddo, bhikkhave, anupubbaninno
analyzed: heṭṭhā sineru pamāṇataḥ upaḍḍha pamāṇaḥ api yugandhara pabbataḥ pathaviyam su patiṭṭhitaḥ  evam īsadhara ādayaḥ api iti daṭṭhabbam vuttam ha etam mahā samuddaḥ bhikkhave anupubba ninnaḥ
translated: The Yugandhara range is firmly embedded in the earth to the depth of a hundred thousand leagues.🔽The Iṣādhara range and the others should be regarded as half the size of the one previously mentioned.🔽For this is said: “Bhikkhus, the great ocean slopes gradually, inclines gradually, tends gradually, inclines not steeply” .

original: anupubbapoṇo anupubbapabbhāro”ti. Sineruyugandharādīnaṃ antare sīdantarasamuddā nāma.
analyzed: anupubba poṇaḥ anupubba pabbhāraḥ iti sineru yugandhara ādīnam antare sīdantara samuddāḥ nāma
translated: Between Sineru and Yugandhara, etc., there are the Sīdantika oceans.🔽They are, respectively, the same size as Sineru, etc., in breadth.

original: Te vitthārato yathākkamaṃ sineruādīnaṃ accuggatasamānaparimāṇāti vadanti. Brahāti mahanto.
analyzed: te vitthārataḥ yathākkamam sineru ādīnam vadanti mahantaḥ
translated: Brahma is great.

original: Sinerussa samantatoti parikkhipanavasena sinerussa samantato ṭhitā. Sineruṃ tāva
analyzed: sinerussa samantataḥ ti parikkhipana vasena sinerussa samantataḥ ṭhitā sinerum tāva
translated: All round Sineru: surrounding Sineru.

original: parikkhipitvā ṭhito yugandharo, taṃ parikkhipitvā īsadharo. Evaṃ taṃ taṃ parikkhipitvā
analyzed: parikkhipitvā ṭhitaḥ yugandharaḥ tam parikkhipitvā īsadharaḥ evam tam tam parikkhipitvā
translated: The Yugandhara range is situated surrounding Sineru, and the Iṣādhara range surrounds that, and so on.

original: ṭhitā “sinerussa samantato”ti vuttā.
analyzed: ṭhitā sinerussa samantataḥ ti vuttā
translated: They are called “all round Sineru” because they are situated surrounding each one in turn.

original: Yojanānaṃ satānucco, himavā pañca pabbatoti himavā pabbato pañca yojanānaṃ satāni
analyzed: yojanānam satānuccaḥ himavā pañca pabbatā iti himavā pabbataḥ pañca yojanānam satāni
translated: The mountain Himavā is five hundred leagues in height,

original: ucco ubbedho. Nagavhayāti naga-saddena avhātabbā rukkhābhidhānā. Paññāsayojanakkhandhasākhāyāmāti’
analyzed: uccaḥ ubbedhaḥ nagavhayā ti naga saddena a vhātabbā rukkha abhidhānā paññāsa yojana kkhandha sākhāyāmā ti
translated: and it is called ‘the mountain of snow’ because of the snow on it.🔽The trees called ‘Naga’ are to be found there, and they are called ‘Naga’ because of their great size. They are fifty leagues in height,

original: ubbedhato paññāsayojanakkhandhāyāmā, ubbedhato, samantato ca paññāsayojanasākhāyāmā
analyzed: ubbedhataḥ paññāsa yojana kkhandha āyāmā ubbedhataḥ samantataḥ ca paññāsa yojana sākhā āyāmā
translated: and their branches spread out fifty leagues on every side.🔽It is because of the power of the Naga tree that the sun’s orb is so great,

original: ca. Tato eva satayojanavitthiṇṇā, tāvadeva ca uggatā. Yassānubhāvenāti yassā mahantatā🔽kappaṭṭhāyitādippakārena pabhāvena.
analyzed: ca tatas eva sata yojana vitthiṇṇā tāvat eva ca uggatā yassa anubhāvena ati yassā mahanta tā  kappa ṭṭhāyi tā ādi ppakārena pa bhāvena
translated: and that it lasts for an aeon and so on.

original: Garuḷānaṃ simbalirukkho sinerussa dutiyaparibhaṇḍe patiṭṭhito.
analyzed: garuḷānam simbali rukkhaḥ sinerussa dutiya paribhaṇḍe patiṭṭhito
translated: The Simbali tree of the Garudas is found in the second range of the Sineru mountain.

original: Sirīsenāti paccatte karaṇavacanaṃ. Sattamanti liṅgavipallāsena vuttaṃ, sirīso bhavati sattamoti attho.
analyzed: sirīsena iti paccatte karaṇa vacanam sattaman ti liṅga vipallāsena vuttam sirīsaḥ bhavati sattamaḥ ti attho
translated: The Sirisa tree is the seventh.

original: Tattha caṇḍamaṇḍalaṃ heṭṭhā, sūriyamaṇḍalaṃ upari. Tassa āsannabhāvena candamaṇḍalaṃ
analyzed: tattha caṇḍa maṇḍalam heṭṭhā sūriya maṇḍalam upari tassa āsanna bhāvena canda maṇḍalam
translated: Here the moon’s orb is below and the sun’s orb is above. Because of its proximity to the sun’s orb, the moon’s orb is seen as though it were incomplete.

original: attano chāyāya vikalabhāvena upaṭṭhāti. Tāni yojanantarikāni yugandharaggapamāṇe
analyzed: vikala bhāvena upaṭṭhāti tāni yojana antarikāni yugandhara gga pamāṇe
translated: and it appears as if it were divided by his own shadow.

original: ākāse vicaranti. Asurabhavanaṃ sinerussa heṭṭhā. Avīci jambudīpassa. Jambudīpo sakaṭasaṇṭhāno.
analyzed: ākāse vicaranti asura bhavanam sinerussa heṭṭhā avīci jambudīpassa jambudīpo sakaṭa saṇṭhāno
translated: and it appears as if it were divided into parts by his own shadow. They are a yojana apart, and they move in the sky at the height of the Yugandhara range. The Asura world is below Sineru. Avīci is under Jambudīpa. Jambudīpa is shaped like a cart.

original: Aparagoyānaṃ ādāsasaṇṭhāno. Pubbavideho addhacandasaṇṭhāno. Uttarakuru pīṭhasaṇṭhāno.
analyzed: aparagoyānam ādāsa saṇṭhānaḥ pubbavidehaḥ addhacanda saṇṭhānaḥ uttarakuru pīṭha saṇṭhānaḥ
translated: Aparagoyāna is shaped like a half-moon. Pubbavideha is shaped like a seat. Uttarakuru is shaped like a bed.

original: Taṃtaṃnivāsīnaṃ, taṃtaṃparivāradīpavāsīnañca manussānaṃ mukhampi taṃtaṃsaṇṭhānanti
analyzed: taṃtaṃnivāsīnam taṃtaṃparivāradīpavāsīnam ca manussānam mukham pi taṃtaṃsaṇṭhānanti
translated: And they say that the faces of the people who live there are shaped accordingly.

original: vadanti. Tadantaresūti tesaṃ cakkavāḷānaṃ antaresu. Tiṇṇaṃ hi pattānaṃ aññamaññaāsannabhāvena
analyzed: vadanti tad antaresu iti tesam cakkavāḷānam antaresu tiṇṇam hi pattānam aññamañña āsanna bhāvena
translated: Between them: between those world-spheres. For just as three leaves may be fixed together,

original: ṭhapitānaṃ antarasadise tiṇṇaṃ tiṇṇaṃ cakkavāḷānaṃ antare ekeko lokantaranirayo.🔽Anantānīti aparimāṇāni, “ettakānī”ti aññehi minituṃ asakkuṇeyyāni. Bhagavā anantena
analyzed: antara sadise tiṇṇam tiṇṇam cakkavāḷānam antare ekekaḥ lokantaranirayo  anantāni iti aparimāṇāni ettakāni iti aññehi minitum a sakkuṇeyyāni bhagavā anantena
translated: so between three of the world-spheres there is one hell of the “interspaces,”

original: buddhañāṇena avedi “ananto ākāso, ananto sattanikāyo, anantāni cakkavāḷānī”ti tividhampi
analyzed: buddha ñāṇena avedi anantaḥ ākāsaḥ anantaḥ satta nikāyaḥ anantāni cakkavāḷāni iti tividham pi
translated: Infinite: immeasurable. They cannot be measured by saying “so many.” The Blessed One knows them by means of his infinite knowledge of a Buddha. He knows that “space is infinite, the realm of beings is infinite, world-spheres are infinite.”

original: anantaṃ buddhañāṇaṃ paricchindati sayampi anantattā. Yāvatakaṃ hi ñeyyaṃ, tāvatakaṃ
analyzed: anantam buddha ñāṇam paricchindati sayam pi ananta ttā yāvatakam hi ñeyyam tāvatakam
translated: He defines the infinite Buddha-knowledge as infinite because he himself is infinite. For the knowledge is as great as the knowable,

original: ñāṇaṃ. Yāvatakaṃ ñāṇaṃ, tāvatakaṃ ñeyyaṃ. Ñeyyapariyantikaṃ ñāṇaṃ, ñāṇapariyantikaṃ
analyzed: ñāṇam yāvatakam ñāṇam tāvatakam ñeyyam ñeyya pariyantikam ñāṇam ñāṇa pariyantikam
translated: and the knowable is as great as the knowledge. The knowledge reaches the limit of the knowable, and the knowable reaches the limit of the knowledge.

original: ñeyyanti. Tena vuttaṃ “anantena buddhañāṇena avedī”ti. Anantatā cassa anantañeyyapaṭivijjhaneneva
analyzed: ñeyyam ti tena vuttam anantena buddha ñāṇena avedi iti ananta tā ca ssa ananta ñeyya paṭivijjhanena iva
translated: Therefore it was said above, “He has penetrated the infinite with infinite knowledge.” And his infinity should be understood as infinite penetration of the infinite knowable,

original: veditabbā tattha appaṭihatacārattā. Nanu cettha vivaṭṭādīnampi viditatā vattabbāti?
analyzed: veditabbā tattha appaṭihata cāra ttā nanu ca ittha vivaṭṭa ādīnam pi vidita tā vattabbā ti
translated: since he has unimpeded movement there. But should not the penetration of the round also be mentioned here?

original: Saccaṃ vattabbaṃ, sā pana parato abhiññākathāyaṃ āgamissatīti idha na gahitā.
analyzed: saccam vattabbam sā pana paratas abhiññā kathā ayam āgamissati iti idha na gahitā
translated: It should, but it will come in the description of direct knowledge elsewhere , so it is not mentioned here.

original: 138. Attanāti nissakkavacanametaṃ. Guṇehi attanā visiṭṭhatarassāti sambandho. Tara-ggahaṇaṃ
analyzed: attanā iti nissakka vacanam etam guṇehi attanā visiṭṭhatarassa iti sambandhaḥ tara gahaṇam
translated: “Himself” is a reflexive pronoun. The construction is: “he is superior to others by his own special qualities.”

original: cettha “anuttaro”ti padassa atthaniddesatāya kataṃ, na visiṭṭhassa kassaci atthitāya.
analyzed: ca ittha anuttarā ti padassa attha niddesa tāya katam na visiṭṭhassa kassaci atthi tāya
translated: The word “infinite” is used here to show the meaning of the word “unsurpassed,” not because there is anyone else who is surpassed.

original: Sadevake hi loke sadisakappopi nāma koci tathāgatassa natthi, kuto sadiso. Visiṭṭhe
analyzed: sa devake hi loke sadisa kappaḥ api nāma koci tathāgatassa natthi kutas sadisaḥ visiṭṭhe
translated: For in the world with its gods, no one is even equal to the Tathāgata, much less superior.

original: pana kā kathā. Kassacīti kassacipi. Abhibhavatīti sīlasampadāya upanissayabhūtānaṃ
analyzed: pana kā kathā kassaci iti kassaci pi abhibhavati iti sīla sampadāya upanissaya bhūtānam
translated: But what need is there to say so? Kassaci = to anyone. Abhibhavatīti = surpasses. From the time of the attainment of the perfection of virtue, the Teacher’s virtue is unsurpassed, because it is not shared by anyone else, and because it has destroyed the opposing qualities together with their traces.

original: hirottappamettākaruṇānaṃ, visesapaccayānaṃ saddhāsativīriyapaññānañca ukkaṃsappattiyā🔽samudāgamato paṭṭhāya anaññasādhāraṇo savāsanapaṭipakkhassa pahīnattā ukkaṃsapāramippatto🔽satthu sīlaguṇo. Tena bhagavā sadevakaṃ lokaṃ aññadatthu abhibhuyya pavattati, na
analyzed: hira uttappa mettā karuṇānam visesa paccayānam saddhā sati vīriya paññānam ca ukkaṃsa ppattiyā  samudāgamataḥ paṭṭhāya anañña sādhāraṇaḥ sa vāsana paṭipakkhassa pahīna ttā ukkaṃsa pārami patto  satthu sīla guṇo tena bhagavā sa devakam lokam añña datthu abhibhuyya pavattati na
translated: It is unsurpassed because it is the basis for the development of shame, moral dread, loving kindness, and compassion, and of the special conditions of faith, mindfulness, energy, and wisdom.

original: sayaṃ kenaci abhibhuyyatīti adhippāyo. Evaṃ samādhiguṇādīsupi yathārahaṃ vattabbaṃ.
analyzed: sayam kenaci abhibhuyyati iti adhippāyaḥ evam samādhi guṇa ādīsu pi yathāraham vattabbam
translated: The intention is that the Blessed One surpasses the world with its gods and men, and is not himself surpassed by anyone, because of the attainment of the perfection of virtue. The same method of explanation should be applied to the perfections of concentration, etc., as is appropriate in each case.

original: Sīlādayo cete lokiyalokuttaramissakā veditabbā. Vimuttiñāṇadassanaṃ pana lokiyaṃ kāmāvacarameva.
analyzed: sīla ādayo ca ite lokiya lokuttara missakā veditabbā vimutti ñāṇa dassanam pana lokiyam kāmāvacaram eva
translated: It should be understood that virtue, etc., are a mixture of mundane and supramundane states. But the knowledge and vision of liberation is mundane and belongs to the sense sphere.

original: Yadi evaṃ, kathaṃ tena sadevakaṃ lokaṃ abhibhavatīti? Tassāpi ānubhāvato asadisattā.
analyzed: yadi evam katham tena sa devakam lokam abhibhavati iti tassa api ānubhāvataḥ asadisa ttā
translated: If that is so, how does it surpass the world with its gods? Because of its unique power.

original: Tampi hi visayato, pavattito, pavatti ākārato ca uttaritarameva. Taṃ hi anaññasādhāraṇaṃ
analyzed: tam pi hi visayataḥ pavattitaḥ ākārato ca uttaritaram eva tam hi anañña sādhāraṇam
translated: For that too is superior to the others in object, mode of progress, and mode of progress in aspect. For that is not shared by anyone else, and it is

original: satthu vimuttiguṇaṃ ārabbha pavattati, pavattamānañca atakkāvacaraṃ paramagambhīraṃ
analyzed: satthu vimutti guṇam ārabbha pavattati pavattamānam ca a takka avacaram parama gambhīram
translated: It occurs in the Blessed One’s mental continuity, and it occurs in a way that is beyond the scope of speculation, supremely profound,

original: saṇhasukhumaṃ savisayaṃ paṭipakkhadhammānaṃ suppahīnattā suṭṭhu pākaṭaṃ vibhūtataraṃ🔽katvā pavattati, sammadeva ca vasībhāvassa pāpitattā, bhavaṅgaparivāsassa ca atiparittakattā
analyzed: saṇha sukhumam sa visayam paṭipakkha dhammānam su pahīna ttā suṭṭhu pākaṭam vibhūtataram  katvā pavattati sammat eva ca vasībhāvassa pāpita ttā bhavaṅga parivāsassa ca ati parittaka ttā
translated: subtle, and hard to see, and it occurs in a way that is very evident because of the complete absence of opposing states,

original: lahuṃ lahuṃ pavattatīti.
analyzed: lahum lahum pavattati iti
translated: and it occurs very rapidly because of the complete mastery of it and because of the extreme brevity of the life continuum.

original: Evaṃ sīlādiguṇehi bhagavato uttaritarassa abhāvaṃ dassetvā idāni sadisassāpi abhāvaṃ
analyzed: evam sīla ādi guṇehi bhagavataḥ uttaritarassa abhāvam dassetvā idāni sadisassa api abhāvam
translated: Having thus shown that there is no one superior to the Blessed One in virtue, etc., the Exalted One now shows that there is no one equal to him either:

original: dassetuṃ “asamo”tiādi vuttaṃ. Tattha asamoti ekasmiṃ kāle natthi etassa sīlādiguṇena
analyzed: dassetum asamaḥ tiādi vuttam tattha asamaḥ ti ekasmin kāle na atthi etassa sīla ādi guṇena
translated: “Incomparable” : at one time there was no one equal to him in virtue, etc.,

original: samā sadisāti asamo. Tathā asamehi atītānāgatabuddhehi samo, asamā vā samā etassāti
analyzed: samā sadisā ati asamaḥ tathā asamehi atīta anāgata buddhehi samaḥ asamāḥ vā samāḥ etassa ati
translated: “incomparable” means “without equal.” Likewise, “equal to the unequalled” means “equal to the Buddhas of the past and future,” or “equal to the unequalled” means “equal to those without equal.”

original: asamasamo. Sīlādiguṇena natthi etassa paṭimāti appaṭimo. Sesapadadvayepi eseva nayo.
analyzed: asamasamaḥ sīla ādi guṇena na atthi etassa paṭimā ati appaṭimaḥ sesa pada dvaye pi esa iva nayo
translated: “Without equal” means “without counterpart.” The same method applies to the other two terms.

original: Tattha upamāmattaṃ paṭimā, sadisūpamā paṭibhāgo, yugaggāhavasena ṭhito paṭipuggalo veditabbo.
analyzed: tattha upamā mattam paṭimā sadisūpamā paṭibhāgaḥ yuga ggāha vasena ṭhitaḥ paṭi puggalaḥ veditabbo
translated: Herein, the image is the measure of the simile, the reflection is the like, and the counterpart should be understood as the person who stands opposite.

original: Na kho panāhaṃ samanupassāmīti mama samantacakkhunā hatthatale āmalakaṃ viya sabbalokaṃ
analyzed: na kho pana aham samanupassāmi iti mama samanta cakkhunā hattha tale āmalakam viya sabba lokam
translated: I do not see: I do not see in the whole world, with my all-round eye, as though I were looking at a ripe emblic myrobalan fruit in the palm of my hand.

original: passantopi tattha sadevake…pe… pajāya attanā attato sīlasampannataraṃ sampannatarasīlaṃ
analyzed: passantaḥ api tattha sa deva kepe pajāya attanā attataḥ sīla sampannataram sampannatara sīlam
translated: In the whole world with its deities, etc., I do not see any person who is more perfect in virtue than myself, who has a more perfect virtue.

original: kañci puggalaṃ na kho pana passāmi, tādisassa abhāvatoti adhippāyo. Aggappasādasuttādīnīti ettha –
analyzed: kañci puggalam na kho pana passāmi tādisassa abhāvato ti adhippāyaḥ agga ppasāda sutta ādīni iti ettha
translated: The meaning is that I do not see anyone like him, because there is no one like him. The “Discourse on Supreme Confidence,” etc., are as follows:

original: “Yāvatā, bhikkhave, sattā apadā vā dvipadā vā catuppadā vā bahuppadā vā rūpino vā
analyzed: yāvatā bhikkhave sattāḥ apadāḥ vā dvipadāḥ vā catuppadāḥ vā bahuppadāḥ vā rūpinaḥ vā
translated: “Bhikkhus, whatever beings there are, whether footless or with two feet, four feet, or many feet, whether having form or formless,

original: arūpino vā saññino vā asaññino vā nevasaññināsaññino vā, tathāgato tesaṃ aggamakkhāyati🔽arahaṃ sammāsambuddho. Ye, bhikkhave, buddhe pasannā, agge te pasannā. Agge kho pana
analyzed: arūpinaḥ vā saññinaḥ vā asaññinaḥ vā nevasaññinā asaññinaḥ vā tathāgataḥ tesam aggam akkhāyati  araham sammāsambuddhaḥ ye bhikkhave buddhe pasannāḥ agge te pasannāḥ agge kho pana
translated: whether conscious or unconscious, or neither conscious nor unconscious, the Tathāgata, the Arahant, the Perfectly Enlightened One is declared the chief among them.🔽Those who have supreme confidence in the Buddha have supreme confidence in the foremost.

original: pasannānaṃ aggo vipāko hotī”ti –
analyzed: pasannānam aggaḥ vipākaḥ hoti iti
translated: For those who have supreme confidence in the foremost, the result ripens in the foremost.”

original: Idaṃ aggappasādasuttaṃ. Ādi-saddena –
analyzed: idam aggappasāda suttam ādi saddena
translated: This is the Discourse on Supreme Confidence. The word “etc.” includes:

original: “Sadevake…pe… sadevamanussāya tathāgato abhibhū anabhibhūto aññadatthudaso vasavattī, tasmā ‘tathāgato’ti vuccatī”ti –
analyzed: sa deva kepe sa deva manussāya tathāgataḥ an abhibhūtaḥ añña datthudasaḥ vasa vattī tasmā tathāgataḥ iti vuccati iti
translated: “The Tathagata is the vanquisher, the unvanquished, the all-seer, the mighty, the powerful, the supreme one, the controller, the wielder of power, the charioteer, the driver of creatures to be tamed, the teacher of gods and men, the Buddha, the Exalted One, the god of gods.”🔽Such are the passages to be understood.

original: Evamādīni suttapadāni veditabbāni. Ādikā gāthāyoti ettha –
analyzed: evamādīni sutta padāni veditabbāni ādikāḥ gāthāyaḥ ti ettha
translated: The first verse:

original: “Ahaṃ hi arahā loke, ahaṃ satthā anuttaro;
analyzed: aham hi arahā loke aham satthā anuttaro
translated: “I am the Arahant in the world, I am the supreme teacher,

original: Ekomhi sammāsambuddho, sītibhūtosmi nibbuto. ;
analyzed: ekaḥ amhi sammāsambuddhaḥ sīti bhūtaḥ asmi nibbutaḥ
translated: I alone am fully enlightened, I am the one who has gone to peace.

original: “Danto damayataṃ seṭṭho, santo samayataṃ isi;
analyzed: dantaḥ damayatam seṭṭhaḥ santaḥ samayatam isi
translated: “I am the tamed one among the tamed, the sage among the restrained,

original: Mutto mocayataṃ aggo, tiṇṇo tārayataṃ varo. ;
analyzed: muttaḥ mocayatam aggaḥ tiṇṇaḥ tārayatam varaḥ
translated: I am the freed one among the freed, the foremost one who has crossed over.

original: “Nayimasmiṃ loke parasmiṃ vā pana,🔽Buddhena seṭṭho sadiso ca vijjati;
analyzed: nayimasmin loke parasmin vā pana  buddhena seṭṭhaḥ sadisaḥ ca vijjati
translated: “In this world or the next, there is no one equal to me,🔽No one resembling me is found,

original: Yamāhu dakkhiṇeyyānaṃ aggataṃ gato,
analyzed: yam āhu dakkhiṇeyyānam aggatam gataḥ
translated: Whom they call the foremost of those worthy of offerings,

original: Puññatthikānaṃ vipulaphalesina”nti. –
analyzed: puññatthikānam vipula phala esinam ti
translated: The one who has gone to the foremost state, seeking great fruit for those who desire merit.”

original: Evamādikā gāthā vitthāretabbā.
analyzed: evamādikā gāthā vitthāretabbā
translated: Such are the verses to be elaborated.

original: 139. Dametīti sameti, kāyasamādīhi yojetīti attho. Taṃ pana kāyasamādīhi yojanaṃ
analyzed: dameti iti sameti kāya sama ādīhi yojeti iti attho tam pana kāya sama ādīhi yojanam
translated: “Tames” means “restrains,” the meaning being “he yokes with bodily restraint.” But this yoking with bodily restraint

original: yathārahaṃ tadaṅgavinayādīsu patiṭṭhāpanaṃ hotīti āha “vinetīti vuttaṃ hotī”ti. Dametuṃ🔽yuttāti damanārahā. Amanussapurisāti ettha na manussāti amanussā. Taṃsadisatā ettha
analyzed: yathāraham tad aṅga vinaya ādīsu patiṭṭhāpanam hoti iti āha vineti iti vuttam hoti iti dametum  yuttā ati damana arahā amanussa purisā ati ettha na manussā ati amanussā tad sadisa tā ettha
translated: and so he says, “he disciplines” is said.🔽Worthy of discipline: fit to be disciplined.

original: jotīyati, tena manussattamattaṃ natthi, aññaṃ samānanti yakkhādayo “amanussā”ti adhippetā,
analyzed: jotīyati tena manussa attamattam natthi aññam samānanti yakkha ādayaḥ amanussā ti adhippetā
translated: Non-human beings: here “non-human” is not human. That similarity is what is intended here. Therefore there is only the absence of humanity, and the rest is the same. Thus the non-human beings intended are ghosts, etc.,

original: na ye keci manussehi aññe. Tathā hi tiracchānapurisānaṃ visuṃ gahaṇaṃ kataṃ, yakkhādayo
analyzed: na ye keci manussehi aññe tathā hi tiracchāna purisānam visum gahaṇam katam yakkha ādayo
translated: not just anyone who is not human. For thus the animals are mentioned separately, and only ghosts, etc., are specified.

original: eva ca niddiṭṭhā. Apalālo himavantavāsī. Cūḷodaramahodarā nāgadīpavāsino. Aggisikhadhūmasikhā
analyzed: eva ca niddiṭṭhāḥ apalālaḥ himavanta vāsī cūḷodara mahodarāḥ nāgadīpa vāsinaḥ aggisikha dhūmasikhā
translated: Apalāla is a mountain-dweller of the Himalayas. Cūḷodara and Mahodara are inhabitants of the island of Lanka. Aggisikha and Dhūmasikha are inhabitants of the island of Ceylon.

original: sīhaḷadīpavāsino. Nibbisā katā dosavisassa vinodanena. Tenāha “saraṇesu ca sīlesu
analyzed: nibbisā katā dosa visassa vinodanena tena āha saraṇesu ca sīlesu
translated: Nibbisā is so called because she removed the poison of hate. Therefore it is said: “established in the refuges and in virtue.”

original: ca patiṭṭhāpitā”ti. Kūṭadantādayoti ādi-saddena ghoṭamukhaupāligahapatiādīnaṃ saṅgaho
analyzed: ca patiṭṭhāpitā ati kūṭa danta ādayaḥ ti ādi saddena ghoṭa mukha aupāli gahapati ādīnam saṅgahaḥ
translated: Kūṭadanta, etc.: the word “etc.” should be seen as including Ghoṭamukha, Upāli, the householder, and others.

original: daṭṭhabbo. Sakkadevarājādayoti ādi-saddena ajakalāpayakkhabakabrahmādīnaṃ saṅgaho
analyzed: daṭṭhabbaḥ sakka devarāja ādayaḥ iti ādi saddena aja kalāpa yakkha baka brahma ādīnam saṅgahaḥ
translated: Sakka, the king of the gods, etc.: the word “etc.” should be seen as including Ajakalāpaka, the ghost, Baka, Brahmā, and others.

original: daṭṭhabbo. Idaṃ cettha suttanti idaṃ kesisuttaṃ. Vinītā vicitrehi vinayanūpāyehīti
analyzed: daṭṭhabbaḥ idam ca ittha suttam ti idam kesi suttam vinītāḥ vicitrehi vinaya nūpāyehi iti
translated: This is the Thread here. “Tamed in various ways”:

original: etasmiṃ atthe vitthāretabbaṃ yathārahaṃ saṇhādīhi upāyehi vinayassa dīpanato.🔽Visuddhasīlādīnaṃ paṭhamajjhānādīnīti “visuddhasīlassa paṭhamajjhānaṃ, paṭhamajjhānalābhino
analyzed: etasmin atthe vitthāretabbam yathāraham saṇha ādīhi upāyehi vinayassa dīpanataḥ  visuddha sīla ādīnam paṭhama jhāna ādīni iti visuddha sīlassa paṭhama jhānam paṭhama jhāna lābhinaḥ
translated: in this sense it should be elaborated in detail, since the Discipline is demonstrated by the method of the gentle etc. as is fitting.🔽“The first jhana for one whose virtue is purified, the second jhana for one who has obtained the first jhana” and so on: the construction is that he teaches the successive special qualities of each one.

original: dutiyajjhāna”ntiādinā tassa tassa uparūpari visesaṃ ācikkhantoti sambandho. Sotāpannādīnanti🔽etthāpi eseva nayo. “Dantepi dametiyevā”ti idaṃ pubbe “sabbena sabbaṃ damathaṃ anupagatā
analyzed: dutiya jhāna nti ādinā tassa tassa upari upari visesaṃ ācikkhanto ti sambandho sotāpanna ādīnam ti  ettha api esā iva nayaḥ dante pi dametiyā iva ati idam pubbe sabbena sabbam damatham an upagatā
translated: “Stream-enterers and so on”:

original: purisadammā”ti vuttāti katvā vuttaṃ. Ye pana vippakatadammabhāvā sabbathā dametabbataṃ
analyzed: purisa dammā ati vuttā ati katvā vuttam ye pana vippakata damma bhāvā sabbathā
translated: the same method applies here too. “He tames even those already tamed” is said because it was said earlier, “Men to be tamed who have not gone to all-in-all taming” .🔽But those who, because of their already tamed state, do not exceed what is to be tamed

original: nātivattā, te satte sandhāya “dantepi dametiyevā”ti vuttaṃ. Tepi hi purisadammā evāti,
analyzed: na ativattā te satte sandhāya dante pi dametiyā iva ati vuttam te pi hi purisa dammāḥ evā ti
translated: are referred to in the words “He tames even those already tamed.” For they too are men to be tamed

original: yato ne satthā dameti.
analyzed: yatas ne satthā dameti
translated: since the Master tames them.

original: Atthapadanti atthābhibyañjakapadaṃ, vākyanti attho. Vākyena hi atthābhibyatti, na
analyzed: attha padanti attha abhibyañjaka padam vākyanti atthaḥ vākyena hi attha abhibyatti na
translated: “The word ‘meaning’ is the word that expresses the meaning; the ‘phrase’ is the meaning. For the meaning is expressed by the phrase,

original: nāmādipadamattena. Ekapadabhāvena ca anaññasādhāraṇo satthu purisadammasārathibhāvo🔽dassito hoti. Tenāha “bhagavā hī”tiādi. Aṭṭha disāti aṭṭha samāpattiyo. Tā hi aññamaññasambandhāpi🔽asaṃkiṇṇabhāvena dissanti apadissantīti disā, disā viyāti vā disā. Asajjamānāti na🔽sajjamānā vasībhāvappattiyā nissaṅgacārā. Dhāvanti javanavuttiyogato. Ekaṃyeva disaṃ🔽dhāvati, attano kāyaṃ aparivattentoti adhippāyo. Satthārā pana damitā purisadammā
analyzed: nāma ādi pada mattena eka pada bhāvena ca anañña sādhāraṇaḥ satthu purisa damma sārathi bhāvo  dassitaḥ hoti tena āha bhagavā hi itiādi aṭṭha disā ati aṭṭha samāpattiyo tāḥ hi aññamañña sambandhā api  a saṃkiṇṇa bhāvena dissanti apadissanti iti disā disā viyāti vā disā a sajjamānā ati na  sajjamānāḥ vasībhāva ppattiyā nissaṅga cārāḥ dhāvanti javana vutti yogataḥ ekaṃ yā iva disam  dhāvati attanaḥ kāyam a parivattento ti adhippāyaḥ satthārā pana damitā purisa dammā
translated: not by the mere word, etc. And by the single word ‘Lord’ the Master’s state of being a charioteer for taming human beings, which is not shared by others, is shown.

original: ekiriyāpatheneva aṭṭha disā dhāvanti. Tenāha “ekapallaṅkeneva nisinnā”ti. Aṭṭha disāti
analyzed: eka iriyāpathena iva aṭṭha disā dhāvanti tena āha eka pallaṅkena iva nisinnā ati aṭṭha disā iti
translated: Hence it is said, ‘The Lord, the Tamer of what is to be tamed’ , etc. ‘The eight directions’: the eight attainments. For these, though mutually related, are seen as unmixed, and so they are ‘directions’ . Or alternatively, they are ‘directions’ in the sense of directing .

original: ca nidassanamattametaṃ, lokiyehi agatapubbaṃ nirodhasamāpattidisaṃ, amatadisañca pakkhandanato.
analyzed: ca nidassana mattam etam lokiyehi agata pubbam nirodha samāpatti disam amata disam ca pakkhandanato
translated: ‘Without stirring’: without stirring, without moving, without wavering, without wavering, without wavering, without wavering, without wavering, without wavering, without wavering, without
