original: 140. Diṭṭhadhammo vuccati paccakkho attabhāvo, tattha niyuttoti diṭṭhadhammiko, idhalokattho.
analyzed: diṭṭhadhammo vuccati paccakkhaḥ attabhāvo tattha niyuttaḥ ti diṭṭhadhammikaḥ idhaloka attho
translated: “The life to come” is the next world; one who is occupied with that is “concerned with the life to come” .🔽“The ultimate aim” is Nibbāna.🔽“As is fitting” means according to what is appropriate.🔽“He instructs” means he trains; he establishes in that aim.🔽“He has a way” means he has a method.

original: Kammakilesavasena samparetabbato sammā gantabbato samparāyo, paraloko, tattha niyuttoti
analyzed: kamma kilesa vasena samparetabbato sammā gantabbato samparāyo para loko tattha niyutto ti
translated: “He has a method” means he has a method.🔽“He has a method” means he has a method.🔽“He has a method” means he has a method.🔽“He has a method” means he has a method.🔽“He has a method” means he has a method.

original: samparāyiko, paralokattho. Paramo uttamo attho paramattho, nibbānaṃ. Tehi diṭṭhadhammikasamparāyikaparamatthehi.
analyzed: samparāyiko para loka attho paramaḥ uttamaḥ attho paramattho nibbānam tehi diṭṭhadhammika samparāyika paramatthehi
translated: “He has a method” means he has a method.🔽“He has a method” means he has a method.

original: Yathārahanti yathānurūpaṃ. Tesu atthesu yo yo puggalo yaṃ yaṃ arahati, tadanurūpaṃ.
analyzed: yathā arahanti yathā anurūpam tesu atthesu yaḥ yaḥ puggalaḥ yam yam arahati tad anurūpam
translated: “He has a method” means he has a method.🔽“He has a method” means he has a method.🔽“He has a method” means he has a method.🔽“He has a method” means he has a method.🔽“He has a method” means he has a method.

original: Anusāsatīti vineti tasmiṃ atthe patiṭṭhapeti, saha atthena vattatīti sattho, bhaṇḍamūlena
analyzed: anusāsati iti vinā iti tasmin atthe patiṭṭhapeti saha atthena vattati iti satthaḥ bhaṇḍa mūlena
translated: “He has a method” means he has a method.🔽“He has a method” means he has a method.🔽“He has a method” means he has a method.🔽“He has a method” means he has a method.🔽“He has a method” means he has a method.

original: vāṇijjāya desantaraṃ gacchanto janasamūho. Hitupadesādivasena paripāletabbo sāsitabbo
analyzed: vāṇijjāya desantaram gacchantaḥ jana samūhaḥ hita upadesa ādi vasena paripāletabbaḥ sāsitabbaḥ
translated: “He has a method” means he has a method.🔽“He has a method” means he has a method.🔽“He has a method” means he has a method.

original: so etassa atthīti satthā, satthavāho. So viya bhagavāti āha “satthā viyāti satthā,🔽bhagavā satthavāho”ti.
analyzed: saḥ etassa atthi iti satthā satthavāhaḥ saḥ viya bhagavā iti āha satthā viya ati satthā 🔽bhagavā satthavāho ti
translated: “He has a method” means he has a method.🔽“He has a method” means he has a method.🔽“He has a method” means he has a method.🔽“He has a method” means he has a method.🔽“He has a method” means he has a method.🔽“He has a method” means he has a method.🔽“He has a method” means he has a method.🔽“He has a method” means he has a method.🔽“He has a method” means he has a method.🔽“He has a method” means he has a method.🔽“He has a method” means he has a method.

original: Idāni tamatthaṃ niddesapāḷinayena dassetuṃ “yathā satthavāho”tiādi vuttaṃ. Tattha
analyzed: idāni tam attham niddesa pāḷi nayena dassetum yathā satthavāhaḥ tiādi vuttam tattha
translated: Now, in order to show that meaning by the method of the Niddesa, the following is said: “As a caravan leader” . Herein:

original: sattheti satthike jane. Kaṃ tārenti etthāti kantāro, nirudako araññappadeso. Ruḷhīvasena
analyzed: satthā iti satthike jane kam tārenti ettha ati kantāraḥ nirudakaḥ arañña ppadesaḥ ruḷhī vasena
translated: In a forest means in a forest-wilderness. But by the method of derivation

original: pana itaropi araññappadeso tathā vuccati. Corakantāranti corehi adhiṭṭhitakantāraṃ.
analyzed: pana itaraḥ api arañña ppadeso tathā vuccati cora kantāram ti corehi adhiṭṭhita kantāram
translated: the other kind of forest-wilderness is also called “forest.” A wilderness of thieves is a wilderness inhabited by thieves.

original: Tathā vāḷakantāraṃ. Dubbhikkhakantāranti dullabhabhikkhaṃ kantāraṃ. Tāretīti akhemantaṭṭhānaṃ🔽atikkāmeti. Uttāretītiādi upasaggena padaṃ vaḍḍhetvā vuttaṃ. Atha vā uttāretīti khemantabhūmiṃ🔽upanento tāreti. Nittāretīti akhemantaṭṭhānato nikkhāmento tāreti. Patāretīti pariggahetvā
analyzed: tathā vāḷa kantāram dubbhikkha kantāram ti dullabha bhikkham kantāram tāreti iti a khemanta ṭṭhānam  atikkāmā iti uttāreti itiādi upasaggena padam vaḍḍhetvā vuttam atha vā uttāreti iti khemanta bhūmim  upanentaḥ tāreti nittāreti iti akhemanta ṭṭhānataḥ nikkhāmentaḥ tāreti patāreti iti pariggahetvā
translated: So too, a wilderness of wild beasts. A wilderness of famine is a wilderness where alms food is hard to get.🔽He crosses over means he goes beyond a place that is not safe. He gets across, etc., are said by way of adding prefixes to the word. Or alternatively, he crosses over means he crosses over while approaching a place that is safe.🔽He gets across means he crosses over while leaving a place that is not safe. He makes the crossing means he crosses over by taking hold of it. The meaning is that he crosses over as if taking hold of it with his hand.

original: tāreti, hatthena pariggahetvā viya tāretīti attho. Sabbampetaṃ tāraṇuttāraṇādikhemaṭṭhāne
analyzed: tāreti hatthena pariggahetvā viya tāreti iti attho sabbam petam tāraṇa uttāraṇa ādi khemaṭṭhāne
translated: All this is said of one who crosses over, gets across, etc., to a place that is safe.

original: ṭhapanamevāti āha “khemantabhūmiṃ sampāpetī”ti. Satteti veneyyasatte. Mahāgahanatāya,
analyzed: ṭhapanam eva iti āha khemanta bhūmim sampāpeti iti satta iti veneyya satte mahā gahana tāya
translated: “He brings them to the state of safety” means that he brings them to the state of the plane of safety. “Beings” means beings to be trained.🔽Birth itself is a jungle because it is overgrown with great thickets,

original: mahānatthatāya, dunnittharaṇatāya ca jātiyeva kantāro jātikantāro, taṃ jātikantāraṃ.
analyzed: mahānattha tāya dunnittharaṇa tāya ca jātiyā iva kantāraḥ jāti kantāraḥ tam jāti kantāram
translated: because it is the cause of great misfortune, and because it is hard to get out of.

original: Ukkaṭṭhaparicchedavasenāti ukkaṭṭhasattaparicchedavasena. Devamanussā eva hi ukkaṭṭhasattā,
analyzed: ukkaṭṭha pariccheda vasena ati ukkaṭṭha satta pariccheda vasena deva manussāḥ eva hi ukkaṭṭha sattā
translated: “By the highest limit” means by the highest limit of beings. For only gods and humans are the highest beings,

original: na tiracchānādayo. Bhabbapuggalaparicchedavasenāti sammattaniyāmokkamanassa yogyapuggalassa
analyzed: na tiracchāna ādayaḥ bhabba puggala pariccheda vasena ati sammatta niyāma ukkamanassa yogya puggalassa
translated: not animals, etc. “By the limit of the person capable” means by the limit of the person capable of entering the right path.

original: paricchindanavasena. Etanti “devamanussāna”nti etaṃ vacanaṃ. Bhagavatoti nissakkavacanaṃ🔽yathā “upajjhāyato ajjhetī”ti, bhagavato santiketi vā attho. Upanissayasampattinti
analyzed: paricchindana vasena etat ti deva manussānam ti etam vacanam bhagavataḥ ti nissakka vacanam  yathā upajjhāyataḥ ajjheti iti bhagavato santike iti vā atthaḥ upanissaya sampattinti
translated: “This” refers to the words “gods and humans.” “Of the Blessed One” is a locative of location.

original: tihetukapaṭisandhiādikaṃ maggaphalādhigamassa balavakāraṇaṃ.
analyzed: ti hetuka paṭisandhi ādikam magga phala adhigamassa balava kāraṇam
translated: It means “in the Blessed One.” “The acquisition of the necessary conditions” means the strong causes for the attainment of the path and fruit, such as the rebirth-linking consciousness accompanied by the three roots of good.

original: Gaggarāyāti gaggarāya nāma rañño deviyā, tāya vā kāritattā “gaggarā”ti laddhanāmāya.
analyzed: gaggarāya ati gaggarāya nāma raññaḥ deviyā tāya vā kārita ttā gaggarā ati laddha nāmāya
translated: “Gaggarā” is the name of the queen of King Gaggarā, or it is the name given to the pond built by her.

original: Sare nimittaṃ aggahesīti “dhammo eso vuccatī”ti dhammasaññāya sare nimittaṃ gaṇhi,🔽gaṇhanto ca pasannacitto parisapariyante nipajji. Sannirumbhitvā aṭṭhāsīti tassa
analyzed: sare nimittam aggahesi iti dhammo eso vuccati iti dhamma saññāya sare nimittam gaṇhi  gaṇhanto ca pasanna citto parisa pariyante nipajji sannirumbhitvā aṭṭhāsi iti tassa
translated: He seized the sign in the sound: he seized the sign in the sound of the words “The Dhamma is taught” through the perception of the Dhamma.

original: sīse daṇḍassa ṭhapitabhāvaṃ apassanto tattha daṇḍaṃ uppīḷetvā aṭṭhāsi. Maṇḍūkopi
analyzed: sīse daṇḍassa ṭhapita bhāvam a passanto tattha daṇḍam uppīḷetvā aṭṭhāsi maṇḍūkaḥ api
translated: And, having seized it, he lay down at the edge of the assembly with a serene mind. He stood pressing down on it: not seeing the stick placed on his head, he stood there pressing down on the stick. The frog

original: daṇḍe ṭhapitepi uppīḷitepi dhammagatena pasādena vissaramakarontova kālamakāsi. Devaloke
analyzed: daṇḍe ṭhapite api uppīḍite api dhamma gatena pasādena vissaram akarontā uva kālam akāsi deva loke
translated: also, though the stick was placed on him and pressed down, did not make a sound, but died through the serenity of mind born of the Dhamma. The beings reborn in the deva world

original: nibbattasattānaṃ ayaṃ dhammatā, yā “kutohaṃ idha nibbatto, tattha kiṃ nu kho kammamakāsi”nti
analyzed: nibbatta sattānam ayam dhamma tā yā kutas aham idha nibbattaḥ tattha kim nu kho kammam akāsin ti
translated: have the following natural disposition: they recollect their previous existence, thinking, “From where have I been reborn here? What action did I perform there?”

original: āvajjanā. Tasmā attano purimabhavassa diṭṭhattā āha “are ahampi nāma idha nibbatto”ti.🔽Bhagavato pāde vandi kataññutāsaṃvaḍḍhitena pemagāravabahumānena.
analyzed: āvajjanā tasmai attanaḥ purima bhavassa diṭṭha ttā āha are aham pi nāma idha nibbattaḥ ti  bhagavataḥ pāde vandi kataññu tā saṃvaḍḍhitena pema gārava bahu mānena
translated: Therefore, because he saw his previous existence, he said, “Oh, I have been reborn here.”🔽He worshipped at the Blessed One’s feet with love and respect increased by his gratitude.

original: Bhagavā jānantova mahājanassa kammaphalaṃ, buddhānubhāvañca paccakkhaṃ kātukāmo “ko
analyzed: bhagavā jānanto iva mahā janassa kamma phalam buddha anubhāvañca paccakkham kātu kāmo
translated: The Blessed One, though he knew already, asked the reason for the assembly’s gathering in order to make manifest to the multitude the result of kamma and the power of the Buddha.

original: me vandatī”ti gāthāya pucchi. Tattha koti devanāgayakkhagandhabbādīsu ko, katamoti🔽attho. Meti mama. Pādānīti pāde. Iddhiyāti imāya evarūpāya deviddhiyā. “Yasasā”ti🔽iminā edisena parivārena, paricchedena ca. Jalanti vijjotamāno. Abhikkantenāti ativiya🔽kantena kamanīyena sundarena. Vaṇṇenāti chavivaṇṇena sarīravaṇṇanibhāya. Sabbā obhāsayaṃ
analyzed: me vandati iti gāthāya pucchi tattha kaḥ iti deva nāga yakkha gandhabba ādīsu kaḥ katamaḥ ti  attha u mā iti mama pādāni iti pāde iddhiyā ati imāya evarūpāya deva iddhiyā yasasā ati  iminā edisena parivārena paricchedena ca jalanti vijjotamānaḥ abhikkantena ati  kantena kamanīyena sundarena vaṇṇena ati chavi vaṇṇena sarīra vaṇṇa nibhāya sabbāḥ obhāsayam
translated: He asked the question in the verse, “Who is that? ” Herein, “Who” is the interrogative for “Which one? ”

original: disāti sabbā dasapi disā pabhāsento, cando viya, sūriyo viya ca ekobhāsaṃ ekālokaṃ karontoti attho.
analyzed: disā iti sabbā dasa api disā pabhāsento candaḥ viya sūriyaḥ viya ca ekobhāsam ekālokam karonto ti attho
translated: “Me” is “my” . “Feet” : the feet. “By magic” : by such divine magic as this. “By glory” : by such a retinue and such a delimitation as this. “Shining” : shining with light. “Shining forth” : shining forth with exceeding loveliness, with exceeding charm, with exceeding beauty. “With beauty” : with the beauty of the six-coloured rays of light issuing from the body. “All quarters” : the ten quarters. The meaning is that he illuminates all the ten quarters, making them one blaze of light, one expanse of light, like the moon and the sun.

original: Evaṃ pana bhagavatā pucchito devaputto attānaṃ pavedento “maṇḍūkohaṃ pure āsi”nti
analyzed: evam pana bhagavatā pucchitaḥ deva putto attānam pavedentaḥ maṇḍūkaḥ uham pure āsin ti
translated: When the Blessed One had asked the question in this way, the god, identifying himself, said the verse, “I was a frog in the past” .

original: gāthamāha. Tattha pureti purimajātiyaṃ. “Udake”ti idaṃ tadā attano uppattiṭṭhānadassanaṃ.
analyzed: gātham āha tattha purā iti purima jātiyam udaka iti idam tadā attanaḥ uppatti ṭṭhāna dassanam
translated: Herein, “In the past” : in a previous birth. “In the water” : this shows the place of his own arising at that time.

original: “Udake maṇḍūko”ti etena uddhamāyikādikassa thale maṇḍūkassa nivattanaṃ kataṃ hoti.
analyzed: udake maṇḍūkaḥ ti etena uddha māyika ādikassa thale maṇḍūkassa nivattanam katam hoti
translated: “A frog in the water” : this excludes the frog on dry land, the frog in the sky, and so on.

original: Gāvo caranti etthāti gocaro, gunnaṃ ghāsesanaṭṭhānaṃ. Idha pana gocaro viyāti gocaro,
analyzed: gāvaḥ caranti ettha ati gocaraḥ gunnam ghāsesana ṭhānam idha pana gocaraḥ viya ati gocaro
translated: “Gocaro” is the place where cows graze, the place for cows to eat grass. But here “gocaro” means “like a place.”

original: vāri udakaṃ gocaro etassāti vārigocaro. Udakacārīpi hi koci kacchapādi avārigocaropi🔽hotīti “vārigocaro”ti visesetvā vuttaṃ. Tava dhammaṃ suṇantassāti brahmassarena karavīkarutamañjunā
analyzed: vāri udakam gocaraḥ etassa ati vāri gocaraḥ udaka cārī ipi hi koci kacchapa ādi a vāri gocaraḥ api  hoti iti vāri gocaro ti visesetvā vuttam tava dhammam suṇantassa iti brahmassarena
translated: “Vārigocaro” is one whose gocara is water. For some aquatic animals such as turtles, etc., are not vārigocara.🔽Therefore, it is said specifically that he is vārigocara.

original: desentassa tava dhammaṃ “dhammo eso vuccatī”ti sare nimittaggāhavasena suṇantassa.
analyzed: desentassa tava dhammam dhammo eso vuccati iti sare nimitta ggāha vasena suṇantassa
translated: “Hearing your Dhamma”: hearing your Dhamma with the ear-consciousness, by way of grasping the sign, thinking “This is called the Dhamma.”

original: Anādare cetaṃ sāmivacanaṃ. Avadhi vacchapālakoti vacche rakkhanto gopāladārako mama
analyzed: an ādare ca itam sāmi vacanam vacche rakkhantaḥ gopāla dārako mama
translated: This is a respectful form of address.

original: samīpaṃ āgantvā daṇḍamolubbha tiṭṭhanto mama sīse daṇḍaṃ sannirumbhitvā maṃ māresīti attho.
analyzed: samīpam āgantvā daṇḍam olubbha tiṭṭhantaḥ mama sīse daṇḍam sannirumbhitvā mama māresi iti attho
translated: “The cowherd, having approached me, stands with his staff raised, threatening to kill me by striking my head with his staff.”

original: Sitaṃ katvāti “tathā parittatarenāpi puññānubhāvena evaṃ ativiya uḷārā lokiyalokuttarā
analyzed: sitam katvā iti tathā parittatarena api puñña anubhāvena evam ativiya uḷārā lokiya lokuttarā
translated: “Having seen”: by the power of even a little merit, such great and excellent worldly and supramundane

original: sampattiyo labbhantī”ti pītisomanassajāto bhāsurataradhavalavipphurantadassanakiraṇāvalīhi
analyzed: sampattiyaḥ labbhanti iti pīti somanassa jātaḥ bhāsuratara dhavala vipphuranta dassana kiraṇa āvalīhi
translated: and the rest of the benefits that are obtained.”🔽And with a rapture and joy, he flooded the whole place with a radiance that was brighter and whiter than the light of the stars,

original: bhiyyoso mattāya taṃ padesaṃ obhāsento sitaṃ katvā. Pītisomanassavasena hi so –
analyzed: bhiyyosaḥ mattāya tam padesam obhāsentaḥ sitam katvā pīti somanassa vasena hi so
translated: and he made it bright. For it was through rapture and joy that he said:🔽“For a moment, have faith in me,

original: “Muhuttaṃ cittapasādassa, iddhiṃ passa yasañca me;
analyzed: muhuttam citta pasādassa iddhim passa yasam ca me
translated: And see my psychic power and fame;

original: Ānubhāvañca me passa, vaṇṇaṃ passa jutiñca me.
analyzed: ānubhāvañca me passa vaṇṇam passa jutiñca me
translated: See my influence, see my beauty, see my radiance.🔽“And those who for a long time

original: “Ye ca te dīghamaddhānaṃ, dhammaṃ assosuṃ gotama;
analyzed: ye ca te dīgham addhānam dhammaṃ assosum gotama
translated: Have listened to the Dhamma of Gotama,🔽They have attained the unshakable state,

original: Pattā te acalaṭṭhānaṃ, yattha gantvā na socare”ti. ;
analyzed: pattā te acala ṭṭhānam yattha gantvā na socarā iti
translated: Having gone to which one does not sorrow.”

original: Imā dve gāthā vatvā pakkāmi.
analyzed: imāḥ dve gāthāḥ vatvā
translated: After he had spoken these two stanzas, he departed.🔽But in the passage, “Whatever there is,” the word “whatever” is an indefinite term,

original: 141. Yaṃ pana kiñcīti ettha yanti aniyamitavacanaṃ. Tathā kiñcīti. Panāti vacanālaṅkāramattaṃ.
analyzed: yam pana kiñci iti ettha yanti aniyamita vacanam tathā kiñci iti panāti vacana alaṅkāra mattam
translated: and so is “anything.” The word “but” is merely a particle of speech.🔽Therefore, “whatever there is” includes everything that is to be known without exception.

original: Tasmā yaṃ kiñcīti ñeyyassa anavasesapariyādānaṃ kataṃ hoti. Panāti vā visesatthadīpako
analyzed: tasmā yam kiñci iti ñeyyassa anavasesa pariyādānam katam hoti pana ati vā visesa attha dīpako
translated: Or the particle “but” indicates a distinction.

original: nipāto. Tena “sammāsambuddho”ti iminā saṅkhepato, vitthārato ca satthu catusaccābhisambodho
analyzed: nipāto tena sammāsambuddhaḥ ti iminā saṅkhepataḥ vitthārataḥ ca satthu catu sacca abhisambodhaḥ
translated: Therefore, “the Fully Enlightened One” indicates the Teacher’s enlightenment in brief and in detail with reference to the four noble truths.

original: vutto. “Buddho”ti pana iminā tadaññassapi ñeyyassāvabodho. Purimena vā satthu paṭivedhañāṇānubhāvo,
analyzed: vuttaḥ buddhaḥ ti pana iminā tad aññassa api ñeyyassa avabodho purimena vā satthu paṭivedha ñāṇa anubhāvo
translated: “Awakened” shows the knowledge of what is to be known other than that. Or the first shows the power of the Master’s penetration-knowledge,

original: pacchimena desanāñāṇānubhāvo. Pīti upari vuccamāno viseso jotīyati. Sabbaso paṭipakkhehi
analyzed: pacchimena desanā ñāṇa anubhāvaḥ pi iti upari vuccamānaḥ visesaḥ jotīyati sabbaso paṭipakkhehi
translated: and the second shows the power of his teaching-knowledge. The word “joy” shows the difference in the sense of superiority.

original: vimuccatīti vimokkho, aggamaggo. Tassa anto aggaphalaṃ, tattha bhavaṃ tasmiṃ laddhe
analyzed: vimuccati iti vimokkhaḥ aggamaggaḥ tassa antaḥ agga phalam tattha bhavam tasmin laddhe
translated: “Liberation” is the path of Arahantship, which is the supreme path. The supreme fruit is in it. The knowledge that “It is to be attained”🔽is the knowledge that is proximate to liberation, and it is all the knowledge of the Enlightened One together with the knowledge of omniscience.

original: laddhabbato vimokkhantikañāṇaṃ, sabbaññutaññāṇena saddhiṃ sabbampi buddhañāṇaṃ. Evaṃ pavattoti ettha –
analyzed: laddhabbataḥ vimokkha antika ñāṇam sabbaññuta ññāṇena saddhim sabbam pi buddha ñāṇam evam pavattaḥ ti ettha
translated: “Thus it occurs” :

original: “Sabbaññutāya buddho, sabbadassāvitāya buddho, anaññaneyyatāya buddho, visavitāya🔽buddho, khīṇāsavasaṅkhātena buddho, nirupalepasaṅkhātena buddho, ekantavītarāgoti
analyzed: sabbaññutāya buddhaḥ sabba dassāvitāya buddhaḥ an añña neyya tāya buddhaḥ visavitāya  buddhaḥ khīṇāsava saṅkhātena buddhaḥ nirupalepa saṅkhātena buddhaḥ ekanta vīta rāgaḥ ti
translated: “He is enlightened because of omniscience, he is enlightened because of seeing all, he is enlightened because of being independent of others’ knowledge, he is enlightened because of being all-seeing,🔽he is enlightened because of being called one whose cankers are destroyed, he is enlightened because of being called one who is unsmeared, he is enlightened because of being one who is utterly free from lust,

original: buddho, ekantavītadosoti buddho, ekantavītamohoti buddho, ekantanikkilesoti buddho,
analyzed: buddhaḥ ekanta vīta dosaḥ iti buddhaḥ ekanta vīta mohaḥ iti buddhaḥ ekanta nikkilesaḥ iti buddhaḥ
translated: he is enlightened because of being one who is utterly free from hatred, he is enlightened because of being one who is utterly free from delusion, he is enlightened because of being one who is utterly free from defilements,

original: ekāyanamaggaṃ gatoti buddho, eko anuttaraṃ sammāsambodhiṃ abhisambuddhoti buddho,
analyzed: ekāyana maggam gataḥ iti buddhaḥ ekaḥ anuttaram sammāsambodhim abhisambuddhaḥ iti buddhaḥ
translated: He has gone the straight way, thus he is a Buddha. He has awakened to the supreme full enlightenment by himself, thus he is a Buddha.🔽He is a Buddha because he has dispelled ignorance and has attained knowledge.

original: abuddhivihatattā buddhipaṭilābhā buddho. Buddhoti netaṃ nāmaṃ mātarā kataṃ, na pitarā
analyzed: a buddhi vihata ttā buddhi paṭilābhāḥ buddhaḥ buddha iti na itam nāmam mātarā katam na pitarā
translated: The name “Buddha” is not made by a mother,🔽not made by a father,

original: kataṃ, na bhātarā kataṃ, na bhaginiyā kataṃ, na mittāmaccehikataṃ, na ñātisālohitehi🔽kataṃ, na samaṇabrāhmaṇehi kataṃ, na devatāhi kataṃ. Vimokkhantikametaṃ buddhānaṃ
analyzed: katam na bhātarā katam na bhaginiyā katam na mitta amaccehi katam na ñāti sālohitehi  katam na samaṇa brāhmaṇehi katam na devatāhi katam vimokkha antikam etam buddhānam
translated: not made by a brother, not made by a sister, not made by friends and companions, not made by relatives and kin,

original: bhagavantānaṃ bodhiyā mūle saha sabbaññutaññāṇassa paṭilābhā sacchikā paññatti yadidaṃ buddho”ti –
analyzed: bhagavantānam bodhiyāḥ mūle saha sabbaññu ta ññāṇassa paṭilābhā sacchikā paññatti yat idam buddhaḥ ti
translated: not made by ascetics and brahmans, not made by gods, but it is a term for the final liberation of the Buddhas, the Blessed Ones, that comes about together with the knowledge of omniscience at the root of the Bodhi tree, namely, “Buddha.”🔽This is the method of explanation of the passage of the Niddesa.

original: Ayaṃ niddesapāḷinayo. Yasmā cettha tassā paṭisambhidāpāḷiyā bhedo natthi, tasmā dvīsu ekenāpi atthasiddhīti dassanatthaṃ “paṭisambhidānayo vā”ti aniyamattho vā-saddo vutto.
analyzed: ayam niddesa pāḷi nayaḥ yasmā ca ittha tassā paṭisambhidā pāḷiyā bhedaḥ natthi tasmā dvīsu ekena api attha siddhi iti dassana ttham paṭisambhidā nayaḥ vā ti aniyama atthaḥ vā saddaḥ vuttaḥ
translated: But since there is no division of the passage of the Paṭisambhidā, therefore the word “or” is stated in the sense of non-restriction in order to show that the meaning is accomplished by either of the two.

original: Tattha yathā loke avagantā “avagato”ti vuccati, evaṃ bujjhitā saccānīti buddho suddhakattuvasena.
analyzed: tattha yathā loke avagantā avagataḥ iti vuccati evam bujjhitā saccāni iti buddhaḥ suddha kattu vasena
translated: Herein, just as one who understands in the world is called “an understander,” so too, he is enlightened with regard to the truths because he has awakened to them; thus he is enlightened in the sense of one who has purified the act of understanding.

original: Yathā paṇṇasosā vātā “paṇṇasusā”ti vuccanti, evaṃ bodhetā pajāyāti buddho hetukattuvasena,
analyzed: yathā paṇṇasosāḥ vātāḥ paṇṇasusā iti vuccanti evam bodhetā pajāyāti buddhaḥ hetu kattu vasena
translated: Just as winds that blow away the chaff are called “chaff-blowers,” so too, he is enlightened because he has awakened the people; thus he is enlightened in the sense of one who has purified the act of causing to understand.

original: hetuattho cettha antonīto.🔽Sabbaññutāya buddhoti sabbadhammabujjhanasamatthāya buddhiyā buddhoti attho. Sabbadassāvitāya🔽buddhoti sabbadhammānaṃ ñāṇacakkhunā diṭṭhattā buddhoti attho. Anaññaneyyatāya buddhoti🔽aññena abodhanīto sayameva buddhattā buddhoti attho. Visavitāya buddhoti nānāguṇavisavanato
analyzed: hetu atthaḥ ca ittha antonītaḥ  sabbaññutāya buddhaḥ ti sabba dhamma bujjhana samatthāya buddhiyā buddhaḥ iti attho sabba dassāvitāya  buddho ti sabba dhammānam ñāṇa cakkhunā diṭṭha ttā buddho ti attho an añña neyya tāya buddhaḥ iti  aññena sayam eva buddha ttā buddhaḥ ti attho visavitāya buddhaḥ ti nānā guṇa visavanato
translated: And here the word “cause” is to be construed with “understanding” .

original: padumamiva vikasanaṭṭhena buddhoti attho. Khīṇāsavasaṅkhātena buddhoti evamādīhi
analyzed: padumam iva vikasana ṭṭhena buddhaḥ ti attho khīṇāsava saṅkhātena buddhaḥ ti evamādīhi
translated: He is enlightened because of omniscience: the meaning is, he is enlightened because of the understanding that is able to awaken to all dhammas. He is enlightened because of all-seeing: the meaning is, he is enlightened because he has seen all dhammas with the eye of knowledge. He is enlightened because of being uninfluenced by others: the meaning is, he is enlightened because he has awakened by himself without being awakened by another. He is enlightened because of being expanded: the meaning is, he is enlightened because he has expanded by the expansion of his various special qualities, like a lotus flower. He is enlightened because of the destruction of the taints: the meaning is, he is enlightened because he has awakened to the destruction of the taints, like a man who has awakened to the destruction of sleep.

original: chahi pariyāyehi niddakkhayavibuddho puriso viya sabbakilesaniddakkhayavibuddhattā
analyzed: chahi pariyāyehi nidda khaya vibuddhaḥ purisaḥ viya sabba kilesa nidda khaya vibuddha ttā
translated: He is enlightened because of the destruction of all cankers: the meaning is, he is enlightened because he has awakened to the destruction of all defilements, like a man who has awakened to the destruction of sleep.

original: buddhoti vuttaṃ hoti. Ekāyanamaggaṃ gatoti buddhoti gamanatthānaṃ buddhiatthatāya
analyzed: buddhaḥ iti vuttam hoti ekāyana maggam gataḥ ti buddhaḥ ti gamana tthānam buddhi attha tāya
translated: “Awakened” is said. “Gone to the culmination of the direct path”: because of the meaning of “going,”

original: buddhiatthānampi gamanatthatā labbhatīti ekāyanamaggaṃ gatattā buddhoti vuccatīti🔽attho. Eko anuttaraṃ sammāsambodhiṃ abhisambuddhoti buddhoti na parehi buddhattā
analyzed: buddhi atthānam pi gamana ttha tā labbhati iti ekāyana maggam gata ttā buddhaḥ iti vuccati iti  attho ekaḥ anuttaram sammāsambodhim abhisambuddhaḥ iti buddhaḥ iti na parehi buddha ttā
translated: “awakened” is said. The meaning is: because of having gone to the culmination of the direct path, he is called “awakened,”🔽because of the meaning of “awakening,” “awakened” is said. The meaning is: because of having awakened to the unsurpassed perfect enlightenment by himself, he is called “awakened,”

original: buddho, atha kho sayameva anuttaraṃ sammāsambodhiṃ abhisambuddhattā buddhoti attho.
analyzed: buddhaḥ atha kho sayam eva anuttaram sammāsambodhim abhisambuddha ttā buddhaḥ iti attho
translated: not because of being awakened by others.

original: Abuddhivihatattā buddhipaṭilābhā buddhoti buddhi buddhaṃ bodhoti anatthantaraṃ. Tattha
analyzed: a buddhi vihata ttā buddhi paṭilābhā buddho ti buddhi buddham bodho ti anatthantaram tattha
translated: Because of the attainment of awakening through the destruction of non-awakening, “awakened” is said. “Awakening” is the same as “awakened.” Herein,

original: yathā rattaguṇayogato ratto paṭo, evaṃ buddhaguṇayogato buddhoti ñāpanatthaṃ vuttaṃ.
analyzed: yathā ratta guṇa yogataḥ rattaḥ paṭaḥ evam buddha guṇa yogataḥ buddhaḥ iti ñāpana attham vuttam
translated: in order to show that just as a cloth is called “red” because of the possession of the quality of redness, so the Blessed One is called “awakened” because of the possession of the qualities of awakening,

original: Tato paraṃ buddhoti netaṃ nāmantiādi atthānugatāyaṃ paññattīti bodhanatthaṃ vuttanti
analyzed: tatas param buddhaḥ ti na itam nāma nti ādi attha anugatā ayam paññattī iti bodhana attham vuttan ti
translated: it is said. “Awakened” is said in order to show that the designation is based on the meaning.

original: evamettha imināpi kāraṇena bhagavā buddhoti veditabbaṃ.
analyzed: evam ettha iminā api kāraṇena bhagavā buddhaḥ ti veditabbam
translated: Thus it should be understood that the Blessed One is called “awakened” for this reason too.

original: 142. Assāti bhagavato. Guṇavisiṭṭhasabbasattuttamagarugāravādhivacananti sabbehi🔽sīlādiguṇehi visiṭṭhassa tato eva sabbasattehi uttamassa garuno gāravavasena vuttavacanamidaṃ
analyzed: assa ati bhagavataḥ guṇa visiṭṭha sabba satta uttama garu gārava adhivacanan ti sabbehi  sīla ādi guṇehi visiṭṭhassa tatas eva sabba sattehi uttamassa garunaḥ gārava vasena vutta vacanam idam
translated: “Bhagavā” is the Blessed One. The word is used in the sense of “venerable” and “honorable” because he is distinguished by virtues such as virtue, etc., and is the highest of all beings.🔽This word “bhagavā” is used in the sense of “venerable” and “honorable” because he is distinguished by virtues such as virtue, etc., and is the highest of all beings.

original: bhagavāti. Tathā hi lokanātho aparimitanirupamappabhāvasīlādiguṇavisesasamaṅgitāya
analyzed: bhagavā ati tathā hi lokanāthaḥ aparimita nirupama ppabhāva sīla ādi guṇa visesa samaṅgi tāya
translated: For the Lord of the World is the object of veneration and honor for the world with its gods and men because he is endowed with the special virtues of immeasurable and incomparable virtue, etc.,

original: sabbānatthaparihārapubbaṅgamāya niravasesahitasukhavidhānatapparāya niratisayāya🔽payogasampattiyā sadevamanussāya pajāya, accantupakāritāya ca aparimāṇāsu lokadhātūsu
analyzed: sabba anattha parihāra pubbaṅgamāya niravasesa hita sukha vidhāna tad parāya niratisayāya  payoga sampattiyā sa deva manussāya pajāya accantupakāritāya ca aparimāṇāsu lokadhātūsu
translated: because he is the supreme field of merit for the performance of worship, since he is the one who has perfected the incomparable method of bringing about the abandonment of all misfortune and the provision of all that is beneficial and pleasant,

original: aparimāṇānaṃ sattānaṃ uttamagāravaṭṭhānanti.🔽Bhagavāti vacanaṃ seṭṭhanti seṭṭhavācakaṃ vacanaṃ seṭṭhaguṇasahacaraṇato “seṭṭha”nti
analyzed: aparimāṇānam sattānam uttama gārava ṭhānam ti  bhagavā ati vacanam seṭṭhanti seṭṭha vācakam vacanam seṭṭha guṇa sahacaraṇato seṭṭhanti
translated: and because he is the highest object of veneration in immeasurable world systems for immeasurable beings, since he is the one who has performed the greatest service to them.🔽“The word ‘bhagavā’ is the best of words” means that the word “bhagavā” is the best of words because it is associated with the best of qualities.

original: vuttaṃ. Atha vā vuccatīti vacanaṃ, attho. Tasmā yo “bhagavā”ti vacanena vacanīyo
analyzed: vuttam atha vā vuccati iti vacanam atthaḥ tasmai yaḥ bhagavā iti vacanena vacanīyaḥ
translated: Or alternatively, “bhagavā” is a word, and “the best of words” means the best of meanings. Therefore, the one who is to be spoken of by the word “bhagavā”

original: attho, so seṭṭhoti attho. Bhagavāti vacanamuttamanti etthāpi eseva nayo. Gāravayuttoti
analyzed: attho so seṭṭho ti attho bhagavā ati vacanam uttaman ti ettha api esā iva nayaḥ gārava yutto ti
translated: the meaning is that it is the best. The word “Blessed” is the best: the method of interpretation is the same here. Endowed with respect:

original: garubhāvayutto garuguṇayogato, garukaraṇaṃ vā sātisayaṃ arahatīti gāravayutto, gāravārahoti attho.
analyzed: garu bhāva yuttaḥ garu guṇa yogataḥ garu karaṇam vā sa atisayam arahati iti gārava yuttaḥ gārava ārahaḥ ti attho
translated: endowed with the state of being weighty, endowed with the qualities of weightiness; the meaning is, worthy of the highest esteem.

original: Guṇavisesahetukaṃ “bhagavā”ti idaṃ bhagavato nāmanti saṅkhepato vuttamatthaṃ vitthārato
analyzed: guṇa visesa hetukam bhagavā ti idam bhagavataḥ nāman ti saṅkhepataḥ vuttam attham vitthārato
translated: The word “Blessed” is due to a special quality: the meaning stated in brief is that he is called “Blessed” because of a special quality.🔽Desiring to expound this in detail, he said, “Name is of four kinds,”

original: vibhajitukāmo nāmaṃyeva tāva atthuddhāravasena dassento “catubbidhaṃ vā nāma”ntiādimāha.
analyzed: vibhajitu kāmaḥ nāmaṃyā iva tāva attha uddhāra vasena dassentaḥ catubbidham vā nāma ti ādim āha
translated: showing the meaning by way of etymological interpretation.

original: Tattha āvatthikanti avatthāya viditaṃ taṃ taṃ avatthaṃ upādāya paññattaṃ voharitaṃ.
analyzed: tattha āvatthikam ti avatthāya viditam tam tam avattham upādāya paññattam voharitam
translated: Herein, “due to a basis” is known by way of a basis, is designated, is spoken of, by taking that or that basis.

original: Tathā liṅgikaṃ tena tena liṅgena voharitaṃ. Nemittikanti nimittato āgataṃ. Adhiccasamuppannanti
analyzed: tathā liṅgikam tena tena liṅgena voharitam nemittikam ti nimittataḥ āgatam adhicca samuppannam ti
translated: Likewise, “due to a mark” is spoken of by way of this or that mark. “Due to a cause” is come by way of a cause. “Due to chance”

original: yadicchāya pavattaṃ, yadicchāya āgataṃ yadicchakaṃ. Paṭhamena ādi-saddena bālo, yuvā,
analyzed: yad icchāya pavattam yad icchāya āgatam yad icchakam paṭhamena ādi saddena bālaḥ yuvā
translated: is arisen by chance, come by chance, is accidental. By the first “and so on” is meant: a fool, a youth,

original: vuḍḍhoti evamādiṃ saṅgaṇhāti, dutiyena muṇḍī, jaṭīti evamādiṃ, tatiyena bahussuto,
analyzed: vuḍḍhaḥ iti evamādim saṅgaṇhāti dutiyena muṇḍī jaṭī iti evamādim tatiyena bahussuto
translated: and so on. By the second, the shaven-headed, the matted-haired, and so on. By the third, the learned,

original: dhammakathiko, jhāyīti evamādiṃ, catutthena aghamarisanaṃ pāvacananti evamādiṃ saṅgaṇhāti.
analyzed: dhamma kathikaḥ jhāyī iti evamādim catutthena aghamarisanam evamādim saṅgaṇhāti
translated: the expounder of Dhamma, the meditator, and so on. By the fourth, the one who does not kill, the one who is pure, and so on.

original: “Nemittika”nti vuttamatthaṃ byatirekavasena patiṭṭhāpetuṃ “na mahāmāyāyā”tiādi vuttaṃ.
analyzed: nemittikam ti vuttam attham byatireka vasena patiṭṭhāpetum na mahāmāyāya itiādi vuttam
translated: “One who has attained the end” : this is said to establish the meaning stated by “one who has attained the end” in terms of distinction.

original: “Vimokkhantika”nti iminā idaṃ nāmaṃ ariyāya jātiyā jātakkhaṇeyeva jātanti dasseti.
analyzed: vimokkhantikam ti iminā idam nāmam ariyāya jātiyā jāta kkhaṇeya iva jāta nti dasseti
translated: “One who has attained emancipation” : by this he shows that this name is born at the very moment of birth in the noble birth.

original: Yadi vimokkhantikaṃ, atha kasmā aññehi khīṇāsavehi asādhāraṇanti āha “saha sabbaññutaññāṇassa
analyzed: yadi vimokkha antikam atha kasmai aññehi khīṇāsavehi asādhāraṇam ti āha saha sabbaññuta ññāṇassa
translated: If he is one who has attained emancipation, then why is he not shared in common with others who are free from the corruptions? He says, “Together with the attainment of omniscient knowledge” .

original: paṭilābhā”ti. Buddhānañhi arahattaphalaṃ nipphajjamānaṃ sabbaññutaññāṇādīhi sabbehi
analyzed: paṭilābhāti buddhānam hi arahatta phalam nipphajjamānam sabbaññuta ññāṇa ādīhi sabbehi
translated: For when the fruit of arahantship of the Buddhas is being produced, it is produced together with all the qualities of a Buddha, such as omniscient knowledge, and so on.

original: buddhaguṇehi saddhiṃyeva nipphajjati. Tena vuttaṃ “vimokkhantika”nti. Sacchikā paññattīti
analyzed: buddha guṇehi saddhiṃyeva nipphajjati tena vuttam vimokkha antikam ti sacchikā paññatti iti
translated: Therefore it is said, “one who has attained emancipation.” “One who has realized” :

original: sabbadhammānaṃ sacchikiriyānimittā paññatti. Atha vā sacchikā paññattīti paccakkhasiddhā
analyzed: sabba dhammānam sacchikiriyā nimittā paññatti atha vā sacchikā paññatti iti paccakkha siddhā
translated: It is a description that has the realization of all ideas as its cause. Or alternatively, it is a description that is realized by himself,

original: paññatti. Yaṃguṇanimittā hi sā, te satthu paccakkhabhūtāti guṇā viya sāpi sacchikatā
analyzed: paññatti yaṃguṇa nimittā hi sā te satthu paccakkha bhūtā ati guṇāḥ viya sā api sacchikatā
translated: for it is he himself who is the cause of the qualities, and so it is as if the description were realized by the qualities themselves.

original: eva nāma hoti, na paresaṃ vohāramattenāti adhippāyo.
analyzed: eva nāma hoti na paresam vohāra mattena ati adhippāyaḥ
translated: The intention is that it is not merely a description by others’ report.

original: 143. Vadantīti mahātherassa garubhāvato bahuvacanenāha, saṅgītikārehi vā katamanuvādaṃ
analyzed: vadanti iti mahā therassa garu bhāvataḥ bahuvacanena āha saṅgīti kārehi vā
translated: ‘They say’: he says this with the plural form because of the great importance of the Elder, or else with reference to the compilers of the Canon.

original: sandhāya. Issariyādibhedo bhago assa atthīti bhagī. Akāsi bhagganti rāgādipāpadhammaṃ
analyzed: sandhāya issariya ādi bhedaḥ bhagaḥ assa atthi iti bhagī akāsi rāga ādi pāpa dhammaṃ
translated: He is a possessor of a portion consisting of lordship, etc., thus he is a Lord . He has destroyed evil ideas such as greed, thus he is a Lord . The meaning is that he is a destroyer .

original: bhaggaṃ akāsi, bhaggavāti attho. Bahūhi ñāyehīti kāyabhāvanādikehi anekehi bhāvanākkamehi.
analyzed: bhaggam akāsi bhaggavā ati atthaḥ bahūhi ñāyehi iti kāya bhāvanā ādikehi anekehi bhāvanā kkamehi
translated: With many kinds of knowledge : with the many kinds of development such as development of the body, etc.

original: Subhāvitattanoti sammadeva bhāvitasabhāvassa. Paccatte cetaṃ sāmivacanaṃ.
analyzed: su bhāvitattanoti sammat eva bhāvita sabhāvassa paccatte ca itam sāmi vacanam
translated: He has well developed himself : he has developed himself rightly. This is a possessive adjective.

original: Niddese vuttanayenāti etthāyaṃ niddesanayo –
analyzed: niddese vutta nayena āti ettha ayam niddesa nayaḥ
translated: In the way stated in the description : here is the way of description:

original: “Bhagavāti gāravādhivacanametaṃ. Apica bhaggarāgoti bhagavā, bhaggadosoti bhagavā,
analyzed: bhagavān ati gārava adhivacanam etam apica bhagga rāgo ti bhagavā bhagga doso ti bhagavā
translated: ‘Bhagavā is a term of respect. Furthermore, he is a Lord in the sense of one who has destroyed the lust, etc., that are enemies ;

original: bhaggamohoti bhagavā, bhaggamānoti bhagavā, bhaggadiṭṭhīti bhagavā, bhaggataṇhoti
analyzed: bhagga moho ti bhagavā bhagga māno iti bhagavā bhagga diṭṭhī iti bhagavā bhagga taṇho ti
translated: the Blessed One is one whose delusion is destroyed, the Blessed One is one whose doubts are destroyed, the Blessed One is one whose views are destroyed, the Blessed One is one whose craving is destroyed,

original: bhagavā, bhaggakilesoti bhagavā, bhaji vibhaji pavibhaji dhammaratananti bhagavā,
analyzed: bhagavā bhagga kileso ti bhagavā bhaji vibhaji pavibhaji dhamma ratananti bhagavā
translated: the Blessed One is one whose defilements are destroyed, the Blessed One is one who enjoys, partakes of, and relishes the jewel of the Dhamma,

original: bhavānaṃ antakaroti bhagavā, bhāvitakāyo bhāvitasīlo bhāvitacitto bhāvitapaññoti
analyzed: bhavānam antakaroti bhagavā bhāvita kāyaḥ bhāvita sīlaḥ bhāvita cittaḥ bhāvita paññā iti
translated: the Blessed One is the ender of the round, the Blessed One is one who has developed the body, developed virtue, developed the mind, developed wisdom,

original: bhagavā, bhaji vā bhagavā araññavanapatthāni pantāni senāsanāni appasaddāni appanigghosāni🔽vijanavātāni manussarāhasseyyakāni paṭisallānasāruppānīti bhagavā, bhāgī vā bhagavā
analyzed: bhagavā bhaji vā bhagavā arañña vana patthāni pantāni senāsanāni appa saddāni appa nigghosāni  vijana vātāni manussa rāhasseyyakāni paṭisallāna sāruppāni iti bhagavā bhāgī vā bhagavā
translated: the Blessed One is one who enjoys, partakes of, and relishes the remote jungle resting places in the forest, secluded, undisturbed by sound, far from the madding crowd, undisturbed, delightful to the heart, fit for retreat,

original: cīvarapiṇḍapātasenāsanagilānapaccayabhesajjaparikkhārānanti bhagavā, bhāgī vā bhagavā
analyzed: cīvara piṇḍapāta senāsana gilāna paccaya bhesajja parikkhārānanti bhagavā bhāgī vā bhagavā
translated: the Blessed One is one who enjoys, partakes of, and relishes the requisites of robes, almsfood, resting place, and medicine,

original: attharasassa dhammarasassa vimuttirasassa adhisīlassa adhicittassa adhipaññāyāti
analyzed: attha rasassa dhamma rasassa vimutti rasassa adhi sīlassa adhi cittassa adhi paññāyā ati
translated: the Blessed One is one who enjoys, partakes of, and relishes the taste of the Dhamma, the taste of the holy life, the taste of peace, the taste of enlightenment, the taste of Nibbāna, the Blessed One is one who enjoys, partakes of, and relishes the higher virtue, the higher consciousness, the higher wisdom,

original: bhagavā, bhāgī vā bhagavā catunnaṃ jhānānaṃ catunnaṃ appamaññānaṃ catunnaṃ arūpasamāpattīnanti
analyzed: bhagavā bhāgī vā bhagavā catunnam jhānānam catunnam appamaññānam catunnam arūpa samāpattīnam ti
translated: the Blessed One is one who enjoys, partakes of, and relishes the four jhānas, the four measureless states, the four immaterial attainments,

original: bhagavā, bhāgī vā bhagavā aṭṭhannaṃ vimokkhānaṃ aṭṭhannaṃ abhibhāyatanānaṃ navannaṃ
analyzed: bhagavā bhāgī vā bhagavā aṭṭhannam vimokkhānam aṭṭhannam abhibhāyatanānam navannam
translated: The Blessed One is a partaker of the eight liberations, the eight spheres of mastery, the nine step-by-step dwellings,

original: anupubbavihārasamāpattīnanti bhagavā, bhāgī vā bhagavā dasannaṃ saññābhāvanānaṃ dasannaṃ🔽kasiṇasamāpattīnaṃ ānāpānassatisamādhissa asubhasamāpattiyāti bhagavā, bhāgī vā bhagavā
analyzed: anupubba vihāra samāpattīnam ti bhagavā bhāgī vā bhagavā dasannam saññā bhāvanānam dasannam  kasiṇa samāpattīnam āna apāna sati samādhissa asubha samāpattiyāḥ ati bhagavā bhāgī vā bhagavā
translated: the ten kasinas, the ten universal dwellings, the concentration of mindfulness of in-&-out breathing, the concentration of the ugliness ,🔽the four establishments of mindfulness, the four right efforts, the four foundations for supernormal power, the five spiritual faculties, the five spiritual powers, the seven factors for awakening, the noble eightfold path,

original: catunnaṃ satipaṭṭhānānaṃ catunnaṃ sammappadhānānaṃ catunnaṃ iddhipādānaṃ pañcannaṃ
analyzed: catunnam satipaṭṭhānānam catunnam sammappadhānānam catunnam iddhipādānam pañcannam
translated: the ten Tathagata powers, the four confidences, the four analytical knowledges, the six direct knowledges, the four kinds of fearlessness,🔽the eighteen distinctive attributes of a Buddha.🔽The Blessed One is a partaker of these things.🔽The Blessed One is a partaker of these things.🔽The Blessed One is a partaker of these things.

original: indriyānaṃ pañcannaṃ balānaṃ sattannaṃ bojjhaṅgānaṃ ariyassa aṭṭhaṅgikassa maggassāti
analyzed: indriyānam pañcannam balānam sattannam bojjhaṅgānam ariyassa aṭṭhaṅgikassa maggassa ati
translated: The Blessed One is a partaker of these things.🔽The Blessed One is a partaker of these things.🔽The Blessed One is a partaker of these things.🔽The Blessed One is a partaker of these things.

original: bhagavā, bhāgī vā bhagavā dasannaṃ tathāgatabalānaṃ catunnaṃ vesārajjānaṃ catunnaṃ
analyzed: bhagavā bhāgī vā bhagavā dasannam tathāgata balānam catunnam vesārajjānam catunnam
translated: The Blessed One is a partaker of these things.🔽The Blessed One is a partaker of these things.🔽The Blessed One is a partaker of these things.🔽The Blessed One is a partaker of these things.🔽The Blessed One is a partaker of these things.🔽The Blessed One is a partaker of these things.🔽The Blessed One is a partaker of these things.🔽The Blessed One is a partaker of these things.🔽The Blessed One is a partaker of these things.

original: paṭisambhidānaṃ channaṃ abhiññānaṃ channaṃ buddhadhammānanti bhagavā, bhagavāti netaṃ🔽nāmaṃ…pe… sacchikā paññatti yadidaṃ bhagavā”ti.
analyzed: paṭisambhidānam channam abhiññānam channam buddha dhammānam ti bhagavā bhagavā ati na itam 🔽sacchikā paññatti yat idam bhagavā ati
translated: The Blessed One is a partaker of these things.🔽The Blessed One is a partaker of these things.🔽The Blessed One is a partaker of these things.🔽The Blessed One is a partaker of these things.🔽The Blessed One is a partaker of these things.🔽The Blessed One is a partaker of these things.🔽The Blessed One is a partaker of these things.🔽The Blessed One is a partaker of these things.🔽The Blessed One is a partaker of these things.🔽The Blessed One is a partaker of these things.🔽The Blessed One is a partaker of these things.🔽The Blessed One is a partaker of these things.🔽The Blessed One is a partaker of these things.🔽The Blessed One is a partaker of these things.🔽The Blessed One is a partaker of these things.

original: Ettha ca “gāravādhivacana”ntiādīni yadipi gāthāyaṃ āgatapadānukkamena na niddiṭṭhāni,
analyzed: ettha ca gārava adhivacana nti ādīni yadi pi gāthāyam āgata pada anukkamena na niddiṭṭhāni
translated: And here, although the words “expression of respect,” etc., are not demonstrated in the order in which the words occur in the verse,

original: yathārahaṃ pana tesaṃ sabbesampi niddesabhāvena veditabbāni. Tattha gāravādhivacananti🔽garūnaṃ garubhāvavācakaṃ vacanaṃ. Bhajīti bhāgaso kathesi. Tenāha “vibhajī”ti. Dhammaratananti🔽maggaphalādiariyadhammaratanaṃ. Puna bhajīti sevi. Bhāgīti bhāgadheyyavā. Puna bhāgīti🔽bhajanasīlo. Attharasassāti atthasannissayassa rasassa. Vimuttāyatanasīse hi ṭhatvā
analyzed: yathāraham pana tesam sabbesam pi niddesa bhāvena veditabbāni tattha gārava adhivacanan ti  garūnam garu bhāva vācakam vacanam bhajīti bhāgaso kathesi tena āha vibhajīti  magga phala ādi ariya dhamma ratanam puna bhajīti sevi bhāgī iti bhāgadheyya vā puna bhāgī iti  bhajana sīlaḥ attha rasassa ati attha sannissayassa rasassa vimutta āyatana sīse hi
translated: nevertheless they should be understood as the demonstration of all of them in the proper order. Herein, “expression of respect” is

original: dhammaṃ kathentassa, suṇantassa ca tadatthaṃ ārabbha uppajjanakapītisomanassaṃ attharaso.
analyzed: dhammam kathentassa suṇantassa ca tad attham ārabbha uppajjanaka pīti somanassam attha rasaḥ
translated: the expression that speaks of the respect due to the venerable ones. “He shared” : he spoke by dividing it up. Hence he said “he analyzed” . “The jewel of the Dhamma” is the jewel of the noble Dhamma consisting of the path, the fruits, etc. “He shared again” : he served. “He shared out” : he spoke as one who has a share. “He shared again” : he is one who is worthy of offerings. “The taste of the meaning” : the taste that has the meaning as its support. For when one speaks the Dhamma and another listens to it, the rapture and gladness that arise in them both in regard to the meaning is the taste of the meaning.

original: Dhammaṃ ārabbha dhammaraso. Yaṃ sandhāya vuttaṃ “labhati atthavedaṃ, labhati dhammaveda”nti.
analyzed: dhammam ārabbha dhamma rasaḥ yam sandhāya vuttam labhati attha vedam labhati dhamma vedam ti
translated: The taste of the Dhamma is that which arises in regard to the Dhamma. It is in reference to this that it is said: “He obtains the taste of the meaning, he obtains the taste of the Dhamma” .

original: Vimuttirasassāti vimuttibhūtassa, vimuttisannissayassa vā rasassa. Saññābhāvanānanti🔽aniccasaññādīnaṃ dasannaṃ saññābhāvanānaṃ. Channaṃ buddhadhammānanti cha asādhāraṇañāṇāni
analyzed: vimutti rasassa ati vimutti bhūtassa vimutti sannissayassa vā rasassa  anicca saññā ādīnam dasannam saññā bhāvanānam channam buddha dhammānam ti cha asādhāraṇa ñāṇāni
translated: ‘The taste of the liberation-peak’: the taste of one who has become liberation, or the taste of one who has liberation as his support. ‘The ten kinds of perception-development’:🔽the ten kinds of perception-development beginning with the perception of impermanence. ‘The six kinds of knowledge of the Buddha’:

original: sandhāya vuttaṃ. Tattha tattha “bhagavā”ti saddasiddhi niruttinayena veditabbā.
analyzed: sandhāya vuttam tattha tattha bhagavā iti sadda siddhi nirutti nayena veditabbā
translated: this is said with reference to the six kinds of knowledge not held in common . Herein, the derivation of the word ‘Blessed’ should be understood according to the method of exposition as follows:

original: 144. Yadipi “bhāgyavā”tiādīhi padehi vuccamāno attho “bhagī bhajī”ti niddesagāthāya
analyzed: yadi api bhāgyavāti ādīhi padehi vuccamānaḥ atthaḥ bhagī bhajī iti niddesa gāthāya
translated: Although the meaning expressed by the words ‘fortunate’ and so on is included in the explanatory verse ‘He who has the portions, who has enjoyed’ ,

original: saṅgahito eva, tathāpi padasiddhi atthavibhāgaatthayojanādisahito saṃvaṇṇanānayo🔽tato aññākāroti vuttaṃ “ayaṃ pana aparo nayo”ti. Ādikanti ādi-saddena vaṇṇavikāro,
analyzed: eva tathā api saṃvaṇṇanā anayo  tatas aññākāro ti vuttam ayam pana aparaḥ nayo ti ādikanti ādi saddena vaṇṇa vikāro
translated: nevertheless the method of exposition together with the analysis of the meaning, the application of the meaning, and so on,🔽is different from that, and so it is said ‘But there is this other method’ . The word ‘and so on’ includes the three kinds of characteristic, namely, the modification of a vowel,

original: vaṇṇalopo, dhātuatthena niyojanañcāti imaṃ tividhaṃ lakkhaṇaṃ saṅgaṇhāti. Saddanayenāti
analyzed: vaṇṇa lopaḥ dhātu atthena niyojanam ca ati imam tividham lakkhaṇam saṅgaṇhāti sadda nayena ati
translated: the omission of a vowel, and the application by the meaning of a verbal root. ‘By the method of grammar’:

original: byākaraṇanayena. Pisodarādīnaṃ saddānaṃ ākatigaṇabhāvato vuttaṃ “pisodarādipakkhepalakkhaṇaṃ
analyzed: byākaraṇa nayena pisodara ādīnam saddānam ākati gaṇa bhāvataḥ vuttam pisodara ādi pakkhepa lakkhaṇam
translated: by the method of grammar. Since the words pisodara and so on are included in the ākaṭa class, it is said ‘The characteristic of the inclusion of pisodara and so on’ .

original: gahetvā”ti. Pakkhipanameva lakkhaṇaṃ. Tappariyāpannatākaraṇaṃ hi pakkhipanaṃ. Pārappattanti
analyzed: gahetvā ti pakkhipanam eva lakkhaṇam tad pariyāpanna tā karaṇam hi pakkhipanam pāra ppattanti
translated: and ‘having seized’ is the characteristic of ‘having seized’. For the act of seizing is included in that. ‘Having reached the end’:

original: paramukkaṃsagataṃ pāramibhāvappattaṃ. Bhāgyanti kusalaṃ. Tattha maggakusalaṃ lokuttarasukhanibbattakaṃ,
analyzed: param ukkaṃsa gatam pārami bhāva ppattam kusalam tattha magga kusalam lokuttara sukha nibbattakam
translated: and ‘having taken’ is the characteristic of ‘having put in’. For ‘putting in’ is the making of what is included in it. ‘Having reached the other side’ means having reached the other side of the world. ‘Good fortune’ means profitable . Herein, the profitable of the path is the producer of supramundane pleasure,

original: itaraṃ lokiyasukhanibbattakaṃ, itarampi vā vivaṭṭūpanissayaṃ pariyāyato lokuttarasukhanibbattakaṃ siyā.
analyzed: itaram lokiya sukha nibbattakam itaram api vā vivaṭṭu upanissayam pariyāyataḥ lokuttara sukha nibbattakam siyā
translated: the other is the producer of mundane pleasure, or the other also may be the producer of supramundane pleasure figuratively as a condition for the turning away .

original: Lobhādayo ekakavasena gahitā. Tathā viparītamanasikāro vipallāsabhāvasāmaññena, ahirikādayo
analyzed: lobha ādayaḥ ekaka vasena gahitā tathā viparītamanasikāraḥ vipallāsa bhāva sāmaññena ahirika ādayaḥ
translated: Greed, etc., are taken singly. So too, wrong reflection is taken as a single term because of the similarity of its state of being a perversion. Shamelessness, etc., are taken as a pair.

original: dukavasena. Lobhādayo ca puna “tividhākusalamūla”nti tikavasena gahitā. Kāyaduccaritādi-taṇhāsaṃkilesādirāgamalādirāgavisamādikāmasaññādikāmavitakkāditaṇhāpapañcādayo
analyzed: lobha ādayaḥ ca puna tika vasena gahitā
translated: Greed, etc., are taken as a triad because of the ‘three roots of what is unprofitable’. Bad conduct of body, etc., defilement by craving, etc., stain by lust, etc., perversion by lust, etc., perception of sensual desires, etc., thought of sensual desires, etc., proliferation of craving, etc.,

original: tividhaduccaritādayo. Subhasaññādikā catubbidhavipariyesā. “Cīvarahetu vā bhikkhuno
analyzed: tividha duccarita ādayaḥ subha saññā ādikā catubbidha vipariyesā cīvara hetu vā bhikkhuno
translated: are taken as a triad. The four perversions beginning with perception of beauty are taken as a fourfold. ‘For the sake of robe-material, bhikkhus, a bhikkhu

original: taṇhā uppajjamānā uppajjati, piṇḍapāta, senāsana, itibhavābhavahetu vā”ti evamāgatā🔽cattāro taṇhuppādā. “Buddhe kaṅkhati, dhamme, saṅghe, sikkhāya, sabrahmacārīsu kupito🔽hoti anattamano āhatacitto khīlajāto”ti evamāgatāni pañca cetokhīlāni. “Kāme avītarāgo
analyzed: taṇhā uppajjamānā uppajjati piṇḍapāta senāsana iti bhava abhava hetu vāti evam āgatā  cattāro taṇhuppādāḥ buddhe kaṅkhati dhamme saṅghe sikkhāya sabrahmacārīsu kupito  hoti an atta manaḥ āhata citto khīla jātaḥ iti evam āgatāni pañca cetaḥ khīlāni kāme a vīta rāgaḥ
translated: and craving arises for the alms food, the resting place, and the requisites of the monastic life, or for rebirth in a good becoming.”🔽These are the four kinds of craving. “He is doubtful about the Enlightened One, about the True Idea, about the Community, about the training,”🔽and so there are the five stakes of sense desire. “He is not free from lust, desire, affection, thirst, fever, and craving for sense desires,

Rūpābhinandanādayo pañcābhinandanā. Kodho, makkho,🔽issā, sāṭheyyaṃ, pāpicchatā, sandiṭṭhiparāmāsoti imāni cha vivādamūlāni. Rūpataṇhādayo cha taṇhākāyā.

original: Kāmarāgapaṭighadiṭṭhivicikicchābhavarāgamānāvijjā sattānusayā. Micchādiṭṭhiādayo
analyzed: kāma rāga paṭigha diṭṭhi vicikicchā bhava rāga māna a vijjāḥ satta anusayāḥ micchā diṭṭhi ādayaḥ
translated: and the underlying tendencies of lust for sense desires, conceit, views, doubt, lust for becoming, and ignorance. The eight wrongnesses beginning with wrong view,

original: aṭṭha micchattā. “Taṇhaṃ paṭicca pariyesanā, pariyesanaṃ paṭicca lābho, lābhaṃ paṭicca🔽vinicchayo, vinicchayaṃ paṭicca chandarāgo, chandarāgaṃ paṭicca ajjhosānaṃ, ajjhosānaṃ
analyzed: micchattā taṇham paṭicca pariyesanā pariyesanam paṭicca lābhaḥ lābham paṭicca  vinicchayaḥ vinicchayam paṭicca chanda rāgaḥ chanda rāgam paṭicca ajjhosānam ajjhosānam
translated: “With craving as condition: pursuit, with pursuit as condition: acquisition, with acquisition as condition:

original: paṭicca pariggaho, pariggahaṃ paṭicca macchariyaṃ, macchariyaṃ paṭicca ārakkhā, ārakkhādhikaraṇaṃ
analyzed: paṭicca pariggahaḥ pariggaham paṭicca macchariyam macchariyam paṭicca ārakkhā ārakkha adhikaraṇam
translated: determination, with determination as condition: desire and lust, with desire and lust as condition: attachment, with attachment as condition: avarice, with avarice as condition: guarding of property, on account of the guarding of property

original: daṇḍādānādayo”ti ete nava taṇhāmūlakā. Cattāro sassatavādā, cattāro ekaccasassatavādā,
analyzed: daṇḍa ādāna ādayo ti ete nava taṇhā mūlakā cattāro sassata vādā cattāro ekacca sassata vādā
translated: there arise the taking up of the stick and sword, quarrels, disputes, arguments, strife, abuse, lying and other evil unskilled states,” these nine are rooted in craving. The four theories of eternalism, the four of limited-eternalism,

original: cattāro antānantikā, cattāro amarāvikkhepikā, dve adhiccasamuppannikā, soḷasa saññīvādā,
analyzed: cattāraḥ antānantikā cattāro amarāvikkhepikā dve adhiccasamuppannikā soḷasa saññīvādā
translated: the four of endless-extremism, the four of chance-coincidence, the two of fortuitous origination, the sixteen of the ideationists,

original: aṭṭha asaññīvādā, aṭṭha nevasaññīnāsaññīvādā, satta ucchedavādā, pañca paramadiṭṭhadhammanibbānavādāti
analyzed: aṭṭha asaññī vādā aṭṭha nevasaññīnāsaññīvādā satta uccheda vādā pañca parama diṭṭhadhamma nibbāna vādā ati
translated: the eight of the non-ideationists, the eight of the neither-ideation-nor-non-ideationists, the seven of annihilationism, and the five of the doctrine of the extinction through insight of the here and now—

original: etāni dvāsaṭṭhi diṭṭhigatāni. Ajjhattikassa upādāya “asmī”ti hoti, “itthasmī”ti,
analyzed: etāni dvāsaṭṭhi diṭṭhigatāni ajjhattikassa upādāya asmi iti hoti ittha asmi iti
translated: These are the sixty-two views. “Because of internal assuming, there is ‘I am’ and ‘I am this’ and

original: “evasmī”ti, “aññathāsmī”ti, “bhavissa”nti, “itthaṃ bhavissa”nti, “evaṃ bhavissa”nti,🔽“aññathā bhavissa”nti, “asasmī”ti, “sātasmī”ti, “siya”nti, “itthaṃ siya”nti, “evaṃ
analyzed: evasmi iti aññathā asmi iti bhavissanti ittham bhavissanti evam bhavissanti  aññathā bhavissanti a sasmi iti siyanti ittham siyanti evam
translated: ‘I am such’ and ‘I am otherwise’ and ‘I will be’ and ‘I will be such’ and ‘I will be thus’ and

original: siya”nti, “aññathā siya”nti, “apāhaṃ siya”nti, “apāhaṃ itthaṃ siya”nti, “apāhaṃ evaṃ🔽siya”nti, “apāhaṃ aññathā siya”nti hotīti aṭṭhārasa, bāhirassupādāya “iminā asmī”ti
analyzed: siyanti aññathā siyanti apāham siyanti apāham ittham siyanti apāham evam  siyanti apa aham aññathā hoti iti aṭṭhārasa bāhirassa upādāya iminā asmi iti
translated: ‘I will be otherwise’ and ‘I will not be’ and ‘I will be gratified’ and ‘I will be such’ and ‘I will be thus’ and

original: hoti, “iminā itthasmī”ti, “iminā evasmī”ti, “iminā aññathāsmī”tiādikā vuttanayā aṭṭhārasāti
analyzed: hoti iminā itthasmi iti iminā evasmi iti iminā aññathā asmi iti ādikāḥ vutta nayāḥ aṭṭhārasā ati
translated: ‘I will be otherwise’ and ‘I will not be such’ and ‘I will not be thus’ and ‘I will not be otherwise’—these are the eighteen . “Because of external assuming, there is ‘By this I am’ and ‘By this I am this’ and ‘By this I am such’ and ‘By this I am otherwise’ and so on in the way described, making eighteen.

original: chattiṃsa, atītā chattiṃsa, anāgatā chattiṃsa, paccuppannā chattiṃsāti aṭṭhasatataṇhāvicaritāni.
analyzed: chattiṃsa atītā chattiṃsa anāgatā chattiṃsa paccuppannā chattiṃsa ati aṭṭhasata taṇhā vicaritāni
translated: These are the thirty-six . There are thirty-six in the past, thirty-six in the future, and thirty-six in the present, making one hundred and eight kinds of resort to craving.

original: Pabheda-saddo paccekaṃ sambandhitabbo. Tatthāyaṃ yojanā – lobhappabhedā dosappabhedā
analyzed: pabheda saddo paccekam sambandhitabbo tattha ayam yojanā lobha ppabhedā dosa ppabhedā
translated: The word ‘distinction’ should be construed with each of the above terms. Here is the construction: The distinctions of greed, the distinctions of hate,

original: yāva aṭṭhasatataṇhāvicaritappabhedāti. Sabbāni sattānaṃ darathapariḷāhakarāni kilesānaṃ
analyzed: yāva aṭṭhasata taṇhā vicarita ppabhedā ti sabbāni sattānam daratha pariḷāha karāni kilesānam
translated: and so on, down to the eighty-four hundred thousand kinds of craving. He broke all the defilements that are the cause of the fever of craving in beings,

original: anekāni satasahassāni abhañjīti yojanā. Ārammaṇādivibhāgato hi pavattiākāravibhāgato🔽ca anantappabhedā kilesāti. Saṅkhepatoti ettha samucchedappahānavasena sabbaso appavattikaraṇena🔽kilesamāraṃ, samudayappahānapariññāvasena khandhamāraṃ, sahāyavekallakaraṇavasena🔽sabbathā appavattikaraṇena abhisaṅkhāramāraṃ, balavidhamanavisayātikkamanavasena
analyzed: anekāni sata sahassāni abhañji iti yojanā ārammaṇa ādi vibhāgataḥ hi pavatti ākāra vibhāgataḥ  ca ananta ppabhedā kilesā ati saṅkhepato ti ettha samuccheda ppahāna vasena sabbaso appavatti karaṇena  kilesa māram samudaya ppahāna pariññā vasena khandha māram sahāya vekalla karaṇa vasena  sabbathā appavatti karaṇena abhisaṅkhāra māram bala vidhamana visaya atikkamana vasena
translated: the many hundreds of thousands of kinds of defilements. The meaning is that he broke them. For defilements have an infinite number of divisions according to the analysis of object, etc., and according to the analysis of mode of activity.

original: devaputtamaccumārañca abhañji bhagge akāsi. Parissayānanti upaddavānaṃ. Sampati,🔽āyatiñca sattānaṃ anatthāvahattā māraṇaṭṭhena vibādhanaṭṭhena kilesāva māroti kilesamāro.
analyzed: devaputta maccumāram ca abhañji bhagge akāsi upaddavānam sampati  āyatim ca sattānam anattha āvaha tā māraṇa ṭhena vibādhana kilesa ava māroti kilesa māro
translated: Briefly: by the abandoning of their entire range of occurrence through the act of cutting them off, he broke the defilements as the “Mara of defilements.” By the full understanding of their origination he broke the aggregates as the “Mara of aggregates.” By the act of making them no longer have a companion he broke the formations as the “Mara of formations.” By the act of making them no longer occur in any way he broke the Mara of death as the “Mara of death.” By the act of banishing their power and by the act of transcending their domain he broke the deva-sons as the “Mara of deva-sons.” He broke them, he made them have gaps.🔽The dangers: the calamities. The defilements are called “Mara” because they kill by causing harm to beings in the present and in the future.

original: Vadhakaṭṭhena khandhāva māroti khandhamāro. Tathā hi vuttaṃ “vadhakaṃ rūpaṃ ‘vadhakaṃ
analyzed: vadha kaṭṭhena khandhā va māro ti khandha māro tathā hi vuttam vadhakam rūpam vadhakam
translated: The aggregates are called “Mara” because they kill by causing harm. For this is said: “Form kills, it kills by the killing of formations, by the killing of defilements, by the killing of aggregates, by the killing of death, by the killing of deva-sons” .

original: rūpa’nti yathābhūtaṃ nappajānātī”tiādi. Jātijarādimahābyasananibbattanena abhisaṅkhārova🔽māroti abhisaṅkhāramāro. Saṃkilesanimittaṃ hutvā guṇamāraṇaṭṭhena devaputtova māroti
analyzed: yathābhūtam na ppajānāti itiādi jāti jarā ādi mahā byasana nibbattanena abhisaṅkhāraḥ uva  māro ti abhisaṅkhāra māro saṃkilesa nimittam hutvā guṇa māraṇa ṭṭhena deva putto va māro ti
translated: He does not understand as it really is: ‘This is suffering’ … ‘This is the way leading to the cessation of suffering.’ ”🔽The “Mara of determinations” is so called because the great calamities beginning with birth and aging are produced by determinations.🔽The “Mara of the heavenly world” is so called because he kills the special qualities by becoming the cause of defilement, like a god.

original: devaputtamāro. Sattānaṃ jīvitassa, jīvitaparikkhārānañca jānikaraṇena mahābādharūpattā
analyzed: deva putta māraḥ sattānam jīvitassa jīvita parikkhārānam ca jāni karaṇena mahā bādha rūpa ttā
translated: The “Mara of death” is so called because he is a great affliction to beings, since he causes the loss of life and of the requisites of life.

original: maccu eva māroti maccumāro.🔽Satapuññalakkhaṇadharassāti anekasatapuññanibbattamahāpurisalakkhaṇavahato rūpakāyasampatti
analyzed: maccu eva māro ti maccumāro  sata puñña lakkhaṇa dharassa ati aneka sata puñña nibbatta mahāpurisa lakkhaṇa vahataḥ rūpa kāya sampatti
translated: The “Mara of the aggregates” is so called because he is the five aggregates.🔽“Possessed of a hundred merits’ marks”: the excellence of his material body is indicated by the fact that he bears the great man’s marks produced by a hundred merits.🔽The excellence of his spiritual body is indicated by the fact that he is the root and foundation of the other kinds of excellence, namely, the excellence of fruition, because the excellence of knowledge, etc., are preceded by the excellence of abandonment.

original: dīpitā hoti, itarāsaṃ phalasampadānaṃ mūlabhāvato, adhiṭṭhānabhāvato ca. Dhammakāyasampatti🔽dīpitā hoti, pahānasampadāpubbakattā ñāṇasampadādīnaṃ. Bhāgyavatāya lokiyānaṃ bahumatabhāvo.
analyzed: dīpitā hoti itarāsam phala sampadānam mūla bhāvataḥ adhiṭṭhāna bhāvataḥ ca dhammakāya sampatti  dīpitā hoti pahāna sampad āpubbaka ttā ñāṇa sampad ādīnam bhāgyavatāya lokiyānam bahu mata bhāvaḥ
translated: The excellence of his spiritual body is indicated by the fact that he is the root and foundation of the other kinds of excellence, namely, the excellence of fruition, because the excellence of knowledge, etc., are preceded by the excellence of abandonment.🔽The excellence of his material body is indicated by the fact that he bears the great man’s marks produced by a hundred merits.🔽The excellence of his spiritual body is indicated by the fact that he is the root and foundation of the other kinds of excellence, namely, the excellence of fruition, because the excellence of knowledge, etc., are preceded by the excellence of abandonment.🔽The excellence of his material body is indicated by the fact that he bears the great man’s marks produced by a hundred merits.🔽The excellence of his spiritual body is indicated by the fact that he is the root and foundation of the other kinds of excellence, namely, the excellence of fruition, because the excellence of knowledge, etc., are preceded by the excellence of abandonment.🔽The excellence of his material body is indicated by the fact that he bears the great man’s marks produced by a hundred merits.🔽The excellence of his spiritual body is indicated by the fact that he is the root and foundation of the other kinds of excellence, namely, the excellence of fruition, because the excellence of knowledge, etc., are preceded by the excellence of abandonment.

original: Bhaggadosatāya parikkhakānaṃ bahumatabhāvoti yojanā. Evaṃ ito paresupi yathāsaṅkhyaṃ
analyzed: bhagga dosa tāya parikkhakānam bahu mata bhāvaḥ ti yojanā evam itas paresu pi yathāsaṅkhyam
translated: The excellence of his material body is indicated by the fact that he bears

original: yojetabbaṃ. Puññavantaṃ hi gahaṭṭhā khattiyādayo abhigacchanti, pahīnadosaṃ pabbajitatāpasaparibbājakādayo
analyzed: yojetabbam puññavantam hi gahaṭṭhāḥ khattiya ādayaḥ abhigacchanti pahīna dosam pabbajita tāpasa paribbājaka ādayo
translated: He should be approached. For householders such as nobles, etc., who are meritorious approach him, and ascetics such as those who are wanderers who have abandoned hate approach him.

original: “dosavinayāya dhammaṃ desetī”ti. Abhigatānañca nesaṃ kāyacittadukkhāpanayane paṭibalabhāvo,
analyzed: dosa vinayāya dhammaṃ deseti iti abhigatānam ca nesam kāya citta dukkha apanayane paṭibala bhāvaḥ
translated: He teaches the Dhamma for the removal of hate. And he is able to remove the bodily and mental pain of those who approach him,

original: āmisadānadhammadānehi upakārasabbhāvato. Rūpakāyaṃ tassa pasādacakkhunā, dhammakāyaṃ
analyzed: āmisa dāna dhamma dānehi upakāra sabbhāvataḥ rūpakāyam tassa pasāda cakkhunā dhammakāyam
translated: because he is helpful to them by giving material things and by giving the Dhamma. Having seen his material body with the eye of confidence and his Dhamma body with the eye of understanding,

original: paññācakkhunā disvā dukkhadvayassa paṭippassambhanato upagatānañca tesaṃ āmisadānadhammadānehi
analyzed: paññācakkhunā disvā dukkha dvayassa paṭippassambhanataḥ upagatānaṃ ca tesam āmisa dāna dhamma dānehi
translated: and having allayed their twofold suffering, he helps those who have approached him by giving them material things and the Dhamma.

original: upakāritā, “pubbe āmisadānadhammadānehi mayā ayaṃ lokaggabhāvo adhigato, tasmā tumhehipi
analyzed: upakāritā pubbe āmisa dāna dhamma dānehi mayā ayam lokagga bhāvaḥ adhigataḥ tasmā tumhehi pi
translated: And he directs them to the right practice, saying: “It was by giving material things and the Dhamma in the past that I reached the position of a world-fulfiller. Therefore you too should practice thus.”

original: evameva paṭipajjitabba”nti evaṃ sammāpaṭipattiyaṃ niyojanena abhigatānaṃ lokiyalokuttarasukhehi🔽saṃyojanasamatthatā ca dīpitā hoti.
analyzed: evam eva paṭipajjitabbanti evam sammā paṭipattiyam niyojanena abhigatānam lokiya lokuttara sukhehi 🔽saṃyojana samattha tā ca dīpitā hoti
translated: And he shows them how they can be bound to the happiness of the worlds and of the supramundane state by the binding of right practice.

original: Sakacitte issariyaṃ attano cittassa vasībhāvāpādanaṃ, yena paṭikkūlādīsu appaṭikkūlasaññitādivihārasiddhi,
analyzed: saka citte issariyam attano cittassa vasībhāva āpādanaṃ yena paṭikkūla ādīsu appaṭikkūla saññita ādi vihāra siddhi
translated: The ‘power of the mind’ is the sovereignty of one’s own mind, by means of which there is success in the abiding consisting in the perception of the unrepulsive, etc., in regard to the repulsive, etc.;

original: adhiṭṭhāniddhiādiko iddhividhopi cittissariyameva cittabhāvanāya vasībhāvappattiyā
analyzed: adhiṭṭhāniddhi ādikaḥ iddhi vidhaḥ api citti ssariyam eva citta bhāvanāya vasībhāva ppattiyā
translated: and the various kinds of supernormal power consisting in resolve, etc., are also ‘power of the mind’ because of the attainment of sovereignty of the mind by means of mental development.

original: ijjhanato. Aṇimālaghimādikanti ādi-saddena mahimā patti pākammaṃ īsitā vasitā yatthakāmāvasāyitāti
analyzed: aṇima alaghima ādikam ti ādi saddena mahimā īsitā vasitā yattha kāmāvasāyi tā ati
translated: ‘The ability to become small, etc.’: the word ‘etc.’ includes the ability to become large, to become light, to do what is wished, to exercise lordship, and to transform.

original: ime chapi saṅgahitā. Tattha kāyassa aṇubhāvakaraṇaṃ aṇimā. Lahubhāvo laghimā ākāse🔽padasā gamanādinā. Mahattaṃ mahimā kāyassa mahantatāpādanaṃ. Iṭṭhadesappatti patti.
analyzed: ime saṅgahitā tattha kāyassa aṇu bhāva karaṇam aṇimā lahu bhāvaḥ laghimā ākāse  gamana ādinā mahattam mahimā kāyassa mahanta tā āpādanam iṭṭha desa ppatti patti
translated: Herein, the ability to make the body small is the ability to become small. The ability to make it light is the ability to become light. The ability to walk on water and in the air, etc.,🔽is the ability to do what is wished. The ability to make the body large is the ability to become large.

original: Adhiṭṭhānādivasena icchitanipphādanaṃ pākammaṃ. Sayaṃvasitā issarabhāvo īsitā. Iddhividhe
analyzed: adhiṭṭhāna ādi vasena icchita nipphādanam pākammam sayaṃvasi tā issara bhāvaḥ īsitā iddhividhe
translated: The ability to produce what is wanted by means of resolve, etc., is the ability to do what is wished. The ability to exercise lordship is the ability to exercise lordship. The ability to transform is the ability to transform.

original: vasībhāvo vasitā. Ākāsena vā gacchato, aññaṃ vā kiñci karoto yattha katthaci vosānappatti
analyzed: vasībhāvaḥ vasitā ākāsena vā gacchataḥ aññam vā kiñci karotaḥ yattha katthaci vosāna ppatti
translated: The ability to go wherever one wishes, whether in the sky or elsewhere, is the ability to do what is wished.

original: yatthakāmāvasāyitā. “Kumārakarūpādidassana”ntipi vadanti. Evamidaṃ aṭṭhavidhaṃ lokiyasammataṃ
analyzed: vadanti evam idam aṭṭhavidham lokiya sammatam
translated: This is the eightfold sovereignty recognized in the world.

original: issariyaṃ. Taṃ pana bhagavato iddhividhantogadhaṃ, anaññasādhāraṇañcāti āha “sabbākāraparipūraṃ atthī”ti.
analyzed: issariyam tam pana bhagavataḥ anañña sādhāraṇam ca ati āha sabba ākāra paripūram atthi iti
translated: But the Blessed One’s sovereignty is complete in all aspects and is not shared by anyone else.

original: Kesañci padesavutti, ayathābhūtaguṇasannissayattā aparisuddho ca yaso hoti, na evaṃ🔽tathāgatassāti dassetuṃ “lokattayabyāpako”tiādi vuttaṃ. Tattha idha adhigatasatthuguṇānaṃ
analyzed: ayathābhūta guṇa sannissaya ttā aparisuddho ca yasaḥ hoti na evam  tathāgatassa iti dassetum loka ttaya byāpaka uti ādi vuttam tattha idha adhigata satthu guṇānam
translated: The fame of some is limited to a certain locality, and it is impure because it is based on unreal qualities.🔽But the fame of the Tathāgata is not so.

original: āruppe uppannānaṃ “itipi so bhagavā”tiādinā bhagavato guṇe anussarantānaṃ yaso pākaṭo
analyzed: āruppe uppannānam saḥ bhagavān iti ādinā bhagavataḥ guṇe anussarantānam pākaṭaḥ
translated: Here, the fame of those who have attained the qualities of a teacher and have given rise to the jhānas in the immaterial sphere becomes evident as they recollect the Tathāgata’s qualities in the way beginning, “Thus indeed that Blessed One is … .”

original: hotīti āha “lokattayabyāpako”ti. Yathābhuccaguṇādhigatattā eva ativiya parisuddho.
analyzed: hoti iti āha loka ttaya byāpakaḥ iti eva parisuddhaḥ
translated: Therefore it is said that it “pervades the three worlds.” It is extremely pure because it is based on real qualities.

original: Anavasesalakkhaṇānubyañjanādisampattiyā sabbākāraparipūrā. Sabbaṅgapaccaṅgasirī sabbesaṃ
analyzed: anavasesa lakkhaṇa anubyañjana ādi sampattiyā sabba ākāra paripūrā sabbaṅga paccaṅga sirī sabbesam
translated: It is complete in all aspects because it is endowed with the complete perfection of the major and minor characteristics, etc. It is the glory of all parts and all limbs,

original: aṅgapaccaṅgānaṃ sobhā. “Tiṇṇo tāreyya”ntiādinā yaṃ yaṃ etena lokanāthena icchitaṃ
analyzed: sobhā tiṇṇo tāreyyanti ādinā yam yam etena lokanāthena icchitam
translated: and the limbs and minor limbs are the beauty. “Having crossed, he would lead others across” and so on: whatever was wished for by this Lord of the World

original: manovacīpaṇidhānavasena, patthitaṃ kāyapaṇidhānavasena. Tathevāti paṇidhānānurūpameva.
analyzed: manaḥ vacī paṇidhāna vasena patthitam kāya paṇidhāna vasena tathā iva ati paṇidhāna anurūpam eva
translated: was prayed for by way of mental and verbal vows, and was prayed for by way of bodily vows. Just so: in accordance with the vows.

original: Vīriyapāramibhāvappatto, ariyamaggapariyāpanno ca sammāvāyāmasaṅkhāto payatto.🔽Bhedehīti sabbattikadukapadasaṃhitehi pabhedehi. Paṭiccasamuppādādīhīti ādi-saddena🔽na kevalaṃ vibhaṅgapāḷiyaṃ āgatā satipaṭṭhānādayova saṅgahitā, atha kho saṅgahādayo,🔽samayavimuttādayo, ṭhapanādayo, tikapaṭṭhānādayo ca saṅgahitāti veditabbaṃ. Dukkhasaccassa🔽pīḷanaṭṭho taṃsamaṅgino sattassa hiṃsanaṃ avipphārikatākaraṇaṃ. Saṅkhataṭṭho sameccasambhūyapaccayehi
analyzed: vīriya pārami bhāva ppattaḥ ariya magga pariyāpanno ca sammāvāyāma saṅkhāto payatto  bhedehi iti sabba ttika duka pada saṃhitehi pabhedehi paṭiccasamuppāda ādīhi iti ādi saddena  na kevalam āgatā sati paṭṭhāna ādayaḥ iva saṅgahitāḥ atha kho saṅgaha ādayaḥ  samaya vimutta ādayo ṭhapana ādayo tika paṭṭhāna ādayo ca saṅgahitā iti veditabbam dukkhasaccassa  pīḷana ṭhaḥ tad samaṅgino sattassa hiṃsanam a vipphārika tā karaṇam saṅkhata ṭhaḥ samecca sambhūya paccayehi
translated: He has reached the perfection of energy, and is called right effort, which is included in the Noble Path.

original: katabhāvo. Santāpaṭṭho dukkhadukkhatādīhi santappanaṃ paridahanaṃ. Vipariṇāmaṭṭho
analyzed: kata bhāvaḥ santāpa ṭṭhaḥ dukkha dukkha tā ādīhi santappanam paridahanam vipariṇāma ṭṭhaḥ
translated: With divisions: with the divisions of the whole, the two, the three, the four, the five, the six, the seven, the eight, the nine, the ten, the eleven, the twelve, the thirteen, the fourteen, the fifteen, the sixteen, the seventeen, the eighteen, the nineteen, the twenty, the twenty-one, the twenty-two, the twenty-three, the twenty-four, the twenty-five, the twenty-six, the twenty-seven, the twenty-eight, the twenty-nine, the thirty, the thirty-one, the thirty-two, the thirty-three, the thirty-four, the thirty-five, the thirty-six, the thirty-seven, the thirty-eight, the thirty-nine, the forty, the forty-one, the forty-two, the forty-three, the forty-four, the forty-five, the forty-six, the forty-seven, the forty-eight, the forty-nine, the fifty, the fifty-one, the fifty-two, the fifty-three, the fifty-four, the fifty-five, the fifty-six, the fifty-seven, the fifty-eight, the fifty-nine, the sixty, the sixty-one, the sixty-two, the sixty-three, the sixty-four, the sixty-five, the sixty-six, the sixty-seven, the sixty-eight, the sixty-nine, the seventy, the seventy-one, the seventy-two, the seventy-three, the seventy-four, the seventy-five, the seventy-six, the seventy-seven, the seventy-eight, the seventy-nine, the eighty, the eighty-one, the eighty-two, the eighty-three, the eighty-four, the eighty-five, the eighty-six, the eighty-seven, the eighty-eight, the eighty-nine, the ninety, the ninety-one, the ninety-two, the ninety-three, the ninety-four,

original: jarāya, maraṇena cāti dvidhā vipariṇāmetabbatā. Samudayassa āyūhanaṭṭho dukkhassa
analyzed: jarāya maraṇena ca ati dvidhā vipariṇāmetabba tā samudayassa dukkhassa
translated: and by aging and by death, is twofold change. The function of origination is to accumulate suffering,

original: nibbattanavasena sampiṇḍanaṃ. Nidānaṭṭho “idaṃ taṃ dukkha”nti nidadantassa viya samuṭṭhāpanaṃ.
analyzed: nibbattana vasena sampiṇḍanam nidānaṭṭhaḥ idam tam dukkham ti nidadantassa viya samuṭṭhāpanaṃ
translated: and by aging and by death, thus it is twofold in the sense of being subject to change. The meaning of accumulation is the amassing of suffering by the amassing of its conditions. The meaning of condition is the production of suffering, as if it were the pointing out of suffering by saying, “This is suffering.”

original: Saṃyogaṭṭho saṃsāradukkhena saṃyojanaṃ. Palibodhaṭṭho maggādhigamassa nivāraṇaṃ.🔽Nirodhassa nissaraṇaṭṭho sabbūpadhīnaṃ paṭinissaggasabhāvattā tato vinissaṭatā, tannissaraṇanimittatā
analyzed: saṃyoga ṭṭhaḥ saṃsāra dukkhena saṃyojanam palibodha ṭṭhaḥ magga adhigamassa nivāraṇam  nirodhassa nissaraṇa ṭṭhaḥ sabba upadhīnam paṭinissagga sabhāva ttā tatas vinissaṭa tā tad nissaraṇa nimitta tā
translated: The meaning of bondage is the binding of the round of rebirths by suffering. The meaning of obstruction is the prevention of the attainment of the path.🔽The meaning of escape is the escape from that, or the sign of escape from that, because of the nature of the relinquishing of all the kinds of being.

original: vā. Vivekaṭṭho sabbasaṅkhāravisaṃyuttatā. Asaṅkhataṭṭho kenacipi paccayena anabhisaṅkhatatā.
analyzed: vā viveka ṭṭhaḥ sabba saṅkhāra visaṃyutta tā asaṅkhata ṭṭhaḥ kenacipi paccayena an abhisaṅkhata tā
translated: The meaning of seclusion is the disjunction from all formations. The meaning of the unformed is the non-formation by any conditions.

original: Amataṭṭho niccasabhāvattā maraṇābhāvo, sattānaṃ maraṇābhāvahetutā vā. Maggassa niyyānaṭṭho
analyzed: amata ṭṭhaḥ nicca sabhāva ttā maraṇa abhāvaḥ sattānam maraṇa abhāva hetu tā vā maggassa niyyāna ṭṭhaḥ
translated: The meaning of deathlessness is the absence of death because of the eternal nature, or the state of being the cause of the absence of death for beings. The meaning of outlet is the path’s

original: vaṭṭadukkhato niggamanaṭṭho. Hetuattho nibbānassa sampāpakabhāvo. Dassanaṭṭho accantasukhumassa
analyzed: vaṭṭa dukkhataḥ niggamana aṭṭhaḥ hetu atthaḥ nibbānassa sampāpaka bhāvaḥ dassana ṭṭhaḥ accanta sukhumassa
