translated: The Community’s special qualities: it is noble because it is far from defilements, because it does not stand in the wrong way, and because it stands in the right way.🔽It is a refuge because it is worthy of refuge to the world with its gods.🔽It is the Community because it is a company.🔽Or alternatively, it is the Community of Noble Ones because it is a company of noble ones.

original: ca lokena “saraṇa”nti araṇīyato ariyo ca so saṅgho ca, ariyānaṃ vā saṅgho ariyasaṅgho, tassa guṇā.
analyzed: ca lokena araṇīyataḥ ariyaḥ ca saḥ saṅgho ca ariyānam vā saṅghaḥ ariya saṅgho tassa guṇā
translated: The special qualities are those of that Community.🔽The right way is the noble path of practice,

original: 155. Yaṃ sammāpaṭipadaṃ paṭipanno “suṭṭhu paṭipanno”ti vuccati. Sā ariyamaggapaṭipadā
analyzed: yam sammā paṭipadam paṭipanno suṭṭhu paṭipannaḥ ti vuccati sā ariya magga paṭipadā
translated: which is called “well practised” when it is practised. It is the way of practice that is the noble path.

original: paṭipakkhadhamme anivattidhamme katvā pajahanato payojanābhāvā sayampi anivattidhammā,
analyzed: paṭipakkha dhamme a nivatti dhamme katvā pajahanataḥ payojana abhāvā sayam pi a nivatti dhammā
translated: It is the way that is not subject to destruction because it is the way that causes the abandoning of states that are subject to destruction by making them have no purpose.

original: adhigantabbassa ca nibbānassa ekaṃsato anulomīti. Tato eva apaccanīkā, anudhammabhūtā
analyzed: adhigantabbassa ca nibbānassa ekaṃsataḥ anulomī iti tatas eva apaccanīkā anudhamma bhūtā
translated: That is why it is said to be “not opposed” and “in accordance with the Dhamma.”🔽And because it is practised, the Noble Sangha is said to “have entered upon the good way.”

original: ca, tassā ca paṭipannattā ariyasaṅgho “suppaṭipanno”ti vuttoti dassetuṃ “suṭṭhu paṭipanno”tiādi🔽vuttaṃ. Tattha “anivattipaṭipada”nti iminā ujuppaṭipattiṃ dasseti. Punappunaṃ nivattane
analyzed: ca tassā ca paṭipanna ttā ariya saṅgho suppaṭipanno ti vuttaḥ ti dassetum suṭṭhu paṭipannaḥ tiādi  vuttam tattha anivatti paṭipadan ti iminā uju ppaṭipattim dasseti punappunam nivattane
translated: To show this, the text says, “The Noble Sangha … has entered upon the good way.”🔽Herein, by the phrase “the way that is not subject to reversal” he shows the way that is direct.🔽For when there is reversal again and again, there is no direct way.🔽By the phrase “the way that is in conformity and not opposed” he shows the way that is in accordance with the rules.

original: hi sati ujuppaṭipatti na hoti. “Anulomapaṭipadaṃ apaccanīkapaṭipada”nti iminā ñāyappaṭipattiṃ.
analyzed: hi sati uju ppaṭipatti na hoti anuloma paṭipadam apaccanīka paṭipadam ti iminā ñāya ppaṭipattim
translated: For it is in conformity with and not opposed to Nibbāna, which is what should be reached by the way.🔽By the phrase “the way that is in accordance with the Dhamma”

original: Paṭipajjitabbassa hi nibbānassa anulomanena, apaccanīkatāya cassā ñāyato. “Dhammānudhammapaṭipada”nti
analyzed: paṭipajjitabbassa hi nibbānassa anulomanena apaccanīka tāya ca ssā ñāyataḥ dhamma anudhamma paṭipadanti
translated: he shows the way that is suitable, since it is the way that is suitable for the attainment of the Dhamma of Nibbāna.

original: iminā sāmīcippaṭipattiṃ anucchavikabhāvadīpanato. Etena paṭhamapadassa papañcaniddeso,
analyzed: iminā sāmīci paṭipattim anucchavika bhāva dīpanataḥ etena paṭhama padassa papañca niddeso
translated: By this he shows that the first phrase is a description of the way’s being direct,🔽and that the other three phrases show that it is in accordance with the rules.

original: itarāni tīṇi padānīti dasseti. Tenāha “yasmā panā”tiādi.
analyzed: itarāni tīṇi padāni iti tena āha yasmā pana atiādi
translated: That is why he said, “But since it is …”

original: Yathānusiṭṭhaṃ paṭipajjanena kiccasiddhito ariyabhāvāvahaṃ savanaṃ sakkaccasavanaṃ
analyzed: yathānusiṭṭham paṭipajjanena kicca siddhitaḥ ariya bhāva āvaham savanam sakkacca savanam
translated: The hearing that brings about the noble state by practising in accordance with what is heard is the hearing that is respectful.

original: nāmāti vuttaṃ “sakkaccaṃ suṇantīti sāvakā”ti, tena ariyā eva nippariyāyato satthu🔽sāvakā nāmāti dasseti. Sīladiṭṭhisāmaññatāyāti ariyena sīlena, ariyāya ca diṭṭhiyā
analyzed: nāma ati vuttam sakkaccam suṇanti iti sāvakā ati tena ariyāḥ eva nippariyāyato satthu  sāvakāḥ nāma ati dasseti sīla diṭṭhi sāmañña tāya ati ariyena sīlena ariyāya ca diṭṭhiyā
translated: “Hearers” is said because they hear with respect. Thus he shows that only Noble Ones are disciples in the true sense of the word.

original: samānabhāvena. Ariyānañhi sīladiṭṭhiyo majjhe bhinnasuvaṇṇaṃ viya ninnānākaraṇaṃ
analyzed: samāna bhāvena ariyānam hi sīla diṭṭhiyaḥ majjhe bhinna suvaṇṇam viya
translated: “By virtue and view” : by virtue and view that are noble. For the virtue and view of Noble Ones are not distinguished in colour as is gold that is broken down and smelted.

original: maggenāgatattā. Tena te yattha katthaci ṭhitāpi saṃhatāva. Tenāha “saṅghātabhāvamāpanno”ti.🔽Māyāsāṭheyyādipāpadhammasamucchedena uju. Tato eva gomuttavaṅkābhāvena avaṅkā. Candalekhāvaṅkābhāvena
analyzed: maggena āgata ttā tena te yattha katthaci ṭhitā api saṃhatā ava tena āha saṅghāta bhāvam āpannā iti  māyā sāṭheyya ādi pāpa dhamma samucchedena uju tatas eva gomutta vaṅka abhāvena avaṅkā candalekhā vaṅka abhāvena
translated: They are the same because they have come by the path. Therefore, wherever they are, they are united. Thus it is said: “They have become a unity.”

original: akuṭilā. Naṅgalakoṭivaṅkābhāvena ajimhā. Avaṅkādibhāvena vā uju. Parisuddhaṭṭhena
analyzed: akuṭilā naṅgala koṭi vaṅka abhāvena ajimhā avaṅka ādi bhāvena vā uju parisuddha ṭṭhena
translated: They are straight by the cutting off of such evil things as deceit and fraud. They are not crooked like a cow’s horn. They are not twisted like the line of a plough. They are not bent like the handle of a hoe. Or they are straight by being uncrooked, etc.

original: ariyā. Apaṇṇakabhāvena ñāyati kamati nibbānaṃ, taṃ vā ñāyati paṭivijjhīyati etenāti
analyzed: ariyā apaṇṇaka bhāvena ñāyati kamati nibbānam tam vā ñāyati paṭivijjhīyati etena ati
translated: They are noble by being pure. They are a principle because they are known, they act, and nibbana is known, or they penetrate it.

original: ñāyo. Vaṭṭadukkhaniyyānāya anucchavikattā. Anurūpattā sāmīci opāyikātipi saṅkhaṃ
analyzed: vaṭṭa dukkha niyyānāya anucchavika ttā anurūpa ttā sāmīci saṅkhaṃ
translated: They are a method because they are suitable for the escape from the suffering of the round. They are a way because they are appropriate, because they are a means.

original: samaññaṃ gatā sammāpaṭipatti, tāya samaṅgitāya suppaṭipannā “sammā paṭipajjantī”ti
analyzed: samaññam gatā sammāpaṭipatti tāya samaṅgi tāya suppaṭipannā sammā paṭipajjanti iti
translated: and the right way is the right practice that has become the common property of the ariyans. Because of being endowed with that, they are well-practised, and so it is said: “practising rightly”.

original: katvā. Vattamānattho hi ayaṃ paṭipanna-saddo yathā “sotāpattiphalasacchikiriyāya🔽paṭipanno”ti. Atītaṃ paṭipadanti yathāvuttamaggasammāpaṭipattiṃ vadati. Ubhayena🔽ca sāmaññaniddesena, “suppaṭipannā ca suppaṭipannā ca suppaṭipannā”ti ekasesanayena
analyzed: katvā vattamāna atthaḥ hi ayam paṭipanna saddaḥ yathā sotāpatti phala sacchikiriyāya  paṭipannaḥ ti atītam paṭipadanti yathā vutta magga sammāpaṭipattim vadati ubhayena  ca sāmañña niddesena suppaṭipannā ca suppaṭipannā ca suppaṭipannā ati eka sesa nayena
translated: For this word “practising” has the meaning of “being practised”, just as in the passage: “practising for the realization of the fruit of stream-entry” .

original: vā gahitānaṃ samūho “suppaṭipanno”ti vuttoti dasseti.🔽Evaṃ ādipadatthaniddesabhāvena itarapadānaṃ atthaṃ vatvā idāni catunnampi padānaṃ🔽avomissakaṃ atthaṃ dassetuṃ “apicā”tiādi vuttaṃ. Tattha yathānusiṭṭhanti satthārā
analyzed: vā gahitānam samūhaḥ suppaṭipannaḥ ti vuttaḥ ti dasseti  evam ādi pada attha niddesa bhāvena itara padānam attham vatvā idāni catunnam pi padānam  avomissakam attham dassetum api ca atiādi vuttam tattha yathā anusiṭṭhanti satthārā
translated: The “right practice in the past” is the right practice of the path as already described. And by both these expressions “right practice” he shows that the “well-practised” is the collection of those who are “well-practised” in the sense of the remainder of the class.

original: yathā anusiṭṭhaṃ, tathā anusāsanīanurūpanti attho. Apaṇṇakapaṭipadanti avirajjhanakapaṭipadaṃ,
analyzed: yathā anusiṭṭham tathā anusāsanī anurūpanti attho apaṇṇaka paṭipadanti a virajjhanaka paṭipadam
translated: Having thus stated the meaning of the other terms by way of the meaning of the first term, he now says “Moreover” in order to point out the meaning of all four terms without omission. Herein, “in accordance with the Teacher’s Dispensation” means in accordance with the instruction of the Teacher; the meaning is, in accordance with the teaching. “The irreversible practice” is the practice that does not swerve away .

original: anavajjapaṭipattinti attho. Ettha ca svākkhāte dhammavinaye apaṇṇakapaṭipadaṃ paṭipannattāti🔽evaṃ sambandhitabbaṃ. Purimapadena sambandhe dutiyapadaṃ na vattabbaṃ siyā, nanu
analyzed: anavajja paṭipattinti attho ettha ca su ākkhāte dhamma vinaye apaṇṇaka paṭipadam paṭipanna ttā ti  evam sambandhitabbam purima padena sambandhe dutiya padam na vattabbam siyā nanu
translated: The meaning is: he has the blameless practice. And here the expression “he has the blameless practice” should be construed with the expression “in the well-proclaimed Dhamma and Discipline” as follows:🔽“He has the blameless practice in the well-proclaimed Dhamma and Discipline.”🔽But if the second expression is construed with the first, then the first should not be construed with the second,🔽and if the first is construed with the second, then the second should not be construed with the first.

original: ca dutiyapadena sambandhepi paṭhamaṃ padaṃ na vattabbaṃ siyāti? Na tassa paṭhamaṃ🔽apekkhitattā. Sā pana sāvakānaṃ apaṇṇakapaṭipadā yathānusiṭṭhaṃ paṭipadāti dassanatthaṃ
analyzed: ca dutiya padena sambandhe pi paṭhamam padam na vattabbam siyā iti na tassa paṭhamam  apekkhita ttā sā pana sāvakānam apaṇṇaka paṭipadā yathānusiṭṭham paṭipadā ti dassana attham
translated: But the first is construed with the second because the second depends on the first.🔽And the disciples’ blameless practice is shown by the expression “he has the practice” as the practice of those who practice in accordance with the Dhamma.

original: “yathānusiṭṭhaṃ paṭipannattā”ti vattabbaṃ. Ubhayassāpi vā suppaṭipannabhāvasādhanattā
analyzed: yathānusiṭṭham paṭipanna ttā iti vattabbam ubhayassa api vā suppaṭipanna bhāva sādhana ttā
translated: Therefore the expression “he has the practice” should be construed with the expression “in accordance with the Dhamma” as follows:🔽“He has the practice in accordance with the Dhamma.”🔽Or else both expressions are given because they both prove that he is well practiced.

original: ubhayaṃ vuttaṃ. Tathā hi pi-saddena ubhayaṃ samuccinoti.
analyzed: ubhayam vuttam tathā hi pisaddena ubhayam samuccinoti
translated: For by the word “thus” both are referred to.

original: Kilesajimhavasena antadvayagāhoti sabbaso taṃ pahāya sammāpaṭipadā kāyādivaṅkappahāyinī ujuppaṭipatti hotīti āha “majjhimāya paṭipadāya…pe… ujuppaṭipanno”ti.
analyzed: kilesa jimha vasena anta dvaya gāho ti sabbaso tam pahāya sammāpaṭipadā kāya ādi vaṅka ppahāyinī uju paṭipatti hoti iti āha majjhimāya uju paṭipannaḥ ti
translated: “He has the middle practice” is said in order to show that the practice of the disciples is the middle practice, which is the right practice that abandons the two extremes, the practice that is straight, which is the practice that abandons the crookedness of the body, etc.

original: Ñāyo nāma yuttappattapaṭipatti, nibbānañca, sabbasaṅkhārasamathatāya ādittaṃ celaṃ,
analyzed: ñāyaḥ nāma yutta patta paṭipatti nibbānañca sabba saṅkhāra samatha tāya ādittam celam
translated: “The way” is the practice that has reached the right pitch, and also Nibbāna. The burning of the cloth is by the stilling of all formations.

original: sīsaṃ vā ajjhupekkhitvāpi paṭipajjitabbamevāti āha “ñāyo vuccati nibbāna”nti. Nibbāyanakiriyāmukhena
analyzed: sīsam vā ajjhupekkhitvā api paṭipajjitabbam eva ati āha ñāyaḥ vuccati nibbānam ti nibbāyana kiriyā mukhena
translated: And even though one might look on with equanimity at one’s head or cloth on fire, one must still act to put out the fire. So it is said: “The way is said to be Nibbāna” .

original: cettha nibbānaṃ vuttanti daṭṭhabbaṃ, maggañāṇādīhi vā ñāyati paṭivijjhīyati sacchikarīyati
analyzed: ca ittha nibbānam vuttanti daṭṭhabbam magga ñāṇa ādīhi vā ñāyati paṭivijjhīyati sacchikarīyati
translated: Here Nibbāna should be regarded as stated by the means of the action of extinguishing. Or alternatively, it is discerned, penetrated, realized by means of the knowledge of the path, etc.,

original: cāti ñāyo nibbānanti evamettha attho daṭṭhabbo.
analyzed: ca ati ñāyaḥ nibbānanti evam ettha atthaḥ daṭṭhabbo
translated: and so the meaning here should be regarded as follows: “The way is Nibbāna” .

original: Guṇasambhāvanāya parehi kayiramānaṃ paccupaṭṭhānādisāmīcikammaṃ arahantīti sāmīcikammārahā.
analyzed: guṇa sambhāvanāya parehi paccupaṭṭhāna ādi sāmīcikammam arahanti iti sāmīcikamma arahā
translated: “Worthy of offerings” : they are worthy of the respectful service of others in the way of paying homage, etc., by honouring their special qualities.

original: 156. Yadidanti antogadhaliṅgavacanabhedo nipātoti tassa vacanabhedena atthamāha “yā
analyzed: yat idam ti tassa vacana bhedena attham āha yā
translated: “That is to say” is a particle that introduces a classification. Its meaning is stated by the classification: “These” .

original: imānī”ti. Evanti pakāratthe nipāto, iminā pakārenāti attho. Tena itarāni tīṇi yugaḷāni
analyzed: imāni iti evam ti pakāra atthe nipātaḥ iminā pakārena ati atthaḥ tena itarāni tīṇi yugaḷāni
translated: “Thus” is a particle in the sense of “in this way.” The meaning is: “in this way.” Consequently, the other three pairs are also shown by it.

original: dassitāni hontīti āha “evaṃ cattāri purisayugaḷāni hontī”ti. Etanti etaṃ “purisapuggalā”ti
analyzed: dassitāni honti iti āha evam cattāri purisa yugaḷāni honti iti etam ti etam purisa puggala ati
translated: So it is said: “Thus there are four pairs of persons” . “These” : these “persons” .

original: bahuvacanavasena vuttaṃ padaṃ. Purisā ca te puggalā ca purisapuggalā. Tattha “purisā”ti
analyzed: bahuvacana vasena vuttam padam purisā ca te puggalā ca purisa puggalā tattha purisā ti
translated: The word “persons” is stated in the plural. They are men and they are persons, thus they are “men and persons.” Herein,

original: iminā paṭhamāya pakatiyā gahaṇaṃ, “puggalā”ti pana dutiyāyapi sattasāmaññenāti evaṃ
analyzed: iminā paṭhamāya pakatiyā gahaṇam puggala ati pana satta sāmaññena ati evam
translated: by the word “men” the first class is included, but by the word “persons” the second class is included as well, since “person” is a general term for living beings. This is how the meaning should be regarded here.

original: vā ettha attho daṭṭhabbo. Catunnaṃ paccayānaṃ kīdisānaṃ? Ānetvā hunitabbānanti adhikārato
analyzed: vā ettha atthaḥ daṭṭhabbo catunnam paccayānam kīdisānam ānetvā hunitabbānam ti adhikārataḥ
translated: Of what kind of four requisites? Requisites that should be brought and offered, is the meaning that is clear from the context.🔽Or alternatively, the word “should be offered” is a reflexive verb that should be construed as a passive

original: pākaṭoyamattho. Dātabbanti vā paccattavacanaṃ “catunnaṃ paccayāna”nti padaṃ apekkhitvā
analyzed: pākaṭaḥ ayam atthaḥ dātabban ti vā paccatta vacanam catunnam paccayānam ti padam apekkhitvā
translated: with the word “of the four requisites,” just as the word “should be eaten” is construed as a passive with the word “rice.”

original: sāmivasena pariṇāmetabbaṃ, aññathā yesaṃ kesañci catunnaṃ paccayānaṃ “āhuna”nti samaññā
analyzed: sāmi vasena pariṇāmetabbam aññathā yesam kesañci catunnam paccayānam āhunanti samaññā
translated: Otherwise, the expression “of the four requisites” might be taken as a genitive depending on the word “should be brought.”

original: siyā. Āhunaṃ arahatīti vā āhuneyyo. Sakkādīnampi vā āhavananti sakkādīhipi diyyamānaṃ
analyzed: siyā āhunam arahati iti vai āhuneyyaḥ sakka ādīnam pi vai diyyamānam
translated: Or alternatively, “worthy of offerings” is one who is worthy of being offered to. Or alternatively, it is an offering that is offered by Sakka, etc.,🔽as well as by others.

original: dānaṃ. Yattha hutaṃ mahapphalanti yasmiṃ āvahanīyaggimhi hutaṃ dadhiādi āhuneyyaggigahapataggidakkhiṇeyyaggīsu
analyzed: dānam yattha hutam mahapphalanti yasmin āvahanīya aggimhi hutam dadhi ādi āhuneyyaggi gahapataggi dakkhiṇeyyaggīsu
translated: Where what is offered bears great fruit, in which fire into which the offering is made, whether curds, etc., in the case of the worthy fire, the householder fire, or the fire of merit.

original: hutato uḷāraphalanti tesaṃ brāhmaṇānaṃ laddhi. Hutanti dinnaṃ. Nikāyantareti sabbatthikavādinikāye.
analyzed: hutataḥ uḷāra phalanti tesam brāhmaṇānam laddhi hutanti dinnam nikāya antare ti sabbatthika vādi nikāye
translated: The brahmins’ opinion is that it is ‘ripe’ when it has been given. ‘Given’ means offered. ‘In another collection’ means in the collection of the Sabbatthivādins.

original: Ṭhapetvā 165 teti te piyamanāpe ñātimitte apanetvā, tesaṃ adatvāti adhippāyo. Esa
analyzed: ṭhapetvā te iti te piya manāpe ñāti mitte apanetvā tesam a datvā iti adhippāyaḥ esa
translated: ‘Excepting those’: the meaning is that, setting them aside, he should not give to them, to his dear and beloved relatives and friends.🔽This is the meaning.

original: eso. Ekabuddhantare ca dissatīti ekasmiṃ buddhantare vītivatte dissati. Ca-saddena
analyzed: esaḥ eka buddha antare ca dissati iti ekasmin buddha antare vītivatte dissati ca saddena
translated: ‘And is seen in one Buddha-interval’: when one Buddha-interval has elapsed, it is seen. The word ‘and’

original: kadāci asaṅkhyeyyepi kappe vītivatteti dasseti. Abbokiṇṇanti paṭipakkhehi avomissaṃ,
analyzed: kadāci asaṅkhyeyye pi kappe vītivatteti dasseti abbokiṇṇam ti paṭipakkhehi avomissam
translated: shows that it is also seen when innumerable eons have elapsed. ‘Uninterrupted’: not mixed with opposites.

original: kiriyāvisesakañcetaṃ. Piyamanāpattakaradhammā nāma sīlādayo, te ariyasaṅghe suppatiṭṭhitā.🔽Ayaṃ hettha adhippāyo – ñātimittā vippayuttā na cirasseva samāgacchanti, anavaṭṭhitā
analyzed: kiriyā visesakam ca itam piya manāpatta kara dhammāḥ nāma sīla ādayo te ariya saṅghe suppatiṭṭhitā  ayam ha ittha adhippāyaḥ ñāti mittāḥ vippayuttāḥ na cirassa iva samāgacchanti anavaṭṭhitā
translated: This is a special use of the word. ‘The things that cause dear and beloved states’ are such things as virtue, etc. They are ‘well established’ in the noble Sangha.

original: ca tesu piyamanāpatā, na evamariyasaṅgho. Tasmā saṅghova pāhuneyyoti. Pubbakāranti
analyzed: ca tesu piya manāpatā na evam ariya saṅgho tasmā saṅghaḥ uva pāhuneyyaḥ ti
translated: The meaning intended here is this: dear and beloved relatives and friends, though separated, soon come together again, and dear and beloved states are not firmly established in them. But the noble Sangha is not like that. Therefore only the Sangha is worthy of offerings. ‘The first’:

original: aggakiriyaṃ. Sabbappakārenāti ādaragāravabahumānādinā, deyyadhammassa sakkaccakaraṇādinā
analyzed: agga kiriyam sabba ppakārena ati ādara gārava bahu māna ādinā deyya dhammassa sakkacca karaṇa ādinā
translated: the foremost. ‘In every way’: with respect, reverence, and esteem, and by making offerings carefully, etc.

original: ca sabbena pakārena. Svāyaṃ pāhavanīya-saddo “pāhuneyyo”ti vuccati pariyāyabhāvena.🔽Dakkhanti etāya sattā yathādhippetāhi sampattīhi vaḍḍhantīti dakkhiṇā. Tathābhāvakaraṇena
analyzed: ca sabbena pakārena svāyam pāhavanīya saddo pāhuneyyaḥ ti vuccati pariyāya bhāvena  dakkhanti etāya sattāḥ yathā adhippetāhi sampattīhi vaḍḍhanti iti dakkhiṇā tathābhāva karaṇena
translated: They give with this: beings give with gifts, giving up what is hard to give up, giving to those worthy of gifts, giving in the right way, giving without defilements.🔽They give with this: beings give with gifts, giving up what is hard to give up, giving to those worthy of gifts, giving in the right way, giving without defilements.🔽They give with this: beings give with gifts, giving up what is hard to give up, giving to those worthy of gifts, giving in the right way, giving without defilements.🔽They give with this: beings give with gifts, giving up what is hard to give up, giving to those worthy of gifts, giving in the right way, giving without defilements.🔽They give with this: beings give with gifts, giving up what is hard to give up, giving to those worthy of gifts, giving in the right way, giving without defilements.🔽They give with this: beings give with gifts, giving up what is hard to give up, giving to those worthy of gifts, giving in the right way, giving without defilements.🔽They give with this: beings give with gifts, giving up what is hard to give up, giving to those worthy of gifts, giving in the right way, giving without defilements.🔽They give with this: beings give with gifts, giving up what is hard to give up, giving to those worthy of gifts, giving in the right way, giving without defilements.

original: dakkhiṇaṃ arahati. Yathā uḷārātivipuludrayalābhena visodhitaṃ nāma hoti, evaṃ dakkhiṇā🔽vipulaphalatāyāti vuttaṃ “mahapphalakaraṇatāya visodhetī”ti.
analyzed: dakkhiṇam arahati yathā uḷāra ati vipula draya lābhena visodhitam nāma hoti evam dakkhiṇā  vipula phala tāya iti vuttam mahat phala karaṇa tāya visodheti iti
translated: They give with this: beings give with gifts, giving up what is hard to give up, giving to those worthy of gifts, giving in the right way, giving without defilements.

original: Puññatthikehi añjali karaṇīyā etthāti añjalikaraṇīyo.🔽Yadipi pāḷiyaṃ “anuttara”nti vuttaṃ. Natthi ito uttaraṃ visiṭṭhanti hi anuttaraṃ.
analyzed: puññatthikehi añjali karaṇīyā ettha ati añjali karaṇīyaḥ  yadi api pāḷiyam anuttaranti vuttam na atthi itas uttaram visiṭṭhanti hi anuttaram
translated: They give with this: beings give with gifts, giving up what is hard to give up, giving to those worthy of gifts, giving in the right way, giving without defilements.🔽They give with this: beings give with gifts, giving up what is hard to give up, giving to those worthy of gifts, giving in the right way, giving without defilements.

original: Samampissa pana natthīti dassento “asadisa”nti āha. Khittaṃ vuttaṃ bījaṃ mahapphalabhāvakaraṇena
analyzed: samam pissa pana natthi iti dassento asadisan ti āha khittam vuttam bījam mahat phala bhāva karaṇena
translated: They give with this: beings give with gifts, giving up what is hard to give up, giving to those worthy of gifts, giving in the right way, giving without defilements.

original: tāyati rakkhati, khipanti vapanti ettha bījānīti vā khettaṃ, kedārādi, khettaṃ viya
analyzed: tāyati rakkhati khipanti vapanti ettha bījāni iti vā khettam kedāra ādi khettam viya
translated: They give with this: beings give with gifts, giving up what is hard to give up, giving to those worthy of gifts, giving

original: khettaṃ, puññānaṃ khettaṃ puññakkhettaṃ. Sesaṃ buddhānussatiyaṃ vuttanayānusārena veditabbaṃ.
analyzed: khettam puññānam khettam puñña kkhettam sesam buddha anussatiyam vutta naya anusārena veditabbam
translated: and the field of merit is the field for merit. The rest can be understood by the method stated in the recollection of the Buddha.

original: 4. Sīlānussatikathāvaṇṇanā
analyzed: sīla anussati kathā vaṇṇanā
translated: The recollection of virtue

original: 158. Aho vata sīlāni akhaṇḍāni, aho vata acchiddānīti evaṃ sabbattha yojetabbaṃ.
analyzed: aho vata sīlāni akhaṇḍāni aho vata acchiddāni iti evam sabbattha yojetabbam
translated: “How good is my virtue unrent, unbroken, unblemished, unblotched, freeing, praised by the wise, not adhered to, and conducing to concentration!”🔽“How good” is an expression of appreciation. Hence it is said: “By virtue of the qualities of being unrent, etc.”

original: Aho vatāti ca sambhāvane nipāto. Tenāha “akhaṇḍatādiguṇavasenā”ti. Akhaṇḍabhāvādisampattivasenāti
analyzed: aho vata iti ca sambhāvane tena āha akhaṇḍa tā ādi guṇa vasena ati akhaṇḍa bhāva ādi sampatti vasena ati
translated: The meaning is: by virtue of the possession of the qualities of being unrent, etc.

original: attho. Parassa sīlāni anussariyamānāni piyamanāpabhāvāvahanena kevalaṃ mettāya padaṭṭhānaṃ
analyzed: attho parassa sīlāni anussariyamānāni piya manāpa bhāva āvahanena kevalam mettāya padaṭṭhānam
translated: When one recollects the virtue of others, it becomes a condition for the arising of loving-kindness only by arousing appreciative esteem;

original: honti, na visuṃ kammaṭṭhānanti āha “attano sīlāni anussaritabbānī”ti. Cāgādīsupi eseva nayo.🔽Yesanti sīlādīnaṃ. Paṭipāṭiyā samādāne samādānakkamena, ekajjhaṃ samādāne uddesakkamena
analyzed: honti na visum kammaṭṭhānan ti āha attanaḥ sīlāni anussaritabbāni iti cāga ādīsu pi esa eva nayaḥ  sīla ādīnam paṭipāṭiyā samādāne samādāna kkamena ekajjham samādāne uddesa kkamena
translated: it is not a separate meditation subject. Hence it is said: “One’s own virtue should be recollected.” The same method applies in the case of generosity, etc.,🔽“The beginning and end of virtue should be understood”: the order of the virtues should be understood as the order of their undertaking, and the beginning and end of virtue should be understood as the beginning and end of the undertaking.

original: sīlānaṃ ādiantaṃ veditabbaṃ. Pariyante chinnasāṭako viyāti vatthante, dasante vā
analyzed: sīlānam ādi antam veditabbam pariyante chinna sāṭakaḥ viyāti vatthante dasante vā
translated: “As a cloth with fringes”: the fringes are the ends of the cloth.

original: chinnavatthaṃ viya, visadisūdāharaṇaṃ cetaṃ. Evaṃ sesānipi udāharaṇāni. Vinivedhavasena
analyzed: chinna vattham viya visa disu udāharaṇam evam sesāni api udāharaṇāni vinivedha vasena
translated: like a torn cloth. This is an example of the dissimilar. So too with the other examples.

original: chinnasāṭako vinividdhasāṭako. Visabhāgavaṇṇena gāvī viyāti sambandho. Sabalarahitāni
analyzed: chinna sāṭakaḥ vinividdha sāṭakaḥ visa bhāga vaṇṇena gāvī sambandho sa bala rahitāni
translated: The cloth that is torn by being cut through is the cloth that is cut through. The cow that is of a different colour is the cow that is dissimilar in colour.🔽The unmixed are those that are free from the unwholesome.

original: vā asabalāni. Tathā akammāsāni. Sattavidhamethunasaṃyogo heṭṭhā sīlakathāyaṃ vutto
analyzed: vā a sabalāni tathā a kammāsāni sattavidha methuna saṃyogaḥ heṭṭhā sīla kathā ayam vutto
translated: The seven kinds of sexual intercourse are given in the explanation of virtue below.

original: eva. Kodhūpanāhādīhīti ādi-saddena makkhapaḷāsaissāmacchariyamāyāsāṭheyyamānātimānādayo
analyzed: eva kodhūpanāha ādīhi iti ādi saddena
translated: The words “and so on” in “anger, enmity, and so on” include contempt, domineering, envy, selfishness, deceit, fraud, obduracy, pride, conceit, and so on.

original: gahitā. Tāniyeva akhaṇḍādiguṇāni sīlāni. Sīlassa taṇhādāsabyato mocanaṃ vivaṭṭūpanissayabhāvāpādanaṃ.
analyzed: akhaṇḍa ādi guṇāni sīlāni sīlassa taṇhā dāsabyataḥ mocanam vivaṭṭu upanissaya bhāva āpādanam
translated: Those very virtues that are unbroken, etc., are the virtues. The deliverance of virtue from the slavery of craving is the bringing about of its being a condition for the turning away from the slavery of craving.

original: Tato eva taṃsamaṅgīpuggalo serī sayaṃvasī bhujisso nāma hoti. Tenāha “bhujissabhāvakaraṇena
analyzed: tatas eva taṃ samaṅgī puggalo serī sayaṃvasī bhujissaḥ nāma hoti tena āha bhujissa bhāva karaṇena
translated: For that reason the person who possesses it is called a “master” , one who is “self-dependent” , and one who “has hands and feet” . That is why it is said that it is “masterly” because it makes one a master.

original: bhujissānī”ti. “Imināhaṃ sīlena devo vā bhaveyyaṃ devaññataro vā, tattha nicco dhuvo
analyzed: bhujissāni iti iminā aham sīlena devaḥ vā bhaveyyam devaññataraḥ vā tattha niccaḥ dhuvaḥ
translated: “By means of this virtue may I become a god or one of the ranks of gods, permanent, stable, eternal, not subject to death and destruction” .

original: sassato”ti, “sīlena suddhī”ti ca evamādinā taṇhādiṭṭhīhi aparāmaṭṭhattā ayaṃ te sīlesu
analyzed: sassatoti sīlena suddhi iti ca evamādinā taṇhā diṭṭhīhi a parāmaṭṭha ttā ayam te sīlesu
translated: “The world is finite” or “The world is infinite” or “The soul is the same as the body” or “The soul is one thing and the body another” or “After death a Tathāgata exists” or “After death a Tathāgata does not exist” or “After death a Tathāgata both exists and does not exist” or “After death a Tathāgata neither exists nor does not exist,” and so on.

original: dosoti catūsu vipattīsu yāya kāyaci vipattiyā dassanena parāmaṭṭhuṃ anuddhaṃsetuṃ.
analyzed: catūsu vipattīsu yāya kāyaci vipattiyā dassanena parāmaṭṭhum an uddhaṃsetum
translated: “Fault” is any one of the four kinds of failure to see that is to be found in the four kinds of failure to see.

original: Samādhisaṃvattanappayojanāni samādhisaṃvattanikāni.
analyzed: samādhi saṃvattana payojanāni samādhi saṃvattanikāni
translated: “Conducive to concentration” : they are conducive to the kinds of concentration described under the heading of “aim” .

original: 159. Sikkhāya sagāravoti sīladhanaṃ nissāya paṭiladdhasamādānattā sātisayaṃ sikkhāya
analyzed: sikkhāya sa gāravaḥ ti sīla dhanam nissāya paṭiladdha samādāna ttā sa atisayam sikkhāya
translated: “Respect for training” : he has respect for and reverence towards training because he has undertaken it by means of the wealth of virtue.

original: sagāravo sappatisso hoti. Sabhāgavuttīti sampannasīlehi sabhāgavuttiko, tāya eva
analyzed: sa gāravaḥ sa patissaḥ hoti sabhāga vuttī iti sampanna sīlehi sabhāga vuttikaḥ tāya eva
translated: “Conduct in conformity” : he has conduct in conformity with those of good virtue.

original: vā sikkhāya sabhāgavutti. Yo hi sikkhāgāravarahito, so tāya visabhāgavutti nāma hoti🔽vilomanato. Yathā parehi saddhiṃ attano chiddaṃ na hoti, evaṃ dhammāmisehi paṭisantharaṇaṃ
analyzed: vā sikkhāya sabhāgavutti yaḥ hi sikkhāgārava rahitaḥ so tāya visabhāgavutti nāma hoti  vilomanataḥ yathā parehi saddhim attanaḥ chiddam na hoti evam dhamma āmisehi paṭisantharaṇam
translated: Or alternatively, he has conduct in conformity with that training. For one who is devoid of respect for training is said to have conduct not in conformity with that,🔽because he is in opposition to it.🔽“Hospitality” : he is hospitable to those who come to him with the Dhamma as their only wealth, so that he does not expose his own shortcomings to them.

original: paṭisanthāro. Sikkhāya sagāravattā eva tattha appamatto hoti. Attānuvādabhayaṃ parānuvādabhayaṃ
analyzed: paṭisanthāraḥ sikkhāya sagāravattā eva tattha appamattaḥ hoti attā anuvāda bhayam para anuvāda bhayam
translated: “He is not negligent” : he is not negligent in that respect because he has respect for training. He is afraid of blame by way of self and by way of others.

original: daṇḍabhayaṃ duggatibhayanti evamādīni bhayāni imassa dūrasamussāritānīti āha “attānuvādādibhayavirahito”ti.
analyzed: daṇḍa bhayam duggati bhayanti evamādīni bhayāni imassa dūra samussāritāni iti āha atta anuvāda ādi bhaya virahitaḥ ti
translated: “Fears of punishment and fears of states of deprivation” are the kinds of fears that he has “set far away.”

original: Sesaṃ suviññeyyameva.
analyzed: sesam su viññeyyam eva
translated: The rest is easy to understand.

original: 5. Cāgānussatikathāvaṇṇanā🔽160. Pakatiyāti sabhāvena. Cāgādhimuttenāti deyyadhammapariccāge yuttappayuttena
analyzed: cāga anussati kathā vaṇṇanā  pakatiyā ati sabhāvena cāga adhimuttena ati deyya dhamma pariccāge yutta ppayuttena
translated: The recollection of generosity🔽“By nature”: naturally. “Devoted to generosity”: devoted to the relinquishing of things to be given, devoted to the giving away of things to be given, devoted to the relinquishing of things to be given.

original: tanninnena tappoṇena. Niccaṃ sadā pavattā dānasaṃvibhāgā yassa so niccapavattadānasaṃvibhāgo,
analyzed: tad ninnena tad poṇena niccam sadā pavattāḥ dāna saṃvibhāgāḥ yassa saḥ nicca pavatta dāna saṃvibhāgo
translated: “Always”: constantly. “One who is always a giver and a sharer”: one who always gives and shares.

original: tena. Idhāpi “pakatiyā”ti ānetvā sambandhitabbaṃ. Yaṃ parassa paṭiyattaṃ diyyati,
analyzed: tena idha api pakatiyā ati ānetvā sambandhitabbam yam parassa paṭiyattam diyyati
translated: Here too the word “naturally” should be brought in and construed with “one who is always a giver and a sharer.”🔽“Giving” is what is given to another.

original: taṃ dānaṃ. Yaṃ attanā paribhuñjitabbato saṃvibhajati, so saṃvibhāgo. Ito dāni pabhutīti
analyzed: tam dānam yam attanā paribhuñjitabbataḥ saṃvibhajati saḥ saṃvibhāgaḥ itas dāni pabhuti iti
translated: “Sharing” is what is shared for the purpose of one’s own enjoyment.🔽“From now on”: from this time onward.🔽“From today onward”: from this day onward.

original: ito paṭṭhāya dāni ajjatagge ajjadivasaṃ ādiṃ katvā. Adatvā na bhuñjissāmīti dānasamādānaṃ
analyzed: itas paṭṭhāya dāni ajja tagge ajja divasam ādim katvā a datvā na bhuñjissāmi iti dāna samādānam
translated: “Having made the resolution to give”: having made the resolution, “I will not eat without first giving.”🔽“On that day”: on the day of the beginning of the development.

original: katvā. Taṃdivasanti tasmiṃ bhāvanārambhadivase. Tattha nimittaṃ gaṇhitvāti tasmiṃ
analyzed: tasmin bhāvanā ārambha divase nimittam gaṇhitvā ati tasmin
translated: “Having apprehended the sign there”:

original: dāne pariccāgacetanāya pavattiākārassa sallakkhaṇavasena nimittaṃ gahetvā. Vigatamalamaccheratādiguṇavasenāti
analyzed: dāne pariccāga cetanāya pavatti ākārassa sat lakkhaṇa vasena nimittam gahetvā vigata mala maccheratā ādi guṇa vasena ati
translated: by discerning the mode of operation of the volition of giving up in giving. By the qualities of being free from stain and from avarice, etc.,

original: vigatāni malamaccherāni etasmāti vigatamalamacchero, cāgo, tassa bhāvo vigatamalamaccheratā.
analyzed: vigatāni mala maccherāni vigata mala maccheraḥ cāgaḥ tassa bhāvaḥ vigata mala macchera tā
translated: means that since stain and avarice are absent in it, it is free from stain and from avarice.🔽The state of being free from stain and from avarice is the quality of generosity.🔽By the qualities of being free from stain and from avarice, etc.,

original: Tadādīnaṃ guṇānaṃ, sampattīnaṃ, ānisaṃsānaṃ vā vasena.
analyzed: tad ādīnam guṇānam sampattīnam ānisaṃsānam vā vasena
translated: by the attainments, or by the benefits, of those qualities.🔽The good people, the noble bodhisattvas, follow the Dhamma,

original: Sataṃ dhammaṃ anukkamanti sādhūnaṃ bodhisattānaṃ dhammaṃ paveṇiṃ anu anu kamanto
analyzed: satam dhammam anukkamanti sādhūnam bodhisattānam dhammam paveṇim anu anu kamantaḥ
translated: following after the Dhamma as a stream.

original: okkamanto, avokkamanto vā. Ye ime dāyakassa lābhā āyuvaṇṇasukhabalapaṭibhānādayo,
analyzed: okkamantaḥ avokkamantaḥ vā ye ime dāyakassa lābhāḥ āyu vaṇṇa sukha bala paṭibhāna ādayo
translated: The gains of the giver, such as longevity, beauty, happiness, strength, eloquence,🔽and the state of being dear, etc., which are praised and extolled by the Blessed One,

original: piyabhāvādayo ca bhagavatā saṃvaṇṇitā pakittitā. Manussattaṃ vāti vā-saddo avuttavikappattho,
analyzed: piya bhāva ādayaḥ ca bhagavatā saṃvaṇṇitā pakittitā manussa ttam vā ti vā saddaḥ a vutta vikappa atthaḥ
translated: and also human birth, etc. The word “and” has the meaning of “also.”

original: tena indriyapāṭavabhāvakammassakatāñāṇādīnaṃ saṅgaho daṭṭhabbo.
analyzed: tena indriya pāṭava bhāva kammassaka tā ñāṇa ādīnam saṅgahaḥ daṭṭhabbo
translated: By it the inclusion of the keenness of the faculties, the state of being the master of one’s actions, knowledge, etc., should be understood.

original: Maccheramalenāti maccherasaṅkhātena malena. Atha vā maccherañca malañca maccheramalaṃ,
analyzed: macchera malena ati macchera saṅkhātena malena atha vā maccheram ca malam ca macchera malam
translated: By the stain of avarice, etc., means by the stain called avarice. Or else, avarice and stain are avarice-stain.

original: tena maccherena ceva lobhādimalena cāti attho. Pajāyanavasenāti yathāsakaṃ kammanibbattanavasena.
analyzed: tena maccherena ca iva lobha ādi malena ca ati attho pajāyana vasena āti yathāsakam kamma nibbattana vasena
translated: by the process of rebirth, according to the kind of kamma that produces it.🔽Of dark states: of bad states that are wholly dark with greed, etc.

original: Kaṇhadhammānanti lobhādiekantakāḷakānaṃ pāpadhammānaṃ. Vigatattāti pahīnattā. Vigatamalamaccherena
analyzed: kaṇha dhammānam ti lobha ādi ekanta kāḷakānam pāpa dhammānam vigata ttā ati pahīna ttā vigata mala maccherena
translated: He has no stain of stinginess: because he has abandoned it.🔽The word “having” is used in the sense of “being” .

original: cetasāti itthambhūtalakkhaṇe karaṇavacanaṃ. Sotāpannassa satoti gehaṃ āvasantassa🔽sotāpannassa samānassa. Nissayavihāranti nissāya viharitabbavihāraṃ, devasikaṃ vaḷañjanakakammaṭṭhānanti
analyzed: cetasā iti ittham bhūta lakkhaṇe karaṇa vacanam sotāpannassa sato ti geham āvasantassa  sotāpannassa samānassa nissaya vihāranti nissāya viharitabba vihāram devasikam vaḷañjanaka kammaṭṭhānam ti
translated: Of one who has entered upon the way: of one who has entered upon the household life.🔽Of one who has entered upon the way to stream-entry.🔽A dwelling place to live in: a dwelling place to live in by depending on it. The meaning is, a meditation subject for daily practice.

original: attho. Abhibhavitvāti agāraṃ āvasantānaṃ aññesaṃ uppajjanakarāgādiupakkilese abhibhuyya.
analyzed: atthaḥ abhibhavitvā ti agāram āvasantānam aññesam uppajjanaka rāga ādi upakkilese abhibhuyya
translated: Having overcome: having overcome the defilements of lust, etc., that arise in others who live in a house.

original: Yo kiñci dentopi sāpekkhova deti, so muttacāgo na hoti, ayaṃ pana na evanti “muttacāgo”ti
analyzed: yaḥ kiñci dentaḥ api sa apekkhaḥ uva deti so mutta cāgaḥ na hoti ayam pana na mutta cāgaḥ ti
translated: One who gives anything at all is not a free giver if he gives with expectation of return, but this one is not like that, thus he is called “a free giver.”🔽A liberal giver: the meaning is, one who gives without expectation of return.

original: vuttaṃ. Vissaṭṭhacāgoti nirapekkhapariccāgoti attho. Yathā pāṇātipātabahulo puggalo
analyzed: vuttam vissaṭṭha cāgaḥ ti nirapekkha pariccāgaḥ ti atthaḥ yathā pāṇātipāta bahulaḥ puggalo
translated: As a person who kills living beings

original: “lohitapāṇī”ti vuccati, evaṃ dānabahulo puggalo “payatapāṇī”ti vuttoti dassento “dātuṃ🔽sadā dhotahatthoyevā”ti āha. Tattha sadāti niccaṃ, abhiṇhanti attho. Pariccāgoti
analyzed: lohita pāṇī iti vuccati evam dāna bahulaḥ puggalaḥ payata pāṇī iti vuttaḥ ti dassentaḥ dātum  sadā āti āha tattha sadā iti niccam abhiṇhanti
translated: “He is called ‘one with washed hands’ who is always ready to give.”🔽Herein, always means constantly, repeatedly is the meaning.🔽

original: deyyadhammapariccāgoti adhikārato viññāyati. Yaṃ yaṃ deyyadhammaṃ pare yācanakā.
analyzed: deyya dhamma pariccāgaḥ ti adhikārataḥ viññāyati yam yam deyya dhammam pare yācanakā
translated: “He is called ‘one with bloody hands’ . So too, the person who is rich in generosity is called ‘one with washed hands’ . Showing this, the Exalted One said: “Always with washed hands, ready to give. ” Herein, always means constantly, repeatedly is the meaning. Ready to give means ready to give up what is to be given. It is understood by implication that it is ready to give up what is to be given. Whatever is to be given, others, the supplicants,

original: Yācane yogo yācanayogo, parehi yācituṃ yuttoti attho. Yājena yuttoti dānena yutto
analyzed: yācane yogaḥ yācana yogo parehi yācitum yutto iti atthaḥ yājena yutto iti dānena yutto
translated: are ready to ask for it. The compound yācanayogo is to be resolved as yācane yogo . The meaning is: it is fit to be asked for by others. He is ready for yājana , for giving,

original: sadā pariccajanato. Ubhayeti yathāvutte dāne, saṃvibhāge ca rato abhirato.🔽161. Yathā parisuddhasīlassa puggalassa akhaṇḍatādiguṇavasena attano sīlassa anussarantassa
analyzed: sadā pariccajanataḥ ubhayā iti yathā vutte dāne saṃvibhāge ca rataḥ abhirataḥ  yathā parisuddha sīlassa puggalassa akhaṇḍa tā ādi guṇa vasena attanaḥ sīlassa anussarantassa
translated: because he is always ready to give up. He is devoted to both means he is devoted to, intent upon, the two kinds of giving described above.🔽Just as the development of the recollection of virtue succeeds for a person of purified virtue by his recollecting his own virtue endowed with the qualities of being unbroken, etc.,

original: sīlānussatibhāvanā ijjhati, evaṃ parisuddhauḷārapariccāgassa puggalassa anupakkiliṭṭhameva
analyzed: sīla anussati bhāvanā ijjhati evam parisuddha oḷāra pariccāgassa puggalassa anupakkiliṭṭham eva
translated: so too the development of the recollection of generosity succeeds for a person of purified, noble generosity by his recollecting his own generosity which is untainted

original: attano pariccāgaṃ anussarantassa bhāvanā ijjhatīti dassetuṃ “vigatamalamaccheratādiguṇavasenā”tiādi
analyzed: attano pariccāgam anussarantassa bhāvanā ijjhati iti dassetum vigata mala maccheratā ādi guṇa vasena atiādi
translated: by the stain of avarice. In order to show this, the Exalted One said: “By the quality of being free from the stain of avarice, etc.”

original: vuttaṃ, taṃ vuttatthameva.
analyzed: vuttam tam vutta ttham eva
translated: What has been said is just what it means.

original: Bhiyyosoti uparipi. Mattāya pamāṇassa mahatiyā mattāya, vipulena pamāṇenāti attho.
analyzed: bhiyyoso ti mattāya pamāṇassa mahatiyā mattāya vipulena pamāṇena ati attho
translated: ‘To a greater extent’: also above. ‘To the extent of the measure’: to the extent of the measure of greatness, to the extent of the measure of abundance, is the meaning.

original: Cāgādhimuttoti pariccāge adhimutto ninnapoṇapabbhāro. Tato eva alobhajjhāsayo katthacipi
analyzed: cāga adhimuttaḥ ti pariccāge adhimuttaḥ ninna poṇa pabbhāro tatas eva a lobha ajjhāsayo katthacipi
translated: ‘Bent on relinquishing’: bent on giving up, inclined to giving up. And because of that he is ‘of a nature to be without stinginess’ anywhere.🔽He is ‘without misgiving’ because of his lack of concern about recipients.🔽‘Giving’ is giving by means of loving-kindness in the case of recipients.

original: anabhisaṅgacitto. Paṭiggāhakesu mettāyanavasena pariccāgo hotīti mettāya mettābhāvanāya
analyzed: an abhisaṅga cittaḥ paṭiggāhakesu mettāyana vasena pariccāgaḥ hoti iti mettāya mettā bhāvanāya
translated: ‘In conformity with loving-kindness’ is in conformity with the development of loving- kindness.

original: anulomakārī anurūpapaṭipatti. Visāradoti visado attanova guṇena katthacipi amaṅkubhūto
analyzed: anuloma kārī anurūpa paṭipatti visāra do ti visadaḥ attanā uva guṇena katthacipi amaṅku bhūto
translated: ‘Confident’: confident, open, not timid anywhere,

original: abhibhuyya vihārī. Sesaṃ suviññeyyameva.
analyzed: abhibhuyya vihārī sesam su viññeyyam eva
translated: ‘The rest is quite clear.’

original: 6. Devatānussatikathāvaṇṇanā
analyzed: devatā anussati kathā vaṇṇanā
translated: . Discussion of the recollection of deities🔽‘By the attainment of the noble path’: by the attainment of the noble path.

original: 162. Ariyamaggavasenāti ariyamaggassa adhigamavasena. Samudāgatehīti sammadeva taduppattito
analyzed: ariya magga vasena ati ariya maggassa adhigama vasena samudāgatehi iti sammat eva tad uppattitaḥ
translated: ‘That have come to be’: that have come to be rightly, that have arisen rightly,

original: uddhaṃ āgatehi. Yādisā hi ariyānaṃ santāne lokiyāpi saddhādayo, na tādisā kadācipi
analyzed: uddham āgatehi yādisā hi ariyānam santāne saddha ādayaḥ na tādisā
translated: For the faith, etc., in the noble one’s continuity are never such as the faith, etc., of ordinary people are.

original: pothujjanikā saddhādayo. Dibbantīti devā. Cattāro mahārājāno etesanti catumahārājā,
analyzed: pothujjanikā saddhā ādayaḥ dibbanti iti devā cattāraḥ mahā rājānaḥ etesanti catu mahā rājā
translated: ‘Gods’ are those who shine . ‘Four Great Kings’ are those who are great kings among them.

original: te eva cātumahārājikā. Tettiṃsa sahapuññakārino tatthūpapannāti taṃsahacaritaṃ ṭhānaṃ🔽tāvatiṃsaṃ, tannivāsinopi devā taṃsahacaraṇato eva tāvatiṃsā. Dukkhato yātā apayātāti🔽yāmā. Tusāya pītiyā itā upagatāti tusitā. Bhogānaṃ nimmāne rati etesanti nimmānaratino.🔽Paranimmitesu bhogesu vasaṃ vattentīti paranimmitavasavattino. Brahmānaṃ kāyo samūho🔽brahmakāyo, tappariyāpannatāya tattha bhavāti brahmakāyikā. Tatuttarīti tato brahmakāyikehi🔽uttari, upari parittābhādike sandhāya vadati. Devatā sakkhiṭṭhāne ṭhapetvāti “yathārūpāya🔽maggenāgatāya saddhāya samannāgatā, sīlena sutena cāgena paññāya samannāgatā ito
analyzed: te eva cātumahārājikā tettiṃsa saha puñña kārino tattha upapannā ati tad saha caritam ṭhānaṃ  tāvatiṃsam tad nivāsinaḥ api devā tad sahacaraṇataḥ eva tāvatiṃsāḥ dukkhataḥ yātāḥ apayātā ati  yāmā tusāya pītiyā itā upagatā ati tusitā bhogānam nimmāne rati nimmāna ratino  para nimmitesu bhogesu vasam vattenti iti para nimmita vasa vattinaḥ brahmānam kāyaḥ samūhaḥ  brahma kāyaḥ tad pariyāpanna tāya tattha bhavāti brahmakāyikā tatuttarī iti tatas brahmakāyikehi  uttari upari paritta ābha ādike sandhāya vadati devatā sakkhiṭṭhāne ṭhapetvā ati yathārūpāya  maggena āgatāya saddhāya samannāgatā sīlena sutena ca āgena paññāya samannāgatā ito
translated: and these are the Four Great Kings. The thirty-three who have made merit together are reborn there, and so the place is their “common resort” .🔽The gods who live there are the Thirty-Three because they have that in common. They have gone from suffering, they have departed from suffering, thus they are Yāma . They have gone to, reached, bliss, thus they are the Bliss Ones . They delight in creating their own enjoyments, thus they are the Delighting in Creating .🔽They exercise control over the enjoyments created by others, thus they are the Controlling of Others’ Creations . The body of Brahmā is a collection , thus it is the Brahmā-body. Because they belong to that, they are of the Brahmā-body . Higher than that : he speaks with reference to the Parittābhā, etc., as higher than the Brahmā-body. The gods are placed in the position of witnesses, thus “As to the kind of person who has faith, virtue, learning, generosity, and understanding that is in conformity with the True Idea and Discipline, and who has arrived at this or that plane of excellence by means of that kind of faith, virtue, learning, generosity, and understanding, the gods are placed in the position of witnesses to him.

original: cutā tattha upapannā tā devatā, mayhampi tathārūpā saddhā sīlaṃ sutaṃ cāgo paññā
analyzed: cutā tattha upapannā tāḥ devatāḥ mayham pi tathārūpā saddhā sīlam sutam ca āgo paññā
translated: and they are the Four Great Kings. The thirty-three who have gone there together with the doers of merit are the Thirty-Three. And the gods who live there are the Thirty-Three because they live together with them. They have gone away from suffering, thus they are the Contented . They have come to the bliss of happiness, thus they are the Contented . They delight in creating their own enjoyments, thus they are the Delighting in Creating . They exercise control over the enjoyments created by others, thus they are the Controlling of Others’ Creations . The body of Brahmā is a collection, thus it is the Brahmā-group. Because they belong to that, they are of the Brahmā-group. Higher than that: he speaks with reference to the Parittābhā, etc., as higher than the Brahmā-group. The gods who are witnesses: “The gods who have come here by the path of such a kind of faith, virtue, learning, generosity, and understanding, and who have reappeared there after passing away from here, are gods who are witnesses for me in regard to faith, virtue, learning, generosity, and understanding.”

original: ca saṃvijjatī”ti devatā sakkhiṭṭhāne ṭhapetvā sakkhiṃ otārentena viya attano saddhādiguṇā anussaritabbā.
analyzed: ca saṃvijjati iti devatā sakkhi ṭṭhāne ṭhapetvā sakkhim otārentena viya attano saddhā ādi guṇā anussaritabbā
translated: and the deities’ virtue of faith, etc., should be recollected.

original: Yadi evaṃ sutte ubhayaguṇānussaraṇaṃ vuttaṃ, taṃ kathanti anuyogaṃ manasi katvā āha🔽“sutte panā”tiādi. Tattha kiñcāpi vuttanti “attano ca, tāsañca devatāna”nti ubhayaṃ
analyzed: yadi evam sutte ubhaya guṇa anussaraṇam vuttam tam kathanti anuyogam manasi katvā āha  sutte pana atiādi tattha kiñca api vuttanti attanaḥ ca tāsam ca devatānam ti ubhayam
translated: If so, since the recollection of both kinds of qualities is stated in the sutta, how is it that the commentary explains the meaning in this way?🔽The question is anticipated and answered in the words “But in the sutta” , etc. Herein, although it is said in the sutta, “of oneself and of the deities” ,

original: samadhuraṃ viya sutte kiñcāpi vuttaṃ. Atha kho taṃ “devatānaṃ saddhañca sīlañcā”tiādivacanaṃ.
analyzed: sa madhuram viya sutte kiñca api vuttam atha kho tam devatānam saddham ca sīlam ca ati ādi vacanam
translated: both are stated as if they were sweet, still the statement “of the deities’ faith and virtue” , etc.,🔽should be placed in the position of a witness.🔽The word “stated” should be brought forward from below and construed with “placed.”

original: Sakkhiṭṭhāne ṭhapetabbanti “vutta”nti parato padaṃ ānetvā sambandhitabbaṃ. Kimatthaṃ
analyzed: sakkhi ṭṭhāne ṭhapetabbanti vuttan ti paratas padam ānetvā sambandhitabbam kimattham
translated: But why is it placed in the position of a witness?

original: pana sakkhiṭṭhāne ṭhapananti āha “devatānaṃ attano saddhādīhi samānaguṇadīpanatthanti
analyzed: pana sakkhi ṭṭhāne ṭhapanam ti āha devatānam attanaḥ saddhā ādīhi samāna guṇa dīpana attham ti
translated: The answer is: “In order to show that the deities’ qualities are the same as one’s own qualities of faith, etc.”🔽This should be understood.

original: veditabba”nti. Kasmā pana sutte yathārutavasena atthaṃ aggahetvā evaṃ attho gayhatīti
analyzed: veditabbam ti kasmā pana sutte yathāruta vasena attham aggahetvā evam atthaḥ gayhati iti
translated: But why is the meaning taken in this way instead of taking it literally in the sutta?

original: āha “aṭṭhakathāyañhī”tiādi.
analyzed: āha aṭṭhakathāyan hi itiādi
translated: The answer is: “For in the commentary” , etc.

original: 163. Tasmāti yasmā aṭṭhakathāyaṃ devatā sakkhiṭṭhāne ṭhapetvā attano guṇānussaraṇaṃ
analyzed: tasmā iti yasmai aṭṭhakathā ayam devatā sakkhi ṭṭhāne ṭhapetvā attanaḥ guṇa anussaraṇam
translated: Therefore, since in the commentary the recollection of the special qualities of the deities is stated after they have been established in the role of witnesses,

original: daḷhaṃ katvā vuttaṃ, sīlacāgānussatīsu viya idhāpi attano guṇānussaraṇaṃ jhānuppattinimittaṃ
analyzed: daḷham katvā vuttam sīla cāga anussatīsu viya idha api attanaḥ guṇa anussaraṇam jhāna uppatti nimittam
translated: and since the recollection of one’s own special qualities is appropriate here as a sign for the attainment of jhāna, as it was in the case of the recollections of virtue and generosity,

original: yuttaṃ, tasmā. Pubbabhāge bhāvanārambhe. Aparabhāgeti yathā bhāventassa upacārajjhānaṃ
analyzed: yuttam tasmā pubbabhāge bhāvanā ārambhe aparabhāge iti yathā bhāventassa upacāra jhānam
translated: then at the beginning, when one starts to develop the meditation subject,🔽and in the later stages, when one is perfecting it, one should recollect one’s own special qualities in this way.

original: ijjhati, tathā bhāvanākāle. Yadi attano eva idha guṇā anussaritabbā, kathamayaṃ devatānussatīti
analyzed: ijjhati tathā bhāvanā kāle yadi attanaḥ eva idha guṇā anussaritabbā katham ayam devatā anussati iti
translated: If one’s own special qualities are to be recollected here, why is it called “recollection of deities”?

original: āha “devatānaṃ guṇasadisasaddhādiguṇānussaraṇavasenā”ti. Tena sadisakappanāya ayaṃ
analyzed: āha devatānam guṇa sadisa saddhā ādi guṇa anussaraṇa vasena ati tena sadisa kappanāya ayam
translated: He said, “By recollecting the special qualities of faith, etc., that are similar to the special qualities of deities.”

original: bhāvanā “devatānussatī”ti vuttā, na devatānaṃ, tāsaṃ guṇānaṃ vā anussaraṇenāti dasseti.
analyzed: bhāvanā devatā anussatī iti vuttā na devatānam tāsam guṇānam vā anussaraṇena ati dasseti
translated: So he shows that this meditation subject is called “recollection of deities” because of the similarity of the qualities, not because of the deities themselves or their special qualities.

original: Pubbabhāge vā pavattaṃ devatāguṇānussaraṇaṃ upādāya “devatānussatī”ti imissā samaññā
analyzed: pubbabhāge vā pavattam devatā guṇa anussaraṇam upādāya devatā anussatī iti imissā samaññā
translated: Or alternatively, the name “recollection of deities” is given to this meditation subject because of the recollection of the special qualities of deities that occurs at the beginning.

original: veditabbā. Tathā hi vakkhati “pubbabhāge devatā ārabbha pavattacittavasenā”ti. Sesaṃ suviññeyyameva.
analyzed: veditabbā tathā hi vakkhati pubba bhāge devatāḥ ārabbha pavatta citta vasena ati sesam su viññeyyam eva
translated: and so he says: “At the beginning, by means of the consciousness that occurs in the form of the reflection.” The rest is easily intelligible.

original: Pakiṇṇakakathāvaṇṇanā
analyzed: pakiṇṇaka kathā vaṇṇanā
translated: The description of the miscellaneous kinds of recollection

original: 164. Etāsanti etāsaṃ buddhānussatiādīnaṃ channaṃ anussatīnaṃ. Vitthāradesanāyanti
analyzed: etāsam ti etāsam buddha anussati ādīnam channam anussatīnam vitthāra desanāyanti
translated: Of these: of these six kinds of recollection beginning with recollection of the Buddha.

original: vitthāravasena pavattadesanāyaṃ, mahānāmasuttaṃ sandhāya vadati. Bhagavātiādīnaṃ
analyzed: vitthāra vasena pavatta desanāyam mahānāma suttam sandhāya vadati
translated: The detailed teaching: in the detailed teaching, he is referring to the Mahānāma Sutta .

original: atthanti bhagavātiādīnaṃ padānaṃ atthaṃ. Atthavedanti vā hetuphalaṃ paṭicca uppannaṃ
analyzed: attham ti bhagavā ati ādīnam padānam attham attha vedam ti vā hetu phalam paṭicca uppannam
translated: The meaning of the Blessed One, etc.: the meaning of the terms Blessed One, etc.

original: tuṭṭhimāha. Dhammavedanti hetuṃ paṭicca uppannaṃ tuṭṭhiṃ. “Ārakattā araha”nti anussarantassa
analyzed: tuṭṭhim āha dhamma vedanti hetum paṭicca uppannam tuṭṭhim ārakattā arahanti anussarantassa
translated: The knowledge of the meaning: he says that the satisfaction arisen in dependence on the cause is knowledge of the meaning. The knowledge of the Dhamma: he says that the satisfaction arisen in dependence on the cause is knowledge of the Dhamma.

original: hi yaṃ taṃ bhagavato kilesehi ārakattaṃ, so hetu. Ñāpako cettha hetu adhippeto, na
analyzed: hi yam tam bhagavataḥ kilesehi ārakattam saḥ hetu ñāpakaḥ ca ittha hetu adhippeto na
translated: For one who recollects the Blessed One’s virtue as “worthy” because of its being “far from the world” , the cause is the Blessed One’s virtue itself, which is far from the world.

original: kārako, sampāpako vā. Yonena ñāyamāno arahattattho, taṃ phalaṃ. Iminā nayena sesapadesupi
analyzed: sampāpakaḥ vā yonena ñāyamānaḥ tam phalam iminā nayena sesa padesu pi
translated: Here the cause is intended as the one who makes known , not as the one who makes or the one who accomplishes. The meaning of arahat is known by the method . That is the fruit. In this way, in the case of the remaining terms, too,

original: hetuphalavibhāgo veditabbo. Dhammānussatiādīsupi “ādimajjhapariyosānakalyāṇattā”tiādinā,
analyzed: hetu phala vibhāgaḥ veditabbaḥ dhamma anussati ādīsu pi ādi majjha pariyosāna kalyāṇa ttā ati ādinā
translated: The distinction of cause and fruit should be understood. In the case of the recollection of the Dhamma, etc., the statement of the cause is made in each instance by the words “because it is good in the beginning, ” etc.,🔽and by the words “But it is the right way” , etc.

original: “yasmā pana sā sammāpaṭipadā”tiādinā ca tattha tattha hetuapadeso katoyevāti. Dhammūpasaṃhitanti
analyzed: yasmā pana sā sammā paṭipadā ati ādinā ca tattha tattha hetu apadeso kataḥ yā iva ati dhamma upasaṃhitanti
translated: “Associated with the Dhamma”:

original: yathāvuttahetuhetuphalasaṅkhātaguṇūpasaṃhitaṃ. Guṇeti attano guṇe.
analyzed: yathā vutta hetu hetu phala saṅkhāta guṇa upasaṃhitam guṇeti attanaḥ guṇe
translated: associated with the qualities called the cause and the fruit of the cause, as stated. “The qualities” : his own qualities.

original: 165. Ariyasāvakānaññeva ijjhantīti ariyasāvakānaṃ ijjhantiyevāti uttarapadāvadhāraṇaṃ
analyzed: ariya sāvakānam na eva ijjhanti iti ariya sāvakānam ijjhantiyā iva ati uttara pada avadhāraṇam
translated: “Only for noble disciples”: the word “only” should be understood as a particle meaning “indeed,”

original: daṭṭhabbaṃ, avadhāraṇañca tesaṃ sukhasiddhidassanatthaṃ. Tenāha “tesaṃ hī”tiādi.
analyzed: daṭṭhabbam avadhāraṇam ca tesam sukha siddhi dassana ttham tena āha tesam hi itiādi
translated: and it is stated in order to show that their success is easy. Hence he said, “For they” , etc.

original: Na puthujjanānaṃ sabbena sabbaṃ ijjhantīti. Tathā hi vakkhati “evaṃ santepī”tiādi.
analyzed: na puthujjanānam sabbena sabbam ijjhanti iti tathā hi vakkhati evam sante pi itiādi
translated: It does not succeed for worldlings in every way. Thus he says, “Even though this is so” , etc.

original: Yadi evaṃ, kasmā mahānāmasuttādīsu bahūsu suttesu ariyasāvakaggahaṇaṃ katanti? Tesaṃ
analyzed: yadi evam kasmā mahānāma sutta ādīsu bahūsu suttesu ariya sāvaka ggahaṇam tesam
translated: If that is so, why is the noble disciple mentioned in many suttas such as the Mahānāma Sutta?

original: bahulavihāratāyāti ācariyā.
analyzed: bahula vihāra tāya ati ācariyā
translated: The teachers say that it is because of their frequent practice.

original: Nikkhantanti niggataṃ nissaṭaṃ. Muttanti vissaṭṭhaṃ. Vuṭṭhitanti apetaṃ. Sabbametaṃ
analyzed: nikkhantanti niggatam nissaṭam muttanti vissaṭṭham vuṭṭhitanti apetam sabbam etam
translated: “Gone forth”: gone out, gone away. “Gone beyond”: gone away from. “Come forth”: come out. All these words

original: vikkhambhanameva sandhāya vadati. Gedhamhāti palibodhato. Idampīti buddhānussativasena
analyzed: vikkhambhanam eva sandhāya vadati palibodhataḥ idam pi iti buddha anussati vasena
translated: He speaks with reference to suppression only. ‘Home’ means by way of hindrance. ‘This too’ is access concentration obtained by means of the recollection of the Buddha.

original: laddhaṃ upacārajjhānamāha. Ārammaṇaṃ karitvāti paccayaṃ katvā, pādakaṃ katvāti attho.
analyzed: laddham upacāra jhānam āha ārammaṇam karitvā iti paccayam katvā pādakam katvā iti attho
translated: ‘Making that the object’: making that the condition, making that the footing, is the meaning.

original: Visujjhantīti paramatthavisuddhiṃ pāpuṇanti.
analyzed: visujjhanti iti paramattha visuddhim pāpuṇanti
translated: ‘Are purified’: they reach the purification of the ultimate goal.🔽‘In the crowded house’: in the crowded home that is crowded with the defilements of craving, etc.

original: Sambādheti taṇhāsaṃkilesādinā sampīḷe saṃkaṭe gharāvāse. Okāsādhigamo lokuttaradhammassa
analyzed: sambādha iti taṇhā saṃkilesa ādinā sampīḷe saṃkaṭe ghara āvāse okāsa adhigamaḥ lokuttara dhammassa
translated: The ‘attainment of opportunity’ is the opportunity to be attained for the realization of the supramundane state.

original: adhigamāya adhigantabbaokāso. Anussatiyo eva anussatiṭṭhānāni. Visuddhidhammāti visujjhanasabhāvā,
analyzed: adhigamāya adhigantabba okāsaḥ anussatiyaḥ eva anussati ṭhānāni visuddhi dhammā ati visujjhana sabhāvā
translated: The recollections themselves are the grounds for the recollections. ‘Purifying states’: having the nature of purification,

original: visujjhituṃ vā bhabbā. Paramatthavisuddhidhammatāyāti paramatthavisuddhiyā nibbānassa
analyzed: visujjhitum vā bhabbā paramattha visuddhi dhamma tāya ati paramattha visuddhiyā nibbānassa
translated: or capable of purification. ‘For the sake of the state of purification of the ultimate goal’: for the sake of the purification of the ultimate goal, Nibbāna,

original: bhabbabhāvena. Upakkamenāti payogena. Pariyodapanāti visodhanā.
analyzed: bhabba bhāvena upakkamena ati payogena pariyodapanā ati visodhanā
translated: by means of the ability . ‘Approaches’: by means of practice. ‘Purifies’: cleanses.

original: 166. Evaṃ santepīti evaṃ mahānāmasuttādīsu anekesu suttesu ariyasāvakasseva vasena
analyzed: evam sante api iti evam mahānāma sutta ādīsu anekesu suttesu ariyasāvakassa iva vasena
translated: ‘Even though this is so’: even though this is so in the many suttas such as the Mahānāma Sutta, which are stated

original: chasu anussatīsu desitāsupi. Yassānubhāvenāti yassa cittappasādassa balena. Pītiṃ
analyzed: chasu anussatīsu desitāsu pi yassa anubhāvena ati yassa citta ppasādassa balena pītim
translated: In the six recollections taught. By the power of which: by the power of which confidence in the Buddha’s mind.

original: paṭilabhitvāti anussavavasena buddhārammaṇaṃ pītiṃ uppādetvā.
analyzed: paṭilabhitvā ti anussava vasena buddha ārammaṇam pītim uppādetvā
translated: Having obtained happiness: having aroused happiness with the Buddha as object by way of recollection.

original: Chaanussatiniddesavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.🔽Iti sattamaparicchedavaṇṇanā.
analyzed: cha anussati niddesa vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā  iti sattama pariccheda vaṇṇanā
translated: The description of the six recollections is ended.🔽The commentary on the seventh chapter is ended.

original: 8. Anussatikammaṭṭhānaniddesavaṇṇanā
analyzed: anussati kammaṭṭhāna niddesa vaṇṇanā
translated: The description of the recollection of deities

original: Maraṇassatikathāvaṇṇanā
analyzed: maraṇa ssati kathā vaṇṇanā
translated: The description of the contemplation of death

original: 167. Itoti devatānussatiyā. Sā hi chasu anussatīsu sabbapacchā niddiṭṭhattā āsannā,
analyzed: itas ti devatā anussatiyā sā hi chasu anussatīsu sabba pacchā niddiṭṭha ttā āsannā
translated: From here: from the recollection of deities. That is near because it is taught last of the six recollections, and it is evident.

original: paccakkhā ca. Anantarāyāti tadanantaraṃ uddiṭṭhattā vuttaṃ. Maraṇassa sati maraṇassatīti
analyzed: paccakkhā ca anantarāya iti tad anantaram uddiṭṭhattā vuttam maraṇassa sati maraṇa assati iti
translated: Without interval: it is said because it is taught next. Mindfulness of death is death-mindfulness.

original: maraṇaṃ tāva dassetuṃ “tattha maraṇa”ntiādi vuttaṃ. Kāmañcettha khandhānaṃ bhedo🔽“jarāmaraṇaṃ dvīhi khandhehi saṅgahita”nti vacanato cutikhandhānaṃ vināso maraṇanti
analyzed: maraṇam tāva dassetum tattha maraṇa ntiādi vuttam kāmam ca ittha khandhānam bhedaḥ  jarā maraṇam dvīhi khandhehi saṅgahitanti vacanataḥ cuti khandhānam
translated: To show death first, “Herein, death” and so on is said. Although here the dissolution of the aggregates

original: vattabbaṃ, visesato pana taṃ jīvitindriyassa vināsabhāvena kammaṭṭhānikānaṃ paccupatiṭṭhatīti
analyzed: vattabbam visesataḥ pana tam jīvitindriyassa vināsa bhāvena kammaṭṭhānikānam paccupatiṭṭhati iti
translated: is death, it should be said that death is the destruction of the aggregates at death because of the words “Aging-and-death is included in two aggregates” . But especially it is established for those who are meditators as the destruction of the life faculty.

original: “jīvitindriyassa upacchedo”ti vuttaṃ. Tenevāha niddese “kaḷevarassa nikkhepo jīvitindriyassupacchedo”ti.
analyzed: jīvitindriyassa upacchedo ti vuttam tena iva āha niddese kaḷevarassa nikkhepaḥ jīvitindriyassa upacchedo ti
translated: “The severance of the life faculty” is said. Hence it is said in the Niddesa: “The casting aside of the corpse, the severance of the life faculty” .

original: Tattha ekabhavapariyāpannassāti ekena bhavena paricchinnassa. Jīvitindriyassa upacchedoti🔽jīvitindriyappabandhassa vicchedo āyukkhayādivasena antaradhānaṃ. Samucchedamaraṇanti
analyzed: tattha eka bhava pariyāpannassa ati ekena bhavena paricchinnassa jīvitindriyassa upacchedaḥ ti  jīvitindriya ppabandhassa vicchedaḥ āyu khaya ādi vasena antaradhānam samuccheda maraṇa nti
translated: Herein, included in a single existence means delimited by a single existence. The severance of the life faculty means🔽the interruption of the continuity of the life faculty, its disappearance by the exhaustion of the life-span, etc. Death as the cutting off of continuity means

original: arahato santānassa sabbaso ucchedabhūtaṃ maraṇaṃ. Saṅkhārānaṃ khaṇabhaṅgasaṅkhātanti
analyzed: arahataḥ santānassa sabbasas uccheda bhūtam maraṇam khaṇabhaṅga saṅkhātanti
translated: death that is the complete cutting off of the continuity of an Arahant. Death as the dissolution of the aggregates, which is called “momentary” means

original: saṅkhatadhammānaṃ udayavayaparicchinnassa pavattikhaṇassa bhaṅgo nirodhoti saṅkhaṃ
analyzed: saṅkhata dhammānam udaya vaya paricchinnassa pavatti khaṇassa bhaṅgo nirodho ti saṅkhaṃ
translated: death that is the dissolution, the cessation, of the aggregates, which are called “momentary” because they are delimited by arising and dissolution. Momentary death means🔽death that occurs in the very moment that is spoken of, which is endowed with the moment .

original: gataṃ. Khaṇikamaraṇanti yathāvuttakhaṇavantaṃ tasmiṃyeva khaṇe labbhamānaṃ maraṇaṃ.🔽Yaṃ khandhappabandhaṃ upādāya rukkhādisamaññā, tasmiṃ anupacchinnepi allatādivigamanaṃ
analyzed: gatam khaṇika maraṇam ti yathā vutta khaṇavantam tasmin yeva khaṇe labbhamānam maraṇam 🔽yam khandha ppabandham upādāya rukkha ādi samaññā tasmin anupacchinne pi alla tā ādi vigamanam
translated: The casting aside of the corpse, the severance of the life faculty, and death as the cutting off of continuity are not momentary.🔽But death as the dissolution of the aggregates, which is called “momentary,” is momentary.🔽The casting aside of the corpse, the severance of the life faculty, and death as the cutting off of continuity are not momentary.🔽But death as the dissolution of the aggregates, which is called “momentary,” is momentary.

original: nissāya matavohāro sammutimaraṇaṃ. Na taṃ idha adhippetanti taṃ samucchedakhaṇikasammutimaraṇaṃ🔽idha maraṇānussatiyaṃ nādhippetaṃ abāhullato, anupaṭṭhahanato, asaṃvegavatthuto cāti adhippāyo.
analyzed: nissāya mata vohāro sammuti maraṇam na tam idha tam samuccheda khaṇika sammuti maraṇam  idha maraṇa anussatiyam na adhippetam a bāhullataḥ an upaṭṭhahanataḥ a saṃvega vatthutaḥ ca ati adhippāyaḥ
translated: This is not intended here.🔽The intention is that the death by cutting off and the death by convention are not intended here in the contemplation of death because they are not frequent, because they are not evident, and because they do not arouse a sense of urgency.

original: Adhippetaṃ satiyā ārammaṇabhāvena. Āyuādīnaṃ khayakāle maraṇaṃ kālamaraṇaṃ. Tesaṃ🔽aparikkhīṇakāle maraṇaṃ akālamaraṇaṃ. “Kālamaraṇaṃ puññakkhayenā”ti idaṃ yathādhikāraṃ
analyzed: adhippetam satiyā ārammaṇa bhāvena āyu ādīnam khaya kāle maraṇam kāla maraṇam tesam  a parikkhīṇa kāle maraṇam akāla maraṇam kāla maraṇam puñña kkhayena ati idam yathādhikāram
translated: What is intended is death at the time of the exhaustion of the life span, etc., as object for mindfulness.🔽Death at the time of the exhaustion of the life span, etc., is timely death.🔽Death at a time when the life span, etc., are not exhausted is untimely death.

original: sampattibhavavasena vuttaṃ, vipattibhavavasena pana “pāpakkhayenā”ti vattabbaṃ.
analyzed: sampatti bhava vasena vuttam vipatti bhava vasena pana pāpa kkhayena ati vattabbam
translated: “Death at the time of the exhaustion of merit is by the merit-side” is said according to the profitable side. But according to the unprofitable side it should be said: “Death at the time of the exhaustion of demerit is by the demerit-side.”

original: Āyusantānajanakapaccayasampattiyāti āyuppabandhassa pavattāpanakānaṃ āhārādipaccayānaṃ
analyzed: āyu santāna janaka paccaya sampattiyā ti āyu ppabandhassa pavatta āpanakānam āhāra ādi paccayānam
translated: “When there is a sufficiency of conditions producing the life-continuum” means when there is a sufficiency of conditions such as nutriment, etc., that cause the life-continuum to occur.

original: sampattiyaṃ. Vipakkavipākattāti attano phalānurūpaṃ dātabbavipākassa dinnattā. Gatikālāhārādisampattiyā
analyzed: sampattiyam vipakka vipāka ttā ati attanaḥ phala anurūpam dātabba vipākassa dinna ttā gati kāla āhāra ādi sampattiyā
translated: “When the kamma that has already reached maturity is exhausted” means when the kamma that has already given its fruit has given it all.

original: abhāvenāti devānaṃ viya gatisampattiyā, paṭhamakappiyānaṃ viya kālasampattiyā, uttarakurukādīnaṃ
analyzed: abhāvena ati devānam viya gati sampattiyā paṭhama kappiyānam viya kāla sampattiyā uttarakuruka ādīnam
translated: ‘Through the absence’ means through the absence of the excellence of destiny like the gods, the excellence of time like the first period, and the excellence of nutriment like Uttarakuru, etc.

original: viya āhārasampattiyā ca abhāvena. Ādi-saddena utusukkasoṇitādiṃ pariggayhati. Ajjatanakālapurisānaṃ
analyzed: āhāra sampattiyā ca abhāvena ādi saddena utu sukka soṇita ādim pariggayhati ajjatana kāla purisānam
translated: The word ‘etc.’ includes season, moon, blood, etc. ‘Like the men of the present time’

original: viyāti viya-saddo aṭṭhāne paṭṭhapito, ajjatanakālapurisānaṃ vassasatamattaparimāṇassa
analyzed: viyā ti viya saddaḥ aṭṭhāne paṭṭhapitaḥ ajjatana kāla purisānam vassa sata matta parimāṇassa
translated: the word ‘like’ is used in the sense of ‘as’, and the meaning is ‘as the life-span of the men of the present time is limited to a hundred years at the most’.

original: viya āyuno khayavasenāti yojanā. Evaṃ hi anāgatepi paramāyuno saṅgaho kato hoti,
analyzed: viyaḥ āyuno khaya vasena ati yojanā evam hi anāgate pi parama āyuno saṅgahaḥ kataḥ
translated: For in this way the inclusion of the maximum life-span in the future is made.

original: atīte pana gatisampattiyā viya kālāhārādisampattiyā bhāvena anekavassasahassa parimāṇopi
analyzed: atīte pana gati sampattiyā viya kāla āhāra ādi sampattiyā bhāvena aneka vassa sahassa
translated: But in the past there was a life-span of many thousands of years, through the excellence of destiny, time, nutriment, etc.,

original: āyu ahosi. Ayañca vibhāgo vattamānassa antarakappassa vasena vuttoti daṭṭhabbaṃ.
analyzed: āyu ahosi ayam ca vibhāgaḥ vattamānassa antara kappassa vasena vuttaḥ ti daṭṭhabbaṃ
translated: just as there was excellence of destiny, etc. This classification should be understood as referring to the present world-interval.

original: Kalāburājādīnanti ādi-saddena nandayakkhanandamāṇavakādīnaṃ saṅgaho daṭṭhabbo. Taṃ
analyzed: kalābu rāja ādīnam ti ādi saddena nanda yakkha nanda māṇavaka ādīnam saṅgahaḥ daṭṭhabbo taṃ
translated: ‘King Kalābu, etc.’ The word ‘etc.’ should be understood to include Nandayakkha, Nandamāṇavaka, etc.

original: sabbampīti yaṃ “kālamaraṇaṃ akālamaraṇaṃ, tatthāpi puññakkhayamaraṇaṃ āyukkhayamaraṇaṃ
analyzed: sabbam pi iti yam kāla maraṇam akāla maraṇam tattha api puñña khaya maraṇam āyu khaya maraṇam
translated: All: whether it is timely death or untimely death, whether it is death from the exhaustion of merit or death from the exhaustion of life,🔽

original: ubhayakkhayamaraṇaṃ upakkamamaraṇa”nti vuttappabhedaṃ maraṇaṃ, taṃ sabbampi.🔽168. Yonisoti upāyena. Manasikāroti maraṇārammaṇo manasikāro. Yena pana upāyena manasikāro
analyzed: ubhaya khaya maraṇam upakkama maraṇam ti vutta ppabhedam maraṇam tat sabbam pi  yoniso ti upāyena manasikāro ti maraṇa ārammaṇaḥ manasikāraḥ yena pana upāyena manasikāro
translated: All: all that is called death, which is classified as timely and untimely death, death through exhaustion of merit, death through exhaustion of life, death through exhaustion of both merit and life, and death through violence.

original: pavattetabbo, taṃ byatirekamukhena dassetuṃ “ayoniso pavattayato”tiādi vuttaṃ. Tattha
analyzed: pavattetabbo tam byatireka mukhena dassetum ayonisaḥ pavattayato tiādi vuttam tattha
translated: Properly: by means of a proper method. Attention: attention to death as object. But in order to show the method by which attention should be given, it is said, “When he gives his attention properly,” and so on. Herein,

original: ayoniso pavattayatoti anupāyena satiṃ, saṃvegaṃ, ñāṇañca anupaṭṭhapetvā maraṇaṃ anussarato.🔽Tadetaṃ sabbampīti sokapāmojjānaṃ uppajjanaṃ, saṃvegassa anuppajjanaṃ, santāsassa🔽uppajjanañca yathākkamaṃ satisaṃvegañāṇaviharato hoti. Yo hi “maraṇaṃ nāmetaṃ jātassa
analyzed: ayonisaḥ pavattayato ti anupāyena satim saṃvegam ñāṇam ca an upaṭṭhapetvā maraṇam anussarato  tat etam sabbam pi iti soka pāmojjānam uppajjanam saṃvegassa an uppajjanam santāsassa  uppajjanam ca yathākkamam sati saṃvega ñāṇa viharataḥ hoti yaḥ hi maraṇam nāma etam jātassa
translated: When he gives his attention properly: when he recalls death without establishing mindfulness, urgency, and knowledge by means of a proper method.

original: ekantika”nti paṇḍitānaṃ vacanaṃ sarati, tattha saṃvegajāto hoti sampajāno ca, tassa
analyzed: ekantikam ti paṇḍitānam vacanam sarati tattha saṃvega jātaḥ hoti sampajāno ca tassa
translated: All this: the arising of sorrow and joy, the non-arising of urgency, and the arising of anxiety, are respectively due to his dwelling in mindfulness, urgency, and knowledge. For he who remembers the words of the wise, “There is no certainty of safety for the life of any living being,” becomes anxious and mindful in this matter.

original: iṭṭhajanamaraṇādinimittaṃ sokādayo anokāsāva. Tasmāti yasmā ayoniso manasikāraṃ pavattayato
analyzed: iṭṭha jana maraṇa ādi nimittam soka ādayaḥ tasmā ati yasmai ayonisaḥ manasikāram pavattayataḥ
translated: Sorrow, etc., have no scope when the cause of the death of a loved person, etc., is not evident.🔽So, since these faults occur when he gives attention in a way that is not in accordance with the truth,

original: ete dosā, tasmā. Tattha tatthāti araññasusānādīsu. Hatamatasatteti corādīhi hate,
analyzed: ete dosā tasmā tattha tattha ati arañña susāna ādīsu hata mata sattā iti cora ādīhi hate
translated: here and there, in the forest, at the foot of a tree, in a deserted temple, in a deserted place, in a heap of chaff, in a charnel ground, in a forest, etc.,🔽when he sees dead bodies of human beings killed by murderers with weapons,

original: sarasena mate ca satte. Diṭṭhapubbā sampatti yesaṃ te diṭṭhapubbasampattī, tesaṃ
analyzed: sa rasena mate ca satte diṭṭha pubbā sampatti yesam te diṭṭha pubba sampattī tesam
translated: or dead bodies of human beings who have died naturally,🔽he should apply himself to them in this way:🔽“The bodies of those who have had good fortune were like this;

original: diṭṭhapubbasampattīnaṃ. Yojetvāti upaṭṭhapetvā. Ekaccassāti tikkhindriyassa ñāṇuttarassa.
analyzed: diṭṭha pubba sampattīnam yojetvā ti upaṭṭhapetvā ekaccassa āti tikkhindriyassa ñāṇa uttarassa
translated: the bodies of those who have had good fortune will be like this;🔽the bodies of those who have good fortune are like this.”🔽As to the appearance of a murderer: as though a murderer were standing near and appearing again and again,

original: 169. Vadhakapaccupaṭṭhānatoti ghātakassa viya pati pati upaṭṭhānato āsannabhāvato.
analyzed: vadhaka paccupaṭṭhānato ti ghātakassa viya pati pati upaṭṭhānataḥ āsanna bhāvato
translated: so too, these things appear again and again to one who gives attention in this way.

original: Sampattivipattitoti ārogyādisampattīnaṃ viya jīvitasampattiyā vipajjanato. Upasaṃharaṇatoti
analyzed: sampatti vipattitaḥ ti ārogya ādi sampattīnam viya jīvita sampattiyāḥ vipajjanataḥ upasaṃharaṇataḥ iti
translated: As to the appearance of the loss of distinction: as though the loss of the distinction of health, etc., were appearing, so too, the loss of the distinction of life appears.🔽As to the appearance of the drawing near: as though the drawing near of one’s own death were being pointed out by others,

original: paresaṃ maraṇaṃ dassetvā attano maraṇassa upanayanato. Kāyabahusādhāraṇatoti sarīrassa
analyzed: paresam maraṇam dassetvā attanaḥ maraṇassa upanayanataḥ kāya bahu sādhāraṇato ti sarīrassa
translated: so too, the drawing near of one’s own death appears.🔽As to the sharing of the body: as though the body were something shared by many,🔽so too, the body appears as something shared by many.🔽As to the weakness of the life faculty: as though the life faculty were weak,

original: bahūnaṃ sādhāraṇabhāvato. Āyudubbalatoti jīvitassa dubbalabhāvato. Animittatoti maraṇassa
analyzed: bahūnam sādhāraṇa bhāvataḥ āyu dubbala to ti jīvitassa dubbala bhāvataḥ animittato ti maraṇassa
translated: so too, the life faculty appears as weak.

original: vavatthitanimittābhāvato. Addhānaparicchedatoti kālassa paricchannabhāvato. Khaṇaparittatoti
analyzed: vavatthita nimitta abhāvataḥ addhāna paricchedato ti kālassa paricchanna bhāvataḥ khaṇa parittato ti
translated: because there is no sign of a distinction in the way it is. As to delimiting the extent of the period: because it is limited by time. As to the shortness of the moment:

original: jīvitakkhaṇassa ittarabhāvato.🔽Vadhakapaccupaṭṭhānatoti ettha viya-saddo luttaniddiṭṭhoti dassento “vadhakassa viya
analyzed: jīvitakkhaṇassa ittara bhāvato  vadhaka paccupaṭṭhānato ti ettha viya saddaḥ lutta niddiṭṭho ti dassento vadhakassa viya
translated: because the moment of life is short.🔽As to appearing as a murderer: here the word viya is a synonym for “like.” Showing this, he said “as if appearing as a murderer.”

original: paccupaṭṭhānato”ti vatvā tamevatthaṃ vivaranto “yathā hī”tiādimāha. Tattha cārayamānoti
analyzed: paccupaṭṭhānato ti vatvā tam eva attham vivarantaḥ yathā hi itiādim āha tattha cārayamāno ti
translated: Explaining the meaning of that, he said “For just as . . . ”

original: āgurento paharaṇākāraṃ karonto. Paccupaṭṭhitova upagantvā ṭhito samīpe eva. Jarāmaraṇaṃ🔽gahetvāva nibbattanti “yathā hi ahicchattakamakuḷaṃ uggacchantaṃ paṃsuvirahitaṃ na
analyzed: āgurento paharaṇa ākāram karonto paccupaṭṭhitaḥ uva upagantvā ṭhitaḥ samīpe eva jarā maraṇam  gahetvā ava nibbattanti yathā hi ahicchattaka makuḷam uggacchantam paṃsu virahitam na
translated: Herein, he is moving along means he is coming, making a blow. He is appearing means he is standing near, having approached.

original: hoti, evaṃ sattā nibbattantā jarāmaraṇavirahitā na hontī”ti ettakena upamā. Ahicchattakamakuḷaṃ
analyzed: hoti evam sattāḥ nibbattantāḥ jarā maraṇa virahitāḥ na honti iti ettakena upamā ahicchattaka makuḷam
