translated: Beings are born only with aging-and-death. “For just as when a snake’s hood is raised there is no place without dust, so when beings are born there is no place without aging-and-death” is the simile.

original: kadāci katthaci paṃsuvirahitampi bhaveyya, sattā pana kathañcipi jarāmaraṇavirahitā
analyzed: kadāci katthaci paṃsu virahitam sattā pana kathañcipi jarā maraṇa virahitā
translated: Sometimes a snake’s hood may be raised without dust, but beings are never born without aging-and-death.

original: na hontīti khaṇikamaraṇaṃ tāva upamābhāvena dassetvā idhādhippetaṃ maraṇaṃ dassetuṃ
analyzed: na honti iti khaṇika maraṇam tāva upamā bhāvena dassetvā idha adhippetam maraṇam dassetuṃ
translated: “They are not”: Having first shown the momentary death by way of simile, he shows the death intended here.

original: “tathā hī”tiādi vuttaṃ. Atha vā yadime sattā jarāmaraṇaṃ gahetvāva nibbattanti, nibbattisamanantarameva🔽maritabbanti codanaṃ sandhāyāha “tathā hī”tiādi. Avassaṃ maraṇatoti avassaṃ maritabbato,🔽ekantena maraṇasabbhāvato vā. Pabbateyyāti pabbatato āgatā. Hārahārinīti pavāhe patitassa🔽tiṇapaṇṇādikassa ativiya haraṇasīlā. Sandatevāti savati eva. Vattatevāti pavāhavasena
analyzed: tathā hi itiādi vuttam atha vā yat ime sattāḥ jarā maraṇam gahetvā ava nibbattanti nibbatti samanantaram eva  maritabbanti codanam sandhāya āha tathā hi itiādi avassam maraṇato ti avassam maritabbato  ekantena maraṇa sabbhāvataḥ vā pabbateyyā ati pabbatataḥ āgatā hāra hārinī iti pavāhe patitassa  tiṇa paṇṇa ādikassa haraṇa sīlā sandatā iva ati savati eva vattatā iva ati pavāha vasena
translated: “They do not last” : having first shown the momentary death by way of simile, he said “Thus” in order to show the death intended here. Or else, since these beings are born only after taking on old age and death, and immediately after birth

original: vattati eva na tiṭṭhati.🔽Yamekarattinti yassaṃ ekarattiyaṃ, bhummatthe upayogavacanaṃ daṭṭhabbaṃ, accantasaṃyoge
analyzed: vattati eva na tiṭṭhati  yam ekarattin ti yassam ekarattiyam bhumma tthe upayoga vacanam daṭṭhabbam ac c anta saṃyoge
translated: they must die, he said “Thus” in order to rebuke the idea that they must die. “Without a doubt” : without fail. “From death” : from the necessity of dying. Or else, because of the certainty of death. “From the mountain” : coming from the mountain. “Carries away” : it is of the nature of carrying away the grass, leaves, etc., that fall into the stream. “Flows on” : it flows on. “Rolls on” : it rolls on by way of the stream. It does not stand still.

original: vā. Paṭhamanti sabbapaṭhamaṃ paṭisandhikkhaṇe. Gabbheti mātukucchiyaṃ. Māṇavoti satto.
analyzed: vā paṭhamanti sabba paṭhamam paṭisandhi kkhaṇe gabbheti mātukucchiyam māṇavo ti satto
translated: “In one night” : in one night. The locative case should be regarded as having the sense of the instrumental case, or else as having the sense of the dative case. “First” : at the first moment of rebirth-linking. “In the womb” : in the mother’s womb. “The child” : the being.

original: Yebhuyyena sattā rattiyaṃ paṭisandhiṃ gaṇhantīti rattiggahaṇaṃ. Abbhuṭṭhitovāti uṭṭhitaabbho
analyzed: yebhuyyena sattāḥ rattiyam paṭisandhim gaṇhanti iti ratti ggahaṇam abbhuṭṭhita uvāti uṭṭhita abbhaḥ
translated: “By night” is said because beings usually take rebirth-linking by night.

original: viya, abhimukhabhāvena vā uṭṭhitova maraṇassāti adhippāyo. So yātīti so māṇavo yāti,
analyzed: viya abhimukha bhāvena vā uṭṭhitaḥ uva maraṇassa ati adhippāyo so yāti iti so māṇavaḥ yāti
translated: “As though rising up”: the meaning is that he rises up as though rising up from sleep, or he rises up facing death.

original: paṭhamakkhaṇato paṭṭhāya gacchateva. Sa gacchaṃ na nivattatīti so evaṃ gacchanto
analyzed: paṭhama kkhaṇataḥ paṭṭhāya gacchatā iva sa gaccham na nivattati iti saḥ evam gacchantaḥ
translated: “He goes on”: that brahmin student goes on, he goes on from the first moment.

original: khaṇamattampi na nivattati, aññadatthu maraṇaṃyeva upagacchati.
analyzed: na nivattati aññadatthu maraṇam yā iva upagacchati
translated: “He goes on, he does not turn back”: he goes on thus, he does not turn back even for a moment. He goes on only to death.🔽“The mountain streams”: small streams falling from the mountain.

original: Kunnadīnanti pabbatato patitānaṃ khuddakanadīnaṃ. Pāto āporasānugatabandhanānanti🔽purimadivase divā sūriyasantāpena anto anupavisitvā puna rattiyaṃ bandhanamūlaṃ upagatena
analyzed: kunnadīnam ti pabbatataḥ patitānam khuddaka nadīnam pāto āpas rasa anugata bandhanānam ti  purima divase divā sūriya santāpena antar an upavisitvā punar rattiyam bandhana mūlam upagatena
translated: “With their bonds loosened by the rain that follows the hot season”:

original: āporasena tintasithilabandhanatāya pāto āporasānugatabandhanānaṃ.
analyzed: āpaḥ rasena tinta sithila bandhana tāya
translated: because the bonds of the clay are loosened by the rain that falls after the hot season, which has not penetrated the clay by day through the heat of the sun.

original: Accayantīti atikkamanti. Uparujjhatīti nirujjhati. Udakameva odakaṃ, udakoghaṃ vā.
analyzed: accayanti iti atikkamanti uparujjhati iti nirujjhati udakam eva odakam udaka ogham vā
translated: “They flow on”: they go on. “They cease”: they cease. “Water” is just water, or a flood of water.

original: Yasmā accayanti ahorattā, tasmā jīvitaṃ uparujjhati. Yasmā jīvitaṃ uparujjhati, tasmā🔽āyu khīyati maccānaṃ. Papatatoti papatanato bhayaṃ sāmikānaṃ rukkhe ṭhatvā kamme🔽viniyuñjitukāmānaṃ, heṭṭhā paviṭṭhānaṃ vā. Uggamanaṃ pati uggamananimittaṃ. Mā maṃ
analyzed: yasmai accayanti ahar rattā tasmai jīvitam uparujjhati yasmai jīvitam uparujjhati tasmai  āyu khīyati maccānam papatato ti papatanataḥ bhayam sāmikānam rukkhe ṭhatvā kamme  viniyuñjitu kāmānam heṭṭhā paviṭṭhānam vā uggamanam pati uggamana nimittam mā mama
translated: the life-span of mortals dwindles away.🔽Papatato: the danger of falling down to those who are desirous of engaging in work by standing on a tree, or of those who have entered below. Uggamanaṃ pati: the sign of rising up.

original: amma nivāraya pabbajjāyāti adhippāyo.
analyzed: amma nivāraya pabbajjāya ati adhippāyaḥ
translated: Mā maṃ amma nivāraya pabbajjāya: the intention is: “Do not prevent me from going forth.”

original: Koci mittamukhasatturandhagavesī saha vattamānopi na haneyya, ayaṃ pana ekaṃsena hanatiyevāti dassetuṃ “sahajātiyā āgatato”ti vatvā “jīvitaharaṇato cā”ti vuttaṃ.
analyzed: koci mitta mukha sattu randha gavesī saha vattamānaḥ api na haneyya ayam pana ekaṃsena hanatiyā iva ati dassetum saha jātiyāḥ āgatataḥ ti vatvā jīvita haraṇato ca ati vuttam
translated: Koci: although one is living together with him, one who is seeking a friend with a face like an enemy would not kill him. But this one kills him without hesitation. In order to show this, after saying “from the time of birth,” it is said “and from the taking of life.”

original: 170. Nanti sampattiṃ. Sukhīti dibbasadisehi bhogehi, ādhipateyyena ca sukhasamaṅgī. Dehabandhenāti sarīrena. Asokoti asokamahārājā. Sokamāgatoti socitabbataṃ gato.
analyzed: sampattim sukhī iti dibba sadisehi bhogehi ādhipateyyena ca sukha samaṅgī dehabandhena ati sarīrena asokaḥ iti asoka mahā rājā sokam āgataḥ iti socitabbatam gataḥ
translated: Nanti: prosperity. Sukhī: endowed with happiness through heavenly-like wealth and lordship. Dehabandhena: with the body. Asoko: King Asoka. Sokamāgato: gone to the state of being grieved.

original: Ārogyaṃ yobbanānaṃ. Byādhijarāpariyosānatā jīvitassa maraṇapariyosānatāya udāharaṇavasena🔽ānītā, paccayabhāgavasena vā. Lokoyeva lokasannivāso yathā sattāvāsāti, sannivasitabbatāya
analyzed: ārogyam yobbanānam byādhi jarā pariyosāna tā jīvitassa maraṇa pariyosāna tāya udāharaṇa vasena  ānītā paccaya bhāga vasena vā lokoyā iva loka sannivāsaḥ yathā sannivasitabba tāya
translated: Health is the end of youth, and death is the end of life.🔽Or they are mentioned as examples of the ending of conditions.🔽The world’s abode is the world itself, as the abode of beings is the world.

original: vā sattanikāyo lokasannivāso. Anugatoti anubandho paccatthikena viya. Anusaṭoti anupaviṭṭho
analyzed: vā satta nikāyaḥ loka sannivāsaḥ anugataḥ ti anubandho paccatthikena viya anusaṭaḥ ti anupaviṭṭho
translated: Or the world’s abode is the world’s population, because it is the place where beings dwell.🔽“Followed” means pursued, as by an enemy. “Surrounded” means surrounded, as by a crowd.

original: upavisena viya. Abhibhūtoti ajjhotthaṭo maddahatthīhi viya. Abbhāhatoti pahaṭo bhūtehi viya.
analyzed: upavisena viya abhibhūtaḥ ti ajjhotthaṭaḥ madda hatthīhi viya abbhāhato ti pahaṭaḥ bhūtehi viya
translated: “Overwhelmed” means overcome, as by a debt. “Oppressed” means struck, as by spirits.

original: Selāti silāmayā, na paṃsuādimayā. Vipulāti mahantā anekayojanāyāmavitthārā. Nabhaṃ🔽āhaccāti vipulattā eva ākāsaṃ abhivihacca sabbadisāsu pharitvā. Anupariyeyyunti anuvicareyyuṃ.
analyzed: silā mayāḥ na paṃsu ādi mayāḥ mahantāḥ aneka yojana āyāma vitthārāḥ  āhacca ati vipula ttāḥ eva ākāsam abhivihacca sabba disāsu pharitvā anupariyeyyunti anuvicareyyuṃ
translated: “Rocks” means rocks, not earth, etc. “Vast” means big, many yojanas in length and breadth.🔽“Reaching up to the sky” means that because of their vastness they reach up to the sky, spreading out in all directions.🔽“They would wander about” means they would move about.

original: Nippothentāti attanā āghātitaṃ cuṇṇavicuṇṇaṃ karontā. Adhivattantīti adhibhavanti.
analyzed: nippothentā ati attanā āghātitam cuṇṇa vicuṇṇam karontā adhivattanti iti adhibhavanti
translated: “Crushing” means reducing to powder what they have struck. “Would overcome” means they would overcome.

original: Kulena vā rūpena vā sīlena vā sutena vā saddhādīhi vā seṭṭhoti sambhāvanāya khattiyādīsu
analyzed: kulena vā rūpena vā sīlena vā sutena vā saddhā ādīhi vā seṭṭhaḥ iti sambhāvanāya khattiya ādīsu
translated: He does not avoid anyone among the Khattiyas, etc., because of the esteem in which they are held as being the best by reason of their birth, their beauty, their virtue, their learning, their faith, etc.

original: na kañci parivajjeti. Tehi eva nihīnoti avamaññamānāya suddādīsu na kañci parivajjeti.
analyzed: na kañci parivajjeti tehi eva nihīnaḥ iti avamaññamānāya sudda ādīsu na kañci parivajjeti
translated: He does not avoid anyone among the Suddas, etc., because of the contempt in which they are held as being inferior to those.

original: Aññadatthu sabbameva abhimaddati nimmathati. Daṇḍādiupāyā ca tattha avisayā evāti
analyzed: sabbam eva abhimaddati nimmathati daṇḍa ādi upāyā ca tattha avisayā eva ati
translated: He crushes and tramples down all alike. And the means of punishment, etc., are not applicable there.

original: dassetuṃ “na tattha hatthīnaṃ bhūmī”tiādi vuttaṃ. Tattha mantayuddhenāti āthabbaṇavedavihitena
analyzed: dassetum na tattha hatthīnam bhūmi itiādi vuttam tattha manta yuddhena āti āthabbaṇa veda vihitena
translated: To show this, it is said: “There is no place there for elephants,” etc. Herein, by the “counsel of war” is meant the application of the stratagem of war by means of counsel, advice, and counsel of policy.

original: mantasaṅgāmappayogena. Dhanenāti dhanadānena. Vā-saddo avuttavikappanattho. Tena
analyzed: dhanena ati dhana dānena vā saddaḥ avutta vikappana atthaḥ tena
translated: By “wealth” is meant the giving of wealth. The word “or” includes the giving of gifts and the giving of fearlessness.

original: sāmaṃ, bhedañca saṅgaṇhāti.🔽171. Parehi saddhiṃ attano upasaṃharaṇatoti parehi matehi saddhiṃ “tepi nāma matā,
analyzed: sāmam bhedam ca saṅgaṇhāti  parehi saddhim attanaḥ upasaṃharaṇato ti parehi matehi saddhim te api nāma matā
translated: By “reconciliation” is meant the bringing together of those who are divided.🔽By “bringing together with others” is meant the bringing of one’s own death near by thinking: “They too have died,🔽what of me?”

original: kimaṅgaṃ pana mādisā”ti attano maraṇassa upanayanato. Yasamahattatoti parivāramahattato,
analyzed: kim aṅgam pana mā ādisā ati attanaḥ maraṇassa upanayanataḥ yasa mahattato ti parivāra mahattato
translated: By “greatness of fame” is meant greatness of retinue.

original: vibhavamahattato ca. Puññamahattatoti mahāpuññabhāvato. Thāmamahattatoti vīriyabalamahattato.
analyzed: vibhava mahattato ca puñña mahattato ti mahā puñña bhāvato thāma mahattato ti vīriya bala mahattato
translated: By the greatness of his strength: by the greatness of his energy.🔽Yudhiṭṭhila, the son of Dhamma,

original: Yudhiṭṭhilo dhammaputto. Cānuro yo baladevena nibbuddhaṃ katvā mārito.
analyzed: yudhiṭṭhilaḥ dhammaputto ca anuraḥ yaḥ baladevena nibbuddham katvā māritaḥ
translated: and Anurodha were killed by Baladeva after being defeated.

original: Saha iddhīhīti vejayantakampananandopanandadamanādīsu diṭṭhānubhāvāhi attano iddhīhi saddhiṃ maccumukhaṃ paviṭṭho.
analyzed: saha iddhīhi iti vejayanta kampana nanda upananda damana ādīsu diṭṭha anubhāvāhi attanaḥ iddhīhi saddhim maccu mukham paviṭṭhaḥ
translated: Together with his psychic powers: together with his psychic powers, which were seen in such instances as the shaking of the Vejayanta Palace, the taming of Nandopananda, and so on, he entered the mouth of death.

original: Kalaṃ nagghanti soḷasinti soḷasannaṃ pūraṇabhāgaṃ na agghanti. Idaṃ vuttaṃ hoti –
analyzed: kalam soḷasinti pūraṇa bhāgam na agghanti idam vuttam hoti
translated: They are not worth a fraction: they are not worth a sixteenth part. This is what is meant.

original: āyasmato therassa sāriputtassa paññaṃ soḷasabhāge katvā tato ekaṃ bhāgaṃ soḷasadhā
analyzed: āyasmataḥ therassa sāriputtassa paññam soḷasa bhāge katvā tatas ekam bhāgam soḷasadhā
translated: The Venerable Elder Sāriputta’s wisdom is worth sixteen parts. Taking one part of that,

original: gahetvā laddhaṃ ekabhāgasaṅkhātaṃ kalaṃ sammāsambuddhaṃ ṭhapetvā aññesaṃ sattānaṃ
analyzed: gahetvā laddham eka bhāga saṅkhātam kalam sammāsambuddham ṭhapetvā aññesam sattānam
translated: he divided it into sixteen parts. The part obtained is called a fraction. Except for the Perfectly Enlightened One,

original: paññā na agghantīti.
analyzed: paññā na agghanti iti
translated: the wisdom of other beings is not worth a fraction of that.

original: Sabbassāpi saṃkilesapakkhassa samugghāto ñāyena āraddhavīriyassa hotīti āha “ñāṇavīriyabalenā”ti.
analyzed: sabbassa api saṃkilesa pakkhassa samugghātaḥ ñāyena āraddha vīriyassa hoti iti āha ñāṇa vīriya balena ati
translated: The complete eradication of the entire side of defilement occurs for one who has begun to exert himself by means of wisdom and energy. Therefore it is said: “by the power of wisdom and energy.”

original: Sammādiṭṭhisammāvāyāmesu hi siddhesu aṭṭhaṅgiko ariyamaggo siddhova hotīti. Ekākībhāvena🔽khaggavisāṇakappā. Paratoghosena vinā sayameva bhūtā paṭividdhākuppāti sayambhuno.
analyzed: sammā diṭṭhi sammā vāyāmesu hi siddhesu aṭṭhaṅgikaḥ ariya maggo siddhaḥ uva hoti iti ekākībhāvena  khagga visāṇa kappā paratoghosena vinā sayam eva bhūtā sayambhunaḥ
translated: he has penetrated the truth by himself.

original: Hatthagatasuvaṇṇavalayānaṃ aññamaññaṃ saṅghaṭṭanaṃ vaṃsakaḷīrassa katthaci asattatāti
analyzed: hattha gata suvaṇṇa valayānam aññamaññam saṅghaṭṭanam vaṃsa kaḷīrassa katthaci a satta tā ati
translated: Like the clashing of bracelets on a woman’s arm or the sound of a bamboo reed when it is struck,

original: evamādikaṃ taṃ taṃ nimittaṃ kāraṇaṃ āgamma. Vīmaṃsantāti pavattinivattiyo upaparikkhantā.
analyzed: evamādikam tam tam nimittam kāraṇam āgamma vīmaṃsantā ati pavatti nivattiyaḥ upaparikkhantā
translated: so is the contact of the eye with visible objects, etc.🔽He is a great seer because he has sought out the great aggregates of virtue, etc.🔽He is a great seer because he has sought out the great aggregates of virtue, etc.🔽He is a great seer because he has sought out the great aggregates of virtue, etc.

original: Mahantānaṃ sīlakkhandhādīnaṃ esanaṭṭhena mahesayo. Ekacariyanivāsenāti ekacariyanivāsamattena,🔽na sīlādinā. Khaggamigasiṅgasamā upamā yesaṃ, khaggamigasiṅgaṃ vā samūpamā yesaṃ🔽te khaggasiṅgasamūpamā.
analyzed: mahantānam sīla kkhandha ādīnam esana ṭṭhena mahesayaḥ eka cariya nivāsena ati eka cariya nivāsa mattena  na sīla ādinā khagga miga siṅga samāḥ upamāḥ yesam khagga miga siṅgam vā samūpamāḥ yesam  te
translated: He is a great seer because he has sought out the great aggregates of virtue, etc.🔽He is a great seer because he has sought out the great aggregates of virtue, etc.🔽He is a great seer because he has sought out the great aggregates of virtue, etc.🔽He is a great seer because he has sought out the great aggregates of virtue, etc.🔽He is a great seer because he has sought out the great aggregates of virtue, etc.🔽He is a great seer because he has sought out the great aggregates of virtue, etc.🔽He is a great seer because he has sought out the great aggregates of virtue, etc.🔽He is a great seer because he has sought out the great aggregates of virtue, etc.🔽He is a great seer because he has sought out the great aggregates of virtue, etc.🔽He is a great seer because he has sought out the great aggregates of virtue, etc.🔽He is a great seer because he has sought out the great aggregates of virtue, etc.🔽He is a great seer because he has sought out the great aggregates of virtue, etc.🔽He is a great seer because he has sought out the great aggregates of virtue, etc.🔽He is a great seer because he has sought out the great aggregates of virtue, etc.🔽He is a great seer because he has sought out the great aggregates of virtue, etc.🔽He is a great seer because he has sought out the great aggregates of virtue, etc.🔽He is a great seer because he has sought out the great aggregates of virtue, etc.🔽He is a great seer because he has sought out the great aggregates of virtue, etc.

original: Tambanakhatuṅganakhatādiasītianubyañjanapaṭimaṇḍitehi suppatiṭṭhitapādatādīhi dvattiṃsāya
analyzed: tamba nakha tuṅga nakha tādi asi iti anubyañjana paṭimaṇḍitehi su patiṭṭhita pāda ta ādīhi dvattiṃsāya
translated: He is a great seer because he has sought out the great aggregates of virtue, etc.🔽He is a great seer because

original: mahāpurisalakkhaṇehi vicitro acchariyabbhuto rūpakāyo etassāti asīti…pe… rūpakāyo.
analyzed: mahā purisa lakkhaṇehi vicitraḥ acchariyabbhutaḥ rūpa kāyaḥ etassa ati rūpa kāyaḥ
translated: His physical body is variegated with the characteristics of a Great Man and is wonderful and marvellous.

original: Saha vāsanāya sabbesaṃ kilesānaṃ pahīnattā sabbākāraparisuddhasīlakkhandhādiguṇaratanehi
analyzed: saha vāsanāya sabbesam kilesānam pahīna ttā sabba ākāra parisuddha sīla kkhandha ādi guṇa ratanehi
translated: His Dhamma body is endowed with the jewel of virtue, etc., purified in all respects, because all defilements together with their residues have been abandoned.

original: samiddho dhammakāyo etassāti sabbākāra…pe… dhammakāyo. Ṭhānasoti taṅkhaṇeyeva.
analyzed: samiddhaḥ dhammakāyaḥ etassa ati sabba ākāra pe dhammakāyo ṭhānaso ti taṅkhaṇeya eva
translated: The word “immediately” means “at that very moment.”

original: Evaṃ mahānubhāvassāti evaṃ yathāvuttarūpakāyasampattiyā, dhammakāyasampattiyā ca viññāyamānavipulāparimeyyabuddhānubhāvassa, vasaṃ nāgataṃ anupagamanavasenāti adhippāyo.
analyzed: evam mahā anubhāvassa ati evam yathā vutta rūpa kāya sampattiyā dhammakāya sampattiyā ca viññāyamāna vipula aparimeyya buddha anubhāvassa vasam na āgatam an upagamana vasena ati adhippāyaḥ
translated: The meaning is: “He has come under the sway of the Buddha’s power, which is known to be vast and immeasurable through the perfection of his physical body and his Dhamma body.”

original: Maraṇaṃ sāmaññaṃ etassāti maraṇasāmañño, tassa bhāvo maraṇasāmaññatā, tāya.
analyzed: maraṇam sāmaññam etassa ati maraṇa sāmaññaḥ tassa bhāvaḥ maraṇa sāmañña tā tāya
translated: “Having death as his companion” : death is his companion. The state of having death as one’s companion is maraṇasāmaññatā.🔽“The various kinds of living beings” : the various kinds of living beings are the various kinds of living beings.

original: 172. Kimikulānanti kimisamūhānaṃ, kimijātīnaṃ vā. Jīyantīti jaraṃ pāpuṇanti.
analyzed: kimi kulānanti kimi samūhānam kimi jātīnam vā jīyanti iti jaram pāpuṇanti
translated: “When they are dead” : when they have reached old age.

original: Nikkhanteti vītivatte. Paṭihitāyāti paccānugatāya. So mamassa antarāyoti sā yathāvuttā
analyzed: nikkhantā iti vītivatte paṭihitāya ati pacca anugatāya saḥ mama assa antarāyaḥ ti sā yathā vuttā
translated: “When it has passed away” : when it has gone by. “When it has returned” : when it has come back. “It would be an obstacle for me” : that which has been mentioned above.

original: na kevalaṃ kālakiriyāva, atha kho mama atidullabhaṃ khaṇaṃ labhitvā ṭhitassa satthusāsanamanasikārassa
analyzed: na kevalam atha kho mama ati dullabham khaṇam labhitvā ṭhitassa satthu sāsana manasikārassa
translated: not only at the time of death, but also while I am standing here having obtained a very difficult opportunity,🔽

original: antarāyo assa bhaveyya. Byāpajjeyyāti vipattiṃ gaccheyya. Satthakena viya aṅgapaccaṅgānaṃ
analyzed: antarāyaḥ assa bhaveyya byāpajjeyya ati vipattim gaccheyya satthakena viya aṅga paccaṅgānam
translated: Not only death, but also the opportunity to attend to the Teacher’s Dispensation, which is so hard to find, would be interrupted for me if I were to fall ill. Would go to destruction: would go to ruin. The winds that cut the joints and sever the limbs,

original: kantanakā maraṇakāle sandhibandhanacchedanakavātā satthakavātā.🔽173. Abalanti balahīnaṃ. Dubbalanti tasseva vevacanaṃ. Abhāvattho hi ayaṃ du-saddo
analyzed: kantanakā maraṇa kāle sandhibandhana chedanakavātā satthakavātā  abalanti bala hīnam dubbalanti tassa iva vevacanam abhāva tthaḥ hi ayam du saddaḥ
translated: like a butcher’s knife, at the time of death are called knife-winds.🔽Weak: lacking strength. Feeble: a synonym for the same. For the prefix du- has the meaning of absence,🔽as in “lacking in virtue” , “lacking in understanding” , etc.

original: “dussīlo duppañño”tiādīsu viya. Tadetaṃ āyu. Assāsapassāsānaṃ samavuttitā aparāparaṃ
analyzed: dussīlaḥ duppaññaḥ ti ādīsu viya tat etam āyu assāsa passāsānam sama vutti tā apara aparam
translated: This is the life-continuum, the regular occurrence of in-breaths and out-breaths, the going in and coming out by turns,

original: pavesanikkhamova. Bahi nikkhantanāsikavāte anto apavisante, paviṭṭhe vā anikkhamanteti
analyzed: pavesa nikkhamaḥ uva bahi nikkhanta nāsika vāte antar a pavisante paviṭṭhe vā a nikkhamantā iti
translated: as if it were the going in and coming out of one single in-breath and out-breath. For when the nose-wind goes out, it does not enter in again, or when it enters in, it does not go out again,

original: ekasseva pavesanikkhamo viya vuttaṃ, taṃ nāsikavātabhāvasāmaññenāti daṭṭhabbaṃ. Adhimattatāya
analyzed: ekassa iva pavesa nikkhamaḥ viya vuttam tam nāsika vāta bhāva sāmaññena ati daṭṭhabbam adhimatta tāya
translated: but it is as if it were the going in and coming out of one single in-breath and out-breath. This should be regarded as said figuratively because of similarity to the nose-wind.🔽Because of the excess of the life-continuum,🔽because of the nearness of the resolve, etc.,

original: accāsannaadhiṭṭhānādinā. Tadabhāvo hi iriyāpathānaṃ samavuttitā. Atisītena abhibhūtassa
analyzed: acca āsanna adhiṭṭhāna ādinā tad abhāvaḥ hi iriyāpathānam sama vutti tā ati sītena abhibhūtassa
translated: for the absence of that is the regular occurrence of postures. When a man is overcome by excessive cold,

original: kāyassa vipajjanaṃ mahiṃsaraṭṭhādīsu himapātakālena dīpetabbaṃ. Tattha hi sattā sītena
analyzed: kāyassa vipajjanam mahiṃsa raṭṭha ādīsu hima pāta kālena dīpetabbam tattha hi sattā sītena
translated: The breakup of the body should be illustrated by the story of the king of Mahiṃsa who was killed by snow in the island of Siṃhala. For beings there die from the cold

original: bhinnasarīrā jīvitakkhayaṃ pāpuṇanti. Atiuṇhena abhibhūtassa vipajjanaṃ marukantāre🔽uṇhābhitattāya pacchiṃ, tattha ṭhapitaṃ upari sāṭakaṃ, puttañca akkamitvā matāya🔽itthiyā dīpetabbaṃ. Mahābhūtānaṃ samavuttitā pakopābhāvo. Pathavīdhātuādīnaṃ pakopena
analyzed: bhinna sarīrāḥ jīvita kkhayam pāpuṇanti ati uṇhena abhibhūtassa vipajjanam maru kantāre  uṇha abhitattāya pacchim tattha ṭhapitam upari sāṭakam puttam ca akkamitvā matāya  itthiyā dīpetabbam mahābhūtānam samavutti tā pakopa abhāvaḥ pathavī dhātu ādīnam pakopena
translated: in the winter. The breakup of one overcome by excessive heat should be illustrated by the story of the woman who died after stepping on her child and a cloth on the ground in the desert of sand,🔽having been overcome by the heat. The non-excess of the primary elements is the absence of disturbance. The occurrence of a change in the body through the disturbance of the earth element, etc.,

original: sarīrassa vikārāpatti parato dhātukammaṭṭhānakathāyaṃ āgamissati. Yuttakāleti bhuñjituṃ
analyzed: sarīrassa vikāra āpatti paratas dhātu kammaṭṭhāna kathā ayam āgamissati yutta kāle iti bhuñjituṃ
translated: will be dealt with later in the exposition of the elements as meditation subjects. The right time is the time suitable for eating,

original: yuttakāle khuddābhibhūtakāle.🔽174. Avavatthānatoti kālādivasena vavatthānābhāvato. Vavatthānanti cettha paricchedo
analyzed: yutta kāle khudda abhibhūta kāle  a vavatthānataḥ ti kāla ādi vasena vavatthāna abhāvataḥ ca ittha paricchedo
translated: the time when one is overcome by hunger.🔽As to delimitation: there is no delimitation by time, etc. Herein, delimitation is what is meant by definition.

original: adhippeto, na asaṅkarato vavatthānaṃ, nicchayo cāti āha “paricchedābhāvato”ti. Na
analyzed: adhippetaḥ na asaṅkarataḥ vavatthānam nicchayo ca ati āha pariccheda abhāvato ti na
translated: It is not a definition by non-confusion, nor a definition by appearance, that is why he said “as to delimitation: there is no delimitation by time, etc.”

original: nāyareti na ñāyanti.
analyzed: na ñāyanti
translated: They do not know: they do not understand.

original: Ito paranti ettha paranti paraṃ aññaṃ kālanti attho. Tena orakālassāpi saṅgaho siddho
analyzed: itas paranti ettha paranti param aññam kālanti attho tena ora kālassa api saṅgahaḥ siddho
translated: “From here on” means “from here on, from here, beyond this.” The meaning is: “beyond this.” Thus the inclusion of the time “from here on” is established.

original: hoti. Paramāyuto orakālaṃ eva cettha “para”nti adhippetaṃ. Tato paraṃ sattānaṃ jīvanassa🔽abhāvato “vavatthānābhāvato”ti vattuṃ na sakkāti. Abbudapesītiādīsu “abbudakāle pesikāle”tiādinā🔽kāla-saddo paccekaṃ yojetabbo. Kāloti idha pubbaṇhādivelā adhippetā. Tenāha “pubbaṇhepi
analyzed: hoti eva ca ittha paranti adhippetam tatas param sattānam jīvanassa  abhāvataḥ vavatthāna abhāvato ti vattum na sakkā ati abbuda pesī itiādīsu abbuda kāle pesi kāla iti ādinā  kāla saddo paccekam yojetabbaḥ kālaḥ iti idha pubbaṇha ādi velā adhippetā tena āha pubbaṇhe pi
translated: But the time “from here on” is intended here by “beyond this.” Beyond that, it is not possible to say that there is a “limit” to the life of beings,🔽because there is no life beyond that. In the case of the words “abbudapesī,” etc., the word “kāla” should be construed separately in each case, as “at the time of the abbudas,” “at the time of the pesis,” etc.🔽Here, by “time” is meant the period of the morning, etc. Thus he says: “Even in the morning, etc.” The construction is: “one must fall down right here with this body.”

original: hī”tiādi. Idheva dehena patitabbanti sambandho. Anekappakāratoti nagare jātānaṃ gāme,
analyzed: hi itiādi idha iva dehena patitabbanti sambandhaḥ aneka ppakārataḥ ti nagare jātānam gāme
translated: “In many ways” means: those born in the city in the village,

original: gāme jātānaṃ nagare, vane jātānaṃ janapade, janapade jātānaṃ vanetiādinā anekappakārato.
analyzed: gāme jātānam nagare vane jātānam janapade janapade jātānam vana iti ādinā aneka ppakārato
translated: those born in the village in the city, those born in the forest in the country, those born in the country in the forest, etc.

original: Ito cutenāti ito gatito cutena. Idha imissaṃ gatiyaṃ. Yantayuttagoṇo viyāti yathā
analyzed: itas cutena ati itas gatitaḥ cutena idha imissam gatiyam viyāti yathā
translated: “From here on, having died”: having gone from here, having died. “Here” means in this destiny. “Like an ox harnessed to a mill” means:

original: yante yuttagoṇo yantaṃ nātivattati, evaṃ loko gatipañcakanti ettakena upamā.
analyzed: yante yutta goṇaḥ yantam na ativattati evam lokaḥ gati pañcakanti ettakena upamā
translated: just as an ox harnessed to a mill does not go beyond the mill, so too, the world does not go beyond the five destinies.

original: 175. Appaṃ vā bhiyyoti vassasatato upari “dasa vā vassāni, vīsati vā”tiādinā dutiyaṃ
analyzed: appam vā bhiyyo ti vassa satataḥ upari dasa vā vassāni vīsati vā ati ādinā dutiyam
translated: “For a short time” means for less than a hundred years, “ten years, twenty years,” etc.

original: vassasataṃ apāpuṇanto appakaṃ vā jīvatīti attho. Gamanīyoti gandhabbo upapajjanavasena.
analyzed: vassa satam apāpuṇantaḥ appakam vā jīvati iti attho gamanīyaḥ ti gandhabbaḥ upapajjana vasena
translated: The meaning is: he lives a short time. “As a gandhabba” means as one who has been reborn as a gandhabba.

original: Samparāyoti paraloko.
analyzed: samparāyoti para lokaḥ
translated: “In the next world” means in the afterlife.

original: Hīḷeyyāti paribhaveyya na sambhāveyya. Nanti āyuṃ. Suporisoti sādhupuriso paññavā. Careyyāti sucaritaṃ careyya. Tenāha “ādittasīsovā”ti.
analyzed: hīḷeyya ati paribhaveyya na sambhāveyya āyum su poriso ti sādhu puriso paññavā careyya ati su caritam careyya tena āha āditta sīsā uvā iti
translated: “He would despise” means he would look down upon, not respect. “Nanti” means “life.” “A good person” means a wise person. “Should conduct himself” means he should conduct himself in good conduct. Therefore it is said: “As one whose head is on fire.”

original: Sattahi upamāhīti –
analyzed: sattahi upamāhi iti
translated: “With the seven similes” means:

original: “Seyyathāpi, brāhmaṇa, tiṇagge ussāvabindu sūriye uggacchante khippaṃyeva paṭivigacchati,
analyzed: seyyathā api brāhmaṇa tiṇagge ussāva bindu sūriye uggacchante khippaṃyā iva paṭivigacchati
translated: “Brahmin, just as a dewdrop on the tip of a blade of grass disappears quickly when the sun rises,

original: na ciraṭṭhitikaṃ hoti. Udake udakapubbuḷaṃ. Udake daṇḍarāji. Nadī pabbateyyā dūraṅgamā
analyzed: na cira ṭṭhitikam hoti udake udaka pubbuḷam udake daṇḍa rāji nadī pabbateyyā dūraṅgamā
translated: and does not last long, just so… In water, a water bubble. In water, a line drawn with a stick. A river flowing down from a mountain, going a long way,

original: sīghasotā hārahārinī. Balavā puriso jivhagge kheḷapiṇḍaṃ saṃyūhitvā akasireneva vameyya.
analyzed: sīgha sotā hāra hārinī balavā purisaḥ jivhagge kheḷa piṇḍam saṃyūhitvā a kasirena iva vameyya
translated: flowing fast, carrying away the grass. A strong man, having collected saliva in his mouth, would spit it out with little effort.

original: Divasaṃ santatte ayokaṭāhe maṃsapesi pakkhittā khippaṃyeva paṭivigacchati, na ciraṭṭhitikā
analyzed: divasam santatte ayaḥ kaṭāhe maṃsa pesi pakkhittā khippaṃyeva paṭivigacchati na cira ṭṭhitikā
translated: A piece of meat thrown into a red-hot iron pan quickly disappears, does not last long.

original: hoti. Gāvī vajjhā āghātanaṃ nīyamānā yaṃ yadeva pādaṃ uddharati, santikeva hoti vadhassa,
analyzed: hoti gāvī vajjhā āghātanam nīyamānā yam yat eva pādam uddharati santikā iva hoti vadhassa
translated: A cow to be slaughtered, being led to the slaughterhouse, whatever foot she lifts, she is ever nearer to the slaughterhouse,

original: santikeva maraṇassa, evamevaṃ kho, brāhmaṇa, govajjhūpamaṃ jīvitaṃ manussānaṃ parittaṃ
analyzed: santikā iva maraṇassa evam evam kho brāhmaṇa go vajjhu upamam jīvitam manussānam parittam
translated: ever nearer to death. So too, brahmin, human life is like a cow to be slaughtered, limited,

original: lahukaṃ bahudukkhaṃ bahupāyāsaṃ mantāyaṃ boddhabbaṃ, kattabbaṃ kusalaṃ, caritabbaṃ
analyzed: lahukam bahu dukkham bahu pāyāsam mantā ayam boddhabbam kattabbam kusalam caritabbam
translated: fleeting, with much suffering, much misery. It should be arousing to one for striving, for exertion, for the higher endeavour.

original: brahmacariyaṃ, natthi jātassa amaraṇa”nti –
analyzed: brahmacariyam na atthi jātassa amaraṇanti
translated: One should live the spiritual life, for there is no certainty about the time of death.”

original: Evamāgatāhi imāhi sattahi upamāhi alaṅkataṃ.
analyzed: evam āgatāhi imāhi sattahi upamāhi alaṅkatam
translated: Thus it is adorned with these seven similes.

original: Rattindivanti ekaṃ rattindivaṃ. Bhagavato sāsananti ariyamaggapaṭivedhāvahaṃ satthu
analyzed: rattindivanti ekam rattindivam bhagavato sāsanam ti ariya magga paṭivedha āvaham satthu
translated: Day and night: one day and night. The Blessed One’s Dispensation: the Teacher’s advice, which brings about the penetration of the Noble Path.

original: ovādaṃ. Bahuṃ vata me kataṃ assāti bahuṃ vata mayā attahitaṃ pabbajitakiccaṃ kataṃ
analyzed: ovādam bahum vata me katam assa ati bahum vata mayā atta hitam pabbajita kiccam katam
translated: I would have done much: I would have done much of the duty of one gone forth, which is for one’s own welfare.

original: bhaveyya. Tadantaranti taṃ khaṇaṃ tattakaṃ velaṃ. Ekaṃ piṇḍapātanti ekaṃ divasaṃ
analyzed: tam khaṇam tattakam velam ekam ekam divasam
translated: In that interval: in that moment, in that second, in that instant. One alms meal: one day’s meal.

original: yāpanappahonakaṃ piṇḍapātaṃ. Dandhanti mandaṃ cirāya. Avissāsiyo avissāsanīyo.
analyzed: yāpana pahonakam piṇḍapātam dandhanti mandam cirāya a vissāsiyaḥ a vissāsanīyaḥ
translated: “Not to be trusted” means not to be relied on.

original: 176. Citte dharanteyeva sattānaṃ jīvitavohāro, cittassa ca atiittaro khaṇo lahuparivattibhāvato.
analyzed: citte sattānam jīvita vohāro cittassa ca atiittaraḥ khaṇaḥ lahu parivatti bhāvato
translated: The life of beings is dependent on the mind alone. And the moment of the mind is more fleeting than life, because of its rapid change.

original: Yathāha bhagavā “nāhaṃ, bhikkhave, aññaṃ ekadhammampi samanupassāmi, yaṃ evaṃ lahuparivattaṃ,
analyzed: yathā āha bhagavā na aham bhikkhave aññam eka dhammam pi samanupassāmi yam evam lahu parivattam
translated: As the Blessed One said: “Bhikkhus, I do not see even one other thing that changes so rapidly as the mind.

original: yathayidaṃ citta”nti. Tasmā sattānaṃ jīvitaṃ ekacittakkhaṇikattā lahusaṃ ittaranti🔽dassento “paramatthato”tiādimāha. Tattha “paramatthato”ti iminā yāyaṃ “yo ciraṃ jīvati,
analyzed: cittam ti tasmā sattānam jīvitam eka citta khaṇika ttā lahusam ittaranti  dassentaḥ paramattha tā ti ādim āha tattha paramattha tā ti iminā yā ayam yaḥ ciram jīvati
translated: “Therefore, because of the brevity of the moment of the mind, life is said to be fleeting and brief.

original: so vassasata”ntiādinā sattānaṃ jīvitappavatti vuttā, sā pabandhavisayattā vohāravasenāti
analyzed: so vassa sata nti ādinā sattānam jīvita ppavatti vuttā sā pabandha visaya ttā vohāra vasena ati
translated: “In the ultimate sense” : by this phrase the Blessed One rejects the statement about the duration of life in the world, which is given in terms of a hundred years, etc.,🔽as being within the domain of the conventional.

original: taṃ paṭikkhipati. “Atiparitto”ti iminā –
analyzed: tam paṭikkhipati atiparittaḥ ti iminā
translated: “Too brief” : by this phrase the Blessed One rejects the statement

original: “Seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, cattāro daḷhadhammā dhanuggahā susikkhitā katahatthā katūpāsanā
analyzed: seyyathā api bhikkhave cattāro daḷha dhammāḥ dhanuggahāḥ su sikkhitāḥ kata hatthāḥ kata upāsanāḥ
translated: that the life of beings is as long as the duration of a finger snap.

original: catuddisā ṭhitā assu, atha puriso āgaccheyya ‘ahaṃ imesaṃ…pe… katūpāsanānaṃ catuddisā
analyzed: catuddisā ṭhitāḥ assu atha purisaḥ āgaccheyya aham katūpāsanānam catuddisā
translated: and four people were standing in the four directions, and a man came up and said, ‘I’ll give you a hundred coins if you can kill these four people and bring me their four fingers.’🔽

original: kaṇḍe khitte appatiṭṭhite pathaviyaṃ gahetvā āharissāmī’ti. Yathā ca, bhikkhave,🔽tassa purisassa javo, yathā ca candimasūriyānaṃ javo, tato sīghataro. Yathā ca, bhikkhave,
analyzed: kaṇḍe khitte a patiṭṭhite pathaviyam gahetvā āharissāmi iti yathā ca bhikkhave  tassa purisassa javaḥ yathā ca candima sūriyānam javaḥ tatas sīghataraḥ yathā ca bhikkhave
translated: and a man came and said: ‘I will catch them before they have gone a quarter of a mile, before they have gone a quarter of a mile, and bring them back to you.’🔽And as the man’s speed is, so is the speed of the sun and moon.

original: tassa purisassa javo, yathā ca candimasūriyānaṃ javo, yathā ca yā devatā candimasūriyānaṃ🔽purato dhāvanti, tāsaṃ devatānaṃ javo, tato sīghataraṃ āyusaṅkhārā khīyantī”ti –🔽Evaṃ vuttaṃ parittampi paṭikkhipati. Tatra hi gamanassādānaṃ devaputtānaṃ heṭṭhupariyena
analyzed: tassa purisassa javaḥ yathā ca candima sūriyānam javaḥ yathā ca yā devatā candima sūriyānam  puratas dhāvanti tāsam devatānam sīghataram āyu saṅkhārā  evam vuttam parittam pi paṭikkhipati tatra hi gamanassa ādānam deva puttānam heṭṭhupariyena
translated: And as the man’s speed is, and as the speed of the sun and moon is, and as the speed of the deities who run in front of the sun and moon is,🔽so much swifter is the wearing out of the life of beings” .

original: paṭimukhaṃ dhāvantānaṃ sirasi, pāde ca baddhakhuradhārāsannipātatopi parittako rūpajīvitindriyassa
analyzed: paṭimukham sirasi pāde ca baddha khura dhārā sannipātataḥ pi parittakaḥ rūpa jīvita indriyassa
translated: So he rejects even the limited life span stated thus. For there the life span of the deities who enjoy magical transformations is limited by the time taken in running back and forth over the earth, which is bounded by the ocean, in the four quarters, beginning with the east, and in the intermediate quarters, beginning with the northeast, by one who runs with the speed of the deities who enjoy magical transformations, and who, after striking a point on the earth in the northeast with the tip of a blade of grass held by him, picks it up again before the grass has lost its sharpness.

original: so khaṇo vutto, cittassa pana ativiya parittataro, yassa upamāpi natthi. Tenevāha
analyzed: so khaṇaḥ vutto cittassa pana ativiya parittataraḥ yassa upamā api natthi tena iva āha
translated: That is called a moment. But the life span of consciousness is much more limited than that, for it has no simile. Hence it is said:

original: “yāvañcidaṃ, bhikkhave, upamāpi na sukarā, yāva lahuparivattaṃ citta”nti. Jīvitakkhaṇoti
analyzed: yāvat cidam bhikkhave upamā api na sukarā yāva lahu parivattam cittam ti
translated: “Bhikkhus, it is not easy to find a simile for how quickly consciousness changes.”🔽The moment of life:

original: jīvanakkhaṇo. Ekacittappavattimattoyeva ekassa cittassa pavattimatteneva sattānaṃ
analyzed: jīvana kkhaṇaḥ eka citta pavattimattaḥ yā iva ekassa cittassa pavattimattena iva sattānam
translated: the moment of living. For the moment of life of beings is delimited by the mere occurrence of a single consciousness, by the mere occurrence of a single consciousness-moment.

original: paramatthato jīvanakkhaṇassa paricchinnattā. Idāni tamatthaṃ upamāya pakāsento “yathā
analyzed: paramatthataḥ jīvana kkhaṇassa paricchinna ttā idāni tam attham upamāya pakāsentaḥ yathā
translated: Now, in order to illustrate that meaning by means of a simile, he said: “Just as …🔽occurs … a single moment of consciousness …

original: nāmā”tiādimāha. Tattha pavattamānanti pavattantaṃ. Ekacittakkhaṇikanti ekacittakkhaṇamattavantaṃ.🔽Tasmiṃ citte niruddhamatteti yena vattamānacittakkhaṇena “jīvatī”ti vuccati, tasmiṃ🔽citte nirodhaṃ bhaṅgaṃ pattamatte taṃsamaṅgī satto niruddho matoti vuccati. Vuttamevatthaṃ🔽pāḷiyā vibhāvetuṃ “yathāhā”tiādi vuttaṃ. Tena tīsupi kālesu sattānaṃ paramatthato
analyzed: nāma atiādim āha tattha pavattamānam iti pavattantam eka cittakkhaṇikam iti eka citta khaṇa mattavantam  tasmim citte niruddha matta iti yena vattamāna citta kkhaṇena jīvati iti vuccati tasmim  citte nirodham bhaṅgam patta matte taṃsamaṅgī sattaḥ niruddhaḥ mataḥ iti vuccati vuttam eva attham  pāḷiyā vibhāvetum yathā āha atiādi vuttam tena tīsu pi kālesu sattānam paramatthato
translated: the moment that consciousness ceases …🔽the being is said to be dead.” In order to elucidate the meaning stated by the text, he said: “Just as …

original: jīvanaṃ nāma cittakkhaṇavasenevāti dasseti.
analyzed: jīvanam nāma cittakkhaṇa vasena iva ati dasseti
translated: in all three instances the life of beings is in the ultimate sense only by way of the moment of consciousness.”

original: Jīvitanti jīvitindriyaṃ. Sukhadukkhāti sukhadukkhavedanā. Upekkhāpi hi sukhadukkhāsu
analyzed: jīvitanti jīvitindriyam sukha dukkhā ati sukha dukkha vedanā upekkhā api hi sukha dukkhāsu
translated: Life faculty: the life faculty. Pleasure and pain: the feelings of pleasure and pain. For equanimity is included in the feeling of indifference.

original: eva antogadhā iṭṭhāniṭṭhabhāvato. Attabhāvoti jīvitavedanāviññāṇāni ṭhapetvā avasiṭṭhadhammā🔽vuttā. Kevalāti attanā, niccabhāvena vā avomissā. Ekacittasamāyuttāti ekekena cittena🔽sahitā. Lahuso vattati khaṇoti vuttanayena ekacittakkhaṇikatāya lahuko atiittaro
analyzed: eva antogadhā iṭṭha aniṭṭha bhāvataḥ atta bhāvaḥ ti jīvita vedanā viññāṇāni ṭhapetvā avasiṭṭha dhammā  vuttā kevalā ati attanā nicca bhāvena vā avomissā eka citta samāyuttā ati ekekena cittena  sahitā lahusaḥ vattati khaṇo ti vutta nayena eka citta khaṇika tāya lahukaḥ ati ittaraḥ
translated: ‘Life’ is the life faculty. ‘Pleasure and pain’ are the feelings of pleasure and pain. Equanimity is included in these too, because it is desirable and undesirable. ‘The self’ is the states other than the life faculty, the feelings, and consciousness.

original: jīvitādīnaṃ khaṇo vattati.
analyzed: jīvita ādīnam khaṇaḥ vattati
translated: ‘Entirely’ means ‘by itself’ or ‘by its permanence.’ ‘In one thought-unit’ means ‘in one consciousness.’ ‘The moment of life, etc., passes swiftly’ means that the moment of life, etc., passes swiftly, more swiftly than the arising and falling away of a single consciousness, according to the method stated in the text.

original: Ye niruddhā marantassāti cavantassa sattassa cutito uddhaṃ “niruddhā”ti vattabbā
analyzed: ye niruddhāḥ marantassa ati cavantassa sattassa cutitaḥ uddham niruddhā ati vattabbā
translated: ‘Those that have ceased in one who is dying’ are the aggregates that should be called ‘ceased’ after the death of a being who is passing away.

original: ye khandhā. Tiṭṭhamānassa vā idhāti ye vā idha pavattiyaṃ tiṭṭhantassa dharantassa
analyzed: ye khandhāḥ tiṭṭhamānassa vai idha ati ye vai idha pavattiyam tiṭṭhantassa dharantassa
translated: ‘Or those that are present here’ are the aggregates that have ceased by reaching dissolution in one who is present here, who is continuing and existing.

original: bhaṅgappattiyā niruddhā khandhā. Sabbepi sadisā te sabbepi ekasadisā. Kathaṃ? Gatā
analyzed: bhaṅga ppattiyā niruddhā khandhā sabbe pi sadisā te sabbe pi eka sadisā katham gatā
translated: ‘All are the same’ means that all are the same in one way. How? They have gone

original: appaṭisandhikā puna āgantvā paṭisandhānābhāvena vigatā. Yathā hi cutikhandhā na nivattanti,
analyzed: appaṭisandhikā punar āgantvā paṭisandhāna abhāvena vigatā yathā hi cuti khandhāḥ na nivattanti
translated: and those that are not reborn are gone by not being reborn.

original: evaṃ tato pubbepi khandhā, tasmā ekacittakkhaṇikaṃ sattānaṃ jīvitanti adhippāyo.
analyzed: evam tatas pubbe api khandhāḥ tasmai eka citta khaṇikam sattānam jīvitanti adhippāyaḥ
translated: Just as the death-consciousness does not return, so too the prior aggregates do not return. That is why the intention is that the life of beings is momentary.

original: Anibbattena na jātoti anuppannena cittena jāto na hoti ajāto nāma hoti. Paccuppannena
analyzed: anibbattena na jātaḥ ti anuppannena cittena jātaḥ na hoti ajātaḥ nāma hoti paccuppannena
translated: Not born with the unborn: he is not born with the unarisen consciousness. He is called unborn.

original: vattamānena cittena jīvati jīvamāno nāma hoti. Cittabhaṅgā mato lokoti cuticittassa
analyzed: vattamānena cittena jīvati jīvamānaḥ nāma hoti citta bhaṅgā mataḥ cuti cittassa
translated: With the born he lives: he lives with the present, occurring consciousness. He is called living.🔽The world is dead with the cessation of consciousness: with the cessation of the death-consciousness,

original: viya sabbassapi tassa tassa cittassa bhaṅgappattiyā ayaṃ loko paramatthato mato nāma
analyzed: viya sabbassa api tassa tassa cittassa bhaṅga ppattiyā ayam loko paramatthataḥ mataḥ nāma
translated: and with the cessation of any consciousness whatever, this world is called dead in the ultimate sense,

original: hoti niruddhassa appaṭisandhikattā. Evaṃ santepi paññatti paramatthiyā yā taṃ taṃ🔽dharantaṃ cittaṃ upādāya “tisso jīvati, phusso jīvatī”ti vacanappavattiyā visayabhūtā
analyzed: hoti niruddhassa appaṭisandhika ttā evam sante pi paññatti paramatthiyā yā tam tam  dharantam cittam upādāya tissaḥ jīvati phussaḥ jīvati iti vacana ppavattiyā visaya bhūtā
translated: because of the non-rebirth of what has ceased.🔽But although that is so, the description of a continuity as a living being, which is the province of the statement “Tissa lives, Phussa lives,” is in the ultimate sense ultimate.

original: santānapaññatti, sā ettha paramatthiyā paramatthabhūtā. Tathā hi vadanti “nāmagottaṃ na jīratī”ti.
analyzed: santāna paññatti sā ettha paramatthiyā paramattha bhūtā tathā hi vadanti nāma gottam na jīrati iti
translated: For they say, “Name-and-surname does not grow old” .

original: 177. Aññataraññatarena ākārena. Cittanti kammaṭṭhānārammaṇaṃ cittaṃ. Āsevanaṃ labhatīti
analyzed: aññatara aññatarena ākārena cittam ti kammaṭṭhāna ārammaṇam cittam āsevanam labhati iti
translated: The consciousness: the consciousness that has the meditation subject as its object.🔽Obtains opportunity for repetition: obtains opportunity for development.

original: bhāvanāsevanaṃ labhati, bahiddhā vikkhepaṃ pahāya ekattavasena maraṇārammaṇameva
analyzed: bhāvanā sevanam labhati bahiddhā vikkhepam pahāya ekatta vasena maraṇa ārammaṇam eva
translated: For, after abandoning distraction on the outside, it has only the object of death as its object in the sense of singleness.🔽That is why it is said, “Mindfulness settles down upon the object of death” .

original: hotīti. Tenāha “maraṇārammaṇā sati santiṭṭhatī”ti. Sabhāvadhammānaṃ bhedo sabhāvadhammagatiko
analyzed: hoti iti tena āha maraṇa ārammaṇā sati santiṭṭhati iti sa bhāva dhammānam bhedaḥ sa bhāva dhamma gatikaḥ
translated: The dissolution of naturally perishable states is in accordance with the nature of what is perishable,🔽and that is why it is said, “But because the object is naturally perishable” .

original: evāti āha “sabhāvadhammattā pana ārammaṇassā”ti. Tenāha bhagavā “jarāmaraṇaṃ, bhikkhave,
analyzed: eva iti āha sa bhāva dhamma ttā pana ārammaṇassa ati tena āha bhagavā jarā maraṇam bhikkhave
translated: That is why the Blessed One said, “Bhikkhus, ageing and death are impermanent, formed, dependently arisen” , and so on.

original: aniccaṃ saṅkhataṃ paṭiccasamuppanna”ntiādi. Saṃvejanīyattāti saṃvegajananato mahābhūtesu
analyzed: aniccam saṅkhatam paṭicca samuppanna nti ādi saṃvejanīya ttā ati saṃvega jananataḥ mahābhūtesu
translated: It arouses a sense of urgency: it arouses urgency because it generates a sense of urgency.

original: mahāvikāratā viya gayhamānā maraṇaṃ anussariyamānaṃ uparūpari ubbegameva āvahatīti
analyzed: mahā vikāra tā viya gayhamānā maraṇam anussariyamānam upari upari ubbegam eva āvahati iti
translated: Death, when it is recollected in this way, produces a sense of urgency that increases more and more, as if it were a great and terrible thing.🔽So the development of consciousness cannot proceed in it.

original: tattha na bhāvanācittaṃ appetuṃ sakkoti. Yadi sabhāvadhammattā appanaṃ na pāpuṇāti,
analyzed: tattha na bhāvanā cittam appetum sakkoti yadi sa bhāva dhamma ttā appanam na pāpuṇāti
translated: If it does not reach absorption because of the natural liability to destruction of the object,

original: lokuttarajjhānaṃ ekaccāni arūpajjhānāni ca kathanti āha “lokuttarajjhānaṃ panā”tiādi.
analyzed: lokuttara jhānam ekaccāni arūpa jhānāni ca kathanti āha lokuttara jhānam pana atiādi
translated: how is it that it is said of the supramundane jhāna and of some of the immaterial jhānas that they have a “natural object”? That is why it is said, “But the supramundane jhāna” , and so on.

original: Visuddhibhāvanānukkamavasenāti heṭṭhimavisuddhiyā ānubhāvena adhigatātisayāya paṭipadāñāṇadassanavisuddhibhāvanāya,🔽sabbasaṅkhārehi nibbindanavirajjanādivisaṃyogādhimuttiappanāya ca paṭipakkhabhūtānaṃ🔽pāpadhammānaṃ vigamoti evaṃbhūtassa visuddhibhāvanānukkamassa vasena lokuttarajjhānaṃ
analyzed: visuddhi bhāvanā anukkama vasena ati heṭṭhima visuddhiyā ānubhāvena adhigata atisayāya paṭipadā āñāṇa dassana visuddhi bhāvanāya  sabba saṅkhārehi nibbindana virajjana ādi visaṃyoga adhimutti appanāya ca paṭipakkha bhūtānam  pāpa dhammānam vigamo ti evaṃbhūtassa visuddhi bhāvanā anukkamassa vasena lokuttara jhānam
translated: The supramundane jhāna is reached by the order of succession of purification of insight,

original: appanāppattameva hoti. Ārammaṇasamatikkamanamattaṃ tattha hotīti aññesaṃ sabhāvadhammārammaṇakammaṭṭhānānaṃ🔽viya cittassa samādhāne byāpāro natthi. Yathāsamāhitena pana cittena ārammaṇasamatikkamanamattameva🔽bhāvanāya kātabbaṃ, tasmā sabhāvadhammepi āruppajjhānaṃ appetīti.🔽Satataṃ appamatto hoti saṃvegabahulattā, tato evassa sabbabhavesu anabhiratisaññāpaṭilābho.
analyzed: appanā appattam eva hoti ārammaṇa samatikkamana mattam tattha hoti iti aññesam sa bhāva dhamma ārammaṇa kammaṭṭhānānam 🔽viya cittassa samādhāne byāpāraḥ natthi yathā samāhitena pana cittena ārammaṇa samatikkamana mattam eva 🔽bhāvanāya kātabbam tasmā sa bhāva dhamme pi āruppa jhānam appeti iti 🔽satatam appamattaḥ hoti saṃvega bahula ttā tatas evassa sabba bhavesu an abhirati saññā paṭilābho
translated: and it is the removal of the opposing states, that is, the unprofitable states, which are the opposite of the insight that is the knowledge and vision of the way, and of the insight that is the change-of-lineage, and of the insight that is the direct-knowledge of the way, and of the insight that is the direct-knowledge of the change-of-lineage, and of the insight that is the resolution of the tension of the mind, and of the insight that is the resolution of the tension of the mind’s object, and of the insight that is the resolution of the tension of both, and of the insight that is the equanimity about things, and of the insight that is the equanimity about both, and of the insight that is the equanimity about the profitable, and of the insight that is the equanimity about the unprofitable, and of the insight that is the equanimity about the neither-profitable-nor- unprofitable, and of the insight that is the equanimity about the past, and of the insight that is the equanimity about the future, and of the insight that is the equanimity about the present, and of the insight that is the equanimity about the internal, and of the insight that is the equanimity about the external, and of the insight that is the equanimity about the external and internal, and of the insight that is the equanimity about the great, and of the insight that is the equanimity about the immeasurable, and of the insight that is the equanimity about the base consisting of boundless space, and of the insight that is the equanimity about the base consisting of boundless consciousness, and of the insight that is the equanimity about the base consisting of nothingness, and of the insight that is the equanimity about the base consisting of neither perception nor non-perception, and of the insight that is the equanimity about the seen, and of the insight that is the equanimity about the heard, and of the insight that is the equanimity about the sensed, and of the insight that is the equanimity about the cognized, and of the insight that is the equanimity about the seen, heard, sensed, and cognized, and of the insight that is the equanimity about the seen, heard, sensed, cognized, and cognized as such, and of the insight that is the equanimity about the seen, heard, sensed,

original: Jīvitanikantiṃ jahāti maraṇassa avassaṃbhāvitādassanato. Pāpagarahī hoti aniccasaññāpaṭilābhato,
analyzed: jīvita nikantim jahāti maraṇassa avassaṃbhāvita a dassanataḥ pāpa garahī hoti anicca saññā paṭilābhato
translated: He abandons the craving for life because he sees death as inevitable. He is a critic of the pleasures of the round because he has acquired the perception of impermanence.

original: tato eva asannidhibahulatā, vigatamalamaccheratā ca. Tadanusārenāti aniccasaññāparicayānusārena.
analyzed: tatas eva asannidhi bahula tā vigata malam acchera tā ca tad anusārena ati anicca saññā paricaya anusārena
translated: And because of that he has little attachment, and he is free from stain and avarice. ‘In accordance with that’: in accordance with the practice of the perception of impermanence.

original: Abhāvitamaraṇāti abhāvitamaraṇānussaraṇā. Abhayo asammūḷho kālaṃ karoti pageva maraṇasaññāya sūpaṭṭhitattā.
analyzed: abhāvita maraṇā ati abhāvita maraṇa anussaraṇā abhayaḥ asammūḷho kālam karoti pagā iva maraṇa saññāya su upaṭṭhita ttā
translated: ‘Not developed death’: not developed recollection of death. He dies fearless and undeluded, all the more so because of the well-established perception of death.

original: Kāyagatāsatikathāvaṇṇanā
analyzed: kāya gata asati kathā vaṇṇanā
translated: The explanation of the “development of mindfulness occupied with the body” is ended.🔽The “arising of Buddhas” is the time when Buddhas arise.

original: 178. Buddhā uppajjanti etthāti buddhuppādo, buddhānaṃ uppajjanakālo, tasmā. Aññatra
analyzed: buddhāḥ uppajjanti ettha ati buddhuppādaḥ buddhānam uppajjana kālo tasmai aññatra
translated: “Elsewhere” means “except there.”

original: taṃ ṭhapetvā, aññasmiṃ kāleti attho. Na pavattapubbanti apavattapubbaṃ. Tato eva
analyzed: tam ṭhapetvā aññasmin kāle ti atthaḥ na pavatta pubbam ti apavatta pubbam tatas eva
translated: It is not previously known, and therefore🔽it is not the province of any sectarians.

original: sabbatitthiyānaṃ avisayabhūtaṃ. Nanu ca sunettasatthārādayo, aññe ca tāpasaparibbājakā
analyzed: sabba titthiyānam avisaya bhūtam nanu ca sunetta satthāra ādayo aññe ca tāpasa paribbājakā
translated: But did not Sunetta and other teachers, and other ascetics and wanderers,

original: sarīraṃ “asubha”nti jāniṃsu. Tathā hi sumedhatāpasena sarīraṃ jigucchantena vuttaṃ –
analyzed: sarīram asubhanti jāniṃsu tathā hi sumedha tāpasena sarīram jigucchantena vuttam
translated: know the body as foul? For this was said by the ascetic Sumedha when he was disgusted with the body:

original: “Yannūnimaṃ pūtikāyaṃ, nānākuṇapapūritaṃ;
analyzed: yat nūnam imam pūti kāyam nānā kuṇapa pūritam
translated: Which is foul and filled with various impurities,

original: Chaḍḍayitvāna gaccheyyaṃ, anapekkho anatthiko”ti. –
analyzed: chaḍḍayitvāna gaccheyyam anapekkhaḥ anatthikaḥ ti
translated: And go away, without concern, without regret.”

original: Ādi. Kāmaṃ bodhisattā, aññe ca tāpasādayo sarīraṃ “asubha”nti jānanti, kammaṭṭhānabhāvena
analyzed: ādi kāmam bodhisattāḥ aññe ca tāpasa ādayo sarīram asubhanti jānanti kammaṭṭhāna bhāvena
translated: Although the Bodhisattas and other ascetics know the body as foul, they do not know it as a subject of meditation.

original: pana na jānanti. Tena vuttaṃ “aññatra buddhuppādā”tiādi. Saṃvegāya saṃvattati yāthāvato
analyzed: pana na jānanti tena vuttam aññatra buddha uppāda āti ādi saṃvegāya saṃvattati yāthāvato
translated: Therefore it is said: “Except when a Buddha arises.”🔽It leads to a sense of spiritual urgency because it reveals the true nature of the body.

original: kāyasabhāvappavedanato. Atthāyāti diṭṭhadhammikādiatthāya. Yogakkhemāyāti catūhi🔽yogehi khemabhāvāya. Satisampajaññāyāti sabbattha satiavippavāsāya ca sattaṭṭhāniyasampajaññāya
analyzed: kāya sabhāva ppavedanataḥ atthāya ati diṭṭhadhammika ādi atthāya yogakkhemāya ati catūhi  yogehi khema bhāvāya sati sampajaññāya ati sabbattha sati a vippavāsāya ca satta ṭṭhāniya sampajaññāya
translated: It is for one’s welfare because it leads to the attainment of the four noble persons beginning with the stream-enterer.🔽It is for one’s security because it leads to the attainment of security from the four bonds.🔽It is for the attainment of mindfulness and clear comprehension because it leads to the non-abandonment of mindfulness and to the clear comprehension of the seven stations of consciousness.

original: ca. Ñāṇadassanapaṭilābhāyāti vipassanāñāṇādhigamāya. Vijjāvimuttiphalasacchikiriyāyāti
analyzed: ca ñāṇa dassana paṭilābhāya ati vipassanā ñāṇa adhigamāya vijjā vimutti phala sacchikiriyāya ati
translated: It is for the attainment of knowledge and insight because it leads to the acquisition of the knowledge of insight.

original: tisso vijjā, cittassa adhimutti nibbānaṃ, cattāri sāmaññaphalānīti etesaṃ paccakkhakaraṇāya.
analyzed: tissaḥ vijjā cittassa adhimutti nibbānam cattāri sāmañña phalāni iti etesam paccakkha karaṇāya
translated: It is for the realization of the fruit of knowledge and freedom because it leads to the realization of the three kinds of knowledge and the four fruits of recluseship.

original: Amatassa nibbānassa adhigamahetutāya, amatasadisātappakasukhasahitatāya ca kāyagatāsati
analyzed: amatassa nibbānassa adhigama hetutāya amata sadisa ātappaka sukha sahita tāya ca kāyagata asati
translated: It is called “deathless” because it is the cause for attaining the deathless Nibbāna, and because it is accompanied by the bliss similar to the deathless.

original: “amata”nti vuttā. Paribhuñjantīti jhānasamāpajjanena vaḷañjanti. Parihīnanti jinaṃ.
analyzed: vuttā paribhuñjanti iti jhāna samāpajjanena vaḷañjanti jinam
translated: “One who enjoys it” is one who makes use of it by attaining the jhānas. “One who has lost it” is one who has failed to attain it.

original: Viraddhanti anadhigamena virajjhitaṃ. Āraddhanti sādhitaṃ nipphāditaṃ. Anekehi ākārehi
analyzed: viraddhanti anadhigamena virajjhitam āraddhanti sādhitam nipphāditam anekehi ākārehi
translated: “One who is without relish for it” is one who has no relish for it because he has not attained it. “One who has undertaken it” is one who has accomplished it, who has produced it.

original: tesu tesu suttantesu pasaṃsitvā yaṃ taṃ kāyagatāsatikammaṭṭhānaṃ niddiṭṭhanti sambandho.🔽Kattha pana niddiṭṭhanti? Kāyagatāsatisutte. Tattha hi “kathaṃ bhāvitā ca bhikkhave”tiādinā
analyzed: tesu tesu suttantesu pasaṃsitvā yam tam kāya gata asati kammaṭṭhānam niddiṭṭhanti sambandho  kattha pana niddiṭṭhanti kāyagata asati sutte tattha hi katham bhāvitā ca bhikkhave iti ādinā
translated: Having thus praised the meditation subject of mindfulness of the body in many a way, he now concludes the sutta by means of the words “I have taught you how the meditation subject of mindfulness of the body is developed and pursued.”🔽But where was it taught? In the Kāyagatāsati Sutta. For that is where this teaching occurs beginning with the words “And how, bhikkhus, is mindfulness of the body developed?”

original: ayaṃ desanā āgatā. Tatrāyaṃ saṅkhepattho – bhikkhave, kena pakārena kāyagatāsatibhāvanā
analyzed: ayam desanā āgatā tatra ayam saṅkhepa atthaḥ bhikkhave kena pakārena kāya gata asati bhāvanā
translated: Here is the meaning in brief: “Bhikkhus, in what way is the development of mindfulness of the body developed?

original: bhāvitā, kena ca pakārena punappunaṃ katā ānāpānajjhānādīnaṃ nipphattiyā mahapphalā,
analyzed: bhāvitā kena ca pakārena punappunam katā āna apāna jhāna ādīnam nipphattiyāḥ mahapphalā
translated: In what way is it repeatedly undertaken? In what way does it bring great fruit and bring great advantages?

original: tesaṃ tesaṃ vijjābhāgiyānaṃ, abhiññāsacchikaraṇīyānañca dhammānaṃ, aratiratisahanatādīnañca
analyzed: tesam tesam vijjā bhāgiyānam abhiññā sacchikaraṇīyānam ca dhammānam arati rati sahana tā ādīnam ca
translated: and for the success of the various kinds of knowledge, of the things to be realized by direct knowledge, and of the endurance of pain, etc.,

original: saṃsiddhiyā mahānisaṃsā ca hotīti? Ānāpānapabbanti ānāpānakammaṭṭhānāvadhi. Esa nayo sesesupi.
analyzed: saṃsiddhiyāḥ mahānisaṃsā ca hoti iti āna āpāna pabbanti āna āpāna kammaṭṭhāna avadhi esa nayo sesesu pi
translated: and it has great advantages. The “end of in-breaths and out-breaths” is the meditation subject consisting of in-breaths and out-breaths. The same method applies in the case of the rest.

original: Dhātumanasikārakammaṭṭhānena yadipi upacārasamādhi ijjhati, sammasanavāro pana tattha
analyzed: dhātu manasikāra kammaṭṭhānena yadi pi upacāra samādhi ijjhati sammasana vāraḥ pana tattha
translated: Although access concentration is successful with the meditation subject of the measureless states,

original: sātisayoti dhātumanasikārapabbampi “vipassanāvasena vutta”nti vuttaṃ. “Ayampi kho
analyzed: sa atisayaḥ ti vipassanā vasena vuttanti vuttam ayam pi kho
translated: the “end of the measureless states” is mentioned in order to show that absorption is not reached without the abandoning of lust, etc.,

original: kāyo evaṃdhammo evaṃbhāvī evaṃanatīto”ti tattha tattha asubhāniccatādīhi saddhiṃ🔽kāye ādīnavassa vibhāvanavasena desanāya āgatattā “navasivathika…pe… vuttānī”ti vuttaṃ.🔽Ettha uddhumātakādīsūti etesu sivathikapabbesu āgatauddhumātakādīsu. Ānāpānassativasenāti
analyzed: kāyaḥ evaṃdhammaḥ evaṃbhāvī evam anatītaḥ ti tattha tattha asubha anicca tā ādīhi saddhiṃ  kāye ādīnavassa vibhāvana vasena desanāya āgata ttā vuttāni iti vuttam  ettha uddhumātaka ādīsu iti etesu sivathika pabbesu āgata oddhumātaka ādīsu āna apāna ssati vasena ati
translated: and because it is said: “This body has such a nature, has such a constitution, has not got beyond such a state” .🔽The “end of the charnel ground” is mentioned in order to show that the meditation subject is successful with the thirty-two aspects, etc.,🔽and because it is said: “This body has such a nature, has such a constitution, has not got beyond such a state” .

original: ānāpānassatibhāvanāvasena. Yo upari “karīsaṃ matthaluṅga”nti matthaluṅgakoṭṭhāso
analyzed: āna apāna ssati bhāvanā vasena yaḥ upari karīsam matthaluṅganti matthaluṅga koṭṭhāsaḥ
translated: The “end of in-breaths and out-breaths” is mentioned in order to show that the meditation subject is successful with the four arisings of mindfulness that have in-breaths and out-breaths as their object,🔽and because it is said: “This body has such a nature, has such a constitution, has not got beyond such a state” .

original: gayhati, taṃ idha pāḷiyaṃ aṭṭhimiñjeneva saṅgaṇhitvā desanā āgatāti dassento “matthaluṅgaṃ🔽aṭṭhimiñjena saṅgahetvā”ti āha. Idhāti imasmiṃ anussatiniddese. Kāyaṃ gatā, kāye
analyzed: gayhati tam idha pāḷiyam aṭṭhimiñjena iva saṅgaṇhitvā desanā āgatā ati dassentaḥ mattha luṅgam  aṭṭhimiñjena saṅgahetvā iti āha idha ati imasmin anussati niddese kāyam gatā kāye
translated: He shows that the bone-marrow is included in the description here by the word “bone” in the text.🔽Here in this description of the recollection of the body.

original: vā gatā sati kāyagatāsatīti satisīsena idaṃ dvattiṃsākārakammaṭṭhānaṃ adhippetanti yojanā.
analyzed: vā gatā sati kāya gatā asati iti sati sīsena idam dvattiṃsa ākāra kammaṭṭhānam adhippetanti yojanā
translated: The meaning is that the meditation subject consisting of the thirty-two aspects is intended here under the heading of mindfulness.🔽The four great elements: having the four great entities as its support.

original: 179. Catumahābhūtikanti catumahābhūtasannissayaṃ. Pūtikāyanti pūtibhūtaṃ paramaduggandhakāyaṃ.
analyzed: catu mahābhūtikam ti catu mahābhūta sannissayam pūtikāyam iti pūtibhūtam parama duggandha kāyam
translated: Corpse: a body that is rotten, become a most foul-smelling corpse.

original: Ṭhānagamanāvatthaṃ sarīraṃ sandhāya, tassa vā avayavesu sabbaheṭṭhimaṃ pādatalanti🔽vuttaṃ “uddhaṃ pādatalā”ti. Tiriyaṃ tacaparicchinnanti ettha nanu kesalomanakhānaṃ,
analyzed: ṭhāna gamana avattham sarīram sandhāya tassa vā avayavesu sabbaheṭṭhimam pāda talanti  vuttam uddham pāda talāti tiriyam taca paricchinnan ti ettha nanu kesa loma nakhānam
translated: The meaning is, referring to the body with its parts, the feet being the lowest part of all.🔽As to the direction: the feet are below, the head is above.🔽As to the surrounding space: the meaning is, as to the surrounding space that is limited by the skin.

original: tacassa ca atacaparicchinnatā atthīti? Kiñcāpi atthi, tacaparicchinnabahulatāya pana
analyzed: tacassa ca a taca paricchinna tā atthi iti kiñcā api atthi taca paricchinna bahula tāya pana
translated: But have not the head hairs, body hairs, and nails, and the skin itself, a surrounding space that is limited by something else?🔽Though that is so, still the body’s surrounding space is limited by the skin,

original: kāyassa tacaparicchinnatā hotīti evaṃ vuttaṃ. Taco pariyanto assāti tacapariyantoti
analyzed: kāyassa taca paricchinna tā hoti iti evam vuttam tacaḥ pariyantaḥ assa ati taca pariyantaḥ ti
translated: and that is why it is said as it is.🔽The skin is the outer limit, thus it is the outer skin.

original: etena pana vacanena kāyekadesabhūto taco gahito eva, tappaṭibaddhā ca kesādayo tadanupaviṭṭhamūlā
analyzed: etena pana vacanena kāya ekadesa bhūto tacaḥ gahitaḥ eva tad paṭibaddhā ca kesa ādayo tad anupaviṭṭha mūlā
translated: But by this statement the skin, which is a part of the body, is included, and the head hairs, etc., which are bound up with it, are included too, since they are rooted in the skin and end in it.

original: tacapariyantāva hontīti dvattiṃsākārasamūho sabbopi kāyo tacapariyanto vuttoti veditabbo.
analyzed: taca pariyantā ava honti iti dvattiṃsa ākāra samūho sabbaḥ api kāyo taca pariyantaḥ vuttaḥ iti veditabbaḥ
translated: So the whole thirty-two-fold item is called “the body ending in skin.”🔽The word “is” is stated by way of a misreading of the text, or it is a locative expression.

original: Atthīti vacanavipallāsena vuttaṃ, nipātapadaṃ vā etaṃ. Tasmā tīsupi saṅkhāsu tadevassa
analyzed: atthi iti vacana vipallāsena vuttam nipāta padam vā etam tasmā tīsu pi saṅkhāsu tad evassa
translated: So in all three instances it is the same materiality.🔽That is why he said “exists.”

original: rūpaṃ. Tenāha “saṃvijjantī”ti. Akkharacintakehi sarīre kāya-saddaṃ vaṇṇantehipi asucisamudāyabhāveneva
analyzed: rūpam tena āha saṃvijjanti iti akkhara cintakehi sarīre kāya saddam vaṇṇantehi pi asuci samudāya bhāvena iva
translated: When grammarians expound the word kāya in the sense of a collection,🔽he shows that it should be accepted as a collection of impurities.

original: icchitabboti dassento “asucisañcayato”ti vatvā puna naṃ niruttinayena dassetuṃ “kucchitāna”ntiādi
analyzed: icchitabbaḥ iti dassentaḥ asuci sañcayato ti vatvā puna nam nirutti nayena dassetum kucchitāna nti ādi
translated: Having done so, he then says “of what is contemptible” in order to point it out by way of a definition.🔽Herein, as to “the source of arising”: because it is the source of arising.

original: vuttaṃ. Tattha āyabhūtatoti uppattiṭṭhānabhūtattā. “Pūraṃ nānappakārassā”ti vuttaṃ.
analyzed: vuttam tattha āya bhūtato ti uppatti ṭṭhāna bhūta ttā pūram nānappakārassa ati vuttam
translated: “Filled with various kinds of” is said.🔽“But what are these kinds by which the various kinds of impurity are spoken of?” In order to point out the head hairs, etc.,

original: “Ke pana te pakārā? Yehi nānappakāraṃ asuci vutta”nti te kesādike dassetuṃ pāḷiyaṃ
analyzed: ke pana te pakārāḥ yehi nānappakāram asuci vuttan ti te kesa ādike dassetum pāḷiyam
translated: he said:

original: “kesā lomā”tiādi vuttanti imamatthaṃ dīpento āha “ete kesādayo dvattiṃsākārā”ti.
analyzed: kesāḥ loma atiādi vuttanti imam attham dīpentaḥ āha ete kesa ādayaḥ dvattiṃsa ākārā iti
translated: “Head hairs, body hairs” and so on is said. He shows the meaning of this by the words “These head hairs and so on are the thirty-two aspects.”

original: Ākārā pakārāti hi eko atthoti. Evaṃ sambandhoti “atthi imasmiṃ kāye nakhā”tiādinā
analyzed: ākārā pakārā ti hi ekaḥ attho ti evam sambandho ti atthi imasmin kāye nakha ati ādinā
translated: For “aspects” and “parts” have the same meaning. The construction is thus: “There are in this body” and so on.

original: sabbakoṭṭhāsesu “atthi imasmiṃ kāye”ti padattayena sambandho veditabbo.
analyzed: sabba koṭṭhāsesu atthi imasmin kāye iti padattayena sambandhaḥ veditabbo
translated: The construction should be understood thus in all the sections.

original: Paritoti tiriyaṃ, samantato vā pādatalakesamūlesu ca tacassa labbhanato. Sucibhāvanti sucino sabbhāvaṃ, sucimeva vā.
analyzed: paritas ti tiriyam samantataḥ vā pāda tala kesa mūlesu ca tacassa labbhanataḥ suci bhāvanti sucino sabbhāvam sucim eva vā
translated: “All round” means all over, or else it is said thus because it is found in the soles of the feet and the roots of the nails. “The nature of foulness” is the individual essence of foulness, or else it is foulness itself.

original: 180. Yena vidhinā uggahe kusalo hoti, so sattavidho vidhi “uggahakosalla”nti vuccati, tannibbattaṃ vā ñāṇaṃ. Manasikārakosallepi eseva nayo.
analyzed: yena vidhinā uggahe kusalaḥ hoti so sattavidhaḥ vidhi uggaha kosallanti vuccati tad nibbattam vā ñāṇam manasikāra kosalle pi esā iva nayo
translated: The method by which one is skilled in learning is called “skill in learning” or else the knowledge that arises is so called. The same method applies to skill in giving attention.

original: Sajjhāyantā vāti sajjhāyaṃ karontā eva. Tesaṃ kira cattāro māse sajjhāyantānaṃ sajjhāyamaggeneva
analyzed: sajjhāyantā vāti sajjhāyam karontā eva tesam kira cattāraḥ māse sajjhāyantānam sajjhāya maggena iva
translated: “As they were developing” means as they were doing the development. It seems that they were developing it for four months. As they were doing the development,

original: koṭṭhāse upadhārentānaṃ paṭipāṭiyā dvattiṃsākārā vibhūtatarā hutvā khāyiṃsu, paṭikkūlasaññā
analyzed: koṭṭhāse upadhārentānam paṭipāṭiyā dvattiṃsa ākārāḥ vibhūtatarāḥ hutvā khāyiṃsu paṭikkūla saññā
translated: the thirty-two aspects became more evident to them as they kept defining them in order by means of the meditation subject of foulness. The perception of foulness

original: saṇṭhāsi, te tasmiṃ nimitte jhānaṃ appetvā jhānapādakaṃ vipassanaṃ vaḍḍhetvā dassanamaggaṃ
analyzed: te tasmim nimitte jhānam appetvā jhāna pādakam vipassanam vaḍḍhetvā dassana maggaṃ
translated: They settled down, and after attaining jhāna in that sign, they extended the insight that had jhāna as its proximate cause, and they penetrated to the path of seeing.

original: paṭivijjhiṃsu. Tena vuttaṃ “sajjhāyantā va sotāpannā ahesu”nti.
analyzed: paṭivijjhiṃsu tena vuttam sajjhāyantāḥ va sotāpannāḥ ahesun ti
translated: That is why it was said above: “They became stream-enterers while they were still occupied in developing.”

original: Paricchinditvāti tacapañcakādivaseneva paricchedaṃ katvā. Pathavīdhātubahulabhāvato
analyzed: paricchinditvā iti taca pañcaka ādi vasena iva paricchedam katvā pathavī dhātu bahula bhāvataḥ
translated: Having defined: having made a definition by means of the fivefold skin group, etc.,🔽The marrow is like the last part of the dung of a cow because of the abundance of the earth element in it.

original: matthaluṅgassa karīsāvasāne tantiāropanamāha. Ettha ca maṃsaṃ, nhāru, aṭṭhi, aṭṭhimiñjaṃ
analyzed: matthaluṅgassa karīsa avasāne tanti āropanam āha ettha ca maṃsam nhāru aṭṭhi aṭṭhimiñjam
translated: Herein, flesh, sinew, bone, bone-marrow,

original: vakkaṃ, vakkaṃ aṭṭhimiñjaṃ, aṭṭhi, nhāru, maṃsaṃ, taco, dantā, nakhā, lomā, kesāti🔽evaṃ vakkapañcakādīsu anulomasajjhāyaṃ vatvā paṭilomasajjhāyo purimehi sambandho🔽vutto. Svāyaṃ sammohavinodaniyaṃ visuṃ tipañcāhaṃ, purimehi ekato tipañcāhanti chapañcāhaṃ
analyzed: vakkam vakkam aṭṭhimiñjam aṭṭhi nhāru maṃsam tacaḥ dantāḥ nakhāḥ lomā kesā ati  evam vakka pañcaka ādīsu anuloma sajjhāyam vatvā paṭiloma sajjhāyaḥ purimehi sambandhaḥ  vuttaḥ sammoha vinodaniyam visum ti pañcāham purimehi ekatas ti pañcāhan ti cha pañcāham
translated: kidney, kidney-marrow, bone, sinew, flesh, skin, teeth, nails, body hairs, head hairs🔽are the order in the fivefold kidney group, etc.,🔽and the order of the order of reviewing is stated in the opposite way.🔽This is the order of reviewing stated separately in the Dispelling of Error for five days, and with the preceding for five days, making ten days.🔽Herein, it should be regarded as stated by way of the beginning and end.

original: sajjhāyo vutto, tattha ādiantadassanavasena vuttoti daṭṭhabbo. Anulomapaṭilomasajjhāyepi
analyzed: sajjhāyaḥ vuttaḥ tattha ādi anta dassana vasena vutto ti daṭṭhabbo anuloma paṭiloma sajjhāye pi
translated: In the case of the order of reviewing and the reverse order of reviewing too,

original: hi paṭilomasajjhāyo antimo hoti, sajjhāyappakārantaraṃ vā etampīti veditabbaṃ.
analyzed: hi paṭiloma sajjhāyaḥ antimaḥ hoti sajjhāya ppakāra antaram vā etam pi iti veditabbam
translated: for it is the last in the order of the forward numerical series, or else it is so called because it is a different kind of recitation.

original: Hatthasaṅkhalikāti aṅgulipantimāha.
analyzed: hattha saṅkhalikā iti aṅguli pantim āha
translated: ‘Hand-to-hand’ is the last of the fingers.

original: Manasā sajjhāyoti cittena cintanamāha, yaṃ mānasaṃ “jappana”nti vuccati, sammadeva
analyzed: manasā sajjhāyaḥ iti cittena cintanam āha yam mānasam jappananti vuccati sammad eva
translated: ‘Recitation with the mind’ is thinking with the mind, which is called ‘mental recitation.’🔽‘Recitation in the way stated’ is the meaning of ‘recitation.’

original: ajjhāyoti vā sajjhāyo, cintananti attho. Cirataraṃ suṭṭhu pavattanena paguṇabhūtā
analyzed: ajjhāyo ti vā sajjhāyo cintananti attho cirataram suṭṭhu pavattanena paguṇa bhūtā
translated: Because it occurs well for a long time, the meditation subject becomes familiarized.

original: kammaṭṭhānatanti samāvajjitvā manasi karontassa ādito paṭṭhāya yāva pariyosānā katthaci
analyzed: kammaṭṭhāna tanti samāvajjitvā manasi karontassa āditaḥ paṭṭhāya yāva pariyosānā katthaci
translated: ‘Meditation subject’ is what is given attention to and kept in mind.🔽From the beginning onwards it appears to one who does so without interruption, without a break anywhere,

original: asajjamānā nirantarameva upaṭṭhāti, tadanusārena tadatthopi vibhūtataro hutvā khāyatīti
analyzed: a sajjamānā nirantaram eva upaṭṭhāti tad anusārena tad atthaḥ api vibhūtataraḥ hutvā khāyati iti
translated: and the meaning appears to him as more evident than the sound.🔽That is why it is said, ‘For the recitation with speech … is a condition for penetration.’

original: āha “vacasā sajjhāyo hi…pe… paṭivedhassa paccayo hotī”ti. Lakkhaṇapaṭivedhassāti
analyzed: āha vacasā sajjhāyaḥ hipe paṭivedhassa paccayaḥ hoti iti lakkhaṇa paṭivedhassa ati
translated: ‘For the penetration of the characteristic’:

original: asubhalakkhaṇapaṭivedhassa.
analyzed: asubha lakkhaṇa paṭivedhassa
translated: for the penetration of the characteristic of foulness.

original: Paṭikkūlasabhāvasallakkhaṇassa kassaci vaṇṇaggahaṇamukhena koṭṭhāsā vavatthānaṃ gacchanti,
analyzed: paṭikkūla sabhāva sat lakkhaṇassa kassaci vaṇṇa ggahaṇa mukhena koṭṭhāsāḥ vavatthānam gacchanti
translated: In some people the delimitation of the parts comes about by apprehending the colour.

original: kassaci saṇṭhānaggahaṇamukhena, kassaci disāvibhāgaggahaṇamukhena, kassaci patiṭṭhitokāsaggahaṇamukhena,
analyzed: kassaci saṇṭhāna ggahaṇa mukhena kassaci disā vibhāga ggahaṇa mukhena kassaci patiṭṭhita ukāsa ggahaṇa mukhena
translated: for some by the way of apprehending the shape, for some by the way of apprehending the division of the directions, for some by the way of apprehending the location of the foundation,

original: kassaci sabbaso paricchijjaggahaṇamukhenāti vaṇṇādito sallakkhaṇaṃ uggahakosallāvahaṃ
analyzed: kassaci sabbaso paricchijja ggahaṇa mukhena ati vaṇṇa āditaḥ sat lakkhaṇam uggaha kosalla āvaham
translated: for some by the way of apprehending the delimitation of all. The discerning of colour and so on is said to be conducive to skill in learning.

original: vuttanti taṃ dassento “kesādīnaṃ vaṇṇo vavatthapetabbo”tiādimāha.
analyzed: vuttanti tam dassentaḥ kesa ādīnam vaṇṇaḥ vavatthapetabbaḥ iti ādim āha
translated: Showing that, he said: “The colour of the head-hairs should be defined,” etc.

original: Attano bhāgo sabhāgo, sabhāgena paricchedo sabhāgaparicchedo, heṭṭhuparitiriyapariyantehi,
analyzed: attanaḥ bhāgo sa bhāgaḥ sa bhāgena paricchedaḥ sa bhāga paricchedaḥ heṭṭhu paritiriya pariyantehi
translated: One’s own portion is a like portion. The delimitation by a like portion is the delimitation by a like portion. The meaning is: the delimitation by the lower and upper limits,

original: sakoṭṭhāsikakesantarādīhi ca paricchedoti attho. Amissakatāvasenāti koṭṭhāsantarehi
analyzed: sa koṭṭhāsika kesantara ādīhi ca paricchedaḥ ti attho amissaka tā vasena ati koṭṭhāsa antarehi
translated: and by one’s own section, the middle of the head-hairs, etc. By the method of non-mixture: by the method of non-mixture with the sections.

original: avomissakatāvasena. Asabhāgo hi idha “visabhāgo”ti adhippeto, na viruddhasabhāgo.
analyzed: avomissaka tā vasena asabhāgaḥ hi idha visabhāgaḥ ti adhippetaḥ na viruddha sabhāgaḥ
translated: For a unlike portion is intended here as “a different portion,” not as a contrary like portion.

original: Svāyamattho kesādisaddato eva labbhati. Saddantaratthāpohanavasena saddo atthaṃ vadatīti
analyzed: kesa ādi saddataḥ eva labbhati sadda antara ttha apohana vasena saddaḥ attham vadati iti
translated: This meaning is obtained even from the word “head-hairs.” A word expresses a meaning by the method of exclusion of the opposite.

original: “kesā”ti vutte “akesā na hontī”ti ayamattho viññāyati. Ke pana te akesā? Lomādayo,
analyzed: kesā ati vutte a kesāḥ na honti iti ayam attho viññāyati ke pana te a kesāḥ loma ādayo
translated: When “head-hairs” is said, this meaning is known: “They are not not-head-hairs.” But what are those not-head-hairs? Body-hairs, etc.

original: na ca ghaṭādīsu pasaṅgopakaraṇeneva tesaṃ nivattitattā.
analyzed: na ca ghaṭa ādīsu pasaṅga upakaraṇena iva tesam nivattita ttā
translated: and not because of the need to turn away from pots, etc., as though they were obstacles to the attainment of jhāna.🔽It is called “repulsive” only because of the repulsive aspect, not because of the aspect of elements, which is common to all.

original: Paṭikkūlavaseneva kathitaṃ dhātuvibhāgassa sāmaññatopi agahitattā. Tattheva visuṃ🔽dhātukammaṭṭhānassa kathitattā ca dhātuvibhaṅgo pakkusātisuttaṃ vibhaṅgappakaraṇe🔽dhātuvibhaṅgapāḷi ca. Yassa vaṇṇato upaṭṭhāti kesādi, taṃ puggalaṃ sandhāya jhānāni
