analyzed: paṭikkūla vasena iva kathitam dhātu vibhāgassa sāmaññataḥ pi a gahita ttā tattha iva visum  dhātu kammaṭṭhānassa kathita ttā ca dhātu vibhaṅgaḥ pakkusāti suttam vibhaṅga ppakaraṇe  ca yassa vaṇṇataḥ upaṭṭhāti kesa ādi tam puggalam sandhāya jhānāni
translated: And it is called “meditation subject consisting of elements” in the Vibhaṅga, in the Paṭṭhāna,🔽and in the Dhātuvibhaṅga Piṭaka.🔽The kasiṇas consisting of colour that are mentioned in the Vibhaṅga in the case of the jhānas in the description of the jhāna factors beginning with “born of seclusion” are so called because they are the proximate cause for the jhāna that is born of seclusion, etc.,

original: kesādīsu vaṇṇakasiṇārammaṇāni vibhattāni. Ñatvā ācikkhitabbanti yadatthaṃ vuttaṃ,
analyzed: kesa ādīsu vaṇṇa kasiṇa ārammaṇāni vibhattāni ñatvā ācikkhitabbanti yadattham vuttam
translated: and they are mentioned in the Vibhaṅga in the case of the jhānas in the description of the jhāna factors beginning with “born of seclusion” in order to show the kind of object each jhāna factor has.🔽“Herein, by the elements’ method” is said in order to show the purpose for which that was said.

original: taṃ dassetuṃ “tattha dhātuvasenā”tiādi vuttaṃ. Idhāti imasmiṃ paṭikkūlamanasikārapabbe.
analyzed: tam dassetum tattha dhātu vasena atiādi vuttam idha āti imasmim paṭikkūla manasikāra pabbe
translated: Here means in this meditation subject consisting in contemplation of the repulsive.

original: Kāyagatāsatisutte hi paṭikkūlamanasikārapabbaṃ gahetvā idha kāyagatāsatibhāvanā niddisīyati.
analyzed: kāyagata asati sutte hi paṭikkūla manasikāra pabbam gahetvā idha kāyagata asati bhāvanā niddisīyati
translated: For in the Kāyagatāsati Sutta the meditation subject consisting in contemplation of the repulsive is taken as the meditation subject for the development of mindfulness occupied with the body.

original: 181. Na ekantarikāyāti ekantarikāyapi na manasi kātabbaṃ, pageva dvantarikādināti
analyzed: na eka antarikāya ati na manasi kātabbam pageva dvantarika ādinā iti
translated: Not in the middle of the body: he should not give attention to it in the middle of the body, nor yet in the extremities, nor in the back, nor in the belly.

original: adhippāyo. Na bhāvanaṃ sampādeti, lakkhaṇapaṭivedhaṃ na pāpuṇāti ekantarikāya manasi🔽karontoti sambandho.🔽Okkamanavissajjananti paṭipajjitabbavissajjetabbe magge. Pucchitvāva gantabbaṃ hoti
analyzed: adhippāyaḥ na bhāvanam sampādeti lakkhaṇa paṭivedham na pāpuṇāti ekantarikāya manasi  karontaḥ iti sambandhaḥ  okkamana vissajjanam ti paṭipajjitabba vissajjetabbe magge pucchitvā ava gantabbam hoti
translated: The meaning is: he does not perfect his development, he does not reach the penetration of the characteristic of foulness.🔽He does not reach the end of the meditation subject: the meaning is that his attention is given only to the meditation subject without reaching the end of it.🔽The path of emergence: the meaning is the path of seeing and the path of development.

original: gahetabbavissajjetabbaṭṭhānassa asallakkhaṇato. Kammaṭṭhānaṃ pariyosānaṃ pāpuṇātīti
analyzed: gahetabba vissajjetabba ṭṭhānassa asat lakkhaṇataḥ kammaṭṭhānam pariyosānam pāpuṇāti iti
translated: He should go after asking permission: because he has not discerned the place to be taken up and laid aside.

original: ādito paṭṭhāya yāva pariyosānā manasikāramattaṃ hotīti adhippāyo. Avibhūtaṃ pana
analyzed: āditas paṭṭhāya yāva pariyosānā manasikāra mattam hoti iti adhippāyaḥ avibhūtam pana
translated: He reaches the end of the meditation subject: the meaning is that from the beginning his attention is given only to the meditation subject without reaching the end of it.

original: hoti paṭikkūlākārassa suṭṭhu asallakkhaṇato. Tato eva na visesaṃ āvahati.
analyzed: hoti paṭikkūla ākārassa suṭṭhu asat lakkhaṇato tatas eva na visesam āvahati
translated: But it is not evident: because he has not discerned the aspect of foulness properly. And for that very reason it does not bring any special quality.

original: Kammaṭṭhānaṃ pariyosānaṃ na gacchatīti paṭipāṭiyā sabbakoṭṭhāse manasi karotoyeva🔽vibhūtā hutvā upaṭṭhahanti. Te sātisayaṃ pāṭikkūlato manasi karontassa kammaṭṭhānaṃ
analyzed: kammaṭṭhānam pariyosānam na gacchati iti paṭipāṭiyā sabba koṭṭhāse manasi  vibhūtāḥ hutvā upaṭṭhahanti te sa atisayam pāṭikkūlataḥ manasi karontassa kammaṭṭhānam
translated: He does not reach the end of the meditation subject: the meaning is that when he gives his attention to all the parts in succession,🔽they appear to him as evident. But when he gives his attention to them as more and more repellent,

original: pariyosānaṃ gaccheyya, imassa pana ativiya dandhaṃ manasi karoto vibhūtato upaṭṭhānameva
analyzed: pariyosānam gaccheyya imassa pana ativiya dandham manasi karotaḥ vibhūtataḥ upaṭṭhānam eva
translated: the meditation subject reaches its end for him. But when he gives his attention to them with extreme slowness,🔽they do not appear to him as evident.

original: natthi, kuto paṭikkūlatāya saṇṭhānaṃ. Tenāha “visesādhigamassa paccayo na hotī”ti.
analyzed: natthi kutas paṭikkūla tāya saṇṭhānam tena āha visesa adhigamassa paccayaḥ na hoti iti
translated: and since there is none, how can there be a shape? That is why he said, “It is not a condition for the attainment of distinction.”

original: Bahiddhā puthuttārammaṇeti “asuci paṭikkūla”nti kesādīsu pavattetabbaṃ asubhānupassanaṃ
analyzed: bahiddhā puthuttā ārammaṇā iti asuci paṭikkūlanti kesa ādīsu pavattetabbam asubha anupassanam
translated: “An external multiplicity as object”: the contemplation of foulness to be undertaken in the head hairs, etc., as “impurity, what is repulsive,”

original: hitvā subhādivasena gayhamānā kesādayopi idha “bahiddhā puthuttārammaṇamevā”ti veditabbā.
analyzed: hitvā subha ādi vasena kesa ādayaḥ api idha bahiddhā puthutta ārammaṇam eva ati veditabbā
translated: is excluded. The head hairs, etc., which are apprehended as beautiful, etc., should be understood as “an external multiplicity as object” here.

original: Rūpādayo hi nīlādivasena puthusabhāvatāya puthuttārammaṇaṃ nāma, nānārammaṇanti attho.🔽Asamādhānaṃ cetaso virūpo khepoti vikkhepo. So satiṃ sūpaṭṭhitaṃ katvā sakkaccaṃ
analyzed: rūpa ādayaḥ hi nīla ādi vasena puthusa bhāvatāya puthutta ārammaṇam nāma nānā ārammaṇanti attho  asamādhānam cetasaḥ virūpaḥ khepo ti vikkhepo saḥ satim su upaṭṭhitam katvā sakkaccam
translated: For the various kinds of materiality, etc., are called “a multiplicity as object” because they are a multiplicity in the sense of being divided into blue, etc., the meaning is “various objects.”

original: kammaṭṭhānaṃ manasi karontena paṭibāhitabbo. Parihāyatīti hāyati. Paridhaṃsatīti vinassati.
analyzed: kammaṭṭhānam manasi karontena paṭibāhitabbo parihāyati iti hāyati paridhaṃsati iti vinassati
translated: “Distraction” is the scattering of the mind in various ways, with lack of concentration, when one is making a careful effort to establish mindfulness well and to give attention to the meditation subject. “It fails” : it fails, it is lost. “It is dispersed” : it is destroyed.

original: Yā ayaṃ kesā lomātiādikā lokasaṅketānugatā. Paṇṇattīti aṭṭha dhamme upādāya paṇṇatti.
analyzed: yā ayam kesā loma ati ādikā loka saṅketa anugatā paṇṇatti iti aṭṭha dhamme upādāya paṇṇatti
translated: “The designation that is in common use in the world” is the designation that occurs in conformity with the world’s conventional usage. “The designation based on the eight things” is the designation based on the eight things beginning with head hairs.

original: Taṃ kesādipaṇṇattiṃ. Atikkamitvāti paṭikkūlabhāvanāya atikkamitvā ugghāṭetvā. Tassā
analyzed: tam kesa ādi paṇṇattim atikkamitvā ati paṭikkūla bhāvanāya atikkamitvā ugghāṭetvā tassā
translated: “Having surmounted the designation of head hairs, etc.”: having surmounted, having eliminated, the designation of head hairs, etc., by means of the development of the contemplation of the repulsive.

original: ugghāṭitattā tasmiṃ tasmiṃ koṭṭhāse paṭikkūlato upaṭṭhahante “paṭikkūla”nti cittaṃ
analyzed: ugghāṭita ttā tasmin tasmin koṭṭhāse paṭikkūlataḥ upaṭṭhahante paṭikkūlanti cittam
translated: As the parts become uncovered, and as they appear as foul, he should establish his cognizance on “foul”

original: ṭhapetabbaṃ. Idāni tamatthaṃ upamāya vibhāvento “yathā hī”tiādimāha. Tatridaṃ upamāsaṃsandanaṃ
analyzed: idāni tam attham upamāya vibhāventaḥ yathā hi iti ādim āha tatra idam upamā saṃsandanam
translated: in this or that part. Now, in order to elucidate that meaning by means of a simile, he said “Just as” . Herein, the correspondence of the simile is this.🔽The meditator is like the men,🔽The parts are like the well,

original: – manussā viya yogāvacaro. Udapānaṃ viya koṭṭhāsā. Tālapaṇṇādisaññāṇaṃ viya kesādipaññatti.
analyzed: manussāḥ viya yogāvacaraḥ udapānam viya koṭṭhāsā tāla paṇṇa ādi saññāṇam viya kesa ādi paññatti
translated: The perception of the palm-leaf, etc., is like the perception of the hair, etc.

original: Tena manussānaṃ udapāne nhānapivanādi viya yogāvacarassa pubbabhāge kesā lomāti paṇṇattivasena
analyzed: tena manussānam udapāne nhāna pivana ādi viya yogāvacarassa pubba bhāge kesāḥ loma ati paṇṇatti vasena
translated: So just as the men’s attention by perception of the hair, etc., is given to the parts in the way beginning “Hair of the head, hair of the body” in the meditator’s prior stage,

original: manasikāro. Abhiṇhasañcārena manussānaṃ saññāṇena vinā udapāne kiccakaraṇaṃ viya🔽yogāvacarassa manasikārabalena paṇṇattiṃ atikkamitvā paṭikkūlabhāveyeva cittaṃ ṭhapetvā
analyzed: manasikāraḥ abhiṇha sañcārena manussānam saññāṇena vinā udapāne kicca karaṇam viya  yogāvacarassa manasikāra balena paṇṇattim atikkamitvā paṭikkūla bhāveya iva cittam ṭhapetvā
translated: and just as the men’s use of the well is without the perception of the palm-leaf, etc.,🔽so the meditator’s practice of development is by his establishing cognizance on foulness only, after surmounting the perception in the way beginning “Hair of the head, hair of the body” by the power of attention,

original: bhāvanānuyogo. Pubbabhāge…pe… pākaṭo hotīti “kesā lomā”tiādinā bhāvanamanuyuñjantassa
analyzed: bhāvanā anuyogaḥ pubbabhāga īpe pākaṭaḥ hoti iti kesāḥ loma ati ādinā bhāvanam anuyuñjantassa
translated: and in the prior stage … becomes evident to him.

original: kesādipaññattiyā saddhiṃyeva koṭṭhāsānaṃ paṭikkūlabhāvo pubbabhāge pākaṭo hoti. Athāti
analyzed: kesa ādi paññattiyā saddhiṃyeva koṭṭhāsānam paṭikkūla bhāvo pubbabhāge pākaṭaḥ hoti atha ati
translated: The repulsiveness of the parts becomes evident to him together with the perception of the head hairs, etc., in the earlier stage. Then:

original: pacchā bhāvanāya vīthipaṭipannakāle. Paṭikkūlabhāveyeva cittaṃ ṭhapetabbanti koṭṭhāsānaṃ
analyzed: pacchā bhāvanāya vīthi paṭipanna kāle paṭikkūla bhāveya iva cittam ṭhapetabbanti koṭṭhāsānam
translated: Afterwards, when he has entered upon the course of development. He should establish his mind:

original: paṭikkūlākāreyeva bhāvanācittaṃ pavattetabbaṃ.🔽Anupubbena muñcanaṃ anupubbamuñcanaṃ, anupaṭṭhahantassa anupaṭṭhahantassa muñcananti🔽attho. Kathaṃ pana anupaṭṭhānaṃ hotīti āha “ādikammikassā”tiādi. Pariyosānakoṭṭhāsameva
analyzed: paṭikkūla ākāreya iva bhāvanā cittam pavattetabbam  anupubbena muñcanam anupubba muñcanam anupaṭṭhahantassa anupaṭṭhahantassa muñcananti  atthaḥ katham pana anupaṭṭhānam hoti iti āha ādikammikassa atiādi pariyosāna koṭṭhāsam eva
translated: he should bring his mind to growth in the aspect of repulsiveness of the parts.🔽Successive leaving: successive letting go. The meaning is: letting go of each part as it is not present. But how does it not become present? He said: “In the case of a beginner” , and so on.🔽The last part: the last part of the head hairs, etc., that is to say, the brain.

original: āhacca tiṭṭhatīti idaṃ kammaṭṭhānaṃ tantianusārena ādito kammaṭṭhānamanasikāro pavattatīti
analyzed: āhat ca tiṭṭhati iti idam kammaṭṭhānam tanti anusārena āditas kammaṭṭhāna manasikāro pavattati iti
translated: It stands as though it were the end of the meditation subject: this meditation subject is called “the meditation subject of the thirty-two aspects” and also “the meditation subject of the parts of the body.” The attention given to the meditation subject at the beginning is called “attention to the sign” .

original: katvā vuttaṃ. Tathā hissa manasā sajjhāyo viya manasikāro te te koṭṭhāse āmaṭṭhamatte
analyzed: katvā vuttam tathā hissa manasā sajjhāyaḥ viya manasikāro te te koṭṭhāse āmaṭṭha matte
translated: For the attention proceeds by rubbing in the parts in this way, as though doing a recitation mentally, and it goes only as far as rubbing in the parts;

original: katvā gacchati, na lakkhaṇasallakkhaṇavasena. Yadā pana ne lakkhaṇasallakkhaṇavasena
analyzed: katvā gacchati na lakkhaṇa sat lakkhaṇa vasena yadā pana lakkhaṇa sat lakkhaṇa vasena
translated: it does not go as far as discerning the characteristics. But when it goes as far as discerning the characteristics,

original: suṭṭhu upadhārento manasi karoti, tadā keci upaṭṭhahanti, keci na upaṭṭhahanti. Tattha
analyzed: suṭṭhu upadhārentaḥ manasi karoti tadā keci upaṭṭhahanti keci na upaṭṭhahanti tattha
translated: When he does so, some of the thirty-two parts become evident to him, while others do not.

original: paṭipajjanavidhiṃ dassento “athassā”tiādimāha. Tattha kammanti manasikārakammaṃ tāva
analyzed: paṭipajjana vidhim dassentaḥ athassa ati ādim āha tattha kamman ti manasikāra kammam tāva
translated: The method of practice is shown in the passage beginning “Then, when he has done that … ” Herein, “Work” is the work of giving attention.

original: kātabbaṃ. Kīva ciranti? Yāva dvīsu upaṭṭhitesu, tesampi dvinnaṃ eko suṭṭhutaraṃ upaṭṭhahati tāva.🔽Ukkuṭṭhukkuṭṭhiṭṭhāneyeva uṭṭhahitvāti pubbe viya ekatthakatāya ukkuṭṭhiyā kamena🔽sabbatālesu patitvā uṭṭhahitvā uṭṭhahitvā pariyantatālaṃ, āditālañca āgantvā tato
analyzed: kātabbam kīva ciranti yāva dvīsu upaṭṭhitesu tesam pi dvinnam ekaḥ suṭṭhutaram upaṭṭhahati tāva  ukkuṭṭha ukkuṭṭhi ṭhāneya iva uṭṭhahitvā ti pubbe viya ekatthaka tāya ukkuṭṭhiyā kamena  sabba tālesu patitvā uṭṭhahitvā uṭṭhahitvā pariyanta tālam ādi tālam ca āgantvā tatas
translated: “For as long as” means: for as long as two of the parts become evident, and of those two, one more clearly than the other.

original: tato tattha tattheva katāya ukkuṭṭhiyā uṭṭhahitvāti attho.🔽Dve bhikkhāti dvīsu gehesu laddhabhikkhā.
analyzed: tatas tattha tattha iva katāya ukkuṭṭhiyā uṭṭhahitvā iti attho  dve bhikkhā ati dvīsu gehesu laddha bhikkhā
translated: “Rising up in the place where he was sitting cross-legged” means that he rises up from the cross-legged posture as described above, and he does so by the method of cross-legged posture described in the way beginning, “Having fallen on all fours” .🔽“Two bhikkhus” means two bhikkhus who have received alms in two houses.

original: Appanātoti appanākārato dvattiṃsākāre appanā honti. Kiṃ paccekaṃ koṭṭhāsesu hoti
analyzed: appanāto ti appanā ākārataḥ dvattiṃsa ākāre appanāḥ honti kim paccekam koṭṭhāsesu hoti
translated: “From absorption” means from the thirty-two aspects. Does absorption occur in each part?

original: udāhu aññathāti vicāraṇāyaṃ āha “appanākoṭṭhāsato”ti, koṭṭhāsato koṭṭhāsatoti attho.
analyzed: udāhu aññathā ti vicāraṇāyaṃ āha appanā koṭṭhāsato ti koṭṭhāsato koṭṭhāsato ti attho
translated: “Or is it otherwise?” The answer is: “From the plane of absorption,” i.e., from the plane of absorption in each case.

original: Tenāha “kesādīsū”tiādi.
analyzed: tena āha kesa ādī sūti ādi
translated: Hence he says: “In the case of the head hairs, etc.”

original: Adhicittanti samathavipassanācittaṃ.
analyzed: adhicittam ti samatha vipassanā cittam
translated: “The higher consciousness”: the consciousness of serenity and insight.

original: Anuyuttenāti yuttappayuttena, bhāventenāti attho. Kālenakālanti kāle kāle. Samādhinimittaṃ🔽upalakkhitasamādhānākāro samādhi eva. Manasi kātabbanti citte kātabbaṃ, uppādetabbanti
analyzed: anuyuttena ati yutta ppayuttena bhāventena ati attho kālena kālanti kāle kāle samādhi nimittam  upalakkhita samādhāna ākāraḥ samādhi eva manasi kātabbanti citte kātabbam uppādetabbanti
translated: “Should be developed”: should be practiced. “From time to time”: at intervals. The sign of concentration is the mode of appearance of the concentration that has been attained.🔽“Should be given attention”: should be brought to mind. The meaning is: should be aroused. Or alternatively, the sign of concentration is the object, the cause of concentration. The meaning is: it should be given attention by adverting to that.

original: attho. Samādhikāraṇaṃ vā ārammaṇaṃ samādhinimittaṃ, taṃ āvajjitabbanti attho. Paggahanimittaupekkhānimittesupi🔽eseva nayo. Ṭhānaṃ atthīti vacanaseso. Taṃ bhāvanā cittaṃ kosajjāya saṃvatteyya,🔽etassa saṃvattanassa ṭhānaṃ kāraṇaṃ atthīti attho. Taṃ vā manasikaraṇacittaṃ kosajjāya
analyzed: samādhi kāraṇam vā ārammaṇam samādhi nimittam tam āvajjitabbanti paggaha nimitta aupekkhā nimittesu pi  esa iva nayo ṭhānam atthi iti bhāvanā cittam kosajjāya saṃvatteyya  etassa saṃvattanassa ṭhānam kāraṇam atthi iti tam vā manasikaraṇa cittam kosajjāya
translated: The same method of explanation applies to the sign of stimulation and the sign of equanimity.🔽“There is a reason”: the remainder of the sentence is “for its occurrence.” The meaning is: there is a reason, a cause, for the occurrence of that development of consciousness.

original: saṃvatteyya, etassa ṭhānaṃ kāraṇaṃ atthīti attho. Mudunti subhāvitabhāvena mudubhūtaṃ,
analyzed: saṃvatteyya etassa ṭhānam kāraṇam atthi iti atthaḥ mudum ti su bhāvita bhāvena mudu bhūtam
translated: Or the meaning is: there is a reason, a cause, for the occurrence of the consciousness that gives attention to that. “Flexible”: made flexible by the state of being well developed.

original: vasībhāvappattanti attho. Muduttā eva kammaññaṃ kammakkhamaṃ kammayoggaṃ. Pabhassaranti
analyzed: vasībhāva ppattanti atthaḥ muduttāḥ eva kammaññam kamma kkhamam kamma yoggam pabhassaranti
translated: the meaning is, it has reached the state of being malleable. It is workable because it is malleable. It is wieldy because it is workable. It is luminous

original: upakkilesavigamena parisuddhaṃ, pariyodātanti attho. Na ca pabhaṅgūti kammaniyabhāvūpagamanena
analyzed: upakkilesa vigamena parisuddham pariyodātam ti atthaḥ na ca pabhaṅgū ti kammaniya bhāva upagamanena
translated: because it is purified by the disappearance of defilements; the meaning is, it is bright. It is not brittle because it has reached the state of being malleable.

original: na ca pabhijjanasabhāvaṃ suddhantaṃ viya suvaṇṇaṃ viniyogakkhamaṃ. Tenāha “sammā🔽samādhiyati āsavānaṃ khayāyā”ti.🔽Ukkaṃ bandhatīti mūsaṃ sampādeti. Ālimpetīti ādīpeti jāleti. Tañcāti taṃ piḷandhanavikatisaṅkhātaṃ
analyzed: na ca pabhijjana sabhāvam suddhantam viya suvaṇṇam viniyoga kkhamam tena āha sammā  samādhiyati āsavānam khayāya āti  ukkam bandhati iti mūsam sampādeti ālimpeti iti ādīpeti jāleti tam ca ati tam piḷandhana vikati saṅkhātam
translated: It is wieldy like pure gold. Hence it is said: “It is rightly concentrated for the destruction of cankers” .

original: atthaṃ payojanaṃ assa suvaṇṇakārassa anubhoti pahoti sādheti. Assa vā suvaṇṇassa🔽atthaṃ suvaṇṇakāro anubhoti pāpuṇāti.🔽Abhiññāya iddhividhādiñāṇena sacchikaraṇīyassa iddhividhapaccanubhavanādikassa abhiññā
analyzed: attham payojanam assa suvaṇṇakārassa anubhoti pahoti sādheti assa vā suvaṇṇassa  attham suvaṇṇa kāraḥ anubhoti pāpuṇāti  abhiññāya iddhividha ādi ñāṇena sacchikaraṇīyassa iddhividha paccanubhavana ādikassa abhiññā
translated: He binds it on the upper part of the arm: he makes a handle. He heats it: he heats it up. He blows on it: he blows on it. He makes it red-hot: he makes it red-hot all over. He plunges it into the furnace: he plunges it into the fire. He draws it out: he draws it out of the fire. He twists it: he twists it round and round. He straightens it: he straightens it. He bends it: he bends it. He makes a coil of it: he makes a coil of it. He makes a mesh of it: he makes a mesh of it. He makes a net of it: he makes a net of it.

original: sacchikaraṇīyassa. Yassa paccakkhaṃ atthi, so sakkhi. Sakkhino bhabbatā sakkhibhabbatā,
analyzed: sacchikaraṇīyassa yassa paccakkham atthi so sakkhi sakkhinaḥ bhabba tā sakkhi bhabba tā
translated: He makes a bowl of it: he makes a bowl of it. He makes a saucer of it: he makes a saucer of it. He makes a pot of it: he makes a pot of it. He makes a pot-lid of it: he makes a pot-lid of it. He makes a spoon of it: he makes a spoon of it. He makes a dipper of it: he makes a dipper of it. He makes a knife of it: he makes a knife of it. He makes a razor of it: he makes a razor of it. He makes a needle of it: he makes a needle of it. He makes an awl of it: he makes an awl of it. He makes a chisel of it: he makes a chisel of it. He makes a hatchet of it: he makes a hatchet of it. He makes an axe of it: he makes an axe of it. He makes a spade of it: he makes a spade of it. He makes a hoe of it: he makes a hoe of it. He makes a plough of it: he makes a plough of it. He makes a goad of it: he makes a goad of it. He makes a wheel of it: he makes a wheel of it.

original: sakkhibhavananti vuttaṃ hoti. Sakkhi ca so bhabbo cāti vā sakkhibhabbo. Ayañhi iddhividhādīnaṃ
analyzed: sakkhibhavananti vuttam hoti sakkhi ca saḥ bhabbo ca ati vā sakkhibhabbaḥ ayam hi iddhividha ādīnam
translated: He is a “possessor of direct-knowledge” because he is a “knower” and because he is a “possessor of ability.” For he is a “knower” of the kinds of supernormal power, etc.,

original: bhabbo, tattha ca sakkhīti sakkhibhabbo, tassa bhāvo sakkhibhabbatā, taṃ pāpuṇāti.
analyzed: bhabbaḥ tattha ca sakkhi iti sakkhi bhabbaḥ tassa bhāvaḥ sakkhi bhabba tā tam pāpuṇāti
translated: and he is a “possessor of ability” because he is able in that . The state of being that is the “possessor of direct-knowledge and ability” is the “state of one possessing direct-knowledge and ability.” He “attains” it.

original: Sati sati āyataneti tasmiṃ tasmiṃ pubbahetuādike kāraṇe sati.
analyzed: sati sati āyatane iti tasmim tasmim pubba hetu ādike kāraṇe sati
translated: “In each instance”: in each instance of a reason such as a previous root-cause, etc.🔽“The state of being cooled”: Nibbāna, or the subsiding of the fever of the defilements.

original: Sītibhāvanti nibbānaṃ, kilesadarathavūpasamaṃ vā. Niggaṇhātīti uddhaṭaṃ cittaṃ uddhaccapātato
analyzed: sīti bhāvanti nibbānam kilesa daratha vūpasamam vā niggaṇhāti iti uddhaṭam cittam uddhacca pātato
translated: “He steadies”: he steadies the aroused mind by protecting it from the danger of agitation.

original: rakkhaṇavasena niggaṇhāti. Paggaṇhātīti līnaṃ cittaṃ kosajjapātato rakkhaṇavasena
analyzed: rakkhaṇa vasena niggaṇhāti paggaṇhāti iti līnam cittam kosajja pātataḥ rakkhaṇa vasena
translated: “He exerts it”: he exerts the slack mind by protecting it from the danger of indolence.

original: paggaṇhāti. Sampahaṃsetīti samappavattaṃ cittaṃ tathāpavattiyaṃ paññāya toseti, uttejeti🔽vā. Yadā vā nirassādaṃ cittaṃ bhāvanāya na pakkhandati, tadā jātiādīni saṃvegavatthūni
analyzed: paggaṇhāti sampahaṃseti iti sama ppavattam cittam tathāpavattiyam paññāya toseti uttejeti  vā yadā vā nirassādam cittam bhāvanāya na pakkhandati tadā jāti ādīni saṃvega vatthūni
translated: “He encourages it”: he encourages the mind that is functioning correctly by delighting it with the knowledge that it is functioning correctly, or he rouses it.🔽Or when the mind is dispirited and does not enter into and resolve upon its object, then he encourages it and rouses it by reviewing the benefits of joy and reviewing the reasons for arousing joy.

original: paccavekkhitvā sampahaṃseti samuttejeti. Ajjhupekkhatīti yadā pana cittaṃ alīnaṃ
analyzed: paccavekkhitvā sampahaṃseti samuttejeti ajjhupekkhati iti yadā pana cittam alīnam
translated: “He looks on at it”: when the mind is neither slack nor agitated,

original: anuddhataṃ sammadeva bhāvanāvīthiṃ otiṇṇaṃ hoti, tadā paggahaniggahasampahaṃsanesu
analyzed: anuddhatam sammat eva bhāvanā vīthim otiṇṇam hoti tadā paggaha niggaha sampahaṃsanesu
translated: and is not over-hasty, but enters the right course of development, then it is time for him to be exhorted, instructed, and gladdened with talk on the Dhamma.

original: kañci byāpāraṃ akatvā samappavattesu yugesu sārathi viya ajjhupekkhati upekkhakova
analyzed: kañci byāpāram a katvā samappavattesu yugesu sārathi viya ajjhupekkhati upekkhakaḥ uva
translated: He is not restless, but he has entered upon the right way of development. Then, when the yokes are proceeding evenly without his having to do anything by way of urging, restraining, encouraging, etc., he is like a charioteer who looks on unconcerned. He is equanimous,

original: hoti. Paṇītādhimuttikoti paṇīte uttame maggaphale adhimutto ninnapoṇapabbhāro.🔽Suggahitaṃ katvāti yathāvuttaṃ uggahakosallasaṅkhātaṃ vidhiṃ suṭṭhu uggahitaṃ pariyāpuṇanādinā
analyzed: hoti paṇīta adhimuttikaḥ ti paṇīte uttame magga phale adhimuttaḥ ninna poṇa pabbhāro  suggahitam katvā iti yathāvuttam uggaha kosalla saṅkhātam vidhim suṭṭhu uggahitam pariyāpuṇana ādinā
translated: having no concern. He is intent on the sublime: he is intent on the noble path and fruition, which are sublime, excellent.🔽Having well received: having well received, well taken up, by the method called skill in learning, which has been described thus: “He is one who has learned much, remembers what he has learned, and accumulates what he has learned” .

original: supariggahitaṃ katvā. Suṭṭhu vavatthapetvāti manasikārakosallasaṅkhātaṃ vidhiṃ sammadeva🔽sallakkhaṇavasena upadhāretvā. Visesanti pubbenāparaṃ bhāvanāya visesaṃ. Punappunaṃ
analyzed: su pariggahitam katvā suṭṭhu vavatthapetvā ati manasikāra kosalla saṅkhātam vidhim sammad eva  sat lakkhaṇa vasena upadhāretvā pubbena aparam bhāvanāya visesam punappunam
translated: Having well defined: having well defined by proper defining through the defining called skill in attending, which has been described thus: “He is one who defines what is the path and what is not the path” .🔽Progress: progress in development from before to after.🔽Having turned the meditation subject over and over again in his mind: having made the meditation subject familiar by repeatedly revolving it again and again in his speech and his mind.

original: parivattetvāti kammaṭṭhānatantiṃ paguṇabhāvaṃ pāpento bhiyyo bhiyyo vācāya, manasā
analyzed: parivattetvā ti kammaṭṭhāna tantim paguṇa bhāvam pāpentaḥ bhiyyas bhiyyas vācāya manasā
translated: Having made the meditation subject familiar by repeatedly revolving it again and again in his speech and his mind.

original: ca parivattetvā. Gaṇṭhiṭṭhānanti yathā rukkhassa dubbinibhedo araññassa vā gahanabhūto
analyzed: ca parivattetvā gaṇṭhi ṭṭhānan ti yathā rukkhassa dubbinibhedaḥ araññassa vā gahana bhūtaḥ
translated: Knots in the wood: a knot in a tree is a place where the wood is defective. A place in a forest that is difficult to pass is a place that is hard to get through.

original: padeso “gaṇṭhiṭṭhāna”nti vuccati, evaṃ kammaṭṭhānatantiyā atthato dubbinibhedo gahanabhūto
analyzed: padesaḥ gaṇṭhiṭṭhānanti vuccati evam kammaṭṭhāna tantiyāḥ atthataḥ dubbinibhedaḥ gahana bhūtaḥ
translated: A place that is hard to penetrate is called a “knot.”

original: ca padeso “gaṇṭhiṭṭhāna”nti vuccati. Taṃ paripucchanādiladdhena ñāṇapharasunā chinditvā.
analyzed: ca padesaḥ gaṇṭhiṭṭhānanti vuccati tam paripucchanā ādi laddhena ñāṇa pharasunā chinditvā
translated: So too, a place that is hard to penetrate in the sense of being hard to see the meaning of the meditation subject is called a “knot.”

original: Nimittanti kammaṭṭhānanimittaṃ, asubhākāro. Edisena payojanena luñcanampi anavajjanti
analyzed: nimittam ti kammaṭṭhāna nimittam asubha ākāraḥ edisena payojanena luñcanam pi
translated: Sign: the sign of the meditation subject, the aspect of foulness.🔽The word “having stripped” is said in order to show that the stripping is blameless for this purpose.

original: dassetuṃ “luñcitvā”ti vuttaṃ. Chinnaṭṭhāneti muṇḍitaṭṭhāne. Vaṭṭatiyeva nissaraṇajjhāsayena
analyzed: dassetum luñcitvā iti vuttam chinna ṭṭhāne ti muṇḍita ṭṭhāne vaṭṭatiyā iva nissaraṇa ajjhāsayena
translated: The place where it is cut off is the place where it is shaved.🔽It is proper to look at it with the intention of finding a way out.

original: olokanato. Ussadavasenāti aphalitānaṃ, phalitānaṃ vā bahulatāvasena. Disvāva nimittaṃ🔽gahetabbaṃ dassanayogyatāya tacapañcakassa, itaresu sutvā ca ñatvā ca nimittaṃ gahetabbaṃ.🔽Koṭṭhāsavavatthāpanakathāvaṇṇanā
analyzed: olokanataḥ ussada vasena ati aphalitānam phalitānam vā bahula tā vasena nimittam  gahetabbam dassana yogyatāya taca pañcakassa itaresu sutvā ca ñatvā ca nimittam gahetabbam  koṭṭhāsa vavatthāpana kathā vaṇṇanā
translated: By the method of height: by the method of the height of the unripe or the ripe.

original: 182. Addāriṭṭhakavaṇṇāti abhinavāriṭṭhaphalavaṇṇā. Kaṇṇacūḷikāti uparikaṇṇasakkhalikāya
analyzed: addā ariṭṭhaka vaṇṇā ati abhinava ariṭṭha phala vaṇṇā kaṇṇacūḷikā ati upari kaṇṇa sakkhalikāya
translated: Having seen it, the sign should be apprehended. The sign should be apprehended by the five aggregates as objects of clinging in the way stated, which is suitable for seeing. In the other cases the sign should be apprehended by hearsay and by inference.

original: parabhāgaṃ sandhāya vuttaṃ. Tiriyaṃ aññamaññena paricchinnā, kathaṃ? Dve kesā ekato natthīti.
analyzed: parabhāgam sandhāya vuttam tiriyam aññamaññena paricchinnā katham dve kesā ekatas natthi iti
translated: and the word “part” is to be understood as referring to the other parts. They are “divided off from each other across” because they are divided off from each other across. How? There are no two head hairs together.

original: Āsayoti nissayo, paccayoti attho.
analyzed: āsayo ti nissayo paccayo ti attho
translated: “Seat” is support; the meaning is, “cause.”

original: 184. Asambhinnakāḷakā aññena vaṇṇena asammissakāḷakā.
analyzed: a sambhinna kāḷakā aññena vaṇṇena a sammissa kāḷakā
translated: “Unmixed black” means black without being mixed with any other colour.

original: 185. Pattasadisattā nakhā eva nakhapattāni. Nakhā tiriyaṃ aññamaññena paricchinnāti visuṃ vavatthitataṃ sandhāya vuttaṃ. Tameva hi atthaṃ dassetuṃ “dve nakhā ekato natthī”ti āha.🔽186. Dantapāḷiyāti dantāvaliyā. Yānakaupatthambhinīti sakaṭassa dhuraṭṭhāne upatthambhakadaṇḍo. Dantānaṃ ādhārabhūtā aṭṭhi hanukaṭṭhi.🔽187. Saṅkaḍḍhiyamānāti sampiṇḍiyamānā. Kosakārakakoso upalliṇḍupoṭṭalakaṃ, yaṃ “koseyyaphala”ntipi
analyzed: patta sadisa ttā nakhāḥ eva nakha pattāni nakhā tiriyam aññamaññena paricchinnā ati visum sandhāya vuttam tam eva hi attham dassetum dve nakhā ekatas natthi iti āha  dantapāḷiyā ati danta āvaliyā yānaka opatthambhinī ti sakaṭassa dhuraṭṭhāne upatthambhaka daṇḍaḥ dantānaṃ ādhāra bhūtā aṭṭhi hanukaṭṭhi  saṅkaḍḍhiyamānā ati sampiṇḍiyamānā kosa kāraka kosaḥ upalliṇḍu poṭṭalakam yam
translated: “Fingernail-shells” are just the finger nails. The words “divided off from each other across” are said with reference to their being individually delimited. And in order to show that same meaning, he said, “There are no two finger nails together.”🔽“Tooth-rows” are the rows of teeth. “Jaw-bone” is the bone that supports the jaw.

original: vuccati. Puṭabandhaupāhano sakalapiṭṭhipādacchādanaupāhano. Ānisadaṃ āsanapadeso.
analyzed: vuccati puṭabandha upāhano sakala piṭṭhi pāda chādana upāhano ānisadam āsana padeso
translated: “When they are collected together” means when they are lumped together. “The flesh of the buttocks” is the flesh of the buttocks. “The flesh of the calves” is the flesh of the calves. “The flesh of the thighs” is the flesh of the thighs. “The flesh of the shoulders” is the flesh of the shoulders. “The flesh of the arms” is the flesh of the arms. “The flesh of the hands” is the flesh of the hands. “The flesh of the back of the neck” is the flesh of the back of the neck. “The flesh of the chest” is the flesh of the chest. “The flesh of the abdomen” is the flesh of the abdomen. “The flesh of the genitals” is the flesh of the genitals. “The flesh of the base” is the flesh of the base. “The flesh of the buttocks” is the flesh of the buttocks. “The flesh of the calves” is the flesh of the calves. “The flesh of the thighs” is the flesh of the thighs. “The flesh of the shoulders” is the flesh of the shoulders. “The flesh of the arms” is the flesh of the arms. “The flesh of the hands” is the flesh of the hands. “The flesh of the back of the neck” is the flesh of the back of the neck. “The flesh of the chest” is the flesh of the chest. “The flesh of the abdomen” is the flesh of the abdomen. “The flesh of the genitals” is the flesh of the genitals. “The flesh of the base” is the flesh of the base. “The flesh of the buttocks” is the flesh of the buttocks. “The flesh of the calves

original: Tūṇiro sarāvāso. Galakañcukaṃ kaṇṭhattāṇaṃ. Kīṭakulāvakaṃ kharamukhakuṭi.
analyzed: tūṇiraḥ sarāvāsaḥ gala kañcukam kaṇṭhattāṇam kīṭa kulāvakam kharamukhakuṭi
translated: The “bladder” is the stomach. The “skin” is the outer skin. The “membrane” is the inner skin. The “flesh” is the flesh. The “sinew” is the sinew. The “bone” is the bone. The “marrow” is the marrow.

original: Anulomena paṭilomena cāti ettha aṃsapadesato paṭṭhāya bāhuno piṭṭhipadesena otaraṇaṃ
analyzed: anulomena paṭilomena ca ati ettha aṃsa padesataḥ paṭṭhāya bāhuno piṭṭhi padesena otaraṇam
translated: “In the forward and reverse order”: descending from the shoulder-joint to the back of the hand is the forward order;

original: anulomo, maṇibandhato paṭṭhāya bāhuno purimabhāgena ārohanaṃ paṭilomo. Teneva nayenāti🔽dakkhiṇahatthe vuttena nayena anulomena paṭilomena cāti attho. Sukhumampīti yathāvuttaoḷārikacammato
analyzed: anulomaḥ maṇibandhataḥ paṭṭhāya bāhuno purima bhāgena ārohanam paṭilomaḥ tena iva nayena ati  dakkhiṇa hatthe vuttena nayena anulomena paṭilomena ca ati attho sukhumam pi iti yathā vutta oḷārika cammato
translated: ascending from the wrist to the upper arm is the reverse order.🔽“In the same way”: the meaning is, in the forward and reverse order, as stated in the case of the right hand.

original: sukhumaṃ. Antomukhacammādikoṭṭhāsesu vā tacena paricchinnattā yaṃ durupalakkhaṇīyaṃ,
analyzed: su khumam antar mukha camma ādi koṭṭhāsesu vā tacena paricchinna ttā yam durupalakkhaṇīyam
translated: “Even the subtle”: the subtle is the skin as stated, which is “subtle” because it is difficult to discern since it is delimited by the parts of the inner skin, etc.

original: taṃ “sukhuma”nti vuttaṃ. Tañhi vuttanayena ñāṇena tacaṃ vivaritvā passantassa pākaṭaṃ
analyzed: tam sukhuman ti vuttam tat hi vutta nayena ñāṇena tacam vivaritvā passantassa pākaṭam
translated: For that becomes evident to one who sees it by removing the skin with the knowledge stated in the way already given.

original: hoti. Idha chavipi tacagatikā evāti “taco upari ākāsena paricchinno”ti vutto.
analyzed: hoti idha taca gatikā eva ati tacaḥ upari ākāsena paricchinno ti vutto
translated: Herein, the outer skin is included in the skin category, so it is said that “the skin is delimited above by space.”

original: 188. Nisadapoto silāputtako. Uddhanakoṭīti mattikāpiṇḍena katauddhanassa koṭi. Tālaguḷapaṭalaṃ
analyzed: nisada poto silāputtakaḥ uddhana koṭī iti mattikā piṇḍena kata oddhanassa tāla guḷa paṭalam
translated: The “tip of the nose” is the tip of the nose-bone. The “root of the nose” is the place where the two nostrils are joined. The “root of the ear” is the place where the ear is joined to the head. The “tip of the ear” is the outer extremity of the ear.

original: nāma pakkatālaphalalasikaṃ tālapaṭṭikādīsu limpitvā sukkhāpetvā uddharitvā gahitapaṭalaṃ.
analyzed: nāma pakka tāla phala lasikam tāla paṭṭikā ādīsu limpitvā sukkhāpetvā uddharitvā gahita paṭalam
translated: The name-flesh is the flesh of the palm of the hand, etc., which is taken after having dried it by smearing the juice of the ripe palmyra fruit on the palm of the hand, on a piece of palmyra bark, etc.

original: Sukhumanti yathāvuttamaṃsato sukhumaṃ. Paṇhikamaṃsādithūlānaṃ sakalasarīrassa kisānaṃ
analyzed: sukhumanti yathāvutta maṃsataḥ sukhumam paṇhika maṃsa ādi thūlānam sakala sarīrassa kisānam
translated: The subtle is the flesh that is more subtle than the flesh already mentioned. The flesh of the buttocks, etc., is the flesh of the buttocks, the flesh of the thighs, the flesh of the calves, and the flesh of the backs of the feet.

original: yebhuyyena maṃsena paṭicchāditattā vuttaṃ “tiriyaṃ aññamaññena paricchinna”nti.
analyzed: yebhuyyena maṃsena paṭicchādita ttā vuttam tiriyam aññamaññena paricchinnanti
translated: The flesh of the whole body is called “flesh” because it is mostly covered by flesh.

original: 189. Jālākāro kañcuko jālakañcuko. Visuṃ vavatthitabhāveneva nhārū tiriyaṃ aññamaññena paricchinnā.
analyzed: jāla ākāraḥ kañcukaḥ jāla kañcukaḥ visum vavatthita bhāvena iva nhārū tiriyam aññamaññena paricchinnā
translated: The net-like flesh is the flesh that is like a net. The sinews are separated from each other by being distributed separately.

original: 190. Dantānaṃ visuṃ gahitattā “ṭhapetvā dvattiṃsa dantaṭṭhīnī”ti vuttaṃ. Ekaṃ jaṇṇukaṭṭhi,
analyzed: dantānam visum gahita ttā ṭhapetvā dvattiṃsa danta ṭṭhīni iti vuttam ekam
translated: The thirty-two teeth are taken separately. Therefore it is said: “Except for the thirty-two teeth-bones.”🔽There is one ankle-bone,

original: ekaṃ ūruṭṭhīti eka-ggahaṇaṃ “ekekasmiṃ pāde”ti adhikatattā. Evaṃ timattānīti evaṃ
analyzed: ekam ūruṭṭhī iti eka gahaṇam eka ekasmin pāde iti adhika tattā evam ti mattāni iti evam
translated: one shin-bone, and one thigh-bone. The word “one” is used because there is one in each leg.

original: mattasaddehi ānisadaṭṭhiādīni idha avuttānipi dassetīti veditabbaṃ. Evañca katvā
analyzed: matta saddehi ānisadaṭṭhi ādīni idha avuttāni pi dasseti iti veditabbam evam ca katvā
translated: In the same way, the word “two” shows that there are two knee-bones, and the word “four” shows that there are four hip-bones. Thus it should be understood that by the words “three” and “four” the bones of the buttocks, etc., which are not mentioned here, are shown.🔽In this way,

original: “atirekatisataaṭṭhikasamussaya”nti idañca vacanaṃ samatthitaṃ hoti.
analyzed: idam ca vacanam samatthitam hoti
translated: the statement “the collection of more than three hundred bones” becomes correct.

original: Kīḷāgoḷakāni suttena bandhitvā aññamaññaṃ ghaṭṭetvā kīḷanagoḷakāni. Dhanukadaṇḍo🔽dārakānaṃ kīḷanakakhuddakadhanukaṃ. Tattha jaṅghaṭṭhikassa patiṭṭhitaṭṭhānanti jaṇṇukaṭṭhimhi
analyzed: kīḷā goḷakāni suttena bandhitvā aññam aññam ghaṭṭetvā kīḷana goḷakāni dhanuka daṇḍaḥ  dārakānam kīḷanaka khuddaka dhanukam tattha jaṅghaṭṭhikassa patiṭṭhita ṭṭhānanti jaṇṇukaṭṭhimhi
translated: Balls for playing with are balls for playing with by striking one against the other after tying them together with thread. A bow-stick is🔽a small bow for children to play with. Herein, the place where the shin-bone is established is the place

original: pavisitvā ṭhitaṭṭhānanti adhippāyo. Tena ūruṭṭhinā patiṭṭhitaṃ ṭhānaṃ yaṃ kaṭiṭṭhino,
analyzed: pavisitvā ṭhita ṭṭhānanti adhippāyo tena ūru ṭṭhinā patiṭṭhitam ṭhānam yam kaṭi ṭṭhino
translated: where it enters the knee-bone. That is the meaning. The place where the thigh-bone is established is the place

original: taṃ aggacchinnamahāpunnāgaphalasadisaṃ.🔽Kumbhakārena nipphāditaṃ uddhanaṃ kumbhakārikauddhanaṃ. Sīsakapaṭṭaveṭhakaṃ veṭhetvā
analyzed: tam agga chinna mahā punnāga phala sadisam  kumbhakārena nipphāditam uddhanam kumbhakārika oddhanam sīsaka paṭṭa veṭhakam veṭhetvā
translated: where it enters the hip-bone. That is like a large bread-fruit that has had its end cut off.

original: ṭhapitaṃ sīsamayaṃ paṭṭakaṃ. Yena suttaṃ kantanti, tasmiṃ takkamhi vijjhitvā ṭhapitagoḷakā🔽vaṭṭanā nāma, vaṭṭanānaṃ āvaḷi vaṭṭanāvaḷi.
analyzed: ṭhapitam sīsa mayam paṭṭakam yena suttam kantanti tasmin takkamhi vijjhitvā ṭhapita goḷakā  vaṭṭanā nāma vaṭṭanānam āvaḷi vaṭṭanāvaḷi
translated: A potter’s wheel is a wheel for making pots by a potter. A head-band is a piece of cloth that is put on the head and tied round it. A ball is a ball that is fixed on a string and is put on a pivot🔽in a hole in a frame. A pivot is a piece of wood or an iron bar or a bamboo splinter fixed in a hole in a frame for a ball to swing on. A frame is a frame for a ball to swing on.

original: Maṇḍalākārena chinnavaṃsakaḷīrakhaṇḍāni vaṃsakaḷīracakkalakāni. Avalekhanasatthakaṃ ucchutacāvalekhanasatthakaṃ.
analyzed: maṇḍala ākārena chinna vaṃsa kaḷīra khaṇḍāni vaṃsa kaḷīra cakkalakāni avalekhana satthakam ucchuta ca avalekhana satthakam
translated: A piece of bamboo is a piece of bamboo that has been cut into the shape of a ring. A razor is a razor for shaving the beard and the hair of the head.

original: 192. Vakkabhāgena paricchinnanti vakkapariyantena bhāgena paricchinnaṃ. Ito paresupi evarūpesu eseva nayo.
analyzed: vakka bhāgena vakka pariyantena bhāgena paricchinnam itas paresu pi evarūpesu eṣa iva nayo
translated: Cut off by the end of the bowel: limited by the end of the bowel as a portion. The same method applies in the other instances.

original: 193. Yaṃ nissāyāti yaṃ lohitaṃ nissāya, nissayanissayopi “nissayo”tveva vuccati.
analyzed: yam nissāya ati yam lohitam nissāya nissaya nissayaḥ api nissayaḥ tu eva vuccati
translated: Depending on: depending on the blood. For the support and the supported are called “support” in the usual way.

original: Bhavati hi kāraṇakāraṇepi kāraṇavohāro yathā “corehi gāmo daḍḍho”ti. Atha vā yasmiṃ
analyzed: bhavati hi kāraṇa kāraṇe api kāraṇa vohāraḥ yathā corehi gāmaḥ atha vā yasmin
translated: For there is the use of the word “cause” for a cause of a cause, as in the passage, “The village was burned down by the thieves’ fire” .

original: rūpakalāpe hadayavatthu, tampi lohitagatikameva hutvā tiṭṭhatīti “yaṃ nissāyā”ti vuttaṃ.🔽194. Paṇḍukadhātukanti paṇḍusabhāvaṃ.
analyzed: rūpa kalāpe hadaya vatthu tam pi lohita gatikam eva hutvā tiṭṭhati iti yam nissāya iti vuttam  paṇḍuka dhātukam ti paṇḍu sabhāvam
translated: Or alternatively, the heart-basis is to be found in the material group in which the blood is, having become the blood’s destiny, and that is why it is said, “depending on the blood.”🔽  The white pellicle: the white aspect.

original: 195. Pariyonahanamaṃsanti paṭicchādakamaṃsaṃ.
analyzed: pariyonahanam aṃsanti paṭicchādakam aṃsam
translated: The flesh that covers: the flesh that conceals.

original: 196. Udarajivhāmaṃsanti jivhāsaṇṭhānaṃ udarassa matthakapasse tiṭṭhanakamaṃsaṃ. “Nīla”nti vatvā nīlaṃ nāma bahudhātukanti āha “nigguṇḍipupphavaṇṇa”nti.
analyzed: udara jivhā maṃsam ti jivhā saṇṭhānam udarassa matthaka passe tiṭṭhanaka maṃsam nīlanti vatvā nīlam nāma bahu dhātukan ti āha nigguṇḍi puppha vaṇṇam ti
translated: The flesh of the tongue of the belly: the flesh that is to be found at the top of the belly in the shape of a tongue. After saying “blue,” he said “blue is of many kinds” and then said “the colour of the nigguṇḍi flower.”

original: 197. Papphāsamaṃsanti yathāṭhāne eva lambitvā thokaṃ parivattakamaṃsaṃ. Nirasanti nihīnarasaṃ. Nirojanti nippabhaṃ, ojārahitaṃ vā.
analyzed: papphāsam aṃsanti yathā ṭhāne eva lambitvā thokam parivattaka maṃsam nirasanti nihīna rasam nirojanti nippabham ojā rahitam vā
translated: 197. Like a piece of chewed food: like a piece of food that has been chewed and is hanging there a little turned. Without taste: of inferior taste. Without nutriment: without radiance, or devoid of nutriment.

original: 198. Obhaggāti avabhujitvā ṭhitā. Sakkharasudhāvaṇṇanti marumbehi katasudhāvaṇṇaṃ. “Setasakkharasudhāvaṇṇa”ntipi pāṭho, setasakkharavaṇṇaṃ, sudhāvaṇṇañcāti attho.
analyzed: obhaggā ti avabhujitvā ṭhitā sakkhara sudhā vaṇṇam ti marumbehi kata sudhā vaṇṇam seta sakkhara sudhā vaṇṇam iti pi pāṭhaḥ seta sakkhara vaṇṇam sudhā vaṇṇam ca ati attho
translated: 198. Like a lump of spittle: like a lump of spittle that has been spat out and is lying there. The colour of white clay: the colour of clay that has been kneaded with water. The reading “white clay, the colour of” is also allowable. The meaning is: the colour of white clay.

original: 199. Antassa ābhujitvā ābhujitvā ṭhitappadesā antabhogaṭṭhānāni. Tesaṃ bandhanabhūtaṃ
analyzed: antassa ābhujitvā ābhujitvā ṭhita ppadesāḥ anta bhogaṭṭhānāni tesam bandhana bhūtam
translated: 199. The places where the coils lie after coiling round: the places where the coils lie after coiling round.

original: antaguṇaṃ nāmāti dassento āha “antaguṇanti antabhogaṭṭhānesu bandhana”nti. Kuddālapharasukammādīni
analyzed: antaguṇam nāma ati dassentaḥ āha anta guṇam ti anta bhogaṭṭhānesu bandhanam ti kuddāla phara sukamma ādīni
translated: The name of the bowel that is the binding of those is “intestines” : showing that the name of the bowel that is the binding of those is “intestines,” he said “Intestines are the binding in the places where the coils lie.”🔽Like the joints of a plough : like the joints of a plough that are not loose but are bound together.

original: karontānaṃ antabhoge agaḷante ekato ābandhitvā, kiṃ viya? Yantasuttakamiva yantaphalakānīti.🔽Kimiva tattha ṭhitanti āha “pādapuñchana…pe… ṭhita”nti. Purimañcettha ābandhanassa,
analyzed: anta bhoge ekatas ābandhitvā kim viya yanta suttakam iva yanta phalakāni iti  kim iva tattha ṭhitanti āha pāda puñchanape ṭhitanti puriman ca itthā ābandhanassa
translated: Like the spokes of a wheel : like the spokes of a wheel that are not loose but are bound together.🔽200. Like a rope for binding sheaves : like a rope for binding sheaves that is not loose but is bound together.

original: dutiyaṃ ṭhānākārassa nidassananti daṭṭhabbaṃ.
analyzed: dutiyam ṭhāna ākārassa nidassanan ti daṭṭhabbam
translated: Like a rope for binding sheaves : like a rope for binding sheaves that is not loose but is bound together.

original: 200. Asitaṃ nāma bhuttaṃ odanādi. Pītaṃ nāma pivanavasena ajjhohaṭapānakādi. Khāyitaṃ nāma saṃkhāditaṃ piṭṭhamūlaphalakhajjādi. Sāyitaṃ nāma assāditaṃ ambapakkamadhuphāṇitādi.
analyzed: asitam nāma bhuttam odana ādi pītam nāma pivana vasena ajjhohaṭa pānaka ādi khāyitam nāma saṃkhāditam piṭṭha mūla phala khajja ādi sāyitam nāma assāditam amba pakka madhu phāṇita ādi
translated: “Eaten” is what is called “food,” such as rice, etc.; “drunk” is what is drunk, such as beverages, etc., that are swallowed; “chewed” is what is chewed, such as cakes, roots, fruits, etc.; “tasted” is what is savoured, such as ripe mangoes, honey, molasses, etc.

original: Yatthāti yasmiṃ udare. Yanti ca udarameva paccāmasati. Yattha pānabhojanādīni patitvā tiṭṭhatīti sambandho. Suvānavamathu sārameyyavantaṃ. Vivekanti vibhāgaṃ.
analyzed: yattha ati yasmin udare yanti ca udaram eva pāna bhojana ādīni patitvā tiṭṭhati iti sambandho suvāna vamathu vibhāgam
translated: “Where” is in which belly. And the belly itself is called “paccāmasati.” The construction is: “where the drinks, foods, etc., having fallen, remain.” It is “full of digested and undigested stuff” because it is full of digested and undigested stuff. It is “with the smell of digested food” because it has the smell of digested food. “Separation” is division.

original: 201. Heṭṭhānābhipiṭṭhikaṇṭakamūlānaṃ antareti purimabhāgavasena nābhiyā heṭṭhāpadesassa pacchimabhāgavasena heṭṭhimapiṭṭhikaṇṭakānaṃ vemajjhe. Veḷunāḷikasadiso padesoti adhippāyo.
analyzed: heṭṭhā nābhi piṭṭhikaṇṭaka mūlānam antare ti purima bhāga vasena nābhiyāḥ heṭṭhā padesassa pacchima bhāga vasena heṭṭhima piṭṭhikaṇṭakānam vemajjhe veḷu nāḷika sadisaḥ padesaḥ ti adhippāyaḥ
translated: Between the navel, the back-bone, and the base of the neck: the meaning is, in the middle between the navel in the lower part and the back-bone and the base of the neck in the upper part. The intention is that the place is like a bamboo tube.

original: 202. Samohitanti nicitaṃ.
analyzed: nicitam
translated: “Accumulated” is collected.🔽A rotten hen’s egg is a “rotten hen’s egg.” The “upward wind” is the wind that moves upwards without bile, etc.

original: 204. Pūtibhāvaṃ āpannaṃ kukkuṭaṇḍaṃ pūtikukkuṭaṇḍaṃ. Uddeko pittādīhi vinā kevalo uddhaṅgamavāto.🔽205. Ācāmo avassāvanakañjikaṃ.
analyzed: pūti bhāvam āpannam kukkuṭaṇḍam pūti kukkuṭaṇḍam uddekaḥ pitta ādīhi vinā kevalaḥ uddhaṅgama vātaḥ 🔽ācāmaḥ avassāvana kañjikam
translated: “Urine” is the liquid that is passed in the lower part of the body.

original: 206. Vakkahadayayakanapapphāse temayamānanti ettha yakanaṃ heṭṭhābhāgapūraṇeneva temeti, itarāni tesaṃ upari thokaṃ thokaṃ paggharaṇenāti daṭṭhabbaṃ.
analyzed: vakka hadaya yakana papphāse ettha yakanam heṭṭhābhāga pūraṇena iva temeti itarāni tesam upari thokam thokam paggharaṇena ati daṭṭhabbaṃ
translated: “The liver, heart, spleen, and lungs are moistened” means that the liver is moistened by the filling up of the lower part, and the other three by the dripping down of a little bile on to them.

original: 207. Utuvikāro uṇhavalāhakādihetuko. Visamacchinno bhisādikalāpo visamaṃ udakaṃ paggharati,
analyzed: utu vikāraḥ uṇha valāhaka ādi hetukaḥ visama chinnaḥ bhisa ādi kalāpaḥ visamam udakam paggharati
translated: “The change of temperature” is due to hot winds, etc. “The uneven cutting” is the uneven dripping down of water from a bundle of sugar-cane, etc.

original: evamevaṃ sarīraṃ kesakūpādivivarehi upari, heṭṭhā, tiriyañca sedaṃ visamaṃ paggharatīti
analyzed: evam evam sarīram kesa kūpa ādi vivarehi upari heṭṭhā tiriyañca sā idam visamam paggharati iti
translated: So too, the body above, below, and across is unevenly moistened by sweat dripping from the pores of the head hairs, etc.

original: dassetuṃ visamacchinna-ggahaṇaṃ kataṃ.
analyzed: dassetum visama chinna ggahaṇam katam
translated: The mention of “uneven cutting” is made in order to show this.

original: 208. Visamāhāranti tadāpavattamānasarīrāvatthāya asappāyāhāraṃ, atikaṭukaaccuṇhādivisabhāgāhāraṃ
analyzed: visama āhāram ti tadā apavattamāna sarīra avatthāya asappāya āhāram ati kaṭuka accuṇha ādi visa bhāga āhāram
translated: “Uneven food” is food that is unwholesome for the physical basis that has arisen then, or food that is of an opposite nature, such as very hot or very sharp food.

original: vā. Sammohavinodaniyaṃ pana “visabhāgāhāra”ntveva vuttaṃ tadā pavattamānānaṃ dhātūnaṃ visabhāgattā.
analyzed: vā sammoha vinodaniyam pana visabhāga āhāra ntu eva vuttam tadā pavattamānānam dhātūnam visabhāga ttā
translated: But in the Visuddhimagga the words “uneven food” are given as “unsuitable food” because the elements that have arisen then are unsuitable .

original: 209. “Nhānakāle”ti idaṃ udakassa upari sinehassa sambhavadassanatthaṃ vuttaṃ. Paribbhamantasinehabinduvisaṭasaṇṭhānāti
analyzed: nhāna kāle ti idam udakassa upari sinehassa sambhava dassana tham vuttam paribbhamanta sineha bindu visaṭa saṇṭhānā ti
translated: “At the time of bathing” is said in order to show the occurrence of oiliness on the surface of the water. “The drops of oiliness that spread out” are the drops of oiliness that spread out on the surface of the water.

original: visaṭaṃ hutvā paribbhamantasinehabindusaṇṭhānā. Utuvisabhāgo bahiddhāsamuṭṭhāno.
analyzed: visaṭam hutvā utu visa bhāgaḥ bahiddhā samuṭṭhānaḥ
translated: and it is the shape of a drop of oil spread out and trickling over the surface of the earth. The “unbalanced state of temperature” is what arises externally.

original: Dhātuvisabhāgo antosamuṭṭhāno. Te padesāti te hatthatalādipadesā.
analyzed: dhātu visa bhāgaḥ antosamuṭṭhāno te padesā ati te hattha tala ādi padesā
translated: The “unbalanced state of elements” is what arises internally. The “parts” are the parts of the palm of the hand, etc.

original: 210. Kiñcīti uṇhādirasānaṃ aññataraṃ āhāravatthu. Nesanti sattānaṃ. Hadayaṃ āgilāyatīti visabhāgāhārādiṃ paṭicca hadayappadeso vivattati.
analyzed: kiñci iti uṇha ādi rasānam aññataram āhāra vatthu sattānam hadayam āgilāyati iti visa bhāga āhāra ādim paṭicca hadaya ppadesaḥ vivattati
translated: “Something” is one of the kinds of nutriment beginning with heat. “They” are living beings. “The heart aches” because of unbalanced nutriment, etc. The part of the heart trembles.

original: 211. Dadhino vissandanaaccharaso dadhimuttaṃ. Gaḷitvāti sanditvā. Tālumatthakavivarena otaritvāti matthakavivarato āgantvā tālumatthakena otaritvā.
analyzed: dadhinaḥ vissandana accha rasaḥ dadhi muttam gaḷitvā ati sanditvā tālu matthaka vivarena otaritvā ati matthaka vivarataḥ āgantvā tālu matthakena otaritvā
translated: “The whey” is the cream of curd. “Having trickled” means having flowed. “Having entered by the hole in the navel” means having come from the hole in the navel.

original: 212. Telaṃ viya sakaṭassa nābhiakkhasīsānaṃ aṭṭhisandhīnaṃ abbhañjanakiccaṃ sādhayamānā.
analyzed: telam viya sakaṭassa nābhi akkha sīsānam aṭṭhi sandhīnam abbhañjana kiccam sādhayamānā
translated: it performs the function of lubricating the joints of the cart-like bones, like oil.

original: Kaṭakaṭāyantīti “kaṭa kaṭā”ti saddaṃ karonti. Anuravadassanaṃ hetaṃ. Dukkhantīti
analyzed: kaṭakaṭāyanti iti saddam karonti anurava dassanam ha etam dukkhanti iti
translated: “Grinding” means making a sound like “kata kata.” This is a Sinhalese word. “They ache” means

original: dukkhitāni sañjātadukkhāni honti.
analyzed: dukkhitāni sañjāta dukkhāni honti
translated: they are painful, they are in pain.

original: 213. Samūlakūlamāsaṃ jhāpetvā chārikaṃ avassāvetvā gahitayūso māsakhāro. Ucchiṭṭhodakagabbhamalādīnaṃ
analyzed: sa mūla kūla māsam jhāpetvā chārikam avassāvetvā gahita yūsaḥ māsa khāraḥ ucchiṭṭha udaka gabbha mala ādīnam
translated: Having burnt the grass-roots and ashes, the juice that is taken is the juice of the month. The place for throwing away the dregs of the water, the dirt of the mouth, etc.,

original: chaḍḍanaṭṭhānaṃ candanikā. Ravaṇaghaṭaṃ nāma pakatiyā sammukhameva hoti. Yassa pana
analyzed: chaḍḍana ṭhānam candanikā ravaṇa ghaṭam nāma pakatiyā sammukham eva hoti yassa pana
translated: is the cesspit. The water-pot is the one that is open at the top. But the one

original: āraggamattampi udakassa pavisanamukhaṃ natthi, taṃ dassetuṃ “amukhe ravaṇaghaṭe”ti
analyzed: āragga mattam pi udakassa pavisana mukham na atthi tam dassetum a mukhe ravaṇa ghaṭe ti
translated: that has no opening for the water to enter is shown by the words, “In the water-pot without an opening.”

original: vuttaṃ. Āyūhananti samīhanaṃ.🔽214. Evañhītiādi yathāvuttāya uggahakosallapaṭipattiyā nigamanaṃ. Idāni yathāvuttaṃ
analyzed: vuttam āyūhanan ti samīhanam  evam hi itiādi yathā vuttāya uggaha kosalla paṭipattiyāḥ nigamanam idāni yathā vuttam
translated: “Gathering” is collecting.

original: manasikārakosallapaṭipattimpi nigamanavasena gahetvā kammaṭṭhānaṃ matthakaṃ pāpetvā
analyzed: manasikāra kosalla paṭipattim pi nigamana vasena gahetvā kammaṭṭhānam matthakam pāpetvā
translated: “In this way”: this is the conclusion of the practice of the skill in learning stated above. Now, in order to show the meditation subject by way of the conclusion of the practice of the skill in attention stated above,🔽after bringing it to the head, he began the sutta with the words “In forward order.” Herein, at the end of the development that proceeds by surmounting the determinations beginning with head hairs, etc.,

original: dassetuṃ “anupubbato”tiādi āraddhaṃ. Tattha paṇṇattisamatikkamāvasāneti kesādipaṇṇattisamatikkamavasena🔽pavattāya bhāvanāya avasāne. Apubbāpariyamivāti ekajjhamiva. Kesāti iti-saddo ādiattho,
analyzed: dassetum anupubbato tiādi āraddham tattha paṇṇatti samatikkama avasāne iti kesa ādi paṇṇatti samatikkama vasena 🔽pavattāya bhāvanāya avasāne apubba apariyam iva ati ekajjham iva kesa iti iti saddaḥ ādi atthaḥ
translated: like what is not new. The word “head hairs” has the sense of “beginning with head hairs.”

original: pakārattho vā, evamādinā iminā pakārena vāti attho. Te dhammāti vaṇṇādivasena vavatthāpitā
analyzed: pakāra atthaḥ vā evamādinā iminā pakārena vā ati atthaḥ te dhammā ti vaṇṇa ādi vasena vavatthāpitā
translated: Or the meaning is: “By this method, by this manner, he adverts to them.” The “things” are the parts of the body defined as colours, etc.,

original: paṭikkūlākārato upaṭṭhitā koṭṭhāsadhammā.
analyzed: paṭikkūla ākārataḥ upaṭṭhitā koṭṭhāsa dhammā
translated: which appear as repulsive aspects.🔽“Externally too”: in another’s physical body, in a corpse, and so on.

original: Bahiddhāpīti sasantānato bahipi, parasantānakāyepīti attho. Manasikāraṃ upasaṃharatīti🔽yathāvuttaṃ paṭikkūlamanasikāraṃ upaneti. Yathā idaṃ, tathā etanti. Evaṃ sabbakoṭṭhāsesu
analyzed: bahiddhā api iti sa santānataḥ para santāna kāye pi iti atthaḥ manasikāram upasaṃharati iti  yathāvuttam paṭikkūla manasikāram upaneti yathā idam tathā etat ti evam sabba koṭṭhāsesu
translated: “He adverts to the application of attention”: he applies the attention in the way stated, that is, to what is repulsive.🔽“Just as in his own body, so externally too”: in the same way in the bodies of others.

original: pākaṭībhūtesūti yathā attano kāye, evaṃ paresampi kāye sabbesu kesādikoṭṭhāsesu paṭikkūlavasena
analyzed: pākaṭībhūtesu iti yathā attano kāye evam paresam pi kāye sabbesu kesa ādi koṭṭhāsesu paṭikkūla vasena
translated: “When all the parts have become evident to him in this way”: the meaning is that they appear to him as repulsive in all their aspects, just as in his own body, in the bodies of others too.

original: vibhūtabhāvena upaṭṭhitesūti attho. Ayamettha kasiṇesu vaḍḍhanasadiso yogino bhāvanāviseso dassito.
analyzed: vibhūta bhāvena upaṭṭhitesu iti atthaḥ ayam ettha kasiṇesu vaḍḍhana sadisaḥ yoginaḥ bhāvanā visesaḥ dassitaḥ
translated: This is the meditator’s special development, which is like the extension of the kasiṇa .

original: Anupubbamuñcanādīti ādi-saddena suttantanayena vibhāvitaṃ vīriyasamatāyojanaṃ saṅgaṇhāti.
analyzed: anupubba muñcana ādi iti ādi saddena suttanta nayena vibhāvitam vīriya sama tā yojanam saṅgaṇhāti
translated: “By successive leaving, etc.”: the word “etc.” includes the equanimity of energy, which is elucidated in the texts.

original: Punappunaṃ manasi karototi vuttanayena attano kāye kesādike “paṭikkūlā paṭikkūlā”ti
analyzed: punappunam manasi karoto ti vutta nayena attano kāye kesa ādike paṭikkūlā paṭikkūlā ati
translated: “By giving attention again and again”: by giving attention again and again in the way already described, to his own head-hairs and so on as “repulsiveness of head-hairs,” etc.,

original: abhiṇhaso manasikāraṃ pavattentassa yadā saddhādīni indriyāni laddhasamathāni visadāni🔽pavattanti, tadā assaddhiyādīnaṃ dūrībhāvena sātisayaṃ balappattehi sattahi saddhammehi
analyzed: manasikāram pavattentassa yadā saddhā ādīni indriyāni laddha samathāni visadāni  pavattanti tadā assaddhi ādīnam dūrībhāvena sa atisayam bala ppattehi sattahi saddhammehi
translated: When he is developing this meditation subject and his faith, etc., become powerful through his giving them attention again and again,🔽then his meditation subject becomes successful with the support of the seven good qualities of a meditation subject,

original: laddhūpatthambhāni vitakkādīni jhānaṅgāni paṭutarāni hutvā pātubhavanti. Tesaṃ ujuvipaccanīkatāya
analyzed: laddhu upatthambhāni vitakka ādīni jhān aṅgāni paṭutarāni hutvā pātubhavanti tesam uju vipaccanīka tāya
translated: and the jhāna factors become evident to him with the support of the seven good qualities of a meditator.

original: nīvaraṇāni vikkhambhitāneva honti saddhiṃ tadekaṭṭhehi pāpadhammehi. Upacārasamādhinā
analyzed: nīvaraṇāni vikkhambhitāna iva honti saddhim tad ekaṭṭhehi pāpa dhammehi upacāra samādhinā
translated: And then the hindrances are quite suppressed, and the meditation subject is successful.🔽The mind becomes concentrated in access concentration,

original: cittaṃ samādhiyati, so taṃyeva nimittaṃ āsevanto bhāvento bahulīkaronto appanaṃ pāpuṇāti.
analyzed: cittam samādhiyati saḥ taṃyeva nimittam āsevantaḥ bhāventaḥ bahulīkarontaḥ appanam pāpuṇāti
translated: and he reaches absorption by developing and repeatedly practicing that same sign.

original: Tena vuttaṃ “anukkamena appanā uppajjatī”ti. Sabbākāratoti vaṇṇādivasena pañcadhāpi. Sāti appanā.
analyzed: tena vuttam anukkamena appanā uppajjati iti sabba ākārataḥ ti vaṇṇa ādi vasena pañcadhā api sā ati appanā
translated: That is why it was said above “absorption arises in due course” . “In all aspects”: in the five ways by colour, etc. “Sā” : this refers to the absorption.

original: Yadi panetaṃ kammaṭṭhānaṃ aviññāṇakāsubhakammaṭṭhānāni viya paṭhamajjhānavasena sijjhati,
analyzed: yadi pana etam kammaṭṭhānam aviññāṇaka asubha kammaṭṭhānāni viya paṭhamajjhāna vasena sijjhati
translated: But if this meditation subject succeeds by means of the first jhāna,

original: atha kasmā “kāyagatāsatī”ti vuttanti āha “evaṃ paṭhamajjhānavasenā”tiādi. Nānāvaṇṇasaṇṭhānādīsu
analyzed: atha kasmā kāya gatā asatī iti vuttan ti āha evam paṭhama jhāna vasena atiādi nānā vaṇṇa saṇṭhāna ādīsu
translated: Why then is it called mindfulness occupied with the body? — He said “In this way, by means of the first jhāna” , etc. Mindfulness occurs in the thirty-two parts that are of different colours, shapes, and so on,

original: dvattiṃsāya koṭṭhāsesu pavattamānāya satiyā kiccamettha sātisayanti āha “satibalena ijjhanato”ti.
analyzed: dvattiṃsāya koṭṭhāsesu pavattamānāya satiyā kiccam ettha āha sati balena
translated: and its function is outstanding here, so he said “because of success through the strength of mindfulness” .

original: Pantasenāsanesu, adhikusalesu ca aratiṃ, kāmaguṇesu ca ratiṃ sahati abhibhavatīti
analyzed: panta senā āsanesu adhi kusalesu ca aratim kāma guṇesu ca ratim sahati abhibhavati iti
translated: In secluded resting places he endures discontent and delight in the skill in the aggregates, etc., and he endures delight in the five cords of sense desire,

original: aratiratisaho sarīrasabhāvacintanena anabhiratiyā pahīnattā. Tathā koṭṭhāsabhāvanāya
analyzed: arati rati sahaḥ sarīra sabhāva cintanena anabhiratiyā tathā koṭṭhāsa bhāvanāya
translated: so he is one who endures discontent and delight . By reflecting on the nature of the body discontent is abandoned in him. Likewise, by the development of the parts,

original: attasinehassa parikkhīṇattā bhayabheravaṃ sahati, sītādīnañca adhivāsakajātiko hoti.
analyzed: atta sinehassa parikkhīṇa ttā bhaya bheravam sahati sītā ādīnam ca adhivāsaka jātikaḥ hoti
translated: he endures fear and dread, and he is of a kind to endure cold, etc., because his self-love has been utterly destroyed.

original: Attasinehavasena hi purisassa bhayabheravaṃ hoti, dukkhassa ca anadhivāsanaṃ. Imaṃ🔽pana koṭṭhāsabhāvanamanuyuttassa na kevalaṃ paṭhamajjhānamattameva, uttaripi paṭivedho🔽atthīti dassetuṃ “kesādīna”ntiādi vuttaṃ.
analyzed: atta sineha vasena hi purisassa bhaya bheravam hoti dukkhassa ca an adhivāsanam imaṃ  pana koṭṭhāsa bhāvanam anuyuttassa na kevalam paṭhamajjhāna mattam eva uttari pi paṭivedhaḥ  atthi iti dassetum kesa ādīnam tiādi vuttam
translated: For it is through self-love that a man has fear and dread and that he cannot endure pain. But when he is devoted to this development of the parts,🔽not only the first jhāna but also higher penetrations are possible for him. To show this he said “With the head hairs … ” , and so on.

original: Ānāpānassatikathāvaṇṇanā
analyzed: āna apāna sati kathā vaṇṇanā
translated: The explanation of the “recollection of in-breaths and out-breaths” is finished.

original: 215. Yaṃ taṃ evaṃ pasaṃsitvā ānāpānassatikammaṭṭhānaṃ niddiṭṭhanti sambandho. Tattha🔽yasmā “kathaṃ bhāvito”tiādikāya pucchāpāḷiyā atthe vibhāvite thomanāpāḷiyāpi attho
analyzed: yam tam evam pasaṃsitvā āna apāna sati kammaṭṭhānam niddiṭṭhanti sambandhaḥ tattha  yasmai katham bhāvitā uti ādikāya pucchā pāḷiyā atthe vibhāvite thomanā pāḷiyā api
translated: The construction is: Having thus praised the meditation subject of mindfulness of breathing, he now describes it. Herein,🔽since the meaning of the question section beginning “How developed, bhikkhus, is mindfulness of breathing” has been elucidated, the meaning of the exposition section is also elucidated,

original: vibhāvitoyeva hoti bhedābhāvato, tasmā taṃ laṅghitvā “kathaṃ bhāvito cā”tiādinā ārabhati.
analyzed: tasmāt tam laṅghitvā katham ca ati ādinā ārabhati
translated: because there is no difference between them. So instead of going through the exposition section too, he begins with the question section, with the words “How developed, bhikkhus,” etc.

original: Tattha hi ito pasaṃsābhāvo “ayampi kho”ti vacanañca viseso. Tesu pasaṃsābhāvaṃ dassetuṃ
analyzed: tattha hi itas pasaṃsā bhāvaḥ ayam pi kho ti vacanam ca visesaḥ tesu pasaṃsā bhāvam dassetuṃ
translated: Herein, the difference is the absence of praise and the words “this, bhikkhus.” To show the absence of praise,

original: “evaṃ pasaṃsitvā”ti vuttaṃ. Pasaṃsā ca tattha abhirucijananena ussāhanatthā. Tañhi🔽sutvā bhikkhū “bhagavā imaṃ samādhiṃ anekehi ākārehi pasaṃsati, santo kirāyaṃ samādhi🔽paṇīto ca asecanako ca sukho ca vihāro pāpadhamme ca ṭhānaso antaradhāpetī”ti sañjātābhirucayo
analyzed: evam pasaṃsitvā iti vuttam pasaṃsā ca tattha abhiruci jananena ussāha atthā tat hi  sutvā bhikkhū bhagavā imam samādhim anekehi ākārehi pasaṃsati santaḥ kira ayam samādhi  paṇīto ca asecanako ca sukho ca vihāro pāpa dhamme ca ṭhānasaḥ antaradhāpeti iti sañjāta abhirucayaḥ
translated: it is said “Having thus praised.” And the praise is for the purpose of arousing zeal, since it arouses zeal by arousing appreciation.🔽For when the bhikkhus hear the meditation subject praised in many a figure by the Blessed One in this way, they think “The Blessed One praises this meditation subject in many a figure; it must be a peaceful and sublime meditation subject, it must be a meditation subject that dispenses benefits,” and they arouse appreciation for it and they think they will practice it carefully.

original: ussāhajātā sakkaccaṃ anuyuñjitabbaṃ paṭipajjitabbaṃ maññanti. “Ayampi kho”ti padassa
analyzed: ussāha jātā sakkaccam anuyuñjitabbam paṭipajjitabbam maññanti ayam pi kho ti padassa
translated: As to the words “this, bhikkhus,”

original: ye ime mayā nibbānamahāsarassa otaraṇatitthabhūtā kasiṇajjhānaasubhajjhānādayo desitā,
analyzed: ye ime mayā nibbāna mahā sarassa otaraṇa tittha bhūtā kasiṇa jhāna asubha jjhāna ādayaḥ desitā
translated: The kasiṇa jhānas, the foulness meditation, and so on, which I have taught as the fords for entering into the great ocean of the Nibbāna element,

original: na kevalaṃ te eva, ayampi khoti bhagavā attano paccakkhabhūtaṃ samādhiṃ desanānubhāvena
analyzed: na kevalam te eva ayam pi kho ti bhagavā attano paccakkha bhūtam samādhim desanā anubhāvena
translated: Not only those, but also this concentration which is known to me, the Exalted One,

original: tesampi bhikkhūnaṃ āsannaṃ, paccakkhañca karonto sampiṇḍanavasena evamāhāti sambandhamukhena attho veditabbo.
analyzed: tesam pi bhikkhūnam āsannam paccakkham ca karontaḥ sampiṇḍana vasena evam āha ati sambandha mukhena atthaḥ veditabbaḥ
translated: He said this in order to show that this concentration is near to and known to those bhikkhus as well. The meaning should be understood by way of the connection.

original: Soḷasavatthukanti catūsu anupassanāsu catunnaṃ catukkānaṃ vasena soḷasaṭṭhānaṃ. Sabbākāraparipūroti🔽kammaṭṭhānapāḷiyā padattho piṇḍattho upamā codanā parihāro payojananti evamādīhi
analyzed: soḷasa vatthukanti catūsu anupassanāsu catunnam catukkānam vasena soḷasa ṭṭhānam sabba ākāra paripūro ti  kammaṭṭhāna pāḷiyā padattho piṇḍattho upamā codanā parihāro payojanan ti evamādīhi
translated: Sixteen bases: sixteen stations in the four contemplations by way of the four tetrads. Complete in every aspect:🔽Complete in all aspects, such as the meaning of the text of the meditation subject, the condensed meaning, the simile, the exhortation, the solution, the purpose,

original: sabbehi ākārehi paripuṇṇo. Niddesoti kammaṭṭhānassa nissesato vitthāro.
analyzed: sabbehi ākārehi paripuṇṇaḥ niddeso ti kammaṭṭhānassa nissesataḥ vitthāro
translated: and so on. Description: the detailed explanation of the meditation subject.

original: 216. Kathanti idaṃ pucchanākāravibhāvanapadaṃ. Pucchā cettha kathetukamyatāvasena
analyzed: kathanti idam pucchana ākāra vibhāvana padam pucchā ca itthā kathā itu kamya tā vasena
translated: How: this is a word that shows the mode of questioning. If it is a question,

original: aññāsaṃ asambhavato. Sā ca upari desanaṃ āruḷhānaṃ sabbesaṃ pakāravisesānaṃ āmasanavasenāti🔽imamatthaṃ dassento “kathanti…pe… kamyatāpucchā”ti āha. Kathaṃ bahulīkatoti etthāpi
analyzed: aññāsam asambhavato sā ca upari desanam āruḷhānam sabbesam pakāra visesānam āmasana vasena ati  imam attham dassento āha katham bahulīkato ti ettha api
translated: because it is impossible for them to be other than that. And that is the meaning of the question.🔽And the meaning of the question “How developed, how made much of?” is this:

original: “ānāpānassatisamādhī”ti padaṃ ānetvā sambandhitabbaṃ. Tattha kathanti ānāpānassatisamādhibahulīkāraṃ
analyzed: āna apāna sati samādhi iti padam ānetvā sambandhitabbam tattha katham ti āna apāna ssati samādhi bahulīkāram
translated: having brought in the words “concentration by mindfulness of breathing,” it should be construed thus. Herein, how is the question one asking for an analysis in various ways of the development and making much of concentration by mindfulness of breathing?

original: nānappakārato vitthāretukamyatāpucchā. Bahulīkato ānāpānassatisamādhīti tathāpuṭṭhadhammanidassananti
analyzed: nānā ppakārataḥ vitthāretu kamyatā pucchā bahulīkataḥ āna apāna ssati samādhi iti tathā puṭṭha dhamma nidassanan ti
translated: It is a question asking for a desire to elaborate. The words “concentration by mindfulness of breathing developed, made much of” are the answer by the demonstration of the idea asked about.

original: imamatthaṃ “eseva nayo”ti iminā atidisati. Tathā santabhāvādayopi tassa yehi bhāvanābahulīkārehi🔽siddhā, taggahaṇeneva gahitā hontīti dassetuṃ “kathaṃ bahulīkato…pe… vūpasametīti
analyzed: imam attham iminā atidisati tathā santa bhāva ādayaḥ api tassa yehi bhāvanā bahulīkārehi  siddhā tad gahaṇena iva gahitāḥ honti iti dassetum katham bahulīka tope vūpasameti iti
translated: The meaning of this is indicated by the words “The same method applies.”🔽And the words “How developed, how made much of … does it lead to …” are said in order to show that such states as quiet, etc.,

original: etthāpi eseva nayo”ti vuttaṃ.
analyzed: ettha api esā iva nayaḥ ti vuttam
translated: which are established by the developments and makings much of of that concentration, are included by the mention of that concentration.

original: “Puna ca paraṃ, udāyi, akkhātā mayā sāvakānaṃ paṭipadā, yathāpaṭipannā me sāvakā
analyzed: puna ca param udāyi akkhātā mayā sāvakānam paṭipadā yathā paṭipannāḥ me sāvakā
translated: “Again, Udayin, a way has been taught by me to my disciples by which, when they practise it, their bodily disturbances and mental disturbances and bodily ailments and mental disquiets are abandoned.

original: cattāro satipaṭṭhāne bhāventī”tiādīsu uppādanavaḍḍhanaṭṭhena bhāvanā vuccatīti tadubhayavasena
analyzed: cattāro sati paṭṭhāne bhāventi itiādīsu uppādana vaḍḍhana ṭṭhena bhāvanā vuccati iti tad ubhaya vasena
translated: in the four foundations of mindfulness” . Herein, it is called “development” in the sense of giving rise to and of increase.

original: atthaṃ dassento “bhāvitoti uppādito vaḍḍhito vā”ti āha. Tattha bhāvaṃ vijjamānataṃ🔽ito gatoti bhāvito, uppādito paṭiladdhamattoti attho. Uppanno pana laddhāsevano,
analyzed: attham dassentaḥ bhāvito ti uppāditaḥ vaḍḍhitaḥ vā ti āha tattha bhāvam vijjamāna tam  itas gataḥ ti bhāvitaḥ uppādito paṭiladdha matto ti attho uppanno pana laddha āsevano
translated: So, showing the meaning in both senses, he said, “Development is giving rise to or increase.” Herein, it has gone bhāvita from this bhāva, that is, from existence,🔽so it is bhāvita. The meaning is, it has been given rise to, obtained. But when it has arisen and obtained repetition,🔽it has been developed, brought to excellence. The meaning is, it has been increased.

original: bhāvito paguṇabhāvaṃ āpādito, vaḍḍhitoti attho. Ānāpānapariggāhikāyāti dīgharassādivisesehi🔽saddhiṃ assāsapassāse paricchijjagāhikāya, te ārabbha pavattāya, satiyaṃ paccayabhūtāyanti
analyzed: bhāvitaḥ paguṇa bhāvam āpāditaḥ vaḍḍhitaḥ ti attho āna apāna pariggāhikāya ti dīgha rassa ādi visesehi  saddhim assāsa passāse paricchijja gāhikāya te ārabbha pavattāya satiyam paccaya bhūtāyanti
translated: In the foundation of mindfulness consisting in contemplation of the way of breath: in the contemplation of in-breaths and out-breaths together with the long and short, etc., distinctions.🔽The meaning is, in the foundation of mindfulness that is the condition for the mindfulness that occurs with that as its object.

original: attho. Purimasmiñhi atthe samādhissa satiyā sahajātādipaccayabhāvo vutto sampayuttavacanato,
analyzed: atthaḥ purimasmin hi atthe samādhissa satiyā sahajāta ādi paccaya bhāvaḥ vuttaḥ sampayutta vacanato
translated: For in the first case the meaning, the expression “conjoined” shows that concentration is a conascent and so on condition for mindfulness.

original: dutiyasmiṃ pana upanissayabhāvopi. Upacārajjhānasahagatā hi sati appanāsamādhissa
analyzed: dutiyasmin pana upanissaya bhāvaḥ api upacāra jhāna sahagatā hi sati appanā samādhissa
translated: But in the second case it is also a decisive-support condition. For the mindfulness that is conjoined with access concentration is a condition for the concentration of absorption.

original: upanissayo hotīti. Bahulīkatoti bahulaṃ pavattito, tena āvajjanādivasībhāvappattimāha.
analyzed: upanissayaḥ hoti iti bahulīkato ti bahulam pavattitaḥ tena āvajjana ādivasībhāva ppattim āha
translated: and is a condition for it.🔽Repeatedly developed: developed in abundance. This shows that the sign has been brought to the stage of mastery of access.

original: Yo hi vasībhāvaṃ āpādito, so icchiticchitakkhaṇe samāpajjitabbato punappunaṃ pavattīyati.🔽Tena vuttaṃ “punappunaṃ kato”ti. Yathā “idheva, bhikkhave, samaṇo”ti, “vivicceva
analyzed: yaḥ hi vasībhāvam āpāditaḥ saḥ icchiti chita khaṇe samāpajjitabbataḥ punappunam pavattīyati  tena vuttam punappunam kataḥ ti yathā idha iva bhikkhave samaṇaḥ ti vivicca iva
translated: For what has been brought to the stage of mastery of access is repeatedly developed, that is to say, it is developed again and again because it must be entered upon whenever there is need.🔽Hence it was said above: “Repeatedly developed means repeatedly practiced” .

original: kāmehī”ti ca evamādīsu paṭhamapade vutto eva-saddo dutiyādīsupi vutto eva hoti, evamidhāpīti🔽āha “ubhayattha evasaddena niyamo veditabbo”ti. Ubhayapadaniyamena laddhaguṇaṃ dassetuṃ
analyzed: kāmehi iti ca evamādīsu paṭhama pade vuttaḥ eva saddo dutiya ādīsu pi vuttaḥ eva hoti evam idha api iti  āha ubhayattha eva saddena niyamaḥ veditabbaḥ iti ubhaya pada niyamena laddha guṇam dassetuṃ
translated: Just as in the passage beginning, “Here, bhikkhus, is a recluse” , and in the passage beginning, “Quite secluded from sense desires, secluded from unprofitable things” , the word “here” is to be construed with each clause, so too here.🔽Hence it was said above: “The word ‘here’ should be construed with each clause” .

original: “ayañhī”tiādi vuttaṃ.🔽Asubhakammaṭṭhānanti asubhārammaṇajhānamāha. Taṃ hi asubhesu yogakammabhāvato, yogino
analyzed: ayam hi itiādi vuttam  asubha kammaṭṭhānam ti asubha ārammaṇa jhānam āha tam hi asubhesu yoga kamma bhāvataḥ yogino
translated: The words “This is the meaning” are a device for bringing out the special quality of the clause “repeatedly developed” by the method of contrast.

original: sukhavisesānaṃ kāraṇabhāvato ca “asubhakammaṭṭhāna”nti vuccati. “Kevala”nti iminā
analyzed: sukha visesānam kāraṇa bhāvato ca asubha kammaṭṭhānan ti vuccati kevalan ti iminā
translated: The meditation subject called foulness: this is the jhāna whose object is foulness. For that is called “the meditation subject called foulness” because it is the work of yoga in regard to foulness and because it is the cause for the various kinds of distinction consisting of the attainment of jhāna, etc., in foulness.🔽By the word “only”

original: ārammaṇaṃ nivatteti. Paṭivedhavasenāti jhānapaṭivedhavasena. Jhānañhi bhāvanāvisesena
analyzed: ārammaṇam nivatteti paṭivedha vasena ati jhāna paṭivedha vasena jhānam hi bhāvanā visesena
translated: He turns away the object. By way of penetration: by way of the penetration of jhāna. For jhāna occurs penetrating its object by way of the distinction of development.

original: ijjhantaṃ attano visayaṃ paṭivijjhantameva pavattati, yathāsabhāvato paṭivijjhīyati🔽cāti “paṭivedho”ti vuccati. Oḷārikārammaṇattāti bībhacchārammaṇattā. Paṭikkūlārammaṇattāti
analyzed: ijjhantam attanaḥ visayam paṭivijjhantam eva pavattati yathā sabhāvataḥ paṭivijjhīyati  ca ati paṭivedhaḥ ti vuccati oḷārika ārammaṇa ttā ati bībhaccha ārammaṇa ttā paṭikkūla ārammaṇa ttā ati
translated: It is called “penetration” because it penetrates the object according to its individual essence.🔽Gross object: because of the repulsiveness of the object. Repulsive object: because of the loathsomeness of the object.

original: jigucchitabbārammaṇattā. Pariyāyenāti kāraṇena, lesantarena vā. Ārammaṇasantatāyāti🔽anukkamena vicetabbataṃ pattaṃ ārammaṇassa paramasukhumataṃ sandhāyāha. Sante hi
analyzed: jigucchitabba ārammaṇa ttā pariyāyena ati kāraṇena lesa antarena vā ārammaṇa santatāya ati  anukkamena vicetabba tam pattam ārammaṇassa parama sukhuma tam sandhāya āha sante hi
translated: By way of reason: by way of cause or by way of condition. By way of the continuity of the object: he says this referring to the extreme subtlety of the object that has reached the state of being able to be discerned only in succession.

original: sannisinne ārammaṇe pavattamāno dhammo sayampi sannisinnova hoti. Tenāha “santo vūpasanto
analyzed: sannisinne ārammaṇe pavattamāno dhammo sayam pi sannisinnaḥ uva hoti tena āha santaḥ vūpasantaḥ
translated: For a state that occurs with regard to a present object is itself present. Therefore he says, “peaceful, sublime,

original: nibbuto”ti, nibbutasabbapariḷāhoti attho. Ārammaṇasantatāya tadārammaṇadhammānaṃ
analyzed: nibbutoti nibbuta sabba pariḷāho ti attho ārammaṇa santatāya tad ārammaṇa dhammānam
translated: and calm.” The meaning is: extinguished in all its feverish conditions.

original: santatā lokuttaradhammārammaṇāhi paccavekkhaṇāhi dīpetabbā.
analyzed: santatā lokuttara dhamma ārammaṇāhi paccavekkhaṇāhi dīpetabbā
translated: The continuity of the states that have that as their object should be illustrated by the reviewing of supramundane states.

original: Nāssa santapaṇītabhāvāvahaṃ kiñci secananti asecanako. Asecanakattā anāsittako. Anāsittakattā🔽eva abbokiṇṇo asammisso parikammādinā. Tato eva pāṭiyekko visuṃyeveko. Āveṇiko asādhāraṇo.🔽Sabbametaṃ sarasato eva santabhāvaṃ dassetuṃ vuttaṃ. Parikammaṃ vā santabhāvanimittaṃ,🔽parikammanti ca kasiṇakaraṇādīni nimittuppādapariyosānaṃ, tādisaṃ idha natthīti adhippāyo.🔽Tadā hi kammaṭṭhānaṃ nirassādattā asantamappaṇītaṃ siyā. Upacārena vā natthi ettha
