analyzed: na assa santa paṇīta bhāva āvaham kiñci asecanakaḥ asecanakattā anāsittakaḥ anāsittakattā  eva abbokiṇṇaḥ asammissaḥ parikamma ādinā tatas eva pāṭiyekkaḥ visuṃyevekaḥ āveṇikaḥ asādhāraṇaḥ  sabbam etam sarasatas eva santa bhāvam dassetum vuttam parikammam vā santa bhāva nimittam  ca kasiṇa karaṇa ādīni nimitta uppāda pariyosānam tādisam idha natthi iti adhippāyaḥ  tadā hi kammaṭṭhānam asantam appaṇītam siyā upacārena vā natthi ettha
translated: It does not have anything that causes it to be moistened and made to grow, thus it is unmoistened. Because it is unmoistened, it is unsoiled. Because it is unsoiled,

original: santatāti yojanā. Yathā upacārakkhaṇe nīvaraṇavigamena, aṅgapātubhāvena ca paresaṃ🔽santatā hoti, na evamimassa. Ayaṃ pana ādisamannā…pe… paṇīto cāti yojanā. Kecīti🔽uttaravihāravāsike sandhāyāha. Anāsittakoti upasecanena na āsittako. Tenāha “ojavanto”ti,
analyzed: santatā iti yojanā yathā upacāra kkhaṇe nīvaraṇa vigamena aṅga pātubhāvena ca paresam 🔽santatā hoti na evam imassa ayam pana ca ati yojanā keci iti 🔽uttaravihāravāsike sandhāya āha anāsittakaḥ iti upasecanena na āsittakaḥ tena āha ojavantaḥ iti

original: ojavantasadisoti attho. Madhūroti iṭṭho, cetasikasukhapaṭilābhasaṃvattanaṃ tikacatukkajjhānavasena,🔽upekkhāya vā santabhāvena sukhagatikattā sabbesampi vasena veditabbaṃ. Jhānasamuṭṭhānapaṇītarūpaphuṭṭhasarīratāvasena
analyzed: ojavanta sadisaḥ ti attho madhūraḥ ti iṭṭho cetasika sukha paṭilābha saṃvattanam tika catukka jhāna vasena  upekkhāya vā santa bhāvena sukha gatika ttā sabbesam pi vasena veditabbam jhāna samuṭṭhāna paṇīta rūpa phuṭṭha sarīra tā vasena
translated: the meaning is, like the one rich in sap. Sweet is what is pleasing. It is to be understood in all ways as conducive to the obtaining of the happiness of mental pleasure by means of the third and fourth jhānas,

original: pana kāyikasukhapaṭilābhasaṃvattanaṃ daṭṭhabbaṃ, tañca kho jhānato vuṭṭhitakāle.
analyzed: pana kāyika sukha paṭilābha saṃvattanam daṭṭhabbam tat ca kho jhānataḥ vuṭṭhita kāle
translated: or as conducive to the obtaining of the happiness of bodily pleasure by means of the bliss of equanimity that has become bodily pleasure owing to the pervasion of the body with the refined bliss arisen from the jhāna.🔽But that should be regarded as occurring when one has emerged from the jhāna.

original: Imasmiṃ pakkhe “appitappitakkhaṇe”ti idaṃ hetumhi bhummavacanaṃ daṭṭhabbaṃ. Avikkhambhiteti
analyzed: imasmin pakkhe appita ppita kkhaṇā iti idam hetumhi bhumma vacanam daṭṭhabbam a vikkhambhita iti
translated: And in this case the words “at each moment of his choice” should be regarded as a locative absolute.🔽Uncurbed: not removed, not abandoned, from his own continuity by means of the jhāna.

original: jhānena sakasantānato anīhaṭe appahīne. Akosallasambhūteti akosallaṃ vuccati avijjā,
analyzed: jhānena saka santānataḥ anīhaṭe appahīne akosalla sambhūtā iti akosallam vuccati avijjā
translated: Arisen from lack of skill: lack of skill is ignorance;🔽arisen from that. For all evil things have ignorance as their forerunner.

original: tato sambhūte. Avijjāpubbaṅgamā hi sabbe pāpadhammā. Khaṇenevāti attano pavattikkhaṇeneva.
analyzed: tatas sambhūte avijjā pubbaṅgamāḥ hi sabbe pāpa dhammāḥ khaṇena iva ati attanaḥ pavatti kkhaṇena iva
translated: In a moment: in its own moment of arising.

original: Antaradhāpetīti ettha antaradhāpanaṃ vināsanaṃ, taṃ pana jhānakattukassa idhādhippetattā
analyzed: antaradhāpeti iti ettha antaradhāpanam vināsanam tam pana jhāna kattukassa idha adhippeta ttā
translated: The word “disappears” is a synonym for “is destroyed.” But since the jhāna is intended here,

original: pariyuṭṭhānappahānaṃ hotīti āha “vikkhambhetī”ti. Vūpasametīti visesena upasameti.
analyzed: pariyuṭṭhāna pahānam hoti iti āha vikkhambheti iti vūpasameti iti visesena upasameti
translated: “It suppresses” is said because there is abandonment by suppression. “It allays” is said because it allays in a special way.

original: Visesena upasamanaṃ pana sammadeva upasamanaṃ hotīti āha “suṭṭhu upasametī”ti.
analyzed: visesena upasamanam pana sammat eva upasamanam hoti iti āha suṭṭhu upasameti iti
translated: But the special way of allaying is the proper way of allaying, so “it allays well” is said.

original: Nanu ca aññopi samādhi attano pavattikkhaṇeneva paṭipakkhadhamme antaradhāpeti vūpasameti,
analyzed: nanu ca aññaḥ api samādhi attanaḥ pavatti kkhaṇena iva paṭipakkha dhamme antaradhāpeti vūpasameti
translated: But does not some other concentration also cause the disappearance of opposing states by the mere fact of its presence?

original: atha kasmā ayameva samādhi evaṃ visesetvā vuttoti? Pubbabhāgato paṭṭhāya nānāvitakkavūpasamasabbhāvato.
analyzed: atha kasmai ayam eva samādhi evam visesetvā vuttaḥ ti pubba bhāgataḥ paṭṭhāya nānā vitakka vūpasama sabbhāvato
translated: Then why is this concentration alone specified? Because it allays the various kinds of applied thought beginning with the first jhāna.

original: Vuttañhetaṃ – “ānāpānassati bhāvetabbā vitakkupacchedāyā”ti. Apica tikkhapaññassa
analyzed: vuttam ha etam  āna apāna sati bhāvetabbā vitakka upacchedāya ati apica tikkha paññassa
translated: For this is said: “In-breaths and out-breaths contemplating a sign are to be developed in order to abandon applied thoughts” . Furthermore,🔽this meditation subject is for one of quick understanding,

original: ñāṇuttarassetaṃ kammaṭṭhānaṃ, ñāṇuttarassa ca kilesappahānaṃ itarehi sātisayaṃ, yathā🔽saddhādhimuttehi diṭṭhippattassa. Tasmā imaṃ visesaṃ sandhāya “ṭhānaso antaradhāpeti
analyzed: ñāṇa uttarassa etam kammaṭṭhānam ñāṇa uttarassa ca kilesa ppahānam itarehi sa atisayam yathā  saddhā adhimuttehi diṭṭhi ppattassa tasmai imam visesam sandhāya ṭhānasaḥ antaradhāpeti
translated: and the abandoning of defilements by one of quick understanding is more outstanding than that by others,🔽just as the penetration of the characteristics of impermanence, etc., is more outstanding in one whose faith is confirmed by insight than in one who has merely reached the stages of purification of virtue and so on.🔽So this distinction should be understood as the reason why it is said that “it causes them to disappear and to allay in being” .

original: vūpasametī”ti vuttaṃ. Atha vā nimittapātubhāve sati khaṇeneva aṅgapātubhāvasabbhāvato
analyzed: vūpasameti iti vuttam atha vā nimitta pātubhāve sati khaṇena iva aṅga pātubhāva sabbhāvato
translated: Or alternatively, because the appearance of the factors is immediate when the sign appears,

original: ayameva samādhi “ṭhānaso antaradhāpeti vūpasametī”ti vutto. Yathā taṃ mahato akālameghassa🔽uṭṭhitassa dhārānipāte khaṇeneva pathaviyaṃ rajojallassa vūpasamo. Tenāha – “seyyathāpi,
analyzed: ayam eva samādhi ṭhānasaḥ antaradhāpeti vūpasameti iti vuttaḥ yathā tam mahataḥ akāla meghassa  uṭṭhitassa dhārā nipāte khaṇena iva pathaviyam rajaḥ jallassa vūpasamo tena āha seyyathā api
translated: This concentration is called “disappears and subsides in its own source” as a great untimely cloud🔽disappears and subsides on the earth in a moment with the fall of its rain. Therefore it is said: “Bhikkhus, just as a great untimely cloud” and so forth.

original: bhikkhave, mahāakālamegho uṭṭhito”tiādi. Sāsanikassa jhānabhāvanā yebhuyyena nibbedhabhāgiyāva
analyzed: bhikkhave mahā akāla meghaḥ uṭṭhito tiādi sāsanikassa jhāna bhāvanā yebhuyyena nibbedha bhāgiyā ava
translated: The development of concentration in one who is a disciple of the Buddha is mostly of the kind called “conducive to penetration” .

original: hotīti āha “nibbedhabhāgiyattā”ti. Buddhānaṃ pana ekaṃsena nibbedhabhāgiyāva hoti.
analyzed: hoti iti āha nibbedha bhāgiya ttā ati buddhānam pana ekaṃsena nibbedha bhāgiyā ava hoti
translated: Therefore it is said: “because of its being conducive to penetration.” But in the case of the Buddhas, it is entirely of the kind called “conducive to penetration.”

original: Imameva hi kammaṭṭhānaṃ bhāvetvā sabbepi sammāsambuddhā sammāsambodhiṃ adhigacchanti.
analyzed: imam eva hi kammaṭṭhānam bhāvetvā sabbe api sammāsambuddhā sammāsambodhim adhigacchanti
translated: For all the Fully Enlightened Ones attain supreme enlightenment by developing this meditation subject itself.

original: Ariyamaggassa pādakabhūto ayaṃ samādhi anukkamena vaḍḍhitvā ariyamaggabhāvaṃ upagato
analyzed: ariya maggassa pādaka bhūtaḥ ayam samādhi anukkamena vaḍḍhitvā ariya magga bhāvam upagataḥ
translated: This concentration, which is the footing for the noble path, having gradually increased, becomes like the noble path.

original: viya hotīti āha “anupubbena ariyamaggavuddhippatto”ti.
analyzed: viya hoti iti āha anupubbena ariya magga vuddhi ppatto ti
translated: Therefore it is said: “it reaches the state of gradual increase of the noble path.”

original: Ayaṃ panattho virāganirodhapaṭinissaggānupassanānaṃ vasena sammadeva yujjati. Heṭṭhā
analyzed: ayam pana atthaḥ virāga nirodha paṭinissagga anupassanānam vasena sammat eva yujjati heṭṭhā
translated: But this meaning is correct only in the sense of the contemplations of fading away, cessation, and relinquishment.

original: papañcavasena vuttamatthaṃ sukhaggahaṇatthaṃ saṅgahetvā dassento “ayaṃ panettha saṅkhepattho”ti
translated: The meaning stated by way of elaboration is given in brief in order to make it easy to grasp. Showing this, he said “The meaning here in brief is this” .

original: āha, piṇḍatthoti vuttaṃ hoti.
analyzed: āha piṇḍa attho ti vuttam hoti
translated: The meaning in brief is what is meant.

original: 217. Tamatthanti taṃ “kathaṃ bhāvito”tiādinā pucchāvasena saṅkhepato vuttamatthaṃ.
analyzed: tam attham ti tam katham bhāvita uti ādinā pucchā vasena saṅkhepataḥ vuttam attham
translated: The meaning of that is the meaning stated in brief by way of the question “How is it developed?”

original: “Idha tathāgato loke uppajjatī”tiādīsu idha-saddo lokaṃ upādāya vutto, “idheva tiṭṭhamānassā”tiādīsu🔽okāsaṃ, “idhāhaṃ, bhikkhave, bhuttāvī assaṃ pavārito”tiādīsu padapūraṇamattaṃ, “idha
analyzed: idha tathāgataḥ loke uppajjati itiādīsu idha saddaḥ lokam upādāya vuttaḥ idha iva tiṭṭhamānassa atiādīsu  okāsam idha aham bhikkhave bhuttāvī assam pavāritaḥ iti ādīsu pada pūraṇa mattam idha
translated: In such passages as “Here, a Tathāgata appears in the world” the word “here” is used in reference to the world. In such passages as “While standing right here”

original: bhikkhu dhammaṃ pariyāpuṇātī”tiādīsu pana sāsanaṃ, “idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhū”ti idhāpi🔽sāsanamevāti dassento “bhikkhave, imasmiṃ sāsane bhikkhū”ti vatvā tamatthaṃ pākaṭaṃ
analyzed: bhikkhu dhammam pariyāpuṇāti iti ādīsu pana sāsanam idha bhikkhave bhikkhu iti idha api  sāsanam eva āti dassentaḥ bhikkhave imasmin sāsane bhikkhū iti vatvā tam attham pākaṭam
translated: it refers to a place. In such passages as “Here, bhikkhus, I have eaten and refused more food” it is used merely to fill out the verse. In such passages as “Here, bhikkhus, a bhikkhu learns the Dhamma” it refers to the Dispensation. Here too it refers to the Dispensation.

original: katvā dassetuṃ “ayañhī”tiādi vuttaṃ. Tattha sabbappakāraānāpānassatisamādhinibbattakassāti
analyzed: katvā dassetum ayam hi itiādi vuttam tattha sabba ppakāra āna apāna ssati samādhi nibbattakassa ati
translated: Showing this, he said “Bhikkhus, in this Dispensation” and then, in order to make the meaning clear, he said “For this is said” and so on. Herein, he is the producer of the concentration of mindfulness of breathing in all its forms.

original: sabbappakāraggahaṇaṃ soḷasa pakāre sandhāya. Te hi imasmiṃyeva sāsane. Bāhirakā hi
analyzed: sabba ppakāra ggahaṇam soḷasa pakāre sandhāya te hi imasmin yeva sāsane bāhirakāḥ hi
translated: The phrase “in every way” is said with reference to the sixteen modes. For these sixteen modes are found in this dispensation alone.

original: jānantā ādito catuppakārameva jānanti. Tenāha “aññasāsanassa tathābhāvapaṭisedhano”ti,
analyzed: jānantā āditas catu pakāram eva jānanti tena āha añña sāsanassa tathābhāva paṭisedhanā ti
translated: For outsiders know only the four modes beginning with in-breath and out-breath. That is why it is said: “to refute the existence of such a person in any other dispensation.”

original: yathāvuttassa puggalassa nissayabhāvapaṭisedhanoti attho. Etena “idha bhikkhave”ti
analyzed: yathā vuttassa puggalassa nissaya bhāva paṭisedhano ti atthaḥ etena idha bhikkhave ti
translated: The meaning is: to refute the existence of such a person as a preceptor. By this he shows that the words “here, bhikkhus”

original: idaṃ antogadhevasaddanti dasseti. Santi hi ekapadānipi sāvadhāraṇāni yathā “vāyubhakkho”ti.
analyzed: idam dasseti santi hi eka padāni pi sa avadhāraṇāni yathā
translated: include the word “only.” For there are single words that have the sense of “only,” as in the passage: “One who eats what is thrown to him” .

original: Tenevāha “idheva, bhikkhave, samaṇo”tiādi. Paripuṇṇasamaṇakaraṇadhammo hi so, yo
analyzed: tena iva āha idha iva bhikkhave samaṇa uti ādi paripuṇṇa samaṇa karaṇa dhammaḥ hi saḥ yaḥ
translated: That is why it is said: “Here, bhikkhus, only a recluse” . For he is a recluse in the full sense who has produced the concentration consisting in mindfulness of breathing in and out in all its aspects.

original: sabbappakāraānāpānassatisamādhinibbattako. Parappavādāti paresaṃ aññatitthiyānaṃ🔽nānappakārā vādā titthāyatanāni.
analyzed: sabba ppakāra āna apāna ssati samādhi nibbattako para ppavādā ti paresam añña titthiyānam  nānappakārā vādāḥ titthāyatanāni
translated: “Other doctrines”: the various doctrines, the abodes of the various sects.

original: Araññādikasseva bhāvanānurūpasenāsanataṃ dassetuṃ “imassa hī”tiādi vuttaṃ. Duddamo
analyzed: arañña ādikassa iva bhāvanā anurūpa senāsana tam dassetum imassa hi itiādi vuttam duddamo
translated: “A forest-dweller” and so on are said in order to show that the dwelling place is suitable for the development of concentration. “For this bhikkhu”

original: damathaṃ anupagato goṇo kūṭagoṇo. Yathā thanehi sabbaso khīraṃ na paggharati, evaṃ🔽dohapaṭibandhinī kūṭadhenu. Rūpasaddādike paṭicca uppajjanako assādo rūpārammaṇādiraso.
analyzed: damatham an upagataḥ goṇaḥ kūṭa goṇaḥ yathā thanehi sabbasas khīram na paggharati evam  doha paṭibandhinī kūṭadhenu rūpa sadda ādike paṭicca uppajjanakaḥ assādaḥ rūpa ārammaṇa ādi rasaḥ
translated: A bull that has not been tamed is a wild bull. Just as milk does not flow from a cow that has no calf or whose calf is dead unless she is milked,🔽so the milk of the meditation subject does not flow unless the meditator makes an effort.🔽The flavour of the meditation subject is the enjoyment that arises dependent on the sign.

original: Pubbe āciṇṇārammaṇanti pabbajjato pubbe, anādimati vā saṃsāre paricitārammaṇaṃ.🔽Nibandheyyāti bandheyya. Satiyāti sammadeva kammaṭṭhānasallakkhaṇasampavattāya satiyā.
analyzed: pubbe āciṇṇa ārammaṇanti pabbajjataḥ pubbe anādimati vā saṃsāre paricita ārammaṇaṃ  nibandheyya ati bandheyya satiyā ati sammat eva kammaṭṭhāna sallakkhaṇa sampavattāya satiyā
translated: The familiar object is the object that was discerned before one went forth into homelessness or the object that was discerned in a previous state of consciousness in the course of this present existence that extends from the moment of rebirth-linking up to the time of the arising of the meditation subject.🔽One should bind one’s mind to that object and keep it anchored there by means of the anchoring mindfulness.

original: Ārammaṇeti kammaṭṭhānārammaṇe. Daḷhanti thiraṃ, yathā satokārissa upacārappanābhedo
analyzed: ārammaṇa iti kammaṭṭhāna ārammaṇe daḷhanti thiram yathā satokārissa upacāra ppanā bhedaḥ
translated: The object is the object of the meditation subject. Firmly: firmly, steadily. The meaning is that it should be made to reach absorption by the development of the absorption of the fine-material sphere, etc.,

original: samādhi ijjhati, tathā thāmagataṃ katvāti attho.🔽Visesādhigamadiṭṭhadhammasukhavihārapadaṭṭhānanti sabbesaṃ buddhānaṃ, ekaccānaṃ paccekabuddhānaṃ,
analyzed: samādhi ijjhati tathā thāma gatam katvā iti attho  visesa adhigama diṭṭha dhamma sukha vihāra padaṭṭhānanti sabbesam buddhānam ekaccānam paccekabuddhānam
translated: which is the condition for the attainment of distinction.🔽The basis for the attainment of distinction and for abiding in bliss here and now is the basis for the attainment of distinction by all Buddhas, by some Paccekabuddhas and disciples,

original: buddhasāvakānañca visesādhigamassa ceva aññakammaṭṭhānena adhigatavisesānaṃ diṭṭhadhammasukhavihārassa
analyzed: buddha sāvakānaṃ ca visesa adhigamassa ca iva añña kammaṭṭhānena adhigata visesānam diṭṭha dhamma sukha vihārassa
translated: and for the abiding in bliss here and now by all Buddhas and some Paccekabuddhas and disciples,

original: ca padaṭṭhānabhūtaṃ.
analyzed: ca padaṭṭhāna bhūtam
translated: which is attained by means of a meditation subject other than the one already obtained.

original: Vatthuvijjācariyo viya bhagavā yogīnaṃ anurūpanivāsaṭṭhānupadisanato.
analyzed: vatthuvijjā cariyaḥ bhagavā yogīnam anurūpa nivāsa ṭhāna upadisanataḥ
translated: The Blessed One is like the teacher of the science of ground-prognostication since he points out to meditators the places suitable for the various kinds of jhāna.

original: Bhikkhu dīpisadiso araññe ekiko viharitvā paṭipakkhanimmathanena icchitatthasādhanato.🔽Phalamuttamanti sāmaññaphalamāha. Parakkamajavayoggabhūminti bhāvanussāhajavassa
analyzed: bhikkhu dīpi sadisaḥ araññe ekikaḥ viharitvā paṭipakkha nimmathanena icchitattha sādhanato  phalam uttaman ti sāmañña phalam āha parakkama java yogga bhūmin ti bhāva nussāha javassa
translated: The bhikkhu is like the deer since he lives alone in the forest and by the exertion of the return stroke accomplishes his desired purpose.

original: yoggakaraṇabhūmibhūtaṃ.
analyzed: yogga karaṇa bhūmi bhūtam
translated: The highest fruit: he refers to the fruit of the life of purity. The ground for the exercise of the energy of exertion: the ground for the exercise of the energy of development.

original: 218. Evaṃ vuttalakkhaṇesūti abhidhammapariyāyena, suttantapariyāyena ca vuttalakkhaṇesu.🔽Rukkhasamīpanti “yāvatā majjhanhike kāle samantā chāyā pharati, nivāte paṇṇāni patanti,
analyzed: evam vutta lakkhaṇesu iti abhidhamma pariyāyena suttanta pariyāyena ca vutta lakkhaṇesu  rukkha samīpanti yāvatā majjhanhike kāle samantā chāyā pharati nivāte paṇṇāni patanti
translated: In the characteristics stated thus: in the characteristics stated in the Abhidhamma and in the Suttanta.

original: ettāvatā rukkhamūlanti vuccatī”ti evaṃ vuttaṃ rukkhassa samīpaṭṭhānaṃ. Avasesasattavidhasenāsananti
analyzed: ettāvatā rukkha mūlanti vuccati iti evam vuttam rukkhassa samīpa ṭṭhānam avasesa sattavidha senāsanam ti
translated: The vicinity of a tree: the vicinity of a tree is stated thus: “As far as the shade extends from a tree at midday, as far as the leaves rustle in a gentle breeze, as far as the branches spread by their own weight, that is called the vicinity of a tree” . The remaining seven kinds of resting place:

original: pabbataṃ kandaraṃ giriguhaṃ susānaṃ vanapatthaṃ abbhokāsaṃ palālapuñjanti evaṃ vuttaṃ.
analyzed: pabbatam kandaram giri guham su sānam vana pattham abbhokāsam palāla puñjanti evam vuttam
translated: a mountain, a gorge, a rocky mountain cave, a cemetery, a forest grove, the open air, a heap of straw, are stated thus.

original: Ututtayānukūlaṃ dhātucariyānukūlanti gimhādiututtayassa, semhādidhātuttayassa, mohādicariyattayassa
analyzed: dhātu cariyā anukūlam gimha ādi ututtayassa semha ādi dhātuttayassa moha ādi cariya ttayassa
translated: In conformity with the three seasons, in conformity with the three humours, in conformity with the three activities,

original: ca anukūlaṃ. Tathā hi gimhakāle ca araññaṃ anukūlaṃ, hemante rukkhamūlaṃ, vassakāle🔽suññāgāraṃ, semhadhātukassa semhapakatikassa araññaṃ, pittadhātukassa rukkhamūlaṃ,🔽vātadhātukassa suññāgāraṃ anukūlaṃ, mohacaritassa araññaṃ, dosacaritassa rukkhamūlaṃ,
analyzed: ca anukūlam tathā hi gimha kāle ca araññam anukūlam hemante rukkha mūlam vassa kāle  suññāgāram semha dhātukassa semha pakatikassa araññam pitta dhātukassa rukkha mūlam  vāta dhātukassa suññāgāram anukūlam moha caritassa araññam dosa caritassa rukkha mūlam
translated: in conformity with the three seasons, namely, the hot season, the cold season, and the rainy season, in conformity with the three humours, namely, phlegm, bile, and wind, and in conformity with the three activities, namely, delusion, hate, and greed.🔽For the forest is suitable in the hot season, the foot of a tree in the cold season, and an empty place in the rainy season.🔽The forest is suitable for one of phlegm humour, the foot of a tree for one of bile humour, and an empty place for one of wind humour.🔽The forest is suitable for one of deluded temperament, the foot of a tree for one of hating temperament, and an empty place for one of greedy temperament.

original: rāgacaritassa suññāgāraṃ anukūlaṃ. Alīnānuddhaccapakkhikanti asaṅkocāvikkhepapakkhikaṃ.
analyzed: rāga caritassa suññāgāram anukūlam a līna an uddhacca pakkhikaṃ ti a saṅkoca avikkhepa pakkhikaṃ
translated: Not tending to sloth and torpor, not tending to agitation and worry.

original: Sayanañhi kosajjapakkhikaṃ, ṭhānacaṅkamanāni uddhaccapakkhikāni, na evaṃ nisajjā.
analyzed: sayanam hi kosajja pakkhikam ṭhāna caṅkamanāni uddhacca pakkhikāni na evam nisajjā
translated: For lying down tends to sloth and torpor, standing and walking to agitation and worry, but sitting does not do so to the same extent.

original: Tato evassa santatā. Nisajjāya daḷhabhāvaṃ pallaṅkābhujanena, assāsapassāsānaṃ pavattanasukhataṃ
analyzed: tatas evassa santatā nisajjāya daḷha bhāvam pallaṅka ābhujanena assāsa passāsānam
translated: That is why it is said to be “in a posture that is neither too hard nor too soft.” The fact that sitting is neither too hard nor too soft is shown by the phrase “having established mindfulness in front of him.” The fact that in-breaths and out-breaths are easy to detect is shown by the phrase “having well-established mindfulness.”

original: uparimakāyassa ujukaṭṭhapanena, ārammaṇapariggahūpāyaṃ parimukhaṃ satiyā ṭhapanena
analyzed: uparima kāyassa ujuka ṭṭhapanena ārammaṇa pariggaha upāyam parimukham satiyā ṭhapanena
translated: By straightening the upper body, he places mindfulness in front by means of the method of apprehending the object.

original: dassento. Ūrubaddhāsananti ūrūnamadhobandhanavasena nisajjā. Heṭṭhimakāyassa anujukaṃ🔽ṭhapanaṃ nisajjā-vacaneneva bodhitanti “ujuṃ kāya”nti ettha kāya-saddo uparimakāyavisayoti
analyzed: dassentaḥ ūru baddha āsananti ūrūnam adhas bandhana vasena nisajja heṭṭhima kāyassa  ṭhapanam nisajjā vacanena iva bodhitanti ujum kāyanti ettha kāya saddo uparima kāya visayo ti
translated: The sitting posture with the thighs bound together is the sitting posture with the thighs bound together below. The straightening of the lower body🔽is indicated by the word “sitting posture.” The word “body” in the phrase “straighten the body” refers to the upper body,

original: āha “uparimasarīraṃ ujukaṃ ṭhapetvā”ti. Taṃ pana ujukaṭṭhapanaṃ sarūpato, payojanato
analyzed: āha uparima sarīram ujukam ṭhapetvā iti tam pana ujuka ṭhapanam sarūpataḥ
translated: he says, “having straightened the upper body.” But in order to show that straightening in its individual essence and its purpose,

original: ca dassetuṃ “aṭṭhārasā”tiādi vuttaṃ. Na paṇamantīti na onamanti. Na paripatatīti
analyzed: ca dassetum aṭṭhārasa iti ādi vuttam na paṇamanti iti na onamanti na paripatati iti
translated: it is said, “the eighteen downfalls,” etc. They do not bend down: they do not bow down. It does not waver:

original: na vigacchati vīthiṃ na vilaṅghati, tato eva pubbenāparaṃ visesuppattiyā vuddhiṃ🔽phātiṃ upagacchati. Idha pari-saddo abhi-saddena samānatthoti āha “kammaṭṭhānābhimukha”nti,
analyzed: na vigacchati vīthim na vilaṅghati tatas eva pubbena aparam visesuppattiyā vuddhim  phātim upagacchati idha parisaddaḥ abhisaddena samāna tthaḥ ti āha kammaṭṭhāna abhimukhanti
translated: it does not depart. It does not fail in the course: it does not deviate from the course. For that very reason, it reaches growth🔽and increase by the arising of distinction in the later part over the earlier.🔽Here the prefix pari has the same meaning as abhi. Therefore he says, “facing the meditation subject.”

original: bahiddhā puthuttārammaṇato nivāretvā kammaṭṭhānaṃyeva purakkhitvāti attho. Parīti
analyzed: bahiddhā puthutta ārammaṇataḥ nivāretvā kammaṭṭhānam yeva purakkhitvā ti attho pari iti
translated: The meaning is: having excluded external miscellaneous objects, he places the meditation subject in front.

original: pariggahaṭṭho “pariṇāyikā”tiādīsu viya. Niyyānaṭṭho paṭipakkhato niggamanaṭṭho. Tasmā🔽pariggahitaniyyānanti sabbathā gahitāsammosaṃ pariccattasammosaṃ satiṃ katvā, paramaṃ
analyzed: pariggaha aṭṭho pariṇāyikā ti ādīsu viya niyyāna aṭṭho paṭipakkhataḥ niggamana ṭṭho tasmā  pariggahita niyyānam ti sabbathā gahita asammosam pariccatta sammosam satim katvā paramam
translated: The meaning of “taking up” is like that of “taking up” in such passages as “The mother is the first bringer, the first nourisher” . The meaning of “going out” is the meaning of “going forth” from the opposite .

original: satinepakkaṃ upaṭṭhapetvāti attho.🔽219. Satovāti satiyā samannāgato eva saranto eva assasati nāssa kāci sativirahitā
analyzed: sati nepakkam upaṭṭhapetvā ti attho  satovāti satiyā samannāgato eva sarantaḥ eva assasati na assa kāci sati virahitā
translated: Therefore it is said: “He trains thus: ‘I shall breathe in … shall breathe out liberating the manner of consciousness belonging to the in-breath … out-breath.’ ”

original: assāsappavatti hotīti attho. Sato passasatīti etthāpi satova passasatīti eva-saddo
analyzed: assāsa ppavatti hoti iti attho sataḥ passasati iti ettha api sataḥ iva passasati iti eva saddaḥ
translated: “Mindfully”: he breathes in and breathes out only with mindfulness, only with recollection; there is no in-breaths and out-breaths that are devoid of mindfulness, devoid of recollection, for him. This is the meaning. “Mindfully he breathes in, mindfully he breathes out”: the word “mindfully” should be brought in here too.

original: ānetvā vattabbo. Satokārīti sato eva hutvā, satiyā eva vā kātabbassa kattā, karaṇasīlo
analyzed: ānetvā vattabbo satokārī iti sataḥ eva hutvā satiyāḥ eva vā kātabbassa kattā karaṇa sīlo
translated: “One who acts mindfully”: one who acts only with mindfulness, or one who has the habit of acting with mindfulness.

original: vā. Yadi “satova assasati sato passasatī”ti etassa vibhaṅge vuttaṃ, atha kasmā “assasati
analyzed: vā yadi sataḥ iva assasati sataḥ passasati iti etassa vibhaṅge vuttam atha kasmai assasati
translated: If it is said that “he breathes in mindfully, breathes out mindfully,” why is it said in the Vibhaṅga: “How does he breathe in, how does he breathe out mindfully? He breathes in … breathes out contemplating relinquishment” ?🔽Because he wants to give a teaching with a single theme.

original: passasati”cceva avatvā “satokārī”ti vuttaṃ? Ekarasaṃ desanaṃ kātukāmatāya. Paṭhamacatukke
analyzed: a vatvā satokārī iti vuttam ekarasam desanam kātu kāma tāya paṭhama catukke
translated: In the first tetrad

original: padadvayameva hi vattamānakālavasena āgataṃ, itarāni anāgatakālavasena. Tasmā ekarasaṃ
analyzed: pada dvayam eva hi vattamāna kāla vasena āgatam itarāni anāgata kāla vasena tasmai ekarasam
translated: for the two terms come in the present tense, the others in the future tense. So they are of one meaning.

original: desanaṃ kātukāmatāya sabbattha “satokāri”cceva vuttaṃ.🔽Dīghaṃ assāsavasenāti dīghaassāsavasena vibhattialopaṃ katvā niddeso. Dīghanti vā
analyzed: desanam kātu kāma tāya sabbattha vuttam  dīgham assa asa vasena ati dīgha assa asa vasena vibhatti a lopam katvā niddesaḥ dīgham ti vā
translated: For the two terms are stated in the present tense, while the others are stated in the future tense. So he said “he trains thus: ‘I shall breathe in … shall breathe out experiencing happiness’ in all cases in order to give emphasis to the practice as a single method.🔽The exposition is by way of the long in-breath and out-breath. The long in-breath and out-breath are stated by the Blessed One as “long.”🔽When he knows unification of cognizance and non-distraction through in-breaths and out-breaths long, he knows unification of cognizance and non- distraction by means of the in-breaths and out-breaths long.🔽The meaning is this: when he is aware of the in-breaths and out-breaths long as they occur, then his cognizance is unified and not distracted.

original: bhagavatā vuttaassāsavasena. Cittassa ekaggataṃ avikkhepanti vikkhepassa paṭipakkhabhāvato
analyzed: bhagavatā vutta assāsa vasena cittassa ekagga tam a vikkhepanti vikkhepassa paṭipakkha bhāvato
translated: Or alternatively, when he is aware of the in-breaths and out-breaths long as they occur, then his cognizance is unified and not distracted.

original: “avikkhepo”ti laddhanāmacittassa ekaggabhāvaṃ pajānato. Sati upaṭṭhitā hotīti ārammaṇaṃ🔽upagantvā ṭhitā hoti. Tāya satiyā tena ñāṇenāti yathāvuttāya satiyā, yathāvuttena
analyzed: avikkhepaḥ ti laddha nāma cittassa ekagga bhāvam pajānataḥ sati upaṭṭhitā hoti iti ārammaṇam  upagantvā ṭhitā hoti tāya satiyā tena ñāṇena ati yathāvuttāya satiyā yathāvuttena
translated: The meaning is this: when he is aware of the in-breaths and out-breaths long as they occur, then his cognizance is unified and not distracted.🔽Or alternatively, when he is aware of the in-breaths and out-breaths long as they occur, then his cognizance is unified and not distracted.🔽The meaning is this: when he is aware of the in-breaths and out-breaths long as they occur, then his cognizance is unified and not distracted.🔽The meaning is this: when he is aware of the in-breaths and out-breaths long as they occur, then his cognizance is unified and not distracted.🔽The meaning is this: when he is aware of the in-breaths and out-breaths long as they occur, then his cognizance is unified and not distracted.🔽The meaning is this: when he is aware of the in-breaths and out-breaths long as they occur, then his cognizance is unified and not distracted.🔽The meaning is this: when he is aware of the in-breaths and out-breaths long as they occur, then his cognizance is unified and not distracted.

original: ca ñāṇena. Idaṃ vutta hoti – dīghaṃ assāsaṃ ārammaṇabhūtaṃ avikkhittacittassa, asammohato🔽vā pajānantassa tattha sati upaṭṭhitā eva hoti, taṃ sampajānantassa ārammaṇakaraṇavasena,
analyzed: ca ñāṇena idam vutta hoti dīgham assāsam ārammaṇa bhūtam avikkhitta cittassa asammohato 🔽vā pajānantassa tattha sati upaṭṭhitā eva hoti tam sampajānantassa ārammaṇa karaṇa vasena
translated: The meaning is this: when he is aware of the in-breaths and out-breaths long as they occur, then his cognizance is unified and not distracted.🔽The meaning is this: when he is aware of the

original: asammohavasena vā sampajaññaṃ, tadadhīnasatisampajaññena taṃsamaṅgī yogāvacaro satokārī🔽nāma hotīti. Paṭinissaggānupassī assāsavasenāti paṭinissaggānupassī hutvā assasanassa
analyzed: asammoha vasena vā sampajaññam tad adhīna sati sampajaññena tad samaṅgī yogāvacaraḥ  nāma hoti iti paṭinissagga anupassī assāsa vasena ati paṭinissagga anupassī hutvā assasanassa
translated: Or else, understanding is the state of being unconfused, and the meditator who possesses understanding, which is dependent on mindfulness, is called “one who has mindfulness and understanding” and “one who acts with understanding”

original: vasena. “Paṭinissaggānupassīassāsavasenā”ti vā pāṭho. Tassa paṭinissaggānupassino
analyzed: vasena paṭinissagga anupassī assāsa vasena ati vā pāṭhaḥ tassa paṭinissagga anupassino
translated: . Contemplating relinquishment by means of in-breaths and out-breaths: having become one who contemplates relinquishment, by means of in-breaths and out-breaths. Or there is the reading “Contemplating relinquishment by in-breaths and out-breaths contemplating relinquishment.” In-breaths and out-breaths of one who contemplates relinquishment are “in-breaths and out-breaths contemplating relinquishment.” By means of those, is the meaning.🔽In the method of training, the in-breath is the occurrence of the in-breath internally, and the out-breath is the occurrence of the out-breath externally.

original: assāsā paṭinissaggānupassīassāsā, tesaṃ vasenāti attho. Vinayanayena anto uṭṭhitasasanaṃ🔽assāso, bahi uṭṭhitasasanaṃ passāso. Suttantanayena pana bahi uṭṭhahitvāpi anto sasanato🔽assāso, anto uṭṭhahitvāpi bahi sasanato passāso. Ayameva ca nayo –🔽“Assāsādimajjhapariyosānaṃ satiyā anugacchato ajjhattaṃ vikkhepagatena cittena kāyopi
analyzed: tesam vasena ati atthaḥ vinaya nayena antaḥ uṭṭhita sasanam  assāsaḥ bahi uṭṭhita sasanam passāsaḥ suttanta nayena pana bahi uṭṭhahitvā api antar sasanato  assāsaḥ antar uṭṭhahitvā api bahi sasanataḥ passāsaḥ ayam eva ca nayaḥ  assāsa ādimajjha pariyosānam satiyā anugacchataḥ ajjhattam vikkhepa gatena cittena kāyaḥ api
translated: But in the method of the discourses, the in-breath is the occurrence of the out-breath internally, and the out-breath is the occurrence of the in-breath externally.🔽And this is the method:🔽“When he follows with mindfulness the in-breath and out-breath that have started up, his mind does not go out from the in-breath and out-breath, and his body and mind are tranquilized by the in-breath and out-breath, and his mind does not leave the in-breath and out-breath, and his mind does not go outside, and his mind does not go inside, and his mind does not go outside and inside, and his mind does not go to stay in the past, and his mind does not go to stay in the future, and his mind does not go to stay in the present internally, and his mind does not go to stay in the present externally, and his mind does not go to stay in the present internally and externally, and his mind does not go to stay in the present thus: ‘Was my in-breath and out-breath in the past thus? Will my in-breath and out-breath be in the future thus? Are my in-breath and out-breath in the present thus?’

original: cittampi sāraddhā ca honti iñjitā ca phanditā cā”ti, “passāsādimajjhapariyosānaṃ
analyzed: cittam pi sāraddhā ca honti iñjitā ca phanditā ca ati passāsa ādi majjha pariyosānam
translated: “When he follows with mindfulness the in-breath and out-breath that have started up, his mind does not go out from the in-breath and out-breath, and his body and mind are tranquilized by the in-breath and out-breath, and his mind does not leave the in-breath and

original: satiyā anugacchato bahiddhā vikkhepagatena cittena kāyopi cittampi sāraddhā ca honti
analyzed: satiyā anugacchataḥ bahiddhā vikkhepa gatena cittena kāyaḥ api cittam pi sāraddhā ca honti
translated: When he follows it with mindfulness, his body and his mind are disturbed by the wind that has gone out externally.

original: iñjitā ca phanditā cā”ti –
analyzed: iñjitā ca phanditā ca ati
translated: They are shaken and stirred up.”

original: Imāya pāḷiyā sameti.
analyzed: imāya pāḷiyā sameti
translated: This is in agreement with the text.

original: Paṭhamaṃ abbhantaravāto bahi nikkhamati, tasmā pavattikkamena assāso paṭhamaṃ vuttoti🔽vadanti. Tāluṃ āhacca nibbāyatīti tāluṃ āhacca nirujjhati. Tena kira sampatijāto
analyzed: paṭhamam abbhantara vāto bahi nikkhamati tasmā pavatti kkamena assāsaḥ paṭhamam vuttaḥ ti  vadanti tālum āhat ca nibbāyati iti tālum āhat ca nirujjhati tena kira sampatijātaḥ
translated: They say that the internal wind first goes out externally, and that is why in the order of occurrence intimation is stated first.🔽It is said that the infant at birth makes a sucking movement.

original: bāladārako khipitaṃ karoti. Evaṃ tāvātiādi yathāvuttassa atthassa nigamanaṃ. Keci
analyzed: bāla dārakaḥ khipitam karoti evam tāva atiādi yathāvuttassa atthassa nigamanam keci
translated: Thus, etc., is the conclusion to the meaning stated.

original: “evaṃ tāvāti anena pavattikkamena assāso bahinikkhamanavātoti gahetabbanti adhippāyo”ti vadanti.
analyzed: evam tāva iti anena pavatti kkamena assāsaḥ bahi nikkhamana vāto ti gahetabbanti adhippāyaḥ ti vadanti
translated: Some say that the intention is this: “Thus, by this order of occurrence intimation should be taken as the wind that goes out externally.”

original: Addhānavasenāti kāladdhānavasena. Ayaṃ hi addhāna-saddo kālassa, desassa ca vācako.
analyzed: addhāna vasena ati kāla ddhāna vasena ayam hi addhāna saddo kālassa desassa ca vācakaḥ
translated: By way of extent: by way of the extent of time. For this word extent is a term for time and for place.

original: Tattha desaddhānaṃ udāharaṇabhāvena dassetvā kāladdhānavasena assāsapassāsānaṃ dīgharassataṃ
analyzed: tattha desa ddhānam udāharaṇa bhāvena dassetvā kāla ddhāna vasena assāsa passāsānam
translated: Herein, the extent of place is shown by the example. The extent of time of in-breaths and out-breaths is shown by the words “in the time of … a finger’s movement” and so on.

original: vibhāvetuṃ “yathā hī”tiādi vuttaṃ. Tattha okāsaddhānanti okāsabhūtaṃ addhānaṃ. Pharitvāti🔽byāpetvā. Cuṇṇavicuṇṇāpi anekakalāpabhāvena. Dīghaṃ addhānanti dīghaṃ padesaṃ. Tasmāti🔽saṇikaṃ pavattiyā dīghasantānatāya “dīghā”ti vuccanti. Ettha ca hatthiādisarīre,
analyzed: vibhāvetum yathā hi itiādi vuttam tattha okāsa ddhānam ti okāsa bhūtam addhānam pharitvā iti  aneka kalāpa bhāvena dīgham dīgham padesam tasmā ati  saṇikam pavattiyā dīgha santāna tāya dīghā ati vuccanti ettha ca hatthi ādi sarīre
translated: “As follows” is said in order to show how. Herein, “in the space” is in the space that is the path. “Having pervaded”:🔽having filled. Even though they are in the form of particles, they are in the form of many groups. “Long path”: a long place. “Long” is said

original: sunakhādisarīre ca assāsapassāsānaṃ desaddhānavisiṭṭhena kāladdhānavaseneva dīgharassatā
analyzed: sunakha ādi sarīre ca assāsa passāsānam desa addhāna visiṭṭhena kāla ddhāna vasena iva dīgha rassa tā
translated: because of the long continuity of occurrence. And here the long and short of the in-breaths and out-breaths should be understood as stated by the time of day distinguished by the place, in the case of the bodies of elephants, etc.,

original: vuttāti veditabbā. “Saṇikaṃ pūretvā saṇikameva nikkhamanti”, “sīghaṃ pūretvā sīghameva🔽nikkhamantī”ti ca vacanato. Manussesūti samānappamāṇesupi manussasarīresu. Dīghaṃ
analyzed: vuttā iti veditabbā saṇikam pūretvā saṇikam eva nikkhamanti sīgham pūretvā sīgham eva  nikkhamanti iti ca vacanataḥ manussesu iti samāna ppamāṇesu pi manussa sarīresu dīgham
translated: and by the time of day distinguished by the place, in the case of the bodies of dogs, etc., “They fill slowly and go out slowly,” and “they fill quickly and go out quickly.”

original: assasantīti dīghaṃ assāsappabandhaṃ pavattentīti attho. Passasantīti etthāpi eseva🔽nayo. Sunakhasasādayo viya rassaṃ assasanti ca passasanti cāti yojanā. Idaṃ pana
analyzed: assasanti iti dīgham assāsa pabandham pavattenti iti attho passasanti iti ettha api esā eva 🔽nayo sunakha sasa ādayaḥ viya rassam assasanti ca passasanti ca ati yojanā idam pana
translated: “In human beings”: in human bodies of the same size. “Long”: the meaning is that they occur in a long series of in-breaths. “They breathe out long”: here too this is the method. The construction should be made in this way: “They breathe in and breathe out short like a dog, etc.”

original: dīghaṃ, rassañca assasanaṃ, passasanañca tesaṃ sattānaṃ sarīrasabhāvoti daṭṭhabbaṃ.
analyzed: dīgham rassam ca assasanam passasanam ca tesam sattānam sarīra sabhāvaḥ ti daṭṭhabbam
translated: The long and short in-breath and out-breath should be regarded as the physical basis of those beings.

original: Tesanti sattānaṃ. Teti assāsapassāsā. Ittaramaddhānanti appakaṃ kālaṃ.
analyzed: tesam ti sattānam te iti assāsa passāsāḥ ittaram addhānam ti appakam kālam
translated: ‘Those’ is beings. ‘Those’ is in-breaths and out-breaths. ‘For a little while’: for a short time.

original: Navahākārehīti bhāvanamanuyuñjantassa pubbenāparaṃ aladdhavisesassa kevalaṃ addhānavasena
analyzed: navahā ākārehi iti bhāvanam anuyuñjantassa pubbena aparam a laddha visesassa kevalam
translated: ‘With the nine grounds’: when one is devoted to development, the difference that has not been obtained previously is obtained by means of the grounds.🔽The first three grounds stated are

original: ādito vuttā tayo ākārā, te ca kho ekacco assāsaṃ suṭṭhu sallakkheti, ekacco passāsaṃ,
analyzed: āditas vuttā tayaḥ ākārā te ca kho ekaccaḥ assāsam suṭṭhu sallakkheti ekaccaḥ passāsam
translated: one who thoroughly comprehends the in-breath, one who thoroughly comprehends the out-breath,🔽and one who thoroughly comprehends both.

original: ekacco tadubhayanti imesaṃ tiṇṇaṃ puggalānaṃ vasena. Keci pana “assasatipi passasatipīti
analyzed: ekaccaḥ tad ubhayan ti imesam tiṇṇam puggalānam vasena keci pana assasati pi passasati pi iti
translated: But some say that the statement ‘he breathes in, he breathes out’

original: ekajjhaṃ vacanaṃ bhāvanāya nirantaraṃ pavattidassanattha”nti vadanti. Chandavasena
analyzed: ekajjham vacanam bhāvanāya nirantaram pavatti dassana atthanti vadanti chanda vasena
translated: is made in order to show that the development occurs uninterruptedly.🔽By means of zeal🔽there are three as before, and likewise by means of gladness.

original: pubbe viya tayo, tathā pāmojjavasenāti imehi navahākārehi.
analyzed: pubbe viya tayo tathā pāmojja vasena ati imehi navahā ākārehi
translated: So there are nine grounds.

original: Kāmaṃ cettha ekassa puggalassa tayo eva ākārā labbhanti, tantivasena pana sabbesaṃ
analyzed: kāmam ca ittha ekassa puggalassa tayaḥ eva ākārāḥ labbhanti tanti vasena pana sabbesam
translated: Though only three grounds are possible for one person, still they are stated

original: pāḷiāruḷhattā, tesaṃ vasena parikammassa kātabbattā ca “tatrāyaṃ bhikkhu navahākārehī”ti🔽vuttaṃ. Evaṃ pajānatoti evaṃ yathāvuttehi ākārehi assāsapassāse pajānato, tattha
analyzed: pāḷi āruḷha ttā tesam vasena parikammassa kātabba ttā ca tatra ayam bhikkhu navahā ākārehi iti  vuttam evam pajānataḥ ti evam yathā vuttehi ākārehi assāsa passāse pajānataḥ tattha
translated: Because they are the basis for the learning sign, and because the preliminary work must be done by means of them, it is said: “Here a bhikkhu, while breathing in long, knows: ‘I breathe in long’ … while breathing out long, knows: ‘I breathe out long’ … while breathing in short, knows: ‘I breathe in short’ … while breathing out short, knows: ‘I breathe out short’ … I shall breathe in … out experiencing the whole body … I shall breathe in … out tranquilizing the body formation” .🔽When he understands thus, when he knows thus, his consciousness is not distracted and scattered externally nor does he remain obsessed with the physical body internally, and so he is called “one who is mindful of in-breaths and out-breaths in all aspects.”

original: manasikāraṃ pavattentassa. Ekenākārenāti dīghaṃ assāsādīsu catūsu ākāresu ekena ākārena,🔽navasu tīsu vā ekena. Tathā hi vakkhati –🔽“Dīgho rasso ca assāso, passāsopi ca tādiso;🔽Cattāro vaṇṇā vattanti, nāsikagge va bhikkhuno”ti.
analyzed: manasikāram pavattentassa ekena ākārena ati dīgham assa as ādīsu catūsu ākāresu ekena ākārena  navasu tīsu vā ekena tathā hi vakkhati  dīghaḥ rassaḥ ca assāsaḥ ca tādisaḥ  cattāro vaṇṇāḥ vattanti nāsikagge va bhikkhuno ti
translated: “When he understands thus, when he knows thus, his consciousness is not distracted and scattered externally”: his consciousness does not go out to the external object consisting of the five cords of sense desire.🔽“Nor does he remain obsessed with the physical body internally”: he does not remain obsessed with the internal physical body.

original: Ayaṃ bhāvanā assāsapassāsakāyānupassanāti katvā vuttaṃ “kāyānupassanāsatipaṭṭhānabhāvanā sampajjatī”ti.
analyzed: ayam bhāvanā assāsa passāsa kāya anupassanā ti katvā vuttam kāya anupassanā sati paṭṭhāna bhāvanā sampajjati iti
translated: “And so he is called ‘one who is mindful of in-breaths and out-breaths in all aspects’”: he is called one who is mindful of in-breaths and out-breaths in all aspects because he is mindful of in-breaths and out-breaths in all aspects.

original: Idāni pāḷivaseneva te nava ākāre, bhāvanāvidhiñca dassetuṃ “yathāhā”tiādi āraddhaṃ.
analyzed: idāni pāḷi vasena iva te nava ākāre bhāvanā vidhiñca dassetum yathā āha atiādi āraddham
translated: The meaning should be understood in this way.

original: Tattha kathaṃ pajānātīti pajānanavidhiṃ kathetukamyatāya pucchati. Dīghaṃ assāsanti
analyzed: tattha katham pajānāti iti pajānana vidhim kathā itu kamyatāya pucchati dīgham
translated: “He trains thus: ‘I shall breathe in experiencing the mind’; he trains thus: ‘I shall breathe out experiencing the mind’” : he trains thus: “I shall breathe in making the mind the object; I shall breathe out making the mind the object.”🔽“He trains thus: ‘I shall breathe in gladdening the mind’; he trains thus: ‘I shall breathe out gladdening the mind’” : he trains thus: “I shall breathe in making the mind joyful; I shall breathe out making the mind joyful.”🔽“He trains thus: ‘I shall breathe in concentrating the mind’; he trains thus: ‘I shall breathe out concentrating the mind’” : he trains thus: “I shall breathe in making the mind one-pointed; I shall breathe out making the mind one-pointed.”🔽“He trains thus: ‘I shall breathe in liberating the mind’; he trains thus: ‘I shall breathe out liberating the mind’” : he trains thus: “I shall breathe in

original: vuttalakkhaṇaṃ dīghaṃ assāsaṃ. Addhānasaṅkhāteti “addhāna”nti saṅkhaṃ gate dīghe🔽kāle, dīghaṃ khaṇanti attho. Koṭṭhāsapariyāyo vā saṅkhāta-saddo “theyyasaṅkhāta”ntiādīsu🔽viya, tasmā addhānasaṅkhāteti addhānakoṭṭhāse, desabhāgeti attho. Chando uppajjatīti🔽bhāvanāya pubbenāparaṃ visesaṃ āvahantiyā laddhassādattā tattha sātisayo kattukāmatālakkhaṇo
analyzed: vutta lakkhaṇam dīgham assāsam addhāna saṅkhātā iti addhāna nti saṅkham gate dīghe  kāle dīgham atthaḥ koṭṭhāsa pariyāyaḥ vā saṅkhāta saddaḥ theyya saṅkhāta nti ādīsu  tasmai addhāna saṅkhātā iti addhāna koṭṭhāse desa bhāge iti attho chandaḥ uppajjati iti  bhāvanāya pubbena aparam visesam āvahantiyāḥ laddhassa ādattā tattha sa atisayaḥ kattu kāma tā lakkhaṇo
translated: Long in-breath is the characteristic stated. In the time reckoned as long: in long time reckoned as “time,” the meaning is, in a long moment. Or the word “reckoned” is a synonym for “part,” as in such passages as “reckoned as theft” . Therefore in the time reckoned as long means in a part of time, the meaning is, in a place. Desire arises: the desire that has the characteristic of a strong wish to act arises there because of the satisfaction obtained through the development of the successive special qualities.

original: kusalacchando uppajjati. Chandavasenāti tathāpavattachandassa vasena savisesaṃ bhāvanamanuyuñjantassa🔽kammaṭṭhānaṃ vuddhiṃ phātiṃ gamentassa. Tato sukhumataranti yathāvuttachandappavattiyā🔽purimato sukhumataraṃ. Bhāvanābalena hi paṭippassaddhadarathapariḷāhatāya kāyassa
analyzed: kusala chandaḥ uppajjati chanda vasena ati tathā pavatta chandassa vasena sa visesam bhāvanam anuyuñjantassa 🔽kammaṭṭhānam vuddhim phātim gamentassa tatas sukhumataranti yathāvutta chanda ppavattiyā 🔽purimatas sukhumataram bhāvanā balena hi paṭippassaddha daratha pariḷāha tāya kāyassa
translated: Long in-breath is the characteristic stated. In the time reckoned as long: in the long time reckoned as “time”; the meaning is, in a long moment. Or the word “reckoned” is a synonym for “section” as in such passages as “reckoned as theft” . Therefore in the time reckoned as long means in a section of time reckoned as long; the meaning is, in a space of time. Desire arises: desire that is wholesome, which is characterized by keenness to act, arises in him in abundance owing to the satisfaction produced by the progress of the development in the way already stated. By means of desire: by means of desire that occurs thus. One who devotes himself to development with that desire, which is accompanied by distinction, will make the meditation subject grow and reach its culmination. More subtle than that: more subtle than the kind already stated. For with the growth of the meditation subject the body becomes tranquilized and the in-breaths and out-breaths become more and more subtle.

original: assāsapassāsā sukhumatarā hutvā pavattanti. Pāmojjaṃ uppajjatīti assāsapassāsānaṃ
analyzed: assāsa passāsā sukhumatarā hutvā pavattanti pāmojjam uppajjati iti assāsa passāsānam
translated: The in-breaths and out-breaths occur more subtly. Joy arises: with the in-breaths and out-breaths occurring more subtly, the object becomes more and more tranquil, and the meditation subject enters its course.

original: sukhumatarabhāvena ārammaṇassa santataratāya, kammaṭṭhānassa ca vīthipaṭipannatāya
analyzed: sukhumatara bhāvena ārammaṇassa santatara tāya kammaṭṭhānassa ca vīthi paṭipanna tāya
translated: Joy accompanied by happiness due to the meditation subject’s entering its course arises in succession to the in-breaths and out-breaths.

original: bhāvanācittasahagato pamodo khuddikādibhedā taruṇapīti uppajjati. Cittaṃ vivattatīti
analyzed: bhāvanā citta sahagataḥ pamodaḥ khuddika ādi bhedā taruṇa pīti uppajjati cittam vivattati iti
translated: The mind becomes concentrated:

original: anukkamena assāsapassāsānaṃ ativiya sukhumatarabhāvappattiyā anupaṭṭhahane vicetabbākārappattehi
analyzed: anukkamena assāsa passāsānam ativiya sukhumatara bhāva pattiyāḥ an upaṭṭhahane vicetabba ākāra ppattehi
translated: when the in-breaths and out-breaths have become extremely subtle, they no longer appear as objects, and so the mind turns away from them.

original: cittaṃ vinivattatīti keci. Bhāvanābalena pana sukhumatarabhāvappattesu assāsapassāsesu🔽tattha paṭibhāganimitte uppanne pakatiassāsapassāsato cittaṃ nivattati. Upekkhā saṇṭhātīti
analyzed: cittam vinivattati iti keci bhāvanā balena pana sukhumatara bhāva ppattesu assāsa passāsesu  tattha paṭibhāga nimitte uppanne pakati assāsa passāsato cittam nivattati upekkhā saṇṭhāti iti
translated: Some say that the mind turns away from the in-breaths and out-breaths because it is frightened by their extreme subtlety.🔽But with the in-breaths and out-breaths having become extremely subtle through the power of development,🔽the mind turns away from the natural in-breaths and out-breaths and arises in the counterpart sign. Equanimity is established:

original: tasmiṃ paṭibhāganimitte upacārappanābhede samādhimhi uppanne puna jhānanibbattanatthaṃ
analyzed: tasmin paṭibhāga nimitte upacāra ppanā bhede samādhimhi uppanne punar jhāna nibbattana attham
translated: when concentration classed as access and absorption has arisen in the counterpart sign, equanimity is established in order to avoid over-exertion, as a result of which the mind would be distracted by the over-exertion.

original: byāpārābhāvato ajjhupekkhanaṃ hotīti. Sā panāyaṃ upekkhā tatramajjhattupekkhāti veditabbā.
analyzed: byāpāra abhāvataḥ ajjhupekkhanam hoti iti sā pana ayam upekkhā tatram ajjhattupekkhā ati veditabbā
translated: And it is equanimity because there is no concern. This equanimity should be understood as equanimity about the object.

original: Imehi navahi ākārehīti imehi yathāvuttehi navahi pakārehi pavattā. Dīghaṃ assāsapassāsā🔽kāyoti dīghākārā assāsapassāsā cuṇṇavicuṇṇāpi samūhaṭṭhena kāyo. Assāsapassāse nissāya
analyzed: imehi navahi ākārehi iti imehi yathā vuttehi navahi pakārehi pavattā dīgham assāsa passāsā  kāyaḥ ti dīgha ākārā assāsa passāsā cuṇṇa vicuṇṇā api samūha aṭṭhena kāyaḥ assāsa passāse nissāya
translated: With these nine grounds: with these nine modes of occurrence stated thus. Long in-breaths and out-breaths are

original: uppannanimittampettha assāsapassāsasamaññameva vuttaṃ. Upaṭṭhānaṃ satīti ārammaṇaṃ
analyzed: uppanna nimittam pa ittha assāsa passāsa samaññam eva vuttam upaṭṭhānam satī ti ārammaṇam
translated: A “group” is a collection of what is discrete. The sign that arises dependent on in-breaths and out-breaths is called here “in-breaths and out-breaths” too. Mindfulness is establishment:

original: upagantvā tiṭṭhatīti sati upaṭṭhānaṃ nāma. Anupassanā ñāṇanti samathavasena nimittassa🔽anupassanā, vipassanāvasena assāsapassāse, tannissayañca kāyaṃ “rūpa”nti, cittaṃ
analyzed: upagantvā tiṭṭhati iti sati upaṭṭhānam nāma anupassanā ñāṇan ti samatha vasena nimittassa  anupassanā vipassanā vasena assāsa passāse tad nissayam ca kāyam cittam
translated: mindfulness is called “establishment” because it occurs by going and remaining. Knowledge is contemplation:

original: taṃsampayuttadhamme ca “arūpa”nti vavatthapetvā nāmarūpassa anupassanā ca ñāṇaṃ,
analyzed: tad sampayutta dhamme ca arūpam ti vavatthapetvā nāma rūpassa anupassanā ca ñāṇam
translated: contemplation of the sign by the serenity way, and contemplation of in-breaths and out-breaths and the body as their support, and of the material body as “materiality,” and of the mind and mental factors associated with that as “the immaterial,” by the insight way, are knowledge.🔽The act of understanding how it is is understanding. The body is establishment:

original: tattha yathābhūtāvabodho. Kāyo upaṭṭhānanti so kāyo ārammaṇakaraṇavasena upagantvā
analyzed: tattha yathā bhūta avabodho kāyaḥ upaṭṭhānan ti saḥ kāyaḥ ārammaṇa karaṇa vasena upagantvā
translated: that body is called “establishment” because it goes and remains as object.

original: sati ettha tiṭṭhatīti upaṭṭhānaṃ nāma. Ettha ca “kāyo upaṭṭhāna”nti iminā itarakāyassāpi
analyzed: sati ettha tiṭṭhati iti upaṭṭhānam nāma ettha ca kāyaḥ upaṭṭhānan ti iminā itara kāyassa api
translated: “It is present here” : the meaning is that it is established here. And by the words “The body is the establishment” the other body is included,

original: saṅgaho hoti yathāvuttasammasanacārassāpi idha icchitattā. No satīti so kāyo sati
analyzed: saṅgahaḥ hoti yathā vutta sammasana cārassa api idha icchita ttā no sati iti saḥ kāyo sati
translated: because the meditation subject described above is intended here. “It is not mindfulness” : that body is not called mindfulness.

original: nāma na hoti. Sati upaṭṭhānañceva sati ca saraṇaṭṭhena, upatiṭṭhanaṭṭhena ca. Tāya🔽satiyāti yathāvuttāya satiyā. Tena ñāṇenāti yathāvutteneva ñāṇena. Taṃ kāyanti taṃ
analyzed: nāma na hoti sati upaṭṭhānam ca iva sati ca saraṇa ṭṭhena upatiṭṭhana ṭṭhena ca tāya  satiyā iti yathā vuttāya satiyā tena ñāṇena ati yathā vuttena iva ñāṇena tam kāyanti tam
translated: Mindfulness is both the establishment and the mindfulness itself, in the sense of remembering and in the sense of attending.🔽“With that mindfulness” : with the mindfulness described in the way beginning “He trains thus: I shall breathe in … shall breathe out experiencing the whole body” .

original: assāsapassāsakāyañceva tannissayarūpakāyañca. Anupassatīti jhānasampayuttañāṇena
analyzed: assāsa passāsa kāyañca iva tad nissaya rūpa kāyañca anupassati iti jhāna sampayutta ñāṇena
translated: “With that knowledge” : with the knowledge described in the way beginning “He trains thus: I shall breathe in … shall breathe out tranquilizing the bodily formation” .🔽“That body” : that in-breath and out-breath body and that material body that is its support.

original: ceva vipassanāñāṇena ca anu anu passati. Tena vuccati kāye kāyānupassanāsatipaṭṭhānabhāvanāti🔽tena anupassanena yathāvutte kāye ayaṃ kāyānupassanāsatipaṭṭhānabhāvanāti vuccati.
analyzed: ca iva vipassanā ñāṇena ca anu anu passati tena vuccati kāye kāya anupassanā sati paṭṭhāna bhāvanā ati  tena anupassanena yathā vutte kāye ayam kāya anupassanā sati paṭṭhāna bhāvanā ti vuccati
translated: “Contemplates”: he contemplates again and again with the knowledge associated with jhāna and with insight knowledge.🔽“Development of the foundation of mindfulness consisting in contemplation of the body as a body”: by means of that contemplation it is said that there is development of the foundation of mindfulness consisting in contemplation of the body as a body in the way already stated.

original: Idaṃ vuttaṃ hoti – yā ayaṃ yathāvutte assāsapassāsakāye, tassa nissayabhūte karajakāye
analyzed: idam vuttam hoti yā ayam yathā vutte assāsa passāsa kāye tassa nissaya bhūte karaja kāye
translated: What is meant is this. In the body as described above, that is to say, in the in-breath and out-breath body and in the material body that is its support,

original: ca kāyasseva anupassanā anudakabhūtāya marīciyā udakānupassanā viya na aniccādisabhāve
analyzed: ca kāyassa iva anupassanā anudaka bhūtāya marīciyā udaka anupassanā viya na anicca ādi sabhāve
translated: And the contemplation of the body as impermanent, painful, and not self is the contemplation of the body as it actually is in its nature of impermanence, etc.,

original: kāye niccādibhāvānupassanā, atha kho yathārahaṃ aniccadukkhānattāsubhabhāvassevānupassanā.
analyzed: kāye nicca ādi bhāva anupassanā atha kho yathāraham anicca dukkha anatta asubha bhāva ssa iva anupassanā
translated: just as the contemplation of water in a mirage as water is the contemplation of a thing as it is not.

original: Atha vā kāye “aha”nti vā “mama”nti vā “itthī”ti vā “puriso”ti vā gahetabbassa kassaci
analyzed: atha vā kāye ahanti vā mamanti vā itthī iti vā puriso ti vā gahetabbassa kassaci
translated: Or alternatively, the contemplation of the body as “not self” is the contemplation of the body as it actually is in the sense of non-self,

original: abhāvato tādisaṃ ananupassitvā kāyamattasseva anupassanā kāyānupassanā, tāya kāyānupassanāya
analyzed: abhāvataḥ tādisam an anupassitvā kāya mattassa iva anupassanā kāya anupassanā tāya kāya anupassanāya
translated: since there is nothing in the body that can be apprehended as “not self” in the way that the body can be apprehended as “this body.”🔽The establishment of mindfulness that is associated with that contemplation of the body is the establishment of mindfulness that has the body as its object.

original: sampayuttā satiyeva upaṭṭhānaṃ satipaṭṭhānaṃ, tassa bhāvanā vaḍḍhanā kāyānupassanāsatipaṭṭhānabhāvanāti.🔽Esa nayoti “navahi ākārehī”tiādinā vuttavidhiṃ rassa-pade atidisati. Etthāti etasmiṃ
analyzed: sampayuttā satiyā eva upaṭṭhānam sati paṭṭhānam tassa bhāvanā vaḍḍhanā kāya anupassanā sati paṭṭhāna bhāvanā ati  esa nayo ti navahi ākārehi itiādinā vutta vidhim rassa pade atidisati ettha ati etasmin
translated: The development of that is the development of the establishment of mindfulness that has the body as its object.

original: yathādassite “kathaṃ dīghaṃ assasanto”tiādinā āgate pāḷinaye. Idhāti imasmiṃ rassapadavasena āgate pāḷinaye.
analyzed: yathā dassite katham dīgham assasanto ti ādinā āgate pāḷi naye idha ati imasmin rassa pada vasena āgate pāḷi naye
translated: This method: this refers to the method stated in the way beginning, “In nine aspects” . Here: in the text stated in the way beginning, “How, when breathing in long, he knows ‘I breathe in long’” . Here: in the text stated in the way beginning, “When he breathes in short” .

original: Ayanti yogāvacaro. Addhānavasenāti dīghakālavasena. Ittaravasenāti parittakālavasena. Imehi ākārehīti imehi navahi ākārehi.
analyzed: yogāvacaraḥ addhāna vasena ati dīgha kāla vasena ittara vasena ati paritta kāla vasena imehi ākārehi iti imehi navahi ākārehi
translated: ‘He’: the meditator. ‘In terms of extent’: in terms of length of time. ‘In terms of shortness’: in terms of shortness of time. ‘In these modes’: in these nine modes.

original: Tādisoti dīgho, rasso ca. Cattāro vaṇṇāti cattāro ākārā, te ca dīghādayo eva. Nāsikagge🔽va bhikkhunoti gāthābandhasukhatthaṃ rassaṃ katvā vuttaṃ “nāsikagge vā”ti, vā-saddo
analyzed: tādisaḥ ti dīghaḥ rasso ca cattāro vaṇṇā ati cattāro ākārā te ca dīgha ādayaḥ eva nāsikagge  bhikkhuno ti gāthā bandha sukha attham rassam katvā vuttam nāsikagge vā iti vā saddaḥ
translated: ‘Such’: long and short. ‘Four aspects’: four modes, which are the long, etc., ‘At the tip of the nose’

original: aniyamattho, tena uttaroṭṭhaṃ saṅgaṇhāti.
analyzed: tena uttara uṭṭham saṅgaṇhāti
translated: ‘Or’ is a particle in the sense of non-restriction. Therefore the upper lip is included.

original: 220. Sabbakāyapaṭisaṃvedīti sabbassa kāyassa paṭi paṭi paccekaṃ sammadeva vedanasīlo
analyzed: sabba kāya paṭisaṃvedī iti sabbassa kāyassa paṭi paṭi paccekam sammad eva vedana sīlo
translated: ‘Experiencing the whole body’: he has the habit of experiencing the whole body by each part in its place,

original: jānanasīlo, tassa vā paṭi paṭi sammadeva vedo etassa atthi, taṃ vā paṭi paṭi sammadeva
analyzed: jānana sīlo tassa vā paṭi paṭi sammadeva vedaḥ etassa atthi tam vā paṭi paṭi sammadeva
translated: he has the habit of knowing it. Or the meaning is that he has the experience of each part in its place.

original: vedamānoti attho. Tattha tattha sabba-ggahaṇena assāsādikāyassa anavasesapariyādāne
analyzed: vedamānaḥ ti attho tattha tattha sabba ggahaṇena anavasesa pariyādāne
translated: Herein, although the inclusion of all is established by the phrase ‘the whole’ in the sense of the entire pervasion of the in-breath’s body,

original: siddhepi anekakalāpasamudāyabhāvato tassa sabbesampi bhāgānaṃ saṃvedanadassanatthaṃ
analyzed: siddhe api aneka kalāpa samudāya bhāvato tassa sabbesam pi bhāgānam saṃvedana dassana ttham
translated: nevertheless, in order to show that he experiences all the parts of it, which is a combination of many components,

original: paṭi-saddaggahaṇaṃ. Tattha sakkaccakārībhāvadassanatthaṃ saṃ-saddaggahaṇanti imamatthaṃ🔽dassento “sakalassā”tiādimāha. Tattha yathā samānepi assāsapassāsesu yogino paṭipattividhāne
analyzed: paṭisadda ggahaṇam tattha sakkacca kārībhāva dassana ttham saṃsadda ggahaṇam ti imam attham  dassentaḥ sakalassa ati ādim āha tattha yathā samāne pi assāsa passāsesu yogino paṭipatti vidhāne
translated: and the taking of the in-breath is the taking of the out-breath.🔽The meaning of this is shown by the words ‘of the whole’ and so on.

original: paccekaṃ sakkaccaṃyeva paṭipajjitabbanti dassetuṃ visuṃ desanā katā, evaṃ tamevatthaṃ
analyzed: paccekam sakkaccam yeva paṭipajjitabbanti dassetum visum desanā katā evam tam eva attham
translated: Herein, although in-breaths and out-breaths are the same, the teaching is given separately in order to show that the practice of the development of understanding by the meditator should be undertaken separately in each case.

original: dīpetuṃ satipi atthassa samānatāya “sakalassā”tiādinā padadvayassa visuṃ visuṃ atthavaṇṇanā
analyzed: dīpetum atthassa samāna tāya sakalassa ati ādinā pada dvayassa visum visum attha vaṇṇanā
translated: And in order to illustrate that same meaning, although the meaning is the same, the commentary on the meaning of the two words ‘of the whole’ and ‘of the whole time’ should be understood to be given separately.

original: katāti veditabbaṃ. Pākaṭaṃ karontoti vibhūtaṃ karonto, sabbaso vibhāventoti attho.🔽Pākaṭīkaraṇaṃ vibhāvanaṃ tattha asammuyhanaṃ ñāṇeneva nesaṃ pavattanena hotīti dassento
analyzed: katā ati veditabbam pākaṭam karonto ti vibhūtam karonto sabbasas vibhāvento ti attho  pākaṭīkaraṇam vibhāvanam tattha a sammuyhanam ñāṇena iva nesam pavattanena hoti iti dassento
translated: ‘Making evident’: making clear; the meaning is, making quite clear.🔽Showing that the making evident is the non-delusion there by means of the occurrence of knowledge only, he said ‘making known in this way’.

original: “evaṃ viditaṃ karonto”tiādimāha. Tattha tasmāti yasmā ñāṇasampayuttacitteneva assāsapassāse
analyzed: evam viditam karontaḥ iti ādim āha tattha tasmā iti yasmā ñāṇa sampayutta cittena iva assāsa passāse
translated: Herein, ‘because’: since it is only by means of consciousness associated with knowledge that in-breaths and out-breaths

original: pavatteti, na vippayuttacittena, tasmā evaṃbhūto sabbakāyapaṭisaṃvedī assasissāmi🔽passasissāmīti sikkhatīti vuccati buddhādīhīti yojanā. Cuṇṇavicuṇṇavisaṭeti anekakalāpatāya🔽cuṇṇavicuṇṇabhāvena visaṭe. Ādi pākaṭo hoti satiyā, ñāṇassa ca vasena tathā pubbābhisaṅkhārassa🔽pavattattā. Tādisena bhavitabbanti catutthapuggalasadisena bhavitabbaṃ, pageva satiṃ,
analyzed: pavatteti na vippayutta cittena tasmai evaṃbhūtaḥ sabba kāya paṭisaṃvedī  passasissāmi iti sikkhati iti vuccati buddha ādīhi iti yojanā cuṇṇa vicuṇṇa visaṭa iti aneka kalāpa tāya  cuṇṇa vicuṇṇa bhāvena ādi pākaṭaḥ hoti satiyā ñāṇassa ca vasena tathā pubba abhisaṅkhārassa  pavatta ttā tādisena bhavitabbanti catuttha puggala sadisena bhavitabbam pagā iva satim
translated: he does not do so with a mind dissociated from mindfulness. That is why it is said that he trains thus: “I shall breathe in … shall breathe out experiencing the whole body. ” The construction of the terms in the first tetrad should be understood in this way. In the second tetrad the words “experiencing the body’s distension with the in-breath and out-breath” are taken as “experiencing the body’s distension with the in-breath and out-breath, which is a distension of the body with the in-breath and out-breath.” Herein, the in-breath and out-breath are a distension of the body because they cause the body to be not constricted. Translation: na vippayuttacittena, tasmā evaṃbhūto sabbakāyapaṭisaṃvedī assasissāmi passasissāmīti sikkhatīti vuccati buddhādīhīti yojanā | cuṇṇavicuṇṇavisaṭeti anekakalāpatāya cuṇṇavicuṇṇabhāvena visaṭe | ādi pākaṭo hoti satiyā, ñāṇassa ca vasena tathā pubbābhisaṅkhārassa pavattattā | tādisena bhavitabbanti catutthapuggalasadisena bhavitabbaṃ, pageva satiṃ,🔽

original: ñāṇañca paccupaṭṭhapetvā tīsupi ṭhānesu ñāṇasampayuttameva cittaṃ pavattetabbanti adhippāyo.🔽Evanti vuttappakārena sabbakāyapaṭisaṃvedanavaseneva. Ghaṭatīti ussahati. Vāyamatīti🔽vāyāmaṃ karoti, manasikāraṃ pavattetīti attho. Tathābhūtassāti ānāpānassatiṃ bhāventassa.
analyzed: ñāṇañca paccupaṭṭhapetvā tīsu pi ṭhānesu ñāṇa sampayuttam eva cittam pavattetabbanti adhippāyaḥ 🔽evam ti vutta ppakārena sabba kāya paṭisaṃvedana vasena iva ghaṭati iti ussahati vā āyamati iti 🔽vāyāmam karoti manasikāram pavatteti iti attho tathābhūtassa ati āna apāna ssatim bhāventassa
translated: He does not do so with a mind dissociated from them. That is why it is said that he trains thus “I shall breathe in … shall breathe out experiencing the whole body. ” The construction of the expression “with mindfulness established” is: with the establishment of mindfulness in him. The words “with mindfulness well established” are a synonym for “with mindfulness established. ” The words “he trains thus” are a synonym for “he breathes in … breathes out. ” The words “in the beginning” are a synonym for “at the time of the first production of the jhāna. ” The words “at the end” are a synonym for “at the time of the last production of the jhāna. ” The words “in the middle” are a synonym for “at the time of the production of the jhāna in between the first production and the last production. ” The words “in the beginning, in the middle, and at the end” are a synonym for “at the time of the production of the jhāna in continuity. ” The words “he trains thus” are a synonym for “he breathes in … breathes out. ” The words “in the beginning, in the middle, and at the end” are a synonym for “at the time of the production of the jhāna in continuity. ” The words “he trains thus” are a synonym for “he breathes in … breathes out. ” The words “in the beginning, in the middle, and at the end” are a synonym for “at the time of the production of the jhāna in continuity. ” The words “he trains thus” are a synonym for “he breathes in … breathes out. ” The words “in the beginning, in the middle, and at the end” are a synonym for “at the time of the production of the jhāna in continuity. ” The words “he trains thus” are a synonym for “he breathes in … breathes out. ” The words “in the beginning, in the middle, and at the end” are a synonym for “at the time of the production of the jhāna in continuity. ” The words “he trains thus” are a synonym for “he breathes in … breathes out. ” The words “in the beginning, in the middle, and at the end” are a synonym for “at the time of the production of the jhāna in continuity. ” The words “he trains thus” are a synonym for “he breathes

original: Saṃvaroti sati, vīriyampi vā. Tāya satiyāti yā ānāpāne ārabbha pavattā sati, tāya.
analyzed: saṃvaroti sati vīriyam pi vā tāya satiyā ati yā āna apāne ārabbha pavattā sati tāya
translated: “Restraint” is mindfulness or energy. “By that mindfulness”: by that mindfulness which occurs contingent upon in-breaths and out-breaths.

original: Tena manasikārenāti yo so tattha satipubbaṅgamo bhāvanāmanasikāro, tena saddhinti
analyzed: tena manasikārena ati yaḥ saḥ tattha sati pubbaṅgamaḥ bhāvanā manasikāro tena saddhinti
translated: “By that attention”: by that attention consisting in development that has mindfulness as its prior condition.🔽The meaning is that he does it together with that.

original: adhippāyo. Āsevatīti “tisso sikkhāyo”ti vutte adhikusaladhamme āsevati. Tadāsevanañhettha
analyzed: adhippāyaḥ āsevati iti tissaḥ sikkhāyaḥ ti vutte adhi kusala dhamme āsevati tad āsevanam ha ittha
translated: “He cultivates”: when it is said “three trainings,” he cultivates higher profitable states. For the meaning of “training” here is

original: sikkhananti adhippetaṃ.
analyzed: sikkhananti adhippetam
translated: cultivation of that.

original: Purimanayeti purimasmiṃ bhāvanānaye, paṭhamavatthudvayeti adhippāyo. Tatthāpi kāmaṃ
analyzed: purima naya iti purimasmim bhāvanā naye paṭhama vatthu dvaya iti adhippāyo tattha api kāmam
translated: “In the first way”: in the first method of development. The meaning is in the first two instances.

original: ñāṇuppādanaṃ labbhateva assāsapassāsānaṃ yāthāvato dīgharassabhāvāvabodhasabbhāvato,🔽tathāpi taṃ na dukkaraṃ yathāpavattānaṃ tesaṃ gahaṇamattabhāvatoti tattha vattamānakālappayogo
analyzed: ñāṇa uppādanam labbhate iva assāsa passāsānam yāthāvataḥ dīgha rassa bhāva avabodha sabbhāvataḥ  tathā api tam na dukkaram yathā a pavattānam tesam gahaṇa matta bhāvato ti tattha vattamāna kāla ppayogo
translated: And although it is true that there is also occurrence of knowledge there too, since it is the understanding of the actual length of the in-breaths and out-breaths,🔽nevertheless that is not difficult since it is only a matter of apprehending them as they occur. So the temporal reference🔽is made there to the present. But this is difficult, like a man’s walking on the edge of a razor, so the temporal reference here is made to the future

original: kato. Idaṃ pana dukkaraṃ purisassa khuradhārāyaṃ gamanasadisaṃ, tasmā sātisayenettha
analyzed: kato idam pana dukkaram purisassa gamana sadisam tasmā sa atisayena ittha
translated: in order to show that it is very difficult.

original: pubbābhisaṅkhārena bhavitabbanti dīpetuṃ anāgatakālappayogo katoti imamatthaṃ dassetuṃ
analyzed: pubba abhisaṅkhārena bhavitabbanti dīpetum anāgata kāla ppayogaḥ kataḥ ti imam attham dassetuṃ
translated: The reference to the future time is made in order to show that it is by a prior choice that he must be.🔽“Herein, since” is said in order to point out the meaning of this.

original: “tattha yasmā”tiādi vuttaṃ. Tattha ñāṇuppādanādīsūti ādi-saddena kāyasaṅkhārapassambhanapītipaṭisaṃvedanādiṃ
analyzed: tattha yasmā itiādi vuttam tattha ñāṇa uppādana ādīsu iti ādi saddena kāya saṅkhāra passambhana pīti paṭisaṃvedana ādim
translated: Herein, by the word “etc.” in “arising of knowledge, etc.” is included the quieting of the bodily formation, the experiencing of happiness, and so on.

original: saṅgaṇhāti. Keci panettha “saṃvarasamādānānaṃ saṅgaho”ti vadanti.🔽Kāyasaṅkhāranti assāsapassāsaṃ. So hi cittasamuṭṭhānopi samāno karajakāyappaṭibaddhavuttitāya🔽tena saṅkharīyatīti kāyasaṅkhāroti vuccati. Yo pana “kāyasaṅkhāro vacīsaṅkhāro”ti🔽evamāgato kāyasaṅkhāro cetanālakkhaṇo satipi dvārantaruppattiyaṃ yebhuyyavuttiyā,
analyzed: saṅgaṇhāti keci pana ittha saṃvara samādānānam saṅgahaḥ iti vadanti  kāya saṅkhāranti assāsa passāsam saḥ hi citta samuṭṭhānaḥ api samānaḥ karaja kāya ppaṭibaddha vutti tāya  tena saṅkharīyati iti kāya saṅkhāro ti vuccati yaḥ pana kāya saṅkhāro vacī saṅkhāro ti  evam āgataḥ kāya saṅkhāro cetanā lakkhaṇo sati pi dvāra antara uppattiyam yebhuyya vuttiyā
translated: But some say that the inclusion of the undertaking of the precepts is also included here.🔽The bodily formation is in-breath and out-breath. Although that is a product of consciousness, still it is called a bodily formation because it occurs bound up with the physical body and it is formed by that.

original: tabbahulavuttiyā ca kāyadvārena lakkhito, so idha nādhippeto. Passambhentotiādīsu
analyzed: tad bahula vuttiyā ca kāya dvārena lakkhito saḥ idha na adhippeto passambhento tiādīsu
translated: But the bodily formation that is referred to in the passage “bodily formation, verbal formation” is the characteristic of volition. Although it arises in the mind door, it is called a bodily formation because it is manifested by the physical body, which is the most evident of the two, and because it occurs in association with the body. That is not intended here.🔽In the passage beginning “quieting the bodily formation”

original: pacchimaṃ pacchimaṃ padaṃ purimassa purimassa atthavacanaṃ, tasmā passambhanaṃ nāma
analyzed: pacchimam pacchimam padam purimassa purimassa attha vacanam tasmā passambhanam nāma
translated: the last word in each phrase is a synonym for the preceding word. So “quieting” is a synonym for “making to cease.”

original: vūpasamanaṃ, tañca tathāpayoge asati uppajjanārahassa oḷārikassa kāyasaṅkhārassa
analyzed: vūpasamanam tat ca tathā apayoge asati uppajjanā rahassa oḷārikassa kāya saṅkhārassa
translated: and its subsiding, and the non-arising of the gross bodily formation that is liable to arise,🔽

original: payogasampattiyā anuppādananti daṭṭhabbaṃ. Tatrāti “oḷārikaṃ kāyasaṅkhāraṃ passambhento”ti
analyzed: payoga sampattiyāḥ anuppādananti daṭṭhabbam tatra ati oḷārikam kāya saṅkhāram passambhento ti
translated: and the non-arising of the gross bodily formation that would have arisen if the requisite conditions had been present, but which does not arise because of the presence of the requisite conditions for its non-arising. Herein, “Here a bhikkhu, having given up, abandoned, relinquished, and relinquished the basis for bodily formation, dwells with the bodily formation tranquillized” .

original: ettha. Apariggahitakāleti kammaṭṭhānassa anāraddhakāle, tato eva kāyacittānampi apariggahitakāle.
analyzed: ettha a pariggahita kāle ti kammaṭṭhānassa anāraddha kāle tatas eva kāya cittānam pi a pariggahita kāle
translated: “Unperceived in the body” : at the time when the meditation subject has not yet been undertaken, and for that reason the body and mind are also unperceived.

original: “Nisīdati pallaṅkaṃ ābhujitvā ujuṃ kāyaṃ paṇidhāyā”ti hi iminā kāyapariggaho, “parimukhaṃ🔽satiṃ upaṭṭhapetvā”ti iminā cittapariggaho vutto. Tenevāha “kāyopi cittampi pariggahitā🔽hontī”ti. Kāyoti karajakāyo. Sadarathāti sapariḷāhā, sā ca nesaṃ sadarathatā garubhāvena
analyzed: nisīdati pallaṅkam ābhujitvā ujum kāyam paṇidhāya ati hi iminā kāya pariggahaḥ parimukham  satim upaṭṭhapetvā ti iminā citta pariggaho vuttaḥ tena iva āha kāyaḥ api cittam pi pariggahitā  honti iti sa pariḷāhā sā ca sadaratha tā garu bhāvena
translated: “He sits, having folded his legs crosswise, set his body erect, and established mindfulness in front of him” .🔽Herein, the body is perceived by the words “having folded his legs crosswise” and “set his body erect,” and the mind is perceived by the words “having established mindfulness in front of him.” That is why it is said, “The body and the mind are perceived” .

original: viya oḷārikatāya avinābhāvinīti āha “oḷārikā”ti. Balavatarāti sabalā thūlā. Santā
analyzed: avinābhāvinī iti āha oḷārikā ati sabalā thūlā
translated: “Body” : the physical body. “With a sense of urgency” : with urgency. That sense of urgency is invariably concomitant with grossness, as urgency is with heaviness.

original: hontīti cittaṃ tāvaṃ bahiddhā vikkhepābhāvena ekaggaṃ hutvā kammaṭṭhānaṃ pariggahetvā
analyzed: honti iti cittam tāva bahiddhā vikkhepa abhāvena ekaggam hutvā kammaṭṭhānam pariggahetvā
translated: “Are stilled” : the mind is stilled by the absence of distraction outwards. It is stilled by the occurrence of the meditation subject.

original: pavattamānaṃ santaṃ hoti vūpasantaṃ, tato eva taṃsamuṭṭhānā rūpadhammā lahumudukammaññabhāvappattā,
analyzed: pavattamānam santam hoti vūpasantam tatas eva tad samuṭṭhānāḥ rūpa dhammāḥ lahu mudu kammañña bhāva ppattā
translated: Because of that, the material phenomena derived from it attain lightness and malleability.🔽The rest of the three-constituent materiality is also stilled in conformity with that.

original: tadanuguṇatāya sesaṃ tisantatirūpanti evaṃ citte, kāye ca vūpasante pavattamāne tannissitā🔽assāsapassāsā santasabhāvā anukkamena sukhumatarasukhumatamā hutvā pavattanti. Tena
analyzed: tad anuguṇa tāya sesam evam citte kāye ca vūpasante pavattamāne tad nissitā  assāsa passāsāḥ santa sabhāvāḥ anukkamena sukhumatara sukhumatamāḥ hutvā pavattanti tena
translated: When the mind and body are stilled in this way, the in-breaths and out-breaths that occur in dependence on them become still in their nature. They occur in a more and more subtle way, in a very subtle way.

original: vuttaṃ “yadā panassa kāyopī”tiādi.🔽Ābhujanaṃ ābhogo, “passambhemī”ti paṭhamāvajjanā. Sammā anu anu āharaṇaṃ samannāhāro,🔽tasmiṃyeva atthe aparāparaṃ pavattaāvajjanā. Tasseva atthassa manasi karaṇaṃ citte🔽ṭhapanaṃ manasikāro. Vīmaṃsā paccavekkhaṇā.
analyzed: vuttam yadā panassa kāyaḥ api itiādi  ābhujanam ābhogaḥ passambhemi iti paṭhamā vajjanā sammā anu anu āharaṇam samannāhāraḥ  tasmin yeva atthe apara aparam pavatta āvajjanā tassa iva atthassa manasi karaṇam citte  ṭhapanam manasikāraḥ vīmaṃsā paccavekkhaṇā
translated: Therefore it was said above: “When his body is thus full” , and so on.

original: Sāraddheti sadarathe sapariḷāhe. Adhimattanti balavaṃ oḷārikaṃ. Liṅgavipallāsena
analyzed: sāraddhā iti sa darathe sa pariḷāhe balavam oḷārikam liṅga vipallāsena
