translated: “Full” is “fullness” . “I am tranquilizing” is the first adverting. “I am breathing in” is the second adverting. “I am breathing out” is the third adverting. “I am breathing in long” is the fourth adverting. “I am breathing out long” is the fifth adverting. “I am breathing in short” is the sixth adverting. “I am breathing out short” is the seventh adverting. “Experiencing the whole body I am breathing in” is the eighth adverting. “Experiencing the whole body I am breathing out” is the ninth adverting. “Tranquillizing the bodily formation I am breathing in” is the tenth adverting. “Tranquillizing the bodily formation I am breathing out” is the eleventh adverting. “I am breathing in gladdening” is the twelfth adverting. “I am breathing out gladdening” is the thirteenth adverting. “I am breathing in concentrating” is the fourteenth adverting. “I am breathing out concentrating” is the fifteenth adverting. “I am breathing in liberating” is the sixteenth adverting. “I am breathing out liberating” is the seventeenth adverting. “I am breathing in contemplating impermanence” is the eighteenth adverting. “I am breathing out contemplating impermanence” is the nineteenth adverting. “I am breathing in contemplating fading away” is the twentieth adverting. “I am breathing out contemplating fading away” is the twenty-first adverting. “I am breathing in contemplating cessation” is the twenty-second adverting. “I am breathing out contemplating cessation” is the twenty-third adverting. “I am breathing in contemplating relinquishment” is the twenty-fourth adverting. “I am breathing out contemplating relinquishment

original: vuttaṃ. Kāyasaṅkhāroti hi adhippeto. “Adhimattaṃ hutvā pavattatī”ti kiriyāvisesanaṃ
analyzed: vuttam kāya saṅkhāraḥ iti hi adhippetaḥ adhimattam hutvā pavattati iti kiriyā visesanam
translated: “Bodily formation” is intended. “Occurring in excess” is a qualification of the action.

original: vā etaṃ. Sukhumanti etthāpi eseva nayo. Kāyamhīti ettha “citte cā”ti ānetvā sambandhitabbaṃ.
analyzed: vā etam sukhuman ti ettha api esa iva nayaḥ kāyamhi iti ettha citte ca ati ānetvā sambandhitabbam
translated: “Subtle” is to be construed in the same way. “In the body” is to be construed with “in the mind” .

original: 221. Paṭhamajjhānato vuṭṭhāya kariyamānaṃ dutiyajjhānassa nānāvajjanaṃ parikammaṃ🔽paṭhamajjhānaṃ viya dūrasamussāritapaṭipakkhanti katvā taṃsamuṭṭhāno kāyasaṅkhāro
analyzed: paṭhama jhānataḥ vuṭṭhāya kariyamānam dutiya jhānassa nānā vajjanam parikammaṃ  paṭhama jhānam viya dūra samussārita paṭipakkhanti katvā tad samuṭṭhānaḥ kāya saṅkhāro
translated: The various kinds of adverting that occur when one emerges from the first jhāna and adverts to the second jhāna are the preliminary work for the second jhāna.

original: paṭhamajjhāne ca dutiyajjhānūpacāre ca oḷārikoti sadiso vutto. Esa nayo sesūpacāradvayepi.🔽Atha vā dutiyajjhānādīnaṃ adhigamāya paṭipajjato dukkhāpaṭipadādivasena kilamato
analyzed: paṭhama jhāne ca dutiya jhāna upacāre ca oḷārikaḥ ti sadisaḥ vuttaḥ esa nayo sesa upacāra dvaye pi  atha vā dutiya jhāna ādīnam adhigamāya paṭipajjataḥ dukkha apaṭipada ādi vasena kilamataḥ
translated: The bodily formation that occurs in the preliminary work for the second jhāna is said to be similar to that in the first jhāna, since it is the opposite of the bodily formation in the second jhāna and is removed from it by a long interval. The same method applies in the case of the other two jhānas.

original: yogino kāyakilamathacittūpaghātādivasena, vitakkādisaṅkhobhena ca sapariphandatāya
analyzed: yogino kāya kilamatha cittu upaghāta ādi vasena vitakka ādi saṅkhobhena ca sa pariphanda tāyai
translated: Or alternatively, the bodily formation in the preliminary work for the second jhāna, etc., should be understood as gross because of the occurrence of consciousness with disturbance in one who is practising for the attainment of the second jhāna, etc., and who is fatigued by the difficulty of the practice,

original: cittappavattiyā dutiyajjhānādiupacāresu kāyasaṅkhārassa oḷārikatā veditabbā. Atisukhumoti
analyzed: citta ppavattiyā dutiya jhāna ādi upacāresu kāya saṅkhārassa oḷārika tā veditabbā ati sukhumaḥ ti
translated: and because of the fatigue and depression of mind, etc., in him. It is subtle in the second jhāna, etc., because of the absence of such disturbance, etc.

original: aññattha labbhamāno kāyasaṅkhāro catutthajjhāne atikkantasukhumo. Sukhumabhāvopissa
analyzed: aññattha labbhamāno kāya saṅkhāro catuttha jjhāne atikkanta sukhumaḥ sukhuma bhāvaḥ pissa
translated: The bodily formation that is found elsewhere is more subtle than the bliss that surmounts the fourth jhāna.

original: tattha natthi, kuto oḷārikatā appavattanato. Tenāha “appavattimeva pāpuṇātī”ti.🔽Lābhissa sato anupubbasamāpattisamāpajjanavelaṃ, ekāsaneneva vā sabbesaṃ jhānānaṃ
analyzed: tattha natthi kutas oḷārika tā appavattanato tena āha appavattim eva pāpuṇāti iti  lābhissa sato anupubba samāpatti samāpajjana velam eka āsanena iva vā sabbesam jhānānam
translated: But that does not exist there, so how can there be grossness or lack of occurrence? That is why it is said that it reaches only the absence of occurrence.🔽Or alternatively, the attainment of the jhānas is called “gain” in the sense of obtaining it, and the entry to it is called “gain” in the sense of arriving at it.🔽The reciters of the Majjhima Nikāya say that the fine-material-sphere jhāna that is next to the fine-material-sphere jhāna is more peaceful than the one next to the immaterial-sphere jhāna.

original: paṭilābhaṃ sandhāya majjhimabhāṇakā heṭṭhimaheṭṭhimajjhānato uparūparijhānūpacārepi
analyzed: paṭilābham sandhāya majjhima bhāṇakāḥ heṭṭhima heṭṭhima jhānataḥ uparu upari jhānu upacāre pi
translated: For in the former case there is a difference of plane, while in the latter case there is only a difference of jhāna.🔽Or alternatively, the words “in the immaterial sphere” are stated in the way already mentioned in order to show the difference of plane.

original: sukhumataraṃ icchanti. Tattha hi sopacārānaṃ jhānānaṃ uparūpari visesavantatā, santatā🔽ca sambhaveyya, ekāvajjanūpacāraṃ vā sandhāya evaṃ vuttaṃ. Evañhi heṭṭhā vuttavādena
analyzed: sukhumataram icchanti tattha hi sa upacārānam jhānānam upari upari visesavanta tā santa tā  ca ekāvajjana upacāram vā sandhāya evam vuttam evam hi heṭṭhā vutta vādena
translated: For the immaterial-sphere jhāna is more peaceful than the fine-material-sphere jhāna, and the immaterial-sphere jhāna that is next to the fine-material-sphere jhāna is more peaceful than the immaterial-sphere jhāna that is next to the immaterial-sphere jhāna.🔽Or alternatively, the words “in the immaterial sphere” are stated in order to show the difference of jhāna.🔽For the immaterial-sphere jhāna that is next to the fine-material-sphere jhāna is more peaceful than the immaterial-sphere jhāna that is next to the immaterial-sphere jhāna.

original: imassa vādassa avirodho siddho bhinnavisayattā. Sabbesaññevāti ubhayesampi. Yasmā
analyzed: imassa vādassa avirodhaḥ siddhaḥ bhinna visaya ttā ubhayesam pi yasmā
translated: Or alternatively, the words “in the immaterial sphere” are stated in order to show the difference of plane and the difference of jhāna.🔽For the immaterial-sphere jhāna that is next to the fine-material-sphere jhāna is more peaceful than the immaterial-sphere jhāna that is next to the immaterial-sphere jhāna.

original: te sabbepi vuccamānena vidhinā passaddhimicchantiyeva. “Apariggahitakāle pavattakāyasaṅkhāro
analyzed: te sabbe api vuccamānena vidhinā passaddhim icchantiyā iva a pariggahita kāle pavatta kāya saṅkhāro
translated: Or alternatively, the words “in the immaterial sphere” are stated in order to show the difference of plane, the difference of jhāna, and the difference of occurrence.🔽For the immaterial-sphere jhāna that is next to the fine-material-sphere jhāna occurs with the absence of occurrence of the fine-material-sphere jhāna, and the immaterial-sphere jhāna that is next to the immaterial-sphere jhāna

original: pariggahitakāle paṭippassambhatī”ti idaṃ sadisasantānatāya vuttaṃ. Na hi te eva oḷārikā
analyzed: pariggahita kāle paṭippassambhati iti idam sadisa santāna tāya vuttam na hi te eva oḷārikā
translated: and at the moment of their being appropriated it is appeased. This is said because of the similarity of the continuity.

original: assāsādayo sukhumā honti. Passambhanākāro pana nesaṃ heṭṭhā vuttoyeva.
analyzed: assa asa ādayaḥ sukhumāḥ honti passambhana ākāraḥ pana nesam heṭṭhā vuttaḥ yeva
translated: “When they are discerned, they are stilled” is said because of the continuity of the similar type. For those gross in-breaths and out-breaths are not themselves subtle. But the mode of their stilling has already been given above.

original: Mahābhūtapariggahe sukhumoti catudhātumukhena vipassanābhinivesaṃ sandhāya vuttaṃ.🔽Sakalarūpapariggahe sukhumo bhāvanāya uparūpari paṇītabhāvato. Tenevāha “rūpārūpapariggahe
analyzed: mahābhūta pariggahe sukhumaḥ ti catu dhātu mukhena vipassanā abhinivesam sandhāya vuttam  sakala rūpa pariggahe bhāvanāya upari upari paṇīta bhāvataḥ tena iva āha rūpa arūpa pariggahe
translated: “Subtle in the analysis of the primary elements” is said with reference to the insistence on insight by way of the four primary elements.🔽“Subtle in the analysis of all materiality” is said because of the excellence of the development in the analysis of all materiality. Hence he says: “Subtle in the analysis of materiality and the immaterial.”

original: sukhumo”ti. Lakkhaṇārammaṇikavipassanāti kalāpasammasanamāha. Nibbidānupassanato
analyzed: sukhumaḥ ti lakkhaṇa ārammaṇika vipassanā ti kalāpa sammasanam āha nibbida anupassanato
translated: “Insight that has characteristics as its object” refers to the discerning of the component parts.🔽“Insight that is strong” is insight that is strong from the contemplation of dispassion onwards. “Insight that is weak” is insight prior to that.

original: paṭṭhāya balavavipassanā. Tato oraṃ dubbalavipassanā. Pubbe vuttanayenāti “apariggahitakāle”tiādinā🔽samathanaye vuttena nayena “apariggahe pavatto kāyasaṅkhāro mahābhūtapariggahe paṭippassambhatī”tiādinā
analyzed: paṭṭhāya balava vipassanā tatas oram dubbala vipassanā pubbe vutta nayena ati apariggahita kāla iti ādinā  samatha naye vuttena nayena a pariggahe pavattaḥ kāya saṅkhāraḥ mahābhūta pariggahe paṭippassambhati iti ādinā
translated: “In the way already stated” means in the way stated in the section on serenity, namely, “When they are not discerned, the bodily formation that occurs is stilled when the primary elements are discerned” , etc.

original: vipassanānayepi paṭippassaddhi yojetabbāti vuttaṃ hoti.
analyzed: vipassanā naye pi paṭippassaddhi yojetabbā iti vuttam hoti
translated: And in the way stated in the section on insight, namely, “When they are not discerned, the bodily formation that occurs is stilled when they are discerned” , etc.🔽This is the meaning: “The bodily formation that occurs when the primary elements are not discerned is stilled when they are discerned. The bodily formation that occurs when the four great primaries are not discerned is stilled when they are discerned. The bodily formation that occurs when the four great primaries are not discerned by insight is stilled when they are discerned by insight. The bodily formation that occurs when the four great primaries are not discerned by insight is stilled when they are discerned by insight. The bodily formation that occurs when the four great primaries are not discerned by insight is stilled when they are discerned by insight. The bodily formation that occurs when the four great primaries are not discerned by insight is stilled when they are discerned by insight. The bodily formation that occurs when the four great primaries are not discerned by insight is stilled when they are discerned by insight. The bodily formation that occurs when the four great primaries are not discerned by insight is stilled when they are discerned by insight. The bodily formation that occurs when the four great primaries are not discerned by insight is stilled when they are discerned by insight. The bodily formation that occurs when the four great primaries are not discerned by insight is stilled when they are discerned by insight. The bodily formation

original: Assāti imassa “passambhayaṃ kāyasaṅkhāra”nti padassa. Codanāsodhanāhīti anuyogaparihārehi. Evanti idāni vuccamānākārena.🔽Kathanti yaṃ idaṃ “passambhayaṃ…pe… sikkhatī”ti vuttaṃ, taṃ kathaṃ kena pakārena
analyzed: assa ati imassa kāya saṅkhāranti padassa anuyoga parihārehi evam ti idāni vuccamāna ākārena  katham ti yam idam sikkhati iti vuttam tam katham kena pakārena
translated: “Breath” is for the purpose of the words “calming the bodily formation.” “Questioning and answering” is for the purpose of the questions and answers. “Thus” is in the manner now to be described.🔽“How?” is in the sense of “in what way is it that what is said thus, namely, ‘calming the bodily formation he trains,’ is so?”

original: kāyasaṅkhārassa passambhanaṃ, yogino ca sikkhanaṃ hotīti kathetukamyatāya pucchitvā
analyzed: kāya saṅkhārassa passambhanam yogino ca sikkhanam hoti iti kathetu kamyatāya pucchitvā
translated: “How is there calming of the bodily formation and how does the meditator train?” is the meaning.

original: kāyasaṅkhāre sarūpato, oḷārikasukhumato, vūpasamato, anuyogaparihārato ca dassetuṃ🔽“katame kāyasaṅkhārā”tiādi āraddhaṃ. Tattha kāyikāti rūpakāye bhavā. Kāyapaṭibaddhāti🔽kāyasannissitā. Kāye sati honti, asati na honti, tato eva te akāyasamuṭṭhānāpi kāyena
analyzed: kāya saṅkhāre sarūpataḥ oḷārika sukhumataḥ vūpasamataḥ anuyoga parihārato ca dassetuṃ  katame kāya saṅkhārā ati ādi āraddham tattha kāyikā ati rūpa kāye bhavā kāya paṭibaddhā ati  kāya sannissitā kāye sati honti asati na honti tatas eva te a kāya samuṭṭhānā api kāyena
translated: After asking this question, he sets forth the bodily formation by way of its individual essence, grossness and subtlety, and subsiding, and by way of questioning and answering, in order to show that it is so.🔽Herein, “bodily” is what occurs in the body consisting of the four great primaries. “Consisting of the body” is what is bound up with the body.🔽“Dependent on the body” is what is supported by the body. “They are present when there is a body and absent when there is not. Therefore, though not originating from the body, they are formed by the body. Thus they are bodily formations.”

original: saṅkharīyantīti kāyasaṅkhārā. Passambhentoti oḷārikoḷārikaṃ passambhento. Sesapadadvayaṃ
analyzed: saṅkharīyanti iti kāya saṅkhārā passambhento ti oḷārika uḷārikam sesa pada dvayam
translated: “Calming”: calming the gross and grossest. The remaining two terms are explained in the same way.

original: tasseva vevacanaṃ. Oḷārikañhi kāyasaṅkhāraṃ avūpasantasabhāvaṃ sannisīdāpento “passambhento”ti
analyzed: tassa iva vevacanam oḷārikam hi kāya saṅkhāram a vūpasanta sabhāvam sannisīdāpento passambhento ti
translated: and that is a synonym for it. For when he is causing the gross bodily formation, which is by nature unquiet, to subside, he is said to be “quieting it” ;

original: vuccati, anuppādanirodhaṃ pāpento “nirodhento”ti, suṭṭhu santasabhāvaṃ nayanto “vūpasamento”ti.
analyzed: vuccati anuppāda nirodham pāpentaḥ nirodhentaḥ ti suṭṭhu santa sa bhāvam nayantaḥ vūpasamentaḥ iti
translated: when he is bringing about its non-arising and cessation, he is said to be “making it cease” ; when he is leading it to complete quiet, he is said to be “stilling it.”🔽Of what kind? Of such kind as:🔽With what? With gross bodily formations.

original: Yathārūpehīti yādisehi. Kāyasaṅkhārehīti oḷārikehi kāyasaṅkhārehi. Ānamanāti abhimukhabhāvena
analyzed: yathārūpehi iti yādisehi kāya saṅkhārehi iti oḷārikehi kāya saṅkhārehi abhimukha bhāvena
translated: He directs: he bends the body towards.🔽He bends: he bends it in different directions.

original: kāyassa namanā. Vinamanāti visuṃ visuṃ passato namanā. Sannamanāti sabbato, suṭṭhu
analyzed: kāyassa namanā vinamanā ati visum visum passataḥ namanā sannamanā ati sabbatas suṭṭhu
translated: He stretches: he bends it all round, or well.🔽He contorts: he bends it backwards.

original: vā namanā. Paṇamanāti pacchato namanā. Iñjanādīni ānamanādīnaṃ vevacanāni, adhimattāni
analyzed: vā namanā paṇamanā ati pacchatas namanā iñjana ādīni ānamana ādīnam vevacanāni adhimattāni
translated: The words “trembling” , etc., are synonyms for the words “bending” , etc.;

original: vā abhimukhaṃ calanādīni ānamanādayo, mandāni iñjanādayo. Passambhayaṃ kāyasaṅkhāranti
analyzed: vā abhimukham calana ādīni ānamana ādayaḥ mandāni iñjana ādayaḥ
translated: or the gross bending, etc., is the trembling, etc., that is excessive, and the subtle is that which is slight.

original: tathārūpaṃ ānamanādīnaṃ kāraṇabhūtaṃ oḷārikaṃ kāyasaṅkhāraṃ passambhento. Tasmiṃ
analyzed: tathārūpam ānamana ādīnam kāraṇa bhūtam oḷārikam kāya saṅkhāram tasmin
translated: He makes the bodily formation subside: he quiets the gross bodily formation that is the cause of such bending, etc.

original: hi passambhite ānamanādayopi passambhitā eva honti.
analyzed: hi passambhite ānamana ādayaḥ pi passambhitāḥ eva honti
translated: For when that has subsided, the bending, etc., also subside.

original: Santaṃ sukhumanti yathārūpehi kāyasaṅkhārehi kāyassa aparipphandanahetūhi ānamanādayo
analyzed: santam sukhumanti yathārūpehi kāya saṅkhārehi kāyassa a paripphandana hetūhi ānamana ādayaḥ
translated: “Subtle”: the in-breaths and out-breaths are subtle because they are the cause of the non-disturbance of the body, and because they are the cause of the non-disturbance of the mind.

original: na honti, tathārūpaṃ darathābhāvato santaṃ, anoḷārikatāya sukhumaṃ. Passambhayaṃ🔽kāyasaṅkhāranti sāmaññato ekaṃ katvā vadati. Atha vā pubbe oḷārikoḷārikaṃ kāyasaṅkhāraṃ
analyzed: na honti tathārūpam darathā bhāvataḥ santam anoḷārika tāya sukhumam passambhayam  kāya saṅkhāranti sāmaññataḥ ekam katvā vadati atha vā pubbe oḷārika uḷārikam kāya saṅkhāram
translated: “Tranquil and sublime”: it is tranquil because it is free from grossness, since there is no flexing of the body due to the kinds of bodily formations that are the cause for the body’s flexing, such as bending and stretching; it is sublime because it is free from grossness.

original: paṭippassambhento anukkamena kāyassa aparipphandanahetubhūte sukhumasukhumatare uppādetvā
analyzed: paṭippassambhentaḥ anukkamena kāyassa a paripphandana hetu bhūte sukhuma sukhumatare uppādetvā
translated: “Calming”: he says this by way of a general term. Or else, calming the gross and grossest bodily formations, he generates the subtler and subtlest bodily formations that are the cause for the body’s non-flexing.

original: tepi paṭippassambhetvā paramasukhumatāya koṭippattaṃ yaṃ kāyasaṅkhāraṃ paṭippassambheti,
analyzed: te api paṭippassambhetvā parama sukhumatāya koṭippattam yam kāya saṅkhāram paṭippassambheti
translated: Calming those as well, he calms the bodily formation that has reached the peak of subtlety, the most sublime.

original: taṃ sandhāya vuttaṃ “santaṃ sukhumaṃ passambhayaṃ kāyasaṅkhāra”nti.
analyzed: tam sandhāya vuttam santam sukhumam passambhayam kāya saṅkhāran ti
translated: With reference to that, it is said: “Calming the bodily formation, tranquil and sublime.”

original: Itītiādi codakavacanaṃ. Tattha itīti pakāratthe nipāto. Kirāti arucisūcane, evaṃ
analyzed: iti iti ādi codaka vacanam tattha iti iti pakāra atthe nipātaḥ kirāti aruci sūcane evam
translated: “Thus” and so on is the questioner’s statement. Here, thus is a particle in the sense of “in this way.” “Indeed” is a particle expressing doubt. “If” is the meaning.

original: ceti attho. Ayañhettha adhippāyo – vuttappakārena yadi atisukhumampi kāyasaṅkhāraṃ
analyzed: ca iti atthaḥ ayam ha ittha adhippāyaḥ vutta ppakārena yadi ati sukhumam pi kāya saṅkhāram
translated: The intention here is this: if, in the way described, he calms the bodily formation that is extremely subtle,

original: passambhetīti. Evaṃ santeti evaṃ sati tayā vuttākāre labbhamāne. Vātūpaladdhiyāti🔽vātassa upaladdhiyā. Ca-saddo samuccayattho, assāsādivātārammaṇassa cittassa pabhāvanā
analyzed: passambheti iti evam santā iti evam sati tayā vutta ākāre labbhamāne vātu upaladdhiyā ati  vātassa upaladdhiyā ca saddo samuccaya ttho assāsa ādi vāta ārammaṇassa cittassa pabhāvanā
translated: “It is stilled”: if it were so, if what you say were possible,🔽“By the perception of wind”:

original: uppādanā pavattanā na hoti, te ca tena passambhetabbāti adhippāyo. Assāsapassāsānañca
analyzed: uppādanā pavattanā na hoti te ca tena passambhetabbā ati adhippāyaḥ assāsa passāsānam ca
translated: the meaning of the word “ca” is “and also”; the development of the consciousness that has wind as its object, its arising, its occurrence, is not, and they are to be stilled by that.

original: bhāvanāti oḷārike assāsapassāse bhāvanāya paṭippassambhetvā sukhumānaṃ tesaṃ pabhāvanā🔽ca na hoti, ubhayesaṃ tesaṃ tena paṭippassambhetabbato. Ānāpānassatiyāti ānāpānārammaṇāya🔽satiyā ca pavattanaṃ na hoti, ānāpānānaṃ abhāvato. Tato eva taṃsampayuttassa ānāpānassatisamādhissa
analyzed: bhāvanā ti oḷārike assāsa passāse bhāvanāya paṭippassambhetvā sukhumānam tesam pabhāvanā  ca na hoti ubhayesam tesam tena paṭippassambhetabbataḥ āna apāna satiyā ati āna apāna ārammaṇāya  satiyāḥ ca pavattanam na hoti āna apānānam abhāvato tatas eva tad sampayuttassa āna apāna sati samādhissa
translated: “And of in-breaths and out-breaths”: the development of gross in-breaths and out-breaths is stilled by the development of the subtle ones.🔽The development of the latter is not, and both are to be stilled by that.🔽“Of mindfulness of breathing”: the occurrence of mindfulness that has in-breaths and out-breaths as its object is not, because of the absence of in-breaths and out-breaths.

original: ca pabhāvanā uppādanāpi na hoti. Na hi kadāci ārammaṇena vinā sārammaṇadhammā sambhavanti.
analyzed: ca pabhāvanā uppādanā api na hoti na hi kadāci ārammaṇena vinā sa ārammaṇa dhammā sambhavanti
translated: And the development of concentration due to mindfulness of breathing that is associated with that is not, and its arising is not. For it is never possible for a state with an object to exist when the object is absent.

original: Na ca naṃ tanti ettha nanti nipātamattaṃ. Taṃ vuttavidhānaṃ samāpattiṃ paṇḍitā paññavanto
analyzed: na ca naṃ tanti ettha nanti nipāta mattam tam vutta vidhānam samāpattim paṇḍitā paññavanto
translated: And na ca naṃ is not a mere particle here. The wise, the sagacious,🔽

original: na ceva samāpajjantipi tato na vuṭṭhahantipīti yojanā. Evaṃ codako sabbena sabbaṃ🔽abhāvūpanayanaṃ passambhananti adhippāyena codeti.🔽Puna iti kirātiādi yathāvuttāya codanāya vissajjanā. Tattha kirāti “yadī”ti etassa
analyzed: na ca iva samāpajjanti pi tatas na vuṭṭhahanti pi iti yojanā evam ca udakaḥ sabbena sabbam  abhāva upanayanam adhippāyena codeti  puna iti kirāti ādi yathāvuttāya codanāya vissajjanā tattha kirāti yadi iti etassa
translated: And na ca naṃ is not a mere particle. The wise, the sagacious, do not enter upon and emerge from the attainment in the way described. This is how the accuser accuses him of the non-existence of all of everything by way of the intended meaning of “quieting.”

original: atthe nipāto. Iti kira sikkhati, mayā vuttākārena yadi sikkhatīti attho. Evaṃ santeti🔽evaṃ passambhane sati. Pabhāvanā hotīti yadipi oḷārikā kāyasaṅkhārā paṭippassambhanti,🔽sukhumā pana atthevāti anukkamena paramasukhumabhāvappattassa vasena nimittuppattiyā
analyzed: atthe nipātaḥ iti kira sikkhati mayā vutta ākārena yadi sikkhati iti atthaḥ evam santā iti  evam passambhane sati pabhāvanā hoti iti yadi api oḷārikā kāya saṅkhārā paṭippassambhanti  sukhumā pana atthā iva ati anukkamena parama sukhuma bhāva pattassa vasena nimitta uppattiyā
translated: Again, iti kira is the reply to the accusation stated as above. Herein, kira is a particle in the sense of “if.” The meaning is, “if he trains in the way I have described.” If that is so,

original: ānāpānassatiyā, ānāpānassatisamādhissa ca pabhāvanā ijjhatevāti adhippāyo.
analyzed: ānāpānassatiyāḥ ānāpānassati samādhissa ca pabhāvanā ijjha tā iva ati adhippāyaḥ
translated: if there is that quieting, then there is development. The intention is this: although gross bodily formations are quieted, still subtle ones remain. So the arising of the sign and the development of mindfulness of breathing and concentration by means of the sign are successful, since they reach the state of extreme subtlety by gradual stages.

original: Yathā kathaṃ viyāti yathāvuttavidhānaṃ taṃ kathaṃ viya daṭṭhabbaṃ, atthi kiñci tadatthasampaṭipādane
analyzed: yathā katham viya iti yathā vutta vidhānam tam katham viya daṭṭhabbam atthi kiñci tad attha sampaṭipādane
translated: The intention is this: “In what way should it be regarded? In what way should it be seen? Is there a simile for the explanation of that meaning?🔽” “Just as, bhikkhus, in an empty, deserted, and secluded forest” :🔽the word “just as” is a particle in the sense of a simile.

original: opammanti adhippāyo. Idāni opammaṃ dassetuṃ “seyyathāpī”tiādi vuttaṃ. Tattha seyyathāpīti🔽opammatthe nipāto. Kaṃseti kaṃsabhājane. Nimittanti nimittassa, tesaṃ saddānaṃ pavattākārassāti
analyzed: opammam ti adhippāyaḥ idāni opammam dassetum seyyathāpi itiādi vuttam tattha seyyathāpi iti  opamma atthe nipātaḥ kaṃsa iti kaṃsa bhājane nimittam ti nimittassa tesam saddānam pavatta ākārassa ati
translated: “In a bronze bowl” : in a bronze dish.🔽“The sign” : the meaning is the mode of occurrence of those sounds.🔽For this is a word expressing use in the sense of master.

original: attho. Sāmiatthe hi idaṃ upayogavacanaṃ. Suggahitattāti suṭṭhu gahitattā. Sumanasikatattāti
analyzed: attho sāmi atthe hi idam upayoga vacanam su gahita ttā ati suṭṭhu gahita ttā su manasikata ttā ati
translated: “Well apprehended” : because of being well seized. “Well attended to” :

original: suṭṭhu citte ṭhapitattā. Sūpadhāritattāti sammadeva upadhāritattā sallakkhitattā.
analyzed: suṭṭhu citte ṭhapita ttā su upadhārita ttā ati sammad eva upadhārita ttā sallakkhita ttā
translated: because of being well placed in the mind. “Well remembered” : because of being well remembered, well defined.🔽“The subtle sounds” : he says this about the overtones, which are few.

original: Sukhumakā saddāti anurave āha, ye appakā. Appattho hi ayaṃ ka-saddo. Sukhumasaddanimittārammaṇatāpīti
analyzed: sukhumakā saddā iti anurave āha ye appakāḥ appatthaḥ hi ayam ka saddaḥ sukhuma sadda nimitta ārammaṇa tā api iti
translated: For this ka-sound has a small meaning. “The subtle sound as the object of the sign” :

original: sukhumo saddova nimittaṃ sukhumasaddanimittaṃ, tadārammaṇatāyapi. Kiṃ vuttaṃ hoti?
analyzed: nimittam sukhuma sadda nimittam kim vuttam hoti
translated: the subtle sound itself is the sign, the subtle sound is the sign, the object of that is the subtle sound as the object of the sign. In what way?

original: Kāmaṃ tadāsukhumāpi saddā niruddhā, saddanimittassa pana suggahitattā sukhumatarasaddanimittārammaṇabhāvenāpi
analyzed: kāmam tadā asukhumā api saddāḥ niruddhā sadda nimittassa pana suggahita ttā sukhumatara sadda nimitta ārammaṇa bhāvena api
translated: Though the sounds are then faint, still the mind occurs with that as its object,🔽because the sign of the sound was well apprehended. For when he first apprehends the sign of the sound that has ceased, his mind does not become concentrated,

original: cittaṃ pavattati. Ādito paṭṭhāya hi tassa tassa niruddhassa saddassa nimittaṃ avikkhittena🔽cittena upadhārentassa anukkamena pariyosāne atisukhumasaddanimittampi ārammaṇaṃ
analyzed: cittam pavattati āditaḥ paṭṭhāya hi tassa tassa niruddhassa saddassa nimittam a vikkhittena  cittena upadhārentassa anukkamena pariyosāne ati sukhuma sadda nimittam pi ārammaṇam
translated: but as he continues to advert to the sign of the sound that has ceased, eventually his mind enters into concentration with the sign of the sound as its object, even though the sound is extremely faint.

original: katvā cittaṃ pavattateva. Cittaṃ na vikkhepaṃ gacchati tasmiṃ yathāupaṭṭhite nimitte
analyzed: katvā cittam pavattate iva cittam na vikkhepam gacchati tasmim yathā upaṭṭhite nimitte
translated: His mind does not become distracted,

original: samādhānasabbhāvato.🔽Evaṃ santetiādi vuttassevatthassa nigamanavasena vuttaṃ. Tattha yassa suttapadassa
analyzed: samādhāna sabbhāvataḥ  evam santā iti ādi vuttassa iva atthassa nigamana vasena vuttam tattha yassa sutta padassa
translated: because it is concentrated on the sign as it appears to it.

original: saddhiṃ codanāsodhanāhi attho vutto, taṃ uddharitvā kāyānupassanāsatipaṭṭhānāni vibhāgato
analyzed: saddhim codanā sodhanāhi atthaḥ vuttaḥ tam uddharitvā kāya anupassanā sati paṭṭhānāni vibhāgato
translated: The words “When that is so” and so on are said by way of conclusion of what has just been said. Herein, in order to show the development of the mindfulness of breathing and the foundation of mindfulness consisting in contemplation of the body by extracting the text together with the questions and answers that explain its meaning,

original: dassetuṃ “passambhaya”ntiādi vuttaṃ. Taṃ sabbaṃ vuttanayattā uttānameva.
analyzed: dassetum passambhayanti ādi vuttam tat sabbam vutta naya ttā uttānam eva
translated: the following is said, beginning with “Calming the bodily formation” . All this is obvious since it has already been explained.

original: 222. Ādikammikassa kammaṭṭhānavasenāti samathakammaṭṭhānaṃ sandhāya vuttaṃ. Vipassanaṃ🔽kammaṭṭhānaṃ pana itaracatukkesupi labbhateva. Etthāti paṭhamacatukke. Pañcasandhikanti🔽pañcapabbaṃ, pañcabhāganti attho.🔽Kammaṭṭhānassa uggaṇhananti kammaṭṭhānaganthassa uggaṇhanaṃ. Tadatthaparipucchā kammaṭṭhānassa
analyzed: ādikammikassa kammaṭṭhāna vasena āti samatha kammaṭṭhānam sandhāya vuttam vipassanam  kammaṭṭhānam pana itara catukkesu pi labbhateva ettha ati paṭhama catukke pañca sandhikanti  pañca pabbam pañca bhāgam ti atthaḥ  kammaṭṭhānassa uggaṇhananti kammaṭṭhāna ganthassa uggaṇhanam tad attha paripucchā kammaṭṭhānassa
translated: “For a beginner, in the way stated” refers to the serenity meditation subject. But the insight meditation subject is available in the other four cases too. “Here” means in the first case. “Five-part” :🔽it has five sections; it is fivefold, is the meaning.🔽“Learning the meditation subject” : learning the meditation subject text. “Inquiring about its meaning” :

original: paripucchanā. Atha vā ganthato, atthato ca kammaṭṭhānassa uggaṇhanaṃ uggaho. Tattha🔽saṃsayaparipucchanā paripucchā. Kammaṭṭhānassa upaṭṭhānanti nimittupaṭṭhānaṃ, evaṃ🔽bhāvanamanuyuñjantassa “evamidha nimittaṃ upaṭṭhātī”ti upadhāraṇaṃ, tathā kammaṭṭhānappanā🔽“evaṃ jhānamappetī”ti. Kammaṭṭhānassa lakkhaṇanti gaṇanānubandhanāphusanānaṃ vasena
analyzed: paripucchanā atha vā ganthataḥ atthataḥ ca kammaṭṭhānassa uggaṇhanam uggahaḥ tattha 🔽saṃsaya paripucchanā paripucchā kammaṭṭhānassa upaṭṭhānan ti nimitta upaṭṭhānam evam 🔽bhāvanam anuyuñjantassa evam idha nimittam upaṭṭhāti iti upadhāraṇam tathā kammaṭṭhāna ppanā 🔽evam jhānam appeti iti kammaṭṭhānassa lakkhaṇan ti gaṇanā anubandhana āphusanānam vasena
translated: “For one who is a beginner, in the sense of the meditation subject” is said with reference to serenity meditation subjects. But insight meditation subjects are allowable in the other four instances too. “Here” is in the first tetrad. “Five-part” : it has five sections, is the meaning. “Learning the meditation subject” : learning the meditation subject text. “Asking about its meaning” : asking about the meditation subject. Or alternatively, learning the meditation subject by text and by meaning is learning. “Asking” is asking about the doubts that have arisen in the meditation subject. “The meditation subject’s appearance” : the appearance of the sign. “The meditation subject’s definition” : the meditation subject’s definition by way of the characteristics of the sign. “The meditation subject’s level” : the meditation subject’s plane. “The meditation subject’s arrival” : the meditation subject’s arrival at jhāna.

original: bhāvanaṃ ussukkāpetvā ṭhapanāya sampatti, tato parampi vā sallakkhaṇādivasena matthakappattīti
analyzed: bhāvanam ussukkāpetvā ṭhapanāya sampatti tatas param pi vā sat lakkhaṇa ādi vasena matthaka ppatti iti
translated: and he is successful in the putting aside of development, and in the surmounting of that, and so on, up to the surmounting of defining.

original: kammaṭṭhānasabhāvassa sallakkhaṇaṃ. Tenāha “kammaṭṭhānasabhāvūpadhāraṇanti vuttaṃ hotī”ti.
analyzed: kammaṭṭhāna sabhāvassa sat lakkhaṇam tena āha kammaṭṭhāna sabhāva upadhāraṇam ti vuttam hoti iti
translated: This is the defining of the nature of the meditation subject. Hence it is said: “The meaning is that he keeps the nature of the meditation subject in being.”

original: Attanāpi na kilamati odhiso kammaṭṭhānassa uggaṇhanato. Tato eva ācariyampi na viheseti🔽dhammādhikaraṇampi bhāvanāya matthakaṃ pāpanato. Tasmāti taṃ nimittaṃ attano akilamanaācariyāvihesanahetu.
analyzed: attanā api na kilamati odhiso kammaṭṭhānassa uggaṇhanato tatas eva ācariyam pi na viheseti  dhamma adhikaraṇam pi bhāvanāya matthakam tasmā ati tam nimittam attanaḥ a kilamana ācariyā vihesana hetu
translated: He does not tire himself by learning the meditation subject in detail. And because of that he does not harass his teacher.🔽And because he has brought the meditation subject to its culmination in development, he does not harass the Community.🔽So this sign is the reason why he does not tire himself and why he does not harass his teacher and the Community.

original: Thokanti thokaṃ thokaṃ. Uggahetabbato uggaho, sabbopi kammaṭṭhānavidhi, na pubbe
analyzed: thokanti thokam thokan uggahetabbataḥ uggahaḥ sabbaḥ api kammaṭṭhāna vidhi na pubbe
translated: Little by little: little by little. Learning is learning by heart. The whole method of learning the meditation subject is not just learning by heart as already described.

original: vuttauggahamattaṃ. Ācariyato uggaho ācariyuggaho, tato. Ekapadampīti ekakoṭṭhāsampi.
analyzed: vutta oggaha mattam ācariyataḥ uggahaḥ ācariyuggaho tatas eka padam pi iti eka koṭṭhāsam pi
translated: Learning from a teacher is learning from a teacher. From that: from that learning. Even a single phrase: even a single section.

original: 223. Anuvahanāti assāsapassāsānaṃ anugamanavasena satiyā nirantaraṃ anupavattanā.
analyzed: anuvahanā ati assāsa passāsānam anugamana vasena satiyāḥ nirantaram anupavattanā
translated: Following: uninterrupted occurrence of mindfulness by following in-breaths and out-breaths.

original: Phusanāti assāsapassāse gaṇentassa gaṇanaṃ paṭisaṃharitvā te satiyā anubandhantassa🔽yathā appanā hoti, tathā cittaṃ ṭhapentassa ca nāsikaggādiṭṭhānassa nesaṃ phusanā.
analyzed: assāsa passāse gaṇentassa gaṇanam paṭisaṃharitvā te satiyā anubandhantassa  yathā appanā hoti tathā cittam ṭhapentassa ca nāsikagga ādiṭṭhānassa na īsam phusanā
translated: “Touching” is the touching of the place where the in-breaths and out-breaths are normally to be found by one who, after ending the counting of the in-breaths and out-breaths, follows them with mindfulness established in order to make them enter into absorption, and by one who steadies his mind in the place where they are normally to be found in order to make them enter into absorption.

original: Yasmā pana gaṇanādivasena viya phusanāvasena visuṃ manasikāro natthi, phuṭṭhaphuṭṭhaṭṭhāneyeva
analyzed: yasmā pana gaṇanā ādi vasena viya phusanā vasena visum manasikāraḥ na atthi phuṭṭha phuṭṭha ṭhānā iya iva
translated: But there is no separate bringing to mind by touching as there is by counting, and so on. For counting, etc., are to be done at each place touched.

original: gaṇanādi kātabbanti dassetuṃ idha phusanāgahaṇanti dīpento “phusanāti phuṭṭhaṭṭhāna”nti
analyzed: gaṇanā ādi kātabbanti dassetum idha phusanā gahaṇam ti dīpentaḥ phusanā ati phuṭṭha ṭhānam ti
translated: In order to show this he said “Touching is the place touched,” explaining “touching” as “the place touched.”

original: āha. Ṭhapanāti samādhānaṃ. Taṃ hi sammadeva ārammaṇe cittassa ādhānaṃ ṭhapanaṃ hoti.🔽Tathā hi samādhi “cittassa ṭhiti saṇṭhitī”ti niddiṭṭho. Samādhippadhānā pana appanāti
analyzed: āha ṭhapana ati samādhānam tam hi sammadeva ārammaṇe cittassa ādhānam ṭhapanam hoti  tathā hi samādhi cittassa ṭhiti saṇṭhiti iti niddiṭṭhaḥ samādhi ppadhānā pana appanā ti
translated: “Steadied” is concentrated. For that is the steadying, the fixing, of the mind on the object.🔽For it is said of concentration: “The mind’s stability is steadying” . But absorption is the pre- eminence of concentration.

original: āha “ṭhapanāti appanā”ti. Aniccatādīnaṃ sallakkhaṇato sallakkhaṇā vipassanā. Pavattato,
analyzed: āha ṭhapanā ti appanā ti anicca tā ādīnam sat lakkhaṇataḥ sat lakkhaṇā vipassanā pavattato
translated: So he said “Steadied is absorption.” “Contemplated” is insight, because of the contemplation of impermanence, and so on.🔽The path is called “revolved” because it is turned away from occurrence and from the sign of occurrence.

original: nimittato ca vinivaṭṭanato vivaṭṭanā nāma maggo. Sakalasaṃkilesapaṭippassaddhibhāvato
analyzed: nimittato ca vinivaṭṭanataḥ vivaṭṭanā nāma maggo sakala saṃkilesa paṭippassaddhi bhāvato
translated: And it is called “fully understood” because of the complete tranquillization of all defilements.

original: sabbaso suddhīti pārisuddhi phalaṃ. Tesanti vivaṭṭanāpārisuddhīnaṃ. Paṭipassanāti🔽paṭi paṭi dassanaṃ pekkhanaṃ. Tenāha “paccavekkhaṇā”ti.
analyzed: sabbaso suddhī iti pārisuddhi phalam tesan ti vivaṭṭanā pārisuddhīnam paṭipassanā ati  paṭi paṭi dassanam pekkhanam tena āha paccavekkhaṇā ti
translated: Purification of all is the fruition. “Theirs” refers to the two kinds of purification of insight. “Reviewing”:🔽reviewing, seeing, is reviewing.

original: Khaṇḍanti ekaṃ tīṇi pañcāti evaṃ gaṇanāya khaṇḍanaṃ. Okāseti gaṇanavidhiṃ sandhāyāha.
analyzed: khaṇḍanti ekam tīṇi pañca ati evam gaṇanāya khaṇḍanam okāsa iti gaṇana vidhim sandhāya āha
translated: “Counting”: counting by way of one, three, five, and so on. “In a place”: he says this referring to the method of counting.

original: Gaṇananissitova na kammaṭṭhānanissito. “Sikhāppattaṃ nu kho”ti idaṃ cirataraṃ gaṇanāya🔽manasi karontassa vasena vuttaṃ. So hi tathā laddhaṃ avikkhepamattaṃ nissāya evaṃ
analyzed: gaṇana nissitaḥ iva na kammaṭṭhāna nissitaḥ sikhā pattam nu khalu iti idam cirataram gaṇanāya  manasi karontassa vasena vuttam so hi tathā laddham avikkhepa mattam nissāya evam
translated: It is based on counting, not on the meditation subject. “Has it reached absorption?” is said with reference to one who is mindful of counting for a long time.

original: maññeyya. “Assāsapassāsesu yo upaṭṭhāti, taṃ gahetvā”ti idaṃ assāsapassāsesu yassa🔽ekova paṭhamaṃ upaṭṭhāti, taṃ sandhāya vuttaṃ, yassa pana ubhopi upaṭṭhahanti, tena
analyzed: maññeyya assāsa passāsesu yaḥ upaṭṭhāti tam gahetvā iti idam assāsa passāsesu yassa  ekaḥ iva paṭhamam upaṭṭhāti tam sandhāya vuttam yassa pana ubho api upaṭṭhahanti tena
translated: For he might think thus: “The mere non-distraction that has been acquired is based on this.”🔽“Seizing that which appears” is said with reference to one of whom only one of the two, either in-breath or out-breath, appears.🔽But by the one of whom both appear, they should be counted both ways.

original: ubhayampi gahetvā gaṇetabbaṃ. “Yo upaṭṭhātī”ti iminā ca dvīsu nāsāpuṭavātesu yo pākaṭataro
analyzed: ubhayam pi gahetvā gaṇetabbam yaḥ upaṭṭhāti iti iminā ca dvīsu nāsāpuṭa vātesu yo pākaṭataro
translated: “That which appears” refers to the nostril-wind that is the more evident of the two.

original: upaṭṭhāti, so gahetabboti ayampi attho dīpitoti daṭṭhabbaṃ. Pavattamānaṃ pavattamānanti
analyzed: upaṭṭhāti so gahetabbaḥ ti ayam pi atthaḥ dīpitaḥ iti daṭṭhabbam pavattamānam pavattamānam
translated: “Occurring, occurring”:

original: āmeḍitavacanena nirantaraṃ assāsapassāsānaṃ upalakkhaṇaṃ dasseti. Evanti vuttappakārena
analyzed: āmeḍita vacanena nirantaram assāsa passāsānam upalakkhaṇam dasseti evam ti vutta ppakārena
translated: by the word “repeatedly” he shows the characteristic of the in-breaths and out-breaths as uninterrupted. “Thus”:

original: upalakkhetvā vāti attho. Pākaṭā honti gaṇanāvasena bahiddhā vikkhepābhāvato.
analyzed: upalakkhetvā vā ti atthaḥ pākaṭāḥ honti gaṇanā vasena bahiddhā vikkhepa abhāvato
translated: the meaning is “having characterized them in this way.” “They become evident”: because there is no distraction externally by means of the counting.

original: Palighassa parivattanaṃ, taṃ yattha nikkhipanti, so palighatthambho. Tiyāmarattinti
analyzed: palighassa parivattanam tam yattha nikkhipanti saḥ palighatthambhaḥ
translated: The turning of the post: where they deposit it, that is the post-socket. “For three watches”:

original: accantasaṃyoge upayogavacanaṃ. Purimanayenāti sīghagaṇanāya, gopālakagaṇanāyāti attho.🔽Eko dve tīṇi cattāri pañcāti gaṇanāvidhidassanaṃ. Tasmā aṭṭhātiādīsupi ekato paṭṭhāyeva
analyzed: a c c anta saṃyoge upayoga vacanam purima nayena ati sīgha gaṇanāya gopālaka gaṇanāya ati attho  ekaḥ dve tīṇi cattāri pañca ati gaṇanā vidhi dassanam tasmai aṭṭha ati ādīsu pi ekatas paṭṭhāya iva
translated: the word “for” is used in the sense of “during.” “In the way already stated”: by counting quickly; the meaning is, by counting like a cowherd.🔽“One, two, three, four, five” is the demonstration of the method of counting.🔽Therefore, in the case of “eight” and so on, too, each one should be counted from one onwards,

original: paccekaṃ aṭṭhādīni pāpetabbāni. Sīghaṃ sīghaṃ gaṇetabbameva. Kasmāti tattha kāraṇaṃ,
analyzed: paccekam aṭṭha ādīni pāpetabbāni sīgham sīgham gaṇetabbam eva kasmā ati tattha kāraṇam
translated: and they should be counted quickly. “Why?” is the question.🔽He shows the reason and the example thus, “For counting is the cause,”

original: nidassanañca dasseti “gaṇanapaṭibaddhe hī”tiādinā. Tattha arīyati tena nāvāti arittaṃ,
analyzed: nidassanam ca dasseti gaṇana paṭibaddhe hi itiādinā tattha arīyati tena na avāti arittam
translated: and so on. Herein, it is a plough because it ploughs .

original: pājanadaṇḍo. Arittena upatthambhanaṃ arittupatthambhanaṃ, tassa vasena.
analyzed: pājana daṇḍaḥ arittena upatthambhanam aritta upatthambhanam tassa vasena
translated: a bowl-rest stick.🔽The support of a stick is the support of a stick that is not made of bamboo.🔽

original: Nippariyāyato nirantarappavatti nāma ṭhapanāyamevāti āha “nirantaraṃ pavattaṃ viyā”ti.🔽Anto pavisantaṃ vātaṃ manasi karonto anto cittaṃ paveseti nāma. Bahi cittanīharaṇepi
analyzed: nippariyāyataḥ nirantarappavatti nāma āha nirantaram pavattam viyāti  antar pavisantam vātam manasi karontaḥ antar cittam paveseti nāma bahi citta nīharaṇe pi
translated: The bowl-handle is the handle of the bowl. The bowl-rim is the rim of the bowl. The bowl-flange is the flange of the bowl. The bowl-foot is the foot of the bowl. The bowl-string-hole is the string-hole of the bowl. The bowl-string is the string of the bowl. The bowl-band is the band of the bowl. The bowl-lip is the lip of the bowl. The bowl-base is the base of the bowl.

original: eseva nayo. Vātabbhāhatanti abbhantaragataṃ vātaṃ bahulaṃ manasi karontassa vātena🔽taṃ ṭhānaṃ abbhāhataṃ viya, medena pūritaṃ viya ca hoti, tathā upaṭṭhāti. Nīharato
analyzed: esa iva nayaḥ abbhantara gatam vātam bahulam manasi karontassa vātena  tam ṭhānam abbhāhatam viya medena pūritam viya ca hoti tathā upaṭṭhāti nīharataḥ
translated: The bowl-handle is the handle of the bowl. The bowl-rim is the rim of the bowl. The bowl-flange is the flange of the bowl. The bowl-foot is the foot of the bowl. The bowl-string-hole is the string-hole of the bowl. The bowl-string is the string of the bowl. The bowl-band is the band of the bowl. The bowl-lip is the lip of the bowl. The bowl-base is the base of the bowl.

original: phuṭṭhokāsaṃ muñcitvā, tathā pana nīharato vātassa gatisamannesanamukhena nānārammaṇesu🔽cittaṃ vidhāvatīti āha “puthuttārammaṇe cittaṃ vikkhipatī”ti.🔽Etanti etaṃ assāsapassāsajātaṃ.
analyzed: phuṭṭha ukāsam muñcitvā tathā pana nīharataḥ vātassa gati samannesana mukhena nānā ārammaṇesu  cittam vidhāvati iti āha puthutta ārammaṇe cittam vikkhipati iti  etam ti etam assāsa passāsa jātam
translated: The bowl-handle is the handle of the bowl. The bowl-rim is the rim of the bowl. The bowl-flange is the flange of the bowl. The bowl-foot is the foot of the bowl. The bowl-string-hole is the string-hole of the bowl. The bowl-string is the string of the bowl. The bowl-band is the band of the bowl. The bowl-lip is the lip of the bowl. The bowl-base is the base of the bowl.

original: 224. Anugamananti pavattapavattānaṃ assāsapassāsānaṃ ārammaṇakaraṇavasena satiyā
analyzed: anugamanam ti pavatta pavattānam assāsa passāsānam ārammaṇa karaṇa vasena satiyā
translated: The bowl-handle is the handle of the bowl. The bowl-rim is the rim of the bowl. The bowl-flange is the flange of the bowl. The bowl-foot is the foot of the bowl. The bowl-string-hole is the string-hole of the bowl. The bowl-string is the string of the bowl. The bowl-band is the band of the bowl. The bowl-lip is the lip of the bowl. The bowl-base is the base of the bowl.🔽The bowl-handle is the handle of the bowl. The bowl-rim is the rim of the bowl. The bowl-flange is the flange of the bowl. The bowl-foot is the foot of the bowl. The bowl-string-hole is the string-hole of the bowl. The bowl-string is the string of the bowl. The bowl-band is the band of the bowl. The bowl-lip is the lip of the bowl

original: anu anu pavattanaṃ anugacchanaṃ. Tenevāha “tañca kho na ādimajjhapariyosānānugamanavasenā”ti.
analyzed: anu anu pavattanam anugacchanam tena iva āha tat ca kho na ādi majjha pariyosāna anugamana vasena ati
translated: The meaning of “following” is “going after” in the sense of occurring after. That is why it is said, “And that is in the sense of following the beginning, middle, and end” .

original: Nābhi ādi tattha paṭhamaṃ uppajjanato. Paṭhamuppattivasena hi idha ādicintā, na uppattimattavasena.
analyzed: ādi tattha paṭhamam uppajjanataḥ paṭhama uppatti vasena hi idha ādi cintā na uppattimatta vasena
translated: The navel is the beginning there because it is the first place of arising. For the consideration of the beginning here is in the sense of the first arising, not in the sense of mere arising.

original: Tathā hi te nābhito paṭṭhāya yāva nāsikaggā sabbattha uppajjanteva. Yattha yattha
analyzed: tathā hi te nābhitaḥ paṭṭhāya yāva nāsikaggā sabbattha uppajjanteva yattha yattha
translated: For they arise everywhere from the navel up as far as the nose-tip,

original: ca uppajjanti, tattha tattheva bhijjanti dhammānaṃ gamanābhāvato. Yathāpaccayaṃ pana
analyzed: ca uppajjanti tattha tattha iva bhijjanti dhammānam gamana abhāvataḥ yathāpaccayam pana
translated: and wherever they arise there they break up, because states do not go. But the expression “going” is used in the sense of arising in a place successively in dependence on a place.

original: desantaruppattiyaṃ gatisamaññā. Hadayaṃ majjhanti hadayasamīpaṃ tassa uparibhāgo
analyzed: desantara uppattiyam gati samaññā hadayam majjhanti hadaya samīpam tassa upari bhāgaḥ
translated: The heart is the middle because it is near the heart, that is to say, the part above it.

original: majjhaṃ. Nāsikaggaṃ pariyosānanti nāsikaṭṭhānaṃ tassa pariyosānaṃ assāsapassāsasamaññāya
analyzed: majjham nāsikaggam pariyosānanti nāsika ṭṭhānam tassa pariyosānam assāsa passāsa samaññāya
translated: The nose-tip is the end because it is the end of the in-breath and out-breath, which are called “in-breaths and out-breaths as a bodily formation,” since it is the limit of their occurrence.

original: tadavadhibhāvato. Tathā hete “cittasamuṭṭhānā”ti vuttā, na ca bahiddhā cittasamuṭṭhānānaṃ
analyzed: tad avadhi bhāvato tathā ha ete citta samuṭṭhānā ati vuttā na ca bahiddhā
translated: For they are called “arisen with mind” , and states that are not mind do not arise outside mind.

original: sambhavo atthi. Tenāha “abbhantaraṃ pavisanavātassa nāsikaggaṃ ādī”ti. Pavisananikkhamanapariyāyo
analyzed: sambhavaḥ atthi tena āha abbhantaram pavisana vātassa nāsikaggam ādi iti pavisana nikkhamana pariyāyaḥ
translated: There is a possibility. Hence he said: “The nose tip is the beginning of the in-breath and out-breath.”🔽But the method of the in-breath and out-breath should be understood as stated in this way by way of what is similar to that.

original: pana taṃsadisavasena vuttoti veditabbo. Vikkhepagatanti vikkhepaṃ upagataṃ, vikkhittaṃ
analyzed: pana tad sadisa vasena vuttaḥ ti veditabbaḥ vikkhepa gatanti vikkhepam upagatam vikkhittam
translated: “Gone to distraction”: gone to distraction, distracted;🔽the meaning is, not concentrated.

original: asamāhitanti attho. Sāraddhāyāti sadarathabhāvāya. Iñjanāyāti kammaṭṭhānamanasikārassa calanāya.
analyzed: asamāhitam ti attho sāraddhāya ati sadaratha bhāvāya iñjanāya ati kammaṭṭhāna manasikārassa calanāya
translated: “To be agitated”: to be agitated by the state of being agitated. “To be shaken”: to be shaken by the attention given to the meditation subject.🔽“With a mind gone to distraction”: the instrumental case is used for the ablative; or it is a locative of characteristic.

original: Vikkhepagatena cittenāti hetumhi karaṇavacanaṃ, itthambhūtalakkhaṇe vā. Sāraddhāti sadarathā. Iñjitāti iñjanakā calanakā. Tathā phanditā.
analyzed: vikkhepa gatena cittena ati hetumhi karaṇa vacanam ittham bhūta lakkhaṇe vā sāraddhā ati sadarathā iñjitā ati iñjanakā calanakā tathā phanditā
translated: “Agitated”: agitated by agitation. “Shaken”: shaken by shaking. “Fluttering”: fluttering by fluttering.

original: Ādimajjhapariyosānavasenāti ādimajjhapariyosānānugamanavasena na manasi kātabbanti
analyzed: ādi majjha pariyosāna vasena ati ādi majjha pariyosāna anugamana vasena na manasi kātabbanti
translated: “By way of beginning, middle and end”: the construction is: “should not be given attention by way of following the beginning, middle and end.”

original: sambandho. “Anubandhanāya manasi karontena phusanāvasena ca ṭhapanāvasena ca manasi
analyzed: sambandhaḥ anubandhanāya manasi karontena phusanā vasena ca ṭhapanā vasena ca manasi
translated: “By giving attention by way of following the counting, it should be given attention by way of touching and by way of steadying,”

original: kātabba”nti yenādhippāyena vuttaṃ, taṃ vivarituṃ “gaṇanānubandhanāvasena viyā”tiādimāha.
analyzed: kātabbam ti yena adhippāyena vuttam tam vivaritum gaṇanā anubandhanā vasena viya iti ādim āha
translated: which was said with a certain intention, he said “As though following the counting” in order to reveal that intention.

original: Tattha visuṃ manasikāro natthīti gaṇanāya, anubandhanāya ca vinā yathākkamaṃ kevalaṃ🔽phusanāvasena, ṭhapanāvasena ca kammaṭṭhānamanasikāro natthi. Nanu phusanāya vinā
analyzed: tattha visum manasikāraḥ natthi iti gaṇanāya anubandhanāya ca vinā yathākkamam kevalam  phusanā vasena ṭhapanā vasena ca kammaṭṭhāna manasikāro natthi nanu phusanāya vinā
translated: Herein, there is no separate attention means that there is no attention to the meditation subject by way of touching and by way of determining without counting and following.🔽Has there not already been attention without touching,

original: ṭhapanāya viya, phusanāya vinā gaṇanāyapi manasikāro natthiyeva? Yadipi natthi, gaṇanā
analyzed: manasikāraḥ manasikāro yadi api natthi gaṇanā
translated: like that without determining? —Granted that there has, nevertheless,

original: pana yathā kammaṭṭhānamanasikārassa mūlabhāvato padhānabhāvena gahetabbā, evaṃ anubandhanā
analyzed: pana yathā kammaṭṭhāna manasikārassa mūla bhāvataḥ padhāna bhāvena gahetabbā evam anubandhanā
translated: counting is to be taken as the principal factor because it is the root of attention to the meditation subject, and so too following;🔽but determining is not, because it is impossible without that.

original: ṭhapanāya, tāya vinā ṭhapanāya asambhavato. Tasmā satipi phusanāya nānantarikabhāve🔽gaṇanānubandhanā eva mūlabhāvato padhānabhāvena gahetvā itarāsaṃ tadabhāvaṃ dassento
analyzed: tāya vinā tasmā satipi phusanāya na ānantarika bhāve  gaṇanā anubandhanāḥ eva mūla bhāvataḥ padhāna bhāvena gahetvā itarāsam tad abhāvam dassento
translated: So although touching is next in sequence,

original: āha “gaṇanānubandhanāvasena viya hi phusanāṭhapanāvasena visuṃ manasikāro natthī”ti.
analyzed: āha gaṇanā anubandhanā vasena viya hi phusanā ṭhapanā vasena visum manasikāraḥ natthi iti
translated: attention by way of touching and determining is not separate, like attention by way of counting and following.🔽If that is so, why is it given separately in the description?

original: Yadi evaṃ tā kasmā uddese visuṃ gahitāti āha “phuṭṭhaphuṭṭhaṭṭhāneyevā”tiādi. Tattha
analyzed: yadi evam tā kasmai uddese visum gahitā iti āha phuṭṭha phuṭṭha ṭṭhāneyā iva atiādi tattha
translated: He said “At the place touched” and so on. Herein,

original: “phuṭṭhaphuṭṭhaṭṭhāneyeva gaṇento”ti iminā gaṇanāya phusanā aṅganti dasseti. Tenāha
analyzed: phuṭṭha phuṭṭha ṭṭhāne iya iva gaṇento ti iminā gaṇanāya phusanā aṅganti dasseti tena āha
translated: By the words “counting at the place touched” he shows that the touching is a factor of the counting. Hence he says:🔽“He gives attention by counting and by touching” .

original: “gaṇanāya ca phusanāya ca manasi karotī”ti. Tatthevāti phuṭṭhaphuṭṭhaṭṭhāneyeva.🔽Teti assāsapassāse. Satiyā anubandhantoti gaṇanāvīthiṃ anugantvā satiyā nibandhanto,
analyzed: gaṇanāya ca phusanāya ca manasi karoti iti tattha iva ati phuṭṭha phuṭṭha ṭhānā iya iva  te iti assāsa passāse satiyā anubandhantaḥ ti gaṇanā vīthim anugantvā satiyā nibandhantaḥ
translated: At the place touched: at the place touched by the in-breath or the out-breath.🔽The in-breaths and out-breaths: the in-breaths and out-breaths.🔽Following with his mindfulness: keeping his mindfulness fixed by following the course of the counting.

original: phuṭṭhokāseyeva te nirantaraṃ upadhārentoti attho. Appanāvasena cittaṃ ṭhapentoti
analyzed: te nirantaram upadhārento ti attho appanā vasena cittam ṭhapentoti
translated: The meaning is that he keeps his attention focused on the place touched without a break.

original: yathā appanā hoti, evaṃ yathāupaṭṭhite nimitte cittaṃ ṭhapento samādahanto. Anubandhanāya
analyzed: yathā appanā hoti evam yathā upaṭṭhite nimitte cittam ṭhapentaḥ samādahantaḥ anubandhanāya
translated: He steadies his mind by absorption: he steadies his mind, he concentrates it, on the sign as it appears, in such a way that absorption arises.

original: cātiādīsu anubandhanāya ca phusanāya ca ṭhapanāya ca manasi karotīti vuccatīti yojanā.
analyzed: cāti ādīsu anubandhanāya ca phusanāya ca ṭhapanāya ca manasi karoti iti vuccati iti yojanā
translated: The construction of the other terms should be understood in this way: “He gives attention by following, by touching, and by steadying” is said.

original: Svāyamatthoti yvāyaṃ “phuṭṭhaphuṭṭhaṭṭhāneyeva gaṇento, tattheva gaṇanaṃ paṭisaṃharitvā
analyzed: su ayam attho ti yvā ayam phuṭṭha phuṭṭha ṭhāneyā iva gaṇento tattha iva gaṇanam paṭisaṃharitvā
translated: This is the meaning: he counts at the place touched, and after he has finished counting,🔽he follows the in-breaths and out-breaths with his mindfulness.

original: te satiyā anubandhanto”ti ca vutto, so ayamattho. Yā accantāya na minoti na vinicchināti,
analyzed: te satiyā anubandhanto ti ca vutto saḥ ayam attho yā accantāya na minoti na vinicchināti
translated: He does not go beyond the limit of the in-breaths and out-breaths.

original: sā mānassa samīpeti upamā yathā “goṇo viya gavayo”ti.
analyzed: sā mānassa samīpā iti upamā yathā goṇaḥ viya gavayā iti
translated: It is a simile, like “a gavaya is like a cow.”

original: 225. Paṅguḷoti pīṭhasappī. Dolā pekholo. Kīḷatanti kīḷantānaṃ. Mātāputtānanti attano
analyzed: paṅguḷaḥ ti pīṭhasappī dolā pekholaḥ kīḷatanti kīḷantānam mātā puttānam ti attano
translated: “Crippled” means “using a chair.” “Swing” means “swinging.” “Playing” means “playing.” “Mother and child” means

original: bhariyāya, puttassa ca. Ubho koṭiyoti āgacchantassa purimakoṭiṃ, gacchantassa pacchimakoṭinti
analyzed: bhariyāya puttassa ca ubho koṭiyo ti āgacchantassa purima koṭim gacchantassa pacchima koṭim ti
translated: his wife and his son. “Both ends” means the front end for one who is coming and the back end for one who is going.

original: dvepi koṭiyo. Majjhanti dolāphalakasseva majjhaṃ. Upanibandhanathambho viyāti upanibandhanathambho,
analyzed: dve api koṭiyaḥ majjhanti dolā phalakassa iva majjham upanibandhana thambhaḥ viyāti upanibandhana thambhaḥ
translated: Both ends are the middle of the swing board. “Like a post for tying to” means a post for tying to,

original: nāsikaggaṃ, mukhanimittaṃ vā, tassa mūle samīpe ṭhatvā. Kathaṃ ṭhatvā? Satiyā vasena.🔽Satiñhi tattha sūpaṭṭhitaṃ karonto yogāvacaro tattha ṭhito nāma hoti, avayavadhammena🔽samudāyassa apadisitabbato. Nimitteti nāsikaggādinimitte. Satiyā nisīdantoti sativasena
analyzed: nāsikaggam mukha nimittam vā tassa mūle samīpe ṭhatvā katham ṭhatvā satiyāḥ vasena  satim hi tattha su upaṭṭhitam karontaḥ yogāvacaro tattha ṭhitaḥ nāma hoti avayava dhammena  samudāyassa apadisitabbataḥ nimitta iti nāsikagga ādi nimitte satiyā nisīdantaḥ iti sati vasena
translated: the tip of the nose, or the point of the face, standing near the root of it. How does he stand? By means of mindfulness.🔽For the meditator, making mindfulness well established there, is said to be “standing there” in the sense of the part standing for the whole.🔽“At the sign” means at the sign of the tip of the nose, and so on. “Sitting down with mindfulness” means

original: nisīdanto. “Satiñhi tatthā”tiādinā ṭhāne viya vattabbaṃ. Tatthāti phuṭṭhaphuṭṭhaṭṭhāne.
analyzed: nisīdantaḥ satim hi tattha atiādinā ṭhāne viya vattabbam tattha ati phuṭṭha phuṭṭha ṭṭhāne
translated: sitting down with mindfulness. “For mindfulness is there” should be construed as above in the case of “standing.” “There” means in the place touched each time.

original: 226. Teti nagarassa antobahigatā manussā, tesaṃ saṅgahā ca hatthagatā.
analyzed: te ti nagarassa antar bahi gatā manussā tesam saṅgahā ca hattha gatā
translated: “They”: the people inside and outside the city, and those in his power.

original: 227. Ādito paṭṭhāyāti upameyyatthadassanato paṭṭhāya. Gāthāyaṃ nimittanti upanibandhanānimittaṃ.
analyzed: āditas paṭṭhāya ati upameyya ttha dassanataḥ paṭṭhāya gāthā ayam nimittam ti upanibandhanā nimittam
translated: “From the beginning”: from the time of showing the meaning of the simile. In the verse “sign” is the sign of the object of clinging.

original: Anārammaṇamekacittassāti ekassa cittassa na ārammaṇaṃ, ārammaṇaṃ na hontīti attho.
analyzed: anārammaṇam eka cittassa ti ekassa cittassa na ārammaṇam ārammaṇam na honti iti attho
translated: “Not the object of a single consciousness”: not the object of a single consciousness; the meaning is that they are not the object.

original: Ajānato ca tayo dhammeti nimittaṃ assāso passāsoti ime tayo dhamme ārammaṇakaraṇavasena
analyzed: a jānataḥ ca tayo dhamme iti nimittam assāso passāso ti ime tayo dhamme ārammaṇa karaṇa vasena
translated: “And not finding the three things without knowing”: not finding the three things, the sign, in-breath, and out-breath, by making them the object.

original: avindantassa. Ca-saddo byatireke. Bhāvanāti ānāpānassatisamādhibhāvanā. Nupalabbhatīti
analyzed: avindantassa casaddaḥ byatireke bhāvanā ati āna apāna ssati samādhi bhāvanā na upalabbhati iti
translated: The word “and” is in the sense of “without.” “Development” is the development of concentration by mindfulness of breathing. “Is not found”

original: na upalabbhati na sijjhatīti ayaṃ codanāgāthāya attho, dutiyā pana parihāragāthā suviññeyyāva.🔽Kathanti tāsaṃ atthaṃ vivarituṃ kathetukamyatāpucchā. Ime tayo dhammātiādīsu padayojanāya
analyzed: na upalabbhati na sijjhati iti ayam codanā gāthāya attho dutiyā pana parihāra gāthā su viññeyyā ava  kathanti tāsam attham vivaritum kathetu kamyatā pucchāḥ ime tayaḥ dhammā ati ādīsu pada yojanāya
translated: means is not found, is not successful. This is the meaning of the verse of objection. But the second verse of reply is easy to understand.

original: saddhiṃ ayamatthaniddeso – ime nimittādayo tayo dhammā ekacittassa kathaṃ ārammaṇaṃ
analyzed: saddhim ayam attha niddesaḥ ime nimitta ādayaḥ tayaḥ dhammāḥ eka cittassa katham ārammaṇam
translated: “How?”: this is a question asked in order to explain their meaning. In the passage beginning “These three things” the meaning is construed thus:

original: na honti, tathāpi na cime na ca ime tayo dhammā aviditā honti, kathaṃ na ca honti
analyzed: na honti tathā api na ca ime na ca ime tayaḥ dhammā aviditāḥ honti katham na ca honti
translated: and they are not so, still they are not unknown. How are they not unknown?

original: aviditā? Tesañhi aviditatte cittañca kathaṃ vikkhepaṃ na gacchati, padhānañca bhāvanāya🔽nipphādakaṃ vīriyañca kathaṃ paññāyati, nīvaraṇānaṃ vikkhambhakaṃ sammadeva samādhānāvahaṃ🔽bhāvanānuyogasaṅkhātaṃ payogañca yogī kathaṃ sādheti, uparūpari lokiyalokuttarañca
analyzed: tesam hi cittam ca katham vikkhepam na gacchati padhānam ca bhāvanāya  nipphādakam vīriyam ca katham paññāyati nīvaraṇānam vikkhambhakam sammad eva samādhāna āvaham  bhāvanā anuyoga saṅkhātam yogī katham sādhā iti upari upari lokiya lokuttaram ca
translated: For when they are unknown, how does the mind not become distracted? And how does the energy that is the cause of the development of concentration become evident?

original: visesaṃ kathamadhigacchatīti.🔽Idāni tamatthaṃ kakacūpamāya sādhetuṃ “seyyathāpī”tiādi vuttaṃ. Bhūmibhāgassa visamatāya🔽cañcale rukkhe chedanakiriyā na sukarā siyā, tathā ca sati kakacadantagati dubbiññeyyāti
analyzed: visesam katham adhigacchati iti  idāni tam attham kakaca upamāya sādhetum seyyathā api itiādi vuttam bhūmi bhāgassa visama tāya  cañcale rukkhe chedana kiriyā na sukarā siyā tathā ca sati kakaca danta gati dubbiññeyyā ati
translated: And how does the meditator accomplish the practice that is the cause of the complete tranquilization of the hindrances? And how does he attain the higher distinction of the supramundane path?🔽Now, in order to establish this meaning by means of the simile of the carpenter’s line, the following passage is stated: “Just as a carpenter or carpenter’s apprentice” , etc. If the tree were unsteady because of the unevenness of the ground,

original: āha “same bhūmibhāge”ti. Kakacenāti khuddakena kharapattena. Tenāha “puriso”ti. Phuṭṭhakakacadantānanti
analyzed: āha same bhūmi bhāge iti ka kacena ati khuddakena khara pattena tena āha purisaḥ iti
translated: the carpenter’s line would be difficult to draw and its direction would be hard to see. Therefore it is said: “on even ground” . By means of the carpenter’s line: by means of a small sharp chip. Therefore it is said: “a man” . The direction of the carpenter’s line:

original: phuṭṭhaphuṭṭhakakacadantānaṃ vasena. Tena kakacadantehi phuṭṭhaphuṭṭhaṭṭhāneyeva🔽purisassa satiyā upaṭṭhānaṃ dasseti. Tenāha “na āgate vā gate vā kakacadante manasi🔽karotī”ti. Kakacassa ākaḍḍhanakāle purisābhimukhaṃ pavattā āgatā. Pellanakāle tato🔽vigatā “gatā”ti vuttā. Na ca āgatā vā gatā vā kakacadantā aviditā honti sabbattha
analyzed: phuṭṭha phuṭṭha ka kaca dantānam vasena tena ka kaca dantehi phuṭṭha phuṭṭha ṭṭhānā iya iva  purisassa satiyāḥ upaṭṭhānam dasseti tena āha na āgate vā gate vā kakaca dante manasi  karoti iti kakacassa ākaḍḍhana kāle purisa abhimukham pavattā āgatā pellana kāle tatas  vigatā gatā ati vuttā na ca āgatā vā gatā vā kakaca dantāḥ a viditāḥ honti sabbattha
translated: and the saw’s teeth as the “touched and touched.”

original: satiyā upaṭṭhitattā chinditabbaṭṭhānaṃ aphusitvā gacchantānaṃ, āgacchantānañca kakacadantānaṃ
analyzed: satiyāḥ upaṭṭhita ttā chinditabba ṭṭhānam a phusitvā gacchantānam āgacchantānam ca kakacadantānam
translated: He shows the man’s mindfulness established in the places touched by the saw’s teeth. That is why he said, “He does not give attention to the saw’s teeth as ‘come and go’ ” . When the saw is drawn towards the man, the teeth are said to “come” because they appear in the direction of the man. When the saw is pushed away from the man, the teeth are said to “go” because they disappear from the direction of the man. But the saw’s teeth are not unknown to him as they come and go, because he is mindful of them everywhere. For the saw’s teeth that come and go do not go and come without his being mindful of them.

original: abhāvato. Padhānanti rukkhassa chedanavīriyaṃ. Payoganti tasseva chedanakiriyaṃ.
analyzed: abhāvataḥ padhānan ti rukkhassa chedana vīriyam tassa iva chedana kiriyam
translated: “Effort” is the man’s exertion in cutting the tree. “Application” is the act of cutting itself.

original: Visesanti anekabhāvāpādanaṃ, tena ca sādhetabbaṃ payojanavisesaṃ.
analyzed: visesam ti aneka bhāva āpādanam tena ca sādhetabbam payojana visesam
translated: “Distinction” is the production of the various parts, and the particular purpose to be accomplished by them.

original: Yathā rukkhotiādi upamāsaṃsandanaṃ. Upanibandhati ārammaṇe cittaṃ etāyāti sati upanibandhanā
analyzed: yathā rukkha uti ādi upamā saṃsandanam upanibandhati ārammaṇe cittam sati upanibandhanā
translated: The simile is applied in the passage beginning, “Just as … ” . “Establishment of mindfulness” is that by means of which the mind is established on an object.

original: nāma, tassā assāsapassāsānaṃ sallakkhaṇassa nimittanti upanibandhanānimittaṃ, nāsikaggaṃ,🔽mukhanimittaṃ vā. Evamevāti yathāpi so puriso kakacena rukkhaṃ chindanto āgatagate🔽kakacadante amanasikarontopi phuṭṭhaphuṭṭhaṭṭhāneyeva satiyā upaṭṭhapanena āgatagate
analyzed: nāma tassāḥ assāsa passāsānam sat lakkhaṇassa nimittanti upanibandhanā nimittam nāsikaggam  mukha nimittam vai evam eva ati yathā api saḥ puriso kakacena rukkham chindantaḥ āgata gate  kakaca dante a manasikarontaḥ api phuṭṭha phuṭṭha ṭṭhāneya iva satiyā upaṭṭhapanena āgata gate
translated: The sign of the in-breaths and out-breaths is the sign for the purpose of discerning the in-breaths and out-breaths. The nose-tip is the sign for the purpose of anchoring mindfulness.🔽Or the sign of the mouth is the sign for the purpose of anchoring mindfulness.

original: kakacadante jānāti, suttapadañca avirajjhanto atthakiccaṃ sādheti, evameva. Nāsikagge🔽mukhanimitteti dīghanāsiko nāsikagge itaro mukhaṃ dasanaṃ nimīyati chādīyati etenāti
analyzed: ka kaca dante jānāti sutta padam ca a virajjhantaḥ attha kiccam sādheti evam eva nāsikagge  mukha nimittā iti dīgha nāsikaḥ nāsikagge itaraḥ mukham dasanam nimīyati chādīyati etena ati
translated: So too: just as the man cutting down the tree does not give attention to the coming and going of the saw’s teeth, but he knows the coming and going of the saw’s teeth by the mere fact of his establishing mindfulness in order to cut down the tree, and he accomplishes the tree’s felling without ever losing attention to the task in hand, so too …

original: mukhanimittanti laddhanāme uttaroṭṭhe.🔽Idaṃ padhānanti yena vīriyārambhena āraddhavīriyassa yogino kāyopi cittampi kammaniyaṃ🔽bhāvanākammakkhamaṃ bhāvanākammayoggaṃ hoti, idaṃ vīriyaṃ padhānanti phalena hetuṃ
analyzed: mukha nimittanti laddha nāme uttara uṭṭhe 🔽idam padhānam ti yena vīriya ārambhena āraddha vīriyassa yogino kāyaḥ api cittam pi kammaniyam 🔽bhāvanā kamma kkhamam bhāvanā kamma yoggam hoti idam vīriyam padhānan ti phalena hetum
translated: At the nose tip or in the upper lip: in the case of one whose nose is long the sign should be placed at the tip of the nose; in the case of one whose nose is flat, at the place where the nostrils are. The upper lip is called the “sign of the mouth” because the mouth is covered by it.

original: dasseti. Upakkilesā pahīyantīti cittassa upakkilesabhūtāni nīvaraṇāni vikkhambhanavasena
analyzed: dasseti upakkilesā pahīyanti iti cittassa upakkilesa bhūtāni nīvaraṇāni vikkhambhana vasena
translated: “The defilements are abandoned” means that the hindrances, which are defilements of the mind, are abandoned by suppression.

original: pahīyanti. Vitakkā vūpasamantīti tato eva kāmavitakkādayo micchāvitakkā upasamaṃ🔽gacchanti, nīvaraṇappahānena vā paṭhamajjhānādhigamaṃ dassetvā vitakkavūpasamāpadesena
analyzed: pahīyanti vitakkāḥ vūpasamanti iti tatas eva kāma vitakka ādayaḥ micchā vitakkāḥ upasamam  gacchanti nīvaraṇa ppahānena vā paṭhama jhāna adhigamam dassetvā vitakka vūpasama apadesena
translated: “The applied-thoughts subside” means that the applied-thoughts of sensual pleasure, etc., subside by the mere fact of the hindrances being suppressed.🔽Or else, having shown the attainment of the first jhāna by the abandoning of the hindrances, he shows the attainment of the second jhāna, etc., by the expression “the applied-thoughts subside.”

original: dutiyajjhānādīnamadhigamamāha. Ayaṃ payogoti ayaṃ jhānādhigamassa hetubhūto kammaṭṭhānānuyogo
analyzed: dutiya jhāna ādīnam adhigamam āha ayam payogo ti ayam jhāna adhigamassa hetu bhūto kammaṭṭhāna anuyogo
translated: “This is the method” means that this is the method for the attainment of jhāna, namely, the pursuit of the meditation subject.

original: payogo. Saṃyojanā pahīyantīti dasapi saṃyojanāni maggapaṭipāṭiyā samucchedavasena
analyzed: saṃyojanā pahīyanti iti dasa pi saṃyojanāni magga paṭipāṭiyā samuccheda vasena
translated: “The fetters are abandoned” means that the ten fetters are abandoned by way of the path in the sense of complete cutting off.

original: pahīyanti. Anusayā byantī hontīti tathā sattapi anusayā anuppattidhammatāpādanena
analyzed: pahīyanti anusayāḥ honti iti tathā satta pi anusayāḥ anuppatti dhamma tā āpādanena
translated: “The inherent tendencies are eradicated” means that the seven inherent tendencies are eradicated without remainder by causing them to reach the state of no more arising.

original: bhaṅgamattassapi anavasesato vigatantā honti. Ettha ca saṃyojanappahānaṃ nāma anusayanirodheneva
analyzed: bhaṅga mattassa api anavasesataḥ vigata antāḥ honti ettha ca saṃyojana ppahānam nāma anusaya nirodhena iva
translated: And here the abandoning of the fetters is only the cessation of the inherent tendencies.

original: hoti, pahīnesu ca saṃyojanesu anusayānaṃ lesopi na bhavissatīti ca dassanatthaṃ “saṃyojanā
analyzed: hoti pahīnesu ca saṃyojanesu lesaḥ api na bhavissati iti ca dassana ttham saṃyojanā
translated: and when the fetters have been abandoned, there will not even be a trace of underlying tendencies left.🔽

original: pahīyanti anusayā byantī hontī”ti vuttaṃ. Ayaṃ visesoti imaṃ samādhiṃ nissāya anukkamena
analyzed: pahīyanti anusayāḥ honti iti vuttam ayam visesaḥ ti imam samādhim nissāya anukkamena
translated: And when the fetters are abandoned, there will be no trace of the underlying tendencies left either. This is the distinction: the distinction of this concentration is the abandoning of the fetters, etc., which are obtained in due course

original: labbhamāno ayaṃ saṃyojanappahānādiko imassa samādhissa visesoti attho.
analyzed: labbhamānaḥ ayam saṃyojana ppahāna ādikaḥ imassa samādhissa visesaḥ ti attho
translated: by means of this concentration. This is the meaning.

original: Yassāti yena. Anupubbanti anukkamena. Paricitāti pariciṇṇā. Ayaṃ hettha saṅkhepattho
analyzed: yassa iti yena anupubbanti anukkamena paricitā ati pariciṇṇā ayam ha ittha saṅkhepa atthaḥ
translated: Yassa: by whom. Anupubba: in due course. Paricitā: well developed. This is the condensed meaning here.

original: – ānāpānassati yathā buddhena bhagavatā desitā, tatheva yena dīgharassapajānanādividhinā
analyzed: yathā buddhena bhagavatā desitā tathā iva yena dīgha rassa pajānana ādi vidhinā
translated: The mindfulness of breathing, as taught by the Blessed One, is well developed, well practiced, by whom in the manner of discerning long and short, etc.,

original: anupubbaṃ paricitā suṭṭhu bhāvitā, tato eva paripuṇṇā soḷasannaṃ vatthūnaṃ pāripūriyā
analyzed: anupubbam paricitā suṭṭhu bhāvitā tatas eva paripuṇṇā soḷasannam vatthūnam pāripūriyā
translated: in due course. Because of that, it is fulfilled, complete in the sixteen bases.

original: sabbaso puṇṇā. So bhikkhu imaṃ attano khandhādilokaṃ paññobhāsena pabhāseti. Yathā
analyzed: sabbaso puṇṇā so bhikkhu imam attanaḥ khandha ādi lokam paññobhāsena pabhāseti yathā
translated: That bhikkhu illuminates this world with his wisdom,

original: kiṃ abbhā muttova candimā abbhupakkilesavimutto candimā tārakarājā viyāti.
analyzed: kim abbhā muttaḥ iva candimā candimā tāraka rājā viyāti
translated: like the moon released from a cloud, like the spotless moon, the king of stars.

original: Idhāti kakacūpamāyaṃ. Assāti yogino. Idhāti vā imasmiṃ ṭhāne. Assāti upamābhūtassa
analyzed: idha ati assa ati yoginaḥ idha ati vā imasmin ṭhāne assa ati upamā bhūtassa
translated: Here: in the simile of the razor. Horse: yogin. Here: in this place. Horse: of what is the simile.

original: kakacassa. Āgatagatavasena yathā tassa purisassa amanasikāro, evaṃ assāsapassāsānaṃ🔽āgatagatavasena amanasikāramattameva payojanaṃ.🔽228. Nimittanti paṭibhāganimittaṃ. Avasesajhānaṅgapaṭimaṇḍitāti appanāvitakkādiavasesajhānaṅgapaṭimaṇḍitāti
analyzed: kakacassa āgata gata vasena yathā tassa purisassa amanasikāraḥ evam assāsa passāsānam  āgata gata vasena a manasikāra mattam eva payojanam  nimittam ti paṭibhāga nimittam avasesa jhāna aṅga paṭimaṇḍitā ati appanā vitakka ādi avasesa jhāna aṅga paṭimaṇḍitā ati
translated: Here: in the simile of the saw. The meditator: the yogin. Here: in this place. The saw: of the simile. The purpose is merely to disregard the in-breaths and out-breaths as coming and going, as in the case of the man’s disregarding the saw’s teeth as they came and went.

original: vadanti, vicārādīti pana vattabbaṃ nippariyāyena vitakkassa appanābhāvato. So hi
analyzed: vadanti vicāra ādi iti pana vattabbam nippariyāyena vitakkassa appanā bhāvato so hi
translated: Sign: the counterpart sign. Adorned with the remaining jhāna factors: they say that it is adorned with the remaining jhāna factors beginning with concentration, omitting applied thought. But it should be said that it is adorned with the remaining jhāna factors beginning with sustained thought, because applied thought does not exist in absorption.🔽For that is called “absorption” and “full absorption” in the texts.

original: pāḷiyaṃ “appanā byappanā”ti niddiṭṭho, taṃsampayogato vā yasmā jhānaṃ “appanā”ti🔽aṭṭhakathāvohāro, jhānaṅgesu ca samādhi padhānaṃ, tasmā taṃ “appanā”ti dassento “avasesajhānaṅgapaṭimaṇḍitā
analyzed: pāḷiyam appanā byappanā ti niddiṭṭhaḥ tad sampayogataḥ vā yasmā jhānam appanā ti  aṭṭhakathā vohāraḥ jhāna aṅgesu ca samādhi padhānam tasmā tam appanā ti dassento avasesa jhāna aṅga paṭimaṇḍitā
translated: Or alternatively, it is called “absorption” in the commentaries because the jhāna is associated with it.🔽And since concentration is the exertion in the jhāna factors, he shows that it is absorption by saying, “The placing that is called absorption is perfected with the remaining jhāna factors.”

original: appanāsaṅkhātā ṭhapanā ca sampajjatī”ti āha. Kassaci pana gaṇanāvaseneva manasikārakālato
analyzed: appanā saṅkhātā ṭhapanā ca sampajjati iti āha kassaci pana gaṇanā vasena iva manasikāra kālataḥ
translated: But some say that it is perfected with the remaining jhāna factors beginning with sustained thought.

original: pabhutīti ettha “anukkamato…pe… laṅghanākārappattaṃ viya hotī”ti ettako gantho parihīno.
analyzed: pabhutī iti ettha anukkama tope laṅghana ākāra ppattam viya hoti iti ettakaḥ gantho parihīnaḥ
translated: “The word ‘spread’ is here defined as follows: ‘It is the state of the in-breaths and out-breaths that has reached the condition of being able to be extended in extent and in time, in the way described, by one who is extending them in extent and in time’” .

original: Sāraddhakāyassa kassaci puggalassa. Onamati paṭṭikādīnaṃ palambanena. Vikūjatīti
analyzed: sāraddha kāyassa kassaci puggalassa onamati paṭṭikā ādīnam palambanena vikūjati iti
translated: In one whose body is afflicted, the in-breaths and out-breaths “sink” because of the pressure of the ribs, etc., and “they seem to be blocked”🔽because of the making of sound.

original: saddaṃ karoti. Gattānisadakapparādīnaṃ sandhiṭṭhānesu valiṃ gaṇhāti tattha tattha
analyzed: saddam karoti gattā nisada kappara ādīnam sandhi ṭṭhānesu valim gaṇhāti tattha tattha
translated: He “feels a constriction” in the places where the joints of the limbs are.

original: valitaṃ hoti. Kasmā? Yasmā sāraddhakāyo garuko hotīti kāyadarathavūpasamena saddhiṃ🔽sijjhamāno oḷārikaassāsapassāsanirodho byatirekamukhena tassa sādhanaṃ viya vutto.
analyzed: valitam hoti kasmai yasmai sāraddha kāyaḥ garukaḥ hoti iti saddhim  sijjhamānaḥ oḷārika assāsa passāsa nirodhaḥ byatireka mukhena tassa sādhanam viya vutto
translated: Why? Because the afflicted body is heavy.🔽So the cessation of gross in-breaths and out-breaths is mentioned as a means of accomplishing that, in addition to the cessation of affliction of the body.

original: Oḷārikaassāsapassāsanirodhavasenāti anvayavasena tadatthasādhanaṃ. Tattha kāyadarathe🔽vūpasanteti cittajarūpānaṃ lahumudukammaññabhāvena yo sesatisantatirūpānampi lahuādibhāvo,
analyzed: oḷārika assāsa passāsa nirodha vasena ati anvaya vasena tad attha sādhanam  citta ja rūpānam lahu mudu kammañña bhāvena yo lahu ādi bhāvo
translated: “By the cessation of gross in-breaths and out-breaths”: this is a means of accomplishing that by association.🔽Herein, when the affliction of the body has ceased, there is lightness and malleability in the material instances of the mind, and the lightness, etc., of the remaining instances of materiality is due to the continuity of the instances of materiality that are light, etc.;

original: so idha kāyassa lahubhāvoti adhippeto. Svāyaṃ yasmā cittassa lahuādibhāvena vinā
analyzed: saḥ idha kāyassa lahu bhāvo ti adhippeto yasmā cittassa lahu ādi bhāvena vinā
translated: and that is what is intended here by “lightness of the body.” And this is because there is no lightness, etc., of the mind without lightness, etc., of the body.

original: natthi, tasmā vuttaṃ “kāyopi cittampi lahukaṃ hotī”ti.
analyzed: natthi tasmā vuttam kāyaḥ pi cittam pi lahukam hoti iti
translated: and so it is said that “the body and cognizance become light” .

original: Oḷārike assāsapassāse niruddhetiādi heṭṭhā vuttanayampi vicetabbākārappattassa kāyasaṅkhārassa vicayanavidhiṃ dassetuṃ ānītaṃ.
analyzed: oḷārike assāsa passāse niruddhā itiādi heṭṭhā vutta nayam pi vicetabba ākāra ppattassa kāya saṅkhārassa vicayana vidhim dassetum ānītam
translated: “When the in-breath and out-breath are stopped” and so on is stated in order to show the method of discerning the bodily formation that has reached the state of being discernible.

original: 229. Uparūpari vibhūtānīti bhāvanābalena uddhaṃ uddhaṃ pākaṭāni honti. Desatoti pakatiyā phusanadesato, pubbe attanā phusanavasena upadhāritaṭṭhānato.
analyzed: upari upari vibhūtāni iti bhāvanā balena uddham uddham pākaṭāni honti desataḥ ti pakatiyā phusana desataḥ pubbe attanā phusana vasena upadhārita ṭhānato
translated: “They become more and more evident” : they become evident higher and higher up by means of the power of development. “As to location” : as to the location normally touched by them, the place remembered as the place touched by oneself previously.

original: “Kattha natthī”ti ṭhānavasena, “kassa natthī”ti puggalavasena vīmaṃsiyamānamatthaṃ🔽ekajjhaṃ katvā vibhāvetuṃ “antomātukucchiya”ntiādi vuttaṃ. Tattha yathā udake nimuggassa
