analyzed: kattha natthi iti ṭhāna vasena kassa natthi iti puggala vasena vīmaṃsiyamānam attham  ekajjham katvā vibhāvetum antomātukucchiya ntiādi vuttam tattha yathā udake nimuggassa
translated: “Where is there no in-breath and out-breath? ” is the meaning that is investigated as to location. “Whose in-breath and out-breath is there no? ” is the meaning that is investigated as to person.

original: puggalassa niruddhokāsatāya assāsapassāsā na pavattanti, evaṃ antomātukucchiyaṃ.
analyzed: puggalassa niruddha okāsa tāya assāsa passāsāḥ na pavattanti evam antar mātukucchiyam
translated: In order to show the meaning that is investigated as to location and as to person combined together, the passage beginning “In the mother’s womb” is stated. Herein, just as in the case of a person submerged in water, the in-breath and out-breath do not occur owing to the absence of an outlet, so too in the mother’s womb.

original: Yathā matānaṃ samuṭṭhāpakacittābhāvato, evaṃ asaññībhūtānaṃ mucchāparetānaṃ, asaññīsu
analyzed: yathā matānam samuṭṭhāpaka citta abhāvataḥ evam asaññībhūtānam mucchā paretānam asaññīsu
translated: Just as in the case of the dead owing to the absence of the kind of consciousness that causes them to occur, so too in the case of those who are unconscious, who are in a faint, and who are without consciousness.

original: vā jātānaṃ, tathā nirodhasamāpannānaṃ. Catutthajjhānasamāpannānaṃ pana dhammatāvaseneva🔽nesaṃ anuppajjanaṃ, tathā rūpārūpabhavasamaṅgīnaṃ. Keci pana “anupubbato sukhumabhāvappattiyā🔽catutthajjhānasamāpannassa, rūpabhave rūpānaṃ bhavaṅgassa ca sukhumabhāvato rūpabhavasamaṅgīnaṃ
analyzed: vā jātānam tathā nirodha samāpannānam catuttha jhāna samāpannānam pana dhamma tā vasena iva  na īsam anuppajjanam tathā rūpa arūpa bhava samaṅgīnam keci pana anupubbataḥ sukhuma bhāva ppattiyā  catuttha jhāna samāpannassa rūpa bhave rūpānam bhavaṅgassa ca sukhuma bhāvataḥ rūpa bhava samaṅgīnam
translated: and of those who have been born and of those attained to cessation. But in the case of those attained to the fourth jhāna, their non-arising is only according to the natural course of events, and likewise in the case of those possessed of the fine-material and immaterial kinds of becoming.🔽But some say that it is because of the attainment of subtlety in the order of succession that there is non-arising in one attained to the fourth jhāna, and that it is because of the subtlety of the materiality and of the life-continuum in the fine-material becoming that there is non-arising in those possessed of the fine-material becoming,🔽and that it is because of the absence of materiality in the immaterial becoming that there is non-arising in those possessed of the immaterial becoming.

original: natthī”ti kāraṇaṃ vadanti. Atthiyeva te assāsapassāsā pariyesatoti adhippāyo, yathāvuttasattaṭṭhānavinimuttassa🔽assāsapassāsānaṃ anuppajjanaṭṭhānassa abhāvato. Pakatiphuṭṭhavasenāti pakatiyā phusanaṭṭhānavasena.
analyzed: na atthi iti kāraṇam vadanti atthiyeva te assāsa passāsā pariyesato ti adhippāyaḥ yathā vutta satta ṭṭhāna vinimuttassa  assāsa passāsānam an uppajjana ṭhānassa abhāvato pakati phuṭṭha vasena ati pakatiyā phusana ṭṭhāna vasena
translated: and in those who have been reborn there, and in those attained to cessation. But in those attained to the fourth jhāna they do not occur owing to the natural result of that jhāna, and likewise in those possessing the fine-material and immaterial kinds of becoming. But some say that it is because of the attainment of subtlety in the order of occurrence that they do not occur in one attained to the fourth jhāna, and that it is because of the subtlety of the materiality in the fine-material becoming and of the life-continuum that they do not occur in those possessing the fine-material becoming. The intention is that they do occur, though they are not sought for, since there is no state in which they do not occur except in the seven mentioned.🔽By the “normal-range-touched” way: by the way of touching the normal range.

original: Nimittaṃ ṭhapetabbanti satiyā tattha tattha sukhappavattanatthaṃ thiratarasañjānanaṃ🔽pavattetabbaṃ. Thirasaññāpadaṭṭhānā hi sati. Imamevāti imaṃ eva anupaṭṭhahantassa
analyzed: nimittam ṭhapetabbanti satiyā tattha tattha sukha ppavattana attham thiratara sañjānanam 🔽pavattetabbam thira saññā padaṭṭhānā hi sati imam eva ati imam eva an upaṭṭhahantassa
translated: The sign should be placed: the sign of in-breaths and out-breaths should be placed by making it the object of mindfulness thus “Pleasant, pleasant” in order to bring about pleasantness of mind. For mindfulness is the footing for the perception of pleasantness.🔽In this very: in this very body.

original: kāyasaṅkhārassa kaṇṭakuṭṭhāpananayena upaṭṭhāpanavidhimeva. Atthavasanti hetuṃ. Atthoti
analyzed: kāya saṅkhārassa kaṇṭa kuṭṭhāpana nayena upaṭṭhāpana vidhim eva attha vasanti hetum
translated: The method of attending to the in-breaths and out-breaths as “long” and “short” is the method of attending to the body’s sign. The method of attending to them as “the whole body” is the method of attending to the body’s aspect. The method of attending to them as “calming the bodily formation” is the method of attending to the body’s activity. “Purpose” is cause. For “purpose” is

original: hi phalaṃ, so yassa vasena pavattati, so atthavasoti. Muṭṭhassatissāti vinaṭṭhassatissa.
analyzed: hi phalam saḥ yassa vasena pavattati saḥ atthavaso ti muṭṭha satissa ati vinaṭṭha ssatissa
translated: fruit, and that is the purpose of which the in-breaths and out-breaths are the cause. “Unmindful”: with mindfulness lost.

original: Asampajānassāti sampajaññarahitassa, bhāventassa anukkamena anupaṭṭhahante assāsapassāse🔽vīmaṃsitvā “ime te”ti upadhāretuṃ, sammadeva pajānituñca samatthāhi satipaññāhi virahitassāti adhippāyo.
analyzed: a sampajānassa ati sampajañña rahitassa bhāventassa anukkamena anupaṭṭhahante assāsa passāse  vīmaṃsitvā ime te ti upadhāretum sammat eva pajānitum ca samatthāhi sati paññāhi virahitassa ati adhippāyaḥ
translated: “Unaware”: without knowledge. The meaning is: without the mindfulness and the full awareness that are able to advert and bear in mind and fully understand the in-breaths and out-breaths as they occur in succession.

original: 230. Ito aññaṃ kammaṭṭhānaṃ. Garukanti bhāriyaṃ. Sā cassa garukatā bhāvanāya sudukkarabhāvenāti🔽āha “garukabhāvana”nti. Uparūpari santasukhumabhāvappattito “balavatī suvisadā sūrā
analyzed: itas aññam kammaṭṭhānam garukanti bhāriyam sā ca ssa garuka tā bhāvanāya su dukkara bhāvena ati  āha garuka bhāvananti upari upari santa sukhuma bhāva ppattitaḥ balavatī su visadā sūrā
translated: “Any other meditation subject” is a meditation subject other than this one. “Difficult to develop”: heavy. For that heaviness is difficult to develop because it is hard to do.🔽Hence it is said, “Its development is heavy” . “Powerful and quite clear” : powerful mindfulness and quite clear understanding are required for the attainment of the increasingly peaceful and subtle state.

original: ca satipaññā ca icchitabbā”ti vatvā sukhumassa nāma atthassa sādhanenāpi sukhumeneva
analyzed: ca sati paññā ca icchitabbā iti vatvā sukhumassa nāma atthassa sādhanena api sukhumena iva
translated: Having said that, he now shows the subtlety of the meaning by the subtlety of the expression.

original: bhavitabbanti dassetuṃ “yathā hī”tiādi vuttaṃ. Idāni anupaṭṭhahantānaṃ assāsapassāsānaṃ
analyzed: bhavitabbanti dassetum yathā hi itiādi vuttam idāni anupaṭṭhahantānam assāsa passāsānam
translated: In order to show that it must be so, he said “For just as … ” .🔽Now, of the in-breaths and out-breaths that do not occur

original: pariyesanupāyaṃ dassento “tāhi ca panā”tiādimāha. Tattha gocaramukheti gocarābhimukhe.
analyzed: pariyesana upāyam dassentaḥ tāhi ca pana ati ādim āha tattha gocara mukha iti gocara abhimukhe
translated: “It should be so” is said to show that it must be so. Now, in order to show the method of searching for in-breaths and out-breaths that do not occur, he said “And when they do not occur” . Herein, in the direction of the domain is in the direction of the domain.🔽Following the steps is following the steps of the feet.

original: Anupadanti padānupadaṃ. Caritvāti gocaraṃ gahetvā. Tasmiṃyeva ṭhāneti upanibandhanānimittasaññitaṭṭhāne.🔽Yojetvāti manasikārena yojetvā. Satirasmiyā bandhitvāti vā vuttamevatthamāha “tasmiṃyeva
analyzed: anupadam ti pada anupadam caritvā ati gocaram gahetvā tasmin yeva ṭhāne iti upanibandhana a nimitta saññita ṭṭhāne  yojetvā iti manasikārena yojetvā bandhitvā iti vā
translated: Having gone is having taken the domain. In that place is in the place called the sign of resolve.

original: ṭhāne yojetvā”ti. Na hi upameyye bandhanayojanaṭṭhānāni visuṃ labbhanti.🔽231. Nimittanti uggahanimittaṃ, paṭibhāganimittaṃ vā. Ubhayampi hi idha ekajjhaṃ vuttaṃ. Tathā hi tūlapicuādiupamattayaṃ uggahe yujjati, sesaṃ ubhayattha. Ekacceti eke ācariyā.
analyzed: ṭhāne yojetvā iti na hi upameyye bandhana yojana ṭṭhānāni visum labbhanti  nimittam ti uggaha nimittam paṭibhāga nimittam vā ubhayam pi hi idha ekajjham vuttam tathā hi tūla picu ādi upamattayam uggahe yujjati sesam ubhayattha ekacce iti eke ācariyāḥ
translated: Having yoked is having yoked with the mind. Having bound persistence to that is what is meant. “In that place” is said. For the place of binding and the place of yoking are not found separately in the simile.🔽Sign is the learning sign or the counterpart sign, for both are included here. For the simile of the cotton-wool, etc., is appropriate to the learning sign, and the rest to both.

original: Tārakarūpaṃ viyāti tārakāya pabhārūpaṃ viya. Maṇiguḷikādiupamā paṭibhāge vaṭṭanti.
analyzed: tāraka rūpam tārakāya pabhā rūpam maṇi guḷikā ādi upamā paṭibhāge vaṭṭanti
translated: Some teachers say that the simile of the star is like the light of the star. The similes of the ball of clay, etc., are appropriate to the counterpart sign.

original: Kathaṃ panetaṃ ekaṃyeva kammaṭṭhānaṃ anekākārato upaṭṭhātīti āha “tañca paneta”ntiādi.🔽Suttantanti ekaṃ suttaṃ. Paguṇappavattibhāvena avicchedaṃ, mahāvisayatañca sandhāyāha
analyzed: katham pana itam ekam yeva kammaṭṭhānam aneka ākārataḥ upaṭṭhāti iti āha tat ca pana itantiādi  suttantam ti ekam suttam paguṇa ppavatti bhāvena avicchedam mahā visaya tat ca sandhāya āha
translated: But how does this one meditation subject come to be evident in these various ways?🔽“And that too”: a single sutta.🔽“Like a great mountain river”: he said this referring to its uninterrupted flow and its great extent.

original: “mahatī pabbateyyā nadī viyā”ti. Atthabyañjanasampattiyā samantabhaddakaṃ suttaṃ
analyzed: mahatī pabbateyyā nadī viyāti attha byañjana sampattiyā samantabhaddakam suttam
translated: A sutta that is all auspicious because of the excellence of its meaning and phrasing🔽is like a forest glade that is delightful in all ways, with all its trees in full blossom.

original: sabbabhāgamanoharā sabbapāliphullā vanaghaṭā viyāti āha “ekā vanarāji viyā”ti. Tenāha
analyzed: sabba bhāga manoharā sabba pāli phullā vanaghaṭā viyāti āha ekā vana rāji viyāti tena āha
translated: That is why he said “like a forest glade.”

original: bhagavā – “vanappagumbe yatha phussitagge”ti. Nānānusandhikaṃ nānāpeyyālaṃ vividhanayanipuṇaṃ
analyzed: bhagavā vanappagumbe phussitagge iti nānā anusandhikam nānā peyyālam vividha naya nipuṇam
translated: Hence the Blessed One said: “When a tree is full of flowers” .

original: bahuvidhakammaṭṭhānamukhasuttantaṃ atthikehi sakkaccaṃ samupajīvitabbanti āha “sītacchāyo…pe…
analyzed: bahuvidha kammaṭṭhāna mukha suttantam atthikehi sakkaccam samupajīvitabbanti āha sītacchāya upe
translated: A sutta that has many kinds of consequences, many kinds of recapitulations, and is clever in many ways,🔽and which is the door to many kinds of meditation subjects, should be carefully attended to by those who want to go forward. That is why he said “like a tree that gives manifold shade” .

original: rukkho viyā”ti. Saññānānatāyāti nimittupaṭṭhānato pubbeva pavattasaññānaṃ nānāvidhabhāvato.
analyzed: rukkhaḥ viya ati saññā nānatāya ati nimitta upaṭṭhānato pubbā iva pavatta saññānam nānāvidha bhāvato
translated: “Because of the variety of perceptions”: because of the variety of perceptions that occur before the sign arises.

original: Ime tayo dhammāti assāso, passāso, nimittanti ime tayo dhammā. Natthīti kammaṭṭhānavasena🔽manasikātabbabhāvena natthi na upalabbhanti. Na ca upacāranti upacārampi na pāpuṇāti,🔽pageva appananti adhippāyo. Yassa panāti vijjamānapakkho vuttanayānusārena veditabbo.
analyzed: ime tayo dhammā ati assāso passāsaḥ nimittanti ime tayo dhammā natthi iti kammaṭṭhāna vasena  manasikātabba bhāvena natthi na upalabbhanti na ca upacāranti upacāram pi na pāpuṇāti  pagā iva appananti adhippāyaḥ yassa pana āti vijjamāna pakkhaḥ vutta naya anusārena veditabbaḥ
translated: These three ideas: in-breath, out-breath, and sign. They are not: they are not, they are not found, as a meditation subject for attention.🔽Nor does it reach access: it does not even reach access, let alone absorption, is the intention. But if anyone: the side of what is possible should be understood in the way already described .🔽🔽

original: Idāni vuttasseva atthassa samatthanatthaṃ kakacūpamāyaṃ āgatā “nimitta”ntiādikā gāthā paccānītā.
analyzed: idāni vuttassa iva atthassa samatthana attham kakaca upamāyam āgatā nimitta nti ādikā gāthā paccānītā
translated: ‘These three things’: in-breath, out-breath, and the sign. ‘There is not’: there is not, there is not to be found, as a subject of meditation by means of which he might bring about absorption. ‘Nor does he reach access’: he does not even reach access, let alone absorption, is the meaning. ‘But if he has’: the side of what is possible should be understood in the way already stated. Now, in order to establish the meaning just stated, the verses beginning with ‘The sign’ are quoted from the Kakudha Sutta .

original: 232. Nimitteti yathāvutte paṭibhāganimitte. Evaṃ hotīti bhāvanamanuyuttassa eva hoti.
analyzed: nimitta iti yathā vutte paṭibhāga nimitte evam hoti iti bhāvanam anuyuttassa eva hoti
translated: ‘In the sign’: in the counterpart sign stated thus . ‘It is like this’: it is only for one devoted to development.

original: Tasmā “punappunaṃ evaṃ manasi karohī”ti vattabbo. Vosānaṃ āpajjeyyāti “nimittaṃ nāma
analyzed: tasmā punappunam evam manasi karohi iti vattabbaḥ vosānam āpajjeyya ati nimittam nāma
translated: So he should be told to give his attention to it again and again in this way. ‘He might reach a standstill’: he might reach a standstill, thinking ‘The sign

original: dukkaraṃ uppādetuṃ, tayidaṃ laddhaṃ, handāhaṃ dāni yadā vā tadā vā visesaṃ nibbattessāmī”ti
analyzed: dukkaram uppādetum tayā idam laddham handa aham dāni yadā vā tadā vā visesam nibbattessāmi iti
translated: is difficult to produce, and now that I have got it, I shall now develop it whenever I want, and so make it reach absorption’.

original: saṅkocaṃ āpajjeyya. Visīdeyyāti “ettakaṃ kālaṃ bhāvanamanuyuttassa nimittampi na
analyzed: saṅkocam āpajjeyya visīdeyya ati ettakam kālam bhāvanam anuyuttassa nimittam pi na
translated: ‘He might fail’: he might fail, thinking ‘For so long I have been devoted to development and I have not even got the sign,🔽let alone absorption. So what is the use of this to me?’

original: uppannaṃ, abhabbo maññe visesassā”ti visādaṃ āpajjeyya.🔽“Imāya paṭipadāya jarāmaraṇato muccissāmīti paṭipannassa nimitta”nti vutte kathaṃ
analyzed: uppannam abhabbaḥ maññe visesassa ati visādam āpajjeyya  imāya paṭipadāya jarā maraṇataḥ muccissāmi iti paṭipannassa nimittam ti vutte katham
translated: He might fall into despondency, thinking, “It seems impossible to make any distinction.”🔽When it is said, “This is the sign for one who is practising thus, ‘I shall escape from the aging-and-death by this path,’”

original: saṅkocāpatti, bhiyyoso mattāya ussāhameva kareyyāti “nimittamidaṃ…pe… vattabbo”ti
analyzed: saṅkoca āpatti bhiyyosaḥ mattāya ussāham eva kareyya ati nimittam idam pe vattabbā ti
translated: how does he fall into despondency? He might think, “I shall not escape from aging-and-death by this path,” and he might slacken his efforts.

original: majjhimabhāṇakā āhu. Evanti vuttappakārena paṭibhāganimitteyeva bhāvanācittassa ṭhapanena.
analyzed: majjhima bhāṇakāḥ āhu evam ti vutta ppakārena paṭibhāga nimittā iya iva bhāvanā cittassa ṭhapanena
translated: The Majjhima reciters say that he should be told, “This is a sign for one who is practising thus, ‘I shall escape from aging-and-death by this path.’🔽” The meaning is that he should be told, “This is a sign for one who is practising thus, ‘I shall escape from aging-and-death by this path.’🔽” “From now on” means from the time of the appearance of the counterpart sign.

original: Ito pabhutīti ito paṭibhāganimittuppattito paṭṭhāya. Pubbe yaṃ vuttaṃ “anubandhanāya🔽ca phusanāya ca ṭhapanāya ca manasi karotī”ti, tattha anubandhanaṃ, phusanañca vissajjetvā
analyzed: itas pabhuti iti itas paṭibhāga nimitta uppattitaḥ paṭṭhāya pubbe yam vuttam anubandhanāya  ca phusanāya ca ṭhapanāya ca manasi karoti iti tattha anubandhanam phusanam ca vissajjetvā
translated: What was said above, namely, “He gives his attention to it as ‘receding, fading, and ceasing,’🔽” should be given in full.

original: ṭhapanāvasena bhāvanā hotīti ṭhapanāvaseneva bhāvetabbanti attho.
analyzed: ṭhapanā vasena bhāvanā hoti iti ṭhapanā vasena iva bhāvetabbanti attho
translated: The meaning is that the development of concentration should be done by means of the giving of attention to it as “receding, fading, and ceasing” only, leaving aside the giving of attention to it as “arisen” and as “present.”

original: Porāṇehi vuttovāyamatthoti “nimitte”ti gāthamāha. Tattha nimitteti paṭibhāganimitte.
analyzed: porāṇehi nimitta iti gātham āha tattha nimitta iti paṭibhāga nimitte
translated: The ancient teachers have given the meaning of this in the verse beginning, “In the sign.” Herein:

original: Ṭhapayaṃ cittanti bhāvanācittaṃ ṭhapento, ṭhapanāvasena manasi karontoti attho. Nānākāranti🔽“cattāro vaṇṇā”ti evaṃ vuttaṃ nānākāraṃ. Ākārasāmaññavasena hetaṃ ekavacanaṃ. Vibhāvayanti🔽vibhāvento antaradhāpento. Nimittuppattito paṭṭhāya hi te ākārā amanasikaroto antarahitā🔽viya honti. Assāsapassāseti assāsapassāse yo nānākāro, taṃ vibhāvayaṃ, assāsapassāsasambhūte🔽vā nimitte. Sakaṃ cittaṃ nibandhatīti tāya eva ṭhapanāya attano cittaṃ upanibandhati,
analyzed: cittanti bhāvanā cittam ṭhapento ṭhapanā vasena manasi karontoti attho nānā ākāranti  cattāro evam vuttam nānā ākāram ākāra sāmañña vasena ha itam ekavacanam vibhāvayanti  vibhāventaḥ antaradhāpentaḥ nimitta uppattitaḥ paṭṭhāya hi te ākārāḥ a manasikaroto antarahitā  viya honti assāsa passāse iti assāsa passāse yaḥ nānā ākāraḥ tam vibhāvayan assāsa passāsa sambhūte  vā nimitte sakam cittam nibandhati iti tāya eva ṭhapanāya attano cittam upanibandhati
translated: “Fixing the mind” means fixing the mind on the development , that is, giving attention by means of fixing. “The various aspects”🔽means the various aspects stated thus, “The four primary elements” . The singular is used because of the similarity of aspect. “He discriminates”🔽means he discriminates, that is, he causes to disappear. For when he gives no attention to those aspects beginning with the appearance of the sign, they disappear as if they had been imagined. “The in-breaths and out-breaths” : he discriminates the various aspects of the in-breaths and out-breaths, or the sign that arises with the in-breaths and out-breaths as its basis. “He anchors his mind”: he anchors his mind on that same fixing.

original: appetīti attho. Ye pana “vibhāvayanti vibhāvento viditaṃ pākaṭaṃ karonto”ti atthaṃ🔽vadanti, taṃ pubbabhāgavasena yujjeyya. Ayañhettha attho – dhitisampannattā dhīro
analyzed: appeti iti atthaḥ ye pana vibhāvayanti vibhāventaḥ viditam pākaṭam karontaḥ iti attham 🔽vadanti tam pubba bhāga vasena yujjeyya ayam ha ittha atthaḥ dhiti sampanna ttā dhīraḥ
translated: He steadies his cognizance: he steadies the development-of-cognizance cognizance. The meaning is that he gives attention by way of steadying. The various aspects: the various aspects stated thus ‘ the four castes ‘ . The singular is used because of the similarity of aspect. He discerns: he discerns, he makes disappear. For when he gives no attention to those aspects from the time of the appearance of the sign, they disappear as if they had been dissolved away. The in-breaths and out-breaths: he discerns the various aspects of the in-breaths and out-breaths, or of the sign that has arisen owing to the in-breaths and out-breaths. He binds his cognizance to his own cognizance: he binds his cognizance to his own cognizance by means of that steadying. The meaning is that he fixes it. But those who say that the meaning is ‘ he discerns, he makes known, he makes evident by discerning ‘ would be right in the sense of the prior stage. The meaning here is this. He is steadfast because he possesses steadfastness. He is strong because he possesses strength.

original: yogī assāsapassāse nānākāraṃ vibhāvento nānākārato te pajānanto vidite pākaṭe karonto,
analyzed: yogī assāsa passāse nānā ākāram vibhāventaḥ nānā ākārataḥ te pajānantaḥ vidite pākaṭe karontaḥ
translated: The meditator, discerning the in-breaths and out-breaths in various ways, understanding them in various ways, making what is directly known plain,

original: nānākāraṃ vā oḷārikoḷārike passambhento vūpasamento tattha yaṃ laddhaṃ nimittaṃ,
analyzed: nānākāram vā oḷārika uḷārike passambhentaḥ vūpasamentaḥ tattha yam laddham nimittam
translated: or else quieting and stilling the gross and subtle aspects,

original: tasmiṃ cittaṃ ṭhapento anukkamena sakaṃ cittaṃ nibandhati appetīti.🔽Vaṇṇatoti picupiṇḍatārakarūpādīsu viya upaṭṭhitavaṇṇato. Lakkhaṇatoti kharabhāvādisabhāvato,🔽aniccādilakkhaṇato vā. Rakkhitabbaṃ taṃ nimittanti sambandho. Nimittassa rakkhaṇaṃ🔽nāma tattha paṭiladdhassa upacārajhānassa rakkhaṇeneva hotīti āha “punappunaṃ manasikāravasena🔽vuddhiṃ viruḷhiṃ gamayitvā”ti.
analyzed: tasmin cittam ṭhapentaḥ anukkamena sakam cittam nibandhati appeti iti  vaṇṇato ti picu piṇḍa tāraka rūpa ādīsu viya upaṭṭhita vaṇṇato lakkhaṇato ti khara bhāva ādi sabhāvato  anicca ādi lakkhaṇataḥ vā rakkhitabbam tat nimittan ti sambandhaḥ nimittassa rakkhaṇam  nāma tattha paṭiladdhassa upacāra jhānassa rakkhaṇena iva hoti iti āha punappunam manasikāra vasena  vuddhim viruḷhim gamayitvā ati
translated: and fixing his mind upon the obtained sign, gradually binds his mind to his own cognizance and restrains it.

original: 233. Etthāti etissaṃ kāyānupassanāyaṃ. Pārisuddhiṃ pattukāmoti adhigantukāmo, samāpajjitukāmo
analyzed: ettha ati etissam kāya anupassanāyam pārisuddhim pattu kāmaḥ ati adhigantu kāmaḥ samāpajjitu kāmaḥ
translated: As to colour: as to the colour that appears in the case of the kasiṇa as a whole, in the case of the parts, and in the case of the sign. As to shape: as to the shape that appears in the case of the kasiṇa as a whole, in the case of the parts, and in the case of the sign. As to direction: as to the direction in which the kasiṇa as a whole appears, in the case of the parts, and in the case of the sign. As to location: as to the location in which the kasiṇa as a whole appears, in the case of the parts, and in the case of the sign. As to delimitation: as to the delimitation of the kasiṇa as a whole, in the case of the parts, and in the case of the sign. As to the sign: as to the sign of the kasiṇa as a whole, in the case of the parts, and in the case of the sign. As to the surmounting of the sign: as to the surmounting of the sign of the kasiṇa as a whole, in the case of the parts, and in the case of the sign. As to the prior and subsequent: as to the prior and subsequent of the kasiṇa as a whole, in the case of the parts, and in the case of the sign. As to the prior and subsequent of the sign: as to the prior and subsequent of the sign of the kasiṇa as a whole, in the case of the parts, and in the case of the sign. As to the prior and subsequent of the surmounting of the sign: as to the prior and subsequent of the surmounting of the sign of the kasiṇa as a whole, in the case of the parts, and in the case of the sign. As to the sign of the prior and subsequent: as to the sign of the prior and subsequent of the kasiṇa as a whole, in the case of the parts, and in the case of the sign. As to the sign of the prior and subsequent of the sign: as to the sign of the prior and subsequent of the sign of the kasi

original: ca, tattha sallakkhaṇāvivaṭṭanāvasena adhigantukāmo, sallakkhaṇāvasena samāpajjitukāmoti🔽yojetabbaṃ. Nāmarūpaṃ vavatthapetvā vipassanaṃ paṭṭhapetīti saṅkhepato vuttamatthaṃ🔽vitthārato dassetuṃ “katha”ntiādi vuttaṃ. Tattha yathā hītiādi kāyassa, cittassa
analyzed: ca tattha sat lakkhaṇā vivaṭṭanā vasena adhigantu kāmo sat lakkhaṇā vasena samāpajjitu kāmo ti  yojetabbam nāma rūpam vavatthapetvā vipassanam paṭṭhapeti iti saṅkhepataḥ vuttam attham  vitthārataḥ dassetum kathan tiādi vuttam tattha yathā hi itiādi kāyassa cittassa
translated: and he who wants to reach it by way of discerning and turning away wants to attain it by way of discerning.🔽The meaning stated in brief as “he defines mentality-materiality and then begins insight”

original: ca assāsapassāsānaṃ samudayabhāvadassanaṃ. Kammāragaggariyāti kammārānaṃ ukkāyaṃ
analyzed: ca assāsa passāsānam samudaya bhāva dassanam kammāra gaggariyā ati kammārāṇam ukkāyam
translated: is shown in detail in the passage beginning, “How? As to the origin” . Herein, “as to the origin” is the seeing of the origin of the in-breaths and out-breaths, of the body, and of the cognizance.🔽“The smith’s bellows bag”: the smith’s bellows bag is the bellows bag used by smiths for blowing on the forge.🔽“As it is being blown”: as it is being blown, as it is being made to take in the wind, is the meaning.

original: aggidhamanabhastā. Dhamamānāyāti dhamayantiyā, vātaṃ gāhāpentiyāti attho. Tajjanti
analyzed: aggi dhamana bhastā dhamamānāya ati dhamayantiyā vātam gāhāpentiyā ati tajjanti
translated: “In conformity with that”: in conformity with that, in accordance with that.

original: tadanurūpaṃ. Evamevāti ettha kammāragaggarī viya karajakāyo, vāyāmo viya cittaṃ daṭṭhabbaṃ.🔽Kiñcāpi assāsapassāsā cittasamuṭṭhānā, karajakāyaṃ pana vinā tesaṃ appavattanato🔽“kāyañca cittañca paṭicca assāsapassāsā”ti vuttaṃ.
analyzed: tad anurūpam evam eva ati ettha kammāra gaggarī viya karaja kāyaḥ vāyāmaḥ viya cittam daṭṭhabbaṃ 🔽kiñcā api assāsa passāsā citta samuṭṭhānā karaja kāyam pana vinā tesam appavattanato 🔽kāyam ca cittam ca paṭicca assāsa passāsā ti vuttam
translated: Herein, the body is like the smith’s bellows bag, and cognizance is like the effort.

original: Tassāti nāmarūpassa. Paccayaṃ pariyesatīti “avijjāsamudayā rūpasamudayo”tiādinā avijjādikaṃ🔽paccayaṃ vīmaṃsati pariggaṇhāti. Kaṅkhaṃ vitaratīti “ahosiṃ nu kho ahaṃ atītamaddhāna”nti
analyzed: tassa ati nāma rūpassa paccayam pariyesati iti avijjā samudayā rūpa samudayā iti ādinā avijjā ādikam  paccayam vīmaṃsati pariggaṇhāti kaṅkham vitarati iti ahosim nu kho aham atītam addhānam ti
translated: ‘He seeks the conditions’: he investigates, he discerns, the conditions beginning with ignorance, in the way beginning, ‘With the arising of ignorance there is the arising of form’ .

original: ādinayappavattaṃ soḷasavatthukaṃ vicikicchaṃ atikkamati pajahati. “Yaṃ kiñci rūpaṃ🔽atītānāgatapaccuppanna”nti ādinayappavattaṃ kalāpasammasanaṃ. Pubbabhāgeti paṭipadāñāṇadassanavisuddhipariyāpannāya
analyzed: ādi naya ppavattam soḷasa vatthukam vicikiccham atikkamati pajahati yam kiñci rūpam  atīta anāgata paccuppanna nti ādi naya ppavattam kalāpa sammasanam pubbabhāge ti paṭipadā ñāṇa dassana visuddhi pariyāpannāya
translated: ‘He dispels doubt’: he surmounts, he abandons, the sixteen kinds of doubt stated as ‘Was I in the past? ’ , etc., and the type of doubt stated as ‘Any kind of materiality … ’ , etc., which is the surmounting of the fivefold and sevenfold reckoning .

original: udayabbayānupassanāya pubbabhāge uppanne. Obhāsādayoti obhāso ñāṇaṃ pīti passaddhi
analyzed: udaya bbaya anupassanāya pubba bhāge uppanne obhāsa ādayaḥ ti obhāsaḥ ñāṇam pīti passaddhi
translated: ‘The prior stage’: the prior stage of the insight that occurs in the first stage of insight, which is purification by knowledge and vision of what is the path and what is not the path .

original: sukhaṃ adhimokkho paggaho upekkhā upaṭṭhānaṃ nikantīti ime obhāsādayo dasa. Udayaṃ
analyzed: sukham adhimokkhaḥ paggahaḥ upekkhā upaṭṭhānam nikanti iti ime obhāsa ādayaḥ dasa udayam
translated: ‘The illumination, etc.’: the illumination, knowledge, rapturous happiness, tranquillity, bliss, resolution, exertion, equanimity, appearance, and confidence.🔽‘Having abandoned the arising’: having abandoned the arising of formations that is included in the contemplation of arising.

original: pahāyāti udayabbayānupassanāya gahitaṃ saṅkhārānaṃ udayaṃ vissajjetvā tesaṃ bhaṅgasseva
analyzed: pahāya ati udaya bbaya anupassanāya gahitam saṅkhārānam udayam vissajjetvā tesam bhaṅgassa eva
translated: ‘He contemplates only their fall’: he contemplates only their dissolution.

original: anupassanato bhaṅgānupassanaṃ ñāṇaṃ patvā ādīnavānupassanāpubbaṅgamāya nibbidānupassanāya
analyzed: anupassanataḥ bhaṅga anupassanam ñāṇam patvā ādīnava anupassanā pubbaṅgamāya nibbida anupassanāya
translated: Having reached the knowledge of contemplation of dissolution by observing the sign of change, he reaches the knowledge of contemplation of danger by observing the contemplation of dispassion.

original: nibbindanto. Muñcitukamyatāpaṭisaṅkhānupassanāsaṅkhārupekkhānulomañāṇānaṃ ciṇṇapariyante
analyzed: nibbindantaḥ muñcitu kamya tā paṭisaṅkhā anupassanā saṅkhāra upekkhā anuloma ñāṇānam ciṇṇa pariyante
translated: Dispassionate, he reaches the knowledge of conformity with the contemplation of equanimity consisting in the contemplation of reflection on the desire for deliverance, which is the culmination of the contemplation of reflection on the sign of dispassion.

original: uppannagotrabhuñāṇānantaraṃ uppannena maggañāṇena sabbasaṅkhāresu virajjanto vimuccanto.
analyzed: uppanna gotra bhuñāṇa anantaram uppannena magga ñāṇena sabba saṅkhāresu virajjantaḥ vimuccantaḥ
translated: Then, with the path knowledge that arises next to the knowledge of change-of-lineage, he becomes dispassionate and is liberated from all formations.

original: Maggakkhaṇe hi ariyo virajjati vimuccatīti ca vuccati. Tenāha “yathākkamena cattāro
analyzed: magga kkhaṇe hi ariyaḥ virajjati vimuccati iti ca vuccati tena āha yathākkamena cattāro
translated: For at the moment of the path it is said that the noble disciple becomes dispassionate and is liberated. Therefore it is said, “Having reached the four noble paths in due succession.”

original: ariyamagge pāpuṇitvā”ti. Maggaphalanibbānapahīnāvasiṭṭhakilesasaṅkhātassa paccavekkhitabbassa🔽pabhedena ekūnavīsatibhedassa. Arahato hi avasiṭṭhakilesābhāvena ekūnavīsatitā. Assāti
analyzed: ariya magge pāpuṇitvā ti magga phala nibbāna pahīna avasiṭṭha kilesa saṅkhātassa paccavekkhitabbassa  pabhedena ekūnavīsati bhedassa arahataḥ hi avasiṭṭha kilesa abhāvena ekūnavīsati tā assa ati
translated: He contemplates the three kinds of change in the formations that remain after the defilements have been abandoned by the path and its fruition and Nibbāna.

original: ānāpānakammaṭṭhānikassa.
analyzed: āna apāna kammaṭṭhānikassa
translated: The contemplation is of twenty-nine kinds according to the different kinds of formations that remain. For the Arahant has twenty-nine kinds of formations that remain, since he has none that are abandoned. “He” refers to the meditator on the breath.

original: 234. Visuṃ kammaṭṭhānabhāvanānayo nāma natthi paṭhamacatukkavasena adhigatajhānassa vedanācittadhammānupassanāvasena desitattā. Tesanti tiṇṇaṃ catukkānaṃ.
analyzed: visum kammaṭṭhāna bhāvanā nayaḥ nāma natthi paṭhama catukka vasena adhigata jhānassa vedanā citta dhamma anupassanā vasena desita ttā tesanti tiṇṇam catukkānam
translated: There is no method of development of meditation subjects separately, because the jhāna has been reached by means of the first tetrad, and the contemplations of feeling, mind, and mental objects have been taught by means of the second and third tetrads. ‘Their’: of the three tetrads.

original: Pītipaṭisaṃvedīti pītiyā paṭi paṭi sammadeva vedanāsīlo, tassā vā paṭi paṭi sammadeva
analyzed: pīti paṭisaṃvedī iti pītiyā paṭi paṭi sammadeva vedanā sīlo tassā vā paṭi paṭi sammadeva
translated: Experiencing happiness: he is a feeler of happiness, a feeler of it again and again, or he has the experience of it again and again.

original: vedo etassa atthi, taṃ vā paṭi paṭi sammadeva vedayamāno. Tattha kāmaṃ saṃvedana-ggahaṇeneva
analyzed: vedaḥ etassa atthi tam vā paṭi paṭi sammat eva vedayamāno tattha kāmam saṃvedana ggahaṇena iva
translated: Or he is one who feels it again and again, or he feels it again and again. Herein, it may be granted that the word ‘experiencing’ already implies

original: pītiyā sakkaccaṃ viditabhāvo bodhito hoti, yehi pana pakārehi tassā saṃvedanaṃ icchitaṃ,
analyzed: pītiyā sakkaccam vidita bhāvaḥ bodhitaḥ hoti yehi pana pakārehi tassā saṃvedanam icchitam
translated: that the happiness is known well and distinctly; nevertheless, the word ‘again and again’ is stated in order to show the way in which it is experienced,

original: taṃ dassetuṃ paṭi-saddaggahaṇaṃ “paṭi paṭi saṃvedīti paṭisaṃvedī”ti. Tenāha “dvīhākārehī”tiādi.
analyzed: tam dassetum paṭisadda ggahaṇam paṭi paṭi saṃvedi iti paṭisaṃvedi iti tena āha dvīhā ākārehi itiādi
translated: which is claimed to be as follows. ‘Experiencing again and again’ is ‘experiencing’ and ‘again and again’ . That is why he said ‘in two ways’ and so on.

original: Tattha kathaṃ ārammaṇato pīti paṭisaṃviditā hotīti pucchāvacanaṃ. Sappītike dve jhāne
analyzed: tattha katham ārammaṇato pi iti paṭisaṃviditā hoti iti pucchā vacanam sappītike dve jhāne
translated: Herein, the question ‘How is happiness known by adverting to the object?’ is stated.

original: samāpajjatīti pītisahagatāni dve paṭhamadutiyajhānāni paṭipāṭiyā samāpajjati. Tassāti
analyzed: samāpajjati iti pīti sahagatāni dve paṭhama dutiya jhānāni paṭipāṭiyā samāpajjati tassa ati
translated: He enters upon and dwells in the two jhānas that are accompanied by happiness: he enters upon and dwells in the two jhānas consisting of the first and second jhānas that are accompanied by happiness. ‘His’:

original: tena. “Paṭisaṃviditā”ti hi padaṃ apekkhitvā kattuatthe etaṃ sāmivacanaṃ. Samāpattikkhaṇeti
analyzed: tena paṭisaṃviditā iti hi padam apekkhitvā kattu atthe etam sāmi vacanam samāpatti kkhaṇe ti
translated: The word “his” is a possessive adjective referring to the word “cognized” in the phrase “cognized as it actually is.”🔽At the moment of absorption: at the moment of attaining.

original: samāpannakkhaṇe. Jhānapaṭilābhenāti jhānena samaṅgibhāvena. Ārammaṇatoti ārammaṇamukhena,
analyzed: samāpanna kkhaṇe jhāna paṭilābhena ati jhānena samaṅgi bhāvena ārammaṇato ti ārammaṇa mukhena
translated: By the obtaining of jhāna: by the state of being accompanied by jhāna.🔽By the object: by the object as the means.

original: tadārammaṇajhānapariyāpannā pīti paṭisaṃviditā hoti ārammaṇassa paṭisaṃviditattā.
analyzed: tad ārammaṇa jhāna pariyāpannā pīti paṭisaṃviditā hoti ārammaṇassa paṭisaṃvidita ttā
translated: The happiness included in the jhāna that has that as its object is cognized as it actually is because the object is cognized as it actually is.

original: Kiṃ vuttaṃ hoti? Yathā nāma sappapariyesanaṃ carantena tassa āsaye paṭisaṃvidite
analyzed: kim vuttam hoti yathā nāma sappa pariyesanam carantena tassa āsaye paṭisaṃvidite
translated: What is meant? Just as when someone is searching for a snake and he cognizes its lair,

original: sopi paṭisaṃvidito gahito eva hoti mantāgadabalena tassa gahaṇassa sukarattā, evaṃ
analyzed: saḥ api paṭisaṃviditaḥ gahitaḥ eva hoti mantā gada balena tassa gahaṇassa evam
translated: then the snake is also cognized as it actually is, because it is easy to catch hold of it by the power of the charm for catching snakes, so too

original: pītiyā āsayabhūte ārammaṇe paṭisaṃvidite sā pīti paṭisaṃviditā eva hoti salakkhaṇato,
analyzed: pītiyāḥ āsaya bhūte ārammaṇe paṭisaṃvidite sā pīti paṭisaṃviditā eva hoti salakkhaṇato
translated: when the object, which is the lair of happiness, is cognized as it actually is, then that happiness is also cognized as it actually is in its individual and general characteristics,

original: sāmaññato ca tassā gahaṇassa sukarattāti.
analyzed: sāmaññataḥ ca tassā gahaṇassa
translated: because it is easy to catch hold of it.

original: Kathaṃ asammohato pīti paṭisaṃviditā hotīti ānetvā sambandhitabbaṃ. Vipassanākkhaṇeti
analyzed: katham asammohataḥ pi iti paṭisaṃviditā hoti iti ānetvā sambandhitabbam vipassanā kkhaṇe ti
translated: How is happiness cognized as it actually is by non-delusion? The question should be construed thus. At the moment of insight:

original: vipassanāpaññāya tikkhavisadappattāya visayato dassanakkhaṇe. Lakkhaṇapaṭivedhenāti🔽pītiyā salakkhaṇassa, sāmaññalakkhaṇassa ca paṭivijjhanena. Yaṃ hi yassa visesato,
analyzed: vipassanā paññāya tikkha visada ppattāya visayataḥ dassana kkhaṇe lakkhaṇa paṭivedhena ati  pītiyā sa lakkhaṇassa sāmañña lakkhaṇassa ca paṭivijjhanena yam hi yassa visesataḥ
translated: and by the kind of insight knowledge that has reached the acuteness and lucidity of the third stage. By penetration of the characteristic:

original: sāmaññato ca lakkhaṇaṃ, tasmiṃ vidite so yāthāvato vidito eva hoti. Tenāha “asammohato🔽pīti paṭisaṃviditā hotī”ti.🔽Idāni tamatthaṃ pāḷiyā eva vibhāvetuṃ “vuttañheta”ntiādimāha. Tattha dīghaṃ assāsavasenātiādīsu
analyzed: sāmaññato ca lakkhaṇam tasmin vidite so yāthāvataḥ viditaḥ eva hoti tena āha a sammohato  pīti paṭisaṃviditā hoti iti  idāni tam attham pāḷiyā eva vibhāvetum vuttam hetat ti ādim āha tattha dīgham assāsa vasena atiādīsu
translated: by penetration of the characteristic of happiness and the general characteristic of formations. For when the specific and general characteristics of anything are known, that thing is known as it actually is. Hence it was said above: “By non-delusion the happiness is well penetrated” .🔽Now, in order to demonstrate that meaning by means of the texts, he said: “It is said” , etc. Herein, what is to be said has already been said above in the Description of the Recollections .

original: yaṃ vattabbaṃ, taṃ heṭṭhā vuttameva. Tattha pana satokāritādassanavasena pāḷi āgatā,
analyzed: yat vattabbam tat heṭṭhā vuttam eva tattha pana satokāri tā dassana vasena āgatā
translated: There the text is given in terms of the seeing of the function of the in-breaths and out-breaths,🔽but here it is in terms of the experiencing of happiness, and the experiencing of happiness has already been dealt with in the Description of the Meditation Subject .

original: idha pītipaṭisaṃveditāvasena, pītipaṭisaṃveditā ca atthato vibhattā eva. Apica ayamettha
analyzed: idha pīti paṭisaṃvedi tā vasena pīti paṭisaṃvedi tā ca atthataḥ vibhattā eva api ca ayam ettha
translated: Moreover, this is the meaning here:

original: saṅkhepattho – dīghaṃ assāsavasenāti dīghassa assāsassa ārammaṇabhūtassa vasena pajānato
analyzed: saṅkhepa atthaḥ dīgham assāsa vasena ati dīghassa assāsassa ārammaṇa bhūtassa vasena pajānato
translated: By means of long in-breaths: in one who understands, by means of the long in-breath that is the object.

original: sā pīti paṭisaṃviditā hotīti sambandho. Cittassa ekaggataṃ avikkhepaṃ pajānatoti
analyzed: sā pi iti paṭisaṃviditā hoti iti sambandho cittassa ekagga tam avikkhepam pajānato ti
translated: The construction is: “He knows the happiness that has been experienced.”🔽When he knows unification of cognizance and non-distraction:🔽unification of cognizance is concentration, which is included in the jhāna and is called “non-distraction” .

original: jhānapariyāpannaṃ “avikkhepo”ti laddhanāmaṃ cittassekaggataṃ taṃsampayuttāya paññāya
analyzed: jhāna pariyāpannam avikkhepaḥ ti laddha nāmam cittassa ekagga tam tad sampayuttāya paññāya
translated: When he knows that with the understanding associated with it,🔽then the states associated with that happiness are also known by the same method as the object,

original: pajānato. Yatheva hi ārammaṇamukhena pīti paṭisaṃviditā hoti, evaṃ taṃsampayuttadhammāpi🔽ārammaṇamukhena paṭisaṃviditā eva hontīti. Sati upaṭṭhitā hotīti dīghaṃ assāsavasena
analyzed: pajānataḥ yathā iva hi ārammaṇa mukhena pīti paṭisaṃviditā hoti evam tad sampayutta dhammā api  ārammaṇa mukhena paṭisaṃviditāḥ eva honti iti sati upaṭṭhitā hoti iti dīgham assāsa vasena
translated: just as the happiness is known by the method of the object.🔽Mindfulness is established:

original: jhānasampayuttā sati tassa ārammaṇe upaṭṭhitā ārammaṇamukhena jhānepi upaṭṭhitā nāma
analyzed: jhāna sampayuttā sati tassa ārammaṇe upaṭṭhitā ārammaṇa mukhena jhāne pi upaṭṭhitā nāma
translated: the mindfulness associated with the jhāna is established with that as its object, and it is called “established in the jhāna” by the method of the object.🔽By means of that mindfulness:🔽by means of that mindfulness thus established,

original: hoti. Tāya satiyāti evaṃ upaṭṭhitāya tāya satiyā yathāvuttena tena ñāṇena suppaṭividitattā
analyzed: hoti tāya satiyā ati evam upaṭṭhitāya tāya satiyā yathā vuttena tena ñāṇena su paṭividita ttā
translated: the happiness is known by means of that knowledge described thus, and so the happiness is “experienced” by him in this way.

original: ārammaṇassa tassa vasena tadārammaṇā sā pīti paṭisaṃviditā hoti. Dīghaṃ passāsavasenātiādīsupi
analyzed: ārammaṇassa tassa vasena tad ārammaṇā sā pi iti paṭisaṃviditā hoti dīgham passāsa vasena ati ādīsu pi
translated: In the case of “When he breathes in long, he knows … When he breathes out long, he knows … When he breathes in short, he knows … When he breathes out short, he knows … ”

original: imināva nayena attho veditabbo.
analyzed: iminā ava nayena atthaḥ veditabbo
translated: the meaning should be understood in this way too.

original: Evaṃ paṭhamacatukkavasena dassitaṃ pītipaṭisaṃvedanaṃ ārammaṇato, asammohato ca vibhāgaso🔽dassetuṃ “āvajjato”tiādi vuttaṃ. Tattha āvajjatoti jhānaṃ āvajjantassa. Sā pītīti🔽sā jhānapariyāpannā pīti. Jānatoti samāpannakkhaṇe ārammaṇamukhena jānato. Tassa🔽sā pīti paṭisaṃviditā hotīti sambandho. Passatoti dassanabhūtena ñāṇena jhānato vuṭṭhāya🔽passantassa. Paccavekkhatoti jhānaṃ paccavekkhantassa. Cittaṃ adhiṭṭhahatoti “ettakaṃ
analyzed: evam paṭhama catukka vasena dassitam pīti paṭisaṃvedanam ārammaṇataḥ asammohato ca vibhāga so  dassetum āvajjato tiādi vuttam tattha āvajjatoti jhānam āvajjantassa sā pīti iti  sā jhāna pariyāpannā pi iti jānato ti samāpanna kkhaṇe ārammaṇa mukhena jānato tassa  sā pi iti paṭisaṃviditā hoti iti sambandho passatoti dassana bhūtena ñāṇena jhānataḥ vuṭṭhāya  passantassa paccavekkhatoti jhānam paccavekkhantassa cittam adhiṭṭhahatoti ettakam
translated: The happiness that is shown in this way by means of the first tetrad is shown by means of the object and by non-delusion in the following way:

original: velaṃ jhānasamaṅgī bhavissāmī”ti jhānacittaṃ adhiṭṭhahantassa. Evaṃ pañcannaṃ vasībhāvānaṃ🔽vasena jhānassa pajānanamukhena ārammaṇato pītiyā paṭisaṃvedanā dassitā.
analyzed: velam jhāna samaṅgī bhavissāmi iti jhāna cittam adhiṭṭhahantassa evam pañcannam vasībhāvānam 🔽vasena jhānassa pajānana mukhena ārammaṇataḥ pītiyā paṭisaṃvedanā dassitā
translated: “By adverting, by knowing, by seeing, by resolving, by exerting, by letting go, by directing, by bending down to, by looking at, by reviewing, by determining, by attaining, by emerging, by
