reviewing, by determining, by

original: Idāni yehi dhammehi jhānaṃ, vipassanā ca sijjhanti; tesaṃ jhānapariyāpannānaṃ, vipassanāmaggapariyāpannānañca🔽saddhādīnaṃ vasena pītipaṭisaṃvedanaṃ dassetuṃ “saddhāya adhimuccato”tiādi vuttaṃ.
analyzed: idāni yehi dhammehi jhānam vipassanā ca sijjhanti tesam jhāna pariyāpannānam vipassanā magga pariyāpannānam ca  saddhā ādīnam vasena pīti paṭisaṃvedanam dassetum saddhāya adhimuccato tiādi vuttaṃ
translated: Now, in order to show the experiencing of happiness by means of faith, etc., which are the states by means of which jhāna and insight are successful, he said “By faith he resolves” , etc., referring to those states included in jhāna and those included in the path of insight.

original: Tattha adhimuccatoti saddahantassa, samathavipassanāvasenāti adhippāyo. Vīriyaṃ paggaṇhatotiādīsupi
analyzed: tattha adhimuccataḥ ti saddahantassa samatha vipassanā vasena ati adhippāyaḥ vīriyam paggaṇhataḥ ti ādīsu pi
translated: Herein, by resolving means by having faith; the meaning is, by one who has faith in the jhāna and insight. By exerting energy means by one who generates energy for the purpose of attaining jhāna and insight. By rousing up means by one who rouses up his own mind. By directing means by one who directs his mind to the object. By concen-trating means by one who concentrates his mind on the object. By equanimity means by one who is possessed of the equanimity of neutrality.

original: eseva nayo. Abhiññeyyanti abhivisiṭṭhāya paññāya jānitabbaṃ. Abhijānatoti vipassanāpaññāpubbaṅgamāya🔽maggapaññāya jānato. Pariññeyyanti dukkhasaccaṃ tīraṇapariññāya, maggapaññāya ca
analyzed: esa iva nayaḥ abhiññeyyanti abhivisiṭṭhāya paññāya jānitabbam abhijānato ti vipassanā paññā pubbaṅgamāya  magga paññāya jānataḥ pariññeyyanti dukkha saccam tīraṇa pariññāya magga paññāya ca
translated: By knowing means by one who knows the object by means of the knowledge of insight. By seeing means by one who sees it by means of the seeing of insight. By fathoming means by one who fathoms it by means of the understanding of insight. By fully understanding means by one who fully understands it by means of the full understanding of abandoning.

original: parijānato. Pahātabbanti samudayasaccaṃ pahānapariññāya, maggapaññāya ca pajahato.🔽Bhāvayato sacchikaroto bhāvetabbaṃ maggasaccaṃ, sacchikātabbaṃ nirodhasaccaṃ. Keci
analyzed: parijānataḥ pahātabbanti samudaya saccam pahāna pariññāya magga paññāya ca pajahataḥ 🔽bhāvayataḥ sacchikarotaḥ bhāvetabbam magga saccam sacchikātabbam nirodha saccam keci
translated: By knowing and seeing means by one who knows and sees it by means of the path knowledge that has insight knowledge as its forerunner. By fully understanding means by one who fully understands it by means of the full understanding of exhaustion. By abandoning means by one who abandons it by means of the full understanding of abandoning.🔽By developing means by one who develops the path. By realizing means by one who realizes Nibbāna. By attaining means by one who attains the fruition. By maintaining means by one who maintains the life of one who has attained the fruition. By causing others to understand means by one who causes others to understand it by teaching it to them. By explaining means by one who explains it by expounding it. By describing means by one who describes it by describing it. By making it known means by one who makes it known by making it known. By demonstrating means by one who demonstrates it by showing it. By exhibiting means by one who exhibits it by revealing it. By pointing out means by one who points out the way to it. By clapping his hands means by one who claps his hands as a signal to the assembly of bhikkhus. By uttering a cry means by one who utters a cry as a signal to the assembly of bhikkhus. By resolving means by one who resolves to attain the jhāna

original: panettha pītiyā eva vasena abhiññeyyādīni uddharanti, taṃ ayuttaṃ jhānādisamudāyaṃ
analyzed: pana ittha pītiyāḥ eva vasena abhiññeyya ādīni uddharanti tam ayuttam jhāna ādi samudāyam
translated: But here they extract the things to be directly known, etc., only by way of happiness. That is incorrect,

original: uddharitvā tato pītiyā niddhāraṇassa adhippetattā.
analyzed: uddharitvā tatas pītiyāḥ niddhāraṇassa adhippeta ttā
translated: because what is intended is the singling out of happiness from the aggregate of jhāna, etc., which have already been singled out.

original: Ettha ca “dīghaṃ assāsavasenā”tiādinā paṭhamacatukkavasena ārammaṇato pītipaṭisaṃvedanaṃ
analyzed: ettha ca dīgham assāsa vasena āti ādinā paṭhama catukka vasena ārammaṇataḥ pīti paṭisaṃvedanam
translated: And here the experiencing of happiness by way of the object is stated in the first tetrad by the words “By means of long in-breaths and out-breaths” ,

original: vuttaṃ, tathā “āvajjato”tiādīhi pañcahi padehi. “Abhiññeyyaṃ abhijānato”tiādīhi pana🔽asammohato. “Saddhāya adhimuccato”tiādīhi ubhayathāpīti saṅkhepato samathavasena
analyzed: vuttam tathā āvajjato tiādīhi pañcahi padehi abhiññeyyam abhijānato tiādīhi pana  a sammohataḥ saddhāya adhimuccato ti ādīhi ubhayathā api iti saṅkhepataḥ samatha vasena
translated: and likewise by the five terms beginning with “Contemplating impermanence.” The experiencing of happiness by way of non-delusion is stated by the words “By knowing” ,🔽and by the five terms beginning with “Contemplating fading away.” The experiencing of happiness by way of both is stated by the words “By direct knowledge” ,

original: ārammaṇato, vipassanāvasena asammohato pītipaṭisaṃvedanaṃ vuttanti daṭṭhabbaṃ. Kasmā
analyzed: ārammaṇataḥ vipassanā vasena asammohato pīti paṭisaṃvedanam vuttanti daṭṭhabbam kasmā
translated: and by the five terms beginning with “Contemplating cessation.” So it should be understood that the experiencing of happiness is stated in brief by way of serenity as the object and by way of insight as non-delusion.

original: panettha vedanānupassanāyaṃ pītisīsena vedanā gahitā, na sarūpato evāti? Bhūmivibhāgādivasena
analyzed: pana ittha vedanā anupassanā ayam pīti sīsena vedanā gahitā na sarūpatas evā ati bhūmi vibhāga ādi vasena
translated: But why is happiness stated here by way of the heading of happiness in the contemplation of feeling, and not by way of its individual essence?🔽In order to show the contemplation of feeling in four ways by dividing up feeling according to the division of planes, etc.

original: vedanaṃ bhinditvā catudhā vedanānupassanaṃ dassetuṃ. Apica vedanākammaṭṭhānaṃ dassento
analyzed: vedanam bhinditvā catudhā vedanā anupassanam dassetum api ca vedanā kammaṭṭhānam dassento
translated: Besides, in showing the meditation subject of feeling,

original: bhagavā pītiyā oḷārikattā taṃsampayuttasukhaṃ sukhaggahaṇatthaṃ pītisīsena dasseti.
analyzed: bhagavā pītiyāḥ oḷārika ttā tad sampayutta sukham sukha ggahaṇa attham pīti sīsena dasseti
translated: The Blessed One shows the pleasure associated with it under the heading of happiness in order to make it easy to grasp the pleasure by the grossness of the happiness.

original: Eteneva nayena avasesapadānīti “sukhapaṭisaṃvedī cittasaṅkhārapaṭisaṃvedī”ti padāni
analyzed: etena iva nayena avasesa padāni iti sukha paṭisaṃvedī citta saṅkhāra paṭisaṃvedī iti padāni
translated: And in the same way the other terms should be understood as to meaning in the remaining passages, that is to say, as “experiencing pleasure” and as “experiencing mental formation” .

original: pītipaṭisaṃvedipade āgatanayeneva atthato veditabbāni. Sakkā hi “dvīhākārehi sukhapaṭisaṃveditā
analyzed: pīti paṭisaṃvedi pade āgata nayena iva atthataḥ veditabbāni sakkā hi dvīhā ākārehi sukha paṭisaṃveditā
translated: For it is possible to understand the meaning in this way, by substituting the terms “pleasure” and so on for the term “happiness” in the passage beginning, “There is happiness in two ways,

original: hoti, cittasaṅkhārapaṭisaṃveditā hoti ārammaṇato”tiādinā pītiṭṭhāne sukhādipadāni
analyzed: hoti citta saṅkhāra paṭisaṃveditā hoti ārammaṇato tiādinā pīti ṭṭhāne sukha ādi padāni
translated: there is mental-formation-feeling in two ways, there is object-contemplation-feeling in two ways” , and so on.

original: pakkhipitvā “sukhasahagatāni tīṇi jhānāni, cattāri vā jhānāni samāpajjatī”tiādinā🔽atthaṃ viññātuṃ. Tenāha “tiṇṇaṃ jhānānaṃ vasenā”tiādi. Vedanādayoti ādi-saddena saññā
analyzed: pakkhipitvā sukha sahagatāni tīṇi jhānāni cattāri vā jhānāni samāpajjati itiādinā  attham viññātum tena āha tiṇṇam jhānānam vasena atiādi vedanā ādayaḥ ti ādi saddena saññā
translated: And so it is said, “In the case of the three jhānas … in the case of the four jhānas he enters upon and dwells in them with happiness and with bliss born of seclusion, etc.,” and so on.🔽The words “feelings, etc.” include perception, and so it is said, “two aggregates” .

original: gahitā. Tenāha “dve khandhā”ti. Vipassanābhūmidassanatthanti pakiṇṇakasaṅkhārasammasanavasena
analyzed: gahitā tena āha dve khandhā ti vipassanā bhūmi dassana atthanti pakiṇṇaka saṅkhāra sammasana vasena
translated: The words “in order to show the plane of insight” mean in order to show the plane of insight by the method of discerning the various aspects of the formations.

original: vipassanāya bhūmidassanatthaṃ “sukhanti dve sukhānī”tiādi vuttaṃ samathe kāyikasukhābhāvato.
analyzed: vipassanāya bhūmi dassana attham sukhanti dve sukhāni itiādi vuttam samathe kāyika sukha abhāvato
translated: “There are two kinds of pleasure” is said in order to show the plane of insight, since there is no bodily pleasure in serenity.

original: Soti so passambhanapariyāyena vutto nirodho. “Imassa hi bhikkhuno pubbe apariggahitakāle”tiādinā
analyzed: so ti so passambhana pariyāyena vuttaḥ nirodhaḥ imassa hi bhikkhuno pubbe a pariggahita kāle tiādinā
translated: “This bhikkhu” is said in detail in the passage beginning, “At the time when he has not yet apprehended the sign” .

original: vitthārato kāyasaṅkhāre vutto, tasmā vuttanayeneva veditabbo. Tattha kāyasaṅkhāravasena
analyzed: vitthārataḥ kāya saṅkhāre vutto tasmā vutta nayena iva veditabbaḥ tattha kāya saṅkhāra vasena
translated: Therefore it should be understood in the way already stated. Herein, it is the bodily formation that is given in the earlier part of the passage,

original: āgato, idha cittasaṅkhāravasenāti ayameva viseso.🔽Evaṃ cittasaṅkhārassa passambhanaṃ atidesena dassetvā yadaññaṃ imasmiṃ catukke vattabbaṃ,
analyzed: āgataḥ idha citta saṅkhāra vasena ati ayam eva visesaḥ  evam citta saṅkhārassa passambhanam atidesena dassetvā yat aññam imasmim catukke vattabbam
translated: and it is the mental formation that is given here. This is the only difference.🔽Having thus shown the surmounting of the mental formation by a special method, he said “Moreover” in order to point out what else should be said in this tetrad.

original: taṃ dassetuṃ “apicā”tiādi vuttaṃ. Tattha pītipadeti “pītipaṭisaṃvedī”tiādinā desitakoṭṭhāse.
analyzed: tam dassetum apica atiādi vuttam tattha pīti pade iti pīti paṭisaṃvedī iti ādinā desita koṭṭhāse
translated: Herein, in the clause “in the case of the clause on happiness” , the reference is to the section taught in the passage beginning, “Experiencing happiness” .

original: Pītisīsena vedanā vuttāti pītiapadesena taṃsampayuttā vedanā vuttā, na pītīti adhippāyo.
analyzed: pīti sīsena vedanā vuttā ati pīti apadesena tad sampayuttā vedanā vuttā na pīti iti adhippāyaḥ
translated: “Feeling is called happiness” : what is meant is that feeling associated with happiness is called “happiness,” not happiness as object.🔽The reason for this is given below.

original: Tattha kāraṇaṃ heṭṭhā vuttameva. Dvīsu cittasaṅkhārapadesūti “cittasaṅkhārapaṭisaṃvedī
analyzed: tattha kāraṇam heṭṭhā vuttam eva dvīsu citta saṅkhāra padesu iti citta saṅkhāra paṭisaṃvedī
translated: In the two instances of the mental formation: in the passage beginning, “Experiencing the mental formation” ,

original: passambhayaṃ cittasaṅkhāra”nti cittasaṅkhārapaṭisaṃyuttesu dvīsu padesu. “Viññāṇapaccayā🔽nāmarūpa”nti vacanato cittena paṭibaddhāti cittapaṭibaddhā. Tato eva kāmaṃ cittena
analyzed: citta saṅkhāran ti citta saṅkhāra paṭisaṃyuttesu dvīsu padesu viññāṇa paccayā  nāma rūpanti vacanataḥ cittena paṭibaddhā ati citta paṭibaddhā tatas eva kāmam cittena
translated: and “with the stilling of applied and sustained thought” in the two passages dealing with the stilling of applied and sustained thought.🔽“With consciousness as condition, mentality-materiality” .🔽So they are bound up with consciousness, bound to consciousness.

original: saṅkharīyantīti cittasaṅkhārā, saññāvedanādayo, idha pana upalakkhaṇamattaṃ saññā
analyzed: saṅkharīyanti iti citta saṅkhārā saññā vedanā ādayo idha pana upalakkhaṇa mattam saññā
translated: And because of that they are formed by consciousness, are mental formations, consisting of perception, feeling, etc. But here perception and feeling are intended as a mere indication,

original: vedanāva adhippetāti āha “saññāsampayuttā vedanā”ti.
analyzed: vedanā va adhippetā ti āha saññā sampayuttā vedanā ti
translated: so he said “feeling associated with perception” .

original: 235. Cittapaṭisaṃvedīti ettha dvīhākārehi cittapaṭisaṃveditā hoti ārammaṇato, asammohato
analyzed: citta paṭisaṃvedī iti ettha dvīhā ākārehi citta paṭisaṃvedi tā hoti ārammaṇataḥ asammohato
translated: “Experiencing the mind”: there are two ways in which there is experiencing of the mind, namely, through the object and through non-delusion.

original: ca. Kathaṃ ārammaṇato? Cattāri jhānāni samāpajjati, tassa samāpattikkhaṇe jhānapaṭilābhenātiādinā
analyzed: ca katham ārammaṇato cattāri jhānāni samāpajjati tassa samāpatti kkhaṇe jhāna paṭilābhena ati ādinā
translated: How through the object? “He enters upon and dwells in the first jhāna … the second jhāna … the third jhāna … the fourth jhāna” .

original: vuttanayānusārena sabbaṃ suviññeyyanti āha “catunnaṃ jhānānaṃ vasena cittapaṭisaṃveditā
analyzed: vutta naya anusārena sabbam su viññeyyan ti āha catunnam jhānānam vasena citta paṭisaṃvedi tā
translated: All this can be understood in the way already stated .

original: veditabbā”ti. Cittaṃ modentoti jhānasampayuttaṃ cittaṃ sampayuttāya pītiyā modayamāno,
analyzed: veditabbā ati cittam modento ti jhāna sampayuttam cittam sampayuttāya pītiyā modayamāno
translated: “He delights in the liberation of mind” : he delights the consciousness associated with the jhāna by means of the happiness associated with it.

original: taṃ vā pītiṃ ārammaṇaṃ katvā pavattaṃ vipassanācittaṃ tāya eva ārammaṇabhūtāya pītiyā
analyzed: tam vā pītim ārammaṇam katvā pavattam vipassanā cittam tāya eva ārammaṇa bhūtāya pītiyā
translated: Or else, the insight consciousness that occurs making that happiness its object

original: modayamāno. Pamodentotiādīni padāni tasseva vevacanāni pītipariyāyabhāvato.
analyzed: modayamānaḥ pamodentaḥ iti ādīni padāni tassa iva vevacanāni pīti pariyāya bhāvato
translated: is gladdened by that same happiness that is its object. The words “he delights, he exalts” are synonyms for that in the sense of synonyms for happiness.

original: Sampayuttāya pītiyā cittaṃ āmodetīti jhānacittasampayuttāya pītisambojjhaṅgabhūtāya🔽odagyalakkhaṇāya jhānapītiyā tameva jhānacittaṃ sahajātādipaccayavasena ceva jhānapaccayavasena
analyzed: sampayuttāya pītiyā cittam āmodeti iti jhāna citta sampayuttāya pīti sambojjhaṅga bhūtāya  odagya lakkhaṇāya jhāna pītiyā tam eva jhāna cittam sahajāta ādi paccaya vasena ca iva jhāna paccaya vasena
translated: He makes the mind joyful by means of happiness: he makes the jhāna consciousness joyful by means of the happiness associated with it, which is the factor of enlightenment called “the enlightenment factor of happiness”

original: ca paribrūhento haṭṭhapahaṭṭhākāraṃ pāpento āmodeti pamodeti ca. Ārammaṇaṃ katvāti🔽uḷāraṃ jhānasampayuttaṃ pītiṃ ārammaṇaṃ katvā pavattamānaṃ vipassanācittaṃ tāya eva
analyzed: ca paribrūhentaḥ haṭṭha pahaṭṭha ākāram pāpentaḥ āmodeti pamodeti ca ārammaṇam katvā ati  uḷāram jhāna sampayuttam pītim ārammaṇam katvā pavattamānam vipassanā cittam tāya eva
translated: and which has the characteristic of exhilaration. He gladdens and delights it by nourishing it and bringing it to growth by means of the jhāna happiness associated with it and by means of the jhāna itself, which is a condition for it by the condition consisting in conascence, etc., and by the condition consisting in jhāna.

original: ārammaṇabhūtāya pītiyā yogāvacaro haṭṭhapahaṭṭhākāraṃ pāpento “āmodeti pamodetī”ti vuccati.
analyzed: ārammaṇa bhūtāya pītiyā yogāvacaraḥ haṭṭha pahaṭṭha ākāram pāpentaḥ āmodeti pamodeti iti vuccati
translated: By making it an object: the insight consciousness that occurs making the sublime jhāna happiness associated with the jhāna its object is said to “gladen and delight” the yogi by bringing it to growth and making it expand by means of that same happiness that is its object and by making it the object of the insight consciousness.

original: Samaṃ ṭhapentoti yathā īsakampi līnapakkhaṃ, uddhaccapakkhañca anupagamma anonataṃ
analyzed: samam ṭhapento ti yathā īsakam pi līna pakkham uddhacca pakkham ca an upagamma an onatam
translated: He steadies it evenly: without allowing it to lean to either side, that is, without allowing it to lean to either the side of sluggishness or the side of agitation.

original: anunnataṃ yathā indriyānaṃ samattapaṭipattiyā avisamaṃ, samādhissa vā ukkaṃsagamanena🔽āneñjappattiyā sammadeva ṭhitaṃ hoti, evaṃ appanāvasena ṭhapento. Lakkhaṇapaṭivedhenāti
analyzed: an unnatam yathā indriyānam samatta paṭipattiyā avisamam samādhissa vā ukkaṃsa gamanena  āneñja ppattiyā sammat eva ṭhitam hoti evam appanā vasena ṭhapentaḥ lakkhaṇa paṭivedhena ati
translated: as steadiness in the case of the attainment of imperturbability by the mind’s going to eminence in concentration.

original: aniccādikassa lakkhaṇassa paṭi paṭi vijjhanena khaṇe khaṇe avabodhena. Khaṇikacittekaggatāti🔽khaṇamattaṭṭhitiko samādhi. Sopi hi ārammaṇe nirantaraṃ ekākārena pavattamāno paṭipakkhena
analyzed: anicca ādikassa lakkhaṇassa paṭi paṭi vijjhanena khaṇe khaṇe avabodhena khaṇika citta ekagga tā ti  khaṇa matta ṭṭhitiko samādhi saḥ api hi ārammaṇe nirantaram eka ākārena pavattamāno paṭipakkhena
translated: By penetration of the characteristics: by the repeated penetration of the characteristics of impermanence, etc., by understanding them again and again.🔽Momentary unification: concentration lasting only a moment. For that too steadies the mind, which is then as if drawn together, by occurring uninterruptedly in a single mode on the object,

original: anabhibhūto appito viya cittaṃ niccalaṃ ṭhapeti. Tena vuttaṃ “evaṃ uppannāyā”tiādi.
analyzed: an abhibhūtaḥ appitaḥ viya cittam niccalam ṭhapeti tena vuttam evam uppannāya atiādi
translated: unopposed by oppositional states.

original: Mocentoti vikkhambhanavimuttivasena vivecento visuṃ karonto, nīvaraṇāni pajahantoti
analyzed: mocento ti vikkhambhana vimutti vasena vivecentaḥ visum karontaḥ nīvaraṇāni pajahantaḥ iti
translated: Liberating: separating, making separate, by way of the liberation of suppression, abandoning the hindrances.

original: attho. Vipassanākkhaṇeti bhaṅgānupassanākkhaṇe. Bhaṅgo hi nāma aniccatāya paramā
analyzed: atthaḥ vipassanā akkhaṇe iti bhaṅga anupassanā akkhaṇe bhaṅgaḥ hi nāma anicca tāya paramā
translated: At the moment of insight: at the moment of insight into dissolution. For dissolution is the ultimate peak of impermanence,

original: koṭi, tasmā tāya bhaṅgānupassako yogāvacaro cittamukhena sabbasaṅkhāragataṃ aniccato
analyzed: tasmā bhaṅga anupassakaḥ yogāvacaro citta mukhena sabba saṅkhāra gatam aniccato
translated: Therefore the meditator who contemplates dissolution by means of impermanence sees all formations through the mind, which is to say, he sees them as impermanent.

original: passati, no niccato. Aniccassa dukkhattā, dukkhassa ca anattakattā tadeva dukkhato
analyzed: passati no niccataḥ aniccassa dukkha ttā dukkhassa ca anattaka ttā tat eva dukkhato
translated: he sees it as impermanent, not as permanent. Because what is impermanent is painful, and what is painful is not self, he contemplates that same state as painful

original: anupassati, no sukhato. Anattato anupassati, no attato. Yasmā pana yaṃ aniccaṃ dukkhaṃ
analyzed: anupassati no sukhataḥ anattataḥ anupassati no attataḥ yasmā pana yam aniccam dukkham
translated: and not as pleasant, as not self and not as self. But because whatever is impermanent, painful, and not self is not worth choosing, adopting, and grasping,🔽therefore, following on the seeing of its dissolution, he contemplates formations in the presently seen state as impermanent, painful, and not self.

original: anattā, na taṃ abhinanditabbaṃ. Yañca na abhinanditabbaṃ, na taṃ rañjitabbaṃ. Tasmā🔽bhaṅgadassanānusārena “aniccaṃ dukkhaṃ anattā”ti saṅkhāragate diṭṭhe tasmiṃ nibbindati,🔽no nandati. Virajjati, no rajjati. So evaṃ nibbindanto virajjanto lokiyeneva tāva
analyzed: anattā na tam abhinanditabbam yat ca na abhinanditabbam na tam rañjitabbam tasmā  bhaṅga dassana anusārena aniccam dukkham anattā ati saṅkhāra gate diṭṭhe tasmin nibbindati  no nandati virajjati no rajjati saḥ evam nibbindantaḥ virajjantaḥ lokiyena iva tāva
translated: He becomes dispassionate towards it, not passionate; he is not delighted by it. He detaches his mind from it, does not cling to it.🔽As he becomes dispassionate and detaches his mind thus, he suppresses lust by means of the mundane dispassion that is simply dispassion,🔽he does not generate it, he does not bring it into existence. Or alternatively, as he becomes dispassionate and detaches his mind thus, he suppresses lust by means of the supramundane dispassion that is the path,

original: ñāṇena rāgaṃ nirodheti, no samudeti, nāssa samudayaṃ karotīti attho. Atha vā so evaṃ
analyzed: ñāṇena rāgam nirodheti no samudeti na assa samudayam karoti iti atthaḥ atha vā saḥ evam
translated: he does not generate it, he does not bring it into existence. He abandons it, he gives it up, he rejects it, he does not consent to it.

original: viratto yathā diṭṭhaṃ saṅkhāragataṃ, tathā adiṭṭhaṃ attano ñāṇena nirodheti, no samudeti.🔽Nirodhamevassa manasikaroti, no samudayanti attho. So evaṃ paṭipanno paṭinissajjati,
analyzed: virattaḥ yathā diṭṭham saṅkhāra gatam tathā adiṭṭham attanaḥ ñāṇena nirodheti no samudeti 🔽nirodham eva assa manasikaroti no samudayanti attho saḥ evam paṭipannaḥ paṭinissajjati
translated: As he does so, he is called a noble disciple of direct vision, of intuitive wisdom, who has seen and experienced the state of Nibbana.

original: no ādiyati. Kiṃ vuttaṃ hoti? Ayañhi aniccādianupassanā saddhiṃ khandhābhisaṅkhārehi🔽kilesānaṃ pariccajanato, saṅkhatadosadassanena tabbiparīte nibbāne tanninnatāya pakkhandanato
analyzed: no kim vuttam hoti ayam hi anicca ādi anupassanā saddhim khandha abhisaṅkhārehi  kilesānam pariccajanataḥ saṅkhata dosa dassanena tad biparīte nibbāne tad ninna tāya pakkhandanato
translated: He does not take them. What is meant? This contemplation of impermanence, etc., is called “relinquishment by giving up” and “relinquishment by entering into” because it gives up defilements together with the khandhas that originate in them,

original: pariccāgapaṭinissaggo pakkhandanapaṭinissaggo cāti vuccati. Tasmā tāya samannāgato
analyzed: pariccāga paṭinissaggo pakkhandana paṭinissaggo ca ati vuccati tasmā tāya samannāgato
translated: and because it enters into and immerses itself in Nibbāna, which is the opposite of the danger in what is formed, by seeing that danger. Therefore the meditator who possesses this contemplation

original: yogāvacaro vuttanayena kilese ca pariccajati, nibbāne ca pakkhandati. Tena vuttaṃ
analyzed: yogāvacaraḥ vutta nayena kilese ca pariccajati nibbāne ca pakkhandati tena vuttam
translated: gives up defilements and enters into Nibbāna in the way already stated. Hence it was said above

original: “so vipassanākkhaṇe aniccānupassanāya niccasaññāto cittaṃ mocento vimocento …pe…
analyzed: so vipassanā kkhaṇe anicca anupassanāya nicca saññāto cittam mocentaḥ vimocentaḥ pe
translated: “At the moment of insight, while he is liberating and releasing his mind from the perception of permanence by means of the contemplation of impermanence …

original: paṭinissaggānupassanāya ādānato cittaṃ mocento vimocento assasati ceva passasati cā”ti.
analyzed: paṭinissagga anupassanāya ādānataḥ cittam mocentaḥ vimocentaḥ assasati ca iva passasati ca ati
translated: and while he is liberating and releasing his mind from grasping by means of the contemplation of relinquishment, he both breathes in and breathes out” .

original: Tattha aniccassa, aniccanti vā anupassanā aniccānupassanā. Tebhūmakadhammānaṃ aniccataṃ
analyzed: tattha aniccassa aniccanti vā anupassanā anicca anupassanā tebhūmaka dhammānam anicca taṃ
translated: Herein, contemplation of impermanence is either the contemplation of what is impermanent as “impermanent” or the contemplation of what is impermanent as “impermanent, not permanent.”

original: gahetvā pavattāya vipassanāya etaṃ nāmaṃ. Niccasaññātoti saṅkhatadhamme “niccā sassatā”ti
analyzed: gahetvā pavattāya vipassanāya etam nāmam nicca saññāto ti saṅkhata dhamme niccā sassatā ti
translated: This is a name for insight that occurs by taking the impermanence of states in the three planes as its object.🔽From the perception of permanence: from the perception that formed things are permanent, eternal,

original: pavattāya micchāsaññāya. Saññāsīsena cittadiṭṭhīnampi gahaṇaṃ daṭṭhabbaṃ. Esa nayo🔽sukhasaññādīsupi. Nibbidānupassanāyāti saṅkhāresu nibbindanākārena pavattāya anupassanāya.
analyzed: pavattāya micchāsaññāya saññā sīsena citta diṭṭhīnam pi gahaṇam daṭṭhabbam esa nayo  sukha saññā ādīsu pi nibbida anupassanāya ati saṅkhāresu nibbindana ākārena pavattāya anupassanāya
translated: and to the wrong view that occurs by way of the perception of pleasure. The inclusion of the views that occur by way of perception should be understood in the same way.🔽So too with the perception of pleasure, etc.🔽By contemplation of dispassion: by contemplation that occurs by way of dispassion for formations.🔽From delight: from craving accompanied by happiness.

original: Nanditoti sappītikataṇhāto. Virāgānupassanāyāti tathā virajjanākārena pavattāya anupassanāya.
analyzed: nandito ti sappītika taṇhātaḥ virāga anupassanāya ati tathā virajjana ākārena pavattāya anupassanāya
translated: By contemplation of fading away: by contemplation that occurs by way of fading away.🔽Hence it is said, “By liberation from greed” .

original: Tena vuttaṃ “rāgato mocento”ti. Nirodhānupassanāyāti saṅkhārānaṃ nirodhassa anupassanāya.
analyzed: tena vuttam rāgataḥ mocento ti nirodha anupassanāya ati saṅkhārānam nirodhassa anupassanāya
translated: By contemplation of cessation: by contemplation of the cessation of formations.

original: Yathā saṅkhārā nirujjhantiyeva, āyatiṃ punabbhavavasena na uppajjanti, evaṃ vā anupassanā
analyzed: yathā saṅkhārāḥ nirujjhantiyā iva āyatim punabbhava vasena na uppajjanti evam vā anupassanā
translated: Contemplation is the contemplation of cessation in so far as it is only formations that cease, not being subject to rearising in the future.

original: nirodhānupassanā. Muñcitukamyatā hi ayaṃ balappattā. Tenāha “samudayato mocento”ti.
analyzed: nirodha anupassanā muñcitu kamya tā hi ayam bala ppattā tena āha samudayataḥ mocentā iti
translated: This contemplation has reached the state of power, since it is the desire for deliverance. Hence it is said, “By liberation from arising” .🔽By contemplation of relinquishment: by contemplation that occurs by way of relinquishment.

original: Paṭinissajjanākārena pavattā anupassanā paṭinissaggānupassanā. Ādānatoti niccādivasena
analyzed: paṭinissajjana ākārena pavattā anupassanā paṭinissagga anupassanā ādānataḥ ti nicca ādi vasena
translated: From grasping: from taking as permanent, etc.,

original: gahaṇato, paṭisandhiggahaṇato vāti evamettha attho daṭṭhabbo.
analyzed: gahaṇataḥ paṭisandhi ggahaṇataḥ vā ti evam ettha atthaḥ daṭṭhabbo
translated: or from taking up rebirth-linking. This is how the meaning should be regarded here.

original: 236. Aniccanti anupassī, aniccassa vā anupassanasīlo aniccānupassīti ettha kiṃ panetaṃ
analyzed: aniccanti anupassī aniccassa vā anupassana sīlaḥ anicca anupassī iti ettha kim pana etam
translated: “Contemplating as impermanent”: he is a virtue-possessor who contemplates as impermanent, or he contemplates impermanence. Herein, what is this?

original: aniccaṃ, kathaṃ vā aniccaṃ, kā vā aniccānupassanā, kassa vā aniccānupassanāti catukkaṃ
analyzed: aniccam katham vā aniccam kā vā anicca anupassanā kassa vā anicca anupassanā ati catukkam
translated: Contemplating as impermanent: he has the habit of contemplating as impermanent what is impermanent. He contemplates as impermanent: here what is impermanent? How is it impermanent? What is contemplation of impermanence? Whose is the contemplation of impermanent? These are the four questions.

original: vibhāvetabbanti taṃ dassento “aniccaṃ veditabba”ntiādimāha.
analyzed: vibhāvetabbanti tam dassentaḥ aniccam veditabba nti ādim āha
translated: To show the answers to them he said: “Impermanent should be known” .

original: Tattha niccaṃ nāma dhuvaṃ sassataṃ yathā taṃ nibbānaṃ, na niccanti aniccaṃ, udayabbayavantaṃ,
analyzed: tattha niccam nāma dhuvam sassatam yathā tam nibbānam na niccanti aniccam udaya bbayavantam
translated: Herein, permanent is what is lasting, eternal, as is Nibbāna. Not permanent is impermanent, subject to rise and fall.

original: atthato saṅkhatā dhammāti āha “aniccanti pañcakkhandhā. Kasmā? Uppādavayaññathattabhāvā”ti,
analyzed: atthataḥ saṅkhatāḥ dhammā ti āha aniccanti pañca kkhandhā kasmai uppāda vayaññathatta bhāvā ti
translated: In the sense of formed dhammas he said: “Impermanent should be known as the five aggregates as objects of clinging. Why? Because of rise and fall and change” .

original: uppādavayaññathattasabbhāvāti attho. Tattha saṅkhatadhammānaṃ hetupaccayehi uppajjanaṃ
analyzed: uppāda vayaññathatta sabbhāvā ti atthaḥ tattha saṅkhata dhammānam hetu paccayehi uppajjanam
translated: The meaning is: because of the nature of rise, fall and change. Herein, the rise of formed dhammas is their occurrence by means of causes and conditions.

original: ahutvā sambhavo attalābho uppādo. Uppannānaṃ tesaṃ khaṇanirodho vināso vayo. Jarāya
analyzed: a hutvā sambhavaḥ atta lābho uppādaḥ uppannānam tesam khaṇa nirodhaḥ vināsaḥ vayaḥ jarāya
translated: It is their coming to be after non-existence, their acquisition of a selfhood, their appearance. The fall of those that have arisen is their destruction, their disappearance. The change of what is subject to fall is its alteration.

original: aññathābhāvo aññathattaṃ. Yathā hi uppādāvatthāya bhinnāya bhaṅgāvatthāyaṃ vatthubhedo
analyzed: aññathābhāvaḥ aññathattam yathā hi uppāda avatthāya bhinnāya bhaṅga avatthā ayam vatthu bhedaḥ
translated: For just as when a thing is broken up in the place where it was, the site of its destruction is different from the site of its breaking up,

original: natthi, evaṃ ṭhitisaṅkhātāya bhaṅgābhimukhāvatthāyampi vatthubhedo natthi, yattha
analyzed: natthi evam ṭhiti saṅkhātāya vatthu bhedaḥ natthi
translated: and there is no difference in the physical basis in the state of presence, which is the opposite of dissolution.

original: jarāvohāro. Tasmā ekassāpi dhammassa jarā yujjati, yā khaṇikajarāti vuccati. Ekaṃsena🔽ca uppādabhaṅgāvatthāsu vatthuno abhedo icchitabbo, aññathā “añño uppajjati, añño
analyzed: jarā vohāraḥ tasmai ekassa api dhammassa jarā yujjati yā khaṇika jarā ati vuccati ekaṃsena  ca uppāda bhaṅga avatthāsu vatthuno abhedaḥ icchitabbaḥ aññathā aññaḥ uppajjati aññaḥ
translated: So ageing is appropriate for a single state, which is called momentary ageing.🔽And the non-difference of the physical basis in the states of arising and dissolution must be admitted, otherwise it would follow that “one arises and another dissolves.”

original: bhijjatī”ti āpajjeyya. Tayimaṃ khaṇikajaraṃ sandhāyāha “aññathatta”nti. Yaṃ panettha
analyzed: bhijjati iti āpajjeyya tayimam khaṇikajaram sandhāya āha aññathattam ti yam pana ittha
translated: So he said “change-of-what-was” with reference to this momentary ageing.

original: vattabbaṃ, taṃ parato kathayissāma.
analyzed: vattabbam tam paratas kathayissāma
translated: But what has to be said here will be said later.

original: Yassa lakkhaṇattayassa bhāvā khandhesu aniccasamaññā, tasmiṃ lakkhaṇattaye aniccatāsamaññāti🔽“aniccatāti tesaṃyeva uppādavayaññathatta”nti vatvā visesato dhammānaṃ khaṇikanirodhe
analyzed: yassa lakkhaṇa ttayassa bhāvā khandhesu anicca samaññā tasmim lakkhaṇa ttaye anicca tā samaññā ati  anicca tā ti tesam yeva uppāda vayaññathattan ti vatvā visesataḥ dhammānam khaṇika nirodhe
translated: The perception of impermanence in the aggregates is due to the presence of the three characteristics. The perception of impermanence in the three characteristics is due to the presence of the characteristic of impermanence.🔽After saying “Impermanence is the alteration of what is formed,” he said “The non-existence after having been” in order to show the impermanence of states specifically in their momentary cessation.

original: aniccatāvohāroti dassento “hutvā abhāvo vā”tiādimāha. Tattha uppādapubbakattā abhāvassa
analyzed: anicca tā vohāraḥ ti dassentaḥ hutvā abhāvaḥ vā tiādim āha tattha uppāda pubbaka ttā abhāvassa
translated: Herein, since non-existence is prior to arising,

original: hutvāgahaṇaṃ. Tena pākabhāvapubbakattaṃ vināsabhāvassa dasseti. Tenevākārenāti nibbattanākāreneva.
analyzed: hutvā gahaṇam tena pāka bhāva pubbaka ttam vināsa bhāvassa dasseti tena iva ākārena ati nibbattana ākārena iva
translated: “By that same means”: by the means of arising.🔽“By momentariness”: by momentary cessation.

original: Khaṇabhaṅgenāti khaṇikanirodhena. Tassā aniccatāyāti khaṇikabhaṅgasaṅkhātāya aniccatāya.
analyzed: khaṇa bhaṅgena ati khaṇika nirodhena tassāḥ anicca tāya ati khaṇika bhaṅga saṅkhātāya anicca tāya
translated: “By its impermanence”: by the impermanence consisting in momentary dissolution.🔽“By that contemplation”: by the contemplation of impermanence stated thus.

original: Tāya anupassanāyāti yathāvuttāya aniccānupassanāya. Samannāgatoti samaṅgibhūto yogāvacaro.
analyzed: tāya anupassanāya ati yathā vuttāya anicca anupassanāya samannāgataḥ ti samaṅgi bhūtaḥ yogāvacaraḥ
translated: “Endowed”: provided with.

original: Khayo saṅkhārānaṃ vināso, virajjanaṃ tesaṃyeva vilujjanaṃ virāgo, khayo eva virāgo🔽khayavirāgo, khaṇikanirodho. Accantamettha etasmiṃ adhigate saṅkhārā virajjanti nirujjhantīti🔽accantavirāgo, nibbānaṃ. Tenāha “khayavirāgo saṅkhārānaṃ khaṇabhaṅgo, accantavirāgo
analyzed: vināsaḥ virajjanam virāgaḥ eva virāgaḥ  khaya virāgaḥ khaṇika nirodhaḥ etasmin adhigate saṅkhārāḥ virajjanti nirujjhanti iti  nibbānam tena āha khaya virāgo saṅkhārānam khaṇa bhaṅgo accanta virāgo
translated: “Destruction” is the dissolution of formations. “Detachment” is their fading away. “Detachment” is the same as “destruction.”🔽“Destruction-detachment” is momentary cessation.🔽“Final detachment” is Nibbāna.

original: nibbāna”nti. Tadubhayavasena pavattāti khayavirāgānupassanāvasena vipassanāya, accantavirāgānupassanāvasena
analyzed: nibbānanti tad ubhaya vasena pavattā ati khaya virāga anupassanā vasena vipassanāya accanta virāga anupassanā vasena
translated: “By that contemplation”: by insight that occurs by way of the contemplation of destruction-detachment and by way of the contemplation of final detachment.

original: maggassa pavatti yojetabbā. Ārammaṇato vā vipassanāya khayavirāgānupassanāvasena🔽pavatti, tanninnabhāvato accantavirāgānupassanāvasena, maggassa pana asammohato khayavirāgānupassanāvasena,
analyzed: maggassa pavatti yojetabbā ārammaṇataḥ vā vipassanāya khaya virāga anupassanā vasena  pavatti tad ninna bhāvataḥ accanta virāga anupassanā vasena maggassa pana asammohataḥ khaya virāga anupassanā vasena
translated: The path should be brought into relation with the object.🔽Or alternatively, the path’s occurrence as insight should be understood as the occurrence of insight as the contemplation of fall and change of state,

original: ārammaṇato accantavirāgānupassanāvasena pavatti veditabbā. “Eseva nayo”ti iminā yasmā🔽virāgānupassī-pade vuttanayānusārena “dve nirodhā khayanirodho ca accantanirodho🔽cā”ti evamādiatthavaṇṇanaṃ atidisati, tasmā virāgaṭṭhāne nirodhapadaṃ pakkhipitvā
analyzed: ārammaṇataḥ accanta virāga anupassanā vasena pavatti veditabbā esā iva nayo ti iminā yasmā  virāga anupassī pade vutta naya anusārena dve nirodhā khaya nirodho ca accanta nirodho  ca ati evamādi attha vaṇṇanam atidisati tasmai virāga ṭṭhāne nirodha padam pakkhipitvā
translated: and as the occurrence of insight as the contemplation of dispassion, since it is devoted to that. But the path’s occurrence as the contemplation of fall and change of state should be understood as the occurrence of insight as the contemplation of fall and change of state, since it is not deluded about the object,🔽and as the occurrence of insight as the contemplation of dispassion, since it is devoted to the object.

original: “khayo saṅkhārānaṃ vināso”tiādinā idha vuttanayena tassa atthavaṇṇanā veditabbā.
analyzed: khayaḥ saṅkhārānam vināsaḥ tiādinā idha vutta nayena tassa attha vaṇṇanā veditabbā
translated: By the words “This is the method” he shows that the explanation of the meaning should be understood in the way given in the passage on the contemplation of dispassion in the Description of the Earth Kasiṇa, substituting “cessation” for “dispassion” and using the words “fall” and “change of state” in the way stated in the passage on the contemplation of fall and change of state in the Description of the Earth Kasiṇa.

original: Paṭinissajjanaṃ pahātabbassa tadaṅgavasena vā samucchedavasena vā pariccajanaṃ pariccāgapaṭinissaggo.
analyzed: paṭinissajjanam pahātabbassa tad aṅga vasena vā samuccheda vasena vā pariccajanam pariccāga paṭinissaggaḥ
translated: “Relinquishment” is the giving up of what is to be abandoned either by substituting the opposite quality for it or by suppressing it.

original: Tathā sabbūpadhīnaṃ paṭinissaggabhūte visaṅkhāre attano nissajjanaṃ, tanninnatāya
analyzed: tathā sabba upadhīnam paṭinissagga bhūte visaṅkhāre attanaḥ nissajjanam tad ninna tāya
translated: Likewise, the relinquishing of them by him who has entered upon the signless as object is relinquishing by entering into.

original: vā tadārammaṇatāya vā tattha pakkhandanaṃ pakkhandanapaṭinissaggo.🔽Tadaṅgavasenāti ettha aniccānupassanā tāva tadaṅgappahānavasena niccasaññaṃ pariccajati,
analyzed: vā tad ārammaṇa tāya vā tattha pakkhandanam pakkhandana paṭinissaggo  tad aṅga vasena āti ettha anicca anupassanā tāva tad aṅga ppahāna vasena nicca saññam pariccajati
translated: Or alternatively, the relinquishing of them by him who has entered upon the signless as object is relinquishing by entering into, because he has gone into that signless object by inclining towards it or by making it his object.🔽By means of a factor: firstly, the contemplation of impermanence relinquishes the perception of permanence by means of the relinquishing of a factor.

original: pariccajantī ca tathā appavattiyaṃ ye “nicca”nti gahaṇavasena kilesā, tammūlakā abhisaṅkhārā,
analyzed: ca tathā appavattiyam ye niccanti gahaṇa vasena kilesā tad mūlakāḥ abhisaṅkhārāḥ
translated: And while it is relinquishing it relinquishes all the defilements that would occur in the future by the non-occurrence of the perception of permanence, and the determinations rooted in that,

original: tadubhayamūlakā ca vipākakkhandhā anāgate uppajjeyyuṃ, te sabbepi appavattikaraṇavasena
analyzed: tad ubhaya mūlakā ca vipāka khandhāḥ anāgate uppajjeyyum te sabbe pi appavatti karaṇa vasena
translated: and the resultant aggregates rooted in both of them, by making them non-existent.

original: pariccajati, tathā dukkhasaññādayo. Tenāha “vipassanā hi tadaṅgavasena saddhiṃ khandhābhisaṅkhārehi🔽kilese pariccajatī”ti.
analyzed: pariccajati tathā dukkha saññā ādayaḥ tena āha vipassanā hi tad aṅga vasena saddhim khandha abhisaṅkhārehi  kilese pariccajati iti
translated: Hence it is said: “For insight relinquishes defilements together with the aggregates and determinations by means of the relinquishing of a factor” .

original: Saṅkhatadosadassanenāti saṅkhate tebhūmake saṅkhāragate aniccatādidosadassanena.
analyzed: saṅkhata dosa dassanena ati saṅkhate tebhūmake saṅkhāra gate anicca tā ādi dosa dassanena
translated: By seeing the danger in what is formed: by seeing the danger in what is formed, that is, in the formed element consisting of the three mundane planes.

original: Niccādibhāvena tabbiparīte. Tanninnatāyāti tadadhimuttatāya. Pakkhandatīti anupavisati🔽anupavisantaṃ viya hoti. Saddhiṃ khandhābhisaṅkhārehi kilese pariccajatīti maggena
analyzed: nicca ādi bhāvena tad biparīte tad ninna tāya ati tad adhimutta tāya pakkhandati iti anupavisati  anupavisantam viya hoti saddhim khandha abhisaṅkhārehi kilese pariccajati iti maggena
translated: By the inclination to that: by the inclination to that.🔽He enters upon: he enters into.🔽As if he were entering upon: as if he were entering into.

original: kilesesu pariccattesu avipākadhammatāpādanena abhisaṅkhārā, tammūlakā ca khandhā
analyzed: kilesesu pariccattesu avipāka dhamma tā āpādanena abhisaṅkhārā tad mūlakā ca khandhā
translated: He surrenders the defilements together with the determinations of assuming: when the defilements have been surrendered by the path, the determinations, which are the cause of their being reborn with ripening, and the aggregates rooted in them,

original: anuppattirahabhāvena pariccattā nāma hontīti sabbepi te maggo pariccajatīti vuttaṃ.
analyzed: anuppatti raha bhāvena pariccattāḥ nāma honti iti sabbe pi te maggo pariccajati iti vuttam
translated: are surrendered by being incapable of arising. So it is said that the path surrenders them all.

original: Ubhayanti vipassanāñāṇaṃ, maggañāṇañca. Maggañāṇampi hi gotrabhuñāṇassa anu pacchā
analyzed: ubhayanti vipassanā ñāṇam magga ñāṇañca magga ñāṇam pi hi gotrabhu ñāṇassa anu pacchā
translated: Both: insight knowledge and path knowledge.

original: nibbānadassanato “anupassanā”ti vuccati.
analyzed: nibbāna dassanataḥ anupassanā ti vuccati
translated: For path knowledge is called “contemplation” because it is after, and because it sees nibbana.

original: Soḷasavatthuvasena cāti soḷasannaṃ vatthūnaṃ vasenāpi vuccamānasantabhāvādivasenāpīti samuccayattho ca-saddo. “Ānāpānassati bhāvitā”ti padaṃ ānetvā sambandhitabbaṃ.
analyzed: soḷasa vatthu vasena ca ati soḷasannam vatthūnam vasena api vuccamāna santa bhāva ādi vasena api iti samuccaya tthaḥ ca saddaḥ āna apāna ssati bhāvitā ati padam ānetvā sambandhitabbam
translated: By way of the sixteen bases: the meaning of the word “also” is inclusive; it is to be construed with the words “when mindfulness of breathing is developed” as follows.

original: 237. Assāti ānāpānassatisamādhissa. Kāmavitakkādivitakkupacchedasamatthatāyapi mahānisaṃsatā🔽veditabbāti sambandho. Ayanti ānāpānassatisamādhi. Uccāvacesu ārammaṇesu pavattiyeva
analyzed: assa ti āna apāna ssati samādhissa mahā nisaṃsa tā  veditabbā ti sambandhaḥ ayanti āna apāna ssati samādhi uccāvacesu ārammaṇesu pavattiyā iva
translated: “Breathes in” is connected with the meaning “it should be understood that the concentration of mindfulness of breathing has great benefits even in the ability to cut off applied thoughts such as sensual thoughts.”

original: ito cito ca cittassa vidhāvanaṃ.
analyzed: itas citas ca cittassa vidhāvanam
translated: “This” is the concentration of mindfulness of breathing. “Wandering here and there” is the occurrence of the mind on various high and low objects.

original: Vijjā nāma maggo. Vimutti phalaṃ. Mūlabhāvo vipassanāya pādakabhāvo. Cattāro satipaṭṭhāne
analyzed: vijjā nāma maggaḥ vimutti phalam mūla bhāvaḥ vipassanāya pādaka bhāvo cattāro satipaṭṭhāne
translated: “Knowledge” is the path. “Liberation” is fruition. “The foundation” is the footing for insight.

original: paripūreti kāyānupassanādīnaṃ catunnaṃ anupassanānaṃ vasena tassā bhāvanāya pavattanato.
analyzed: paripūreti kāya anupassanā ādīnam catunnam anupassanānam vasena tassāḥ bhāvanāya pavattanato
translated: He fulfills the four foundations of mindfulness because the development of that takes place by means of the four contemplations beginning with the contemplation of the body.

original: Satta bojjhaṅge paripūrenti bojjhaṅgabhāvanāya vinā satipaṭṭhānabhāvanāpāripūriyā
analyzed: satta bojjhaṅge paripūrenti bojjhaṅga bhāvanāya vinā sati paṭṭhāna bhāvanā pāripūriyā
translated: He fulfills the seven enlightenment factors because there is no development of the foundations of mindfulness without the development of the enlightenment factors.

original: abhāvato. Vijjāvimuttiṃ paripūrenti bojjhaṅgabhāvanāya tāsaṃ sikhāppattibhāvato.
analyzed: abhāvataḥ vijjā vimuttim paripūrenti bojjhaṅga bhāvanāya tāsam sikhā appatti bhāvataḥ
translated: He fulfills knowledge and liberation because the enlightenment factors reach their culmination in that.

original: Carimakānanti antimakānaṃ.
analyzed: antima kānam
translated: “The last” means the final.

original: 238. Nirodhavasenāti nirujjhanavasena. Bhavacarimakāti bhavavasena carimakā nihīnabhavapavattino.
analyzed: nirodha vasena ati nirujjhana vasena bhava carimakāḥ ati bhava vasena carimakāḥ nihīna bhava pavattinaḥ
translated: “By way of cessation” means by way of cessation. “The last in the world” are the lowest in the world, who are reborn in the lowest realms of existence.

original: Tathā jhānacarimakā veditabbā. Cuticarimakāti cutiyā carimakā cutikkhaṇapavattino
analyzed: tathā jhāna carimakā veditabbā cuti carimakā ati cutiyā carimakā cuti khaṇa pavattino
translated: And so too the last in the jhāna, and the last in the death consciousness.🔽The last in the death consciousness are the last of all, occurring in the death consciousness.🔽Because of that: because of occurring in the lower sensual-desire existence among the three kinds of existence.

original: sabbapariyosānakā. Tasmāti tīsu bhavesu nihīne kāmabhave pavattanato. Teti assāsapassāsā.
analyzed: sabba pariyosānakā tasmā ati tīsu bhavesu nihīne kāma bhave pavattanato te ti assāsa passāsā
translated: Those: in-breaths and out-breaths.🔽In front: below.

original: Puratoti heṭṭhā. Yasmā vibhaṅgaṭṭhakathāyaṃ rūpadhammānaṃ soḷasacittakkhaṇāyukatā
analyzed: puratas ti heṭṭhā yasmā rūpa dhammānam soḷasa cittakkhaṇa āyuka tā
translated: Because in the Vibhaṅga Commentary the sixteen-moment life of material phenomena is demonstrated,

original: vibhāvitā, tasmā “soḷasamena cittena saddhiṃ uppajjitvā”ti vuttaṃ. Cuticittassa puratoti
analyzed: vibhāvitā tasmā soḷasamena cittena saddhim uppajjitvā ati vuttam cuti cittassa puratas ti
translated: therefore it is said, “arising together with the sixteenth consciousness.”

original: vā cuticittaṃ avadhibhāvena gahetvā tato oraṃ soḷasamena cittena saddhiṃ uppajjitvāti
analyzed: vā cuti cittam avadhi bhāvena gahetvā tatas oram soḷasamena cittena saddhim uppajjitvā ati
translated: Or “in front of the death consciousness” can be taken to mean “having taken the death consciousness as a limit.” So it is said, “arising together with the sixteenth consciousness before that.”

original: evaṃ pana atthe gayhamāne sattarasacittakkhaṇāyukatāva assāsapassāsānaṃ vuttā hoti.
analyzed: evam pana atthe gayhamāne satta rasa cittakkhaṇa āyuka tā va assāsa passāsānam vuttā hoti
translated: But when the meaning is taken in this way, it is said that the life of the in-breaths and out-breaths is seventeen moments of consciousness.

original: Ime kira imaṃ kammaṭṭhānaṃ anuyuttassa bhikkhuno pākaṭā hontīti ānetvā sambandho.
analyzed: ime kira imam kammaṭṭhānam anuyuttassa bhikkhuno pākaṭāḥ honti iti ānetvā sambandhaḥ
translated: The connection is made by taking it that these are evident to a bhikkhu devoted to this meditation subject.🔽Herein, he gives the reason: “because the object of in-breaths and out-breaths is well discerned.”

original: Tattha kāraṇamāha “ānāpānārammaṇassa suṭṭhu pariggahitattā”ti. Tamevatthaṃ vibhāvetuṃ
analyzed: tattha kāraṇam āha āna apāna ārammaṇassa suṭṭhu pariggahita ttā ti tam eva attham vibhāvetum
translated: To elucidate that same meaning he says:

original: “cuticittassā”tiādi vuttaṃ.
analyzed: cuti cittassa atiādi vuttam
translated: “The death consciousness” and so on is said.

original: Tattha āyuantaraṃ nāma jīvitantaraṃ jīvanakkhaṇāvadhi. Dhammatāya evāti sabhāveneva, rucivasenevāti attho.🔽Candālokaṃ oloketvāti juṇhapakkhe padosavelāyaṃ samantato āsiñcamānakhīradhāraṃ viya
analyzed: tattha āyu antaram nāma jīvita antaram jīvana kkhaṇa avadhi dhamma tāya eva ati sa bhāvena iva ruci vasena iva ati attho  canda ālokam oloketvā ati juṇha pakkhe padosa velāyam samantataḥ āsiñcamāna khīra dhāram viya
translated: Herein, the life-continuum is the life-continuum up to the life-moment. “Naturally” means by its own nature; the meaning is, “by its own inclination.”🔽“Looking at the moon and the light” means looking at the sky, which is like a stream of milk pouring down all around at the end of the night in the bright fortnight,

original: gaganatalaṃ, rajatapattasadisavālikāsanthatañca bhūmibhāgaṃ disvā “ramaṇīyo vatāyaṃ
analyzed: gagana talam bhūmi bhāgam disvā ramaṇīyaḥ vata ayam
translated: and at the ground, which is like a silver plate, and thinking, “How pleasant is this time and this place,

original: kālo, deso ca mama ajjhāsayasadiso, kīva ciraṃ nu kho ayaṃ dukkhabhāro vahitabbo”ti🔽attano āyusaṅkhāre upadhāretvā parikkhīṇeti adhippāyo. Lekhaṃ katvāti caṅkame tiriyaṃ lekhaṃ katvā.🔽Anuyuñjethāti anuyuñjeyya, bhāveyyāti attho.
analyzed: kālaḥ deso ca mama ajjhāsaya sadiso kīva ciram nu kho ayam dukkha bhāro vahitabbo ti  attanaḥ āyu saṅkhāre upadhāretvā parikkhīṇā iti adhippāyaḥ lekham katvā ati caṅkame tiriyam lekham katvā  anuyuñjetha ati anuyuñjeyya bhāveyya ati attho
translated: which are just as I like! But how long must I carry this burden of suffering?”🔽The meaning is that he considers his life-constituents and finds that they are exhausted. “He draws a line” means he draws a line across the walking-path.

original: Upasamānussatikathāvaṇṇanā
analyzed: upasama anussati kathā vaṇṇanā
translated: “He should apply himself” means he should apply himself; the meaning is, he should develop.

original: 239. Evanti yathāvuttena virāgādiguṇānussaraṇappakārena. Sabbadukkhūpasamasaṅkhātassāti dukkhadukkhādibhedaṃ sabbampi dukkhaṃ upasammati etthāti sabbadukkhūpasamoti saṅkhātabbassa.
analyzed: evam ti yathā vuttena virāga ādi guṇa anussaraṇa ppakārena sabba dukkha upasama saṅkhātassa ati dukkha dukkha ādi bhedam sabbam pi dukkham upasammati ettha ati sabba dukkha upasamaḥ iti saṅkhātabbassa
translated: “Thus”: in the way already stated, by recollecting the special qualities of dispassion, etc. “Which is called the stilling of all suffering”: it is the stilling of all suffering of the kinds of suffering beginning with pain itself, thus it is “the stilling of all suffering” .🔽“The dhammas that are ideas”: although they are not realities, they are called “dhammas” because they are borne in mind by knowledge, that is to say, they are borne in mind as objects.

original: “Paññattidhammā”tiādīsu asabhāvopi ñāṇena dhārīyati avadhārīyatīti dhammoti vuccatīti
analyzed: paññatti dhamma ati ādīsu asabhāvaḥ pi ñāṇena dhārīyati avadhārīyati iti dhammo ti vuccati iti
translated: “The dhammas that are realities” : the word “dhammas” is repeated in order to show that the word “realities” is a synonym for “dhammas.”🔽“The dhammas that are realities” : the dhammas that are realities are the dhammas that are realities,🔽because they are borne in mind as their own realities.🔽“The dhammas that are realities” : the dhammas that are realities are the dhammas that are realities,🔽because they are borne in mind as their own realities.

original: tato nivattento “dhammāti sabhāvā”ti āha. Bhavanaṃ paramatthato vijjamānatā bhāvo,
analyzed: tatas nivattentaḥ dhammā ati sabhāvā ti āha bhavanam paramatthataḥ vijjamāna tā bhāvaḥ
translated: “The dhammas that are realities” : the dhammas that are realities are the dhammas that are realities,🔽because they are borne in mind as their own realities.🔽“The dhammas that are realities” : the dhammas that are realities are the dhammas that are realities,🔽because they are borne in mind as their own realities.🔽“The dhammas that are realities” : the dhammas that are realities are the dhammas that are realities,🔽because they are borne in mind as their own realities.

original: saha bhāvenāti sabhāvā, sacchikaṭṭhaparamatthato labbhamānarūpāti attho. Te hi attano
analyzed: saha bhāvena ati sabhāvā sacchikaṭṭha paramatthataḥ labbhamāna rūpā ti te hi attanaḥ
translated: “The dhammas that are realities” : the dhammas that are realities are the dhammas that are realities,🔽because they are borne in mind as their own realities.🔽“The dhammas that are realities” : the dhammas that are realities are the dhammas that are realities,🔽because they are borne in mind as their own realities.

original: sabhāvassa dhāraṇato dhammāti, yathāvuttenaṭṭhena sabhāvāti ca vuccanti. Saṅgammāti
analyzed: sabhāvassa dhāraṇataḥ dhammā ti yathā vuttena aṭṭhena sabhāvā ti ca vuccanti saṅgamma ati
translated: “The dhammas that are realities” : the dhammas that are realities are the dhammas that are realities,🔽because they are borne in mind as their own realities.🔽“The dhammas that are realities” : the dhammas that are realities are the dhammas that are realities,

original: paccayasamodhānalakkhaṇena saṅgamena sannipatitvā. Samāgammāti tasseva vevacanaṃ.
analyzed: paccaya samodhāna lakkhaṇena saṅgamena sannipatitvā samāgamma iti tassa iva vevacanam
translated: because they are borne in mind as their own realities.

original: Paccayehīti anurūpehi paccayehi. Katāti nibbattitā. Akatāti kehicipi paccayehi na
analyzed: paccayehi iti anurūpehi paccayehi katā ati nibbattitā a katā ati kehici pi paccayehi na
translated: “The dhammas that are realities” : the dhammas that are realities are the dhammas that are realities,🔽because they are borne in mind as their own realities.🔽“The dhammas that are realities”

original: katā. Asaṅkhatāti bahuvacanassa kāraṇaṃ heṭṭhā vuttameva. Aggamakkhāyatīti aggo akkhāyati,🔽ma-kāro padasandhikaro. So asaṅkhatalakkhaṇo sabhāvadhammo virāgoti paccetabbo, virajjati🔽ettha saṃkilesadhammoti. Nibbānaṃ ārammaṇaṃ katvā pavattamānena ariyamaggena pahīyamānā
analyzed: katā asaṅkhatā iti bahuvacanassa kāraṇam heṭṭhā vuttam eva aggam akkhāyati iti aggaḥ akkhāyati  makāro pada sandhi karo so asaṅkhata lakkhaṇo sa bhāva dhammo virāgaḥ ti paccetabbaḥ virajjati  ettha saṃkilesa dhammaḥ ti nibbānam ārammaṇam katvā pavattamānena ariya maggena pahīyamānā
translated: the m-syllable being a linking one. That should be understood as the unformed element, the state of things as they really are, called fading away of lust,🔽because the states of defilement fade away here.🔽When the noble path occurs with Nibbāna as its object, the defilements that are being abandoned by means of that path are abandoned.🔽They are said to be abandoned when they have reached Nibbāna. That is why it is said: “They are destroyed on arrival at it” .

original: mānamadādayo taṃ patvā pahīyanti nāmāti āha “tamāgamma…pe… vinassantī”ti. Tattha🔽“seyyohamasmī”tiādinā maññanāvasena pavatto māno eva mānamado. Purisabhāvaṃ nissāya🔽uppajjanakamado purisamado. Ādi-saddena jātimadādīnaṃ saṅgaho daṭṭhabbo. Nimmadāti
analyzed: māna mada ādayaḥ tam patvā pahīyanti nāma ati āha vinassanti iti tattha  seyya uham asmi itiādinā maññanā vasena pavatto mānaḥ eva māna madaḥ purisa bhāvam nissāya  uppajjanaka madaḥ purisa madaḥ ādi saddena jāti mada ādīnam saṅgahaḥ daṭṭhabbo nimmadā ti
translated: Herein, conceit is conceit consisting in the thought “I am better” , etc., which occurs by making the five aggregates the object.

original: vigatamadabhāvā. Imameva hi atthaṃ dassetuṃ “amadā”ti vuttaṃ. Madā nimmadīyanti ettha🔽amadabhāvaṃ vināsaṃ gacchantīti madanimmadano. Eseva nayo sesapadesupi. Kāmapipāsāti
analyzed: vigata mada bhāvāḥ imam eva hi attham dassetum amadā ti vuttam madāḥ nimmadīyanti ettha 🔽a mada bhāvam vināsam gacchanti iti mada nimmadanaḥ eṣa iva nayaḥ sesa padesu pi kāma pipāsā ati
translated: The conceit of manhood is conceit that arises by making the state of being a man the object. The word “etc.” should be understood to include the conceit of birth, the conceit of youth, the conceit of life, the conceit of health, the conceit of freedom, the conceit of being a man, the conceit of being a householder, the conceit of being a clansman, the conceit of being a khattiya, the conceit of being a brāhmaṇa, the conceit of being rich, the conceit of being famous, the conceit of being honoured, the conceit of being a master, the conceit of being a lord, the conceit of being a great man, the conceit of being a warrior, the conceit of being a hero, the conceit of being a man, the conceit of being a person, the conceit of being a human being, the conceit of being a being, the conceit of being a living being, the conceit of being a creature, the conceit of being a man of discernment, the conceit of being a man of knowledge, the conceit of being a man of wisdom, the conceit of being a knower, the conceit of being a seer, the conceit of being a speaker, the conceit of being a man of virtue, the conceit of being a man of meditation, the conceit of being a man of learning, the conceit of being a man of good birth, the conceit of being a man of good family, the conceit of being a man of good character, the conceit of being a man of good conduct, the conceit of being a man of good behaviour, the conceit of being a man of good qualities, the conceit of being a man of good qualities of training, the conceit of being

original: kāmānaṃ pātukamyatā, kāmataṇhā. Kāmaguṇā eva āliyanti ettha sattāti kāmaguṇālayā.
analyzed: kāmānam pātukamyatā kāma taṇhā kāma guṇāḥ eva āliyanti ettha kāma guṇa ālayā
translated: The desire to enjoy sense desires is sense-desire craving. The sense-desire sense-sphere is that to which beings are attached by taking the sense desires as a sense-sphere.

original: Tebhūmakaṃ vaṭṭanti tīsu bhūmīsu kammakilesavipākavaṭṭaṃ. Esa asaṅkhatadhammo. Aparāparabhāvāyāti
analyzed: tebhūmakam vaṭṭanti tīsu bhūmīsu kamma kilesa vipāka vaṭṭam esa asaṅkhata dhammaḥ apara apara bhāvāya ati
translated: The round of existence is the round of kamma, defilements, and result in the three planes. This is the unformed element.🔽For the sake of the state of being in successive births: for the sake of the state of being in successive births beginning with the rebirth-linking.

original: aparāparaṃ yoniādito yoniādibhāvāya. Ābandhanaṃ gaṇṭhikaraṇaṃ. Saṃsibbanaṃ tunnakāraṇaṃ.
analyzed: apara aparam yoni āditaḥ yoni ādi bhāvāya ābandhanam gaṇṭhikaraṇam saṃsibbanam tunna kāraṇam
translated: Bondage is the binding. Entanglement is the entangling.

original: Nikkhamanaṃ, nissaraṇañcassa taṇhāya visaṃyogo evāti āha “visaṃyutto”ti.🔽Ye guṇe nimittaṃ katvā madanimmadanādināmāni nibbāne niruḷhāni, te madanimmadanatādike
analyzed: nikkhamanam nissaraṇam ca assa taṇhāya visaṃyogaḥ eva ati āha visaṃyuttaḥ ti  ye guṇe nimittam katvā mada nimmadana ādi nāmāni nibbāne niruḷhāni te mada nimmadana tā ādike
translated: The escape from it is the disjunction from craving.🔽The qualities of Nibbāna, which are called “intoxication-destroying,” etc., are so called because they are the destruction of intoxication, etc.

original: yathāvutte nibbattitanibbānaguṇe eva gahetvā āha “madanimmadanatādīnaṃ guṇānaṃ vasenā”ti,
analyzed: yathā vutte nibbattita nibbāna guṇe eva gahetvā āha mada nimmadana tā ādīnam guṇānam vasena iti
translated: He said “by the qualities of ‘intoxication-destroying,’ etc.,” taking the qualities of Nibbāna as they are described above,

original: na pana madā nimmadīyanti etenāti evamādike. Te hi ariyamaggaguṇā. Bhagavatā upasamaguṇā
analyzed: na pana madāḥ nimmadīyanti etena ati evamādike te hi ariya magga guṇāḥ bhagavatā upasama guṇā
translated: but not “by the intoxication-destroying, etc.,” because these are the qualities of the noble path.🔽The Blessed One said that the qualities of peace are

original: vuttāti sambandho. Kattha pana vuttāti? Asaṅkhatasaṃyuttādīsu. Tattha saccanti avitathaṃ.
analyzed: vuttā iti sambandhaḥ kattha pana vuttā ati asaṅkhata saṃyutta ādīsu tattha saccam ti avitatham
translated: where? In the Unformed Element, etc. Herein, “true” is unfalsified.

original: Nibbānaṃ hi kenaci pariyāyena asantabhāvābhāvato ekaṃseneva santattā aviparītaṭṭhena
analyzed: nibbānam hi kenacid pariyāyena asanta bhāva abhāvato ekaṃsena iva santattā aviparīta ṭṭhena
translated: For nibbana is peaceful in the sense of being unopposed, since it is peaceful in the ultimate sense in that it is non-existent as unrest by any manner of analysis.🔽It is the truth in the sense of non-deceptive, thus: “There is one truth, there is a second truth not” .

original: saccaṃ. Tenāha “ekaṃ hi saccaṃ, na dutiyamatthī”ti. Pāranti saṃsārassa paratīrabhūtaṃ.
analyzed: saccam tena āha ekam hi saccam na dutiyam atthi iti saṃsārassa para tīra bhūtam
translated: It is the further shore in the sense of being the further shore of the round of rebirths.

original: Tenevāha “tiṇṇo pāraṅgato thale tiṭṭhati brāhmaṇo”ti, “appakā te manussesu, ye janā🔽pāragāmino”ti ca. Sududdasanti paramagambhīratāya, atisukhumasantasabhāvatāya ca
analyzed: tena iva āha tiṇṇaḥ pāraṅgataḥ thale tiṭṭhati brāhmaṇaḥ ti appakā te manussesu ye janā  ca ca
translated: Hence it is said: “The brahmin has crossed over and gone to the further shore, he stands on firm ground” , and: “Few are they among men who go to the further shore” .

original: anupacitañāṇasambhārehi daṭṭhuṃ asakkuṇeyyatāya suṭṭhu duddasaṃ. Natthi ettha jarā,
analyzed: an upacita ñāṇa sambhārehi daṭṭhum a sakkuṇeyya tāya suṭṭhu duddasam na atthi ettha jarā
translated: It is very hard to see in the sense of being extremely hard to see, since it cannot be seen by those who have not accumulated the equipment of knowledge.

original: etasmiṃ vā adhigate puggalassa jarābhāvoti ajaraṃ. Tato eva jarādīhi apalokiyatāya
analyzed: etasmin vā adhigate puggalassa jarā bhāvaḥ ti ajaram tatas eva jarā ādīhi
translated: There is no ageing here, or one whose nature is such that there is no ageing in him when he has attained it, thus it is deathless.

original: thiraṭṭhena dhuvaṃ. Taṇhādipapañcābhāvato nippapañcaṃ. Natthi ettha matanti amataṃ.
analyzed: thira aṭṭhena dhuvam taṇhā ādi papañca abhāvataḥ nippapañcam natthi ettha matam nti amatam
translated: It is permanent in the sense of being firm, since it is not subject to dissolution by ageing, etc.,

original: Asivabhāvakarānaṃ saṃkilesadhammānaṃ abhāvena sivaṃ. Catūhi yogehi anupaddutattā
analyzed: saṃkilesa dhammānam abhāvena sivam catūhi yogehi anupadduta ttā
translated: It is unformed in the sense of being unformed by the formations consisting in ignorance, etc. It is blissful in the sense of being naturally blissful, since it is blissful by being the opposite of suffering. It is pure in the sense of being naturally pure, since it is pure by being the opposite of the defilements.

original: khemaṃ. Visaṅkhārabhāvena acchariyatāya, abhūtapubbatāya ca abbhutaṃ. Sabbāsaṃ ītīnaṃ🔽anatthānaṃ abhāvena anītikaṃ. Niddukkhatāya abyābajjhaṃ. Sabbasaṃkilesamalato accantasuddhiyā🔽visesato suddhīti visuddhi. Catūhipi oghehi anajjhottharaṇīyatāya dīpaṃ. Sakalavaṭṭadukkhato
analyzed: khemam visaṅkhāra bhāvena a chariya tāya a bhūta pubba tāya ca abbhutam sabbāsam ītīnam  anatthānam abhāvena anītikam niddukkha tāya abyābajjham sabba saṃkilesa malataḥ accanta suddhiyā  visesataḥ catūhi pi oghehi an ajjhottharaṇīya tāya dīpam sakala vaṭṭa dukkhato
translated: It is safe, because it is free from the formation of kamma. It is wonderful, because it is marvellous, and because it was not existent before. It is without fear, because it is free from the three fears. It is without grief, because it is free from the five griefs. It is without distress, because it is free from the three distresses. It is without defilement, because it is free from the three defilements. It is the supreme security, because it is free from the four bonds. It is the supreme island, because it is free from the four migrations. It is the supreme shelter, because it is free from the five darts. It is the supreme sanctuary, because it is free from the seven bonds of sexuality. It is the supreme friend, because it is free from the four kinds of bad friends. It is the supreme treasure, because it is free from the four kinds of wealth. It is the supreme heir, because it is free from the four kinds of bad heirs. It is the supreme footing, because it is free from the four kinds of bad footings. It is the supreme rest, because it is free from the five kinds of bad rests. It is the supreme bliss, because it is free from the four kinds of bad bliss. It is the supreme couch, because it is free from the five kinds of bad couches. It is the supreme shelter from wind and rain, because it is free from the four kinds of bad shelter from wind and rain. It is the supreme protection from cold and heat, because it is free from the four kinds of bad protection from cold and heat. Ādi-saddena🔽anantaanāsavanipuṇaajajjaraapalokitaanidassanapaṇītaacchariyaanītikadhammamuttileṇaparāyaṇagambhīrādivacanehi🔽ca bodhitā idha avuttā guṇā saṅgayhanti, tattha natthi etassa uppādanto vā vayanto🔽vāti ananto, asaṅkhatadhammo. original: nipuṇo. Saṅkhatadhammo viya jarāya ajajjaritatāya ajajjaro. Byādhiādīhi apalokiyatāya
analyzed: nipuṇaḥ saṅkhata dhammaḥ viya jarāya ajajjarita tāya ajajjaraḥ byādhi ādīhi apalokiya tāya
translated: He is looked at, as if he were looked at by disease, etc., owing to his not being looked at by them.

original: apalokitaṃ. Acakkhuviññāṇaviññeyyatāya anidassano. Atittikaraṭṭhena paṇīto. Apacuratāya
analyzed: apalokitam a cakkhu viññāṇa viññeyya tāya anidassanaḥ a tittika raṭṭhena paṇītaḥ apacura tāya
translated: He is not visible, as if he were not visible to eye-consciousness. He is sublime, as if he were a supreme bull because of his being the supreme bull.

original: acchariyo. Ītīhi anabhibhavanīyasabhāvattā, anītikabhāvahetuto ca anītikadhammo.
analyzed: ītīhi an abhibhavanīya sabhāva ttā anītika bhāva hetutaḥ ca anītika dhammo
translated: He is wonderful, as if he were not subject to the wonder of death owing to his not being subject to the wonder of death.

original: Vaṭṭadukkhamuttinimittatāya mutti. Saṃsāraṃ bhayato passantehi nilīyanīyato leṇaṃ.
analyzed: vaṭṭa dukkha mutti nimitta tāya mutti saṃsāram bhayataḥ passantehi nilīyanīyataḥ leṇam
translated: He is freedom, as if he were the cause of the freedom from the suffering of the round. He is a shelter, as if he were a shelter for those who see the fear in the round.🔽He is the supreme goal, as if he were the supreme goal for those same beings.

original: Tesaṃyeva parā gatīti parāyaṇo. Pakatiñāṇena aladdhapatiṭṭhatāya agādhaṭṭhena gambhīro.
analyzed: tesam yā iva parā gatī iti parāyaṇo pakati ñāṇena a laddha patiṭṭha tāya agādha ṭṭhena gambhīraḥ
translated: He is deep, as if he were unfathomable in his natural state.

original: Katapuññehipi dukkhena kicchena anubujjhitabbato duranubodho. Sacchikiriyaṃ muñcitvā
analyzed: kata puññehi pi dukkhena kicchena anubujjhitabbataḥ duranubodhaḥ sacchikiriyam muñcitvā
translated: He is hard to penetrate, as if he were hard to penetrate by those who have done merit with difficulty.

original: na takkañāṇena avacaritabboti atakkāvacaro. Buddhādīhi paṇḍiteheva veditabbato adhigantabbato
analyzed: na takka ñāṇena avacaritabbaḥ ti atakkāvacaraḥ buddha ādīhi paṇḍitehi iva veditabbataḥ adhigantabbataḥ
translated: He is not within the sphere of dialectic, as if he were not to be reached by the knowledge of mere dialectic, having abandoned the realization of it.🔽He is to be known by the wise, as if he were to be known by the wise, by the intelligent, by the sagacious.

original: paṇḍitavedanīyoti evamattho veditabbo.
analyzed: paṇḍita vedanīyaḥ ti evamatthaḥ veditabbo
translated: This is how the meaning should be understood.

original: Ariyasāvakasseva ijjhati sacchikiriyābhisamayavasena nibbānaguṇānaṃ pākaṭabhāvato.
analyzed: ariya sāvakassa iva ijjhati sacchikiriyā abhisamaya vasena nibbāna guṇānam pākaṭa bhāvato
translated: It succeeds for a noble disciple, because the special qualities of Nibbāna become evident to him through realization by direct-knowledge.

original: Aṭṭhāne cāyaṃ eva-saddo vutto, ijjhati evāti yojanā. Sukhasiddhivasena vā evaṃ vuttaṃ
analyzed: aṭṭhāne ca ayam eva saddo vuttaḥ ijjhati eva ati yojanā sukha siddhi vasena vā evam vuttam
translated: And the word “only” is used in the sense of “alone,” “it succeeds for him alone.” Or alternatively, it is said thus because of the ease of success.🔽“For a noble disciple”: that is why it is said, “Even though that is so, etc.”

original: “ariyasāvakassevā”ti. Tenevāha “evaṃ santepī”tiādi. Upasamagarukenāti nibbānaninnena.
analyzed: ariya sāvakassa iva āti tena iva āha evam sante pi itiādi upasama garukena ati nibbāna ninnena
translated: “With the foremost tranquillization”: with the foremost of tranquillizations, that is, with Nibbāna.🔽The special qualities of tranquillization mentioned above should be borne in mind.

original: Manasi kātabbā yathāvuttā upasamaguṇā. Sukhaṃ supatītiādīsu vattabbaṃ mettākathāyaṃ
analyzed: manasi kātabbā yathā vuttā upasama guṇā sukham supati iti ādīsu vattabbam mettākathā ayam
translated: What should be said about “he sleeps happily” and so on will be said in the Description of Loving-kindness .

original: āvi bhavissati. Paṇītādhimuttiko hoti nibbānādhimuttattā.
analyzed: āvi bhavissati paṇīta adhimuttikaḥ hoti nibbāna adhimutta ttā
translated: He is intent on the sublime, that is, on Nibbāna, because he is intent on Nibbāna.

original: Anussatikammaṭṭhānaniddesavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: anussati kammaṭṭhāna niddesa vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The commentary on the description of the meditation subject consisting in recollection of the Buddha is ended.

original: Iti aṭṭhamaparicchedavaṇṇanā.
analyzed: iti aṭṭhama pariccheda vaṇṇanā
translated: The commentary on the eighth chapter is ended.

original: 9. Brahmavihāraniddesavaṇṇanā
analyzed: brahmavihāra niddesa vaṇṇanā
translated: The description of the divine abidings

original: Mettābhāvanākathāvaṇṇanā🔽240. Mettaṃ brahmavihāraṃ. Bhāvetukāmenāti uppādetukāmena paccavekkhitabboti sambandho. Sukhanisinnenāti visamaṃ anisīditvā pallaṅkābhujanena sukhanisinnena.
analyzed: mettā bhāvanā kathā vaṇṇanā 🔽mettam brahmavihāram bhāvetu kāmena ati uppādetu kāmena paccavekkhitabbaḥ iti sambandhaḥ sukha nisinnena ati visamam a nisīditvā pallaṅka bhujanena sukha nisinnena
translated: The explanation of the development of loving-kindness🔽One who wants to develop the divine abiding of loving-kindness should go into solitary retreat and carefully reflect thus: “If I were to spend my time talking thoughtlessly, my mindfulness would be distracted from its object and my mind would be liable to become excited. But if I were to develop loving-kindness, my mindfulness would not be distracted from its object and my mind would not become excited.” So when he has thus seen the benefit in developing loving-kindness and the harm in developing any other meditation subject, he should go into solitary retreat and first of all form the mental image of one person, leaving out anyone towards whom he feels aversion, and arouse loving-kindness towards him in the way already described under the recollection of beings’ good deeds .

original: Kasmāti paccavekkhaṇāya kāraṇapucchā, aññaṃ adhigantukāmena aññattha ādīnavānisaṃsapaccavekkhaṇā🔽kimatthiyāti adhippāyo. Mettā nāma atthato adoso. Tathā hi adosaniddese “metti mettāyanā
analyzed: kasmā iti paccavekkhaṇāya kāraṇa pucchā aññam adhigantu kāmena aññattha ādīnava anisaṃsa paccavekkhaṇā  kim atthiyā ti adhippāyaḥ mettā nāma atthataḥ adoso tathā hi adosa niddese metti mettāyanā
translated: “Why?” is a question for a reason for reviewing. For one who wants to reach the other side, reviewing the danger and the benefit in the other way is the purpose.🔽“For what purpose?” is the purpose. “Loving kindness” is non-hate in meaning. For it is described in the description of non-hate thus “Loving kindness, loving, loving kindness” .

original: mettāyitatta”nti niddiṭṭhaṃ. Khantīti ca idha adhivāsanakkhanti adhippetā. Sā pana
analyzed: niddiṭṭham khantī iti ca idha adhivāsana khanti adhippetā sā pana
translated: And here “patience” is intended as the patience of endurance. But that

original: atthato adosappadhānā cattāro arūpakkhandhāti mettāya sijjhamānāya titikkhākhanti
analyzed: atthataḥ a dosa ppadhānā cattāro arūpa kkhandhā ati mettāya sijjhamānāya titikkhā khanti
translated: is non-hate as the predominance in meaning, and the four immaterial aggregates. So when loving kindness succeeds, the patience of endurance

original: siddhā eva hotīti āha “khanti adhigantabbā”ti. Tena khantiyaṃ ānisaṃsapaccavekkhaṇā
analyzed: siddhā eva hoti iti āha khanti adhigantabbā ti tena khantiyam ānisaṃsa paccavekkhaṇā
translated: succeeds too. That is why he said “patience should be reached.” He thereby shows that the reviewing of the benefit in patience is the purpose.

original: satthikāvāti dasseti. Abhibhūto pariyuṭṭhānena. Pariyādinnacitto kusaluppattiyā okāsālābhena.
analyzed: satthikā avāti dasseti abhibhūtaḥ pariyuṭṭhānena pariyādinna citto kusala uppattiyā okāsa alābhena
translated: “Overcome by anger” is overcome by anger that has arisen. “His mind is overcome and had no room” is that there is no opportunity for the arising of profitable ideas.

original: Ādīnavo daṭṭhabbo pāṇaghātādivasena diṭṭhadhammikasamparāyikādianatthamūlabhāvato.
analyzed: ādīnavaḥ daṭṭhabbo pāṇa ghāta ādi vasena diṭṭhadhammika samparāyika ādi anattha mūla bhāvato
translated: “The danger” is to be seen as the source of harm in the present life and in the life to come, and so on.

original: Khantī paramaṃ tapoti parāpakārasahanādikā titikkhalakkhaṇā khanti uttamaṃ tapo akattabbākaraṇakattabbakaraṇalakkhaṇāya🔽sammāpaṭipattiyā mūlabhāvato. Dosādipaṭipakkhavidhamanasamatthatāya🔽anīkabhūtena teneva ca khantibalena balānīkaṃ. Khantyā bhiyyo na vijjatīti attano🔽paresañca anatthapaṭibāhano, atthāvaho ca khantito uttari apassayo natthi.

translated: Patience is the army, the strength, the supreme blessing,

original: Vivecanatthāyāti vikkhambhanatthāya. Khantiyā saṃyojanatthāya attānanti adhippāyo.🔽Bhāvanaṃ dūsentīti dosā, puggalāyeva dosā puggaladosā. Yesu bhāvanā na sampajjati,

original: aññadatthu vipajjateva, te eva vuttā. Paṭhamanti vakkhamānena koṭṭhāsato koṭṭhāsantarupasaṃharaṇanayena vinā sabbapaṭhamaṃ.🔽Piyāyitabbo piyo, tappaṭipakkho appiyo. So saṅkhepato duvidho atthassa akārako, anatthassa
analyzed: añña datthu vipajjatā iva te eva vuttā paṭhamanti vakkhamānena koṭṭhāsataḥ koṭṭhāsa antar upasaṃharaṇa nayena vinā sabba paṭhamam  piyāyitabbaḥ piyaḥ tad paṭipakkhaḥ appiyaḥ so saṅkhepataḥ duvidhaḥ atthassa akārakaḥ anatthassa
translated: Or alternatively, it is the first in the sense of being the first to be reached by the method of inclusion of one part by another.🔽One who is dear is a “beloved,” and the opposite of that is an “unbeloved.” He is twofold in brief as one who does not do what is wanted and one who does what is not wanted.🔽Herein, the person who does what is not wanted by himself and by his loved ones and does what is wanted by his enemies should be regarded as an enemy.🔽But the person who does not do what is wanted by himself and by his loved ones and does what is wanted by his enemies should be regarded as an unloved person.

original: kārakoti. Tattha yo attano, piyassa ca anatthassa kārako, so veripuggalo daṭṭhabbo.🔽Yo pana attano, piyassa ca atthassa akārako, appiyassa ca atthassa kārako, “atthaṃ
analyzed: kārakaḥ ti tattha yaḥ attanaḥ piyassa ca anatthassa kārakaḥ saḥ veri puggalaḥ daṭṭhabbo  yaḥ pana attanaḥ piyassa ca atthassa akārakaḥ appiyassa ca atthassa kārakaḥ attham
translated: And the person who does what is wanted by himself and by his loved ones and does not do what is wanted by his enemies should be regarded as a loved person.🔽And the person who does not do what is wanted by himself and by his loved ones and does what is wanted by his enemies should be regarded as a neutral person.🔽And the person who does what is not wanted by himself and by his loved ones and does what is wanted by his enemies should be regarded as an enemy.🔽And the person who does what is not wanted by himself and by his loved ones and does what is wanted by his enemies should be regarded as an enemy.🔽And the person who does what is not wanted by himself and by his loved ones and does what is wanted by his enemies should be regarded as an enemy.

original: me nācarī”tiādinā, “appiyassa me amanāpassa atthaṃ acarī”tiādinā ca āghātavatthubhūto,🔽so appiyo, ananukūlavuttiko aniṭṭhoti attho. Liṅgavisabhāgeti itthiliṅgādinā liṅgena
analyzed: me na acari iti ādinā appiyassa me amanāpassa attham acari iti ādinā ca āghāta vatthu bhūtaḥ  so appiyaḥ an anukūla vuttikaḥ aniṭṭhaḥ ti attho liṅga visabhāge iti itthi liṅga ādinā liṅgena
translated: And the person who does what is not wanted by himself and by his loved ones and does what is wanted by his enemies should be regarded as an enemy.🔽And the person who does what is not wanted by himself and by his loved ones and does what is wanted by his enemies should be regarded as an enemy.🔽And the person who does what is not wanted by himself and by his loved ones and does what is wanted by his enemies should be regarded as an enemy.🔽And the person who does what is not wanted by himself and by his loved ones and does what is wanted by his enemies should be regarded as an enemy.

original: visadise. Odhisoti bhāgaso. “Tissa dattā”tiādinā odhisakanti attho.
analyzed: visadise odhiso ti bhāgaso tissa dattā atiādinā odhisakanti atthaḥ
translated: And the person who does what is not wanted by himself and by his loved ones and does what is wanted by his enemies should be regarded as an enemy.🔽And the person who does what is not wanted by himself and by his loved ones and does

original: Idāni yathāvuttesu chasu puggalesu abhāvetabbatāya kāraṇaṃ dassento “appiyaṃ hī”tiādimāha.
analyzed: idāni yathā vuttesu chasu puggalesu abhāvetabba tāya kāraṇam dassentaḥ appiyam hi iti ādim āha
translated: Now, in order to show the reason why the six kinds of persons mentioned should not be developed, he says: “For one tires in placing the unlovely in the place of the lovely, etc.”

original: Tattha appiyaṃ hi piyaṭṭhāne ṭhapento kilamatīti dosena bhāvanāya saparissayatamāha.
analyzed: tattha appiyam hi piya ṭṭhāne ṭhapento kilamati iti dosena bhāvanāya sa parissaya tam āha
translated: Herein, in placing the unlovely in the place of the lovely, one tires through hate, which is the greatest hindrance to development.

original: Appiyatā hi piyabhāvassa ujupaṭipakkhā, na ca tassa piyaṭṭhāne ṭhapanena vinā bhāvanā
analyzed: appiya tā hi piya bhāvassa uju paṭipakkhā na ca tassa piya ṭṭhāne ṭhapanena vinā bhāvanā
translated: For the unlovely is the direct opposite of the lovely, and development is not successful without placing the unlovely in the place of the lovely.

original: sijjhati. Atippiyasahāyakaṃ majjhattaṭṭhāne ṭhapento kilamatīti rāgena bhāvanāya🔽saparissayatamāha atippiyasahāyassa gehassitapemaṭṭhānabhāvato. Tenāha “appamattakepī”tiādi.
