analyzed: sijjhati atippiya sahāyakam majjhatta ṭṭhāne ṭhapento kilamati iti rāgena bhāvanāya  sa parissaya tam āha atippiya sahāyassa geha ssita pema ṭṭhāna bhāvato tena āha appamattake pi itiādi
translated: In placing a very dear friend in the place of the neutral, one tires through lust, which is the greatest hindrance to development.🔽For a very dear friend is the basis for the love called “attachment to a house” . That is why he said “even in a trifle” .🔽The neutral is neither lovely nor unlovely because of the neutrality of its nature as neither desirable nor undesirable.

original: Majjhattaṃ iṭṭhāniṭṭhatāhi majjhasabhāvaṃ neva piyaṃ nāppiyanti attho. Garuṭṭhāne
analyzed: majjhattam iṭṭha aniṭṭha tāhi majjha sabhāvam na iva piyam na appiyanti atthaḥ garuṭṭhāne
translated: In placing the neutral in the place of the lovely and the place of the unlovely, one tires because there is no respect for the neutral and no love for the lovely.🔽For there is no development in one who is indifferent, nor does the lovely appear lovely to him.

original: piyaṭṭhāne ca ṭhapento kilamati majjhatte sambhāvanīyapiyāyitabbatānaṃ abhāvā. Na🔽hi ajjhupekkhitabbe bhāvanīyatā, manāpatā vā paccupaṭṭhāti, piyagarubhāvasampanne
analyzed: piya ṭṭhāne ca ṭhapentaḥ kilamati majjhatte sambhāvanīya piyāyitabba tānam abhāvā na 🔽hi ajjhupekkhitabbe bhāvanīya tā manāpa tā vā paccupaṭṭhāti piya garu bhāva sampanne
translated: In placing the neutral in the place of the lovely and the place of the unlovely, one tires because there is no respect for the neutral and no love for the lovely.

original: ca paṭhamaṃ mettā bhāvetabbā. Kodho uppajjati koṭṭhāsantarabhāvānupanayanato.
analyzed: ca paṭhamam mettā bhāvetabbā kodhaḥ uppajjati koṭṭhāsa antara bhāva an upanayanato
translated: and he should first develop loving-kindness. Anger arises through the influence of the state of nearness to the object.

original: Tamevāti visabhāgaliṅgameva. Liṅgasabhāgeti avisesetvā “piyapuggale”ti āha. Bhittiyuddhamakāsīti
analyzed: tam eva ati visabhāga liṅgam eva liṅga sabhāga iti avisesetvā piya puggala iti āha bhitti yuddham akāsi iti
translated: “That same” : the object of the opposite sex. “The object of the opposite sex” : without specifying, he says “a dear person.” He made a hole in the wall.

original: sīlaṃ adhiṭṭhāya pihitadvāre gabbhe sayanapīṭhe nisīditvā mettaṃ bhāvento mettāmukhena🔽uppannarāgena andhīkato bhariyāya santikaṃ gantukāmo dvāraṃ asallakkhetvā bhittiṃ
analyzed: sīlam adhiṭṭhāya pihita dvāre gabbhe sayana pīṭhe nisīditvā mettam bhāventaḥ mettā mukhena  uppanna rāgena andhīkataḥ bhariyāya santikam gantu kāmaḥ dvāram a saṃlakkhetvā bhittim
translated: Having resolved upon virtue, he sat down on a bed in a room with the door closed and was developing loving-kindness.🔽Overwhelmed by lust that arose through the door of loving-kindness, he wanted to go to his wife. Without noticing the door,

original: bhinditvāpi nikkhamitukāmatāya bhittiṃ pahari. Tenāha “mettāyanāmukhena rāgo vañcetī”ti,
analyzed: bhinditvā api nikkhamitu kāma tāya bhittim tena āha mettāyanā mukhena rāgaḥ vañca iti iti
translated: he wanted to go out by breaking through the wall. Therefore it was said: “Lust deceives through the door of loving-kindness.”

original: “andhatamaṃ tadā hoti, yaṃ rāgo sahate nara”nti ca.
analyzed: andhatamam tadā hoti yam rāgaḥ sahate ca
translated: “When lust overcomes a man, then there is utter darkness” .

original: Ādānanikkhepaparicchinne addhāpaccuppannabhūte dharamānatāya paccakkhato viya upalabbhamāne
analyzed: ādāna nikkhepa paricchinne addhā paccuppanna bhūte dharamāna tāya paccakkhataḥ viya upalabbhamāne
translated: The aggregates that are limited by the act of grasping and the act of releasing, and that exist in the present, are perceived as if they were evident,

original: khandhappabandhe idha sattādiggahaṇaṃ, na tiyaddhagateti āha “kālakate panā”tiādi.
analyzed: khandha ppabandhe idha sattā ādi ggahaṇam na āha kālakate pana atiādi
translated: because they are present. The apprehension of “beings” here is in regard to the continuity of aggregates, not in regard to a being that is eternal. Therefore it was said: “But in the case of one who is dead” .

original: Kasmā pana kālakate mettābhāvanā na ijjhatīti? Mettābyāpārassa ayogyaṭṭhānabhāvato.🔽Na hi matapuggalo hitūpasaṃhārāraho. Yattha sati sambhave payogato hitūpasaṃhāro
analyzed: kasmā pana kālakate mettā bhāvanā na ijjhati iti mettā byāpārassa ayogya ṭṭhāna bhāvato  na hi mata puggalaḥ hitūpasaṃhāra arahaḥ yattha sati sambhave payogataḥ
translated: But why is it not successful when the person is dead? Because the object is not a fit one for the process of developing loving- kindness.

original: labbheyya, tattheva mānaso hitūpasaṃhāro yujjeyya. Dukkhāpanayanamodappavattīsupi
analyzed: labbheyya tattha iva mānasaḥ hitu upasaṃhāraḥ yujjeyya dukkha apanayana moda ppavattīsu pi
translated: For a dead person is not a fit object for the provision of helpful things. And where it is possible to provide helpful things by action, there it is proper to provide helpful things by thought.

original: eseva nayoti karuṇābhāvanādīnampi kālakate anijjhanaṃ vuttanti daṭṭhabbaṃ. Aññattha🔽paguṇamettājhāno ācariyassa kālakatabhāvaṃ ajānanto taṃ mettāya pharitukāmo “ācariyaṃ
analyzed: esā iva nayaḥ ti karuṇā bhāvanā ādīnam pi kālakate anijjhanam vuttanti daṭṭhabbam aññattha  ācariyassa kāla kata bhāvam a jānanto tam mettāya pharitu kāmaḥ ācariyam
translated: And the same method of explanation applies to the case of the other divine abidings beginning with compassion.

original: ārabbha mettaṃ ārabhatī”ti vutto. Tenāha “paguṇāva me mettājhānasamāpattī”ti. Nimittanti
analyzed: ārabbha mettam ārabhati iti vuttaḥ tena āha me mettā jhāna samāpatti iti nimittam ti
translated: The meditator who has reached mastery in the development of loving- kindness, not knowing that his teacher has died, and wanting to pervade him with loving-kindness, begins with the words, “May the venerable one be happy and secure,” and so on. That is why it is said, “When the person is dead, it is unsuccessful in one who has reached mastery in the development of the meditation subject.”🔽“Sign” is object.

original: ārammaṇaṃ. Gavesāhīti “yaṃ puggalaṃ uddissamettaṃ ārabhasi, so jīvati na jīvatī”ti
analyzed: ārammaṇam gavesāhi iti yam puggalam ārabhasi saḥ jīvati na jīvati iti
translated: “Seek” : find out whether the person for whose sake you began the loving-kindness is still alive or not.

original: jānāhīti attho. Mettāyantoti mettaṃ karonto, mettaṃ bhāventoti attho.
analyzed: jānāhi iti attho mettāyantaḥ ti mettam karontaḥ mettam bhāventaḥ iti attho
translated: “One who is practising loving-kindness” is one who is doing loving-kindness, who is developing loving-kindness.

original: 241. Attani bhāvanā nāma sakkhibhāvatthāti nānāvidhasukhānubandhaanavajjasukhaabyāsekasukhādi
analyzed: bhāvanā nāma nānāvidha sukha anubandha anavajja sukha a byāseka sukha ādi
translated: “In oneself” : the development of pleasure is the state of being a witness. The pleasure that is a consequence of various kinds of happiness, the pleasure of blamelessness, the pleasure of seclusion, etc.,

original: yaṃ attani upalabbhati, taṃ nidassento tassa vattamānatāya āha “ahaṃ sukhito homī”ti.🔽Sarīrasukhaṃ nāma anekantikaṃ, īdisassa puggalassa anokāsaṃ cittadukkhanti tadabhāvaṃ
analyzed: yam attani upalabbhati tam nidassento tassa vattamāna tāya āha aham sukhitaḥ homi iti  sarīra sukham nāma anekantikam īdisassa puggalassa anokāsam citta dukkhanti tad abhāvam
translated: is what is found in oneself. Pointing this out, he says “I am happy” in order to show its actuality.🔽“Bodily pleasure” is manifold. For such a person there is no opportunity for bodily pain. With reference to the absence of that, he says “or free from pain.” “I am” is the connection.

original: sandhāyāha “niddukkhoti vā”ti. Homīti sambandho. Tathā averotiādīsu, visesato ca
analyzed: sandhāya āha niddukkhaḥ ti vā ati homi iti sambandhaḥ tathā averaḥ ti ādīsu visesato ca
translated: Likewise, in the case of “free from hatred,” etc., and especially

original: dukkhābhāve sukhasaññā. Sā panāyaṃ niddukkhatā verīnaṃ puggalānaṃ verasaññitānaṃ
analyzed: dukkha abhāve sukha saññā sā pana ayam niddukkha tā verīnam puggalānam vera saññitānam
translated: in the case of the absence of pain, there is the perception of pleasure. But this absence of pain is due to the absence of persons who are enemies and of evil persons who have the perception of enmity,

original: pāpadhammānaṃ abhāvato, visesato byāpādavirahato īghasaññitāya ītiyā abhāvato, anavajjakāyikasukhasamaṅgitāya
analyzed: pāpa dhammānam abhāvataḥ visesataḥ byāpāda virahataḥ īgha saññi tāya ītiyāḥ abhāvataḥ anavajja kāyika sukha samaṅgi tāya
translated: and especially due to the absence of ill will, and due to the absence of the perception of contempt, which is a kind of contempt, and due to the possession of blameless bodily pleasure.

original: ca hotīti dassento āha “avero abyāpajjo anīgho sukhī”ti. Attānaṃ pariharāmīti evaṃbhūto
analyzed: ca hoti iti dassentaḥ āha a veraḥ a byāpajjaḥ anīghaḥ sukhī iti attānam pariharāmi iti evaṃbhūtaḥ
translated: Pointing this out, he says “free from hatred, free from ill will, unconstrained, happy.” “I maintain myself” : being such,

original: hutvā mama attabhāvaṃ pavattemi, yāpemīti attho.
analyzed: hutvā mama atta bhāvam pavattemi yāpemi iti attho
translated: I maintain my own being, I nourish it—this is the meaning.

original: Evaṃ sante yaṃ vibhaṅge vuttaṃ, taṃ virujjhatīti sambandho. Evaṃ santeti evaṃ sati,
analyzed: evam sante yam vibhaṅge vuttam tam virujjhati iti sambandhaḥ evam santā iti evam sati
translated: If that is so, then the statement in the Vibhaṅga is contradicted.🔽If that is so: if it is so, if it is the case that loving-kindness should be developed towards oneself as well.

original: yadi attanipi mettā bhāvetabbāti attho. “Yaṃ vibhaṅge vutta”nti vatvā vibhaṅgadesanāya
analyzed: yadi mettā bhāvetabbā ti atthaḥ yam vibhaṅge vuttanti vatvā vibhaṅga desanāya
translated: Having said, “The statement in the Vibhaṅga,” he quotes the sutta passage corresponding to the Vibhaṅga statement,

original: samānagatikaṃ suttapadaṃ āharanto “kathañca bhikkhū”tiādimāha. Tassattho parato āgamissati.
analyzed: samāna gatikam sutta padam āharantaḥ katham ca bhikkhu iti ādim āha tassa atthaḥ paratas āgamissati
translated: beginning, “And how, bhikkhus, does a bhikkhu dwell pervading one direction with his heart filled with loving- kindness? ” The meaning of that will emerge in the commentary.🔽That: the statement in the Vibhaṅga, etc.

original: Tanti vibhaṅgādīsu vacanaṃ. Appanāvasenāti appanāvahabhāvanāvasena. Idanti “ahaṃ🔽sukhito homī”tiādivacanaṃ. Sakkhibhāvavasenāti ahaṃ viya sabbe sattā attano sukhakāmā,
analyzed: tat ti vibhaṅga ādīsu vacanam appanā vasena ati appanā vaha bhāvanā vasena idam ti aham  sukhitaḥ homi iti ādi vacanam sakkhibhāva vasena ati aham viya sabbe sattāḥ attanaḥ sukha kāmā
translated: By the method of absorption: by the method of development that leads to absorption.🔽This: the statement beginning, “May all beings be happy and secure” .

original: tasmā tesu mayā attani viya sukhūpasaṃhāro kātabboti evaṃ tattha attānaṃ sakkhibhāve
analyzed: tasmā tesu mayā attani viya sukhu upasaṃhāraḥ kātabbaḥ ti evam tattha attānam sakkhibhāve
translated: By the method of realization: by the method of establishing oneself in the position of a realizer in the way beginning, “Just as I am happy and secure” .🔽That is why he said, “Even if he is only able to think … ” .

original: ṭhapanavasena. Tenāha “sacepi hī”tiādi. Kasmā pana attani bhāvanā appanāvahā na hotīti?
analyzed: ṭhapana vasena tena āha sace pi hi itiādi kasmā pana attani bhāvanā appanā āvahā na hoti iti
translated: But why is development in oneself not a method of absorption?

original: Attasinehavasena saparissayabhāvato. Koṭṭhāsantare pana bhāvitabhāvanassa tatthāpi
analyzed: atta sineha vasena sa parissaya bhāvato koṭṭhāsa antare pana bhāvita bhāvanassa tattha api
translated: Because of the presence of defilements due to affection for oneself. But in one who has developed it in the other three directions, it becomes a method of absorption even in oneself,

original: sīmasambhedo hotiyeva.
analyzed: sīma sambhedaḥ hotiyā iva
translated: The boundary is broken.

original: Sabbā disāti anavasesā dasapi disā. Anuparigamma cetasāti cittena pariyesanavasena
analyzed: sabbāḥ disā ati anavasesāḥ dasa api disāḥ anuparigamma cetasā ati cittena pariyesana vasena
translated: All directions: all the ten directions without exception. Having gone: having gone by way of searching with the mind.

original: anugantvā. Nevajjhagā piyataramattanā kvacīti sabbussāhena pariyesanto atisayena
analyzed: anugantvā piyatara mattanā kvaci iti sabbussāhena pariyesantaḥ atisayena
translated: Nowhere: having searched with the utmost searching.

original: attato piyataraṃ aññaṃ sattaṃ katthaci disāya neva adhigaccheyya na passeyya. Evaṃ🔽piyo puthu attā paresanti evaṃ kassaci attato piyatarassa anupalabbhanavasena puthu
analyzed: attataḥ piyataram aññam sattam katthaci disāya na iva adhigaccheyya na passeyya evam  piyaḥ puthu attā paresanti evam kassaci attataḥ piyatarassa an upalabbhana vasena puthu
translated: More dear than self: he would not find or see any being anywhere in any direction more dear than himself.🔽Thus: in this way.🔽Dear is each one’s self to others: thus, because of the non-apprehension of anyone dearer than oneself, each one’s self is dear to each one.

original: visuṃ visuṃ tesaṃ tesaṃ sattānaṃ attā piyo. Tasmā tena kāraṇena, attakāmo attano🔽hitasukhaṃ icchanto, paraṃ sattaṃ antamaso kunthakipillikampi, na hiṃse na haneyya,
analyzed: visum visum tesam tesam sattānam attā piyaḥ tasmā tena kāraṇena atta kāmaḥ  hita sukham icchantaḥ param sattam antamasaḥ na hiṃse na haneyya
translated: Therefore: for this reason.🔽One who desires his own good: one who wishes for his own welfare and happiness.

original: na viheṭheyyāti attho.
analyzed: na viheṭheyya ati attho
translated: Should not harm another: should not injure another, should not afflict another, is the meaning.

original: Ayaṃ nayoti sabbehi sattehi, attano ca piyatarabhāvaṃ nidassetvā tesu karuṇāyanaṃ
analyzed: ayam nayo ti sabbehi sattehi attano ca piyatara bhāvam nidassetvā tesu karuṇāyanam
translated: This is the method: having shown that each one’s self is dear to himself, he should look upon all beings with compassion.

original: vadatā bhagavatā sukhesitāya “attānaṃ sakkhibhāve ṭhapetvā sattesu mettā bhāvetabbā”ti
analyzed: vadatā bhagavatā sukhesitāya attānam sakkhibhāve ṭhapetvā sattesu mettā bhāvetabbā ti
translated: When the Blessed One had spoken thus, for the sake of the happiness of those who were listening, he established himself in the state of a witness and said: “Loving-kindness should be developed towards beings.”

original: mettābhāvanāya nayadassanaṃ katamevāti attho.
analyzed: mettā bhāvanāya naya dassanam katamā eva ati attho
translated: The meaning is: the method of developing loving-kindness should be seen.

original: 242. Sukhapavattanatthanti sukhena akicchena mettāya pavattanatthaṃ. Yvāssāti yo
analyzed: sukha pavattana attham ti sukhena akicchena mettāya pavattana attham
translated: For the sake of the occurrence of happiness: for the sake of the occurrence of loving-kindness with happiness, with ease.🔽Yo yo puggalo: whatever person, whatever yogin.

original: puggalo assa yogino. Piyoti iṭṭho. Manāpoti manavaḍḍhanako. Garūti guṇavisesavasena🔽garukātabbo. Bhāvanīyoti sambhāvetabbo. Ācariyamattoti sīlādinā ācariyappamāṇo. Piyavacanādīnīti
analyzed: puggalaḥ assa yoginaḥ piyaḥ ti iṭṭhaḥ manāpaḥ oti guṇa visesa vasena  garu kātabbaḥ bhāvanīyaḥ ti sambhāvetabbaḥ ācariya mattaḥ iti sīla ādinā ācariya ppamāṇaḥ piya vacana ādīni iti
translated: Piyo: dear. Manāpo: pleasing. Garu: to be respected by reason of his special qualities.

original: ādi-saddena atthacariyādike saṅgaṇhāti. Sīlasutādīnīti ādi-saddena saddhādike, dhutadhammajāgariyānuyogādike ca saṅgaṇhāti.🔽Kāmanti yuttappattakāritāsukhasiddhidīpanoyaṃ nipāto. Tenetaṃ dīpeti – tādisaṃ puggalaṃ
analyzed: ādi saddena attha cariyā ādike saṅgaṇhāti sīla suta ādīni iti ādi saddena saddhā ādike dhuta dhamma jāgariya anuyoga ādike ca saṅgaṇhāti  nipātaḥ tena itam dīpeti tādisam puggalam
translated: Bhāvanīyo: to be honoured. Ācariyamatto: equal to a teacher in virtue, etc. Piyavacanādīni: the word “etc.” includes helpfulness, etc. Sīlasutādīni: the word “etc.” includes faith, etc., and the practice of the ascetic practices, of wakefulness, etc.🔽Kāma: this is a particle that shows the accomplishment of the happiness of doing what is suitable.

original: uddissa bhāvanaṃ ārabhanto yogī yuttappattakārī, sukhena cassa tattha bhāvanā ijjhati,
analyzed: uddissa bhāvanam ārabhantaḥ yogī yuttappatta kārī sukhena ca ssa tattha bhāvanā ijjhati
translated: By it this is shown: when a yogin begins development with reference to such a person, he does what is suitable, and his development succeeds with happiness.

original: tena pana yoginā tāvatā santoso na kātabboti. Tenāha “appanā sampajjatī”tiādi. Sīmāsambhedanti🔽mariyādāpanayanaṃ, attā piyo majjhatto verīti vibhāgākaraṇanti attho. Tadanantaranti🔽tato piyamanāpagarubhāvanīyato, tattha vā mettādhigamato anantaraṃ. Atippiyasahāyake🔽mettā bhāvetabbāti sambandho, garuṭṭhānīye paṭiladdhaṃ mettāmanasikāraṃ atippiyasahāyake
analyzed: tena pana yoginā tāvatā santosaḥ na kātabbaḥ iti tena āha appanā sampajjati itiādi  mariyādā apanayanam attā piyaḥ majjhattaḥ verī iti vibhāga akaraṇanti  tatas tattha vā mettā adhigamataḥ anantaram ati piya sahāyake  mettā bhāvetabbā ti sambandhaḥ garu ṭhānīye paṭiladdham mettā manasikāram atippiya sahāyake
translated: But the meditator should not be satisfied with that much. Hence it is said, “Rapture arises” and so on.🔽The “division of the boundary” is the removal of the boundary, the meaning is, the making of the division “friend, neutral, enemy.”🔽Immediately after that:🔽immediately after the development of the dear and beloved person, or immediately after the attainment of loving-kindness towards him.🔽Towards a very dear friend:🔽the construction is: loving-kindness should be developed towards a very dear friend.🔽

original: upasaṃharitabbanti attho. Sukhūpasaṃhārakatassa taṃ hoti pageva paṭipakkhadhammānaṃ🔽vikkhambhitattā. Atippiyasahāyakato anantaraṃ majjhatte mettā bhāvetabbā majjhattaṃ🔽piyagaruṭṭhāne ṭhapetuṃ sukarabhāvato. “Atippiyasahāyakato”ti ca idaṃ purimāvatthaṃ🔽gahetvā vuttaṃ. Paguṇamanasikārādhigamato paṭṭhāya hissa sopi piyaṭṭhāne eva tiṭṭhati.
analyzed: upasaṃharitabbanti atthaḥ sukha upasaṃhāra katassa tat hoti pagā iva paṭipakkha dhammānam 🔽vikkhambhita ttā atippiya sahāyakato anantaram majjhatte mettā bhāvetabbā majjhattam 🔽piya garu ṭhāne ṭhapetum sukara bhāvataḥ atippiya sahāyaka tā iti ca idam purima avattham 🔽gahetvā vuttam paguṇa manasikāra adhigamataḥ paṭṭhāya hissa saḥ api piya ṭṭhāne eva tiṭṭhati
translated: But the meditator should not be satisfied with that much. Hence it is said: “absorption arises” and so on. “The defining of the boundaries” is the defining of the limits. The meaning is the making of a division, thinking: “Friend, neutral, foe.” “Immediately next to that” is immediately next to the surmounting of the state of being loved, dear, and so on. “In the case of a very dear friend” is the construction. The meaning is that the attention given to loving-kindness towards a person of high esteem should be extended to a very dear friend. For one who extends happiness to another finds it easy to suppress the opposing states. After the very dear friend, loving-kindness should be developed towards a neutral person because it is easy to place a neutral person in the position of one who is dear and loved. “In the case of a very dear friend” is said with reference to the previous section. For from the time that he has attained attention concerned with the person who is loved, he stands in the position of one who is dear and loved.

original: Majjhattato verīpuggaleti majjhattapuggale mettāyantena tattha paguṇamanasikārādhigamena🔽piyabhāvaṃ upasaṃharitvā tadanantaraṃ verīpuggalaṃ bhāvanāya majjhatte ṭhapetvā tato
analyzed: majjhattataḥ verī puggala iti majjhatta puggale mettāyantena tattha paguṇa manasikāra adhigamena  piya bhāvam upasaṃharitvā tad anantaram verī puggalam bhāvanāya majjhatte ṭhapetvā tatas
translated: In the case of a neutral person who is an enemy: by one who is developing loving-kindness towards a neutral person, after he has acquired the familiarization in the way already stated,🔽the neutral person is to be brought to mind as dear in the way already stated. Then, after he has set his mind on that neutral person in a neutral way through development,

original: majjhattato piyabhāvūpasaṃhārena verīpuggale mettā bhāvetabbā. “Verīpuggale”ti ca🔽idaṃ purimāvatthaṃ gahetvā vuttaṃ. Ekekasmiṃ koṭṭhāse muduṃ kammaniyaṃ cittaṃ katvāti
analyzed: majjhattataḥ piya bhāva upasaṃhārena verī puggale mettā bhāvetabbā verī puggala iti ca  idam purima avattham gahetvā vuttam ekekasmin koṭṭhāse mudum kammaniyam cittam katvā ati
translated: he should next develop loving-kindness towards the person who is an enemy by bringing the neutral person to mind as dear in the way already stated. And the words “in the case of a person who is an enemy”🔽are said by way of the first section. Having made his mind pliant and wieldy in each section: having first acquired the development of loving-kindness towards the four kinds of persons, that is to say,

original: piyagaruṭṭhānīyo, atippiyo, majjhatto, verīti catūsu puggalakoṭṭhāsesu paṭhamaṃ tāva🔽piyagaruṭṭhānīye mettābhāvanaṃ adhigantvā vasībhāvappattiyā tathāpavattaṃ cittaṃ🔽koṭṭhāsantarūpasaṃhāratthaṃ muduṃ kammaniyaṃ katvā tadanantaraṃ atippiyasahāye atippiyabhāvaṃ
analyzed: piya garu ṭhānīyaḥ atippiyaḥ majjhattaḥ verī iti catūsu puggala koṭṭhāsesu paṭhamam tāva  piya garu ṭhānīye mettā bhāvanam adhigantvā vasībhāva ppattiyā tathāpavattam cittam  koṭṭhāsanta rūpa saṃhāra attham mudum kammaniyam katvā tad anantaram atippiya sahāye atippiya bhāvam
translated: the person who is a source of danger and enmity, the very dear person, the neutral person, and the hostile person, by making the mind occur thus in each case in order to gain mastery,🔽and then having made the mind pliant and wieldy by removing the very dear person’s dearness and treating him as neutral, the development should be brought to fulfilment by him in the case of the very dear friend by making the mind rest in dearness alone,

original: vikkhambhetvā piyabhāvamatte cittaṃ ṭhapentena bhāvanā upasaṃharitabbā, tampi vasībhāvāpādanena
analyzed: vikkhambhetvā piya bhāva matte cittam ṭhapentena bhāvanā upasaṃharitabbā tam pi vasībhāva āpādanena
translated: and then in the case of the neutral person by making the mind rest in neutrality alone, and then in the case of the person who is a source of danger and enmity by making the mind rest in neutrality alone, and then in the case of the hostile person by making the mind rest in neutrality alone, and then in the case of all four kinds of persons by making the mind rest in neutrality alone,

original: muduṃ kammaniyaṃ katvā tadanantaraṃ majjhatte udāsinabhāvaṃ vikkhambhetvā piyabhāvaṃ
analyzed: mudum kammaniyam katvā tad anantaram majjhatte udāsina bhāvam vikkhambhetvā piya bhāvam
translated: and after that he should make it malleable and wieldy by abandoning the state of neutrality and indifference and arousing the state of dearness and loveliness in the enemy.

original: upaṭṭhapetvā bhāvanā upasaṃharitabbā, puna tampi vasībhāvāpādanena muduṃ kammaniyaṃ🔽katvā tadanantaraṃ verimhi verīsaññaṃ vikkhambhetvā majjhattabhāvūpaṭṭhapanamukhena
analyzed: upaṭṭhapetvā bhāvanā upasaṃharitabbā puna tam pi vasībhāva āpādanena mudum kammaniyam  katvā tad anantaram verimhi verī saññam vikkhambhetvā majjhatta bhāva upaṭṭhapana mukhena
translated: Then he should bring the development to its culmination by making that too malleable and wieldy by producing mastery in it.🔽After that he should bring the development to its culmination by abandoning the perception of the enemy in the neutral person and arousing the state of dearness and loveliness in him by producing the state of neutrality and indifference.

original: piyabhāvaṃ uppādentena bhāvanā upasaṃharitabbā. Tena vuttaṃ “tadanantare tadanantare
analyzed: piya bhāvam uppādentena bhāvanā upasaṃharitabbā tena vuttam tad anantare tad anantare
translated: That is why it is said that he should bring the development to its culmination in the neutral person next to the dear person and next to the enemy.

original: upasaṃharitabba”nti, jhānacittaṃ upanetabbaṃ uppādetabbanti attho.
analyzed: upasaṃharitabbanti jhāna cittam upanetabbam uppādetabbanti attho
translated: The meaning is that he should cause the jhāna consciousness to occur, to arise, in each case.

original: Verīpuggalo vā natthi kammabalena vā etarahi payogasampattiyā vā sabbaso anatthakarassa
analyzed: verī puggalaḥ vā natthi kamma balena vā etarahi payoga sampattiyā vā sabbaso anattha karassa
translated: There is no such person as an enemy, either because of the absence of any doer of harm in the ultimate sense or because of the absence of any doer of harm in the absolute sense.

original: abhāvato. Mahāpurisajātikattāti mahāpurisasabhāvattā cirakālaparicayasamiddhakhantimettānuddayādiguṇasampannatāya
analyzed: abhāvataḥ mahāpurisa jātikattā ati mahāpurisa sabhāvattā cira kāla paricaya samiddha khanti mettā anuddaya ādi guṇa sampanna tāya
translated: He has the nature of a Great Man: he has the nature of a magnanimous person, that is, the nature of one who is endowed with the qualities of patience, loving kindness, loving speech, loving deeds, and so on, which have been developed for a long time.

original: uḷārajjhāsayattāti attho. Tādiso hi sabbasaho parāparādhaṃ tiṇāyapi na maññati. Tena
analyzed: attho tādisaḥ hi sabbasahaḥ parāparādham na maññati tena
translated: The meaning is that he has a noble disposition. For such a person does not think even of grass as harmful to another.

original: vuttaṃ “anatthaṃ karontepi pare verīsaññāva nuppajjatī”ti. Tenāti tena yoginā. Atthi
analyzed: vuttam anattham karonte pi pare verī saññā ava nuppajjati iti tena ati tena yoginā atthi
translated: “By that”: by that meditator.

original: verīpuggaloti sambandho.
analyzed: verī puggalaḥ ti sambandho
translated: “There is an enemy person”: the construction is with this.

original: 243. Purimapuggalesūti piyādīsu jhānassa ārammaṇabhūtesu purimesu puggalesu. Mettaṃ
analyzed: purima puggalesu ti piya ādīsu jhānassa ārammaṇa bhūtesu purimesu puggalesu
translated: “In the case of the former persons”: in the case of the former persons who are objects of the jhāna, that is to say, the loved one, etc.

original: samāpajjitvāti paṭighaṃ vikkhambhetvā uppāditaṃ mettājhānaṃ samāpajjitvā. Mettāyantena🔽paṭighaṃ paṭivinodetabbanti ettha keci pana “upacārajjhānaṃ sampādetvā”ti atthaṃ
analyzed: samāpajjitvā ti paṭigham vikkhambhetvā uppāditam mettā jhānam samāpajjitvā mettāyantena  paṭigham paṭivinodetabbanti ettha keci pana upacāra jhānam sampādetvā ati attham
translated: “Having entered upon the jhāna of loving-kindness”: having entered upon the jhāna of loving-kindness, which is aroused by suppression of resentment.

original: vadanti, tesaṃ upacārajjhānato vuṭṭhānampi icchitabbaṃ siyā “vuṭṭhahitvā”ti vuttattā.🔽Pubbe tasmiṃ puggale asatiyā amanasikārena paṭighaṃ anuppādentassa sādhāraṇato taṃ🔽vikkhambhetvā jhānassa uppādanaṃ, samāpajjanañca vuttaṃ. Idāni pana taṃ anussarantassapi
analyzed: vadanti tesam upacāra jjhānataḥ vuṭṭhānam pi icchitabbam siyā vuṭṭhahitvā iti vutta ttā  pubbe tasmin puggale asatiyā amanasikārena paṭigham an uppādentassa sādhāraṇataḥ tam  vikkhambhetvā jhānassa uppādanam samāpajjanañca vuttam idāni pana tam anussarantassa api
translated: “The resentment should be dispelled by the current of loving-kindness”: here some people say that the meaning is “having reached access jhāna.” But in that case it would be necessary to admit that he comes out of the access jhāna, since it is said “having come out.”

original: manasi karontassapi yathā paṭighaṃ na uppajjati, taṃ vidhiṃ dassetuṃ idaṃ vuttaṃ
analyzed: manasi karontassa api yathā paṭigham na uppajjati tam vidhim dassetum idam vuttam
translated: What was said previously was that he should arouse the jhāna by suppressing resentment by non-attention to that person, who is not present, and that he should enter upon it. But now, in order to show the method by which resentment does not arise in him even when he does attend to him and recollect him, this is said:

original: “taṃ puggalaṃ mettāyantena paṭighaṃ vinodetabba”nti. Mettāyanameva hi idha paṭighavinodanaṃ
analyzed: tam puggalam mettāyantena paṭigham vinodetabbanti mettāyanam eva hi idha paṭigha vinodanam
translated: “The person who is full of loving-kindness should dispel resistance.” For it is only loving-kindness that is intended here as the dispelling of resistance.

original: adhippetaṃ. Na nibbātīti na vūpasammati.
analyzed: adhippetam na nibbāti iti na vūpasammati
translated: “Does not cool down”: does not subside.🔽“By following”: by pursuing; the meaning is, by reviewing.

original: Anusāratoti anugamanato, paccavekkhaṇatoti attho. Ghaṭitabbanti vāyamitabbaṃ.
analyzed: anusārataḥ ti anugamanataḥ paccavekkhaṇataḥ ti attho ghaṭitabbam ti vāyamitabbam
translated: “Should be applied”: should be exerted.

original: Tañca kho ghaṭanaṃ vāyamanaṃ. Iminā idāni vakkhamānena ākārena.
analyzed: tat ca kho ghaṭanam vāyamanam iminā idāni vakkhamānena ākārena
translated: And that application of exertion is now going to be stated in the following way.

original: Ubhato dvīsu ṭhānesu daṇḍo etassāti ubhatodaṇḍakaṃ, tena. Ocarakā lāmakācārā pāpapurisā.
analyzed: ubhatas dvīsu ṭhānesu daṇḍaḥ etassa ati ubhatodaṇḍakam tena ocarakāḥ lāmaka ācārāḥ pāpa purisāḥ
translated: “With a double staff”: with a staff on both sides; with a staff on each side, is the meaning. “Beggars”: wretched men of evil conduct.

original: Tatrāpīti tesupi aṅgamaṅgāni okkantesupi. Tenāti manopadosena. Na sāsanakaro. Sabbapāpassa🔽akaraṇaṃ hi sāsanaṃ. Tassevāti tatopi. Nissakke hi idaṃ sāmivacanaṃ, samuccaye ca
analyzed: tatra api iti tesu pi aṅgam aṅgāni okkantesu pi tena ati manaḥ upadosena na sāsana karo sabba pāpassa  akaraṇam hi sāsanam tassa iva āti tatas pi nissakke hi idam sāmi vacanam samuccaye ca
translated: “There too”: even when his limbs are cut off. “By that”: by the resentment. “Does not serve the True Ideal”: does not serve the Dispensation.🔽For the service of the Dispensation is the non-performance of any evil.🔽“By that too”: by that very thing. For this is a possessive expression with the ablative case ending in -to; and the word eva has the sense of samuccaye, “inclusive collection.” The meaning is: even when the man who is angry first has cut off the limbs of another.

original: eva-saddo, paṭhamaṃ kuddhapurisatopīti attho. Tenāti kujjhanena. Pāpiyoti pāpataro.
analyzed: eva saddo paṭhamam kuddha purisa to pi iti attho tena ati kujjhanena pāpiyaḥ iti pāpataraḥ
translated: “By that”: by the anger. “More evil”: more wicked.

original: Sārambhādikassa kilesānubandhassa vatthubhāvato kodhassa sāvajjataṃ ñatvāpi kujjhanato
analyzed: sa ārambha ādikassa kilesa anubandhassa vatthu bhāvataḥ kodhassa sāvajja tam ñatvā api kujjhanato
translated: Knowing that anger is blameworthy because it is the basis for the defilements beginning with resentment, he does not get angry even when there is ground for anger.

original: sace kodhe anavajjasaññī kuddhassa puggalassa na paṭikujjheyyāti keci. Ubhinnanti
analyzed: sace kodhe anavajja saññī kuddhassa puggalassa na paṭikujjheyya ati keci
translated: Some say that the phrase “if he does not get angry” should be taken to mean that he does not get angry with a person who is angry, thinking that anger is not blameworthy.🔽“Both”:

original: dvinnaṃ puggalānaṃ. Tenāha “attano ca parassa cā”ti. Atha vā ubhinnanti ubhayesaṃ
analyzed: dvinnam puggalānam tena āha attanaḥ ca parassa ca ati atha vā ubhinnam iti ubhayesam
translated: two persons. Hence it is said: “himself and another.” Or alternatively, “both” can refer to both worlds,

original: lokānaṃ, idhalokaparalokānanti attho.
analyzed: lokānam idhaloka paralokānam ti attho
translated: the world of men and the world beyond.

original: Sapattakantāti paṭisattūhi icchitā. Sapattakaraṇāti tehi kātabbā. Kodhananti kujjhanasīlaṃ.
analyzed: sa patta kantā ati paṭisattūhi icchitā sa patta karaṇā ati tehi kātabbā kodhanam ti kujjhana sīlam
translated: “Despised”: desired by adversaries. “To be despised”: to be done by them. “Angry”: having the habit of getting angry.

original: Kodhanāyanti kodhano ayaṃ, ayanti ca nipātamattaṃ. Kodhaparetoti kodhena anugato,
analyzed: kodhanāyanti kodhanaḥ ayam ayanti ca nipāta mattam kodha paretaḥ iti kodhena anugataḥ
translated: “Angry one”: this is a compound in which “aya” is a mere indeclinable. “Overcome by anger”: followed by anger,

original: parābhibhūto vā. Dubbaṇṇova hotīti pakatiyā vaṇṇavāpi alaṅkatapaṭiyattopi mukhavikārādivasena
analyzed: para abhibhūtaḥ vā dubbaṇṇaḥ uva hoti iti pakatiyā vaṇṇavā api alaṅkata paṭiyattaḥ api mukha vikāra ādi vasena
translated: or overcome by another. “Ugly”: even though he is naturally beautiful and well adorned, he becomes ugly by the change in his face, etc.,

original: virūpo eva hoti etarahi, āyatiṃ cāti. Kodhābhibhavassa ekantikamidaṃ phalanti dīpetuṃ
analyzed: virūpaḥ eva hoti etarahi āyatim ca ati kodha abhibhavassa ekantikam idam phalanti dīpetum
translated: both now and in the future. This is the invariable fruit of being overcome by anger.

original: “dubbaṇṇo vā”ti avadhāraṇaṃ katvā puna “kodhābhibhūto”ti vuttaṃ. Na pacuratthoti
analyzed: dubbaṇṇaḥ vā ti avadhāraṇam katvā puna kodha abhibhūto ti vuttam na pacurattho ti
translated: “Ugly” is a restrictive term. The rest is said in order to show the ugliness.

original: na pahūtadhano. Na bhogavāti upabhogaparibhogavatthurahito. Na yasavāti na kittimā.
analyzed: na pahūta dhanaḥ na bhogavāti upabhoga paribhoga vatthu rahitaḥ na yasavāti na kittimā
translated: He has no wealth: he is not rich. He has no property: he has no property to be used and enjoyed. He has no fame: he is not well known.

original: Chavālātanti chavadahanālātaṃ, citakāyaṃ santajjanummukkantipi vadanti. Ubhatopadittanti
analyzed: chava alātam chava dahana alātam vadanti
translated: The funeral pyre: the funeral pyre is called the “fire place” . The middle part: the middle part of the funeral pyre is called the “fire place” .

original: ubhosu koṭīsu daḍḍhaṃ. Majjhe gūthagatanti vemajjhaṭṭhāne sunakhassa vā siṅgālassa
analyzed: ubhosu koṭīsu daḍḍham majjhe gūtha gatanti vemajjha ṭṭhāne sunakhassa vā siṅgālassa
translated: Burnt at both ends: burnt at both ends. Smeared with dung in the middle: smeared in the middle with the dung of dogs or jackals.

original: vā uhadena gūthena makkhitaṃ. Kaṭṭhatthanti dārukiccaṃ. Neva pharati na sādheti.🔽Tathūpamāhanti tathūpamaṃ tādisaṃ ahaṃ. Imanti “so ca hoti abhijjhālū”tiādinā heṭṭhā
analyzed: vai uhadena gūthena makkhitam dāru kiccam na iva pharati na sādheti  tathūpama ahanti tathūpamam tādisam aham imanti saḥ ca hoti abhijjhālūti ādinā heṭṭhā
translated: For the sake of wood: for the sake of wood for building. He does not succeed: he does not succeed.

original: vuttaṃ sandhāya satthā vadati, tasmā kāmesu tibbasārāgatādinā sīlarahitanti adhippāyo.
analyzed: vuttam sandhāya satthā vadati tasmā kāmesu tibba sāra āgata ādinā sīla rahitanti adhippāyaḥ
translated: Such a one: such a one like that. This: the Teacher says this referring to what was said below beginning with “He is full of greed” . Therefore the meaning is: “he is devoid of virtue because of his intense attachment to sensual pleasures, etc.”

original: Idha pana byāpannacittaṃ paduṭṭhamanasaṅkappatāvasena yojetabbaṃ.
analyzed: idha pana byāpanna cittam paduṭṭha mana saṅkappa tā vasena yojetabbam
translated: But here the expression “his mind is expansive” should be understood as meaning “his mind is corrupted by evil thoughts.”

original: So dāni tvantiādi yathāvuttehi suttapadehi attano ovadanākāradassanaṃ.
analyzed: saḥ dāni tvanti ādi yathāvuttehi sutta padehi attano ovadana ākāra dassanam
translated: So dāni tvan ti ādi yathāvuttehi suttapadehi attano ovadanākāradassanam.

original: 244. Yo yo dhammoti kāyasamācārādīsu yo yo sucaritadhammo. Vūpasantoti saṃyato. Parisuddhoti
analyzed: yaḥ yaḥ dhammo ti kāya samācāra ādīsu yaḥ yaḥ su carita dhammo vūpasanto ti saṃyato parisuddho ti
translated: Yo yo dhammo ti kāyasamācārādīsu yo yo sucaritadhammo. Vūpasanto ti saṃyato. Parisuddho ti

original: kilesamalavigamena visuddho. Kilesadāhābhāvena vā upasanto, anavajjabhāvena parisuddho,
analyzed: kilesa mala vigamena visuddhaḥ kilesa dāha abhāvena vā upasantaḥ anavajja bhāvena parisuddhaḥ
translated: kilesamalavigamena visuddho. Kilesadāhābhāvena vā upasanto, anavajjabhāvena parisuddho,

original: kāyasamācārasseva upasamo cirakālaṃ saṃyatakāyakammatāya veditabbo. Evaṃ sesesupi.
analyzed: kāya samācārassa iva upasamaḥ cira kālam saṃyata kāya kamma tāya veditabbo evam sesesu pi
translated: kāyasamācārass’ eva upasamo cirakālaṃ saṃyatakāyakammatāya veditabbo. Evaṃ sesesupi.

original: Teti vacīmanosamācāre.
analyzed: tā iti vacī manaḥ samācāre
translated: Te ti vacīmanosamācāre.

original: Soti upasantavacīsamācāro puggalo. Paṭisanthārakusaloti yathā parehi chiddaṃ na hoti,
analyzed: saḥ ti upasanta vacī samācāraḥ puggalo paṭisanthāra kusalo ti yathā parehi chiddam na hoti
translated: So ti upasantavacīsamācāro puggalo. Paṭisanthārakusalo ti yathā parehi chiddaṃ na hoti,

original: evaṃ paṭisantharaṇe kusalo. Sakhiloti adhivāsanakhantisaṅkhātena sakhilabhāvena samannāgato.
analyzed: evam paṭisantharaṇe kusalo sakhilaḥ ti adhivāsana khanti saṅkhātena sakhila bhāvena samannāgataḥ
translated: evaṃ paṭisantharaṇe kusalo. Sakhilo ti adhivāsanakhantisaṅkhātena sakhilabhāvena samannāgato.

original: Sukhasambhāsoti piyakatho. Sammodakoti sammodanīyakathāya sammodanasīlo. Uttānamukhoti
analyzed: sukha sambhāsaḥ ti piya katho sammodako ti sammodanīya kathāya sammodana sīlo uttāna mukhaḥ iti
translated: Sukhasambhāso ti piyakatho. Sammodako ti sammodanīyakathāya sammodanasīlo. Uttānamukho ti

original: vikuṇitamukho ahutvā pītisomanassavasena vikasitamukho. Pubbabhāsīti yena kenaci
analyzed: vikuṇita mukhaḥ a hutvā pīti somanassa vasena vikasita mukhaḥ pubbabhāsi iti yena kenacid
translated: and his face was not drawn, but with joy and gladness it was blooming. Pubbabhāsīti by whomsoever

original: samāgato paṭisanthāravasena paṭhamaṃyeva ābhāsanasīlo. Madhurena sarena dhammaṃ osāreti🔽sarabhaññavasena. Sarabhāṇaṃ pana karonto parimaṇḍalehi paripuṇṇehi padehi ca byañjanehi
analyzed: samāgataḥ paṭisanthāra vasena ābhāsana sīlo madhurena sarena dhammam osāreti  sarabhañña vasena sarabhāṇam pana karontaḥ parimaṇḍalehi paripuṇṇehi padehi ca byañjanehi
translated: and his face was not drawn but blossomed with the happiness of rapture. He was a first speaker: he was one who, when he met anyone, was the first to greet him with a friendly word. He spoke Dhamma with a sweet voice: he spoke Dhamma with a voice that was melodious,🔽pleasing, and so on. He was a good speaker: he gave a talk on the Dhamma with words that were rounded,

original: ca abyākulehi dhammakathaṃ katheti.
analyzed: ca a byākulehi dhamma katham katheti
translated: complete, pure, and unfaltering.

original: Sabbajanassa pākaṭo sakkaccakiriyāyāti adhippāyo. Tenāha “yo hī”tiādi. Okappetvāti
analyzed: sabba janassa pākaṭaḥ sakkacca kiriyāya ati adhippāyaḥ tena āha yaḥ hi itiādi okappetvā iti
translated: The meaning is that he was well known to all people because of his respectful behaviour. Hence he said, “For one who is respected,” and so on.🔽Having had confidence: having had faith. For faith has the characteristic of confidence.

original: saddahitvā. Okappanalakkhaṇā hi saddhā. Ohitasototi avahitasoto, sussusantoti attho.
analyzed: saddahitvā okappana lakkhaṇā hi saddhā ohita soto ti avahita soto sussusanto ti attho
translated: With ear-element directed: with ear-element collected, the meaning is, with ear-element focused.

original: Aṭṭhiṃkatvā atthaṃ katvā, atthiko vā hutvā.
analyzed: aṭṭhiṃkatvā attham katvā atthikaḥ vā hutvā
translated: Having made the meaning clear: having made the meaning plain.

original: “Ekopi na vūpasanto hotī”ti pāṭho, evarūpo puggalo nirayato nirayaṃ upapajjanto bahukālaṃ
analyzed: ekaḥ api na vūpasantaḥ hoti iti pāṭhaḥ evarūpaḥ puggalaḥ nirayataḥ nirayam upapajjantaḥ bahukālam
translated: The reading is “not one who is not satisfied,” and the meaning is that such a person, being reborn from hell to hell,

original: tattheva saṃsaratīti dassetuṃ “aṭṭhamahānirayasoḷasaussadanirayaparipūrako bhavissatī”ti
analyzed: tattha iva saṃsarati iti dassetum aṭṭha mahāniraya soḷasa ussada niraya paripūrakaḥ bhavissati iti
translated: wanders there for a long time. In order to show this, the commentary says, “he will fill up the eight great hells and the sixteen adjacent hells.”

original: vuttaṃ. Tattha sañjīvādayo aṭṭha mahānirayā. Avīcimahānirayassa dvāre dvāre cattāro
analyzed: vuttam tattha sañjīva ādayaḥ aṭṭha mahānirayāḥ avīci mahānirayassa dvāre dvāre cattāro
translated: This has been said. Herein, the Sañjīva, etc., are the eight great hells. At the gates of the Avīci Great Hell there are four🔽

original: cattāro katvā kukkuḷādayo soḷasa ussadanirayā. Kāruññaṃ upaṭṭhapetabbaṃ mahādukkhabhāgibhāvato.
analyzed: cattāro katvā kukkuḷa ādayaḥ soḷasa ussada nirayā kāruññam upaṭṭhapetabbam mahā dukkha bhāgi bhāvato
translated: “This has been said” . Herein, the eight great hells beginning with Sañjīva are the great hells. The sixteen adjacent hells beginning with Kukkula are the adjacent hells, being placed at the gates of the Avīci great hell. “He should establish … compassion” for the sake of the great suffering they undergo.

original: Yasmiṃ puggale avihesābhūtā dukkhāpanayanakāmatā upatiṭṭhati, tattha paṭigho anokāsovāti
analyzed: yasmin puggale a vihesa bhūtā dukkha apanayana kāma tā upatiṭṭhati tattha paṭighaḥ anokāsaḥ uvāti
translated: When non-ill-will, which is the desire to remove suffering, is established in a person, resentment has no opportunity.

original: āha “kāruññampi paṭicca āghāto vūpasammatī”ti.
analyzed: āha kāruññam pi paṭicca āghāto vūpasammati iti
translated: That is why it is said, “Resentment ceases with compassion as condition” .

original: Imassa ca atthassāti “yo yo dhammo”tiādinā vuttassa atthassa.
analyzed: imassa ca atthassa ati yaḥ yaḥ dhammo ti ādinā vuttassa atthassa
translated: “The meaning of this” : the meaning of what is stated in the passage beginning, “Whatever states are … ” .

original: 245. Yaṃ verī dukkhāpetuṃ sakkoti, so tassa vasena “attano visaye”ti vutto bhikkhuno
analyzed: yam verī dukkhāpetum sakkoti saḥ tassa vasena attanaḥ visaye ti vuttaḥ bhikkhuno
translated: “The enemy’s” : the bhikkhu’s. “Own domain” : the domain of the enemy, in the sense that the enemy is able to inflict suffering there.

original: kāyo. Kinti kiṃ kāraṇaṃ. Tassāti verino. Avisayeti dukkhaṃ uppādetuṃ asakkuṇeyyatāya
analyzed: kāyaḥ kinti kim kāraṇam tassa ati verino a visayā iti dukkham uppādetum a sakkuṇeyya tāya
translated: “Why? ” : for what reason? “The enemy” : the bhikkhu. “In a domain that is not his own” : because he is unable to produce suffering there.

original: agocare. Sacitteti attano citte. Mahānatthakaranti idhalokatthaparalokatthaparamatthānaṃ
analyzed: agocare sa citta iti citte idha lokattha para lokattha parama tthānam
translated: “In his own mind” : in his own consciousness. “A great harm” : a harm to the good of this world, the good of the other world, and the supreme good.

original: virādhanavasena mahato vipulassa, nānāvidhassa ca diṭṭhadhammikādibhedassa anatthassa
analyzed: virādhana vasena mahataḥ vipulassa nānāvidhassa ca diṭṭhadhammika ādi bhedassa anatthassa
translated: It is the cause of great, extensive, and various kinds of harm in this life, etc.

original: kāraṇaṃ. Mūlanikantananti sīlassa mūlāni nāma hirottappakhantimettānuddayā, tesaṃ
analyzed: kāraṇam mūla nikantananti sīlassa mūlāni nāma hira uttappa khanti mettā anuddayā tesam
translated: “Cutting the roots” means cutting the roots of virtue, which are shame, compunction, patience, loving kindness, and harmlessness.

original: chindanaṃ. Kodho hi uppajjamānova pāṇātipātādivasena hirottappādīni ucchindati. Jaḷoti andhabālo.
analyzed: chindanam kodhaḥ hi uppajjamānaḥ iva pāṇa atipāta ādi vasena hirā uttappa ādīni ucchindati andha bālaḥ
translated: For when anger arises, it cuts off these . “Foolish” means blind and ignorant.

original: Anariyaṃ kammanti verinā katamahāparādhamāha. Yo sayanti yo tvaṃ sayampi. Dosetukāmoti🔽kodhaṃ uppādetukāmo. Yadi kari yadi akāsi. Dosuppādenāti dosassa uppādanena. Dukkhaṃ
analyzed: anariyam tvam sayampi dosa etu kāmaḥ iti  kodham uppādetu kāmaḥ yadi kari yadi akāsi dos uppādena ati dosassa uppādanena dukkham
translated: “A base deed” is a great offense committed by an enemy. “If you sleep” means if you sleep even though you should be angry.

original: tassa ca nāmāti dukkhañca nāma tassa aparādhakassa. Nāmāti asambhāvane nipāto, tena🔽tassa kāraṇaṃ anekantikanti dasseti. Tenāha “kāhasi vā na vā”ti, karissasi na vā
analyzed: tassa ca nāma ati dukkham ca nāma tassa aparādhakassa nāma ati asambhāvane nipātaḥ tena  tassa kāraṇam anekantikanti dasseti tena āha kā ahasi vā na vā ati karissasi na vā
translated: “If you do not sleep” means if you do not sleep even though you should be angry. “If you do” means if you do or do not do it. “If you do not do” means if you do not do it. “The arising of anger” means the arising of anger. “The suffering”🔽means the suffering of the offender. “Name” is a particle of contempt, by which he shows that the reason is uncertain.

original: karissasīti attho. Ahitaṃ magganti attano ahitāvahaṃ duggatimaggaṃ.
analyzed: karissasi iti attho ahitam magganti attanaḥ ahita āvaham duggati maggam
translated: Therefore he says, “Whether you do or not,” meaning whether you will do it or not. “The path of harm” is the path to an unhappy destination that brings about one’s own harm.

original: Aṭṭhāneti doso tava appiyassa kārāpako, sattu pana tassa vasavattitāya dāsasadisoti🔽aṭṭhānaṃ paccāpakiriyāya. Tasmā tameva dosaṃ chindassu ucchinda. Khaṇikattāti udayavayaparicchinno
analyzed: aṭṭhāne ti doso tava appiyassa kārāpako sattu pana tassa vasa vatti tāya dāsa sadisaḥ ti  aṭṭhānam pacca apakiriyāya tasmai tam eva dosam chindassu ucchinda khaṇikattā ati udaya vaya paricchinno
translated: “It is not right,” means: anger is your own enemy, it is the doer of what is unloved, but the enemy is like a slave to you because of your subjection to him.🔽Therefore, cut off that very anger, destroy it. “Because of momentariness” means: they have a moment, that is to say, the time of their occurrence which is limited by arising and dissolution.

original: attano pavattikālasaṅkhāto khaṇo etesaṃ atthīti khaṇikā, tabbhāvato khaṇapabhaṅgubhāvatoti🔽attho. Kassa dānīdha kujjhasīti aparādhakassa santāne yehi khandhehi te aparādho
analyzed: attano pavatti kāla saṅkhāto khaṇaḥ etesam atthi iti khaṇikā tad bhāvataḥ khaṇa pabhaṅgu bhāvato ti  attho kassa dānīdha kujjhasi iti aparādhakassa santāne yehi khandhehi te aparādhaḥ
translated: They are momentary because of that, because of the state of being broken up into moments.

original: kato, te taṃkhaṇaṃyeva sabbaso niruddhā. Idāni pana aññe tiṭṭhantīti kassa tvaṃ idha🔽kujjhasi. Na hi yuttaṃ anaparādhesu kujjhananti adhippāyo. Taṃ vinā kassa so kareti🔽yo puggalo yassa dukkhaṃ karoti, taṃ dukkhakiriyāya visayabhūtaṃ puggalaṃ vinā kassa
analyzed: kato te sabbasas niruddhāḥ idāni pana aññe tiṭṭhanti iti kassa tvam idha  kujjhasi na hi yuttam anaparādhesu adhippāyaḥ tam vinā kassa saḥ kareti  yaḥ puggalaḥ yassa dukkham karoti tam dukkha kiriyāya visaya bhūtam puggalam vinā kassa
translated: “Now, whom do you get angry with here?” means: in the continuum of the offender, by means of which aggregates the offence was committed, they have ceased completely at that very moment. Now, others remain. Whom do you get angry with here?🔽For it is not proper to get angry with those who are not offenders. This is the purport. “Without him, whose does he do it?” means: without the person who is the object of the action of suffering, whose suffering does that doer of suffering do?

original: nāma so dukkhakārako dukkhaṃ kare kareyya. Sayampi dukkhahetu tvamitīti evaṃ sayampi
analyzed: nāma saḥ dukkha kārakaḥ dukkham kare kareyya sayam pi dukkha hetu tvam iti iti evam sayam pi
translated: He should do it to himself, too, because of the cause of suffering.

original: tvaṃ etassa dukkhassa hetu, evaṃ samāne tassa tuyhañca tassa dukkhassa hetubhāve
analyzed: tvam etassa dukkhassa hetu evam samāne tassa tuyhan ca tassa dukkhassa hetu bhāve
translated: You are the cause of this suffering. So, when there is equality between you and him as causes of suffering,

original: kiṃ kāraṇā tassa kujjhasi na tuyhanti attho.🔽246. Paralokepi anugāmibhāvato kammaṃyeva sakaṃ santakaṃ etesanti kammassakā, tesaṃ
analyzed: kim kāraṇā tassa kujjhasi na attho  para loke pi anugāmi bhāvato kammaṃya iva sakam santakam etesan ti kammassakā tesam
translated: why do you get angry with him and not with yourself?🔽Kamma is one’s own, since it alone follows one into the next world.

original: bhāvo kammassakatā. Paccavekkhaṇā nāma nisedhanatthā, nisedhanañca bhāvino kammassāti
analyzed: bhāvaḥ kammassaka tā paccavekkhaṇā nāma nisedhana tthā nisedhanam ca bhāvino kammassa ati
translated: The state of that is kammassakatā. The reflection is for the purpose of restraint, and restraint is of future kamma.

original: āha “yaṃ kammaṃ karissasī”ti. Paṭighavasena pana pavattakammaṃ pākaṭabhāvato āsannaṃ,🔽paccakkhañcāti āha “idañcā”ti. Ca-saddo byatireke, so tassa kammassa phalanissandena
analyzed: āha yam kammam karissasi iti paṭigha vasena pana pavatta kammam pākaṭa bhāvataḥ āsannam  paccakkham ca iti āha idam ca ati casaddaḥ byatireke so tassa kammassa phala nissandena
translated: Therefore it is said: “Whatever kamma you will do.” But kamma that occurs through resistance is near because it is manifest and evident.

original: “neva sammāsambodhi”ntiādinā byatirekato vuccamānamevatthaṃ joteti. Neva samatthanti
analyzed: na iva sammāsambodhi nti ādinā byatirekataḥ vuccamānam evattham na iva samattha nti
translated: Therefore it is said: “and this.” The word “and” has the sense of “but.” That kamma is not able to give the fruit of the result of that kamma,🔽either in this world or in the next, either in heaven or in hell.🔽The meaning is: “It is not able to give the result of that kamma either in this world or in the next, either in heaven or in hell.”

original: sambandho. Niraye niyuttaṃ, jātanti vā nerayikaṃ. Attānaṃyeva okirati dosarajenāti adhippāyo.
analyzed: sambandhaḥ niraye niyuttam jātanti vā nerayikam attānaṃ yeva okirati dosa rajena ati adhippāyaḥ
translated: It is bound for hell, or it is born in hell. The intention is: “One only besprinkles oneself with the dust of hate.”

original: 247. Satthu pubbacariyaguṇā paccavekkhitabbā, satthu gāravenāpi paṭighaṃ vūpasameyyāti.
analyzed: satthu pubba cariya guṇā paccavekkhitabbā satthu gāravena api paṭigham vūpasameyya
translated: The virtue of the Master’s previous lives should be reviewed, and resentment can be quelled by respect for the Master.

original: Bodhisattopi samāno nanu te satthā cittaṃ nappadūsesi, pageva abhisambuddhoti adhippāyo.
analyzed: bodhisattaḥ api samānaḥ nanu te satthā cittam na ppadūsesi pagā iva abhisambuddhaḥ ti adhippāyaḥ
translated: The intention is this: “When he was a Bodhisatta, did not your Master spare your life? How much more so when he was fully enlightened?”

original: Deviyā paduṭṭhenāti deviyā saddhiṃ padubbhinā micchācāravasena aparaddhena. Yattha🔽susāne chavasarīraṃ chaḍḍīyati, taṃ āmakasusānaṃ. Nikhaññamānoti nikhaṇiyamāno. Purisakāraṃ🔽katvāti āvāṭato nikkhamanatthāya bāhubalena purisakāraṃ katvā. Yakkhānubhāvenāti
analyzed: deviyā paduṭṭhena ati deviyā saddhim padubbhinā micchā ācāra vasena aparaddhena yattha  susāne chava sarīram chaḍḍīyati tam āmaka susānam nikhaññamānaḥ ati nikhaṇiyamānaḥ purisakāram  katvā iti āvāṭataḥ nikkhamana atthāya bāhu balena purisakāram katvā yakkha anubhāvena ati
translated: With the queen’s resentment: with the queen’s resentment, with the offence committed by the misbehaviour. Where

original: aḍḍavinicchayena ārādhitacittassa yakkhassa ānubhāvena. Sirigabbhanti vāsāgāre.
analyzed: aḍḍa vinicchayena ārādhita cittassa yakkhassa ānubhāvena sirigabbhanti vāsāgāre
translated: a dead body is thrown out in a charnel ground, that is a charnel ground. Was being buried: was being buried. Having made an effort: having made an effort with the strength of his arms to get out of the pit. By the yakkha’s power: by the power of the yakkha whose mind had been satisfied by his self-sacrifice. The pavilion of fame: the dwelling house.

original: Āsīsethevāti yathādhippete atthe ñāyato anavajjato āsaṃ kareyya. Na nibbindeyyāti
analyzed: āsīsetha iva ati yathā adhippete atthe ñāyataḥ an avajjataḥ āsam kareyya na nibbindeyya ati
translated: He should hope: he should hope for the desired object in the way approved by conscience and without blame. He should not despair:

original: “evaṃ kicchāpannassa me kuto sotthibhāvo”ti na nibbindeyya. Vuttañhi “āpadāsu kho,
analyzed: evam kicchā āpannassa me kutas sotthi bhāvaḥ ti na nibbindeyya vuttam hi āpadāsu kho
translated: he should not despair, thinking “How can I be safe when I have got into such trouble?” For this is said: “In the case of misfortune

original: mahārāja, thāmo veditabbo”ti. Yathā icchinti yena pakārena kassaci pīḷaṃ akatvā rajje
analyzed: mahā rāja thāmaḥ veditabbaḥ uti yathā yena pakārena kassaci pīḷam a katvā rajje
translated: “Great king, the ‘test’ should be understood.”

original: patiṭṭhitaṃ attānaṃ icchiṃ, tathā ahaṃ ahunti passāmi. Voti hi nipātamattaṃ.
analyzed: patiṭṭhitam attānam icchim tathā aham passāmi vo ti hi nipāta mattam
translated: As I desired, in the way I desired, without causing suffering to anyone, I see that I have been established in the kingdom. Vo is merely a particle.

original: Kāsiraññāti kalābunā kāsirājena. Sakaṇṭakāhīti ayakaṇṭakehi sakaṇṭakāhi.
analyzed: kāsiraññā ati kalābunā kāsirājena sa kaṇṭakāhi iti ayakaṇṭakehi sa kaṇṭakāhi
translated: The king of Kāsi means the king of Kāsi with the Kalābu branch. With its thorns means with thorns.

original: Mahallakoti vuddho vayoanuppatto. Rujjhantīti nirujjhanti.
analyzed: mahallakaḥ iti vuddhaḥ vayaḥ anuppatto rujjhanti iti nirujjhanti
translated: Great means old, having reached old age. They cease means they stop.

original: Cittapariggaṇhanakāloti visevanaṃ kātuṃ adatvā cittassa sammadeva damanakālo.
analyzed: citta pariggaṇhana kālaḥ iti visevanam kātum a datvā cittassa sammadeva damana kālaḥ
translated: The time for the mind to be restrained means the time for the mind to be properly tamed without giving rise to indulgence.

original: Puthusallenāti vipulena sallena. Nāgoti hatthināgo. Vadhīti vijjhi, māresīti vā attho.
analyzed: puthu sallena ati vipulena sallena nāgaḥ ti hatthi nāgaḥ vadhi iti vijjhi māresi iti vā attho
translated: With a great arrow means with a large arrow. Elephant means a tusker. He killed means he pierced, or the meaning is he destroyed.

original: Imaṃ ṭhānaṃ āgantvā mayi evaṃ karaṇaṃ nāma na tava vasena hoti, tasmā kassa vā rañño,
analyzed: imam ṭhānam āgantvā mayi evam karaṇam nāma na tava vasena hoti tasmā kassa vā rañño
translated: Having come to this place, this doing to me is not due to your will, therefore whose king,

original: rājamattassa vā ayaṃ payogo uyyojanāti attho.
analyzed: rāja mattassa vai ayam payogaḥ uyyojanā ati atthaḥ
translated: or whose royal order is this use, this dispatch?

original: Chabbaṇṇarasmīti nīlapītalohitādivasena chabbaṇṇamayūkhā. Chabbaṇṇakiraṇavantadantatāya hi te hatthī “chaddantā”ti vuccanti, na chaddantavantatāya.
analyzed: chabbaṇṇa rasmi iti nīla pīta lohita ādi vasena chabbaṇṇa mayūkhā chabbaṇṇa kiraṇavanta danta tāya hi te hatthī chaddantā ati vuccanti na chaddantavanta tāya
translated: “Six-coloured rays” : the six colours blue, yellow, red, etc. , in the form of rays. For the elephants are called “six-tusked” because they have six-coloured rays in their tusks, not because they have six tusks.

original: Chātoti jighacchito. Khādeyyāti khādeyyaṃ, ayameva vā pāṭho. Āhitoti suhito. Sambalanti
analyzed: chāto iti khādeyyam ati khādeyyam ayam eva vā pāṭhaḥ āhitaḥ iti su hitaḥ
translated: “Hungry” : hungry, desirous of food. “To eat” : to be eaten; or this is the reading. “Satisfied” : well-fed. “With gruel” :

original: maggāhāraṃ. Taṃ pana yasmā upacārena pathassa hitanti vuccati, tasmā “pātheyya”ntipi
analyzed: magga āhāram tam pana yasmai upacārena pathassa hitanti vuccati tasmai
translated: with the food of the path. But since that is called “good for the path” by way of approximation, therefore it is also said “pātheyya” .

original: vuttaṃ. “Mittadubbhī vatāyaṃ andhabālo”ti kāruññena assupuṇṇehi nettehi taṃ purisaṃ udikkhamāno.🔽Mā ayyosi me bhadanteti ettha māti nipātamattaṃ, māti vā paṭikkhepo, tena upari tena🔽kātabbaṃ vippakāraṃ paṭisedheti. Ayyo meti ayyirako tvaṃ mama atithibhāvato. Bhadanteti
analyzed: vuttam mitta dubbhī vata ayam andha bālaḥ ti kāruññena assu puṇṇehi nettehi tam purisam udikkhamāno  mā ayyā asi me bhadanta iti ettha mā ati nipāta mattam mā ati vā paṭikkhepaḥ tena upari tena  kātabbam vippakāram paṭisedha iti ayyaḥ mā iti tvam mama atithi bhāvataḥ bhadanta iti
translated: looking at the man with eyes filled with tears out of compassion, saying, “This blind fool has deceived me.”

original: piyasamudācāro. Tvaṃ nāmetādisaṃ karīti tvampi evarūpaṃ akāsi nāma.
analyzed: piya samudācāraḥ tvam nāma etādisam kari iti tvam pi evarūpam nāma
translated: “Don’t be angry with me, venerable sir” : here mā is merely a particle, or mā is a prohibition. By that he prohibits the displeasure that should be done to him above. “Venerable sir” : you are a venerable sir to me by reason of your being a guest. “Bhadantē” : this is a mode of address to a dear one. “You have done such a thing” : you have done such a thing.

original: Tiracchānabhūtopi pana mahākapi hutvā khemantabhūmiṃ sampāpesīti yojanā.🔽Peḷāya pakkhipantepīti khuddakāya peḷāya pādehi koṭetvā pakkhipantepi. Maddantepīti dubbalabhāvakaraṇatthaṃ nānappakārehi maddantepi. Alampāneti evaṃnāmake ahituṇḍike.
analyzed: tiracchāna bhūtaḥ api pana mahā kapi hutvā khemanta bhūmim sampāpesi iti yojanā  peḷāya pakkhipante iti khuddakāya peḷāya pādehi koṭetvā pakkhipante ipi maddante ipi iti dubbala bhāva karaṇa ttham nānappakārehi maddante ipi alampāne iti evaṃnāmake ahituṇḍike
translated: But the interpretation is that he even brought the Khemantabhūmi to perfection as a great monkey in the animal realm.🔽Even if they put him in a basket and carried him on their feet, even if they beat him in various ways in order to weaken him, even if they did so with a snake-charmer’s magic called “alampāta,”

original: Pītaṃ vāti ettha vā-saddo avuttatthavikappe, tena odātamañjiṭṭhādiṃ avuttaṃ saṅgaṇhāti.
analyzed: pītam vā ti ettha vā saddaḥ a vutta attha vikappe tena odāta mañjiṭṭha ādim a vuttam saṅgaṇhāti
translated: “Even if they make him yellow” : the word “even if” has the function of including what is not stated, namely, “white, pink, etc.,”

original: Cittānuvattantoti cittaṃ anuvattanto. Homi cintitasannibho evamayaṃ bahulābhaṃ labhatūti.
analyzed: citta anuvattanto ti cittam anuvattantaḥ homi cintita sannibhaḥ evam ayam bahu lābham labhatu iti
translated: “Conforming to his mind” : conforming to his mind, “I will be like what he thinks, and so may he get much gain.”

original: Ānubhāvena pana thalaṃ kareyya udakaṃ…pe… chārikaṃ kare. Evaṃ pana yadi cittavasī
analyzed: ānubhāvena pana thalam kareyya uda kaṃpe chārikam kare evam pana yadi
translated: But by his power he could have made the water into land … and made it into embers. But if he were to do this, if he were to have power over his mind,

original: hessaṃ…pe… uttamattho na sijjhatīti tadā attanā tattha diṭṭhaṃ ādīnavaṃ dasseti bhagavā.
analyzed: uttamatthaḥ na sijjhati iti tadā attanā tattha diṭṭham ādīnavam dasseti bhagavā
translated: then the highest good would not be accomplished. So the Blessed One shows the danger he saw in that.

original: Tattha uttamatthoti buddhabhāvamāha. Bhojaputtehīti luddaputtehi.
analyzed: tattha uttama atthaḥ iti buddha bhāvam āha bhoja puttehi iti ludda puttehi
translated: Herein, the highest good is the state of a Buddha. “By the hunters” is by the hunters’ sons.

original: Aḷārāti yena sayaṃ tadā luddahatthato mocito, taṃ satthavāhaṃ nāmena ālapati. Atikassāti
analyzed: aḷārā ati yena sayam tadā ludda hatthataḥ mocitaḥ tam satthavāham nāmena ālapati atikassa ati
translated: Aḷāra: he addresses the caravan-leader by name, by whom he was then rescued from the hands of the brigands. Atikassati🔽by pulling the rope that went through his nose. Samparigayhāti

original: nāsāya āvutarajjuṃ ākaḍḍhitvā. Samparigayhāti kāḷavettalatādīhi sabbaso pariggahetvā,
analyzed: nāsāya āvuta rajjum ākaḍḍhitvā samparigayhāti kāḷa vetta latā ādīhi sabbaso pariggahetvā
translated: by completely surrounding him with black-wood creepers, etc.

original: acchariyāni dussahānaṃ sahanavasenāti adhippāyo.
analyzed: acchariyāni dussahānam sahana vasena ati adhippāyaḥ
translated: The meaning intended is: “because of the ability to endure the most difficult things, the most amazing things.”

original: Ativiya ayuttaṃ appatirūpaṃ paṭighacittuppādanena kenaci appaṭisamakhantiguṇassa satthusāsanāvokkamanappasaṅgato.
analyzed: ativiya ayuttam appatirūpam paṭigha citta uppādanena kenaci appaṭisama khanti guṇassa satthu sāsana avokkamana ppasaṅgato
translated: It is most improper, most unbecoming, for anyone to transgress the Teacher’s Dispensation, which is endowed with the quality of being the most excellent by the absence of resentment, by the arising of a thought of resentment.

original: 248. “Anamataggoyaṃ, bhikkhave, saṃsāro”tiādinā āgatāni suttapadāni anamataggasaddo, tadattho vā etesanti anamataggiyāni.
analyzed: anamataggoyam bhikkhave saṃsāraḥ ti ādinā āgatāni sutta padāni anamatagga saddo tad atthaḥ vā etesanti anamataggiyāni
translated: The sutta passages that occur beginning with the words “Bhikkhus, this round of births is without discoverable beginning” are called “the statements about the beginningless cycle of births.”

original: Ajehi gamanamaggo ajapatho. Saṅkū laggāpetvā te ālambitvā gamanamaggo saṅkupatho.
analyzed: ajehi gamana maggo aja pathaḥ saṅkū laggāpetvā te ālambitvā gamana maggo saṅku pathaḥ
translated: The path of the goats is the path by which goats go. The path of the thorns is the path by which one goes after having had thorns stuck into one’s feet.

original: Saṅkūti aṅkusākārena katadīghadaṇḍo vuccati. Ādi-saddena papātamaggaduggamaggādike
analyzed: aṅkusa ākārena kata dīgha daṇḍaḥ vuccati ādi saddena papāta magga dugga magga ādike
translated: A goad is called a saṅku. The word ādi is used to include the paths of the precipice and the path of the difficult passage.

original: saṅgaṇhāti. Ubhatobyūḷheti sampahāratthaṃ dvīhipi pakkhehi gāḷhasannāhe. Aññāni ca
analyzed: saṅgaṇhāti ubhatobyūḷhā iti sampahāra attham dvīhi pi pakkhehi gāḷha sannāhe aññāni ca
translated: he gathers them. ‘Both sides’ means both sides of the yoke-tie for the purpose of yoking together. And other

original: dukkarāni karitvā dhanāsāya pabbatavidugganadīviduggādipakkhandanavasenāti adhippāyo.
analyzed: dukkarāni karitvā dhanāsāya pabbata vidugga nadī vidugga ādi pakkhandana vasena ati adhippāyaḥ
translated: difficult things, such as crossing mountains, difficult rivers, etc., for the sake of wealth.

original: Maṃ posesi, upakāraṃ akāsi, tatra nappatirūpaṃ manaṃ padūsetunti evaṃ cittaṃ uppādetabbanti🔽sambandho. Evaṃ cittuppādanañca etarahi dissamānena puttādīnaṃ posanādinā atītassa
analyzed: mam posesi upakāram akāsi tatra na patirūpam manam padūsetunti evam cittam uppādetabbanti  sambandhaḥ evam citta uppādanam ca etarahi dissamānena putta ādīnam posana ādinā atītassa
translated: He nourished me, he did me a service, it is not proper for me to defile my mind there.’ Thus the mind should be aroused.🔽This is the construction. And the arousing of the mind in this way should be understood as the taking of the past by way of inference, in accordance with what is seen at present

original: anumānato gahaṇavasena veditabbaṃ.
analyzed: anumānataḥ gahaṇa vasena veditabbam
translated: of the nourishing, etc., of sons, etc.

original: 249. Mettāyāti mettāsaṅkhātāya, mettāsahitāya vā. Cetovimuttiyāti cittasamādhāne.🔽Āsevitāyāti ādarena sevitāya. Bhāvitāyāti vaḍḍhitāya. Bahulīkatāyāti punappunaṃ katāya.
analyzed: mettāya ati mettā saṅkhātāya mettā sahitāya vā cetaḥ vimuttiyā ati citta samādhāne  āsevitāya ati ādarena sevitāya bhāvitāya ati vaḍḍhitāya bahulīkatāya ati punappunam katāya
translated: ‘With loving-kindness’: with what is called loving-kindness, or associated with loving-kindness. ‘With deliverance of mind’: with concentration of mind.🔽‘Cultivated’: cultivated with devotion. ‘Developed’: increased. ‘Brought to maturity’: made to arise again and again.

original: Yānīkatāyāti yuttayānaṃ viya katāya. Vatthukatāyāti adhiṭṭhānavatthuṃ viya katāya.
analyzed: yānīkatāya ati yutta yānam viya katāya vatthukatāya ati adhiṭṭhāna vatthum viya katāya
translated: ‘Made the vehicle’: made the vehicle as though it were a vehicle. ‘Made the bed’: made the object of resolve.

original: Anuṭṭhitāyāti adhiṭṭhitāya. Paricitāyāti pariciṇṇāya ciṇṇavasībhāvāya. Susamāraddhāyāti
analyzed: anuṭṭhitāya ati adhiṭṭhitāya paricitāya ati pariciṇṇāya ciṇṇavasībhāvāya su samāraddhāya ati
translated: “Not developed”: not undertaken. “Not practiced”: not practiced, not brought to mastery.

original: suṭṭhu sampāditāya. Pāṭikaṅkhāti icchitabbā avassaṃbhāvino. Sesaṃ parato āgamissati.
analyzed: suṭṭhu sampāditāya pāṭikaṅkhā ati icchitabbā avassaṃbhāvino sesam paratas āgamissati
translated: ‘Not developed’ means not resolved. ‘Not consolidated’ means not consolidated by consolidation, not brought under control. ‘Not well undertaken’ means not well accomplished. ‘To be expected’ means to be desired, to be hoped for. The rest will come in later.

original: 250. Dhātuvinibbhogoti sasambhārasaṅkhepādinā dhātūnaṃ vinibbhujanaṃ. Aparādho nāma
analyzed: dhātu vinibbhogaḥ iti sa sambhāra saṅkhepa ādinā vinibbhujanam aparādhaḥ nāma
translated: ‘The analysis of the elements’: the analysis of the elements by way of the ‘aggregate of material form’ and so on. ‘Fault’:

original: aparajjhantassa puggalassa rūpadhammamukhena gayhatīti katvā āha “kiṃ kesānaṃ kujjhasī”tiādi,
analyzed: aparajjhantassa puggalassa rūpa dhamma mukhena gayhati iti katvā āha kim kesānam kujjhasi itiādi
translated: since it is said that one who is angry is seized by the material form of the person he is angry with, it is said: “Why are you angry with the hair?”

original: kesādivinimuttassa aparajjhanakassa puggalassa abhāvato. Idāni nibbattitaparamatthadhammavaseneva
analyzed: kesa ādi vinimuttassa aparajjhanakassa puggalassa abhāvataḥ idāni nibbattita paramattha dhamma vasena iva
translated: and so on, because there is no person who is angry with the hair and so on, who is separate from the hair and so on. Now, in order to show the method of analysis by way of the ultimate realities that have been produced,🔽‘Or else, taking the five aggregates … taking the twelve bases’

original: vinibbhogavidhiṃ dassetuṃ “atha vā panā”tiādi vuttaṃ. Pañcakkhandhe upādāya, dvādasāyatanāni🔽upādāyāti paccekaṃ upādāya-saddo yojetabbo. Kodhassa patiṭṭhānaṭṭhānaṃ na hotīti
analyzed: vinibbhoga vidhim dassetum atha vā pana atiādi vuttam pañca kkhandhe upādāya dvādasa āyatanāni 🔽upādāya ati paccekam upādāya saddaḥ yojetabbo kodhassa patiṭṭhāna ṭhānam na hoti iti
translated: the word ‘taking’ should be construed with each. ‘Anger has no footing’:

original: yathā āragge sāsapassa, ākāse ca cittakammassa patiṭṭhānaṭṭhānaṃ natthi, evamassa
analyzed: yathā āragge sāsapassa ākāse ca citta kammassa patiṭṭhāna ṭṭhānam natthi evam assa
translated: Just as there is no footing for a mustard seed on the point of an awl or for a palm leaf in the sky, so too,

original: “verī”ti parikappite puggale kodhassa patiṭṭhānaṭṭhānaṃ na hoti, kesādīnaṃ akujjhitabbato,
analyzed: verī iti parikappite puggale kodhassa patiṭṭhāna ṭṭhānam na hoti kesa ādīnam a kujjhitabbato
translated: there is no footing for anger in a person who is conceived of as an enemy. Because the hair of the head, etc., are not to be blamed,

original: tabbinimuttassa ca puggalassa abhāvato.
analyzed: tad vinimuttassa ca puggalassa abhāvato
translated: and because there is no person who is not bound up with these.

original: 251. Saṃvibhāgoti āmisasaṃvibhāgo. Parassāti paccatthikassa. Bhinnājīvoti aparisuddhājīvo.
analyzed: saṃvibhāgaḥ ti āmisa saṃvibhāgaḥ parassa ati paccatthikassa bhinna ājīvaḥ ti aparisuddha ājīvaḥ
translated: “Sharing” is sharing of material things. “With others” means with an enemy. “With a mixed livelihood” means with an impure livelihood.

original: Tassevaṃ karototi evaṃ saṃvibhāgaṃ karontassa tassa dāyakassa. Itarassāti paṭiggāhakassa.
analyzed: tassa ivam karoto ti evam saṃvibhāgam karontassa tassa dāyakassa itarassa ati paṭiggāhakassa
translated: “To the one who does this” means to the giver who does this sharing. “To the other” means to the receiver.

original: “Mama mātarā upāsikāya dinno”ti idaṃ “dhammiyalābho”ti etassa kāraṇavacanaṃ. Tena
analyzed: mama mātarā upāsikāya dinnaḥ ti idam dhammiya lābhaḥ ti etassa kāraṇa vacanam tena
translated: “Given by my mother, the lay devotee” is a reason for the statement “it is a legitimate gain.”

original: pana tassa āgamanasuddhiṃ dasseti.🔽Sabbatthasādhakanti “attattho parattho diṭṭhadhammiko attho samparāyiko attho”ti
analyzed: pana tassa āgamana suddhim dasseti  sabba ttha sādhakam ti atta tthaḥ para tthaḥ diṭṭhadhammikaḥ attho samparāyikaḥ attho ti
translated: By this he shows the purity of his coming.🔽“Satisfying in every way”: it produces all kinds of benefits, all kinds of welfare, all kinds of aims, such as one’s own benefit, others’ benefit, benefit visible in this very life, and benefit in the life to come.

original: evamādīnaṃ sabbesaṃ atthānaṃ, hitānaṃ, payojanānañca nipphādakaṃ. Unnamanti dāyakā.
analyzed: evamādīnam sabbesam atthānam hitānam payojanānam ca nipphādakam unnamanti dāyakāḥ
translated: The givers are elated.

original: Namanti paṭiggāhakā.
analyzed: namanti paṭiggāhakā
translated: The receivers bow down.

original: 252. Evanti yathāvuttehi kakacūpamovādānussaraṇādīhi attano ovadanākārehi. Vūpasantapaṭighassāti🔽paṭisaṅkhānabalena vinoditāghātassa. Tasmimpīti verīpuggalepi. Verī-gahaṇeneva cettha🔽appiyapuggalassāpi gahaṇaṃ daṭṭhabbaṃ verimhi mettāya siddhāya tasmimpi mettāsiddhito,
analyzed: evam ti yathā vuttehi ka kacca upama uvāda anussaraṇa ādīhi attanaḥ ovadana ākārehi vūpasanta paṭighassa ati  paṭisaṅkhāna balena vinodita āghātassa tasmim pi iti verī puggale pi verī gahaṇena iva ca ittha  appiya puggalassa api gahaṇam daṭṭhabbam verimhi mettāya siddhāya tasmim pi mettā siddhito
translated: ‘Thus’: in the way already described, with the similes of the stick, the counsel, the recollection, and so on, which are the ways of giving counsel to oneself. ‘With resistance stilled’🔽means with resentment abolished by the power of reflection. ‘In him too’: in the enemy. And here the ‘enemy’ should be regarded as the ‘unbeloved person’ too,

original: piyato pana atippiyasahāyakassa visuṃ gahaṇaṃ āsannapaccatthikassa dubbinimocayabhāvadassanatthaṃ.
analyzed: piyataḥ pana atippiya sahāyakassa visum gahaṇam āsanna paccatthikassa dubbinimocaya bhāva dassana attham
translated: because when loving-kindness towards the enemy is accomplished, it is also accomplished towards the beloved, and the ‘beloved’ is mentioned separately from the ‘unbeloved’ in order to show that it is easier to deliver those who are well disposed than those who are hostile.

original: Mettāvasenāti mettāyanavasena. Samacittatanti hitūpasaṃhārena samānacittataṃ. Sīmāsambhedo
analyzed: mettā vasena ati mettāyana vasena hitu upasaṃhārena sīmā sambhedaḥ
translated: ‘By the method of loving-kindness’: by the method of loving-kindness loving. ‘With a mind that is impartial’: with a mind that is the same through being intent on their welfare. ‘The boundary is reached’

original: sā eva samacittatā. Imasmiṃ puggaleti mettākammaṭṭhānikapuggale. Nisinneti bhāvenabhāvalakkhaṇe bhummaṃ.
analyzed: sā eva sama citta tā imasmin puggala iti mettā kammaṭṭhānika puggale nisinnā iti bhāvena bhāva lakkhaṇe bhummam
translated: means that same impartiality. ‘In this person’: in the person who is a subject of meditation for the development of loving- kindness. ‘Is seated’: the present participle is used in the sense of the past partciple.

original: Hitamajjhatteti piye, majjhatte ca. Catubbidheti catubbidhe jane, yattha katthacīti
analyzed: hita majjhattā iti piye majjhatte ca catubbidhā iti catubbidhe jane yattha katthaci iti
translated: ‘In the beloved and the unbeloved’: in the four kinds of persons.

original: adhippāyo. Nānattanti piyamajjhattādinānākaraṇaṃ. Hitacittova pāṇinanti kevalaṃ sattesu
analyzed: adhippāyaḥ nānattanti piya majjhatta ādi nānākaraṇam hita cittaḥ uva kevalam sattesu
translated: “The intention” is the intention to kill. “The variety” is the variety of beings, such as dear ones, neutral persons, and enemies. “With a mind of good will” means with a mind of loving-kindness.

original: hitacitto evāti pavuccati, na pana “mettāya nikāmalābhī”ti vā “kusalī”ti vā pavuccati.
analyzed: hita cittaḥ eva ati pavuccati na pana mettāya nikāma lābhī iti vā kusalī iti vā pavuccati
translated: “The intention” is the intention of loving-kindness. “The various kinds” are the various kinds of beings, such as dear, neutral, and hostile ones. “He is called one who has the thought of loving-kindness for all beings” is said not because he is “one who has attained loving-kindness at will” or “one who is skilled” in it.

original: Kasmā? Yasmā attādīsu passati nānattanti. Kasmā panāyaṃ hitacitto kusalīti na vuccatīti?
analyzed: kasmai yasmai atta ādīsu passati nānattanti kasmai pana ayam hita citto kusalī iti na vuccati iti
translated: Why is this? Because he sees diversity in self and so on. But why is he not called “one who is skilled” in it?

original: Sātisayassa kusalassa vasena kusalibhāvassa adhippetattā. Imassa ca puggalassa mettābhāvanā
analyzed: sa atisayassa kusalassa vasena kusali bhāvassa adhippeta ttā imassa ca puggalassa mettā bhāvanā
translated: Because one who is skilled is intended here in the sense of one who has attained to a high degree of skill. And this person’s development of loving-kindness

original: na visesavatī. Atha vā na nikāmalābhī mettāya yato attādīsu passati nānattaṃ. Kusalīti
analyzed: na visesavatī atha vā na nikāma lābhī mettāya yatas atta ādīsu passati nānattam kusalī iti
translated: is not distinguished. Or else, he is not called “one who is skilled” in it because he has not attained loving-kindness at will, since he sees diversity in self and so on. He is called “one who has the thought of loving-kindness for all beings”

original: pavuccati, yasmā hitacittova pāṇinanti evamettha attho daṭṭhabbo. Gāmasīmādayo viya
analyzed: pavuccati yasmai hita cittaḥ iva evam ettha atthaḥ daṭṭhabbaḥ gāma sīmā ādayaḥ viya
translated: because he has the thought of loving-kindness for all beings. This is how the meaning should be regarded here. Just as the boundaries of a village, etc.,

original: gāmantarādīhi sattasaṅkhāte mettāvisaye bhāvanāya pubbe aññamaññaṃ asaṃkiṇṇamariyādārūpena
analyzed: gāmantara ādīhi satta saṅkhāte mettā visaye bhāvanāya pubbe aññam aññam asaṃkiṇṇam ariyādā rūpena
translated: are not mixed up with each other, so too, in the case of the person who develops loving-kindness, his loving-kindness is not mixed up with the other three, since he does not arouse loving-kindness towards beings included in the other directions.

original: ṭhitattā attādayo idha sīmā nāmāti āha “catasso sīmāyo”ti. Sambhinnā hontīti ettha
analyzed: ṭhita ttāḥ atta ādayaḥ idha sīmā nāma ati āha catasso sīmāyo ti sambhinnāḥ honti iti ettha
translated: The self, etc., are called “boundaries” here because they are stood upon. So he said “four boundaries.”🔽As to “they are broken up”:🔽the “breaking up” mentioned there is shown by the words “He pervades with loving- kindness. ”

original: vuttaṃ sambhedaṃ dassetuṃ “samaṃ pharati mettāyā”tiādi vuttaṃ. Mahāvisesoti mahanto
analyzed: vuttam sambhedam dassetum samam pharati mettāya atiādi vuttam mahā visesaḥ ti mahantaḥ
translated: “Great distinction” is a great special quality of development.🔽“The former” is the one who sees the diversity of self, etc., as former.

original: bhāvanāya viseso atisayo. Purimena purimato attādinānattadassinā. Na nāyatīti na ñāyati.🔽253. Nimittanti yathā kasiṇakammaṭṭhānādīsu taṃtaṃkasiṇamaṇḍalādipariggahamukhena
analyzed: bhāvanāya visesaḥ atisayaḥ purimena purimataḥ na na  nimittam ti yathā kasiṇa kammaṭṭhāna ādīsu taṃ taṃ kasiṇa maṇḍala ādi pariggaha mukhena
translated: “He does not go” : he is not known.

original: bhāvanāvasena laddhaṃ uggahanimittaṃ nissāya jhānassa gocarabhāvena paṭibhāganimittaṃ
analyzed: bhāvanā vasena laddham uggaha nimittam nissāya jhānassa gocara bhāvena paṭibhāga nimittam
translated: “Sign” : in the kasiṇa meditations, etc., the counterpart sign of the jhāna is established as the object by means of development, depending on the learning sign acquired by apprehending the kasiṇa, etc., as a circle, etc.,🔽but here there is no such sign established as a sign in that way.

original: upatiṭṭhati, na evamidha upaṭṭhitaṃ nimittaṃ nāma atthi. Yo panāyaṃ yathāvutto sīmāsambhedo🔽laddho, sveva nimittaṃ viyāti nimittaṃ. Tasmiṃ hi laddhe bhāvanāya sātisayattā nīvaraṇāni
analyzed: upatiṭṭhati na evam idha upaṭṭhitam nimittam nāma atthi yaḥ pana ayam yathā vutto sīmā sambhedo  laddhaḥ u sva iva nimittam viyāti nimittam tasmin hi laddhe bhāvanāya nīvaraṇāni
translated: But the “sign” is the “breaking up of the boundaries” mentioned in the way already stated.

original: vikkhambhitāneva honti, kilesā sannisinnāva, upacārasamādhinā cittaṃ samāhitameva.
analyzed: vikkhambhitānā eva honti kilesāḥ upacāra samādhinā cittam samāhitam eva
translated: For when that is acquired, the hindrances are quite suppressed, the defilements subside, and the mind becomes concentrated in access concentration, because of the special qualities of the development.

original: Tenāha “nimittañca upacārañca laddhaṃ hotī”ti. Tameva nimittanti sīmāsambhedavasena
analyzed: tena āha nimittam ca upacāram ca laddham hoti iti tam eva sīmā sambheda vasena
translated: The same sign: the sign of serenity occurring as the delimitation of the sign.

original: pavattasamathanimittaṃ. Appakasireneva akiccheneva, pageva paripanthassa visodhitattā.🔽Ettāvatāti ettakena bhāvanānuyogena. Anena yoginā. Pañcaṅgavippahīnantiādīnaṃ padānaṃ attho heṭṭhā vutto eva.
analyzed: pavatta samatha nimittam appa kasirena iva akicchena iva pagā iva paripanthassa visodhita ttā  ettāvatā iti ettakena bhāvanā anuyogena anena yoginā pañcaṅga vippahīna nti ādīnam padānam atthaḥ heṭṭhā vuttaḥ eva
