translated: With little trouble: with little difficulty, with no trouble at all, because the hindrances have been quite cleared away.🔽To that extent: to that extent with the devotion of the meditation subject.🔽By that yogin: the meaning of the terms “with five factors abandoned” and so on has already been given .

original: “Paṭhamajjhānādīnaṃ aññataravasenā”ti idaṃ vakkhamānāya vikubbanāya tesaṃ sādhāraṇatāya
analyzed: paṭhama jhāna ādīnam aññatara vasena ati idam vakkhamānāya vikubbanāya tesam sādhāraṇa tāya
translated: By means of one of the first five jhānas: this is said because the kinds of supernormal power are common to all the first five jhānas.

original: vuttaṃ. Appanāppattacittasseva na upacāramattalābhino. Paguṇabalavabhāvāpādanena
analyzed: vuttam appanā appatta cittassa iva na upacāra matta lābhinaḥ paguṇa balava bhāva āpādanena
translated: Only one whose consciousness has reached absorption, not one who has merely reached the neighbourhood of absorption.🔽By the development of the power of resolve: by the development of the power of resolution.

original: vepullādivisesappattassa odhiso, anodhiso ca disāpharaṇādivasena jhānassa pavijambhanā
analyzed: vepulla ādi visesa pattassa odhisaḥ anodhisaḥ ca disā pharaṇa ādi vasena jhānassa pavijambhanā
translated: By the surmounting of the jhāna in the way beginning with “having resolved upon water” and so on.

original: vikubbanā vividhā kiriyāti katvā.
analyzed: vikubbanā vividhā kiriyā ati katvā
translated: The surmounting of the jhāna is the doing of the various kinds of creation after resolving upon the various kinds of creation, thus it is called “surmounting of the jhāna” .

original: 254. Mettāsahagatenāti uppādato yāva bhaṅgā mettāya saha pavattena saṃsaṭṭhena sampayuttenāti
analyzed: mettā sahagatena ati uppādataḥ yāva bhaṅgāḥ mettāya saha pavattena saṃsaṭṭhena sampayuttena ati
translated: With the mind accompanied by loving-kindness: with the mind occurring together with loving-kindness from its arising to its dissolution, associated with loving-kindness, conjoined with loving-kindness.

original: attho. Yasmā pana taṃ vuttanayena mettāya sahagataṃ, tāya ekuppādādividhinā sammadeva🔽āgataṃ hoti, tasmā vuttaṃ “mettāya samannāgatenā”ti. Ceto-saddo “adhicetaso”tiādīsu
analyzed: atthaḥ yasmā pana tam vutta nayena mettāya sahagatam ekuppāda ādi vidhinā sammat eva  āgatam hoti tasmā vuttam mettāya samannāgatena ati cetaḥ saddaḥ adhicetasā utiādīsu
translated: But since it is accompanied by loving-kindness in the way already stated, it is rightly called “gone to the culmination of the development of loving-kindness” because it has reached its consummation by the method of single function, etc.,🔽and so it is said, “By one whose mind is imbued with loving- kindness” . The word “mind” , which is the word that actually occurs in the text, is a term for concentration in such passages as “The mind, friends, is cultured by culture of the courses” .

original: samādhipariyāyopi hotīti tato visesetuṃ “cetasāti cittenā”ti vuttaṃ. Etanti etaṃ
analyzed: samādhi pariyāyaḥ api hoti iti tatas visesetum cetasā iti cittena ati vuttam etat ti etam
translated: So in order to distinguish it from that, “By one whose mind is imbued with loving- kindness” is said. The word “that” refers back to the word “mind” .

original: padaṃ. Disodhipariggaho sattodhipariggahamukheneva hotīti dassento āha “ekissā disāya
analyzed: padam disodhi pariggahaḥ satta ūdhi pariggaha mukhena iva hoti iti dassentaḥ āha ekissā disāya
translated: The inclusion of the direction is by the method of the inclusion of the being, which is why he said “starting with the being first included in the direction” .

original: paṭhamapariggahitaṃ sattaṃ upādāyā”ti. Disāsu hi ṭhitasattā disāgahaṇena gahitā.🔽Tenāha “ekadisāpariyāpannasattapharaṇavasena vutta”nti. Pharaṇañca sārammaṇassa dhammassa
analyzed: paṭhama pariggahitam sattam upādāya ati disāsu hi ṭhita sattā disā gahaṇena gahitā  tena āha eka disā pariyāpanna satta pharaṇa vasena vuttan ti pharaṇam ca sārammaṇassa dhammassa
translated: For the beings that stand in the directions are included by the inclusion of the directions.🔽That is why he said “stated by the pervasion of beings in a single direction” .🔽And pervasion is the seeing, the apprehending, the making a living experience of one’s own object by the contact of the object that is the object of the pervasion.

original: attano ārammaṇassa phassanā paccakkhato dassanaṃ gahaṇaṃ ārammaṇakaraṇamevāti āha
analyzed: attanaḥ ārammaṇassa phassanā paccakkhataḥ dassanam gahaṇam ārammaṇa karaṇam eva ati āha
translated: That is why he said “having pervaded, having touched, having made a living experience” .

original: “pharitvāti phusitvā ārammaṇaṃ katvā”ti. Brahmavihārādhiṭṭhitanti mettājhānupatthambhitaṃ.
analyzed: pharitvā iti phusitvā ārammaṇam katvā iti brahmavihāra dhiṭṭhitam ti mettā jhāna upatthambhitam
translated: “Established in the divine abidings” means established in the jhāna of loving-kindness.

original: Tathāti niyamanaṃ. Taṃ aniyamāpekkhasambandhībhāvato upamākāraniyamanaṃ. Dutiyanti
analyzed: tathā iti niyamanam aniyama apekkha sambandhībhāvataḥ upamā ākāra niyamanam
translated: “Thus” is a restriction. That is a restriction of the simile by way of the state of being related to one who is desirous of non-restriction. “The second” is

original: upameyyadassanaṃ, upameyyañca nāma upamaṃ, tena sambandhañca vinā natthīti tadubhayampi
analyzed: upameyya dassanam upameyyañca nāma upamam tena sambandham ca vinā natthi iti tat ubhayam pi
translated: the seeing of the object compared. And the object compared is the simile. Without that, there is no connection. Therefore, in order to show both of those,

original: dassetuṃ “yathā puratthimādīsū”tiādi vuttaṃ. Tattha tathā dutiyanti ettha pharitvā
analyzed: dassetum yathā puratthima ādīsu itiādi vuttam tattha tathā dutiyanti ettha pharitvā
translated: “like the east and so on” is said. There, “thus the second” is to be connected

original: viharatīti ānetvā sambandhitabbaṃ. Evaṃ tatiyaṃ catutthanti etthāpi. Tadanantaranti
analyzed: viharati iti ānetvā sambandhitabbam evam tatiyam catuttham ti ettha api tad anantaram ti
translated: by bringing in “he abides pervading.” Thus also in the third and the fourth. “The next to that” is

original: ca pharaṇāpekkhaṃ anantaraggahaṇaṃ, na pharitabbadisāpekkhaṃ disānaṃ aniddiṭṭharūpattā.
analyzed: ca pharaṇa apekkham anantara ggahaṇam na pharitabba disa apekkham disānam aniddiṭṭha rūpa ttā
translated: the apprehension of the next to that which is desirous of pervasion, not the apprehension of the next to that which is desirous of the direction to be pervaded, because the directions have not been shown.

original: Pharaṇānukkamena hi tāsaṃ dutiyāditā, na sarūpato. Tenevāha “yaṃ kiñci ekaṃ disa”nti.🔽Itīti evaṃ yathāvuttaṃ catasso, evaṃ uddhaṃ disaṃ pharitvā viharatīti attho. Tenāha
analyzed: hi tāsam dutiya ādi tā na tena iva āha yam kiñci ekam disanti  iti iti evam yathāvuttam catassaḥ evam uddham disam pharitvā viharati iti attho tena āha
translated: For it is by the order of pervasion that they are the second and so on, not by their own nature. Therefore it is said: “any one direction.”🔽“Thus” is in this way, as already stated. The meaning is: he abides pervading the upward direction with a mind that is similar. Therefore it is said:

original: “eteneva nayenā”ti. Idampi iti-saddasseva atthadassanaṃ. Pāḷiyaṃ adho tiriyanti ettha
analyzed: etena iva nayena ati idam pi iti saddassa iva attha dassanam pāḷiyam adho tiriyanti ettha
translated: “in the same way.” This is the seeing of the meaning of the word “thus.” In the text, “below, across”

original: pi-saddo luttaniddiṭṭhoti dassetuṃ “adhodisampi tiriyaṃ disampī”ti vuttaṃ. Eteneva
analyzed: pi saddaḥ lutta niddiṭṭhaḥ ti dassetum adhas disam pi tiriyam disam pi iti vuttam etena eva
translated: The word “also” is stated to show that the word “below” is to be taken in the sense of “downwards.”

original: “dutiya”ntiādīsupi pi-saddassa luttaniddiṭṭhatā dīpitāti veditabbaṃ. Evamevāti idampi
analyzed: dutiya nti ādīsu pi pi saddassa lutta niddiṭṭha tā dīpitā iti veditabbam evam eva iti idam pi
translated: The word “also” in the phrase “the second direction” should be understood to show that the word “below” is to be taken in the sense of “downwards.”🔽The phrase “in the same way” shows the meaning of the word “also.”

original: iti-saddasseva atthadassanaṃ. Ettha ca “adho”ti iminā yathā nirayesu, nāgabhavanādīsu,
analyzed: iti saddassa iva attha dassanam ettha ca adho ti iminā yathā nirayesu nāga bhavana ādīsu
translated: Herein, by the word “below” beings are included in the hells, in the nāga world, etc.,

original: yattha tattha vā attano heṭṭhimadisāya sattā gayhanti, evaṃ “uddha”nti iminā devaloke,
analyzed: yattha tattha vā attanaḥ heṭṭhima disāya sattāḥ gayhanti evam uddhanti iminā deva loke
translated: and in any other place below one’s own level. By the word “above” beings are included in the heavenly world,

original: yattha tattha vā attano uparimadisāyaṃ sattā gahitāti veditabbaṃ.
analyzed: yattha tattha vā attanaḥ uparima disā ayam sattā gahitā iti veditabbam
translated: and in any other place above one’s own level.

original: Majjhattādīti ādi-saddena itthipurisaariyānariyadevamanussādike pabhede saṅgaṇhāti.
analyzed: majjhatta ādi iti ādi saddena itthi purisa ariya anariya deva manussa ādike pabhede saṅgaṇhāti
translated: The word “middle” includes the various kinds of beings such as women, men, noble ones, ordinary people, gods, and humans.

original: Īsakampi bahi avikkhipamānoti appakampi kammaṭṭhānato bahi vikkhepaṃ anāpajjanto
analyzed: īsakampi bahi a vikkhipamānaḥ ti appakampi kammaṭṭhānato bahi vikkhepam an āpajjanto
translated: “Not letting his mindfulness fall off”: not letting his attention fall off from the meditation subject even a little.

original: hitūpasaṃhārato aññathā thokampi avattamāno. Sabbattatāyāti vā sabbena attabhāvena
analyzed: hitu upasaṃhārataḥ aññathā thokam pi avattamāno sabbattatāya ati vā sabbena atta bhāvena
translated: “In every way”: with his whole being.

original: yathā sabbabhāvena attani attano attabhāve hitesitā, evaṃ sabbadhi sabbasattesu mettāya
analyzed: yathā sabba bhāvena attani attano atta bhāve hita isitā evam sabbadhi sabba sattesu mettāya
translated: Just as he wishes welfare for his own self in every way, so he wishes welfare for all beings everywhere with loving-kindness.

original: pharitvā viharatīti attho. Mettāya vuccamānattā sattavisayo sabba-saddo, so ca dīghaṃ
analyzed: pharitvā viharati iti atthaḥ mettāya vuccamāna ttā satta visayaḥ sabba saddaḥ saḥ ca dīgham
translated: This is the meaning. The word all has as its domain the seven kinds of beings, and it is stated in the extended form.

original: katvā vutto, tasmā sabbasattakāyasaṅkhātā pajā etassa atthīti sabbāvantoti padatthato🔽dassento “sabbāvantanti sabbasattavanta”nti āha. Ettha ca sabbadhīti disodhinā, desodhinā
analyzed: katvā vuttaḥ tasmā sabba satta kāya saṅkhātā pajā etassa atthi iti sabbāvantaḥ ti padatthato  dassentaḥ āha ettha ca sabbadhi iti disodhinā desodhinā
translated: Therefore, showing the meaning of the words, he said, “All beings” means “all beings that exist.”🔽Herein, all beings everywhere is said by way of the directions and the regions.🔽All beings in every way is said by way of the kinds of beings.

original: ca anodhisopharaṇaṃ vuttaṃ, sabbattatāya sabbāvantanti sattodhinā. Tathā hi vuttaṃ
analyzed: ca anodhi sopharaṇam vuttam sabbattatāya sabbāvantanti satta ūdhinā tathā hi vuttam
translated: For this is said: “The word all is stated by way of the directions and the regions. The word every is stated by way of the kinds of beings.”

original: “anodhiso dassanattha”nti. Ekamevatthaṃ pakārato pariyāyenti ñāpentīti pariyāyā,
analyzed: dassana tthanti ekam eva attham pakārato pariyāyenti ñāpenti iti pariyāyā
translated: The synonyms are the words that make known the one meaning by way of the different categories.

original: vevacanāni. Vipulādisaddā cettha tādisāti adhippāyo. Tenāha “vipulenāti evamādipariyāyadassanato”ti.
analyzed: vevacanāni vipula ādi saddā ca ittha tādisā ati adhippāyo tena āha vipulena ati evamādi pariyāya dassanato ti
translated: The intention is that the words extensive, etc., are of that kind. Therefore he said, “By way of the synonyms such as extensive, etc.”

original: Pariyāyadassane ca pubbe gahitapadānipi puna gayhanti, yathā “saddhā saddahanā”ti
analyzed: pariyāya dassane ca pubbe gahita padāni pi puna gayhanti yathā
translated: And in the demonstration of the synonyms, the words already used are repeated, as in the passage beginning, “Faith is confidence” .

original: ettha vuttampi saddhāpadaṃ puna indriyādipariyāyadassane “saddhā saddhindriya”nti
analyzed: ettha vuttam pi saddhā padam punar indriya ādi pariyāya dassane saddhā saddhi indriyanti
translated: The word “faith” mentioned there is mentioned again in the exposition of the faculties, etc., as “faith is the faith faculty” .

original: vuttaṃ. Tathāsaddo vā itisaddo vā na vuttoti “mettāsahagatena cetasā ekaṃ disaṃ pharitvā🔽viharatī”ti etassa anuvattako tathā-saddo ca iti-saddo ca tesaṃ pharaṇānantarādiṭṭhānaṃ
analyzed: vuttam tathā saddaḥ vā iti saddaḥ vā na vuttaḥ iti mettā sahagatena cetasā ekam disam pharitvā  viharati iti etassa anuvattakaḥ tathā saddo ca iti saddo ca tesam
translated: Or the words “thus” and “so” are not mentioned. So the words “thus” and “so” are in conformity with the words “He dwells pervading one direction with a mind imbued with loving- kindness” .🔽The words “thus” and “so” are not mentioned because the words “He dwells pervading … with a mind imbued with loving- kindness” are mentioned in order to show the place of pervasion, etc.,

original: aṭṭhānanti katvā te na vuttāti puna “mettāsahagatena cetasāti vutta”nti attho. Vuttassevatthassa
analyzed: aṭṭhānam ti katvā te na vuttā ati puna mettā sahagatena cetasā ati vuttanti atthaḥ vuttassa iva atthassa
translated: after the pervasion has been mentioned. So the meaning is: “The words ‘with a mind imbued with loving- kindness’ are mentioned again.”

original: puna vacanaṃ nigamananti āha “nigamanavasena vā etaṃ vutta”nti. Nanu ca samāpanavasena
analyzed: puna vacanam nigamanam iti āha nigamana vasena vā etam vuttam ti nanu ca samāpana vasena
translated: The mention again of a meaning already stated is a conclusion. That is why he said: “Or this is said by way of conclusion.”

original: vuttassevatthassa puna vacanaṃ nigamananti? Nāyaṃ doso odhisoanodhisopharaṇānaṃ samāpane
analyzed: vuttassa iva atthassa puna vacanam nigamanam ti na ayam dosaḥ samāpane
translated: But is not the mention again of a meaning already stated by way of the attainment a conclusion?🔽There is no fault here because the pervasion by delimitation and by non-delimitation is mentioned only in the attainment.

original: eva vuttattā. Vipulenāti mahantena, mahattañcassa asubhakammaṭṭhānādīsu viya ārammaṇassa
analyzed: eva vutta ttā vipulena ati mahantena asubha kammaṭṭhāna ādīsu viya ārammaṇassa
translated: “Extensive”: great. And its greatness is due to the object,

original: ekadesameva aggahetvā anavasesaggahaṇavasenāti āha “pharaṇavasena vipulatā daṭṭhabbā”ti.
analyzed: eka desam eva aggahetvā anavasesa ggahaṇa vasena āti āha pharaṇa vasena vipula tā daṭṭhabbā ti
translated: and it is not taken by way of a part of it, but by way of taking it without remainder. That is why he said “the greatness should be seen by way of its pervasiveness.”

original: Kilesavikkhambhanasamatthatādīhi mahattaṃ gataṃ, mahantehi vā uḷāracchandacittavīriyapaññehi
analyzed: kilesa vikkhambhana samattha tā ādīhi mahattam gatam mahantehi vā uḷāra chanda citta vīriya paññehi
translated: It has gone to greatness by way of the ability to suppress defilements, etc., or it has gone to greatness by way of the great, lofty desire, thought, energy, and understanding that are its associates.

original: gataṃ paṭipannanti mahaggataṃ. Tayidaṃ yasmā ekantato rūpāvacaraṃ, tasmā vuttaṃ “bhūmivasena
analyzed: gatam paṭipannanti mahaggatam tayidam yasmai ekantataḥ rūpāvacaram tasmai vuttam bhūmi vasena
translated: And this is entirely of the fine-material sphere, that is why he said “by way of plane.”

original: mahaggata”nti. Niruḷho hi rūpārūpāvacaresu mahaggatavohāro. Paguṇavasenāti pakārato
analyzed: mahaggata nti niruḍhaḥ hi rūpa arūpāvacaresu mahaggata vohāro paguṇa vasena ati pakārato
translated: For the expression “great” is used in the fine-material and immaterial spheres.

original: guṇitaṃ bahulīkataṃ paguṇaṃ, tassa vasena, subhāvitabhāvenāti attho. Taṃ hi pamāṇaṃ
analyzed: guṇitam bahulīkatam paguṇam tassa vasena su bhāvita bhāvena ati attho tam hi pamāṇam
translated: By way of what is familiar: what is familiar is what has been done much and often; by way of that, is the meaning.🔽For that is called “measureless” because it cannot be measured by any measure.

original: gahetuṃ asakkuṇeyyatāya appamāṇaṃ nāma hoti. Appamāṇasattārammaṇavasenāti aparimāṇasattārammaṇakaraṇavasena.
analyzed: gahetum a sakkuṇeyya tāya appamāṇam nāma hoti appamāṇa sattā ārammaṇa vasena ati aparimāṇa sattā ārammaṇa karaṇa vasena
translated: By way of having immeasurable beings as object: by way of making immeasurable beings its object.🔽It is also called “free from enmity” because it is itself free from enmity and because it is the cause for the absence of enmity in those who possess it.

original: Sayampi verarahitattā, taṃsamaṅgino verābhāvahetuttā ca averaṃ. Tayidaṃ dvayaṃ yato
analyzed: vera rahita ttā ca averam tayā idam dvayam yatas
translated: And this pair

original: labhati, taṃ dassetuṃ “byāpādapaccatthikappahānenā”ti vuttaṃ. Cetaso byāpattivasena
analyzed: labhati tam dassetum byāpāda paccatthika ppahānena ati vuttam cetasaḥ byāpatti vasena
translated: and in order to show that he has it, it is said, “By abandoning ill will and enmity.”🔽Because of the mental state of ill will,

original: hananato byāpajjaṃ, cetasikaṃ asātaṃ, tadabhāvato abyāpajjaṃ. Tenāha “niddukkha”nti.
analyzed: hananataḥ byāpajjam cetasikam asātam tad abhāvataḥ abyāpajjam tena āha niddukkhanti
translated: there is ill will, which is mental pain. Because of the absence of that, there is non-ill will. Therefore it is said, “free from grief.”

original: Taṃ panassa abyāpajjattaṃ pañcaviññāṇādīnaṃ viya na sabhāvato, atha kho paccatthikavivekatoti
analyzed: tam panassa abyāpajjattam pañca viññāṇa ādīnam viya na sabhāvataḥ atha kho paccatthika vivekato ti
translated: But that non-ill will of his is not, like the five-fold consciousness, etc., due to its own individual essence, but rather it is due to the absence of enmity.

original: dassento “domanassappahānato”ti āha. Ayanti idha yathānītaṃ appamaññāvibhaṅge, tesu
analyzed: dassentaḥ domanassa pahānato ti āha ayanti idha yathānītam appamaññā vibhaṅge tesu
translated: In order to show this, it is said, “By abandoning worry.”🔽Here, by “thus” is meant the miracle of supernormal power as described in the Discourse on the Miracle and in the Description of the Immeasurables,

original: tesu ca suttapadesesu āgataṃ mettābrahmavihāravikubbanamāha.
analyzed: tesu ca sutta padesesu āgatam mettā brahmavihāra vikubbanam āha
translated: and as it occurs in various places in the suttas.

original: 255. “Tathā”ti iminā imissā “pañcahākārehi, sattahākārehi, dasahākārehī”ti ākāravibhāgena
analyzed: tathā ati iminā imissā pañcahā ākārehi satta hākārehi dasahā ākārehi iti ākāra vibhāgena
translated: By the word “thus” he includes the miracle described in the Paṭisambhidā in the passage beginning, “In five ways, in seven ways, in ten ways” ,🔽as if it were a single piece of gold.

original: paṭisambhidāyaṃ vuttāya ca vikubbanāya majjhe bhinnasuvaṇṇassa viya bhedābhāvamupasaṃharati
analyzed: paṭisambhidā ayam vuttāya ca vikubbanāya majjhe bhinna suvaṇṇassa viya bheda abhāvam upasaṃharati
translated: For it is mentioned in the teaching as the “pervading of directions” in the sense of the “pervading of directions with light” and the “pervading of directions without light.”

original: odhisopharaṇaanodhisopharaṇadisāpharaṇavasena desanāya āgatattā. Kevalaṃ panettha
analyzed: odhi sopharaṇa anodhi sopharaṇa disāpharaṇa vasena desanāyaḥ āgata ttā kevalam pana itthā
translated: But here,

original: paṭisambhidāmagge viya sattodhi na gahitoti ayameva viseso. Yampīti vikubbanaṃ sandhāyāha.
analyzed: paṭisambhidā magge viya sattaḥ dhi na gahitaḥ iti ayam eva visesaḥ yam pi iti vikubbanam sandhāya āha
translated: and the word “being” is not included as in the Paṭisambhidā, is the only difference. “ And that” refers to the transformation.

original: Idāni bhedābhāvadassanamukhena uddesato ānītaṃ paṭisambhidāmaggapāḷiṃ niddesato dassetvā tassā anuttānapadavaṇṇanaṃ kātuṃ “tattha cā”tiādimāha.
analyzed: idāni bheda abhāva dassana mukhena uddesataḥ ānītam paṭisambhidā magga pāḷim niddesataḥ dassetvā tassāḥ anuttāna pada vaṇṇanam kātum tattha ca ati ādim āha
translated: Now, after showing by the method of demonstration the text of the Paṭisambhidā Magga brought in by the method of indication under the heading of the seeing of the absence of differentiation, he said “Tattha ca” in order to comment on the words not commented on there.

original: 256. Tattha sabbe sattāti sabba-saddo kāmaṃ padesasabbavisayo, na sabbasabbavisayo
analyzed: tattha sabbe sattā ti sabba saddo kāmam padesa sabba visayaḥ na sabba sabba visayaḥ
translated: Herein, the word “all” is, of course, a word for a part, not a word for the whole.

original: yathā “sabbaṃ jānātīti sabbaññutaññāṇa”nti, “sattā”ti pana padena paricchinnaṃ attano
analyzed: yathā sabbam jānāti iti sabbaññuta ññāṇan ti sattā ati pana padena paricchinnam attanaḥ
translated: As in the passage “He knows all, thus he is the All-knowing One” , but the word “beings” defines its own domain without remainder.

original: visayaṃ asesetvāva pariyādiyatīti āha “anavasesapariyādānameta”nti.
analyzed: visayam a sesetvā ava pariyādiyati iti āha anavasesa pariyādānam etat ti
translated: Therefore he said “This is the complete pervasion” .

original: Tatrāti tasmiṃ rūpe. Sattoti sajjanakiccena chandādipariyāyena lobhena āsatto laggo. Tatrāti vā karaṇe bhummaṃ, tena chandādināti attho.
analyzed: tatra ati tasmin rūpe satto ti sat jana kiccena chanda ādi pariyāyena lobhena āsattaḥ laggo tatra ati vā karaṇe bhummam tena chanda ādinā ati atthaḥ
translated: “ There” : in that materiality. “ Being” : clung to, stuck to, by craving, which is the function of a being, by greed, which is a synonym for will, etc. “ There” is locative case in the sense of instrument, thus the meaning is “ by will, etc.” .

original: Yadi sattatāya sattā, kathaṃ vītarāgesūti āha “ruḷhīsaddenā”tiādi. Avītarāgesu ruḷhena,
analyzed: yadi sattatāya sattā katham vīta rāgesu iti āha ruḷhī saddena atiādi avīta rāgesu ruḷhena
translated: If beings are so called because of being, how is it that “ in those free from lust” ? He said “ By the word in common use” , etc. In those not free from lust it is by the word in common use, by the word in common use in the world.

original: avītarāgesu vā pavattitvā indriyabaddhakhandhasantānatāya taṃsadisesu vītarāgesu
analyzed: a vīta rāgesu vā indriya baddha khandha santāna tāya tad sadisesu vīta rāgesu
translated: Or else, after occurring in those not yet free from lust, it occurs in those free from lust in the same way, by way of the continuity of aggregates bound by faculties.

original: ruḷhena saddena. Atha vā kiñci nimittaṃ gahetvā satipi aññasmiṃ tannimittayutte katthaci
analyzed: ruḷhena saddena atha vā kiñci nimittam gahetvā satipi aññasmin tad nimitta yutte katthaci
translated: By the word “settled” . Or else, taking some sign, it occurs in some other place where that sign is found, even though it is not actually present,

original: visaye sammutiyā cirakālatāya nimittavirahepi pavatti ruḷhī nāma yathā “gacchantīti
analyzed: visaye sammutiyā cira kāla tāya nimitta virahe pi pavatti ruḷhī nāma yathā gacchanti iti
translated: by convention, because of long-standingness, as in the case of the word “cows” in the expression “the cows are lowing” .

original: gāvo”ti, evaṃ sattasaddassāpi ruḷhībhāvo daṭṭhabbo. Bhūtapubbagatiyā vā vītarāgesu
analyzed: gāvaḥ ti evam satta saddassa api ruḷhībhāvaḥ daṭṭhabbaḥ bhūta pubba gatiyā vā vīta rāgesu
translated: So too the word “beings” should be regarded as settled by convention.

original: sattavohāro daṭṭhabbo. Satvayogatoti ettha satvaṃ nāma buddhi, vīriyaṃ, tejo vā,
analyzed: satta vohāro daṭṭhabbo satva yogato ti ettha satvam nāma buddhi vīriyam tejaḥ vā
translated: By the word “endowed” : here “endowment” is understanding, energy, or heat,

original: tena yogato sattā, yathā “nīlaguṇayogato nīlo paṭo”ti.🔽Pāṇanti etenāti pāṇanaṃ, assāsapassāsā, tassa kammaṃ pāṇanatā, tāya, assāsapassāsasampayogenāti
analyzed: tena yogataḥ sattā yathā nīla guṇa yogataḥ nīlaḥ paṭaḥ iti  pāṇanti etena ati pāṇanam assāsa passāsā tassa kammam pāṇana tā tāya assāsa passāsa sampayogena ati
translated: by which they are endowed, as a cloth is endowed with blue by the blue colour.🔽“By the word ‘life’” : the act of breathing in and out is “life” ; the function of that is “vitality” ; by that, by the association with the in-and-out breathing, is the meaning.

original: attho. Bhūtattāti kammakilesehi jātattā. Pūraṇato, galanato ca puggalāti neruttā.
analyzed: atthaḥ bhūta ttā ati kamma kilesehi jāta ttā pūraṇataḥ galanataḥ ca
translated: “By the word ‘being’” : by the word “being” is meant a person who is filled up and who moves about by means of the in-and-out breathing.

original: Sattā hi nibbattantā taṃtaṃsattanikāyaṃ pūrentā viya honti, sabbāvatthanipātitāya
analyzed: sattāḥ hi nibbattantā taṃ taṃ satta nikāyam pūrentāḥ viya honti sabbāvattha nipātitāya
translated: And they go, that is, they die, having been brought to all the states of existence.

original: ca galanti cavantīti attho. Apariññātavatthukānaṃ “attā”ti bhavati ettha abhidhānaṃ,
analyzed: ca galanti cavanti iti atthaḥ a pariññāta vatthukānam attā iti bhavati ettha abhidhānam
translated: The designation “self” is made in regard to the five aggregates of clinging, which are not fully understood.🔽“Mind” is the selfhood, the body, or the five aggregates of clinging.

original: cittañcāti attabhāvo, sarīraṃ, khandhapañcakameva vā. Tanti khandhapañcakaṃ. Upādāyāti🔽gahetvā upādānaṃ nissayaṃ katvā. Paññattimattasambhavatoti paramatthato asantepi
analyzed: cittam ca ati sarīram khandha pañcakam eva vā tanti khandha pañcakam upādāya ati  gahetvā upādānam nissayam katvā paññattimat ta sambhavato ti paramatthataḥ asante pi
translated: “Clinging” means taking as a basis, taking as a support.

original: sattasaññite paññattimattena sambhavato.🔽Yathā ca sattāti vacananti yathā satta-saddo yathāvuttenaṭṭhena nippariyāyato padesavuttipi
analyzed: satta saññite paññattimattena sambhavataḥ  yathā ca satta ati vacanan ti yathā satta saddaḥ yathāvuttena ṭṭhena nippariyāyato
translated: Because of the possibility of the mere designation.🔽And just as the word “being” is used,

original: ruḷhīvasena anavasesapariyādāyako. Sesānipīti pāṇādivacanānipi. Tānipi hi rūpārūpabhavūpagacatutthajjhānādisamaṅgīnaṃ
analyzed: ruḷhī vasena sesāni pi iti pāṇa ādi vacanāni pi tāni pi hi rūpa arūpa bhava upaga catuttha jjhāna ādi samaṅgīnam
translated: so too the words “living being,” “breathing being,” and “person” are used in the ultimate sense, in the literal sense, in the sense of a part,

original: assāsapassāsābhāvato avinipātadhammānaṃ pugalanassa abhāvato padesavuttīni. Ruḷhīvasena
analyzed: assāsa passāsa abhāvataḥ avinipāta dhammānam pugalanassa abhāvataḥ padesa vuttīni ruḷhī vasena
translated: by way of popular usage, without exception, without remainder.🔽And the other words, “creature,” and so on,🔽for they too are used in the sense of a part, in the literal sense, in the sense of a part, by way of popular usage,

original: āropetvā yathāvuttāya ruḷhiyā vasena katthaci visaye avijjamānampi pāṇapuggalabhāvaṃ
analyzed: āropetvā yathā vuttāya ruḷhiyā vasena katthaci visaye a vijjamānam pi pāṇa puggala bhāvam
translated: and having superimposed the state of being a living being or a person, which is non-existent in a certain object according to the above-mentioned method of superimposition,

original: āropetvā. Yadi sādhāraṇato sattavevacanānīti gahetvā anodhisopharaṇā mettā vuccati,
analyzed: āropetvā yadi sādhāraṇato mettā vuccati
translated: if loving-kindness is said to be the meditation subject of mere words, which is common to all,🔽then why is it said to be only fivefold? Anticipating this question, he says, “If you like, it can be said … .”

original: atha kasmā pañcaheva ākārehi vuttāti anuyogaṃ sandhāyāha “kāmañcā”tiādi. Keci panāhu🔽“na kho panetāni “sattā”tiādīni padāni vevacanatāmattaṃ upādāya gahitāni, yato jantuādīnampi
analyzed: atha kasmā pañcahā iva ākārehi vuttā iti anuyogam sandhāya āha kāmañca atiādi keci pana āhu  na kho pana etāni satta ati ādīni padāni vevacana tā mattam upādāya gahitāni yatas jantu ādīnam pi
translated: But some say this:🔽“The words ‘living beings’ and so on are not taken as mere synonyms, since in that case they would include ‘creatures’ and so on as well. They are taken as synonyms only for the purpose of showing a particular meaning that is the basis for the terms.”

original: gahaṇaṃ āpajjeyya, atthavisesaṃ pana nimittabhūtaṃ upādāya gahitānī”ti, te sandhāyāha
analyzed: gahaṇam āpajjeyya attha visesam pana nimitta bhūtam upādāya gahitāni iti te sandhāya āha
translated: Anticipating this question, he says, “But those who say … .”

original: “ye panā”tiādi. Tattha atthatoti sajjanaṭṭhena sattā, pāṇanaṭṭhena pāṇāti evamādiatthato.
analyzed: ye pana atiādi tattha atthato ti sajjana ṭhena sattā pāṇana ṭṭhena pāṇa ati evamādi atthato
translated: Herein, as to meaning: they are living beings in the sense of being alive , they are creatures in the sense of being born , they are persons in the sense of being able to know , they are breathing things in the sense of breathing , and so on.

original: Tesaṃ taṃ matimattanti dassento āha “anodhisopharaṇā virujjhatī”ti. Kasmā? Keci sattā,
analyzed: tesam tam matimattanti dassentaḥ āha anodhi sopharaṇāḥ virujjhati iti kasmā keci sattā
translated: Showing that he is wise in their meaning, he says, “The meditation subject of mere words is contradicted.” Why? Because some living beings,

original: keci pāṇā, keci puggalāti āpajjanato. Tathā atthaṃ aggahetvāti sattādisaddā sappadesavisayāti
analyzed: keci pāṇā keci puggalā ati āpajjanato tathā attham aggahetvā ati satta ādi saddā sa padesa visayā ti
translated: And likewise as to the meaning, “The words ‘all beings’ and so on have as their domain the general and not the particular,”

original: evamatthaṃ aggahetvā pubbe vuttanayena nippadesavisayāti evamatthaṃ gahetvāti adhippāyo.
analyzed: evam attham aggahetvā pubbe vutta nayena nippadesa visayā ati evam attham gahetvā ati adhippāyaḥ
translated: the intention is that it is as to the meaning that he does not take them thus, but as to the meaning that he takes them as stated in the way already given, namely, as having as their domain the particular and not the general.🔽That is why he said “And here” and so on.

original: Tenāha “imesū”tiādi. Pañcasu ākāresūti “sabbe sattā”tiādinā pāḷiyaṃ āgatesu pañcasu
analyzed: tena āha imesu utiādi pañcasu ākāresu iti sabbe sattā ti ādinā pāḷiyam āgatesu pañcasu
translated: In the five ways is in the five ways stated in the text with “All beings … may they be free from hatred” and so on.

original: bhāvanākāresu. Aññataravasenāti yassa kassaci vasena.
analyzed: bhāvanā ākāresu aññatara vasena ati yassa kassaci vasena
translated: In any one way is in any one of them.

original: 257. Idāni dvāvīsatiyā bhāvanākāresu appanā pariggahetvā dassetuṃ “ettha cā”tiādi
analyzed: idāni dvāvīsatiyā bhāvanā ākāresu appanā pariggahetvā dassetum ettha ca atiādi
translated: Now, in order to point out the absorption by defining it in the twenty-two ways, he said, “And here” and so on.🔽Free from ill will and hate is free from grief and hate.

original: vuttaṃ. Byāpādarahitāti domanassabyāpādarahitā. Tasmāti yasmā na kevalaṃ yathāvuttaākāravibhāgamattato
analyzed: vuttam byāpāda rahitā ati domanassa byāpāda rahitā tasmā iti yasmā na kevalam yathā vutta ākāra vibhāga mattataḥ
translated: Because is because not only is the definition of absorption by the mere analysis of the ways stated thus,

original: appanāvibhāgo, tasmā. Imesupi padesūti “sabbe sattā averā hontū”tiādikoṭṭhāsesupi.
analyzed: appanā vibhāgaḥ tasmai imesu pi padesu iti sabbe sattāḥ averāḥ hontu iti ādi koṭṭhāsesu pi
translated: but also in these phrases too, that is to say, in the passages beginning, “All beings … may they be free from hatred” and so on.

original: Yaṃ yaṃ pākaṭaṃ hotīti yadipi pubbabhāge tattha tattha abhinivese anekakoṭṭhāsavaseneva
analyzed: yam yam pākaṭam hoti iti yadi pi pubba bhāge tattha tattha abhinivese aneka koṭṭhāsa vasena iva
translated: Whatever is evident is that although in the earlier stages the various passages are evident to him in the way already stated, still, when he has reached absorption, only the meaning is evident to him, not the phrasing.

original: manasikāraṃ pavatteti, bhāvanāya samijjhanakkhaṇe pana tattha yaṃ paguṇataratāya
analyzed: manasikāram bhāvanāya samijjha nakkhaṇe pana tattha yam paguṇatara tāya
translated: When he gives attention to it as “beautiful, beautiful,” then at the moment of the breakthrough to absorption, absorption is only of the kind described thus, “He gives attention to it as peaceful only, keeps it in being as peaceful only” .🔽But at the moment of absorption, when he gives attention to it as “beautiful, beautiful,” then at the moment of the breakthrough to absorption, absorption is only of the kind described thus, “He gives attention to it as beautiful only, keeps it in being as beautiful only” .

original: supākaṭaṃ hoti, tassa vasena appanā hoti, yathā taṃ dvattiṃsākāre. Tattha pana ārammaṇaṃ,
analyzed: su pākaṭam hoti tassa vasena appanā hoti yathā tam dvattiṃsa ākāre tattha pana ārammaṇam
translated: And here the difference is this. In the case of the thirty-two aspects, the object is the thirty-two aspects,🔽but here the aspect is the meditation subject.

original: idha bhāvanākāroti ayameva viseso. Catunnanti catunnaṃ catunnaṃ. Byāpanicchālopena
analyzed: idha bhāvanā kāro ti ayam eva visesaḥ catunnam ti catunnam catunnam byāpana icchā lopena
translated: “Four fours”: for it is shown by the method of permutation that there are four fours.

original: hi niddiṭṭhaṃ. Esa nayo sesesupi.
analyzed: hi niddiṭṭham esa nayaḥ sesesu pi
translated: The same method applies in the case of the rest.

original: Liṅgavasena vuttaṃ tesaṃ pacurato labbhamānattā. Tatiyā pana pakati yadipi paṭhamadukena na saṅgahitā, dutiyadukena pana tikena ca saṅgahitā eva.
analyzed: liṅga vasena vuttam tesam pacuratas labbhamāna ttā tatiyā pana pakati yadi api paṭhama dukena na saṅgahitā dutiya dukena pana tikena ca saṅgahitā eva
translated: The third method is included in the first and second tetrads, though not in the first tetrad.

original: Iti sabbānipīti anodhisopharaṇe vīsati, odhisopharaṇe aṭṭhavīsati, disāpharaṇe cattāri satāni, asīti cāti evaṃ sabbānipi. Sata-saddāpekkhāya napuṃsakaniddeso.
analyzed: iti sabbāni pi iti anodhi sopharaṇe vīsati odhi sopharaṇe aṭṭhavīsati disāpharaṇe cattāri satāni asīti ca ati evam sabbāni pi sata sadda apekkhāya napuṃsaka niddeso
translated: “So all these”: twenty in the case of non-pervasion, eighty in the case of pervasion, four hundred and eighty in the case of directional pervasion—all these are included in the first and second tetrads. The neuter form is used because of the word “hundred” .

original: 258. Evaṃ mettābhāvanaṃ vibhāvetvā idāni tattha ānisaṃse vibhāvetuṃ “itī”tiādi āraddhaṃ.
analyzed: evam mettā bhāvanam vibhāvetvā idāni tattha ānisaṃse vibhāvetum iti iti ādi āraddham
translated: Having thus analyzed the development of loving-kindness, he now began the analysis of the benefits in the passage beginning “Thus, bhikkhus, a bhikkhu who finds a delight outside, who is affected by what is outside, who has not risen up out of the world. ”

original: Tattha sesā janāti mettāya cetovimuttiyā alābhino. Samparivattamānāti dakkhiṇena🔽passena asayitvā sabbaso parivattamānā. Kākacchamānāti ghurughurupassāsavasena vissaraṃ🔽karontā. Sukhaṃ supatīti ettha duvidhāsupanā sayane piṭṭhippasāraṇalakkhaṇā, kiriyāmayacittehi
analyzed: tattha sesāḥ janāti mettāya cetaḥ vimuttiyā alābhinaḥ samparivattamānāti dakkhiṇena  passena sabbaso parivattamānā ghuru ghuru passāsa vasena vissaram  karontā sukham supati iti ettha duvidhā a supanā sayane piṭṭhi pasāraṇa lakkhaṇā kiriyā āmaya cittehi
translated: Herein, the rest of the people are those who have not acquired the deliverance of mind through loving-kindness. They turn over: they turn over completely without lying on their right side. They snore: they breathe out and breathe in with a loud noise. They sleep happily: there are two kinds of sleeping: that with the characteristic of stretching out the back on a bed, and that with the characteristic of a state of unknowing in one who is active.

original: avokiṇṇabhavaṅgappavattilakkhaṇā ca. Tatthāyaṃ ubhayathāpi sukhameva supati. Yasmā🔽saṇikaṃ nipajjitvā aṅgapaccaṅgāni samodhāya pāsādikena ākārena sayati, niddokkamanepi
analyzed: ca tattha ayam ubhayathā api sukham eva supati yasmai  saṇikam nipajjitvā aṅga paccaṅgāni samodhāya pāsādikena ākārena sayati niddokkamane pi
translated: Herein, the rest of the people are those who have not acquired the deliverance of mind through loving-kindness. They lie on their right side: they lie down after turning over on their right side. They are restless: they toss and turn with loud snoring and deep breathing. They sleep happily: there are two kinds of sleeping: that characterized by the stretching of limbs in bed and that characterized by the occurrence of the life-continuum unmixed with the functional consciousnesses. Herein, he sleeps happily in both ways. For

original: jhānaṃ samāpanno viya hoti. Tenāha “evaṃ asupitvā”tiādi.
analyzed: jhānam samāpannaḥ viya hoti tena āha evam a supitvā iti ādi
translated: he lies down in a lovely manner after going to bed quietly and collecting his limbs together. And when he wakes up he is like one who has attained jhāna. That is why it is said, “Having slept thus” .

original: Niddākāle sukhaṃ alabhitvā dukkhena suttattā eva paṭibujjhanakāle sarīrakhedena nitthunanaṃ,
analyzed: niddā kāle sukham a labhitvā dukkhena suttattā eva paṭibujjhana kāle sarīra khedena nitthunanaṃ
translated: Because he has slept badly without happiness and with pain, when he wakes up he yawns and stretches and turns himself this way and that.

original: vijambhanaṃ, ito cito viparivattanañca hotīti āha “nitthunantā vijambhantā samparivattantā
analyzed: vijambhanam itas citas viparivattanam ca hoti iti āha nitthunantā vijambhantā samparivattantā
translated: Because of the fatigue in his body. That is why it is said, “Yawning, stretching, and turning themselves this way and that” .

original: dukkhaṃ paṭibujjhantī”ti. Ayaṃ pana sukhena suttattā sarīrakhedābhāvato nitthunanādirahitova🔽paṭibujjhati. Tena vuttaṃ “evaṃ appaṭibujjhitvā”tiādi. Sukhapaṭibodho ca sarīravikārābhāvenāti
analyzed: dukkham paṭibujjhanti iti ayam pana sukhena sutta ttā sarīra kheda abhāvataḥ nitthunana ādi rahitaḥ uva  paṭibujjhati tena vuttam evam a paṭibujjhitvā atiādi sukha paṭibodhaḥ ca sarīra vikāra abhāvena ati
translated: and he wakes up with pain.🔽But he wakes up with ease because of the ease of the state of composure and because of the absence of bodily disturbance.🔽So it is said, “Without waking up with pain” and so on.🔽And the waking up with ease is because of the absence of bodily disturbance.

original: āha “sukhaṃ nibbikāra”nti.
analyzed: āha sukham
translated: So it is said, “With ease, without bodily disturbance”

original: “Bhaddakameva supinaṃ passatī”ti idaṃ anubhūtapubbavasena, devatūpasaṃhāravasena
analyzed: bhaddakam eva supinam passati iti idam anubhūta pubba vasena deva tu upasaṃhāra vasena
translated: “He sees only auspicious dreams” is said because of his having experienced them before and because of the presence of deities.🔽For his dreams are only auspicious, not inauspicious.

original: cassa bhaddakameva supinaṃ hoti, na pāpakanti katvā vuttaṃ. Tenāha “cetiyaṃ vandanto
analyzed: cassa bhaddakam eva supinam hoti na pāpakam ti katvā vuttam tena āha cetiyam vandantaḥ
translated: Therefore it is said, “As though worshipping a shrine” and so on.

original: viyā”tiādi. Dhātukkhobhahetukampi cassa bahulaṃ bhaddakameva siyā yebhuyyena cittajarūpānuguṇatāya utuāhārajarūpānaṃ.
analyzed: viya atiādi dhātu khobha hetukam pi cassa bahulam bhaddakam eva siyā yebhuyyena citta ja rūpa anuguṇa tāya utu āhāra ja rūpānam
translated: And even if they are due to a disturbance of the elements, they are usually auspicious for him, because the materiality originated by kamma is usually in conformity with the materiality originated by consciousness.

original: Ure āmuttamuttāhāro viyāti gīvāya bandhitvā ure lambitamuttāhāro viyāti kehici vuttaṃ.
analyzed: ure āmuttam utta āhāraḥ viyāti gīvāya bandhitvā ure lambitam utta āhāraḥ viyāti kehici vuttam
translated: “Like a pearl necklace resting on his chest”: some say that it is like a pearl necklace fastened round his neck and hanging down on his chest.

original: Taṃ ekāvalivasena vuttaṃ siyā, anekaratanāvalisamūhabhūto pana muttāhāro aṃsappadesato
analyzed: tat eka āvali vasena vuttam siyā aneka ratana āvali samūha bhūtaḥ pana mutta āhāraḥ aṃsa ppadesato
translated: That may be said to be like a single string of pearls, but a pearl necklace is a collection of many strings of pearls.

original: paṭṭhāya yāva kaṭippadesassa heṭṭhābhāgā palambanto ure āmukkoyeva nāma hoti.
analyzed: paṭṭhāya yāva kaṭi ppadesassa heṭṭhābhāgā palambanto nāma hoti
translated: and hanging down from the navel to the thighs, it is called “hanging down to the chest.”

original: Tatthevāti pāṭaliputteyeva. Sakkā nisīdituṃ vā nipajjituṃ vā desassa khematāya, tassa tassa padesassa ramaṇīyatāya ca.
analyzed: tattha iva ati pāṭaliputteya iva sakkā nisīditum vā nipajjitum vā desassa khema tāya tassa tassa padesassa ramaṇīya tāya ca
translated: Right there means right there in Pāṭaliputta. It is a place where it is possible to sit or lie down, because of the safety of the place and the pleasantness of the various parts of the place.

original: Dasāva anto dasanto, vatthassa osānanto.
analyzed: dasāva antar dasantaḥ vatthassa osānanto
translated: The end of the cloth means the end of the robe.

original: Samappavattavāsanti tattha tattha vihāre samappavattavattavāsaṃ. Thero kira attanā
analyzed: tattha tattha vihāre thero kira attanā
translated: Dwelling in the practice of universal pervasion means dwelling in the practice of universal pervasion in this and that monastery. The Elder, it seems,

original: paviṭṭhapaviṭṭhavihāre “ahamettha āgantuko”ti acintetvā tattha tattha yathārahaṃ
analyzed: paviṭṭha paviṭṭha vihāre aham ettha āgantukaḥ ti a cintetvā tattha tattha yathāraham
translated: did not think, “I am a visitor here” in the monasteries he entered. He dwelt in this and that monastery,

original: attanā kātabbavattāni paripūrento eva vihāsi. Apare pana bhaṇanti sabbasattesu samappavattamettāvihāravāsaṃ.
analyzed: attanā kātabba vattāni paripūrentaḥ eva vihāsi apare pana bhaṇanti sabba sattesu
translated: fulfilling the duties he had to perform there. Others say: “Dwelling in the practice of universal pervasion means dwelling in the practice of universal pervasion of loving-kindness towards all beings.”

original: Ayaṃ hi thero arahattādhigamato pubbepi mettāvihārī ahosi.
analyzed: ayam hi theraḥ arahatta adhigamataḥ pubbe pi mettā vihārī ahosi
translated: For this Elder was a dweller in loving-kindness even before he attained arahantship.

original: Vanantare ṭhitoti thero kira tathā samappavattavāsavasena caramāno ekadivasaṃ aññataraṃ
analyzed: ṭhito ti thero kira tathā sama pavatta vāsa vasena caramāno eka divasam aññataram
translated: Standing in the forest means that the Elder, it seems, while wandering thus in the practice of universal pervasion, one day,

original: ramaṇīyaṃ vanantaraṃ disvā tattha aññatarasmiṃ rukkhamūle samāpattiṃ samāpajjitvā
analyzed: ramaṇīyam vanantaram disvā tattha aññatarasmim rukkha mūle samāpattim samāpajjitvā
translated: and after seeing a delightful forest grove, he attained a state of concentration at the foot of a certain tree.

original: yathāparicchedena tato uṭṭhito attano guṇāvajjanahetukena pītisomanassena udānento
analyzed: yathā paricchedena tatas uṭṭhitaḥ attanaḥ guṇāvajjana hetukena pīti somanassena udānento
translated: and after rising from that state of concentration after the lapse of a certain period of time, he uttered this Solemn Utterance in a mood of joy and gladness born of his own realization of the virtues of the Buddha’s Dispensation:

original: “yāvatā upasampanno”ti gāthaṃ abhāsi. Tamatthaṃ dassetuṃ “vanantare ṭhito”ti paṭhamagāthā
analyzed: yāvatā upasampannaḥ iti gātham abhāsi tam attham dassetum vana antare ṭhitaḥ ti paṭhama gāthā
translated: “As long as I have been ordained … “ . In order to explain the meaning of this Solemn Utterance, the first stanza was composed:🔽“Roaring like a lion, seeking his own virtues,🔽the Elder, the Great Maung̃galīputta,🔽the Elder, the Great Maung̃galīputta,🔽the Elder, the Great Maung̃galīputta,

original: ṭhapitā. Tattha gajjamānakoti sīhagajjitaṃ gajjanto. Guṇamesantoti attano guṇasamudayaṃ
analyzed: tattha gajjamānako ti sīha gajjitam gajjantaḥ guṇam esantaḥ iti attanaḥ guṇa samudayam
translated: the Elder, the Great Maung̃galīputta,🔽the Elder, the Great Maung̃galīputta,

original: gavesanto paccavekkhanto.
analyzed: gavesantaḥ paccavekkhantaḥ
translated: the Elder, the Great Maung̃galīputta,🔽the Elder, the Great Maung̃galīputta,

original: Maṇilarukkhe nivāsitāya taṃ devataṃ “maṇiliyā”ti voharanti, tasmā sā devatāpi “ahaṃ,
analyzed: nivāsitāya tam devatam voharanti tasmai sā devatā api aham
translated: the Elder, the Great Maung̃galīputta,🔽the Elder, the Great Maung̃galīputta,🔽the Elder, the Great Maung̃galīputta,🔽the Elder, the Great Maung̃galīputta,🔽the Elder, the Great Maung̃galīputta,🔽the Elder, the Great Maung̃galīputta,🔽the Elder, the Great Maung̃galīputta,🔽the Elder, the Great Maung̃galīputta,🔽the Elder, the Great Maung̃galīputta,🔽the Elder, the Great Maung̃galīputta,🔽the Elder, the Great Maung̃galīputta,🔽the Elder, the Great Maung̃galīputta,🔽the Elder, the Great Maung̃galīputta,🔽the Elder, the Great Maung̃galīputta,🔽the Elder, the Great Maung̃galīputta,🔽the Elder, the Great Maung̃galīputta,🔽the Elder, the Great Maung̃galīputta,🔽the Elder, the Great Maung̃galīputta,🔽the Elder, the Great Maung̃galīputta,🔽the Elder, the Great Maung̃galīputta,🔽the Elder, the Great Maung̃galīputta,

original: bhante, maṇiliyā”ti āha. Rukkhadevatānaṃ hi yebhuyyena nivāsarukkhavasena vohāro🔽yathā phandanadevatāti. Tatthevāti cittalapabbateyeva.
analyzed: bhante maṇiliyā ti āha rukkhadevatānam hi yebhuyyena nivāsa rukkha vasena vohāraḥ 🔽yathā phandana devatā ati tattha iva ati
translated: the Elder

original: “Balavapiyacittatāyā”ti iminā balavapiyacittatāmattenapi satthaṃ na kamati, pageva mettāya cetovimuttiyāti dasseti.🔽Khippameva cittaṃ samādhiyati kenaci paripanthena parihīnajjhānassa byāpādassa dūrasamussāritabhāvato
analyzed: balava piya citta tāya ati iminā sattham na kamati pagā iva mettāya cetaḥ vimuttiyā ati dasseti  khippam eva cittam samādhiyati kenaci paripanthena parihīna jhānassa byāpādassa dūra samussārita bhāvataḥ
translated: “By the strength of the mind’s loving-kindness” : this shows that the weapon does not strike even through the mere strength of the mind’s loving-kindness, much less through the deliverance of the mind through loving-kindness.🔽The mind becomes concentrated quickly because the jhāna factors are strong in one who has lost his jhāna through anger.

original: khippameva samādhiyati. Āsavānaṃ khayāyāti keci. Sesaṃ suviññeyyameva. Ettha ca kiñcāpi
analyzed: khippam eva samādhiyati āsavānam khayāya ati keci sesam su viññeyyam eva ettha ca kiñcā api
translated: Some say that the mind becomes concentrated quickly because of the destruction of the defilements. The rest is easy to understand.

original: ito aññakammaṭṭhānavasena adhigatajjhānānampi sukhasupanādayo ānisaṃsā labbhanti, yathāha –
analyzed: itas añña kammaṭṭhāna vasena adhigata jhānānam pi sukha supana ādayaḥ ānisaṃsāḥ labbhanti yathā āha
translated: Here, although the benefits such as pleasant sleep, etc., are obtained by one who has attained jhāna through other meditation subjects as well, still it is said:

original: “Sukhaṃ supanti munayo, ajjhattaṃ susamāhitā;
analyzed: sukham supanti munayaḥ ajjhattam su samāhitāḥ
translated: “The sages sleep happily, well concentrated within;

original: Suppabuddhaṃ pabujjhanti, sadā gotamasāvakā”ti. –
analyzed: su pabuddham pabujjhanti sadā gotama sāvakāḥ ati
translated: The disciples of Gotama always wake up refreshed.”

original: Ca ādi, tathāpime ānisaṃsā brahmavihāralābhino anavasesā labbhanti byāpādādīnaṃ ujuvipaccanīkabhāvato
analyzed: ca ādi tathā api ime ānisaṃsāḥ brahmavihāra lābhinaḥ anavasesāḥ labbhanti byāpāda ādīnam uju vipaccanīka bhāvato
translated: And these benefits are obtained by one who has attained the divine abidings without exception, because anger, etc., are directly opposed to the divine abidings.

original: brahmavihārānaṃ. Tenevāha “nissaraṇaṃ hetaṃ, āvuso, byāpādassa, yadidaṃ mettā cetovimuttī”tiādi.
analyzed: tena iva āha nissaraṇam āvuso byāpādassa yat idam mettā cetaḥ vimutti itiādi
translated: That is why it is said: “Now this, friend, is the escape from the arisen ill will, namely, the deliverance of the mind through loving-kindness” , and so on.

original: Byāpādādivasena ca sattānaṃ dukkhasupanādayoti tappaṭipakkhabhūtesu brahmavihāresu
analyzed: byāpāda ādi vasena ca sattānam tad paṭipakkha bhūtesu brahmavihāresu
translated: And it is by means of the divine abidings that he gives beings the happiness of freedom from enmity, etc.,🔽

original: siddhesu sukhasupanādayo hatthagatā eva hontīti.
analyzed: siddhesu sukha supana ādayaḥ hattha gatāḥ eva honti iti
translated: And by means of the absence of ill will, etc., he gives them pleasure. So when the divine abidings that are the opposites of these are successful, giving pleasure is as good as done.

original: Karuṇābhāvanāvaṇṇanā🔽259. Karuṇanti karuṇābrahmavihāraṃ. Nikkaruṇatāyāti vihesāya, “idhekacco pāṇinā vā
analyzed: karuṇā bhāvanā vaṇṇanā  karuṇanti karuṇā brahmavihāram vihesāya pāṇinā vā
translated: The explanation of the development of compassion🔽Compassion: the divine abiding of compassion.

original: leḍḍunā vā daṇḍena vā satthena vā aññataraññatarena vā sattānaṃ viheṭhanajātiko hotī”ti🔽evaṃ vuttaviheṭhaneti attho. Ādīnavanti dosaṃ. Yathā tathā sattānaṃ viheṭhanāya pāpako🔽vipāko idha ceva samparāye ca. Tathā hi yo satte jīvitā voropanena vā aṅgapaccaṅgacchedanena🔽vā dhanajāniyā vā alābhāya vā avāsāya vā anatthāya vā ayasatthāya vā parisaṃsakkanena
analyzed: leḍḍunā vā daṇḍena vā satthena vā aññatara aññatarena vā sattānam viheṭhana jātikaḥ hoti iti  evam vutta viheṭhanā iti atthaḥ ādīnavanti dosam yathā tathā sattānam viheṭhanāya pāpakaḥ  vipākaḥ ca iva samparāye ca tathā hi satte jīvitā voropanena vā aṅga paccaṅga chedanena  vā dhana jāniyā vā alābhāya vā avāsāya vā anatthāya vā ayasatthāya vā parisaṃsakkanena
translated: Lack of compassion: lack of pity, “Here someone is of a kind to inflict harm on beings with his hand, a clod, a stick, or a knife” ,🔽and the meaning is that he is of a kind to inflict harm on beings in any one of these five ways.

original: vā antamaso yathāvajjadassanenapi viheṭheti, tassa so pamādavihāro diṭṭheva dhamme
analyzed: vā antamasaḥ yathāvat ja dassanena api viheṭheti tassa saḥ pamāda vihāraḥ diṭṭhe iva dhamme
translated: The danger: the danger in hate. For the unprofitable result of harm to beings in this way and in the next world is evil here and in the life to come. For when someone inflicts harm on beings by depriving them of life, or by cutting off their limbs, or by robbing them of their possessions, or by slandering them, or by causing their goods to be confiscated, or by having them unjustly imprisoned, or by imposing excessive taxes, or by acting inimically towards them in some way or other, down even to the giving of advice that is not in their interests or not according to their wishes, then that is a state of his that is negligence. And that negligence of his has an unprofitable result here and now and in the life beyond.

original: alābhāyapi hoti, laddhassa parihānāyapi hoti, tannimittaṃ pāpako kittisaddo abbhuggacchati,
analyzed: alābhāya api hoti laddhassa parihānāya api hoti tad nimittam pāpakaḥ kitti saddaḥ abbhuggacchati
translated: and he has no gain, and he loses what he has, and a bad report gets spread about him,

original: avisārado parisaṃ upasaṅkamati maṅkubhūto, sammūḷho kālaṃ karoti, kāyassa bhedā duggati
analyzed: a visāradaḥ parisam upasaṅkamati maṅku bhūto sammūḷhaḥ kālam karoti kāyassa bhedā duggati
translated: and he goes to a meeting self-depreciating and tongue-tied, and he dies confused, and after death at the breaking-up of the body he is reborn in an unhappy destination,

original: pāṭikaṅkhā, sugatiyampi manussabhūto dujjaccopi hoti nīcakuliko, dubbaṇṇopi hoti
analyzed: pāṭikaṅkhā sugatiyam pi manussa bhūtaḥ dujjaccaḥ api hoti nīca kulikaḥ dubbaṇṇaḥ api hoti
translated: and in a happy destination too, if he gets a human birth, he is of low family, and he is ugly,

original: duddasiko, bahvābādhopi hoti rogabahulo, duggatopi hoti appannapāno, appāyukopi hoti🔽parittajīvitoti evamādianekānatthānubandhitā vihesāya paccavekkhitabbā, tappaṭipakkhato🔽karuṇāya ānisaṃsā paccavekkhitabbā. Tena vuttaṃ “nikkaruṇatāya ādīnavaṃ karuṇāya
analyzed: duddasikaḥ bahu ābādhaḥ api hoti roga bahulaḥ duggataḥ api hoti appanna pānaḥ appāyukaḥ api hoti  paritta jīvito ti evamādi aneka anattha anubandhi tā vihesāya paccavekkhitabbā tad paṭipakkhato  karuṇāya ānisaṃsā paccavekkhitabbā tena vuttam nikkaruṇa tāya ādīnavam karuṇāya
translated: and he is uninfluential, and he is sickly, and he is short-lived,

original: ca ānisaṃsaṃ paccavekkhitvā”ti. “Piyo hī”tiādinā paṭhamaṃ piyapuggalādīsu anārambhassa
analyzed: ca ānisaṃsam paccavekkhitvā ti piyaḥ hi iti ādinā paṭhamam piya puggala ādīsu anārambhassa
translated: and he is poor, and he is of little intelligence. So the disadvantage of lack of pity should be reviewed as entailing these and other misfortunes. The advantages of pity should be reviewed as the opposite of these. Hence it was said above: “Having reviewed the disadvantage in lack of pity and the advantage in pity” .🔽“For one who is dear” and so on. The reason for not beginning with those who are dear is stated in the first line. For one who begins by arousing pity for those who are dear does not at first abandon his affection for them,

original: kāraṇamāha. Piyaṃ hi puggalaṃ karuṇāyitumārabhantassa na tāva piyabhāvo vigacchati,
analyzed: kāraṇam āha piyam hi puggalam karuṇāyitum ārabhantassa na tāva piya bhāvaḥ vigacchati
translated: and

original: avigate ca tasmiṃ kuto karuṇāyanā. Tenāha “piyaṭṭhāneyeva tiṭṭhatī”ti. Sesapuggalesupi🔽eseva nayo. Liṅgavisabhāgakālakatānaṃ akhettabhāve kāraṇaṃ heṭṭhā vuttameva.
analyzed: avigate ca tasmin kutas karuṇāyanā tena āha piya ṭṭhāneyā iva tiṭṭhati iti sesa puggalesu pi  esa iva nayaḥ liṅga visabhāga kālakatānam akhetta bhāve kāraṇam heṭṭhā vuttam eva
translated: And when there is no suffering, how can there be compassion? That is why it is said, “He stands in the place of the dear one.” The same method applies in the case of the other persons.🔽The reason for the unploughability of the sexless, etc., has already been given above.

original: Yattha pana paṭhamaṃ ārabhitabbā, taṃ pāḷinayeneva dassetuṃ “kathañca bhikkhū”tiādi
analyzed: yattha pana paṭhamam ārabhitabbā tam pāḷi nayena iva dassetum katham ca bhikkhu iti ādi
translated: But in order to show by the method of the text where one should begin, the Exalted One said, “And how, bhikkhus, does a bhikkhu stand in the place of the dear one? Here a bhikkhu does not tolerate an arisen thought of sense desire; he abandons it, destroys it, dispels it, and wipes it out of existence.🔽He does not tolerate an arisen thought of ill will … an arisen thought of cruelty … any other bad unwholesome states … that have arisen … He abandons them … and wipes them out of existence” .

original: āraddhaṃ. Tattha duggatanti daliddaṃ. So hi bhogapārijuññato sukhasādhanānaṃ abhāvena
analyzed: āraddham tattha duggatanti daliddam saḥ hi bhoga pārijuññataḥ sukha sādhanānam abhāvena
translated: Herein, poor means destitute. For he who is destitute of wealth is called poor because he has gone to , has approached, has come to, suffering, owing to the absence of the means of happiness.

original: dukkhaṃ gato upagato duggatoti vuccati. Atha vā duggatanti dukkhena samaṅgibhāvaṃ🔽gataṃ. Durupetanti kāyaduccaritādīhi upetaṃ. Gatikularūpādivasena vā tamabhāve ṭhito
analyzed: dukkham gataḥ upagataḥ duggataḥ iti vuccati atha vā duggatam ti dukkhena samaṅgi bhāvam  gatam upetam gati kula rūpa ādi vasena vā
translated: Or alternatively, poor means gone to , come to, the state of being endowed with suffering.🔽Deprived means endowed with bodily misconduct, etc. Or he is deprived because he is devoid of the good qualities of destiny, family, beauty, etc.🔽Or he is deprived because he is devoid of the good qualities of destiny, family, beauty, etc.🔽Or he is deprived because he is devoid of the good qualities of destiny, family, beauty, etc.

original: duggato. Kāyaduccaritādīhi upetattā tamaparāyaṇabhāve ṭhito durupetoti evamettha🔽attho veditabbo. Paramakicchappattanti ativiya kicchamāpannaṃ mahābyasanaṃ nimuggaṃ.
analyzed: duggataḥ kāya duccarita ādīhi upeta ttā tam aparāyaṇa bhāve ṭhitaḥ durupetaḥ iti evam ettha  atthaḥ veditabbo parama kiccha ppattanti ativiya kiccham āpannam mahā byasanam nimuggam
translated: Or he is deprived because he is devoid of the good qualities of destiny, family, beauty, etc.🔽Or he is deprived because he is devoid of the good qualities of destiny, family, beauty, etc.🔽Or he is deprived because he is devoid of the good qualities of destiny, family, beauty, etc.🔽Or he is deprived because he is devoid of the good qualities of destiny, family, beauty, etc.🔽Or he is deprived because he is devoid of the good qualities of destiny, family, beauty, etc.🔽Or he is deprived because he is devoid of the good qualities of destiny, family, beauty, etc.🔽Or he is deprived because he is devoid of the good qualities of destiny, family, beauty, etc.🔽Or he is deprived because he is devoid of the good qualities of destiny, family, beauty, etc.

original: Appeva nāmāti sādhu vata.
analyzed: nāma ati sādhu vata
translated: Or he is deprived because he is devoid of

original: Vadhetha nanti “ghātetha naṃ cora”nti evaṃ pahitāya rañño āṇāya khādanīyampi…pe… denti “idāneva māriyamāno ettakampi sukhaṃ labhatū”ti. Susajjitoti sukhānubhavane sannaddho.
analyzed: vadhetha nanti ghātetha nam coranti evam pahitāya rañño āṇāya khādanīyam pipe denti idānā iva māriyamānaḥ ettakam pi sukham labhatu iti su sajjitaḥ iti sukha anubhavane sannaddhaḥ
translated: “Kill him” means “kill that thief.” They give him food, etc., thinking, “Even as he is being killed, let him have the pleasure of this.” “Well prepared” means well equipped for the experience of pleasure.

original: Eteneva upāyenāti yena yena vidhinā etarahi yathāvutte paramakicchāpanne āyatiṃ vā🔽dukkhabhāgimhi puggale karuṇāyituṃ karuṇā uppāditā, eteneva nayena. Piyapuggaleti
analyzed: etena iva upāyena ati yena yena vidhinā etarahi yathā vutte parama kicchā āpanne āyatim vā  dukkha bhāgimhi puggale karuṇāyitum karuṇā uppāditā etena iva nayena piya puggala iti
translated: By this method: by whatever method he arouses compassion now towards the person who is in great distress as described or towards one who will be in such a state in the future,

original: piyāyitabbapuggale. Etarahi vā dissamānaṃ āyatiṃ vā bhāviniṃ dukkhappattiṃ gahetvā
analyzed: piyāyitabba puggale etarahi vā dissamānam āyatim vā bhāvinim dukkha ppattim gahetvā
translated: By this method. Towards a dear person: towards a person who should be loved. The construction is: taking his present appearance or his future appearance as one who will meet with suffering,

original: karuṇā pavattetabbāti sambandho. Majjhattaverīsupi eseva nayo. Yo hi so karuṇāya
analyzed: karuṇā pavattetabbā ati sambandhaḥ majjhatta verī supi esā iva nayaḥ yaḥ hi saḥ karuṇāya
translated: compassion should be aroused. The same method applies in the case of a neutral person and a hostile person.

original: vatthubhūto duvidho puggalo vutto, kāmaṃ tattha karuṇābhāvanā sukheneva ijjhati,
analyzed: vatthu bhūtaḥ duvidhaḥ puggalaḥ vuttaḥ kāmam tattha karuṇā bhāvanā sukhena iva ijjhati
translated: For the person of the two kinds stated here who is the object of compassion, the development of compassion succeeds easily.

original: iminā pana bhikkhunā tattha bhāvanaṃ paguṇataraṃ katvā sīmāsambhedaṃ kātuṃ tadanantaraṃ
analyzed: iminā pana bhikkhunā tattha bhāvanam paguṇataram katvā sīmā sambhedam kātum tad anantaram
translated: But this bhikkhu should make the development familiar with that person first, and then he should break down the barriers.

original: piyapuggale, tato majjhatte, tato veripuggale karuṇā bhāvetabbā. Bhāventena ca ekekasmiṃ
analyzed: piya puggale tatas majjhatte tatas veri puggale karuṇā bhāvetabbā bhāventena ca ekekasmin
translated: towards a neutral person, and then towards a hostile person. And in developing this🔽

original: koṭṭhāse muduṃ kammaniyaṃ cittaṃ katvā tadanantare tadanantare upasaṃharitabbaṃ.🔽Yassa pana veripuggalo vā natthi, mahāpurisajātikattā vā anatthaṃ karontepi verisaññāva🔽nuppajjati, tena majjhatte me cittaṃ kammaniyaṃ jātaṃ, idāni verimhi upasaṃharāmīti🔽byāpārova na kātabbo. Yassa pana atthi, taṃ sandhāyāha “sace panā”tiādi.🔽Tattha pubbe vuttanayenevāti mettākammaṭṭhānikassa vuttanayena. Taṃ mettāya vuttanayeneva.🔽Vūpasametabbanti “athānena purimapuggalesū”tiādinā, “kakacūpamaovādādīnaṃ anussarato”tiādinā
analyzed: koṭṭhāse mudum kammaniyam cittam katvā tad anantare tad anantare upasaṃharitabbam  yassa pana veri puggalaḥ vā natthi mahā purisa jātika ttā vā anattham karonte pi veri saññā va  nuppajjati tena majjhatte me cittam kammaniyam jātam idāni verimhi upasaṃharāmi iti  byāpāraḥ uva na kātabbaḥ yassa pana atthi tam sandhāya āha sace pana atiādi  tattha pubbe vutta nayena iva āti mettā kammaṭṭhānikassa vutta nayena tam mettāya vutta nayena iva  vūpasametabbanti atha anena purima puggalesu itiādinā anussarato itiādinā
translated: He should develop it towards a dear person, then towards a neutral person, then towards a hostile person. And in doing so he should make his mind workable by treating each of these three kinds of persons as a single category. Then he should extend loving-kindness to the four quarters, the four intermediate points, the zenith and the nadir, and to all quarters universally, with a mind that is free from enmity, ill will, or enmity, and that is abundant, exalted, measureless, well developed.

original: ca mettābhāvanāya vuttena nayena taṃ paṭighaṃ vūpasametabbaṃ. Evaṃ etarahi mahādukkhappatte
analyzed: ca mettā bhāvanāya vuttena nayena tat paṭigham vūpasametabbam evam etarahi mahā dukkha ppatte
translated: And he should develop it in this way: “May all beings be free from enmity, affliction and anxiety, and live happily. May they keep themselves unhurt and unharmed, and control themselves well. May they be able to keep to the good and obtain happiness. May they be able to keep to the good and obtain happiness. May they be able to keep to the good and obtain happiness. May they be able to keep to the good and obtain happiness. May they be able to keep to the good and obtain happiness. original: sukhitepi akatakusalatāya āyatiṃ dukkhappattiyā vasena karuṇāyanavidhiṃ dassetvā
analyzed: sukhite api akata kusala tāya āyatim dukkha ppattiyāḥ vasena karuṇāyana vidhim dassetvā
translated: Having shown the way to have compassion on those who are happy because of their failure to do good and so they will come to suffering in the future,🔽he now said “And whoever here” in order to show that way with reference to those who have done good. “Their” : of the misfortunes.

original: idāni katakalyāṇepi taṃ dassetuṃ “yopi cetthā”tiādi vuttaṃ. Tesanti byasanānaṃ. Vaṭṭadukkhaṃ🔽anatikkantattāti sammāsambuddhenāpi akkhānena pariyosāpetuṃ asakkuṇeyyassa anāgatassa🔽āpāyikassa sugatīsupi jātijarādibhedassāti aparimitassa saṃsāradukkhassa anatikkantabhāvato.🔽Sabbathāpi karuṇāyitvāti dukkhappattiyā, sukhappattiyā akatakusalatāya vā katākusalatāya🔽vāti sabbapakārenapi karuṇāya vatthubhāvassa sallakkhaṇena tasmiṃ tasmiṃ puggale
analyzed: idāni kata kalyāṇe api tam dassetum yaḥ api ca itthā tiādi vuttam tesan ti byasanānam vaṭṭa dukkham  an atikkanta ttā ati sammāsambuddhena api akkhānena pariyosāpetum a sakkuṇeyyassa anāgatassa  āpāyikassa jāti jarā ādi bhedassa ati aparimitassa saṃsāra dukkhassa an atikkanta bhāvato  sabbathā api karuṇāyitvā ati dukkha ppattiyā sukha ppattiyā akata kusala tāya vā kata akusala tāya  vāti sabba pakārena api karuṇāya vatthu bhāvassa sat lakkhaṇena tasmim tasmim puggale
translated: The suffering of the round of rebirths🔽because it is not transcended.

original: karuṇaṃ katvā karuṇābhāvanaṃ vaḍḍhetvā. Vuttanayenevāti “athānena punappunaṃ mettāyantenā”tiādinā
analyzed: karuṇam katvā karuṇā bhāvanam vaḍḍhetvā vutta nayena iva ati atha anena punappunam mettāyantena ati ādinā
translated: Because it is not transcended, because it is not got beyond, because it is not escaped from, because it is not gone beyond, because it is not gone over, because it is not crossed over, because it is not passed beyond, because it is not done away with, because it is not destroyed, because it is not abandoned, because it is not vanished, because it is not stopped, because it is not dried up, because it is not made to cease, because it is not made to be no more, because it is not made to be not born again, because it is not made to be unoriginated, because it is not made to be non-arisen, because it is not made to be non-reviving, because it is not made to be non-reoccurring, because it is not made to be non-reviving, because it is not made to be non-arising, because it is not made to be non-reviving, because it is not made to be non-arising, because it is not made to be non-reviving, because it is not made to be non-arising, because it is not made to be non-reviving, because it is not made to be non-arising, because it is not made to be non-reviving, because it is not made to be non-arising, because it is not made to be non-reviving, because it is not made to be non-arising, because it is not made to be non-reviving, because it is not made to be non-arising, because it is not made to be non-reviving, because it is not made to be non-arising, because it is not made to be non-reviving, because it is not made to be non-arising, because it is not made to be non-reviving, because it is not made to be non-arising, because it is not made to be non-reviving, because it is

original: mettābhāvanāyaṃ vuttena nayena. Taṃ nimittanti sīmāsambhedavasena pavattaṃ samathanimittaṃ.🔽Mettāya vuttanayenevāti yathā mettābhāvanāyaṃ “appakasirenevā”tiādinā tikacatukkajjhānavasena
analyzed: mettā bhāvanā ayam vuttena nayena tam nimittam ti sīmā sambheda vasena pavattam samatha nimittam  mettāya vutta nayena iva ati yathā mettā bhāvanā ayam appa kasirena iva āti ādinā tika catukka jjhāna vasena
translated: As in the case of the development of loving-kindness. The sign of that: the sign of serenity occurring with the resolution of the boundary.

original: appanā “ekaṃ disaṃ pharitvā viharatī”tiādinā tassā vaḍḍhanā ca vuttā, evamidha karuṇābhāvanāyaṃ
analyzed: appanā ekam disam pharitvā viharati itiādinā tassāḥ vaḍḍhanā ca vuttā evam idha karuṇā bhāvanā ayam
translated: As in the case of loving-kindness: just as in the case of the development of loving-kindness it is said that “with the phrase ‘without remainder’ … he should surmount the third jhāna and enter the fourth” , and just as it is said that “he should extend that loving-kindness … evenly over the whole world, above, below, and across” ,

original: tikacatukkajjhānavasena appanā veditabbā ca vaḍḍhetabbā ca, tathevassā vaḍḍhanāvidhipi🔽veditabbāti adhippāyo. Vuttanayenevāti avadhāraṇena “paṭhamaṃ veripuggalo karuṇāyitabbo”ti🔽idaṃ yathā pāḷiviruddhaṃ, evaṃ yuttiviruddhampīti imamatthaṃ dīpeti. Paṭhamaṃ hi
analyzed: tika catukka jhāna vasena appanā veditabbā ca vaḍḍhetabbā ca tathā iva assā  veditabbā ti adhippāyaḥ vutta nayena iva āti avadhāraṇena paṭhamam veri puggalo karuṇāyitabbaḥ ti  idam yathā pāḷi viruddham evam yutti viruddham pi iti imam attham dīpeti paṭhamam hi
translated: so too should the surmounting and the extending be understood here in the case of the development of compassion. And the method of extending should be understood in this way:🔽The intention is that it should be understood as stated. As in the case of loving-kindness: by the word “just” the meaning is that what is stated in the text is contrary to right method as well as to the sequence of practice. For if he first recollects an enemy, anger would arise in him when he does the loving-kindness meditation, and compassion would not arise.

original: veriṃ samanussarato kodho uppajjeyya, na karuṇā. Attāpi sakkhibhāvena karuṇāyanavasena
analyzed: verim samanussarataḥ kodhaḥ uppajjeyya na karuṇā attā api sakkhibhāvena karuṇāyana vasena
translated: And if he first recollects himself, compassion would not arise in him through his being a witness to his own suffering,

original: gahetabbo, so kimiti pacchā gayhatīti. “Appanā vaḍḍhetabbā”ti iminā ca appanāppattacittasseva
analyzed: gahetabbo so kim iti pacchā gayhati iti appanā vaḍḍhetabbā ti iminā ca appanā appatta cittassa iva
translated: and why is it that it is not taken later?

original: “karuṇāsahagatena cetasā ekaṃ disaṃ pharitvā viharatī”tiādinā vuttavikubbanā ijjhatīti ayamattho dassito.
analyzed: karuṇā sahagatena cetasā ekam disam pharitvā viharati iti ādinā vutta vikubbanā ijjhati iti ayam atthaḥ dassito
translated: By the words “The absorption should be extended” the meaning of the passage “He dwells suffusing one quarter with a mind imbued with compassion” is shown to be successful only for one whose consciousness has reached absorption.

original: Karuṇāpadamattameva cassā pāḷiyā visesoti taṃ anāmasitvā paṭisambhidāyaṃ vuttavikubbanā,🔽mettāya vuttaānisaṃsā ca idha labbhantīti dassetuṃ “tato paraṃ…pe… veditabbā”ti vuttaṃ.
analyzed: karuṇā pada mattam eva cassā pāḷiyā visesaḥ ti tam an āmasitvā paṭisambhidā ayam vutta vikubbanā  mettāya vutta ānisaṃsā ca idha labbhanti iti dassetum tatas paraṃpe veditabbā ati vuttam
translated: And since only the words “with compassion” are mentioned in the text, the kinds of success mentioned in the Paṭisambhidā are not mentioned by name.🔽But the kinds of success mentioned there and the benefits mentioned in the case of loving-kindness are applicable here too. That is why it is said, “The rest should be understood in the way already described” .

original: Tattha tato paranti “karuṇāsahagatena cetasā”ti vuttavikubbanato upari. Sesaṃ vuttanayameva.
analyzed: tattha tatas paranti karuṇā sahagatena cetasā ati vutta vikubbanataḥ upari sesam vutta nayam eva
translated: Herein, the rest should be understood in the way already described means that the kinds of success mentioned in the Paṭisambhidā and the benefits mentioned in the case of loving- kindness should be understood in the way already described.

original: Muditābhāvanāvaṇṇanā🔽260. Piyapuggalādīsūti piyamajjhattaverīsu na ārabhitabbā. Muditābhāvanāti vibhattiṃ
analyzed: piya puggala ādīsu iti piya majjhatta verīsu na ārabhitabbā muditā bhāvanā iti vibhattim
translated: The development of gladness is finished.🔽“With regard to dear persons, etc., he should not arouse gladness” means that he should not arouse gladness towards dear persons, etc., as “dear,” etc.;🔽for the words “he should arouse gladness” are to be construed with “having made them the object” .

original: pariṇāmetvā yojanā. Na hītiādi tattha kāraṇavacanaṃ. Piyabhāvamattenāti ettha matta-saddo
analyzed: pariṇāmetvā yojanā na hi itiādi tattha kāraṇa vacanam piya bhāva mattena ati ettha matta saddo
translated: “For what reason?” Because of the words “He should not arouse gladness” .🔽“Merely as living beings” : the word merely is intended to show that he should not arouse gladness towards them as “dear,” etc.

original: visesanivatti attho, tena somanassapaṭisandhikatādisiddhā niccappahaṃsitamukhatā,🔽pubbabhāsitā, sukhasambhāsatā, sakhilatā, sammodakatāti evamādike muditāya padaṭṭhānabhūte🔽visese ulliṅgeti, īdisehi visesehi virahitoti vuttaṃ hoti. Eva-kārena pana piyapuggalassa
analyzed: visesa nivatti tena somanassa paṭisandhika tā ādi siddhā nicca ppahaṃsita mukha tā  pubba bhāsi tā sukha sambhāsa tā sa khila tā sammodaka tā ati evamādike muditāya padaṭṭhāna bhūte  visese ulliṅgeti īdisehi visesehi virahitaḥ ti vuttam hoti evakārena pana piya puggalassa
translated: The meaning of the word is “the state of being distinguished.” So the state of having a happy rebirth-linking, etc., is established.🔽The state of being one who is always smiling,🔽the state of being one who speaks first, the state of being one who is easy to talk with, the state of being one who is friendly, the state of being one who is courteous, and so on, are the specific states that are the basis for gladness.

original: sukhasamappitatādiṃ, muditāya ca hetubhūtaṃ pamodappavattiṃ nivatteti. Piyapuggalepi
analyzed: sukha samappita tā ādim muditāya ca hetu bhūtam pamoda ppavattim nivatteti piya puggale pi
translated: He “points to” these specific states, which are the cause for gladness. What is meant is: he is devoid of such specific states. But by the words “in such a way” he “reverses” the occurrence of the gladness that is the cause for gladness, such as the state of being gladdened by a dear person.

original: hi paramāya sampattiyā pamudite haṭṭhatuṭṭhe bhikkhuno muditokāsaṃ labheyya. Vakkhati
analyzed: hi paramāya sampattiyā pamudite haṭṭha tuṭṭhe bhikkhunaḥ mudita ukāsam labheyya vakkhati
translated: For if a dear person were gladdened by the highest excellence, the bhikkhu would have an opportunity for gladness.🔽For it is said: “Or a dear person” , etc.

original: hi “piyapuggalaṃ vā”tiādi. Ādito majjhattapuggalaṃ anussarantassa udāsinatā saṇṭhāti,
analyzed: hi piya puggalam vā ati ādi āditas majjhatta puggalam anussarantassa saṇṭhāti
translated: When he recollects a neutral person, he first experiences equanimity.

original: veriṃ samanussarantassa kodho uppajjati. Tenāha “pageva majjhattaverino”ti.
analyzed: verim samanussarantassa kodhaḥ uppajjati tena āha pagā iva majjhatta verinā ti
translated: When he recollects an enemy, anger arises. Therefore it is said: “How much more so a neutral person or a friend.”

original: Pamodappavattiyā soṇḍasadiso sahāyo soṇḍasahāyo. Muditamuditovāti pasādasommatāya
analyzed: pamoda ppavattiyā soṇḍa sadisaḥ sahāyaḥ soṇḍa sahāyaḥ mudita muditaḥ uvāti pasāda sommatāya
translated: A friend who is like a companion in the sense of being a fellow in the occurrence of gladness is a “glad friend” . The “glad gladden” is one who is gladdened by confidence.

original: ativiya mudito eva. Pasāde hi idaṃ āmeḍitaṃ. Evaṃ aṭṭhakathānayena ādito muditābhāvanāya
analyzed: muditaḥ eva pasāde hi idam āmeḍitam evam aṭṭhakathā nayena āditas muditā bhāvanāya
translated: and he is glad, and his gladness is called ‘abundant’.🔽For this is the explanation in the Commentaries.

original: vatthuṃ dassetvā idāni pāḷinayena dassetuṃ “piyapuggalaṃ vā”tiādi vuttaṃ. Tattha🔽sukhitanti sañjātasukhaṃ, sukhappattanti attho. Sajjitanti sukhānubhavane sannaddhaṃ
analyzed: vatthum dassetvā idāni pāḷi nayena dassetum piya puggalam vā tiādi vuttam tattha  sukhitanti sañjāta sukham sukha ppattanti attho sajjitanti sukha anubhavane sannaddham
translated: After showing the object for the development of the first meditation in this way according to the method of the Commentaries, he now said ‘Or a dear person’ in order to show it according to the method of the texts. Herein,🔽Happy means possessed of pleasure; has attained pleasure is the meaning.🔽Rejoicing means ready for the experience of pleasure,🔽having prepared the means to pleasure.

original: paṭiyattasukhasādhanaṃ. Aho sādhūti tassa sattassa sampattiyaṃ sampajaññapubbapamodanākāradassanaṃ.
analyzed: paṭiyatta sukha sādhanam aho sādhu iti tassa sattassa sampattiyam sampajañña pubba pamodana ākāra dassanam
translated: How good, how excellent is the good fortune of that being is the seeing of the mode of sympathetic joy preceded by knowledge of the good fortune.🔽Again, how good, how excellent is the seeing of the abundance of that sympathetic joy.

original: Puna aho suṭṭhūti tassa pamodanassa bahulīkāradassanaṃ. Piyaṃ manāpanti ettha manāpa-ggahaṇena
analyzed: puna aho suṭṭhu iti tassa pamodanassa bahulīkāra dassanam piyam manāpanti ettha manāpa gahaṇena
translated: Dear and pleasing: some say that the words ‘dear’ and ‘pleasing’ include

original: pāḷiyampi atippiyasahāyako adhippetoti eke.🔽Atīteti tasmiṃyeva attabhāve atīte. Anāgateti etthāpi eseva nayo. Na hi bhavantaragate
analyzed: pāḷiyam pi atippiya sahāyakaḥ adhippeto ti eke  atīta iti tasmin yā iva atta bhāve atīte anāgata iti etthā api eṣa iva nayaḥ na hi
translated: a very dear friend.🔽In the past: in the past in that same individual existence. In the future: the same explanation applies here. For the development of the divine abidings does not proceed in one who has reached another existence.

original: brahmavihārabhāvanā ruhati. Yadi evaṃ, atītānāgate kathanti? Nāyaṃ doso. “So evāyaṃ
analyzed: brahmavihāra bhāvanā ruhati yadi evam atīta anāgate na ayam dosaḥ saḥ eva ayam
translated: If that is so, then how is it said that they are in the past and in the future? There is no contradiction here. For this is said:

original: datto tisso”ti addhāpaccuppannatāya vijjamānabhāvena gahetabbato. Kathaṃ panassa
analyzed: dattaḥ tissaḥ tissaḥ ti addhā paccuppanna tāya vijjamāna bhāvena gahetabbato katham panassa
translated: But how can the future be a condition for it?

original: anāgate sampatti ārammaṇaṃ hotīti? Ādesādito, paccuppannāya vā payogasampattiyā anumānato🔽laddhāya gahetabbato.🔽Piyapuggaleti soṇḍasahāyasaññite atippiyapuggale, piyapuggale ca. Duvidhopi cesa
analyzed: anāgate sampatti ārammaṇam hoti iti ādesa āditaḥ paccuppannāya vā payoga sampattiyā anumānato  laddhāya gahetabbato  piya puggala iti soṇḍa sahāya saññite atippiya puggale piya puggale ca duvidhaḥ api ca īsa
translated: Because it can be apprehended as obtained by inference from the success of the practice in the present, or by the sign of the future.

original: idha piyabhāvasāmaññato “piyapuggalo”ti vutto. Anukkamenāti atippiyapuggalo piyapuggalo
analyzed: idha piya bhāva sāmaññato piya puggalo ti vuttaḥ anukkamena ati atippiya puggalo piya puggalo
translated: “A dear person” is a very dear person, a dear person, and a person who is a friend as a boon. Both kinds are called “a dear person” here because of the similarity of their dearness.

original: majjhatto verīti catūsu koṭṭhāsesu ekekasmiṃ kammaṭṭhānaṃ paguṇaṃ, muduṃ, kammaniyañca
analyzed: majjhattaḥ verī iti catūsu koṭṭhāsesu ekekasmin kammaṭṭhānam paguṇam mudum kammaniyam ca
