translated: “In due course”: after making the meditation subject familiar, tender and wieldy in each of the four parts, namely, a very dear person, a dear person, a neutral person, and an enemy.

original: katvā sesesu upasaṃharaṇānukkamena. Kiñcāpi catūsu janesu samacittatāva sīmāsambhedo
analyzed: katvā sesesu upasaṃharaṇa anukkamena kiñca api catūsu janesu sīmā sambhedaḥ
translated: And after gathering it all together in each part, although equanimity towards the four persons is the breaking of the boundary,

original: sīmā sambhijjati etāyāti katvā. Bhāvanāya pana tathā bahuso pavattamānāya purimasiddhaṃ
analyzed: sīmā sambhijjati etāya ati katvā bhāvanāya pana tathā bahuso pavattamānāya purima siddham
translated: it is so called because it breaks the boundary. But when it occurs frequently in this way through development, it is called “broken down”🔽because it has been made to break down the boundary.

original: hetuṃ, itaraṃ phalañca katvā vuttaṃ “samacittatāya sīmāsambhedaṃ katvā”ti. Yathāvuttasīmābhāvo🔽vā sīmāsambhedoti vuttaṃ “samacittatāya sīmāsambhedaṃ katvā”ti. Sesamettha yaṃ vattabbaṃ,
analyzed: hetum itaram phalam ca katvā vuttam sama citta tāya sīmā sambhedam katvā ati yathā vutta sīmā bhāvaḥ  vā sīmā sambhedaḥ iti vuttam sama citta tāya sīmā sambhedam katvā iti sesam ettha yam vattabbam
translated: and the other is the fruit. The state of the boundary as described is called

original: taṃ heṭṭhā vuttanayameva.
analyzed: tat heṭṭhā vutta nayam eva
translated: “the breaking of the boundary” . So it is said: “having broken the boundary by means of impartiality.” The rest here should be understood in the way already stated.

original: Upekkhābhāvanāvaṇṇanā🔽261. Upekkhābhāvananti upekkhābrahmavihārabhāvanaṃ. Yasmā purimabrahmavihārattayanissando
analyzed: upekkhā bhāvanā vaṇṇanā  upekkhā bhāvanam ti upekkhā brahmavihāra bhāvanam yasmai purima brahmavihāra ttaya nissandaḥ
translated: The Description of the Development of Equanimity🔽The development of equanimity: the development of the divine abiding of equanimity. Since the fourth divine abiding is the outcome of the first three,

original: catutthabrahmavihāro, tasmā vuttaṃ “mettādīsu paṭiladdhatikacatukkajjhānenā”ti. Paguṇatatiyajjhānāti🔽subhāvitaṃ vasībhāvaṃ pāpitaṃ paguṇaṃ, tathārūpā tatiyabrahmavihārajjhānato. Appaguṇaṃ
analyzed: catuttha brahmavihāro tasmā vuttam metta ādīsu paṭiladdha tika catukka jjhānena ati paguṇa tatiya jjhānā ati  su bhāvitam vasībhāvam pāpitam paguṇam tathārūpā tatiya brahmavihāra jhānataḥ appaguṇam
translated: it is said: “by one who has reached the third jhāna in the fourfold system in the case of the divine abiding of loving-kindness, etc.” The third jhāna that is “mastered” :

original: hi uparijhānassa padaṭṭhānaṃ na hoti. Catukkanayavasena cettha tatiyaggahaṇaṃ. Sukhitā
analyzed: hi upari jhānassa padaṭṭhānam na hoti catukka naya vasena ca ittha tatiya gahaṇam sukhitā
translated: mastered, made one’s own, by repeated practice, is “mastered.” Such a third divine abiding jhāna as that is called “mastered.” For the third jhāna that is not mastered is not a footing for the fourth. But here the third is mentioned according to the fourfold system.

original: hontūtiādivasenāti ādi-saddena “niddukkhā hontū”ti evamādīnaṃ saṅgaho daṭṭhabbo.
analyzed: hontu uti ādi vasena ati ādi saddena niddukkhāḥ hontu iti evamādīnam saṅgahaḥ daṭṭhabbo
translated: By the phrase “in the way beginning ‘May they be happy’” the phrase “May they be free from suffering” is also included.

original: Sattakelāyanaṃ sattesu mamāyanaṃ mamattakaraṇaṃ, tathā manasikārena yogo sattakelāyanamanasikārayuttattaṃ,
analyzed: satta kelāyanam sattesu mamāyanam mamatta karaṇam tathā manasikārena yogaḥ satta kelāyana manasikāra yuttattam
translated: The “seven kinds of loving kindness” are the seven kinds of loving kindness towards beings, namely, “May they be happy and free from suffering,” etc., and the “mental development” is the yoking of the mind to that by attention.

original: tasmā. Mettādīnaṃ rāgagehassitadomanassasomanassānaṃ āsannavuttitāya yathārahaṃ paṭighānunayasamīpacāritā🔽veditabbā. Atha vā “sukhitā hontu, dukkhato muccantu modantū”ti hitesitabhāvappattiyā
analyzed: tasmā mettā ādīnam āsanna vutti tāya yathāraham paṭigha anunaya samīpa cāri tā  veditabbāḥ atha vā sukhitāḥ hontu dukkhataḥ muccantu modantu uti hita īsita bhāva ppattiyā
translated: So the “proximity of resentment, of envy, and of disparaging” should be understood as the unfitness of resentment, envy, and disparaging, respectively, for the three kinds of loving kindness, according as each is appropriate.

original: tissannampi anunayassa āsannacāritā. Sati ca tabbipariyāye lohitappakope pubbo viya🔽laddhokāsamevettha paṭighanti avisesena tāsaṃ paṭighānunayasamīpacāritā daṭṭhabbā.
analyzed: anunayassa āsanna cāri tā sati ca tad bipariyāye lohita ppakope pubbaḥ viya  laddha okāsam eva ittha paṭighanti avisesena tāsam paṭigha anunaya samīpa cāri tā daṭṭhabbā
translated: Or alternatively, the proximity of resentment, etc., should be understood as the proximity of resentment, envy, and disparaging, respectively, for the three kinds of loving kindness, since they are respectively the opposite of the three kinds of loving kindness consisting in wishing for beings’ happiness, wishing for their welfare, and wishing for their abiding in happiness.🔽And the “proximity of resentment” should be understood as the proximity of resentment for the three kinds of loving kindness, since it is the opposite of the three kinds of loving kindness consisting in wishing for beings’ welfare, wishing for their happiness, and wishing for their abiding in happiness.🔽“Because of the grossness of the association with joy” is said with reference to the third jhāna.

original: “Somanassayogena oḷārikattā”ti idaṃ tatiyajjhānassa vasena vuttaṃ, tato vuṭṭhitassa
analyzed: somanassa yogena oḷārika ttā ti idam tatiya jhānassa vasena vuttam tatas vuṭṭhitassa
translated: “Because of seeing the danger in it” is said with reference to the fourth jhāna.

original: idamādīnavadassananti. Mettādivasena pana oḷārikabhāve vuccamāne vitakkavicārapītiyogeneva
analyzed: idam ādīnava dassanam ti mettā ādi vasena pana oḷārika bhāve vuccamāne vitakka vicāra pīti yogena iva
translated: But when grossness is spoken of according to the distinction of loving kindness, etc., then it is only the association with applied thought, etc., that should be understood as the grossness in each case.

original: oḷārikatā vattabbā siyā, tāhipi tāsaṃ samāyogasambhavato, upekkhāya ca tadabhāvato.
analyzed: oḷārika tā vattabbā siyā tāhi pi tāsam samāyoga sambhavataḥ upekkhāya ca tad abhāvataḥ
translated: and it should be said that it is gross, because it is possible to combine the two, and because equanimity is not like that.

original: Na vā vattabbā tatiyajjhānikānaṃyeva mettādīnaṃ idhādhippetattā, taṃtaṃjhānasamatikkameneva🔽ca taṃtaṃjhānikā mettādayopi samatikkantā eva nāma honti, jhānasāmaññena viya mettādisāmaññena
analyzed: na vā vattabbā tatiya jhānikānam yeva mettā ādīnam idha adhippeta ttā tad tad jhāna samatikkamena iva  ca taṃ taṃ jhānikāḥ mettā ādayaḥ api samatikkantāḥ eva nāma honti jhāna sāmaññena viya mettā ādi sāmaññena
translated: Or it should not be said, because only loving-kindness, etc., belonging to the third jhāna are intended here.🔽And it is only by surmounting the third jhāna that loving-kindness, etc., belonging to the third jhāna are sur- mounted,🔽just as they are by the surmounting of the third jhāna itself. The expression of them is only a matter of common usage, like the expression “the jhāna of loving- kindness” and so on.

original: vohāramattaṃ. Purimāsūti mettākaruṇāmuditāsu. Santabhāvatoti yathāvuttasattakelāyanādianupasantabhāvābhāvato
analyzed: vohāra mattam purimāsu iti mettā karuṇā muditāsu santa bhāvataḥ ti yathā vutta satta kelāyana ādi anupasanta bhāva abhāvataḥ
translated: In the former three, that is, in loving-kindness, compassion and gladness.🔽In the sense of being undisturbed, in the sense of being undisturbed by the disturbance of the living beings’ welfare, etc., mentioned above.

original: upekkhāya santabhāvato. “Santabhāvato”ti ca idaṃ nidassanamattaṃ daṭṭhabbaṃ. Sukhumatā
analyzed: upekkhāya santa bhāvato santa bhāvato ti ca idam nidassana mattam daṭṭhabbam sukhumatā
translated: And this “in the sense of being undisturbed” should be regarded as an illustration.

original: paṇītatā vidūrakilesatā vipulaphalatāti evamādayopi upekkhāya ānisaṃsā daṭṭhabbā.
analyzed: paṇīta tā vidūra kilesa tā vipula phala tā ti evamādayaḥ api upekkhāya ānisaṃsā daṭṭhabbā
translated: The advantages of equanimity should be regarded as being its subtlety, its excellence, its remoteness from defilement, its great fruit, and so on.

original: Pakatimajjhattoti kiñci kāraṇaṃ anapekkhitvā pakatiyā sabhāveneva imassa bhikkhuno
analyzed: pakatim ajjhattaḥ ti kiñci kāraṇam an apekkhitvā pakatiyā sabhāvena iva imassa bhikkhuno
translated: The natural neutrality is the neutrality of this bhikkhu by nature, without his having to make an effort to be neutral.

original: udāsinapakkhe ṭhito. Ajjhupekkhitvāti attanā katakammavaseneva ayamāyasmā āgato gacchati
analyzed: ṭhitaḥ ajjhupekkhitvā ati attanā kata kamma vasena iva ayam āyasmai āgataḥ gacchati
translated: He stands aside as a neutral.

original: ca, tvampi attanā katakammavaseneva āgato gacchasi ca, na tassa tava payogena kiñci
analyzed: ca tvam pi attanā kata kamma vasena iva āgataḥ gacchasi ca na tassa tava payogena kiñci
translated: He looks on with equanimity: he has come and gone by the force of his own kamma, and you have come and gone by the force of your own kamma.

original: sukhaṃ vā upanetuṃ, dukkhaṃ vā apanetuṃ labbhā, kevalaṃ panetaṃ cittassa anujukammaṃ,
analyzed: sukham vā upanetum dukkham vā apanetum labbhā kevalam pana itam cittassa anuju kammaṃ
translated: There is no way you can bring him happiness or take away his suffering.🔽You can only help your mind by being friendly to beings, etc.,

original: yadidaṃ mettāyanādinā sattesu kelāyanaṃ. Buddhādīhi ariyehi gatamaggo cesa apaṇṇakapaṭipadābhūto,
analyzed: yat idam mettāyana ādinā sattesu kelāyanam buddha ādīhi ariyehi gata maggaḥ ca īsa apaṇṇaka paṭipadā bhūto
translated: and by following the path gone by the Noble Ones, the Buddhas, etc.,

original: yadidaṃ sabbasattesu majjhattatāti evaṃ paṭipakkhajigucchāmukhena majjhattatāya samupajātagāravabahumānādaro🔽taṃ puggalaṃ punappunaṃ ajjhupekkhati, tattha ca savisesaṃ upekkhaṃ paccupaṭṭhapeti,
analyzed: yat idam sabba sattesu majjhatta tā ati evam paṭipakkha jigucchā mukhena majjhatta tāya samupajāta gārava bahu māna ādaraḥ  tam puggalam punappunam ajjhupekkhati tattha ca savisesam upekkham paccupaṭṭhapeti
translated: which is the way to the unerring practice, namely, by being impartial to all beings.🔽Thus, by way of the disgust that is the opposite of partiality, he generates respect and esteem for that person and

original: tassa tathā paṭipajjato pakatiyāpi udāsinattā sātisayaṃ tattha majjhattatā saṇṭhāti.
analyzed: tassa tathā paṭipajjataḥ pakatiyā api sa atisayam tattha majjhatta tā saṇṭhāti
translated: again and again looks on at him with equanimity, and he establishes a special kind of equanimity towards him.🔽As he practices in this way, his natural impartiality towards that person becomes more pronounced.

original: Bhāvanābalena nīvaraṇāni vikkhambhitāneva honti, kilesā sannisinnā eva honti, so
analyzed: bhāvanā balena nīvaraṇāni vikkhambhitāni iva honti kilesāḥ sannisinnāḥ eva honti
translated: By the power of development the hindrances are merely suppressed, and the defilements are merely suppressed.

original: taṃ upekkhaṃ piyapuggalādīsu upasaṃharati. Tenāha “upekkhā uppādetabbā. Tato piyapuggalādīsū”ti.
analyzed: tam upekkham piya puggala ādīsu upasaṃharati tena āha upekkhā uppādetabbā tatas piya puggala ādīsu iti
translated: He directs that equanimity towards the dear person, and so on. Hence it was said above: “Equanimity should be aroused towards the dear person, and so on” .

original: Ekaṃ puggalanti ettha aññattho eka-saddo “ittheke abhivadantī”tiādīsu viya. Ekavacaneneva
analyzed: ekam puggalam ti ettha aññatthaḥ eka saddo itthā eke abhivadanti itiādīsu viya ekavacanena iva
translated: “One person”: the word “one” has the meaning of another, as in such passages as “Some say thus” .🔽And the distinction of number is established by the singular form.

original: cettha saṅkhyāviseso siddho, tasmā aññaṃ ekaṃ puggalanti ayamettha attho. Tena attānaṃ🔽nivatteti. “Neva manāpa”nti iminā piyapuggalaṃ, atippiyasahāyakañca nivatteti, attānampi
analyzed: ca ittha saṅkhyā visesaḥ siddhaḥ tasmai aññam ekam puggalan ti ayam ettha attho tena attānam  nivatteti na iva manāpanti iminā piya puggalam atippiya sahāyakam ca nivatteti attānam pi
translated: So the meaning here is: “another person.” He excludes himself by that.🔽By “not-displeasing” he excludes the dear person and the very dear friend, or himself,

original: vā attani amanāpatāya abhāvato. “Na amanāpa”nti iminā appiyaṃ, veripuggalañca, pārisesato🔽majjhattapuggalassa gahaṇaṃ āpannaṃ. Iti “ekaṃ puggalaṃ neva manāpaṃ nāmanāpa”nti
analyzed: vā attani amanāpatāya abhāvataḥ na iminā appiyam veri puggalam ca pārisesato  majjhatta puggalassa gahaṇam āpannam iti ekam puggalam na iva manāpam na amanāpanti
translated: since there is no displeasure towards himself. By “not- displeasing” he excludes the neutral person, since he is included in the category of the displeasing, the enemy.

original: iminā attano, piyādīnañca paṭikkhepamukhena udāsinapuggalaṃ dasseti.
analyzed: iminā attanaḥ piya ādīnam ca paṭikkhepa mukhena udāsina puggalam dasseti
translated: Thus by the words “one person who is neither displeasing nor pleasing” he shows a person who is neutral, by way of excluding himself and the dear person, and so on.

original: Vuttanayenāti “yvāssa pakatimajjhatto”tiādinā anantaraṃ vuttena nayena. Attasinehassa
analyzed: vutta nayena ati yvā assa pakatim ajjhattaḥ ti ādinā anantaram vuttena nayena
translated: In the way already stated: in the way stated immediately before in the passage beginning, “The middle one of his three fingers is neither painful nor pleasant” .

original: balavabhāvato veritopi attani majjhattatāya durūpasaṃhārattā “imesu ca attani cā”ti🔽attā pacchā vutto. Pathavīkasiṇe vuttanayenevāti “ayaṃ samāpatti āsannapītipaccatthikā”tiādinā
analyzed: balava bhāvataḥ attani majjhatta tāya durūpa saṃhāra ttā imesu ca attani ca ati  attā pacchā vuttaḥ pathavī kasiṇe vutta nayena iva ati ayam samāpatti āsanna pīti paccatthika ati ādinā
translated: Because of the strength of self-love, even an enemy is neutral to himself, and so he is mentioned last as “himself” in the passage beginning, “In these and in himself” .🔽In the way already stated in the case of the earth kasiṇa: in the way already stated in the case of the earth kasiṇa in the passage beginning, “This attainment has near and far neighbors” .

original: pathavīkasiṇe vuttanayena. Yaṃ hi heṭṭhā “paguṇatatiyajjhānā vuṭṭhāyā”tiādi vuttaṃ,
analyzed: pathavī kasiṇe vutta nayena yam hi heṭṭhā paguṇa tatiya jhānāḥ vuṭṭhāya atiādi vuttaṃ
translated: For what was said there in the passage beginning, “after emerging from the third jhāna, which is made familiar by the fourfold method,”

original: taṃ heṭṭhā tīsu brahmavihāresu, catutthabrahmavihāre ca ādīnavānisaṃsadassanavasena🔽vuttaṃ. Idaṃ pana tatiyajjhāne ādīnavaṃ, catutthajjhāne ca ānisaṃsaṃ disvā catutthādhigamāya
analyzed: tam heṭṭhā tīsu brahmavihāresu catuttha brahmavihāre ca ādīnava a nisaṃsa dassana vasena  vuttam idam pana tatiya jhāne ādīnavam catuttha jhāne ca ānisaṃsam disvā catuttha adhigamāya
translated: was said there in the case of the first three divine abidings and the fourth divine abiding by showing the danger in them and the benefit in the fourth divine abiding.

original: yogaṃ karontassa catutthajjhānassa uppajjanākāradassanaṃ. Tasmā tattha vuttaṃ “pathavīsaddaṃ
analyzed: yogam karontassa catuttha jjhānassa uppajjana ākāra dassanam tasmā tattha vuttam pathavī saddam
translated: But here the danger in the third jhāna and the benefit in the fourth jhāna are shown, and this is said for one who is practising for the attainment of the fourth jhāna after seeing the danger in the third jhāna and the benefit in the fourth jhāna.🔽That is why it is said, “The earth kasiṇa” , and so on.

original: apanetvā tadeva nimittaṃ ārammaṇaṃ katvā manodvārāvajjanaṃ uppajjatī”tiādinā yojetabbaṃ.
analyzed: apanetvā tat eva nimittam ārammaṇam katvā manaḥ dvāra āvajjanam uppajjati iti ādinā yojetabbam
translated: and after it has done so, the adverting of the mind-door consciousness arises making that same sign its object.”

original: Pathavīkasiṇādīsūti ādi-saddena sesakasiṇāni, assāsapassāsanimittañca saṅgaṇhāti.
analyzed: pathavī kasiṇa ādīsu iti ādi saddena sesa kasiṇāni assāsa passāsa nimittam ca saṅgaṇhāti
translated: The earth kasiṇa, etc.,

original: Kāmaṃ kasiṇānāpānesu uppannassāpi tatiyajjhānassa upekkhābrahmavihārena rūpāvacarajjhānāditāya
analyzed: kāmam kasiṇa anāpānesu uppannassa api tatiya jhānassa upekkhā brahmavihārena rūpāvacara jhāna āditāya
translated: Though the third jhāna arisen in the kasiṇa and in the respiration is of the fine-material sphere,

original: attheva sabhāgatā, taṃ pana akāraṇaṃ ārammaṇassa visadisatāyāti āha “ārammaṇavisabhāgatāyā”ti.🔽Nanu ca aññathāva kasiṇādibhāvanā, aññathā brahmavihārabhāvanāti bhāvanāvasenāpi
analyzed: atthā iva sabhāga tā tam pana akāraṇam ārammaṇassa visadisa tāya ati āha ārammaṇa visabhāga tāya ati  nanu ca kasiṇa ādi bhāvanā aññathā brahmavihāra bhāvanā ati bhāvanā vasena api
translated: nevertheless it is not a cause for rebirth in the fine-material sphere because its object is unlike that of the fine-material jhānas.

original: yathāvuttajjhānānaṃ attheva visadisatāti? Saccametaṃ, bhāvanāvasena pana visadisatā🔽anuppattiyā na ekantikaṃ kāraṇaṃ. Tathā hi aññathāva mettādibhāvanā, aññathā upekkhābhāvanā.
analyzed: yathā vutta jhānānam atthā iva visadisa tā ati saccam etam bhāvanā vasena pana visadisa tā  anuppattiyāḥ na ekantikam kāraṇam tathā hi aññathā va mettā ādi bhāvanā aññathā upekkhā bhāvanā
translated: But is not the development of the kasiṇa, etc., different from the development of the divine abidings? And is not the difference in the development a cause for the difference in the jhāna?🔽Though that is so, the difference in the development is not a decisive cause for the difference in the jhāna.🔽For the development of loving-kindness, etc., is different from the development of equanimity,🔽and yet the equanimity is of the same kind as the others.

original: Tathāpi sattesu yathāpavattitaṃ hitesitādiākāraṃ byatirekamukhena āmasantī, tato
analyzed: tathā api sattesu yathā pavattitam hita isita ādi ākāram byatireka mukhena āmasantī tatas
translated: So it is the difference in the object that is the decisive cause here.

original: vinivattamānarūpena ajjhupekkhanākārena brahmavihārupekkhā pavattati. Tathā hi vakkhati
analyzed: vinivattamāna rūpena ajjhupekkhana ākārena brahmavihāra upekkhā pavattati tathā hi vakkhati
translated: The equanimity of the divine abidings occurs in the aspect of looking on with equanimity, which is the opposite of the aspect of turning away.🔽For it is said:

original: “kammassakā sattā, te kassa ruciyā sukhitā vā bhavissantī”tiādi. Ārammaṇasabhāgatāpi
analyzed: kammassakā sattā te kassa ruciyā sukhitāḥ vā bhavissanti itiādi ārammaṇa sabhāga tā api
translated: Equanimity as a divine abiding occurs in the aspect of looking on with equanimity, in the aspect of non-opposition. For this is said: “Beings are owners of their kamma, kamma is their kin, kamma is what they are born from, kamma is their refuge, kamma is their distinct portion” , and so on. And there is similarity of object too,

original: cettha atthīti mettādivasena paṭiladdhatatiyajjhānassa ijjhati upekkhābrahmavihāro.🔽Tena vuttaṃ “mettādīsū”tiādi. Tattha mettādīsūti mettādīsu nipphādetabbesu, mettādivasenāti
analyzed: ca ittha atthi iti mettā ādi vasena paṭiladdha tatiya jhānassa ijjhati upekkhā brahmavihāro  tena vuttam mettā ādīsu utiādi tattha mettā ādīsu iti mettā ādīsu nipphādetabbesu mettā ādi vasena ati
translated: so the divine abiding of equanimity succeeds by means of the third jhāna obtained by the method of loving-kindness, and so on.

original: attho. Sesaṃ heṭṭhā vuttanayameva.
analyzed: atthaḥ sesam heṭṭhā vutta nayam eva
translated: That is why it is said, “By the method of loving-kindness, and so on.” Herein, “by the method of loving-kindness, and so on” means by the method of loving-kindness, and so on, that is to be produced. The rest is as already stated.

original: Pakiṇṇakakathāvaṇṇanā
analyzed: pakiṇṇaka kathā vaṇṇanā
translated: The description of the supplementary discussion is ended.

original: 262. Brahmuttamenāti ettha sammutibrahmāno upapattibrahmāno visuddhibrahmānoti tividhā brahmāno.
analyzed: brahmuttamena ati ettha sammuti brahmānaḥ upapatti brahmānaḥ visuddhi brahmānaḥ ti tividhāḥ brahmānaḥ
translated: As to “Brahma’s highest,” here the Brahmas are of three kinds, that is to say, conventional Brahmas, Brahmas as rebirth, and purified Brahmas.🔽“The well-filled rice and juicy meat,

original: “Sampannaṃ sālikedāraṃ, suvā bhuñjanti kosiya;
analyzed: sampannam sāli kedāram suvā bhuñjanti kosiya
translated: The Suvāsas eat, O Brahmā,

original: Paṭivedemi te brahme, na ne vāretumussahe. ;
analyzed: paṭivedemi te brahme na ne vāretum ussahe
translated: I confess to you, O Brahmā, I am not able to lead them away.

original: Paribbaja mahābrahme, pacantaññepi pāṇino”ti. –
analyzed: paribbaja mahābrahme
translated: Wander forth, O Great Brahmā, while other breathing things are cooking” .

original: Ca evamādīsu hi brahmasaddena sammutibrahmāno vuttā.
analyzed: ca evamādīsu hi brahma saddena sammuti brahmānaḥ vuttā
translated: Herein, it is conventional Brahmas that are called “Brahmā” in such passages as this.

original: “Apārutā tesaṃ amatassa dvārā,
analyzed: apārutā tesam amatassa dvārā
translated: “The doors to the Deathless are thrown open;

original: Ye sotavanto pamuñcantu saddhaṃ;🔽Vihiṃsasaññī paguṇaṃ na bhāsiṃ,
analyzed: ye sotavantaḥ pamuñcantu saddham  vihiṃsa saññī paguṇam na bhāsim
translated: Let those with ears to hear come and believe.🔽I have not spoken of the subtle Dhamma

original: Dhammaṃ paṇītaṃ manujesu brahme”.
analyzed: dhammam paṇītam manujesu brahme
translated: To one who is not receptive to it, O Brahmā.”

original: “Atha kho brahmā sahampatī”ti ca evamādīsu brahmasaddena upapattibrahmāno vuttā.
analyzed: atha kho brahmā sahampati iti ca evamādīsu brahma saddena upapatti brahmānaḥ vuttā
translated: In such passages as “Then Brahmā Sahampati” , the word “brahmā” refers to the Brahmās of rebirth.

original: “Brahmacakkaṃ pavattetī”tiādi vacanato “brahma”nti ariyadhammo vuccati, tato nibbattattā
analyzed: brahma cakkam pavatteti itiādi vacanataḥ brahman ti ariya dhammaḥ vuccati tatas nibbatta ttā
translated: In the passage “He sets in motion the wheel of the Dhamma” , the word “brahmā” refers to the noble Dhamma.

original: avisesena sabbepi ariyā visuddhibrahmāno nāma paramatthabrahmatāya. Visesato pana
analyzed: avisesena sabbe pi ariyāḥ visuddhibrahmānaḥ nāma paramattha brahmatāya visesato pana
translated: All noble persons are called “pure brahmās” because they have attained the ultimate brahma-state.

original: “brahmāti, bhikkhave, tathāgatassetaṃ adhivacana”nti vacanato sammāsambuddho uttamabrahmā
analyzed: brahmā ati bhikkhave tathāgatassa itam adhivacanan ti vacanataḥ sammāsambuddhaḥ uttama brahmā
translated: In the passage “‘Brahmā,’ bhikkhus, is a designation for the Tathāgata” , the Supreme Buddha is called the “highest brahmā”

original: nāma sadevake loke brahmabhūtehi guṇehi ukkaṃsapāramippattito. Iti brahmānaṃ uttamo,
analyzed: nāma sa devake loke brahma bhūtehi guṇehi ukkaṃsa pārami ppattitaḥ iti brahmānam uttamaḥ
translated: because he has reached the culmination of the brahma-qualities in the world with its gods. Thus he is the “highest brahmā”

original: brahmā ca so uttamo cāti vā brahmuttamo, bhagavā. Tena kathite “so mettāsahagatena
analyzed: brahmā ca saḥ uttamaḥ ca ati vā brahmuttamaḥ bhagavā tena kathite saḥ mettā sahagatena
translated: because he is the highest of the brahmās. He is also called “brahmā” because he is the highest brahmā. It is said of him:🔽“He who has taught the Dhamma to the world

original: cetasā”tiādinā tattha tattha veneyyānaṃ desite. Itīti evaṃ yathāvuttena bhāvanākkamena
analyzed: cetasā ati ādinā tattha tattha veneyyānam desite iti iti evam yathāvuttena bhāvanā kkamena
translated: and so on, in the various places where they are taught. Thus: having known, having understood, in the way stated, in the order of the development and in the order of the commentary.

original: ceva atthavaṇṇanākkamena ca viditvā jānitvā. Pakiṇṇakakathāpi viññeyyāti pubbe viya
analyzed: ca iva attha vaṇṇanā kkamena ca viditvā jānitvā pakiṇṇaka kathā api viññeyyā ati pubbe viya
translated: The miscellaneous explanations should be understood: as before,

original: asādhāraṇaṃ taṃtaṃbrahmavihārapaṭiniyatameva atthaṃ aggahetvā sādhāraṇabhāvato tattha🔽tattha pakiṇṇakaṃ visaṭaṃ atthaṃ gahetvā pavattitā pakiṇṇakakathāpi vijānitabbā.
analyzed: asādhāraṇam taṃ taṃ brahmavihāra paṭiniyatam eva attham aggahetvā sādhāraṇa bhāvato tattha  tattha pakiṇṇakam visaṭam attham gahetvā pavatti tā pakiṇṇaka kathā api vijānitabbā
translated: not taking up the special meaning peculiar to each divine abiding, but rather the miscellaneous, scattered meaning common to all,🔽which occurs in the various places.

original: Mejjatīti dhammato aññassa kattunivattanatthaṃ dhammameva kattāraṃ katvā niddisati.🔽Siniyhatīti ettha sattesu byāpajjanavasena lūkhabhāvassa paṭipakkhabhūtaṃ ñāṇapubbaṅgamaṃ🔽hitākārapavattivasena sinehanaṃ daṭṭhabbaṃ, na taṇhāyanavasena. Taṃ hi mohapubbaṅgamaṃ
analyzed: mejjati iti dhammataḥ aññassa kattu nivattana attham dhammam eva kattāram katvā niddisati  siniyhati iti ettha sattesu byāpajjana vasena lūkha bhāvassa paṭipakkha bhūtam ñāṇa pubbaṅgamam  hita ākāra pavatti vasena sinehanam daṭṭhabbam na taṇhāyana vasena tam hi moha pubbaṅgamam
translated: It is shown: the Dhamma is shown as the doer for the sake of the occurrence of the doer’s function in the sense of the Dhamma.🔽It is moistened: here the moistening should be regarded as the wetting of the heart’s core with loving-kindness, etc., which has knowledge as its forerunner and is the opposite of the state of being rough through lack of loving- kindness towards beings, not as the moistening through craving. For that has delusion as its forerunner and is by nature a clinging, while this is by nature a non-clinging associated with non-greed.

original: lubbhanasabhāvaṃ, idaṃ pana adussanasabhāvaṃ alobhasampayuttaṃ. Nanu ca taṇhāsinehopi
analyzed: lubbhana sabhāvam idam pana adussana sabhāvam alobha sampayuttam nanu ca taṇhā sinehaḥ api
translated: But is not the moistening through craving

original: byāpādavirodhī tena sahānavaṭṭhānato. Yadipi tena saha ekasmiṃ citte nappavattati,
analyzed: byāpāda virodhī tena saha anavaṭṭhānataḥ yadi api tena saha ekasmim citte na ppavattati
translated: Because it is incompatible with ill will. Even though it does not occur in the same consciousness with ill will,🔽it is not incompatible with it because it is not abandoned by the path that abandons ill will.

original: virodhī pana na hoti appahāyakato. Mejjatīti mitto, hitajjhāsayo khandhappabandho,
analyzed: virodhī pana na hoti appahāyakato mejjati iti mittaḥ hi tajjhāsayaḥ khandha ppabandho
translated: “Friend” is one who is friendly, a continuity of being that has the disposition to help.

original: tappariyāpannatāya mitte bhavā, mitte vā ārammaṇabhūte piye puggale bhavā, mittassa
analyzed: tad pariyāpanna tāya mitte bhavā mitte vā ārammaṇa bhūte piye puggale bhavā mittassa
translated: It is “in a friend” because it is included in a friend, or it is “in a friend” because it is in a dear person who is a friend as object.

original: esā pavatti mejjanavasena vāti veditabbā.
analyzed: esā pavatti mejjana vasena vā ati veditabbā
translated: The occurrence of compassion should be understood as shaking in a friend.

original: Karotīti karuṇā, kiṃ karoti, kesaṃ, kiṃ nimittanti āha “paradukkhe sati sādhūnaṃ
analyzed: karoti iti karuṇā kim karoti kesam kim nimittam ti āha para dukkhe sati sādhūnam
translated: “Compassion” is the shaking of the heart of good people when there is the suffering of others.

original: hadayakampana”nti. Kampananti ca paresaṃ dukkhaṃ disvā tassa apanetukāmassa asahanākārena🔽cittassa aññathattaṃ. Tayidaṃ sappurisānaṃyeva hotīti āha “sādhūna”nti. Sappurisā
analyzed: hadaya kampananti kampananti ca paresam dukkham disvā tassa apanetu kāmassa a sahana ākārena  cittassa aññathattam tayidam hoti iti āha sādhūnanti sappurisā
translated: “Shaking” is the alteration of the mind of one who, on seeing the suffering of others, is unable to bear it and wants to remove it.🔽And this occurs only in good people, thus it is said to be “of good people.”🔽For good people are called “good” because they accomplish the welfare of others.

original: hi saparahitasādhanena “sādhū”ti vuccanti. Vināsetīti adassanaṃ gameti, apanetīti
analyzed: hi sa para hita sādhanena sādhu uti vuccanti vināseti iti adassanam gameti apaneti iti
translated: “It destroys” means it sends to the undestroyed, it removes.

original: attho. Tenettha hiṃsanaṃ apanayananti dasseti. Paradukkhāpanayanākārappavattilakkhaṇā🔽hi karuṇā. Pharaṇavasenāti phusanavasena, ārammaṇakaraṇavasenāti attho. Ārammaṇakaraṇañcettha
analyzed: atthaḥ tena ittha hiṃsanam apanayananti dasseti para dukkha apanayana ākāra ppavatti lakkhaṇā  hi karuṇā pharaṇa vasena ati phusana vasena ārammaṇa karaṇa vasena ati atthaḥ ārammaṇa karaṇam ca ittha
translated: and the meaning is that he shows the removal of the harm.🔽For compassion has the characteristic of occurrence in the aspect of the removal of the suffering of others.

original: dukkhitesu dukkhāpanayanākārenevāti daṭṭhabbaṃ.
analyzed: dukkhitesu dukkha apanayana ākārena iva ati daṭṭhabbam
translated: By means of pervading: by means of pervading, by means of making the object, is the meaning. And here the making the object should be regarded as being by means of the aspect of the removal of suffering in those who are suffering.

original: Modanti tāyāti modanakiriyāya muditāya karaṇabhāvaniddeso, svāyaṃ upacārasiddho,🔽muditāvinimutto natthi tattha koci kattāti tameva kattubhāvena niddisati “sayaṃ vā
analyzed: modanti tāya ati modana kiriyāya muditāya karaṇa bhāva niddeso su ayam upacāra siddho  muditā vinimuttaḥ na atthi tattha koci kattā ati tam eva kattu bhāvena niddisati sayam vā
translated: They rejoice by means of it: this is a description of the instrumentality of gladness in the act of rejoicing. This is established by convention,🔽for there is no agent there apart from gladness. He describes it as the agent itself, saying, “It itself rejoices,” and this too is a conventional description.

original: modatī”ti, ayampi upacāraniddesova. Dhammānaṃ avasavattanatoti vasavattibhāvanivāraṇatthaṃ
analyzed: modati iti ayam pi upacāra niddesaḥ uva dhammānam vasa vatti bhāva nivāraṇa attham
translated: Because of the non-existence of the state of being a master: in order to prevent the state of being a master,

original: “modanamattameva vā tanti muditā”ti āha.
analyzed: modana mattam eva vā tanti muditā iti āha
translated: he says, “Gladness is mere rejoicing.”

original: Piyādīsu pakkhapātupacchedanamukhena udāsinabhāvasaṅkhātā upapattito ikkhā upekkhā. Tenāha “averā hontū”tiādi. Tattha upekkhatīti kattuniddese kāraṇaṃ heṭṭhā vuttameva.
analyzed: piya ādīsu pakkha pāta upacchedana mukhena upapattitaḥ ikkhā upekkhā tena āha averāḥ hontu utiādi tattha upekkhati iti kattu niddese kāraṇam heṭṭhā vuttam eva
translated: Equanimity is so called because of the occurrence of neutrality, which is called “neutrality” in the sense of the severing of the partiality consisting in affection, etc., towards those who are the bases of equanimity. Hence he said, “May they be free from enmity” , etc. Herein, the reason for the description of the agent is the same as that given above .

original: 263. Hito nāma atthacaro, tasmā hitākārappavattilakkhaṇāti sattānaṃ hitacaraṇākārena
analyzed: hitaḥ nāma attha caraḥ tasmā hita ākāra ppavatti lakkhaṇā ati sattānam hita caraṇa ākārena
translated: The meaning of “beneficial” is “beneficial conduct.” So its characteristic is that of occurring in the aspect of what is beneficial,

original: pavattilakkhaṇā, hitākārassa vā pavattanalakkhaṇā. Hitūpasaṃhārarasāti sattesu hitassa🔽upanayanakiccā, upanayanasampattikā vā. “Anatthaṃ me acarī”tiādinā pavattanakassa🔽āghātassa vinayanākārena paccupatiṭṭhati, ñāṇassa gocarabhāvaṃ gacchati, yattha vā
analyzed: pavatti lakkhaṇā hita ākārassa vā pavattana lakkhaṇā hitu upasaṃhāra rasā ati sattesu hitassa  upanayana kiccāḥ upanayana sampattikāḥ vā anattham me acari iti ādinā pavattanakassa  āghātassa vinayana ākārena paccupatiṭṭhati ñāṇassa gocara bhāvam gacchati yattha vā
translated: or its characteristic is that of causing the aspect of what is beneficial to occur. Its function is to bring about what is beneficial for beings,🔽or its function is to bring about the success of bringing about what is beneficial. It is manifested as the allaying of annoyance,

original: sayaṃ uppajjati, tattha āghātavinayanaṃ paccupaṭṭhapetīti āghātavinayapaccupaṭṭhānā.
analyzed: sayam uppajjati tattha āghāta vinayanam paccupaṭṭhapeti iti āghāta vinaya paccupaṭṭhānā
translated: for it is manifested as the allaying of annoyance in the way already stated, that is, in the way beginning, “When someone does me harm” , and it is manifested as the allaying of annoyance wherever it arises, either in the field of knowledge or of action.

original: Amanāpānampi sattānaṃ paṭikkūle appaṭikkūlasaññitārūpena, pageva manāpānaṃ yaṃ manāpabhāvadassanaṃ,
analyzed: a manāpānam pi sattānam paṭikkūle appaṭikkūla saññi tā rūpena pagā iva manāpānam yam manāpa bhāva dassanam
translated: It has as its proximate cause the seeing of what is lovable in beings, for it occurs in one who sees what is lovable in beings, even in those who are unlovely, as though they were unlovely, still more in those who are lovely.

original: tathāpavatto yonisomanasikāro, taṃ padaṭṭhānaṃ etissāti manāpabhāvadassanapadaṭṭhānā.
analyzed: tathā pavattaḥ yoniso manasikāro tam padaṭṭhānam etissa ati manāpa bhāva dassana padaṭṭhānā
translated: The right reflection that occurs in this way is its proximate cause.

original: Byāpādūpasamoti byāpādassa vikkhambhanavasena vūpasamo. Sampattīti sampajjanaṃ sammadeva
analyzed: byāpāda upasamaḥ ti byāpādassa vikkhambhana vasena vūpasamaḥ sampatti iti sampajjanam sammat eva
translated: Its cessation is the subsiding of ill will.

original: nibbatti. Sinehasambhavoti taṇhāsinehassa uppatti. Vipattīti vināso. Mettāmukhena hi rāgo vañceti.
analyzed: nibbatti sineha sambhavo ti taṇhā sinehassa uppatti vipatti iti vināsaḥ mettā mukhena hi rāgaḥ vañca iti
translated: The origination of affection is the arising of the affection of craving. The destruction is the disappearance of that. For love deceives by the face of friendliness.

original: Karuṇādīnaṃ lakkhaṇādīsu iminā nayena attho veditabbo. Visesamattameva vaṇṇayissāma.
analyzed: karuṇā ādīnam lakkhaṇa ādīsu iminā nayena atthaḥ veditabbaḥ visesa mattam eva vaṇṇayissāma
translated: The meaning should be understood in this way in the case of the characteristics, etc., of compassion, and so on. We shall only comment on the difference.

original: Sattānaṃ pavattadukkhassa apanayanākāro. Apanayanaṃ pana hotu vā mā vā, yo dukkhāpanayanākāro,
analyzed: sattānam pavatta dukkhassa apanayana ākāraḥ apanayanam pana hotu vā mā vā yaḥ dukkha apanayana ākāro
translated: The mode of removing suffering that occurs in beings. And the removal may or may not take place, but the mode of removing suffering is

original: tathāpavattilakkhaṇā dukkhāpanayanākārappavattilakkhaṇā. Apanetukāmatāya paresaṃ🔽dukkhassa asahanaṃ anadhivāsanaṃ paradukkhāsahanaṃ. Na vihiṃsā avihiṃsā, sattānaṃ
analyzed: tathā pavatti lakkhaṇā dukkha apanayana ākāra ppavatti lakkhaṇā apanetu kāma tāya paresam  dukkhassa asahanam anadhivāsanam para dukkha asahanam na vihiṃsā avihiṃsā sattānam
translated: the characteristic of which is the occurrence of the mode of removing suffering. The wish to remove is the wish to remove the suffering of others.🔽The inability to bear, the non-endurance, of the suffering of others is the non-endurance of the suffering of others. Non-violence is the opposite of violence.

original: aviheṭhanaṃ. Taṃ paccupaṭṭhapeti, vihiṃsāya vā paṭipakkhabhāvena paccupatiṭṭhatīti
analyzed: a viheṭhanam tam paccupaṭṭhapeti vihiṃsāya vā paṭipakkha bhāvena paccupatiṭṭhati iti
translated: The non-harming of beings is the non-harming of beings. It is manifested as the opposite of violence. Or it is manifested as the opposite of violence in the sense that it stands opposed to violence.

original: avihiṃsāpaccupaṭṭhānā. Vihiṃsūpasamoti ettha vihiṃsanti etāya satte, vihiṃsanaṃ vā
analyzed: a vihiṃsā paccupaṭṭhānā vihiṃsu upasamā ti ettha vihiṃsanti etāya satte vihiṃsanam vā
translated: The pacification of violence: here, one is violent through this, or it causes violence,🔽or it is violence itself.

original: nesaṃ tanti vihiṃsā, sattānaṃ viheṭhanākārena pavatto karuṇāya paṭipakkhabhūto paṭighacittuppādo.
analyzed: na īsam tanti vihiṃsā sattānam viheṭhana ākārena pavatto karuṇāya paṭipakkha bhūto paṭigha cittuppādo
translated: It is the arising of a thought of resistance in the opposite sense to that of compassion, which occurs in the aspect of annoyance with beings.

original: Karuṇāmukhena soko vañcetīti āha “sokasambhavo vipattī”ti.
analyzed: karuṇā mukhena sokaḥ vañca iti iti āha soka sambhavaḥ vipatti iti
translated: Since it deceives by the aspect of sorrow, it is said that “the source of sorrow is misfortune.”

original: Pamodanalakkhaṇāti parasampattiyā pamodanalakkhaṇā. Anissāyanarasāti issāyanassa
analyzed: pamodana lakkhaṇā ati para sampattiyā pamodana lakkhaṇā a nissāyana rasā ati issāyanassa
translated: The characteristic of gladdening is the characteristic of gladness at another’s success. The function of non-envy is the function of being the opposite of envy and jealousy.

original: usūyanassa paṭipakkhabhāvakiccā. Sattānaṃ sampattiyā, pantasenāsanesu, adhikusaladhammesu
analyzed: usūyanassa paṭipakkha bhāva kiccā sattānam sampattiyā panta senāsanesu adhi kusala dhammesu
translated: The manifestation of non-envy is the manifestation of the non-bearing, the non-enjoyment, of the success of beings, of the good things of the world, and of the higher profitable ideas.

original: ca asahanaṃ aramaṇaṃ aratiicceva saṅgahaṃ gacchati, tassā vihananākārena paccupatiṭṭhati,
analyzed: ca a sahanam a ramaṇam a rati icca iva saṅgaham gacchati tassāḥ vihanana ākārena paccupatiṭṭhati
translated: It is the manifestation of the non-bearing of the success of beings, etc., which occurs in the aspect of annoyance with that success.

original: tassa vā vighātaṃ vūpasamaṃ paccupaṭṭhapetīti arativighātapaccupaṭṭhānā.🔽Pahāso gehasitapītivasena pahaṭṭhabhāvo uppilāvitattaṃ. Sattesu samabhāvadassanarasāti
analyzed: tassa vā vighātam vūpasamam paccupaṭṭhapeti iti arati vighāta paccupaṭṭhānā
translated: Or it is the manifestation of the allaying of the annoyance with that success.🔽It is the state of being gladdened by the gladness of the householders. It is the state of being elated. The function of equanimity towards beings is the function of seeing the neutrality of all beings without making distinctions such as “friend” and “enemy.”

original: piyādibhedesu sabbasattesu udāsinavuttiyā samabhāvasseva dassanakiccā, upapattito
analyzed: piya ādi bhedesu sabba sattesu udāsina vuttiyā sama bhāvassa iva dassana kiccā upapattito
translated: The manifestation of equanimity towards beings is the manifestation of neutrality in conduct towards all beings without making distinctions such as “friend” and “enemy.”

original: ikkhaṇato samabhāveneva tesaṃ gahaṇakiccāti attho. Sattesu paṭikkūlāpaṭikkūlākārānaṃ🔽aggahaṇato tattha paṭighānunayānaṃ vūpasamanākārena vuttiyā tesaṃ vūpasamaṃ vikkhambhanaṃ
analyzed: ikkhaṇataḥ sama bhāvena iva tesam gahaṇa kiccā ati attho sattesu  aggahaṇato tattha paṭigha anunayānam vūpasamana ākārena vuttiyā tesam vūpasamam vikkhambhanam
translated: The meaning is that they function by apprehending them as equal in the sense of non-difference.🔽Because they do not apprehend the aspects of repulsiveness and non-repulsiveness in beings,

original: paccupaṭṭhapetīti paṭighānunayavūpasamapaccupaṭṭhānā. Evaṃ pavattakammassakatādassanapadaṭṭhānāti🔽ettha “eva”nti iminā byatirekamukhena hitūpasaṃhāradukkhāpanayanasampattipamodanākārena🔽paccāmasanto mettādīnaṃ tissannaṃ pavattiākārapaṭisedhanamukhena pavattaṃ kammassakatāñāṇaṃ
analyzed: paccupaṭṭhapeti iti paṭigha anunaya vūpasama paccupaṭṭhānā evam pavatta kammassaka tā dassana padaṭṭhānā ti  ettha evanti iminā byatireka mukhena hitu upasaṃhāra dukkha apanayana sampatti pamodana ākārena  mettā ādīnam tissannam pavatti ākāra paṭisedhana mukhena pavattam kammassaka tā ñāṇam
translated: they occur by way of the mode of tranquilizing resistance and resentment. So they are described as “having tranquilizing of resistance and resentment as their province” .🔽The “and so on” indicates the four divine abodes beginning with loving-kindness.🔽The “and so on” indicates that the knowledge of the state of owning that occurs by way of the mode of taking up what is beneficial, of gathering it together, of removing suffering, and of rejoicing in the attainment of excellence,

original: upekkhābrahmavihārassa āsannakāraṇaṃ, na yaṃ kiñcīti dasseti.
analyzed: upekkhā brahmavihārassa āsanna kāraṇam na yam kiñci iti dasseti
translated: by way of the mode of preventing the occurrence of the three modes of loving-kindness, etc., is the proximate cause for the equanimity divine abode, not just anything.

original: 264. Vipassanāsukhañceva bhavasampatti cāti ettha diṭṭhadhammasukhavihāro cāti vattabbaṃ.
analyzed: vipassanā sukham ca iva bhava sampatti ca ati ettha diṭṭhadhamma sukha vihāro ca ati vattabbam
translated: And the happiness of insight and the excellence of existence. Here it should be said: “and the abiding in bliss here and now.”

original: Tampi hi nesaṃ sādhāraṇapayojanaṃ. Tathā “sukhaṃ supatī”tiādayo ekādasānisaṃsā. Te
analyzed: hi hi sādhāraṇa payojanam tathā sukham supati iti ādayaḥ te
translated: For that too is a common purpose of theirs. So too, the eleven benefits beginning with “he sleeps in comfort” .

original: pana heṭṭhā vuttā evāti idha na gahitā.
analyzed: pana heṭṭhā vuttā eva ati idha na gahitā
translated: but since they have already been mentioned above, they are not included here.

original: Nissarati apagacchati etenāti nissaraṇaṃ, pahāyakaṃ. Kāmañcetehi pañcapi nīvaraṇāni,
analyzed: nissarati apagacchati etena ati nissaraṇam pahāyakam nīvaraṇāni
translated: The word nissaraṇa is derived from the prefix ni + s + √rañj; it means “that by which one goes out , departs ,” i.e., that which abandons . Although the five hindrances are abandoned by the practice of these four divine abidings,

original: tadekaṭṭhā ca pāpadhammā vikkhambhanavasena pahīyanti, ujuvipaccanīkadassanavasena🔽pana byāpādādayo pāḷiyaṃ vuttā. Evañca katvā rāganissaraṇatāvacanaṃ upekkhābrahmavihārassa
analyzed: tad ekaṭṭhā ca pāpa dhammā vikkhambhana vasena pahīyanti uju vipaccanīka dassana vasena  pana byāpāda ādayaḥ pāḷiyam vuttāḥ evañca katvā rāga nissaraṇa tā vacanam upekkhā brahmavihārassa
translated: and also other evil states that are rooted in them, it is only the abandoning of ill will, etc., that is mentioned in the text.

original: suṭṭhu samatthitaṃ daṭṭhabbaṃ.
analyzed: suṭṭhu samatthitam daṭṭhabbam
translated: And this is said in order to show the direct opposition .🔽Herein, in these divine abidings,

original: 265. Etthāti etesu brahmavihāresu. Mettā sattesu yathārahaṃ dānapiyavacanādisīlasutādiguṇagahaṇavasena🔽pavattati. Tena vuttaṃ “sattānaṃ manāpabhāvadassanapadaṭṭhānā”ti. Rāgopi tattha yathā
analyzed: ettha ati etesu brahmavihāresu mettā sattesu yathāraham dāna piya vacana ādi sīla suta ādi guṇa gahaṇa vasena  pavattati tena vuttam sattānam manāpa bhāva dassana padaṭṭhānā ati rāgaḥ upi tattha yathā
translated: loving-kindness occurs in the aspect of wishing happiness for beings according to their deserts,🔽and it is the basis for the perception of beings’ lovability, which arises in the aspect of seeing beings as worthy of affection through their possession of such and such qualities.

original: tathā guṇaggahaṇamukheneva pavattati manāpasaññāpalobhatoti āha “guṇadassanasabhāgatāyā”ti.
analyzed: tathā guṇa ggahaṇa mukhena iva pavattati manāpa saññā apalobhato ti āha guṇa dassana sabhā gatāya ati
translated: And greed occurs in the aspect of seeing such and such qualities, as the lust that delights in the perception of lovability.

original: Tasmā mittamukhasapatto viya tulyākārena dūsanato rāgo mettāya āsannapaccatthiko,
analyzed: tasmā mitta mukha sapattaḥ viya tulya ākārena dūsanataḥ rāgaḥ mettāya āsanna paccatthiko
translated: Therefore greed is a near enemy of loving-kindness, because it corrupts it by similarity of aspect, like an enemy with a friendly face.

original: so lahuṃ otāraṃ labhati satisammosamattenāpi mettaṃ apanīya tassā vatthusmiṃ uppajjanārahattā.🔽Tatoti rāgato, rāgassa vā otāralābhato. Sabhāgavisabhāgatāyāti sabhāgassa, sabhāgena
analyzed: saḥ lahum otāram labhati sati sammosa mattena api mettam apanīya tassāḥ vatthusmim uppajjana araha ttā  tatas iti rāgataḥ rāgassa vā otāra lābhato sabhāga visabhāga tāya ati sabhāgassa sabhāgena
translated: He finds an opportunity quickly, even by the mere lapse of mindfulness, because he is liable to arouse it on that object when he has abandoned loving-kindness.

original: vā visabhāgatāya. Sattesu hi manāpākāragāhino mettāsabhāgassa tabbiparītasabhāvo🔽byāpādo tena visabhāgo. Tasmā so otāraṃ labhamāno cireneva labheyyāti purisassa dūre
analyzed: vā visabhāga tāya sattesu hi manāpa ākāra gāhinaḥ mettā sabhāgassa tad biparīta sabhāvaḥ  byāpādaḥ tena visabhāgaḥ tasmā saḥ otāram labhamāno cirena iva labheyyāti purisassa dūre
translated: “From that”: from lust, or because lust finds an opportunity. “By similarity and dissimilarity”: by similarity to what is similar, or by dissimilarity to what is dissimilar. For ill will, which is the opposite of loving-kindness, is dissimilar to loving-kindness, which takes the aspect of loving-kindness towards beings who are objects of the latter.

original: ṭhitasapatto viya mettāya dūrapaccatthiko. Tatoti byāpādato. Nibbhayenāti anussaṅkanaparisaṅkanena,
analyzed: ṭhita sapattaḥ viya mettāya dūra paccatthiko tatas ti byāpādataḥ nibbhayena ati anussaṅkana parisaṅkanena
translated: Therefore, when it finds an opportunity, it does so only after a long time, like an enemy of a man who keeps far away. “From that”: from ill will. “It is driven out”: by the suspicion and the doubt;

original: laddhapatiṭṭhāya mettāya byāpādena duppadhaṃsiyattāti adhippāyo. Tenāha “mettāyissatī”tiādi.
analyzed: laddha patiṭṭhāya mettāya byāpādena duppadhaṃsiya ttā ati adhippāyaḥ tena āha mettāyissati itiādi
translated: the meaning is that it is hard to overcome by ill will when loving- kindness has gained a footing. That is why he said “it will be loving-kindness” and so on.

original: Iṭṭhānanti piyānaṃ. Kantānanti kamanīyānaṃ. Manāpānanti manavaḍḍhanakānaṃ. Tato eva
analyzed: piyānam kantānam kamanīyānam manāpānam anti tatas eva
translated: “Dear” : lovable. “Beloved” : delightful. “Agreeable” : enhancing.

original: mano ramentīti manoramānaṃ. Lokāmisapaṭisaṃyuttānanti taṇhāsannissitānaṃ. Appaṭilābhato
analyzed: manaḥ ramenti iti manoramānam loka āmisa paṭisaṃyuttānam ti taṇhā sannissitānam appaṭilābhato
translated: Delightful: delightful to the mind. Associated with worldly material things: associated with craving. As to non- acquisition:

original: samanupassatoti appaṭilābhena ahamime na labhāmīti paritassato. Atītanti atikkantaṃ.
analyzed: samanupassato ti appaṭilābhena aham ime na labhāmi iti paritassataḥ atītam ti atikkantam
translated: as to non-acquisition, thinking, “I do not get these.” As to the past: what is past.

original: Niruddhanti nirodhappattaṃ. Vipariṇatanti sabhāvavigamena vigataṃ. Samanussaratoti
analyzed: niruddhanti nirodha ppattam vipariṇatanti sabhāva vigamena vigatam samanussaratoti
translated: As to the ceased: what has reached cessation. As to the changed: what has departed by the dissolution of its individual essence. As to recollecting:

original: anutthunanavasena cintayato. Gehasitanti kāmaguṇanissitaṃ. “Ādinā”ti iminā “sotaviññeyyānaṃ
analyzed: cintayataḥ geha sitam ti kāma guṇa nissitam ādinā ti iminā sota viññeyyānam
translated: as to bringing to mind by way of not letting go. As to what is cherished: as to what is associated with the strands of sensual desire. “And so on” includes “sounds cognizable by the ear” and so on.

original: saddāna”nti evamādiṃ saṅgaṇhāti. Vipattidassanasabhāgatāyāti yesu sattesu bhogādivipattidassanamukhena🔽karuṇā pavattati, tesu tannimittameva ayoniso ābhoge sati yathāvuttadomanassamukhena
analyzed: saddānam ti evamādim saṅgaṇhāti vipatti dassana sabhāgatāya ati yesu sattesu bhoga ādi vipatti dassana mukhena  karuṇā pavattati tesu tad nimittam eva ayonisas ābhoge sati yathāvutta domanassa mukhena
translated: As to similarity in seeing failure: in regard to those beings in whom compassion arises by the way of seeing failure in their wealth, etc.,🔽when there is unwise attention to that as a reason, grief arises by way of the aforesaid sorrowfulness,

original: soko uppajjeyya, so karuṇāya āsannapaccatthiko. Soko hi idha domanassasīsena vutto.
analyzed: sokaḥ uppajjeyya saḥ karuṇāya āsanna paccatthiko sokaḥ hi idha domanassa sīsena vutto
translated: when there is unwise attention to that as a reason. This is an enemy close to compassion. For grief is mentioned here under the heading of sorrowfulness.

original: Sabhāgavisabhāgatāyāti ettha sattesu dukkhāpanayanakāmatākārassa karuṇāsabhāgassa🔽tesu dukkhūpanayanākāro vihesāsabhāvo visabhāgoti tāya sabhāgavisabhāgatāya sā otāraṃ
analyzed: sabhāga visabhāga tāya ti ettha sattesu dukkha apanayana kāma tā kārassa karuṇā sabhāgassa  tesu dukkha upanayana ākāraḥ vihesāsa bhāvaḥ visabhāgaḥ ti tāya sabhāga visabhāga tāya sā otāram
translated: As to similarity and dissimilarity of state: in the case of beings whom one loves because one wants to remove their suffering, compassion is similar in state to the loving-kindness that is the opposite of the ill will that finds pleasure in their suffering.

original: labhamānā cireneva labheyyāti purisassa dūre ṭhitasapatto viya karuṇāya dūrapaccatthikā vuttā.
analyzed: labhamānā cirena iva labheyya ati purisassa dūre ṭhita sapattaḥ viya karuṇāya dūra paccatthikā vuttā
translated: But the ill will that finds pleasure in their suffering is dissimilar in state to that. So this equanimity, which finds pleasure in the neutrality that is the opposite of both of these, gets an opportunity to arise and it arises after a long time, like an enemy who lives far away.

original: Sampattidassanasabhāgatāyāti yesu sattesu bhogādisampattidassanamukhena muditā pavattati,
analyzed: sampatti dassana sabhāga tāya ati yesu sattesu bhoga ādi sampatti dassana mukhena muditā pavattati
translated: As to similarity of state in seeing excellence: in the case of beings in whom loving- kindness arises through seeing their excellence in the possession of wealth, etc.,

original: tesu tannimittameva ayoniso ābhoge sati “cakkhuviññeyyānaṃ rūpāna”ntiādinā vuttasomanassamukhena
analyzed: tesu tad nimittam eva ayonisas ābhoge sati cakkhu viññeyyānam rūpa ananti ādinā vutta somanassa mukhena
translated: when there is unwise attention to that as a reason for their being reborn in a happy destiny, etc., there arises delight in the form of joy in the way stated thus, “On seeing forms with the eye … he delights in them, finds pleasure in them, and holds on to them” .

original: pahāso uppajjeyya, so ca muditāya āsannapaccatthiko. Pahāso hi idha somanassasīsena
analyzed: pahāsaḥ uppajjeyya saḥ ca muditāya āsanna paccatthiko pahāsaḥ hi idha somanassa sīsena
translated: And that is near to the enemy, namely, compassion. For delight is here stated by way of joy.

original: vutto. Sabhāgavisabhāgatāyāti bhogādisampattīhi muditesu sattesu pamodanākārassa
analyzed: vuttaḥ sabhāga visabhāga tāya ati bhoga ādi sampattīhi muditesu sattesu pamodana ākārassa
translated: As to similarity and dissimilarity of state: in the case of beings whom one delights in through their excellence in wealth, etc., compassion is similar in state to the gladness that is the opposite of the annoyance that finds no pleasure in that.

original: muditāsabhāgassa tattha anabhiramanākārā arati visabhāgāti tāya sabhāgavisabhāgatāya
analyzed: mudita asabhāgassa tattha an abhiramana ākārā tāya sabhāga visabhāga tāya
translated: But the annoyance that finds no pleasure in that is dissimilar in state to that. So this equanimity, which finds pleasure in the neutrality that is the opposite of both of these, gets an opportunity to arise and it arises after a long time, like an enemy who lives far away.

original: sā otāraṃ labhamānā cireneva labheyyāti purisassa dūre ṭhitasapatto viya muditāya
analyzed: sā otāram labhamānā cirena iva labheyya ati purisassa dūre ṭhita sapattaḥ viya muditāya
translated: If it gets an opportunity, it will get it sooner or later, like an enemy who is far away.🔽So it is called “far-off enemy.”

original: dūrapaccatthikā vuttā. Pamudito cātiādi muditāya siddhāya ayampi arati na hotīti
analyzed: dūra paccatthikā vuttā pamudito ca atiādi muditāya siddhāya ayam pi arati na hoti iti
translated: When he is gladdened, this discontent does not arise in him.

original: laddhabbaguṇadassanavasena vuttaṃ, na idhādhippetaaratiniggahadassanavasena. Kāyacittavivekapaṭipakkhāya🔽vā aratiyā vikkhambhitāya muditāya paṭipakkhā arati suvikkhambhaneyyā hotīti dassanatthaṃ
analyzed: laddhabba guṇa dassana vasena vuttam na idha adhippeta arati niggaha dassana vasena kāya citta viveka paṭipakkhāya  vā aratiyā vikkhambhitāya muditāya paṭipakkhā arati su vikkhambhaneyyā hoti iti dassana ttham
translated: This is said by way of the virtue to be obtained, not by way of showing the definition of discontent, which is the intended meaning here.🔽Or alternatively, since discontent, which is the opposite of the solitude of body and mind, is suppressed by gladness, discontent, which is its opposite, is well suppressed.🔽So it should be regarded as discontent shown in part.

original: ekadesena arati dassitāti daṭṭhabbaṃ. Adhikusaladhammesūti samathavipassanādhammesu.
analyzed: eka desena dassitā ati daṭṭhabbam adhi kusala dhammesu ti samatha vipassanā dhammesu
translated: In the more profitable states: in the states of serenity and insight.🔽Of the fool: because of his association with the dhammas of a fool.

original: Bālakaradhammayogato bālassa. Attahitaparahitabyāmūḷhatāya mūḷhassa. Puthūnaṃ kilesādīnaṃ
analyzed: bāla kara dhamma yogataḥ bālassa atta hita para hita byāmūḷhatāya mūḍhassa puthūnam kilesa ādīnam
translated: Of the confused: because of his confusion about his own and others’ welfare.🔽Of the worldling: because of his generation, etc., of the various defilements, etc.

original: jananādīhi kāraṇehi puthujjanassa. Kilesodhīnaṃ maggodhīhi ajitattā anodhijinassa,
analyzed: janana ādīhi kāraṇehi puthujjanassa kilesa udhīnam magga udhīhi ajita ttā anodhi jinassa
translated: Of the unabandoned: because of his failure to abandon the defilements by the abandoning of the paths.

original: odhijinā vā sekkhā odhisova kilesānaṃ jitattā. Tena imassa odhijitabhāvaṃ paṭikkhipati.🔽Sattamabhavādito uddhaṃ pavattanavipākassa ajitattā avipākajinassa, vipākajinā vā
analyzed: odhi jinā vā sekkhā odhiso uva kilesānam jita ttā tena imassa odhi jita bhāvam paṭikkhipati  sattama bhava āditas uddham pavattana vipākassa ajita ttā avipāka jinassa vipāka jināḥ vā
translated: Or alternatively, the word “conqueror” is used because the trainers have conquered defilements by means of the path, which is the conqueror of defilements. So he denies that he is a conqueror in this way.

original: arahanto appaṭisandhikattā. Tenassa asekkhattaṃ paṭikkhipati. Anekādīnave sabbesampi
analyzed: arahantaḥ appaṭisandhika ttā tena assa asekkha ttam paṭikkhipati aneka ādīnave sabbesam pi
translated: He is not a conqueror of the non-conquerable, that is, of the kamma-result of rebirth-linking that occurs after the seventh existence, or he is not a conqueror of the kamma-result, that is, of the kamma-result of the kinds already mentioned, because of his failure to reach the state of a non-returner. Or alternatively, he is not a conqueror of the non-conquerable, that is, of the defilements, because of his failure to reach the state of an Arahant, which is the non-conquerable. So he denies that he is a non-returner or an Arahant.🔽He is not a seer of danger in what is dangerous, because of his habit of not seeing the danger in all the various kinds of evil states that are dangerous.

original: pāpadhammānaṃ mūlabhūte sammohe ādīnavānaṃ adassanasīlatāya anādīnavadassāvino. Āgamādhigamābhāvā
analyzed: pāpa dhammānam mūla bhūte sammohe ādīnavānam a dassana sīla tāya anādīnava dassāvinaḥ āgama adhigama abhāvā
translated: He is unlearned, because of his failure to learn the scriptures and the realizations.

original: assutavato. Ediso ekaṃsena andhaputhujjano nāma hotīti tassa andhaputhujjanabhāvadassanatthaṃ
analyzed: assutavataḥ edisaḥ ekaṃsena andhaputhujjanaḥ nāma hoti iti tassa andha puthujjana bhāva dassana attham
translated: Such a person is called a blind worldling in the sense of one who is completely blind. So in order to show that he is a blind worldling,

original: punapi “puthujjanassā”ti vuttaṃ. Evarūpāti vuttākārena sammohapubbikā. Rūpaṃ sā nātivattatīti
analyzed: puna api puthujjanassa ati vuttam evarūpā ati vutta ākārena sammoha pubbikā rūpam sā na ativattati iti
translated: “the worldling” is said again. He is a worldling in the sense stated, that is, in the sense of being preceded by delusion. He does not transcend form,

original: rūpānaṃ samatikkamanāya kāraṇaṃ na hoti, rūpārammaṇe kilese nātivattatīti adhippāyo.
analyzed: rūpānam samatikkamanāya kāraṇam na hoti rūpa ārammaṇe kilese na ativattati iti adhippāyaḥ
translated: he is not a cause for the surmounting of form, he does not transcend the defilements that have form as their object, is the meaning.

original: Somanassadomanassarahitaṃ aññāṇameva aññāṇupekkhā. Dosaguṇāvicāraṇavasena sabhāgattāti🔽yathā brahmavihārupekkhā mettādayo viya sattesu hitūpasaṃhārādivasena guṇadose avicārentī🔽kevalaṃ ajjhupekkhanavaseneva pavattati, evaṃ aññāṇupekkhā sattesu vijjamānampi guṇadosaṃ
analyzed: somanassa domanassa rahitam aññāṇam eva aññāṇupekkhā dosa guṇa avicāraṇa vasena sabhā gattā ati  yathā sattesu  kevalam ajjhupekkhana vasena iva pavattati evam aññāṇupekkhā sattesu vijjamānam pi guṇa dosam
translated: Equanimity as non-knowing is simply non-knowing devoid of joy and grief.🔽It is similar to the others in not discerning virtue and vice,🔽Just as the equanimity in the divine abidings does not discern virtue and vice in beings by way of wishing them welfare, etc., so too this equanimity as non-knowing does not discern virtue and vice in beings that exist,

original: acintentī kevalaṃ ajjhupekkhanavaseneva pavattatīti dosaguṇāvicāraṇavasena sabhāgā.
analyzed: a cintentī kevalam ajjhupekkhana vasena iva pavattati iti dosa guṇa avicāraṇa vasena sabhāgā
translated: but occurs only by way of looking on without seeing. So it is similar to the others in not discerning virtue and vice.🔽Therefore it is said to be the divine abidings’ near enemy because it gets an opportunity quickly.

original: Tasmā sā lahuṃ otāraṃ labhatīti brahmavihārupekkhāya āsannapaccatthikā vuttā. Sabhāgavisabhāgatāyāti
analyzed: tasmā sā lahum otāram labhati iti brahmavihāra upekkhāya āsanna paccatthikā vuttā sabhāga visabhāga tāya ati
translated: It is dissimilar to the others in being similar and dissimilar,

original: iṭṭhāniṭṭhesu majjhattākārassa upekkhāsabhāgassa tattha anurodhavirodhapavattiākārā
analyzed: iṭṭha aniṭṭhesu majjhatta ākārassa upekkhā sabhāgassa tattha anurodha virodha pavatti ākārā
translated: The equanimity that is similar to the others is that of the neutral state of mind towards the desirable and the undesirable. Its mode of occurrence is the absence of approval and resistance.

original: rāgapaṭighā visabhāgāti tāya sabhāgavisabhāgatāya te otāraṃ labhamānā cireneva labheyyunti
analyzed: rāga paṭighāḥ visabhāgā ati tāya sabhāga visabhāga tāya te otāram labhamānā cirena iva labheyyunti
translated: But greed and hate are dissimilar to it in being its opposites. So it is said that they get an opportunity only after a long time because of its dissimilarity to the others.

original: purisassa dūre ṭhitasapatto viya upekkhābrahmavihārassa dūrapaccatthikā vuttā.🔽266. Kattukāmatā chando ādi “chandamūlakā kusalā dhammā”ti vacanato, atha vā sattesu🔽hitesitādukkhāpanayanakāmatādinā anavajjābhipatthanāvasena pavattanato “kattukāmatā🔽chando ādī”ti vuttaṃ. Upekkhābrahmavihāropi hi sattesu anirākatahitacchandoyeva “tattha
analyzed: purisassa dūre ṭhita sapattaḥ viya upekkhā brahmavihārassa dūra paccatthikā vuttā  kattu kāma tā chandaḥ ādi chanda mūlakā kusalāḥ dhammā ati vacanataḥ atha vā sattesu  hita īsita a dukkha apanayana kāma tā ādinā anavajja abhipatthanā vasena pavattanataḥ kattu kāma tā  chandaḥ ādi iti vuttam upekkhā brahmavihāraḥ api hi sattesu anirākata hita chandaḥ yā iva tattha
translated: The enemies of the divine abidings are called “enemies” because they are far away, like an enemy who stays far away.

original: abyāvaṭatā apaṇṇakapaṭipadā”ti ajjhupekkhanākārena pavattati mātā viya sakiccapasute🔽putte. Nīvaraṇādīti ādi-saddena tadekaṭṭhakilesānaṃ saṅgaho daṭṭhabbo. Katthaci sattaggahaṇampi
analyzed: a byāvaṭa tā a paṇṇaka paṭipadā ti ajjhupekkhanā ākārena pavattati mātā viya sa kicca pasute  putte nīvaraṇa ādi iti ādi saddena tad ekaṭṭha kilesānam saṅgahaḥ daṭṭhabbo katthaci satta gahaṇam pi
translated: The will to act is zeal, etc. because of the words, “The profitable ideas have will to act as their root” . Or alternatively, the will to act is zeal, etc., because it occurs as a blameless aspiration in the aspect of the will to act to benefit beings and to remove suffering from them, etc. For the divine abiding of equanimity occurs as a looking on with equanimity in the aspect of non-aversion, as a mother does when her children are quarrelling, since it has no will to act to benefit or harm beings.

original: saṅkhāraggahaṇameva hoti puggalādhiṭṭhānāya desanāya yathā “sabbe sattā āhāraṭṭhitikā”ti,
analyzed: saṅkhāra ggahaṇam eva hoti puggala adhiṭṭhānāya desanāya yathā sabbe sattāḥ āhāra ṭṭhitikā ti
translated: The hindrances, etc., are the defilements that are included in the hindrances, etc. In some places the apprehension of beings is the apprehension of formations, as in the teaching of the person-making, where it is said, “All beings subsist by nutriment” .

original: na evamidhāti āha “paññattidhammavasena eko vā satto aneke vā sattā ārammaṇa”nti.
analyzed: na evam idha āti āha paññatti dhamma vasena ekaḥ vā sattaḥ aneke vā sattāḥ ārammaṇanti
translated: But it is not so here, so he said “Either one being or many beings as object by way of the ideas of the description” .

original: Paññattidhammavasenāti paññattisaṅkhātadhammavasena. Kāmañcettha “sukhitā hontū”tiādinā
analyzed: paññatti dhamma vasena ati paññatti saṅkhāta dhamma vasena kāmañca ittha sukhitāḥ hontu iti ādinā
translated: Of course, in the meditation “May they be happy” and so on,

original: bhāvanāyaṃ sukhādiggahaṇampi labbhati. Taṃ pana “sabbe saṅkhārā aniccā”ti vipassanāya
analyzed: bhāvanā ayam sukha ādi gahaṇam pi labbhati tam pana sabbe saṅkhārāḥ aniccāḥ ati vipassanāya
translated: the apprehending of happiness, etc., is also possible. But that is subordinate,🔽like the apprehending of the characteristic of impermanence in the insight

original: aniccalakkhaṇagahaṇaṃ viya appadhānabhūtaṃ, sattapaññatti eva padhānabhāvena gayhatīti
analyzed: anicca lakkhaṇa gahaṇam viya appadhāna bhūtam satta paññatti eva padhāna bhāvena gayhati iti
translated: knowledge “All formations are impermanent.” The seven designations are🔽apprehended as the principal factor.🔽The intention is that the extension of the object in the access and the jhāna

original: daṭṭhabbaṃ. Upacāre vā patte ārammaṇavaḍḍhanaṃ tatthāpi sīmāsambhedasiddhitoti adhippāyo.🔽Ekamāvāsaṃ paricchinditvāti ettha “satte mettāya pharissāmī”ti evaṃ ñāṇena paricchedaṃ
analyzed: daṭṭhabbam upacāre vā patte ārammaṇa vaḍḍhanam tattha api sīmā sambheda siddhito ti adhippāyaḥ  ekam āvāsam paricchinditvā ti ettha satte mettāya pharissāmi iti evam ñāṇena paricchedam
translated: is due to the non-division of the boundary.🔽“Having defined a single abode”: the definition of a single street should be🔽done by defining it with knowledge in this way, “I shall extend loving- kindness to beings.”

original: katvā ekā racchā paricchinditabbāti yojanā. Racchāgahaṇena racchāvāsino sattā gahitā
analyzed: katvā ekā racchā paricchinditabbā ati yojanā racchā gahaṇena racchā vāsinaḥ sattā gahitā
translated: By the word “street” beings who live in the street are included,

original: yathā ekaṃ disanti. Evaṃ sabbattha.
analyzed: yathā ekam disanti evam sabbattha
translated: just as by the word “one direction” beings in all directions are included.

original: 267. Kasiṇānaṃ nissandoti kasiṇajjhānānaṃ nissandaphalasadisā āruppā arūpajjhānāni,
analyzed: kasiṇānam nissandaḥ ti kasiṇa jhānānam nissanda phala sadisāḥ āruppāḥ arūpa jhānāni
translated: “The formless jhānas are like the outcome of the kasiṇas”: the immaterial jhānas are like the fruition of the kasiṇas’ jhānas.

original: kasiṇajjhānānaṃ pāripūriyāva sijjhanato. Tehi vinā asijjhanatoti keci. Samādhinissandoti🔽rūpajjhānasamādhīnaṃ, heṭṭhimānaṃ tiṇṇaṃ arūpajjhānasamādhīnañca nissando paṭipāṭiyā
analyzed: kasiṇa jhānānam tehi vinā a sijjhanato ti keci samādhi nissando ti  rūpa jhāna samādhīnam heṭṭhimānam tiṇṇam arūpa jhāna samādhīnam ca nissandaḥ paṭipāṭiyā
translated: Some say: because they are not successful without them.🔽The outcome of concentration:🔽the outcome of the jhānas of the fine-material sphere and of the first three immaterial jhānas is the attainment of cessation, because it is to be reached only by one who has attained them in order.

original: te adhigantvāva paṭilabhitabbato. Vipassanānissando vipassanānubhāvena laddhabbato,
analyzed: te adhigantvā ava paṭilabhitabbataḥ vipassanā nissandaḥ vipassanā anubhāvena laddhabbataḥ
translated: The outcome of insight: because it is to be reached by the power of insight,🔽and because it is to be reached only by one who has attained it by means of insight.

original: vipassanāvaseneva ca samāpajjitabbato. Samathavipassanānissando nirodhasamāpatti.
analyzed: vipassanā vasena iva ca samāpajjitabbataḥ samatha vipassanā nissandaḥ nirodha samāpatti
translated: The outcome of serenity and insight: the attainment of cessation.

original: Yathāha “dvīhi balehi samannāgatattā”tiādi. “Purimabrahmavihārattayanissando”ti iminā
analyzed: yathā āha dvīhi balehi iminā
translated: As it is said: “Because he possesses two strengths” , etc.

original: mettādivasena tīṇi jhānāni adhigantvā ṭhitasseva upekkhābrahmavihāro, na itarassāti
analyzed: mettā ādi vasena tīṇi jhānāni adhigantvā ṭhitassa iva upekkhā brahmavihāraḥ na itarassa ati
translated: The outcome of the first three divine abidings: this shows that the divine abiding of equanimity is only for one who has attained the three jhānas by means of loving-kindness, etc., and is not for anyone else.

original: dasseti. Tamevatthaṃ upamāya pākaṭataraṃ katvā dassetuṃ “yathā hī”tiādi vuttaṃ. Yaṃ
analyzed: dasseti tam eva attham upamāya pākaṭataram katvā dassetum yathā hi itiādi vuttam yam
translated: In order to make this clear by means of an illustration he said, “Just as, etc.”

original: panettha vattabbaṃ, taṃ heṭṭhā vuttameva.
analyzed: pana ittha vattabbam tat heṭṭhā vuttam eva
translated: But what is to be said about this has already been said above.

original: 268. Siyāti vuccamānākārena siyā kassaci parivitakko. Etthāti etesu mettādīsu brahmavihāratā🔽veditabbā, itarakammaṭṭhānāni attahitapaṭipattimattāni. Imāni pana “sabbe sattā sukhitā
analyzed: siyā ti vuccamāna ākārena siyā kassaci parivitakkaḥ ettha ati etesu metta ādīsu brahmavihāra tā  veditabbā itara kammaṭṭhānāni atta hita paṭipattimattāni imāni pana sabbe sattā sukhitā
translated: “Might be” : it might occur to someone to think thus. “Herein” : in these divine abidings of loving-kindness, etc.,

original: hontū”tiādinā parahitapaṭipattibhūtāni. Tasmā sattesu sammā paṭipattibhāvena seṭṭhā🔽ete vihārā. Brahmānoti upapattibrahmāno. Te hi idha jhānabhāvanāya vinīvaraṇacittā
analyzed: hontu iti ādinā para hita paṭipatti bhūtāni tasmā sattesu sammā paṭipatti bhāvena seṭṭhā  ete vihārāḥ brahmānaḥ ti upapatti brahmānaḥ te hi idha jhāna bhāvanāya
translated: the state of a divine abiding should be understood as follows. The other meditations are only concerned with one’s own welfare. But these are concerned with the welfare of others, beginning with the wish, “May all beings be free from affliction.” Therefore they are the best in being concerned with the welfare of others.

original: hutvā brahmaloke uppannā tattha yāvatāyukaṃ vinīvaraṇacittāva honti. Tasmā “niddosacittā🔽viharantī”ti vadanti. Brahmānoti vā sakalabuddhaguṇahetubhūtānaṃ dānapāramitādīnaṃ
analyzed: hutvā brahma loke uppannā tattha yāvatā āyukam honti tasmā niddosa cittā  viharanti iti vadanti vā dāna pāramitā dīnam
translated: “Brahma” : this is rebirth-brahmas . For these have their minds free from hindrances by developing jhāna, and they are reborn in the Brahmā-world, where they live out their lives with minds free from hindrances. That is why it is said that they “live with minds free from hate” .

original: buddhakaradhammānaṃ paripūraṇavasena brūhitaguṇā mahāsattā bodhisattā. Te hi sabbasattānaṃ
analyzed: buddha kara dhammānam paripūraṇa vasena mahāsattāḥ bodhisattā te hi sabba sattānam
translated: Or alternatively, “Brahma” is great beings , that is, bodhisattvas. For they have minds free from hate because they have fulfilled the requisites for Buddhahood, that is, the pāramīs, beginning with giving.

original: hitesanena, ahitāpanayanena, sampattipamodanena, sabbattha vivajjitāgatigamanamajjhattabhāvādhiṭṭhānena
analyzed: hita īsanena ahita apanayanena sampatti pamodanena sabbattha vivajjita āgati gamana majjhatta bhāva adhiṭṭhānena
translated: with the wish for welfare, with the removal of harm, with rejoicing in attainment, with the state of neutrality that avoids all sides,

original: ca niddosacittā viharanti. Evanti yathā te upapattibrahmāno, mahābodhisattabrahmāno🔽vā, evaṃ etehi brahmavihārehi sampayuttā samaṅgībhūtā.🔽269. Catassovātiādipañhassāti catassotiādikassa tividhassa pañhassa. Visuddhimaggādivasāti🔽ettha byāpādasaṃkilesādito visujjhanupāyo visuddhimaggo. Ādi-saddena hitūpasaṃhārādimanasikāravisesā🔽saṅgahitā. Āsaṃ mettādīnaṃ. Appamāṇeti pamāṇarahite. Yenāti yena kāraṇena. Tanti🔽tasmā. Da-kāro padasandhikaro.🔽Byāpādabahulassa visuddhimaggoti ānetvā sambandhitabbaṃ, ujuvipaccanīkabhāvatoti
analyzed: ca niddosa cittāḥ viharanti yathā te upapatti brahmānaḥ mahā bodhisatta brahmānaḥ 🔽vā evam etehi brahmavihārehi sampayuttā samaṅgībhūtā 🔽catasso uva ati ādi pañhassa ati catasso ti ādikassa tividhassa pañhassa visuddhi magga ādi vasā ti 🔽ettha byāpāda saṃkilesa āditaḥ visujjhan upāyaḥ visuddhi maggaḥ ādi saddena hitu upasaṃhāra ādi manasikāra visesā 🔽saṅgahitā āsam metta ādīnam appamāṇā iti pamāṇa rahite yena ati yena kāraṇena 🔽tasmāt dakāraḥ pada sandhi karaḥ 🔽byāpāda bahulassa visuddhi maggo ti ānetvā sambandhitabbam uju vipaccanīka bhāvato ti
translated: They live with a mind free from hate, with a mind free from enmity, with a mind free from rivalry, with a mind free from ill will, with a mind free from anger, with a mind free from hatred, with a mind free from affliction, with a mind free from torment, with a mind free from anxiety, with a mind free from distress, with a mind free from danger, with a mind free from violence, with a mind free from harm, with a mind free from fever, with a mind free from burning, with a mind free from defilement, with a mind free from corruption, with a mind free from stain, with a mind free from taint, with a mind free from impurity, with a mind free from defilement, with a mind free from evil, with a mind free from evilness, with a mind free from evilness of mind, with a mind free from corruption, with a mind free from corruption of mind, with a mind free from corruption of mind, with a mind free from corruption of mind, with a mind free from corruption of mind, with a mind original: adhippāyo. Esa nayo sesesupi. Pakkhapātavasena anābhujanamanābhogo majjhattākāroti🔽adhippāyo. Yvāyaṃ catubbidho sattesu manasikāro vutto, tameva upamāya dassetuṃ “yasmā🔽ca yathā mātā”tiādi vuttaṃ. Tattha vuttassāpi hitūpasaṃhārādiatthassa upameyyabhāvaṃ
analyzed: adhippāyaḥ esa nayo sesesu pi pakkhapāta vasena  adhippāyaḥ yvā ayam catubbidhaḥ sattesu manasikāraḥ vuttaḥ tam eva upamāya dassetum yasmā  ca yathā mātā ati ādi vuttam tattha vuttassa api hitu upasaṃhāra ādi atthassa upameyya bhāvam
translated: This is the purport. The same method applies to the rest. The non-inclination of the mind towards partiality is non-bias. The middle way is the middle.🔽This is the purport. The four kinds of attention to beings mentioned above are illustrated by the following similes, beginning with the words, “And just as a mother,” etc. The word “and” in the words, “And just as a mother,” etc., is used in the sense of a reason.

original: upanetvā dassetuṃ atthupanayanattho “yasmā cā”ti ca-saddo. Pariyāyeti vāre, tasmiṃ
analyzed: upanetvā dassetum attha upanayana atthaḥ yasmā ca ati ca saddaḥ pariyāya iti vāre tasmin
translated: The meaning is: because of the reason. The word “and” is used in the sense of a conclusion to show that the meaning of the words, “gathering together what is beneficial,” etc., which is mentioned in the sutta, is to be applied to the simile.🔽“In turn” means in order, in succession. The meaning is: in the process of revolving in the various kinds of duties.

original: tasmiṃ kiccavasena parivattanakkameti attho. Abyāvaṭāti anussukkā. Tathāti yathā
analyzed: tasmin kicca vasena parivattana kkamā iti atthaḥ abyāvaṭā ati anussukkā tathā iti yathā
translated: “Without reserve” means without holding back. The meaning is: without exception. “Just as” means in the same way as a mother.

original: mātā daharādīsu puttesu, tathā sabbasattesu mettādivasena mettāyanādivasikena bhavitabbanti🔽yojanā. Tasmāti yasmā sabbepi saṃkilesadhammā yathārahaṃ dosamoharāgapakkhiyā, tehi
analyzed: mātā dahara ādīsu puttesu tathā sabba sattesu mettā divasena mettāyanā divasikena bhavitabbanti  yojanā tasmā iti yasmā sabbe pi saṃkilesa dhammā yathāraham dosa moha rāga pakkhiyā tehi
translated: The application is this: just as a mother is loving, etc., towards her children, beginning with her infant, in the same way one should be loving, etc., towards all beings by means of loving-kindness, etc.

original: ca visujjhanupāyo appamaññā, hitūpasaṃhārādivasena catubbidho ca sattesu manasikāro,
analyzed: ca visujjhan upāyaḥ appamaññā hitu upasaṃhāra ādi vasena catubbidhaḥ ca sattesu manasikāro
translated: “Because” means: since all the states of defilement are, as the case may be, on the side of hatred, delusion, and lust, and since the means of purification is the immeasurables, and the attention to beings in four ways by means of gathering together what is beneficial, etc.,

original: tasmā visuddhimaggādivasā catassova appamaññā. Catassopi etā bhāvetukāmena na ekekanti
analyzed: tasmā visuddhi magga ādivasā catasso uva appamaññā catasso pi etāḥ bhāvetu kāmena na ekekam ti
translated: The intention is that one who wants to develop all four should not do so by each one separately.🔽For it is necessary to do so by a single act of attention in each case.

original: adhippāyo. Sati hi sabbasaṅgahe kamena bhavitabbaṃ. Hitesitā mettāyananti āha “evaṃ
analyzed: adhippāyaḥ sati hi sabba saṅgahe kamena bhavitabbam hita īsitā mettāyanaḥ ti āha evam
translated: He should do so by the act of attention consisting in wishing welfare and lovingkindness,🔽thus he said “after wishing welfare for” .🔽After resolving thus: after resolving thus, “By this practice he might be reborn in hell, etc.,”

original: patthitahitāna”nti. Sambhāvetvā vāti “imāya paṭipattiyā ayaṃ nirayādīsu nibbatteyyā”ti
analyzed: patthita hitānam ti sambhāvetvā vā ti imāya paṭipattiyā ayam niraya ādīsu nibbatteyya iyyā ti
translated: or after resolving thus, “By this practice he might be reborn in the animal realm, etc.,”

original: parikappetvā vā. Dukkhāpanayanākaārappavattivasena paṭipajjitabbanti sambandho. Tato
analyzed: parikappetvā vā sambandho tatas
translated: The construction is: he should practice by the occurrence of the aspect of removing suffering.🔽After that: after the occurrence of the aspect of wishing welfare, etc.

original: paranti tato hitākārappavattiādito paraṃ. Kattabbābhāvatoti catutthassa pakārassa
analyzed: param ti tatas hita ākāra ppavatti āditaḥ param kattabba abhāvato ti catutthassa pakārassa
translated: Because there is nothing else to be done: because there is nothing else of the fourth kind to be done.

original: kattabbassa abhāvato. Ayaṃ kamoti ayaṃ imāsaṃ appamaññānaṃ yebhuyyena pavattanakkamoti
analyzed: kattabbassa abhāvataḥ ayam kamaḥ ti ayam imāsam appamaññānam yebhuyyena pavattana kkamaḥ ti
translated: This is the order: this is the order in which these four divine abidings mostly occur.

original: katvā vuttaṃ, na “imināva kamena etāsaṃ pavatti, na aññathā”ti. Mettādīnaṃ hi tissannaṃ
analyzed: katvā vuttam na iminā ava kamena etāsam pavatti na aññathā ati mettā ādīnam hi tissannam
translated: This is said with reference to the order in which they are developed, not with reference to the order in which they are reached, for the order in which they are reached is indefinite. For the order in which they are reached is as follows:

original: bhāvanānaṃ kamaniyamo natthi, yaṃ vā taṃ vā paṭhamaṃ bhāvetuṃ labbhā, desanākkamavasena vā evaṃ vuttaṃ.
analyzed: bhāvanānam kama niyamaḥ na atthi yam vā tam vā paṭhamam bhāvetum labbhā desanā kkama vasena vā evam vuttam
translated: There is no fixed order for the jhānas, so it is permissible to develop whichever one wants first. Or alternatively, the order is given according to the order in which they are taught.

original: Ekasattassāpīti ekassāpi sattassa. Appaṭibhāganimittattā paricchedaggahaṇaṃ natthi,
analyzed: eka sattassa api iti ekassa api sattassa appaṭibhāga nimitta ttā pariccheda ggahaṇam natthi
translated: “Even in one being”: in one being. There is no delimitation of the object by apprehending a limited number of beings, because there is no sign of a limited number of beings.

original: na ca sammutisaccavasena pavattaṃ sattaggahaṇaṃ paricchinnarūpādiggahaṇaṃ hotīti🔽appanāppattiyā aparāmāsasattaggahaṇamuddhabhūtānaṃ mettādīnaṃ ekasattārammaṇānampi🔽appamāṇagocaratā vuttā. Evaṃ pamāṇaṃ aggahetvāti yathā uddhumātakādīsu atirekuddhumātakādibhāvappatte
