analyzed: na ca sammuti sacca vasena pavattam satta ggahaṇam paricchinna rūpa ādi ggahaṇam hoti iti  appanā appattiyāḥ mettā ādīnam eka satta ārammaṇānam pi  appamāṇa gocara tā vuttā evam pamāṇam aggahetvā iti yathā uddhumātaka ādīsu atireka uddhumātaka ādi bhāva ppatte
translated: And the apprehending of beings that occurs by way of conventional truth does not constitute the apprehending of a limited number of material forms, etc.,🔽So the objects of the measureless states of loving-kindness, etc., are beings, and they are measureless because they are not limited by the delimitation of the measure of beings.🔽“Without apprehending any sign”: just as, when one apprehends a sign in bloated corpses, etc., one does so only in a part of the place where they are,

original: padese nimittaṃ gayhati, evaṃ pamāṇaṃ aggahetvā. Sakalapharaṇavasenāti niravasesapharaṇavasena.
analyzed: padese nimittam evam pamāṇam aggahetvā sakala pharaṇa vasena ati niravasesa pharaṇa vasena
translated: because the bloatedness, etc., are limited, so too, without apprehending any such measure,

original: 270. Nissaraṇattāti ettha yaṃ yassa nissaraṇaṃ, taṃ tassa ujupaṭipakkhabhūtameva
analyzed: nissaraṇa ttā ti ettha yam yassa nissaraṇam tam tassa uju paṭipakkha bhūtam eva
translated: “Because of escape”: here, that from which there is escape is the direct opponent of that from which one escapes.

original: hoti. Yathā kāmānaṃ nekkhammaṃ, rūpānaṃ āruppā, saṅkhārānaṃ nibbānaṃ, evaṃ domanassasahitānaṃ
analyzed: hoti yathā kāmānam nekkhammam rūpānam āruppā saṅkhārānam nibbānam evam domanassa sahitānam
translated: is the case. As renunciation is to sense desires, the immaterial to material things, and Nibbāna to formations, so too is the equanimity

original: byāpādavihiṃsāratīnaṃ nissaraṇabhūtā mettākaruṇāmuditā na somanassarahitā honti.
analyzed: byāpāda vihiṃsā ratīnam nissaraṇa bhūtāḥ mettā karuṇā muditāḥ na somanassa rahitāḥ honti
translated: And just as renunciation is the escape from sensual desire, the immaterial from material form, and Nibbāna from formations, so too loving- kindness, compassion and gladness, which are the escape from annoyance, cruelty and delight in others’ joy respectively, are not devoid of joy.

original: Nissaraṇaggahaṇeneva ca pubbabhāgiyānaṃ tāsaṃ upekkhāsampayogopi anuññātoti daṭṭhabbaṃ
analyzed: nissaraṇa ggahaṇena iva ca pubbabhāgiyānam tāsam upekkhā sampayogaḥ api anuññātaḥ ti daṭṭhabbam
translated: And by the mention of the escape, the association of equanimity with the kinds of fear mentioned is also allowed in the earlier stage,

original: anissaraṇabhāvato. Tathā hi aṭṭhavīsatiyā cittuppādesu karuṇāmuditānaṃ pavattiṃ ācariyā
analyzed: anissaraṇa bhāvataḥ tathā hi aṭṭhavīsatiyā cittuppādesu karuṇā muditānam pavattim ācariyā
translated: because they are not the escape from those fears. For the teachers of the commentaries explain the occurrence of compassion and gladness in the twenty-eight kinds of consciousness as follows.

original: icchanti. Na hi brahmavihārupekkhā upekkhāvedanaṃ vinā vattati pārisuddhiupekkhā
analyzed: icchanti na hi brahmavihāra upekkhā upekkhā vedanam vinā vattati pārisuddhi upekkhā
translated: For the equanimity of the divine abidings does not occur without the feeling of equanimity, as does the purification equanimity.

original: viya. Na hi kadāci pārisuddhiupekkhā vedanupekkhaṃ vinā vattatīti.
analyzed: viya na hi kadāci pārisuddhi upekkhā vedanupekkham vinā vattati iti
translated: For the latter never occurs without the equanimity of feeling.

original: 271. Sātasahagatanti sukhasahagataṃ. Tasmāti yasmā “tato tvaṃ bhikkhū”tiādikāya desanāya
analyzed: sāta sahagatanti sukha sahagatam tasmā iti yasmā tvam bhikkhu iti ādikāya desanāya
translated: “With happiness”: with happiness associated with it. “Therefore”: because in the teaching beginning, “Therefore, bhikkhus, you should train yourselves thus: ‘We shall be possessed of equanimity that is not clung to’” ,

original: catunnampi appamaññānaṃ savitakkādibhāvo viya upekkhāsahagatabhāvopi viññāyati, tasmā.
analyzed: catunnam pi appamaññānam sa vitakka ādi bhāvaḥ viya upekkhā sahagata bhāvaḥ api viññāyati tasmā
translated: the state of being possessed of equanimity is discerned just as the state of being possessed of applied thought, etc., is discerned in the case of the four divine abidings, therefore.

original: Catassopi appamaññā catukkapañcakajjhānikāti codakassa adhippāyo. Evañhi satīti yadi🔽mūlasamādhimhi vuttamatthaṃ anantaraṃ vuttatāya brahmavihāresu pakkhipati, evaṃ sante🔽kāyānupassanādayopi catukkapañcakajjhānikā siyuṃ, na pana honti vipassanāvasena desitattāti🔽adhippāyo, hontu kāyānupassanādayo ānāpānabhāvanāvasena catukkapañcakajjhānikāti
analyzed: catasso pi appamaññā catukka pañcaka jjhānikā ati codakassa adhippāyaḥ evam hi sati iti yadi  mūlasamādhimhi vutta mattham anantaram vutta tāya brahmavihāresu pakkhipati evam sante  kāya anupassanā ādayaḥ api siyum na pana honti vipassanā vasena desita ttā ti  adhippāyaḥ hontu kāya anupassanā ādayaḥ āna apāna bhāvanā vasena catukka pañcaka jhānikā ti
translated: The questioner’s intention is that all four divine abidings are of the fourfold and fivefold jhāna. If that were so,🔽then the contemplations of the body, etc., would also be of the fourfold and fivefold jhāna, but they are not, because they are taught as insight.

original: vadeyyāti āsaṅkanto āha “vedanādīsū”tiādi. Byañjanacchāyāmattaṃ gahetvāti “mettā🔽me cetovimutti bhāvitā bhavissatī”tiādīhi byañjanehi pakāsito eva cittasamādhi “ajjhattaṃ🔽me cittaṃ ṭhitaṃ bhavissatī”tiādīhipi byañjanehi pakāsitoti byañjanato labbhamānasamādhicchāyāmattaṃ
analyzed: āha vedanā ādīsu utiādi byañjana chāyā mattam gahetvā ati mettā  me cetaḥ vimutti bhāvitā bhavissati itiādīhi byañjanehi pakāsitaḥ eva citta samādhi ajjhattam  me cittam ṭhitam bhavissati itiādīhi pi byañjanehi byañjanataḥ labbhamāna samādhi chāyā mattam
translated: The intention is that the questioner might say that the contemplations of the body, etc., are of the fourfold and fivefold jhāna as the development of mindfulness of breathing is.

original: gahetvā ubhayattha labbhamānaṃ adhippāyaṃ aggahetvāti attho. Suttatthaṃ hi aññathā
analyzed: gahetvā ubhayattha labbhamānam adhippāyam aggahetvā iti atthaḥ sutta ttham hi aññathā
translated: Taking the mere shadow of the phrasing: the mental concentration that is revealed by the phrases “May my mind be possessed by loving-kindness” and so on is the same as that revealed by the phrases “My mind is steadied internally” and so on. So taking the mere shadow of the concentration revealed by the phrasing, without taking the intention revealed in both,🔽for the meaning of the sutta is otherwise stated in the Paṭisambhidā.

original: vadanto ayathāvāditāya satthāraṃ apavadanto nāma hoti. Tenāha “mā bhagavantaṃ abbhācikkhī”ti.
analyzed: vadantaḥ a yathāvāditāya satthāram apavadantaḥ nāma hoti tena āha mā bhagavantam abbhācikkhi iti
translated: In saying this, he is misrepresenting the Teacher by misrepresenting the Dhamma, which is why the Blessed One said: “Do not misrepresent the Tathagata, Ananda.”

original: 272. “Tayimaṃ dosaṃ pariharitukāmena na sabbaṃ suttaṃ nītatthameva, tasmā garukulato
analyzed: tayā imam dosam pariharitu kāmena na sabbam suttam nīta ttham eva tasmai garu kulataḥ
translated: “One who wants to avoid this fault should not take the whole sutta literally, and so the intention should be sought in the following way.”

original: adhippāyo maggitabbo”ti dassento “gambhīraṃ hī”tiādiṃ vatvā tattha ādito paṭṭhāya
analyzed: adhippāyaḥ maggitabbaḥ ti dassentaḥ gambhīram hi itiādim vatvā tattha āditaḥ paṭṭhāya
translated: Having said “It is profound,” etc., in order to show how the intention should be sought, he said “This is the meaning,” etc.

original: adhippāyaṃ dassetuṃ “ayañhī”tiādimāha. Āyācitā dhammadesanā etenāti āyācitadhammadesano,
analyzed: adhippāyam dassetum ayaṃ hi iti ādim āha āyācitā dhamma desanā etena ati āyācita dhamma desano
translated: The teaching of the Dhamma requested by him is the teaching of the Dhamma requested by Ananda;🔽that is the teaching of the Dhamma requested by Ananda.

original: taṃ āyācitadhammadesanaṃ. Evamevāti garahane nipāto, mudā evāti attho. Ajjhattanti
analyzed: tam āyācita dhamma desanam evam evā iti gara hane nipātaḥ mudā evā ati atthaḥ ajjhattam ti
translated: In the same way: the particle eva is in the sense of blame; the meaning is: in joy.

original: gocarajjhatte, kammaṭṭhānārammaṇeti attho. Yasmā cittekaggatā nāma sasantatipariyāpannā
analyzed: gocara jjhatte kammaṭṭhāna ārammaṇā iti atthaḥ yasmā citta ekagga tā nāma sa santati pariyāpannā
translated: Internally: in the internal domain of experience; the meaning is: in the object of meditation.🔽Because unification of mind is included in one’s own continuity,

original: hoti, tasmā atthavaṇṇanāyaṃ “niyakajjhattavasenā”ti vuttaṃ. Cittaṃ ṭhitaṃ bhavissatīti
analyzed: hoti tasmai attha vaṇṇanāyam niyaka jjhatta vasena ati vuttam cittam ṭhitam bhavissati iti
translated: it is said in the commentary on the meaning: “in one’s own internal domain.”🔽The mind will be steadied: it will be steadied in the state of concentration without wavering externally.

original: bahiddhā avikkhippamānaṃ ekaggabhāve ṭhitaṃ bhavissati. Tato eva susaṇṭhitaṃ, suṭṭhu
analyzed: bahiddhā a vikkhippamānam ekagga bhāve ṭhitam bhavissati tatas eva su saṇṭhitam suṭṭhu
translated: And because of that, it will be well steadied, well settled,

original: samāhitanti attho. Uppannāti avikkhambhitā. Pāpakāti lāmakā. Akusalā dhammāti kāmacchandādayo
analyzed: samāhitanti atthaḥ uppannā ati a vikkhambhitā pāpakā ati lāmakāḥ akusalāḥ dhammā ati kāmacchanda ādayaḥ
translated: “Concentrated” means “composed.” “Arisen” means “not suppressed.” “Evil” means “defiled.” “Unprofitable states” are the unprofitable consciousnesses and its concomitants.

original: akosallasambhūtaṭṭhena akusalā dhammā. Cittaṃ pariyādāya pavattituṃ okāsādānena kusalacittaṃ
analyzed: akosalla sambhūta ṭṭhena akusalāḥ dhammāḥ cittam pariyādāya pavattitum okāsa ādānena kusala cittam
translated: “Unprofitable states” are so called because they are produced by unprofitable roots.

original: khepetvā na ca ṭhassantīti yojanā. Iminā yathāvuttassa samādhānassa kāraṇamāha.
analyzed: khepetvā na ca ṭhassanti iti yojanā iminā yathā vuttassa samādhānassa kāraṇam āha
translated: “Will not remain obsessing his mind” means that they will not prevent the profitable consciousness from occurring by taking possession of the opportunity to do so. This is the reason for the concentration stated in the way already described.

original: Cittekaggatāmattoti bhāvanamanuyuttena paṭiladdhamattaṃ nātisubhāvitaṃ samādhānaṃ.
analyzed: citta ekagga tā mattaḥ ti bhāvanam anuyuttena paṭiladdha mattam na ati su bhāvitam samādhānam
translated: “Mere unification of the mind” is concentration that has been obtained by one devoted to development but is not well developed.

original: Taṃ pana upari vuccamānānaṃ samādhivisesānaṃ mūlakāraṇabhāvato “mūlasamādhī”ti vutto.
analyzed: tam pana upari vuccamānānam samādhi visesānam mūla kāraṇa bhāvataḥ mūlasamādhi iti vuttaḥ
translated: But it is called “basic concentration” because it is the root cause of the kinds of concentration that will be mentioned later.

original: Svāyaṃ cittekaggatāmatto “ajjhattameva cittaṃ saṇṭhapemi sannisādemi ekodiṃ karomi🔽samādahāmī”tiādīsu viya khaṇikasamādhi adhippeto. Yatheva hi aññatthāpi “āraddhaṃ
analyzed: su ayam citta ekagga tā mattaḥ ajjhattam eva cittam saṇṭhapemi sannisādemi ekodim karomi  samādahāmi itiādīsu khaṇika samādhi adhippetaḥ yathā iva hi aññattha api āraddham
translated: This mere unification of the mind is intended here as momentary concentration, as in such passages as “I compose the mind, settle it, concentrate it, and unify it” .

original: kho pana me, bhikkhave, vīriyaṃ ahosi asallīnaṃ…pe… samāhitaṃ cittaṃ ekagga”nti vatvā
analyzed: kho pana me bhikkhave vīriyam ahosi a sallīnam pe samāhitam cittam ekaggam ti vatvā
translated: For just as elsewhere, after saying “My energy was aroused … my mind was concentrated … my …” ,

original: “vivicceva kāmehī”tiādivacanato paṭhamaṃ vuttacittekaggatā “khaṇikasamādhī”ti viññāyati,
analyzed: vivicca iva kāmehi iti ādi vacanataḥ paṭhamam vutta citta ekagga tā khaṇika samādhi iti viññāyati
translated: “The unification of mind stated first is known as momentary concentration because of the words, ‘Quite secluded from sense desires, secluded from unprofitable things’ ,

original: evamidhāpīti. So eva samādhīti mūlasamādhimāha.
analyzed: evam idha api iti sā u eva samādhi iti mūlasamādhim āha
translated: and so here too. ‘That concentration’ is the basic concentration.

original: Assāti bhikkhuno, assa vā mūlasamādhissa. Bhāvananti vaḍḍhanaṃ. Ayaṃ samādhīti ca🔽mūlasamādhiyeva adhippeto. Evaṃ bhāvitoti yathā araṇisahitena uppādito aggi gomayacuṇṇādīhi🔽vaḍḍhito gomayaggiādibhāvaṃ pattopi araṇisahitena uppāditamūlaggītveva vuccati, evamidhāpi
analyzed: assa ati bhikkhunaḥ assa vā mūlasamādhissa bhāvanan ti vaḍḍhanam ayam samādhi iti ca  mūla samādhiyā iva adhippetaḥ evam bhāvitaḥ ti yathā araṇi sahitena uppāditaḥ aggi gomaya cuṇṇa ādīhi  vaḍḍhitaḥ gomaya ggi ādi bhāvam pattaḥ api araṇi sahitena uppādita mūla ggī tvā iva vuccati evam idha api
translated: ‘His’: the bhikkhu’s, or the basic concentration’s. ‘Development’: increase. ‘This concentration’:🔽the basic concentration is what is intended. ‘So developed’: just as the fire produced by rubbing the two sticks together, when it spreads, is called ‘faggish’ , though it is produced by sticks and

original: mūlasamādhi eva mettādivasena vaḍḍhitoti katvā vuttaṃ.
analyzed: mūlasamādhi eva mettā ādi vasena vaḍḍhito ti katvā vuttam
translated: is still produced by sticks, so too this concentration is called ‘developed by loving-kindness’ because it is increased by loving-kindness.

original: Aññesupi ārammaṇesu pathavīkasiṇādīsu. Tattha yathā mettābhāvanāpubbaṅgamena bhāvanānayena
analyzed: aññesu pi ārammaṇesu pathavī kasiṇa ādīsu tattha yathā mettā bhāvanā pubbaṅgamena bhāvanā nayena
translated: ‘In other objects too’ means in the earth kasiṇa, and so on. Herein, just as, when the method of development is preceded by development of loving-kindness,

original: pathavīkasiṇādīsu savitakkādibhāvavasena catukkapañcakajjhānasampāpanavidhinā mūlasamādhissa
translated: the basic concentration is increased by obtaining the fourfold and fivefold jhāna in the earth kasiṇa, and so on, by means of the states of consciousness accompanied by applied thought, and so on,

original: bhāvanā vuttā, evaṃ karuṇādibhāvanāpubbaṅgamaṃ pathavīkasiṇādīsupi bhāvanāvidhiṃ🔽dassetvā pacchā kāyānupassanādipubbaṅgamaṃ bhāvanāvidhiṃ dassento āsavakkhayāya dhammaṃ
analyzed: bhāvanā vuttā evam karuṇā ādi bhāvanā pubbaṅgamam pathavī kasiṇa ādīsu pi bhāvanā vidhim  dassetvā pacchā kāya anupassanā ādi pubbaṅgamam bhāvanā vidhim dassento āsava kkhayāya dhammaṃ
translated: and the development of the kasiṇa has been stated. So too, after showing the method of development of the earth kasiṇa, etc., with the development of compassion, etc., as the forerunner,🔽he now shows the method of development with the contemplation of the body, etc., as the forerunner, saying “for the destruction of cankers” .🔽

original: desesi. Tena vuttaṃ “karuṇā me cetovimuttī”tiādi. Yadi evaṃ dhammānupassanāpariyosānāya🔽desanāya arahattādhigamāya kammaṭṭhānassa kathitattā puna “tato tvaṃ, bhikkhu, imaṃ
analyzed: desesi tena vuttam karuṇā me cetaḥ vimutti itiādi yadi evam dhamma anupassanā pariyosānāya  desanāya arahatta adhigamāya kammaṭṭhānassa kathita ttā puna tatas tvam bhikkhu imaṃ
translated: and the development of the kasiṇas has been stated. In the same way, having shown the method of development of the earth kasiṇa, etc., with the development of compassion, etc., as the forerunner, he then showed the method of development with the contemplation of the body, etc., as the forerunner, teaching the Dhamma for the destruction of the taints. Therefore it is said: “My deliverance of mind has been attained by means of compassion” , etc.

original: samādhiṃ savitakkampī”tiādi kasmā vuttanti? Dhammānupassanāya matthakappattidassanatthaṃ.
analyzed: samādhim sa vitakkam pi itiādi kasmā vuttan ti dhamma anupassanāya matthaka ppatti dassana attham
translated: If that is so, since the method of development has been stated for the attainment of arahatship by means of the teaching that ends with the contemplation of dhammas, why is it said again: “Then, bhikkhu, you should develop this concentration with thinking and exploring only” , etc.?🔽In order to show the attainment of the peak of the contemplation of dhammas.

original: Sā hi saṅkhārupekkhābhāvena vattamānā yathāvuttajjhānadhamme sammasantī visesato
analyzed: sā hi saṅkhāra upekkhā bhāvena vattamānā yathā vutta jhāna dhamme sammasantī visesataḥ
translated: For that contemplation, occurring as equanimity about formations, is called “attained to the peak” in the sense of penetrating the dhammas of jhāna mentioned above.

original: matthakappattā nāma hoti. Phalasamāpattibhūmidassanatthaṃ vuttanti keci.
analyzed: matthakappattā nāma hoti phala samāpatti bhūmi dassana attham vuttan ti keci
translated: Some say that it is stated in order to show the plane of fruition attainment.

original: Puna yato kho tetiādi arahattappattito uddhaṃ laddhabbaphāsuvihāradassanaṃ. Tattha
analyzed: puna yatas kho te iti ādi arahatta ppattitaḥ uddham laddhabba phāsu vihāra dassanam tattha
translated: Again, “When you are thus” , etc., is said in order to show the pleasant abiding to be attained after the attainment of arahatship. Herein:

original: gagghasīti gamissasi. Tasmāti yasmā “savitakkampī”tiādikā desanā mettādīnaṃ ārammaṇato
analyzed: gagghasi iti gamissasi tasmā ati yasmā desanā mettā ādīnam ārammaṇato
translated: you will go to the place of the dead.🔽Therefore, since the teaching beginning with “accompanied by thinking” is about the object of loving-kindness, etc.

original: aññasmiṃ ārammaṇe samādhiṃ sandhāya vuttā, na appamaññā, tasmā. “Tathevā”tiādinā
analyzed: aññasmin ārammaṇe samādhim sandhāya vuttā na appamaññā tasmā tathā iva āti ādinā
translated: You will go. Therefore, since the teaching beginning with “With applied thought and sustained thought” was stated with reference to concentration on an object other than loving-kindness, etc., as its object, not with reference to the measureless states, therefore,

original: ganthantarenapi tamevatthaṃ samattheti. Tattha tathevāti tikacatukkajjhānavaseneva.
analyzed: gantha antarena api tam eva attham samattha iti tattha tathā iva ati tika catukka jjhāna vasena iva
translated: with the next clause beginning with “So too” he confirms that same meaning. Herein, so too = only by means of the triple and quadruple jhānas.

original: Abhidhammeti cittuppādakaṇḍe, appamaññāvibhaṅgādīsu ca tattha tattha abhidhammappadesesu.
analyzed: abhidhammeti cittuppāda kaṇḍe appamaññā vibhaṅga ādīsu ca tattha tattha abhidhamma ppadesesu
translated: In the Abhidhamma = in the “Description of the Arising of Consciousness” and in the various passages in the Abhidhamma dealing with the measureless states, etc.

original: 273. Subhaparamādivasenāti subha-saddo “subhanteva adhimutto hotī”ti evaṃ vuttasubhavimokkhaṃ🔽sandhāya vutto uttarapadalopena. Parama-saddo ukkaṃsattho. Subho subhavimokkho paramo🔽ukkaṃso paramā koṭi etissāti subhaparamā, mettācetovimutti, tato paraṃ tāya sādhetabbaṃ
analyzed: subha parama ādi vasena ati subha saddo subhantā iva adhimuttaḥ hoti iti evam vutta subha vimokkham  sandhāya vuttaḥ uttara pada lopena parama saddaḥ ukkaṃsa atthaḥ subhaḥ subha vimokkho paramaḥ  ukkaṃso paramā koṭi etissa ati subha paramā mettā cetaḥ vimutti tatas param tāya sādhetabbam
translated: By the word “subhaparamā” the word “subha” is used with reference to the “liberation of mind by the beautiful” stated thus, “He is intent on the beautiful” ,

original: natthīti attho. Asādhāraṇassa atthassa adhippetattā vipassanāsukhādayo idha anavasarā.
analyzed: na atthi iti atthaḥ asādhāraṇassa atthassa adhippeta ttā vipassanā sukha ādayaḥ idha anavasarā
translated: with omission of the middle term. The word “paramā” has the sense of “highest.” The beautiful, the liberation of mind by the beautiful, is the highest, the best, the supreme, the ultimate. This is the meaning. And since the meaning of the word “paramā” is intended in the sense of “ultimate,” the words “happiness of insight” and so on are out of place here.

original: Itaretaravisiṭṭhāpete visesā, pageva parehi. Tenāha “aññamaññaṃ asadiso ānubhāvaviseso🔽veditabbo”ti. Visesetvāti aññamaññaṃ visiṭṭhaṃ katvā.🔽Tassa tassa upanissayattāti subhavimokkhādikassa tassa tassa vimokkhassa pakatūpanissayavasena🔽upanissayapaccayabhāvato. Idāni tamatthaṃ pākaṭataraṃ katvā dassetuṃ “mettāvihārissā”tiādi
analyzed: itaretara visiṭṭha apete visesā pagā iva parehi tena āha aññam aññam asadisaḥ ānubhāva visesaḥ  veditabbaḥ iti visesetvā iti aññam aññam visiṭṭham katvā  tassa tassa upanissaya ttā ti subha vimokkha ādikassa tassa tassa vimokkhassa pakatūpanissaya vasena  upanissaya paccaya bhāvataḥ idāni tam attham pākaṭataram katvā dassetum mettāvihārissa ātiādi
translated: The differences in their respective special qualities are even more marked than those of the rest. That is why it is said: “The difference in their respective special qualities should be understood as due to the difference in their respective bases, objects, etc., and to the difference in their respective special qualities.”🔽“Having distinguished them”: having made them different from each other.🔽“As the decisive-support condition for each”: as the decisive-support condition for each of the deliverances beginning with the beautiful deliverance,🔽by way of the natural decisive-support condition. Now, in order to show that meaning more clearly, he said: “The meditator who develops the deliverance of the beautiful, etc.”🔽🔽

original: vuttaṃ. Assa mettāvihārissa cittaṃ upasaṃharatoti sambandho. Appaṭikkūlaparicayāti🔽mettābhāvanāvasena sattasaññite yattha katthaci ārammaṇe appaṭikkūlākāreneva gahaṇassa🔽paricitattā. Tassa saṅkhārabhūtampi yaṃ kiñci ārammaṇaṃ appaṭikkūlākāreneva paccupatiṭṭhati,🔽pageva sabhāvato. “Appaṭikkūla”nti tatthassa cittaṃ abhirativasena nirāsaṅkaṃ pavattati,
analyzed: vuttam assa mettāvihārissa cittam upasaṃharato ti sambandhaḥ appaṭikkūla paricayā ti 🔽mettā bhāvanā vasena satta saññite yattha katthaci ārammaṇe appaṭikkūla ākārena iva gahaṇassa 🔽paricita ttā tassa saṅkhāra bhūtam pi yam kiñci ārammaṇam appaṭikkūla ākārena iva paccupatiṭṭhati 🔽pagā iva sabhāvataḥ appaṭikkūlanti tattha assa cittam abhirati vasena nirāsaṅkam pavattati
translated: The distinction between them is due to their individual pre-eminence, not to say their pre-eminence over others. That is why it is said, “The distinction in their individual pre-eminence should be understood” . Having distinguished them: having made them individually pre-eminent. As the decisive-support condition for each: as the decisive-support condition for each of the deliverances beginning with the beautiful deliverance, by way of the natural decisive-support condition . Now, in order to show that meaning more clearly, he said “For one who is developing the meditation subject of loving-kindness” , etc. The construction is: for one who is developing the meditation subject of loving-kindness, for one who is giving attention to loving-kindness, for one who is practising loving-kindness meditation, the mind enters into that, enters into any object whatsoever that is not repulsive, that is to say, that is not a cemetery, a skeleton, etc., or that is not repulsive in aspect, that is to say, that is not a bloated corpse, etc., or that is not repulsive in mode, that is to say, that is not a corpse with flesh and blood, etc. Because of the familiarization with the non-repulsive: because of the familiarization with the apprehension of any object whatsoever in the concept of a living being by means of the development of loving-kindness. For him any object whatsoever, even though it is a formation, presents itself as non-repulsive in aspect. How much more so one that is so naturally! His mind enters into that without hesitation, without doubt, because of his confidence in it as non-repulsive.

original: paccanīkadhammehi ca sukhena, suṭṭhu ca vimuccati, yatassa jhānassa vimokkhapariyāyo
analyzed: paccanīka dhammehi ca sukhena suṭṭhu ca vimuccati yatassa jhānassa vimokkha pariyāyo
translated: and he is well released from the opposite states, and he is well released from the defilements by surmounting them with the jhana that has the path as its object.

original: vutto. Tenāha “appaṭikkūlesū”tiādi. Yathāvutto ca attho anatthacaraṇādiadhippāyena
analyzed: vuttaḥ tena āha appaṭikkūlesu itiādi yathā vuttaḥ ca atthaḥ anattha caraṇa ādi adhippāyena
translated: The meaning stated thus is to be illustrated by the example of the unprofitable thought of harming, etc.,

original: sacetane ārammaṇe āghātaṃ uppādentassa paṭikkūlaparicayā acetanepi vātātapādike āghātuppattiyā
analyzed: sa cetane ārammaṇe āghātam uppādentassa paṭikkūla paricayā acetane pi vāta ātapa ādike āghāta uppattiyā
translated: in the case of one who arouses annoyance towards a conscious object of the kind described above, and by the example of the unprofitable thought of sensual-desire, etc.,🔽in the case of one who arouses lust towards a conscious object of the kind described above.

original: vibhāvetabbo. Na tato paranti tato subhavimokkhato paraṃ kassaci vimokkhassa upanissayo na hotīti attho.🔽Abhihananti etenāti abhighāto, daṇḍo abhighāto yassa taṃ daṇḍābhighātaṃ, taṃ ādi🔽yassa taṃ daṇḍābhighātādi, daṇḍābhighātādi rūpaṃ nimittaṃ yassa taṃ daṇḍābhighātādirūpanimittaṃ.
analyzed: vibhāvetabbaḥ na tatas paranti tatas subha vimokkhataḥ param kassaci vimokkhassa upanissayaḥ na hoti iti attho  abhihananti etena ati abhighātaḥ daṇḍaḥ abhighātaḥ yassa tam daṇḍa abhighātam tam ādi  yassa tam daṇḍa abhighāta ādi daṇḍa abhighāta ādi rūpam nimittam yassa tam daṇḍa abhighāta ādi rūpa nimittam
translated: The meaning is that it is not a condition for any other kind of deliverance beyond that of the beautiful.🔽“Affliction” is what is meant by “afflictive” . “Afflictive” is the same as “affliction” . “Afflictive” is a term for the pain of the stroke, etc., that is to say, the pain of the stroke, the pain of the cut, the pain of the blow, the pain of the stabbing, the pain of the burning, the pain of the constriction, the pain of the crushing, the pain of the cutting off of the hands and feet, the pain of the cutting off of the nose, the pain of the cutting off of the ears, the pain of the cutting off of the head.

original: Kiṃ pana tanti āha “sattadukkha”nti, daṇḍappahārādijanitaṃ karajarūpahetukaṃ sattānaṃ
analyzed: kim pana tat ti āha satta dukkham ti daṇḍa ppahāra ādi janitam kara ja rūpa hetukam
translated: “Afflictive” is a term for the form of the sign of the pain of the stroke, etc., that is to say, the form of the sign of the pain of the stroke, the form of the sign of the pain of the cut, the form of the sign of the pain of the blow, the form of the sign of the pain of the stabbing, the form of the sign of the pain of the burning, the form of the sign of the pain of the constriction, the form of the sign of the pain of the crushing, the form of the sign of the cutting off of the hands and feet, the form of the sign of the cutting off of the nose, the form of the sign of the cutting off of the ears, the form of the sign of the cutting off of the head.

original: uppajjanakadukkhanti attho. Rūpe ādīnavo suparividito hoti karuṇāvihārissa rūpanimittattā,
analyzed: uppajjanaka dukkhanti atthaḥ rūpe ādīnavaḥ su parividitaḥ hoti karuṇā vihārissa rūpa nimitta ttā
translated: The meaning is: the suffering that arises. The danger in materiality is very evident to one who abides in compassion because materiality is the sign of materiality,

original: dukkhassa karuṇāya ca paradukkhāsahanarasattāti adhippāyo. Tattha ākāse. Cittaṃ pakkhandati
analyzed: dukkhassa karuṇāya ca para dukkha asahana rasa ttā ti adhippāyaḥ tattha ākāse cittam pakkhandati
translated: and because compassion is the state of mind that cannot bear the suffering of others. The intention is this: “In space his mind has confidence,

original: sabbaso rūpānaṃ abhāvo vivaramapagamoti.🔽Tena tenātiādīsu ayaṃ yojanā – tena tena bhogasampattiādinā pāmojjakāraṇena pamuditānaṃ
analyzed: sabbasas rūpānaṃ abhāvaḥ vivaram apagamo ti  tena tena ati ādīsu ayam yojanā tena tena bhoga sampatti ādinā pāmojja kāraṇena
translated: the non-existence of materiality in all ways, the absence of the sign of materiality, is the object of his jhāna.”🔽In the passages beginning, “In whatever way … he sees … consciousness … with the thought ‘It is good that he has such consciousness’ … his mind enters into that state and acquires confidence, steadiness, and decision” , the construction is this:

original: sattānaṃ uppannapāmojjaviññāṇaṃ samanupassantassa yogino “sādhu vatāyaṃ satto pamodatī”ti
analyzed: sattānam uppanna pāmojja viññāṇam samanupassantassa yogino sādhu vata ayam satto pamodati iti
translated: beings who are glad because of some success in obtaining requisites, etc.,🔽have arisen gladness consciousness. When the meditator sees that, his mind is pervaded by gladness with the thought “How good it is that this being is glad.”

original: muditāya pavattisambhavato pamuditaviññāṇassa dassanena viññāṇaggahaṇaparicitaṃ cittaṃ hotīti.🔽Anukkamādhigatanti ākāsakasiṇavajje yattha katthaci kasiṇe rūpāvacarajjhānādhigamānukkamena
analyzed: muditāya pavatti sambhavataḥ pamudita viññāṇassa dassanena viññāṇa ggahaṇa paricitam cittam hoti iti  anukkama adhigatam ti ākāsa kasiṇa vajje yattha katthaci kasiṇe rūpāvacara jhāna adhigama anukkamena
translated: So his mind becomes familiar with the apprehension of consciousness by seeing gladness consciousness.🔽“Attained in due course”: attained by the development of the fine-material jhāna in whatever one of the kasiṇas beginning with the earth kasiṇa, and so on up to the limited-space kasiṇas, in the way stated in the Description of the Fine-Material Sphere .

original: rūpavirāgabhāvanāya adhigataṃ. Ākāsanimittaṃ gocaro etassāti ākāsanimittagocaraṃ,
analyzed: rūpa virāga bhāvanāya adhigatam ākāsa nimittam gocaraḥ etassa ati ākāsa nimitta gocaram
translated: The sign of space is its object, thus it has the sign of space as its object,

original: tasmiṃ ākāsanimittagocare paṭhamāruppaviññāṇe. Cittaṃ upasaṃharatoti dutiyāruppādhigamāya🔽bhāvanācittaṃ nentassa, tathā bhāvayatoti attho. Tatthāti tasmiṃ paṭhamāruppaviññāṇe.
analyzed: tasmin ākāsa nimitta gocare paṭhama āruppa viññāṇe cittam upasaṃharato ti dutiya āruppa adhigamāya  bhāvanā cittam nentassa tathā bhāvayato ti attho tattha ati tasmim paṭhama āruppa viññāṇe
translated: In that: in the first immaterial-sphere consciousness.🔽Mind: the consciousness of the base of infinite consciousness.

original: Cittanti viññāṇañcāyatanacittaṃ. Pakkhandatīti anupavisati vimokkhabhāvena appeti.
analyzed: cittam ti viññāṇam ca āyatana cittam pakkhandati iti anupavisati vimokkha bhāvena appeti
translated: Enters upon and dwells in: penetrates and makes its object by way of the liberation.

original: Ābhogābhāvatoti “sukhitā hontū”tiādinā sukhāsīsanādivasena ābhujanābhāvato. Sattānaṃ
analyzed: ābhoga abhāvataḥ iti sukhitāḥ hontu uti ādinā sukha āsīsana ādi vasena ābhujana abhāvataḥ
translated: Because of the absence of application: because of the absence of application in the form of wishing for the happiness of beings, etc., by means of the wish “May they be happy.”

original: sukhāsīsanādivasena pavattamānā mettādibhāvanāva paramatthaggahaṇamukhena satte ārammaṇaṃ
analyzed: sukha āsīsana ādi vasena pavattamānā mettā ādi bhāvanā vā paramattha ggahaṇa mukhena satte ārammaṇam
translated: The development of loving-kindness, etc., which occurs by way of wishing for the happiness of beings, etc., makes beings its object by way of the apprehension of their ultimate reality.

original: karoti, upekkhābhāvanā pana tathā appavattitvā kevalaṃ ajjhupekkhanavaseneva satte🔽ārammaṇaṃ karotīti āha “upekkhāvihārissa sukhadukkhādiparamatthaggāhavimukhabhāvato
analyzed: karoti upekkhā bhāvanā pana tathā appavatti tvā kevalam ajjhupekkhana vasena iva satte  ārammaṇam karoti iti āha upekkhāvihārissa sukha dukkha ādi paramattha ggāha vimukha bhāvato
translated: But the development of equanimity, not occurring in that way, makes beings its object only by way of mere equanimity.🔽Therefore it is said: “The mind of one who abides in equanimity is free from the desire to apprehend the ultimate reality of beings in the form of their happiness, suffering, etc., and it is free from the desire to apprehend the non-existent in the form of their ultimate reality.”

original: avijjamānaggahaṇadukkhaṃ cittaṃ hotī”ti. Nanu ca “kammassakā sattā, te kassa ruciyā
analyzed: a vijjamāna ggahaṇa dukkham cittam hoti iti nanu ca kammassakā sattā te kassa ruciyā
translated: But are not beings the result of kamma?

original: sukhitā vā bhavissantī”tiādinā paṭikkhepavasenapi paramatthaggahaṇamukheneva upekkhābrahmavihāropi
analyzed: sukhitāḥ vā bhavissanti iti ādinā paṭikkhepa vasena api parama attha ggahaṇa mukhena iva upekkhā brahmavihāraḥ api
translated: But in the earlier stage of development of the divine abidings of loving-kindness, etc.,

original: satte ārammaṇaṃ karotīti? Saccametaṃ, taṃ pana bhāvanāya pubbabhāge, matthakappattiyaṃ
analyzed: satte ārammaṇam karoti iti saccam etam tam pana bhāvanāya pubba bhāge matthaka ppattiyam
translated: it is only in the sense of the ultimate meaning that they have beings as their object that is distinctive in the way already stated.

original: pana kevalaṃ ajjhupekkhanavaseneva satte ārammaṇaṃ karotīti savisesaṃ paramatthato🔽avijjamāne eva visaye tassa pavatti. Avijjamānaggahaṇadukkhatā ca ajjhupekkhanavasena
analyzed: pana kevalam ajjhupekkhana vasena iva satte ārammaṇam karoti iti sa visesam paramatthato  avijjamāne eva visaye tassa pavatti avijjamāna ggahaṇa dukkha tā ca ajjhupekkhana vasena
translated: But when they reach their culmination, they have only the mere “beings” as object by way of mere looking on.

original: appanāppattiyā aparāmāsasattaggahaṇamuddhabhūtatāya veditabbā. Sesaṃ vuttanayameva.
analyzed: appanā appattiyā veditabbā sesam vutta nayam eva
translated: And the difficulty about apprehending what is non-existent should be understood as due to the fact that the looking on is by way of mere equanimity and to the fact that the apprehending of beings as permanent, etc., is what is prominent in the attainment of absorption. The rest is as already stated.🔽All these: all these four divine abidings.

original: 274. Sabbāpetāti sabbāpi etā appamaññā. Dānādīnanti pāramibhāvappattānaṃ dānādīnaṃ🔽buddhakaradhammānaṃ. Sabbakalyāṇadhammānanti sabbesaṃ anavajjadhammānaṃ, samatiṃsāya
analyzed: sabbā apetā ti sabbā api etāḥ appamaññāḥ dāna ādīnam ti pārami bhāva pattānam dāna ādīnam  buddha kara dhammānam sabba kalyāṇa dhammānam ti sabbesam anavajja dhammānam samatiṃsāya
translated: The special qualities beginning with giving: the special qualities beginning with giving that have reached perfection.🔽All the special qualities: all the blameless special qualities, the thirty perfections,🔽the qualities that are the requisites of enlightenment, and the special qualities of the Enlightened One, or all the special qualities that are of a beautiful nature.

original: pāramitānaṃ, tannimittānaṃ buddhayāniyānañca, sabbehi vā sundarasabhāvānaṃ. Na hi
analyzed: pāramitānam tad nimittānam buddha yāniyānam ca sabbehi vā sunda rasa bhāvānam na hi
translated: For there is no special quality in the Enlightened One that is not blameless, no special quality of the requisites of enlightenment that is not a perfection, and no special quality of the requisites of enlightenment that is not a requisite of enlightenment.

original: lokiyadhammā buddhakaradhammehi ānubhāvato ukkaṭṭhā nāma atthi, buddhadhammesu vattabbameva
analyzed: lokiya dhammā buddha kara dhammehi ānubhāvataḥ ukkaṭṭhāḥ nāma atthi buddha dhammesu vattabbam eva
translated: There are mundane states which are called “supreme” in the sense of surpassing the states that are not causes of Buddhahood. But this is not so in the case of the Buddha-qualities.

original: natthi. Paripūrikāti parivuddhikarā. Adhiṭṭhānāni viya hi appamaññā sabbāsaṃ pāramitānaṃ🔽pāripūrikarā. “Hitajjhāsayatāyā”tiādinā mettābrahmavihārādīnaṃ upekkhābrahmavihārassa
analyzed: natthi paripūrikā ati parivuddhi karā adhiṭṭhānāni viya hi appamaññā sabbāsam pāramitānam
translated: “Fulfillment” means “that which brings about completion.” For the immeasurables are like the bases of success in that they bring about the completion of all the pāramīs.

original: adhiṭṭhānabhāvadassanamukhena catūhi appamaññāhi attano santānassa pageva abhisaṅkhatattā
analyzed: adhiṭṭhāna bhāva dassana mukhena catūhi appamaññāhi attanaḥ santānassa pagā iva abhisaṅkhata ttā
translated: “The intention for welfare” and so on show that the four immeasurables are the bases for the four divine abodes, beginning with loving-kindness and ending with equanimity.

original: mahābodhisattā dānādipāramiyo pūretuṃ samatthā honti, nāññathāti imamatthaṃ dasseti.🔽Imassa dātabbaṃ, imassa na dātabbanti nidassanamattaṃ daṭṭhabbaṃ, “idaṃ dātabbaṃ,🔽idaṃ na dātabbanti ca vibhāgaṃ akatvā”ti vattabbato. Deyyapaṭiggāhakavikapparahitā
analyzed: mahā bodhisattāḥ dāna ādi pāramiyaḥ pūretum samatthāḥ honti na aññathā iti imam attham dasseti  imassa dātabbam imassa na dātabbanti nidassana mattam daṭṭhabbam idam dātabbam  idam na dātabban ti ca vibhāgam a katvā iti vattabbataḥ deyya paṭiggāhaka vikappa rahitā
translated: The great bodhisattvas are able to fulfill the pāramīs of giving and so on because they have already resolved their own continuity by means of the four immeasurables, and not otherwise.🔽“This should be given, this should not be given” should be seen as mere indication, because it is said, “without making any distinction as to ‘This should be given, this should not be given.’”

original: hi dānapāramitā. Yathāha –
analyzed: hi dāna pāramitā yathā āha
translated: For the perfection of giving is devoid of any discrimination between what should be given and what should not be given, as is stated:

original: “Yathāpi kumbho sampuṇṇo, yassa kassaci adhokato;
analyzed: yathā api kumbhaḥ sampuṇṇaḥ yassa kassaci adhokataḥ
translated: “Just as a pot filled to the brim, From whatever side one pours,

original: Vamatevudakaṃ nissesaṃ, na tattha parirakkhatī”ti. ;
analyzed: vamateva udakam nissesam na tattha parirakkhati iti
translated: He does not protect it, and it is lost to him.

original: “Sabbasattāna”nti idaṃ “sukhanidāna”nti imināpi sambandhitabbaṃ, “dentī”ti iminā
analyzed: sabba sattānam ti idam sukha nidānam ti iminā api sambandhitabbam denti iti iminā
translated: “To all beings” is to be construed with “giving” and with “the source of happiness.”

original: ca. Tena deyyadhammena viya dānadhammenāpi mahāsattānaṃ lokassa bahūpakāratā vuttā
analyzed: ca tena deyya dhammena viya dāna dhammena api mahāsattānam lokassa bahu upakāra tā vuttā
translated: Thus it is said that the great beings are a great help to the world by the virtue of giving,🔽as well as by the gift itself, since the latter is dedicated to that end.

original: hoti, tathā tassa pariṇāmanato. Tadatthadīpanatthaṃ hi “vibhāgaṃ akatvā”ti vatvāpi
analyzed: hoti tathā tassa pariṇāmanataḥ tad attha dīpana attham hi vibhāgam a katvā ati vatvā api
translated: For this is the meaning of the passage: “without making distinctions” is said in order to show that meaning.🔽“To all beings” is said in order to show that meaning.

original: “sabbasattāna”nti vuttaṃ. Tesanti sabbasattānaṃ. Upaghātanti etthāpi “vibhāgaṃ akatvā”ti🔽ānetvā sambandhitabbaṃ. Ayaṃ hettha padayojanā – vibhāgaṃ akatvā upaghātaṃ parivajjayantā
analyzed: sabba sattānam nti vuttam tesan ti sabba sattānam upaghātam ti ettha api vibhāgam a katvā iti  ānetvā sambandhitabbam ayam ha itthā pada yojanā vibhāgam a katvā upaghātam parivajjayantā
translated: “To them” means to all beings. “Harm” is to be construed with “without making distinctions”🔽as well. This is the word-construction here: “without making distinctions, avoiding harm, they undertake virtue, the source of happiness for all beings.”

original: sabbasattānaṃ sukhanidānaṃ sīlaṃ samādiyantīti. Sattakālavikapparahitā hi sīlapāramitā,
analyzed: sabba sattānam sukha nidānam sīlam samādiyanti iti satta kāla vikappa rahitā hi sīla pāramitā
translated: For the perfection of virtue is free from the fluctuations of the life-cycle;

original: lokatthameva cassa phalaṃ pariṇamīyati. Nekkhammaṃ bhajantīti pabbajjaṃ upagacchanti.
analyzed: lokattham eva cassa phalam pariṇamīyati nekkhammam bhajanti iti pabbajjam upagacchanti
translated: and its fruit ripens in the welfare of the world. “They resort to renunciation” means they go forth.

original: Pabbajitassa hi sabbaso sīlaṃ paripūrati, na gahaṭṭhassa. Idhāpi “vibhāgaṃ akatvā
analyzed: pabbajitassa hi sabbasas sīlam paripūrati na gahaṭṭhassa idha api vibhāgam a katvā
translated: For the virtue of one gone forth is fulfilled in every way, not that of a householder. Here too, without making any distinction,

original: sabbasattānaṃ sukhanidāna”nti idaṃ ānetvā sambandhitabbaṃ. Na hi bodhisattā kālavibhāgaṃ
analyzed: sabba sattānam sukha nidānam ti idam ānetvā sambandhitabbam na hi bodhisattā kāla vibhāgam
translated: it should be construed as follows: “The source of happiness for all beings.” For the Bodhisattvas do not practice going forth or undertake virtue making a distinction of time.

original: katvā pabbajjaṃ anutiṭṭhanti, sīlaṃ vā samādiyanti, nidassanamattañcetaṃ jhānādinekkhammabhajanassāpi
analyzed: katvā pabbajjam anutiṭṭhanti sīlam vā samādiyanti nidassana mattam ca itam jhāna ādi nekkhamma bhajanassa api
translated: This is merely an illustration, for renunciation in the form of jhana, etc., is also required.

original: icchitabbattā. Sabbasattānaṃ sukhanidānatā heṭṭhā vuttanayāva. Esa nayo sesesupi.🔽Hitāhitesūti atthānatthesu. Asammohatthāyāti sammohaviddhaṃsanāya. Paññaṃ pariyodapentīti🔽yogavihitaṃ vijjāṭṭhānādiṃ assutaṃ suṇantā sutaṃ vodapentā ahaṃkāramamaṃkārādiṃ vidhunantā
analyzed: icchitabba ttā sabba sattānam sukha nidāna tā heṭṭhā esa nayo sesesu pi  hita ahitesu uti attha anatthesu a sammoha tthāya ati sammoha viddhaṃsanāya paññam pariyodapenti iti  yoga vihitam vijjā aṭṭhāna ādim assutam suṇantā sutam vodapentā ahaṃkāra mamaṃkāra ādim vidhunantā
translated: The source of happiness for all beings is as stated above. The same method applies to the rest.🔽“To beings in trouble and out of trouble”: to those in misfortune and those not in misfortune. “For the sake of non-delusion”: for the purpose of dispelling delusion. “They purify their knowledge”: they purify their knowledge by listening to the undiscovered knowledge of the requisites of enlightenment, etc., and by dispelling what has been discovered through listening, by removing the conceit “I am” and the conceit “mine.”

original: ñāṇaṃ visodhenti. “Ahaṃ mamā”ti vikapparahitā hi paññāpāramitā. Hitasukhatthāyāti
analyzed: ñāṇam visodhenti aham mama ati vikappa rahitā hi paññāpāramitā hita sukha tthāya ati
translated: For the perfection of wisdom is free from the discrimination “I” and “mine.” “For the sake of welfare and happiness”:

original: sattānaṃ hitasukhādivuddhiyatthameva. Niccanti satataṃ avicchedena paṭipakkhena avokiṇṇaṃ.🔽Vīriyamārabhantīti yathā sattānaṃ anuppannaṃ hitasukhaṃ uppajjati, uppannaṃ abhivaḍḍhati,
analyzed: sattānam hita sukha ādi vuddhiyattham eva niccanti satatam avicchedena paṭipakkhena avokiṇṇam  vīriyam ārabhanti iti yathā sattānam anuppannam hita sukham uppajjati uppannam abhivaḍḍhati
translated: for the sake of the growth of beings’ welfare, happiness, etc. Constant means uninterrupted, not interrupted by its opposite.🔽They exert energy means they make effort so that beings’ non-arisen welfare and happiness arise and their arisen welfare and happiness increase.

original: evaṃ parakkamaṃ karonti. Saṅkocavikkheparahitā hi vīriyapāramitā. “Vīrabhāvaṃ pattāpī”ti
analyzed: evam parakkamam karonti saṅkoca vikkhepa rahitā hi vīriya pāramitā vīra bhāvam pattā api iti
translated: For the perfection of energy is free from contraction and distraction. “Even though they have attained the state of heroes”

original: iminā aparaddhānaṃ niggahasamatthataṃ dasseti. Nānappakārakaṃ aparādhaṃ khamantīti🔽mammacchedanākārena attani pavattitaṃ nānāvidhaṃ aparādhaṃ sahanti. Attaparavikappavirahitā
analyzed: iminā aparaddhānam niggaha samattha tam dasseti nānā pakārakam aparādham khamanti iti  mamma chedana ākārena attani pavattitam nānāvidham aparādham sahanti atta para vikappa virahitā
translated: shows their ability to punish those who offend them. They forgive all kinds of offenses means🔽they tolerate the various kinds of offenses committed against them as if they were cutting up their own flesh.

original: hi dosasahanā khantipāramitā.🔽Paṭiññaṃ na visaṃvādentīti avisaṃvādanasāmaññena sabbassapi anariyavohārassa akaraṇamāha.
analyzed: hi dosa sahanā khanti pāramitā  paṭiññam na visaṃvādenti iti avisaṃvādana sāmaññena sabbassa api anariya vohārassa akaraṇam āha
translated: For the perfection of patience is free from the discrimination of self and other and from the hatred that tolerates nothing.🔽They do not deceive by way of their promise means they do not do any kind of ignoble talking by way of the common characteristic of non-deception.

original: Paṭiññāte, apaṭiññāte ca diṭṭhādike micchāvikapparahitā hi saccapāramitā. Avicalādhiṭṭhānāti
analyzed: paṭiññāte a paṭiññāte ca diṭṭha ādike micchā vikappa rahitā hi sacca pāramitā avicala adhiṭṭhānā ati
translated: For the perfection of truth is free from the discrimination of what is seen, etc., and from the perversity of wrong discrimination. Their resolve is unshakable means

original: yathāsamādinnesu dānādidhammesu niccalādhiṭṭhāyino acalasamādānādhiṭṭhānā, samādinnesu🔽ca buddhakaradhammesu sammadeva avaṭṭhānaṃ adhiṭṭhānapāramitā. Tesūti sattesu. Avicalāyāti
analyzed: yathā samādinnesu dāna ādi dhammesu niccala adhiṭṭhāyinaḥ acala samādāna adhiṭṭhānā samādinnesu  ca buddha kara dhammesu sammat eva avaṭṭhānam adhiṭṭhāna pāramitā tesu iti sattesu avicalāya ati
translated: The perfection of resolution is the resolution of one who is unshaken in the things beginning with giving, etc., that have been undertaken, and who is unshaken in the undertaking of the things that lead to Buddhahood that have been undertaken.🔽“In them” means in beings. “Unshakable” means unshaken by the defilements.

original: paṭipakkhena akampanīyāya. Evanti yathāvuttena sattesu hitajjhāsayatādiākārena. Yathā🔽ca brahmavihārādhiṭṭhānā pāramiyo, evaṃ adhiṭṭhānādhiṭṭhānāpi. Tathā hi yathāpaṭiññaṃ
analyzed: paṭipakkhena akampanīyāya evam ti yathāvuttena sattesu hita jhāsayata ādi ākārena yathā  ca brahmavihāra adhiṭṭhānā pāramiyaḥ evam adhiṭṭhāna adhiṭṭhānā api tathā hi yathāpaṭiññam
translated: The perfection of determination is the determination to be unshaken in the practice of the virtues of giving, etc., as undertaken, and the determination to maintain well the virtues of giving, etc., as undertaken for the purpose of attaining Buddhahood. “In beings” means in all beings. “To be unshaken” means to be unmoved by their opposition. “Thus” means in the way described above, by the mode of wishing for the welfare of beings, etc.

original: parānuggahāya pāramīnaṃ anuṭṭhānena saccādhiṭṭhānaṃ, tappaṭipakkhapariccāgato cāgādhiṭṭhānaṃ,
analyzed: para anuggahāya pāramīnam anuṭṭhānena sacca adhiṭṭhānam tad paṭipakkha pariccāgataḥ cāga adhiṭṭhānam
translated: Just as the perfections are the basis for the divine abidings, so too are they the basis for the determinations. For the determination of truth is the undertaking of the perfections for the purpose of helping others in accordance with one’s promise. The determination of relinquishment is the relinquishment of their opposition.

original: pāramīhi sacittupasamato upasamādhiṭṭhānaṃ, tāhi parahitūpāyakosallato paññādhiṭṭhānaṃ.
analyzed: pāramīhi sa cittupasamataḥ upasama adhiṭṭhānam tāhi para hitu upāya kosallato paññā adhiṭṭhānam
translated: The determination of peace is the pacification of the mind through the perfections. The determination of understanding is the skill in means for the welfare of others through the perfections.

original: Evaṃ paccekampi pāramitāsu yathārahaṃ netabbaṃ. Ayamettha saṅkhepo, vitthārato pana
analyzed: evam paccekam pi pāramitāsu yathāraham netabbam ayam ettha saṅkhepaḥ vitthārato pana
translated: Thus, in brief, the perfections should be understood according to their determinations. But in detail, they are infinite.

original: pāramitāsu yaṃ vattabbaṃ, taṃ paramatthadīpaniyaṃ cariyāpiṭakavaṇṇanāyaṃ vuttanayeneva
analyzed: pāramitāsu yam vattabbam tam paramattha dīpaniyam cariyāpiṭaka vaṇṇanāyam vutta nayena iva
translated: What should be said about the pāramīs is given in the commentary on the Cariyāpiṭaka, in the section on the paramattha.🔽We have not expanded on it here for fear of being too prolix.

original: veditabbaṃ, ativitthārabhayena na vitthārayimha. Tathā dasabalañāṇādiketi. Etāva
analyzed: veditabbam ati vitthāra bhayena na vitthārayimha tathā dasa bala ñāṇa ādikā iti
translated: So too with the knowledge of the ten powers, etc.

original: hontīti etā honti evāti yojanā.
analyzed: honti iti etāḥ honti eva ati yojanā
translated: They are just these, etc.

original: Brahmavihāraniddesavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: brahmavihāra niddesa vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The explanation of the divine abidings is ended.

original: Iti navamaparicchedavaṇṇanā.🔽10. Āruppaniddesavaṇṇanā
analyzed: iti navama pariccheda vaṇṇanā  āruppa niddesa vaṇṇanā
translated: The commentary on the ninth chapter is ended.🔽The explanation of the immaterial states

original: Paṭhamāruppavaṇṇanā🔽275. Uddiṭṭhesūti “cattāro āruppā”ti evaṃ uddiṭṭhesu, niddhāraṇe cetaṃ bhummaṃ. Tenevāha🔽“catūsu āruppesū”ti. Tattha rūpavivekena arūpaṃ, arūpameva āruppaṃ jhānaṃ, idha pana
analyzed: paṭhama āruppa vaṇṇanā  uddiṭṭhesu iti cattāro āruppā ati evam uddiṭṭhesu niddhāraṇe ca itam bhummam tena iva āha  catūsu āruppesu ti tattha rūpa vivekena arūpam arūpam eva āruppam jhānam idha pana
translated: The explanation of the first immaterial state

original: tadatthaṃ kammaṭṭhānaṃ adhippetaṃ. Taṃ bhāvetukāmo catutthajjhānaṃ uppādetīti sambandho.
analyzed: tad attham kammaṭṭhānam adhippetam tam bhāvetu kāmaḥ catuttha jhānam uppādeti iti sambandho
translated: In the four immaterial states: in the four immaterial states that have been “set up” in the way beginning, “Four immaterial states” . The word “states” is a substantive formed from the verb “to set up” . That is why he says “in the four immaterial states.” Herein, immaterial is that which is without materiality. An immaterial state is a jhāna that is immaterial. But here the meditation subject is intended. The construction of the words should be understood thus: “One who is developing that, who wants to develop that, first of all, after rising from the fourth jhāna, which is the basis for leaping up to the immaterial states, and after that, by means of the same consciousness that has the fourth jhāna as its object, he defines materiality as ‘materiality’ and immateriality as ‘immateriality’ in the way already described under the fourth jhāna. Then, after that, he sees the danger in materiality and he finds no satisfaction in it. He sees the peace and excellence of immateriality and is satisfied with it. Then, after that, he surmounts the material, that is to say, he surmounts the fourth jhāna, which is material since it has materiality as its object. He does so by means of the same consciousness that has the fourth jhāna as its object, by means of the same consciousness that has the defining of materiality and immateriality as its object. He surmounts it in the way already described under the fourth jhāna. He enters upon and dwells in the base consisting of boundless space.

original: Rūpādhikaraṇanti rūpahetu. Hetuattho hi ettha adhikaraṇa-saddo “kāmādhikaraṇa”ntiādīsu
analyzed: rūpa adhikaraṇanti rūpa hetu hetu atthaḥ hi ettha adhikaraṇa saddo kāma adhikaraṇa nti ādīsu
translated: “With the support of materiality”: with the support of materiality as cause. For the word “support” here stands for cause, as in the passages, “With sensuality as cause, sensuality as source” ,

original: viya. Daṇḍanaṭṭhena daṇḍo, muggarādi. Parapīḷādhippāyena tassa ādānaṃ daṇḍādānaṃ.
analyzed: viya daṇḍana ṭṭhena daṇḍaḥ muggara ādi para pīḷā adhippāyena tassa ādānam daṇḍa ādānam
translated: As a stick is for beating, so is a stick for striking. The taking up of it with the intention of hurting is the taking up of a stick.

original: Sattānaṃ sasanaṭṭhena satthaṃ, āvudhaṃ. Bhaṇḍanaṃ kalaho. Virodho viggaho. Nānāvādo
analyzed: sattānam sasana ṭṭhena sattham āvudham bhaṇḍanam kalahaḥ virodhaḥ viggahaḥ nānāvādaḥ
translated: A weapon is a knife, etc., because of its cutting. Quarrelling is a dispute. Contention is a quarrel. Disputation is a difference of opinion.

original: vivādo. Etanti yathāvuttaṃ daṇḍādānādikaṃ. Sabbasoti anavasesato. Āruppe arūpabhāve,
analyzed: vivādaḥ etat ti yathā vuttam daṇḍa ādāna ādikam sabbaso ti anavasesataḥ āruppe arūpa bhāve
translated: These are the taking up of a stick, etc., already mentioned. All means without exception. In the immaterial, the state of being immaterial,

original: āruppe vā bhave. Rūpānaṃyevāti diṭṭhādīnavānaṃ rūpānaṃyeva, na arūpānanti adhippāyo.🔽Nibbidāyāti vikkhambhanavasena nibbindanatthāya. Virāgāyāti virajjanatthāya. Nirodhāyāti🔽nirujjhanatthāya. Sabbametaṃ samatikkamaṃ sandhāya vuttaṃ. Daṇḍādānādīnanti ādi-saddena
analyzed: āruppe vā bhave diṭṭha ādīnavānam na arūpānam ti adhippāyaḥ  nibbidāya ati vikkhambhana vasena nibbindana tthāya virāgāya ati virajjana tthāya nirodhāya ati  nirujjhana atthāya sabbam etam samatikkamam sandhāya vuttam daṇḍa ādāna ādīnam ti ādi saddena
translated: or in the immaterial world. Only of material things means only of material things such as visible forms, etc., which are seen to be disadvantageous, not of immaterial things. This is the purport.

original: adinnādānādikaṃ sabbaṃ rūpahetukaṃ anatthaṃ saṅgaṇhāti, na idha pāḷiyaṃ āgatamevāti
analyzed: adinnādāna ādikam sabbam rūpa hetukam anattham saṅgaṇhāti na idha pāḷiyam āgatam eva ati
translated: For the purpose of dispassion means for the purpose of becoming dispassionate by way of suppression. For the purpose of fading away means for the purpose of fading away. For the purpose of cessation means for the purpose of cessation. All this is said with reference to surmounting. The taking up of a stick, etc., means that by the word “etc.,” all the disadvantage that is caused by material things, such as taking what is not given, etc., is included, and not only what is mentioned in the text.

original: daṭṭhabbaṃ. Karajarūpeti yathāvuttādīnavādhikaraṇabhāvayogyaṃ dassetuṃ vuttaṃ, oḷārikarūpeti
analyzed: daṭṭhabbam kara ja rūpā iti yathāvutta ādīnava adhikaraṇa bhāva yogyam dassetum vuttam oḷārika rūpā iti
translated: It should be seen thus. Materiality produced by kamma means that it is said in order to show that it is suitable to be the basis for the disadvantage already mentioned, etc. Gross materiality means

original: attho. Ādīnavanti dosaṃ. Tassāti rūpassa. Ālokoti vaṇṇaviseso evāti tattha pavattaṃ
analyzed: atthaḥ ādīnavanti dosam tassa ati rūpassa āloko iti vaṇṇa visesaḥ eva ati tattha pavattam
translated: “Meaning” is the profitable, etc. “Disadvantage” is the unprofitable, etc. “That” is the visible-data object. “Light” is a particular visible datum.

original: paṭibhāganimittaṃ ugghāṭetvā siyā ākāsanimittaṃ uggahetuṃ, na pana paricchinnākāsakasiṇaṃ
analyzed: paṭibhāga nimittam ugghāṭetvā siyā ākāsa nimittam uggahetum na pana paricchinna ākāsa kasiṇam
translated: So he should remove the counterpart sign and apprehend the space-element sign. But he should not remove the limited-space kasiṇa and apprehend that.🔽For its removal would be only by means of the visible-data sign.

original: ugghāṭetvā. Tassa hi ugghāṭanā nāma rūpanimitteneva siyāti āha “ṭhapetvā paricchinnākāsakasiṇaṃ
analyzed: ugghāṭetvā tassa hi ugghāṭanā nāma rūpa nimittena iva siyā ti āha ṭhapetvā paricchinna ākāsa kasiṇam
translated: That is why it is said, “except the limited-space kasiṇa.”

original: navasū”ti. Keci pana “ālokakasiṇampi ṭhapetvā aṭṭhasū”ti vadanti, tassa pana ṭhapane
analyzed: keci pana āloka kasiṇam pi ṭhapetvā aṭṭhasū ti vadanti tassa pana ṭhapane
translated: But some say that the light kasiṇa should also be omitted, so that there are only eight.

original: kāraṇaṃ na dissati, karajarūpaṃ atikkantaṃ hoti tassa anālambanato.🔽Yadi evaṃ kasmā “catutthajjhānavasenā”ti vuttaṃ. Nanu paṭhamajjhānādīnipi tassa anālambanavaseneva
analyzed: kāraṇam na dissati karaja rūpam atikkantam hoti tassa anālambanato  yadi evam kasmā catuttha jhāna vasena ati vuttam nanu paṭhama jhāna ādīni pi tassa anālambana vasena iva
translated: But there is no reason to omit the light kasiṇa.🔽If that is so, why is it said, “in the way beginning ‘With the abandoning of pleasure and pain’ ” ?🔽Are not the first jhāna, etc., also a non-object for it in the way that the fourth jhāna is?

original: pavattanti paṭibhāganimittārammaṇattā? Saccametaṃ, oḷārikaṅgappahānato pana santasabhāvena
analyzed: pavattanti paṭibhāga nimitta ārammaṇa ttā saccam etam oḷārika aṅga ppahānato pana santa sabhāvena
translated: It is true that they are, but they are not so in the way that the fourth jhāna is,

original: āneñjappattena catutthajjhānena atikkantaṃ suṭṭhu atikkantaṃ nāma hotīti “catutthajjhānavasenā”ti
analyzed: āneñja ppattena catuttha jhānena atikkantam suṭṭhu atikkantam nāma hoti iti catuttha jhāna vasena ati
translated: It is well sur-mounted when it has surmounted the fourth jhāna, which has reached imperturbability, thus it is said in the Vibhanga that it is “surmounted by the fourth jhāna.”

original: vuttaṃ. Keci “assāsapassāsānaṃ nirujjhanato, kāmadhātusamatikkamanato cā”ti vadanti,
analyzed: vuttam keci assāsa passāsānam nirujjhanataḥ kāmadhātu samatikkamanataḥ ca ati vadanti
translated: Some say that it is because of the cessation of in-breaths and out-breaths and because of the surmounting of the sense sphere.

original: taṃ akāraṇaṃ, itaresaṃ cittasamuṭṭhānarūpānaṃ sambhavato, heṭṭhimajjhānānañca akāmadhātusaṃvattanīyato.
analyzed: tam akāraṇam itaresam citta samuṭṭhāna rūpānam sambhavataḥ heṭṭhima jhānānam ca a kāmadhātu saṃvattanīyataḥ
translated: That is no reason, because other kinds of materiality originated by consciousness occur, and because the lower jhānas are not included in the sense sphere.

original: Tappaṭibhāgamevāti karajarūpapaṭibhāgameva nimittaggāhasambhavato. Sadisañca nāma
analyzed: tad paṭibhāgam eva ati kara ja rūpa paṭibhāgam eva nimitta ggāha sambhavataḥ sadisam ca nāma
translated: It is only a semblance of that, only a semblance of the materiality of the first jhāna, because there is apprehension of a sign. And it is not the same as that,

original: taṃ na hoti, tasmā kiṃ tassa samatikkamanenāti anuyogaṃ sandhāya “kathaṃ? Yathā”tiādi🔽vuttaṃ. Tattha kathanti kathetukamyatāpucchā. Yathāti opammatthe nipāto. Lekhācittanti🔽kāḷavaṇṇādinā kataparikammāya lekhāya cittaṃ. Phalitantaranti vivaraṃ. Disvāti dūrato
analyzed: tam na hoti tasmā kim tassa samatikkamanena ati anuyogam sandhāya katham yathā itiādi  vuttam tattha katham ti kathā itu kamya tā pucchā yathā ti opamma atthe nipātaḥ lekhā cittam ti  kāḷavaṇṇa ādinā kata parikammāya lekhāya cittam vivaram disvā ati dūratas
translated: so what is the use of surmounting it? The question is asked in this way with reference to the argument.

original: disvā. Samānarūpasaddasamudācāranti sadisarūpasaṇṭhānasarappayogaṃ.
analyzed: disvā samāna rūpa sadda samudācaranti sa disa rūpa saṇṭhāna sara ppayogam
translated: Herein, how? is a question expressing a desire to know. As is the … of the … of writing is a locative absolute. Writing is the action consisting in the drawing of lines in various ways with charcoal or with chalk or with a pen on earth or on a wooden board or on a rock or on a tablet or on a leaf. The mind is the mind element. The mind element is the mind faculty. The mind faculty is the mind base. The mind base is consciousness. Consciousness is the mind. The mind is the mental body. The mental body is a person. A person is a living being. A living being is a soul. A soul is a man. A man is a human being. A human being is a human. A human is a human being. A human being is a person. A person is a human being. A human being is a man. A man is a soul. A soul is a living being. A living being is a mental body. A mental body is consciousness. Consciousness is the mind faculty. The mind faculty is the mind base. The mind base is the mind element. The mind element is writing. The writing is the mind. The mind is the mental body. The mental body is a person. A person is a human being. A human being is a man. A man is a soul. A soul is a living being. A living being is a mental body. A mental body is consciousness. Consciousness is the mind faculty. The mind faculty is the mind base. The mind base is the mind element. The mind element is writing. The writing is the mind. The mind is the mental body. The

original: Ārammaṇavasenāti “mama cakkhu sobhanaṃ, mama kāyo thiro, mama parikkhārā sundarā”ti🔽evaṃ ārammaṇakaraṇavasena. Karajarūpasamaṅgikāloti attano attabhāvarūpena ceva ārammaṇarūpena
analyzed: ārammaṇa vasena ati mama cakkhu sobhanam mama kāyaḥ thiraḥ mama parikkhārā sundarā ti  evam ārammaṇa karaṇa vasena attano atta bhāva rūpena ca iva ārammaṇa rūpena
translated: “By way of object” means by making it an object in the way beginning, “My eye is beautiful,” “my body is strong,” “my requisites are fine.”🔽“The time when it is endowed with the materiality of the process of contraction” means the time when it is endowed with the materiality of its own self and the materiality of its object.

original: ca samannāgatakālo. Tampīti kasiṇarūpassapi. Sāmiatthe hi idaṃ upayogavacanaṃ. Bhayasantāsaadassanakāmatā
analyzed: ca samannāgata kālo tam pi iti kasiṇa rūpassa api sāmi atthe hi idam upayoga vacanam bhaya santāsa a dassana kāma tā
translated: “That too”: the kasiṇa materiality too. For this is a statement of the use of the word “too” in the sense of ownership. The construction is this: “The desire to get free from it, like the desire to see the terror and the fear” .

original: viya samatikkamitukāmatāti yojanā. Idañca yathāvuttānaṃ nibbidāvirāganirodhānaṃ sādhāraṇavacanaṃ.🔽Te hi tayo apekkhitvā bhayasantāsaadassanakāmatā vuttā. Eko kira sunakho vane sūkarena🔽pahaṭamatto palāto, so arūpadassanavelāya bhattapacanaukkhaliṃ dūrato disvā sūkarasaññāya
analyzed: viya samatikkamitu kāma tā ati yojanā idam ca yathā vuttānam nibbida avirāga nirodhānam sādhāraṇa vacanam  te hi tayaḥ apekkhitvā bhaya santāsa a dassana kāma tā vuttā ekaḥ kira su nakhaḥ vane sūkarena  pahaṭa mattaḥ palāto saḥ arūpa dassana velāya bhatta pacana okkhalim dūratas disvā sūkara saññāya
translated: And this is a statement in common of the three kinds of dispassion, fading away, and cessation stated as above.

original: bhīto uttasanto palāyi, pisācabhīruko puriso rattibhāge aparicite dese matthakacchinnaṃ
analyzed: bhītaḥ uttasanto palāyi pisāca bhīruko puriso ratti bhāge a paricite dese matthaka chinnaṃ
translated: For these three are mentioned with the words “desire to see the terror and the fear” as the object. A certain dog, it seems, was frightened and terrified by a boar that charged it in a wood. At the time of seeing the form it saw the cauldron for boiling rice in the kitchen from a distance, and it fled in its delusion that it was a boar. A man who was afraid of ogres, it seems, saw a stump in the dark in an unfamiliar place at night,🔽and he fled in terror, thinking it was an ogre.

original: tālakkhandhaṃ disvā pisācasaññāya bhīto uttasanto mucchito papati, taṃ sandhāya vuttaṃ
analyzed: tāla kkhandham disvā pisāca saññāya bhītaḥ uttasantaḥ mucchitaḥ papati tam sandhāya vuttam
translated: On seeing the palm-tree trunk he was frightened and terrified and fell down in a faint. That is what is meant by “he sees danger in it.”

original: “sūkarā…pe… veditabbā”ti.
analyzed: veditabbā ati
translated: “The pigs … should be understood” .

original: 276. Evanti yathāvuttaṃ opammatthaṃ nigamento āha. Soti yogāvacaro. Tasmiṃ jhāne
analyzed: evam ti yathāvuttam opamma attham nigamentaḥ āha saḥ ti yogāvacaraḥ tasmim jhāne
translated: Thus: he said this in order to conclude the meaning of the simile as stated. He: the meditator.

original: ādīnavaṃ passatīti sambandho. Rūpanti kasiṇarūpaṃ. Santavimokkhatoti arūpajjhānato.
analyzed: ādīnavam passati iti sambandhaḥ rūpanti kasiṇa rūpam santa vimokkhato ti arūpa jhānato
translated: In that jhāna: the phrasing is “he sees danger in it.” Materiality: the kasiṇa materiality.🔽In the peaceful deliverances: from the immaterial jhānas.

original: Tāni hi “ye te santā vimokkhā atikkamma rūpe āruppā”tiādīsu santavimokkhāti āgatā.🔽Santatāsiddhi cassa anussutito daṭṭhabbā. Yathevāti eva-kārena yena pakārena etaṃ🔽rūpāvacaracatutthajjhānaṃ duvaṅgikaṃ, evaṃ āruppānipīti upekkhācittekaggatāvasena
analyzed: tāni hi ye te santā vimokkhā atikkamma rūpe āruppa ati ādīsu santa vimokkhā ati āgatā  santa tā siddhi ca ssa anussutitaḥ daṭṭhabbā yathā iva ati evakārena yena pakārena etam  rūpāvacara catuttha jjhānam duvaṅgikam evam upekkhā citta ekagga tā vasena
translated: For these are called “peaceful deliverances” in such passages as “Those peaceful deliverances that transcend the material form element and are formless” .🔽And their peacefulness should be regarded as due to their being free from defilements.🔽As: the word eva shows the mode in which the fourth jhāna of the fine-material sphere has two factors, and so does the immaterial state.

original: duvaṅgikattaṃ dasseti, na tatiyajjhāne viya duvaṅgikatāmattaṃ. Nanu cetthāpi duvaṅgikatāmattameva
analyzed: duvaṅgika ttam dasseti na tatiya jhāne viya duvaṅgika tā mattam nanu ca itthā api duvaṅgika tā mattam eva
translated: He shows that it has two factors in the way that the fourth jhāna has, that is, by equanimity and unification of mind, not that it has only two factors, as the third jhāna has.🔽But has it not only two factors, too, in the way that the third jhāna has?

original: bhūmibhedatoti? Nāyaṃ doso upamopameyyabhāvassa bhinnādhikaraṇato.
analyzed: bhūmi bhedataḥ ti na ayam dosaḥ upamā upameyya bhāvassa bhinna adhikaraṇato
translated: This is not a defect, because the state of being simile and that of being object are different.

original: Tatthāti tasmiṃ rūpāvacaracatutthajjhāne. Nikantinti apekkhaṃ. Pariyādāyāti ādīnavadassanena
analyzed: tattha āti tasmim rūpāvacara catuttha jhāne apekkham pariyādāya ati ādīnava dassanena
translated: ‘Therein’: in that fourth jhāna of the fine-material sphere. ‘No longer concern himself’: no longer have any interest.

original: tasmiṃ jhāne khepetvā, anapekkho hutvāti attho. Santato manasikaraṇeneva paṇītato,
analyzed: tasmin jhāne khepetvā anapekkhaḥ hutvā iti attho santataḥ manasikaraṇena iva paṇītataḥ
translated: Herein, in that fine-material fourth jhāna. Without concern: without looking for. Having brought it to its culmination: having brought it to the end of the plane of the fourth jhāna by seeing its danger and abandoning it. Without looking for it: without being concerned with it. By giving attention to it as peaceful and sublime, attention to it as superior and choice is accomplished.

original: sukhumato ca manasikāro siddho hotīti āha “santato anantato manasi karitvā”ti. Pattharitvāti🔽pageva vaḍḍhitaṃ, tadā vaḍḍhanavasena vā pattharitvā. Tenāti kasiṇarūpena. Ugghāṭeti
analyzed: sukhumataḥ ca manasikāraḥ siddhaḥ hoti iti āha santataḥ anantataḥ manasi karitvā ati pattharitvā ati  pagā iva vaḍḍhitam tadā vaḍḍhana vasena vā pattharitvā tena ati kasiṇa rūpena ugghāṭeti
translated: So he said, “having given attention to it as peaceful and sublime, as sublime and peaceful,” and “having given attention to it as endless and boundless.”

original: kasiṇanti rūpāvacaracatutthajjhānassa ārammaṇabhūtaṃ pathavīkasiṇādikasiṇarūpaṃ apaneti.
analyzed: rūpāvacara catuttha jhānassa ārammaṇa bhūtam pathavī kasiṇa ādi kasiṇa rūpam apaneti
translated: Having extended it: having extended it by increasing it still further, or having extended it by making it the object of extension. By that: by the kasiṇa materiality. He obliterates: he removes the kasiṇa materiality, which is the object of the fine-material fourth jhāna.🔽But showing the method of obliteration he said, “When he obliterates it, he does so by not giving attention to it” .

original: Ugghāṭanavidhiṃ pana dassento “ugghāṭento hī”tiādimāha. Tattha saṃvelletīti paṭisaṃharati.
analyzed: ugghāṭana vidhim pana dassentaḥ ugghāṭentaḥ hi iti ādim āha tattha saṃvelleti iti paṭisaṃharati
translated: Herein, he contracts it means he gathers it in.

original: Aññadatthūti ekaṃsena. Neva ubbaṭṭatīti neva uṭṭhahati. Na vivaṭṭatīti na vinivaṭṭati.
analyzed: ekaṃsena na iva ubbaṭṭati iti na iva uṭṭhahati na vivaṭṭati iti na vinivaṭṭati
translated: To another purpose: to a different purpose. It does not occur to him means it does not arise. It does not occur to him that it is dispersed means it does not occur to him that it is dispersed.

original: Imassāti imassa kasiṇarūpassa. Amanasikāranti manasi akaraṇaṃ acintanaṃ. Manasikārañca🔽paṭiccāti “ākāso ākāso”ti bhāvanāmanasikārañca nissāya. Idaṃ vuttaṃ hoti – rūpāvacaracatutthajjhānassa🔽ārammaṇabhūtaṃ kasiṇarūpaṃ na sabbena sabbaṃ manasi karoto, tena ca phuṭṭhokāsaṃ
analyzed: imassa ati imassa kasiṇa rūpassa amanasikāram ti manasi akaraṇam acintanam manasikāram ca  paṭicca ati ākāsaḥ ākāsaḥ ti bhāvanā manasikāram ca nissāya idam vuttam hoti rūpāvacara catuttha jhānassa  ārammaṇa bhūtam kasiṇa rūpam na sabbena sabbam manasi karoto tena ca phuṭṭha ukāsam
translated: ‘Of that’: of that kasiṇa materiality. ‘Non-attention’: non-giving attention, non-reflection. ‘With attention’:

original: “ākāso ākāso”ti manasi karoto yadā taṃ bhāvanānubhāvena ākāsaṃ hutvā upaṭṭhāti, tadā🔽so kasiṇaṃ ugghāṭeti nāma, tañca tena ugghāṭitaṃ nāma hotīti. Tenāha “kasiṇugghāṭimākāsamattaṃ
analyzed: ākāsaḥ ākāsaḥ iti manasi karotaḥ yadā tam bhāvanā anubhāvena ākāsam hutvā upaṭṭhāti tadā  saḥ kasiṇam ugghāṭa iti nāma tat ca tena ugghāṭitam nāma hoti iti tena āha kasiṇugghāṭim ākāsa mattam
translated: with attention to the development of the kasiṇa, which is called ‘space, space’. This is what is meant: when he does not give attention to the kasiṇa materiality that is the object of the fourth jhāna of the fine-material sphere, and he does not give attention to the space pervaded by it, but instead gives attention to the space that remains unpervaded by it as ‘space, space,’ then when that appears to him as space through the influence of the development,

original: paññāyatī”ti. Sabbametanti tividhampetaṃ ekameva pariyāyabhāvato.🔽“Nīvaraṇāni vikkhambhantī”ti kasmā vuttaṃ? Nanu rūpāvacarapaṭhamajjhānassa upacārakkhaṇeyeva
analyzed: paññāyati iti sabbam etat ti tividham petam ekam eva pariyāya bhāvato  nīvaraṇāni vikkhambhanti iti kasmai vuttam nanu rūpāvacara paṭhama jhānassa upacāra kkhaṇe yeva
translated: then he is said to have ‘removed the kasiṇa’ and that kasiṇa is said to have been ‘removed by him.’ Therefore it is said: ‘The mere space left by the removal of the kasiṇa is evident.’ ‘All this’: this is threefold, but it is the same in being a mere mode of expression.

original: nīvaraṇāni vikkhambhitāni, tato paṭṭhāya cassa na nesaṃ pariyuṭṭhānaṃ. Yadi siyā,
analyzed: nīvaraṇāni vikkhambhitāni tatas paṭṭhāya ca ssa na nesam pariyuṭṭhānam yadi siyā
translated: Why is it said, ‘The hindrances are suppressed’ ? Are not the hindrances already suppressed at the moment of access to the first jhāna of the fine-material sphere, and is not their suppression reaffirmed in the attainment of each jhāna? If so,

original: jhānato parihāyeyya? Yaṃ paneke vadanti “attheva sukhumāni arūpajjhānavikkhambhaneyyāni🔽nīvaraṇāni, tāni sandhāyetaṃ vutta”nti, taṃ tesaṃ matimattaṃ. Na hi mahaggatakusalesu
analyzed: jhānataḥ parihāyeyya yam pana eke vadanti attha iva sukhumāni a rūpa jhāna vikkhambhaneyyāni  nīvaraṇāni tāni sandhāya itam vuttanti tam tesam matimattam na hi mahaggata kusalesu
translated: Would he fall away from jhāna?

original: lokuttarakusalesu viya odhiso pahānaṃ nāma atthi. Yo pana rūpāvacarehi āruppānaṃ
analyzed: lokuttara kusalesu viya odhiso pahānam nāma atthi yaḥ pana rūpāvacarehi
translated: But what some say, namely, “The hindrances are subtle in the immaterial sphere and are suppressed only by the jhānas,” is mere opinion. For there is no suppression of hindrances by choice, as there is of unprofitable things by the profitable, and of the defilements by the supramundane, in the immaterial sphere as there is in the fine-material sphere.

original: uḷāraphalatādiviseso, so bhāvanāvisesena santatarapaṇītatarabhāvena tesuyeva purimapurimehi
analyzed: uḷāra phala tā ādi visesaḥ saḥ bhāvanā visesena santatara paṇītatara bhāvena purima purimehi
translated: But the difference in the degree of grossness of the immaterial jhānas is due to the difference in the degree of subtlety of the defilements suppressed, and to the difference in the degree of remoteness of the jhāna factors from the proximity of the hindrances.

original: pacchimapacchimānaṃ viyāti daṭṭhabbaṃ. “Vikkhambhantī”ti pana vacanaṃ vaṇṇabhaṇanavasena
analyzed: pacchima pacchimānam viyā ti daṭṭhabbam vikkhambhanti iti pana vacanam vaṇṇa bhaṇana vasena
translated: And the words “suppresses” should be understood as said with reference to the jhāna factors, which are called “suppressors” because they suppress defilements and because they suppress the hindrances.🔽For it is said in the Paṭisambhidā: “What is the jhāna factor of sustained thought? It is any wise man’s or man’s sustained thought, reflection, reviewing, associated with the jhāna that has arisen, which is steadying, steadying of consciousness, fixing, unification, single-functionality of consciousness and its concomitants” .

original: vuttaṃ. Tathā hi aññatthāpi heṭṭhā pahīnānaṃ upari pahānaṃ vuccati. Ye pana “sabbe🔽kusalā dhammā sabbesaṃ akusalānaṃ paṭipakkhāti katvā evaṃ vutta”nti vadanti, tehi🔽dutiyajjhānūpacārādīsu nīvaraṇavikkhambhanāvacanassa kāraṇaṃ vattabbaṃ. Sati santiṭṭhatīti
analyzed: vuttam tathā hi aññattha api heṭṭhā pahīnānam upari pahānam vuccati ye pana sabbe 🔽kusalāḥ dhammā sabbesam akusalānam paṭipakkhā ti katvā evam vuttan ti vadanti tehi 🔽dutiya jhānu upacāra ādīsu nīvaraṇa vikkhambhanā vacanassa kāraṇam vattabbam sati santiṭṭhati iti
translated: And the words “it is any wise man’s or man’s” are said in order to show that the jhāna factors are not only four in number, but there are also others.

original: ākāsanimittārammaṇā sati sammā sūpaṭṭhitā hutvā tiṭṭhati. Satisīsena cettha upacārajjhānānuguṇānaṃ
analyzed: ākāsa nimitta ārammaṇā sati sammā su upaṭṭhitā hutvā tiṭṭhati sati sīsena ca ittha
translated: And mindfulness, which has the sign of space as its object, stands guard well established.

original: saddhāpañcamānaṃ sakiccayogaṃ dasseti. Upacārenāti upacārajjhānena. Idhāpīti rūpāvacaracatutthajjhānaṃ
analyzed: saddhā pañcamānam sa kicca yogam dasseti upacārena ati upacāra jhānena idha api iti rūpāvacara catuttha jjhānam
translated: Herein, the word “mindfulness” shows the working of faith, etc., which are five in number and are in conformity with access concentration.🔽“By access”: by access concentration. “Here too”: this is said referring to the fourth jhāna of the fine-material sphere.

original: sandhāya sampiṇḍanaṃ. Taṃ hi upekkhāvedanāsampayuttaṃ. Sesanti “sesāni kāmāvacarānī”tiādi.
analyzed: sandhāya sampiṇḍanam tat hi upekkhā vedanā sampayuttam sesanti sesāni kāmāvacarāni itiādi
translated: For that is associated with the feeling of equanimity. “The rest”: the rest are the kinds in the sense sphere.🔽What should be said here has been said in the description of the earth kasiṇa.

original: Yaṃ idha vattabbamavuttaṃ, taṃ pana pathavīkasiṇaniddese vuttanayānusārena veditabbanti🔽āha “pathavīkasiṇe vuttanayamevā”ti.
analyzed: yam idha vattabbam avuttam tam pana pathavīkasiṇa niddese vutta naya anusārena veditabban ti  āha pathavīkasiṇe vutta nayam eva ati
translated: That should be understood in the way given there.

original: Evaṃ yaṃ tattha avisiṭṭhaṃ, taṃ atidisitvā idāni visiṭṭhaṃ dassetuṃ “ayaṃ pana viseso”tiādimāha.🔽Yānapputoḷi kumbhimukhādīnanti oguṇṭhanasivikādiyānānaṃ mukhaṃ yānamukhaṃ, putoḷiyā
analyzed: evam yam tattha avisiṭṭham tam atidisitvā idāni visiṭṭham dassetum ayam pana visesaḥ ti ādim āha  yānapputoḷi mukham yāna mukham
translated: So after pointing out what is not stated there, he now said, “But there is this difference” in order to point out what is stated there.

original: khuddakadvārassa mukhaṃ putoḷimukhaṃ, kumbhimukhanti paccekaṃ mukha-saddo sambandhitabbo.
analyzed: khuddaka dvārassa mukham putoḷi mukham kumbhi mukham ti paccekam mukha saddo sambandhitabbo
translated: The mouth of a carriage, etc.: the mouth of a carriage with a hood and curtains, etc., is the carriage mouth. The mouth of a small door is the putoḷi mouth. The mouth of a pot is the pot mouth. The word “mouth” should be construed with each of these.

original: Ākāsaṃyeva yānamukhādiparicchinnaṃ. Parikammamanasikārenāti parikammabhūtena manasikārena
analyzed: ākāsaṃyā iva yāna mukha ādi paricchinnam parikamma manasikārena ati parikamma bhūtena manasikārena
translated: The vehicle is the space delimited by the head-hairs, etc.,🔽By the attention given to the preliminary-work: by the attention given to the preliminary-work jhāna.

original: upacārajjhānena. Parikammaṃ anulomaṃ upacāroti ca anatthantarañhetaṃ. Pekkhamāno
analyzed: upacāra jhānena parikammam anulomam upacāro ti ca anatthantaram ha etam pekkhamāno
translated: The access jhāna is called “preliminary-work” and “approximation” too, because it is uninterrupted by defilements.🔽Looking:

original: arūpāvacarajjhānacakkhunā.
analyzed: arūpa avacara jhāna cakkhunā
translated: with the eye of the immaterial-sphere jhāna.

original: 277. Sabbākārenāti rūpanimittaṃ daṇḍādānasambhavadassanādinā sabbena rūpadhammesu,
analyzed: sabba ākārena ati rūpa nimittam daṇḍa ādāna sambhava dassana ādinā sabbena rūpa dhammesu
translated: In all aspects: in all aspects consisting of the seeing of the sign of materiality as a mere head-hairs, etc., as a mere object of revulsion, and so on.

original: pathavīkasiṇādirūpanimittesu, tadārammaṇajjhānesu ca dosadassanākārena, tesu eva🔽vā rūpādīsu nikantippahānaanāvajjitukāmatādinā. Rūpajjhānampi rūpanti vuccati uttarapadalopena
analyzed: pathavī kasiṇa ādi rūpa nimittesu tad ārammaṇa jhānesu ca dosa dassana ākārena tesu eva  vā rūpa ādīsu nikanti ppahāna anāvajjitukāma tā ādinā rūpa jjhānam pi rūpanti vuccati uttara pada lopena
translated: Or in all aspects consisting of the seeing of the faults in the materiality of the earth kasiṇa sign, etc., and in the jhāna that has that as its object, and of the desire to abandon attachment to them, and so on.🔽Materiality is called “materiality” in the sense of the prior term being dropped,

original: “rūpūpapattiyā maggaṃ bhāvetī”tiādīsu yathā rūpabhavo rūpaṃ. Rūpīti hi rūpajjhānalābhīti
analyzed: rūpa upapattiyā maggam bhāveti itiādīsu yathā rūpa bhavaḥ rūpam rūpī iti hi rūpa jjhāna lābhī iti
