translated: as in such passages as “He develops the path leading to reappearance in the material rūpabrahma-world” .

original: attho. Ārammaṇampi kasiṇarūpaṃ rūpanti vuccati purimapadalopena yathā “devadatto
analyzed: attho ārammaṇam pi kasiṇa rūpam rūpanti vuccati purima pada lopena yathā devadatto
translated: And the materiality of the kasiṇa is called “materiality” in the sense of the subsequent term being dropped, as in such passages as “The bhikkhu Devadatta

original: datto”ti. Rūpāni passatīti kasiṇarūpāni jhānacakkhunā passatīti attho. Tasmāti yasmā
analyzed: datto ti rūpāni passati iti kasiṇa rūpāni jhāna cakkhunā passati iti attho tasmā iti yasmā
translated: He sees visible objects: he sees the kasiṇa objects with the eye of jhāna. Therefore:

original: uttarapadalopena, purimapadalopena ca yathākkamaṃ rūpajjhānakasiṇarūpesu rūpavohāro🔽dissati, tasmā. Rūpe rūpajjhāne taṃsahagatā saññā rūpasaññā. Tadārammaṇassa cāti
analyzed: uttara pada lopena purima pada lopena ca yathākkamam rūpa jjhāna kasiṇa rūpesu rūpa vohāraḥ  dissati tasmā rūpe rūpa jjhāne tad sahagatā saññā rūpa saññā tad ārammaṇassa ca ati
translated: because the expression “visible objects” is found in the first and second ways of construing the compound,🔽“visible-object perception” is perception associated with the jhāna that has visible objects as its object. The word “also”🔽includes the jhāna itself, which is stated in the text as “perceptions of visible objects.”🔽The word “also” in the phrase “and the cessation of that” includes the jhāna stated in the text as “perceptions of visible objects.”

original: ca-saddena yathāvuttaṃ rūpāvacarajjhānaṃ sampiṇḍeti, tena pāḷiyaṃ “rūpasaññāna”nti🔽sarūpekasesena niddeso katoti dasseti. Virāgāti jigucchanato. Nirodhāti tappaṭibandhachandarāgavikkhambhanena
analyzed: ca saddena yathāvuttam rūpāvacara jhānam sampiṇḍeti tena pāḷiyam rūpa saññānam ti  sarūpa ikasesena niddeso kato ti dasseti virāgā ati jigucchanataḥ nirodhā ati tad paṭibandha chanda rāga vikkhambhanena
translated: The meaning is that the expression “perceptions of visible objects” is used in the text to include both the visible-object jhāna and its object, the kasiṇa as visible-object.🔽The words “dispassion” and “cessation” are stated in the text in the sense of the abandoning of the desire and lust for the jhāna and its object respectively.

original: nirodhanato. Vuttamevatthaṃ pākaṭataraṃ kātuṃ “kiṃ vuttaṃ hotī”tiādi vuttaṃ. Tassa
analyzed: nirodhanataḥ vuttam eva attham pākaṭataram kātum kim vuttam hoti itiādi vuttam tassa
translated: The words “What is said? ” and so on are stated to make the meaning clear.

original: sabbākārena virāgā anavasesānaṃ nirodhāti evaṃ vā ettha yojanā kātabbā.
analyzed: sabba ākārena virāgāḥ anavasesānam evam vā ettha yojanā kātabbā
translated: The construction should be made in this way: “dispassion for it in all ways, cessation without remainder.”

original: “Ārammaṇe avirattassa saññāsamatikkamo na hotī”ti idaṃ yasmā imāni jhānāni ārammaṇātikkamena
analyzed: ārammaṇe avirattassa saññā samatikkamaḥ na hoti iti idam yasmai imāni jhānāni ārammaṇa atikkamena
translated: “For one not dispassionate towards the object, there is no surmounting of perception” .

original: pattabbāni, na aṅgātikkamenāti katvā vuttaṃ. Yasmā panettha saññāsamatikkamo ārammaṇasamatikkamena
analyzed: pattabbāni na aṅga atikkamena ati katvā vuttam yasmā pana ittha saññā samatikkamaḥ ārammaṇa samatikkamena
translated: and not by a mere part. But since the surmounting of perception here is not without the surmounting of the object,🔽therefore he said: “When the perceptions have been surmounted, the object has been surmounted too.”

original: vinā na hoti, tasmā “samatikkantāsu ca saññāsu ārammaṇaṃ samatikkantameva hotī”ti
analyzed: vinā na hoti tasmā samatikkantāsu ca saññāsu ārammaṇam samatikkantam eva hoti iti
translated: The construction is: “without having surmounted.” In the passages beginning “When he has entered upon” ,

original: āha. Avatvā vuttoti sambandho. Samāpannassātiādīsu kusalasaññāvasena samāpannaggahaṇaṃ,
analyzed: āha a vatvā vuttaḥ iti sambandho samāpannassa ati ādīsu kusala saññā vasena samāpanna ggahaṇam
translated: the “entered upon” is said with profitable perception,

original: vipākasaññāvasena upapannaggahaṇaṃ, kiriyāsaññāvasena diṭṭhadhammasukhavihāraggahaṇaṃ.🔽Arahato hi jhānāni visesato diṭṭhadhammasukhavihāro. Yadi saññāsamatikkamassa anunipphādiārammaṇasamatikkamo
analyzed: vipāka saññā vasena upapanna ggahaṇam kiriyā saññā vasena diṭṭhadhamma sukha vihāra ggahaṇam  arahataḥ hi jhānāni visesataḥ diṭṭhadhamma sukha vihāraḥ yadi saññā samatikkamassa anunipphādi ārammaṇa samatikkamaḥ
translated: the “arisen” with resultant perception, and the “pleasant abiding here and now” with functional perception.🔽For the jhānas are a “pleasant abiding here and now” in a special sense for an Arahant.🔽If the surmounting of the object is not stated in the Vibhaṅga along with the surmounting of perception,

original: vibhaṅge ca avutto, atha kasmā idha gahitoti anuyogaṃ sandhāyāha “yasmā panā”tiādi.🔽Ārammaṇasamatikkamavasenāpi ayamatthavaṇṇanā katā, “tadārammaṇassa cetaṃ adhivacana”ntiādinā
analyzed: vibhaṅge ca a vuttaḥ atha kasmai idha gahitaḥ iti anuyogam sandhāya āha yasmai  ārammaṇa samatikkama vasena api ayam attha vaṇṇanā katā tad ārammaṇassa ca itam adhivacanam ti ādinā
translated: why is it included here? The intention in asking this question is as follows.🔽The explanation of the meaning is given also as the surmounting of the object,

original: vibhaṅge viya saññāsamatikkamameva avatvāti adhippāyo.
analyzed: vibhaṅge viya saññā samatikkamam eva avatvā ati adhippāyaḥ
translated: and the Vibhaṅga passage beginning, “That is a term for the object” is intended to show that the surmounting of the object is not stated there as it is here.

original: 278. Paṭighātenāti paṭihananena visayīvisayasamodhānena. Atthaṅgamātiādīsu purimaṃ
analyzed: paṭighātena ati paṭihananena visayī visaya samodhānena atthaṅgamā ati ādīsu purimam
translated: By the impact: by the impact of the object and the sense base coming together. The meaning of the rest is as follows:

original: purimaṃ pacchimassa pacchimassa atthavacanaṃ, tasmā paṭighasaññānaṃ atthaṅgamo jhānasamaṅgikāle
analyzed: purimam pacchimassa pacchimassa attha vacanam tasmā paṭigha saññānam atthaṅgamaḥ jhāna samaṅgi kāle
translated: The disappearance of perceptions of resistance is the non-arising of perceptions of resistance at the time of possessing jhāna.

original: anuppattīti tassa idheva gahaṇe kāraṇaṃ anuyogamukhena dassetuṃ “kāmañcetā”tiādi
analyzed: anuppatti iti tassa idha iva gahaṇe kāraṇam anuyoga mukhena dassetum kāmañcetā atiādi
translated: The reason for taking it here is shown by the question and answer beginning with “Why is that? ”🔽The purpose of the question and answer is to encourage those who are practising the way.

original: vuttaṃ. Ussāhajananatthaṃ paṭipajjanakānaṃ. Etāsaṃ paṭighasaññānaṃ. Ettha paṭhamāruppakathāyaṃ.
analyzed: vuttam ussāha janana attham paṭipad janakānam etāsam paṭigha saññānam ettha paṭhama āruppa kathāyam
translated: The disappearance of perceptions of resistance is the non-arising of perceptions of resistance here.

original: Vacanaṃ atthaṅgamavasena.
analyzed: vacanam atthaṅgama vasena
translated: The answer is given in terms of disappearance.

original: Kiṃ vā pasaṃsākittanena, paṭighasaññānaṃ pana atthaṅgamo idheva vattabbattā vuttoti
analyzed: kim vā pasaṃsā kittanena paṭigha saññānam pana atthaṅgamaḥ idhā iva vattabbattā vutto ti
translated: Or what is the use of praising it? The disappearance of perceptions of resistance should be mentioned here, so it is said “Or alternatively” in order to show it.

original: dassetuṃ “atha vā”tiādi vuttaṃ. Tattha sabhāvadhammassa abhāvo nāma paṭipakkhena
analyzed: dassetum atha vā tiādi vuttam tattha sabhāva dhammassa abhāvaḥ nāma paṭipakkhena
translated: Herein, the non-existence of a naturally existent state is called “disappearance” either because of abandonment by its opposite or because of the absence of conditions.

original: pahīnatāya vā paccayābhāvena vā. Tesu rūpajjhānasamaṅgino paṭighasaññānaṃ abhāvo
analyzed: pahīna tāya vā paccaya abhāvena vā tesu rūpa jjhāna samaṅgino paṭigha saññānam abhāvo
translated: The non-existence of perceptions of resistance in one who possesses the fine-material sphere jhāna is called “disappearance” because of abandonment by its opposite.

original: paccayābhāvamattena, na paṭipakkhādhigamenāti dassento āha “kiñcāpī”tiādi. Tattha
analyzed: paccaya abhāva mattena na paṭipakkha adhigamena ati dassentaḥ āha kiñcā api itiādi tattha
translated: He shows that it is not by mere absence of conditions but by the attainment of the opposite that the perception of resistance is abandoned.

original: tāti paṭighasaññā. Rūpāvacaranti rūpāvacarajjhānaṃ. Samāpannassāti samāpajjitvā viharantassa.
analyzed: tā ati paṭigha saññāḥ rūpāvacaranti rūpāvacara jhānam samāpannassa ati samāpajjitvā viharantassa
translated: “Tā” is the perception of resistance. “Rūpāvacarā” is the fine-material-sphere jhāna. “Samāpannassa” is of one who has attained and is living in it.

original: Kiñcāpi na santīti yojanā. Na pahīnattā na santīti na tadā paṭighasaññā pahīnabhāvena
analyzed: kiñca api na santi iti yojanā na pahīna ttā na santi iti na tadā paṭigha saññā pahīna bhāvena
translated: The construction is: “Although they are not absent.” They are not absent because they have not been abandoned.

original: na santi nāma. Tattha kāraṇamāha “na hi rūpavirāgāya rūpāvacarabhāvanā saṃvattatī”ti.
analyzed: na santi nāma tattha kāraṇam āha na hi rūpa virāgāya rūpāvacara bhāvanā saṃvattati iti
translated: At that time the perception of resistance is not absent in the sense that it has been abandoned. The reason is given: “for the development of the fine-material sphere does not lead to fading of lust for materiality.”

original: Nanu ca paṭighasaññāpi arūpadhammā evāti codanaṃ sandhāyāha “rūpāyattā ca etāsaṃ
analyzed: nanu ca paṭigha saññā api arūpa dhammā evā ti codanam sandhāya āha rūpa āyattā ca etāsam
translated: But is not the perception of resistance itself an immaterial state? Anticipating this objection, he says, “and their occurrence is dependent on materiality.”

original: pavattī”ti. Ayaṃ pana bhāvanāti arūpabhāvanamāha. Dhāretunti avadhāretuṃ. Idhāti🔽arūpajjhāne. Āneñjābhisaṅkhāravacanādīhi āneñjatā. “Ye te santā vimokkhā atikkamma
analyzed: pavatti iti ayam pana bhāvanā ati arūpa bhāvanam āha avadhāretum idha ati  arūpa jhāne āneñja abhisaṅkhāra vacana ādīhi āneñja tā ye te santā vimokkhāḥ atikkamma
translated: “This development” is the immaterial development. “To retain” is to hold. “Here” is in the immaterial jhānas.

original: rūpe āruppā”tiādinā santavimokkhatā ca vuttā.
analyzed: rūpe āruppa ati ādinā santa vimokkha tā ca vuttā
translated: The state of imperturbability is stated by the words “the imperturbable,” etc., and the state of being a peaceful deliverance by the words “the peaceful deliverances that transcend the material” , etc.

original: 279. Dosadassanapubbakapaṭipakkhabhāvanāvasena paṭighasaññānaṃ suppahīnattā mahatāpi🔽saddena arūpasamāpattito na vuṭṭhāti. Tathā pana na suppahīnattā sabbarūpāvacarasamāpattito🔽vuṭṭhānaṃ siyā, paṭhamajjhānaṃ pana appakampi saddaṃ na sahatīti taṃ samāpannassa
analyzed: dosa dassana pubbaka paṭipakkha bhāvanā vasena paṭigha saññānam su pahīna ttā mahatā api  saddena arūpa samāpattitaḥ na vuṭṭhāti tathā pana na su pahīna ttā sabba rūpāvacara samāpattito  vuṭṭhānam siyā paṭhamajjhānam pana appakampi saddam na sahati iti tam samāpannassa
translated: Because of the complete abandoning of perceptions of resistance by the development of the opposite, which is the seeing of ill will, he does not emerge from the immaterial states even though there is a great sound. But because of the incomplete abandoning of that he may emerge from all the fine-material states. But the first jhāna does not endure even a slight sound. So when he has attained that,🔽

original: saddo kaṇṭakoti vuttaṃ. Āruppabhāvanāya abhāve cutito uddhaṃ uppattirahānaṃ rūpasaññāpaṭighasaññānaṃ🔽yāva attano vipākappavatti, tāva anuppattidhammatāpādanena samatikkamo, atthaṅgamo🔽ca vutto. Nānattasaññāsu pana yā tasmiṃ bhave na uppajjanti ekantarūpanissitā, tā
analyzed: saddo kaṇṭako ti vuttam āruppa bhāvanāya abhāve cutitaḥ uddham uppatti rahānam rūpa saññā paṭigha saññānam  yāva attanaḥ vipāka ppavatti tāva anuppatti dhamma tā āpādanena samatikkamaḥ atthaṅgamo  ca vuttaḥ nānatta saññāsu pana yā tasmin bhave na uppajjanti ekanta rūpa nissitā tā
translated: Since perceptions of resistance have been well suppressed by the development of the opposite qualities beginning with the seeing of hate, he does not emerge from the immaterial states even though there is a great deal of sound. But since they have not been well suppressed in the fine-material sphere, emergence from the fine-material jhānas may occur. However, the first jhāna does not tolerate even a little sound, so it is said that sound is an obstruction to it. The surmounting of material and resistant signs and their non-occurrence is stated in the case of the immaterial states by the non-arising of material and resistant signs after death until the exhaustion of their life span, which is effected by the non-arising of materiality due to the non-existence of the development of the immaterial states.

original: anokāsatāya na uppajjanti, na āruppabhāvanāya nivāritattā, anivāritattā ca kāci uppajjanti.
analyzed: anokāsa tāya na uppajjanti na āruppa bhāvanāya nivārita ttā a nivārita ttā ca kāci uppajjanti
translated: As to the diversity of perceptions, those that do not occur in that becoming do not do so because there is no opportunity for them, not because of suppression by the immaterial states. And those that do occur do so because there is opportunity for them, not because of non-suppression.

original: Tasmā tāsaṃ amanasikāro anāvajjanaṃ apaccavekkhaṇaṃ, javanapaṭipādakena vā bhavaṅgamanassa
analyzed: tasmā tāsam a manasikāraḥ an āvajjanam a paccavekkhaṇam javana paṭipādakena vā bhavaṅga manassa
translated: Therefore non-attention to them is non-repetition, non-reviewing, or the life-continuum consciousness that is the forerunner of impulsion.

original: anto akaraṇaṃ appavesanaṃ vuttaṃ.🔽Tena ca nānattasaññāmanasikārahetūnaṃ rūpānaṃ samatikkamā samādhissa thirabhāvaṃ🔽dassetuṃ “saṅkhepato”tiādi vuttaṃ. Apica imehi tīhi padehi ākāsānañcāyatanasamāpattiyā
analyzed: antar a karaṇam a pavesanam vuttam  tena ca nānatta saññā manasikāra hetūnam rūpānam samatikkamā samādhissa thira bhāvam  dassetum saṅkhepato tiādi vuttam api ca imehi tīhi padehi ākāsa ānañca āyatana samāpattiyā
translated: So the words “he does not give attention to them” mean that he does not advert to them, does not review them, does not give them attention by way of the impulsions,🔽does not give them a footing in the mind by way of the life-continuum.🔽And the words “in brief” are said to show that the concentration is firm because of the surmounting of the material dhammas that are the cause for the giving attention to the diversity of materiality.🔽Moreover, these three terms are said in order to arouse enthusiasm in listeners and to tempt them to attain the base consisting of boundless space.

original: vaṇṇo kathito sotūnaṃ ussāhajananatthaṃ, palobhanatthañca. Ye hi akusalā evaṃgāhino
analyzed: vaṇṇaḥ kathitaḥ sotūnam ussāha janana attham palobhana attham ca ye hi akusalāḥ evaṃgāhino
translated: For those who are unskilled in the way and misapprehend it, thinking,

original: “sabbassādarahite ākāse pavattitasaññāya ko ānisaṃso”ti, te tato micchāgāhato nivattetuṃ🔽tīhi padehi jhānassa ānisaṃso kathito. Taṃ hi sutvā tesaṃ evaṃ bhavissati “evaṃ santā
analyzed: sabbassāda rahite ākāse pavattita saññāya kaḥ ānisaṃso ti te tatas micchā gāhataḥ nivattetum  tīhi padehi jhānassa ānisaṃso kathito tam hi sutvā tesam evam bhavissati evam santā
translated: “What is the advantage of a perception occurring in space, which is devoid of all tastes?,”🔽the advantage of the jhāna is stated by the three terms in order to turn them away from that misapprehension.🔽For when they hear that, they will think, “So this attainment is of such profit;

original: kirāyaṃ samāpatti evaṃ paṇītā, handassā nibbattanatthaṃ ussāhaṃ karissāmī”ti.
analyzed: kira ayam samāpatti evam paṇītā handa assāḥ nibbattana attham ussāham karissāmi iti
translated: let us strive to reach it.”

original: 280. Assāti ākāsassa. Uppādo eva anto uppādanto, tathā vayanto. Sabhāvadhammo hi🔽ahutvā sambhavato, hutvā ca vinassanato udayavayaparicchinno. Ākāso pana asabhāvadhammattā
analyzed: assa ati ākāsassa uppādaḥ eva antaḥ uppādanto tathā vayanto sabhāva dhammo hi  a hutvā sambhavataḥ hutvā ca vinassanataḥ udaya vaya paricchinno ākāsaḥ pana a sabhāva dhamma ttā
translated: Space is the space element. Its arising is its appearance, and its disappearance is its disappearance. For what has the nature of an existing thing🔽is limited by arising and by disappearance, since it comes to be after not having been and having been, ceases. But space, having no such nature,

original: tadubhayābhāvato ananto vutto. Ajaṭākāsaparicchinnākāsānaṃ idha anadhippetattā “ākāsoti
analyzed: tad ubhaya abhāvataḥ anantaḥ vuttaḥ ajaṭa ākāsa paricchinna ākāsānam idha an adhippeta ttā ākāsaḥ ti
translated: is said to be infinite because it is devoid of both. Since the space delimited by an aperture in a wall, etc., is not intended here, he said “space” meaning

original: kasiṇugghāṭimākāso vuccatī”ti āha. Kasiṇaṃ ugghāṭīyati etenāti kasiṇugghāṭo, tadeva🔽kasiṇugghāṭimaṃ. Manasikāravasenāpīti rūpavivekamattaggahaṇena paricchedassa aggahaṇato
analyzed: kasiṇugghāṭim ākāsaḥ vuccati iti āha kasiṇam ugghāṭīyati etena ati kasiṇugghāṭaḥ tat eva  manasikāra vasena api iti rūpa viveka matta ggahaṇena paricchedassa a gahaṇato
translated: the kasiṇa that has space as its object. It is a “kasiṇa that has space as its object” because it is the object of a kasiṇa that has space as its object.

original: anantapharaṇākārena pavattaparikammamanasikāravasenāpi. Anantaṃ pharatīti aggahitaparicchedatāya🔽anantaṃ katvā parikammasamphassapubbakena jhānasamphassena phusati. Yathā bhisaggameva
analyzed: ananta pharaṇa ākārena pavatta parikamma manasikāra vasena api anantam pharati iti agga hita pariccheda tāya 🔽anantam katvā parikamma samphassa pubbakena jhāna samphassena phusati yathā bhisaggam eva
translated: Or it is a kasiṇa that has space as its object because it is the object of a kasiṇa. It is a “kasiṇa that has space as its object” because it is the object of a kasiṇa that has space as its object. It is a kasiṇa that has space as its object because it is the object of a kasiṇa. It is a kasiṇa that has space as its object because it is the object of a kasiṇa. It is a kasiṇa that has space as its object because it is the object of a kasiṇa. It is a kasiṇa that has space as its object because it is the object of a kasiṇa. It is a kasiṇa that has space as its object because it is the object of a kasiṇa. It is a kasiṇa that has space as its object because it is the object of a kasiṇa. It is a kasiṇa that has space as its object because it is the object of a kasiṇa. original: bhesajjaṃ, evaṃ ākāsānantameva ākāsānañcaṃ saṃyogaparassa ta-kārassa ca-kāraṃ katvā.🔽Jhānassa pavattiṭṭhānabhāvato ārammaṇaṃ adhiṭṭhānaṭṭhena “āyatanamassā”ti vuttaṃ,
analyzed: bhesajjam evam ākāsa anantam eva ākāsa anañcam saṃyoga parassa takārassa cakāram katvā  jhānassa pavatti ṭṭhāna bhāvataḥ ārammaṇam adhiṭṭhāna ṭṭhena āyatanam assa ati vuttam
translated: and the medicine, thus the base consisting of boundless space is so called by the substitution of the letter ca for the letter ta in the last syllable of the word parasaṃyoga.🔽The object is called its “base” in the sense of foundation for the occurrence of the jhāna,

original: adhiṭṭhānaṭṭhe āyatana-saddassa dassanato. Kāraṇākarasañjātidesanivāsatthepi āyatana-saddo idha yujjateva.
analyzed: adhiṭṭhāna aṭṭhe āyatana saddassa dassanataḥ kāraṇa ākara sañja atidesa nivāsa atthe pi āyatana saddaḥ idha yujjatā iva
translated: and the word “base” is appropriate here in the sense of foundation for the reason that the word āyatana is used in the sense of foundation.

original: Viññāṇañcāyatanakathāvaṇṇanā
analyzed: viññāṇañcāyatana kathā vaṇṇanā
translated: The explanation of the base consisting of boundless consciousness

original: 281. Ciṇṇo carito paguṇikato āvajjanādilakkhaṇo vasībhāvo etenāti ciṇṇavasībhāvo,
analyzed: ciṇṇaḥ caritaḥ paguṇikataḥ āvajjana ādi lakkhaṇaḥ vasībhāvaḥ etena ati ciṇṇavasībhāvaḥ
translated: He has had his fill of, has practiced, has made much of, the state of mastery consisting in adverting, etc., thus he is one who has had his fill of mastery.🔽By him who has had his fill of mastery. Because it cannot be reached without surmounting perception of the fine-material sphere,

original: tena ciṇṇavasībhāvena. Rūpāvacarasaññaṃ anatikkamitvā anadhigantabbato, taṃsahagatasaññāmanasikārasamudācārassa
analyzed: tena ciṇṇavasībhāvena rūpāvacara saññam an atikkamitvā an adhigantabbataḥ tad sahagata saññā manasikāra samudācārassa
translated: and because the manifestation of the associated perception and attention is obstructed by the fact that it is included in the plane of non-percipient beings,

original: hānabhāgiyabhāvāvahato, taṃsamatikkameneva tadaññesaṃ samatikkamitabbānaṃ samatikkamasiddhito
analyzed: hāna bhāgiya bhāva avahataḥ tad samatikkamena iva tad aññesam samatikkamitabbānam samatikkama siddhito
translated: and because the surmounting of the others to be surmounted is effected by surmounting that,

original: ca vuttaṃ “āsannarūpāvacarajjhānapaccatthikā”ti. Vīthipaṭipannāya bhāvanāya uparūparivisesāvahabhāvato,
analyzed: ca vuttam āsanna rūpāvacara jhāna paccatthikā ati vīthi paṭipannāya bhāvanāya
translated: it is said that “it has the fine-material jhāna as its near enemy” because it is threatened by the occurrence of the successively higher kinds of fine-material jhāna.

original: paṇītabhāvasiddhito ca paṭhamāruppato dutiyāruppaṃ santatarasabhāvanti āha “no ca
analyzed: paṇīta bhāva siddhitaḥ ca paṭhama āruppataḥ dutiya āruppam āha no ca
translated: and because of the establishment of the state of excellence, the second jhāna is more peaceful than the first, in other words, it is more tranquil in its way of being developed. Hence it is said: “not-rough-and-ready” .🔽🔽

original: viññāṇañcāyatanamiva santā”ti vakkhati hi “suppaṇītatarā honti, pacchimā pacchimā
analyzed: viññāṇam ca āyatanam iva vakkhati hi suppaṇītatarāḥ honti pacchimā pacchimā
translated: And because the second jhāna is more tranquil in its nature than the first, it is said that it is “not as though peaceful” . For it is said: “The later are more and more refined, The later than the earlier here” .

original: idhā”ti. Anantaṃ anantanti kevalaṃ “anantaṃ ananta”nti na manasi kātabbaṃ na bhāvetabbaṃ,
analyzed: idha ati anantam anantam iti kevalam anantam anantam iti na manasi kātabbam na bhāvetabbam
translated: “Endless, endless”: only “endless, endless” should not be given attention and developed;

original: “anantaṃ viññāṇaṃ, anantaṃ viññāṇa”nti pana manasi kātabbaṃ, “viññāṇaṃ viññāṇa”nti vā.
analyzed: anantam viññāṇam anantam viññāṇanti pana manasi kātabbam viññāṇam viññāṇanti vā
translated: but “endless consciousness, endless consciousness” should be given attention, or “consciousness, consciousness.”🔽“In that sign”: in the sign of consciousness consisting in the first immaterial jhāna.

original: Tasmiṃ nimitteti tasmiṃ paṭhamāruppaviññāṇasaṅkhāte viññāṇanimitte. Cittaṃ cārentassāti
analyzed: tasmim nimitta iti tasmim paṭhama āruppa viññāṇa saṅkhāte viññāṇa nimitte cittam cārentassa ati
translated: “Directing the mind”: giving attention to the sign of the second jhāna.

original: bhāvanācittaṃ pavattentassa. Ākāsaphuṭe viññāṇeti kasiṇugghāṭimākāsaṃ pharitvā pavatte🔽paṭhamāruppaviññāṇe ārammaṇabhūte. Appetīti appanāvasena pavattati. Sabhāvadhammepi
analyzed: bhāvanā cittam pavattentassa ākāsa phuṭe viññāṇe iti kasiṇugghāṭim ākāsam pharitvā pavatte  paṭhama āruppa viññāṇe ārammaṇa bhūte appeti iti appanā vasena pavattati sa bhāva dhamme pi
translated: “Spreading consciousness over the space”: in the consciousness consisting in the first immaterial jhāna that occurs spreading over the space that has displaced the kasiṇa.🔽“It occurs with the word ‘endless’”: it occurs with the word “endless” in the sense of “endless, endless.”

original: ārammaṇasamatikkamabhāvanābhāvato idaṃ appanāppattaṃ hoti catutthāruppaṃ viya. Appanānayo
analyzed: ārammaṇa samatikkama bhāvanā bhāvataḥ idam appanā appattam hoti catuttha āruppam viya appanā anayo
translated: “In the natural state too”: because there is no development of surmounting the object, this fourth immaterial state is reached by absorption in the natural state, as is the fourth jhāna.

original: panettha vuttanayenevāti ettha dutiyāruppajjhāne purimabhāge tīṇi, cattāri vā javanāni
analyzed: pana ittha vutta nayena iva āti ettha dutiya āruppa jhāne purima bhāge tīṇi cattāri vā javanāni
translated: Herein, in the way stated is as follows. In the first part of the second immaterial jhāna there are three or four impulsions,🔽which are of the sense sphere and are accompanied by equanimous feeling.

original: kāmāvacarāni upekkhāvedanāsampayuttāneva honti. “Catutthaṃ pañcamaṃ vā arūpāvacara”ntiādinā
analyzed: kāmāvacarāni upekkhā vedanā sampayuttāna iva honti catuttham pañcamam vā arūpa avacara nti ādinā
translated: The fourth or the fifth is of the immaterial sphere,

original: paṭhamāruppajjhāne vuttena nayena, atha vā appanānayoti sabhāvadhammepi ārammaṇe
analyzed: paṭhama āruppa jhāne vuttena nayena atha vā appanā nayo ti sa bhāva dhamme pi ārammaṇe
translated: in the way stated in the case of the first immaterial jhāna. Or alternatively, the method of attaining jhāna in the case of the jhāna that has a real dhammā as its object is the same as that of attaining jhāna in the case of the jhāna that has a concept as its object.

original: jhānassa appanānayo ārammaṇātikkamabhāvanāvasena āruppaṃ appanaṃ pāpuṇāti, “appanāppattasseva
analyzed: jhānassa appanā anayaḥ ārammaṇa atikkama bhāvanā vasena āruppam appanam pāpuṇāti appanā appattassa iva
translated: The attainment of jhāna in the immaterial states is reached by the development of the jhāna that surmounts the concept of the kasiṇa by the method of “non-attention to that” .

original: hi jhānassa ārammaṇasamatikkamanamattaṃ tattha hotī”ti maraṇānussatiniddese vuttanayena veditabboti attho.
analyzed: hi jhānassa ārammaṇa samatikkamana mattam tattha hoti iti maraṇānussatiniddese vutta nayena veditabbaḥ iti attho
translated: The meaning is that it should be understood in the way stated in the description of the recollection of death .

original: 282. Sabbasoti sabbākārena paṭhamāruppe “āsannarūpajjhānapaccatthikatā, asantasabhāvatā”ti
analyzed: sabbaso ti sabba ākārena paṭhama āruppe āsanna rūpa jjhāna paccatthika tā asanta sabhāva tā ati
translated: In every way: in all aspects. In the first immaterial jhāna the faults are seen in the concept of the fine-material sphere in the way stated thus: “The fine-material sphere is near to this jhāna, and it is inferior to it” , and so on.

original: evamādinā sabbena dosadassanākārena, tattha vā nikantipahānaanāvajjitukāmatādiākārena,
analyzed: evamādinā sabbena dosa dassana ākārena tattha vā nikanti pahāna anāvajjitukāma tā ādi ākārena
translated: Or alternatively, the abandoning of attachment to that jhāna, the desire to advert to it, and so on, are all seen as faults in it in every way.

original: sabbaṃ vā kusalavipākakiriyābhedato anavasesanti attho. Svāyamattho heṭṭhā vuttanayena
analyzed: sabbam vā kusala vipāka kiriyā bhedataḥ anavasesanti attho svāyamattho heṭṭhā vutta nayena
translated: Or else the meaning is that it is all without exception, since it is classified as profitable, resultant, and functional.🔽This meaning can be known in the way already stated below,

original: ñātuṃ sakkāti āha “sabbasoti idaṃ vuttanayamevā”ti. Jhānassa ākāsānañcāyatanatā bāhiratthasamāsavasena🔽heṭṭhā vuttāti āha “pubbe vuttanayena jhānampi ākāsānañcāyatana”nti. Ārammaṇassa
analyzed: ñātum sakkā iti āha sabbaso ti idam vutta nayam eva ati jhānassa ākāsa anañca āyatana tā bāhirattha samāsa vasena  heṭṭhā vuttā ti āha pubbe vutta nayena jhānam pi ākāsa ānañca āyatanan ti ārammaṇassa
translated: so it is said, “The word all is as already stated” .🔽The base of the infinity of space is the jhāna’s “base” in the sense of external sphere,🔽so it is said, “The jhāna is the base of the infinity of space in the way already stated” .🔽But the object is the base in the sense of the object of the jhāna.

original: pana samānādhikaraṇasamāsavasenāti sandassetuṃ “ārammaṇampī”tiādi vuttaṃ. Tattha
analyzed: pana samāna adhikaraṇa samāsa vasena ati sandassetum ārammaṇam pi itiādi vuttam tattha
translated: To illustrate this, “The object too” is said.

original: “purimanayenevā”ti idaṃ “nāssa anto”tiādinā vuttapadasiddhiṃ sandhāya vuttaṃ. Yathā
analyzed: purima nayena iva iti idam vutta pada siddhim sandhāya vuttam yathā
translated: Herein, “in the way already stated” is said with reference to the establishment of the words beginning with “There is no near or far in it” .

original: adhiṭṭhānaṭṭhena, evaṃ sañjātidesaṭṭhenapi āyatana-saddena idha attho yujjatīti dassetuṃ
analyzed: adhiṭṭhāna ṭṭhena evam sañjā atidesa ṭṭhena api āyatana saddena idha atthaḥ yujjati iti dassetum
translated: Just as it is in the sense of resolving, so it is also in the sense of the place of rebirth that the word “base” is applicable here.🔽To point this out, “Likewise” is said.

original: “tathā”tiādi vuttaṃ. Tattha sañjāyati etthāti sañjāti, sañjāti eva deso sañjātideso.
analyzed: tathā tiādi vuttam tattha sañjāyati ettha ati sañjāti sañjāti eva desaḥ sañjātideso
translated: Herein, it is born here, thus it is rebirth ; the place is the place of rebirth.

original: Jhānaṃ appavattikaraṇena. Ārammaṇaṃ amanasikaraṇena. Ubhayampi vā ubhayatā yojetabbā.
analyzed: jhānam appavatti karaṇena ārammaṇam amanasikaraṇena ubhayam pi vā ubhaya tā yojetabbā
translated: By preventing the occurrence of the jhāna. By not giving attention to the object. Or both can be construed with each of the two phrases.

original: Jhānassapi hi anāvajjanaṃ, javanapaṭipādakena vā bhavaṅgamanassa anto akaraṇaṃ amanasikaraṇaṃ,
analyzed: jhānassa api hi an āvajjanam javana paṭipādakena vā bhavaṅga manassa antaḥ akaraṇam amanasikaraṇam
translated: For the non- adverting of the jhāna, or the non-attention to it by the life-continuum consciousness that is the proximate cause of the impulsion, or the non- occurrence of the object by its not occurring as object, is the non-attention to it.

original: ārammaṇassa ca ārammaṇakaraṇavasena appavattanaṃ appavattikaraṇanti atthassa sambhavato🔽ekajjhaṃ katvā sāmaññaniddesena, ekasesanayena vā.
analyzed: ārammaṇassa ca ārammaṇa karaṇa vasena appavattanam appavatti karaṇanti atthassa sambhavato  ekajjham katvā sāmañña niddesena eka sesa nayena vā
translated: And the non-occurrence of the object by its not occurring as object is the non-occurrence of the object by its not occurring as object.

original: Pubbe anantassa ākāsassa ārammaṇakaraṇavasena paṭhamāruppaviññāṇaṃ attano pharaṇākāreneva
analyzed: pubbe anantassa ākāsassa ārammaṇa karaṇa vasena paṭhama āruppa viññāṇam attano pharaṇa ākārena iva
translated: So the meaning is construable in each case, and therefore the non-attention is stated by a single expression in the description of the first jhāna, or else in the way beginning, “With the stilling of applied and sustained thought” .🔽The first consciousness arisen in the fine-material sphere is called “ infinite consciousness” because it occurs in making infinite space its object, and because it is the first to do so, and because it is the condition for the jhāna consciousness that actually occurs in making infinite space its object.

original: “ananta”nti manasi kātabbattā “anantaṃ viññāṇa”nti vuttanti puna “manasikāravasena
analyzed: anantam ti manasi kātabba ttā anantam viññāṇam ti vuttam ti puna manasikāra vasena
translated: And it is called “ infinite consciousness” because it is the first to make infinite space its object by giving attention to it as “infinite,”

original: vā ananta”nti vuttaṃ, sabbaso manasikaraṇavasenāti adhippāyo. Tenāha “anavasesato
analyzed: vā anantam ti vuttam sabbaso manasikaraṇa vasena āti adhippāyaḥ tena āha anavasesato
translated: or else because it is the first to make infinite space its object by giving attention to it as “infinite” in the sense of non- cessation.

original: manasi karonto ‘ananta’nti manasi karotī”ti. Jhānavibhaṅgepi ayamevattho vuttoti
analyzed: manasi karontaḥ anantam ti manasi karoti iti jhāna vibhaṅge pi ayam eva attho vutto ti
translated: This is the meaning intended. That is why he said: “He gives attention to it as ‘infinite’ by giving attention to it as ‘non-ceased’” .🔽And the meaning stated in the Vibhaṅga is the same as this.🔽To show this he says: “But the meaning stated in the Vibhaṅga” , etc.

original: dassento “yaṃ pana vibhaṅge vutta”ntiādimāha. Tassā pāḷiyā evaṃ vā attho veditabbo
analyzed: dassentaḥ yam pana vibhaṅge vutta nti ādim āha tassā pāḷiyā evam vā atthaḥ veditabbo
translated: The meaning of the Vibhaṅga passage should be understood in this way.

original: – taṃyeva ākāsaṃ phuṭaṃ viññāṇaṃ viññāṇañcāyatanaviññāṇena manasi karotīti. Ayaṃ🔽panattho yutto viya dissati, taṃyeva ākāsaṃ viññāṇena phuṭaṃ tena gahitākāraṃ manasi🔽karoti. Evaṃ taṃ viññāṇaṃ anantaṃ pharatīti. Yaṃ hi ākāsaṃ paṭhamāruppasamaṅgī viññāṇena
analyzed: taṃyeva ākāsam phuṭam viññāṇam viññāṇam ca āyatana viññāṇena manasi karoti iti ayam  pana atthaḥ yuttaḥ viya dissati tam yeva ākāsam viññāṇena phuṭam tena gahita ākāram manasi  karoti evam tam viññāṇam anantam pharati iti yam hi ākāsam paṭhama āruppa samaṅgī viññāṇena
translated: He gives attention to the consciousness that has pervaded the space as consciousness of the base consisting of boundless consciousness.🔽But this meaning appears to be appropriate: he gives attention to the space as pervaded by consciousness, to the aspect of its being apprehended by that consciousness. So that consciousness spreads out for him as boundless.

original: anantaṃ pharati, taṃ pharaṇākārasahitameva viññāṇaṃ manasi karonto dutiyāruppasamaṅgī🔽anantaṃ pharatīti vuccati.
analyzed: anantam pharati tam pharaṇa ākāra sahitam eva viññāṇam manasi karontaḥ dutiya āruppa samaṅgī  anantam pharati iti vuccati
translated: For the consciousness that the possessor of the first jhāna spreads out over the space is the consciousness that the possessor of the second jhāna gives attention to as “boundless” by giving attention to the aspect of its spreading out as “boundless.”

original: Manasikāravasena anantapharaṇākārena idha anantatā, na ākāsassa viya uppādantādiabhāvenāti🔽“nāssa antoti ananta”nti ettakamevāha. “Ruḷhīsaddo”ti iminā “viññāṇānañca”nti etassa
analyzed: manasikāra vasena ananta pharaṇa ākārena idha ananta tā na ākāsassa viya uppādanta ādi abhāvena ati  na assa anto ti ananta nti ettakam eva āha ruḷhī saddo ti iminā etassa
translated: The “boundlessness” here is in the aspect of spreading out as boundless by giving attention, not in the absence of arising, etc., as in the case of the base consisting of boundless space.🔽So he says only, “It has no boundary, thus it is boundless” .

original: padassa atthe viññāṇañca-saddo niruḷhoti dasseti, yathāvuttaṃ vā viññāṇaṃ dutiyāruppajjhānena
analyzed: padassa atthe viññāṇañca saddo niruḷhaḥ ti dasseti yathāvuttam vā viññāṇam dutiya āruppa jhānena
translated: By the words “The term ‘consciousness’ is a conventional expression” he shows that the word “consciousness” is a conventional expression for the meaning of the words “of the base consisting of boundless consciousness” . Or alternatively, he shows that the consciousness described as above is a conventional expression.

original: añcīyati vuttākārena ālambīyatīti viññāṇañcanti evampettha attho daṭṭhabbo. Sesaṃ
analyzed: vutta ākārena ālambīyati iti evam pi ittha atthaḥ daṭṭhabbo sesam
translated: It is consciousness because it is conscious of the aspect of the sign as stated . This is how the meaning should be regarded here. The rest is as stated .

original: vuttatthamevāti āha “sesaṃ purimasadisamevā”ti.
analyzed: vuttattham eva iti āha sesam purima sadisam eva iti
translated: The rest is as stated in the earlier case.

original: Ākiñcaññāyatanakathāvaṇṇanā
analyzed: ākiñcaññāyatana kathā vaṇṇanā
translated: The third immaterial state

original: 283. Tatiyāruppakammaṭṭhāne yaṃ heṭṭhā vuttasadisaṃ, taṃ vuttanayānusārena veditabbaṃ,
analyzed: tatiya āruppa kammaṭṭhāne yam heṭṭhā vutta sadisam tam vutta naya anusārena veditabbam
translated: What is similar to what has been stated above in the case of the third immaterial state should be understood in the same way as stated.

original: apubbameva vaṇṇayissāma. Tattha tassevāti yaṃ ārabbha viññāṇañcāyatanaṃ pavattaṃ,
analyzed: apubbam eva vaṇṇayissāma tattha tassa iva ati yam ārabbha viññāṇam ca āyatanam pavattam
translated: We shall comment only on what is new. Herein, that same: that which is the basis for the occurrence of the base-of-infinite-consciousness.

original: tasseva. Kiṃ pana tanti āha “ākāsānañcāyatanaviññāṇassā”ti. Etena tato aññaṃ tatiyāruppajjhānassa
analyzed: tassa iva kim pana tat ti āha ākāsa anañcāyatana viññāṇassa ati etena tatas aññam tatiya āruppa jhānassa
translated: What is that? He said: “of the consciousness of the base-of-infinite-space.” By this he shows that there is no object for the third immaterial jhāna apart from that.

original: ārammaṇaṃ natthīti dasseti. “Ārammaṇabhūtassā”ti iminā tassa anārammaṇabhūtaṃ dutiyāruppaviññāṇaṃ
analyzed: ārammaṇam natthi iti dasseti ārammaṇa bhūtassa ati iminā tassa anārammaṇa bhūtam dutiya āruppa viññāṇam
translated: By “as object” he excludes the second-jhana consciousness, which is not its object.🔽Non-existence: non-being. Void: voidness.

original: nivatteti. Abhāvoti natthitā. Suññatāti rittatā. Vivittākāroti viveko. Tīhi padehi
analyzed: nivattā iti abhāvo ti natthi tā suñña tā ati ritta tā vivitta ākāro ti viveko tīhi padehi
translated: The aspect of seclusion: seclusion. By these three terms he states only the departure of the first-jhana consciousness.

original: paṭhamāruppaviññāṇassa apagamameva vadati. “Manasi kātabbo”ti vatvā manasikāravidhiṃ
analyzed: paṭhama āruppa viññāṇassa apagamam eva vadati manasi kātabbaḥ iti vatvā manasikāra vidhim
translated: Having said “should be given attention as void,” he now shows the method of giving attention to it as void.

original: dassetuṃ “taṃ viññāṇa”ntiādi vuttaṃ. Tattha amanasikaritvāti sabbena sabbaṃ manasi
analyzed: dassetum tam viññāṇam tiādi vuttam tattha a manasikaritvā ti sabbena sabbam manasi
translated: “That consciousness” is said in order to show that. Herein, without giving attention to that: not giving attention to it in any way at all,

original: akatvā acintetvā. Vā-saddo aniyamattho, tena tīsu pakāresu ekenapi atthasiddhīti dasseti.
analyzed: a katvā a cintetvā vā saddaḥ aniyama tthaḥ tena tīsu pakāresu ekena api attha siddhi iti dasseti
translated: “That consciousness” is said in order to show that. There, not giving attention to that means not giving attention to it at all, not thinking about it. The word “or” indicates no restriction; it shows that the meaning is established by one or other of the three terms.

original: Tasmiṃ nimitteti tasmiṃ paṭhamāruppaviññāṇassa abhāvasaṅkhāte jhānuppattinimitte.
analyzed: tasmim nimitta iti tasmim paṭhama āruppa viññāṇassa abhāva saṅkhāte jhāna uppatti nimitte
translated: In that sign means in the sign consisting in the non-existence of the first jhāna consciousness that has arisen.

original: Ākāse phuṭeti ākāsaṃ pharitvā pavatte. “Ākāsaphuṭe”ti vā pāṭho. Suññavivittanatthibhāveti🔽suññabhāve, vivittabhāve, natthibhāve cāti yena ākārena bhāvitaṃ, tassa gahaṇatthaṃ
analyzed: ākāse phuṭā iti ākāsam pharitvā pavatte ākāsa phuṭā iti vā pāṭhaḥ suñña vivitta natthi bhāvā iti  suñña bhāve vivitta bhāve natthi bhāve ca ati yena ākārena bhāvitam tassa gahaṇa attham
translated: Spreading over the space means occurring by spreading over the space. Or there is the reading “ākāsa-phuṭe,” in which case the meaning is: in the space that is spread over.

original: vuttaṃ. Atha vā suññavivittanatthibhāveti suññavivittatāsaṅkhāte natthibhāve, tena
analyzed: vuttam atha vā suñña vivitta natthi bhāva iti suñña vivitta tā saṅkhāte natthi bhāve tena
translated: In the state of voidness, in the state of emptiness, in the state of non-existence means in the state of voidness, in the state of emptiness, in the state of non-existence, in the state of non-being, in the state of non-occurrence, in the state of non-manifestation, in the state of non-perception, in the state of non-cognizing, in the state of non-existence of the sign of the first jhāna consciousness that has arisen.

original: vināsābhāvameva dasseti, na pure abhāvādike.
analyzed: vināsā bhāvam eva dasseti na pure abhāva ādike
translated: In order to show the way in which it is developed, it is said:

original: Tasmiṃ hi appanācitteti ākiñcaññāyatanajjhānasampayutte appanāvasena pavatte citte,
analyzed: tasmin hi appanā citta iti ākiñcaññāyatana jhāna sampayutte appanā vasena pavatte citte
translated: In the state of voidness, in the state of emptiness, in the state of non-existence. Or alternatively, in the state of non-existence called voidness and emptiness, in the state of non-existence called non-being, in the state of non-existence called non-occurrence, in the state of non-existence called non-manifestation, in the state of non-existence called non-perception, in the state of non-existence called non-cognizing, in the state of non-existence called non-being, in the state of non-existence called non-occurrence, in the state of non-existence called non-manifestation, in the state of non-existence called non-perception, in the state of non-existence called non-cognizing, in the state of non-existence called non-being, in the state of non-existence called non-occurrence, in the state of non-existence called non-manifestation, in the state of non-existence called non-perception, in the state of non-existence called non-cognizing, in the state of non-existence called non-being, in the state of non-existence called non-occurrence, in the state of non-existence called non-manifestation, in the

original: tasmiṃ vā paṭhamāruppassa apagamasaṅkhāte natthibhāve yathāvutte appanācitte uppanne.🔽So bhikkhu abhāvameva passanto viharatīti sambandho. Puriso katthaci gantvā āgantvā
analyzed: tasmin vā paṭhama āruppassa apagama saṅkhāte natthi bhāve yathā vutte appanā citte uppanne  so bhikkhu abhāvam eva passantaḥ viharati iti sambandho puriso katthaci gantvā āgantvā
translated: Or alternatively, the meaning can be regarded as follows: when the first jhāna consciousness has disappeared, that is, when it is no longer present, and the second-jhāna consciousness has arisen in the way already described.🔽The construction of the words should be understood thus: “That bhikkhu abides resolved upon in-breaths and out-breaths as void.”🔽The simile should be worked out as follows: a man goes somewhere and returns;

original: suññameva passati, natthibhāvameva passatīti yojanā. Taṃ ṭhānanti taṃ sannipātaṭṭhānaṃ.
analyzed: suññam eva passati natthi bhāvam eva passati iti yojanā tam ṭhānam ti tam sannipāta ṭṭhānam
translated: on his return he sees the place as void, he sees the absence of the bhikkhus.

original: “Parikammamanasikārena antarahite”ti iminā ārammaṇakaraṇābhāvena tassa antaradhānaṃ🔽na naṭṭhattāti dasseti. Tatridaṃ opammasaṃsandanaṃ – yathā so puriso tattha sannipatitaṃ
analyzed: parikamma manasikārena antarahitā iti iminā ārammaṇa karaṇa abhāvena tassa antaradhānam  na naṭṭha ttā ati dasseti tatra idam opamma saṃsandanam yathā saḥ purisaḥ tattha sannipatitam
translated: “When the bhikkhus have disappeared through the attention given to the preliminary work” shows that their disappearance is not by their having gone away.

original: bhikkhusaṅghaṃ disvā gato, tato sabbesu bhikkhūsu kenacideva karaṇīyena apagatesu
analyzed: bhikkhu saṅgham disvā gataḥ tatas sabbesu bhikkhūsu kenacid eva karaṇīyena apagatesu
translated: The application of the simile should be understood as follows: just as that man, after seeing the bhikkhu community assembled there, went away, and then on his return saw that place as void of bhikkhus because all the bhikkhus had left on some business or other,

original: āgantvā taṃ ṭhānaṃ bhikkhūhi suññameva passati, na bhikkhūnaṃ tatopi apagatakāraṇaṃ,
analyzed: āgantvā tam ṭhānam bhikkhūhi suññam eva passati na bhikkhūnam tatas pi apagata kāraṇam
translated: and he did not know the reason for their having gone away,

original: evamayaṃ yogāvacaro pubbe viññāṇañcāyatanajjhānacakkhunā paṭhamāruppaviññāṇaṃ disvā
analyzed: evam ayam yogāvacaro pubbe viññāṇañcāyatana jhāna cakkhunā paṭhama āruppa viññāṇam disvā
translated: so too, this meditator, after seeing the first-jhāna consciousness with the eye of the fine-material-sphere jhāna that he has already obtained,

original: pacchā natthīti parikammamanasikārena tasmiṃ apagate tatiyāruppajjhānacakkhunā tassa
analyzed: pacchā na atthi iti parikamma manasikārena tasmin apagate tatiya āruppa jhāna cakkhunā tassa
translated: “Afterwards there is not” means that when it has disappeared through the attention given to the preliminary work, it is seen with the eye of the third jhāna’s adverting.

original: natthibhāvameva passanto viharati, na tassa apagamanakāraṇaṃ vīmaṃsati jhānassa tādisābhogābhāvatoti.
analyzed: natthi bhāvam eva passantaḥ viharati na tassa apagamana kāraṇam vīmaṃsati jhānassa tādisa ābhoga abhāvato ti
translated: “There is no future” means that he dwells seeing only the non-existence of that consciousness by means of the third jhāna eye, which arises after the preliminary-work consciousness has disappeared, and he does not investigate the reason for its disappearance, because the jhāna is of such a nature as not to need any such concern.

original: Sabbaso viññāṇañcāyatanaṃ samatikkammāti ettha yaṃ vattabbaṃ, taṃ heṭṭhā vuttanayānusārena veditabbaṃ.🔽284. Natthitā pariyāyāsuññavivittabhāvāti “natthī”ti padassa atthaṃ vadantena suññavivittapadānipi🔽gahitāni. Āmeḍitavacanaṃ pana bhāvanākāradassanaṃ. Vibhaṅgepi imassa padassa ayamevattho
analyzed: sabbasas viññāṇañca āyatanam samatikkamma ati ettha yat vattabbam tat heṭṭhā vutta naya anusārena veditabbam  natthitā pariyāya a suñña vivitta bhāvā ti natthi iti padassa attham vadantena suñña vivitta padāni pi  gahitāni āmeḍita vacanam pana bhāvanā ākāra dassanam vibhaṅge pi imassa padassa ayam eva atthaḥ
translated: “Having completely transcended the base of infinite consciousness”: what is to be said here should be understood in the way already stated .🔽“The modes of non-existence, the modes of voidness, the modes of solitude”: the words “the modes of voidness, the modes of solitude” are included by the words “the modes of non-existence” . But the words “he abides contemplating non-existence” show the mode of development. And in the Vibhaṅga the meaning of this expression is stated in the same way in order to show that, thus: “And in the Vibhaṅga” .🔽There “he develops the signless concentration of mind” means that he develops the jhāna that possesses the aspect of the signless.

original: vuttoti dassetuṃ “yampi vibhaṅge”tiādi vuttaṃ. Tattha taññeva viññāṇaṃ abhāvetīti
analyzed: vuttaḥ ti dassetum yat pi vibhaṅga itiādi vuttam tattha tañca eva viññāṇam abhāveti iti
translated: “He abides in the attainment of the base consisting of nothingness” means that he abides in the attainment of the base consisting of nothingness.

original: yaṃ pubbe “anantaṃ viññāṇa”nti manasi kataṃ paṭhamāruppaviññāṇaṃ, taṃyevāti attho.
analyzed: yam pubbe anantam viññāṇam ti manasi katam paṭhama āruppa viññāṇam tam yeva āti atthaḥ
translated: “He develops the base consisting of neither perception nor non-perception” means that he develops the jhāna that possesses the aspect of the base consisting of neither perception nor non-perception.🔽“He develops the cessation of perception and feeling” means that he develops the attainment of cessation.🔽“He develops the signless concentration of mind” is said in order to show the development of the first three immaterial states. “He develops the base consisting of neither perception nor non-perception” is said in order to show the development of the fourth. “He develops the cessation of perception and feeling” is said in order to show the development of the attainment of cessation.

original: Taṃyeva hi ārammaṇabhūtaṃ paṭhamena viya rūpanimittaṃ tatiyenāruppenābhāvetīti. Khayato🔽sammasananti bhaṅgānupassanamāha. Sā hi saṅkhatadhammānaṃ bhaṅgābhāvameva passantī
analyzed: hi ārammaṇa bhūtam paṭhamena viya rūpa nimittam tatiyena āruppena abhāveti iti khayato  sammasanam ti bhaṅga anupassanam āha sā hi saṅkhata dhammānam bhaṅga abhāvam eva passantī
translated: ‘Contemplation as destruction’: this is a term for the contemplation of dissolution. For that contemplates only the non-existence of the dissolution of formed dhammas.

original: “viññāṇampi abhāvetī”tiādinā vattabbataṃ labhatīti adhippāyenāha “khayato sammasanaṃ
analyzed: viññāṇam pi abhāveti itiādinā vattabba tam labhati iti adhippāyena āha khayataḥ sammasanam
translated: ‘Contemplation as destruction is stated as if it were made to disappear’ is said with the intention that it deserves to be stated thus: ‘Consciousness is made to disappear.’

original: viya vutta”nti. Assāti pāṭhassa. Puna assāti viññāṇassa. Abhāvetīti abhāvaṃ karoti.🔽Yathā ñāṇassa na upatiṭṭhati, evaṃ karoti amanasikaraṇato. Tato eva vibhāveti vigatabhāvaṃ🔽karoti, vināseti vā yathā na dissati, tathā karaṇato. Teneva antaradhāpeti tirobhāvaṃ🔽gameti. Na aññathāti imissā pāḷiyā evamattho, na ito aññathā ayujjamānakattāti adhippāyo.
analyzed: viya vuttanti assa ati pāṭhassa puna assa ati viññāṇassa abhāveti iti abhāvam karoti  yathā ñāṇassa na upatiṭṭhati evam karoti amanasikaraṇato tatas eva vibhāveti vigata bhāvam  karoti vināseti vā yathā na dissati tathā karaṇato tena iva antaradhāpeti tirobhāvam  gameti na aññathā ti imissā pāḷiyā evamatthaḥ na itas aññathā ayujjamānaka ttā ti adhippāyaḥ
translated: ‘Again, as to “not”’: the reading is ‘assā’ . ‘Again, as to “not”’: as to consciousness. ‘Made to disappear’: made non-existent.🔽‘As to “not”’: as to not being attended to, as to not being given attention. ‘Made to disappear’: made to vanish.

original: Assāti paṭhamāruppaviññāṇābhāvassa. Kiñcananti kiñcipi. Sabhāvadhammassa appāvasesatā
analyzed: assa ti paṭhama āruppa viññāṇa abhāvassa kiñcana nti sabhāva dhammassa appāvasesa tā
translated: ‘Made to disappear’: made to vanish. ‘Made to disappear’: made to vanish. ‘Made to disappear’: made to vanish. ‘Made to disappear’: made to vanish. ‘Made to disappear’: made to vanish. ‘Made to disappear’: made to vanish. ‘Made to disappear’: made to vanish. ‘Made to disappear’: made to vanish. ‘Made to disappear’: made to vanish. ‘Made to disappear’: made to vanish. ‘Made to disappear’: made to vanish. ‘Made to disappear’: made to vanish. ‘Made to disappear’: made to vanish. ‘Made to disappear’: made to vanish. ‘Made to disappear’: made to vanish. ‘Made to disappear’: made to vanish. ‘Made to disappear’: made to vanish. ‘Made to disappear’: made to vanish. ‘Made to disappear’: made to vanish. ‘Made to disappear’: made to vanish. ‘Made to disappear’: made to vanish. ‘Made to disappear’: made to vanish. ‘Made to disappear’: made to vanish. ‘Made to disappear’: made to vanish. ‘Made to disappear’: made to vanish. ‘Made to disappear’: made to vanish. ‘Made to disappear’: made to vanish. ‘Made to disappear’: made to vanish. ‘Made to disappear’: made to vanish. ‘Made to disappear’: made to vanish. ‘Made to disappear’: made to vanish. ‘Made to disappear’: made to vanish. ‘Made to disappear’: made to vanish. ‘Made to disappear’: made to vanish. ‘Made to disappear’: made to vanish. ‘Made to disappear’: made to vanish. ‘Made to disappear’: made to vanish. ‘Made to disappear’: made to vanish

original: nāma bhaṅgo eva siyāti āha “bhaṅgamattampi assa avasiṭṭhaṃ natthī”ti. Sati hi bhaṅgamattepi🔽tassa sakiñcanatā siyā. Akiñcananti ca viññāṇassa kiñci pakāraṃ aggahetvā sabbena
analyzed: nāma bhaṅgaḥ eva siyā iti āha bhaṅga mattam pi assa avasiṭṭham natthi iti sati hi bhaṅga matte pi  tassa sa kiñcana tā siyā akiñcananti ca viññāṇassa kiñci pakāram aggahetvā sabbena
translated: then it would have something left to it. “Nothing” is said to be the complete

original: sabbaṃ vibhāvanamāha. Sesaṃ vuttanayameva.
analyzed: sabbam vibhāvanam āha sesam vutta nayam eva
translated: disappearance of consciousness without taking anything as a basis. The rest is as already explained.

original: Nevasaññānāsaññāyatanakathāvaṇṇanā🔽285. No ca santāti yathā nevasaññānāsaññāyatanasamāpatti saṅkhārāvasesasukhumabhāvappattiyā
analyzed: nevasaññā nāsañña āyatana kathā vaṇṇanā  no ca yathā nevasaññā nāsañña āyatana samāpatti saṅkhāra avasesa sukhuma bhāva ppattiyā
translated: The explanation of the section on the base of neither-perception-nor-non-perception

original: savisesā santā, evamayaṃ ākiñcaññāyatanasamāpatti no ca santā tadabhāvato. Yā ayaṃ🔽khandhesu paccayayāpanīyatāya, rogamūlatāya ca rogasarikkhatā, dukkhatāsūlayogādinā🔽gaṇḍasarikkhatā, pīḷājananādinā sallasarikkhatā ca, sā saññāya sati hoti, nāsatīti
analyzed: sa visesā santā evam ayam ākiñcaññāyatana samāpatti no ca santā tad abhāvataḥ yā ayam  khandhesu paccaya yāpanīya tāya roga mūla tāya ca roga sarikkha tā dukkha tā sūla yoga ādinā  gaṇḍa sarikkha tā pīḷā janana ādinā salla sarikkha tā ca sā saññāya sati hoti na asati iti
translated: is not peaceful: just as the attainment of the base of neither-perception-nor-non-perception is more peaceful than the attainment of the base of nothingness because it is the attainment of a more subtle state of being with less remaining formations, so this attainment of the base of nothingness is not peaceful because it does not have that.🔽The resemblance to a boil, etc., is stated in the way beginning, “Bhikkhus, perception is a boil, perception is a dart” , since the perception of the five aggregates as self, which is the root of the disease of suffering, is similar to a boil because it is the cause of the disease of suffering, and since the perception of the five aggregates as self, which is the cause of the dart of suffering, is similar to a dart because it generates pain, etc. This is said as long as there is perception. But when there is no perception,

original: vuttaṃ “saññā rogo, saññā gaṇḍo, saññā salla”nti. Sā cettha paṭukiccā pañcavokārabhavato
analyzed: vuttam saññā rogo saññā gaṇḍo saññā sallanti sā ca ittha paṭu kiccā pañca vokāra bhavato
translated: then the five aggregates are like a lump of flesh, like a clod of earth, like a piece of wood, like a wall, like a piece of straw, like an empty fist, like a mirage, like a dream, like a shadow, like an echo, like an apparition, like a magical creation.

original: oḷārikasaññā veditabbā. Na kevalaṃ saññā eva, atha kho vedanācetanādīnampi saṅgaho
analyzed: oḷārika saññā veditabbā na kevalam saññā eva atha kho vedanā cetanā ādīnam pi saṅgahaḥ
translated: Perception gross should be understood. And not only perception but also feeling, choice, etc., are included.

original: daṭṭhabbo. Saññāsīsena pana niddeso kato. Etaṃ santanti etaṃ asantabhāvakararogādisarikkhasaññāvirahato
analyzed: daṭṭhabbo saññā sīsena pana niddeso kato etam etam etam asanta bhāva kara roga ādi sarikkha saññā virahato
translated: But the teaching is given under the heading of perception.🔽Peaceful: peaceful because of the absence of perception like that of disease, etc., which is not peaceful.🔽And sublime: and also sublime because of the absence of perception like that of disease, etc., which is not sublime.

original: santaṃ. Tato eva paṇītaṃ. Kiṃ pana tanti āha “nevasaññānāsaññā”ti? Tadapadesena taṃsampayuttajjhānamāha
analyzed: santam tatas eva paṇītam kim pana tat ti āha nevasaññā nāsaññā iti tad apadesena tad sampayutta jhānam āha
translated: What is it? He said: “Neither perception nor non-perception.”

original: “ādīnava”nti. Ettha rogādisarikkhasaññādisabbhāvopi ādīnavo daṭṭhabbo, na āsannaviññāṇañcāyatanapaccatthikatāva.
analyzed: ādīnavanti ettha ādīnavaḥ daṭṭhabbaḥ na āsanna viññāṇañca āyatana paccatthika tā vat
translated: By the word “peril” he means the absence of perception like that of disease, etc., and not merely the fact that the base consisting of nothingness is a nearer neighbour to the base consisting of neither perception nor non-perception than the base consisting of the infinity of consciousness.🔽Above: in the fourth jhāna.🔽That: that same.

original: Uparīti catutthāruppe. Sā vāti sā eva. Vattitāti pavattitā nibbattitā vaḷañjitā.
analyzed: upari iti catuttha āruppe sā vāti sā eva vatti tā ati pavatti tā nibbatti tā vaḷañjitā
translated: It occurs: it is generated, produced, brought into being.

original: Tasmiṃ nimitteti tasmiṃ tatiyāruppasamāpattisaṅkhāte jhānanimitte. Mānasanti cittaṃ
analyzed: tasmin nimitta iti tasmin tatiya āruppa samāpatti saṅkhāte jhāna nimitte mānasanti cittam
translated: In that sign: in the jhāna that is called the attainment of the third base.🔽Mental: the mind.

original: “mano eva mānasa”nti katvā, bhāvanāmanasikāraṃ vā. Taṃ hi manasi bhavanti mānasanti
analyzed: manaḥ eva katvā bhāvanā manasikāram vā tam hi manasi bhavanti mānasanti
translated: Or it is mental because it occurs in the mind.

original: vuccati. Jhānasampayuttadhammānampi jhānānuguṇatāya samāpattipariyāyo labbhatīti
analyzed: vuccati jhāna sampayutta dhammānam pi jhāna anuguṇa tāya samāpatti pariyāyaḥ labbhati iti
translated: it is said. And since the states associated with the jhāna are in conformity with it, the expression “attainment” is applicable to them too.

original: āha “ākiñcaññāyatanasamāpattisaṅkhātesu catūsu khandhesū”ti, ārammaṇabhūtesūti adhippāyo.🔽286. Yathāvuttaṃ ākiñcaññaṃ ārammaṇapaccayabhāvato āyatanaṃ kāraṇamassāti jhānaṃ
analyzed: āha ākiñcaññāyatana samāpatti saṅkhātesu catūsu khandhesu iti ārammaṇa bhūtesu iti adhippāyaḥ  yathā vuttam ākiñcaññam ārammaṇa paccaya bhāvataḥ āyatanam kāraṇam assa ati jhānam
translated: So he said “in the four mental aggregates called the attainment of the base of nothingness” . The meaning is: in those that are the object.🔽The base of nothingness is the cause of the jhāna in the sense of object condition, since it is the object of the jhāna.

original: ākiñcaññāyatanaṃ, ākiñcaññameva ārammaṇapaccayabhūtaṃ jhānassa kāraṇanti ārammaṇaṃ
analyzed: ākiñcaññāyatanaṃ ākiñcaññam eva ārammaṇa paccaya bhūtam jhānassa kāraṇanti ārammaṇaṃ
translated: The base of nothingness is the cause of the jhāna in the sense of object condition, since it is the object of the jhāna.

original: ākiñcaññāyatananti evaṃ vā attho daṭṭhabbo. Sesamettha heṭṭhā vuttanayānusārena veditabbaṃ.
analyzed: ākiñcaññāyatananti evam vā attho daṭṭhabbo sesam ettha heṭṭhā vutta naya anusārena veditabbam
translated: The meaning should be regarded thus: “The base of nothingness is the cause of the jhāna in the sense of object condition, since it is the nothingness that is the object.” The rest should be understood in the way already described under the fourth immaterial jhāna .

original: Yāya saññāya bhāvatoti yādisāya saññāya atthibhāvena. Yā hi sā paṭusaññākiccassa
analyzed: yāya saññāya bhāvato ti yādisāya saññāya atthi bhāvena yā hi sā paṭu saññā kiccassa
translated: By the kind of perception that exists: by the kind of perception that exists as a real entity. For that is not to be called perception because it is devoid of the function of normal perception;

original: abhāvato saññātipi na vattabbā, saññāsabhāvānātivattanato asaññātipi na vattabbā,
analyzed: abhāvataḥ saññā tipi na vattabbā saññā sabhāva an ativattanataḥ asaññā tipi na vattabbā
translated: nor is it not to be called perception because it does not transcend the mental-data element.

original: tassā vijjamānattāti attho. Tanti taṃ jhānaṃ. Taṃ tāva dassetunti ettha tanti taṃ
analyzed: tassāḥ vijjamāna ttā ti attho tanti tam jhānam tam tāva dassetunti ettha tanti tam
translated: The meaning is that it exists. That: that jhāna. That, firstly, should be understood: the word “that” refers

original: sasāpaṭipadaṃ, yathāvuttasaññaṃ, tassā ca adhigamupāyanti attho. Nevasaññīnāsaññīti
analyzed: yathā vutta saññam tassā ca adhigama upāyanti atthaḥ nevasaññī nāsaññī ti
translated: and the way of practice, the perception stated, and the means to attain it.

original: hi puggalādhiṭṭhānena dhammaṃ uddharantena saññāvantamukhena saññā uddhaṭā, aññathā
analyzed: hi puggala adhiṭṭhānena dhammam uddharantena saññāvanta mukhena saññā uddhaṭā aññathā
translated: For one who extracts the Dhamma with the person as the support, perception is extracted under the heading of perception. Otherwise,🔽it would have to be extracted as the base of neither-perception-nor-non-perception.

original: nevasaññānāsaññāyatananti uddharitabbaṃ siyā. Sā pana paṭipadā yattha pavattati,
analyzed: nevasaññānāsaññāyatananti uddharitabbam siyā sā pana paṭipadā yattha pavattati
translated: But the way of practice in which that is found,

original: yathā ca pavattati, taṃ dassetuṃ “ākiñcaññāyatanaṃ santato manasi karoti, saṅkhārāvasesasamāpattiṃ
analyzed: yathā ca pavattati tam dassetum ākiñcaññāyatanam santataḥ manasi karoti saṅkhāra avasesa samāpattim
translated: and the way in which it is found, are shown by the words “He gives attention to the base consisting of nothingness as peaceful … he develops the attainment of the base consisting of nothingness” .🔽For the base consisting of nothingness is the place of occurrence of the fourth immaterial state, and the attainment of the base consisting of nothingness

original: bhāvetī”ti vuttaṃ. Ākiñcaññāyatanaṃ hi catutthāruppabhāvanāya pavattiṭṭhānaṃ, saṅkhārāvasesasamāpatti
analyzed: bhāveti iti vuttam ākiñcaññāyatanam hi catuttha āruppa bhāvanāya pavatti ṭṭhānam saṅkhāra avasesa samāpatti
translated: is the mode of occurrence.🔽“Where, indeed, is it?”: the meaning is, “Where, indeed, is there such a peaceful object?”

original: pavattiākāroti. Yatra hi nāmāti yā nāma. Natthibhāvampīti viññāṇassa suññatampi,
analyzed: pavatti ākāraḥ ti yatra hi nāma ati yā nāma natthi bhāvam pi iti viññāṇassa suññatam pi
translated: “The emptiness of consciousness”: the meaning is, “The emptiness of consciousness is so peaceful.”

original: evaṃ sukhumampīti adhippāyo. Santārammaṇatāyāti santaṃ ārammaṇaṃ etissāti santārammaṇā,
analyzed: evam sukhumam pi iti adhippāyaḥ santa ārammaṇa tāya ati santam ārammaṇam etissa ati santa ārammaṇā
translated: “Because of the object’s peacefulness”: it is peaceful because it goes to a peaceful object.

original: tabbhāvo santārammaṇatā, tāya, na jhānasantatāya. Na hi tatiyāruppasamāpatti catutthāruppajjhānato santā.
analyzed: tad bhāvaḥ santa ārammaṇa tā tāya na jhāna santa tāya na hi tatiya āruppa samāpatti catuttha āruppa jhānato santā
translated: The state of that is the state of the object of the jhāna. It is not the state of the jhāna continuity. For the third immaterial jhāna is not in the state of the fourth immaterial jhāna.

original: Codako “yaṃ santato manasi karoti, na tattha ādīnavadassanaṃ bhaveyya. Asati ca ādīnavadassane🔽samatikkamo eva na siyā”ti dassento “santato ce manasi karoti, kathaṃ samatikkamo
analyzed: codakaḥ yam santataḥ manasi karoti na tattha ādīnava dassanam bhaveyya asati ca ādīnava dassane  samatikkamaḥ eva na siyāti dassento santataḥ ce manasi karoti katham samatikkamaḥ
translated: The accuser, pointing out that if he gives attention to the state of the jhāna, then the seeing of the danger in it would not be there, and that if the seeing of the danger in it is not there,

original: hotī”ti āha. Itaro “asamāpajjitukāmatāyā”ti parihāramāha, tena ādīnavadassanampi🔽atthevāti dasseti. So hītiādinā vuttamevatthaṃ pākaṭataraṃ karoti. Tattha yasmiṃ🔽jhāne abhirati, tattha āvajjanasamāpajjanādipaṭipattiyā bhavitabbaṃ. Sā panassa tatiyāruppe
analyzed: hoti iti āha itaraḥ a samāpajjitu kāma tāya ati parihāram āha tena ādīnava dassanam pi  attha iva ati dasseti saḥ hi iti ādinā vuttam eva attham pākaṭataram karoti tattha yasmin  jhāne abhirati tattha āvajjana samāpajjana ādi paṭipattiyā bhavitabbam sā panassa tatiya āruppe
translated: then surmounting it would not be possible, says, “If he gives attention to the state of the jhāna, how is there surmounting?” The other replies, “Through the desire not to enter upon it,” showing that the seeing of the danger in it is there too.🔽For he says this: “If he gives attention to the state of the jhāna, then the seeing of the danger in it would not be there, and if the seeing of the danger in it is not there, then surmounting it would not be possible. But if he gives attention to the desire not to enter upon it, then the seeing of the danger in it is there, and if the seeing of the danger in it is there, then surmounting it is possible.”

original: sabbaso natthi, kevalaṃ aññābhāvato ārammaṇakaraṇamattamevāti dassento “kiñcāpī”tiādimāha.
analyzed: sabbasas na atthi kevalam aññā bhāvataḥ ārammaṇa karaṇa mattam eva ti dassentaḥ kiñcā api iti ādim āha
translated: He makes the meaning stated in the way beginning, “For he does not enter upon it” clearer in the way beginning, “For he does not enter upon it, etc.” Herein, he should enter upon the practice of adverting to and attaining the jhāna in the jhāna in which he is interested. But he has none of that in the third immaterial jhāna. He has only the mere adverting to it as an object by way of its specific characteristic, since it is not known by him. This is how the expositor should make the meaning clear.

original: Samatikkamitvāva gacchatīti tesaṃ sippīnaṃ jīvikaṃ tiṇāyapi amaññamāno te vītivattatiyeva.🔽Soti yogāvacaro. Tanti tatiyāruppasamāpattiṃ. Pubbe vuttanayenāti “santā vatāyaṃ🔽samāpattī”tiādinā vuttena nayena santato manasi karonto. Tanti yāya nevasaññīnāsaññī
analyzed: samatikkamitvā ava gacchati iti tesam sippīnam jīvikam a maññamāno te  saḥ iti yoga avacaraḥ tanti tatiya āruppa samāpattim pubbe vutta nayena ati santā vata ayam  samāpatti iti ādinā vuttena nayena santataḥ manasi karonto tanti yāya nevasaññī nāsaññī
translated: He goes beyond them, not regarding even as straw the livelihood of those craftsmen.

original: nāma hoti, saṅkhārāvasesasamāpattiṃ bhāvetīti vuccati, taṃ saññaṃ pāpuṇātīti yojanā.
analyzed: nāma hoti saṅkhāra avasesa samāpattim bhāveti iti vuccati tam saññam pāpuṇāti iti yojanā
translated: He: the meditator. That: the third attainment. In the way already described: by giving his attention to it as “peaceful” in the way already described under the second jhāna . That: the perception by means of which he is called neither-percipient-nor-non-percipient, which is called “attainment with a residual formation” . The construction is: he reaches that perception.

original: Saññāsīsena hi desanā. Paramasukhumanti ukkaṃsagatasukhumabhāvaṃ. Saṅkhārāvasesasamāpattinti
analyzed: saññā sīsena hi desanā parama sukhumanti ukkaṃsa gata sukhuma bhāvam saṅkhāra avasesa samāpattinti
translated: For the teaching is given in terms of perception. Supremely refined: it has reached the refinement of the ultimate. Attainment with a residual formation:

original: ukkaṃsagatasukhumatāya saṅkhārānaṃ sesatāmattaṃ samāpattiṃ. Tenāha “accantasukhumabhāvappattasaṅkhāra”nti.
analyzed: ukkaṃsa gata sukhumatāya saṅkhārānam sesa tā mattam samāpattim tena āha accanta sukhuma bhāva ppatta saṅkhāranti
translated: an attainment in which only a residual formation of formations remains because of the refinement of the ultimate. Hence it is said, “a formation that has reached ultimate refinement” .

original: Antamaticca accantaṃ. Yato sukhumatamaṃ nāma natthi, tathāparamukkaṃsagatasukhumasaṅkhāranti
analyzed: antam aticca accantam yatas sukhumatamam nāma na atthi tathā aparam ukkaṃsa gata sukhuma saṅkhāranti
translated: Ultimate is extreme, since there is nothing more extreme than it. So too, a formation that has reached the refinement of the ultimate is called “the most refined” .

original: attho. Paṭhamajjhānūpacārato paṭṭhāya hi tacchantiyā viya pavattamānāya bhāvanāya
analyzed: attho paṭhama jhāna upacārato paṭṭhāya hi tad chantiyā viya pavattamānāya bhāvanāya
translated: For the development of the fourth jhāna, which occurs as if it were repressing, represses formations by degrees beginning with the access of the fourth jhāna, and it brings them to cessation in the ultimate sense.

original: anukkamena saṅkhārā tattha antimakoṭṭhāsataṃ pāpitā, tato paraṃ nirodho eva, na saṅkhārappavattīti.
analyzed: anukkamena saṅkhārā tattha antima koṭṭhāsatam tato param nirodhaḥ eva na saṅkhāra ppavatti iti
translated: After that there is only cessation, not the occurrence of formations.

original: Tena vuccati “saṅkhārāvasesasamāpattī”ti.
analyzed: tena vuccati saṅkhāra avasesa samāpatti iti
translated: That is why it is said that it is “attained by the cessation of the remaining formations.”🔽As to meaning: as to the ultimate meaning, which is distinguished by the special qualities of the profitable, etc.

original: 287. Yaṃ taṃ catukkhandhaṃ. Atthatoti kusalādivisesavisiṭṭhaparamatthato. Visesato
analyzed: yam tam catukkhandham atthataḥ ti kusala ādi visesa visiṭṭha paramatthataḥ visesataḥ
translated: As to distinction: as to the distinction of the fourth immaterial jhāna, which is the basis for the higher wisdom training, and which is intended here.

original: adhipaññāsikkhāya adhiṭṭhānabhūtaṃ idhādhippetanti āha “idha samāpannassa cittacetasikā🔽dhammā adhippetā”ti. Oḷārikāya saññāya abhāvatoti yadipi catutthāruppavipākasaññāya🔽catutthāruppakusalasaññā oḷārikā, tathā vipassanāmaggaphalasaññāhi, tathāpi oḷārikasukhumatā
analyzed: adhi paññā sikkhāya adhiṭṭhāna bhūtam idha adhippetanti āha idha samāpannassa citta cetasikā  dhammā adhippetā ti oḷārikāya saññāya abhāvato ti yadi pi catuttha āruppa vipāka saññāya  catuttha āruppa kusala saññā oḷārikā tathā vipassanā magga phala saññāhi tathā api oḷārika sukhuma tā
translated: That is why he said: “What is intended here is the consciousness and its concomitants in one who has entered upon this jhāna.”

original: nāma upādāyupādāya gahetabbāti pañcavokārabhavapariyāpannāya viya catuvokārepi heṭṭhā
analyzed: nāma upādāya upādāya gahetabbā ati pañcavokāra bhava pariyāpannāya catuvokāre pi heṭṭhā
translated: As to the absence of grossness in perception: although the resultant perception in the fourth immaterial jhāna is gross compared with the profitable fourth immaterial jhāna, and so too the profitable fourth immaterial jhāna is gross compared with the insight, path and fruition, nevertheless grossness and subtlety should be understood as applicable only by way of what is included and what is not so included, as in the case of the five-constituent kind of becoming and the four-constituent kind.

original: tīsu bhūmīsu saññāya viya oḷārikāya abhāvato. Sukhumāyāti saṅkhārāvasesasukhumabhāvappattiyā🔽sukhumāya saññāya bhāvato vijjamānattā. Nevasaññāti ettha na-kāro abhāvattho, nāsaññanti
analyzed: tīsu bhūmīsu saññāya viya oḷārikāya abhāvato sukhumāya ati saṅkhāra avasesa sukhuma bhāva ppattiyā  sukhumāya saññāya bhāvataḥ vijjamāna ttā na ivasaññā iti ettha nakāraḥ abhāva atthaḥ na asaññam ti
translated: Because of the presence of subtle perception, that is, because of the attainment of the subtle state of the residual formation.🔽Herein, the negative particle na in the compound nevasaññā has the meaning of non-existence, while the negative particle na in the compound asaññā has the meaning of otherness, and the negative particle na in the compound nāsaññā has the meaning of non-existence. The meaning is: neither perception nor non-perception.

original: ettha na-kāro aññattho, a-kāro abhāvatthova, asaññaṃ anasaññañcāti attho. Pariyāpannattāti
analyzed: ettha nakāraḥ añña tthaḥ akāraḥ abhāva tthaḥ uva asaññam an asaññam ca ati attho pariyāpanna ttā ati
translated: Because of inclusion,🔽because of being included by way of a part. Herein, in the fourth immaterial state.

original: ekadesabhāvena antogadhattā. Etthāti catutthāruppe. Dutiye atthavikappe nevasaññāti
analyzed: eka desa bhāvena ettha ati catuttha āruppe dutiye attha vikappe na ivasaññā ti
translated: In the second interpretation, the negative particle na in the compound nevasaññā has the meaning of otherness.

original: ettha na-kāro aññattho. Tathā nāsaññāti ettha na-kāro, a-kāro ca aññattho evāti tena
analyzed: ettha nakāraḥ aññattho tathā nāsaññā ti ettha nakāro akāro ca aññattho eva ati tena
translated: Likewise, the negative particle na in the compound nāsaññā and the negative particle na in the compound asaññā have the meaning of otherness. Therefore

original: dvayena saññābhāvo eva dassitoti dhammāyatanapariyāpannatāya āyatanabhāvo vuttovāti
analyzed: dvayena saññā bhāvaḥ eva dassito ti dhammāyatana pariyāpanna tāya āyatana bhāvaḥ vuttaḥ uvā ati
translated: by these two compounds only the absence of perception is indicated. Thus the state of being a base is mentioned because of its inclusion in the mental-data base.

original: “adhiṭṭhānaṭṭhenā”ti vuttaṃ nissayapaccayabhāvato.
analyzed: adhiṭṭhāna ṭṭhena iti vuttam nissaya paccaya bhāvato
translated: “Because of the meaning of determination” is said because of the condition being a decisive-support condition.

original: Kiṃ pana kāraṇaṃ, yenettha saññāva edisī jātāti anuyogaṃ sandhāyāha “na kevala”ntiādi.
analyzed: kim pana kāraṇam yena ittha edisī jātā ati anuyogam sandhāya āha na kevala ntiādi
translated: But what is the reason that perception is of this kind here? Anticipating this question, he says, “Not only” and so on.

original: Saññāsīsenāyaṃ desanā katā “nānattakāyā nānattasaññino”tiādīsu viyāti daṭṭhabbaṃ.🔽Evaṃ esa atthoti kañci visesaṃ upādāya sabhāvato atthīti vattabbasseva dhammassa
analyzed: saññā sīsena ayam desanā katā nānatta kāyāḥ nānatta saññino ti ādīsu viya ati daṭṭhabbam  evam esa atthaḥ ti kañci visesam upādāya sabhāvataḥ atthi iti vattabbassa iva dhammassa
translated: The teaching is given by way of the perception faculty, as in the case of the teaching that “some have different bodies and different perceptions” .🔽So this is the meaning.

original: kañci visesaṃ upādāya natthīti vattabbatāsaṅkhāto attho.
analyzed: kañci visesam upādāya natthi iti vattabba tā saṅkhātaḥ atthaḥ
translated: The meaning is the state of being describable as “non-existent” in respect of some particular mode of the same state of being describable as “existent” in respect of another particular mode.

original: Atithokampi yaṃ telamatthi bhanteti āha akappiyabhāvaṃ upādāya, tadeva natthi, bhante, telanti āha nāḷipūraṇaṃ upādāya. Tenāha “tattha yathā”tiādi.
analyzed: yam telam atthi bhante ti āha akappiya bhāvam upādāya tat eva natthi bhante telam ti āha nāḷi pūraṇam upādāya tena āha tattha yathā itiādi
translated: “There is no oil, venerable sir,” he said, referring to the fact that it was not allowable; “there is oil, venerable sir,” he said, referring to the filling of the tube. That is why the Master said, “Herein, just as … ” .

original: Yadi ārammaṇasañjānanaṃ saññākiccaṃ, taṃ saññā samānā kathamayaṃ kātuṃ na sakkotīti🔽āha “dahanakiccamivā”tiādi. Saṅkhārāvasesasukhumabhāvappattiyā eva hesā paṭusaññākiccaṃ
analyzed: yadi ārammaṇa sañjānanam saññā kiccam tam saññā samānā katham ayam kātum na sakkoti iti  āha dahana kiccam iva ati ādi saṅkhāra avasesa sukhuma bhāva ppattiyā eva ha isā paṭu saññā kiccam
translated: If the function of perceiving is the function of perception, then how is it that perception cannot perform that function?

original: kātuṃ na sakkoti, tato eva ca ñāṇassa sugayhāpi na hoti. Tenāha “nibbidājananampi
analyzed: kātum na sakkoti tatas eva ca ñāṇassa sugayhā api na hoti tena āha nibbidā jananam pi
translated: He says, “Just as … ” . For it is unable to perform the function of gross perception because it has reached the state of subtle residual formations. And for that very reason it is not easy for knowledge to approach it either. That is why he said, “The arousing of dispassion … ” .

original: kātuṃ na sakkotī”ti. Akatābhinivesoti akatavipassanābhiniveso appavattitasammasanacāro.🔽Pakativipassakoti pakatiyā vipassako. Khandhādimukhena vipassanaṃ abhinivisitvā dvārālambanehi
analyzed: kātum na sakkoti iti akata abhinivesaḥ ti akata vipassanā abhinivesaḥ appavattita sammasana cāro  pakati vipassakaḥ ti pakatiyā vipassakaḥ khandha ādi mukhena vipassanam abhinivisitvā dvāra ālambanehi
translated: Who has not yet made a choice: who has not yet made a choice about insight, who has not yet begun the process of reflection.🔽One who is a natural abider in insight: one who is a natural abider in insight in the sense of one who has made insight his habit.

original: saddhiṃ dvārappavattadhammānaṃ vipassako sakkuṇeyya tabbisayaudayabbayañāṇaṃ uppādetuṃ,
analyzed: saddhim dvāra ppavatta dhammānam vipassakaḥ sakkuṇeyya tad visaya udaya bbaya ñāṇam uppādetum
translated: Having made insight his choice by way of the aggregates, etc., he is one who can generate knowledge of rise and fall with respect to the states occurring through the doors together with the doors as objects.🔽But in order to show how he can do so, the text says, “He too, etc.”

original: yathā pana sakkoti, taṃ dassetuṃ “sopī”tiādi vuttaṃ. Kalāpasammasanavasenevāti catutthāruppacittuppādapariyāpanne🔽phassādidhamme avinibbhujja ekato gahetvā kalāpato samūhato sammasanavasena nayavipassanāsaṅkhātakalāpasammasanavasena.
analyzed: yathā pana sakkoti tam dassetum saḥ api itiādi vuttam kalāpa sammasana vasena iva āti catuttha āruppa cittuppāda pariyāpanne  phassa ādi dhamme a vinibbhujja ekatas gahetvā kalāpato samūhato sammasana vasena naya vipassanā saṅkhāta kalāpa sammasana vasena
translated: By the method of reflection on the clusters: by the method of reflection on the clusters called “sequential insight.”🔽The reflection on the states of contact, etc., without distinguishing them, taking them as a whole, as a cluster,🔽is called “reflection on the states without distinguishing them.” The reflection on the states of contact, etc., by distinguishing them, taking them individually,

original: Phassādidhamme vinibbhujjitvā visuṃ visuṃ sarūpato gahetvā aniccādivasena sammasanaṃ
analyzed: phassa ādi dhamme vinibbhujjitvā visum visum sarūpataḥ gahetvā anicca ādi vasena sammasanam
translated: is called “reflection on the states by distinguishing them.”

original: anupadadhammavipassanā. Evaṃ sukhumattaṃ gatā yathā dhammasenāpatināpi nāma anupadaṃ
analyzed: anupada dhamma vipassanā evam sukhuma ttam gatā yathā dhammasenāpatinā api nāma anupadam
translated: So subtle does it become that it cannot be reflected upon even by the General of the Dhamma, the Elder Sāriputta.

original: na vipassaneyyāti attho.
analyzed: na vipassaneyyā ti attho
translated: The meaning is that it cannot be reflected upon by anyone.

original: Therassāti aññatarassa therassa. Aññāhipīti ettha ayamaparā upamā – eko kira brāhmaṇo
analyzed: therassa ati aññatarassa therassa ettha ayam aparā upamā ekaḥ kira brāhmaṇaḥ
translated: To a certain elder: to a certain elder. Also in other ways: here is another simile. A certain brahmin,

original: aññataraṃ purisaṃ manuññaṃ mattikabhājanaṃ gahetvā ṭhitaṃ disvā yāci “dehi me imaṃ🔽bhājana”nti. So surāsittataṃ sandhāya “nāyyo sakkā dātuṃ, surā ettha atthī”ti āha.
