analyzed: aññataram purisam manuññam mattika bhājanam gahetvā ṭhitam disvā yāci dehi me imaṃ  saḥ surāsittatam sandhāya nāyyaḥ sakkā dātum surā ettha atthi iti āha
translated: To a certain elder: to a certain elder. Also in other ways: here is another simile. A brahmin, it seems, saw a man standing nearby holding a clay pot. He asked him, “Give me that pot.” “I cannot give it, sir, there is liquor in it.”

original: Brāhmaṇo attano samīpe ṭhitaṃ purisaṃ uddissa āha “tena hi imassa pātuṃ dehī”ti.🔽Itaro “natthayyo”ti āha. Tattha yathā brāhmaṇassa ayogyabhāvaṃ upādāya “atthī”tipi
analyzed: brāhmaṇaḥ attanaḥ samīpe ṭhitam purisam uddissa āha tena hi imassa pātum dehi iti  itaraḥ āha tattha yathā brāhmaṇassa ayogya bhāvam upādāya atthi iti pi
translated: The brahmin said to the man standing near him, “Well then, give him some to drink.”

original: vattabbaṃ, pātabbatāya tattha abhāvato “natthī”tipi vattabbaṃ jātaṃ, evaṃ idhāpīti daṭṭhabbaṃ.🔽Kasmā panettha yathā heṭṭhā “ananto ākāso, anantaṃ viññāṇaṃ, natthi kiñcī”ti tattha
analyzed: vattabbam pātabbatāya tattha abhāvataḥ natthi iti pi vattabbam jātam evam idha api iti daṭṭhabbam  kasmā pana ittha yathā heṭṭhā anantaḥ ākāsaḥ anantam viññāṇam na atthi kiñci iti tattha
translated: The other said, “No, sir.” Herein, just as it is proper to say “There is” because of the brahmin’s unfitness, and it is proper to say “There is not” because of the absence of anything to drink there, so it is here too.

original: tattha bhāvanākāro gahito, evaṃ koci bhāvanākāro na gahitoti? Keci tāva āhu – “bhāvanākāro
analyzed: tattha bhāvanā ākāraḥ gahito evam koci bhāvanā ākāraḥ na gahitaḥ iti keci tāva āhu bhāvanā ākāraḥ
translated: But why is no aspect of development mentioned here as it is in the passages beginning, “Infinite is the consciousness element, infinite is the realm of infinite consciousness, there is nothing beyond” ?🔽Some say that the aspect of development is implied by the words “There is nothing beyond.”

original: nāma sopacārassa jhānassa yathāsakaṃ ārammaṇe pavattiākāro, ārammaṇañcettha ākiñcaññāyatanadhammā.🔽Te pana gayhamānā ekassa vā pubbaṅgamadhammassa vasena gahetabbā siyuṃ, sabbe eva
analyzed: nāma sa upacārassa jhānassa yathāsakam ārammaṇe pavatti ākāraḥ ārammaṇam ca ittha ākiñcaññāyatana dhammā  te pana gayhamānāḥ ekassa vā pubbaṅgama dhammassa vasena gahetabbā siyum sabbe eva
translated: The mode of occurrence of the jhāna with its associated states in its object is its mode of thought. And here the object is the fine-material dhammas of the base consisting of boundless space.

original: vā. Tattha paṭhamapakkhe viññāṇassa gahaṇaṃ āpannanti ‘viññāṇaṃ viññāṇa’nti manasikāre🔽catutthāruppassa viññāṇañcāyatanabhāvo āpajjati. Dutiyapakkhe pana sabbaso ākiñcaññāyatanadhammārammaṇatāya
analyzed: vā tattha paṭhama pakkhe viññāṇassa gahaṇam āpannanti viññāṇam viññāṇanti manasikāre  catuttha āruppassa viññāṇañcāyatana bhāvo āpajjati dutiya pakkhe pana sabbaso ākiñcaññāyatana dhamma ārammaṇa tāya
translated: But when they are apprehended, they can be apprehended either as the property of one of them or as the property of all of them. Herein, in the first instance, when the apprehending of consciousness has come about in one who has given attention to “consciousness, consciousness,”🔽the fourth-jhāna attainment comes to have the nature of the base consisting of boundless consciousness. But in the second instance, when the apprehending of the base consisting of nothingness has come about in one who has given attention to “nothingness, nothingness,”

original: jhānassa ‘ākiñcaññaṃ ākiñcañña’nti manasikāre ākiñcaññāyatanatā vā siyā, abhāvārammaṇatā🔽vā. Sabbathā nevasaññānāsaññāyatanabhāvo na labbhatī”ti. Tadidamakāraṇaṃ tathā jhānassa
analyzed: jhānassa ākiñcaññam ākiñcaññanti manasikāre ākiñcañña āyatana tā vā siyā abhāva ārammaṇa tā  vā sabbathā nevasaññānāsaññāyatana bhāvaḥ na labbhati iti tat idam akāraṇam tathā jhānassa
translated: the fourth-jhāna attainment comes to have the nature either of the base consisting of nothingness or of the base consisting of the infinitude of space, which is the object consisting of non-existence.🔽But the nature of the base consisting of neither perception nor non-perception is not possible at all.

original: appavattanato. Na hi catutthāruppabhāvanā viññāṇamākiñcaññaṃ vā āmasantī pavattati,
analyzed: appavattanataḥ na hi catuttha āruppa bhāvanā viññāṇam ākiñcaññam vā āmasantī pavattati
translated: This is not a reason, because the jhāna does not occur in that way. For the development of the fourth immaterial state does not occur by touching consciousness or nothingness;

original: kiñcarahi? Tatiyāruppassa santataṃ.
analyzed: kiñcarahi tatiya āruppassa santatam
translated: but rather by touching the continuum of the third immaterial state.

original: Yadi evaṃ, kasmā pāḷiyaṃ “santa”nti na gahitanti? Kiñcāpi na gahitataṃ sutte, vibhaṅge
analyzed: yadi evam kasmai na kiñca api na sutte vibhaṅge
translated: If that is so, why is it not included in the text? —Although it is not included in the sutta,🔽it is included in the Vibhaṅga,

original: pana gahitameva. Yathāha – “taññeva ākiñcaññāyatanaṃ santato manasi karoti, saṅkhārāvasesasamāpattiṃ
analyzed: pana gahitam eva yathā āha tat ñeva ākiñcaññāyatanam santataḥ manasi karoti saṅkhāra avasesa samāpattim
translated: where it is said: “He gives attention to the base consisting of nothingness as peaceful; he develops the attainment with residual formations” .

original: bhāvetī”ti. Atha kasmā vibhaṅge viya sutte bhāvanākāro na gahitoti? Veneyyajjhāsayato,🔽desanāvilāsato ca. Ye hi veneyyā yathā heṭṭhā tīsu āruppesu “ananto ākāso, anantaṃ🔽viññāṇaṃ, natthi kiñcī”ti bhāvanākāro gahito, evaṃ aggahite eva tasmiṃ tamatthaṃ
analyzed: bhāveti iti atha kasmā vibhaṅge viya sutte bhāvanā ākāraḥ na gahito ti  desanā vilāsato ca ye hi veneyyāḥ yathā heṭṭhā tīsu āruppesu anantaḥ ākāsaḥ anantam  viññāṇam na atthi kiñci iti bhāvanā ākāraḥ gahitaḥ evam aggahite eva tasmin tam attham
translated: But why is the mode of development not given in the sutta as it is in the Vibhaṅga? —Because of the inclination of those susceptible of teaching,🔽and because of the elegance of the teaching.

original: paṭivijjhanti, tesaṃ vasena sutte tathā desanā katā, suttantagatikāva abhidhamme🔽suttantabhājanīye uddesadesanā. Ye pana veneyyā vibhajitvā vutteyeva tasmiṃ tamatthaṃ
analyzed: paṭivijjhanti tesam vasena sutte tathā desanā katā abhidhamme  suttanta bhājanīye uddesa desanāḥ ye pana veneyyāḥ vibhajitvā vuttā iya iva tasmin tam attham
translated: For those susceptible of teaching who are like those mentioned above in the case of the first three immaterial states, namely, “Infinite space … down to … he enters upon and dwells in the base consisting of nothingness,” understand the meaning when the mode of development is stated thus. The teaching is given in the sutta accordingly for their sake. For those who follow the suttas the teaching in the Abhidhamma is a help in the suttas.

original: paṭivijjhanti, tesaṃ vasena vibhaṅge bhāvanākāro vutto. Dhammissaro pana bhagavā
analyzed: paṭivijjhanti tesam vasena vibhaṅge bhāvanā kāraḥ vuttaḥ dhammissaraḥ pana bhagavā
translated: But those susceptible of teaching who understand the meaning when the mode of development is stated in the Vibhaṅga thus, “He gives attention to the base consisting of nothingness as peaceful; he develops the attainment with residual formations,” are taught in the Vibhaṅga accordingly. The Blessed One, the Lord of the Dhamma,

original: sammāsambuddho dhammānaṃ desetabbappakāraṃ jānanto katthaci bhāvanākāraṃ gaṇhāti,🔽katthaci bhāvanākāraṃ na gaṇhāti. Sā ca desanā yāvadeva veneyyavinayatthāti ayamettha🔽desanāvilāso. Suttantadesanā vā pariyāyakathāti tattha bhāvanākāro na gahito, abhidhammadesanā
analyzed: sammāsambuddhaḥ dhammānam desetabba ppakāram jānantaḥ katthaci bhāvanā ākāram gaṇhāti  katthaci bhāvanā ākāram na gaṇhāti sā ca desanā yāvat eva ayam ettha  desanā vilāsaḥ suttanta desanā vā pariyāya kathā ti tattha bhāvanā ākāraḥ na gahitaḥ abhidhamma desanā
translated: The Fully Enlightened One, knowing the way in which ideas should be taught, sometimes takes the aspect of development into account,🔽sometimes he does not. And that teaching is only for the purpose of disciplining those who need training. This is the

original: pana nippariyāyakathāti tattha bhāvanākāro gahitoti evampettha bhāvanākārassa gahaṇe,🔽aggahaṇe ca kāraṇaṃ veditabbaṃ.
analyzed: pana nippariyāya kathā ati tattha bhāvanā ākāraḥ gahito ti evam pa ittha bhāvanā ākārassa gahaṇe  aggahaṇe ca kāraṇam veditabbam
translated: display of teaching here. Or else the teaching of the sutta is a teaching by way of a method, and so the aspect of development is not taken into account there. But the teaching of the Abhidhamma is a teaching without a method, and so the aspect of development is taken into account there. So the reason for the taking into account and for not taking into account the aspect of development should be understood here in this way.

original: Apare pana bhaṇanti – “catutthāruppe visesadassanatthaṃ sutte bhāvanākārassa aggahaṇaṃ,🔽svāyaṃ viseso anupubbabhāvanājanito. Sā ca anupubbabhāvanā pahānakkamopajanitā pahātabbasamatikkamena
analyzed: apare pana bhaṇanti catuttha āruppe visesa dassana attham sutte bhāvanā kārassa aggahaṇam  svā ayam visesaḥ anupubba bhāvanā janitaḥ sā ca anupubba bhāvanā pahāna kkama upajanitā pahātabba samatikkamena
translated: But others say that the aspect of development is not taken into account in the sutta for the purpose of showing the difference in the fourth jhana.🔽And this difference is due to successive development. And that successive development is due to the order of abandoning.🔽The jhanas are to be reached by surmounting what should be abandoned. For it is in this way that they are reached by the means of the outlet consisting in the surmounting of the hindrances, which are to be abandoned, in the way beginning with “Quite secluded from sense desires, secluded from unprofitable things” ,

original: jhānānaṃ adhigantabbato. Tathā hi kāmādivivekavitakkavicāravūpasamapītivirāgasomanassatthaṅgamamukhena
analyzed: jhānānaṃ adhigantabbato tathā hi kāma ādi viveka vitakka vicāra vūpasama pīti virāga so manassa atthaṅgama mukhena
translated: and in the way beginning with “By special development of the jhanas” .

original: rūpāvacarajjhānāni desitāni, rūpasaññādisamatikkamamukhena arūpajjhānāni. Na kevalañca
analyzed: rūpāvacara jhānāni desitāni rūpa saññā ādi samatikkama mukhena arūpa jhānāni na kevalam ca
translated: The jhānas of the fine-material sphere are taught by the method of surmounting perception of matter, etc., and the immaterial jhānas by the method of surmounting perception of the fine-material sphere.

original: jhānāniyeva, atha kho sabbampi sīlaṃ, sabbāpi paññā paṭipakkhadhammappahānavaseneva🔽sampādetabbato pahātabbadhammasamatikkamadassanamukheneva desanā āruḷhā. Tathā hi
analyzed: jhānāniyā iva atha kho sabbam pi sīlam sabbā api paññā paṭipakkha dhamma ppahāna vasena iva  sampādetabbataḥ pahātabba dhamma samatikkama dassana mukhena iva desanā āruḷhā tathā hi
translated: And not only the jhānas, but also all virtue and all understanding are taught by the method of surmounting states to be abandoned,🔽because they are all accomplished by abandoning their opposites.🔽For the restraint of virtue is taught thus: “Having abandoned the destruction of life, he abstains from the destruction of life” , etc.

original: “pāṇātipātaṃ pahāya pāṇātipātā paṭivirato”tiādinā sīlasaṃvaro, “cakkhunā rūpaṃ disvā
analyzed: pāṇa atipātam pahāya pāṇa atipātā paṭivirataḥ iti ādinā sīla saṃvaro cakkhunā rūpam disvā
translated: The restraint of the faculties is taught thus: “On seeing a visible object with the eye, he apprehends neither the signs nor the particulars through which, on seeing a visible object, a bhikkhu might be intent on visible objects and pursue the enjoyment of them” , etc.

original: na nimittaggāhī hoti nānubyañjanaggāhī”tiādinā indriyasaṃvaro, “neva davāya na madāyā”tiādinā
analyzed: na nimitta ggāhī na anubyañjana ggāhī iti ādinā indriya saṃvaraḥ na iva davāya na madāya ati ādinā
translated: The moderation in eating is taught thus: “Not for amusement, for intoxication, for smartening, for beautification” , etc.

original: bhojane mattaññutā, “idha bhikkhu micchājīvaṃ pahāya sammāājīvena jīvikaṃ kappetī”tiādinā
analyzed: bhojane mattaññu tā idha bhikkhu micchājīvam pahāya sammāājīvena jīvikam kappeti itiādinā
translated: The purification of livelihood is taught thus: “Here a bhikkhu, having abandoned wrong livelihood, earns his living by right livelihood” , etc.

original: ājīvapārisuddhi, “abhijjhaṃ loke pahāya vigatābhijjhena cetasā”tiādinā jāgariyānuyogo,
analyzed: ājīva pārisuddhi abhijjham loke pahāya vigata abhijjhena cetasā ati ādinā jāgariya anuyogaḥ
translated: The undertaking of the practice of waking in the first watch of the night and in the last watch of the night is taught thus: “Having abandoned covetousness for the world, he abides with a mind free from covetousness” , etc.

original: “aniccasaññā bhāvetabbā asmimānasamugghātāya, aniccasaññino, meghiya, anattasaññā
analyzed: anicca saññā bhāvetabbā asmimāna samugghātāya anicca saññinaḥ anatta saññā
translated: The development of the perception of impermanence is taught thus: “The perception of impermanence, Meghiya, when developed and cultivated, leads to the abandoning of the conceit ‘I am’ …

original: saṇṭhāti, anattasaññī asmimānasamugghātaṃ gacchati, āsavānaṃ khayā anāsavaṃ cetovimuttiṃ
analyzed: saṇṭhāti anatta saññī gacchati āsavānam khayā anāsavam cetaḥ vimuttim
translated: he attains to the destruction of the taints.🔽With the destruction of the taints, he directly experiences Nirvana.

original: paññāvimuttiṃ diṭṭheva dhamme sayaṃ abhiññā sacchikatvā upasampajja viharatī”tiādinā🔽paññā paṭipakkhadhammappahānavaseneva desitā. Tasmā jhānāni desento bhagavā “vivicceva🔽kāmehī”tiādinā pahātabbadhammasamatikkamadassanamukheneva desesi. Tena vuttaṃ “kāmādivivekavitakkavicāravūpasamapītivirāgasomanassatthaṅgamamukhena
analyzed: paññā vimuttim diṭṭhe iva dhamme sayam abhiññā sacchikatvā upasampajja viharati itiādinā  paññā paṭipakkha dhamma ppahāna vasena iva desitā tasmā jhānāni desentaḥ bhagavā vivicca iva  kāmehi itiādinā pahātabba dhamma samatikkama dassana mukhena iva desesi tena vuttam kāma ādi viveka vitakka vicāra vūpasama pīti virāga so manassa atthaṅgama mukhena
translated: and he attains to the resolution of the conceit “I am,” and he enters upon and abides in that liberation of mind, liberation by wisdom, which is in each case in accordance with reality, having directly known and realized it for himself in this very life. ’🔽So it is taught by way of the abandoning of the opposite states.🔽Therefore, when teaching the jhānas, the Blessed One taught them by way of showing the surmounting of the states to be surmounted, with the words ‘quite secluded from sense desires, secluded from unprofitable things’ .

original: rūpāvacarajjhānāni desitāni, rūpasaññādisamatikkamamukhena arūpajjhānānī”ti. Tattha🔽yathā rūpāvacaraṃ paṭhamaṃ jhānaṃ bhāvanāvisesādhigatehi vitakkādīhi viya saddhādīhipi
analyzed: rūpāvacara jhānāni desitāni rūpa saññā ādi samatikkama mukhena arūpa jhānāni iti tattha  yathā rūpāvacaram paṭhamam jhānam bhāvanā visesa adhigatehi vitakka ādīhi saddhā ādīhi pi
translated: So it was said by the Blessed One that the jhānas of the fine-material sphere are taught by way of the outlet from sense desires, and the immaterial jhānas by way of the outlet from materiality.🔽Herein,🔽just as the first fine-material jhāna is possessed of the states of applied thought, etc., that are acquired by the special development of faith, etc.,

original: tikkhavisadasūrasabhāvehi dhammehi samannāgatattā kāmacchandādīnaṃ nīvaraṇānaṃ, tadekaṭṭhānañca
analyzed: tikkha visada sūrasa bhāvehi dhammehi samannāgata ttā kāmacchanda ādīnam nīvaraṇānam tad eka ṭṭhānam ca
translated: so it is also possessed of states of the opposite kind that are purified, bright, pure, and clean, since it is possessed of the states of applied thought, etc., that are acquired by the special development of faith, etc.,

original: pāpadhammānaṃ vikkhambhanato uttarimanussadhammabhāvappattaṃ kāmāvacaradhammehi saṇhasukhumaṃ,
analyzed: pāpa dhammānam vikkhambhanataḥ uttari manussa dhamma bhāva ppattam kāmāvacara dhammehi saṇha sukhumam
translated: It is peaceful and sublime because it is the opposite of the gross states of the sense sphere.

original: santaṃ, paṇītañca hoti; dutiyajjhānādīni pana bhāvanāvisesena oḷārikaṅgappahānato
analyzed: santam paṇītam ca hoti dutiya jhāna ādīni pana bhāvanā visesena oḷārika aṅga pahānato
translated: But the second jhāna, etc., are more and more subtle and more and more peaceful and sublime as the respective gross factors disappear through the different kinds of development.🔽So too, the immaterial states

original: tato sātisayaṃ saṇhasukhumasaṇhasukhumatarādibhāvappattāni honti. Tathā arūpāvacaraṃ🔽paṭhamajjhānaṃ rūpavirāgabhāvanābhāvena pavattamānaṃ ārammaṇasantatāyapi aṅgasantatāyapi
analyzed: tato sa atisayam saṇha sukhuma saṇha sukhumatara ādi bhāva ppattāni honti tathā arūpāvacaram  paṭhamajjhānam rūpa virāga bhāvanā bhāvena pavattamānam ārammaṇa santatāya api aṅga santatāya api
translated: are more and more subtle and more and more peaceful and sublime as the respective gross objects disappear through the different kinds of development.

original: pākatikaparittadhammehi viya sabbarūpāvacaradhammehi santasukhumabhāvappattaṃ hoti.🔽Ārammaṇasantabhāvenāpi hi tadārammaṇadhammā santasabhāvā honti, seyyathāpi lokuttaradhammārammaṇā dhammā.
analyzed: pākatika paritta dhammehi viya sabba rūpāvacara dhammehi santa sukhuma bhāva ppattam hoti  ārammaṇa santa bhāvena api hi tad ārammaṇa dhammā santa sabhāvāḥ honti seyyathā api lokuttara dhamma ārammaṇāḥ dhammāḥ
translated: The first jhāna, which occurs with the support of the first-jhāna fine-material-sphere object, is peaceful and sublime compared with the kinds of states belonging to the fine-material sphere, like natural things that are already subtle and fine compared with gross things.🔽For the states that have that as their object are peaceful and sublime too, like the supramundane states that have the supramundane states as their object.

original: Satipi dhammato, mahaggatabhāvenāpi ca abhede rūpāvacaracatutthato āruppaṃ aṅgatopi
analyzed: sati api dhammataḥ mahaggata bhāvena api ca abhede rūpāvacara catutthataḥ āruppam aṅgataḥ pi
translated: And although there is no difference in their excellence, the immaterial states are more peaceful and sublime than the fine-material-sphere states because of the difference in their objects.

original: santameva, yatassa santavimokkhatā vuttā. Dutiyāruppādīni pana paṭhamāruppādito aṅgato,
analyzed: santam eva yatassa santa vimokkha tā vuttā dutiya āruppa ādīni pana paṭhama āruppa āditaḥ aṅgato
translated: and it is this that is called the “peaceful liberation.” The second absorption, etc., are to be understood as the second, third, and fourth liberations respectively.

original: ārammaṇato ca santasantatarasantatamabhāvappattāni tathā bhāvanāvisesasamāyogato,
analyzed: ārammaṇato ca santa santatara santatama bhāva ppattāni tathā bhāvanā visesa samāyogato
translated: and it is called “peaceful” because it has the peacefulness of the deliverance . But the second, third, and fourth immaterial states are more and more peaceful than the preceding one both because of the object and because of the support,🔽because of the combination of the particular kind of development.

original: svāyaṃ bhāvanāviseso paṭhamajjhānūpacārato paṭṭhāya taṃtaṃpahātabbasamatikkamanavasena
analyzed: svā ayam bhāvanā visesaḥ paṭhama jhānu upacārataḥ paṭṭhāya tat tat pahātabba samatikkamana vasena
translated: And this particular kind of development is the bringing about of the more and more peaceful and sublime state of each jhāna by surmounting the particular imperfection in each case, starting from the first jhāna’s proximity to states partaking of distraction.

original: tassa tassa jhānassa santasukhumabhāvaṃ āpādento catutthāruppe saṅkhārāvasesasukhumabhāvaṃ
analyzed: tassa tassa jhānassa santa sukhuma bhāvam āpādento catuttha āruppe saṅkhāra avasesa sukhuma bhāvam
translated: So it brings about the more and more subtle state consisting in the remainder of formations in the fourth immaterial state.

original: pāpeti. Yato catutthāruppaṃ yathā anupadadhammavipassanāvasena vipassanāya ārammaṇabhāvaṃ
analyzed: pāpa iti yatas catuttha āruppam yathā anupada dhamma vipassanā vasena vipassanāya ārammaṇa bhāvam
translated: For the fourth immaterial state does not become the object of insight leading to emergence in one who is a pure insight worker,

original: upagantvā pakativipassakassāpi nibbiduppattiyā paccayo na hoti saṅkhārāvasesasukhumabhāvappattito,
analyzed: upagantvā pakati vipassakassa api nibbid uppattiyā paccayaḥ na hoti saṅkhāra avasesa sukhuma bhāva ppattito
translated: because it is so subtle owing to the subtlety of the remainder of formations, and it cannot then be a condition for the arousing of dispassion.

original: tathā sayaṃ tatiyāruppadhammesu pavattamānaṃ te yāthāvato vibhāvetuṃ na sakkoti,
analyzed: tathā sayam tatiya āruppa dhammesu pavattamānam te yāthāvataḥ vibhāvetum na sakkoti
translated: And so too, when it occurs in the third immaterial state, it cannot then discern those states as they are because of the subtlety of the object.

original: yathā tadaññajjhānāni attano ārammaṇaṃ. Kevalaṃ pana ārabbha pavattimattamevassa
analyzed: yathā tad añña jhānāni attanaḥ ārammaṇam kevalam pana ārabbha pavattimattam eva assa
translated: It occurs only as mere occurrence in dependence on the object,

original: tattha hoti, tayidaṃ ārammaṇabhāvenāpi nāma vibhūtākāratāya ṭhātuṃ appahontaṃ ārammaṇakaraṇe
analyzed: tattha hoti tayidam ārammaṇa bhāvena api nāma vibhūta ākāra tāya ṭhātum ārammaṇa karaṇe
translated: Herein, since it is unable to stand in the aspect of the sign’s being evident, how can it be able to do so when it is made the object?

original: kiṃ pahoti. Tasmā tadassa avibhūtakiccataṃ disvā satthā heṭṭhā tīsu ṭhānesu bhāvanākāraṃ🔽vatvā tādiso idha na labbhatīti dīpetuṃ catutthāruppadesanāyaṃ sutte bhāvanākāraṃ
analyzed: kim tasmā tad assa avibhūta kicca tam disvā satthā heṭṭhā tīsu ṭhānesu bhāvanā ākāram  vatvā tādisaḥ idha na labbhati iti dīpetum sutte bhāvanā kāram
translated: So the teacher, seeing that its function is not evident, taught the mode of its development in the first three instances below,

original: pariyāyadesanattā na kathesi.🔽Yasmā pana sārammaṇassa dhammassa ārammaṇe pavattiākāro atthevāti atisukhumabhāvappattaṃ🔽taṃ dassetuṃ “taṃyeva ākiñcaññāyatanaṃ santato manasi karotī”ti vibhaṅge vuttaṃ yathādhammasāsanabhāvato,
analyzed: pariyāya desanattā na kathesi  yasmā pana sārammaṇassa dhammassa ārammaṇe pavatti ākāro attha eva ati ati sukhuma bhāva ppattam  tam dassetum tam yeva ākiñcaññāyatanam santataḥ manasi karoti iti vibhaṅge vuttam yathā dhamma sāsana bhāvato
translated: and in order to show that such a mode is not found here, he did not teach the mode of development in the fourth instance in the sutta, because the teaching there is by way of a roundabout way.🔽But since the occurrence of an object in the sign is a fact, he showed that it has reached extreme subtlety by saying in the Vibhaṅga, “He brings to mind that same base consisting of nothingness as peaceful” ,

original: pubbabhāgavasena vā vibhaṅge “santato manasi karotī”ti vuttaṃ tadā yogino tassa vibhūtabhāvato.
analyzed: pubba bhāga vasena vā vibhaṅge santataḥ manasi karoti iti vuttam tadā yoginaḥ tassa vibhūta bhāvato
translated: and he said in the Vibhaṅga, “He brings to mind that same base consisting of nothingness as peaceful” in the sense of the prior stage, or else in the sense of the jhāna’s being peaceful because of the stilling of the agitation that occurred in the prior stage.

original: Appanāvasena pana sutte bhāvanākāro na gahito avibhūtabhāvato. Kammaṭṭhānaṃ hi kiñci
analyzed: appanā vasena pana sutte bhāvanā ākāraḥ na gahitaḥ avibhūta bhāvato kammaṭṭhānam hi kiñci
translated: But in the sutta the mode of development by way of absorption is not given, because that is not evident there. For the meditation subject is either

original: ādito avibhūtaṃ hoti, yathā taṃ? Buddhānussatiādi. Kiñci majjhe, yathā taṃ? Ānāpānassati.🔽Kiñci ubhayattha, yathā taṃ? Upasamānussatiādi. Catutthāruppakammaṭṭhānaṃ pana pariyosāne
analyzed: āditas avibhūtam hoti yathā tam buddha anussati ādi kiñci majjhe yathā tam āna apāna ssati  ubhayattha yathā tam upasama anussati ādi catuttha āruppa kammaṭṭhānam pana pariyosāne
translated: It is not analyzed at the beginning, as in the case of the recollection of the Buddha, etc. It is not analyzed in the middle, as in the case of mindfulness of breathing.🔽It is not analyzed at the end, as in the case of the fourth immaterial attainment.

original: avibhūtaṃ bhāvanāya matthakappattiyaṃ ārammaṇassa avibhūtabhāvato. Tasmā catutthāruppe🔽imaṃ visesaṃ dassetuṃ satthārā sutte bhāvanākāro na gahito, na sabbena sabbaṃ abhāvatoti
analyzed: avibhūtam bhāvanāya matthaka ppattiyam ārammaṇassa avibhūta bhāvato tasmā catuttha āruppe  imam visesam dassetum satthārā sutte bhāvanā ākāraḥ na gahitaḥ na sabbena sabbam abhāvato ti
translated: For the object of the fourth immaterial attainment is not analyzed because it has reached the peak of development in the meditation.🔽Therefore, in order to point out this difference, the method of development has not been stated by the Master in the sutta.

original: niṭṭhamettha gantabbaṃ.
analyzed: niṭṭham ettha gantabbam
translated: It should be understood that it is not because it does not exist in all ways.

original: Pakiṇṇakakathāvaṇṇanā🔽288. Asadisarūpoti dvattiṃsamahāpurisalakkhaṇaasītianubyañjanabyāmappabhāketumālādīhi
analyzed: pakiṇṇaka kathā vaṇṇanā  asadisa rūpaḥ ti
translated: The explanation of the miscellaneous discussion.

original: rūpaguṇehi aññehi asādhāraṇarūpakāyo, sabhāvattho vā rūpa-saddo “yaṃ loke piyarūpaṃ
analyzed: rūpa guṇehi aññehi asādhāraṇa rūpa kāyaḥ sabhāva tthaḥ vā rūpa saddaḥ yam loke piya rūpam
translated: The incomparable form: the incomparable form is the incomparable nature. The word “form” has the meaning of “nature” in the sense of “what is dear and lovely in the world” in such passages as “what is dear and lovely in the world is form” , etc.

original: sātarūpa”ntiādīsu viya. Tasmā asadisarūpoti asadisasabhāvo, tena dasabalacatuvesārajjādiguṇavisesasamāyogadīpanato
analyzed: tasmā asadisa rūpaḥ ti asadisa sabhāvaḥ tena dasa bala catu vesārajja ādi guṇa visesa samāyoga dīpanato
translated: Therefore, the incomparable form is the incomparable nature. By this, the combination of the special qualities such as the ten powers and the four kinds of intrepidity is shown.

original: satthu dhammakāyasampattiyāpi asadisatā dassitā hoti. Itīti evaṃ vuttappakārena.🔽Tasminti āruppe. Pakiṇṇakakathāpi viññeyyāti pubbe viya asādhāraṇaṃ tattha tattha
analyzed: satthu dhammakāya sampattiyā api asadisa tā dassitā hoti iti iti evam vutta ppakārena  tasmin ti āruppe pakiṇṇaka kathā api viññeyyā ti pubbe viya asādhāraṇam tattha tattha
translated: and the Teacher’s incomparable excellence in the Dhamma body is also shown. In this way: in this way described above.

original: jhāne patiniyatameva atthaṃ aggahetvā sādhāraṇabhāvato tattha tattheva pakiṇṇakaṃ🔽visaṭaṃ atthaṃ gahetvā pavattā pakiṇṇakakathāpi vijānitabbā.
analyzed: jhāne pati niyatam eva attham aggahetvā sādhāraṇa bhāvato tattha tattha iva pakiṇṇakam  visaṭam attham gahetvā pavattā pakiṇṇaka kathā api vijānitabbā
translated: In that immaterial state: in the immaterial sphere. The miscellaneous explanations should be understood: as in the case of the first jhāna, so too in this case the miscellaneous explanations should be understood as occurring by taking as the starting point some special property that is common to a number of jhānas, without confining the explanation to the particular jhāna stated.

original: 289. Rūpanimittātikkamatoti kasiṇarūpasaṅkhātassa paṭibhāganimittassa atikkamanato.
analyzed: rūpa nimitta atikkamataḥ ti kasiṇa rūpa saṅkhātassa paṭibhāga nimittassa atikkamanataḥ
translated: The surmounting of the material-form element: the surmounting of the material-form element consisting in the counterpart sign of the kasiṇa.

original: Ākāsātikkamatoti kasiṇugghāṭimākāsassa atikkamanato. Ākāse pavattitaviññāṇātikkamatoti🔽paṭhamāruppaviññāṇassa atikkamanato, na dutiyāruppaviññāṇātikkamanato. Tadatikkamato
analyzed: ākāsa atikkamato ti kasiṇugghāṭim ākāsassa atikkamanataḥ ākāse pavattita viññāṇa atikkamato ti  paṭhama āruppa viññāṇassa atikkamanataḥ na dutiya āruppa viññāṇa atikkamanataḥ tad atikkamataḥ
translated: The surmounting of space: the surmounting of the space element consisting in the kasiṇa’s clear expanse. The surmounting of consciousness: the surmounting of the consciousness element consisting in the jhāna consciousness.🔽For the jhāna consciousness is called “consciousness” too, and it is the surmounting of that that is meant.

original: hi tasseva vibhāvanaṃ hoti. Dutiyāruppaviññāṇavibhāvane hi tadeva atikkantaṃ siyā,
analyzed: hi tassa iva vibhāvanam hoti dutiya āruppa viññāṇa vibhāvane hi tat eva atikkantam siyā
translated: For when the jhāna is ended, the jhāna consciousness ceases, and then the consciousness that occurred in the prior stage—that is to say, the fine-material-sphere consciousness—arises again, and that is called the “surmounting of consciousness.”

original: na tassa ārammaṇaṃ, na ca ārammaṇe dosaṃ disvā anārammaṇassa vibhāvanātikkamo yujjati.
analyzed: na tassa ārammaṇam na ca ārammaṇe dosam disvā anārammaṇassa vibhāvanā atikkamaḥ yujjati
translated: and it is not right to say that the surmounting of the meditation subject is the abandoning of a non- object by seeing the danger in the object.

original: Pāḷiyañca “viññāṇañcāyatanaṃ sato samāpajjati…pe… sato vuṭṭhahitvā taṃyeva viññāṇaṃ
analyzed: pāḷiyam ca viññāṇañca āyatanam sataḥ samāpajjati pe sataḥ vuṭṭhahitvā taṃ yeva viññāṇam
translated: And in the text “He enters upon and dwells in the base consisting of boundless consciousness … having seen with understanding how the base consisting of boundless space is tranquilized by the surmounting of the consciousness that had the base consisting of boundless space as its object” ,

original: abhāvetī”ti vuttaṃ, na vuttaṃ “taṃyeva viññāṇañcāyatanaṃ abhāvetī”ti, “taṃyeva abhāvetī”ti🔽vā. “Anantaṃ viññāṇanti viññāṇañcāyatanaṃ upasampajjā”ti ettha pana dvayaṃ vuttaṃ
analyzed: abhāveti iti vuttam na vuttam tam yeva viññāṇam ca āyatanam abhāveti iti tam yeva abhāveti iti  vā anantam viññāṇanti viññāṇañca āyatanam upasampajja ti ettha pana dvayam vuttam
translated: it is said, “He enters upon and dwells in the base consisting of boundless consciousness,” not “He enters upon and dwells in the base consisting of boundless consciousness having tranquilized the base consisting of boundless consciousness,” or “having tranquilized the base consisting of boundless consciousness that had the base consisting of boundless space as its object.”🔽But in the text “He enters upon and dwells in the base consisting of boundless consciousness … having seen with understanding how the base consisting of boundless space is tranquilized by the surmounting of the consciousness that had the base consisting of boundless space as its object” ,

original: ārammaṇañca viññāṇaṃ, viññāṇañcāyatanañca. Tasmiṃ dvaye yena kenaci, yato vā vuṭṭhito,
analyzed: ārammaṇam ca viññāṇam viññāṇañca āyatanañca tasmim dvaye yena kenacid yatas vā vuṭṭhitaḥ
translated: two things are mentioned, namely, the consciousness that had the base consisting of boundless space as its object and the base consisting of boundless consciousness.

original: teneva padhānaniddiṭṭhena taṃ-saddassa sambandhe āpanne “ayañca ārammaṇātikkamabhāvanā”ti🔽viññāṇañcāyatanassa nivattanatthaṃ viññāṇavacanaṃ. Tasmā paṭhamāruppaviññāṇasseva
analyzed: tena iva padhāna niddiṭṭhena taṃ saddassa sambandhe āpanne ayam ca ārammaṇa atikkama bhāvanā ti  viññāṇañcāyatanassa nivattana attham viññāṇa vacanam tasmā paṭhama āruppa viññāṇassa iva
translated: And since the word “that” in the phrase “having seen with understanding how the base consisting of boundless space is tranquilized by the surmounting of the consciousness that had the base consisting of boundless space as its object”🔽is related to the word “consciousness” in the phrase “the consciousness that had the base consisting of boundless space as its object,”

original: abhāvanātikkamo vutto.
analyzed: abhāvanā atikkamaḥ vutto
translated: the mention of “consciousness” is for the purpose of showing the abandoning of the base consisting of boundless space by the development of the surmounting of the object.🔽Therefore the surmounting of the first jhāna of the fine-material sphere is stated.

original: 290. Evaṃ santepīti aṅgātikkame asatipi. Suppaṇītatarāti suṭṭhu paṇītatarā, sundarā
analyzed: evam sante pi iti aṅga atikkame asati pi suppaṇītatarā ati suṭṭhu paṇītatarā sundarā
translated: Still, even though there is no excess of factors, they are more and more refined, more and more excellent, more and more sublime.🔽Or the meaning can be taken as “more refined, more excellent, and more sublime.”

original: paṇītatarā cāti vā attho. Satipi catunnaṃ pāsādatalānaṃ, sāṭikānañca tabbhāvato,
analyzed: paṇītatarā ca ati vā attho catunnam pāsāda talānam sāṭikānam ca tad bhāvato
translated: Even though the four terraces and the cloths are equal in size and in the sense of being a condition for the pleasure,

original: pamāṇato ca samabhāve uparūpari pana kāmaguṇānaṃ, sukhasamphassādīnañca visesena
analyzed: ca sama bhāve upari upari pana kāma guṇānam sukha samphassa ādīnam ca visesena
translated: still, because of the difference in the qualities of the sense desires and in the contact that is a basis for pleasure, they are more and more refined, etc.

original: paṇītatarādibhāvo viya etāsaṃ catunnaṃ samāpattīnaṃ āruppabhāvato, aṅgato ca satipi
analyzed: paṇītatara ādi bhāvaḥ etāsam catunnam samāpattīnam āruppa bhāvataḥ aṅgataḥ ca sati pi
translated: In the same way, even though these four attainments are equal in being immaterial and in having the same factors,

original: samabhāve bhāvanāvisesasiddho pana sātisayo uparūpari paṇītatarādibhāvoti imamatthaṃ
analyzed: sama bhāve bhāvanā visesa siddho pana sa atisayaḥ upari upari paṇītatara ādi bhāvo ti imam attham
translated: still, the more and more refined, etc., nature is due to the excellence of the development,

original: dasseti “yathā hī”tiādinā.
analyzed: dassa iti yathā hi itiādinā
translated: which is shown by the example of the terraces.

original: 291. Nissitoti nissāya ṭhito. Duṭṭhitāti na sammā ṭhitā, dukkhaṃ vā ṭhitā. Tannissitanti
analyzed: nissitaḥ ti nissāya ṭhitaḥ duṭṭhitā ati na sammā ṭhitā dukkham vā ṭhitā tat nissitam ti
translated: “Supported” means “resting.” “Not well supported” means “not well established,” or “established with difficulty.” “Supported by that” means “having that as its support,”

original: tena nissitaṃ, ṭhānanti attho. Tannissitanti vā taṃ maṇḍapalaggaṃ purisaṃ nissāya
analyzed: tena nissitam ṭhānan ti atthaḥ tad nissitanti vā tam maṇḍapa laggam purisam nissāya
translated: that is, its place. Or the meaning can be taken as “supported by that man standing at the head of the terrace,”

original: ṭhitaṃ purisanti attho. Maṇḍapalaggañhi anissāya tena vinābhūte vivitte bahi okāse
analyzed: ṭhitam purisanti atthaḥ maṇḍapa laggam hi a nissāya tena vinābhūte vivitte bahi okāse
translated: that is, “the other men standing outside in the open space without the terrace, not supported by it, not depending on it.”

original: ṭhānaṃ viya ākāsalaggaviññāṇassa viveke tadapagame tatiyāruppassa ṭhānanti.
analyzed: ṭhānam viya ākāsa lagga viññāṇassa viveke tad apagame tatiya āruppassa ṭhānam ti
translated: and the space-element is the support for the consciousness that has the space-element as its object, and when that has gone, the third jhāna has the space-element as its support.

original: 292. Ārammaṇaṃ karoteva, aññābhāvena taṃ idanti “āsannaviññāṇañcāyatanapaccatthikarūpāsannākāsārammaṇaviññāṇāpagamārammaṇaṃ,🔽no ca santa”nti ca diṭṭhādīnavampi taṃ ākiñcaññāyatanaṃ idaṃ nevasaññānāsaññāyatanajjhānaṃ
analyzed: ārammaṇam karotā iva aññābhāvena tam idam ti āsanna viññāṇañca āyatana paccatthika rūpa āsanna ākāsa ārammaṇa viññāṇa apagama ārammaṇam  no ca ca diṭṭha ādīnavam pi tam ākiñcaññāyatanam idam nevasaññānāsaññāyatana jhānam
translated: . It makes the object of the fourth jhāna, which is the near side of the base consisting of boundless consciousness, and the near side of the space-element that is the object of the consciousness that has the space-element as its object, and the disappearance of that as its object,🔽but it is not peaceful. And the danger in the seen, etc., is the danger in the base consisting of nothingness.🔽That base consisting of nothingness is the object of the jhāna called the base consisting of neither perception nor non-perception,

original: aññassa tādisassa ārammaṇabhāvayogyassa abhāvena alābhena ārammaṇaṃ karoti eva. “Sabbadisampati”nti
analyzed: aññassa tādisassa ārammaṇa bhāva yogyassa abhāvena alābhena ārammaṇam karoti eva
translated: because there is no other object fit to be the counterpart of that, since there is none of equal strength.

original: idaṃ janassa agatikabhāvadassanatthaṃ vuttaṃ. Vuttinti jīvikaṃ. Vattatīti jīvati.
analyzed: idam janassa agatika bhāva dassana attham vuttam vuttinti jīvikam vattati iti jīvati
translated: . “It is the master of all that is seen”: this is said in order to show that it is beyond the range of men. “Livelihood” is living. “It lives” is the same as “it lives by.”

original: 293. Āruḷhotiādīsu ayaṃ saṅkhepattho – yathā koci puriso anekaporisaṃ dīghanisseṇiṃ
analyzed: āruḷhaḥ ti ādīsu ayam saṅkhepa atthaḥ yathā koci purisaḥ aneka porisam dīgha nisseṇim
translated: . The meaning in brief is this. Suppose a man were to climb up a very long ladder step by step,

original: āruḷho tassa uparimapade ṭhito tassā nisseṇiyā bāhumeva olubbhati aññassa alābhato,
analyzed: āruḷhaḥ tassa uparima pade ṭhitaḥ tassā nisseṇiyāḥ bāhum eva olubbhati aññassa alābhato
translated: and when he had reached the top and was standing on the topmost step, he were to stretch out his limbs, thinking “I am standing on the top of this ladder,”

original: yathā ca paṃsupabbatassa, missakapabbatassa vā aggakoṭiṃ āruḷho tassa matthakameva🔽olubbhati, yathā ca giriṃ silāpabbataṃ āruḷho paripphandamāno aññābhāvato attano
analyzed: yathā ca paṃsu pabbatassa missaka pabbatassa vā agga koṭim āruḷhaḥ tassa matthakam eva  olubbhati yathā ca girim silā pabbatam āruḷhaḥ paripphandamānaḥ aññābhāvataḥ attano
translated: And just as when one climbs to the top of a mound of dust or a mound of sand, one sinks down to the bottom of it,

original: jaṇṇukameva olubbhati, tathā etaṃ catutthāruppajjhānaṃ taṃ tatiyāruppaṃ olubbhitvā
analyzed: jaṇṇukam eva olubbhati tathā etam catuttha āruppa jhānam tam tatiya āruppam olubbhitvā
translated: and just as when one climbs a mountain of rock, one falls down to one’s knees or to one’s feet, so too, this fourth jhāna, having climbed to the top of the third,

original: pavattatīti. Yaṃ panettha atthato avibhattaṃ, taṃ uttānameva.
analyzed: pavattati iti yam pana ittha atthataḥ a vibhattam tam uttānam eva
translated: sinks down to its bottom and occurs there. But what has not been analysed here has already been analysed in the Description of the Aggregates .

original: Āruppaniddesavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: āruppa niddesa vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The explanation of the description of the formless is ended.

original: Iti dasamaparicchedavaṇṇanā.
analyzed: iti dasama pariccheda vaṇṇanā
translated: The commentary on the tenth chapter is ended.

original: 11. Samādhiniddesavaṇṇanā
translated: The explanation of the description of concentration

original: Āhārepaṭikkūlabhāvanāvaṇṇanā
analyzed: āhāre paṭikkūla bhāvanā vaṇṇanā
translated: The explanation of the development of the perception of the repulsiveness of food

original: 294. Uddeso nāma niddesattho mudumajjhimapaññābāhullato, āgato ca bhāro avassaṃ vahitabboti
analyzed: uddesaḥ nāma niddesa atthaḥ mudu majjhima paññā bāhullataḥ āgataḥ ca bhāraḥ avassam vahitabbaḥ ti
translated: The meaning of “set out” is “described.” It is “set out” because it is stated in the texts for the purpose of being described. And the burden that has been taken up must necessarily be borne.

original: āha “ekā saññāti evaṃ uddiṭṭhāya āhāre paṭikkūlasaññāya bhāvanāniddeso anuppatto”ti.
analyzed: āha ekā saññā iti evam uddiṭṭhāya āhāre paṭikkūla saññāya bhāvanā niddeso anuppatto ti
translated: So it is said: “The description of the development of the perception of the repulsiveness of food, which was set out in this way, has now been completed” .

original: Tatthāyaṃ saññā-saddo “rūpasaññā saddasaññā”tiādīsu sañjānanalakkhaṇe dhamme āgato,
analyzed: tattha ayam saññā saddaḥ rūpa saññā sadda saññā ati ādīsu sañjānana lakkhaṇe dhamme āgataḥ
translated: Herein, this word “perception” occurs with the characteristic of perceiving in such passages as “Perception of forms, perception of sounds” ,

original: “aniccasaññā dukkhasaññā”tiādīsu vipassanāyaṃ āgato, “uddhumātakasaññāti vā sopākarūpasaññāti🔽vā ime dhammā ekatthā udāhu nānatthā”tiādīsu samathe āgato. Idha pana samathassa🔽parikamme daṭṭhabbo. Āhāre hi paṭikkūlākāraggahaṇaṃ, tappabhāvitaṃ vā upacārajjhānaṃ🔽idha “āhāre paṭikkūlasaññā”ti adhippetaṃ. Tattha yasmiṃ āhāre paṭikkūlasaññā bhāvetabbā,
analyzed: anicca saññā dukkha saññā ti ādīsu vipassanāyam āgataḥ uddhumātaka saññā ati vā sopāka rūpa saññā ati  vā ime dhammā ekatthāḥ udāhu nānatthā ati ādīsu samathe āgataḥ idha pana samathassa  parikamme daṭṭhabbaḥ āhāre hi paṭikkūla ākāra ggahaṇam tad pabhāvitam vā upacāra jjhānam  idha āhāre paṭikkūla saññā ti adhippetam tattha yasmin āhāre paṭikkūla saññā bhāvetabbā
translated: In such passages as “Perception of impermanence, perception of pain” , it is found in insight. In such passages as “Perception of a bloated corpse, perception of a livid corpse” , “Perception of a skeleton, perception of a worm-infested corpse” , “Perception of a loathesome thing, perception of original: tattha nibbedavirāguppādanāya tappasaṅgena sabbampi āhāraṃ kiccappabhedādīnavopammehi🔽vibhāvetuṃ “āharatīti āhāro”tiādi āraddhaṃ.🔽Tattha āharatīti āhārapaccayasaṅkhātena uppattiyā, ṭhitiyā vā paccayabhāvena attano🔽phalaṃ āneti nibbatteti pavatteti cāti attho. Kabaḷaṃ karīyatīti kabaḷīkāro, vatthuvasena
analyzed: tattha nibbeda virāga uppādanāya tad pasaṅgena sabbam pi āhāram kicca ppabheda ādīnava upammehi 🔽āharati iti āraddham 🔽tattha āharati iti āhāra paccaya saṅkhātena uppattiyā ṭhitiyā vā paccaya bhāvena attano 🔽phalam āneti nibbatteti pavatteti ca ati attho kabaḷam karīyati iti kabaḷīkāraḥ vatthu vasena

original: cetaṃ vuttaṃ, lakkhaṇato pana ojālakkhaṇo veditabbo, kabaḷīkāro ca so yathāvuttenatthena
analyzed: cetam vuttam lakkhaṇato pana ojā lakkhaṇaḥ veditabbo kabaḷīkāraḥ ca saḥ yathāvuttena atthena
translated: But it should be understood as having the characteristic of nutritive essence, and it is “physical” in the sense already stated.

original: āhāro cāti kabaḷīkārāhāro. Esa nayo sesesupi. Phusatīti phasso. Ayaṃ hi arūpadhammopi
analyzed: āhāro ca ati kabaḷīkāra āhāro esa nayaḥ sesesu pi phusati iti phassaḥ ayam hi arūpa dhammaḥ api
translated: And it is “food” in the sense of being a condition for the maintenance of beings. So it is “physical nutriment.” The same method of explanation applies in the case of the other three.🔽It touches, thus it is contact . Although this is a mental datum,

original: samāno ārammaṇe phusanākāreneva pavattati. Tathā hi so phusanalakkhaṇoti vuccati.🔽Cetayatīti cetanā, attano sampayuttadhammehi saddhiṃ ārammaṇe abhisandahatīti attho,
analyzed: samānaḥ ārammaṇe phusana ākārena iva pavattati tathā hi so phusana lakkhaṇo ti vuccati  cetayati iti cetanā attano sampayutta dhammehi saddhim ārammaṇe abhisandahati iti attho
translated: nevertheless it occurs as the mere touching of an object, and that is why it is said to have the characteristic of touching.🔽It intends, thus it is intention . The meaning is that it impinges on the object together with the associated states.🔽It is intention in the mind’s door, and it is mental-object-contact’s condition for producing the volition in the mind’s door.

original: manosannissitā cetanā manosañcetanā. Upapattiparikappanavasena vijānātīti viññāṇaṃ.
analyzed: manaḥ sannissitā cetanā manaḥ sañcetanā upapatti parikappana vasena vijānāti iti viññāṇam
translated: It cognizes by apprehending the mode of the object, thus it is consciousness .

original: Evamettha sāmaññatthato, visesatthato ca āhārā veditabbā. Kasmā panete cattārova
analyzed: evam ettha sāmañña tthataḥ visesa tthataḥ ca āhārāḥ veditabbā kasmā pana ete cattāraḥ va
translated: This is how food should be understood according to the general and particular meanings of the terms.

original: vuttā, aññe dhammā kiṃ attano phalassa paccayā na hontīti? No na honti, ime pana
analyzed: vuttāḥ aññe dhammā kim attanaḥ phalassa paccayāḥ na honti iti no na honti ime pana
translated: But why are only these called “food”? Are there not other states that are conditions for their own fruit?🔽There are. But these are the most outstanding among them.

original: tathā ca honti aññathā cāti samānepi paccayabhāve atirekapaccayā honti, tasmā āhārāti vuccanti.
analyzed: tathā ca honti aññathā ca ati samāne pi paccaya bhāve atireka paccayāḥ honti tasmai āhārā ti vuccanti
translated: And they are so both as conditions and as nutriment. So they are called “food” because they are outstanding conditions.

original: Kathaṃ? Etesu hi paṭhamo sayaṃ yasmiṃ kalāpe tappariyāpannānaṃ yathārahaṃ paccayo🔽hontova ojaṭṭhamakaṃ rūpaṃ āharati, dutiyo tisso vedanā āharati, tatiyo tīsu bhavesu
analyzed: katham etesu hi paṭhamaḥ sayam yasmin kalāpe tad pariyāpannānam yathāraham paccayaḥ  rūpam āharati dutiyaḥ tissaḥ vedanāḥ āharati tatiyaḥ tīsu bhavesu
translated: How? The first, while being a condition in the way appropriate to each in the category in which it is included,🔽brings in the materiality of nutritive essence. The second brings in the three kinds of feeling. The third brings in🔽the three kinds of becoming.

original: paṭisandhiṃ āharati, catuttho paṭisandhikkhaṇe nāmarūpaṃ āharati. Tenāha “kabaḷīkārāhāro”tiādi.🔽Ettha ca kammajādibhedabhinnā ojā sati paccayalābhe dve tisso paveṇiyo ghaṭentī ojaṭṭhamakarūpaṃ🔽āharati, sukhavedanīyādibhedabhinno phassāhāro yathārahaṃ tisso vedanā āharati, puññābhisaṅkhārādibhedabhinno🔽manosañcetanāhāro kāmabhavādīsu tīsu bhavesu yathārahaṃ saviññāṇaṃ, aviññāṇañca paṭisandhiṃ
analyzed: paṭisandhim āharati catutthaḥ paṭisandhi kkhaṇe nāma rūpam āharati tena āha kabaḷīkāra āhāra itiādi  ettha ca kamma ja ādi bheda bhinnā ojā sati paccaya lābhe dve tisso paveṇiyaḥ ghaṭentī  āharati sukha vedanīya ādi bheda bhinno phassa āhāraḥ yathāraham tissaḥ vedanāḥ āharati puñña abhisaṅkhāra ādi bheda bhinno  manaḥ sañcetanā āhāraḥ kāma bhava ādīsu tīsu bhavesu yathāraham sa viññāṇam aviññāṇam ca paṭisandhim
translated: How? The first of these, namely, nutriment consisting of edible food, is a condition in the way already stated for the materiality that is the eighth of the kinds of materiality classed as the fourfold nutriment. The second, namely, nutriment consisting of contact, is a condition for the three kinds of feeling. The third, namely, nutriment consisting of mental volition, is a condition for rebirth-linking in the three kinds of becoming. The fourth, namely, nutriment consisting of consciousness, is a condition for the mentality-materiality at the moment of rebirth-linking. That is why it is said, “Edible food is a condition for the materiality that is the eighth of the kinds of materiality classed as the fourfold nutriment” , and so on.

original: āharati, viññāṇāhāro yathāpaccayaṃ paṭisandhikkhaṇe nāmaṃ rūpaṃ, nāmarūpañca āharatīti
analyzed: āharati viññāṇa āhāraḥ yathāpaccayam paṭisandhi kkhaṇe nāmam rūpam nāma rūpañca āharati iti
translated: And here the nutriment called “edible food,” which is classed as “nutriment derived from gross or fine food,” is a condition for the materiality that is the eighth of the kinds of materiality classed as the fourfold nutriment, since it brings about the continuity of the kinds of materiality classed as the fourfold nutriment, which are classed as “nutriment derived from gross or fine food” and are divided into the kinds beginning with “nutriment derived from gross or fine food that has been eaten” , and so on. Nutriment consisting of contact is a condition for the three kinds of feeling, which are classed as “nutriment derived from gross or fine food” and are divided into the kinds beginning with “contact that has been contacted” . Nutriment consisting of mental volition is a condition for rebirth-linking in the three kinds of becoming, which are classed as “nutriment derived from gross or fine food” and are divided into the kinds beginning with “volitional kamma that has been accumulated” . Nutriment consisting of consciousness is a condition for mentality-materiality at the moment of rebirth-linking, which is classed as “nutriment derived from gross or fine food” and is divided into the kinds beginning with “consciousness that has been cognized” .

original: daṭṭhabbaṃ. Atha vā upatthambhakaṭṭhena ime eva dhammā āhārāti vuttā. Yathā hi kabaḷīkārāhāro
analyzed: daṭṭhabbam atha vā upatthambhaka ṭṭhena ime eva dhammā āhārā ti vuttā yathā hi kabaḷīkāra āhāro
translated: Or else these states are called nutriment in the sense of consolidating. For just as material food is a condition for the material body in the sense of consolidating,

original: rūpakāyassa upatthambhakaṭṭhena paccayo, evaṃ arūpino āhārā sampayuttadhammānaṃ.🔽Tathā hi vuttaṃ “kabaḷīkāro āhāro imassa kāyassa āhārapaccayena paccayo, arūpino
analyzed: rūpa kāyassa upatthambhaka ṭṭhena paccayaḥ evam arūpino āhārā sampayutta dhammānam  tathā hi vuttam kabaḷīkāraḥ āhāraḥ imassa kāyassa āhāra paccayena paccayaḥ arūpino
translated: so the immaterial kinds of nutriment are for the states associated with them.

original: āhārā sampayuttakānaṃ dhammānaṃ taṃsamuṭṭhānānañca rūpānaṃ āhārapaccayena paccayo”ti.
analyzed: āhārā sampayuttakānam dhammānam tad samuṭṭhānānaṃ ca rūpānaṃ āhāra paccayena paccayaḥ ti
translated: For this is said: “Material food is a condition for this material body in the sense of nutriment. The three immaterial kinds of nutriment are a condition for the states associated with them and for the kinds of materiality originated thereby in the sense of nutriment” .

original: Aparo nayo – ajjhattikasantatiyā visesapaccayattā kabaḷīkārāhāro, phassādayo ca tayo
analyzed: aparaḥ nayaḥ ajjhattika santatiyāḥ visesa paccaya ttā kabaḷīkāra āhāro phassa ādayo ca tayo
translated: Another method: material food is called nutriment because it is a condition for the distinction in the internal continuity. The other three, contact, etc.,

original: dhammā āhārāti vuttā. Visesapaccayo hi kabaḷīkārāhārabhakkhānaṃ sattānaṃ rūpakāyassa
analyzed: dhammā āhārā ti vuttā visesa paccayaḥ hi kabaḷīkāra āhāra bhakkhānam sattānam rūpa kāyassa
translated: are called nutriment because they are conditions for the distinction in the external continuity. For material food is a condition for the material body of beings who eat material food in the sense of nutriment.

original: kabaḷīkārāhāro, nāmakāye vedanāya phasso, viññāṇassa manosañcetanā, nāmarūpassa viññāṇaṃ.
analyzed: kabaḷīkāra āhāraḥ nāmakāye vedanāya phassaḥ viññāṇassa manas sañcetanā nāma rūpassa viññāṇam
translated: Contact is a condition for the feeling in the immaterial states. Mental volition is a condition for consciousness. Consciousness is a condition for mentality-materiality.

original: Yathāha “seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, ayaṃ kāyo āhāraṭṭhitiko, āhāraṃ paṭicca tiṭṭhati,
analyzed: yathā āha seyyathā api bhikkhave ayam kāyaḥ āhāra ṭṭhitikaḥ āhāram paṭicca tiṭṭhati
translated: As it is said: “Bhikkhus, this body, I say, is nourished by material food. It exists in dependence on material food.

original: anāhāro no tiṭṭhati. Tathā phassapaccayā vedanā, saṅkhārapaccayā viññāṇaṃ, viññāṇapaccayā nāmarūpa”nti.
analyzed: anāhāraḥ no tiṭṭhati tathā phassa paccayā vedanā saṅkhāra paccayā viññāṇam viññāṇa paccayā nāma rūpanti
translated: and without food it does not remain. So too, with contact as condition, feeling; with formations as condition, consciousness; with consciousness as condition, mentality-materiality” .

original: Kabaḷīkārāhāreti kabaḷīkāre āhāre nikanti taṇhā, taṃ bhayaṃ anatthāvahato. Gadhitassa
analyzed: kabaḷīkāra āhāra iti kabaḷīkāre āhāre taṇhā tam bhayam anattha āvahataḥ gadhitassa
translated: “With regard to the nutriment edible food” : craving for the nutriment edible food is the danger in it. For one who is greedy

original: hi āhāraparibhogo anatthāya hoti. Hetuatthe bhummaṃ. Evaṃ sesesu. Nikantīti nikāmanā
analyzed: hi āhāra paribhogaḥ anatthāya hoti hetu atthe bhummam evam sesesu nikantī iti nikāmanā
translated: for it, the use of food is to his harm. The locative case is in the sense of cause. So too with the rest. “Craving” is the will for sensual desires.

original: chandarāgo. Bhāyati etasmāti bhayaṃ, nikanti eva bhayaṃ nikantibhayaṃ. Kabaḷīkārāhārahetu🔽imesaṃ sattānaṃ chandarāgo bhayaṃ bhayānakaṃ diṭṭhadhammikādibhedassa anatthassa🔽sakalassāpi vaṭṭadukkhassa hetubhāvato. Tenevāha “kabaḷīkāre ce, bhikkhave, āhāre
analyzed: chanda rāgaḥ bhāyati eva bhayam nikanti bhayam kabaḷīkāra āhāra hetu  imesam sattānam chanda rāgaḥ bhayam bhayānakam diṭṭhadhammika ādi bhedassa anatthassa  sakalassa api vaṭṭa dukkhassa hetu bhāvataḥ tena iva āha kabaḷīkāre ce bhikkhave āhāre
translated: “Danger” is that from which one is afraid . “Danger in craving” is the danger in craving. “With the nutriment edible food as cause” :

original: atthi rāgo, atthi nandī, atthi taṇhā, patiṭṭhitaṃ tattha viññāṇaṃ viruḷha”ntiādi.
analyzed: atthi rāgaḥ atthi nandī atthi taṇhā patiṭṭhitam tattha viññāṇam viruḷhantiādi
translated: with the nutriment edible food as cause, the will and lust for these beings is the danger, the fearful thing, in regard to the whole of the suffering of the round of rebirths, which is classed as that to be experienced here and now, in the next rebirth, and in some subsequent existence. Hence it is said: “If, bhikkhus, there is lust for the nutriment edible food, if there is delight, if there is craving, consciousness becomes established therein and comes to growth” .

original: Upagamanaṃ appahīnavipallāsassa ārammaṇena samodhānaṃ saṅgati sukhavedanīyādiphassuppatti
analyzed: upagamanam appahīna vipallāsassa ārammaṇena samodhānam saṅgati sukha vedanīya ādi phassa uppatti
translated: “The meeting” : the meeting with the object of one who has not abandoned the perversions is the arising of contact that is to be felt as pleasant, etc.

original: bhayaṃ bhayānakaṃ tīhi dukkhatāhi aparimuccanato. Tenāha “sukhavedanīyaṃ, bhikkhave,
analyzed: bhayam bhayānakam tīhi dukkha tāhi a parimuccanato tena āha sukha vedanīyam bhikkhave
translated: because it is not free from the three kinds of suffering. Hence it is said: “Bhikkhus, there is no pleasure more exquisite than this:

original: phassaṃ paṭicca uppajjati sukhā vedanā, tassa vedanāpaccayā taṇhā…pe… dukkhakkhandhassa🔽samudayo hotī”ti. Tattha tattha bhave upapajjati etenāti upapatti, upapajjanaṃ vā
analyzed: phassam paṭicca uppajjati sukhā vedanā tassa vedanā paccayā taṇhā pe dukkha kkhandhassa  samudayaḥ hoti iti tattha tattha bhave upapajjati etena ati upapatti upapajjanam vā
translated: because it is not free from the three kinds of suffering. Hence it is said: “Bhikkhus, pleasant feeling is born with pleasant feeling as its condition. With the arising of pleasant feeling, joy arises. With joy as condition there is craving. With craving as condition there is grasping. With grasping as condition there is becoming. With becoming as condition there is birth. With birth as condition there arises in the future aging and death, sorrow, lamentation, pain, grief, and despair. Thus there is the origin of this whole mass of suffering” .

original: upapatti, khipanaṃ bhayaṃ bhayānakaṃ upapattimūlakehi byasanehi aparimuttato. Tenāha🔽“avidvā, bhikkhave, purisapuggalo puññañce saṅkhāraṃ abhisaṅkharoti, puññupagaṃ bhavati
analyzed: upapatti khipanam bhayam bhayānakam upapatti mūlakehi byasanehi tena āha  a vidvā bhikkhave purisa puggalaḥ puññam ce saṅkhāram abhisaṅkharoti puñña upagam bhavati
translated: Herein, it is rebirth because of being reborn here and there in the various kinds of becoming. Or alternatively, rebirth is the act of being reborn. It is fearful and terrible because it is not free from the calamities that have rebirth as their ground. Hence it is said:

original: viññāṇaṃ. Apuññañce saṅkhāraṃ abhisaṅkharoti, apuññupagaṃ bhavati viññāṇa”ntiādi.🔽Paṭisandhīti bhavantarādīhi paṭisandhānaṃ, taṃ bhayaṃ bhayānakaṃ paṭisandhinimittehi
analyzed: viññāṇam saṅkhāram abhisaṅkharoti apuñña upagam bhavati viññāṇa ntiādi  paṭisandhi iti bhavantara ādīhi paṭisandhānam tam bhayam bhayānakam paṭisandhi nimittehi
translated: “Bhikkhus, an unwise person who generates a meritorious volitional formation generates it for the sake of pleasant feeling. With the arising of pleasant feeling, joy arises. With joy as condition there is craving. With craving as condition there is grasping. With grasping as condition there is becoming. With becoming as condition there is birth. With birth as condition there arises in the future aging and death, sorrow, lamentation, pain, grief, and despair. Thus there is the origin of this whole mass of suffering” .

original: dukkhehi avimuccanato. Tenāha “viññāṇe ce, bhikkhave, āhāre atthi rāgo, atthi nandī,
analyzed: dukkhehi a vimuccanato tena āha viññāṇe ce bhikkhave āhāre atthi rāgaḥ atthi nandī
translated: Herein, rebirth-linking is the linking of the next becoming. It is fearful and terrible because it is not free from the suffering of the conditions for rebirth-linking. Hence it is said: “Bhikkhus, if there is lust for the nutriment consciousness, if there is delight, if there is craving,

original: atthi taṇhā, patiṭṭhitaṃ tattha viññāṇaṃ viruḷha”ntiādi.
analyzed: atthi taṇhā patiṭṭhitam tattha viññāṇam viruḷhantiādi
translated: “There is craving, and consciousness is established there and grows” .

original: Puttamaṃsūpamena ovādena dīpetabbo nicchandarāgaparibhogāya. Evaṃ hi tattha nikantibhayaṃ
analyzed: putta maṃsu upamena ovādena dīpetabbaḥ nicchanda rāga paribhogāya evam hi tattha nikanti bhayam
translated: The nutriment of contact should be illustrated by the simile of the cow’s mouth for the enjoyment of lust and desire, for in this way there is no danger of attachment there.

original: na hoti. Niccammā gāvī yaṃ yaṃ ṭhānaṃ upagacchati, tattha tattheva naṃ pāṇino khādantiyeva.
analyzed: na hoti niccammā gāvī yam yam ṭhānam upagacchati tattha tattha iva nam pāṇino
translated: For just as a cow that is milked regularly gives more milk and so is never dry, so too, when one who has lust and desire enjoys the five cords of sense desire, his lust and desire increase;🔽and when lust and desire increase, the danger of attachment to existence increases.

original: Evaṃ phasse sati vedanā uppajjati, vedanā ca dukkhasallādito daṭṭhabbāti phasse ādīnavaṃ
analyzed: evam phasse sati vedanā uppajjati vedanā ca dukkha salla āditaḥ daṭṭhabbā ati phasse ādīnavam
translated: When he sees that feeling arises with contact as its condition, and that feeling is the bait of suffering,

original: passantassa upagamanabhayaṃ na hotīti āha “phassāhāro niccammagāvūpamena dīpetabbo”ti.
analyzed: passantassa upagamana bhayam na hoti iti āha phassa āhāraḥ dīpetabbaḥ ti
translated: he does not go to meet contact, and so the danger of going to meet does not exist for him.🔽That is why it is said that the nutriment of contact should be illustrated by the simile of the cow that always gives milk.

original: Ekādasahi aggīhi sabbaso ādittā bhavā aṅgārakāsusadisāti passato upapattibhayaṃ na
analyzed: ekādasahi aggīhi sabbasas ādittāḥ bhavāḥ aṅgāraka asu sadisāḥ ti passataḥ upapatti bhayam na
translated: When he sees that the becomings are entirely ablaze with eleven fires, the danger of rebirth does not exist for him.

original: hotīti āha “manosañcetanāhāro aṅgārakāsūpamena dīpetabbo”ti. Corasadisaṃ viññāṇaṃ
analyzed: hoti iti āha manaḥ sañcetanā āhāraḥ aṅgārakāsu upamena dīpetabbo ti cora sadisam viññāṇam
translated: That is why it is said that the nutriment of mental volition should be illustrated by the simile of the charcoal pit.🔽He sees consciousness as like a thief because of the danger of harm, and he sees feeling as like a blow because of the danger of oppression.

original: anatthapātato, pahārasadisī vedanā duradhivāsatoti sammadeva passato paṭisandhibhayaṃ
analyzed: anattha pātato pahāra sadisī vedanā duradhivāsato ti sammat eva passato paṭisandhi bhayam
translated: When he sees this truly, the danger of rebirth-linking does not exist for him.

original: na hotīti āha “viññāṇāhāro sattisatūpamena dīpetabbo”ti.
analyzed: na hoti iti āha viññāṇa āhāraḥ satti satu upamena dīpetabbaḥ ti
translated: “The nutriment consciousness should be illustrated by the hundred spears.”

original: Evaṃ kiccādimukhena āhāresu ādīnavaṃ vibhāvetvā idāni tattha yathādhippetaṃ āhāraṃ🔽niddhāretvā paṭikkūlato manasikāravidhiṃ dassetuṃ “imesu panā”tiādi vuttaṃ. Upādāyarūpaniddesepi
analyzed: evam kicca ādi mukhena āhāresu ādīnavam vibhāvetvā idāni tattha yathā adhippetam āhāram  niddhāretvā paṭikkūlataḥ manasikāra vidhim dassetum imesu pana atiādi vuttam upādāya rūpa niddese pi
translated: Having thus shown the danger in the nutriments by way of function, etc., he now points out the method of bringing the nutriments to mind as repulsive by extracting the nutriment intended,🔽saying “As to these, etc.”🔽In the description of derived materiality,

original: “kabaḷīkāro āhāro”ti āgatattā tato visesento “asitapītakhāyitasāyitappabhedo”ti āha,
analyzed: kabaḷīkāraḥ āhāro ti āgata ttā tatas visesentaḥ asita pīta khāyita sāyita ppabhedaḥ ti āha
translated: he says “divided into what is eaten, drunk, chewed, and tasted,” distinguishing it from the nutriment “physical nutriment,” which is mentioned in the passage, “Physical nutriment is a condition for the production of this body and for the renewal of what has been produced.”

original: bhūtakathanaṃ vā etaṃ. Tattha asitapītakhāyitasāyitappabhedoti asitabbapātabbakhāyitabbasāyitabbavibhāgo
analyzed: bhūta kathanam vā etam tattha asita pīta khāyita sāyita ppabhedaḥ ti asitabba pātabba khāyitabba sāyitabba vibhāgaḥ
translated: Or this is a statement of the elements. Herein, “divided into what is eaten, drunk, chewed, and tasted” is the division of what is to be eaten, drunk, chewed, and tasted.🔽It is like “curds,” since there is no desire to state a difference in time.

original: kālabhedavacanicchāya abhāvato yathā “duddha”nti. Kabaḷīkāro āhāro vāti avadhāraṇaṃ🔽yathā phassāhārādinivattanaṃ, evaṃ ojāhāranivattanampi daṭṭhabbaṃ. Savatthuko eva
analyzed: kāla bheda vacanicchāyai abhāvataḥ yathā kabaḷīkāraḥ āhāraḥ vāti avadhāraṇam  yathā phassa āhāra ādi nivattanam evam ojā āhāra nivattanam pi daṭṭhabbam sa vatthukaḥ eva
translated: The word “only” is for the purpose of excluding contact, etc., as nutriment.🔽So too, the word “only” should be seen as excluding the nutriment “vital-force” as well.

original: hi āhāro idha kammaṭṭhānabhūto, tena āharīyatīti āhāroti evamettha attho daṭṭhabbo.
analyzed: hi āhāraḥ idha kammaṭṭhāna bhūto tena āharīyati iti āhāraḥ iti evam ettha atthaḥ daṭṭhabbo
translated: For only that nutriment which is a physical basis is the object of meditation here. It is called “nutriment” because it is what is eaten, drunk, chewed, and tasted. This is how the meaning should be regarded here.

original: Āharatīti āhāroti ayaṃ panattho nibbattitaojāvasena veditabbo. Imasmiṃ attheti imasmiṃ🔽kammaṭṭhānasaṅkhāte atthe. Uppannā saññāti saññāsīsena bhāvanaṃ vadati. Tathā hi
analyzed: āharati iti āhāraḥ iti ayam pana atthaḥ nibbattita ojā vasena veditabbaḥ imasmin atthe iti imasmin  kammaṭṭhāna saṅkhāte atthe uppannā saññā iti saññā sīsena bhāvanam vadati tathā hi
translated: In this meaning : in this meaning of the meditation subject.🔽“Arisen perception” : he speaks of development by way of the perception.

original: vakkhati “paṭikkūlākāraggahaṇavasena panā”tiādi.
analyzed: vakkhati paṭikkūla ākāra ggahaṇa vasena pana atiādi
translated: For he says, “But the perception of repulsiveness is the meditation subject.”

original: Kammaṭṭhānaṃ uggahetvāti kammaṭṭhānaṃ pariyattidhammato, atthato ca suggahitaṃ sumanasikataṃ
analyzed: kammaṭṭhānam uggahetvā ti kammaṭṭhānam pariyatti dhammataḥ atthataḥ ca su gahitam su manasikatam
translated: Having learned the meditation subject : having learned the meditation subject well, having given it careful attention, having thoroughly grasped it, both as text and as meaning.

original: sūpadhāritaṃ katvā. Tenāha “uggahato ekapadampi avirajjhantenā”ti. Tattha uggahatoti
analyzed: sūpadhāritam katvā tena āha uggahato eka padam pi a virajjhantena ati tattha uggahato ti
translated: Hence he says, “without letting even a single word slip.”🔽Herein, “having learned” is from the teacher.

original: ācariyuggahato. Ekapadampīti ekampi padaṃ, ekakoṭṭhāsampi vā, padesamattampīti attho.🔽Dasahākārehīti kasmā vuttaṃ, nanu antimajīvikābhāvato, piṇḍapātassa alābhalābhesu🔽paritassanagedhādisamuppattito, bhuttassa sammadajananato, kimikulasaṃvaddhanatoti
analyzed: eka padam pi iti ekam pi padam eka koṭṭhāsam pi vā padesa mattam pi iti attho 🔽dasahā ākārehi iti kasmā vuttam nanu antima jīvikā bhāvato piṇḍapātassa alābha lābhesu 🔽paritassana gedha ādi samuppattitaḥ bhuttassa sammada jananato kimi kula saṃvaddhanato ti
translated: “Even a single word” : even a single phrase or a single clause or a single sentence.

original: evamādīhipi ākārehi āhāre paṭikkūlatā paccavekkhitabbā? Vuttaṃ hetaṃ “antamidaṃ,🔽bhikkhave, jīvikānaṃ yadidaṃ piṇḍolyaṃ, abhisāpoyaṃ, bhikkhave, lokasmiṃ ‘piṇḍolo🔽vicarasi pattapāṇī”’ti, “aladdhā ca piṇḍapātaṃ paritassati, laddhā ca piṇḍapātaṃ
analyzed: evamādīhi pi ākārehi āhāre paṭikkūla tā paccavekkhitabbā vuttam ha itam antam idam  bhikkhave jīvikānam yat idam piṇḍolyam abhisāpaḥ yam bhikkhave lokasmim piṇḍolaḥ  vicarasi patta pāṇī iti a laddhā ca piṇḍapātam paritassati laddhā ca piṇḍapātam
translated: For this is said: “Bhikkhus, this is the end of craving for sensual desires, that is, renunciation; this is the end of the pursuit of sensual pleasures, that is, fewness of wishes” .🔽“He is anxious if he does not get alms, and he enjoys the alms he gets greedily, gluttonously, blindly, unseeing, unmindful of danger, without knowing moderation.🔽After eating, he indulges in the pleasures of sleeping and drowsing and of leaning here and there, oblivious to the fact that his allotted time is passing.

original: gadhito mucchito ajjhosanno anādīnavadassāvī anissaraṇapañño paribhuñjatī”ti, “bhutto🔽ca āhāro kassaci kadāci maraṇaṃ vā maraṇamattaṃ vā dukkhaṃ āvahati, ukkocakādayo,
analyzed: gadhitaḥ mucchitaḥ ajjhosannaḥ anādīnava dassāvī anissaraṇa pañño paribhuñjati iti bhutto  ca āhāro kassaci kadāci maraṇam vā maraṇa mattam vā dukkham āvahati ukkocaka ādayo
translated: He is a burden to the country, a burden to the people, a burden to his parents, a burden to his wife and children, a burden to his slaves, servants, and workers.🔽He is a burden to his friends and companions, and he is a burden to his relatives.🔽He is a burden to the Sangha, a burden to the country, and a burden to the people.🔽He is a burden to the country, a burden to the people, a burden to his parents, a burden to his wife and children, a burden to his slaves, servants, and workers.🔽He is a burden to his friends and companions, and he is a burden to his relatives.🔽He is a burden to the Sangha, a burden to the country, and a burden to the people.

original: takkoṭakādayo ca dvattiṃsa dvattiṃsa kulappabhedā kimayo ca naṃ upanissāya jīvantī”ti.🔽Vuccate – antimajīvikābhāvo tāva cittasaṃkilesavisodhanatthaṃ kammaṭṭhānābhinivesato
analyzed: takkoṭaka ādayo ca dvattiṃsa dvattiṃsa kula ppabhedā ca nam upanissāya jīvanti iti  vuccate antima jīvikā bhāvo tāva citta saṃkilesa visodhana attham kammaṭṭhāna abhinivesato
translated: He is a burden to the country, a burden to the people, a burden to his parents, a burden to his wife and children, a burden to his slaves, servants, and workers.🔽He is a burden to his friends and companions, and he is a burden to his relatives.🔽He is a burden to the Sangha, a burden to the country, and a burden to the people.🔽He is a burden to the country, a burden to the people, a burden to his parents, a burden to his wife and children, a burden to his slaves, servants, and workers.🔽He is a burden to his friends and companions, and he is a burden to his relatives.🔽He is a burden to the Sangha, a burden to the country, and a burden to the people.🔽He is a burden to the country, a burden to the people, a burden to his parents, a burden to his wife and children, a burden to his slaves, servants, and workers.

original: pageva manasi kātabbo “māhaṃ chavālātasadiso bhaveyya”nti. Tathā piṇḍapātassa alābhalābhesupi
analyzed: pagā iva manasi kātabbaḥ mā aham chava alāta sadisaḥ bhaveyyan ti tathā piṇḍapātassa alābha lābhesu pi
translated: He is

original: paritassanagedhādisamuppattinivāraṇaṃ pageva anuṭṭhātabbaṃ suparisuddhasīlassa paṭisaṅkhānavato
analyzed: paritassana gedha ādi samuppatti nivāraṇam pagā iva anuṭṭhātabbam su parisuddha sīlassa paṭisaṅkhānavato
translated: and the prevention of the arising of the fear, etc., that have fear as their ground, must be undertaken by one whose virtue is purified and who is given to reviewing,

original: tadabhāvato. Bhattasammado anekantiko, paribhogantogadho vā veditabbo. Kimikulasaṃvaddhanaṃ
analyzed: tad abhāvataḥ bhatta sammadaḥ anekantiko vā veditabbo
translated: because of the absence of that. The satisfaction of the stomach is not definite, or it should be understood as deep in the sense of being hard to fill.

original: pana na saṅgahetabbaṃ, saṅgahitameva vā “dasahākārehī”ti ettha niyamassa akatattā.
analyzed: pana na saṅgahetabbam saṅgahitam eva vā dasahā ākārehi iti ettha niyamassa a kata ttā
translated: But the nourishing of the families of worms is not to be included, or it is included in the words “in ten ways,” because no restriction is stated.

original: Iminā vā nayena itaresampettha saṅgaho daṭṭhabbo yathāsambhavamettha paṭikkūlatāpaccavekkhaṇassa
analyzed: iminā vā nayena itaresam pa ittha saṅgahaḥ daṭṭhabbo yathāsambhavam ettha paṭikkūla tā paccavekkhaṇassa
translated: Or the inclusion of the others here should be understood in this way according to circumstances, because the contemplation of repulsiveness is intended here.

original: adhippetattā. Tathā hi gharagoḷikavaccamūsikajatukavaccādikaṃ sambhavantaṃ gahitaṃ,
analyzed: adhippeta ttā tathā hi ghara goḷika vat ca mūsika jatuka vat ca ādikam sambhavantam gahitam
translated: For the dung of village pigs, the dung of rats, etc., are included here according to circumstances,

original: na ekantikanti. Tathā pariyesanādīsupi yathāsambhavaṃ vattabbaṃ.
analyzed: na ekantikam ti tathā pariyesana ādīsu pi yathāsambhavam vattabbam
translated: but not definitely. And so too with the search, etc., it should be said according to circumstances.

original: Gamanatotiādīsu paccāgamanampi gamanasabhāgattā gamaneneva saṅgahitaṃ. Paṭikkamanasālādiupasaṅkamanaṃ
analyzed: gamanato ti ādīsu pacca āgamanam pi gamana sabhā gattā gamanena iva saṅgahitam paṭikkamana sāla ādi upasaṅkamanam
translated: As regards the words “by going,” etc., the return is included by the going because it has the same nature as the going. The approaching of the place for turning back, etc.,

original: viya pariyesane samānapaṭikkūlaṃ hi asuciṭṭhānakkamanavirūpaduggandhadassanaghāyanādhivāsanehi.
analyzed: viya pariyesane samāna paṭikkūlam hi asuci ṭṭhāna kkamana virūpa duggandha dassana ghāyana adhivāsanehi
translated: for what is repulsive in seeking is the sight, smell, and so on, of the place where the excrement is discharged, which is ugly and malodorous.

original: Gamanatoti bhikkhācāravasena gocaragāmaṃ uddissa gamanato. Pariyesanatoti gocaragāme🔽bhikkhatthaṃ āhiṇḍanato. Paribhogatoti āhārassa paribhuñjanato. Ubhayaṃ ubhayena
analyzed: gamanato ti bhikkhā cāra vasena gocara gāmam uddissa gamanato pariyesanato ti gocara gāme  bhikkha attham āhiṇḍanataḥ paribhogato ti āhārassa paribhuñjanataḥ ubhayam ubhayena
translated: By going: by going to the alms-resort village for the purpose of going on continuous alms round.🔽By seeking: by wandering for alms in the alms-resort village.

original: āsayati, ekajjhaṃ pavattamānopi kammabalavavatthito hutvā mariyādavasena aññamaññaṃ
analyzed: āsayati ekajjham pavattamānaḥ api kamma bala vavatthitaḥ hutvā mariyāda vasena aññam aññam
translated: By using: by using the food. Both are “stored” by each in the sense of a limit since, though occurring together, they are distinguished by the strength of the kamma that is the cause of their occurrence.

original: asaṅkarato sayati tiṭṭhati pavattatīti āsayo, āmāsayassa upari tiṭṭhanako pittādiko.🔽Mariyādattho hi ayamākāro, tato āsayato. Nidadhāti yathābhutto āhāro nicito hutvā
analyzed: asaṅkarataḥ sayati tiṭṭhati pavattati iti āsayaḥ āma āsayassa upari tiṭṭhanako pitta ādiko  mariyādatthaḥ hi ayam ākāraḥ tatas āsayataḥ nidadhāti yathābhuttaḥ āhāraḥ nicitaḥ hutvā
translated: They “stay” in the sense of a store, that is, the bile, etc., that stay above the receptacle for digested food.🔽For this is the meaning of the word “store”: a limit.

original: tiṭṭhati etthāti nidhānaṃ, āmāsayo, tato nidhānato. Aparipakkatoti gahaṇīsaṅkhātena
analyzed: tiṭṭhati ettha ati nidhānam tatas nidhānataḥ gahaṇī saṅkhātena
translated: “It is deposited” in the sense of a receptacle, that is, the receptacle for digested food, where the food that has been eaten is stored.🔽“It is undigested” in the sense of being seized by the heat of the fire element and not being ejected.

original: kammajatejena aparipakkato. Paripakkatoti yathābhuttassa āhārassa vipakkabhāvato.
analyzed: kamma ja tejena a paripakkataḥ paripakkataḥ ti yathā bhuttassa āhārassa vipakka bhāvato
translated: “It is digested” in the sense of being cooked by the heat of the fire element.

original: Phalatoti nibbattito. Nissandatoti ito cito ca vissandanato. Sammakkhanatoti sabbaso🔽makkhanato. Sabbattha āhāre paṭikkūlatā paccavekkhitabbāti yojanā. Taṃtaṃkiriyānipphattipaṭipāṭivasena
analyzed: phalato ti nibbattitaḥ nissandato ti itas ca itas ca vissandanato sammakkhanato ti sabbaso
translated: As to fruit: it is produced. As to outcome: because it issues here and there. As to thorough contemplation: because it is thoroughly contemplated. The construction of the sentence is: “The repulsiveness in nutriment should be reviewed in all instances.”

original: cāyaṃ gamanatotiādikā anupubbī ṭhapitā, sammakkhanaṃ pana paribhogādīsu labbhamānampi
analyzed: ca ayam gamanataḥ ti ādikā anupubbī ṭhapitā sammakkhanam pana paribhoga ādīsu labbhamānam pi
translated: The order of the exposition beginning with “as to going” is given according to the order of the successive results of the several kinds of action. But though thorough contemplation is found in the case of using, etc.,

original: nissandavasena visesato paṭikkūlanti sabbapacchā ṭhapitanti daṭṭhabbaṃ.🔽295. Evaṃ mahānubhāveti idāni vattabbapaṭipattiyā mahānubhāveti vadanti, sabbatthakakammaṭṭhānapariharaṇādisiddhaṃ🔽vā dhammasudhammataṃ purakkhatvā yogāvacarena evaṃ paṭipajjitabbanti dassento “evaṃ
analyzed: nissanda vasena visesato paṭikkūlanti sabba pacchā ṭhapitanti daṭṭhabbaṃ  evam mahā anubhāvā iti idāni vattabba paṭipattiyā mahā anubhāvā iti vadanti sabbatthaka kammaṭṭhāna pariharaṇa ādi siddham  vā dhamma su dhamma tam purakkhatvā yogāvacarena evam paṭipajjitabbanti dassento evam
translated: it is placed last as the most outstanding kind of repulsiveness as outcome.🔽As to great import: they say that it has great import as the practice that should now be undertaken. Or else, considering the true state of things that is achieved by the successful practice of all the meditation subjects,

original: mahānubhāve nāma sāsane”tiādimāha. Tattha nāma-saddo sambhāvane daṭṭhabbo. Pabbajitena
analyzed: mahā anubhāve nāma sāsana iti ādim āha tattha nāma saddo sambhāvane daṭṭhabbo pabbajitena
translated: the meditator should practice in this way. Showing how he should practice, he said, “In a dispensation such as this,” etc. Herein, the word “such” should be regarded as a demonstrative pronoun referring to the following terms: “in a dispensation that is so well taught,” “in a doctrine that is so well proclaimed,” “in a discipline that is so well expounded,” “in a path that is so well described,” “in a non-obstruction that is so well defined,” “in a non-confusion that is so well defined,” “in a non-interruption that is so well defined,” “in a non-hindrance that is so well defined,” “in a non-obstruction that is so well defined,” “in a non-confusion that is so well defined,” “in a non-interruption that is so well defined,” “in a non-hindrance that is so well defined,” “in a non-obstruction that is so well defined,” “in a non-confusion that is so well defined,” “in a non-interruption that is so well defined,” “in a non-hindrance that is so well defined,” “in a non-obstruction that is so well defined,” “in a non-confusion that is so well defined,” “in a non-interruption that is so well defined,” “in a non-hindrance that is so well defined,” “in a non-obstruction that is so well defined,” “in a non-confusion that is so well defined,” “in a non-interruption that is so well defined,” “in a non-hindrance that is so well defined,” “in a non-obstruction that is so

original: gāmābhimukhena gantabbanti yojanā. Ayañca gamanādito paccavekkhaṇā yogino na attuddesikāva,
analyzed: gāma abhimukhena gantabbanti yojanā ayam ca gamana āditas paccavekkhaṇā yoginaḥ na attuddesikā ava
translated: This reflection on going and so on is not only for the purpose of directing the bhikkhu’s attention to himself;

original: atha kho anuddesikāpīti dassento “sakalaratti”ntiādinā dhuradvayaṃ pariggahesi. Pariveṇanti
analyzed: atha kho anuddesikā api iti dassento sakala ratti nti ādinā dhura dvayam pariggahesi
translated: it is also for the purpose of directing it to others. So he includes a second subject by mentioning “the whole night.”🔽The “courtyard” is the courtyard of the monastery.

original: pariveṇaṅgaṇaṃ. Vīsatiṃsavāreti ettha santatipaccuppannavasena vāraparicchedoti keci,
analyzed: pariveṇaṅgaṇam vīsatiṃsa vāra iti ettha santati paccuppanna vasena vāra paricchedaḥ ti keci
translated: As to “twenty-one times”: some say that the division into times is according to continuity and momentary arising.

original: apare pana “uṇhāsanenā”ti vadanti. Nīvaraṇavikkhambhanañhi appattā bhāvanā pharaṇapītiyā
analyzed: apare pana uṇhāsanena ati vadanti nīvaraṇa vikkhambhanam hi appattā bhāvanā pharaṇa pītiyā
translated: But others say that it is according to the “hot seat.”

original: abhāvato nisajjāvasena kāyakilamathaṃ na vinodatiyevāti iriyāpathacalanaṃ hotiyeva.🔽Vīsatiṃsaggahaṇaṃ pana yathāsallakkhitabhikkhācaraṇavelāvasena. Atha vā gamanato
