analyzed: abhāvataḥ nisajjā vasena kāya kilamatham na iriyāpatha calanam  vīsatiṃsa ggahaṇam pana yathāsat lakkhita bhikkhā caraṇa velā vasena atha vā gamanataḥ
translated: For when the development of the meditation subject has not reached suppression of hindrances, the fatigue of the body is not removed by sitting because there is no pervading of happiness.🔽So there is movement of posture.

original: yāva sammakkhanamanasikāro eko vāro, evaṃ vīsatiṃsavāre kammaṭṭhānaṃ manasi karitvā.
analyzed: yāva sammakkhana manasikāraḥ ekaḥ vāraḥ evam vīsatiṃsa vāre kammaṭṭhānam manasi karitvā
translated: But the mentioning of twenty-one times is according to the time of going for alms as observed. Or alternatively, from the time of going until the time of attention given to smearing the body with unguent is one time. He should give attention to the meditation subject in this way twenty-one times.

original: Nijanasambādhānīti janasambādharahitāni, tena appākiṇṇataṃ, appasaddataṃ, appanigghosatañca
analyzed: nijana sambādhāni iti jana sambādha rahitāni tena appa ākiṇṇa tam appa sadda tam appa nigghosa tam ca
translated: ‘Secluded from human beings’ means free from the presence of human beings. He shows thereby that they are uncrowded, quiet, and undisturbed.

original: dasseti. Tato eva pavivekasukhāni janavivekena iṭṭhāni, pavivekassa vā jhānānuyogassa
analyzed: dasseti tatas eva paviveka sukhāni jana vivekena iṭṭhāni pavivekassa vā jhāna anuyogassa
translated: And because of that they are ‘pleasing because of seclusion’ since they are liked because of the absence of people, or they are ‘helpful to the pleasure of seclusion’ since they are helpful to the jhāna that is the practice of seclusion.

original: upakārāni. Yasmā chāyūdakasampannāni, tasmā sītalāni. Yasmā sucīni, tasmā ramaṇīyabhūmibhāgānīti
analyzed: upakārāni chāyu udaka sampannāni tasmā sītalāni yasmā sucīni tasmā ramaṇīya bhūmi bhāgāni iti
translated: And because they are endowed with shade and water they are ‘cool,’ and because they are clean they are ‘delightful in ground,’

original: purimāni dve pacchimānaṃ dvinnaṃ kāraṇavacanāni. Ariyanti niddosaṃ. Vivekaratinti jhānānuyogaratiṃ.
analyzed: purimāni dve pacchimānam kāraṇavacanāni niddosam jhāna anuyoga ratim
translated: so that the first two terms are a reason for the last two. ‘Noble’ means free from danger. ‘Seclusion-lovers’ means lovers of the practice of jhāna.

original: Kiñcāpi yogāvacarānaṃ vasanaṭṭhānaṃ nāma sujaggitaṃ susammaṭṭhameva hoti, kadāci🔽pana jagganato pacchā evampi siyāti paṭikkūlatāpaccavekkhaṇāya sambhavadassanatthaṃ
analyzed: kiñca api vasanaṭṭhānam nāma su jaggitam su sammaṭṭham eva hoti kadāci  pana jagganato pacchā evam pi siyā ti paṭikkūla tā paccavekkhaṇāya sambhava dassana ttham
translated: And although the dwelling place of meditators is well swept and clean, still it may be so🔽after sweeping. So ‘strewn with the cast-off leavings of offerings, with sweepings, with rubbish’ is said in order to show that the contemplation of repulsiveness is possible there.

original: “pādarajagharagolikavaccādisamparikiṇṇa”ntiādi vuttanti daṭṭhabbaṃ. Tattha paccattharaṇanti
analyzed: pāda raja ghara golika vacca ādi samparikiṇṇa ntiādi vuttanti daṭṭhabbam tattha paccattharaṇam ti
translated: Herein, ‘bedding’ is

original: bhūmiyā chavirakkhaṇatthaṃ attharitabbaṃ cimilikādiattharaṇamāha. Jatukā khuddakavagguliyo.🔽Upahatattāti dūsitattā. Tatoti tato tato. Appekadā ulūkapārāvatādīhīti idhāpi “appekadā”ti
analyzed: bhūmiyā chavi rakkhaṇa attham attharitabbam cimilikā ādi attharaṇam āha jatukā khuddaka vagguliyo  upahata ttā ati dūsita ttā tatoti tato tato appekadā ulūka pārāvata ādīhi iti idha api appekadā ti
translated: The spread of grass, etc., is the spread of grass, etc., for the purpose of protecting the ground. Small lizards.

original: padaṃ ānetvā sambandhitabbaṃ. Udakacikkhallādīhīti ādi-saddena kacavarādiṃ saṅgaṇhāti.
analyzed: padam ānetvā sambandhitabbam udakacikkhalla ādīhi iti ādi saddena kaca vara ādim saṅgaṇhāti
translated: Because it is spoiled. From here and there: from here and there. Sometimes by owls, crows, etc. Here too the word “sometimes” should be brought in and connected. By water, mud, etc.: the word “etc.” includes refuse, and so on.

original: Pariveṇato vihāraṅgaṇappavesamaggo vihāraracchā.
analyzed: pariveṇataḥ vihāra aṅgaṇa pavesa maggaḥ vihāra racchā
translated: The path from the surrounding space to the courtyard of the monastery building is the monastery path.

original: Vitakkamāḷaketi “kattha nu kho ajja bhikkhāya caritabba”ntiādinā vitakkanamāḷake.🔽Gāmamagganti gāmagāmimaggaṃ. Khāṇukaṇṭakamaggoti khāṇukaṇṭakavanto maggo. Daṭṭhabbo
analyzed: vitakka māḷaka iti kattha nu kho ajja bhikkhāya caritabbanti ādinā vitakkana māḷake  gāma maggam ti gāma gāmi maggam khāṇu kaṇṭaka maggo ti khāṇu kaṇṭakavantaḥ maggaḥ daṭṭhabbo
translated: In the place of thinking: in the place of thinking, “Where shall I go for alms today?”

original: hotīti dassanena gamanaṃ upalakkheti.🔽Gaṇḍaṃ paṭicchādentenātiādi evamajjhāsayena nivāsanādi kātabbanti vattadassanaṃ,
analyzed: hoti iti dassanena gamanam upalakkheti  gaṇḍam paṭicchādentena atiādi evam ajjhāsayena nivāsana ādi kātabbanti vatta dassanam
translated: The village path: the path going to the village. The path with stumps and thorns: the path with stumps and thorns. Should be seen: he indicates going by seeing.🔽By one who is concealing a boil, etc.: the showing of the proper conduct is that the wearing of the robe, etc., should be done with such an intention,

original: gaṇḍaroginā vātātapādiparissayavinodanatthaṃ gaṇḍaṃ paṭicchādayamānena viya. Atha
analyzed: gaṇḍaroginā vāta ātapa ādi parissaya vinodana attham gaṇḍam paṭicchādayamānena atha
translated: as if by one who is concealing a boil, who is sick with a boil, for the purpose of avoiding the danger of wind, sun, etc. Then,

original: vā gaṇḍaṃ viya gaṇḍaṃ paṭicchādayamānenāti ekaṃ gaṇḍa-saddaṃ ānetvā sambandhitabbaṃ
analyzed: vā gaṇḍam viya gaṇḍam paṭicchādayamānena ati ekam gaṇḍa saddam ānetvā sambandhitabbam
translated: As if concealing a boil with a boil. The word boil should be brought in once only.

original: bhavati. “Gaṇḍoti kho, bhikkhave, pañcannetaṃ upādānakkhandhānaṃ adhivacana”nti vacanato
analyzed: bhavati gaṇḍaḥ iti kho bhikkhave pañcanna etam upādānakkhandhānam adhivacananti vacanato
translated: “Bhikkhus, the word boil is a term for the five aggregates as objects of clinging” .

original: gaṇḍoti attabhāvassa pariyāyo, visesato rūpakāyassa dukkhatāsūlayogato, asucipaggharaṇato,🔽uppādajarābhaṅgehi uddhumātakapakkapabhijjanato. Vaṇacoḷakanti vaṇapaṭicchādakavatthakhaṇḍaṃ.
analyzed: gaṇḍo ti atta bhāvassa pariyāyaḥ visesataḥ rūpa kāyassa dukkha tā sūla yogataḥ asuci paggharaṇato  uppāda jarā bhaṅgehi vaṇa coḷakanti vaṇa paṭicchādaka vattha khaṇḍam
translated: A boil is a synonym for the individual form, especially for the material body, because it is associated with the suffering of the boil, because it discharges impurities,🔽and because it is subject to swelling up, ripening and bursting, like a boil. A rag from a charnel ground: a piece of cloth used for covering a wound.

original: Nīharitvāti thavikato uddharitvā. Kuṇapānipīti pi-saddo garahāyaṃ evarūpānipi daṭṭhabbāni
analyzed: nīharitvā ti thavikataḥ uddharitvā kuṇapāni api iti pi saddaḥ evarūpāni api daṭṭhabbāni
translated: Having taken out: having extracted from the body. A corpse: the word pi is a particle of contempt. Such things as these are to be seen,

original: bhavantīti, sambhavadassane vā idampi tattha sambhavatīti. Adhivāsetabboti khamitabbo
analyzed: bhavanti iti sambhava dassane vā idam pi tattha sambhavati iti adhivāsetabbaḥ ti khamitabbaḥ
translated: or else it is a statement of what is possible, that this is possible there. Should be endured: should be borne.

original: aññathā āhārassa anupalabbhanato. Gāmadvāreti gāmadvārasamīpe, ummārabbhantare vā.
analyzed: aññathā āhārassa anupalabbhanataḥ gāma dvāra iti gāma dvāra samīpe ummāra bbhantare vā
translated: Otherwise, since there would be no food, in the vicinity of the village gate or in the middle of the village.

original: Gāmaracchā vinivijjhitvā ṭhitā oloketabbā honti yugamattadassināpi satāti adhippāyo.
analyzed: gāma racchāḥ vinivijjhitvā ṭhitāḥ oloketabbāḥ honti yuga matta dassinā api satā ati adhippāyaḥ
translated: The meaning is that the village lanes should be looked on as if they were cut in two and were lying there, even by one who sees only a yoke’s length in front of him.

original: Paccattharaṇādīti gharagolikavaccādisaṃkiliṭṭhapaccattharaṇādikaṃ. Anekakuṇapapariyosānanti
analyzed: paccattharaṇa ādi iti ghara golika vacca ādi saṃkiliṭṭha paccattharaṇa ādikam aneka kuṇapa pariyosānam ti
translated: ‘Spreading, etc.’: the spreading, etc., that are soiled by the leavings of food, by spittle, and so on. ‘Up to corpses’:

original: ettha dunnivatthaduppārutamanussasamākulānaṃ gāmaracchānaṃ olokanampi ānetvā vattabbaṃ.🔽Tampi hi paṭikkūlamevāti. Aho vatāti garahane nipāto. Bhoti dhammālapanaṃ. Yāvañcidaṃ
analyzed: ettha dunnivattha duppāruta manussa samākulānam gāma racchānam olokanam pi ānetvā vattabbam  tat pi hi paṭikkūlam evā ati aho vata ati gara hane nipātaḥ bhoti dhamma ālapanam yāvañcidam
translated: here the looking at village lanes crowded with men and women who are badly clothed and poorly fed should be brought in too.

original: paṭikkūlo āhāro yadatthaṃ gamanampi nāma evaṃ jegucchaṃ, duradhivāsanañcāti attho.
analyzed: paṭikkūlaḥ āhāraḥ yadattham gamanam pi nāma evam jeguccham duradhivāsanam ca ati
translated: For that is repulsive too. ‘Oh, what’’: the particle ‘oh’ is an exclamation of disgust. ‘Food’: this is a term for requisites. ‘How repulsive is food’: the meaning is that it is hard to endure because of the loathsomeness of the going for it.

original: 296. Gamanapaṭikkūlanti gamanameva paṭikkūlaṃ gamanapaṭikkūlaṃ. Adhivāsetvāpīti pi-saddo🔽sampiṇḍanattho, tena “ettakenāpi mutti natthi, ito parampi mahantaṃ paṭikkūlaṃ sakalaṃ
analyzed: gamana paṭikkūlanti gamanam eva paṭikkūlam gamana paṭikkūlam adhivāsetvā api iti pi saddaḥ  sampiṇḍana tthaḥ tena ettakena api mutti natthi itas param pi mahantam paṭikkūlam sakalam
translated: ‘Repulsive in going’: the going itself is repulsive, thus it is ‘repulsive in going.’ ‘Even after enduring’: the word ‘even’

original: adhivāsetabbamevā”ti vakkhamānaṃ paṭikkūlaṃ sampiṇḍeti. Saṅghāṭipārutenāti saṅghāṭiyā
analyzed: adhivāsetabbam eva ati vakkhamānam paṭikkūlam sampiṇḍeti saṅghāṭi pārutena ati saṅghāṭiyā
translated: has the meaning of an inclusive particle. Its purpose is to include the following repulsive things that are going to be mentioned, which are more repulsive still, in the word ‘repulsive’ in the phrase ‘there is no escape by means of even this much, but still, after enduring, one should go for more and more of it’: ‘Wearing the outer robe as a sunshade,’ etc.

original: kappanapārupanena pārutasarīrena. Yatthāti yāsu vīthīsu. Yāva piṇḍikamaṃsāpīti yāva🔽jaṅghapiṇḍikamaṃsappadesāpi. Udakacikkhalleti udakamisse kaddame. Ekena cīvaranti
analyzed: kappana pārupanena pāruta sarīrena yatthā ati yāsu vīthīsu yāva  jaṅgha piṇḍika maṃsa ppadesā api udakacikkhallā iti udaka misse kaddame ekena cīvaranti
translated: with the robe on, with the body covered. Where: in which streets. As far as the meat of the thigh: as far as the place of the thigh meat. In the mud of water: in the mud mixed with water. With one robe:🔽

original: ekena hatthena nivatthacīvaraṃ. Macchā dhovīyanti etenāti macchadhovanaṃ, udakaṃ.🔽Sammissa-saddo paccekaṃ sambandhitabbo. Oḷigallāni ucchiṭṭhodakagabbhamalādīnaṃ sakaddamānaṃ🔽sandanaṭṭhānāni, yāni jaṇṇumattaasucibharitānipi honti. Candanikāni kevalānaṃ ucchiṭṭhodakagabbhamalādīnaṃ
analyzed: ekena hatthena nivattha cīvaram macchā dhovīyanti etena ati maccha dhovanam udakam  sammissa saddaḥ paccekam sambandhitabbaḥ oḷigallāni ucchiṭṭha udaka gabbha mala ādīnam sa kaddamānam  sandana ṭṭhānāni yāni honti candanikāni kevalānam ucchiṭṭha udaka gabbha mala ādīnam
translated: with the robe on, with the body covered. Where: in which streets. As far as the meat of the thigh: as far as the place of the thigh and the flesh of the thigh. In the mud of water: in the mud mixed with water. With one robe: with one hand. The robe that is put on. The fish-washing: that by which the fish are washed. Water.

original: sandanaṭṭhānāni. Yatoti oḷigallādito. Tā makkhikāti tattha saṇḍasaṇḍacārino nīlamakkhikā.
analyzed: sandana ṭṭhānāni yatas ti oḷigalla āditaḥ tā makkhikā ti tattha saṇḍa saṇḍa cārinaḥ nīla makkhikā
translated: The word “mixed” should be construed with each. The cesspools: the places for the disposal of the contents of the cesspit, the urine-disposal trenches, etc., which are full of mud. The open drains: the places for the disposal of urine-disposal trenches, etc., which are not covered. From there: from the cesspools, etc. The flies: the bluebottles that wander about here and there.

original: Nilīyantīti acchanti.
analyzed: nilīyanti iti acchanti
translated: They settle: they stay.

original: Dadamānāpītiādi satipi kesañci saddhānaṃ vasena sakkaccakāre paṭikkūlapaccavekkhaṇāyogyaṃ
analyzed: dadamānā api itiādi vasena sakkacca kāre paṭikkūla paccavekkhaṇā yogyam
translated: Giving: although some people give respectfully, it is suitable for reflection on the repulsive nature of the body.

original: pana asaddhānaṃ vasena pavattanakaasakkaccakārameva dassetuṃ āraddhaṃ. Tuṇhī honti
analyzed: pana asaddhānam vasena pavattanaka asakkacca kāram eva dassetum āraddham tuṇhī honti
translated: But it is begun in order to show the mode of procedure by way of lack of faith.🔽They are silent.🔽“Go away” means “Depart.” “Bald-head” is a term of disrespect.

original: sayameva riñcitvā gacchissatīti. Gacchāti apehi. Reti ambho. Muṇḍakāti anādarālapanaṃ.🔽Samudācarantīti kathenti. Piṇḍolyassa antimajīvikābhāvenāha “kapaṇamanussena viya
analyzed: sayam eva riñcitvā gacchissati iti gacchāti apehi re ti ambhaḥ muṇḍaka ati an ādara ālapanam  samudācaranti iti kathenti piṇḍolyassa antima jīvikā bhāvena āha kapaṇa manussena viya
translated: “They are talking about you” means “They are saying.”

original: gāme piṇḍāya caritvā nikkhamitabba”nti.🔽297. Tatthāti tasmiṃ pattagate āhāre. Lajjitabbaṃ hoti “ucchiṭṭhaṃ nu kho ayaṃ mayhaṃ
analyzed: gāme piṇḍāya caritvā nikkhamitabbanti  tattha ati tasmin patta gate āhāre lajjitabbam hoti ucchiṭṭham nu kho ayam mayham
translated: “As if you were a beggar” means that he should go out after having gone for alms in the village as if he were a beggar, because of his having a low means of livelihood.🔽“There” means in that food that has been brought. “He should be ashamed” means “He should be apprehensive, thinking, ‘Does he want to give me what has been left over by others?’”

original: dātukāmo”ti āsaṅkeyyāti, sedo paggharamāno āhārassa vā uṇhatāya, bhikkhuno vā sapariḷāhatāyāti
analyzed: dātu kāmo ti āsaṅkeyya ati sedaḥ paggharamānaḥ āhārassa vā uṇha tāya bhikkhuno vā sa pariḷāha tāya ati
translated: The intention is that the sweat is produced either by the heat of the food or by the heat of the bhikkhu’s own fever.

original: adhippāyo. Sukkhathaddhabhattampīti sukkhatāya thaddhampi bhattaṃ, pageva takkakañjikādinā
analyzed: adhippāyaḥ sukkha thaddha bhattam pi iti sukkha tāya thaddham pi bhattam pageva takka kañjika ādinā
translated: “Even dry hard food” means that the intention is that even dry hard food is repulsive because of the sweat that is produced by its dryness and hardness, much more so food that is mixed with oil, sour, etc.

original: upasittanti adhippāyo. Tena sedena kilinnatāya paṭikkūlataṃ vadati.
analyzed: adhippāyo tena sedena kilinna tāya paṭikkūla tam vadati
translated: He speaks of its repulsiveness because of its being soiled by that sweat.

original: Tasminti piṇḍapāte. Sambhinnasobheti sabbaso vinaṭṭhasobhe. Vemajjhato paṭṭhāyāti🔽jivhāya majjhato paṭṭhāya. Dantagūthako dantamalaṃ. Vicuṇṇitamakkhitoti ubhayehi
analyzed: tasmin ti piṇḍapāte sambhinna sobhe iti sabbasas vinaṭṭha sobhe vemajjhataḥ paṭṭhāya ati  jivhāya majjhataḥ paṭṭhāya danta gūthakaḥ danta malam ubhayehi
translated: In that alms food: in that alms food. Its beauty is destroyed: its beauty is all destroyed. From the middle onwards:🔽from the middle of the tongue. Tooth-scrapings: the dirt on the teeth. Smeared with spittle: smeared with spittle, etc.,

original: dantehi vicuṇṇito kheḷādīhi samupalitto. Evaṃbhūtassa cassa yāyaṃ pubbe vaṇṇasampadā,🔽gandhasampadā, abhisaṅkhārasampadā ca, sā ekaṃsena vinassati, raso pana nasseyya
analyzed: dantehi vicuṇṇitaḥ kheḷa ādīhi samupalittaḥ evaṃbhūtassa ca ssa yā ayam pubbe vaṇṇa sampadā  gandha sampadā abhisaṅkhāra sampadā ca sā ekaṃsena vinassati rasaḥ pana nasseyya
translated: by both teeth. In this way: in this way, having become like this, its former excellence of colour,

original: vā na vāti āha “antarahitavaṇṇagandhasaṅkhāraviseso”ti. Suvānadoṇiyanti sārameyyānaṃ🔽bhuñjanakaambaṇe. Suvānavamathu viyāti vantasunakhachaḍḍanaṃ viya. Cakkhussa āpāthaṃ
analyzed: vā na vā iti āha antara hita vaṇṇa gandha saṅkhāra visesaḥ iti suvāna doṇiyanti  bhuñjana kaambaṇe suvāna vamathu viyā ati vanta su nakha chaḍḍanam viya cakkhussa āpātham
translated: excellence of smell, and excellence of preparation, is all destroyed. But the taste may or may not be destroyed. Therefore it is said: “The distinction of colour, smell, and preparation is lost” . In a dog’s drinking-dish:

original: atītattā ajjhoharitabbo hotīti ukkaṃsagataṃ tassa paṭikkūlabhāvaṃ vibhāveti.
analyzed: atīta ttā ajjhoharitabbo hoti iti ukkaṃsa gatam tassa paṭikkūla bhāvam vibhāveti
translated: in a dog’s drinking-bowl. Like a dog’s vomit: like a dog’s vomit. It is swallowed: it is swallowed because it has gone beyond the range of the eye. Thus he defines its repulsiveness as “in the mouth.”

original: 298. Paribhoganti ajjhoharaṇaṃ. Esa āhāro anto pavisamāno bahalamadhukatelamakkhito
analyzed: paribhoganti ajjhoharaṇam esaḥ āhāraḥ antar pavisamānaḥ bahala madhuka tela makkhito
translated: Eating: swallowing. This food, when it has gone inside, is mixed with the thick phlegm, bile, and wind.

original: viya paramajeguccho hotīti sambandho. Antoti koṭṭhassa abbhantare. Nidhānamanupagato🔽āmāsayaṃ appattoyeva āhāro pittādīhi vimissito hotīti āha “pavisamāno”ti. Āmāsayapakkāsayavinimutto
analyzed: viya parama jegucchaḥ hoti iti sambandho antar ti koṭṭhassa abbhantare nidhānam anupagataḥ  āma āsayam appatto yeva āhāraḥ pitta ādīhi vimissitaḥ hoti iti āha pavisamānaḥ ti āma āsaya pakka āsaya vinimuttaḥ
translated: The food, not yet reached the receptacle, is mixed with bile, etc.🔽The receptacle is the stomach.

original: koyamāsayo nāmāti āsaṅkaṃ sandhāyāha “yasmā”tiādi. Pittamevāsayo pittāsayo. Adhiko
analyzed: kaḥ ayam āsayaḥ nāma ati āsaṅkam sandhāya āha pittam eva āsayaḥ pitta āsayaḥ
translated: The receptacle of bile is the place where bile is stored.🔽The bile is in excess there.

original: hotīti vuttaṃ mandapuññabāhullato lokassa. Evaṃ āsayatoti jeguccho hutvā anto paviṭṭho
analyzed: hoti iti vuttam manda puñña bāhullato lokassa evam āsayataḥ ti jegucchaḥ hutvā antar paviṭṭhaḥ
translated: This is said because people have little merit.

original: jegucchatarehi pittādīhi vimissito ativiya jeguccho hotīti evaṃ āsayato paṭikkūlatā paccavekkhitabbā.
analyzed: jegucchatarehi pitta ādīhi vimissitaḥ ativiya jegucchaḥ hoti iti evam āsayataḥ paṭikkūla tā paccavekkhitabbā
translated: Thus the repulsiveness should be reviewed as to receptacle in this way: “Having become disgusting, the food enters the stomach and, mixed with bile, etc., becomes even more disgusting.”🔽The same method applies to the “source.”🔽The food, not yet reached the receptacle, is mixed with bile, etc.,🔽in the place called the stomach.🔽Such: of that kind. For ten years: for ten years of age.

original: 299. Nidhānatoti etthāpi eseva nayo. Soti āhāro. Dasavassikenāti jātiyā dasavassena sattena. Okāseti āmāsayasaṅkhāte padese.🔽300. Evarūpeti edise, dasavassāni yāva vassasataṃ adhotavaccakūpasadiseti attho.
analyzed: nidhānato ti ettha api esā iva nayaḥ saḥ ti āhāraḥ dasavassikena ati jātiyāḥ dasa vassena sattena okāse āmāsaya saṅkhāte padese 🔽evarūpā iti edise dasa vassāni yāva vassa satam adhotavaccakūpa sadisā iti attho
translated: In the place: in the place called the stomach.

original: Nidhānanti nidhātabbataṃ. Yathāvuttappakāreti sace pana “dasavassikenā”tiādinā yathāvutto
analyzed: nidhānam ti nidhātabba tam yathāvutta ppakāra iti sace pana dasa vassikena āti ādinā yathāvuttaḥ
translated: Nidhana = the state of being laid down. Yathāvuttappakāreti. If it is the kind of thing described in the way beginning, “By one of ten years” , then it is of the kind described in that way.

original: pakāro etassāti yathāvuttappakāro, tasmiṃ. Paramandhakāratimiseti ativiya andhakaraṇamahātamasi.
analyzed: pakāraḥ etassa ati yathā vutta ppakāraḥ tasmin param andhakāra timise ti andha karaṇa mahā tamasi
translated: In that: in the place described in that way. In the thick darkness of the night: in the thick darkness of the night, which is very dark.

original: Atiduggandhajegucche padese paramajegucchabhāvaṃ upagantvā tiṭṭhatīti sambandho.
analyzed: ati duggandha jegucche padese parama jeguccha bhāvam upagantvā tiṭṭhati iti sambandhaḥ
translated: In a place that is extremely malodorous and filthy: the construction is “it lies down having reached the state of being extremely filthy.”

original: Kattha kiṃ viyāti āha “yathā nāmā”tiādi. Kālameghena abhivuṭṭhe āvāṭe bahuso vassanena
analyzed: kattha kim viya iti āha yathā nāma atiādi kāla meghena abhivuṭṭhe āvāṭe bahusas vassanena
translated: Where? What like? He said “Just as, for instance,” and so on.🔽In a pit that has been rained on by a timely cloud, some of the filth that has arisen might disappear by swelling up,

original: ekaccaṃ asucijātaṃ uppilavitvā vigaccheyyāti akālamegha-ggahaṇaṃ. Tiṇapaṇṇakilañjakhaṇḍa-ggahaṇaṃ🔽na asubhassāpi asubhena sammissatāya asubhabhāvappattidassanatthaṃ. Kāyaggisantāpakuthitakuthanasañjātapheṇapubbuḷakācitoti
analyzed: ekaccam asuci jātam uppilavitvā vigaccheyya ati akāla megha ggahaṇam tiṇa paṇṇa kilañja khaṇḍa ggahaṇam  na asubhassa api asubhena sammissa tāya asubha bhāva ppatti dassana tham kāya aggi santāpa kuthita kuthana sañjāta pheṇa pubbuḷaka ācitā ti
translated: so he mentions an untimely cloud. He mentions grass, leaves, twigs, and so on,🔽in order to show that the foulness of the foulness does not reach the state of foulness because it is mixed with the foulness of that.🔽The body is heated by the fire of the charnel ground, and it is covered with froth and bubbles produced by the boiling,

original: gahaṇitejena pakkuthitanippakkatāya samuppannapheṇapubbuḷanicito. Aparipakkatoti aparipakkabhāvato.
analyzed: gahaṇi tejena pakkuthita nippakka tāya samuppanna pheṇa pubbuḷa nicitaḥ a paripakka to ti a paripakka bhāvataḥ
translated: so he mentions it by the heat of the fire of the charnel ground. It is covered with froth and bubbles produced by the boiling and bubbling that arise because it is boiled and heated by the heat of the charnel ground fire. It is uncooked: because it is uncooked.

original: 301. Suvaṇṇarajatādidhātuyo viyāti yathā suvaṇṇarajatādidhātuyo vidhinā tāpiyamānā
analyzed: suvaṇṇa rajata ādi dhātuyaḥ viyāti yathā suvaṇṇa rajata ādi dhātuyaḥ vidhinā
translated: Like the elements of gold, silver, etc.,🔽Just as the elements of gold, silver, etc., when heated in a furnace,

original: suvaṇṇarajatādike muñcantiyo suvaṇṇarajatādibhāvaṃ upagacchantīti vuccanti, na evamayaṃ.
analyzed: suvaṇṇa rajata ādike suvaṇṇa rajata ādi bhāvam upagacchanti iti vuccanti na evam ayam
translated: are said to “emit” gold, silver, etc., and to “assume” the state of gold, silver, etc., so this nutriment, when digested by the body’s fire, emits phlegm, etc., and assumes the state of the soft inner part.

original: Ayaṃ pana āhāro kāyagginā paripakko pheṇapubbuḷake muñcanto saṇhaṃ karonti etthāti🔽“saṇhakaraṇī”ti laddhanāmake nisade pisitvā nāḷike khuddakaveḷunāḷikāyaṃ vaṇṇasaṇṭhānamattena🔽pakkhippamānapaṇḍumattikā viya karīsabhāvaṃ upagantvā pakkāsayaṃ pūreti, muttabhāvaṃ
analyzed: ayam pana āhāro kāya agginā paripakko pheṇa pubbuḷake muñcantaḥ saṇham karonti ettha ati  saṇhakaraṇī iti laddha nāmake nisade pisitvā nāḷike khuddaka veḷu nāḷikāyam vaṇṇa saṇṭhāna mattena  pakkhippamāna paṇḍu mattikā viya karīsa bhāvam upagantvā pakka āsayam pūreti mutta bhāvam
translated: But this nutriment, when digested by the body’s fire, emits phlegm, etc., and makes the soft inner part compact.🔽It is called “that which makes compact” because it is there that it makes the soft inner part compact.🔽It is like clay that is kneaded and then put into a small bamboo tube, which is filled with clay of the same colour and shape.

original: upagantvā muttavatthiṃ pūretīti yojanā. Gahaṇiyā indhanabhāgo viya kimibhakkhabhāgo
analyzed: upagantvā mutta vatthim pūreti iti yojanā gahaṇiyāḥ indhana bhāgaḥ viya kimi bhakkha bhāgaḥ
translated: It should be interpreted as follows: the nutriment in the form of morsels fills the large intestine, and the nutriment in the form of contact fills the bladder.🔽The part of the fuel that is the receptacle is not evident, nor is the part that is eaten by worms.🔽The part that is juice is evident as a result, and the part that is unripe is not evident.

original: ca apākaṭova. Rasabhāgo phalato pakāsīyati, aparipakkasabhāgā ca teti te anāmasitvā
analyzed: ca apākaṭaḥ uva rasa bhāgaḥ phalataḥ pakāsīyati aparipakka sabhāgā ca te iti te an āmasitvā
translated: Therefore, omitting those,

original: karīsamuttabhāgā evettha dassitā.
analyzed: eva ittha dassitā
translated: only the parts that are excrement and urine are shown here.

original: 302. Paṭikkūlassa nāma phalena paṭikkūleneva bhavitabbanti dassento “sammā paripaccamāno”tiādimāha.🔽Nakhadantādīnīti ādi-saddena na kevalaṃ tacādīni eva dvattiṃsākārapāḷiyaṃ āgatāni,
analyzed: paṭikkūlassa nāma phalena paṭikkūlena iva bhavitabbanti dassentaḥ sammā paripaccamānaḥ tiādim āha  nakha danta ādīni iti ādi saddena na kevalam taca ādīni eva dvattiṃsa ākāra pāḷiyam āgatāni
translated: Pointing out that what is repulsive must be so by its fruit, he said, “When it is properly cooked” ,

original: atha kho akkhigūthakaṇṇagūthadantamalajallikāsambhavādīni dvattiṃsakoṭṭhāsavinimuttāni
analyzed: atha kho akkhi gūtha kaṇṇa gūtha danta mala jallikā sambhava ādīni dvattiṃsa koṭṭhāsa vinimuttāni
translated: “Nails, teeth, etc.”: the word “etc.” includes not only the thirty-two parts of the body given in the text but also the impurities that are not included in the thirty-two parts, such as the eyes, snot, ear-wax, dental plaque, and the like.

original: asubhāni saṅgaṇhanto “nānākuṇapānī”ti āhāti daṭṭhabbaṃ.
analyzed: asubhāni saṅgaṇhantaḥ nānā kuṇapāni iti āha ati daṭṭhabbam
translated: “Various kinds of ordure” should be understood as including the impurities.

original: 303. Nissandamānoti vissavanto, paggharantoti attho. Ādinā pakārenāti ettha ādi-saddena
analyzed: nissandamāno ti vissavantaḥ paggharantaḥ ti attho ādinā pakārena ati ettha ādi saddena
translated: “Flowing out”: trickling out, oozing out, is the meaning. “From the beginning”: the word “beginning” includes

original: nāsikāya siṅghāṇikā, mukhena kheḷo, kadāci pittaṃ, semhaṃ, lohitaṃ vamati, vaccamaggena
analyzed: nāsikāya siṅghāṇikā mukhena kheḷo kadāci pittam semham lohitam vamati vaccamaggena
translated: snot from the nose, spittle from the mouth, and sometimes bile, phlegm, and blood that are vomited up,

original: uccāro, passāvamaggena passāvo, sakalakāye lomakūpehi sedajallikāti evaṃpakāraṃ asuciṃ
analyzed: uccāraḥ passāva maggena passāvaḥ sakala kāye lomakūpehi evaṃpakāram asucim
translated: and excrement from the anus, urine from the urethra, and the sweat and dirt that ooze from the pores of the entire body.

original: saṅgaṇhāti. “Paṭhamadivase”ti idaṃ nissandadivasāpekkhāya vuttaṃ. Tenāha “dutiyadivase
analyzed: saṅgaṇhāti paṭhama divasa iti idam nissanda divasa apekkhāya vuttam tena āha dutiya divase
translated: “On the first day”: this is said with reference to the day on which the flow occurs. Therefore it is said, “On the second day,

original: nissandento”ti. Vikuṇitamukhoti jigucchāvasena saṅkucitamukho. Tenāha “jegucchī”ti.🔽Maṅkubhūtoti vimanakajāto “imampi nāma posemī”ti. Rattoti vatthaṃ viya raṅgajātena🔽cittassa vipariṇāmākārena chandarāgena ratto. Giddhoti abhikaṅkhanasabhāvena abhigijjhanena
analyzed: nissandentaḥ iti vikuṇita mukhaḥ iti jigucchā vasena saṅkucita mukhaḥ tena āha jegucchī iti  maṅku bhūtaḥ iti vimanaka jātaḥ imam pi nāma posemi iti rattaḥ ti vattham viya raṅga jātena  cittassa vipariṇāma ākārena chanda rāgena rattaḥ giddhaḥ ti abhikaṅkhana sabhāvena abhigijjhanena
translated: “Dripping” means “trickling.” “With a contorted face” means with a face drawn together through disgust. Hence it is said: “He is disgusted.”🔽“Embarrassed” means ashamed, thinking “I am supporting him.” “Lustful” means “lusting” with a lust-born desire,

original: giddho gedhaṃ āpanno. Gadhitoti dummocanīyabhāvena ganthito viya tattha paṭibaddho.
analyzed: giddhaḥ gedham āpannaḥ gadhito ti dummocanīya bhāvena ganthitaḥ viya tattha paṭibaddho
translated: like a cloth with dye. “Greedy” means greedy with a greed-born longing,🔽like a cloth with oil. “Bound” means bound as if by a strong bond.

original: Mucchitoti rasataṇhāya mucchaṃ mohaṃ āpanno. Virattoti vigatarāgo. Aṭṭīyamānoti dukkhiyamāno.
analyzed: mucchitaḥ iti rasa taṇhāya muccham moham āpannaḥ virattaḥ iti vigata rāgaḥ aṭṭīyamānaḥ iti dukkhiyamānaḥ
translated: “Entangled” means entangled, deluded by craving for taste. “Dispassionate” means free from lust. “Afflicted” means suffering.

original: Harāyamānoti lajjamāno. Jigucchamānoti hīḷento.
analyzed: harāyamānaḥ uti lajjamānaḥ jigucchamānaḥ uti hīḍentaḥ
translated: “Ashamed” means ashamed. “Disgusted” means despising.

original: Navadvārehīti pākaṭānaṃ mahantānaṃ vasena vuttaṃ, lomakūpavivarehipi sandatevāti.
analyzed: nava dvārehi iti pākaṭānam mahantānam vasena vuttam
translated: “Through the nine orifices” is said in terms of the obvious, large orifices; but it trickles through the pores of the skin as well.

original: Nilīyatīti attānaṃ adassento nigūhati, saṅkucati vā. Evanti ekena dvārena pavesanaṃ
analyzed: nilīyati iti attānam a dassentaḥ nigūhati saṅkucati vā evam ti ekena dvārena pavesanam
translated: “It trickles” means it hides itself, or it shrinks, by not showing itself. “In this way” means by entering through one orifice.

original: anekehi dvārehi anekadhā nikkhāmanaṃ, pakāsanaṃ pavesanaṃ, nigūḷhaṃ nikkhāmanampīti🔽somanassajātena pavesanaṃ, maṅkubhūtena nikkhāmanaṃ, sārattena pavesanaṃ, virattena
analyzed: anekehi dvārehi anekadhā nikkhāmanam pakāsanam pavesanam nigūḍham nikkhāmanam pi iti  somanassa jātena pavesanam maṅku bhūtena nikkhāmanam sārattena pavesanam virattena
translated: The meaning is: the entering by one who is glad, the going out by one who is disgusted, the entering by one who is greedy, the going out by one who is dispassionate.

original: nikkhāmananti imehi pakārehi.🔽304. Paribhogakālepīti pi-saddena paviṭṭhamattopi nāma pavesadvāraṃ jegucchaṃ karoti,
analyzed: nikkhāmananti imehi pakārehi  paribhoga kāle pi iti pi saddena paviṭṭha mattaḥ api nāma pavesa dvāram jeguccham karoti
translated: This is the method.🔽The meaning of “at the time of using” is this: the one called “entering” makes the door of entering disgusting,🔽to say nothing of the one who has obtained a dwelling and is ripe for full understanding. The meaning of “at the time of going out” is this: the one called “going out” makes the door of going out disgusting,

original: pageva laddhaparivāso paripākappatto itaradvārānīti dasseti. Esa āhāro. Gandhaharaṇatthanti🔽vissagandhāpanayanatthaṃ. Kāyaggināti gahaṇitejānugatena kāyusmānā. Pheṇuddehakanti
analyzed: pagā iva laddha parivāsaḥ paripāka patto itara dvārāni iti dasseti esaḥ āhāraḥ gandha haraṇa ttham ti  vissa gandha apanayana tham kāya agginā ati gahaṇi teja anugatena pheṇu dehakam ti
translated: to say nothing of the one who has obtained a dwelling and is ripe for full understanding. The meaning of “at the time of using” is this: the one called “entering” makes the door of entering disgusting,🔽to say nothing of the one who has obtained a dwelling and is ripe for full understanding. The meaning of “at the time of going out” is this: the one called “going out” makes the door of going out disgusting,🔽to say nothing of the one who has obtained a dwelling and is ripe for full understanding. The meaning of “at the time of using” is this: the one called “entering” makes the door of entering disgusting,🔽to say nothing of the one who has obtained a dwelling and is ripe for full understanding. The meaning of “at the time of going out” is this: the one called “going out” makes the door of going out disgusting,🔽to say nothing of the one who has obtained a dwelling and is ripe for full understanding. The meaning of “at the time of using” is this: the one called “entering” makes the door of entering disgusting,🔽to say nothing of the one who has obtained a dwelling and is ripe for full understanding. The meaning of “at the time of going out” is this: the one called “going out” makes the door of going out disgusting,

original: pheṇāni uṭṭhapetvā uṭṭhapetvā. Paccitvāti paripākaṃ gantvā. Uttaramānoti uppilavanto.🔽Semhādīti ādi-saddena pittādike saṅgaṇhāti. Karīsādīti ādi-saddena sedajallikādike.
analyzed: pheṇāni uṭṭhapetvā uṭṭhapetvā paccitvā ati paripākam gantvā uttaramāno ti uppilavantaḥ 🔽semha ādi iti ādi saddena pitta ādike saṅgaṇhāti karīsa ādi iti ādi saddena seda jallikā ādike
translated: to say nothing of the one who has obtained a dwelling and is ripe for full understanding. The meaning of “at the time of using” is this: the one called “entering” makes the door of entering disgusting,🔽to say nothing of the one who has obtained a dwelling and is ripe for full understanding. The meaning of “at the time of going out” is this: the one called

original: Imāni dvārāni mukhādīni. Ekaccanti passāvamaggaṃ sandhāya vadati. Cokkhajātikā pana
analyzed: imāni dvārāni mukha ādīni ekaccanti passa avamaggam sandhāya vadati cokkha jātikā pana
translated: ‘One’ is the passage for urine. But those of the eye-disease type

original: mukhādīnipi dhovitvā hatthaṃ puna dhovantiyeva. Puna ekaccanti vaccamaggaṃ. Dvattikkhattunti🔽dvikkhattuṃ, tikkhattuṃ vā. Ettha ca āhāratthāya gamanapariyesanānaṃ paṭikkūlatā
analyzed: mukha ādīni pi dhovitvā hattham puna dhovantiyā iva puna vacca maggam  dvi khattum ti khattum vā ettha ca āhāra atthāya gamana pariyesanānam paṭikkūla tā
translated: wash the mouth and then wash the hand again. ‘One again’ is the passage for excrement. ‘Thirty-two times’ is🔽two or three times. And here the repulsiveness of going and seeking food is called🔽‘repulsiveness of nutriment’ because it is a condition for it. And the repulsiveness of the receptacle and of the store is called

original: āhāre paṭikkūlatā vuttā. Paribhogassa tannissayato, āsayanidhānānaṃ taṃsambandhato,🔽itaresaṃ tabbikāratoti ayampi viseso veditabbo. Kimibhakkhabhāvopi hissa vikārapakkheyeva ṭhapetabboti.
analyzed: āhāre paṭikkūla tā vuttā paribhogassa tad nissayataḥ āsaya nidhānānam tad sambandhataḥ  itaresam tad bikārato ti ayam pi visesaḥ veditabbaḥ kimibhakkha bhāvaḥ api hissa vikāra pakkhe yā iva ṭhapetabbaḥ ti
translated: ‘repulsiveness of nutriment’ because it is connected with it.

original: 305. Taṃ nimittanti yathāvuttehi ākārehi punappunaṃ manasi karontassa paṭikkūlākāravasena
analyzed: tam nimittam ti yathā vuttehi ākārehi punappunam manasi karontassa paṭikkūla ākāra vasena
translated: And the repulsiveness of what is eaten and drunk is called ‘repulsiveness of nutriment’ because it is a modification of it. This is how the difference should be understood here. For the state of being what is eaten and drunk should be placed among the modifications.

original: upaṭṭhitaṃ kabaḷīkārāhārasaññitaṃ bhāvanāya nimittaṃ ārammaṇaṃ, na uggahapaṭibhāganimittaṃ.
analyzed: upaṭṭhitam kabaḷīkāra āhāra saññitam bhāvanāya nimittam ārammaṇam na uggaha paṭibhāga nimittam
translated: ‘The sign of that’ is the sign of the meditation subject consisting of the resolved form of the physical nutriment that appears as repulsiveness in the way already stated, which is the object of the jhāna, not the learning sign or the counterpart sign.

original: Yadi hi tattha uggahanimittaṃ uppajjeyya, paṭibhāganimittenapi bhavitabbaṃ. Tathā
analyzed: yadi hi tattha uggaha nimittam uppajjeyya paṭibhāga nimittena api bhavitabbam tathā
translated: For if the learning sign were to arise there, then the counterpart sign would have to arise too.🔽And if that were so, then the jhāna would have to have reached absorption, but it does not do so. Why not?

original: ca sati appanāppattena jhānena bhavitabbaṃ, na ca bhavati, kasmā? Bhāvanāya nānākārato,🔽sabhāvadhammabhāvena ca kammaṭṭhānassa gambhīrabhāvato. Tenāha “kabaḷīkārāhārassa
analyzed: ca sati appanā appattena jhānena bhavitabbam na ca bhavati kasmā bhāvanāya nānākārato  sabhāva dhamma bhāvena ca kammaṭṭhānassa gambhīra bhāvato tena āha kabaḷīkāra āhārassa
translated: Because of the profundity of the meditation subject in its nature as a mental object🔽with the dhammas as object. That is why it is said, “because of the profundity of the mental object with the dhammas as object owing to the dhammas’ nature as dhammas.”

original: sabhāvadhammatāya gambhīrattā”ti. Ettha hi yadipi paṭikkūlākāravasena bhāvanā pavattati.
analyzed: sa bhāva dhamma tāya gambhīra ttā ati ettha hi yadi api paṭikkūla ākāra vasena bhāvanā pavattati
translated: For although the development of this meditation subject proceeds by way of the aspect of repulsiveness,

original: Ye pana dhamme upādāya kabaḷīkārāhārapaññatti, te eva dhammā paṭikkūlā, na paññattīti
analyzed: ye pana dhamme upādāya kabaḷīkāra āhāra paññatti te eva dhammā paṭikkūlāḥ na paññatti iti
translated: nevertheless the dhammas that are the basis for the concept “repulsive” are the dhammas themselves, not the concept.

original: paṭikkūlākāraggahaṇamukhenapi sabhāvadhammeyeva ārabbha bhāvanāya pavattanato, sabhāvadhammānañca
analyzed: paṭikkūla ākāra ggahaṇa mukhena api ārabbha bhāvanāya pavattanataḥ sabhāva dhammānam ca
translated: So the development of this meditation subject proceeds by way of the dhammas themselves, even though it is the aspect of repulsiveness that is intended.

original: sabhāveneva gambhīrabhāvato na tattha jhānaṃ appetuṃ sakkoti. Gambhīrabhāvato hi
analyzed: sa bhāvena iva gambhīra bhāvataḥ na tattha jhānam appetum sakkoti gambhīra bhāvato hi
translated: And because the dhammas are profound in their nature, the jhāna does not reach absorption.🔽For it is because of their profundity that the first two truths are called “deep, difficult to see” .

original: purimasaccadvayaṃ duddasaṃ jātanti. Yadi upacārasamādhinā cittaṃ samādhiyati, kathaṃ
analyzed: purima sacca dvayam duddasam yadi upacāra samādhinā cittam katham
translated: If the mind becomes concentrated with access concentration, then:

original: kammaṭṭhānaṃ “saññā” icceva voharīyatīti āha “paṭikkūlākāraggahaṇavasena panā”tiādi.
analyzed: kammaṭṭhānam saññā icca iva voharīyati iti āha paṭikkūla ākāra ggahaṇa vasena pana atiādi
translated: The meditation subject is called perception, thus it is said: “But it is called perception because of the apprehending of the repulsive aspect” .

original: Idāni imissā bhāvanāya ānisaṃsaṃ dassetuṃ “imañca panā”tiādi vuttaṃ. Rasataṇhāyāti🔽madhurādirasavisayāya taṇhāya. Patilīyatīti saṅkucati anekākāraṃ tattha paṭikkūlatāya
analyzed: idāni imissā bhāvanāya ānisaṃsam dassetuṃ iman ca pana atiādi vuttam rasa taṇhāya ati  madhura ādi rasa visayāya taṇhāya patilīyati iti saṅkucati aneka ākāram tattha paṭikkūla tāya
translated: Now, in order to point out the benefits of this meditation, the following is said: “And this meditation” , etc. Craving for tastes : craving for the taste of sweet, etc.🔽It shrinks : it contracts, because of the repulsive aspect in it in various ways.

original: saṇṭhitattā. Patikuṭatīti apasakkati na visarati. Pativattatīti nivattati. Kantāranittharaṇatthikoti
analyzed: saṇṭhita ttā patikuṭati iti apasakkati na visarati pativattati iti nivattati kantāra nittharaṇatthikā ti
translated: It recoils : it does not spread out because it is confined there. It turns back : it turns away.🔽One who is intent on crossing the desert : one who is intent on getting out of a great desert of scarcity.

original: mahato dubbhikkhakantārassa nittharaṇappayojano. Vigatamadoti mānamadādīnaṃ abhāvena
analyzed: mahataḥ dubbhikkha kantārassa nittharaṇa ppayojanaḥ vigata madaḥ ti māna mada ādīnam abhāvena
translated: Free from vanity : free from vanity, because of the absence of conceit, vanity, etc.

original: nimmado, madābhāvaggahaṇeneva cassa davamaṇḍanavibhūsanādīnampi abhāvo gahitoyevāti
analyzed: nimmadaḥ mada abhāva ggahaṇena iva ca ssa dava maṇḍana vibhūsana ādīnam pi abhāvaḥ
translated: It should be regarded as if he had said: “free from conceit, free from vanity, free from arrogance, free from pride, free from intoxication, free from folly, free from folly’s intoxication, free from folly’s giddiness, free from folly’s exaltation, free from folly’s giddiness of exaltation.”

original: daṭṭhabbaṃ. Kabaḷīkārāhārapariññāmukhenāti vuttanayena paṭikkūlākārato kabaḷīkārāhārassa
analyzed: daṭṭhabbam kabaḷīkāra āhāra pariññā mukhena ati vutta nayena paṭikkūla ākārataḥ kabaḷīkāra āhārassa
translated: By the way of full-understanding of physical nutriment : by the way described above, that is, by the repulsive aspect of physical nutriment.

original: paricchijja jānanadvārena. Pañcakāmaguṇiko rāgoti anativattanaṭṭhena pañcasu kāmaguṇesu
analyzed: paricchijja jānana dvārena pañca kāmaguṇikaḥ rāgaḥ ti an ativattana ṭṭhena pañcasu kāmaguṇesu
translated: by the door of knowing after discerning. The lust for the five strands of sense pleasure is lust that is not beyond the five strands of sense pleasure,

original: niyutto, tappayojano vā rāgo. Pariññaṃ samatikkamaṃ gacchati. Rasataṇhāya hi sammadeva
analyzed: niyuttaḥ tad payojanaḥ vā rāgaḥ pariññam samatikkamam gacchati rasa taṇhāya hi sammat eva
translated: or it is lust that is bound to, or applied to, them. It goes to the surmounting of full-understanding. For when craving for taste is fully understood,

original: vigatāya rūpataṇhādayopi vigatā eva honti bhojane mattaññutāya ukkaṃsagamanato. Sati🔽ca visayisamatikkame visayo samatikkanto eva hotīti āha “so pañcakāmaguṇapariññāmukhena🔽rūpakkhandhaṃ parijānātī”ti. Rūpāyatanādīsu hi pariññaṃ gacchantesu tannissayabhūtāni,
analyzed: vigatāya rūpa taṇhā ādayaḥ api vigatāḥ eva honti bhojane mattaññu tāya ukkaṃsa gamanataḥ sati  ca visayi samatikkame visayo samatikkantaḥ eva hoti iti āha saḥ pañca kāmaguṇa pariññā mukhena  rūpa kkhandham parijānāti iti rūpa āyatana ādīsu hi pariññam gacchantesu tad nissaya bhūtāni
translated: craving for materiality, etc., are also fully understood, just as over-eating is when the right amount in eating is known. And when🔽attention as the faculty of mindfulness is beyond the object, the object is also beyond it. So he said: “He fully understands the materiality aggregate by the means of fully understanding the five strands of sense pleasure.”

original: taggāhakā pasādā ca sukheneva pariññaṃ gacchantīti. Aparipakkādīti ādi-saddena āsayanidhānānampi
analyzed: tad gāhakā pasādā ca sukhena iva pariññam gacchanti iti aparipakka ādi iti ādi saddena
translated: For when there is full understanding of the base of materiality, etc., then the feelings that are based on materiality, etc., and the perceptions that apprehend them are also fully understood without difficulty, just as when there is full understanding of over-eating there is also full understanding of the right amount in eating.

original: saṅgaho daṭṭhabbo. Tattha aparipakkaṃ tāva udariyameva. Āsayaggahaṇena pittasemhapubbalohitānaṃ,
analyzed: saṅgahaḥ daṭṭhabbo tattha aparipakkam tāva udariyam eva āsaya ggahaṇena pitta semha pubba lohitānam
translated: The words “unripe, etc.” should be taken as including the “receptacle” and the “store.” Herein, what is unripe is only the stomach. The words “receptacle” and “store” include bile, phlegm, pus, blood, etc.,

original: paripakkaggahaṇena karīsamuttānaṃ, phalaggahaṇena kesādīnaṃ sabbesaṃ pariggaho siddho
analyzed: paripakka ggahaṇena karīsam uttānam phala ggahaṇena kesa ādīnam sabbesam pariggahaḥ siddho
translated: By the word “ripe” the dung is included, and by the word “fruit” the hair, etc., are all included.🔽So it is said: “The development of mindfulness occupied with the body reaches its culmination” .

original: hotīti āha “kāyagatāsatibhāvanāpi pāripūriṃ gacchatī”ti. Asubhasaññāyāti asubhabhāvanāya,
analyzed: hoti iti āha kāya gata asati bhāvanā api pāripūrim gacchati iti asubha saññāya ati asubha bhāvanāya
translated: “Contemplation of perception of foulness”: of the development of foulness,🔽of the practice of the development of foulness without consciousness, is the meaning.

original: aviññāṇakaasubhabhāvanānuyogassāti attho. Anulomapaṭipadaṃ paṭipanno hoti paṭikkūlākāraggahaṇena
analyzed: aviññāṇaka asubha bhāvanā anuyogassa ati atthaḥ anuloma paṭipadam paṭipanno hoti paṭikkūla ākāra ggahaṇena
translated: He is practicing in conformity with the practice: by apprehending the repulsive aspect of the body,

original: kāyassa asuciduggandhajegucchabhāvasallakkhaṇato. Imaṃ pana paṭipattinti imaṃ āhāre🔽paṭikkūlasaññābhāvanaṃ. Amatapariyosānatanti nibbānaniṭṭhitaṃ āhāre paṭikkūlasaññābhāvanāsaṅkhātaṃ
analyzed: kāyassa asuci duggandha jeguccha bhāva sat lakkhaṇato imam pana paṭipattim ti imam āhāre  paṭikkūla saññā bhāvanam amata pariyosāna tanti nibbāna niṭṭhitam āhāre paṭikkūla saññā bhāvanā saṅkhātam
translated: he is discerning the body’s impurity, foul smell, and loathsome nature.🔽This practice: this development of perception of repulsiveness in nutriment.

original: upacārajjhānaṃ pādakaṃ katvā vipassanaṃ vaḍḍhetvā nibbānādhigamanti attho.
analyzed: upacāra jhānam pādakam katvā vipassanam vaḍḍhetvā nibbāna adhigamanti attho
translated: It has the deathless as its culmination: it has Nibbāna as its culmination. The meaning is that he extends insight by making the access jhāna, called the development of perception of repulsiveness in nutriment, the basis for insight and reaches Nibbāna.

original: Āhārepaṭikkūlabhāvanāvaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: āhāre paṭikkūla bhāvanā vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The description of the development of the perception of repulsiveness in nutriment is ended.

original: Catudhātuvavatthānabhāvanāvaṇṇanā
analyzed: catu dhātu vavatthāna bhāvanā vaṇṇanā
translated: Development of the Foundation of Mindfulness consisting in the Four Noble Truths

original: 306. “Ekaṃ vavatthānanti evaṃ uddiṭṭhassa catudhātuvavatthānassa bhāvanāniddeso anuppatto”ti
analyzed: ekam vavatthānan ti evam uddiṭṭhassa catu dhātu vavatthānassa bhāvanā niddeso anuppatto ti
translated: “‘One foundation’: the description of the development of the foundation of mindfulness consisting in the four noble truths, which was listed under the heading ‘One foundation’ , comes now.”

original: uddeso nāma niddesattho mudumajjhapaññābāhullato, āgato ca bhāro avassaṃ vahitabboti🔽katvā vuttaṃ. Tattha satipi visayabhedena vavatthānassa bhede vavatthānabhāvasāmaññena🔽pana taṃ abhinnaṃ katvā vuttaṃ “ekaṃ vavatthāna”nti, pubbabhāge vā satipi visayabhede
analyzed: uddesaḥ nāma niddesa atthaḥ mudu majjha paññā bāhullataḥ āgataḥ ca bhāraḥ avassam vahitabbaḥ ti  katvā vuttam tattha sati pi visaya bhedena vavatthānassa bhede vavatthāna bhāva sāmaññena  pana tam abhinnam katvā vuttam ekam vavatthānanti pubba bhāge vā sati pi visaya bhede
translated: And the burden that has been taken up must be borne without fail.🔽Herein, although the definition is differentiated by the difference in the objects, still it is said “one definition” because of the similarity of the definition.

original: atthasiddhiyaṃ tassa ekavisayatāvāti “ekaṃ vavatthāna”nti vuttaṃ. Yathā hi dvattiṃsākāre
analyzed: tassa eka visaya tā vā ati ekam vavatthānam ti vuttam yathā hi dvattiṃsa ākāre
translated: Or alternatively, although there is a difference in the objects in the earlier stage, still the definition is said to be “one” because of the single object of the accomplishment of the purpose.

original: kammaṃ karontassa yogino yadipi pubbabhāge visuṃ visuṃ koṭṭhāsesu manasikāro pavattati,
analyzed: kammam karontassa yoginaḥ yadi pi pubba bhāge visum visum koṭṭhāsesu manasikāro pavattati
translated: For just as, when a meditator is doing his work on the thirty-two aspects, although the attention is given in the earlier stage to the different parts separately,

original: aparabhāge pana ekasmiṃ khaṇe ekasmiṃyeva koṭṭhāse atthasiddhi hoti, na sabbesu,🔽evamidhāpīti. Tattha siyā – yathā paṭikkūlabhāvasāmaññena dvattiṃsākārakammaṭṭhāne
analyzed: aparabhāge pana ekasmim khaṇe ekasmiṃ yeva koṭṭhāse attha siddhi hoti na sabbesu  evam idha api iti tattha siyā yathā paṭikkūla bhāva sāmaññena dvattiṃsa ākāra kammaṭṭhāne
translated: in the later stage the accomplishment of the purpose is in a single part only, not in all,🔽so too here.🔽Here it may be asked: Just as in the case of the meditation subject of the thirty-two aspects the attention is given to the parts without distinction because of the similarity of foulness,

original: abhedato manasikāro pavattati, evaṃ idha dhātubhāvasāmaññena abhedato manasikāro
analyzed: abhedataḥ manasikāro pavattati evam idha dhātu bhāva sāmaññena abhedataḥ manasikāro
translated: so here too the attention should be given to the elements without distinction because of the similarity of the state of being elements.

original: pavattatīti “ekaṃ vavatthāna”nti vuttanti? Nayidamevaṃ. Tattha hi paṇṇattisamatikkamato
analyzed: pavattati iti ekam vavatthānan ti vuttam ti na idam evam tattha hi paṇṇatti samatikkamataḥ
translated: “But is it not said, ‘One discernment’?”—

original: paṭṭhāya paṭikkūlavaseneva sabbattha manasikāro pavattetabbo, idha pana sabhāvasarasalakkhaṇato
analyzed: paṭṭhāya paṭikkūla vasena iva sabbattha manasikāro pavattetabbaḥ idha pana sabhā vasa rasa lakkhaṇato
translated: No, it is not said. For there the attention is to be given to repulsiveness in all cases beginning with the surmounting of perceptions of permanence, etc.,

original: dhātuyo manasi kātabbā, na dhātubhāvasāmaññato. Tenevāha “sabhāvūpalakkhaṇavasena
analyzed: dhātuyaḥ manasi kātabbāḥ na dhātu bhāva sāmaññato tena iva āha sabhāva upalakkhaṇa vasena
translated: but here the elements are to be given attention according to their individual essences, their individual natures, their individual characteristics, not according to their mere general nature as elements. That is why it is said, “One discernment” means that attention is given to the four elements according to their individual essences, their individual natures, their individual characteristics.

original: sanniṭṭhāna”nti. Kiṃ vā etena papañcena, aññehi ekūnacattālīsāya kammaṭṭhānehi asaṃsaṭṭhaṃ🔽catudhātuvavatthānaṃ nāma ekaṃ kammaṭṭhānanti dassetuṃ “ekaṃ vavatthāna”nti vuttanti
analyzed: sanniṭṭhānam ti kim vā etena papañcena aññehi ekūnacattālīsāya kammaṭṭhānehi a saṃsaṭṭham  catu dhātu vavatthānam nāma ekam kammaṭṭhānan ti dassetum ekam vavatthānan ti vuttan ti
translated: Or else, why all this? The meaning can be understood in this way: “One discernment” is said in order to show that the defining of the four elements is a meditation subject by itself, not mixed up with any other among the thirty-nine other meditation subjects.🔽“The description of the development of the defining of the four elements” is said because the defining of the four elements is development.

original: daṭṭhabbaṃ. “Catudhātuvavatthānassa bhāvanāniddeso”ti kasmā vuttaṃ, nanu catudhātuvavatthānaṃ🔽bhāvanāva? Saccaṃ bhāvanāva, sakiṃ pavattaṃ pana vavatthānaṃ, tassa bahulīkāro bhāvanāti
analyzed: daṭṭhabbam catu dhātu vavatthānassa bhāvanā niddeso ti kasmā vuttam nanu catu dhātu vavatthānam 🔽bhāvanā va saccam bhāvanā va sakim pavattam pana vavatthānam tassa bahulīkāraḥ bhāvanā ati
translated: But is not the defining of the four elements development? It is indeed. But the defining is only once, and the development is the repetition of that defining.

original: vacanabhedena vuttaṃ. Kathaṃ pana bhāvanā niddisīyati tassā vacīgocarātikkantabhāvatoti?🔽Nāyaṃ doso bhāvanatthe bhāvanāvohārato. Bhāvanattho hi kammaṭṭhānapariggaho idha
analyzed: vacana bhedena vuttam katham pana bhāvanā niddisīyati tassāḥ vacī gocara atikkanta bhāvato ti  na ayam dosaḥ bhāvanā tthe bhāvanā avohārataḥ bhāvanā atthaḥ hi kammaṭṭhāna pariggahaḥ idha
translated: and it is said in terms of the speech. But how is it shown that it is beyond the range of speech?🔽There is no fault here. For “development” is said figuratively for the sake of development.

original: “bhāvanā”ti adhippeto.
analyzed: bhāvanā ati adhippeto
translated: For the choosing of a meditation subject is intended here by “development.”

original: Sabhāvūpalakkhaṇavasenāti kakkhaḷattādikassa salakkhaṇassa upadhāraṇavasena. Idaṃ
analyzed: sabhāva upalakkhaṇa vasena ati kakkhaḷa tta ādikassa sa lakkhaṇassa upadhāraṇa vasena idam
translated: By the defining of the individual essences: by the apprehending of the individual essences, such as hardness, etc.

original: hi kammaṭṭhānaṃ pathavīkasiṇādikammaṭṭhānaṃ viya na paṇṇattimattasallakkhaṇavasena,
analyzed: hi kammaṭṭhānam pathavī kasiṇa ādi kammaṭṭhānam viya na paṇṇattimatta sat lakkhaṇa vasena
translated: For this meditation subject does not proceed by defining the mere concepts, as does the earth kasiṇa meditation subject, etc.;

original: nīlakasiṇādikammaṭṭhānaṃ viya na nīlādivaṇṇasallakkhaṇavasena, nāpi vipassanākammaṭṭhānaṃ
analyzed: nīla kasiṇa ādi kammaṭṭhānam viya na nīla ādi vaṇṇa sat lakkhaṇa vasena na api vipassanā kammaṭṭhānam
translated: nor by defining the colour such as blue, etc., as does the blue kasiṇa meditation subject, etc.; nor by defining the general characteristics of impermanence, etc., in formations, as does the meditation subject for the development of understanding.

original: viya saṅkhārānaṃ aniccatādisāmaññalakkhaṇasallakkhaṇavasena pavattati, atha kho pathavīādīnaṃ
analyzed: viya saṅkhārānam anicca tā ādi sāmañña lakkhaṇa sat lakkhaṇa vasena pavattati atha kho pathavī ādīnam
translated: But rather it proceeds by defining the individual essences of earth, etc.,

original: sabhāvasallakkhaṇavasena pavattati. Tena vuttaṃ “sabhāvūpalakkhaṇavasenā”ti, kakkhaḷattādikassa
analyzed: sabhāva sat lakkhaṇa vasena pavattati tena vuttam sabhāva upalakkhaṇa vasena ati kakkhaḷa ttā ādikassa
translated: Hence it was said above: “By the defining of the individual essences.”

original: salakkhaṇassa upadhāraṇavasenāti attho. Sanniṭṭhānanti ñāṇavinicchayo veditabbo,
analyzed: sa lakkhaṇassa upadhāraṇa vasena ati attho sanniṭṭhānam ti ñāṇa vinicchayaḥ veditabbo
translated: The meaning is: by way of apprehending the specific characteristics. “Decision” should be understood as the discernment of knowledge,

original: na yevāpanakavinicchayo, nāpi vitakkādivinicchayo. Dhātumanasikāroti dhātūsu manasikāro,🔽catasso dhātuyo ārabbha bhāvanāmanasikāroti attho. Kātabbato kammaṃ, yogino sukhavisesānaṃ🔽kāraṇabhāvato ṭhānañcāti kammaṭṭhānaṃ, catunnaṃ mahābhūtānaṃ sabhāvasallakkhaṇavasena
analyzed: na vitakka ādi vinicchayaḥ dhātu manasikāraḥ ti dhātūsu manasikāraḥ  catasso dhātuyaḥ ārabbha bhāvanā manasikāraḥ ti attho kātabbataḥ kammam yogino sukha visesānam  kāraṇa bhāvato ṭhānam ca ati kammaṭṭhānam catunnam mahābhūtānam sa bhāva sat lakkhaṇa vasena
translated: not as the discernment of the non-appearance of the object, nor as the discernment of applied thought, etc. “Attention given to the elements” means attention to the elements,🔽the meaning being: the attention given to the elements in the development of insight. “Meditation subject” : kammaṭṭhāna is kamma, work, because it is to be done, and it is ṭhāna, a place, because it is the basis for the yogin’s attainment of the distinction of happiness.

original: pavattaṃ yogakammaṃ. Tenāha “dhātumanasikāro, dhātukammaṭṭhānaṃ, catudhātuvavatthānanti
analyzed: pavattam yoga kammam tena āha dhātu manasikāraḥ dhātu kammaṭṭhānam catu dhātu vavatthānam ti
translated: It is the work of the yogin that occurs by way of the specific characteristics of the four great primaries. Therefore it is said: “Attention given to the elements, a meditation subject based on the elements, the defining of the four elements—in meaning they are the same.”

original: atthato eka”nti. Tayidaṃ catudhātuvavatthānaṃ. “Dvidhā āgata”nti kasmā vuttaṃ, nanu
analyzed: atthataḥ ekam ti tayā idam catu dhātu vavatthānam dvidhā āgatam ti kasmā vuttam nanu
translated: This is the defining of the four elements. Why is it said that it “comes in two ways”?

original: dhātuvibhaṅge nātisaṅkhepavitthāravasena āgataṃ, tasmā “tidhā āgata”nti vattabbanti?
analyzed: dhātu vibhaṅge na ati saṅkhepa vitthāra vasena āgatam tasmā tidhā āgatam iti vattabbanti
translated: Is it not stated in the element-by-element analysis in a way that is neither too brief nor too detailed? Therefore should it not be said that it “comes in three ways”?

original: Na, tatthāpi ajjhattikānaṃ dhātūnaṃ pabhedato anavasesapariyādānassa katattā, bāhirānañca
analyzed: na tattha api ajjhattikānam dhātūnam pabhedataḥ anavasesa pariyādānassa kata ttā bāhirānam ca
translated: No, because there the internal elements are stated without remainder by way of their classification, and the external elements are stated by way of their general characteristics.

original: dhātūnaṃ pariggahitattā. Atha vā dvidhā āgatanti ettha dvidhāva āgatanti na evaṃ🔽niyamo gahetabbo, atha kho dvidhā āgatamevāti, tena tatiyassāpi pakārassa saṅgaho🔽siddho hoti. So ca nātisaṅkhepavitthāranayo “saṅkhepato ca vitthārato cā”ti ettha🔽āvuttivasena, ca-saddeneva vā saṅgahoti daṭṭhabbo. Atha vā yo nātisaṅkhepavitthāranayena🔽atisaṅkhepapaṭikkhepamukhena labbhamāno vitthārabhāgo, taṃ vitthāranayantogadhameva🔽katvā vuttaṃ “dvidhā āgata”nti. Evañca katvā “nātitikkhapaññassa dhātukammaṭṭhānikassa🔽vasena vitthārato āgata”nti idañca vacanaṃ samatthitaṃ hoti. “Mahāsatipaṭṭhāne”ti
analyzed: dhātūnam pariggahita ttā atha vā dvidhā āgatanti ettha dvidhā u āgatanti na evam  niyamaḥ gahetabbaḥ atha kho dvidhā āgatam eva ati tena tatiyassa api pakārassa saṅgahaḥ  siddhaḥ hoti saḥ ca na ati saṅkhepa vitthāra nayo saṅkhepato ca vitthārato ca ati ettha  āvutti vasena ca saddena iva vā saṅgahaḥ ti daṭṭhabbo atha vā yaḥ na ati saṅkhepa vitthāra nayena  ati saṅkhepa paṭikkhepa mukhena labbhamānaḥ vitthāra bhāgaḥ tam vitthāra nayantogadham eva  katvā vuttam dvidhā āgatan ti evam ca katvā na a titikkha paññassa dhātu kammaṭṭhānikassa  vasena vitthārataḥ idam ca vacanam samatthitam hoti mahā sati paṭṭhānā iti
translated: because the elements are included in it. Or alternatively, as to “comes in two ways”: the meaning should not be taken as “comes in only two ways,” but rather as “comes in two ways.” Thus the third “way” is included.🔽And that should be regarded as included by the word “and” in the phrase “in brief and in detail” or by the word “also” in the phrase “in brief, in detail, and in brief again.”🔽Or alternatively, the detailed part that occurs by way of the “neither too briefly nor too much in detail” method, which is stated by way of the “not too briefly” method, is called “comes in two ways” when it is stated by way of the “not too much in detail” method.🔽And when it is taken in this way, the statement “for one of dull understanding, by way of the elements” is established.🔽As to “in the Mahāsatipaṭṭhāna”:

original: ca idaṃ nidassanamattaṃ daṭṭhabbaṃ, satipaṭṭhāna kāyagatāsatisuttādīsupi tatheva
analyzed: ca idam nidassana mattam daṭṭhabbam sati paṭṭhāna kāya gata asati sutta ādīsu pi tathā iva
translated: because the elements are included in them. Or alternatively, as to “comes in two ways”: the restriction should not be taken as “comes in only two ways,” but rather as “comes in two ways.” Thus the third “way” is included. And that should be regarded as included by the word “and” in the phrase “in brief and in detail” , or by the word “and” in the phrase “in a way that is neither too long nor too brief” . Or alternatively, the detailed part that is found by the way of neither too long nor too brief is stated by the words “comes in two ways” after being brought forward in the way already stated. And when it is stated in this way, the words “in detail for one of sluggish understanding” are also justified. And the words “in the Mahāsatipaṭṭhāna Sutta” should be regarded as an illustration only, for it is also in the Satipaṭṭhāna Sutta, in the Kāyagatāsati Sutta, etc.,

original: āgatattā. Rāhulovādeti mahārāhulovāde. Dhātuvibhaṅgeti dhātuvibhaṅgasutte, abhidhamme dhātuvibhaṅge ca.
analyzed: rāhulovāde iti mahārāhulovāde dhātu vibhaṅge iti dhātu vibhaṅga sutte abhidhamme dhātu vibhaṅge ca
translated: because it has come. In the Mahā Rāhula Sutta: in the Mahā Rāhula Sutta. In the Elements: in the Elements Discourse, in the Vibhaṅga of the Elements in the Abhidhamma.

original: Kāmaṃ mahāsatipaṭṭhāne atthena upamaṃ parivāretvā desanā āgatā, upamā ca nāma yāvadeva
analyzed: kāmam mahā sati paṭṭhāne atthena upamam parivāretvā desanā āgatā upamā ca nāma yāvat eva
translated: In the Mahā Satipaṭṭhāna Sutta the teaching has come with a simile surrounding the meaning, and a simile is only for the purpose of

original: upameyyatthavibhāvanatthāti upamaṃ tāva dassetvā upameyyatthaṃ vibhāvetuṃ “seyyathāpī”tiādinā
analyzed: upameyya attha vibhāvana atthā ti upamam tāva dassetvā upameyya attham vibhāvetum seyyathā api iti ādinā
translated: explaining the meaning of what is to be illustrated. So after showing the simile he brought in the text beginning with “Just as if” in order to explain the meaning of what is to be illustrated.

original: pāḷi ānītā. Kasmā panettha dhātuvasena, tatthapi catumahābhūtavasena kammaṭṭhānaniddeso🔽katoti? Sattasuññatāsandassanatthaṃ, ettha dhātuvasena, tatthāpi oḷārikabhāvena supākaṭatāya,
analyzed: ānītā kasmā pana ittha dhātu vasena tattha api catu mahābhūta vasena kammaṭṭhāna niddeso  kataḥ ti satta suñña tā sandassana attham ettha dhātu vasena tattha api oḷārika bhāvena su pākaṭa tāya
translated: But why is the meditation subject stated here in terms of elements and there in terms of the four great entities?🔽It should be understood that it is done in terms of elements here in order to show the seven voids, and there in terms of the four great entities because they are very evident there by reason of their grossness,

original: ekaccaveneyyajanacaritānukulatāya ca mahābhūtavasena kammaṭṭhānaniddeso katoti veditabbo.
analyzed: ekacca veneyya jana carita anukula tāya ca mahābhūta vasena kammaṭṭhāna niddeso kato ti veditabbo
translated: and because it is suitable to the temperament of some of those susceptible of teaching.🔽Herein, the meaning of “element” is the meaning of individual essence,

original: Tattha pathavīdhātūtiādīsu dhātuttho nāma sabhāvattho, sabhāvattho nāma suññatattho,
analyzed: tattha pathavī dhātu utiādīsu dhātutthaḥ nāma sabhāvattho sabhāvatthaḥ nāma suññatattho
translated: and the meaning of individual essence is the meaning of void.

original: suññatattho nāma nissattattho. Evaṃ sabhāvasuññatanissattatthena pathavīyeva dhātu🔽pathavīdhātu. Āpodhātuādīsupi eseva nayo. Pathavīdhātūti sahajarūpadhammānaṃ patiṭṭhā
analyzed: suññatattho nāma nissattattho evam sabhāva suññata nissattatthena pathavīyā iva dhātu  pathavī dhātu āpodhātu ādīsu pi esa iva nayo pathavī dhātu uti sahaja rūpa dhammānam patiṭṭhā
translated: The meaning of void is the meaning of non-existence of creatures. So the earth itself is the “element” in the sense of the voidness of individual essence and the non-existence of creatures.

original: dhātu, tathā āpodhātūti ābandhanadhātu, tejodhātūti paripācanadhātu, vāyodhātūti
analyzed: dhātu tathā āpaḥ dhātu uti ābandhana dhātu tejaḥ dhātu uti paripācana dhātu vāyaḥ dhātu uti
translated: The earth element is the element that is the support of the conascent material dhammas. Similarly, the water element is the element that coalesces them; the fire element is the element that matures them; and the air element is the element that in- flates them.🔽This is how the compound should be understood here.

original: vitthambhanadhātūti evamettha samāso, bhāvattho ca veditabbo. Ayamettha saṅkhepo,
analyzed: vitthambhana dhātu uti evam ettha samāsaḥ bhāva atthaḥ ca veditabbaḥ ayam ettha saṅkhepaḥ
translated: The meaning of the words is this. This is a brief account.

original: vitthāro pana parato āgamissati.🔽Evaṃ tikkhapaññassātiādīsu evanti yathādassitaṃ pāḷiṃ paccāmasati. Nātitikkhapaññassa
analyzed: vitthāraḥ pana paratas āgamissati  evam tikkha paññassa ati ādīsu evam ti yathā dassitam pāḷim paccāmasati na ati tikkha paññassa
translated: The detailed account will come later.🔽In the passage beginning, “One whose understanding is keen in this way” , the word “in this way” refers back to the way of explaining the four elements.🔽One whose understanding is not keen in this way is called “one whose understanding is not keen” .

original: vitthāradesanāti katvā āha “tikkhapaññassā”ti. Yathā vatthayugaṃ arahatīti vatthayugiko,🔽evaṃ dhātukammaṭṭhānaṃ arahati, dhātukammaṭṭhānapayojanoti vā dhātukammaṭṭhāniko,
analyzed: vitthāra desanā ti katvā āha tikkha paññassa ati yathā vattha yugam arahati iti vatthayugikaḥ  evam dhātu kammaṭṭhānam arahati dhātu kammaṭṭhāna payojano ti vā dhātu kammaṭṭhānikaḥ
translated: The detailed teaching is called “the teaching for one whose understanding is keen.”🔽One who is worthy of the meditation subject consisting of the elements is “one who is a candidate for the meditation subject consisting of the elements” .

original: tassa dhātukammaṭṭhānikassa.
analyzed: tassa dhātu kammaṭṭhānikassa
translated: Or alternatively, the meditation subject consisting of the elements is suitable for him, thus he is “one who is a candidate for the meditation subject consisting of the elements” .🔽For one who is a candidate for the meditation subject consisting of the elements.

original: Chekoti taṃtaṃsamaññāya kusalo, yathājāte sūnasmiṃ naṅguṭṭhakhuravisāṇādivante aṭṭhimaṃsādiavayavasamudāye
analyzed: cheko ti taṃ taṃsam aññāya kusalaḥ yathā jāte sūnasmim naṅguṭṭha khura visāṇa ādivante aṭṭhim aṃsa ādi avayava samudāye
translated: “Skilled” means skilled in the name “ox” as a collective name for the various parts. For when the calf is born, it has a dewlap, a tail, horns, etc., and a collection of bones, flesh, etc.,

original: avibhatte gāvīsamaññā, na vibhatte, vibhatte pana aṭṭhimaṃsādiavayavasamaññāti jānanako.
analyzed: a vibhatte gāvī samaññā na vibhatte vibhatte pana aṭṭhi maṃsa ādi avayava samaññā ti jānanako
translated: but the name “cow” is not yet applied to it. When it is not yet dissected, the name “cow” is applied to the collection of bones, flesh, etc., but when it is dissected the name “bones, flesh, etc.” is applied.

original: Goghātakoti jīvikatthāya gunnaṃ ghātako. Antevāsīti kammakaraṇavasena tassa samīpavāsī🔽tassa tannissāya jīvanato. Vinivijjhitvāti ekasmiṃ ṭhāne aññaṃ vinivijjhitvā. Mahāpathānaṃ
analyzed: go ghātako ti jīvika atthāya gunnam ghātakaḥ antevāsī iti kamma karaṇa vasena tassa samīpa vāsī  tassa tat nissāya jīvanataḥ vinivijjhitvā ti ekasmin ṭhāne aññam vinivijjhitvā mahāpathānam
translated: “A cow-killer” is one who kills cows for a living. “A pupil” is one who lives near him in the sense of being his pupil by being employed by him.🔽Because he lives in dependence on him. “Having dissected” means having dissected one in one place. “At the junction of four roads”

original: vemajjhaṭṭhānasaṅkhāteti catunnaṃ mahāpathānaṃ tāya eva vinivijjhanaṭṭhānasaṅkhāte.
analyzed: vemajjha ṭṭhāna saṅkhātā iti catunnam mahāpathānam tāyaḥ eva vinivijjhana ṭṭhāna saṅkhāte
translated: means at the junction of four great roads, which is called the “place of dissection.”

original: Yasmā te cattāro mahāpathā catūhi disāhi āgantvā samohitā viya honti, tasmā taṃ ṭhānaṃ
analyzed: yasmā te cattāraḥ mahāpathā catūhi disāhi āgantvā samohitāḥ viya honti tasmā tam ṭhānam
translated: Because those four great roads meet there as if they have come together, that place is🔽called “the junction of four great roads.” In that “junction of four great roads,”

original: catumahāpathānaṃ, tasmiṃ catumahāpathe. Vilīyanti bhijjanti vibhajjantīti bīlā, bhāgā,
analyzed: catu mahā pathānam tasmin catu mahā pathe vilīyanti bhijjanti vibhajjanti iti bīlāḥ bhāgāḥ
translated: “the parts” are the parts, the pieces.

original: va-kārassa ba-kāraṃ, i-kārassa ca ī-kāraṃ katvā. Tameva hi bhāgatthaṃ dassetuṃ “koṭṭhāsaṃ
analyzed: vakārassa bakāram ikārassa ca īkāram katvā tam eva hi bhāga attham dassetum koṭṭhāsam
translated: and the letter va for the letter ba, and the letter i for the letter ī. It is in order to show that very meaning of the word that it is said, “having divided it up into parts” .

original: katvā”ti vuttaṃ. Kiñcāpi ṭhita-saddo “ṭhito vā”tiādīsu viya ṭhānasaṅkhātairiyāpathasamaṅgitāya,
analyzed: katvā iti vuttam kiñcā api ṭhita saddo ṭhitaḥ vā ati ādīsu viya ṭhāna saṅkhāta eriyāpatha samaṅgi tāya
translated: Although the word ṭhita is a designation for the possession of the posture called “standing” , as in such passages as “standing” ,

original: gatinivattiatthatāya vā ṭhā-saddassa aññattha ṭhapetvā gamanaṃ sesairiyāpathasamaṅgitāya🔽bodhako, idha pana yathā tathā rūpakāyassa pavattiākārabodhako adhippetoti āha “catunnaṃ🔽iriyāpathānaṃ yena kenaci ākārena ṭhitattā yathāṭhita”nti. Tattha ākārenāti ṭhānādinā
analyzed: gati nivatti attha tāya vā ṭhā saddassa aññattha ṭhapetvā gamanam sesa iriyā patha samaṅgi tāya  bodhakaḥ idha pana yathā tathā rūpa kāyassa pavatti ākāra bodhakaḥ adhippeto ti āha catunnam  iriyāpathānam yena kenacid ākārena ākārena ati ṭhāna ādinā
translated: or it is a designation for the meaning of the turning back of the going, as in the case of the word ṭhā- , which is a designation for the possession of the other postures except for going,🔽here it is intended as a designation for the mode of occurrence of the material body, as it is, as it were. Therefore it is said, “because of standing in some mode or other of the four postures” .

original: rūpakāyassa pavattiākārena. Ṭhānādayo hi iriyāsaṅkhātāya kāyikakiriyāya pavattiṭṭhānatāya
analyzed: rūpa kāyassa pavatti ākārena ṭhāna ādayaḥ hi iriyā saṅkhātāya kāyika kiriyāya pavatti ṭṭhāna tāya
translated: Herein, in some mode or other means by the mode of occurrence of the material body as standing, etc.🔽For standing, etc., are called “postures” because they are the bases for the occurrence of bodily action called “posture” .

original: “iriyāpathā”ti vuccanti. Yathāṭhitanti yathāpavattaṃ. Yathāvuttaṭṭhānamevettha paṇidhānanti
analyzed: iriyāpathā ti vuccanti yathā ṭhitam ti yathāpavattam yathā vutta ṭṭhānam eva ittha paṇidhānam ti
translated: As it is standing means as it occurs.

original: adhippetanti āha “yathāṭhitattāva yathāpaṇihita”nti. Ṭhitanti vā kāyassa ṭhānasaṅkhātairiyāpathasamāyogaparidīpanaṃ.🔽Paṇihitanti tadaññairiyāpathasamāyogaparidīpanaṃ. Ṭhitanti vā kāyasaṅkhātānaṃ rūpadhammānaṃ
analyzed: adhippetanti āha yathā paṇihitanti ṭhitanti vā kāyassa ṭhāna saṅkhāta eriyāpatha samāyoga paridīpanam  paṇihitanti tad añña eriyāpatha samāyoga paridīpanam ṭhitanti vā kāya saṅkhātānam rūpa dhammānam
translated: “As it stands” is said to be “as it is placed” . “ Standing” is the revealing of the combination of postures of the body called “standing” .🔽“ Placed” is the revealing of the combination of other postures .

original: tasmiṃ tasmiṃ khaṇe sakiccavasena avaṭṭhānaparidīpanaṃ. Paṇihitanti paccayakiccavasena🔽tehi tehi paccayehi pakārato nihitaṃ paṇihitanti evamettha attho veditabbo. Dhātusoti
analyzed: tasmim tasmim khaṇe sa kicca vasena avaṭṭhāna paridīpanam paṇihitanti paccaya kicca vasena  tehi tehi paccayehi pakārataḥ nihitam paṇihitan ti evam ettha atthaḥ veditabbaḥ dhātuso ti
translated: “ Standing” is the revealing of the non-disappearance of the material phenomena called “body” in each moment by their own function. “ Placed” is the placing of them by the various conditions in the sense of the function of the conditions.🔽This is how the meaning should be understood here. “ By elements” means by the elements of earth, etc., each separately.

original: dhātuṃ dhātuṃ pathavīādidhātuṃ visuṃ visuṃ katvā. Paccavekkhatīti pati pati avekkhati
analyzed: dhātum dhātum pathavī ādi dhātum visum visum katvā paccavekkhati iti pati pati avekkhati
translated: “ He contemplates” means he contemplates each one.

original: ñāṇacakkhunā vinibbhujitvā passati.🔽Yathā chekotiādinā pāḷiyā saddatthavivaraṇavasena vuttamevatthaṃ idāni bhāvatthavibhāvanavasena
analyzed: ñāṇa cakkhunā vinibbhujitvā passati  yathā cheka uti ādinā pāḷiyā saddattha vivaraṇa vasena idāni bhāva ttha vibhāvana vasena
translated: He sees by penetrating with the eye of knowledge.🔽The meaning stated by the words of the text beginning with “as a butcher” , etc., is now stated by way of the exposition of the meaning of the word “being” .

original: dassetuṃ “yathā goghātakassā”tiādi vuttaṃ. Tattha posentassāti maṃsūpacayaparibrūhanāya
analyzed: dassetum yathā go ghātakassa atiādi vuttam tattha posentassa ati maṃsu upacaya paribrūhanāya
translated: “ As one who tends” means for the purpose of increasing the flesh.

original: kuṇḍakabhattakappāsaṭṭhiādīhi saṃvaḍḍhentassa. Vadhitaṃ matanti hiṃsitaṃ hutvā mataṃ.
analyzed: kuṇḍaka bhatta kappāsa ṭṭhi ādīhi saṃvaḍḍhentassa vadhitam matanti hiṃsitam hutvā matam
translated: and the bones are increased by the addition of the flesh, sinews, etc., that grow up.🔽“Killed” is dead after being killed.

original: Matanti ca matamattaṃ. Tenevāha “tāvadevā”ti. Gāvīti saññā na antaradhāyati yāni
analyzed: matam ti ca mata mattam tena iva āha tāvat eva ati gāvi iti saññā na antaradhāyati yāni
translated: “Dead” is just dead. Hence it is said, “the idea of a cow does not disappear.”🔽The idea of a cow is the name “cow” given to the collection of the parts beginning with the hump.

original: aṅgapaccaṅgāni upādāya gāvīsamaññā, matamattāyapi gāviyā tesaṃ sannivesassa avinaṭṭhattā.🔽Bilāsoti bilaṃ bilaṃ katvā. Vibhajitvāti aṭṭhisaṅghātato maṃsaṃ vivecetvā, tato vā
analyzed: aṅga paccaṅgāni upādāya gāvī samaññā gāviyā tesam sannivesassa a vinaṭṭha ttā  bilāso ti bilam bilam katvā vibhajitvā ati aṭṭhi saṅghātataḥ maṃsam vivecetvā tatas vā
translated: The arrangement of the parts is not destroyed even in a dead cow.🔽“Scattered” means made into a heap. “Dispersed” means divided up.

original: vivecitaṃ maṃsaṃ bhāgaso katvā. Tenevāha “maṃsasaññā pavattatī”ti. Pabbajitassapi
analyzed: vivecitam maṃsam bhāgasaḥ katvā tena iva āha maṃsa saññā pavattati iti pabbajitassa api
translated: Or the flesh is first divided up, and then it is scattered, made into a heap. Hence it is said, “the idea of flesh occurs.”🔽Even in a bhikkhu🔽who has not taken up a meditation subject.

original: apariggahitakammaṭṭhānassa. Ghanavinibbhoganti santatisamūhakiccaghanānaṃ vinibbhujanaṃ
analyzed: a pariggahita kammaṭṭhānassa ghana vinibbhogam ti santati samūha kicca ghanānam vinibbhujanam
translated: “The dissolution of the compact” is the resolution of the continuity and the resolution of the mass and the resolution of the function.

original: vivecanaṃ. Dhātuso paccavekkhatoti yathāvuttaṃ ghanavinibbhogaṃ katvā dhātuso paccavekkhantassa.
analyzed: vivecanam dhātuso paccavekkhato ti yathāvuttam ghana vinibbhogam katvā dhātuso paccavekkhantassa
translated: “He contemplates as elements”: having effected the resolution of the compact in the way just stated, he contemplates by discerning the elements.

original: Sattasaññāti attānudiṭṭhivasena pavattā sattasaññāti vadanti, vohāravasena pavattasattasaññāyapi
analyzed: satta saññā iti atta anudiṭṭhi vasena pavattā satta saññā iti vadanti vohāra vasena pavatta satta saññā api
translated: “Perception of a being” is the perception of a being that occurs by way of the view of self, they say. But the perception of a being that occurs by way of conventional usage

original: tadā antaradhānaṃ yuttameva yāthāvato ghanavinibbhogassa sampādanato. Evaṃ hi sati🔽yathāvuttaopammatthena opameyyattho aññadatthu saṃsandati sameti. Tenevāha “dhātuvaseneva
analyzed: tadā antaradhānam yuttam eva yāthāvataḥ ghana vinibbhogassa sampādanataḥ evam hi sati  yathā vutta opamma atthena opameyya tthaḥ aññadatthu saṃsandati sameti tena iva āha dhātu vasena iva
translated: is also suitable to disappear at that time, because of the accomplishment of the penetration of the compact . For in that case,

original: cittaṃ santiṭṭhatī”ti.
analyzed: cittam santiṭṭhati iti
translated: the meaning of the simile, namely, the simile of the elephant’s footprint, is connected with and fits the meaning of the object of the simile, namely, the meditation subject. Therefore it is said: “The mind becomes steadied in the elements” .

original: 307. Evaṃ dhātukammaṭṭhānassa saṅkhepato āgataṭṭhānaṃ dassetvā idāni vitthārato āgataṭṭhānaṃ
analyzed: evam dhātu kammaṭṭhānassa saṅkhepataḥ āgata ṭṭhānam dassetvā idāni vitthārataḥ āgata ṭṭhānam
translated: Having thus shown the place where the meditation subject of the elements is found in brief, he now shows the place where it is found in detail

original: dassetuṃ “mahāhatthipadūpame panā”tiādi vuttaṃ. Evanti iminā rāhulovāda- dhātuvibhaṅgesu🔽dhātukammaṭṭhānassa vitthārato āgamanameva upasaṃharati, na sabbaṃ desanānayaṃ aññathāpi
analyzed: dassetum mahā hatthi pada upame pana atiādi vuttam evam ti iminā dhātu vibhaṅgesu  dhātu kammaṭṭhānassa vitthārataḥ āgamanam eva upasaṃharati na sabbam desanā nayam aññathā api
translated: with the words “In the Mahāhatthipadopama Sutta, etc.” The word “thus” refers only to the detailed treatment of the meditation subject of the elements in the Rāhulovāda and Dhātuvibhaṅga Suttas,

original: tattha desanānayassa āgatattā.
analyzed: tattha desanā nayassa āgata ttā
translated: not to the whole method of teaching, because the method of teaching is found elsewhere too.

original: Tatrāti tasmiṃ yathādassite mahāhatthipadūpamapāṭhe. Ajjhattikāti sattasantānapariyāpannā.
analyzed: tatra ati tasmin yathā dassite mahā hatthi pada upama pāṭhe ajjhattikā ati satta santāna pariyāpannā
translated: “There” means in the Mahāhatthipadopama Sutta as it has been quoted. “Internal” means included in one’s own life-continuum.

original: Ajjhattaṃ paccattanti padadvayenāpi taṃtaṃpāṭipuggalikadhammo vuccatīti āha “ubhayampi🔽niyakassa adhivacana”nti. Sasantatipariyāpannatāya pana attani gahetabbabhāvūpagamanavasena
analyzed: ajjhattam paccattam iti pada dvayena api taṃ taṃ pāṭipuggalika dhammaḥ vuccati iti āha ubhayam pi  niyakassa adhivacanam ti sa santati pariyāpanna tāya pana attani gahetabba bhāva upagamana vasena
translated: “Both terms are synonyms for ‘one’s own’”

original: attānaṃ adhikicca pavattaṃ ajjhattaṃ. Taṃtaṃsantatipariyāpannatāya paccattaṃ. Tenevāha
analyzed: attānam adhikicca pavattam ajjhattam taṃ taṃ saṃtati pariyāpanna tāya paccattam tena iva āha
translated: . But “in oneself” is so called because it is what is to be apprehended as belonging to one’s own continuum.🔽“In another” is so called because it occurs in dependence on another’s continuum.

original: “attani pavattattā ajjhattaṃ, attānaṃ paṭicca paṭicca pavattattā paccatta”nti. Kakkhaḷanti
analyzed: attani pavatta ttā ajjhattam attānam paṭicca paṭicca pavatta ttā paccattanti kakkhaḷanti
