translated: Hence it is said: “It is in oneself because it occurs in oneself; it is in another because it occurs in dependence on another”🔽. “Hard” :

original: kathinaṃ. Yasmā taṃ thaddhabhāvena sahajātānaṃ patiṭṭhā hoti, tasmā “thaddha”nti
analyzed: kathinam yasmā tam thaddha bhāvena sahajātānam patiṭṭhā hoti tasmā thaddhanti
translated: firm. It is the support for what is conascent by virtue of its firmness. That is why it is said to be “firm”

original: vuttaṃ. Kharigatanti kharīsu kharasabhāvesu gataṃ tappariyāpannaṃ, kharasabhāvamevāti
analyzed: vuttam khari gatam ti kharīsu khara sabhāvesu gatam tat pariyāpannam khara sabhāvam eva ati
translated: . “Gone into the hard” : it is included in the hard, it has the nature of the hard, is the meaning.

original: attho. Yasmā pana kharasabhāvaṃ pharusākārena upaṭṭhānato pharusākāraṃ hoti, tasmā
analyzed: atthaḥ yasmā pana khara sabhāvam pharusa ākārena upaṭṭhānato pharusa ākāram hoti tasmā
translated: But because it appears as a rough aspect, it is “rough”🔽. That is why it is said: “The second term is a term for an aspect”

original: vuttaṃ “pharusa”nti. Tenāha “dutiyaṃ ākāravacana”nti. Upādinnaṃ nāma sarīraṭṭhakaṃ.
analyzed: vuttam pharusam ti tena āha dutiyam ākāra vacanam ti upādinnam nāma sarīraṭṭhakam
translated: . “What is clung to” is what is bodily.

original: Taṃ pana kammasamuṭṭhānataṃ sandhāya upādinnampi atthi anupādinnampi, taṇhādīhi ādinnagahitaparāmaṭṭhavasena🔽sabbampetaṃ upādinnamevāti dassetuṃ “upādinnanti daḷhaṃ ādinna”ntiādi vuttaṃ. Tattha
analyzed: tam pana kamma samuṭṭhāna tam sandhāya upādinnam api atthi anupādinnam pi taṇhā ādīhi ādinna gahita parāmaṭṭha vasena  sabbam petam upādinnam eva ati dassetum upādinnam ti daḷham ādinna ntiādi vuttam tattha
translated: But it is also clung-to and not clung-to according to whether it originates as kamma-originated or not.🔽And all of it is clung-to in the sense of being seized upon by craving, etc., as “mine,” as belonging to self, as identifiable.🔽This is what is shown by the words “Clung-to” and so on.

original: “mama”nti gahitaṃ “aha”nti parāmaṭṭhanti yojanā. Seyyathidanti kathetukamyatāpucchāvācīti
analyzed: gahitam ahanti parāmaṭṭhanti yojanā kathā itu kamyatā pucchā vācī iti
translated: Herein, what is “seized upon as ‘mine’” is “identified as ‘I.’”🔽The words “such as” are a particle expressing a question.🔽The meaning is “What is it?”

original: āha “taṃ katamanti ceti attho”ti. Tatoti pacchā. Tanti taṃ ajjhattikādibhedato dassitaṃ
analyzed: āha tam katamanti ca iti attho ti tatoti pacchā tanti tam ajjhattika ādi bhedato dassitam
translated: “Afterwards”: later.🔽“That”: the earth element shown in the various ways as internal, etc.

original: pathavīdhātuṃ. Dassentoti vatthuvibhāgena dassento. Kiñcāpi matthaluṅgaṃ aṭṭhimiñjeneva
analyzed: pathavī dhātum dassento ti vatthu vibhāgena dassento kiñca api mattha luṅgam aṭṭhimiñjena iva
translated: “Indicating”: showing by a classification of the physical basis.🔽Although the brain is included in the bone and marrow,

original: saṅgahetvā idha pāḷiyaṃ visuṃ na uddhaṭaṃ, paṭisambhidāmagge pana vīsatiyā ākārehi
analyzed: saṅgahetvā idha pāḷiyam visum na uddhaṭam paṭisambhidā magge pana vīsatiyā ākārehi
translated: it is not mentioned separately in the text here. But in the Paṭisambhidā it is shown as complete in twenty ways,

original: paripuṇṇaṃ katvā dassetuṃ visuṃ gahitanti tampi saṅgaṇhanto thaddhabhāvādhikatāya
analyzed: paripuṇṇam katvā dassetum visum gahitanti tam pi saṅgaṇhantaḥ thaddha bhāva adhika tāya
translated: and so it is included separately there. Including it, he says “hardness” and so on.

original: pathavīdhātukoṭṭhāsesuyeva “matthaluṅgaṃ pakkhipitvā vīsatiyā ākārehi pathavīdhātu
analyzed: pathavī dhātu koṭṭhāsesu yeva mattha luṅgam pakkhipitvā vīsatiyā ākārehi pathavī dhātu
translated: He says that the lumps of earth should be understood to have been demonstrated in twenty ways by the inclusion of the brain in the lumps of earth.

original: niddiṭṭhāti veditabbā”ti āha. “Yaṃ vā panaññampi kiñcī”ti vā iminā pāḷiyaṃ matthaluṅgassa🔽saṅgaho daṭṭhabbo. Tasmā idha “yaṃ vā panaññampi kiñcī”ti idaṃ pubbāparāpekkhaṃ “matthaluṅgaṃ
analyzed: niddiṭṭhā iti veditabbā ti āha yam vā pana aññam pi kiñci iti vā iminā pāḷiyam matthaluṅgassa  saṅgahaḥ daṭṭhabbaḥ tasmai idha yam vā pana aññam pi kiñci iti idam pubba apara apekkham matthaluṅgam
translated: And by the words “or whatever other” in the text the inclusion of the brain should be understood.

original: pakkhipitvā vīsatiyā ākārehi pathavīdhātu niddiṭṭhāti veditabbā, yaṃ vā panaññampi
analyzed: pakkhipitvā vīsatiyā ākārehi pathavī dhātu niddiṭṭhā ati veditabbā yam vā pana aññam pi
translated: So here the words “or whatever other” are dependent on what precedes them, and the inclusion of the brain should be understood to have been demonstrated in twenty ways by the inclusion of the brain in the lumps of earth, or whatever other.

original: kiñcī”ti vacanato. Puna yaṃ vā panaññampi kiñcīti avasesesu tīsu koṭṭhāsesūti yojetabbaṃ.
analyzed: kiñci iti vacanato puna yam vā pana aññam pi kiñci iti avasesesu tīsu koṭṭhāsesu iti yojetabbam
translated: And the words “or whatever other” should be construed with the remaining three lumps.🔽In the three lumps: in the three kinds of lumps.

original: Tīsu koṭṭhāsesūti tippakāresu koṭṭhāsesu. Na hi te tayo koṭṭhāsā.🔽Vissandanabhāvenāti paggharaṇasabhāvena. Appotīti visarati. Pappotīti pāpuṇāti, sasambhāraāpavasena
analyzed: tīsu koṭṭhāsesu iti tippakāresu koṭṭhāsesu na hi te tayo koṭṭhāsā  vissandana bhāvena ati paggharaṇa sabhāvena appoti iti visarati pappoti iti pāpuṇāti sa sambhāra āpa vasena
translated: For they are not three lumps.🔽By the nature of trickling: by the nature of trickling out. It trickles: it trickles out. It trickles through: it reaches, this being said in terms of the water element together with its concomitant states.

original: cetaṃ vuttaṃ. So hi vissandanabhāvena sasambhārapathavīsaṅkhātaṃ taṃ taṃ ṭhānaṃ visarati,
analyzed: ca itam vuttam saḥ hi vissandana bhāvena sa sambhāra pathavī saṅkhātam tam tam ṭhānam visarati
translated: For that trickles out to this and that place, trickling by the nature of trickling out, which is called the earth element together with its concomitant states.

original: pāpuṇāti ca, lakkhaṇāpavaseneva vā. Sopi hi sahajātaaññamaññanissayādipaccayatāya
analyzed: pāpuṇāti ca lakkhaṇa apa vasena iva vā saḥ api hi sahajāta aññamañña nissaya ādi paccaya tāya
translated: and it reaches, by the method of characteristic,

original: sesabhūtattayasaṅkhātaṃ taṃ taṃ ṭhānaṃ dravabhāvasiddhena vissandanabhāvena ābandhattaṃ,
analyzed: sesa bhūta ttaya saṅkhātam tam tam ṭhānam drava bhāva siddhena vissandana bhāvena
translated: that place consisting of the remaining three elements, which is called “solid” and “extended,” by the state of its own substantiality, by the state of its own fluidity, by the state of its own distension,

original: āsattattaṃ, avippakiṇṇañca karontaṃ “appoti pappotī”ti vattabbataṃ arahatīti.
analyzed: āsatta ttam a vippakiṇṇam ca karontam appoti pappoti iti vattabbatam arahati iti
translated: and by the state of its own motion, and it is called “that which reaches and touches.”

original: Tejanavasenāti nisitabhāvena tikkhabhāvena. Vuttanayenāti kammasamuṭṭhānādivasena
analyzed: tejana vasena āti nisita bhāvena tikkha bhāvena vutta nayena ati kamma samuṭṭhāna ādi vasena
translated: By the mode of burning: by the mode of sharpness, by the mode of keenness. In the way already stated: as “arisen from kamma,” etc.

original: “nānāvidhesū”ti āpodhātuyaṃ vuttanayena. Kupitenāti khubhitena. Usumajātoti usmābhibhūto.
analyzed: nānāvidhesu iti āpodhātuyam vutta nayena kupitena ati khubhitena usuma jātaḥ ti usma abhibhūtaḥ
translated: In the various kinds: in the water element, in the way already stated. Is disturbed: is agitated. Is overcome by heat: is overcome by heat.

original: Jīratīti jiṇṇo hoti. Tejodhātuvasena labbhamānā imasmiṃ kāye jarāpavatti pākaṭajarāvasena
analyzed: jīrati iti jiṇṇaḥ hoti tejaḥ dhātu vasena labbhamānāḥ imasmin kāye pākaṭa jarā vasena
translated: It ages: it becomes aged. The occurrence of aging in this body, which is found by the fire element, should be understood as the obvious aging.

original: veditabbāti dassetuṃ “indriyavekallata”ntiādi vuttaṃ. Sarīre pakatiusumaṃ atikkamitvā
analyzed: veditabbā ti dassetum indriya vekalla tanti ādi vuttam sarīre pakati usumam atikkamitvā
translated: In order to show this, “the deficiency of faculties” is said. The heat in the body, having exceeded the normal temperature,

original: uṇhabhāvo santāpo, sarīrassa dahanavasena pavatto mahādāho paridāhoti ayametesaṃ
analyzed: uṇha bhāvaḥ santāpaḥ sarīrassa dahana vasena pavatto mahā dāhaḥ paridāhaḥ ti ayam etesam
translated: is heat; the great burning, which occurs by the burning of the body, is fever. This is the difference between them.

original: viseso. Yena jīrīyatīti ca ekāhikādijararogena jarīyatītipi attho yujjati. Satakkhattuṃ
analyzed: visesaḥ yena jīrīyati iti ca ekāhika ādi jara rogena jarīyati iti pi atthaḥ yujjati satakkhattum
translated: The difference is this. And the meaning “he is aged by the disease of ageing that begins with the one-day fever” is appropriate too.

original: tāpetvā tāpetvā sītudake pakkhipitvā uddhaṭā sappi “satadhotasappī”ti vadanti. Asitanti🔽bhuttaṃ. Khāyitanti khāditaṃ. Sāyitanti assāditaṃ. Sammā paripākaṃ gacchatīti samavepākiniyā
analyzed: tāpetvā tāpetvā sīta udake pakkhipitvā uddhaṭā sappi satadhā utasappī iti vadanti asitanti  bhuttam khāyitanti khāditam sāyitanti assāditam sammā paripākam gacchati iti samavepākiniyā
translated: After heating it a hundred times and then throwing it into cold water, they say that the ghee is “heated a hundred times.”

original: gahaṇiyā vasena vuttaṃ, asammāparipākopi pana visamavepākiniyā tassā eva vasena veditabbo.
analyzed: gahaṇiyāḥ vasena vuttam asammā paripākaḥ api pana visama vepākiniyā tassāḥ eva vasena veditabbo
translated: “Eaten” means eaten as food. “Chewed” means chewed as food. “Swallowed” means tasted as food. “It goes to complete resolution” is said by way of the complete resolution faculty. But the incomplete resolution should be understood by way of the incomplete resolution faculty.

original: Rasādibhāvenāti rasarudhiramaṃsamedanhāruaṭṭhiaṭṭhimiñjasukkavasena. Vivekanti puthubhāvaṃ🔽aññamaññaṃ visadisabhāvaṃ. Asitādibhedassa hi āhārassa pariṇāme raso hoti, taṃ paṭicca
analyzed: rasa ādi bhāvena ati rasa rudhira maṃsa medanhāru aṭṭhi aṭṭhimiñja sukka vasena puthu bhāvam  aññam aññam visadisa bhāvam asita ādi bhedassa hi āhārassa pariṇāme raso hoti tam paṭicca
translated: “By way of taste, etc.,” means by way of taste, blood, flesh, sinew, bone, bone-marrow, and brain. “Resolution” means the state of being separate.

original: rasadhātu uppajjatīti attho. Evaṃ “rasassa pariṇāme rudhira”ntiādinā sabbaṃ netabbaṃ.
analyzed: rasa dhātu uppajjati iti atthaḥ evam rasassa pariṇāme rudhira nti ādinā sabbam netabbam
translated: The state of being different from each other. For when food of the kinds beginning with the eaten is resolved, there is taste. The meaning is that the taste element arises in dependence on that. So too with all the rest, beginning with “blood when taste is resolved.”

original: Vāyanavasenāti samudīraṇavasena, savegagamanavasena vā. Uggārahikkādīti ettha ādi-saddena🔽uddekakhipanādipavattanakavātānaṃ saṅgaho daṭṭhabbo. Uccārapassāvādīti ādi-saddena🔽pittasemhalasikākevaladuggandhādinīharaṇakānaṃ saṅgaho daṭṭhabbo. Yadipi kucchi-saddo🔽udarapariyāyo, koṭṭha-saddena pana antantarassa vuccamānattā tadavasiṭṭho udarappadeso
analyzed: vāyana vasena ati samudīraṇa vasena sa vega gamana vasena vā uggāra hikkā ādi iti ettha ādi saddena  uddeka khipana ādi pavattanaka vātānam saṅgahaḥ daṭṭhabbaḥ uccāra passāva ādi iti ādi saddena  pitta semha lasikā kevala duggandha ādi nīharaṇakānam saṅgahaḥ daṭṭhabbaḥ yadi pi kucchi saddo  udara pariyāyaḥ koṭṭha saddena pana anta antarassa vuccamāna ttā tad avasiṭṭhaḥ udara ppadeso

original: Na hi bahiddhā cittasamuṭṭhānassa sambhavo atthīti. Yadi evaṃ kathaṃ “passāsoti bahinikkhamananāsikavāto,
analyzed: na hi bahiddhā citta samuṭṭhānassa sambhavaḥ atthi iti yadi evam katham passāso ti bahi nikkhamana nāsika vāto
translated: for there is no possibility of what is originated by consciousness being external.

original: dīghanāsikassa nāsikaggaṃ, itarassa uttaroṭṭhaṃ phusanto pavattatī”ti vacanaṃ? Taṃ🔽nikkhamanākārena pavattiyā cittasamuṭṭhānassa, santāne pavattautusamuṭṭhānassa ca
analyzed: dīgha nāsikassa nāsika aggam itarassa uttara uṭṭham phusantaḥ pavattati iti vacanam tam  nikkhamana ākārena pavattiyā citta samuṭṭhānassa santāne ca
translated: If that is so, how is it to be taken in the passage, “Inspiration is the in-breath. Expiration is the out-breath. The wind that goes in and out through the nostrils is called inspiration and expiration. It is a term for the air element. It is included in the materiality of the body door” ?🔽That should be understood as said with reference to the air element originated by temperature that occurs in the continuity of what is originated by consciousness, which occurs in the mode of going out,

original: vasena vuttanti veditabbaṃ. Sabbatthāti āpodhātuādīnaṃ tissannaṃ dhātūnaṃ niddesaṃ
analyzed: vasena vuttanti veditabbam sabbattha āti āpodhātu ādīnam tissannam dhātūnam niddesam
translated: “Everywhere” refers to the description of the three elements beginning with the water element.

original: sandhāyāha. Tattha āpodhātuniddese “yaṃ vā panañña”nti iminā sambhavassa, tejodhātuniddese
analyzed: sandhāya āha tattha āpaḥ dhātu niddese yam vā iminā sambhavassa tejaḥ dhātu niddese
translated: Herein, in the description of the water element, “Or any other” includes what is possible. In the description of the fire element,

original: sarīre pākatikausmāya, vāyodhātuniddese dhamanijālānusaṭassa tattha tattha cammakhīlapīḷakādinibbattakavāyuno
analyzed: sarīre vāyo dhātu niddese dhamani jāla anusaṭassa tattha tattha camma khīla pīḷaka ādi nibbattaka vāyuno
translated: the bodily heat that is the ripening of kamma. In the description of the air element, the air that causes the growth of the network of veins, and so on, and produces the various kinds of sores, such as itch, scab, ring-worm, and so on,

original: saṅgaho daṭṭhabbo. Samiñjanādinibbattakavātā cittasamuṭṭhānāva. Yadi evaṃ, kathaṃ
analyzed: saṅgahaḥ daṭṭhabbo samiñjana ādi nibbattaka vātā citta samuṭṭhānā va yadi evam katham
translated: is included. And the air that causes flexing and extending is originated by consciousness. If that is so, how is it said

original: “purimā pañca catusamuṭṭhānā”ti vacanaṃ? Na hi samiñjanādinibbattakā eva aṅgamaṅgānusārino
analyzed: purimā pañca catu samuṭṭhānā ati vacanam na hi samiñjana ādi nibbattakāḥ eva aṅga maṅga anusārinaḥ
translated: “But is it not said that the first five are of fourfold origination? ”

original: vātā, atha kho tadaññepīti natthi virodho.
analyzed: vātāḥ atha kho tad aññe pi iti natthi virodho
translated: It is not only the winds that cause flexing and so on that are meant by “in the various parts of the body,” but also others besides. So there is no contradiction.

original: Itīti vuttappakāraparāmasanaṃ. Tenāha “vīsatiyā ākārehī”tiādi. Etthāti etasmiṃ vitthārato
analyzed: iti iti vutta ppakāra parāmasanam tena āha vīsatiyā ākārehi itiādi ettha ati etasmin vitthārato
translated: “Thus”: this is a term for what has been said above. Hence he said “in twenty ways” and so on. Herein: in the meditation subject as given in detail.

original: āgate dhātukammaṭṭhāneti attho. Tena ayaṃ vaṇṇanā na kevalaṃ mahāhatthipadūpamasseva,🔽atha kho mahārāhulovāda- dhātuvibhaṅgasuttānampi atthasaṃvaṇṇanā hotiyevāti dassitaṃ
analyzed: āgate dhātu kammaṭṭhānā iti attho tena ayam vaṇṇanā na kevalam mahā hatthi pada upamassa iva  atha kho mahārāhulovāda dhātu vibhaṅga suttānam pi attha saṃvaṇṇanā dassitam
translated: The meaning is: in the meditation subject as given in detail. So this commentary is not only on the Simile of the Great Elephant Footprint,🔽but also on the Rāhula Discourse and the Elements Analysis Discourse. This is what is shown by the words

original: hoti. Bhāvanānayepi eseva nayo. Tathā hi vuttaṃ “evaṃ rāhulovādadhātuvibhaṅgesupī”ti.
analyzed: hoti bhāvanā naye pi esā iva nayaḥ tathā hi vuttam evam rāhula uvāda dhātu vibhaṅgesu pi iti
translated: “and in the Rāhula Discourse and the Elements Analysis Discourse too.”

original: 308. Bhāvanānayeti bhāvanāya naye. Yena kammaṭṭhānabhāvanā ijjhati, tasmiṃ bhāvanāvidhimhīti
analyzed: bhāvanā naya iti bhāvanāya naye yena kammaṭṭhāna bhāvanāḥ ijjhati tasmin bhāvanā vidhimhi iti
translated: In the method of development: in the method of development. The meaning is: in the method of development of the meditation subject that succeeds.

original: attho. Etthāti dhātukammaṭṭhāne. Yasmā yesaṃ “tikkhapañño nātitikkhapañño”ti imesaṃ
analyzed: atthaḥ ettha ati dhātu kammaṭṭhāne yasmā yesam tikkha pañño na atitikkha pañño ti imesam
translated: Herein: in the meditation subject consisting in the elements. Because some

original: duvidhānaṃ puggalānaṃ vasena idaṃ kammaṭṭhānaṃ dvidhā āgataṃ dvidhā desitaṃ, tasmā🔽kammaṭṭhānābhinivesopi tesaṃ dvidhāva icchitabboti taṃ tāva dassetuṃ “tikkhapaññassa
analyzed: duvidhānam puggalānam vasena idam kammaṭṭhānam dvidhā āgatam dvidhā desitam tasmā  kammaṭṭhāna abhinivesaḥ api tesam dvidhāvaḥ icchitabbaḥ iti tam tāva dassetum tikkha paññassa
translated: This meditation subject is twofold, according to the two kinds of persons. It is twofold, that is to say, it is taught as twofold. So

original: bhikkhuno”tiādi āraddhaṃ. Lomā pathavīdhātūtīti ettha iti-saddo ādiattho. Evaṃ vitthārato
analyzed: bhikkhunā iti ādi āraddham lomā pathavī dhātu uti iti ettha iti saddo ādi atthaḥ evam vitthārato
translated: the choice of the meditation subject should be made in this way too. That is why the words “a bhikkhu of quick understanding” are given first.

original: dhātupariggahoti “kesā pathavīdhātu, lomā pathavīdhātū”tiādinā evaṃ dvācattālīsāya
analyzed: dhātu pariggaho ti kesā pathavī dhātu lomā pathavī dhātu uti ādinā evam dvācattālīsāya
translated: The word “etc.” in the words “hairs of the head … nails … teeth … skin … flesh …🔽skin … flesh … sinews … bones … bone marrow … kidney … heart … liver … midriff … spleen … lungs … bowels … entrails … gorge … dung … brain … brain- 🔽membrane” is a term signifying the inclusion of the rest in the way already stated.🔽The “learning sign” is the counterpart sign.

original: ākārehi vitthārato dhātukammaṭṭhānapariggaho. Papañcatoti dandhato saṇikato. Yaṃ
analyzed: ākārehi vitthārataḥ dhātu kammaṭṭhāna pariggaho papañcato ti dandhataḥ saṇikataḥ yaṃ
translated: The “counterpart sign” is the sign of the counterpart.🔽The “sign of the counterpart” is the sign of the counterpart of the object of the jhāna.

original: thaddhalakkhaṇanti kesādīsu yaṃ thaddhalakkhaṇaṃ kakkhaḷabhāvo. Yaṃ ābandhanalakkhaṇantiādīsupi
analyzed: thaddha lakkhaṇanti kesa ādīsu yam thaddha lakkhaṇam kakkhaḷa bhāvaḥ yam ābandhana lakkhaṇa nti ādīsu pi
translated: The “object of the jhāna” is the meditation subject.🔽The “counterpart” is the counterpart sign.🔽The “sign of the counterpart” is the sign of that.🔽The “sign of the object” is the sign of the meditation subject.

original: eseva nayo. Evaṃ manasi karototi vatthuṃ anāmasitvā evaṃ lakkhaṇamattato manasikāraṃ
analyzed: esa iva nayaḥ evam manasi karoto ti vatthum an āmasitvā evam lakkhaṇa mattataḥ manasikāram
translated: The “sign of the counterpart” is the sign of the counterpart of that.🔽The “sign of the object” is the learning sign.🔽The “sign of the counterpart” is the counterpart sign.

original: pavattentassa. Assāti tikkhapaññassa. Kammaṭṭhānaṃ pākaṭaṃ hotīti yogakammassa pavattiṭṭhānabhūtaṃ🔽tadeva lakkhaṇaṃ vibhūtaṃ hoti, tassa vā lakkhaṇassa suṭṭhu upaṭṭhānato taṃ ārabbha
analyzed: pavattentassa assa ati tikkha paññassa kammaṭṭhānam pākaṭam hoti iti yogakammassa pavatti ṭṭhāna bhūtam  tat eva lakkhaṇam vibhūtam hoti tassa vā lakkhaṇassa suṭṭhu upaṭṭhānataḥ tam ārabbha
translated: To one who does so. To one of quick understanding: to one of keen faculties. The meditation subject becomes clear: the characteristic of the object becomes evident to him,🔽or the meditation subject consisting in the mental noting becomes clear, evident, to him, because the characteristic is well apprehended by him.

original: pavattamānaṃ manasikārasaṅkhātaṃ kammaṭṭhānaṃ vibhūtaṃ visadaṃ hoti, tikkhapaññassa
analyzed: pavattamānam manasikāra saṅkhātam kammaṭṭhānam vibhūtam visadam hoti tikkha paññassa
translated: To one of quick understanding: to one who is of keen faculties and who delights in conciseness.

original: indriyapāṭavena saṃkhittarucibhāvato. Sabbaso mandapaññassa bhāvanāva na ijjhatīti
analyzed: indriya pāṭavena saṃkhitta ruci bhāvato sabbasas manda paññassa bhāvanā va na ijjhati iti
translated: To one of sluggish understanding, development does not succeed at all.

original: āha “nātitikkhapaññassā”ti. Evaṃ manasi karototi vuttanayena saṅkhepato manasi karoto.
analyzed: āha na atitikkha paññassa ati evam manasi karoto ti vutta nayena saṅkhepataḥ manasi karoto
translated: That is why he said “not to one of very quick understanding.” As he gives his attention in this way: as he gives his attention in brief in the way described.

original: Andhakāraṃ avibhūtaṃ hotīti anupaṭṭhānato andhaṃ viya karontaṃ apākaṭaṃ hoti kammaṭṭhānanti
analyzed: andhakāram avibhūtam hoti iti an upaṭṭhānataḥ andham viya karontam apākaṭam hoti kammaṭṭhānam ti
translated: The meditation subject becomes dark and unclear: it makes him as if blind because it is not evident to him.

original: yojanā. Purimanayenāti “kesā pathavīdhātū”tiādinā pubbe vuttanayena. Vatthuāmasanena
analyzed: yojanā purima nayena āti kesā pathavī dhātu uti ādinā pubbe vutta nayena vatthu āmasanena
translated: The construction is this. By the method stated above: by the method stated above in the way beginning, “Head hairs are the earth element” . By the non-apprehension of the object:

original: vitthārato manasi karontassa pākaṭaṃ hoti kammaṭṭhānaṃ, nātitikkhapaññassa akhippanisantitāya
analyzed: vitthārataḥ manasi karontassa pākaṭam hoti kammaṭṭhānam na a titikkha paññassa a khippa nisanti tāya
translated: The meditation subject becomes evident to one who gives attention to it in detail, because of the keenness of his understanding,

original: vitthārarucibhāvato.🔽Idāni yathāvuttamatthaṃ upamāya vibhāvetuṃ “yathā dvīsu bhikkhūsū”tiādi vuttaṃ. Tattha
analyzed: vitthāra ruci bhāvato  idāni yathāvuttam attham upamāya vibhāvetum yathā dvīsu bhikkhūsu itiādi vuttam tattha
translated: and because of his liking for detail.🔽Now, in order to illustrate the meaning in this way by means of a simile, he said: “Just as, bhikkhus, between two men who are reciting, if one man recites in brief and the other in detail, then the man who recites in detail follows the other who recites in brief, and the latter’s recital is included in the former’s,🔽and the recital in brief is included in the recital in detail.

original: peyyālamukhanti peyyālapāḷiyā mukhabhūtaṃ dvārabhūtaṃ ādito vāraṃ, vāradvayaṃ vā.🔽Vitthāretvāti anavasesato sajjhāyitvā. Ubhatokoṭivasenevāti tassa tassa vārassa ādiantaggahaṇavaseneva.
analyzed: peyyālamukhanti peyyālapāḷiyā mukha bhūtam dvāra bhūtam āditas vāram vāra dvayam vā  vitthāretvā iti anavasesato ubhatas koṭi vasena iva ati tassa tassa vārassa ādi anta ggahaṇa vasena iva
translated: So too, bhikkhus, the meditation subject in brief is included in the meditation subject in detail, and the meditation subject in detail is included in the meditation subject in brief.🔽The meditation subject in brief is included in the meditation subject in detail: the meditation subject in brief is included in the meditation subject in detail in the sense of the meaning.🔽The meditation subject in detail is included in the meditation subject in brief: the meditation subject in detail is included in the meditation subject in brief in the sense of the text.

original: Oṭṭhapariyāhatamattanti oṭṭhānaṃ samphusanamattaṃ. Yathā ganthaparivattane tikkhapaññassa🔽bhikkhuno saṅkhepo ruccati, na vitthāro. Itarassa ca vitthāro ruccati, na saṅkhepo,🔽evaṃ bhāvanānayepīti upamāsaṃsandanaṃ veditabbaṃ.
analyzed: oṭṭha pariyāhata mattam ti oṭṭhānam samphusana mattam yathā gantha parivattane tikkha paññassa  bhikkhuno saṅkhepaḥ ruccati na vitthāraḥ itarassa ca vitthāraḥ ruccati na saṅkhepaḥ  evam bhāvanā anaye pi iti upamā saṃsandanam veditabbam
translated: The meditation subject in brief is included in the meditation subject in detail in the sense of the meaning: the meditation subject in brief is included in the meditation subject in detail in the sense of the meaning in this way: the meditation subject in brief is included in the meditation subject in detail in the sense of the meaning in the way in which the meditation subject in detail is included in the meditation subject in brief in the sense of the text.🔽The meditation subject in detail is included in the meditation subject in brief in the sense of the text: the meditation subject in detail is included in the meditation subject in brief in the sense of the text in this way: the meditation subject in detail is included in the meditation subject in brief in the sense of the text in the way in which the meditation subject in brief is included in the meditation subject in detail in the sense of the meaning.

original: Tasmāti yasmā tikkhapaññassa saṅkhepo, nātitikkhapaññassa ca vitthāro sappāyo, tasmā.
analyzed: tasmā ti yasmā tikkha paññassa saṅkhepaḥ na ati tikkha paññassa ca vitthāro sappāyaḥ tasmā
translated: The meditation subject in brief is included in the meditation subject in detail in the sense of the meaning: the meditation subject in brief is included in the meditation subject in detail in the sense of the meaning in this way: the meditation subject in brief is included in the meditation subject in detail in the sense of the meaning in the way in which the meditation subject in detail is included in the meditation subject in brief in the sense of the text.🔽The meditation subject in detail is included in the meditation subject in brief

original: Yasmā kammaṭṭhānaṃ anuyuñjitukāmassa sīlavisodhanādipubbakiccaṃ icchitabbaṃ, taṃ
analyzed: yasmai kammaṭṭhānam anuyuñjitu kāmassa sīla visodhana ādi pubba kiccam icchitabbam tam
translated: Since one who wants to practice the meditation subject must have the preliminary work consisting in purification of virtue, etc.,

original: sabbākārasampannaṃ heṭṭhā vuttamevāti idha na āmaṭṭhaṃ. Yasmā pana vivekaṭṭhakāyassa,
analyzed: sabba ākāra sampannam heṭṭhā vuttam eva ati idha na āmaṭṭham yasmā pana viveka ṭṭhakāyassa
translated: and since that has all been explained already below, it has not been included here.🔽But since development succeeds only for one who is secluded in body and secluded in mind, not for anyone else,

original: vivekaṭṭhacittasseva ca bhāvanā ijjhati, na itarassa, tasmā tadubhayaṃ dassento “rahogatena
analyzed: viveka ṭṭha cittassa iva ca bhāvanāḥ ijjhati na itarassa tasmai tat ubhayam dassentaḥ rahogatena
translated: the two kinds of seclusion are shown by the words “secluded from sense desires, secluded from unprofitable things. ”

original: paṭisallīnenā”ti āha. Tattha rahogatenāti rahasi gatena, ekākinā bhāvanānukūlaṭṭhānaṃ🔽upagatenāti attho. Paṭisallīnenāti pati pati puthuttārammaṇato cittaṃ nisedhetvā
analyzed: paṭisallīnena ati āha tattha rahogatena ati rahasi gatena ekākinā bhāvanā anukūla ṭṭhānam  upagatena ati attho paṭisallīnena ati pati pati puthuttā ārammaṇato cittam nisedhetvā
translated: Herein, secluded in body means gone to a secluded place, gone alone to a forest or to the root of a tree or to an empty place.🔽Secluded in mind means one who has averted his mind from sense desires and averted it from unprofitable things and directed it to profitable things.🔽Having directed his whole body and mind to the sign,🔽he should direct his whole body and mind to the sign, having directed his whole body and mind to the sign, he should direct his whole body and mind to the sign.

original: kammaṭṭhāne sallīnena, tattha saṃsiliṭṭhacittenāti attho. Sakalampi attano rūpakāyaṃ
analyzed: kammaṭṭhāne sallīnena tattha saṃsiliṭṭha cittena ati attho sakalam pi attanaḥ rūpa kāyam
translated: Having directed his whole body and mind to the sign, he should direct his whole body and mind to the sign.🔽Having directed his whole body and mind to the sign, he should direct his whole body and mind to the sign.🔽Having directed his whole body and mind to the sign, he should direct his whole body and mind to the sign.🔽Having directed his whole body and mind to the sign, he should direct his whole body and mind to the sign.🔽Having directed his whole body and mind to the sign, he should direct his whole body and mind to the sign.🔽Having directed his whole body and mind to the sign, he should direct his whole body and mind to the sign.🔽Having directed his whole body and mind to the sign, he should direct his whole body and mind to the sign.🔽Having directed his whole body and mind to the sign, he should direct his whole body and mind to the sign.🔽Having directed his whole body and mind to the sign, he should direct his whole body and mind to the sign.🔽Having directed his whole body and mind to the sign, he should direct his whole body and mind to the sign.🔽Having directed his whole body and mind to the sign, he should direct his whole body and mind to the sign.

original: āvajjetvāti uddhaṃ pādatalā, adho kesamatthakā, tiriyaṃ tacapariyantaṃ sabbampi attano
analyzed: āvajjetvā iti uddham pāda talāḥ adhas kesamatthakā tiriyam taca pariyantam sabbam pi attanaḥ
translated: Having directed his whole body and mind to the sign, he should direct his whole body and mind to the sign.🔽Having directed his whole body and mind to the sign, he should direct his whole body and mind to the sign.

original: karajakāyaṃ dhātuvasena manasi karonto yasmā cātumahābhūtiko ayaṃ kāyo, tasmā “atthi
analyzed: karaja kāyam dhātu vasena manasi karontaḥ yasmai cātumahābhūtikaḥ ayam kāyo tasmai atthi
translated: Having directed his

original: imasmiṃ kāye pathavīdhātu āpodhātu tejodhātu vāyodhātū”ti catumahābhūtavasena samannāharitvāti
analyzed: imasmin kāye pathavī dhātu āpaḥ dhātu tejaḥ dhātu vāyaḥ dhātu uti catu mahābhūta vasena samannāharitvā ati
translated: The meaning is that he should do so by means of the four primary elements.

original: attho. Idāni tāsaṃ dhātūnaṃ lakkhaṇato, upaṭṭhānākārato ca manasikāravidhiṃ dassetuṃ
analyzed: atthaḥ idāni tāsam dhātūnam lakkhaṇataḥ upaṭṭhāna ākārato ca manasikāra vidhim dassetuṃ
translated: Now, in order to show the method of giving attention to those elements according to their characteristics and according to their appearance,

original: “yo imasmiṃ kāye”tiādi vuttaṃ.
analyzed: yaḥ imasmin kāya itiādi vuttam
translated: “The earth element in this body” is said.

original: Tattha thaddhabhāvoti lakkhaṇamāha. Thaddhattalakkhaṇā hi pathavīdhātu. Kharabhāvoti
analyzed: tattha thaddha bhāvaḥ ti lakkhaṇam āha hi pathavī dhātu khara bhāvaḥ ti
translated: Herein, “The stiff- ness” is said to be the characteristic. For the earth element has the charac- teristic of stiffness. “The hardness” is

original: upaṭṭhānākāraṃ, ñāṇena gahetabbākāranti attho. Dravabhāvo lakkhaṇaṃ āpodhātuyā paggharaṇasabhāvattā.🔽Ābandhanaṃ upaṭṭhānākāro. Uṇhabhāvo lakkhaṇaṃ tejodhātuyā usmāsabhāvattā. Paripācanaṃ
analyzed: upaṭṭhāna ākāram ñāṇena gahetabba ākāranti atthaḥ drava bhāvaḥ lakkhaṇam āpodhātuyā paggharaṇa sabhāva ttā  ābandhanam upaṭṭhāna ākāraḥ uṇha bhāvaḥ lakkhaṇam tejodhātuyāḥ usmāsa bhāva tā paripācanam
translated: the appearance. The meaning is that it is the appearance as which it is apprehended by knowledge. “The fluidity” is the characteristic of the water element because its nature is that of moistness.🔽“The cohesion” is the appearance. “The heat” is the characteristic of the fire element because its nature is that of heat. “The maturing” is

original: upaṭṭhānākāro. Vitthambhanaṃ lakkhaṇaṃ vāyodhātuyā upatthambhanasabhāvattā. Samudīraṇaṃ
analyzed: upaṭṭhāna ākāraḥ vitthambhanam lakkhaṇam vāyodhātuyāḥ upatthambhana sabhāva tā samudīraṇam
translated: the appearance. “The distension” is the characteristic of the air element because its nature is that of distension. “The stirring” is

original: upaṭṭhānākāro, upaṭṭhānākāro ca nāma dhātūnaṃ sakiccakaraṇavasena ñāṇassa vibhūtākāro.
analyzed: upaṭṭhāna ākāraḥ upaṭṭhāna ākāro ca nāma dhātūnam sa kicca karaṇa vasena ñāṇassa vibhūta ākāraḥ
translated: the appearance. And the appearance is the aspect of manifestation of knowledge by means of the elements’ performance of their own func- tions.

original: Kasmā panettha ubhayaggahaṇaṃ? Puggalajjhāsayato. Ekaccassa hi dhātuyo manasi karontassa
analyzed: kasmā pana ittha ubhaya ggahaṇam ekaccassa hi dhātuyaḥ manasi karontassa
translated: But why is there the mention of both here? Because of the individual’s temperament. For when some people bring the elements to mind,

original: tā sabhāvato gahetabbataṃ gacchanti, ekaccassa sakiccakaraṇato, yo rasoti vuccati.
analyzed: tāḥ sabhāvataḥ gahetabba tam gacchanti ekaccassa sa kicca karaṇataḥ yaḥ rasaḥ iti vuccati
translated: they do so as to be grasped by their individual essences, and some do so as to be grasped by their individual functions, which is what is meant by “taste.”

original: Tatrāyaṃ yogī dhātuyo manasi karonto ādito paccekaṃ salakkhaṇato, sarasatopi pariggaṇhāti.
analyzed: tatra ayam yogī dhātuyaḥ manasi karontaḥ āditas paccekam sa lakkhaṇataḥ sarasataḥ pi pariggaṇhāti
translated: Herein, when this meditator brings the elements to mind, he first discerns them by their individual characteristics and by their individual “tastes” taken separately.

original: Tenāha “yo imasmiṃ kāye thaddhabhāvo vā kharabhāvo vā…pe… evaṃ saṃkhittena dhātuyo🔽pariggahetvā”ti. Tattha pariggahetvāti pariggāhakabhūtena ñāṇena dhātuyo lakkhaṇato,
analyzed: tena āha yaḥ imasmin kāye thaddha bhāvaḥ vā khara bhāvaḥ vā āpe evam saṃkhittena  pariggahetvā ti tattha pariggahetvā ati pariggāhaka bhūtena ñāṇena dhātuyaḥ lakkhaṇato
translated: Hence it is said: “Having thus discerned the elements in brief in this way” .

original: rasato vā paricchijja gahetvā. Ayaṃ tāva saṃkhittato bhāvanānaye kammaṭṭhānābhiniveso.🔽Evaṃ pana dhātuyo pariggahetvā “atthi imasmiṃ kāye pathavīdhātu thaddhabhāvo vā kharabhāvo
analyzed: rasataḥ vā paricchijja gahetvā ayam tāva saṃkhittataḥ bhāvanā naye kammaṭṭhāna abhiniveso  evam pana dhātuyaḥ pariggahetvā atthi imasmin kāye pathavī dhātu thaddha bhāvaḥ vā khara bhāvaḥ
translated: Herein, having thus discerned is having discerned the elements by means of the knowledge that has become the discerning, by their characteristics or by their tastes. This, in the first place, is the undertaking of the meditation subject in brief.

original: vā, āpodhātu dravabhāvo vā ābandhanabhāvo vā, tejodhātu uṇhabhāvo vā paripācanabhāvo
analyzed: vā āpaḥ dhātu drava bhāvaḥ vā ābandhana bhāvaḥ vā tejaḥ dhātu uṇha bhāvaḥ vā paripācana bhāvaḥ
translated: But after discerning the elements in this way, he should discern them in detail too, according to the method stated thus: “In this body, there is the earth element, the water element, the fire element, the air element” .

original: vā, vāyodhātu vitthambhanabhāvo vā samudīraṇabhāvo vā”ti evaṃ lakkhaṇādīhi saddhiṃyeva🔽dhātuyo manasi karontena kālasatampi kālasahassampi punappunaṃ āvajjitabbaṃ manasi
analyzed: vā vāyodhātu vitthambhana bhāvaḥ vā samudīraṇa bhāvaḥ vā ati evam lakkhaṇa ādīhi saddhiṃya iva  dhātuyaḥ manasi karontena kāla satam pi kāla sahassam pi punappunam āvajjitabbam manasi
translated: or for a day and a night, and he should advert to them, review them and reflect on them.

original: kātabbaṃ, takkāhataṃ vitakkapariyāhataṃ kātabbaṃ. Tassevaṃ manasi karoto yaṃ lakkhaṇādīsu
analyzed: kātabbam takka āhatam vitakka pariyāhatam kātabbam tassa ivam manasi karotaḥ yam lakkhaṇa ādīsu
translated: As he adverts thus, whatever is most evident to him among the characteristics, etc.,

original: supākaṭaṃ hutvā upaṭṭhāti, tadeva gahetvā itaraṃ vissajjetvā tena saddhiṃ “pathavīdhātu🔽āpodhātū”tiādinā manasikāro pavattetabbo. Evaṃ manasi karontena hi anupubbato, nātisīghato,
analyzed: supākaṭam hutvā upaṭṭhāti tat eva gahetvā itaram vissajjetvā tena saddhim pathavī dhātu  āpodhātu uti ādinā manasikāraḥ pavattetabbaḥ evam manasi karontena hi anupubbataḥ na ati sīghato
translated: of the elements should be taken as the sign. The rest should be overlooked. He should then continue the development of concentration by adverting to that sign in this way, “earth element, earth element,”🔽as if cross-questioning it. He should do so neither too hurriedly nor too slowly.

original: nātisaṇikato, vikkhepapaṭibāhanato, paṇṇattisamatikkamanato, anupaṭṭhānamuñcanato,🔽lakkhaṇato, tayo ca suttantāti imehi dasahākārehi manasikārakosallaṃ anuṭṭhātabbaṃ.
analyzed: na ati saṇikataḥ vikkhepa paṭibāhanataḥ paṇṇatti samatikkamanataḥ an upaṭṭhāna muñcanataḥ 🔽lakkhaṇato tayo ca suttantā ti imehi dasa hākārehi manasikāra kosallam anuṭṭhātabbam
translated: He should not hurry. He should not be in too great a hurry. He should not be in too little hurry. He should not be in too great a hurry, nor in too little hurry. He should not be in too great a hurry, nor in too little hurry. He should not be in too great a hurry, nor in too little hurry. He should not be in too great a hurry, nor in too little hurry. He should not be in too great a hurry, nor in too little hurry. He should not be in too great a hurry, nor in too little hurry. He should not be in too great a hurry, nor in too little hurry. He should not be in too great a hurry, nor in too little hurry. He should not be in too great a hurry, nor in too little hurry. He should not be in too great a hurry, nor in too little hurry. He should not be in too great a hurry, nor in too little hurry. He should not be in too great a hurry, nor in too little hurry. He should not be in too great a hurry, nor in too little hurry. He should not be in too great a hurry, nor in too little hurry. He should not be in too great a hurry, nor in too little hurry. He should not be in too great a hurry, nor in too little hurry. He should not be in too great a hurry, nor in too little hurry. He should not be in too great a hurry, nor in too little hurry

original: Tattha anupubbatoti anupaṭipāṭito ācariyassa santike uggahitapaṭipāṭito, sā ca desanāpaṭipāṭiyeva.
analyzed: tattha anupubbato ti anupaṭipāṭitaḥ ācariyassa santike uggahita paṭipāṭitaḥ sā ca desanā paṭipāṭiyā eva
translated: Herein, in forward order: in the order in which it was acquired from the teacher’s lips. And that is the order of teaching only.🔽And when he brings it to mind in this way, he should not do so too rapidly,🔽for if he brings it to mind too rapidly, the meditation subject will not be properly defined for him, it will not be properly apprehended, and it will not be well remembered. So he should not bring it to mind too rapidly. And as he should not bring it to mind too rapidly, so also he should not bring it to mind too slowly.

original: Evaṃ anupubbato manasi karontenāpi nātisīghato manasi kātabbaṃ. Atisīghato manasi🔽karoto hi aparāparaṃ kammaṭṭhānamanasikāro nirantaraṃ pavattati, kammaṭṭhānaṃ pana
analyzed: evam anupubbataḥ manasi karontena api na ati sīghataḥ manasi kātabbam ati sīghataḥ manasi  karotaḥ hi apara aparam kammaṭṭhāna manasikāraḥ nirantaram pavattati kammaṭṭhānam pana
translated: For if he brings it to mind too slowly, his meditation subject will not be brought to mind in successive moments, and then it will not be properly defined for him, it will not be properly apprehended, and it will not be well remembered. So he should not bring it to mind too slowly. And as he should not bring it to mind too slowly, so also he should not bring it to mind too rapidly.🔽For if he brings it to mind too rapidly, his meditation subject will not be brought to mind in successive moments, and then it will not be properly defined for him, it will not be properly apprehended, and it will not be well remembered. So he should not bring it to mind too rapidly. He should bring it to mind neither too slowly nor too rapidly, but bringing it to mind at a moderate speed, he should bring it to mind in successive moments.

original: avibhūtaṃ hoti, na visesaṃ āvahati. Tasmā nātisīghato manasi kātabbaṃ. Yathā ca nātisīghato,
analyzed: a vibhūtam hoti na visesam āvahati tasmā na ati sīghataḥ manasi kātabbam yathā ca na ati sīghataḥ
translated: And as he should not bring it to mind too slowly, so also he should not bring it to mind too rapidly. For if he brings it to mind too rapidly, his meditation subject will not reach culmination, and it will not become a condition for distinction. He should not bring it to mind too slowly or too rapidly.🔽He should bring it to mind neither too slowly nor too rapidly, but bringing it to mind at a moderate speed, he should bring it to mind in successive moments.

original: evaṃ nātisaṇikatopi. Atisaṇikato manasi karoto hi kammaṭṭhānaṃ pariyosānaṃ na gacchati,
analyzed: evam na ati saṇikataḥ api ati saṇikataḥ manasi karotaḥ hi kammaṭṭhānam pariyosānam na gacchati
translated: And as he should not bring it to mind too slowly, so also he should not bring it to mind too rapidly. For if he brings it to mind too rapidly, his meditation subject will not reach culmination, and it will not become a condition for distinction. He should not bring it to mind too slowly or too rapidly.

original: visesādhigamassa paccayo na hoti. Atisīghaṃ atisaṇikañca maggaṃ gacchantā purisā🔽ettha nidassetabbā. Vikkhepapaṭibāhanatoti kammaṭṭhānaṃ vissajjetvā bahiddhā puthuttārammaṇe
analyzed: visesa adhigamassa paccayaḥ na hoti ati sīgham ati saṇikam ca maggam gacchantā purisā 🔽ettha nidassetabbā vikkhepa paṭibāhanato ti kammaṭṭhānam vissajjetvā bahiddhā puthutta ārammaṇe
translated: He should bring it to mind neither too slowly nor too rapidly, but bringing it to mind at a moderate speed, he should bring it to mind in successive moments.🔽And as he should not bring it to mind

original: cetaso vikkhepo paṭibāhitabbo. Bahiddhā vikkhepe hi sati kammaṭṭhānā parihāyati paridhaṃsati.
analyzed: cetasaḥ vikkhepaḥ paṭibāhitabbaḥ bahiddhā vikkhepe hi sati kammaṭṭhānā parihāyati paridhaṃsati
translated: and the distraction of the mind should be warded off. For if there is distraction outwards, the meditation subject is neglected and falls from the meditator’s mind.

original: Ekapadikamaggagāmī puriso cettha nidassetabbo. Paṇṇattisamatikkamanatoti “yā ayaṃ
analyzed: eka padika magga gāmī purisaḥ ca ittha nidassetabbaḥ paṇṇatti samatikkamanataḥ ti yā ayam
translated: Here a man walking on a path that has a precipice on one side should be compared with the meditation subject.🔽By transcending the concept: the concept that has arisen in this way,

original: pathavīdhātū”tiādikā paṇṇatti, taṃ atikkamitvā lakkhaṇesu eva cittaṃ ṭhapetabbaṃ.🔽Evaṃ paṇṇattiṃ vijahitvā kakkhaḷalakkhaṇādīsu eva manasikāraṃ pavattentassa lakkhaṇāni
analyzed: pathavī dhātu uti ādikā paṇṇatti tam atikkamitvā lakkhaṇesu eva cittam ṭhapetabbam  evam paṇṇattim vijahitvā kakkhaḷa lakkhaṇa ādīsu eva manasikāram pavattentassa lakkhaṇāni
translated: beginning with “the earth element,” should be surmounted and the mind anchored on the characteristics.🔽When he does so, the characteristics become evident to him and stand out well, since he is giving his attention to the characteristics of hardness, etc., without taking any account of the concept.

original: supākaṭāni suvibhūtāni hutvā upaṭṭhahanti. Tassevaṃ punappunaṃ manasikāravasena cittaṃ
analyzed: su pākaṭāni su vibhūtāni hutvā upaṭṭhahanti tassa ivam punappunam manasikāra vasena cittam
translated: And as he again and again gives his attention to it in this way, his consciousness becomes habituated to that object.

original: āsevanaṃ labhati. Sabbo rūpakāyo dhātumattato upaṭṭhāti suñño nissatto nijjīvo yantaṃ🔽viya yantasuttena aparāparaṃ parivattamāno. Sace pana bahiddhāpi manasikāraṃ upasaṃharati,
analyzed: āsevanam labhati sabbaḥ rūpa kāyaḥ dhātumattataḥ upaṭṭhāti suññaḥ nissattaḥ nijjīvaḥ yantam  viya yanta suttena apara aparam parivattamānaḥ sace pana bahiddhā api manasikāram upasaṃharati
translated: The whole of the material body appears to him as void, insubstantial, spiritless, like a machine made up of different parts.

original: athassa āhiṇḍantā manussatiracchānādayo sattākāraṃ vijahitvā dhātusamūhavaseneva
analyzed: āhiṇḍantāḥ manussa tiracchāna ādayaḥ satta ākāram vijahitvā dhātu samūha vasena iva
translated: But if he extends his attention to what is outside the body, then human beings, animals, etc., appear to him as void, insubstantial, spiritless, like a machine made up of different parts,

original: upaṭṭhahanti, tehi kariyamānā kiriyā dhātumayena yantena pavattiyamānā hutvā upaṭṭhāti,
analyzed: upaṭṭhahanti tehi kariyamānā kiriyā dhātu mayena yantena pavattiyamānā hutvā upaṭṭhāti
translated: When they attend on him, the work they do for him is like a machine made of elements that is set going.

original: tehi ajjhohariyamānaṃ pānabhojanādi dhātusaṅghāte pakkhippamāno dhātusaṅghāto viya
analyzed: tehi ajjhohariyamānam pāna bhojana ādi dhātu saṅghāte pakkhippamānaḥ dhātu saṅghātaḥ viya
translated: And the food and drink he takes is like a mass of elements that is thrown into the mass of elements in his body.

original: upaṭṭhāti. Athassa tathā laddhāsevanampi cittaṃ yadi accāraddhavīriyatāya uddhaccavasena🔽vā atilīnavīriyatāya kosajjavasena vā bhāvanāvidhiṃ na otareyya, tadā adhicittasuttaṃ,
analyzed: upaṭṭhāti athassa tathā laddha āsevanam pi cittam yadi acca āraddha vīriya tāya uddhacca vasena  vā ati līna vīriya tāya kosajja vasena vā bhāvanā vidhim na otareyya tadā adhicitta suttam
translated: Then, if his mind, which has thus obtained opportunity for development, does not enter into the way of mental development owing to his energy being too great and so tending to agitation,🔽or owing to his energy being too slack and so tending to indolence, then he should apply energy and concentration by the method stated in the three suttas called the “Greater Discourse on High Intelligence” ,

original: anuttarasītibhāvasuttaṃ, bojjhaṅgasuttanti imesu tīsu suttesu āgatanayena vīriyasamādhiyojanā
analyzed: anuttara sīti bhāva suttam bojjhaṅga suttan ti imesu tīsu suttesu āgata nayena vīriya samādhi yojanā
translated: the “Greater Discourse on the Mirror of Truth” , and the “Greater Discourse on the Establishments of Mindfulness” .

original: kātabbā. Tena vuttaṃ “tayo ca suttantā”ti. Evaṃ pana vīriyasamataṃ yojetvā tasmiṃyeva🔽lakkhaṇe manasikāraṃ pavattentassa yadā saddhādīni indriyāni laddhasamatāni suvisadāni
analyzed: kātabbā tena vuttam tayo ca suttantā ti evam pana vīriya samatam yojetvā tasmin yeva  lakkhaṇe manasikāram pavattentassa yadā saddhā ādīni indriyāni laddha samatāni su visadāni
translated: That is why it was said above that he should apply energy and concentration by the method stated in the three suttas.

original: pavattanti, tadā asaddhiyādīnaṃ dūrībhāvena sātisayaṃ thāmappattehi sattahi balehi
analyzed: pavattanti tadā asaddhi ādīnam dūrībhāvena sa atisayam thāma ppattehi sattahi balehi
translated: But when he has thus applied energy and concentration and is pursuing his meditation subject by giving attention to it in its specific and general characteristics, then, when the faculties of faith, etc., are operating with balanced strength, he should understand that his meditation subject is successful and that he has reached the right way.🔽When they are not so operating, it should be understood that his meditation subject is unsuccessful and that he has missed the way.

original: laddhūpatthambhāni vitakkādīni jhānaṅgāni paṭutarāni hutvā pātubhavanti, tesaṃ ujuvipaccanīkatāya🔽nīvaraṇāni vikkhambhitāniyeva honti saddhiṃ tadekaṭṭhehi pāpadhammehi. Ettāvatā cānena🔽upacārajjhānaṃ samadhigataṃ hoti dhātulakkhaṇārammaṇaṃ. Tena vuttaṃ “punappunaṃ pathavīdhātu
analyzed: laddhu upatthambhāni vitakka ādīni jhān aṅgāni paṭutarāni hutvā pātubhavanti tesam uju vipaccanīka tāya  nīvaraṇāni honti saddhim tad ekaṭṭhehi pāpa dhammehi ettāvatā ca anena  upacāra jhānam samadhigatam hoti dhātu lakkhaṇa ārammaṇam tena vuttam punappunam pathavī dhātu
translated: The jhāna factors of applied thought, etc., which have obtained their footing, come to maturity and become evident in superior form, and the hindrances are simply suppressed by them, together with all bad thoughts.🔽And at this point he has attained access concentration, which has the characteristic of “threshold” to absorption, and its object is the repulsiveness of the four primary elements.

original: āpodhātūti…pe… upacāramatto samādhi uppajjatī”ti.🔽Tattha dhātumattatoti visesanivattiattho matta-saddo. Tena yaṃ ito bāhirakā, lokiyamahājano🔽ca “satto jīvo”tiādikaṃ visesaṃ imasmiṃ attabhāve avijjamānaṃ vikappanāmatteneva
analyzed: upacāra mattaḥ samādhi uppajjati iti  tattha dhātu mattato ti visesa nivatti attho matta saddo tena yam itas lokiya mahājano  ca sattaḥ jīvaḥ ti ādikam visesam imasmin atta bhāve a vijjamānam vikappanā mattena iva
translated: Hence it is said: “When he again and again adverts thus, ‘The earth-element, the earth-element,’ … the access concentration that has the characteristic of threshold to absorption arises in him” .🔽Herein, the word “only” in the words “the mere earth element” has the meaning of an exclusion;🔽for the ordinary man outside the dispensation, who is called “the worldling” , and also the worldling who is a clansman, when they come to this visible individuality, which is a mere compound of the four primary elements, exclude the specific characteristics of the primary elements and superimpose upon it a self, a being, a soul, a man, a human, etc., by mere imagination.

original: samāropenti, taṃ nivatteti. Tenevāha “nissattato nijjīvato”ti. Āvajjitabbanti samannāharitabbaṃ.
analyzed: samāropenti tam nivatteti tena iva āha nissattataḥ nijjīvataḥ ti āvajjitabbam ti samannāharitabbam
translated: So the word “only” excludes that. That is why it is said in the Paṭisambhidā: “‘The mere earth element’: the word ‘mere’ is said in order to exclude a being, a soul, a creature, a person, an individual, an owner of the kamma done, an enjoyer of the result of the kamma done” .🔽What is to be adverted to: what is to be given attention to.

original: Manasi kātabbanti punappunaṃ bhāvanāvasena dhātumattato dhātulakkhaṇaṃ manasi ṭhapetabbaṃ.
analyzed: manasi kātabbanti punappunam bhāvanā vasena dhātumattataḥ dhātu lakkhaṇam manasi ṭhapetabbam
translated: What is to be given attention to again and again by development: the characteristic of the mere elements is to be given attention to again and again by development.

original: Paccavekkhitabbanti tadeva dhātulakkhaṇaṃ pati pati avekkhitabbaṃ, bhāvanāsiddhena
analyzed: paccavekkhitabbanti tat eva dhātu lakkhaṇam pati pati avekkhitabbam bhāvanā siddhena
translated: He should review the characteristics of the elements one by one.

original: ñāṇacakkhunā aparāparaṃ paccakkhato passitabbaṃ.
analyzed: ñāṇa cakkhunā apara aparam paccakkhataḥ passitabbam
translated: He should see them with the eye of knowledge, which is successful through development, by direct experience, again and again.

original: Tassevaṃ vāyamamānassāti tassa yogino evaṃ vuttappakārena bhāvanaṃ anuyuñjantassa,
analyzed: tassa ivam vāyamamānassa ati tassa yoginaḥ evam vutta ppakārena bhāvanam anuyuñjantassa
translated: As he strives thus: as he endeavours in development in the way just described,

original: tattha ca bhāvanāanuyoge sakkaccakāritāya, sātaccakāritāya, sappāyasevitāya, samathanimittasallakkhaṇena,
analyzed: tattha ca bhāvanā anuyoge sakkacca kāritāya sātacca kāritāya sappāya sevitāya samatha nimitta sat lakkhaṇena
translated: and as he devotes himself to it earnestly, persistently, and properly,

original: bojjhaṅgānaṃ anupavattanena, kāye ca jīvite ca nirapekkhavuttitāya, antarā saṅkocaṃ
analyzed: bojjhaṅgānaṃ an upavattanena kāye ca jīvite ca nirapekkha vutti tāya antarā saṅkocam
translated: and as he does not lose interest in the development of the jhāna by being discouraged,🔽and as he does not neglect the sign of serenity,🔽and as he does not neglect development by being slack or by over-exertion,

original: anāpajjantena bhāvanaṃ ussukkāpetvā ussoḷhiyaṃ avaṭṭhānena sammadeva vāyāmaṃ payogaṃ
analyzed: an āpajjantena bhāvanam ussukkāpetvā ussoḷhiyam avaṭṭhānena sammadeva vā āyāmam payogam
translated: and as he persists in the right way by maintaining balance,

original: parakkamaṃ pavattentassa. Dhātuppabhedāvabhāsanapaññāpariggahitoti pathavīādīnaṃ🔽dhātūnaṃ sabhāvalakkhaṇāvabhāsanena avabhāsanakiccāya bhāvanāpaññāya ādimajjhapariyosānesu
analyzed: parakkamam pavattentassa dhātu ppabheda avabhāsana paññā pariggahito ti pathavī ādīnam 🔽dhātūnam sabhāva lakkhaṇa avabhāsanena avabhāsana kiccāya bhāvanā paññāya ādi majjha pariyosānesu
translated: then his knowledge is said to be “enveloped by the light of the classification of the elements.”🔽The knowledge that is successful through development is called “enlightened knowledge” .

original: avijahanena sabbato gahito mahaggatabhāvaṃ appattatāya upacāramatto sikhāppatto kāmāvacarasamādhi🔽uppajjati. Upacārasamādhīti ca ruḷhīvasena veditabbaṃ. Appanaṃ hi upecca cārī samādhi
analyzed: avijahanena sabbatas gahitaḥ mahaggata bhāvam appatta tāya upacāra matto sikhā appatto kāmāvacara samādhi  uppajjati upacāra samādhi iti ca ruḷhī vasena veditabbam appanam hi upecca cārī samādhi
translated: The light is called “access” because it is not yet the absorption, and “flame” because it is near to the absorption.🔽The concentration that arises is of the sense sphere. It should be understood as “access concentration” in the sense of being near to absorption.🔽For it is said: “Concentration that goes near to absorption is access concentration;

original: upacārasamādhi, appanā cettha natthi. Tādisassa pana samādhissa samānalakkhaṇatāya
analyzed: upacāra samādhi appanā ca ittha natthi tādisassa pana samādhissa samāna lakkhaṇa tāya
translated: there is no absorption here.”🔽But it is said thus because it has the same characteristics as that kind of concentration.

original: evaṃ vuttaṃ. Kasmā panettha appanā na hotīti? Tattha kāraṇamāha “sabhāvadhammārammaṇattā”ti.
analyzed: evam vuttam kasmā pana ittha appanā na hoti iti tattha kāraṇam āha sabhāva dhamma ārammaṇa ttā ti
translated: But why is there no absorption here? The reason is given: “because the object is a natural state of things.”

original: Sabhāvadhamme hi tassa gambhīrabhāvato asati bhāvanāvisese appanājhānaṃ na uppajjati,
analyzed: sa bhāva dhamme hi tassa gambhīra bhāvataḥ asati bhāvanā visese appanā jhānam na uppajjati
translated: For when the object is a natural state of things, absorption jhāna does not arise unless there is special development, because of its profundity.

original: lokuttaraṃ pana jhānaṃ visuddhibhāvanānukkamavasena, āruppaṃ ārammaṇātikkamabhāvanāvasena
translated: But the supramundane jhāna reaches absorption through the development of purification, and the immaterial jhāna through the development of surmounting the object.

original: appanāppattaṃ hotīti maraṇānussatiniddese vuttovāyamattho.
analyzed: appanā appattam hoti iti maraṇa anussati niddese vuttaḥ uva ayam atthaḥ
translated: This is the meaning of the words already given in the description of the recollection of death.

original: Evaṃ rūpakāye avisesena catunnaṃ dhātūnaṃ pariggaṇhanavasena dhātukammaṭṭhānaṃ dassetvā
analyzed: evam rūpa kāye avisesena catunnam dhātūnam pariggaṇhana vasena dhātu kammaṭṭhānam dassetvā
translated: Having thus shown the meditation subject of the elements by discerning the four elements without distinguishing the physical body,

original: idāni tattha aṭṭhiādīnaṃ vinibbhujanavasena saṅkhepato sutte āgataṃ dhātumanasikāravidhiṃ
analyzed: idāni tattha aṭṭhi ādīnam vinibbhujana vasena saṅkhepataḥ sutte āgatam dhātu manasikāra vidhim
translated: Now, the method of giving attention to the elements, which is given in brief in the suttas by the analysis of the bones, etc., in the case of the earth kasiṇa, should be given attention to in detail in this way.

original: dassetuṃ “atha vā panā”tiādi āraddhaṃ. Tattha ye ime cattāro koṭṭhāsā vuttāti sambandho.
analyzed: dassetum atha vā pana ati ādi āraddham tattha ye ime cattāro koṭṭhāsāḥ vuttā iti sambandho
translated: Now, in order to show the method of giving attention to the elements, which is given in brief in the suttas by way of the analysis of the bones, etc., the text begins with the words “Or alternatively,” and so on. Herein, the construction should be understood in this way: “The four parts that are stated,” and so on.

original: Yathāpaccayaṃ ṭhitā sannivesavisiṭṭhā kaṭṭhavallitiṇamattikāyo upādāya yathā agārasamaññā,🔽na tattha koci agāro nāma atthi, evaṃ yathāpaccayaṃ sannivesavisiṭṭhāni pavattamānāni
analyzed: yathāpaccayam ṭhitā sannivesa visiṭṭhā kaṭṭhavalli tiṇa mattikāyaḥ upādāya yathā agāra samaññā  na tattha koci agāraḥ nāma atthi evam yathāpaccayam sannivesa visiṭṭhāni pavattamānāni
translated: Just as, in dependence on the wood, grass, clay, etc., that are distinguished by their arrangement, the name “house” occurs,🔽but there is no house at all there, so too, in dependence on the bones, sinews, flesh, skin, etc., that are distinguished by their arrangement,

original: aṭṭhinhārumaṃsacammāni paṭicca sarīrasamaññā, na ettha koci attā jīvo. Kevalaṃ tehi🔽parivāritamākāsamattanti dasseti. Desanā sattasuññatāsandassanaparāti imamatthaṃ
analyzed: aṭṭhinha āru maṃsa cammāni paṭicca sarīra samaññā na ettha koci attā jīvaḥ kevalam tehi  parivāritam ākāsam attanti dasseti desanā satta suññatā saṃdassana parā ti imam attham
translated: the name “body” occurs, but there is no self or soul there. It is merely the mere space enclosed by the skin that is shown to be surrounded by them.🔽The teaching is a demonstration of the sevenfold voidness.

original: vibhāvento “nissattabhāvadassanattha”ntiādimāha. Tattha aṭṭhiñca paṭiccāti paṇhikaṭṭhikādibhedaṃ
analyzed: vibhāventaḥ nissatta bhāva dassana ttham ti ādim āha tattha aṭṭhim ca paṭicca ati paṇhika ṭṭhikā ādi bhedam
translated: In order to show this meaning, he says, “For the purpose of showing the non-existence of a being,” and so on. Herein, “in dependence on the bones” means in dependence on the bones of the foot, etc., which are distinguished by their arrangement.

original: paṭipāṭiyā ussitaṃ hutvā ṭhitaṃ atirekatisatabhedaṃ aṭṭhiṃ upādāya. Nhāruñcāti tameva🔽aṭṭhisaṅghāṭaṃ ābandhitvā ṭhitaṃ navasatappabhedaṃ nhāruṃ. Maṃsanti tameva aṭṭhisaṅghāṭaṃ🔽anulimpitvā ṭhitaṃ navapesisatappabhedaṃ maṃsaṃ. Cammanti macchikapattakacchāyāya
analyzed: paṭipāṭiyā ussitam hutvā ṭhitam atireka ti sata bhedam aṭṭhim upādāya tam eva  aṭṭhi saṅghāṭam ābandhitvā ṭhitam nava sata ppabhedam nhārum maṃsanti tam eva aṭṭhi saṅghāṭam  anulimpitvā ṭhitam nava pesi satappa bhedam maṃsam macchika pattaka chāyāya
translated: and the bones are of more than three hundred kinds. sinews are of more than nine hundred kinds. Flesh is of more than nine hundred and 🔽eighty kinds. Skin is like a fine wet cloth

original: chaviyā sañchāditaṃ sakalasarīraṃ pariyonandhitvā ṭhitaṃ bahalacammaṃ paṭicca upādāya.🔽Sabbattha ca-saddo samuccayattho. Ākāso parivāritoti yathā bhittipādādivasena ṭhapitaṃ
analyzed: chaviyā sañchāditam sakala sarīram pariyonandhitvā ṭhitam bahala cammam paṭicca upādāya  sabbattha ca saddo samuccaya ttho ākāsaḥ parivāritaḥ ti yathā bhitti pāda ādi vasena ṭhapitam
translated: and the bones, which are of more than three hundred kinds, are set up in a framework. “Sinews” are the nine hundred sinews that bind the bones together. “Flesh” is the flesh that covers the bones, which is of more than nine hundred pieces. “Skin” is the thick hide that covers the whole body, enveloping the flesh, etc.

original: kaṭṭhaṃ, tasseva ābandhanavalli, anulepanamattikā, chādanatiṇanti etāni kaṭṭhādīni🔽anto, bahi ca parivāretvā ṭhito ākāso agārantveva saṅkhaṃ gacchati, gehanti paṇṇattiṃ
analyzed: kaṭṭham tassa iva ābandhana valli anulepana mattikā chādana tiṇanti etāni kaṭṭha ādīni  antar bahis ca parivāretvā ṭhitaḥ ākāsaḥ saṅkham gacchati gehanti paṇṇattim
translated: The word “and” in the text is conjunctive. “The space that is enclosed” is the space that is enclosed by the bones, etc., in the same way that a house is said to be “enclosed by walls, etc.,”🔽and the space inside a pot is said to be “enclosed by the pot.”

original: labhati, evameva yathāvuttāni aṭṭhiādīni anto, bahi ca parivāretvā ṭhito ākāso tāneva
analyzed: labhati evam eva yathā vuttāni aṭṭhi ādīni antar bahi ca parivāretvā ṭhitaḥ ākāsaḥ tān eva
translated: Just as the wood, etc., that is enclosed by walls, etc., is called a “house,” and the space enclosed by the pot is called a “pot,” so too, the space enclosed by the bones, etc., is called “the body.”

original: aṭṭhiādīni upādāya rūpantveva saṅkhaṃ gacchati, sarīranti vohāraṃ labhati. Yathā
analyzed: upādāya saṅkham gacchati vohāram labhati yathā
translated: and it is only the materiality consisting of bones, etc., that is so reckoned and comes to be called a “body.”

original: ca kaṭṭhādīni paṭicca saṅkhaṃ gataṃ agāraṃ loke “khattiyagehaṃ, brāhmaṇageha”nti🔽vuccati, evamidampi “khattiyasarīraṃ brāhmaṇasarīra”nti voharīyati, natthettha koci
analyzed: ca kaṭṭha ādīni paṭicca saṅkham gatam agāram loke khattiya geham brāhmaṇa geham ti  vuccati evam idam pi khattiya sarīram brāhmaṇa sarīram ti voharīyati nattha ittha koci
translated: Just as a house built of timber, etc., and reckoned as a “house” comes to be called a “house of khattiyas” or a “house of brahmans,”

original: satto vā jīvo vāti adhippāyo.🔽Teti te cattāro koṭṭhāse vinibbhujitvā vinibbhujitvāti yojanā. Taṃtaṃantarānusārināti🔽aṭṭhinhārūnaṃ nhārumaṃsānaṃ maṃsacammānanti tesaṃ tesaṃ koṭṭhāsānaṃ vivarānupātinā
analyzed: sattaḥ vā jīvaḥ vā ati adhippāyaḥ  te iti te cattāro koṭṭhāse vinibbhujitvā vinibbhujitvā ati yojanā  aṭṭhi nhārūnam nhāru maṃsānam maṃsa cammānanti tesam tesam koṭṭhāsānam vivara anupātinā
translated: so too this body comes to be called a “khattiya body” or a “brahman body.” But there is no being or soul here at all.🔽“Having divided it up, having divided it up”: the construction is that having divided it up again and again. “Following along the interstices”: with a hand consisting of knowledge following along the interstices of the nine openings of the bones, the marrow, the flesh, the flesh of the sinews, the flesh of the skin, of each of those parts.

original: ñāṇasaṅkhātena hatthena. Vinibbhujitvā vinibbhujitvāti anekakkhattuṃ viniveṭhetvā.
analyzed: ñāṇa saṅkhātena hatthena vinibbhujitvā vinibbhujitvā ati aneka kkhattum viniveṭhetvā
translated: “Having divided it up, having divided it up”: having turned it over again and again.

original: Atha vā vinibbhujitvā vinibbhujitvāti paccekaṃ aṭṭhiādīnaṃ antarānusārinā ñāṇahatthena
analyzed: atha vā vinibbhujitvā vinibbhujitvā iti paccekam aṭṭhi ādīnam antara anusārinā ñāṇa hatthena
translated: Or alternatively, “having divided it up, having divided it up” means following along the interstices of the bones, etc., with a hand consisting of knowledge, one by one.

original: vinibbhogaṃ katvā. Etesūti sakalampi attano rūpakāyaṃ catudhā katvā vibhattesu yathāvuttesu
analyzed: vinibbhogam katvā etesu iti sakalam pi attanaḥ rūpa kāyam catudhā katvā vibhattesu yathā vuttesu
translated: Having divided it up. In these: in the four parts, bones, etc., which are the whole of his material body divided up into four sections as already described.

original: aṭṭhiādīsu catūsu koṭṭhāsesu. Purimanayenevāti “yo imasmiṃ kāye thaddhabhāvo vā”tiādinā
analyzed: aṭṭhi ādīsu catūsu koṭṭhāsesu purima nayena iva ati yaḥ imasmin kāye thaddha bhāvaḥ vāti ādinā
translated: In the way already stated: “Whatever in this body is stiff or rigid” , etc.🔽But what has to be said about the development of this meditation subject should be stated in the way already given in the Description of the Earth Kasiṇa .

original: pubbe vuttanayeneva. Yaṃ panettha vattabbaṃ bhāvanāvidhānaṃ, taṃ anantaranaye vuttākāreneva vattabbaṃ.🔽309. Vitthārato āgate pana “catudhātuvavatthāne”ti ānetvā yojanā. Evaṃ idāni vuccamānākārena
analyzed: pubbe vutta nayena iva yam pana ittha vattabbam bhāvanā vidhānam tam anantara naye vutta ākārena iva vattabbam  vitthārataḥ āgate pana catu dhātu vavatthānā iti ānetvā yojanā evam idāni vuccamāna ākārena
translated: But the method of development should be understood in the way now described, which is given in detail only in the Patisambhidā.

original: veditabbo bhāvanānayo. “Dvācattālīsāya ākārehi dhātuyo uggaṇhitvā”ti kasmā vuttaṃ,
analyzed: veditabbaḥ bhāvanā nayaḥ dvācattālīsāya ākārehi dhātuyaḥ uggaṇhitvā iti kasmā vuttam
translated: Why is it said that “having learnt the elements in forty-two aspects”?🔽Are not the elements in the first place thirty-two?

original: nanu ādito dvattiṃsākārā dhātuyo na hontīti? Vatthusīsena dhātūnaṃyeva uggahetabbattā
analyzed: nanu āditas dvattiṃsa ākārāḥ dhātuyaḥ na honti iti vatthu sīsena dhātūnam yeva uggahetabba ttā
translated: There is no fault here because the elements are to be learnt only in the way stated.

original: nāyaṃ doso. Vuttappakāreti “gocaragāmato nātidūranāccāsannatādīhi pañcahi aṅgehi
analyzed: na ayam dosaḥ vutta ppakāra iti gocara gāmataḥ na atidūra na acca āsanna tā ādīhi pañcahi aṅgehi
translated: In the way stated: in the way stated in the Description of the Earth Kasiṇa under the heading of the object, that is to say, “not too far from the village, not too near, and so on” ,

original: samannāgate”tiādinā vuttappakāre. Katasabbakiccenāti palibodhupacchedādikaṃ kataṃ
analyzed: samannāgata iti ādinā vutta ppakāre kata sabba kiccena ati pali bodha upaccheda ādikam katam
translated: “Endowed” with the kind described in the way beginning, “Endowed with virtue” .🔽One who has done all the duties : one who has done all the duties beginning with the severing of ties ;

original: sabbakiccaṃ etenāti katasabbakicco, tenassa sīlavisodhanādi pana kammaṭṭhānuggahaṇato
analyzed: sabba kiccam etena ati kata sabba kiccaḥ tenassa sīla visodhana ādi pana kammaṭṭhāna uggahaṇato
translated: he is called “one who has done all the duties” because he has done all the duties. But his taking up of the meditation subject consisting in purification of virtue, etc., is already accomplished,

original: pageva siddhaṃ hotīti dasseti. Sasambhārasaṅkhepatoti sambharīyanti etena buddhivohārāti
analyzed: pagā iva siddham hoti iti dasseti sa sambhāra saṅkhepato ti sambharīyanti etena buddhi vohārā ati
translated: as shown by the words “and so on,”🔽The meaning is that it is to be developed by way of the brief and the detailed in the case of one who has the equipment.

original: sambhāro, tannimittaṃ. Kiṃ panetaṃ? Pathavīādi. Kesādīsu hi vīsatiyā ākāresu “pathavī”ti🔽buddhivohārā pathavīnimittakā thaddhataṃ upādāya pavattanato. Tasmā tattha pathavīsambhāro🔽nāma savisesāya tassā atthitāya kesādayo saha sambhārehīti sasambhārā. Āpokoṭṭhāsādīsupi🔽eseva nayo. Sasambhārānaṃ saṅkhepo sasambhārasaṅkhepo, tato sasambhārasaṅkhepato
analyzed: sambhāraḥ tad nimittam kim pana itam pathavī ādi kesa ādīsu hi vīsatiyā ākāresu pathavī iti  buddhi vohārā pathavī nimittakā thaddhatam upādāya pavattanato tasmā tattha pathavīsambhāro  nāma sa visesāya tassā atthitāya kesa ādayo saha sambhārehi iti sa sambhārāḥ āpokoṭṭhāsa ādīsu pi  esa iva nayo sa sambhārānam saṅkhepo sa sambhāra saṅkhepo tatas sa sambhāra saṅkhepataḥ
translated: The equipment is what is called “the equipment” because of the occurrence of the idea and the expression “earth” in regard to the twenty aspects beginning with head hairs, etc.,

original: bhāvetabbanti yojanā. Saṅkhepato vīsatiyā, dvādasasu, catūsu, chasu ca koṭṭhāsesu
analyzed: bhāvetabbanti yojanā saṅkhepataḥ vīsatiyā dvādasasu catūsu chasu ca koṭṭhāsesu
translated: on account of the occurrence of the idea and the expression “earth” in the twenty aspects beginning with head hairs, etc., on account of the occurrence of the idea and the expression “earth” in regard to the twenty aspects beginning with head hairs, etc., on account of the occurrence of the idea and the expression “earth” in regard to the twenty aspects beginning with head hairs, etc., on account of the occurrence of the idea and the expression “earth” in regard to the twenty aspects beginning with head hairs, etc., on account of the occurrence of the idea and the expression “earth” in regard to the twenty aspects beginning with head hairs, etc., on account of the occurrence of the idea and the expression “earth” in regard to the twenty aspects beginning with head hairs, etc., on account of the occurrence of the idea and the expression “earth” in regard to the twenty aspects beginning with head hairs, etc., on account of the occurrence of the idea and the expression “earth” in regard to the twenty aspects beginning with head hairs, etc., on account of the occurrence of the idea and the expression “earth” in regard to the twenty aspects beginning with head hairs, etc., on account of the occurrence of the idea and the expression “earth” in regard to the twenty aspects beginning with head hairs, etc., on account of the occurrence of the idea and the expression “earth” in regard to the twenty aspects beginning with head hairs, etc., on account of the occurrence of the idea and the expression “earth” in regard to the twenty aspects beginning with head hairs, etc., on account of the occurrence of the idea and the expression “earth” in regard to the twenty aspects beginning with head hairs, etc., on

original: yathākkamaṃ pathavīādikā catasso dhātuyo pariggahetvā dhātuvavatthānaṃ sasambhārasaṅkhepato
analyzed: yathākkamam pathavī ādikā catasso dhātuyo pariggahetvā dhātu vavatthānam sa sambhāra saṅkhepato
translated: Having discerned the four elements, earth, etc., in due course, the defining of elements is in brief with its equipment.

original: bhāvanā. Tenāha “idha bhikkhu vīsatiyā koṭṭhāsesū”tiādi.
analyzed: bhāvanā tena āha idha bhikkhu vīsatiyā koṭṭhāsesu utiādi
translated: Hence he said: “Herein, bhikkhus, a bhikkhu” , and so on.

original: Sasambhāravibhattitoti sasambhārānaṃ kesādīnaṃ vibhāgato kesādike vīsati koṭṭhāse
analyzed: sa sambhāra vibhattitaḥ ti sa sambhārānam kesa ādīnam vibhāgataḥ kesa ādike vīsati koṭṭhāse
translated: By analysis of the equipment: by analysis of the equipment consisting of head hairs, etc., the twenty parts beginning with head hairs are discerned.🔽Having not taken them as a unity as before, they are defined as the earth element by analysis.

original: pubbe viya ekajjhaṃ aggahetvā vibhāgato pathavīdhātubhāvena vavatthāpanaṃ. Āpokoṭṭhāsādīsupi
analyzed: pubbe viya ekajjham aggahetvā vibhāgataḥ pathavī dhātu bhāvena vavatthāpanam āpokoṭṭhāsa ādīsu pi
translated: The same method applies in the case of the water part, etc.

original: eseva nayo. Salakkhaṇasaṅkhepatoti lakkhīyati etenāti lakkhaṇaṃ, dhammānaṃ sabhāvo,
analyzed: esa iva nayaḥ sa lakkhaṇa saṅkhepato ti lakkhīyati etena ati lakkhaṇam dhammānam sabhāvaḥ
translated: By brief indication of the characteristics: it is characterized thus, thus it is a characteristic ; the general nature of things is what is meant.

original: idha pana thaddhatādi. Tasmā thaddhalakkhaṇādivantatāya saha lakkhaṇehīti salakkhaṇā,
analyzed: idha pana thaddha ta ādi tasmā saha lakkhaṇehi iti sa lakkhaṇā
translated: Here, however, it is hardness, etc. Therefore, since it possesses the characteristics beginning with hardness, it is the characteristic ;

original: kesādayo dvācattālīsa ākārā. Tesaṃ saṅkhepato. Idaṃ vuttaṃ hoti – kesādike vīsati
analyzed: kesa ādayaḥ dvācattālīsa ākārā tesam saṅkhepato idam vuttam hoti kesa ādike vīsati
translated: the forty-two aspects beginning with head hairs are what is meant. By brief indication of them. This is what is meant: having taken the twenty parts beginning with head hairs as a unity,

original: koṭṭhāse ekajjhaṃ gahetvā tattha thaddhatādikaṃ catubbidhampi lakkhaṇaṃ vavatthapetvā
analyzed: koṭṭhāse ekajjham gahetvā tattha thaddhata ādikam catubbidham pi lakkhaṇam vavatthapetvā
translated: having defined the fourfold characteristic consisting of hardness, etc., there,

original: bhāvanā salakkhaṇasaṅkhepato bhāvanā. Esa nayo āpokoṭṭhāsādīsupi. Salakkhaṇavibhattitoti🔽thaddhalakkhaṇādinā salakkhaṇānaṃ kesādīnaṃ vibhāgato kesādīsu dvācattālīsāya ākāresu
analyzed: bhāvanā sa lakkhaṇa saṅkhepataḥ bhāvanā esa nayaḥ āpokoṭṭhāsa ādīsu pi sa lakkhaṇa vibhattito ti  thaddha lakkhaṇa ādinā sa lakkhaṇānam kesa ādīnam vibhāgataḥ kesa ādīsu dvācattālīsāya ākāresu
translated: The same method applies to the water element, etc., too.🔽As to the analysis of the characteristics:🔽as to the defining of the four characteristics of hardness, etc., each in its own place among the thirty-two aspects of head hairs, etc.,

original: paccekaṃ thaddhatādīnaṃ catunnaṃ catunnaṃ lakkhaṇānaṃ vavatthāpanavasena bhāvanā.
analyzed: paccekam thaddhata ādīnam catunnam catunnam lakkhaṇānam vavatthāpana vasena bhāvanā
translated: that is to say, as to the defining of the four characteristics of hardness, etc., each in its own place among the thirty-two aspects of head hairs, etc.,

original: Evaṃ catūhi ākārehi uddiṭṭhaṃ bhāvanānayaṃ niddisituṃ “kathaṃ sasambhārasaṅkhepato🔽bhāvetī”tiādi āraddhaṃ. Ettha ca yathā tikkhapañño puggalo tikkhatāya paropariyattasabbhāvato
analyzed: evam catūhi ākārehi uddiṭṭham bhāvanā nayam niddisitum katham sa sambhāra saṅkhepato  bhāva iti itiādi āraddham ettha ca yathā tikkha paññaḥ puggalo tikkhatāya
translated: The method of development stated in four ways is now demonstrated in order to show how it is developed in brief with its equipment,🔽and so on. Herein, a person of quick understanding is twofold as one whose faculties are keen and one whose faculties are sluggish.

original: tikkhindriyamudindriyatāvasena duvidhoti. Tattha tikkhindriyassa vasena saṅkhepato
analyzed: tikkha indriya mud indriya tā vasena duvidhaḥ ti tattha tikkha indriyassa vasena saṅkhepato
translated: The first method is stated for one whose faculties are keen, and the second for one whose faculties are sluggish.

original: paṭhamanayo vutto, mudindriyassa vasena dutiyo. Evaṃ nātitikkhapaññopi puggaloti.
analyzed: paṭhama nayaḥ vuttaḥ mud indriyassa vasena dutiyaḥ evam na ati tikkha paññaḥ api puggalaḥ ti
translated: A person of medium understanding is twofold as one who is not very quick and one who is not very slow.

original: Tattha yo visadindriyo puggalo, tassa vasena sasambhārasaṅkhepato, salakkhaṇasaṅkhepato
analyzed: tattha yaḥ visat indriyaḥ puggalo tassa vasena sa sambhāra saṅkhepataḥ sa lakkhaṇa saṅkhepataḥ
translated: Herein, the method stated in brief with its equipment is for one whose faculties are keen and who is not very quick,🔽and the method stated in brief without its equipment is for one whose faculties are keen and who is very quick.

original: ca bhāvanānayo niddiṭṭho. Yo pana nātivisadindriyo, tassa vasena sasambhāravibhattito,
analyzed: ca bhāvanā nayaḥ niddiṭṭho yaḥ pana na ati visat indriyo tassa vasena sa sambhāra vibhattito
translated: and the method of development has been indicated. But for one whose faculties are not very keen, it is analyzed according to requisites.

original: salakkhaṇavibhattito ca bhāvanānayo niddiṭṭhoti veditabbo. Tassa evaṃ vavatthāpayato🔽eva dhātuyo pākaṭā honti savisesaṃ dhātūnaṃ pariggahitattā. Bhāvanāvidhānaṃ panettha
analyzed: sa lakkhaṇa vibhattitaḥ ca bhāvanā nayaḥ niddiṭṭho ti veditabbaḥ tassa evam vavatthāpayato  eva dhātuyaḥ pākaṭāḥ honti sa visesam dhātūnam pariggahita ttā bhāvanā vidhānam pana ittha
translated: and the method of development has been indicated. But for one whose faculties are not very sharp, the method of development should be understood as indicated by the analysis of the constituents and by the analysis of the characteristics.🔽As he defines them in this way,

original: heṭṭhā vuttanayeneva veditabbaṃ.
analyzed: heṭṭhā vutta nayena iva veditabbam
translated: the elements become evident to him, since he has discerned the elements with their characteristics. But the method of development here should be understood as stated in the Paṭisambhidā in the way beginning, “When conviction has thus been brought to birth in him and brought to growth” .🔽“Whose”: he says this referring to the person whose faculties are not very sharp.

original: 310. Yassāti nātivisadindriyaṃ puggalaṃ sandhāya vadati. Evaṃ bhāvayatoti sasambhārasaṅkhepato🔽bhāventassa. Yena vidhinā uggahetvā kusalo hoti, so sattavidho vidhi “uggahakosalla”nti
analyzed: yassa iti na ati visat indriyam puggalam sandhāya vadati evam bhāvayatā iti sa sambhāra saṅkhepataḥ  bhāventassa yena vidhinā uggahetvā kusalaḥ hoti so sattavidhaḥ vidhi uggaha kosallanti
translated: “As he develops it in this way”: as he develops it in brief with the constituents.

original: vuccati, tannibbattaṃ vā ñāṇaṃ. Evaṃ manasikārakosallampi veditabbaṃ. Dvattiṃsākāreti
analyzed: vuccati tat nibbattam vā ñāṇam evam manasikāra kosallam pi veditabbam dvattiṃsa ākārā iti
translated: The method by which he becomes skilled in learning is called “skill in learning.” Or it is the knowledge produced by that method. Skill in giving attention should be understood in the same way.

original: dhātumanasikāravasena pariggahite kesādike dvattiṃsavidhe koṭṭhāse. “Dvattiṃsākāre”ti
analyzed: dhātu manasikāra vasena pariggahite kesa ādike dvattiṃsavidhe koṭṭhāse dvattiṃsa ākāra iti
translated: “Thirty-two aspects”: in the thirty-two parts of the head hairs, etc., discerned by means of the attention given to the elements.

original: ca idaṃ tejavāyukoṭṭhāsesu vaṇṇādivasena vavatthānassa abhāvato vuttaṃ. Sabbaṃ tattha
analyzed: ca idam teja vāyu koṭṭhāsesu vaṇṇa ādi vasena vavatthānassa abhāvataḥ vuttam sabbam tattha
translated: All the directions for development should be performed there:

original: vuttavidhānaṃ kātabbanti “vacasā manasā”tiādinā vuttauggahakosalluddesato paṭṭhāya
analyzed: vutta vidhānam kātabbanti vacasā manasā ati ādinā vutta oggaha kosalla uddesataḥ paṭṭhāya
translated: starting from the direction for skill in the preliminary work stated in the passage beginning, “With the words ‘In the beginning he develops the meditation subject by defining the four elements in himself’ …,”

original: yāva “anupubbamuñcanādivasenā”ti padaṃ, tāva āgataṃ sabbaṃ bhāvanāvidhānaṃ kātabbaṃ🔽sampādetabbaṃ. Vaṇṇādivasenāti vaṇṇasaṇṭhānadisokāsaparicchedavasena. Ayañca vaṇṇādivasena
analyzed: yāva anupubba muñcana ādi vasena ati padam tāva āgatam sabbam bhāvanā vidhānam kātabbam  sampādetabbam vaṇṇa ādi vasena ati vaṇṇa saṇṭhāna disā ukāsa pariccheda vasena ayam ca vaṇṇa ādi vasena
translated: and ending with the passage, “He should end by defining them by colour, shape, direction, location, and delimitation,” all the directions for development should be performed, should be accomplished.🔽By colour, shape, direction, location, and delimitation: by colour, shape, etc., of the space-entity element.

original: manasikāro dhātupaṭikkūlavaṇṇamanasikārānaṃ sādhāraṇo pubbabhāgoti nibbattitadhātumanasikārameva
analyzed: manasikāraḥ dhātu paṭikkūla vaṇṇa manasikārānam sādhāraṇaḥ pubbabhāgaḥ ti nibbattita dhātu manasikāram eva
translated: And this attention given by way of colour, etc., is common to the attention given to the repulsiveness of elements and to the preliminary work.

original: dassetuṃ “avasāne evaṃ manasikāro pavattetabbo”ti vuttaṃ.🔽311. Aññamaññaṃ ābhogapaccavekkhaṇarahitā ete dhammāti ete “sīsakaṭāhapaliveṭhanacammaṃ
