analyzed: dassetum avasāne evam manasikāraḥ pavattetabbaḥ iti vuttam  aññam aññam ābhoga paccavekkhaṇa rahitāḥ ete dhammā ti ete sīsa kaṭāha paliveṭhana cammaṃ
translated: In order to show that it is only the attention given to the origin of the elements that is the generation of the jhāna, it is said, “At the end, attention should be given in this way.”

original: kesā”ti evaṃ vohariyamānā bhūtupādāyadhammā “mayi kesā jātā, mayamettha jātā”ti evaṃ
analyzed: kesā iti evam vohariyamānāḥ bhūta upādāya dhammāḥ mayi kesāḥ jātāḥ mayam ettha jātā ati evam
translated: These states have no mutual concern or reviewing: these states consisting of primary and derived matter called “head hairs,” “body hairs,” etc., have no mutual concern or reviewing in the way stated in the description of the earth kasiṇa, “Here ends head hairs and here begin body hairs,” etc.

original: aññamaññaṃ ābhogapaccavekkhaṇasuññā. Iminā kāraṇassa ca phalassa ca abyāpāratāya
analyzed: aññamaññam ābhoga paccavekkhaṇa suññā iminā kāraṇassa ca phalassa ca a byāpāra tāya
translated: and they are void of the mutual contact and reviewing.

original: dhātumattataṃ sandasseti, tena ca ābhogapaccavekkhaṇānampi evameva abyāpāratā dīpitāti
analyzed: dhātumat tatam sandasseti tena ca ābhoga paccavekkhaṇānam pi evam eva abyāpāra tā dīpitā ati
translated: By this he shows the mere element nature of the two, since the cause and the fruit are not-conjoined. And by that he shows that the contact and the reviewing are not-conjoined in the same way.

original: daṭṭhabbaṃ. Na hi tāni, tesaṃ kāraṇāni ca tathā tathā ābhujitvā, paccavekkhitvā ca
analyzed: daṭṭhabbam na hi tāni tesam kāraṇāni ca tathā tathā ābhujitvā paccavekkhitvā ca
translated: For they do not arise or become conditions by being conjoined and reviewed in such and such a way.

original: uppajjanti, paccayabhāvaṃ vā gacchantīti. Itīti vuttappakāraparāmasanaṃ. Acetanoti
analyzed: uppajjanti paccaya bhāvam vā gacchanti iti iti iti vutta ppakāra parāmasanam acetanoti
translated: “Thus”: he refers to the kind of reviewing already mentioned. “Insentient”:

original: na cetano, cetanārahito vā. Abyākatoti abyākatarāsipariyāpanno. Suññoti attasuñño.
analyzed: na cetano cetanā rahitaḥ vā abyākatoti abyākata rāsi pariyāpanno suñño ti atta suñño
translated: not sentient, or devoid of consciousness. “Indeterminate”: included in the indeterminate class. “Void”: void of self.

original: Tato eva nissatto. Thaddhalakkhaṇādhikatāya thaddho. Tato eva pathavīdhātūti evaṃ
analyzed: tatas eva nissatto thaddha lakkhaṇa adhikatāya thaddho tatas eva pathavī dhātu uti evam
translated: “Lifeless”: because of that. “Rigid”: because of the predominance of the characteristic of rigidity. “Earth element”:

original: manasikāro pavattetabboti sambandho. Evaṃ sabbattha.
analyzed: manasikāraḥ pavattetabbaḥ iti sambandhaḥ evam sabbattha
translated: the application of this term should be understood thus.🔽The same method applies in the case of the other three great primaries.

original: 312. Suññagāmaṭṭhāneti ettha suññagāmaggahaṇaṃ paramatthato vedakavirahadassanatthaṃ kāyassa.
analyzed: suñña gāma ṭṭhāne ti ettha suñña gāma gahaṇam paramatthataḥ vedaka viraha dassana ttham kāyassa
translated: “Like a deserted village”: the mention of a deserted village is for the purpose of showing the absence of a real experiencer in the case of the body.

original: 313. Madhukaṭṭhiketi madhukabījāni.
analyzed: madhukaṭṭhikā iti madhuka bījāni
translated: “Like a sugar-cane stalk”: sugar-cane seeds.

original: 314. Gehathambhānaṃ ādhārabhāvena ṭhapitasilāyo pāsāṇaudukkhalakānīti adhippetāni.
analyzed: geha thambhānam ādhāra bhāvena ṭhapita silāyaḥ pāsāṇa audukkhalakāni iti adhippetāni
translated: The stones that are placed as the foundation of the house-site are what are intended by the words “the stone mortar.”

original: 315. Duggandhādibhāve cassa sadisabhāvadassanatthaṃ allagocammaggahaṇaṃ.
analyzed: duggandha ādi bhāve ca ssa sadisa bhāva dassana attham alla go camma ggahaṇam
translated: The “fresh cow-dung” is mentioned in order to show that it is similar to the “foul-smelling” and so on.

original: 316. Yebhuyyena maṃsapesīnaṃ bahalatāya mahāmattikaggahaṇaṃ.
analyzed: yebhuyyena maṃsa pesīnam bahala tāya mahā mattika ggahaṇam
translated: The “great clay” is mentioned because of the thickness of the lumps of flesh for the most part.

original: 317. Kuṭṭadārūsūti dārukuṭṭikāya kuṭiyā bhittipādabhūtesu kaṭṭhesu.
analyzed: kuṭṭa dārūsu iti dāru kuṭṭikāya kuṭiyāḥ bhitti pāda bhūtesu kaṭṭhesu
translated: The “wood and wattle” is the timber that serves as the foundation for the walls of a wattle-and-daub house.

original: 318. Paṇhikaṭṭhiādīnaṃ ādhārabhāvo viya gopphakaṭṭhiādīnaṃ ādheyyabhāvopi asamannāhārasiddhoti🔽dassanatthaṃ “paṇhikaṭṭhigopphakaṭṭhiṃ ukkhipitvā ṭhita”ntiādiṃ vatvā puna “sīsaṭṭhigīvaṭṭhike
analyzed: ādhāra bhāvaḥ viya gopphaka ṭṭhi ādīnam ādheyya bhāvaḥ api  dassana attham paṇhika ṭṭhi gopphaka ṭṭhim ukkhipitvā ṭhita nti ādim vatvā puna sīsa ṭṭhi gīvaṭṭhike
translated: Just as the thigh-bone, etc., have the function of supporting the hip-bone, etc., so too the hip-bone, etc., have the function of being supported by the thigh-bone, etc.

original: patiṭṭhita”ntiādi vuttaṃ.
analyzed: patiṭṭhita ntiādi vuttam
translated: In order to show this, after saying “the hip-bone and thigh-bone stand supporting the knee-bone,” it is said again: “the head-bone and neck-bone stand supporting the shoulder-bone.”

original: 319. Sinnavettaggādīsūti seditavettakaḷīrādīsu.
analyzed: sinna vetta gga ādīsu iti sedita vetta kaḷīra ādīsu
translated: The “dried-up hide, etc.,” are the dried-up skin, sinews, etc.

original: 321. Uraṭṭhisaṅghāṭo pañjarasadisatāya “uraṭṭhipañjara”nti vutto. Tassa athirabhāvadassanatthaṃ jiṇṇasandamānikapañjaraṃ nidassanabhāvena gahitaṃ.
analyzed: uraṭṭhi saṅghāṭaḥ pañjara sadisa tāya uraṭṭhi pañjaram ti vutto tassa athira bhāva dassana attham jiṇṇa sandamānika pañjaram nidassana bhāvena gahitam
translated: The “chest-bone cage” is called “chest-bone cage” because it is like a cage. In order to show that it is not solid, a dilapidated wire cage is taken as an illustration.

original: 322. Yamakamaṃsapiṇḍeti maṃsapiṇḍayugaḷe.
analyzed: yamaka maṃsa piṇḍa iti maṃsa piṇḍa yugaḷe
translated: The pair of flesh-lumps is the pair of buttocks.

original: 323. Kilomakassa setavaṇṇatāya “pilotikapaliveṭhite”ti pilotikaṃ nidassanabhāvena🔽vuttaṃ. Evameva na vakkahadayāni sakalasarīre ca maṃsaṃ jānātīti ettha na vakkahadayāni🔽jānanti “mayaṃ paṭicchannakilomakena paṭicchannānī”ti, na sakalasarīre ca maṃsaṃ
analyzed: kilomakassa seta vaṇṇa tāya pilotika paliveṭhitā iti pilotikam nidassana bhāvena  vuttam evam eva na vakka hadayāni sakala sarīre ca maṃsam jānāti iti ettha na vakka hadayāni  jānanti mayam paṭicchanna kilomakena paṭicchannāni iti na sakala sarīre ca maṃsam
translated: Because the white colour of the rice is like the colour of the skin, the skin is said to be “covered with a skin of silk” by way of illustration.🔽So too, the kidneys and heart do not know, “We are covered by the skin that covers the down,” nor does the flesh in the whole body know, “I am covered by the skin that covers the down.”

original: jānāti “ahaṃ paṭicchannakilomakena paṭicchanna”nti yojetabbaṃ.
analyzed: jānāti aham paṭicchanna kilomakena paṭicchanna nti yojetabbam
translated: This is how it should be construed.

original: 324. Koṭṭhamatthakapassanti kusūlassa abbhantare matthakapassaṃ.
analyzed: koṭṭha matthaka passanti kusūlassa abbhantare matthaka passam
translated: The corner of the mouth is the corner of the mouth inside the lips.

original: 325. Dvinnaṃ thanānamantareti dvinnaṃ thanappadesānaṃ vemajjhe, thanappadeso ca abbhantaravasena veditabbo.
analyzed: dvinnam thanānam antareti dvinnam thana ppadesānam vemajjhe thana ppadeso ca abbhantara vasena veditabbo
translated: Between the two jaws: between the two jawbones.

original: 327. Ekavīsatiantabhogeti ekavīsatiyā ṭhānesu obhaggobhagge antamaṇḍale.
analyzed: ekavīsati anta bhoga iti ekavīsatiyāḥ ṭhānesu obhagga ubhagge anta maṇḍale
translated: In twenty-one places: in each of the twenty-one sections of the inner circle.

original: 328. Āmāsaye ṭhito paribhuttāhāro udariyanti adhippetanti āha “udariyaṃ udare ṭhitaṃ asitapītakhāyitasāyita”nti.
analyzed: āma āsaye ṭhitaḥ paribhutta āhāraḥ udariyanti adhippetanti āha udariyam udare ṭhitam asita pīta khāyita sāyitanti
translated: The meaning intended by “in the belly” is “in the stomach” , since it is there that what is eaten, drunk, etc., is stored up.

original: 331. Abaddhapittaṃ saṃsaraṇalohitaṃ viya, kāyusmā viya ca kammajarūpapaṭibaddhavuttikanti
analyzed: abaddha pittam saṃsaraṇa lohitam viya viya ca kamma ja rūpa paṭibaddha vuttikam
translated: The free bile is like the circulating blood and like the bodily heat, since it has a mode of occurrence dependent on the kamma-born materiality.

original: āha “ābaddhapittaṃ jīvitindriyapaṭibaddhaṃ sakalasarīraṃ byāpetvā ṭhita”nti. Paṭibaddhatāvacanena
analyzed: āha ābaddha pittam jīvitindriya paṭibaddham sakala sarīram byāpetvā paṭibaddha tā vacanena
translated: That is why he said: “The free bile is dependent on the life faculty and is distributed throughout the whole body” .

original: cassa jīvitindriye sati sabbhāvameva dīpeti, na jīvitindriyassa viya ekantakammajatanti🔽daṭṭhabbaṃ. Pittakosaketi mahākosāṭakīkosasadise pittādhāre. Yūsabhūtoti rasabhūto.
analyzed: ca ssa jīvita indriye sati sabbhāvam eva dīpeti na jīvita indriyassa viya ekanta kamma jatanti  daṭṭhabbam pitta kosake iti mahā kosāṭakī kosa sadise pitta ādhāre yūsa bhūtaḥ ti rasa bhūtaḥ
translated: By the words “dependent on” he shows that it exists only as long as the life faculty exists, and that it is not exclusively kamma-born like the life faculty.🔽The bile receptacle is the bile’s location, which is like a large bag.🔽The “swamp” is the place where urine, excrement, spittle, mucus, etc., are collected.

original: 332. Ucchiṭṭhodakagabbhamalādīnaṃ chaḍḍanaṭṭhānaṃ candanikā, tassaṃ candanikāyaṃ.
analyzed: ucchiṭṭha udaka gabbha mala ādīnam chaḍḍana ṭhānam candanikā tassam candanikāyam
translated: The “swamp-place” is the place where the urine, excrement, etc., are discharged.

original: 333. Pubbāsayo mandapaññānaṃ kesañcideva hotīti katvā asabbasādhāraṇanti adhippāyenāha “pubbo anibaddhokāso”ti.
analyzed: pubba āsayaḥ manda paññānam kesañcid eva hoti iti katvā asabba sādhāraṇam ti adhippāyena āha pubbaḥ anibaddha ukāsaḥ ti
translated: The “putrescence” is not common to all, since it occurs only in some slow-witted people. That is why he said: “The putrescence is not confined to any particular place” .

original: 334. Pittaṃ viyāti abaddhapittaṃ viya. Sakalasarīranti jīvitindriyapaṭibaddhaṃ sabbaṃ
analyzed: pittam viyāti abaddha pittam viya sakala sarīram jīvitindriya paṭibaddham sabbam
translated: Like bile that is not bound up: like bile that is not bound up with the flesh. In the whole body: in the whole body that is bound up with the life faculty.

original: sarīrappadesaṃ. Vakkahadayayakanapapphāsāni tementanti ettha yakanaṃ heṭṭhābhāgapūraṇena,
analyzed: sarīra ppadesam vakka hadaya yakana papphāsāni ettha yakanam heṭṭhā bhāga pūraṇena
translated: Like the bile that is not bound to a location: like the bile that is not bound to a location in the body. In the whole body: in the whole physical frame bound up with the life faculty.🔽The liver, heart, spleen, and lungs are soaked: here the liver is soaked by being filled up below,

original: itarāni tesaṃ upari thokaṃ thokaṃ paggharaṇena ca temetīti daṭṭhabbaṃ. Heṭṭhā leḍḍukhaṇḍādīni
analyzed: itarāni tesam upari thokam thokam paggharaṇena ca daṭṭhabbam heṭṭhā leḍḍu khaṇḍa ādīni
translated: and the others are soaked by the bile trickling down a little on to them. The pieces of stone, etc.,

original: temayamāneti temakatemitabbānaṃ abyāpāratāsāmaññanidassanatthaṃ eva upamā daṭṭhabbā,
analyzed: temayamānā iti temaka temitabbānam a byāpāra tā sāmañña nidassana attham eva upamā daṭṭhabbā
translated: are soaked below: the simile should be understood as given only in order to show the similarity of the state of being soaked and the state of being that which is soaked,

original: na ṭhānasāmaññanidassanatthaṃ. Sannicitalohitena hi temetabbānaṃ kesañci heṭṭhā,
analyzed: na ṭhāna sāmañña nidassana attham sannicita lohitena hi temetabbānam kesañci heṭṭhā
translated: not in order to show similarity of location. For some of the things that are soaked are below the bile,🔽and some are above it, as was shown in the description of mindfulness of the body .

original: kassaci upari ṭhitatā kāyagatāsatiniddese dassitāti. Yakanassa heṭṭhābhāgaṭṭhānaṃ
analyzed: kassaci upari ṭhita tā kāya gata asati niddese dassitā ati yakanassa heṭṭhā bhāga ṭṭhānam
translated: The place below the liver

original: “mayi lohitaṃ ṭhita”nti na jānāti, vakkādīni “amhe temayamānaṃ lohitaṃ ṭhita”nti
analyzed: mayi lohitam na jānāti vakka ādīni amhe temayamānam lohitam ṭhitanti
translated: does not know, “Bile is situated in me,” nor do the spleen, etc., know, “Bile situated in us is soaking us.”

original: na jānantīti evaṃ yojanā veditabbā.
analyzed: na jānanti iti evam yojanā veditabbā
translated: This is how the construction should be understood.

original: 336. Patthinnasinehoti thinabhāvaṃ ghanabhāvaṃ gatasineho. Sakalasarīre maṃsanti🔽yojanā, tañca thūlasarīraṃ sandhāya vuttaṃ. Medassa satipi patthinnatāya ghanabhāve
analyzed: patthinna sineho ti thina bhāvam ghana bhāvam gata sineho sakala sarīre maṃsanti  yojanā tat ca thūla sarīram sandhāya vuttam medassa sati pi patthinna tāya ghana bhāve
translated: The expression “with its moisture solidified” means that the moisture has become compact. The meaning is that the flesh is in the whole body.🔽But this is said with reference to a stout person. Even though there is fat, it is not bound up like the flesh because of its compactness.

original: maṃsassa viya na baddhatāti vuttaṃ “patthinnayūso”ti. Tenevassa āpokoṭṭhāsatā.🔽337. Udakapuṇṇesu taruṇatālaṭṭhikūpakesūti nātipariṇatānaṃ sajalakānaṃ aggato chinnānaṃ tālasalāṭukānaṃ vivarāni sandhāya vuttaṃ.
analyzed: maṃsassa viya na baddha tā ti vuttam patthinna yūso ti tena iva assa āpokoṭṭhāsa tā  udaka puṇṇesu taruṇa tāla ṭṭhi kūpakesu iti na ati pariṇatānam sa jalakānam aggataḥ chinnānam tāla sa lāṭukānam vivarāni sandhāya vuttam
translated: That is why it is said, “The solidified essence.” That is why it has a hundred and one water-bellies.🔽In the young palm sprouts filled with water: this is said with reference to the openings of young palm sprouts that have not fully developed and have been cut off at the top and are full of water.🔽The oil in the channels should be regarded as shown by the oil in a palm leaf.

original: 338. Vasāya attano ādhāre abhibyāpanamukhena abyāpāratāsāmaññaṃ vibhāvetabbanti ācāmagatatelaṃ nidassitanti daṭṭhabbaṃ.🔽339. Kheḷuppattipaccaye ambilaggamadhuraggādike.
analyzed: vasāya attanaḥ ādhāre abhibyāpana mukhena abyāpāra tā sāmaññam vibhāvetabbanti ācāma gata telam nidassitanti daṭṭhabbaṃ  kheḷuppatti paccaye ambi lagga madhu ragga ādike
translated: The expression “in the condition of the arising of spittle” refers to the sour, sweet, etc., tastes.

original: 343. Kesādīsu manasikāraṃ pavattetvā tejokoṭṭhāsesu pavattetabbo manasikāroti vibhattiṃ
analyzed: kesa ādīsu manasikāram pavattetvā tejaḥ koṭṭhāsesu pavattetabbaḥ manasikāraḥ iti vibhattim
translated: The attention that should be given to the head hairs, etc., and to the fire element in the water-bellies, etc., is shown by the analysis.

original: pariṇāmetvā yojetabbaṃ. Yena santappatīti yena kāyo santappati, ayaṃ santappanakicco.
analyzed: pariṇāmetvā yojetabbam yena santappati iti yena kāyaḥ santappati ayam santappana kicco
translated: and then it should be combined with the other elements. “By which one is warmed”: by which the body is warmed. This is the function of warming.

original: Tejoti tassa pariggaṇhanākāro eva paccāmaṭṭho. Yena jīrīyatītiādīsupi eseva nayo.🔽344. Assāsapassāsavasenāti antopavisanabahinikkhamananāsikāvātabhāvena. “Evaṃ pavattamanasikārassā”ti
analyzed: tejaḥ ti tassa pariggaṇhana ākāraḥ eva paccāmaṭṭhaḥ yena jīrīyati iti ādīsu pi esa iva nayo  assāsa passāsa vasena ati anta upavisana bahinikkhamana nāsikā vāta bhāvena evam pavatta manasikārassa ati
translated: “Fire” is the name for the characteristic of that element. “By which one is cooked”: the method of discerning this is the same as that for the above.🔽“By means of in-breaths and out-breaths”: by means of the air in the nostrils that goes in and out. “When he gives his attention”

original: iminā vuttākārena sasambhāravibhattito pavattakammaṭṭhānamanasikārassa. Dhātuyo pākaṭā🔽hontīti vitthārato pariggahitattā dhātuyo vibhūtā honti. Idhāpi bhāvanāvidhānaṃ heṭṭhā
analyzed: iminā vutta ākārena sa sambhāra vibhattitaḥ pavatta kammaṭṭhāna manasikārassa dhātuyaḥ pākaṭā  honti iti vitthārato dhātuyaḥ vibhūtāḥ honti idha api bhāvanā vidhānam heṭṭhā
translated: means when he gives attention to the meditation subject consisting of the elements with its full complement of characteristics, etc., in the way described.

original: vuttanayeneva veditabbaṃ.
analyzed: vutta nayena iva veditabbam
translated: The elements become evident to him: the elements become evident by being discerned in detail. Here too the method of development should be understood in the way already described.

original: 345. Tatthevāti tesuyeva vīsatiyā koṭṭhāsesu. Paripācanalakkhaṇaṃ vitthambhanalakkhaṇanti etthāpi “tatthevā”ti ānetvā sambandhitabbaṃ.
analyzed: tattha iva ati tesu yeva vīsatiyā koṭṭhāsesu paripācana lakkhaṇam vitthambhana lakkhaṇam ti ettha api tattha eva ati ānetvā sambandhitabbam
translated: In those same places: in those same twenty parts. The characteristic of maturing, the characteristic of distending: here too the words “in those same places” should be brought in and construed.

original: Puna tatthevāti tesuyeva dvādasasu koṭṭhāsesūti attho. Ettha ca kesādikoṭṭhāsānaṃ
analyzed: puna tattha iva ati tesu yeva dvādasasu koṭṭhāsesu iti attho ettha ca kesa ādi koṭṭhāsānam
translated: Again, “in those same places” means in those same twelve parts. And here the parts beginning with the head-hairs

original: saṃviggahatāya tattha vijjamānā āpodhātuādayo nhāniyacuṇṇādīsu udakādayo viya suviññeyyāti
analyzed: saṃvigga hatāya tattha vijjamānāḥ āpodhātu ādayaḥ nhāniya cuṇṇa ādīsu udaka ādayaḥ viya su viññeyyā ati
translated: The water element, etc., which are present there are easy to recognize, like the water, etc., in bath powder, etc.

original: “tattheva ābandhanalakkhaṇa”ntiādi vuttaṃ.
analyzed: tattha iva ābandhana lakkhaṇa ntiādi vuttam
translated: So it is said that they have the characteristic of “binding there.”

original: Santappanāditejokoṭṭhāsesu pana vāyodhātuādayo na tathā suviññeyyāti katvā “tena
analyzed: santappana ādi tejaḥ koṭṭhāsesu pana vāyo dhātu ādayaḥ na tathā su viññeyyā ati katvā tena
translated: But the air element, etc., in the sections of heat that cause distension, etc., are not so easy to recognize, so it is said that they are “not discerned there.”

original: avinibhutta”nti vuttaṃ, na tatthevāti. Yadi evaṃ, vāyukoṭṭhāsesu kathaṃ tatthevāti?
analyzed: a vinibhuttam ti vuttam na tattha eva ati yadi evam vāyu koṭṭhāsesu katham tattha eva ati
translated: But if that is so, how is it said that they are “there” in the sections of air?

original: Vāyukoṭṭhāsāpi hi uddhaṅgamavātādayo piṇḍākāreneva pariggahetabbataṃ upagacchanti,
analyzed: vāyu koṭṭhāsāḥ api hi uddhaṅgama vāta ādayaḥ piṇḍa ākārena iva pariggahetabbatam upagacchanti
translated: For the sections of air, too, such as the upward moving air, etc., come to be apprehended as a mass.

original: na pana santappanāditejokoṭṭhāsāti nāyaṃ doso. Tattha tenāti tena tejena. Avinibhuttanti🔽avinābhūtaṃ, taṃtaṃkalāpagatavasena vā evaṃ vuttaṃ. Evaṃ vavatthāpayatoti vuttākārena
analyzed: na pana santappana ādi tejaḥ koṭṭhāsā ti na ayam doso tattha tena ati tena tejena a vinibhuttam ti  avinābhūtam taṃ taṃ kalāpa gata vasena vā evam vuttam evam vavatthāpayataḥ iti vutta ākārena
translated: But the sections of heat that cause distension, etc., do not. So there is no fault in this.🔽Herein, “by that”: by that heat. “Not discerned”: not undiscerned, or this is said according to the meaning of “not separated.”🔽“When he defines them in this way”: when he defines the elements by way of the characteristic in brief as stated.

original: salakkhaṇasaṅkhepato dhātuyo vavatthāpentassa. Vuttanayenāti “tassevaṃ vāyamamānassā”tiādinā heṭṭhā vuttanayena.
analyzed: sa lakkhaṇa saṅkhepataḥ dhātuyaḥ vavatthāpentassa vutta nayena ati tassa ivam vāyamamānassa atiādinā heṭṭhā vutta nayena
translated: “In the way aforesaid”: in the way stated below in the passage beginning, “When he has thus exerted himself” .

original: 346. Evampi bhāvayatoti salakkhaṇasaṅkhepato dhātuyo pariggahetvā bhāventassāpi.
analyzed: evam pi bhāvayato ti sa lakkhaṇa saṅkhepataḥ dhātuyaḥ pariggahetvā bhāventassa api
translated: And also when he develops it in this way: also when he does so by discerning the elements in brief according to their characteristics.

original: Pubbe vuttanayenāti sasambhāravibhattito bhāvanāyaṃ vuttena nayena. Evanti yathā🔽kese, evaṃ. Sabbakoṭṭhāsesūti ekacattālīsabhedesu sesasabbakoṭṭhāsesu evamettha aṭṭhasaṭṭhidhātusatassa
analyzed: pubbe vutta nayena āti sa sambhāra vibhattitaḥ bhāvanā ayam vuttena nayena evam ti yathā  kese evam sabba koṭṭhāsesu iti ekacattālīsa bhedesu sesa sabba koṭṭhāsesu evam ettha aṭṭha saṭṭhi dhātu satassa
translated: In the way already stated: in the way already stated under development by analysis. In this way: as in the case of head hairs.

original: pariggaho vutto hoti. Bhāvanāvidhānaṃ panettha heṭṭhā vuttanayameva.
analyzed: pariggahaḥ vuttaḥ hoti bhāvanā vidhānam pana ittha heṭṭhā vutta nayam eva
translated: In all the remaining parts: in the remaining parts of the whole physical frame, which are of forty-one kinds. In this way the discerning of the hundred and fifty-six elements is stated here. But the method of development is as already stated.

original: Idāni vacanatthādimukhenapi dhātūsu manasikāravidhānaṃ dassetuṃ “vacanatthato”tiādi🔽vuttaṃ. Tattha vacanatthatoti yasmā sabbapaṭhamaṃ kammaṭṭhānassa uggahaṇaṃ vacanavasena
analyzed: idāni vacana attha ādi mukhena api dhātūsu manasikāra vidhānam dassetum vacana atthataḥ tiādi  vuttam tattha vacana atthato ti yasmā sabba paṭhamam kammaṭṭhānassa uggahaṇam vacana vasena
translated: Now, in order to point out the method of giving attention to the elements by way of the meaning of the word, etc., it is said: “As to the meaning of the word,” and so on.

original: hoti vacanadvārena tadatthassa ādito gahetabbato, tasmā vacanatthatopi dhātūnaṃ manasikātabbatā
analyzed: hoti vacana dvārena tad atthassa āditaḥ tasmā vacana tthataḥ pi dhātūnam manasikātabba tā
translated: Herein, as to the meaning of the word: because the learning sign of the meditation subject is apprehended by word first, by the word door, since it must be apprehended at the beginning by means of the meaning of the word, therefore the giving attention to the elements as to the meaning of the word is stated.🔽As to order:

original: vuttā. Kalāpatoti vacanatthavasena visesato, sāmaññato ca dhātuyo pariggahetvā ṭhitassa
analyzed: vuttā kalāpataḥ ti vacana attha vasena visesato sāmaññato ca dhātuyo pariggahetvā ṭhitassa
translated: after discerning the elements by the meaning of the word, by the specific characteristic and the general characteristic, and after discerning them by order,

original: yasmā tā piṇḍaso pavattanti, na paccekaṃ, tasmā kalāpatopi manasikātabbatā vuttā.🔽Te pana kalāpā paramāṇuparimāṇā hontīti tappariyāpannānaṃ pathavīdhātuādīnaṃ ekasmiṃ🔽sarīre parimeyyaparicchedaṃ dassetuṃ cuṇṇato manasikātabbatā vuttā. So panāyaṃ tāsaṃ
analyzed: yasmā tā piṇḍaso pavattanti na paccekam tasmā kalāpataḥ api manasikātabba tā vuttā  te pana kalāpā paramāṇu parimāṇāḥ honti iti tad pariyāpannānam pathavī dhātu ādīnam ekasmin  sarīre parimeyya paricchedam dassetum cuṇṇataḥ manasikātabba tā vuttā saḥ pana ayam tāsam
translated: Since they occur in combination, not separately, it is said that they should be given attention as a collection.🔽But these collections are the size of atoms. So in order to show the measure and delimitation of the earth element, etc., included in them, it is said that they should be given attention as powder.

original: cuṇṇato manasikāro saṅghāṭavasena hotīti nibbaṭṭitasarūpameva pariggahetabbaṃ dassetuṃ
analyzed: cuṇṇataḥ manasikāraḥ saṅghāṭa vasena hoti iti nibbaṭṭita sarūpam eva pariggahetabbam dassetuṃ
translated: But this attention to them as powder is by way of the groups of matter. So in order to show that only the matter that has been defined should be discerned,

original: lakkhaṇādito manasikāro vutto. Lakkhaṇādito dhātuyo pariggaṇhantena salakkhaṇavibhattito
analyzed: lakkhaṇa āditaḥ manasikāraḥ vuttaḥ lakkhaṇa āditaḥ dhātuyaḥ pariggaṇhantena sa lakkhaṇa vibhattitaḥ
translated: attention is said to be given to them by characteristics, etc. When one is discerning elements by characteristics, etc.,

original: kammaṭṭhānābhinivese yasmā dvācattālīsāya koṭṭhāsānaṃ vasena dhātūsu pariggayhamānāsu
analyzed: kammaṭṭhāna abhinivese yasmai dvācattālīsāya koṭṭhāsānam vasena dhātūsu pariggayhamānāsu
translated: in order to make sure of the meditation subject, the elements should be discerned in the forty-two aspects,

original: “ettakā utusamuṭṭhānā, ettakā cittādisamuṭṭhānā”ti ayaṃ vibhāgo ñātabbo hoti, tasmā
analyzed: ettakā utu samuṭṭhānā ettakā citta ādi samuṭṭhānā ti ayam vibhāgaḥ ñātabbaḥ hoti tasmā
translated: namely, as “This much is originated by temperature,” “This much is originated by kamma,” and so on. So

original: samuṭṭhānato manasikāro vutto.
analyzed: samuṭṭhānataḥ manasikāraḥ vutto
translated: attention is said to be given to them by their origination.

original: Evaṃ pariññātasamuṭṭhānānampi tāsaṃ saddānusārena vinā visesasāmaññapariggaho kātabboti
analyzed: evam pariññāta samuṭṭhānānam pi tāsam sadda anusārena vinā visesa sāmañña pariggaho kātabbaḥ ti
translated: So the attention given to the various kinds of derived materiality should be undertaken by discerning their individual essences and general characteristics without relying on mere verbal description, even though their origins have been fully discerned.

original: dassetuṃ nānattekattato manasikāro vutto. Lakkhaṇavisesato vinibhuttarūpāpi etā aniddisitabbaṭṭhānatāya🔽padesena avinibhuttāti ayaṃ viseso pariggahetabboti dassetuṃ vinibbhogāvinibbhogato
analyzed: dassetum nānatta ekattataḥ manasikāraḥ vuttaḥ lakkhaṇa visesataḥ vinibhutta rūpā api etāḥ a niddisitabba ṭṭhāna tāya  padesena a vinibhuttā ti ayam viseso pariggahetabbo ti dassetum vinibbhoga a vinibbhogato
translated: Attention is given to them as to whether they are classed as different or as the same in order to show that although they are classed as different in the ultimate sense, they are classed as the same in the conventional sense.

original: manasikāro vutto. Satipi avinibbhogavuttiyaṃ kācideva kāsañci sabhāgā, kāci visabhāgāti
analyzed: manasikāro vutto sati pi avinibbhoga vuttiyam kācid eva sabhāgā kāci visabhāgā ti
translated: Attention is given to them as to whether they are classed as discrete or not discrete in order to show that although they are classed as discrete in the ultimate sense, they are classed as not discrete in the conventional sense.

original: ayampi viseso pariggahetabboti dassetuṃ sabhāgavisabhāgato manasikāro vutto. Sabhāgavisabhāgāpi🔽dhātuyo ajjhattikā īdisakiccavisesayuttā, bāhirā tabbiparītāti ayaṃ viseso pariggahetabboti
analyzed: ayam pi visesaḥ pariggahetabbaḥ ti dassetum sabhāga visabhāgataḥ manasikāraḥ vuttaḥ sabhāga visabhāgā api  dhātuyaḥ ajjhattikāḥ īdisa kicca visesa yuttāḥ bāhirā tad biparītā ati ayam visesaḥ pariggahetabbaḥ ti
translated: Attention is given to them as to whether they are classed as similar or dissimilar in order to show that although they are classed as similar in the conventional sense, they are classed as dissimilar in the ultimate sense.🔽Attention is given to them as to whether they are classed as internal or external in order to show that although they are classed as similar in the conventional sense, they are classed as dissimilar in the ultimate sense.

original: dassetuṃ ajjhattikabāhiravisesato manasikāro vutto. Sajātisaṅgahādiko dhātusaṅgahavisesopi
analyzed: dassetum ajjhattika bāhira visesataḥ manasikāraḥ vuttaḥ sa jāti saṅgaha ādikaḥ dhātu saṅgaha visesaḥ api
translated: Attention is given to them as to whether they are classed according to the khandhas, etc., in order to show that although they are classed according to the khandhas, etc., in the conventional sense, they are classed according to the elements, etc., in the ultimate sense.

original: pariggahitabboti dassetuṃ saṅgahato manasikāro vutto. Sandhāraṇādīhi yathāsakakiccehi
analyzed: pariggahitabbaḥ iti dassetum saṅgahataḥ manasikāraḥ vuttaḥ sandhāraṇa ādīhi yathā saka kiccehi
translated: Attention by inclusion is mentioned in order to show that they are to be discerned as “included” in the sense of being “taken in” by the aggregates.

original: aññamaññūpatthambhabhāvatopi dhātuyo pariggahetabbāti dassetuṃ paccayato manasikāro🔽vutto. Abyāpāranayato dhātuyo pariggahetabbāti dassetuṃ asamannāhārato manasikāro🔽vutto. Attano paccayadhammavisesato, paccayabhāvavisesato ca dhātuyo pariggahetabbāti
analyzed: aññamaññu upatthambha bhāvataḥ pi dhātuyo pariggahetabbā ti dassetum paccayataḥ manasikāraḥ  vuttaḥ a byāpāra nayataḥ dhātuyaḥ pariggahetabbā ti dassetum a samannāhārataḥ manasikāraḥ  vuttaḥ attanaḥ paccaya dhamma visesataḥ paccaya bhāva visesataḥ ca dhātuyo pariggahetabbā ti
translated: Attention by condition is mentioned in order to show that they are to be discerned as “included” in the sense of mutually supporting each other by acting as conditions in the way stated.🔽Attention by non-attention is mentioned in order to show that they are to be discerned as “included” in the sense of being “taken in” by the element of non-attention.

original: dassetuṃ paccayavibhāgato manasikāro vuttoti evametesaṃ terasannaṃ ākārānaṃ pariggahe
analyzed: dassetum paccaya vibhāgataḥ manasikāraḥ vuttaḥ ti evam etesam terasannam ākārānam pariggahe
translated: Attention by analysis of conditions is mentioned in order to show that they are to be discerned as “included” in the sense of being “taken in” by the element of conditions.🔽This is how the reason for the thirteen aspects should be understood.

original: kāraṇaṃ veditabbaṃ. Ākārehīti pakārehi, kāraṇehi vā.🔽347. Tattha patthaṭattāti puthuttā, tena puthubhāvato puthuvī, puthuvī eva pathavīti
analyzed: kāraṇam veditabbam ākārehi iti pakārehi kāraṇehi vā  tattha patthaṭa ttā ati puthuttā tena puthubhāvato puthuvī puthuvī eva pathavī iti
translated: By aspects: by kinds, or by reasons.🔽Herein, pathavī is derived from patthaṭa, which is a synonym for pathavy.

original: niruttinayena saddatthamāha. Patthanaṭṭhena vā pathavī, patiṭṭhābhāvena patthāyati
analyzed: nirutti nayena saddattham āha patthana aṭṭhena vā pathavī patiṭṭhā bhāvena patthāyati
translated: The meaning of the word is “solidity.” Or alternatively, it is pathavī in the sense of patthanā, because of its state of being a foundation.

original: upatiṭṭhatīti attho. “Appotī”ti padassa attho heṭṭhā vutto eva. Āpīyatīti sosīyati,
analyzed: upatiṭṭhati iti atthaḥ appoti iti padassa atthaḥ heṭṭhā vuttaḥ eva āpīyati iti sosīyati
translated: the meaning is, it stands. The meaning of the word “floods” has already been given above . “It flows” : it is moistened,

original: pivīyatīti keci. “Ayaṃ panattho sasambhārāpe yujjatī”ti vadanti, lakkhaṇāpepi yujjateva.
analyzed: pivīyati iti keci ayam pana attho sa sambhāra āpe yujjati iti vadanti lakkhaṇa āpe pi yujjatā iva
translated: some say. “This meaning is appropriate as ‘flooding together with its associated states,’ ” they say. But it is appropriate as a characteristic too.

original: Sopi hi pharusapācanavisosanākārena sesabhūtattayena pīyamāno viya pavattatīti. Appāyatīti🔽brūheti. Paribrūhanarasā hi āpodhātu. Tejatīti niseti, tikkhabhāvena sesabhūtattayaṃ
analyzed: saḥ api hi pharusa pācana visosana ākārena sesa bhūta ttayena pīyamānaḥ viya pavattati iti appāyati iti  brūha iti paribrūhana rasā hi āpodhātu tejati iti nisā iti tikkha bhāvena
translated: For that too occurs as if it were being moistened by the remaining three elements in the way that a liquid is boiled up and then falls back. “It flows” :🔽it spreads. For the water element has the characteristic of spreading. “It burns” : it heats. The meaning is that by its sharp nature it heats the remaining three elements,

original: usmāpayatīti attho. Vāyatīti samīreti, desantaruppattihetubhāvena bhūtasaṅghātaṃ gametīti attho.🔽Evaṃ tāva visesato vacanatthaṃ vatvā idāni sāmaññato vattuṃ “avisesena panā”tiādi
analyzed: usmāpayati iti atthaḥ vāyati iti samīreti desantara uppatti hetu bhāvena bhūta saṅghātam gameti iti atthaḥ  evam tāva visesataḥ vacana attham vatvā idāni sāmaññataḥ vattum avisesena pana atiādi
translated: as if it were boiling them. “It moves” : it causes to move. The meaning is that it causes the mass of elements to go by becoming the cause for the arising of the elements in another place.

original: vuttaṃ. Salakkhaṇadhāraṇatoti yathā titthiyaparikappito “pakati attā”ti evamādiko
analyzed: vuttam sa lakkhaṇa dhāraṇato ti yathā titthiya parikappito pakati attā ati evamādiko
translated: So far, after stating the meaning of the words in particular, he now said “But in general” , etc., in order to state it in general. “By bearing its own characteristic” : as the “nature” , etc.,🔽imagined by sectarians.

original: sabhāvato natthi, na evametā. Etā pana salakkhaṇaṃ sabhāvaṃ dhārentīti dhātuyo. Dukkhādānatoti🔽dukkhassa vidahanato. Etā hi dhātuyo kāraṇabhāvena vavatthitā hutvā ayalohādidhātuyo
analyzed: sabhāvataḥ natthi na evam etāḥ etā pana salakkhaṇam sabhāvam dhārenti iti dhātuyaḥ dukkha ādānato ti  dukkhassa vidahanataḥ etāḥ hi dhātuyaḥ kāraṇa bhāvena vavatthitāḥ hutvā aya loha ādi dhātuyaḥ
translated: They do not exist in the way they are supposed to. But they are elements in the sense of bearing their own characteristics.

original: viya ayalohādiṃ anekappakāraṃ saṃsāradukkhaṃ vidahanti. Dukkhādhānatoti anappakassa🔽dukkhassa vidhānamattato avasavattanato, taṃ vā dukkhaṃ etāhi kāraṇabhūtāhi sattehi
analyzed: viya aya loha ādim aneka ppakāram saṃsāra dukkham vidahanti dukkha ādhānato ti anappakassa  dukkhassa vidhāna mattataḥ avasavattanataḥ tam vā dukkham etāhi kāraṇa bhūtāhi sattehi
translated: They are elements in the sense of burning up suffering. For these elements, being defined as causes, burn up the suffering of the round of rebirths in its various forms, like the elements of fire, etc., burn up iron, copper, etc.

original: anuvidhīyati, tathāvihitañca taṃ etāsveva dhīyati ṭhapīyatīti evaṃ dukkhādhānato,🔽dhātuyo. Apica “nijjīvaṭṭho dhātuṭṭho”ti vuttovāyamattho. Tathā hi bhagavā “chadhāturoyaṃ
analyzed: anuvidhīyati tathā vihitam ca tam etāsu eva dhīyati ṭhapīyati iti evam dukkha ādhānato  apica nijjīva ṭṭhaḥ dhātuṭṭhaḥ ti vuttaḥ uva ayam attho tathā hi bhagavā
translated: They are elements in the sense of being the source of suffering. Because they are the source of suffering in its various forms, they are not subject to the control of any self. Or else, that suffering is distributed among these elements as causes, and it is stored up in them as well.

original: bhikkhu puriso”tiādīsu jīvasaññāsamūhananatthaṃ dhātudesanaṃ akāsīti. Iti vacanatthamukhenapi🔽asādhāraṇato, sādhāraṇato ca dhātūnaṃ sarasalakkhaṇameva vibhāvīyatīti āha “evaṃ
analyzed: bhikkhu puriso ti ādīsu jīva saññā samūhanana attham dhātu desanam akāsi iti iti vacana ttha mukhena api 🔽asādhāraṇataḥ sādhāraṇataḥ ca dhātūnam sa rasa lakkhaṇam eva āha evam
translated: The meaning of “element” is also said to be the meaning of “lifeless.” For the Blessed One taught the elements in the passage, “Bhikkhu, this person is made up of six elements” , in order to dispel the conception of a living being.

original: visesasāmaññavasena vacanatthato manasi kātabbā”ti. Manasikāro pana vacanatthamukhena
analyzed: visesa sāmañña vasena vacana atthataḥ manasi kātabbā ati manasikāraḥ pana vacana ttha mukhena
translated: and should be given attention as to the meaning of the terms in the way already stated under the head of the elements.

original: dhātuyo pariggahetvā ṭhitassa heṭṭhā vuttanayeneva veditabbo.
analyzed: dhātuyaḥ pariggahetvā ṭhitassa heṭṭhā vutta nayena iva veditabbaḥ
translated: But the attention given to the elements by way of the meaning of the terms should be understood in the way already stated under the head of the faculties.

original: 348. Ākārehīti pakārehi. Atha vā ākarīyanti dissanti ettha dhātuyoti ākārā, koṭṭhāsā.🔽Aṭṭhadhammasamodhānāti yathāvuttānaṃ paccayavisesena visiṭṭharūpānaṃ vaṇṇādīnaṃ aṭṭhannaṃ
analyzed: ākārehi iti pakārehi atha vā ākarīyanti dissanti ettha ākārā koṭṭhāsā  aṭṭha dhamma samodhānā ti yathāvuttānam paccaya visesena visiṭṭha rūpānam vaṇṇa ādīnam aṭṭhannam
translated: By their aspects: by their modes. Or alternatively, they are aspects in the sense that they are seen here, thus they are aspects ; they are parts.

original: dhammānaṃ samavadhānato sannivesavisesavasena sahāvaṭṭhānato taṃ upādāya. Kesāti
analyzed: dhammānam samavadhānato sannivesa visesa vasena saha avaṭṭhānato tam upādāya kesā ti
translated: By the combination of eight things: by the combination of the eight things, namely, the visible-data base, etc., which are distinguished by the distinction of their conditions, and which are stated thus: “The visible-data base, the sound base, the odour base, the flavour base, the tangible-data base, the space element, the water element, the earth element” .🔽The term “hair of the head” is a mere conventional expression.

original: sammuti samaññāmattaṃ hoti. Tesaṃyeva vinibbhogāti tesaṃyeva vaṇṇādīnaṃ vinibbhujanato.🔽Yathā hi vaṇṇādayo aṭṭha dhammā paññāya vinibbhujjamānā aññamaññabyatirekena paramatthato
analyzed: sammuti samaññā mattam hoti tesam yeva vinibbhogā ati tesam yeva vaṇṇa ādīnam vinibbhujanato  yathā hi vaṇṇa ādayaḥ aṭṭha dhammā paññāya vinibbhujjamānāḥ aññamañña byatirekena paramatthato
translated: By their analysis: by their dissection.

original: upalabbhanti, na evaṃ vaṇṇādibyatirekena paramatthato kesā upalabbhanti. Tasmā ye
analyzed: upalabbhanti na evam vaṇṇa ādi byatirekena paramatthato kesāḥ upalabbhanti tasmā ye
translated: For just as the eight things, namely, colour, shape, etc., are found in the ultimate sense as distinguishable from each other when they are dissected by understanding, so the hair of the head is not found in the ultimate sense as distinguishable from them. Therefore,

original: ca dhamme samudite upādāya “kesā”ti sammuti, tesu visuṃ visuṃ katesu natthi “kesā”ti
analyzed: ca dhamme samudite upādāya kesāti sammuti tesu visum visum katesu natthi kesāti
translated: and the concept “hair of the head” is a concept derived by conceptualization from the collection of the four primary elements and the derived materiality originated by kamma. When they are separated out individually, there is no concept “hair of the head” left;

original: sammuti, vohāramattanti attho.🔽“Aṭṭhadhammakalāpamattamevā”ti idaṃ kesapaññattiyā upādāyabhūte vaṇṇādike ekattena🔽gahetvā vuttaṃ, na tesaṃ aṭṭhadhammamattabhāvato. Kammasamuṭṭhāno koṭṭhāsoti kesesu🔽tāva kesamūlaṃ, evaṃ lomādīsupi yathārahaṃ veditabbaṃ. Dasadhammakalāpopīti ettha
analyzed: sammuti vohāra mattanti attho  aṭṭha dhamma kalāpa mattam evā ti idam kesa paññattiyā upādāya bhūte vaṇṇa ādike ekattena  gahetvā vuttam na tesam aṭṭha dhamma matta bhāvato kamma samuṭṭhānaḥ koṭṭhāso ti kesesu  tāva kesa mūlam evam loma ādīsu pi yathāraham veditabbam dasa dhamma kalāpaḥ api iti ettha
translated: the meaning is that it is a mere concept.🔽“A mere collection of eight factors”: this is said by taking the colour, etc., that is the physical basis for the concept “hair of the head” as a unity. It is not because they are a mere collection of eight factors. The portion originated by kamma: in the case of the hair of the head, the roots of the hair are so called. The same method applies in the case of the body hair, etc., as appropriate. The mere collection of ten factors: here the portion of heat that digests what is eaten, etc., should be called the mere collection of nine factors.

original: asitādiparipācako tejokoṭṭhāso navadhammakalāpopīti vattabbo. Yadime kesādikoṭṭhāsā🔽yathārahaṃ aṭṭhanavadasadhammasamūhabhūtā, atha kasmā pathavīādidhātumattato manasi
analyzed: asita ādi paripācako tejo koṭṭhāsaḥ nava dhamma kalāpo api iti vattabbo yat ime kesa ādi koṭṭhāsā  yathāraham aṭṭha nava dasa dhamma samūha bhūtāḥ atha kasmai pathavī ādi dhātumat tataḥ manasi
translated: And although these portions of the body, such as the hair of the head, are a collection of eight, nine, or ten factors, as the case may be,🔽why are they brought to mind as the primary elements, earth, and so on? He said, “But they are brought to mind according to predominance,” etc.

original: karīyantīti āha “ussadavasena panā”tiādi. Yasmā ayaṃ dhātumanasikāro yāvadeva sattasaññāsamugghāṭanattho,
analyzed: āha ussada vasena pana atiādi yasmai ayam dhātu manasikāraḥ yāvat eva satta saññā samugghāṭana atthaḥ
translated: Because this bringing to mind of the primary elements is intended only to remove the perception of living beings.

original: dhammavinibbhogo ca sātisayaṃ sattasaññāsamugghāṭāya saṃvattati, tasmā koṭṭhāsesu
analyzed: dhamma vinibbhogaḥ ca sa atisayam satta saññā samugghāṭāya saṃvattati tasmai koṭṭhāsesu
translated: And the analysis of the mental body is conducive to the complete uprooting of the perception of a being, which is why the analysis is given in the mental body.

original: evaṃ dhammavibhāgo veditabbo. Ettha hi udariyaṃ karīsaṃ pubbo muttañca utusamuṭṭhānā,
analyzed: evam dhamma vibhāgaḥ veditabbaḥ ettha hi udariyam karīsam utu samuṭṭhānā
translated: Herein, the belly’s inner skin, dung, pus, blood, urine, and wind are originated by temperature.

original: asitādiparipācakatejo kammasamuṭṭhāno, assāsapassāsavāto cittasamuṭṭhānoti cha ekasamuṭṭhānā,
analyzed: asita ādi paripācaka tejo kamma samuṭṭhāno assāsa passāsa vāto citta samuṭṭhāno ti cha eka samuṭṭhānā
translated: The fire element that digests what is eaten, etc., is kamma-originated. The in-breath and out-breath are consciousness-originated.

original: sedoassu kheḷo siṅghāṇikāti cattāro utucittavasena dvisamuṭṭhānā, sesā dvattiṃsa catusamuṭṭhānā.
analyzed: kheḷaḥ siṅghāṇikā ati cattāro utu citta vasena dvi samuṭṭhānā sesāḥ dvattiṃsa catu samuṭṭhānā
translated: Sweat, tears, grease, spittle, snot, oil of the joints, and urine are originated both by temperature and by consciousness. The remaining thirty-two parts are originated by the four primaries.

original: Tesu asitādiparipācake tejokoṭṭhāse eko kalāpo jīvitanavako, aññesu ekasamuṭṭhānesu
analyzed: tesu asita ādi paripācake tejokoṭṭhāse ekaḥ kalāpaḥ jīvita navakaḥ aññesu eka samuṭṭhānesu
translated: Herein, in the case of the fire element that digests what is eaten, etc., one lump is a life-faculty ennead,🔽in those originated by temperature there are eight each originated by temperature,

original: utusamuṭṭhāno, cittasamuṭṭhāno vā ekeko aṭṭhako, dvisamuṭṭhānesu utucittavasena dve
analyzed: utu samuṭṭhāno citta samuṭṭhāno vā ekekaḥ aṭṭhakaḥ dvi samuṭṭhānesu utu citta vasena dve
translated: in those originated both by temperature and by consciousness there are two each originated by temperature and by consciousness,

original: dve aṭṭhakā, catusamuṭṭhānesu utucittāhārasamuṭṭhānā tayo tayo aṭṭhakā, utucittasamuṭṭhānesu
analyzed: dve aṭṭhakā catu samuṭṭhānesu utu citta āhāra samuṭṭhānā tayo tayo aṭṭhakā utu citta samuṭṭhānesu
translated: in those originated by the four primaries there are three each originated by the four primaries, temperature, consciousness, and nutriment, and two each originated by temperature and by consciousness,

original: saddanavakā, aṭṭhasu tejovāyokoṭṭhāsesu aṭṭha jīvitanavakā, sesesu catuvīsatiyā koṭṭhāsesu
analyzed: sadda navakāḥ aṭṭhasu tejaḥ vāyo koṭṭhāsesu aṭṭha jīvita navakāḥ sesesu catuvīsatiyā koṭṭhāsesu
translated: In the eight fire and air components there are eight life faculties,🔽and in the remaining twenty-four components there are two sets of ten bodily formations,

original: kāyabhāvadasakadvayasahitā, cakkhādisaññitesu maṃsakoṭṭhāsesu cakkhusotaghānajivhāvatthudasakasahitā🔽cāti paripuṇṇāyatanake rūpakāye bhedaṃ anāmasitvā ekattavasena gayhamānā sattacattālīsādhikasatarūpakalāpā
analyzed: kāya bhāva dasaka dvaya sahitā cakkhu ādi saññitesu maṃsa koṭṭhāsesu cakkhu sota ghāna jivhā vatthu dasaka sahitā  ca ati paripuṇṇa āyatanake rūpa kāye bhedam an āmasitvā ekatta vasena gayhamānā satta cattālīsa adhika sata rūpa kalāpā
translated: and in the flesh components called eye, etc., there are ten eye, ten ear, ten nose, ten tongue, and ten body components.🔽Thus in a body with complete sense bases, when the components are taken as one without distinguishing their individual dissolution, there are 470 groups of materiality.

original: rūpavibhāgato sādhikaṃ diyaḍḍharūpasahassaṃ hoti, koṭṭhāsānaṃ pana avayavavibhāgena
analyzed: rūpa vibhāgato sādhikam diyaḍḍha rūpa sahassam hoti koṭṭhāsānam pana avayava vibhāgena
translated: But when the materiality is analysed according to the analysis of the components, there are more than 1,250 kinds of materiality. But when the groups of components are analysed according to the analysis of the components’ parts,

original: tadavayavakalāpānaṃ bhede gayhamāne rūpadhammānaṃ asaṅkhyeyyabhedatā veditabbā. Evaṃ🔽dhammavibhāgato anekabhedabhinnāpi ime dvācattālīsa koṭṭhāsā ussadaggahaṇena catudhātuvaseneva🔽vavatthapetabbā. Tenāha “ussadavasena pana…pe… manasi kātabbā”ti. Tattha manasikāravidhi
analyzed: tad avayava kalāpānam bhede gayhamāne rūpa dhammānam asaṅkhyeyya bheda tā veditabbā evam  dhamma vibhāgataḥ aneka bheda bhinnā api ime dvācattālīsa koṭṭhāsāḥ ussada gahaṇena catu dhātu vasena iva  tena āha ussada vasena panape manasi kātabbā ti tattha manasikāra vidhi
translated: and the dissolution of the groups of parts is taken as the analysis, then the analysis of the material dhammas should be understood as incalculable.

original: vuttanayeneva veditabbo.
analyzed: vutta nayena iva veditabbaḥ
translated: Thus, although these forty-two components are divided into many kinds according to the analysis of the dhammas, they should be defined by the method of the four elements only, by taking the outstanding element. Therefore it is said: “But when they are defined according to prominence, etc., they should be defined by the method of the four elements, etc., and they should be given attention as ‘earth,’ etc.” Herein, the method of giving attention should be understood according to the method stated in the case of the kasiṇas.

original: 349. Majjhimena pamāṇenāti ārohapariṇāhehi majjhimasarīre labbhamānena majjhimena
analyzed: majjhimena pamāṇena ati āroha pariṇāhehi majjhima sarīre labbhamānena majjhimena
translated: With a measure middling: with a measure middling in the body, that is, with a measure to be found in a middling body as to height and breadth.

original: parimāṇena. Pariggayhamānāti paññāya paritakketvā gayhamānā. Paramāṇubhedasañcuṇṇāti🔽ettha yathā “aṅgulassa aṭṭhamo bhāgo yavo, yavassa aṭṭhamo bhāgo ūkā, ūkāya aṭṭhamo🔽bhāgo likkhā, likkhāya aṭṭhamo bhāgo rathareṇu, rathareṇussa aṭṭhamo bhāgo tajjārī,
analyzed: parimāṇena pariggayhamānā ati paññāya paritakketvā gayhamānā paramāṇu bheda sañcuṇṇā ati  ettha yathā aṅgulassa aṭṭhamaḥ bhāgaḥ yavaḥ yavassa aṭṭhamaḥ bhāgaḥ ūkā ūkāya aṭṭhamaḥ  bhāgaḥ likkhā likkhāya aṭṭhamaḥ bhāgaḥ ratha reṇu ratha reṇussa aṭṭhamaḥ bhāgo tajjārī
translated: Is discerned: is apprehended by being delimited with understanding.

original: tajjāriyā aṭṭhamo bhāgo aṇu, evaṃ aṇuno aṭṭhamo bhāgo paramāṇu nāmā”ti keci. Aṭṭhakathāyaṃ🔽pana “sattadhaññamāsappamāṇaṃ ekaṃ aṅgulaṃ, sattaūkāpamāṇo eko dhaññamāso, sattalikkhāpamāṇā🔽ekā ūkā, chattiṃsarathareṇuppamāṇā ekā likkhā, chattiṃsatajjārippamāṇo eko rathareṇu,
analyzed: tajjāriyāḥ aṭṭhamaḥ bhāgaḥ aṇu evam aṇunaḥ aṭṭhamaḥ bhāgo paramāṇu nāma ati keci  pana satta dhañña māsa ppamāṇam ekam aṅgulam satta ūkā pamāṇaḥ ekaḥ dhañña māsaḥ satta likkhā pamāṇā  ekā ūkā chattiṃsa ratha reṇu ppamāṇā ekā likkhā chattiṃsa tajjāri ppamāṇaḥ ekaḥ ratha reṇu
translated: Broken up into ultimate units: here some say this: “An aṅgula is one-eighth of a span. An ūka is one-eighth of an aṅgula. A likkhā is one-eighth of an ūka. A rathareṇu is one-eighth of a likkhā. A tajjārī is one-eighth of a rathareṇu. An aṇu is one-eighth of a tajjārī. An ultimate unit is one-eighth of an aṇu.”

original: chattiṃsaaṇuppamāṇā ekā tajjārī, chattiṃsaparamāṇuppamāṇo eko aṇū”ti vuttaṃ. Tasmā
analyzed: chattiṃsa aṇu ppamāṇā ekā tajjārī chattiṃsa paramāṇu ppamāṇaḥ ekaḥ aṇu iti vuttam tasmā
translated: But in the commentary it is said: “Seven grains of rice make one aṅgula. Seven ūkas make one grain of rice. Seven likkhās make one ūka. Thirty-six rathareṇus make one likkhā. Thirty-six tajjārīs make one rathareṇu. Thirty-six aṇus make one tajjārī. Thirty-six ultimate units make one aṇu.”🔽Therefore,

original: aṇuno chattiṃsatimabhāgamatto paramāṇu nāma ākāsakoṭṭhāsiko maṃsacakkhussa agocaro
analyzed: aṇuno chattiṃsatima bhāga mattaḥ paramāṇu nāma ākāsa koṭṭhāsikaḥ maṃsa cakkhussa agocaro
translated: A paramāṇu is the thirty-sixth part of an aṇu. It is a space-particle. It is not the domain of the fleshly eye.

original: dibbacakkhusseva gocarabhūto. Taṃ sandhāyāha “paramāṇubhedasañcuṇṇā”ti, yathāvuttaparamāṇuppabhedena
analyzed: dibba cakkhussa iva gocara bhūto tam sandhāya āha paramāṇu bheda sañcuṇṇā ti yathā vutta paramāṇu ppabhedena
translated: It is the domain of the divine eye. With reference to that, it is said: “It is reduced to the state of a paramāṇu.”

original: cuṇṇavicuṇṇabhūtā. Sukhumarajabhūtāti tatoyeva ativiya sukhumarajabhāvaṃ gatā.
analyzed: cuṇṇa vicuṇṇa bhūtā sukhuma raja bhūtā ati sukhuma raja bhāvam gatā
translated: It is reduced to the state of a paramāṇu by the division of the paramāṇu as already stated. It is reduced to the state of a very fine dust.

original: Doṇamattā siyāti soḷasa nāḷimattā. Idhāpi “majjhimena pamāṇenā”ti ānetvā sambandhitabbaṃ.
analyzed: doṇa mattā siyā ti soḷasa nāḷi mattāḥ idha api majjhimena pamāṇena ati ānetvā sambandhitabbam
translated: It is the size of a doṇa. It is the size of sixteen nāḷis. Here too, it should be connected with “by the average measure.”

original: Tena “pakatiyā catumuṭṭhikaṃ kuḍuvaṃ, catukuḍuvaṃ nāḷi, tāya nāḷiyā soḷasa nāḷiyo🔽doṇaṃ, taṃ pana magadhanāḷiyā dvādasa nāḷiyo hontī”ti vadanti. Saṅgahitāti yathā
analyzed: tena pakatiyā catu muṭṭhikam kuḍuvam catu kuḍuvam nāḷi tāya nāḷiyā soḷasa nāḷiyaḥ  doṇam tam pana magadhanāḷiyāḥ dvādasa nāḷiyaḥ honti iti vadanti saṅgahitā ati yathā
translated: Therefore, they say: “A kuḍuva is four muṭṭhis. Four kuḍavas are a nāḷi. Sixteen nāḷis are a doṇa.

original: na vippakirati, evaṃ ābandhanavasena sampiṇḍitvā gahitā. Anupālitāti yathā paggharaṇasabhāvāya
analyzed: na vippakirati evam ābandhana vasena sampiṇḍitvā gahitā anupālitā ati yathā paggharaṇa sabhāvāya
translated: But twelve nāḷis are a doṇa by the Magadha nāḷi.” It is collected means it is taken by being bound together so that it does not scatter. It is maintained means it is kept so that it does not flow away by its nature.

original: āpodhātuyā vasena kilinnabhāvaṃ, picchilabhāvaṃ vā nāpajjati, evaṃ anurakkhitā. Vitthambhitāti🔽saṅghātavāyunā ativiya vitthambhanaṃ pāpitā. Na vikirati na viddhaṃsatīti sukhumarajabhūtāpi🔽pathavīdhātu ābandhanaparipācanasamudīraṇakiccāhi āpotejovāyodhātūhi laddhapaccayā🔽sinehena temitā tejasā paripakkā vāyunā vitthambhanaṃ pāpitā piṭṭhacuṇṇā viya na
analyzed: āpodhātuyāḥ vasena kilinna bhāvam picchila bhāvam vā na āpajjati evam anurakkhitā vitthambhitā ati  saṅghāta vāyunā vitthambhanam pāpitā na vikirati na viddhaṃsati iti  pathavī dhātu ābandhana paripācana samudīraṇa kiccāhi āpaḥ tejaḥ vāyo dhātūhi laddha paccayā  sinehena temitā tejasā paripakkā vāyunā vitthambhanam pāpitā piṭṭha cuṇṇā viya na
translated: does not scatter and break up like the fine dust of the earth element that has obtained conditions through the water, fire, and air elements, which have the respective functions of cohesion, ripening, and distension.

original: ito cito ca vikirati na viddhaṃsati, atha kho piṇḍitā ghanabhūtā hutvā nānappakārena🔽gahetabbataṃ āpajjati. Tenāha “avikiriyamānā”tiādi. Tattha vikappanti vibhāgaṃ. Yadipi🔽tejovāyodhātuyopi saviggahā rūpadhammabhāvato, yādiso pana ghanabhāvo pathavīāpodhātūsu🔽labbhati, na tādiso tejovāyodhātūsu labbhatīti meyyabhāvābhāvato tattha cuṇṇabhedo
analyzed: ito cito ca vikirati na viddhaṃsati atha kho piṇḍitāḥ ghana bhūtāḥ hutvā nānappakārena 🔽āpajjati tena āha a vikiriyamāna itiādi tattha vikappanti vibhāgam yadi api 🔽tejaḥ vāyo dhātuyaḥ pi sa viggahāḥ rūpa dhamma bhāvataḥ yādisaḥ pana ghana bhāvaḥ pathavī āpaḥ dhātūsu 🔽labbhati na tādisaḥ tejaḥ vāyaḥ dhātūsu labbhati iti meyya bhāva abhāvato tattha cuṇṇa bhedo
translated: It does not scatter and break up like the fine dust of the earth element that has obtained conditions through the water, fire, and air elements, which have the respective functions of cohesion, ripening, and distension. It does not scatter and break up like the fine dust of the earth element that has obtained conditions through the water, fire, and air elements, which have the respective functions of cohesion, ripening, and distension. It does not scatter and break up like the fine dust of the earth element that has obtained conditions through the water, fire, and air elements, which have the respective functions of cohesion, ripening, and distension. It does not scatter and break up like the fine dust of the earth element that has obtained conditions through the water, fire, and air elements, which have the respective functions of cohesion, ripening, and distension. It does not scatter and break up like the fine dust of the earth element that has obtained conditions through the water, fire, and air elements, which have the respective functions of cohesion, ripening, and distension. It does not scatter and break up like the fine dust of the earth element that has obtained conditions through the water, fire, and air elements, which have the respective functions of cohesion, ripening, and distension. It does not scatter and break up like the fine dust of the earth element that has obtained conditions through the water, fire, and air elements, which have the respective functions of cohesion, ripening, and distension. It does not scatter and break up like the fine dust of the earth element that has obtained conditions through the water, fire, and air elements, which have the respective functions of cohesion, ripening, and distension. It does not scatter and break up like the fine dust of the earth element that has obtained conditions through the water, fire, and air elements, which have the respective functions of cohesion, ripening, and distension. It does not scatter and break up like the fine dust of the earth element that has obtained conditions through the water, fire, and air elements, which have the respective functions of cohesion, ripening, and dist

original: na uddhaṭo. Tathā hi sasambhāratejovāyūsupi meyyabhāvo na labbhateva.
analyzed: tathā hi meyya bhāvaḥ na
translated: for the state of being food is not found in the fire and air elements with their accessories.

original: Yūsagatāti yūsabhāvaṃ dravabhāvaṃ gatā. Tato eva ābandhanākārabhūtā. Na paggharatīti
analyzed: yūsa gatā ati yūsa bhāvam drava bhāvam gatā tatas eva ābandhana ākāra bhūtā na paggharati iti
translated: ‘Has become liquid’: has become a liquid, a fluid; and so it is the binding together. ‘Does not ooze out’:

original: na ogaḷati. Na parissavatīti na vissandati. Pīṇitapīṇitabhāvaṃ dassetīti āpodhātuyā
analyzed: na ogaḷati na parissavati iti na vissandati pīṇita pīṇita bhāvam dasseti iti āpodhātuyā
translated: does not flow out. ‘Does not trickle away’: does not leak away. ‘Shows the state of being compact and so on’: this is said of the water element

original: brūhanarasatāya vuttaṃ.🔽Usumākārabhūtāti etena kāye pākatikausmāpi gahaṇīsaṅkhātāya tassāyeva tejodhātuyā🔽vasena hotīti dasseti. Paripācetīti santejeti. Sā hi yathābhuttassa āhārassa sammā
analyzed: brūhana rasa tāya vuttam  etena kāye gahaṇī saṅkhātāya tassāya iva tejaḥ dhātuyā  vasena hoti iti dasseti paripāceti iti santejeti sā hi yathā bhuttassa āhārassa sammā
translated: because of its property of cohesion.🔽‘Has become the state of heat’: by this he shows that the heat in the body is due to that same fire element itself, which is called ‘nutritive essence’ .

original: pariṇāmanena rasādisampattiyā hetubhāvaṃ gacchantī imaṃ kāyaṃ paripāceti santejetīti
analyzed: pariṇāmanena rasa ādi sampattiyāḥ hetu bhāvam gacchantī imam kāyam paripāca iti santeja iti iti
translated: ‘It digests’: it cooks. For that is called ‘digestive heat’ because it becomes the cause of the perfection of the nutritive essence, etc., by the proper digestion of what has been eaten, and it is said to ‘digest,’ to ‘cook,’ this body.

original: vuccati. Tenevāha “na pūtibhāvaṃ dassetī”ti. Kammūpanissayāya, cittappasādahetukāya
analyzed: vuccati tena iva āha na pūti bhāvam dasseti iti kamma upanissayāya citta ppasāda hetukāya
translated: That is why it is said, ‘It shows the state of being unrotten.’

original: ca sarīre vaṇṇasampadāya tejodhātu visesapaccayo, pageva utuāhārasamuṭṭhānāya rūpasampattiyā
analyzed: ca sarīre vaṇṇa sampadāya tejodhātu visesa paccayo pagā iva utu āhāra samuṭṭhānāya rūpa sampattiyā
translated: The fire element is a condition for the perfection of the bodily form that arises from kamma-result and from temperature and nutriment, and still more so for the perfection of the bodily form that arises from consciousness and from kamma-result, temperature, and nutriment.

original: yathāvuttatejodhātūti āha “vaṇṇasampattiñcassa āvahatī”ti.🔽Samudīraṇavitthambhanalakkhaṇāti ettha samudīraṇaṃ anupellanaṃ, visosananti keci.
analyzed: yathā vutta tejaḥ dhātu iti āha vaṇṇa sampattim ca assa āvahati iti  samudīraṇa vitthambhana lakkhaṇā ti ettha samudīraṇam anupellanam visosananti keci
translated: and so he says, “and it brings about the beauty of the colour.”🔽The characteristic of distending and diffusing: distending is spreading out, some say, and diffusing is purifying.🔽Diffusing is causing the other three elements to be firm, some say, and distending is causing them to be raised up.

original: Vitthambhanaṃ sesabhūtattayassa thambhitattāpādanaṃ, uppīlananti eke. Tāyāti vitthambhanalakkhaṇāya
analyzed: vitthambhanam sesa bhūta ttayassa thambhita tta āpādanam uppīlananti eke tāya ati vitthambhana lakkhaṇāya
translated: By the air element with the characteristic of diffusing: by the air element with the characteristic of distending.

original: vāyodhātuyā. Aparāyāti samudīraṇalakkhaṇāya. Sā hi pellanasabhāvā. Tenāha “samabbhāhato”ti.
analyzed: vāyodhātuyā aparā āyāti samudīraṇa lakkhaṇāya sā hi pellana sabhāvā tena āha samabbhāhatā iti
translated: The other: the air element with the characteristic of diffusing. For that has the nature of spreading out. Hence it is said, “is well shaken.”

original: Samabbhāhanañca rūpakalāpassa desantaruppattiyā hetubhāvo. Avaghaṭṭanaṃ āsannataruppattiyā.
analyzed: samabbhāhanam ca rūpa kalāpassa desantara uppattiyāḥ hetu bhāvaḥ avaghaṭṭanam āsannatara uppattiyāḥ
translated: And the shaking is the cause of the material group’s arising in another place, while the striking is the cause of its arising nearer.

original: Lāḷetīti parivatteti. Idāni yadatthaṃ cuṇṇato manasikāro āgato, taṃ nigamanavasena
analyzed: lāḷeti iti parivattā iti idāni yadattham cuṇṇataḥ manasikāraḥ āgataḥ tam nigamana vasena
translated: It is “disturbed” because it is moved. Now, in order to show by way of conclusion the purpose for which the exercise of attention by way of elements has come in,

original: dassetuṃ “evameta”ntiādi vuttaṃ. Tattha dhātuyantanti suttena viya yantarūpakaṃ asatipi
analyzed: dassetum evam etat tiādi vuttam tattha dhātu yantam ti suttena viya yanta rūpakam asati pi
translated: he said “Thus” and so on. Herein, the machine of the elements: the machine of the elements is worked by the mind, as if by a mechanic, though there is no self existing

original: kattubhūte attani cittavasena dhātumayaṃ yantaṃ pavattati, idhāpi manasikāravidhi
analyzed: kattu bhūte attani citta vasena dhātu mayam pavattati idha api manasikāra vidhi
translated: as a worker. The machine works by the mind’s direction.

original: vuttanayeneva veditabbo.
analyzed: vutta nayena iva veditabbaḥ
translated: It should be understood in the way already stated.

original: 350. Yadipi catunnaṃ dhātūnaṃ lakkhaṇādayo heṭṭhā tattha tattha vuttā eva, tathāpi
analyzed: yadi api catunnam dhātūnam lakkhaṇa ādayaḥ heṭṭhā tattha tattha vuttāḥ eva tathā api
translated: Although the characteristics, etc., of the four elements have already been stated here and there, still

original: te anavasesato dassetvā visuṃ kammaṭṭhānapariggahavidhiṃ dassetuṃ “lakkhaṇādito”tiādi
analyzed: te anavasesataḥ dassetvā visum kammaṭṭhāna pariggaha vidhim dassetum lakkhaṇa āditaḥ tiādi
translated: the method of discerning the meditation subject is given by showing them without omission, beginning with the words “As to characteristic, etc.”

original: āraddhaṃ. Tattha lakkhīyati etenāti lakkhaṇaṃ, kakkhaḷattaṃ lakkhaṇametissāti kakkhaḷattalakkhaṇā.🔽Nanu ca kakkhaḷattameva pathavīdhātūti? Saccametaṃ, tathāpi viññātāviññātasaddatthatāvasena
analyzed: āraddham tattha lakkhīyati etena ati lakkhaṇam kakkhaḷattam lakkhaṇam etissa ati kakkhaḷatta lakkhaṇā  nanu ca kakkhaḷattam eva pathavī dhātu uti saccam etam tathā api viññāta a viññāta saddattha tā vasena
translated: Herein, that by which there is characterizing is a characteristic . The characteristic of hardness is the characteristic of the earth element.🔽But is not hardness the earth element itself? It is true; nevertheless,

original: abhinnepi dhamme kappanāsiddhena bhedena evaṃ niddeso kato. Evaṃ hi atthavisesāvabodho
analyzed: abhinne pi dhamme kappanā siddhena bhedena evam niddeso kataḥ evam hi attha visesa avabodho
translated: the teaching is given in this way in order to show the difference in the mode of conceiving, which is due to the difference in the way of entry. For the mode of conceiving is different in the case of one who conceives after discerning the mode of behaviour of the earth element by discerning the characteristic of hardness, and in the case of one who conceives after discerning the mode of behaviour of the earth element by discerning the characteristic of the earth element.

original: hotīti. Atha vā lakkhīyatīti lakkhaṇaṃ, kakkhaḷattaṃ hutvā lakkhiyamānā dhātu kakkhaḷattalakkhaṇāti
analyzed: hoti iti atha vā lakkhīyati iti lakkhaṇam kakkhaḷattam hutvā lakkhiyamānā dhātu kakkhaḷatta lakkhaṇā ati
translated: Or alternatively, the characteristic is that by which there is characterizing ; the element that is characterized as hardness is the earth element with the characteristic of hardness.

original: evamettha attho daṭṭhabbo. Sesāsupi eseva nayo. Patiṭṭhānarasāti sahajātadhammānaṃ
analyzed: evam ettha atthaḥ daṭṭhabbo sesāsu pi esa iva nayaḥ patiṭṭhāna rasā ati sahajāta dhammānam
translated: This is how the meaning should be regarded here. The same method of discerning the characteristics, etc., should be applied to the remaining three elements.🔽The meaning of the words “nutritive essence” , “cohesion” , and “motion” should be understood in accordance with the Suttas.

original: patiṭṭhābhāvakiccā. Tato eva nesaṃ sampaṭicchanākārena ñāṇassa paccupatiṭṭhatīti
analyzed: patiṭṭhā bhāva kiccā tatas eva nesam sampaṭicchana ākārena ñāṇassa paccupatiṭṭhati iti
translated: and its function is to support. And because of that it is the establishment for the knowledge that approves,

original: sampaṭicchanapaccupaṭṭhānā. Padaṭṭhānaṃ panettha aññadhammatāya na uddhaṭaṃ, sādhāraṇabhāvasabbhāvato🔽vā dūrakāraṇaṃ viya. Yathā vā dhammuddesavāravaṇṇanādīsu rasādinā aññesaṃ paccayabhāvaṃ🔽dassetvā paccayavantatādassanatthaṃ padaṭṭhānaṃ uddhaṭaṃ, na evamidha. Idha pana🔽dhātūnaṃ anaññasādhāraṇavisesavibhāvanaparāya codanāya aññadhammabhūtaṃ padaṭṭhānaṃ
analyzed: sampaṭicchana paccupaṭṭhānā padaṭṭhānam pana ittha añña dhamma tāya na uddhaṭam sādhāraṇa bhāva sabbhāvato  vā dūra kāraṇam viya yathā vā dhamma uddesa vāra vaṇṇanā ādīsu rasa ādinā aññesam paccaya bhāvam  dassetvā paccayavanta tā dassana attham padaṭṭhānam uddhaṭam na evam idha idha pana  dhātūnam anañña sādhāraṇa visesa vibhāvana parāya codanāya añña dhamma bhūtam padaṭṭhānam
translated: so it is the establishment for approval. But the condition for it is not stated as a separate state, either because it is common to all or🔽because it is a remote cause. Or just as in the case of the description of the “sign” in the explanation of the “definition” in the “Description of the Bases” (§10), etc., where the conditionality of the other states is shown by the mention of “flavour” and so on, and the presence of the condition is shown by the mention of “cause” and so on, so here too

original: na uddhaṭanti daṭṭhabbaṃ. Brūhanarasāti sahajātadhammānaṃ vaḍḍhanakiccā. Tathā hi
analyzed: na uddhaṭanti daṭṭhabbam brūhana rasā ati sahajāta dhammānam vaḍḍhana kiccā tathā hi
translated: the condition is not stated separately because the conditionality of the other states is shown by the mention of “nutriment” and so on, and the presence of the condition is shown by the mention of “cause” and so on.🔽But it should be regarded as the condition for the other states in the sense of the state of being a separate state.

original: sā nesaṃ pīṇitabhāvaṃ dassetīti vuccati. Saṅgahapaccupaṭṭhānāti bāhiraudakaṃ viya
analyzed: sā na esam pīṇita bhāvam dasseti iti vuccati saṅgaha paccupaṭṭhānā ati bāhira audakam viya
translated: It is the “nourishing essence” because its function is to nourish the states associated with it. For it is said that it shows their plumpness.🔽It is the “establishment for collecting” because it is the establishment for the collecting of the states associated with it, like the outer skin of the bath powder.

original: nhānīyacuṇṇassa sahajātadhammānaṃ saṅgahaṇapaccupaṭṭhānā. Maddavānuppadānapaccupaṭṭhānāti
analyzed: nhānīya cuṇṇassa sahajāta dhammānam saṅgahaṇa paccupaṭṭhānā maddava anuppadāna paccupaṭṭhānā ati
translated: It is the establishment for the non-disappearance of the soft state.

original: bāhiraggi viya jatulohādīnaṃ sahajātadhammānaṃ mudubhāvānuppadānapaccupaṭṭhānā. Abhinīhāro
analyzed: bāhiraggi viya jatu loha ādīnam sahajāta dhammānam mudu bhāva anuppadāna paccupaṭṭhānā abhinīhāro
translated: and its manifestation is the non-production of softness in the conascent states such as the hair of the head, etc., as in the case of the external fire.

original: bhūtasaṅghāṭassa desantaruppattihetubhāvo, nīharaṇaṃ vā bījato aṅkurassa viya.
analyzed: bhūta saṅghāṭassa desa antara uppatti hetu bhāvaḥ nīharaṇam vā bījataḥ aṅkurassa viya
translated: The arousing is the cause for the arising of the body in another place, or the carrying out, as in the case of the shoot from the seed.

original: 351. Utusamuṭṭhānāva kammādivasena anuppattito. Utucittasamuṭṭhānā kadāci ututo,
analyzed: utu samuṭṭhānā ava kamma ādi vasena anuppattitaḥ utu citta samuṭṭhānā kadāci ututaḥ
translated: The temperature-born are not produced by kamma, etc., as the case may be.

original: kadāci cittato uppajjanato. Avasesāti vuttāvasesā kesādayo catuvīsati, ādito tayo
analyzed: kadāci cittataḥ uppajjanataḥ avasesā ati vuttā avasesā kesa ādayaḥ catuvīsati āditaḥ tayo
translated: The temperature-and-consciousness-born are sometimes born of temperature and sometimes of consciousness.

original: tejokoṭṭhāsā, pañca vāyokoṭṭhāsā cāti dvattiṃsa. Sabbepīti te sabbepi kammādivasena
analyzed: tejo koṭṭhāsā pañca vāyo koṭṭhāsā ca ati dvattiṃsa sabbe pi iti te sabbe pi kamma ādi vasena
translated: The remaining twenty-four, namely, the hair of the head, etc., the first three elements, and the five kinds of air, are the thirty-two.🔽All these are of fourfold origination as well,

original: uppajjanato catusamuṭṭhānā. Kesādīnampi hi maṃsato avimuttabhāgo kammāhāracittasamuṭṭhānova hotīti.🔽352. Nānattekattatoti visesasāmaññato. Dhammānaṃ hi aññamaññaṃ visadisatā nānattaṃ,
analyzed: uppajjanataḥ catu samuṭṭhānā kesa ādīnam pi hi maṃsataḥ avimutta bhāgo kamma āhāra citta samuṭṭhānaḥ va hoti iti  nānatta ekattato ti visesa sāmaññato dhammānam hi aññam aññam visadisa tā nānattam
translated: because they are produced by kamma, etc., too. For the part of the hair, etc., that is not free from flesh is only of the kinds originating from kamma, nutriment, and consciousness.🔽As to variety and unity: as to particularity and generality. For the particularity of states is their variety,🔽their generality is their unity.

original: samānatā ekattaṃ. Sabbāsampīti catunnampi. Salakkhaṇāditoti sakaṃ lakkhaṇaṃ salakkhaṇaṃ,
analyzed: samāna tā ekattam sabbāsam pi iti catunnam pi salakkhaṇa āditaḥ ti sakam lakkhaṇam salakkhaṇam
translated: All four: all four kinds of origination. As to characteristic, etc.: the characteristic is the individual essence of each state.

original: tato salakkhaṇādito. Ādi-saddena rasapaccupaṭṭhānānaṃ viya mudusaṇhapharusabhāvādīnampi
analyzed: tatas sa lakkhaṇa āditaḥ ādi saddena rasa paccupaṭṭhānānam viya mudu saṇha pharusa bhāva ādīnam pi
translated: Then by characteristic, etc. The word “etc.” should be understood to include the characteristics of softness, hardness, and roughness, etc., which are manifested by the primary elements in the way described under the materiality aggregate as the form of modification.

original: saṅgaho daṭṭhabbo. “Kammasamuṭṭhānādivasena nānattabhūtāna”nti kasmā vuttaṃ, nanu
analyzed: saṅgahaḥ daṭṭhabbo kamma samuṭṭhāna ādi vasena nānatta bhūtānam ti kasmā vuttam nanu
translated: Why is it said, “They are of different natures as kamma-originated, etc.”?

original: kammasamuṭṭhānādivasena catunnaṃ dhātūnaṃ ekattaṃ hoti sādhāraṇattāti? Na, “aññā
analyzed: kamma samuṭṭhāna ādi vasena catunnam dhātūnam ekattam hoti sādhāraṇa ttā ati na aññā
translated: For is it not the case that the four primary elements are of the same nature as kamma-originated, etc., because of their commonality?🔽No, it is said thus because of the difference in the way of origination, etc.,

original: eva dhātuyo kammasamuṭṭhānā, aññā utuādisamuṭṭhānā”tiādikaṃ bhedaṃ sandhāya tathā
analyzed: eva dhātuyaḥ kamma samuṭṭhānāḥ aññāḥ utu ādi samuṭṭhānā ati ādikam bhedam sandhāya tathā
translated: as follows: “The primary elements are of one kind as kamma-originated, of another kind as temperature-originated, etc.”🔽The characteristic of being molested, the nature of being molested, is the characteristic of the primary elements.

original: vacanato. Etāsaṃ dhātūnaṃ. Ruppanalakkhaṇaṃ ruppanasabhāvaṃ. Kimpanetaṃ ruppanaṃ
analyzed: vacanataḥ etāsam dhātūnam ruppana lakkhaṇam ruppana sabhāvam kimpanetam ruppanam
translated: But what is this molestation?

original: nāma? Yā sītādivirodhipaccayasannipāte visadisuppatti, tasmiṃ vā sati yo vijjamānasseva
analyzed: nāma yā sītā ādi virodhi paccaya sannipāte tasmin vā sati yaḥ vijjamānassa eva
translated: It is the occurrence of a different state when the conditions of cold, etc., that are opposed to each other come together, or it is the fact that the cause of the occurrence of a different state exists when they do.🔽That is molestation.

original: visadisuppattiyā hetubhāvo, taṃ ruppanaṃ. Anatītattāti apariccajanato.
analyzed: visadisuppattiyāḥ hetu bhāvaḥ tam ruppanam an atīta ttā ati a pariccajanato
translated: The state of being not abandoned is the state of not being given up.

original: Mahantapātubhāvo cettha sasambhāradhātuvasena veditabbo, tathā mahāvikāratā mahābhūtasāmaññalakkhaṇadhātuvasena,
analyzed: mahanta pātubhāvo ca ittha sa sambhāra dhātu vasena veditabbo tathā mahā vikāra tā mahābhūta sāmañña lakkhaṇa dhātu vasena
translated: The great manifestation should be understood here as the primary elements with their conascent materiality; the great modification as the primary elements with their general characteristics.

original: mahāparihāratā, mahattavijjamānatā ca ubhayavasenāti. Bhūtasaddāpekkhāya “etānī”ti🔽napuṃsakaniddeso. Mahantāni pātubhūtāni anekasatasahassa rūpakalāpasaṅghāṭatāya samūhavasena,
analyzed: mahā parihāra tā mahatta vijjamāna tā ca ubhaya vasena ati bhūta sadda apekkhāya etāni iti  napuṃsaka niddesaḥ mahantāni pātubhūtāni aneka sata sahassa rūpa kalāpa saṅghāṭa tāya samūha vasena
translated: The neuter form “etānī” is used because of the expectation of the word “bhūta”.

original: santativasena ca aparimitaparimāṇānaṃ, anekayojanāyāmavitthārānañca uppajjanato.🔽Cattāri nahutānīti cattāri dasasahassāni. Devadānavādīnaṃ tigāvutādisarīravasena
analyzed: santati vasena ca uppajjanataḥ  cattāri nahutāni iti cattāri dasa sahassāni deva dānava ādīnam tigāvuta ādi sarīra vasena
translated: They are great because they are manifested as great, in the sense of a collection and in the sense of continuity, because of the arising of immeasurable dimensions and of many leagues in length and breadth.🔽Four nahutas means forty thousand.

original: mahantāni pātubhūtāni.
analyzed: mahantāni pātubhūtāni
translated: They are great because they are manifested as great in the sense of the bodies of the gods, demons, etc., which are three gavutas in size.

original: Tatthāyaṃ vacanattho – mahantāni bhūtāni jātāni nibbattānīti mahābhūtānīti. Anekābhūtavisesadassanena,
analyzed: tattha ayam vacana atthaḥ mahantāni bhūtāni jātāni nibbattāni iti mahābhūtāni iti aneka abhūta visesa dassanena
translated: Here is the word-meaning: great elements are so called because they are born, produced, arisen as great, as many.🔽Because of the seeing of many different elements,

original: anekabbhutadassanena ca anekacchariyadassanavasena mahanto abbhuto, mahantāni vā
analyzed: aneka abbhuta dassanena ca aneka chariya dassana vasena mahantaḥ abbhutaḥ mahantāni vā
translated: and because of the seeing of many wonders, they are great because of the seeing of many miracles.🔽Or alternatively, the great element is the magician, because of the state of being a great wonder, because of the state of being a great element here.

original: abhūtāni etthāti mahābhūto, māyākāro. Yakkhādayo jātivaseneva mahantā bhūtāti mahābhūtā,
analyzed: abhūtāni ettha ati mahābhūtaḥ māyākāraḥ yakkha ādayaḥ jāti vasena iva mahantā bhūtā ati mahābhūtā
translated: The ghosts, etc., are great elements because of the state of being great by way of species.

original: niruḷho vā ayaṃ tesu mahābhūtasaddo daṭṭhabbo. Pathavīādayo pana vañcakatāya, aniddisitabbaṭṭhānatāya
analyzed: niruḷhaḥ vā ayam tesu mahābhūta saddo daṭṭhabbo pathavī ādayaḥ pana vañcaka tāya a niddisitabba ṭṭhāna tāya
translated: Or else the term “great” should be taken as meaning “well known,” as in the passage, “The great are difficult to know” .🔽But the earth element, etc., are called “great” because of their multiplicity, because of their being the bases for the occurrence of many things, and because of their being the source of the great variety of the world’s sustenance, etc.

original: ca mahābhūtā viya mahābhūtā. Bhūtasaddassa ubhayaliṅgatāya napuṃsakatā katā. Tattha🔽vañcakatā sayaṃ anīlādisabhāvāni hutvā nīlādisabhāvassa upaṭṭhāpanaṃ, anitthipurisādisabhāvāneva🔽ca hutvā itthipurisādiākārassa upaṭṭhāpanaṃ. Tathā aññamaññassa anto, bahi ca aṭṭhitānaṃyeva
analyzed: ca mahābhūtāḥ viya mahābhūtāḥ bhūta saddassa ubhaya liṅga tāya napuṃsaka tā katā tattha  vañcaka tā sayam a nīla ādi sabhāvāni hutvā nīla ādi sabhāvassa upaṭṭhāpanam anitthi purisa ādi sabhāvānaṃ eva  ca hutvā itthi purisa ādi ākārassa upaṭṭhāpanam tathā aññamaññassa antar bahi ca aṭṭhitānam yeva
translated: The earth element, etc., are called “great primaries” because they are great and because they are primaries. The word “great” is a common attribute, and the word “primaries” is a common noun.🔽The earth element, etc., are great because they are the bases for the occurrence of many things. They are primaries because they are the source of the great variety of the world’s sustenance, etc.🔽The earth element, etc., are great because they are the bases for the occurrence of many things. They are primaries because they are the source of the great variety of the world’s sustenance, etc.

original: aññamaññaṃ nissāya avaṭṭhānato aniddisitabbaṭṭhānatā. Yadi hi imā dhātuyo aññamaññassa
analyzed: aññamaññam nissāya avaṭṭhānataḥ a niddisitabba ṭṭhāna tā yadi hi imāḥ dhātuyaḥ aññamaññassa
translated: The earth element, etc., are great because they are the bases for the occurrence of many things. They are primaries because they are the source of the great variety of the world’s sustenance, etc.

original: anto ṭhitā, na sakiccakarā siyuṃ aññamaññānuppavesanato, atha bahi ṭhitā vinibbhuttā🔽siyuṃ. Tathā sati avinibbhuttavādo hāyeyya, tasmā na niddisitabbaṭṭhānā. Evaṃ santepi
analyzed: antar ṭhitāḥ na sa kicca karāḥ siyum aññamañña an uppavesanataḥ atha bahi ṭhitāḥ vinibbhuttā 🔽siyum tathā sati avinibbhutta vādaḥ hāyeyya tasmā na niddisitabba ṭṭhānāḥ evam sante pi
translated: The earth element, etc., are great because they are the bases for the occurrence of many things. They are primaries because they are the source of the great variety of the world’s sustenance, etc.🔽The earth element, etc., are great because they are the bases for the occurrence of many things. They are primaries because they are the source of the great variety of the world’s sustenance, etc.🔽The earth element, etc., are great because they are the bases for the occurrence of many things. They are primaries because they are the source of the great variety of the world’s sustenance, etc.🔽The earth element, etc., are great because they are the bases for the occurrence of many things. They are primaries because they are the source of the great variety of the world’s sustenance, etc.🔽The earth element, etc., are great because they are the bases for the occurrence of many things. They are primaries because they are the source of the great variety of the world’s sustenance, etc.

original: patiṭṭhānādinā yathāsakaṃ kiccavisesena sesānaṃ tiṇṇaṃ tiṇṇaṃ upakārikā honti, yena
analyzed: patiṭṭhāna ādinā yathāsakam kicca visesena sesānam tiṇṇam tiṇṇam upakārikāḥ honti yena
translated: They are helpful to the remaining three each in its own function, beginning with the support,

original: sahajātādinā paccayena paccayā honti. Tenāha “na ca aññamaññaṃ nissāya na tiṭṭhantī”ti.
analyzed: sahajāta ādinā paccayena paccayāḥ honti tena āha na ca aññam aññam nissāya na tiṭṭhanti iti
translated: by means of which they are conditions for each other as conascent, etc., conditions. That is why he said, “They do not stand without mutual reliance.”

original: Manāpehīti manoharehi cāturiyavantehi. Vaṇṇasaṇṭhānavikkhepehīti kāḷasāmatādivaṇṇehi,
analyzed: manāpehi iti manoharehi cāturiyavantehi vaṇṇa saṇṭhāna vikkhepehi iti kāḷa sāmata ādi vaṇṇehi
translated: “Agreeable” means delightful. “By their colour, shape, and size” means by their colour such as black and white,

original: puthulavivarakisatādisaṇṭhānehi, hatthabhamukādivikkhepehi ca. Sarasalakkhaṇanti
analyzed: puthula vivara kisata ādi saṇṭhānehi hattha bhamuka ādi vikkhepehi ca sa rasa lakkhaṇanti
