translated: by their shape such as broad, narrow, long, and short, and by their size such as small, medium, and large. “By their characteristics” means

original: sabhāvabhūtaṃ lakkhaṇaṃ, sakiccakaṃ vā sabhāvaṃ.🔽Mahāparihāratoti ettha vacanatthaṃ vadanto āha “mahantehi…pe… bhūtāni, mahāparihārāni
analyzed: sabhāva bhūtam lakkhaṇam sa kiccakam vā sabhāvam  ettha vacana attham vadantaḥ āha bhūtāni mahā parihārāni
translated: by their individual essences or by their individual functions.

original: vā bhūtānī”ti. Tattha pacchimatthe purimapade uttarapadassa parihāra-saddassa lopaṃ
analyzed: vā bhūtāni iti tattha pacchimatthe purima pade uttara padassa parihāra saddassa lopaṃ
translated: “By their great service” : explaining the meaning of the words, he says, “because they are great in service to the great primaries, or because the great primaries are their great service.” Herein, the word “service” is dropped from the second “great primaries” and the compound is resolved

original: katvā “mahābhūtānī”ti vuttaṃ.
analyzed: katvā mahābhūtāni iti vuttam
translated: “great primaries.”

original: Tathā hīti tato eva vikārassa mahantattā evāti taṃ vikāraṃ dassetuṃ “bhūmito”tiādi
analyzed: tathā hi iti tatas eva vikārassa mahantattā eva ati tam vikāram dassetum bhūmitaḥ itiādi
translated: “Because of that” : because of that very great modification, thus, in order to show that modification, he said “from the earth” and so on.

original: vuttaṃ. Tattha accimatoti aggissa. Koṭisatasahassaṃ ekaṃ koṭisatasahassekaṃ cakkavāḷanti🔽taṃ sabbaṃ āṇākhettabhāvena ekaṃ katvā vadati. Vilīyatīti vipattikarameghābhivuṭṭhena
analyzed: vuttam tattha accimataḥ ti aggissa koṭi sata sahassam ekam koṭi sata sahassa ekam cakkavāḷanti  tam sabbam āṇā khetta bhāvena ekam katvā vadati vilīyati iti vipatti kara megha abhivuṭṭhena
translated: “From the flame” means from the fire. “A hundred thousand koṭis” means one hundred thousand koṭis. “One world-sphere” means one world-sphere.

original: khārudakena lavaṇaṃ viya vilayaṃ gacchati viddhaṃsati. Kupitenāti khubhitena. Vikīratīti
analyzed: khāru dakena lavaṇam vilayam gacchati kupitena ati khubhitena vikīrati iti
translated: He says this, taking all of it as one, by way of the state of being something that can be ordered around. “Dissolves” means it goes to destruction, it is destroyed, by the water of caustic soda that falls from the clouds of the calamity. “Is churned up” means it is churned. “Is scattered” means

original: vidhamati viddhaṃsati.
analyzed: vidhamati
translated: it is dispersed, it is destroyed.

original: Anupādinnesu vikāramahattaṃ dassetvā upādinnesu dassento “patthaddho”tiādimāha. Tattha🔽kaṭṭhamukhena vāti vā-saddo upamattho. Yathā kaṭṭhamukhena sappena ḍaṭṭho patthaddho🔽hoti, evaṃ pathavīdhātuppakopena so kāyo kaṭṭhamukheva hoti, kaṭṭhamukhamukhagato
analyzed: an upādinnesu vikāra mahattam dassetvā upādinnesu dassentaḥ patthaddho ti ādim āha tattha  kaṭṭha mukhena vā ati vāsaddaḥ upamatthaḥ yathā kaṭṭha mukhena sappena ḍaṭṭhaḥ patthaddhaḥ  hoti evam pathavī dhātu pakopena so kāyo kaṭṭha mukhā iva hoti kaṭṭha mukha mukha gato
translated: Having shown the great change in the undigested food, he said “is distended” in order to show the change in the digested food. Herein,🔽the word vā means “like.” Just as a person bitten by a snake in the mouth of a tree becomes distended,

original: viya patthaddho hotīti attho. Atha vā vā-saddo avadhāraṇattho. So “pathavīdhātuppakopena
analyzed: viya patthaddhaḥ hoti iti atthaḥ atha vā vā saddaḥ avadhāraṇa atthaḥ saḥ pathavī dhātu pakopena
translated: so too, by the disturbance of the earth element, that body becomes like the mouth of a tree, and the meaning is that it becomes distended, as if it had gone into the mouth of the tree. Or else, the word vā has the meaning of “only.” It is only by the disturbance of the earth element

original: vā”ti evaṃ ānetvā sambandhitabbo. Ayañhettha attho – kaṭṭhamukhena ḍaṭṭhopi kāyo🔽pathavīdhātuppakopeneva patthaddho hoti, tasmā pathavīdhātuyā aviyutto so kāyo sabbadā🔽kaṭṭhamukhamukhagato viya hotīti. Vā-saddo vā aniyamattho, tatrāyamattho – kaṭṭhamukhena
analyzed: vā ti evam ānetvā sambandhitabbaḥ ayam ha ittha atthaḥ kaṭṭha mukhena ḍaṭṭhaḥ api kāyaḥ  pathavī dhātu pakopena iva patthaddho hoti tasmā pathavī dhātuyā a viyuttaḥ so kāyo sabbadā  kaṭṭha mukha mukha gataḥ viya hoti iti vā saddaḥ vā aniyama atthaḥ tatra ayam attho kaṭṭha mukhena
translated: and so on. The meaning here is this. The body is parched by the earth element’s disturbance even when it is burned by a fire-stick. Therefore that body is never free from the earth element, like the man with the fire-stick in his mouth.

original: ḍaṭṭho kāyo patthaddho hoti vā, na vā hoti mantāgadavasena, pathavīdhātuppakopena🔽pana mantāgadarahito so kāyo kaṭṭhamukhamukhagato viya hoti ekantapatthaddhoti.🔽Pūtiyoti kuthito. Santattoti sabbaso tatto samuppannadāho. Sañchinnoti samantato🔽chinno paramāṇubhedasañcuṇṇo āyasmato upasenattherassa sarīraṃ viya. Mahāvikārāni
analyzed: ḍaṭṭhaḥ kāyo patthaddhaḥ hoti vā na vā hoti mantā gada vasena pathavī dhātu pakopena  pana mantāgada rahito so kāyo kaṭṭha mukha mukha gataḥ viya hoti ekanta patthaddho ti  pūtiyaḥ ti kuthitaḥ santatto ti sabbaso tatto samuppanna dāho sañchinnaḥ ti samantataḥ  chinnaḥ paramāṇu bheda sañcuṇṇaḥ āyasmataḥ upasena therassa sarīram viya mahā vikārāni
translated: The word “or” has the meaning of non-restriction. The meaning here is this. The body is parched by the earth element’s disturbance whether or not it is burned by a fire-stick, according to whether or not it has the condition of a dry stick. But the body that is without the condition of a dry stick is like the man with the fire-stick in his mouth, and it is parched by the earth element alone.🔽“Rotten” means decayed. “Inflamed” means all inflamed, with heat arisen all over. “Cut up” means cut up all over, reduced to atoms, like the body of the venerable elder Upasena.

original: bhūtānīti mahāvikāravantāni bhūtāni mahābhūtānīti purimapade uttarapadalopena niddeso
analyzed: bhūtāni iti mahā vikāravantāni bhūtāni mahābhūtāni iti purima pade uttara pada lopena niddesaḥ
translated: “The great disturbances” are the great disturbances, i.e. the great disturbances of the great elements. The demonstrative pronoun “this” in the expression “this body” is omitted, as in the expression “the great disturbances of the great elements.”

original: daṭṭhabbo. “Pathavī”tiādinā sabbalokassa pākaṭānipi vipallāsaṃ muñcitvā yathāsabhāvato
analyzed: daṭṭhabbo pathavī iti ādinā sabba lokassa vipallāsam muñcitvā yathā sabhāvato
translated: “They are to be seen” means that they are to be seen as they really are.🔽“They are great” means that they are not discerned by one who has not made a great effort to discern them as they really are, even though they are obvious to all the world by such terms as “earth,” etc.,

original: pariggaṇhane mahantena vāyāmena vinā na pariggaṇhantīti duviññeyyasabhāvattā “mahantānī”ti
analyzed: pariggaṇhane mahantena vā āyāmena vinā na pariggaṇhanti iti du viññeyya sabhāva ttā mahantāni iti
translated: and are free from the perversion of perception. They are “great” because they are hard to discern.

original: vuccanti. Tāni hi suviññeyyāni. “Amahantānī”ti mantvā ṭhitā tesaṃ duppariggahataṃ🔽disvā “aho mahantāni etānī”ti jānātīti mahābhūtekadesatādīhi vā kāraṇehi mahābhūtāni.
analyzed: vuccanti tāni hi su viññeyyāni amahantāni iti mantvā ṭhitā tesam duppariggaha tataṃ  disvā aho mahantāni etāni iti jānāti iti vā kāraṇehi mahābhūtāni
translated: For they are easy to discern, and one who thinks, “They are not great,” sees that they are hard to discern,

original: Etā hi dhātuyo mahābhūtekadesato, mahābhūtasāmaññato, mahābhūtasannissayato, mahābhūtabhāvato,🔽mahābhūtapariyosānato cāti imehipi kāraṇehi “mahābhūtānī”ti vuccanti.
analyzed: etāḥ hi dhātuyaḥ mahābhūta ekadesataḥ mahābhūta sāmaññataḥ mahābhūta sannissayataḥ mahābhūta bhāvato  mahābhūta pariyosānato ca ati imehi pi kāraṇehi mahābhūtāni iti vuccanti
translated: and he knows, “They are great.” Or alternatively, the great primaries are so called for the following reasons: because of the great elements’ being a part, because of their similarity to the great elements, because of their being the support for the great elements, because of their being the essence of the great elements,🔽and because of their being the culmination of the great elements.

original: Tattha mahābhūtekadesatoti “bhūtamidanti, bhikkhave, samanupassathā”tiādīsu hi avisesena🔽khandhapañcakaṃ “bhūta”nti vuccati. Tattha yadidaṃ kāmabhave, rūpabhave, pañcavokārabhave,
analyzed: tattha mahābhūta ekadesataḥ ti bhūtam idam ti bhikkhave samanupassatha atiādīsu hi avisesena 🔽khandha pañcakam bhūtanti vuccati tattha yat idam kāma bhave rūpa bhave pañcavokāra bhave
translated: Herein, because of their being a part of the great elements is illustrated by the passage: “Monks, you should look upon the five aggregates as an enemy” , where the five aggregates are called “great elements” without distinction.🔽Herein, the “great elements” are the four great primaries in the five-constituent becoming, the four great primaries in the four-constituent becoming, and the four great primaries in the one-constituent becoming.

original: ekacce ca saññībhave pavattaṃ khandhapañcakaṃ, taṃ mahāvisayatāya “mahābhūta”nti
analyzed: ekacce ca saññībhave pavattam khandha pañcakam tam mahā visaya tāya mahābhūtan ti
translated: And the five aggregates occurring in some kinds of percipient becoming are also called “great primaries” because they have a great scope.

original: vattabbataṃ arahati. Pathavīādayo pana catasso dhātuyo tassa mahābhūtassa ekadesabhūtā🔽“mahābhūtā”ti vuccanti. Samudāyesu hi pavattavohārā avayavesupi dissanti yathā “samuddo
analyzed: vattabba tam arahati pathavī ādayo pana catasso dhātuyo tassa mahābhūtassa eka desa bhūtā  mahābhūtā ti vuccanti samudāyesu hi pavatta vohārāḥ avayavesu pi dissanti yathā samuddaḥ
translated: But the four elements, earth, and so on, are called “great primaries” because they are the primary states of that great primary.🔽For designations of what is a collection are seen in the parts too, as in the case of the expressions “The ocean is seen” and “The cloth is burnt.”

original: diṭṭho, paṭo daḍḍho”ti ca. Mahābhūtasamaññatoti tadadhīnavuttitāya bhavanti ettha🔽upādārūpānīti bhūtāni, pathavīādayo catasso dhātuyo. Sā panāyametāsu bhūtasamaññā
analyzed: diṭṭhaḥ paṭaḥ daḍḍhaḥ ti ca mahābhūta samaññatā uti tad adhīna vutti tāya bhavanti ettha  upādā rūpāni iti bhūtāni pathavī ādayo catasso dhātuyo sā pana ayam etāsu bhūta samaññā
translated: The meaning of “great primaries” is this: they are primaries because the derived materiality occurs dependent on them,🔽and they are great because of the greatness of their functions.🔽This designation of “great primaries” is not erroneous as to the derived materiality’s occurrence for a different purpose.

original: anaññatthavuttitāya upādārūpānaṃ aviparītaṭṭhā, lokassa cetā bahūpakārā, cakkhusamuddādīnaṃ🔽nissayabhūtā cāti mahantāni bhūtānīti samaññāyiṃsu. Mahābhūtasannissayatoti mahantānaṃ
analyzed: anaññattha vutti tāya upādā rūpānaṃ aviparīta ṭṭhā lokassa cetā bahu upakārā cakkhu samudda ādīnam  nissaya bhūtā ca ati mahantāni bhūtāni iti samaññāyiṃsu mahābhūta sannissayato ti mahantānam
translated: It is very helpful to the world, and it is the support of the eye-ocean, and so on.🔽So they are called “great primaries” .

original: mahānubhāvānaṃ mahāsammatamandhātuppabhutīnaṃ raññaṃ, sakkādīnaṃ devānaṃ, vepacittiādīnaṃ
analyzed: mahā anubhāvānam mahā sammata mandhātu ppabhutīnam raññam sakka ādīnam devānam vepacitti ādīnam
translated: The meaning of “great primaries as support” is this: they are great primaries because they are the support of great kings of great power such as Mahā-Sammata and Mahā-Sudassana, of great gods such as Sakka, and of great nāga kings such as Vepacitti.

original: asurānaṃ, mahābrahmādīnaṃ brahmānaṃ, guṇato vā mahantānaṃ buddhānaṃ, paccekabuddhānaṃ,
analyzed: mahābrahma ādīnam brahmānam guṇataḥ vā mahantānam buddhānam paccekabuddhānam
translated: Or they are great because they are great in the sense of being of great account among the asuras, the Brahmās beginning with Mahā-Brahmā, the Enlightened Ones, the Hermit Enlightened Ones,🔽and the disciples, or because they are great in the sense of being great in the physical bodies of all creatures.

original: sāvakānaṃ upādāyupādāya vā sabbesampi bhūtānaṃ sattānaṃ nissayabhūtatāya mahantā
analyzed: sāvakānam upādāya upādāya vā sabbesam pi bhūtānam sattānam nissaya bhūta tāya mahantā
translated: They are great because they are the support of the great,🔽or they are great because they are great in the sense of the great elements.🔽For their bodies are made up of the four great primaries.

original: bhūtā etesūti mahābhūtā. Cātumahābhūtiko hi nesaṃ kāyoti. Mahābhūtabhāvatoti bahubhūtabhāvato.
analyzed: bhūtāḥ etesu uti mahābhūtā cātumahābhūtikaḥ hi mahābhūta bhāvataḥ uti bahu bhūta bhāvataḥ
translated: In the sense of being many elements: in the sense of being many elements.

original: Ayaṃ hi mahā-saddo “mahājano sannipatito”tiādīsu bahubhāve dissati. Pathavīādayo
analyzed: ayam hi mahā saddaḥ mahā janaḥ sannipatito ti ādīsu bahu bhāve dissati pathavī ādayo
translated: For this word mahā is found in the sense of many in such passages as “Great crowds have assembled” .🔽And the earth element, etc., occur in an individual’s body with an incalculable differentiation.

original: ca dhātuyo ekasmimpi attabhāve aparimeyyappabhedā pavattanti. Tasmā mahantā bahū🔽anekasatasahassappabhedā bhūtāti mahābhūtā. Mahābhūtapariyosānatoti mahābhūtassa
analyzed: ca dhātuyaḥ ekasmim pi atta bhāve aparimeyya pabhedā pavattanti tasmā mahantā bahū  aneka sata sahassa ppabhedāḥ bhūtā ati mahābhūtāḥ mahābhūta pariyosānato ti mahābhūtassa
translated: So they are great because they are many,🔽because they are many with an incalculable differentiation of hundreds and thousands.

original: vasena pariyosānappattito.🔽“Kālo ghasati bhūtāni, sabbāneva sahattanā;
analyzed: vasena pariyosāna pattito  kālaḥ ghasati bhūtāni sabbān eva sahattanā
translated: In the sense of the culmination of the great: in the sense of reaching the culmination by means of the great.

original: Yo ca kālaghaso bhūto, sa bhūtapacaniṃ pacī”ti. –
analyzed: yaḥ ca kālaghasaḥ sa bhūtapacanim pacīti
translated: “Time devours all creatures, Each in its turn, with its jaws; But time, devoured by death, Is itself devoured by death” .

original: Hi evamādīsu khīṇāsavo “bhūto”ti vutto. So hi ucchinnabhavanettikatāya āyatiṃ appaṭisandhikattā
analyzed: hi evamādīsu khīṇa āsavaḥ bhūtaḥ ti vutto saḥ hi ucchinna bhava nettika tāya āyatim appaṭisandhika ttā
translated: For in such passages as “The canker-free bhikkhu is called a being” , the canker-free bhikkhu is called “a being” . For he is called “a being” absolutely because he has cut off the process of becoming by not taking up any new existence;

original: ekantato “bhūto”ti vuccati, na itare, bhavissantīti vohāraṃ anatītattā. Bhūto eva
analyzed: ekantataḥ bhūto ti vuccati na itare bhavissanti iti vohāram anatīta ttā bhūto eva
translated: the others are not so called because they have not yet passed beyond the usage of being called “beings.”

original: idha pūjāvasena “mahābhūto”ti vutto yathā “mahākhīṇāsavo, mahāmoggallāno”ti ca. Imāsañca🔽dhātūnaṃ anādimati saṃsāre pabandhavasena pavattamānānaṃ yathāvuttassa mahābhūtasseva
analyzed: pūjā vasena mahābhūto ti vutto yathā mahā khīṇāsavaḥ mahā moggallānaḥ iti ca imāsam ca  dhātūnam anādimati saṃsāre pabandha vasena pavattamānānam yathā vuttassa mahābhūtassa iva
translated: The “great being” is called “great” here in the sense of being worthy of worship, as in the expressions “great canker-free one” and “great Moggallāna.”🔽And the end of the continuity of the great being described above is reached only in the continuity of the great primaries, not elsewhere, because these elements occur in the beginningless and endless round of becoming as the cause for the arising of the great being.

original: santāne pariyosānappatti, nāññatra. Tasmā mahābhūte bhūtā pariyosānaṃ pattāti mahābhūtā🔽purimapade bhūta-saddassa lopaṃ katvā. Evametā dhātuyo mahābhūtekadesatādīhi mahābhūtāti
analyzed: santāne pariyosāna ppatti na aññatra tasmai mahābhūte bhūtā pariyosānam pattā ati mahābhūtā  purima pade bhūta saddassa lopam katvā evam etāḥ dhātuyaḥ mahābhūta ika desa tā ādīhi
translated: Therefore the great primaries are so called because the primaries reach their end in the great primaries,🔽the word “bhūta” being dropped in the second instance as in the expression “great canker-free one.”🔽This is how the elements should be understood as “great primaries” in the sense of being a part of the great primaries, and so on.

original: veditabbā. Pathavīādīnaṃ kakkhaḷapaggharaṇādivisesalakkhaṇasamaṅgitā apariccattadhātulakkhaṇānaṃyevāti
analyzed: veditabbā pathavī ādīnam kakkhaḷa paggharaṇa ādi visesa lakkhaṇa samaṅgi tā a pariccatta dhātu lakkhaṇānam yeva ati
translated: The individual essences of the great primaries are not different from the individual essences of the elements, earth, and so on, which are respectively hardness, and so on.

original: āha “dhātulakkhaṇaṃ anatītattā”ti. Na hi sāmaññapariccāgena viseso, visesanirapekkhaṃ
analyzed: āha dhātu lakkhaṇam anatīta ttā ti na hi sāmañña pariccāgena visesaḥ visesa nirapekkham
translated: He says, “Because of the non-transcending of the characteristic of the elements.” For the general is not distinguished by the abandoning of the particular,

original: vā sāmaññaṃ pavattati. Tathā hi vadanti –
analyzed: vā sāmaññam pavattati tathā hi vadanti
translated: or the general occurs without regard to the particular. For it is said:

original: “Tamatthāpekkhato bhedaṃ, sasāmaññaṃ jahāti no;
analyzed: tam attha apekkhataḥ bhedam sa sāmaññam jahāti no
translated: “When the particular is sought, the general abandons the particular;

original: Gaṇhāti saṃsayuppādā, samevekatthakaṃ dvaya”nti.
analyzed: gaṇhāti saṃsaya uppādā
translated: When doubt arises, the two are the same in the one meaning.”

original: Salakkhaṇadhāraṇena cāti yena salakkhaṇadhāraṇena “dhātuyo”ti vuccanti, teneva “dhammā”tipi🔽vuccanti ubhayathāpi nissattanijjīvatāya eva vibhāvanato. Tenevāha – “chadhāturoyaṃ
analyzed: sa lakkhaṇa dhāraṇena ca ati yena sa lakkhaṇa dhāraṇena dhātuyaḥ ti vuccanti tena iva dhamma atipi  vuccanti ubhayathā api nissatta nijjīva tāyai eva vibhāvanataḥ tena iva āha cha dhāturaḥ oyam
translated: And by the bearing of the specific characteristic: by the bearing of the specific characteristic by which they are called “elements,” by that very thing they are called “mental data” too,

original: bhikkhu puriso, dhammesu dhammānupassī viharatī”ti ca. Arūpānaṃ khaṇato rūpānaṃ khaṇassa
analyzed: bhikkhu purisaḥ dhammesu dhamma anupassī viharati iti ca arūpānam khaṇataḥ rūpānam khaṇassa
translated: because of the demonstration of their soullessness and insubstantiality in both cases. Hence it is said, “This person, bhikkhu, is six elements, he dwells contemplating mental data as mental data” .🔽As to the non-transcending of the moment of the materiality, he says, “in conformity with its own moment.”

original: nātiittaratāyāha “attano khaṇānurūpa”nti. Dharaṇenāti ṭhānena, pavattanenāti attho.
analyzed: na ati ittaratāya āha attano khaṇa anurūpam ti dharaṇena ati ṭhānena pavattanena ati attho
translated: As to bearing: as to steadying, as to occurrence, is the meaning.

original: Khayaṭṭhenāti khaṇabhaṅgutāya. Bhayaṭṭhenāti udayavayapaṭipīḷanādinā sappaṭibhayatāya.
analyzed: khaya ṭṭhena ati khaṇa bhaṅgu tāya bhaya ṭṭhena ati udaya vaya paṭipīḍana ādinā sa paṭibhaya tāya
translated: As to the meaning of destruction: as to momentariness. As to the meaning of terror: as to being fearful with the oppression of uprising and subsidence, and so on.

original: Asārakaṭṭhenāti attasāravirahena.
analyzed: asāra kaṭṭhena ati atta sāra virahena
translated: As to the meaning of insubstantiality: as to the absence of a self that is a substance.

original: 353. Sahuppannāva etāti etā catasso dhātuyo saha uppannāva saha pavattamānāva samānakāle🔽labbhamānāpi avakaṃsato sabbapariyantime utucittāhārasamuṭṭhānesu suddhaṭṭhake, kammajesu
analyzed: saha uppannāva etā ati etā catasso dhātuyo saha uppannāva saha pavattamānāva samāna kāle  labbhamānā api avakaṃsato utu citta āhāra samuṭṭhānesu suddhaṭṭhake kamma jesu
translated: They are only found together, these four elements are only found arisen together, occurring together, existing at the same time.🔽Though they are found thus, still, in the case of the four primary elements that are originated by temperature and by kamma-born nutriment, which are the utmost limit of what is possible, they are not unmixed, not separate, not definable as to location,

original: jīvitanavaketi ekekasmiṃ suddhaṭṭhakādikalāpepi padesena avinibbhuttā visuṃ visuṃ🔽aniddisitabbaṭṭhānatāya. Yattha hi tissannaṃ dhātūnaṃ patiṭṭhāvasena pathavī, tattheva
analyzed: jīvita navaka iti ekekasmin suddhaṭṭhaka ādi kalāpe pi padesena avinibbhuttā visum visum  a niddisitabba ṭṭhāna tāya yattha hi tissannam dhātūnam patiṭṭhā vasena pathavī tattha eva
translated: in the sense of this or that part, in each group consisting of the four primary elements, etc.,

original: tassā ābandhanaparipācanasamudīraṇavasena itarā. Esa nayo sesāsupi.
analyzed: ābandhana paripācana samudīraṇa vasena itarā nayaḥ sesāsu pi
translated: For where there is the earth element as the support of the other three elements, there too there is the other three elements as the binding, the ripening, and the distending. The same method applies in the case of the other three elements.

original: 354. Purimā dve garukattā sabhāgā aññamaññanti adhippāyo. Ettha ca nanu pathaviyāpi🔽lahubhāvo atthi. Tathā hi sā “kakkhaḷaṃ mudukaṃ saṇhaṃ pharusaṃ garukaṃ lahuka”nti
analyzed: purimā dve sabhāgā aññam aññanti adhippāyaḥ ettha ca nanu pathaviyā api  lahu bhāvaḥ atthi tathā hi sā kakkhaḷam mudukam saṇham pharusam garukam lahukanti
translated: The intention is that the first two are homogeneous because of their heaviness.🔽But has not the earth element also lightness? For it is described thus: “Hard, stiff, rough, solid, heavy, light” .🔽And lightness is found in water too?

original: niddiṭṭhā, āpepi lahubhāvo labbhatevāti? Na, nippariyāyagarubhāvassa adhippetattā.
analyzed: niddiṭṭhāḥ lahu bhāvaḥ labbha tā iva ati na nippariyāya garu bhāvassa adhippeta ttā
translated: No; for heaviness in the ultimate sense is intended here.

original: Garubhāvo eva hi pathavīdhātuyā garutaraṃ upādāya lahubhāvoti pariyāyena vutto sītabhāvo
analyzed: garu bhāvaḥ eva hi pathavī dhātuyāḥ garutaram upādāya lahu bhāvaḥ ti pariyāyena vutto sīta bhāvo
translated: For heaviness is said figuratively by a figure of speech in the way beginning, “The heaviness of the earth principle is the heaviest, and lightness is the lightest” .🔽Just as coolness is said of the fire principle.

original: viya tejodhātuyā. Yadi evaṃ rūpassa lahutāti kathaṃ? Ayampi vuttanayā eva lahutākāraṃ
analyzed: viya tejaḥ dhātuyā yadi evam rūpassa lahu tā ati katham ayam pi vutta nayā eva lahu tā ākāram
translated: If that is so, then how is it that lightness is a characteristic of materiality? This is also found by a figure of speech in the way beginning, “Lightness is the lightness of the characteristic of materiality” .

original: upādāya labbhanato. Na hi paricchedavikāralakkhaṇāni paramatthato labbhanti nipphannarūpānaṃ
analyzed: upādāya labbhanataḥ na hi pariccheda vikāra lakkhaṇāni paramatthataḥ labbhanti
translated: For the characteristic of delimitation and the characteristic of change are not found in the ultimate sense, because they are not the individual essences of the different states of materiality that has arisen.

original: avatthāvisesasabhāvato. Tasmā paramatthasiddhaṃ garubhāvaṃ sandhāya vuttaṃ “purimā🔽dve garukattā sabhāgā”ti. “Tathā”ti padena “sabhāgā”ti imamatthaṃ upasaṃharati. “Dve”ti
analyzed: avatthā avisesa sabhāvato tasmā paramattha siddham garu bhāvam sandhāya vuttam purimā  dve sabhāgā ati tathā ati padena sabhāgā ati imam attham upasaṃharati dve iti
translated: So it is said with reference to the heaviness that is established in the ultimate sense that the first two are similar in being heavy.🔽The word “similarly” brings in the meaning of “similar” .

original: pana idaṃ yathā “purimā”ti ettha, evaṃ “pacchimā”ti etthāpi ānetvā sambandhitabbaṃ.🔽Visabhāgā garukalahukabhāvatoti adhippāyo. Yathā ca garukalahukabhāvehi, evaṃ peyyabhāvāpeyyabhāvehi
analyzed: pana idam yathā purimā ati ettha evam pacchimā ati ettha api ānetvā sambandhitabbam  visabhāgāḥ garuka lahuka bhāvato ti adhippāyaḥ yathā ca garuka lahuka bhāvehi evam peyya bhāva apeyya bhāvehi
translated: And the word “two” should be construed with the word “last” in the way in which it is construed with the word “first” .🔽The intention is that they are dissimilar because of the difference of heaviness and lightness.

original: ca sabhāgavisabhāgatā yojetabbā.
analyzed: ca sabhāga visabhāga tā yojetabbā
translated: And just as they are similar and dissimilar because of the difference of heaviness and lightness, so they are similar and dissimilar because of the difference of fluidity and non-fluidity.

original: 355. Ajjhattikā heṭṭhā vuttaajjhattikā, sattasantānapariyāpannāti attho. Viññāṇavatthu
analyzed: ajjhattikā heṭṭhā vutta ajjhattikā satta santāna pariyāpannā ti atthaḥ viññāṇa vatthu
translated: Internal means the internal already mentioned, that is to say, what is included in one’s own continuity.

original: viññattiindriyānanti cakkhādīnaṃ channaṃ viññāṇavatthūnaṃ, dvinnaṃ viññattīnaṃ, itthipurisindriyajīvitindriyānañca.
analyzed: viññatti indriyānanti cakkha ādīnam channam viññāṇa vatthūnam dvinnam viññattīnam itthi purisa indriya jīvitindriyānan ca
translated: The bases of consciousness and the two kinds of intimation and the sex faculties and the life faculty.

original: Ye pana “viññāṇavatthūti hadayavatthu gahita”nti vadanti, tesaṃ indriya-ggahaṇena
analyzed: ye pana viññāṇa vatthu uti hadaya vatthu gahitan ti vadanti tesam indriya ggahaṇena
translated: But those who say that the “bases of consciousness” are the heart- basis are to be told that by the words “the faculties”🔽the eight material faculties are included too.

original: aṭṭhannampi rūpindriyānaṃ gahaṇaṃ veditabbaṃ. “Vuttaviparītappakārā”ti idaṃ bāhirānaṃ🔽dhātūnaṃ yathā sabbaso viññāṇavatthuviññattiindriyānaṃ anissayatā ca iriyāpathaviraho
analyzed: aṭṭhannam pi rūpindriyānam gahaṇam veditabbam vutta viparīta ppakārā ti idam bāhirānam  dhātūnam yathā sabbasas viññāṇa vatthu viññatti indriyānam anissaya tā ca iriyāpatha viraho
translated: The external elements are the opposite in the way stated.🔽The external elements are the opposite of the internal elements in the way stated. That is, they are not the support of the bases of consciousness, intimation, and faculties. They are not postures.

original: ca vuttavipariyāyo, evaṃ catusamuṭṭhānatāpīti katvā vuttaṃ, na lakkhaṇarūpassa viya
analyzed: ca vutta vipariyāyaḥ evam catu samuṭṭhāna tā api iti katvā vuttam na lakkhaṇa rūpassa viya
translated: They are of fourfold origination.🔽They are not derived from food.

original: kutocipi samuṭṭhānassa abhāvato utusamuṭṭhānatāya tāsaṃ. Lahutādinissayatāpi ajjhattikānaṃ
analyzed: kutocipi samuṭṭhānassa abhāvataḥ utu samuṭṭhāna tāya tāsam lahu tā ādi nissaya tā api ajjhattikānam
translated: They are not the support of lightness, etc.

original: dhātūnaṃ vattabbā, na vā vattabbā. Viññatti-ggahaṇaṃ hi lakkhaṇanti.🔽356. Itarāhīti āpotejovāyudhātūhi. Ekasaṅgahāti sajātisaṅgahena ekasaṅgahā. Samānajātiyānaṃ hi saṅgaho sahajātisaṅgaho. Tenāha “samuṭṭhānanānattābhāvato”ti.
analyzed: dhātūnam vattabbāḥ na vā vattabbāḥ viññatti ggahaṇam hi lakkhaṇan ti  itarāhi iti āpaḥ tejaḥ vāyu dhātūhi eka saṅgahā ati sajāti saṅgahena eka saṅgahā samāna jāti yānam hi saṅgahaḥ saha jāti saṅgaho tena āha samuṭṭhāna nānatta abhāvato ti
translated: and the elements should be said not to be, because the act of intimation is a characteristic.🔽The rest are not, i.e. the water, fire and air elements. They are included in one, i.e. they are included in one by inclusion in a single class. For the inclusion of what is of the same class is inclusion in a single class. Hence he said, “because there is no difference in their origination.”

original: 357. Tiṇṇaṃ mahābhūtānaṃ patiṭṭhā hutvā paccayo hotīti yehi mahābhūtehi sampiṇḍanavasena
analyzed: tiṇṇam mahābhūtānam patiṭṭhā hutvā paccayaḥ hoti iti yehi mahābhūtehi sampiṇḍana vasena
translated: It is a condition, acting as support for the three elements, i.e. it is a condition by acting as support for the three elements that are included by aggregation,🔽are maintained by ripening, and are extended by distension.🔽It is a support for the three elements that are its own conascent

original: saṅgahitā, paripācanavasena anupālitā, samudīraṇavasena vitthambhitā ca, tesaṃ attanā🔽sahajātānaṃ tiṇṇaṃ mahābhūtānaṃ patiṭṭhā hutvā tato eva sandhāraṇavasena avassayo
analyzed: saṅgahitā paripācana vasena anupālitā samudīraṇa vasena vitthambhitā ca tesam attanā  sahajātānam tiṇṇam mahābhūtānam patiṭṭhāḥ hutvā tatas eva sandhāraṇa vasena avassayo
translated: originations, and it is a reliance by virtue of its very support for them.

original: hoti, vuttanayena vā patiṭṭhā hutvā sahajātādivasena paccayo hotīti. Esa nayo sesāsupi.
analyzed: hoti vutta nayena vā patiṭṭhā hutvā sahajāta ādi vasena paccayaḥ hoti iti esa nayo sesāsu pi
translated: Or it is a condition by acting as support in the way already stated for the conascent, etc., elements. The same method applies in the case of the rest.

original: 358. Yadipi aññamaññaābhogapaccavekkhaṇarahitā ete dhammāti heṭṭhā dhātūnaṃ asamannāhāratā
analyzed: yadi pi aññamañña ābhoga paccavekkhaṇa rahitāḥ ete dhammā ti heṭṭhā dhātūnam a samannāhāra tā
translated: Although these states are devoid of mutual contact and reviewing, the earth element is a condition for the other three elements, etc., as conascence, etc.,

original: dassitā eva, athāpi imināva nayena visuṃ kammaṭṭhānapariggaho kātabboti dassento
analyzed: dassitāḥ eva atha api iminā ava nayena visum kammaṭṭhāna pariggaho kātabbaḥ ti dassento
translated: and he shows how the meditation subject should be discerned separately by this method too.

original: “pathavīdhātu cetthā”tiādimāha. Tattha pathavīdhātu cetthāti ca-saddo sampiṇḍanattho,
analyzed: pathavī dhātu ca itthā tiādim āha tattha pathavī dhātu ca itthā iti ca saddo sampiṇḍana ttho
translated: “The earth element here” : the word “here” has the meaning of inclusion.

original: tena ayampi eko manasikārappakāroti dīpeti. Etthāti etāsu dhātūsu. Ahaṃ “pathavīdhātū”ti
analyzed: tena ayam pi ekaḥ manasikāra ppakāro ti dīpeti ettha ati etāsu dhātūsu aham pathavī dhātu uti
translated: By it he shows that this is a single mode of attention. “Here” means in these elements.🔽I do not know that I am the earth element or that I am a condition.

original: vā “paccayo homī”ti vā na jānātīti attani viya attano kicce ca ābhogābhāvaṃ dassetvā
analyzed: vā paccayaḥ homi iti vā na jānāti iti attani viya attano kicce ca ābhoga abhāvam dassetvā
translated: Having thus shown the absence of any exertion of will on his own part and on the part of his functions as though they were himself,

original: upakārakassa viya upakattabbānampi ābhogābhāvaṃ dassetuṃ “itarānipī”tiādi vuttaṃ.
analyzed: upakārakassa viya upakattabbānam api ābhoga abhāvam dassetum itarāni ipi itiādi vuttam
translated: he says “The other three” in order to show the absence of any exertion of will on the part of those that are helped as though they were helpful.

original: Sabbatthāti sabbāsu dhātūsu, tatthāpi attakiccupakattabbabhedesu sabbesu.
analyzed: sabbattha ati sabbāsu dhātūsu tattha api atta kiccu pakattabba bhedesu sabbesu
translated: “Everywhere” : in all the elements. There too, in all the distinctions of function and what is helped.

original: 359. Paccayavibhāgatoti paccayadhammavibhāgato ceva paccayabhāvavibhāgato ca. “Paccayato”ti
analyzed: paccaya vibhāgato ti paccaya dhamma vibhāgato ca iva paccaya bhāva vibhāgato ca paccayato ti
translated: “By way of condition” : by way of the distinction of states of condition and by way of the distinction of the mode of being a condition.

original: hi iminā pathavīādīnaṃ aññāsādhāraṇo patiṭṭhābhāvādinā sesabhūtattayassa paccayabhāvo
analyzed: hi iminā pathavī ādīnam aññā sādhāraṇaḥ patiṭṭhā bhāva ādinā sesa bhūta ttayassa paccaya bhāvo
translated: For by “by way of condition” he shows that the mode of being a condition of the remaining three primaries, water, fire, and air, is by means of the uncommon foundation of the earth, etc.,

original: vutto. Idha pana yehi dhammehi pathavīādīnaṃ uppatti, tesaṃ pathavīādīnañca anavasesato🔽paccayabhāvavibhāgo vuccatīti ayaṃ imesaṃ dvinnaṃ ākārānaṃ viseso. Kammanti kusalākusalaṃ🔽rūpuppādakaṃ kammaṃ. Cittanti yaṃ kiñci rūpuppādakaṃ cittaṃ. Āhāroti ajjhattiko rūpuppādako🔽āhāro. Utūti yo koci utu, atthato tejodhātu. Kammamevāti avadhāraṇaṃ samuṭṭhānasaṅkarābhāvadassanatthaṃ,
analyzed: vuttaḥ idha pana yehi dhammehi pathavī ādīnam uppatti tesam pathavī ādīnam ca anavasesato  paccaya bhāva vibhāgaḥ vuccati iti ayam imesam dvinnam ākārānam viseso kammanti kusala akusalam  rūpa uppādakam kammam cittanti yam kiñci rūpa uppādakam cittam āhāraḥ ti ajjhattikaḥ rūpa uppādakaḥ  āhāro utu uti yaḥ koci utu atthato tejodhātu kammam eva ati avadhāraṇam samuṭṭhāna saṅkara abhāva dassana ttham
translated: Herein, the exposition of the conditions for the occurrence of earth, etc., and for the occurrence of the various kinds of earth, etc., is stated. This is the difference between these two modes. “Kamma” is profitable and unprofitable kamma that produces materiality. “Consciousness” is any kind of consciousness that produces materiality. “Nutriment” is internal nutriment that produces materiality. “Temperature” is temperature in the sense of the fire element. The word “only” is stated to show that there is no confusion in the origination.🔽

original: tena akammajānampi kesañci kammassa pariyāyapaccayabhāvo dīpito hoti. Tathā hi vakkhati🔽“kammapaccayacittasamuṭṭhāna”ntiādi. Nanu ca kammasamuṭṭhānānaṃ kammato aññenapi
analyzed: tena akamma jānam pi kesañci kammassa pariyāya paccaya bhāvaḥ dīpitaḥ hoti tathā hi vakkhati  kamma paccaya citta samuṭṭhāna ntiādi nanu ca kamma samuṭṭhānānam kammataḥ aññena api
translated: Herein, the exposition of the conditions for the occurrence of earth, etc., and for the occurrence of the remaining kinds of materiality is called “the exposition of the conditions in detail.” This is the difference between these two modes. “Kamma” is profitable and unprofitable kamma that generates materiality. “Consciousness” is any kind of consciousness that generates materiality. “Nutriment” is internal nutriment that generates materiality. “Temperature” is any kind of temperature, which in meaning is the fire element. The word “only” is stated in order to show that there is no confusion of origination. For by that means the conditionality of some kinds of materiality that are not generated by kamma is also shown. For this is said: “Conditioned by kamma-originated consciousness” , and so on. But is it not necessary for what is originated by kamma to be originated by other conditions as well? It is necessary, but that is included in the kamma-process, and so in order to forestall the question, “Is what is originated by kamma also originated by consciousness, etc.? ” the words “only what is originated by kamma” are stated.

original: paccayena bhavitabbanti? Bhavitabbaṃ, so pana kammagatikovāti paṭiyogīnivattanatthaṃ
analyzed: paccayena bhavitabbanti bhavitabbam so pana kamma gatikaḥ vā ti paṭiyogī nivattana attham
translated: But is it not necessary for what is originated by consciousness, etc., to be originated by other kinds of kamma as well? It is necessary, but that is included in the consciousness-process, and so in order to forestall the question, “Is what is originated by consciousness also originated by kamma? ” the words “only what is originated by consciousness” are stated.

original: avadhāraṇaṃ kataṃ, tenāha “na cittādayo”ti. Cittādisamuṭṭhānānanti etthāpi ayamattho
analyzed: avadhāraṇam katam tena āha na citta ādayaḥ iti citta ādi samuṭṭhānāni ettha api ayam attho
translated: The word “only” is stated, and so it is said, “not mind, etc.” As regards the words “arisen by mind, etc.,” the meaning should be stated as follows:

original: yathārahaṃ vattabbo. Itareti cittādito aññe. Janakapaccayoti samuṭṭhāpakataṃ sandhāya🔽vuttaṃ, paccayo pana kammapaccayova. Vuttaṃ hi “kusalākusalā cetanā vipākānaṃ khandhānaṃ
analyzed: yathāraham vattabbaḥ itare iti citta āditaḥ aññe janaka paccayo ti samuṭṭhāpaka tam sandhāya  vuttam paccayaḥ pana kamma paccayaḥ va vuttam hi kusala akusalā cetanā vipākānam khandhānam
translated: The other means those other than mind, etc. The generating condition is stated

original: kaṭattā ca rūpānaṃ kammapaccayena paccayo”ti.
analyzed: kaṭattā ca rūpānam kamma paccayena
translated: with reference to the originating cause. But the condition is only the kamma condition, for it is said: “Wholesome and unwholesome volition is a condition, as kamma condition, for resultant aggregates and for the materiality originated thereby” (Dhs.

original: Sesānanti cittādisamuṭṭhānānaṃ. Pariyāyato upanissayapaccayo hotīti paṭṭhāne arūpānaṃyeva
analyzed: sesānam ti citta ādi samuṭṭhānānam pariyāyataḥ upanissaya paccayaḥ hoti iti paṭṭhāne arūpānam yeva
translated: As regards the remaining, i.e., those arisen by mind, etc., it is a condition by way of decisive support. In the Paṭṭhāna, only the immaterial dhammas are given as decisive support conditions.

original: upanissayapaccayassa āgatattā nippariyāyena rūpadhammānaṃ upanissayapaccayo natthi.🔽Sutte pana “puggalaṃ upanissāya vanasaṇḍaṃ upanissāyā”ti vacanato suttantikapariyāyena
analyzed: upanissaya paccayassa āgata ttā nippariyāyena rūpa dhammānam upanissaya paccayo natthi  sutte pana puggalam upanissāya vana saṇḍam upanissāya ati vacanato sutta antika pariyāyena
translated: Therefore, in the strict sense of the word, material dhammas have no decisive support condition.🔽But in the Suttas, the words “dependent on a person” and “dependent on a forest grove” are used. Therefore, by way of the Suttas, the absence of the material dhammas is to be understood as a decisive support condition.

original: vinā abhāvo upanissayapaccayoti veditabbo. Cittaṃ janakapaccayo hotīti sahajātanissayāhārādivasena
analyzed: vinā abhāvaḥ upanissaya paccayo ti veditabbaḥ cittam janaka paccayaḥ hoti iti sahajāta nissaya āhāra ādi vasena
translated: The mind is a generating condition by way of conascence, support, nutriment, etc.

original: paccayo hontaṃ cittaṃ samuṭṭhāpakataṃ upādāya “janakapaccayo hotī”ti vuttaṃ. Āhārautūsupi eseva nayo.
analyzed: paccayaḥ hontam cittam samuṭṭhāpaka tam upādāya janaka paccayaḥ hoti iti vuttam āhāra otu supi esa eva nayo
translated: “As a condition being a condition by way of decisive support condition” is said by way of the decisive support condition that generates the mind-originated materiality. The same method applies to nutriment and season.

original: Evaṃ kammādīnaṃ paccayadhammānaṃ vasena dhātūsu paccayavibhāgaṃ dassetvā idāni taṃsamuṭṭhānānaṃ
analyzed: evam kamma ādīnam paccaya dhammānam vasena dhātūsu paccaya vibhāgam dassetvā idāni tad samuṭṭhānānam
translated: Having shown the analysis of conditions in the elements by way of the conditional states of kamma, etc., now, in order to show the analysis of conditions by way of the elements that originate from them,

original: dhātūnampi vasena paccayavibhāgaṃ dassento paṭhamaṃ tāva “kammasamuṭṭhānaṃ mahābhūta”ntiādinā
analyzed: dhātūnam pi vasena paccaya vibhāgam dassento paṭhamam tāva kamma samuṭṭhānam mahābhūta nti ādinā
translated: he first of all, after announcing with the words “Great primaries originated by kamma”

original: uddisitvā puna “tattha kammasamuṭṭhānā pathavīdhātū”tiādinā niddisati. Tattha kammasamuṭṭhānā
analyzed: uddisitvā puna tattha kamma samuṭṭhānā pathavī dhātu uti ādinā niddisati tattha kamma samuṭṭhānā
translated: etc., then defines with the words “Therein, the earth element originated by kamma” etc. Herein, the earth element originated by kamma

original: pathavīdhātūti “kammasamuṭṭhānaṃ mahābhūta”nti ettha sāmaññato vuttā kammajapathavīdhātu.
analyzed: pathavī dhātu uti kamma samuṭṭhānam mahābhūtan ti ettha sāmaññataḥ vuttā kamma ja pathavī dhātu
translated: is the earth element that is kamma-born, which is mentioned in general terms in the words “Great primaries originated by kamma.”🔽The other elements originated by kamma are the three elements of water, fire, and air, which are kamma-born.

original: Kammasamuṭṭhānānaṃ itarāsanti kammajānaṃ āpodhātuādīnaṃ tissannaṃ dhātūnaṃ sahuppattiyā
analyzed: kamma samuṭṭhānānam kamma jānam āpodhātu ādīnam tissannam dhātūnam sahuppattiyā
translated: Because they are helpful to the earth element originated by kamma,

original: attano upakārakānaṃ tāsaṃ upakārakato, ādhārabhāvato, uppādato yāva bhaṅgādharaṇato,
analyzed: upakārakānam tāsam upakārakataḥ ādhāra bhāvataḥ uppādataḥ yāva bhaṅga ādharaṇataḥ
translated: because they are its support, because they are its origin, and because they maintain it until its dissolution,

original: vigamābhāvato ca sahajātaaññamaññanissayaatthiavigatavasena ceva patiṭṭhāvasena ca
analyzed: vigama abhāvataḥ ca sahajāta aññamañña nissaya atthi avigata vasena ca iva patiṭṭhā vasena ca
translated: And it is a condition by way of support, because of the absence of separation, and by way of conascence, support, dissociation, presence, non-disappearance, and by way of support,

original: paccayo hoti, hontī ca kammaṃ viya attano, tāsañca na janakavasena paccayo hoti asamuṭṭhāpakattā🔽tāsaṃ. Kāmañcettha nissayapaccaya-ggahaṇeneva patiṭṭhābhāvo saṅgahito, pathavīdhātuyā
analyzed: paccayaḥ hoti hontī ca kammam viya attano tāsam ca na janaka vasena paccayaḥ hoti a samuṭṭhāpaka ttā  tāsam kāmañca ittha nissaya paccaya ggahaṇena iva patiṭṭhā bhāvo saṅgahito pathavī dhātuyā
translated: just as kamma is a condition for the great primaries by way of kamma-result. But it is not a condition by way of generation, because it does not generate them.

original: pana anaññasādhāraṇakiccaṃ sahajātānaṃ patiṭṭhābhāvoti imaṃ visesaṃ dassetuṃ “patiṭṭhāvasena🔽cā”ti visuṃ katvā vuttaṃ. Ābandhanavasena cātiādīsupi eseva nayo. Tisantatimahābhūtānanti
analyzed: pana anañña sādhāraṇa kiccam sahajātānam patiṭṭhā bhāvaḥ ti imam visesam dassetum patiṭṭhā vasena  ca iti visum katvā vuttam ābandhana vasena ca ati ādīsu pi esa iva nayaḥ ti santati mahābhūtānam ti
translated: And although the state of support is included by the taking of support as condition, still the state of support of the great primaries for the conascent is mentioned separately as “by way of support” in order to show the special function of the earth element, which is not shared by the others.

original: utucittāhārasamuṭṭhānānaṃ catumahābhūtānaṃ aññamaññaṃ avokiṇṇānaṃ, avicchedena pavattiṃ
analyzed: utu citta āhāra samuṭṭhānānam catu mahābhūtānam aññamaññam avokiṇṇānam avicchedena pavattim
translated: The same method applies to the phrases “by way of binding” and so on. The phrase “in the continuity of the great primaries” is said with reference to the continuity of the four great primaries arisen by temperature, consciousness, and nutriment, which are not mixed with each other and which occur without interruption.

original: upādāya santatīti santatiggahaṇaṃ. Pathavīdhātuyā patiṭṭhābhāvo nāma sahajātānaṃ
analyzed: upādāya santati iti santati ggahaṇam pathavī dhātuyā patiṭṭhā bhāvaḥ nāma
translated: The state of support of the earth element is the state of support of the conascent.

original: dhammānaṃyevāti āha “na patiṭṭhāvasenā”ti. Na ābandhanavasenātiādīsupi eseva nayo.🔽Etthāti etesu kammasamuṭṭhānamahābhūtesu. “Cittasamuṭṭhānā pathavīdhātu cittasamuṭṭhānānaṃ
analyzed: āha na patiṭṭhā vasena ati na ābandhana vasena ati ādīsu pi esa eva nayaḥ  ettha ati etesu kamma samuṭṭhāna mahābhūtesu citta samuṭṭhānā pathavī dhātu
translated: “Not by way of support” is said because of the words “the great primaries of kamma-originated earth-element, etc., are not supported by the great primaries of consciousness-originated earth-element, etc.” The same method applies in the case of the words “not by way of binding” and so on.🔽Herein, in these great primaries that originate from kamma. In the passage “The earth-element originated from consciousness, etc., is not supported by the other elements originated from consciousness, etc.,” the method of the weaver is easy to see.

original: itarāsa”ntiādīsu sukaro tantinayo netunti “cittaāhāra…pe… eseva nayo”ti atidisati.🔽Sahajātādipaccayavasappavattāsu ca panāti ettha ca-saddo samuccayattho, pana-saddo
analyzed: itarā santi ādīsu citta āhāra pe atidisati  sahajāta ādi paccaya vasa ppavattāsu ca pana ati ettha ca saddo samuccaya ttho pana saddo
translated: “The method is the same in the case of the nutriment of consciousness, etc.” is what is meant.🔽And in the case of the elements that occur by means of the conascent and other conditions, etc.: here the word and has the meaning of “also.” The word but has the meaning of

original: visesattho, tadubhayena ca yathāvuttasahajātādipaccayehi pavattamānā dhātuyo iminā🔽visesena pavattantīti imamatthaṃ dīpeti.
analyzed: visesa atthaḥ tad ubhayena ca yathā vutta sahajāta ādi paccayehi pavattamānāḥ dhātuyaḥ iminā  visesena pavattanti iti imam attham dīpeti
translated: distinction. And by both of these the meaning that is indicated is that the elements that occur by means of the conascent and other conditions mentioned above occur by means of this distinction.

original: Idāni taṃ visesaṃ dassetuṃ “ekaṃ paṭiccā”tigāthamāha. Tattha ekaṃ dhātuṃ paṭicca
analyzed: idāni tam visesam dassetum ekam paṭicca atigātham āha tattha ekam dhātum paṭicca
translated: Now, in order to show that distinction, he uttered the stanza “One element, etc.” Herein, one element,

original: tisso dhātuyo catudhā sampavattanti, tisso dhātuyo paṭicca ekāva dhātu catudhā sampavattati,
analyzed: tissaḥ dhātuyo catudhā sampavattanti tissaḥ dhātuyo paṭicca ekā ava dhātu catudhā sampavattati
translated: three elements, in four ways, occur; three elements, one element, in four ways, occur.

original: dve dhātuyo paṭicca dve dhātuyo chadhā sampavattantīti yojanā. Attho pana pathavīādīsu🔽ekekissā paccayabhāve itarāsaṃ tissannaṃ tissannaṃ paccayuppannatāti ayameko catukko,
analyzed: dve dhātuyo paṭicca dve dhātuyo chadhā sampavattanti iti yojanā attho pana pathavī ādīsu  ekekissā paccaya bhāve itarāsam tissannam tissannam paccaya uppanna tā ti ayam ekaḥ catukkaḥ
translated: The meaning is this. In the case of earth, etc.,🔽there is one tetrad in the arising of three, three, three with each as condition,

original: tissannaṃ tissannaṃ paccayabhāve itarāya ekekissā paccayuppannatāti ayamaparo catukko,
analyzed: tissannam tissannam paccaya bhāve itarāya ekekissā paccaya uppanna tā ati ayam aparaḥ catukkaḥ
translated: and another tetrad in the arising of one, one, one with each as condition.

original: paṭhamadutiyā, tatiyacatutthā, paṭhamatatiyā, dutiyacatutthā, paṭhamacatutthā, dutiyatatiyāti
analyzed: paṭhama dutiyā tatiya catutthā paṭhama tatiyā dutiya catutthā paṭhama catutthā dutiya tatiyā ati
translated: There are two dyads in the arising of the first and second, the third and fourth, the first and third, the second and fourth, the first and fourth, the second and third,🔽with each dyad as condition.

original: imāsaṃ dvinnaṃ dvinnaṃ paccayabhāve tattha tattha itarāsaṃ dvinnaṃ dvinnaṃ paccayuppannatāti🔽ayameko chakko. Evaṃ paccayabhāvena catudhā, chadhā ca pavattamānānaṃ ekakadvikatikavasena
analyzed: imāsam dvinnam dvinnam paccaya bhāve tattha tattha itarāsam dvinnam dvinnam paccaya uppanna tā ti  ayam ekaḥ chakkaḥ evam paccaya bhāvena catudhā chadhā ca pavattamānānam ekaka dvika tika vasena
translated: There is one triad in the arising of the two, two, two with each as condition.🔽So the analysis of conditions and conditionally-arisen should be understood in the four ways and six ways respectively, according to the single and double dyads and the double and single triads.

original: tikadukaekakavasena ca yathākkamaṃ paccayapaccayuppannatāvibhāgo veditabbo. Ayañca
analyzed: tika duka ekaka vasena ca yathākkamam paccaya paccaya uppanna tā vibhāgaḥ veditabbaḥ ayam ca
translated: And this analysis of conditions and conditionally-arisen

original: paccayabhāvo sahajātaaññamaññanissayaatthiavigatapaccayavasena, tatthāpi ca aññamaññamukheneva
analyzed: paccaya bhāvo sahajāta aññamañña nissaya atthi avigata paccaya vasena tattha api ca aññamañña mukhena iva
translated: and the condition is by way of conascence, mutuality, support, dissociation, presence, non-disappearance, and root conditions. And here too it should be understood by way of mutuality.

original: veditabbo. Yaṃ sandhāya vuttaṃ paṭiccavāre “ekaṃ mahābhūtaṃ paṭicca tayo mahābhūtā,
analyzed: veditabbaḥ yam sandhāya vuttam paṭicca vāre ekam mahābhūtam paṭicca tayaḥ mahābhūtā
translated: With reference to what was said in the Paṭṭhāna: “With one great primary as condition, three great primaries,

original: tayo mahābhūte paṭicca ekaṃ mahābhūtaṃ, dve mahābhūte paṭicca dve mahābhūtā uppajjantī”ti.🔽Abhikkamapaṭikkamādīti ādi-saddena ādānavissajjanādikāyikakiriyākaraṇassa saṅgaho
analyzed: tayaḥ mahābhūte paṭicca ekam mahābhūtam dve mahābhūte paṭicca dve mahābhūtāḥ uppajjanti iti  abhikkama paṭikkama ādi iti ādi saddena ādāna vissajjana ādi kāyika kiriyā karaṇassa saṅgahaḥ
translated: with three great primaries, one great primary, with two great primaries, two great primaries arise” .🔽By “going forward and returning, etc.,” the inclusion of the performance of bodily action such as taking up and putting down should be understood.

original: daṭṭhabbo. Uppīḷanassa paccayo hoti ghaṭṭanakiriyāya pathavīdhātuvasena sijjhanato.
analyzed: daṭṭhabbaḥ uppīḷanassa paccayaḥ hoti ghaṭṭana kiriyāya pathavī dhātu vasena sijjhanato
translated: It is a condition for oppression because it succeeds as the earth element in the action of striking.

original: Sāvāti pathavīdhātuyeva. Āpodhātuyā anugatā āpodhātuyā tattha appadhānabhāvaṃ, pathavīdhātuyā
analyzed: sā avāti pathavī dhātuyā iva āpodhātuyā anugatā āpodhātuyā tattha appadhāna bhāvam pathavī dhātuyā
translated: “That” is the earth element itself. It is “accompanied by the water element” in the sense that the water element is not lacking there. The earth element🔽has predominance in steadiness, and the water element has predominance in cohesion. In the act of steadying, too, the water element has predominance in steadying,

original: ca padhānabhāvanti patiṭṭhābhāve viya patiṭṭhāpanepi sātisayakiccattā tassā patiṭṭhāpanassa
analyzed: ca padhāna bhāvanti patiṭṭhā bhāve viya patiṭṭhāpane pi sa atisaya kicca ttā tassā patiṭṭhāpanassa
translated: because of its greater efficiency in that.

original: pādaṭṭhapanassa paccayo hotīti sambandho. Avakkhepanassāti adhonikkhipanassa. Tattha🔽ca garutarasabhāvāya āpodhātuyā sātisayo byāpāroti āha “pathavīdhātuyā anugatā āpodhātū”ti.
analyzed: pāda ṭṭhapanassa paccayaḥ hoti iti sambandhaḥ avakkhepanassa ati adhas nikkhipanassa tattha  ca garuta rasa bhāvāya āpaḥ dhātuyā sa atisayaḥ āha pathavī dhātuyā anugatāḥ āpaḥ dhātu uti
translated: The meaning is: for the throwing down.🔽And because the water element has the characteristic of fluidity in excess, he said: “The water element is present in the earth element”

original: Tathā uddhaṅgatikā tejodhātūti uddharaṇe vāyodhātuyā tassā anugatabhāvo vutto. Tiriyaṃ
analyzed: tathā uddhaṅgatikā tejaḥ dhātu uti uddharaṇe vāyo dhātuyā tassāḥ anugata bhāvaḥ vutto tiriyam
translated: . Likewise, the fire element has the characteristic of heat in excess, and the air element has the characteristic of distension in excess.🔽The air element has the characteristic of distension in excess, and the fire element is present in the air element.🔽The air element is present in the fire element.🔽The air element is present in the water element.🔽The water element is present in the air element.

original: gatikāya vāyodhātuyā atiharaṇavītiharaṇesu sātisayo byāpāroti tejodhātuyā tassā anugatabhāvo
analyzed: gatikāya vāyodhātuyāḥ atiharaṇa vītiharaṇesu sa atisayaḥ tejaḥ dhātuyāḥ tassāḥ anugata bhāvo
translated: The fire element is present in the water element.🔽The earth element is present in the fire element.🔽The earth element is present in the air element.🔽The earth element is present in the water element.

original: gahito. Tattha ṭhitaṭṭhānato abhimukhaṃ pādassa haraṇaṃ atiharaṇaṃ, purato haraṇaṃ.
analyzed: tattha ṭhita ṭṭhānataḥ abhimukham pādassa haraṇam atiharaṇam puratas haraṇam
translated: The water element is present in the earth element.🔽The air element is present in the earth element.

original: Tato thokaṃ vītikkamma haraṇaṃ vītiharaṇaṃ, passato haraṇaṃ.
analyzed: tatas thokam vītikkamma haraṇam vītiharaṇam passataḥ haraṇam
translated: The fire element is present in the earth element.🔽The earth element is present in the fire element.🔽The earth element is present in the air element.🔽The earth element is present in the water element.

original: Ekekena mukhenāti “patthaṭattā pathavī”tiādinā vibhattesu terasasu ākāresu ekekena
analyzed: ekekena mukhena ati patthaṭattā pathavī ti ādinā vibhattesu terasasu ākāresu ekekena
translated: The water element is present in the air element.🔽The fire element is present in the water element.🔽The air element is present in the fire element.🔽The water element is present in the air element.🔽The fire element is present in the earth element.🔽The air element is present in the water element.

original: dhātūnaṃ pariggaṇhanamukhena. Svāyanti so ayaṃ upacārasamādhi. Kathaṃ panassa vavatthānapariyāyoti
analyzed: dhātūnam pariggaṇhana mukhena su āyanti saḥ ayam upacāra samādhi katham panassa vavatthāna pariyāyaḥ ti
translated: The fire element is present in the earth element.🔽The water element is present in the air element.🔽The earth element is present in the fire element.🔽The air element is present in the water element.🔽The fire element is present in the earth element.🔽The water element is present in the air element.🔽The earth element is present in the fire element.🔽The air element is present in the water element.🔽The fire element is present in the earth element.🔽The water element is present in the air element.🔽The earth element is present in the fire element.🔽The air element is present in the water element.🔽The fire element is present in the earth element.🔽The water element is present in the air element.🔽The earth element is present in the fire element.🔽The air element is present in the water element.🔽The fire element is present in the earth element.🔽The water element is present in the air element.🔽The earth element is present in

original: āha “catunnaṃ dhātūna”ntiādi.
analyzed: āha catunnam dhātūn antiādi
translated: He said “With the four great entities” , etc.

original: 360. Idāni imissā bhāvanāya ānisaṃse dassetuṃ “idañca panā”tiādi vuttaṃ. Suññataṃ🔽avagāhatīti dhātumattatādassanena rūpakāyassa anattakataṃ vavatthāpayato tadanusārena🔽nāmakāyassāpi anattakatā supākaṭā hotīti sabbaso attasuññataṃ pariyogāhati tattha
analyzed: idāni imissā bhāvanāya ānisaṃse dassetuṃ idam ca pana atiādi vuttam  avagāhati iti dhātumatta tā dassanena rūpa kāyassa anatta katam vavatthāpayato tad anusārena  nāmakāyassa api anattaka tā su pākaṭā hoti iti sabbaso atta suññatam pariyogāhati tattha
translated: Now, in order to point out the benefits of this development, the following is said: “And he penetrates the voidness of self” .🔽By seeing the mere entities, he defines the material body as not-self. Then, in accordance with that, the voidness of self in the mental body becomes evident to him. He penetrates it thoroughly. He stands upon it.

original: patiṭṭhahati. Sattasaññaṃ samugghātetīti tato eva “satto poso itthī puriso”ti evaṃ🔽pavattaṃ ayāthāvasaññaṃ ugghāteti samūhanati. Vāḷamigayakkharakkhasādivikappaṃ anāvajjamānoti
analyzed: patiṭṭhahati satta saññam samugghāteti iti tatas eva satto posaḥ itthī puriso ti evam  pavattam a yāthāvasaññam ugghāteti samūhanati vāḷa miga yakkha rakkhasa ādi vikappam an āvajjamānaḥ ti
translated: “He eradicates the perception of a being” . Because of that, he eradicates, he removes the perception that occurs as “a being,” “a man,” “a woman,” “a he,” “a she,” etc., which is not in accordance with actuality.

original: sasantāne viya parasantānepi dhātumattatāya sudiṭṭhattā khīṇāsavo viya “ime sīhabyagghādayo
analyzed: sa santāne para santāne pi dhātumat tatāya su diṭṭha ttā khīṇa asavaḥ ime sīha byaggha ādayaḥ
translated: “He endures without fear the undaunted fearlessness” . Because he has seen well that the other’s continuum is mere entities just as his own continuum is, he endures, he conquers, the undaunted fearlessness, the fearlessness that is not frightened, in regard to the thought “These are lions, tigers, etc.,🔽these are yakkhas, rakkhasas, etc.”, without making the discrimination “These are lions, tigers, etc.,

original: vāḷamigā, ime yakkharakkhasā”ti evamādivikappaṃ akaronto bhayabheravaṃ sahati abhibhavati.
analyzed: vāḷamigāḥ ime yakkharakkhasā ti evamādi vikappam a karontaḥ bhaya bheravam sahati abhibhavati
translated: these are yakkhas, rakkhasas, etc.,” like one whose cankers are destroyed.

original: Yathāvuttavikappanāpajjanaṃ hi bhayabheravasahanassa kāraṇaṃ vuttaṃ. Ugghāto uppilāvitattaṃ.
analyzed: yathā vutta vikappana āpajjanam hi bhaya bherava sahanassa kāraṇam vuttam ugghātaḥ uppilāvitattam
translated: Agitation is the state of being upset.🔽Depression is the state of being downcast.

original: Nigghāto dīnabhāvappatti. Mahāpañño ca pana hoti dhātuvasena kāye sammadeva ghanavinibbhogassa
analyzed: nigghātaḥ dīna bhāva ppatti mahā pañño ca pana hoti dhātu vasena kāye sammad eva ghana vinibbhogassa
translated: And he is one of great understanding, because he has thoroughly disentangled the compact mass of this body by means of the elements.

original: karaṇato. Tathā hidaṃ kammaṭṭhānaṃ buddhicaritassa anukūlanti vuttaṃ, sugatiparāyaṇo
analyzed: karaṇato tathā hi dam kammaṭṭhānam buddhi caritassa anukūlan ti vuttam sugati parāyaṇaḥ
translated: For this meditation subject is said to be suitable for one of intellectual temperament.

original: vā indriyānaṃ aparipakkatāyanti adhippāyo.🔽Ekūnavīsatibhāvanānayapaṭimaṇḍitassa
analyzed: vā indriyānam aparipakkatāyanti adhippāyaḥ  ekūnavīsati bhāvanā naya paṭimaṇḍitassa
translated: Or the meaning intended may be that he is not one who has not reached the right age.🔽The commentary on the meaning of the word “compact” in the phrase “having thoroughly disentangled the compact mass of this body” is ended.

original: Catudhātuvavatthānaniddesassa līnatthavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: catu dhātu vavatthāna niddesassa līna ttha vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The exposition of the discernment of the four elements, adorned with nineteen kinds of meditation, is ended.

original: 361. “Ko samādhī”tiādinā sarūpādipucchā yāvadeva vibhāgāvabodhanatthā. Sarūpādito
analyzed: samādhi iti ādinā sarūpa ādi pucchā yāvat eva vibhāga avabodhana tthā sarūpa āditaḥ
translated: The questions beginning “What is concentration?” are asked only in order to make the divisions clear.

original: hi ñātassa pabhedo vuccamāno suviññeyyo hoti saṅkhepapubbakattā vitthārassa, vitthāravidhinā🔽ca saṅkhepavidhi saṅgayhatīti “samādhissa vitthāraṃ bhāvanānayañca dassetu”nti vuttaṃ.
analyzed: hi ñātassa pabhedaḥ vuccamānaḥ su viññeyyaḥ hoti saṅkhepa pubbaka ttā vitthārassa vitthāra vidhinā 🔽ca saṅkhepa vidhi saṅgayhati iti samādhissa vitthāram bhāvanā nayam ca dassetun ti vuttam
translated: For when the divisions of what is known are being stated, it is easier to understand if they are stated in brief at first, since the method of exposition in the texts is to begin with a brief statement and then to fill in the details later.🔽And the brief statement is remembered because it is included in the detailed exposition.

original: Atha vā “ko samādhī”tiādināpi samādhisseva pakārabhedo dassīyati, bhāvanānisaṃsopi
analyzed: atha vā ko samādhi iti ādinā api samādhissa iva pakāra bhedaḥ bhāvanā nisaṃsaḥ api
translated: Or else, by the question “What is concentration?” and so on, the different kinds of development of concentration are shown, and the benefits of development are shown too.

original: bhāvanānayanissito evāti adhippāyena “vitthāraṃ bhāvanānayañca dassetu”nti vuttaṃ.
analyzed: bhāvanā naya nissitaḥ evā ti adhippāyena vitthāram bhāvanā nayam ca dassetun ti vuttam
translated: The intention is that the benefits of development are based on the method of development.

original: Sabbappakāratoti palibodhupacchedādikassa sabbassa bhāvanāya pubbakiccassa karaṇappakārato
analyzed: sabba ppakārato ti palibodha upaccheda ādikassa sabbassa bhāvanāya pubba kiccassa karaṇa ppakārato
translated: “In all its aspects”: in all its aspects as the performance of the preliminary work for development, which consists in the severing of impediments, etc.,

original: ceva sabbakammaṭṭhānabhāvanāvibhāvanato ca.
analyzed: ca iva sabba kammaṭṭhāna bhāvanā vibhāvanataḥ ca
translated: and in the arousing of all the meditation subjects.

original: “Samattā hotī”ti vatvā tameva samattabhāvaṃ vibhāvetuṃ “duvidhoyevā”tiādi vuttaṃ.
analyzed: samattā hoti iti vatvā tam eva samatta bhāvam vibhāvetum vuttaṃ
translated: After saying “it is unified,” he said “it is of two kinds” in order to show the meaning of unification.

original: Idha adhippeto samādhīti lokiyasamādhiṃ āha. Dasasu kammaṭṭhānesūti yāni heṭṭhā “upacārāvahānī”ti
analyzed: idha adhippetaḥ samādhi iti lokiya samādhim āha dasasu kammaṭṭhānesu iti yāni heṭṭhā upacāra āvahāni iti
translated: “The kind of concentration intended here”: he is referring to mundane concentration.

original: vuttāni dasa kammaṭṭhānāni, tesu. Appanāpubbabhāgacittesūti appanāya pubbabhāgacittesu
analyzed: vuttāni dasa kammaṭṭhānāni tesu appanā pubbabhāga cittesu ati appanāya pubbabhāga cittesu
translated: “In the ten meditation subjects”: in the ten meditation subjects stated below in the stanza, “When the impediments are abandoned” .🔽“In the consciousnesses that precede absorption”: in the consciousnesses that precede absorption.🔽“In the consciousnesses that precede the eight attainments”: in the consciousnesses that precede the eight attainments.

original: aṭṭhannaṃ jhānānaṃ pubbabhāgacittuppādesu. Ekaggatāti ekāvajjanavīthiyaṃ, nānāvajjanavīthiyañca
analyzed: aṭṭhannam jhānānam pubbabhāga cittuppādesu ekagga tā ati eka āvajjana vīthiyam nānā āvajjana vīthiyam ca
translated: “In the unification in a single cognitive series and in a multiple cognitive series”:

original: ekaggatā. Avasesakammaṭṭhānesūti “appanāvahānī”ti vuttesu tiṃsakammaṭṭhānesu.
analyzed: ekagga tā avasesa kammaṭṭhānesu ti appanā vahāni iti vuttesu tiṃsa kammaṭṭhānesu
translated: and unification. In the remaining meditation subjects: in the thirty meditation subjects stated in the way beginning, “When the perception of a skeleton is developed and enlarged” .

original: Samādhiānisaṃsakathāvaṇṇanā
translated: The explanation of the section of text dealing with the benefits of concentration

original: 362. Diṭṭhadhammo vuccati paccakkhabhūto attabhāvo, tattha sukhavihāro diṭṭhadhammasukhavihāro.
analyzed: diṭṭhadhammo vuccati paccakkha bhūtaḥ atta bhāvo tattha sukha vihāraḥ diṭṭhadhamma sukha vihāro
translated: The visible here and now means the visible, i.e. the visible state, which is one’s own person. The pleasant abiding here and now is the pleasant abiding in the visible here and now.🔽Although the word “having attained” in the text refers only to the concentration of jhāna,

original: Kāmaṃ “samāpajjitvā”ti etena appanāsamādhiyeva vibhāvito, “ekaggacittā”ti pana padena
analyzed: kāmam samāpajjitvā iti etena vibhāvitaḥ ekagga cittā iti pana padena
translated: the word “with a mind that is one-pointed” refers also to access concentration.

original: upacārasamādhinopi gahaṇaṃ hotīti tato nivattanatthaṃ “appanāsamādhibhāvanā”ti vuttaṃ.
analyzed: upacāra samādhinaḥ api gahaṇam hoti iti tatas nivattana attham appanā samādhi bhāvanā iti vuttam
translated: So in order to exclude that, the word “development” is added.

original: Na kho paneteti ete bāhirakabhāvitā jhānadhammā cittekaggatāmattakarā. Ariyassa vinaye🔽buddhassa bhagavato sāsane “sallekhā”ti na vuccanti kilesānaṃ sallekhanapaṭipadā
analyzed: na kho pana iti ete bāhiraka bhāvitāḥ jhāna dhammāḥ citta ekagga tā matta karāḥ ariyassa vinaye  buddhassa bhagavataḥ sāsane sallekhā ati na vuccanti kilesānam sallekhana paṭipadā
translated: They are not called: these jhāna states developed by worldlings are only makers of one-pointedness of mind. In the Noble Ones’ Discipline🔽they are not called “purifications” because they are not a way of burning up defilements.

original: na hotīti katvā, sāsane pana avihiṃsādayopi sallekhāva lokuttarapādakattā.
analyzed: na katvā sāsane pana avihiṃsā ādayaḥ api
translated: But in the Dispensation they are called “purifications” because they are a way of burning up defilements, and also because they are the harmlessness, etc., that are the requisites for the supramundane state.

original: Sambādheti taṇhāsaṃkilesādinā saṃkiliṭṭhatāya paramasambādhe ativiya saṅkaṭaṭṭhānabhūte🔽saṃsārappavatte. Okāsādhigamanayenāti atthapaṭilābhayoggassa navamakhaṇasaṅkhātassa
analyzed: sambādha iti taṇhā saṃkilesa ādinā saṃkiliṭṭhatāya parama sambādhe saṅkaṭa ṭṭhāna bhūte  saṃsāra ppavatte okāsa adhigama nayena ati attha paṭilābha yoggassa navama khaṇa saṅkhātassa
translated: In the crowded place, that is to say, in the round of rebirths, which is a very crowded place because it is defiled by the defilements of craving, etc.,🔽By the attainment of the opportunity, that is to say, by the attainment of the opportunity called the ninth proximate-liberation stage,

original: okāsassa adhigamanayena. Tassa hi dullabhatāya appanādhigamampi anadhigamayamāno🔽saṃvegabahulo puggalo upacārasamādhimhiyeva ṭhatvā vipassanāya kammaṃ karoti “sīghaṃ
analyzed: okāsassa adhigama nayena tassa hi dullabha tāya appanā adhigamam pi an adhigamayamāno  saṃvega bahulaḥ puggalo upacāra samādhimhiyā iva ṭhatvā vipassanāya kammam karoti sīgham
translated: which is the opportunity for the acquisition of the meaning. For the person who has much sense of spiritual urgency does the work of insight only in access concentration, not attaining absorption,

original: saṃsāradukkhaṃ samatikkamissāmī”ti.
analyzed: saṃsāra dukkham samatikkamissāmi iti
translated: because of the difficulty of attaining it, thinking “I shall quickly escape from the suffering of the round of rebirths.”

original: Abhiññāpādakanti iddhividhādiabhiññāñāṇapādakabhūtaṃ adhiṭṭhānabhūtaṃ. Hotīti vuttanayāti
analyzed: abhiññā pādakanti iddhividha ādi abhiññā ñāṇa pādaka bhūtam adhiṭṭhāna bhūtam hoti iti vutta nayā ti
translated: The foundation for direct-knowledge, that is to say, the foundation for the knowledge of the kinds of supernormal power, etc., which is the basis for the direct-knowledges.

original: ettha iti-saddo pakārattho, tena “iminā pakārena vuttanayā”ti sesābhiññānampi vuttappakāraṃ
analyzed: ettha iti saddo pakāra attho tena iminā pakārena vutta nayā ati sesa abhiññānam pi vutta ppakāram
translated: The meaning of the word iti is the meaning of “in this way.” So by the words “in the way aforesaid” the rest of the direct-knowledges are included as stated.

original: saṅgaṇhāti. Sati sati āyataneti purimabhavasiddhe abhiññādhigamassa kāraṇe vijjamāne.
analyzed: saṅgaṇhāti sati sati āyatane iti purima bhava siddhe abhiññā adhigamassa kāraṇe vijjamāne
translated: In each instance where the conditions are present, that is to say, in each instance where the conditions for the acquisition of the direct-knowledges are present, which conditions are established in a previous existence.

original: Abhiññādhigamassa hi adhikāro icchitabbo, yo “pubbahetū”ti vuccati. Na samāpattīsu
analyzed: abhiññā adhigamassa hi adhikāraḥ icchitabbaḥ yaḥ pubba hetū ti vuccati na samāpattīsu
translated: Not mastery in attainment.

original: vasībhāvo. Tenāha bhagavā “sati sati āyatane”ti. Abhiññāsacchikaraṇīyassāti vakkhamānavibhāgāya
analyzed: vasībhāvaḥ tena āha bhagavā sati sati āyatane iti abhiññā sacchikaraṇīyassa ati vakkhamāna vibhāgāya
translated: Hence the Blessed One said: “In each instance in a particular field” .

original: abhivisiṭṭhāya paññāya sacchikātabbassa. Dhammassāti bhāvetabbassa ceva vibhāvetabbassa
analyzed: abhivisiṭṭhāya paññāya sacchikātabbassa dhammassa ati bhāvetabbassa ca iva vibhāvetabbassa
translated: For direct-knowledge to be realized: for the Dhamma that is to be realized by the knowledge called “direct-knowledge” to be realized.🔽For the Dhamma that is to be developed and that is to be verified is meant.

original: ca dhammassa. Abhiññāsacchikiriyāya cittaṃ abhininnāmetīti yojanā. Tatra tatrevāti
analyzed: ca dhammassa abhiññā sacchikiriyāya cittam abhininnāmeti iti yojanā tatra tatra iva ati
translated: The construction is: he directs his mind to the realization of direct-knowledge.🔽In that very object: in that very object to be realized.

original: tasmiṃ tasmiṃyeva sacchikātabbadhamme. Sakkhibhāvāya paccakkhakāritāya bhabbo sakkhibhabbo,
analyzed: tasmin tasmiṃ yeva sacchikātabba dhamme sakkhibhāvāya paccakkha kāritāya bhabbaḥ sakkhibhabbo
translated: The state of being a witness: the state of being a witness by direct experience.

original: tassa bhāvo sakkhibhabbatā, taṃ sakkhibhabbataṃ.🔽Taṃ taṃ bhavagamikammaṃ ārabbha bhavapatthanāya anuppannāyapi kammassa katūpacitabhāveneva
analyzed: tassa bhāvaḥ sakkhibhabba tā tam sakkhibhabba tam  tam tam bhava gami kammam ārabbha bhava patthanāya kammassa kata upacita bhāvena iva
translated: The state of being a witness: the state of being a witness by direct experience.🔽The function of the wish for becoming is accomplished by the fact that the kamma has been performed and stored up, even though the wish for becoming has not arisen in regard to the kamma that leads to becoming.

original: bhavapatthanākiccaṃ sijjhatīti dassento āha “apatthayamānā vā”ti. Saha byeti pavattatīti
analyzed: bhava patthanā kiccam sijjhati iti dassentaḥ āha apatthayamānā vāti saha byeti pavattati iti
translated: The function of the wish for becoming is accomplished by the fact that the kamma has been performed and stored up, even though the wish for becoming has not arisen in regard to the kamma that leads to becoming.

original: sahabyo, sahāyo, idha pana ekabhavūpago adhippeto, tassa bhāvo sahabyatā, taṃ sahabyataṃ.
analyzed: sahabyaḥ sahāyaḥ idha pana eka bhava upagaḥ adhippeto tassa bhāvaḥ sahabya tā tam sahabya tam
translated: “The state of companionship” is the state of being a companion. Here, however, it is the state of being reborn in the same plane of existence as the noble ones that is intended.

original: Kiṃ pana appanāsamādhibhāvanāyeva bhavavisesānisaṃsā, udāhu itarāpīti codanaṃ manasi katvā āha “upacārasamādhibhāvanāpī”tiādi.
analyzed: kim pana appanā samādhi bhāvanāya iva bhava visesa anisaṃsā udāhu itarā api iti codanam manasi katvā āha upacāra samādhi bhāvanā api itiādi
translated: “But is the development of concentration only for the purpose of attaining the distinction of rebirth in a happy destiny, or is it also for other purposes?” Considering this question, he said, “The development of access concentration too,” and so on.

original: Nibbānanti tissannaṃ dukkhatānaṃ nibbutiṃ. Rūpadhamme pariyāpannā vijjamānāpi saṅkhāradukkhatā
analyzed: nibbānam tissannam dukkha tānam nibbutim rūpa dhamme pariyāpannā vijjamānā api saṅkhāra dukkha tā
translated: “Nibbāna”: the cessation of the three kinds of suffering. Although the suffering due to formations exists included in the form-plane,🔽it is as good as non-existent because of the absence of consciousness. Hence it is said: “We shall dwell happily.”

original: cittassa abhāvena asantasamāva. Tenāha “sukhaṃ viharissāmā”ti. Soḷasahi ñāṇacariyāhīti
analyzed: cittassa abhāvena tena āha sukham viharissāma ati soḷasahi ñāṇa cariyāhi iti
translated: “Sixteen kinds of knowledge”:

original: aniccānupassanādukkhaanattanibbidāvirāganirodhapaṭinissaggavivaṭṭānupassanāti imāhi
analyzed: anicca anupassanā dukkha anatta nibbidā virāga nirodha paṭinissagga vivaṭṭa anupassanā ti imāhi
translated: eight kinds of insight knowledge—of impermanence, of suffering, of non-self, of fading away, of cessation, of relinquishment, of turning away, and of dispassion—🔽and eight kinds of knowledge of the noble paths and fruits.

original: aṭṭhahi, aṭṭhahi ca ariyamaggaphalañāṇehīti evaṃ soḷasahi. Navahi samādhicariyāhīti
analyzed: aṭṭhahi aṭṭhahi ca ariya magga phala ñāṇehi iti evam soḷasahi navahi samādhi cariyāhi iti
translated: “Nine kinds of concentration”:

original: pañcannaṃ rūpajjhānānaṃ, catunnaṃ arūpajjhānānañca vasena evaṃ navahi. Keci pana
analyzed: vasena evam pana
translated: five kinds of jhāna in the fine-material sphere and four kinds of jhāna in the immaterial sphere.

original: “cattāro rūpajjhānasamādhī, cattāro arūpajjhānasamādhī, ubhayesaṃ upacārasamādhiṃ
analyzed: cattāraḥ rūpa jhāna samādhī cattāro arūpa jhāna samādhī ubhayesam upacāra samādhim
translated: “The four absorptions of the form realm, the four absorptions of the formless realm, and the access concentration to both of them,

original: ekaṃ katvā evaṃ navā”ti vadanti.
analyzed: ekam katvā evam nava ati vadanti
translated: “The four jhana concentrations in the fine-material sphere and the four in the immaterial sphere, and the access concentration to both, making nine in all.”

original: Samādhibhāvanāyogeti samādhibhāvanāya anuyoge anuyuñjane, samādhibhāvanāsaṅkhāte vā yoge. Yogoti bhāvanā vuccati. Yathāha “yogā ve jāyatī bhūrī”ti.
analyzed: samādhi bhāvanā yoga iti samādhi bhāvanāya anuyoge anuyuñjane samādhi bhāvanā saṅkhāte vā yoge bhāvanā vuccati yathā āha yogā jāyati bhūri iti
translated: “For the development of concentration”: for the sake of the development of concentration, for the purpose of the development of concentration. Or else, “for the development of concentration” is a bahuvrīhi compound meaning “for whom concentration is the development.”

original: 363. Samādhipīti pi-saddena sīlaṃ sampiṇḍeti.🔽Samādhiniddesavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: samādhi pīti pisaddena sīlam sampiṇḍeti  samādhi niddesa vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The word “and” in the verse includes virtue.🔽The commentary on the exposition of concentration is finished.

original: Iti ekādasamaparicchedavaṇṇanā.
analyzed: iti ekādasama pariccheda vaṇṇanā
translated: The commentary on the eleventh chapter is finished.

original: Paṭhamo bhāgo niṭṭhito.
analyzed: paṭhamaḥ bhāgaḥ niṭṭhitaḥ
translated: The first part is finished.
